{"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Two people were killed and five others wounded in a series of bombings centered on Austin, Tex., this month. The police have said the attacks are linked, and on Wednesday a man suspected of being the bomber, Mark Conditt, 23, blew himself up as officers approached him.\n\nBoth people killed by the bombings were black and belonged to prominent African-American families in the city, raising the specter that the violence was racially motivated.\n\nBrian Manley, the Austin police chief, said investigators had not yet determined a motive for the attacks, in which homemade bombs were used to kill and maim people.\n\nChief Manley said on Wednesday that it was not clear whether more than one bomber may have been responsible for the explosions, which spread fear across the capital of Texas for nearly three weeks.", "title": "Austin Bombing Victims Included a Father and a 17-Year-Old Musician", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "What drew you to Wall Street?\n\nIn business school I really liked product management. As a product manager, you have to own the four P\u2019s of marketing \u2014 product, placement, pricing and promotion. If you own the product, it\u2019s like being the C.E.O. of your own little company. I didn\u2019t think that I would be that excited to do that for consumer goods, but I would love to be able to do that for financial products. So I went to Nasdaq.\n\nYou joined Nasdaq in 1993. What was it like being a woman on Wall Street back then?\n\nThere were not a lot of women in the office. But the man I worked for saw me as someone who was an M.B.A. grad. He would give me something to do, and I would go do it, and I would do it well. He never once made me feel at all different or disadvantaged by being a woman. I just got stuff done.\n\nWhen I got my first promotion I was actually pregnant. For him it was like: \u201cOh, that\u2019s fine. You\u2019ll be gone for three months, and you\u2019ll come back.\u201d He really just didn\u2019t even factor it into his decision making.\n\n\u201cNo more mousy voice. Get in the room and speak at the same tone as everyone else, and I can assure you your voice will be heard.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Adena Friedman\n\nWhat advice do you give to women who feel like they aren\u2019t receiving equal treatment?\n\nFirst of all, make sure you have a voice. I had this one woman that worked for me, and every time she had an idea she would whisper it into the room. So I took her aside, and I said: \u201cSpeak up. You are really, really smart. No more mousy voice. Get in the room and speak at the same tone as everyone else, and I can assure you your voice will be heard.\u201d\n\nNext time she had an opinion, she spoke up, and everyone was like, \u201cWow, that\u2019s a really good idea.\u201d Then she was empowered to do it again and again.\n\nAnd still, some women may face discrimination. What then?\n\nIf you really don\u2019t feel you\u2019re getting the opportunities that you should be getting, maybe you should look for a different place to work or a different person to work for. Then, of course, if you really feel like you\u2019re not being treated properly, as a person, there should be many means for women to be able to voice that concern, to H.R., to legal.\n\nWhen you rejoined Nasdaq after a stint at the Carlyle Group, you went from being a C.F.O. to being the C.E.O. Was that a difficult transition?", "title": "How Nasdaq C.E.O. Adena Friedman Beat the Odds on Wall Street", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The animated videos show Russian warheads speeding toward Florida and missiles outmaneuvering obstacles in the southern Atlantic. Russia has a new class of weapons, President Vladimir V. Putin said on Thursday, that could make American defenses obsolete.\n\nMr. Putin could be bluffing. It\u2019s unclear how many of the five weapons he described actually exist. But a close look at the videos he presented indicates some telling details about their state of readiness and how they work.\n\nHere is what we know:\n\nNuclear Cruise Missile", "title": "Putin Flaunted Five Powerful Weapons. Are They a Threat?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "After months of escalating tensions between North Korea and the United States, officials made a stunning announcement on Thursday: Kim Jong-un, the North\u2019s leader, had invited President Trump to meet and discuss his country\u2019s nuclear program \u2014 and Mr. Trump accepted.\n\nThe report is particularly surprising given that no sitting American president has ever met with a North Korean leader, and that Mr. Trump himself had ruled out direct talks unless North Korea agreed to take measurable steps toward relinquishing its nuclear arsenal.\n\nThat, and for the last year, the two leaders have been trading insults. Here are some of the most notable things Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim have said about each other.\n\n(If you\u2019d like to know more about today\u2019s news, here\u2019s our article and a transcript of the announcement.)", "title": "Trump and Kim Jong-un, and the Names They\u2019ve Called Each Other", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "She gathered the courage to ask co-workers to join her in a lawsuit. When the boss caught wind of her plans, she was fired. \u201cIt felt like hopelessness,\u201d she said later. \u201cIt felt like this is not going to change. Especially with what\u2019s going on in the media and all the celebrities, and this still happens.\u201d\n\nWomen with wider influence share those anxieties. When Tina Tchen, a lawyer and former chief of staff to Michelle Obama, left the White House, she thought she would quietly restart her legal career focusing on workplace issues. Now she is helping to guide the Time\u2019s Up Legal Defense Fund, an initiative that sprang up virtually overnight, spearheaded by women in entertainment, and that faces a critical question: whether the more than $20 million donated so far can fund both immediate legal help for low-income workers like Ms. Parra and a longer-term strategy of filing potential landmark cases.\n\nMs. Tchen has also been working with organizations that have faced harassment allegations: the Service Employees International Union, which was particularly embarrassed given its mission of protecting workers; and Pixar Animation, where John Lasseter, perhaps the most revered animator since Walt Disney, recently took a leave of absence.\n\nAcross industries, Ms. Tchen says she sees plenty of resolve for fighting harassment, but a lack of proven mechanisms. \u201cThe tool kit is a little bit bare,\u201d she said, explaining that there is no consensus on how to report a repeat offender who goes from job to job, or address more minor infractions with measures short of suspension or firing.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut among some major corporations, a fear-driven shift has begun: Harassment is now considered not just a legal liability, but also a serious reputational and business risk. Executives and boards are beginning to look at harassment \u201cthe same way you think about other risks to your organization\u201d like security or hacking, said Kaye Foster-Cheek, former head of human resources for Johnson & Johnson and a member of three boards.\n\nIt\u2019s impossible to tell how many workplaces are increasing their efforts. Many do not want to discuss it publicly, for fear of implying that they didn\u2019t do enough in the past. But Microsoft made a bold move in December, eliminating forced confidential arbitration for employees who make sexual harassment claims, saying it didn\u2019t want to pressure those women to stay silent. For the first time, the Screen Actors Guild has introduced a clear code of conduct on harassment, detailing prohibited behavior and vowing to protect members. Facebook recently made public its sexual harassment policy, staking the company to those guidelines. New York University banned romantic relationships between faculty members and undergraduates or anyone over whom they exercise \u201csupervisory authority,\u201d a move that was already under consideration but that passed after the Weinstein allegations. And Seattle enacted new city rules and procedures to ensure respectful behavior on construction sites.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor the first time I\u2019m seeing a discussion about, \u2018Even if this behavior doesn\u2019t rise to the level of legal sexual harassment, we won\u2019t tolerate it,\u2019\u201d said Johnny C. Taylor Jr., president of the Society for Human Resource Management.\n\nIn the past, the burden for uncovering misconduct was almost always on victims, but now some companies are assuming a fact-finding role. More are turning to anonymous but detailed employee surveys with questions like \u201cDo you feel safe?\u201d and \u201cHave you experienced harassment?\u201d If workers say yes, the company won\u2019t know the particulars, but it can initiate investigations or increase training.\n\nIn recent months, Katharine Zaleski, an entrepreneur in New York, has been contacted by two powerful institutional investors, Invesco and Cambridge Associates, that were vetting male venture capitalists whom they were considering funding. They wanted to make sure these men had not behaved problematically, she said. (Invesco declined to comment; Cambridge Associates declined to address specifics, but a spokeswoman said in an email, \u201cWe take culture, policies and conduct very seriously when we consider managers for our clients\u2019 investments.\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nMore companies are now accepting that \u201ccomplaint and reporting procedures have failed,\u201d said Freada Kapor Klein, who helped establish the field of sexual harassment training and, as an investor, has helped push through changes at Uber and other companies.\n\nEntrepreneurs are developing new systems for women to report their experiences \u2014 and for businesses to understand what is transpiring. TEQuitable, a platform created by Lisa Gelobter and Heidi Williams, connects workers with real-world support and can send companies anonymized alerts about complaints. Callisto, which is used on campuses to report sexual assaults, is being adapted for workplace use, said Jess Ladd, the founder. Vault, created by Neta Meidav, helps women save evidence and, like Callisto, shows users if others have named the same offender.\n\nMore traditional strategies, like sexual harassment training, are also booming. \u201cI could be booked between now and 10 years from now and still not fulfill the degree of demand,\u201d said Stephen Paskoff, a longtime trainer whose clients include Coca-Cola and Verizon Wireless.\n\nBut the record on workplace harassment training is mixed. California, Connecticut and Maine have required it for years (New York City may soon join them). Those requirements led to a surge in cheap, off-the-shelf training videos and software that could insulate companies from lawsuits, by demonstrating that they had taken measures to prevent harassment, while actually helping perpetuate the problem, because the tutorials were superficial. After harassment allegations surfaced last fall in the Texas Legislature, leaders promised training and then distributed a rote-sounding video and quiz that drew derision.\n\nThe most effective training is expensive, requiring small-group sessions, deep looks at organizational culture and frequent follow-up. But even those who deliver it warn that it is not a complete solution. \u201cDo you think if Harvey Weinstein went to a harassment training class it would have prohibited his behavior?\u201d Mr. Paskoff asked.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd in some cases, the public pressure on companies just means that more quiet financial force is being used. Several employment lawyers say that settlement amounts have been rising. \u201cCases are settling for premium dollars very quickly,\u201d said Debra Katz, a lawyer in Washington, who added that she had settled three cases against chief executives in recent months. Employers are \u201cpaying to avoid the public black eye, being outed as harassers,\u201d she said. (New Jersey and other states are considering bans or limits on secret settlements, setting up what is likely to be a fight between those who argue that the agreements enable harassment by burying the problem and those who stress that they are often a woman\u2019s best recourse.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn industries like food service and cleaning that have typically offered workers fewer protections, the momentum that has picked up in recent months has no clear outlet. Organizers who work with female janitors, fast food workers, hotel housekeepers, nannies and eldercare providers say that women in those fields have become more willing to speak up. But it\u2019s not clear whom they should tell.\n\nEtelbina Hauser, a Honduran immigrant who cleans houses in Seattle, said she felt bolstered by the Hollywood women who spoke out about harassment. \u201cIt makes me feel powerful because I feel like all women are joining together,\u201d she said in Spanish. Two men have exposed themselves to Ms. Hauser while she was cleaning their homes. A third propositioned her for sex. In each case she fled, gave up the job and essentially kept the experience to herself.\n\nSelf-employed workers like Ms. Hauser have no colleagues, no human resources department, no concrete employment policies. \u201cIn many cases no one knows this woman is working there,\u201d said Ai-jen Poo, executive director of the National Domestic Workers Alliance.\n\nWhen The New York Times asked a number of low-wage employers if they had taken new steps in recent months to prevent harassment, almost none said yes. Some would not comment; others, including Walmart, Target, Sears Holdings, Subway, Costco, Aramark and ABM Industries, said they already had the right policies and procedures in place.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat frustrates advocates, lawyers and activists most are giant holes in the federal laws meant to protect women from harassment. Few of the cases that shocked the court of public opinion in recent months would have been likely to prevail in a real court. The law covers only workplaces with 15 or more employees. The federal statute of limitations for filing a suit can be as short as 180 days. Even when a woman wins her case, damages can be capped at $300,000 \u2014 less if she works at a small company. This month, a jury awarded Rosanna Mayo-Coleman, a sugar refinery worker in New York, $13.4 million in a lawsuit against Domino Sugar\u2019s parent company, but because of the cap she is likely to collect only a fraction of that.\n\nCalifornia legislators are working on what activists hope will be a model for the rest of the country: building up state-level protections for victims of sexual harassment to patch the gaps in the federal rules. One proposed state law extends the statute of limitations. Another specifically defines the business roles it addresses: not just \u201cemployer,\u201d but also producer, director, investor. Another would make supervisors personally liable for any retaliation. \u201cThese are wholesale changes in the law; they are new rights,\u201d said Noreen Farrell, executive director of Equal Rights Advocates, an anti-discrimination group helping to push the California bills.\n\nJust this week, Washington State enacted laws to make it easier for women to come forward about harassment, including by prohibiting nondisclosure agreements that prevent them from describing their experiences.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ultimate solution to sexual harassment, many believe, is having more women in positions of power. Until more women are owners, chief executives and bosses, the dynamic may always be the same: a man calling the shots, and a more junior woman afraid to resist or report. (As Time\u2019s Up grows, this will be its central focus, a leader of the group said; offshoots in advertising and journalism have been announced, and others in sports, technology and venture capital are forming.)\n\nSeveral weeks ago, Renee LaChance, a general contractor in Portland, Ore., was discussing a renovation with a male electrician when he unleashed a stream of explicit comments about her breasts.\n\n\u201cHaven\u2019t you been paying attention?\u201d she asked him, flabbergasted that all the recent news about harassment had not deterred him.\n\nHer solution was simple. \u201cI\u2019m the person in power in the relationship,\u201d she said. \u201cI fired him on the spot.\u201d", "title": "#MeToo Called for an Overhaul. Are Workplaces Really Changing?", "authors": ["Jodi Kantor"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "And for a minute, I actually believed that what we were looking for in the last two years were direct responses to the Trump administration. But what if I\u2019ve been looking for the wrong thing? What if the crux of the moment \u2014 really since 2008 \u2014 is a matter of selfhood and representation and political correctives? This isn\u2019t shocking. But it is worth noting.\n\nIn almost any other year, \u201cDunkirk\u201d or \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d or \u201cThe Post\u201d would have been slam-dunk best picture winners. These are movies by white men starring mostly most white men (and Meryl Streep), and they fell out of a lot of the serious forecasts for the major categories despite, in at least the cases of \u201cDunkirk\u201d and \u201cThe Post,\u201d being nearly perfectly made. The energies were around \u201cGet Out\u201c and \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d two very different films about America right now. (Although with \u201cThree Billboards,\u201d I should say \u201cabout America.\u201d)\n\nDARGIS I\u2019ve started to think that the academy members are trying to correct their own industry\u2019s flaws by voting for movies that don\u2019t fit the old ideas about best picture. Some of these recent wins surely reflect the increased diversity of the membership, but some of this may also be an earnest self-conscious corrective.\n\nAs to the underbelly that Tony mentioned \u2014 we caught a flash of it every so often. We saw it most directly when Ms. Sciorra \u2014 her voice at times faltering \u2014 addressed the room while she helped present what was termed new (activist, change-minded) voices. \u201cHi, it\u2019s nice to see you all again, it\u2019s been a while.\u201d She was warmly greeted \u2014 someone yelled, \u201cLove you!\u201d \u2014 and the applause sounded sincere, at least on my TV. At the same time, how many in that very same room, even some who were applauding, have been complicit in all the ugliness that continues to be exhumed? And I don\u2019t mean only those who did business with Mr. Weinstein while knowing or at least guessing the truth about him.\n\nI mean everyone else in that room who has never hired a woman to do anything except look beautiful or prop up the male hero, everyone who never casts Asians or Latinos or African-Americans except as tokens even while (occasionally) publicly fawning over their famous black best friends? I\u2019m very hopeful about some of the righteous activism that has emerged in the wake of the allegations against Mr. Weinstein, and it was a relief not to see him last night. But of course he\u2019s just part of the industry\u2019s larger, systemic problems. And, as we\u2019ve discussed before (repeatedly!), the Oscars are not the movie industry. They are simply its public dolled-up face.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBecause I am pretty sure that the biggest night in Hollywood happens during Disney\u2019s annual shareholders\u2019 meeting. That\u2019s where the action is, where the money is, where the power is.\n\nSCOTT Those shareholders will be basking in the afterglow of \u2014 and cashing dividend checks fattened by \u2014 \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi,\u201d \u201cCoco\u201d and \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d and possibly also \u201cA Wrinkle in Time.\u201d Those movies show diversity taking hold at the tentpole level, which is the strongest evidence that it\u2019s a matter of economic calculation as well as social consciousness. And why shouldn\u2019t it be? White men have held a near-monopoly on movie storytelling for the last 90 years, and as Kumail Nanjiani suggested on Sunday night, there\u2019s nothing threatening about everyone else getting a turn.\n\nBut there\u2019s never progress without backlash, so we can expect a certain amount of grumbling about Hollywood liberals and social justice warriors, and about how a white man just can\u2019t catch a break anymore. And nothing is easier than pointing out the hypocrisy of the entertainment industry. Except maybe remarking on how long and boring the Oscar broadcast is. A lot of good movies were recognized, though, including a bunch that might have seemed too small, too genre or too niche in past years. I wish \u201cLady Bird\u201d had gotten something, that \u201cGet Out\u201d had gotten more and that \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d had been more of a presence. Still, I\u2019m not mad that \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d won, and kind of astonished that it almost looks like the safe, mainstream choice for best picture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMORRIS Yes, Tony, it feels meaningful that the best picture winner wasn\u2019t about World War II or journalism (during the Vietnam War!) but about a woman whose soul mate and lover is an amphibian and that it was made by a Mexican man. I don\u2019t think \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d is a great movie. But I do like it. And I don\u2019t know how it won, but somehow it did. And, after \u201cMoonlight\u201d last year (ultimately, a love story between two black men), that feels like a rejection and an embrace.\n\nDARGIS Oh, I wish many things, including that another movie had won best picture and other performers had carted off the best supporting statuettes. Guillermo del Toro seems like a nice man. And both Sam Rockwell and Allison Janney are exceptionally fine actors. I\u2019m looking forward to whatever all three do next. (I\u2019ll just pretend Mr. Rockwell won for \u201cMoon\u201d and Ms. Janney won for anything but \u201cI, Tonya.\u201d) Honestly, other than the sight of all those great women last night, I am most pleased that \u201cThree Billboards\u201d didn\u2019t win best picture or anything else, really. The love for it is baffling, though it does suggest that \u2014 with the lack of love for \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d \u2014 class is the industry\u2019s biggest blind spot.\n\nI look forward to tweeting next year that Raoul Peck\u2019s \u201cThe Young Karl Marx\u201d was robbed.", "title": "#MeToo, Harvey Weinstein and Awkward TV: Our Critics Talk Oscars", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "A.O. Scott", "Wesley Morris"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "INDOORS The original owner, a 19th-century hardware retailer, incorporated fine examples of his inventory into the house, including pressed-tin ceilings. The current owners, the third family to have possession, have conserved these elements as well as pocket doors, Steuben glass ceiling lamps and floors of pine surrounded by oak \u2014 the more expensive wood protruding from the areas that would have been covered by carpets. Reproduction Victorian wallpaper is another period feature of their historic restoration project.\n\nDouble pocket doors open from the foyer to the parlor, which has a large front-facing window with a window seat. This room adjoins the living room, with its original coal-burning fireplace surrounded by ceramic tile and topped by an ornate wood mantel. The dining room next to it has direct access to one of three outdoor porches. The kitchen, which once occupied the space now used as a mudroom, was moved and expanded to include floor-to-ceiling hardwood cabinets with concrete countertops and a walk-in pantry. The main floor also includes a study and a full bathroom.\n\nUpstairs, the master bedroom has an alcove that could be used as a sitting room or nursery. One of the two guest rooms has a Jotul gas stove. There is also a full bathroom and laundry room on this floor.\n\nOUTDOOR SPACE The 0.24-acre property includes a fenced backyard with a brick patio, perennial gardens and distinctive hickory and pecan trees. A small two-story building constructed in 2003 in the backyard, on the site of the original owner\u2019s carrier pigeon house, has a greenhouse and a full bathroom on the lower level and a loft space above. An adjacent lot includes a two-car garage, additional parking and vegetable and herb gardens.\n\nTAXES $8,133\n\nCONTACT Elizabeth Brien, Reinhart Realtors, 734-645-4444; reinhartrealtors.com\n\n\u2022\n\nNew Orleans\n\nWHAT A home built around 1901, with three bedrooms and three and a half bathrooms\n\nHOW MUCH $1.2 million\n\nSIZE 2,803 square feet\n\nPRICE PER SQUARE FOOT $428\n\nSETTING Originally a doctor\u2019s residence and office, the house is in the Marigny neighborhood next to the French Quarter, and is close to cafes, restaurants and arts spaces.\n\nINDOORS The current owners bought the building in 2001 and extensively restored it. It occupies an acre on a principal street near an intersection of two expressways known as the Braintree split. The South Shore Plaza mall is less than a 10-minute drive away.\n\nINDOORS Formerly a convent for the Archdiocese of Boston, the house was vacant for a decade before it was bought in 2011. In the multiyear renovation that followed, most of the original details were preserved; the plumbing, heating and electrical systems were updated; and the property, including the pool area, was landscaped.\n\nThe main entrance takes you into a foyer, with a formal dining room on the left and a long living room on the right. The floors of the principal rooms here and upstairs are the original oak with walnut pegs. The living room has a working fireplace with flanking bookshelves. Earl Wear, who designed several homes in the area, created Owl\u2019s Nest in 1963 as his own residence. Subscribing to Frank Lloyd Wright\u2019s organic principles, he used redwood, stone and glass for their harmony with the landscape.\n\nThe open-plan main floor is paved with smooth stone slabs and centers on a two-story-high stone fireplace that rises through intersecting redwood beams. A built-in sofa with integrated cabinets anchors the living area. The kitchen is on the other side of the fireplace and has a large island with a separate oven and stovetop. The dining area also has a built-in sofa, as well as double glass doors that lead to a large paved outdoor seating area.\n\nThe larger main-level bedroom has three exposures and direct access to the backyard; the smaller bedroom has built-in bookshelves. The main-floor bathroom has a walk-in shower with period tiles and a wall of open storage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA loft area suspended over the main floor contains another bedroom with an en-suite bathroom and windows that let occupants see the stars at night.\n\nOUTDOOR SPACE Entry to the .88-acre property is through a wood-and-corrugated-metal gate. Pine, oak, redwood and eucalyptus trees surround the house. There is a separate artist\u2019s studio as well as a hot tub and a ring of tree stumps that can be used as a drum circle. Eight cars can comfortably park in the gravel driveway. The home also has a detached two-car garage.\n\nTAXES $22,918\n\nCONTACT Tenny Kilmore, Hilton & Hyland, 310-849-8252; 2440minard.com", "title": "$2 Million Homes in Illinois, South Carolina and California", "authors": ["Julie Lasky", "What You Get"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The winner of a $560 million Powerball jackpot \u2014 one of the largest prizes in United States history \u2014 can remain anonymous, a New Hampshire judge ruled Monday.\n\nThe woman who bought the winning ticket in January had gone to court to keep her name from being made public. Her lawyers argued that she feared being overwhelmed with requests for a share of her winnings and was concerned about her safety.\n\nThe state had argued that the names of lottery winners must be disclosed to ensure that prizes are distributed fairly and that winners are not related to lottery employees.\n\nIn the end, the court sided with the woman, saying disclosing her name would amount to an invasion of privacy.", "title": "$560 Million Powerball Winner Can Keep Her Name Private, Judge Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "INDOORS A thorough renovation involved updated electrical and plumbing systems, a new roof and siding and the addition of a front porch with built-in planters and a pergola. A large room with a combined living and dining area terminates in a new kitchen with a long peninsula. French doors lead to a large backyard deck with a shaded area.\n\nOff the main room are the master bedroom with a new en-suite bathroom, and a guest bedroom and second new bathroom. An external flight of stairs leads to a private third bedroom that could be used as a guest room or rented. It has an in-room sink, stall shower and water closet.\n\nOUTDOOR SPACE The .29-acre property includes a cedar-fenced yard with a driveway gate. An outbuilding could be used as a one-car garage or a \u201cgame hangar\u201d with a Ping-Pong table or other recreations. The structure has a screened porch with views of Boggy Creek.\n\nTAXES $9,588 (estimated)\n\nCONTACT Mark Str\u00fcb, Str\u00fcb Residential, 512-922-8992; 3505grayson.com\n\nPhiladelphia\n\nWHAT A former carriage house built in 1932, with three bedrooms and two bathrooms\n\nHOW MUCH $650,000\n\nSIZE 1,755 square feet\n\nPRICE PER SQUARE FOOT $370\n\nSETTING The home is in the Chestnut Hill district, on an 18th-century road that winds through nearby Fairmount Park. The Morris Arboretum, Woodmere Art Museum and Chestnut Hill College are all within walking distance. Two stations on the SEPTA regional rail line are each a mile away.\n\nINDOORS The front entrance of the stone-and-stucco home takes you into a foyer with large coat closet. From the foyer, you enter a combined living and dining area with parquet floors, built-in bookshelves and a wood-burning fireplace. The adjoining den has a picture window, as well as access to a large closet and a full bathroom; it could be used as a third bedroom. The eat-in kitchen has extensive cabinetry and counter space, and a Dutch door leading to a stone outdoor patio.\n\nThe two upstairs bedrooms have hardwood floors and canted walls. One bedroom has access through a Dutch door to a small outdoor porch.", "title": "$650,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Texas and Pennsylvania", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 Two Texas oil companies joined forces on Wednesday in the biggest deal yet in the Southwestern oil patch, one that should add momentum to the rush to produce more oil as prices rise.\n\nThe creation of a shale-oil colossus comes at a precarious moment, when production in the region is expanding so fast that pipeline construction is barely keeping up. That may cap the potential of the deal, at least over the next year or two, to get oil to the market profitably.\n\nThe move by Concho Resources to purchase RSP Permian for $9.5 billion will make it the biggest shale oil and natural gas producer in the Permian Basin, the oil-rich area. With 27 rigs, the company said it would have the area\u2019s largest drilling and hydraulic fracturing operation and a reach of 640,000 acres.\n\nMuch larger companies, like Exxon Mobil and Chevron, are also increasing their investments in the Permian Basin, where output has doubled to roughly three million barrels a day over the last five years, making it the principal driver of the domestic oil production boom.", "title": "$9.5 Billion Purchase by Concho Is Latest Sign of West Texas Oil Boom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s look at an example, 49A: \u201c\u2018I need everyone\u2019s help!\u2019\u201d. If you\u2019re on a ship, or even just in an office where people try to sound dramatic, this is a call for ALL HANDS ON DECK. But this answer doesn\u2019t fit; you need to enter ALL H + S ON DECK, and the H + S (or HANDS, or HS) needs to squeeze into the fourth square across.\n\nMeanwhile, at 31D, you\u2019ve got a six-letter word for \u201cReddish-purple.\u201d I couldn\u2019t find any colors that fit, and the strange \u201cH+S\u201d at the fourth spot is an indication for the color FUCHSIA.\n\nA few of the across-themed clues are nostalgic but not terribly obscure (one was an excellent debut and one-off, A FISH CALLED WANDA), and Mr. Ezersky nonchalantly pulls references from the 1730s and the 1970s, among other eras. I suppose when one is the age of Mr. Ezersky everything that\u2019s not on Snapchat counts as nostalgia. As is mentioned in his notes, today marks the first Ezersky Sunday puzzle, which means he\u2019s now constructed grids for all seven days, surely the first of many, many times he will \u201chit for the cycle.\u201d Mr. Ezersky, please stay away from steroids, as we\u2019d hate to have to put an asterisk next to your name in the 2050 record books.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n22A: This is a new clue for an age-old entry, AVE MARIA. It\u2019s often nice to be reminded of wonderful things from the past, in this case \u201cFantasia.\u201d There\u2019s an interesting history to this movie; it had an enormous creative army behind it and the first stereophonic movie soundtrack, but it was initially such a failure that it nearly drove Disney out of business.\n\nNowadays, even though it feels like we are inundated with streaming content, I wonder how someone would watch a movie like this, unless they still had a DVD or VHS player and could either buy a recording or rent it from their library. Disney is planning a streaming service in a year but it\u2019s a good example of an incontrovertible classic that isn\u2019t at our fingertips.\n\n32A: Not sure if this tripped people up, but a cute variety of misdirection. What do you hope people have when they leave? If I\u2019m the people, then it\u2019s a) keys, b) wallet with MetroCard, c) laptop for work, d) phone, e) headphones and f) head, which I would forget if it weren\u2019t screwed on. Here, though, it\u2019s NICE DAY, which is a nice thing to say to someone when you\u2019re parting ways (nicer than \u201chave a nice life!\u201d \u2014 which has unpleasant undertones).\n\n56A: Any cereal I was given as a child came with fiber and umlauts, but no toys. Any freebie from one of the boxes I got would have been either educational or utilitarian; conservation flash cards or carrot seeds, maybe. Not till today did I realize the toys and the cereal could be a TIE-IN to something else, like a movie or a TV show. I didn\u2019t even get to go down that aisle; we stayed on the supermarket perimeter and now I have no shut-off valve and lose it to an embarrassing degree when exposed to sweets (see 23A, although I\u2019m certainly not a kid).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n108A: This clue sent me to my mental spice drawer, as that\u2019s what I initially thought of as \u201cused in a pinch.\u201d That was wrong, but even though I had heard the term \u201cpinch of snuff\u201d many times, for some weird reason I\u2019d always thought that snuff was opium. I imagined the founding fathers inhaling ample amounts of opium while they devised our nation\u2019s blueprint, and for some reason a spittoon was involved. Not true! Snuff is just TOBACCO. In my highbrow research endeavors I uncovered a really cute fable about a \u201cpinch of snuff,\u201d if you feel like reading a mash-up of O. Henry and Judaica.\n\n120A: A mass\u00e9 is a trick shot in pool, from the Old French for sledgehammer. The move is more delicate than you\u2019d think, given that fact; it\u2019s also known as a SPIN SHOT. I suppose that not all spin shots are mass\u00e9s, but I think all mass\u00e9s are spin shots, since the spin is what lets the ball move so precisely. On another note, if any one of you happens to watch the below video and become a professional pool player because of it, please let the Wordplay team know, so that we can provide you with a snazzy sponsorship patch for your vest.\n\n41D: \u201cReaches\u201d seemed to be a good entry here for \u201cMakes a connection,\u201d meaning a meeting of the minds between two people. The meaning implied by the right answer, LIAISES, is a little bit different, indicating the use of a go-between or some form of collaboration. This is a useful puzzle entry with all those vowels, I\u2019m sure.\n\n51D: Unless you knew TV-MA was the entry at 61A (a red herring for me for a while, since the numbers in the title of this puzzle led me to \u201cNC-17\u201d), then LEMMESEE might have been a tough one to figure out here. It\u2019s a debut; the stodgier \u201cLet me see\u201d appears pretty often.\n\n95D: Back in the clackety 20th century we would create TABSETS to format manuscripts and letters, typed on a manual or electric typewriter. They still exist in word programs, but I don\u2019t think they\u2019re referred to often; you could also use the term for the dozens of tabbed pages you have open in a browser after you look online at, well, anything these days.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nNo April fooling; one week after my A.C.P.T. playoff puzzle, I actually have a Sunday publication in The Times! This achievement has eluded me for years, so I\u2019m super stoked to finally \u201chit for the cycle\u201d on being published throughout the week. Funny enough, I originally built the 15 X 16 grid here, intending the puzzle for a Thursday. I didn\u2019t want a single rebus-ized letter to be repeated anywhere else, and figured the special squares should always appear at the ends of answers. My only hitch was whether or not the last example, THERE\u2019S NOT A LOT I CAN DO, was an unfair inconsistency or a fun final twist. When I showed it all to Joel on a subway ride, he not only thought the former was true, but that my other restrictions were unnecessary. He wondered if the idea would be best in Sunday form altogether, and it took me maybe a half-second to excitedly agree. If I may say, I\u2019m super thrilled with how this thing turned out. These theme answers seem like a fun set in themselves, and I\u2019m glad to have worked in four sets of triple-stacked 8s as well as fun bonuses in YEAH MAN, BAR SOAP and NICE DAY. The clues for TOBACCO and OLES feel like some of my best work, and even the angles for OMAN, ALABAMA and AVE MARIA have a fresh feel. Did anyone catch the \u201cIt\u2019s lit\u201d and \u201cTotally, bro\u201d one-two punch? That was \u2014 *sigh* \u2014 very intentional. Curious to see how people feel about RIGHT FIT. I could\u2019ve easily made this RIGHTFUL, but I thought the former was an interesting, lexical phrase. You hope that a new setting is the right fit for someone, no? Or, as I clued it, that your clothing has the right fit on you? Two certain people that I work with closely seem to feel otherwise \u2026 so I guess I should brace myself for an earful in the comments :) Happy solving, and may this puzzle not fool you as much as yesterday\u2019s early surprise!\n\nThe Sunday Sherpa\n\nDoes something still not compute? Throw that calculator out the window and take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "1 + 1 = 5", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nAILEY II at Ailey Citigroup Theater (March 14-25). The 12 dancers of Ailey II \u2014 the second company of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater \u2014 return to New York after a 32-city world tour with two programs and premieres by Juel D. Lane, Renee I. McDonald and Darrell Grand Moultrie. Coming back into the repertory are dances by Jae Man Joo, Bridget L. Moore and the former Ailey dancer Marcus Jarrell Willis. Led by the artistic director Troy Powell, the dancers are the draw. While many move on to the esteemed main company, even the ones who don\u2019t are spilling over with talent. As for the choreography? It\u2019s likely a mix of heartfelt and physical.\n\n866-811-4111, alvinailey.org\n\nBRIAN BROOKS DANCE at the Joyce Theater (March 14, 7:30 p.m.; March 15-17, 8 p.m.). The contemporary choreographer Brian Brooks \u2014 a favorite of the ballerina Wendy Whelan \u2014 returns to the Joyce as the inaugural choreographer in residence of Chicago\u2019s Harris Theater for Music and Dance. In \u201cPrelude,\u201d commissioned by the Harris Theater, he focuses on the concept of undoing as dancers continually rewind their movements. The program also features a revival of \u201cDivision,\u201d in which six performers find themselves maneuvering rectangular wooden boards.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nCULLEN + THEM: \u2018MARK IT IN PENCIL\u2019 at New York Live Arts (March 14, 7 p.m., through March 17). In this work, Hannah Cullen, who presides over this performing arts organization of adult and adolescent dancers, explores ideas about unity and division. Joined by Avery-Jai Andrews, Ramiro Batista, Adriana Santos and members of the Young Dance Collective \u2014 its performers are between 11 and 14 \u2014 Ms. Cullen uses dance and theater to address gender, sexuality and mental illness. How can conflict be resolved through listening? It\u2019s a theme.\n\n212-691-6500, newyorklivearts.org\n\n\u2018DANCING PLATFORM PRAYING GROUNDS: BLACKNESS, CHURCHES AND DOWNTOWN DANCE\u2019 at Danspace Project and other locations (through March 24). This ongoing platform \u2014 a series of performances, talks and walking tours curated by the choreographer Reggie Wilson \u2014 examines the cultural, dance and architectural histories of downtown New York and beyond. On Thursday, Mr. Wilson presents a shared evening featuring new works by Keely Garfield, Same as Sister \u2014 Briana Brown-Tipley and Hilary Brown \u2014 and Ni\u2019Ja Whitson. On Wednesday, the choreographer Emily Johnson explores our relationship with land and indigenous New York in a silent walk through the East Village, which was once part of Lenapehoking, the homeland of the Lenape people. The event is sold out, but there is a waiting list.\n\n866-811-4111, danspaceproject.org\n\n\u2018FROM THE HORSE\u2019S MOUTH\u2019 at the Theater at the 14th Street Y (March 13, 6 p.m.; March 15, 8 p.m., through March 18). The latest iteration of \u201cFrom the Horse\u2019s Mouth,\u201d the popular series created by Tina Croll and Jamie Cunningham in which figures from the dance world share stories about their careers and lives, focuses on Egyptian dance \u2014 specifically the ballet dancer Magda Saleh, as well as the development of ballet and other dance forms in Egypt. Over the course of four days, more than 30 dancers, musicians, historians and choreographers share memories, anecdotes and, of course, dance. The series also features film screenings, including one of \u201cA Footnote in Ballet History?\u201d on Tuesday.\n\n212-780-0800, 14streety.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWENDY OSSERMAN at Theater for the New City (March 14-17, 8 p.m.). The veteran choreographer Wendy Osserman unveils her latest evening of work \u2014 with a group of talented dancers, including Joshua Tuason and Cori Kresge \u2014 that features the premiere of \u201cUndermine.\u201d Inspired by the current political climate, it draws on concepts from the Native American medicine wheel and features music by Skip LaPlante, who creates scores for traditional and homemade instruments. Also included is \u201cUdjat,\u201d a trio from 1985.\n\n212-868-4444, theaterforthenewcity.net", "title": "10 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "IMPEACHMENT: A Citizen\u2019s Guide, by Cass R. Sunstein. (Harvard University, paper, $7.95.) Sunstein\u2019s topic has obvious contemporary resonance, as Andrew Sullivan notes in his review, and though this short book does not take up the Trump presidency directly it does tease out \u201cvarious hypotheticals with some similarities to our current concerns,\u201d concluding that \u201ceach of these is an impeachable offense.\u201d Yet Sunstein also cautions that the Constitution was written to ensure that a clear national consensus was necessary if a president was to be judged to be gravely violating his oath of office, or betraying the country. \u201cThis is why in well over two centuries the impeachment power has been invoked against sitting presidents only four times,\u201d Sullivan writes, \u201cand never actually pursued to conviction.\u201d\n\nTHE TEMPTATION OF FORGIVENESS, by Donna Leon. (Atlantic Monthly, $26.) Commissario Guido Brunetti embarks on another atmospheric Venetian criminal investigation, this time coming to the aid of a woman whose husband has been attacked on one of the city\u2019s stone bridges. \u201cTagging along after this sleuth is a wonderful way to see Venice like a native,\u201d Marilyn Stasio writes in the Book Review\u2019s crime column, \u201cespecially since Leon takes care to give us precise directions for his routes. But Brunetti\u2019s observations aren\u2019t always pretty. The air pollution is beyond acceptable limits, and don\u2019t even mention the pollution of the canals.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA LONG WAY FROM HOME, by Peter Carey. (Knopf, $26.95.) This latest novel from the two-time Booker Prize-winning author of \u201cTrue History of the Kelly Gang\u201d and \u201cOscar and Lucinda\u201d follows a married couple and their bachelor neighbor on a bumptious 10,000-mile auto race in 1950s Australia, grappling along the way with the country\u2019s historical treatment of its Aboriginal population. \u201cWith all its inventive momentum, all its pleasurable beats, the fast pace of the race, the scenery unfurling, the novel ends up far from where it started, in a place of historical reckoning and colonial guilt,\u201d Craig Taylor writes in his review. \u201cCarey\u2019s longtime readers will appreciate his arrival here. \u2026 Using a wild road race, he\u2019s found a journey into Australia\u2019s broken past.\u201d\n\nMY FATHER\u2019S WAKE: How the Irish Teach Us How to Live, Love and Die, by Kevin Toolis. (Da Capo, $26.) The hospital death of Toolis\u2019s brother, followed by his father\u2019s death in small-town Ireland, led him to examine death rituals around the world. The Irish wake, he concludes, is \u201cthe best guide to life you could ever have.\u201d In her review, Ann Neumann says that the author\u2019s \u201cfine skill at showing the means and aftermath of death\u201d most animates the book: \u201cToolis\u2019s writing is so visceral and profound when he is near dying bodies that the lessons of such experiences become evident.\u201d\n\nTHE NEIGHBORHOOD, by Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Edith Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Written telenova-style, with chapters alternating among various characters, the Nobel laureate Vargas Llosa\u2019s new novel is an edgy sendup of life in Peru before the downfall of Alberto Fujimori. Wealthy friends find themselves in a difficult situation when one is blackmailed by a tabloid editor and the other, a lawyer, tries to help. \u201cIn a diseased body politic \u2026 no one is exempt from infection, and the sanity of every citizen is dependent upon that of his neighbor,\u201d Michael Greenberg writes in his review, speculating that \u201cthe book\u2019s \u2018happy\u2019 ending reflects its author\u2019s belief, perhaps, in the power of individual morality and will.\u201d\n\nVICTORIANS UNDONE: Tales of the Flesh in the Age of Decorum, by Kathryn Hughes. (Johns Hopkins University, $29.95.) Hughes\u2019s detailed account of five notable 19th-century body parts topples great figures from their pedestals. From baby bumps to facial hair, the book asks what we can learn about a culture by studying the human bodies it produces. \u201cWhile microhistorians have long zoomed in on individual case studies, Hughes pinpoints her subjects even more narrowly,\u201d our reviewer, Leah Price, writes. \u201cHer ultimate question, though, is a broad one: How did the Victorians understand the interplay between mind and body?\u201d\n\nTHE WHICH WAY TREE, by Elizabeth Crook. (Little, Brown, $26.) Crook\u2019s western-inflected novel follows a pair of siblings on their hunt for the wild panther that upended their lives. The teenage narrator \u201cunspools his tale of Civil War-era Texas in a first-person voice that is utterly convincing, consistent and believable,\u201d Paulette Jiles says, in a review that finds echoes of \u201cMoby-Dick\u201d in the siblings\u2019 quest. (\u201cThink Ahab in the Texas Hill Country.\u201d) The book\u2019s voice, Jiles adds, \u201cswings between the rhythms of the Southern hills and the lofty, elevated tone encountered in Twain and contemporary westerns (which ultimately comes from an acquaintance with the King James Bible).\u201d", "title": "10 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018BOBBIE CLEARLY\u2019 at the Black Box Theater in the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater (previews start on March 8; opens on April 3). Eleven actors crowd into Roundabout Underground\u2019s cramped basement for Alex Lubischer\u2019s comedy-drama of truth, reconciliation and snacks. Bobbie committed murder. Bobbie is out of prison. A town of Nebraskans are asked to apportion guilt and innocence. Will Davis directs.\n\n212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org\n\n\u2018THE FALL\u2019 at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse (previews start on March 8; opens on March 12). We continue to reckon with our flags and our monuments, and there are reckonings elsewhere, too. In 2015, students at the University of Cape Town rose up to remove a statue of the colonial minister Cecil Rhodes. In this documentary-drama, seven students use dance, speech and song to recall their campaign.\n\n866-811-4111, stannswarehouse.org\n\n\u2018GOOD FOR OTTO\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (in previews; opens on March 8). Good for the New Group. In this David Rabe play, a fine cast, including F. Murray Abraham, Ed Harris, Amy Madigan, Rhea Perlman and Mark Linn-Baker, has been assembled to play doctors and patients at a New England mental health center, a metaphor for a troubled United States.\n\n212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org", "title": "10 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Plus, a Times Talks event. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018ADMISSIONS\u2019 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center Theater (in previews; opens on March 12). A play of personal statements and professional compromise, Joshua Harmon\u2019s drama centers on the admissions director of a private school whose own son is applying to college. Daniel Aukin directs a cast including Jessica Hecht, Andrew Garman and Ben Edelman.\n\n212-239-6200, lct.org\n\n\u2018DIDO OF IDAHO\u2019 at Ensemble Studio Theater (previews start on March 14; opens on March 22). E.S.T.\u2019s Youngblood, one of the city\u2019s balmiest incubators of new talent, produces Abby Rosebrock\u2019s new play. When Aeneas deserted Dido, it didn\u2019t go especially well for Carthage, so what will happen if musicologist Nora convinces her lover to leave his wife? Mikhaela Mahony directs.\n\nwww.ensemblestudiotheatre.org\n\n\u2018ESCAPE TO MARGARITAVILLE\u2019 at the Marquis Theater (in previews; opens on March 15). That frozen concoction that helps us hang on comes to Broadway. The Jimmy Buffett jukebox musical, with the book by Greg Garcia (\u201cMy Name Is Earl\u201d) and Mike O\u2019Malley (\u201cShameless\u201d), interweaves porch-rock classics with a story of a woman\u2019s vacation romance with the resort\u2019s showman. Director Christopher Ashley salts the rim.\n\n877-250-2929, escapetomargaritavillemusical.com", "title": "10 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Igor Stravinsky commented that he \u201cwas struck by the way in which the extraordinary qualities of this pianism had directed the thought of Debussy the composer.\u201d Debussy\u2019s discovery of new sounds at the piano is directly related to the physiology of hands on keyboard. It is impossible to conceive of most of Debussy\u2019s piano music being written at a desk, or outdoors, despite his frequent use of \u201cen plein air\u201d titles.\n\nA Pianist\u2019s Favorite Debussy Recordings\n\nNo, this is music made as molded by playing, as dough is folded with yeast to create bread. As the fingers reach the keys, sound and touch seem to fuse into one. The keyboard has ceased to be a mere function for hammers to strike strings, and has become a precious horizontal artifact to caress. This is music of the piano as much as for the piano. The poet L\u00e9on-Paul Fargue, having watched Debussy play, wrote that he \u201cwould start by brushing the keys, prodding the odd one here and there, making a pass over them and then he would sink into velvet.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe gave the impression of delivering the piano of its song,\u201d Fargue added, \u201clike a mother of her child.\u201d\n\nDebussy\u2019s piano music is perfectly conceived for the instrument. But it isn\u2019t just that it fits beautifully under the hand or sounds wonderful as the vibrations leave the soundboard and enter the ear. To play the opening of \u201cReflets dans l\u2019Eau\u201d (from \u201cImages,\u201d Book One) feels as if the composer has transplanted his fingerprints onto the pads of your digits. The way the chords are placed on the keys (flat-fingered on the black notes) is not so much a vision of reflections, whether trees, clouds or water lilies. It is as if each three-padded triad is an actual laying of a flower onto the water\u2019s surface.\n\nLater in the piece, as the waters become more agitated, the cascading arpeggios are like liquid running through the fingers, all shimmer and sparkle. In \u201cPoissons d\u2019Or\u201d (from \u201cImages,\u201d Book Two), the opening motive, a darting duplet of double thirds, is like trying to catch a fish\u2019s flip as it slips out of the finger\u2019s grasp. And in the central section, the slinky tune slithers with grace notes as the hand has to slide off the key as if off the scales of a freshly caught trout. In the first piece of this set, \u201cCloches \u00e0 Travers les Feuilles,\u201d the fingers are required to tap the keys (pedal held down, fingers pulled up) as if mallets against a bell.\n\nNo other composer feels to me more improvised, more free-flowing. But then the player is conscious of a contradiction as the score is studied more closely: Music that sounds created in the moment is loaded with instructions on how to achieve this. The first measure of \u201cCloches \u00e0 Travers les Feuilles\u201d is marked pianissimo and contains just eight notes, each of which carries a staccato dot. But the first is also coupled with a strong-accented whole note; the fifth has an additional dash; all the notes are covered with a slur; and, if that were not enough, Debussy instructs the pianist to play \u201cdoucement sonore\u201d (\u201csweetly resonant\u201d).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis suite \u201cChildren\u2019s Corner\u201d may be like so many toys in his daughter\u2019s nursery, but the workmanship behind every join and seam is of the highest fastidiousness. All of his pieces sound spontaneous, but every stitch (every dot, dash, hairpin or slur) is specific. This is not mood music, pretty sounds assembled at a dilettante\u2019s whim. Behind the bells and the water and all the poetic imagery is an abstract musical mind of the utmost intellectual rigor \u2014 an architect of genius, despite the small scale of the buildings.\n\nIf most of his piano music has a feel of improvisation about it, the two books of \u201cPr\u00e9ludes\u201d celebrate this in a special way. Until well into the 20th century, a pianist would rarely begin to play a piece cold. A few chords, an arpeggio or two, served as a warm-up as well as allowing the audience to settle down. This was known as \u201cpreluding,\u201d and Liszt spoke of it as a technique to be learned by any aspiring pianist. Debussy\u2019s \u201cPr\u00e9ludes\u201d are perfectly crafted jewels, conveying more in their few minutes\u2019 duration than many an opera, yet they can also seem as intangible as mist \u2014 with titles, tacked on with ellipses at the end of each piece, like mere trails of perfume in the air.\n\nPhoto\n\nDebussy began piano lessons at the age of 7 in Cannes as an evacuee from Paris at the start of the Franco-Prussian War, and he died during the final year of World War I, unable to have a public funeral because of the aerial bombing of the French capital. The circumstances of his life, framed by his country\u2019s enmity with Germany, seem an apt symbol for his music\u2019s rejection of a kind of German aesthetic.\n\nHis instinct to steer clear of classical structures; his elevation and celebration of small, ephemeral forms; and his delight in the atmosphere of beautiful chords for their own sake, with no desire to find a specific function for them, was an audacious challenge to some more self-consciously serious German intellectual fashions of the time. Indeed, the \u201cGolliwog\u2019s Cakewalk\u201d (from \u201cChildren\u2019s Corner\u201d) is a direct hit, with its cheerful celebration of popular culture and the cheeky quote from Wagner\u2019s \u201cTristan und Isolde,\u201d followed by the minstrel\u2019s scoffing sniggers.\n\nWhen assessing a composer\u2019s place in history, there\u2019s always the question as to whether he or she leans backward or forward. But despite the opinion of Elliott Carter that Debussy \u201csettled the technical direction of contemporary music,\u201d and despite the impossibility of the existence of the piano music of modernists such as Messiaen or Ligeti without him, I think the secret to playing Debussy\u2019s music lies in its Chopinist roots \u2014 he edited the Polish composer\u2019s works for Durand \u2014 and in his ties to his older, old-fashioned compatriots Massenet, Delibes and others.\n\nHe may have stretched harmony and form into new shapes, but it seems to me that it is in a Parisian cafe, a Gauloise in hand and coffee at his side, that we glimpse something essential about the spirit of Debussy. For all his sophistication, he could never resist the lilt and leer of a corny cabaret song \u2014 not just overtly, like in \u201cLa Plus que Lente\u201d (1910), but tucked away inside more experimental pieces such as \u201cLes Collines d\u2019Anacapri,\u201d \u201cReflets dans l\u2019Eau,\u201d and \u201cPoissons d\u2019Or.\u201d He never left behind completely the romantic sentimentality of early piano pieces like \u201cClair de Lune\u201d and the \u201cDeux Arabesques.\u201d\n\nAlthough his taste for popular styles found expression in ragtime takeoffs such as \u201cMinstrels\u201d and the \u201cGolliwog\u2019s Cakewalk,\u201d it was his more serious music that later had an immense influence on jazz composers like Gershwin, Bill Evans, Keith Jarrett and Fred Hersch. And not just because of a shared sense of improvisation: The repeated patterns, the piling up of sonorities and the way Debussy would crack open a chord, finding creativity in the very color of its vibrations, found its way into their very DNA.\n\nAnd if the ghost of this Parisian ended up haunting every American jazz bar, it also found its way east, too. Debussy may have discovered his own pianistic voice after hearing the gamelan, but by the end of the 20th century the inspiration had reversed direction and his impact on Asian piano music is incalculable. Toro Takemitsu, American Minimalists and New Age Muzak \u2014 they all owe Debussy virtual royalties. The first \u201cmodern\u201d composer, a hundred years after his death, vibrates afresh in every corner of the globe.", "title": "100 Years After Debussy\u2019s Death, He Remains the First \u2018Modern\u2019 Composer", "authors": ["Stephen Hough"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, as various licenses expire, streaming services lose movies and TV series from their catalogs. Here are 11 great movies and TV shows leaving Netflix in April.\n\nTom Hanks in \u201cApollo 13.\u201d Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Apollo 13\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nApril 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThere\u2019s no greater testament to the skill and craft of this 1995 smash from Ron Howard than the fact that he manages to build (and sustain, for two-plus hours) tension and suspense around an event with a widely known outcome. That event is the Apollo 13 lunar mission in 1970, intended to be the third manned landing on the moon but aborted after a mechanical failure that put the lives of its three astronauts in jeopardy. Tom Hanks, Kevin Bacon and Bill Paxton project credible professionalism in those roles, finding the proper, fleeting moments to let their understandable fear and frustration blast through; an Oscar-nominated Ed Harris is brilliant as the flight director on the ground, marshaling the minds tasked with bringing their boys home.\n\n\u2014\n\nMichael Keaton, left, and Jack Nicholson in \u201cBatman.\u201d Warner Bros., via Everett Collection\n\n\u2018Batman\u2019 / \u2018Batman Returns\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nOnce upon a time, a big-budget, big-screen adaptation of a popular comic book was actually a big deal. But the attraction to Tim Burton\u2019s 1989 \u201cBatman\u201d wasn\u2019t just its subject, but its style: The Gothically-inclined Burton (\u201cBatman\u201d was released between \u201cBeetlejuice\u201d and \u201cEdward Scissorhands\u201d) followed the lead of the graphic novels by Frank Miller, eschewing the fizzy, cartoon-pop sensibility of the \u201960s television series (and its film spinoff) and crafting a decidedly darker take on the Dark Knight, casting Michael Keaton against type in the title role opposite a riveting (and scenery-chewing) Jack Nicholson as the Joker. It was so successful, Burton was given more even freedom on its 1992 follow-up, which takes Gotham into grimmer territory thanks to Danny DeVito\u2019s freakish take on the Penguin and Michelle Pfeiffer\u2019s sizzling turn as Catwoman.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cCaddyshack.\u201d Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018Caddyshack\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the most quotable comedies of the modern era (\u201cCinderella story,\u201d \u201cBe the ball,\u201d \u201cSo I got that goin\u2019 for me, which is nice\u201d), this 1980 favorite from director Harold Ramis (\u201cGroundhog Day\u201d) often feels like channel surfing between several movies at once: a W.C. Fields-style personality comedy starring Rodney Dangerfield; a wiseguy, post-\u2018Saturday Night Live\u2019 vehicle for Chevy Chase; a slapstick farce starring Bill Murray; and an earnest coming-of-age comedy-drama featuring Michael O\u2019Keefe. But the inconsistency and incongruity somehow mesh, due in part to the picture\u2019s spirit of cheerful, slobs-vs.-snobs anarchy, resulting in something akin to a coked-up Marx Brothers movie.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cCool Runnings.\u201d Buena Vista Pictures\n\n\u2018Cool Runnings\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the highlights of the 1988 Winter Olympics (from a storytelling perspective, if not a sporting one) was the debut of the Jamaican national bobsled team, which quickly became a fan favorite for their clear discomfort with an event not exactly common to their tropical home. But it soon became a feel-good underdog story of teamwork in the face of adversity \u2014 in other words, ideal fodder for a big-screen dramatization by Disney. And what could have been a one-joke physical comedy play instead became a warmhearted \u201990s classic, thanks to the energetic direction by Jon Turteltaub (\u201cNational Treasure\u201d) and the charismatic turns by Doug E. Doug, Leon, Malik Yoba, and Rawle D. Lewis as the team members, and (in one of his final performances) the great John Candy as their coach.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nJohn Mulaney on \u201cJohn Mulaney: New in Town.\u201d Comedy Central\n\n\u2018John Mulaney: New in Town\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 2012 special from John Mulaney, the former \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d writer and stand-up comic extraordinaire, which originally aired on Comedy Central, was only his second such showcase, but he already showed an old-timer\u2019s mastery of the form. His deceptively simple persona, of a meek but good-hearted soul doing his very best to navigate a complicated world, proves durable and reliable as he explores dating, doctor\u2019s visits and basic social interactions. The show\u2019s funniest (if somewhat specialized) bit, however, may be his lengthy rumination on the pleasures of \u201cLaw & Order: Special Victims Unit\u201d and its resident skeptic, Ice-T.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlex Bailey/Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\n\u2018Never Let Me Go\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nKazuo Ishiguro\u2019s 2005 dystopian romance novel gets the big-screen treatment in this 2010 drama from director Mark Romanek (\u201cOne Hour Photo\u201d). Keira Knightley, Carey Mulligan and Andrew Garfield star as three students and occasional romantic partners who discover, in their teens, that all of them are clones \u2014 born and raised for the eventual harvesting of their organs. Screenwriter Alex Garland displays the thoughtful, chamber-music approach to science fiction of his subsequent \u201cEx Machina\u201d and \u201cAnnihilation\u201d (both of which he directed). Romanek, meanwhile, pulls off the neat trick of creating a cold, sterile world that is nonetheless infected by warmth and humanity \u2014 attributable in no small part to the skillful work of his crackerjack cast.\n\n\u2014\n\nMorgan Freeman in \u201cThe Shawshank Redemption.\u201d Columbia Pictures, via Everett Collection\n\n\u2018The Shawshank Redemption\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRemoving this 1994 prison drama from Netflix probably won\u2019t dent its ubiquity \u2014 it\u2019s a regular topper of IMDb\u2019s Top 250 list and it seems to pop up on TNT or TBS on a near-weekly basis. But it still smarts not to have this cinematic comfort food a mouse-click away, as it features the quintessential Morgan Freeman performance (wise, calm, and narrating for clarity) and some of Tim Robbins\u2019 most complicated work (as a man who says little and reveals even less). Frank Darabont\u2019s patient filmmaking, in which a series of seemingly casual vignettes crescendo into an emotionally overwhelming climax, makes this a particularly re-watchable film, in which little throwaways and asides take on extra meaning upon second (and third, and tenth) viewings.\n\n\u2014\n\nDavid Bowie in \u201cThe Prestige.\u201d Touchstone Pictures\n\n\u2018The Prestige\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 21\n\nApril 21 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBetween his first and second cracks at Batman, director Christopher Nolan slid in this twisty, stylish exercise in sleight-of-hand moviemaking, as if to assure the fans of his breakthrough movie \u201cMemento\u201d that he was still up to his old tricks. This time around, the term \u201ctricks\u201d is literal: In \u201cThe Prestige,\u201d Nolan tells the story of two stage magicians in 1890s London, whose friendly rivalry first becomes fraught, then deadly. Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale scheme and connive appropriately in the leading roles; a standout supporting cast includes Michael Caine, Scarlett Johansson, Rebecca Hall and David Bowie.\n\n\u2014\n\nBanksy in a scene from \u201cExit Through the Gift Shop.\u201d Paranoid Pictures\n\n\u2018Exit Through the Gift Shop\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 22\n\nApril 22 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe enigmatic and eccentric street artist Banksy directs this Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, in which he profiles the rise of Thierry Guetta, known by the street-art name \u201cMister Brainwash.\u201d Frisky and funny, it casts a cynical insider\u2019s eye on the art world, as well as on Banksy\u2019s place inside it \u2014 particularly in retrospect because of rumors that Guetta was, in fact, a creation of Banksy\u2019s and that the entire story is a made-up prank. The director (who never reveals his face in the film) has denied the rumors, but they lend an extra dimension to this film, in which everything (and perhaps everyone) could be a bluff.\n\n\u2014\n\nMark Ruffalo and Keira Knightley in \u201cBegin Again.\u201d Andrew Schwartz/Weinstein Company\n\n\u2018Begin Again\u2019\n\nLeaving Netflix: April 27\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Irish writer and director John Carney revisited his microbudget, Oscar-winning indie sensation \u201cOnce\u201d with a well-financed, star-cast exploration of the same themes: the magnificence of pop music, the semi-romantic charge of collaboration and the power of a song to say what can\u2019t be put into words alone. Keira Knightley is charming (and believable) as a songwriter who finds an unexpected champion in a burned-out record executive (Mark Ruffalo). The musical numbers are stirring, and the dramatic beats land, but its best scene is its simplest: its two protagonists, wandering through New York City with their headphones, playing each other their favorite songs. Sweet but not saccharine, it is full of tiny moments of truth.\n\n\u2014", "title": "11 Great Titles Expiring From Netflix in April", "authors": ["Jason Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018The Great Buddha +\u2019\n\nUsing a moody, noirish monochrome palette (punctuated with garish swatches of color video) and mordant, monotone voice-over narration (interrupted by stretches of deadpan dialogue), Huang Hsin-yao composes a dark satire of corruption and class resentment in Taiwan. Two friends, Pickle and Belly Button, spend their nights in compulsive voyeurism, watching and listening to dashcam recordings of Pickle\u2019s boss, a big shot named Kevin, as he drives around in his Mercedes looking for (and sometimes having) sex with a series of women. Pickle and Belly Button are envious, aroused and appalled by the amorality of the rich, and the viewer is at once dismayed by the cruelty of this society and seduced by Mr. Huang\u2019s smooth and witty style. (A.O.S.)\n\n\u2018The Guilty\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe most commercial movie playing in the festival\u2019s first week, this tight, showy thriller gives it a much welcome blast of genre filmmaking. Seated in an arid Danish call center and flanked by colleagues he barely speaks with, a cop named Asger (Jakob Cedergren) is having what is clearly another bad day among many. He\u2019s tethered to a phone in a harshly lit room, fielding calls from a citizenry he scarcely tolerates. His bad attitude rapidly shifts when he takes a call from a frantic woman, who says she\u2019s been kidnapped, setting off a classic race-against-the-clock rescue. The director Gustav M\u00f6ller doesn\u2019t dig deep, but he skims the surface with entertaining wit and finesse. (M.D.)\n\n\u2018Hale County This Morning, This Evening\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe closing-night film of the festival poses a quietly radical challenge to assumptions about race, class and the aesthetics of filmmaking. The director, RaMell Ross (also credited as writer, producer, editor, cinematographer and sound recorder), chronicles several years in the lives of two young African-American men and their families. Mr. Ross focuses on work, school, parenthood and other ordinary experiences, but his method is the opposite of prosaic. He glimpses arresting, at times almost hallucinatory beauty in the rural Alabama landscape, and finds nuances of emotion that grow in intensity over 75 heady minutes. The movie is framed by a bluntly political question \u2014 as the film\u2019s website puts it, \u201cHow does one express the reality of individuals whose public image, lives and humanity originate in exploitation?\u201d \u2014 that yields pure cinematic poetry. (A.O.S.)\n\n\u2018The Nothing Factory\u2019 and \u2018Djon \u00c1frica\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nIn recent years, Portugal has emerged as a laboratory for cinematic experimentation, yielding fascinating and ambitious hybrids of documentary and fiction that tackle the country\u2019s colonial legacy, its cultural traditions, the state of its working class and much more. \u201cThe Nothing Factory,\u201d an astonishing film by Pedro Pinho, extends this tradition. It\u2019s an almost clinical study of working conditions and labor discontent, set at an elevator factory whose employees are in conflict with management. It\u2019s also a musical. Mr. Pinho, shooting in 16-millimeter film, fuses nostalgia with a militant sense of novelty.\n\nJo\u00e3o Miller Guerra and Filipa Reis\u2019s \u201cDjon \u00c1frica,\u201d which was written by Mr. Pinho, achieves a different kind of fusion. A road movie (involving a quest for a lost father) that passes through the thickets of Portugal\u2019s imperialist past and present-day Cape Verde, it mixes longing with exuberance, and finds an anarchic sense of possibility in a world of pain and injustice. (A.O.S.)\n\n\u2018Our House\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe conceit suggests a horror movie. A house in a small town on Japan\u2019s coast has two sets of occupants \u2014 a single mother and her adolescent daughter; a single woman and a stranger afflicted with amnesia \u2014 who are unaware of each other\u2019s existence. Are they ghosts? Inhabitants of different dimensions? It\u2019s never made clear, and while the film, the feature debut of Yui Kiyohara, is haunting, it\u2019s more disquieting than terrifying. Its texture is delicately emotional and boldly, eccentrically philosophical. How do we recognize the reality of other people? How can we be sure that we ourselves are real? (A.O.S.)\n\n\u2018Scary Mother\u2019\n\nLess scary than driven and dyspeptically funny, the title character of this mordant comedy is on a mission. It takes a while to figure out what that is, though clues are scribbled in pen across Manana\u2019s arm and etched into her feverish face. She\u2019s writing a novel, a labor of (perhaps) love that her editor, a humble stationery store owner, believes is a masterpiece. Whether both writer and editor are fantasists or not, the novel has become their shared passion and her life\u2019s blood. It sustains Manana even as her loving if unsupportive husband and children conspire against her literary ambitions (especially after they discover her subject). With her terrific star, Nato Murvanidze, the Georgian director Ana Urushadze opens up one woman\u2019s life with dark laughter, great feeling and truth. (M.D.)", "title": "11 Movies You Need to Know at New Directors/New Films", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "A.O. Scott"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Last December, LVMH announced that Phoebe Philo would be stepping down from her role as creative director of C\u00e9line after nearly a decade at the helm; the pre-fall 2018 collection she showed in Paris was her last for the house. (A fall/winter 2018 collection designed by the in-house atelier will be presented to press and buyers in March.) Arriving in 2008, Philo took a previously staid brand and remade it in her own image, infusing it with sensuality, modernity and more than just a hint of eccentricity.\n\nPhilo lead a quiet revolution. Her subtly subversive wardrobe staples \u2014 tuxedo jackets, luxuriant knits, wide-legged trousers, all cut just so \u2014 became a de facto uniform not only for fashion and art world insiders, but also for writers, filmmakers, architects. The pieces came with high price tags, but it only took an encounter with a single garment to appreciate Philo\u2019s ability to empower her wearer. More than the silhouette or color of any particular design, it was her personal attention that turned customers into acolytes: she was sensitively attuned to the ways in which women live their lives.\n\nIn January, Hedi Slimane, was announced as Philo\u2019s successor \u2014 becoming C\u00e9line\u2019s first-ever artistic, creative and image director, with plans to introduce men\u2019s wear, couture and fragrance into the mix. Slimane is poised to inject C\u00e9line with his own electric, youthful energy and his debut offering for the brand, which he will show in September, is already the most eagerly anticipated show of the spring/summer 19 season. The tectonic plates of fashion are shifting again \u2014 but the mark Philo has left is undeniable. Here, some of her most loyal fans and collaborators reflect on Philo\u2019s C\u00e9line legacy.\n\nSofia Coppola, filmmaker", "title": "11 Women on Phoebe Philo\u2019s C\u00e9line Era", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Nakesha Williams resisted help from social workers, friends and acquaintances, some who only knew her as a homeless woman, and others who knew of her past. Over more than a year, our reporter delved into Nakesha\u2019s life, trying to understand the events and forces that put her and so many of the city\u2019s homeless on the street.
