Read on!\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI know it\u2019s $100 million\u201d for Disney, she says. \u201cThey\u2019ll be fine.\u201d She made the movie she wanted, about a multiracial world and the loss of a beloved parent. Travel", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": ["Kaly Soto"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Why go to Cuba and dive into the cross hairs of both diplomatic and acoustic uncertainty? Because this is why we travel, our writer says: \u201cNo one can predict what will happen to Cuba in the coming years, which is why you must rush there now. As in, right now.\u201d Travel\n\n___", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the weekend! It\u2019s a holiday, so maybe you\u2019ve got friends and family crowding the house. If you need a mental getaway, here\u2019s some great journalism to feast on. The articles in this list are not political, for the most part, so feel free to discuss with frenemies and in-laws.", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "A visit by our 52 Places Traveler to the Puerto Rican capital, still recovering from last year\u2019s hurricanes, was one of the most calming and soul-filling experiences of her trip so far. \u201cThe beauty I saw was in the rebuilding, in the lives being lived with joy and grace in the most trying of circumstances,\u201d she wrote. Travel\n\n___", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "There are still a few days left in Women\u2019s History Month, and coming out of the Book Review\u2019s recent theme issue we recommend a number of titles this week exploring the place of women in the culture at large. Women in science: \u201cA Lab of One\u2019s Own,\u201d by Patricia Fara. Women in business: \u201cThat\u2019s What She Said,\u201d by Joanne Lipman. Women in television: both \u201cJust the Funny Parts,\u201d by the comedy writer Nell Scovell, and \u201cStealing the Show,\u201d by the TV reporter Joy Press, who has just signed on as a Vanity Fair correspondent. (Yes, her book discusses \u201cRoseanne,\u201d and much else besides.) There\u2019s also a novel and a story collection, a book of essays about being black and female in white male society, and a graphic novelist\u2019s celebration of rebellious women in history. Changing course \u2014 you\u2019ll get the bad joke in a second \u2014 we also recommend a new translation of the Bhagavad Gita, a deeply reported profile of a Chinese immigrant to New York City and a biography of Tiger Woods. I warned you \u201cchanging course\u201d was bad.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nTIGER WOODS, by Jeff Benedict and Armen Keteyian. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) There have been many books about Tiger Woods, but this new biography by Benedict and Keteyian \u2014 which arrives just as the golfer is rounding into form again on the course \u2014 draws on previous sources and new interviews with more than 250 people to bring grainy new detail to almost every aspect of Woods\u2019s life. \u201cIt\u2019s a confident and substantial book that\u2019s nearly as sleek as a Christopher Nolan movie. It makes a sweet sound, like a well-struck golf ball,\u201d our critic Dwight Garner writes. \u201cI found it exhilarating, depressing, tawdry and moving in almost equal measure. It\u2019s a big American story that rolls across barbered lawns and then leaves you stranded in some all-night Sam\u2019s Club of the soul.\u201d\n\nGODSONG: A Verse Translation of the Bhagavad Gita, With Commentary, by Amit Majmudar. (Knopf, $25.) \u201cGodsong\u201d is the poet Amit Majmudar\u2019s translation of the Bhagavad Gita, the enigmatic religious text composed between 400 B.C. and A.D. 200. Majmudar, who is a radiologist as well as a writer, embarked on a crash course in Sanskrit to write it. \u201cEach word became its own research project, the radiologist turned translator peering past the surface of language in search of the inner workings of the text,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. \u201cThe translation is ravishing and faithful, marked by what Nabokov once called \u2018the precision of a poet and the imagination of a scientist.\u2019\u201d\n\nPATRIOT NUMBER ONE: American Dreams in Chinatown, by Lauren Hilgers. (Crown, $27.) Hilgers, a New York-based journalist who lived in Shanghai for six years, has written a rich and absorbing profile of a Chinese activist and immigrant named Zhuang Liehong. In addition to being a character study of Zhuang, our critic Jennifer Szalai writes, the book also serves as \u201can indelible portrait of his wife and their marriage; a canny depiction of Flushing, Queens; a lucid anatomy of Chinese politics and America\u2019s immigration system. Such a comprehensive project could have easily sprawled across a book twice as long, but \u2018Patriot Number One\u2019 stays close to the people it follows, in a narrative as evocative and engrossing as a novel.\u201d", "title": "12 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "AARON BURNETT AND THE BIG MACHINE at Roulette (March 14, 8 p.m.). There\u2019s something oddly potent about Mr. Burnett\u2019s tenor saxophone sound, a tightly channeled and searing thing that cuts a trench in your mind without giving you a whole lot of graspable melodic information. Is he completely in control of this strange sonic language, or is the instrument having its way with him? Mr. Burnett will present \u201cNew Spectrums in Electronic Acoustics,\u201d a suite in which he will augment his saxophone with a range of electronic effects and processors. The work is meant as an interrogation into the relationship between ubiquitous technology, financial capital and human experience. His band, Big Machine, includes Carlos Homs on piano, Nick Jozwiak on bass and Kush Abadey on drums.\n\n917-267-0368, roulette.org\n\nKURT ELLING at Birdland (March 14-17, 8:30 and 11 p.m.). With his earnest and elastic baritone, Mr. Elling is among the most highly regarded jazz crooners of the past quarter century. He\u2019s about to release \u201cThe Questions,\u201d a literary-minded album that collects songs from across the American canon. At various moments in the recording, Mr. Elling grafts the poetry of Rumi or Sara Teasdale onto modern jazz melodies by the likes of Carla Bley and Jaco Pastorius. He celebrates the album\u2019s release with a four-night run featuring Marquis Hill on trumpet, Stu Mindeman on piano and Hammond B3, John McLean on guitar, Clark Sommers on bass and Jeff (Tain) Watts on drums.\n\n212-581-3080, birdlandjazz.com\n\nLEDISI PRESENTS \u2018NINA AND ME\u2019 at the Apollo Theater (March 9, 8 p.m.). On her latest album, \u201cLet Love Rule,\u201d the vocalist Ledisi refuses to sit still. She moves from snakily grooving songs of uplift to romantic entreaties to reggae-tinged protest anthems. Altogether, the album seems to suggest a liberated neo-soul concept, constantly reimagining what a groove can feel like and how a voice can be woven into an ensemble sound. In the depth of her convictions and the proud intimacy of her reveal, Ledisi has some things in common with Nina Simone. At this concert, she will perform classics from Simone\u2019s repertoire, as well as her own tunes. Her strong backing band includes the esteemed pianist and vocalist Patrice Rushen.\n\n212-531-5305, apollotheater.org\n\nARTURO O\u2019FARRILL QUINTET at Minton\u2019s Playhouse (March 15, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). The pianist Mr. O\u2019Farrill is an irrepressible synthesizer and a conceptual long-distance runner. With his Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra, he presents original works that tangle up Cuban folklore with modernism and experimental jazz. With smaller ensembles, his commanding pianism \u2014 equal parts Thelonious Monk, Chucho Vald\u00e9s and Bill Evans \u2014 bursts to the fore. This concert is part of the Minton\u2019s Jazz Legends Series, celebrating the 80th anniversary of the landmark club\u2019s founding.\n\n212-243-2222, mintonsharlem.com\n\n\u2018UPTOWN NIGHTS: MOTHERS OF THE MOVEMENTS\u2019 at Harlem Stage (March 9, 7:30 p.m.). When his career was first taking flight, Marc Cary spent roughly a dozen years as the pianist in Abbey Lincoln\u2019s band, internalizing the musical philosophy, poetics and loose rhythmic phrasing of that venerated vocalist and composer. Now almost 50, Mr. Cary has recently been embracing his own role as a mentor to some of New York\u2019s brightest young improvisers. Here, he presents a reimagining of \u201cWe Insist! The Freedom Now Suite,\u201d which Ms. Lincoln recorded in 1960 with the drummer Max Roach. Mr. Cary\u2019s excellent band includes the drummer Terri Lyne Carrington and the bassist Reggie Workman. The concert is part of a series presented by Harlem Stage and the National Black Theater.\n\n212-281-9240, harlemstage.org\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "13 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "FRED HERSCH, DREW GRESS AND BILLY HART at the Village Vanguard (March 6-11, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). These three expert musicians all boast a lightness of touch and a keen sense of suspenseful development. Mr. Hersch, a pianist, has played separately with the bassist Mr. Gress and the drummer Mr. Hart, but they haven\u2019t performed as a trio in more than a decade. This week provides a chance to hear three elder musicians whose creative drive remains undiminished, exploring a fresh scenario.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nMIMI JONES at Lehman College (March 3, 7:30 p.m.). Ms. Jones vests her bass with hearty power; she often sings as well, adding a spirit of gentle reassurance. She\u2019s an ambitious composer, too, writing music that mingles jazz with funk, rock and American folk influences. Here she presents \u201cThe Black Madonna,\u201d a new series of compositions inspired by images of an African Mary. Her band includes Leonor Falcon on viola, Nir Felder on guitar and Darrian Douglas on drums.\n\n718-601-7399, bronxartsensemble.org\n\nCHARLES MCPHERSON at Dizzy\u2019s Club Coca-Cola (through March 4, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). In the 1960s, after the alto saxophonist Eric Dolphy departed from Charles Mingus\u2019s band, Mr. McPherson stepped in. He stayed with Mingus through the mid-1970s, and his ardent, chirruping attack \u2014 heavily influenced by Charlie Parker and Sonny Stitt \u2014 became a defining component of the ensemble. In the years since, Mr. McPherson has hardly strayed from the path of bebop conservationism. He will perform in a stalwart quintet with the guitarist Yotam Silberstein, the pianist Jeb Patton, the bassist Todd Coolman and the drummer Jonathan Blake.\n\n212-258-9595, jazz.org/dizzys\n\nBOBBY PREVITE at Roulette (March 2, 8 p.m.). Mr. Previte, a drummer, composed \u201cRhapsody\u201d \u2014 a long-form suite, designed for an unorthodox instrumentation \u2014 with migration and intermingling in mind. The work, which bears the subtitle \u201cTerminals Part II: In Transit,\u201d unfolds with dizzying intensity and convulsing complexity, often employing abstraction to evoke the dislocation of travel. Mr. Previte just released the music on CD, MP3 and vinyl, and he performs it here with four of the five musicians who appear on the album. It\u2019s a stalwart crew: the vocalist and multi-instrumentalist Jen Shyu, the guitarist Nels Cline, the pianist John Medeski and the harpist Zeena Parkins.\n\n917-267-0368, roulette.org\n\nMIGUEL ZEN\u00d3N at Hunter College (March 3, 8 p.m.). Mr. Zen\u00f3n, an acclaimed alto saxophonist and a MacArthur fellow, presents \u201cEn Pie de Lucha,\u201d a new work dedicated to the struggle for self-determination in his homeland of Puerto Rico. He will play the lush, marching, almost bellicose piece in a concert benefiting victims of Hurricane Maria. Mr. Zen\u00f3n will be joined by a 23-piece iteration of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Festival Jazz Ensemble, led by the conductor Fred Harris; the orchestra was planning to perform the work during a tour of Puerto Rico in January but had to postpone because of damage wrought by the storm.\n\n212-772-5020, music.hunter.cuny.edu\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO\n\nTimes Talks\n\nBEN HARPER AND CHARLIE MUSSELWHITE at the Times Center (March 5, 7 p.m.). See a performance and conversation with these two award-winning artists, who have teamed up on \u201cNo Mercy in This Land,\u201d which comes out on March 30. Their last collaboration, \u201cGet Up!,\u201d won a Grammy for best blues album in 2014. All of their New York City shows are sold out, so don\u2019t miss this unique opportunity.\n\ntimestalks.com", "title": "13 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "BILL FRISELL at the Village Vanguard (through March 25, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). On Friday, the guitarist, an eminence on New York\u2019s greater improvised music scene, releases \u201cMusic Is,\u201d his first solo album in almost 20 years. Mr. Frisell has exerted his influence gently, funneling inspiration from 1960s folk rock and 1970s free jazz into a sound that\u2019s hearthlike and imperturbable, whether spinning through reverb-drenched runs or caressing its way through a slow, major-chord progression. This weekend he\u2019s at the Village Vanguard with his trio, featuring the bassist Thomas Morgan and the drummer Rudy Royston. He takes a break on Monday, then returns for six more nights with the violist Eyvind Kang joining the group.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nHAROLD MABERN QUARTET at Smoke (March 16-18; 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). With a crisp, harmonically rich attack, Mr. Mabern carries the mantle of a piano tradition that runs through Ahmad Jamal and Phineas Newborn Jr. From time to time, Mr. Mabern holds court for a weekend at Smoke, presenting his grooving, varnished brand of hard bop with a small group. This weekend is of particular note, as it is Mr. Mabern\u2019s 82nd birthday celebration. He performs here with Eric Alexander on tenor saxophone, John Webber on bass and Louis Hayes on drums.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nOMAR SOSA AND SECKOU KEITA at Roulette (March 22, 8 p.m.). The argument that a piano is a glorified percussion instrument \u2014 a big box of strings, to be struck by hammers \u2014 finds ample support in \u201cTransparent Water,\u201d the engulfing new album by Mr. Sosa, a Cuban pianist, and Mr. Keita, a kora player from Senegal. The kora, too, is a stringed instrument with a largely percussive charter. On the album, Mr. Sosa ornaments the space around Mr. Keita\u2019s playing with lilting undercurrents and deftly studded terrain. At Roulette, they will perform with the Venezuelan percussionist Gustavo Ovalles, a longtime collaborator of Mr. Sosa\u2019s who appears as a guest on the album.\n\n917-267-0368, roulette.org\n\n\u2018(UN)SILENT FILM NIGHT: IMPROV EDITION\u2019 at the New School\u2019s John L. Tishman Auditorium (March 16, 7 p.m.). The New School has been presenting \u201c(Un)Silent Film Night\u201d shows for the past few years, but never before has the event focused on improvising musicians. This evening\u2019s program includes three combos led by pre-eminent jazz improvisers, all accompanying short films. The guitarist Marc Ribot\u2019s band will play an original score to the 2005 short \u201cShadows Choose Their Horrors\u201d; the pianist Kris Davis\u2019s combo will accompany Charlie Chaplin\u2019s \u201cThe Pawnshop\u201d; and a group led by the bassist Reggie Workman and the drummer Andrew Cyrille will score a pair of Superman shorts from 1941.\n\nevents.newschool.edu\n\n\u2018WEST SIDE STORY: REIMAGINED\u2019 at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture (March 17, 7:30 p.m.). Bobby Sanabria is a leading Cuban percussionist and historian of the Afro-Cuban folkloric tradition, as well as others from across Latin America. Here he leads his 21-piece Multiverse Big Band in a creative homage to Leonard Bernstein\u2019s \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d teasing out the various strands of musical information that Bernstein used \u2014 from Dominican merengue, Brazilian samba and Cuban mambo \u2014 and offering extrapolations of his own.\n\nhostos.cuny.edu/culturearts\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "13 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nThe Olympics are over. The Super Bowl was played. Oscar season is drawing to a close. Folks, it\u2019s TV time. The major networks and the cable outlets have been holding back a lot of their bigger midseason offerings the last few months, staying clear of everything else that was going on. Suddenly we\u2019re facing one of the most crowded March television schedules in memory: HBO, FX, ABC, NBC and other major outlets will be delivering a mix of old favorites and new \u2014 each competing in its own way with Netflix\u2019s rising tide of originals.\n\nFrom new citizens of \u201cShondaland\u201d to the return of \u201cThe Americans,\u201d these are just some of the potential highlights of a busy, busy month:\n\nFX Networks\n\n\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarted: March 1, on FX.\n\nMarch 1, on FX. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis award-winning dramedy from Donald Glover returns with a second season promising a more focused kind of storytelling than that of its often dreamlike debut. As Paper Boi (Brian Tyree Henry) deals with the unexpected fallout from regional hip-hop success and Darius (Lakeith Stanfield) disappears deeper into druggie weirdness, Glover\u2019s moody protagonist, Earn, reckons with whether finally making enough money to support his child can satisfy his restless soul. Given the remarkable ways in which the first season explored the complexities of African-American life, it will be fascinating to see what the career progress of these three friends \u2014 or the lack thereof \u2014 has to offer as a comment on the real world.\n\n\u2014\n\nOscars\n\n\u201890th Annual Academy Awards\u2019\n\nAirs: March 4, on ABC.\n\nIt will be tough for this year\u2019s Oscars to spring a moment as memorable as announcing the wrong movie for best picture last year, although given that this is a year with few obvious front-runners for the big prize, who knows what\u2019s in store? Once again, Jimmy Kimmel will host, and he will have a lot of topical material to work with, from the actions of the Trump administration to the #MeToo moment. Many of the nominated movies are already on streaming services, and we matched each best picture nominee with several films that inform them, either directly or indirectly.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarts: March 8, on Netflix.\n\nMarch 8, on Netflix. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWidely regarded as the best of Netflix\u2019s Marvel productions, \u201cJessica Jones\u201d was on the sidelines while its heroine was on loan to \u201cThe Defenders.\u201d The new season of this gritty superhero detective series promises to reveal more about Jessica\u2019s powers and her past. As always, the main selling point will be Krysten Ritter\u2019s performance as a woman whose gruff exterior and compulsive indulgence in sex and booze is covering some deep, deep pain. Unlike some of the other shows in this franchise, \u201cJessica Jones\u201d earns its heaviness.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nABC Television Network\n\n\u2018For the People\u2019\n\nStarts: March 13, on ABC.\n\n\u2018Station 19\u2019\n\nStarts: March 22, on ABC.\n\nBefore the writer-producer Shonda Rimes begins her new deal with Netflix, she has two more series to add to ABC\u2019s \u201cShondaland\u201d family of TV dramas. \u201cFor the People\u201d (created by Paul William Davies) is a character-driven legal procedural, tracking ambitious young lawyers competing with each other in a busy New York federal court. \u201cStation 19\u201d (created by Stacy McKee) is a \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d spinoff, set in Seattle, following the men and women working in a firehouse. Rhimes and her colleagues should bring the usual Shondaland strengths: Fast-paced dialogue, accelerated storytelling, up-to-date political savvy and characters whom audiences love to watch screw up.\n\n\u2014\n\nRise\n\n\u2018Rise\u2019\n\nStarts: March 13, on NBC.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cGlee\u201d meets \u201cThis Is Us\u201d in this fictionalized adaptation of the Michael Sokolove nonfiction book \u201cDrama High,\u201d which follows an innovative high school drama program. Josh Radnor (\u201cHow I Met Your Mother\u201d) returns to TV, playing a teacher who gets a diverse class of students in a working-class Pennsylvania town to rally around the arts. Jason Katims, the showrunner for \u201cFriday Night Lights,\u201d created and executive produced \u201cRise,\u201d whose executive producers also include the Broadway producer Jeffrey Seller.\n\n\u2014\n\n\n\nSYFY\n\n\u2018Krypton\u2019\n\nStarts: March 21, on Syfy.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nEver wondered what life was like for Superman on his home planet? Scratch that: Ever wonder what life was like for Superman\u2019s grandpa? Long in development, \u201cKrypton\u201d joins \u201cGotham\u201d as a DC Comics-derived origin story that goes way, way back, beyond the beginning. Set 200 years before Krypton exploded and baby Superman was sent to Earth, this show, created by writer David S. Goyer (\u201cMan of Steel,\u201d \u201cThe Dark Knight Rises\u201d) is ostensibly a wholly original sci-fi epic, merely related to one of pop culture\u2019s most famous characters. The setting and costumes looks fantastic, and it islikely that, as Goyer explores the politics of this other world, he\u2019ll have something pertinent to say about our own.\n\n\u2014\n\nHBO\n\n\u2018Barry\u2019\n\nStarts: March 25, on HBO.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBill Hader plays a burned-out gun-for-hire in this dark comedy, which follows the titular Barry from the wastelands of the American Midwest to Los Angeles, where the hit man discovers an unexpected passion for theater. Hader has an unusual comic sensibility, informed equally by broad humor and by a love of the arty. His new show promises to pair stinging showbiz satire with a genuine exploration of a melancholy soul. The fact that \u201cBarry\u201d was created in part by a \u201cSilicon Valley\u201d producer, Alec Berg \u2014 and features supporting performances by Henry Winkler and Stephen Root \u2014 secures its status as a must-see.\n\n\u2014\n\nBBC\n\n\u2018Call the Midwife\u2019 Season 7\n\nStarts: March 25, on PBS.\n\nMarch 25, on PBS. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis beloved BBC drama returns for its 7th season, having gradually worked its way from 1957 to the mid-1960s, with its nurse-midwives handling the early rumblings of the \u201cswinging London\u201d sexual revolution. In this new season, the heroines will continue to witness the highs and lows of changing times \u2014 from modest gains in feminist liberation to simmering racism \u2014 through the lens of their patients\u2019 medical complaints.\n\n\u2014\n\nFX Networks\n\n\u2018Trust\u2019\n\nStarts: March 25, on FX.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFor those who didn\u2019t get enough of the John Paul Getty III kidnapping in \u201cAll the Money in the World,\u201d this new FX anthology series begins its first season with the same strange, sad tale. In this version, Donald Sutherland plays the mega-rich J. Paul Getty, who responds to the abduction of his grandson with skepticism and stinginess, creating a rift within his family. Hilary Swank and Brendan Fraser are also in the cast, although what\u2019s most attractive for cinephiles is the creative team that includes director Danny Boyle and screenwriter Simon Beaufoy, who previously collaborated on \u201cSlumdog Millionaire,\u201d \u201c127 Hours\u201d and \u201cBattle of the Sexes.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\namc\n\n\u2018The Terror\u2019\n\nStarts: March 26, on AMC.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBased on the best-selling Dan Simmons novel about an Arctic naval expedition gone awry, this offbeat horror series will combine realistic detail about wilderness survival with a story that features a supernatural evil that stalks stranded sailors. Given that \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d is starting to stumble in the ratings, AMC could use another breakout genre hit. \u201cThe Terror\u201d has an appropriately arresting name, although its premise suggests that it deals with a different kind of \u201cbrainy\u201d than the channel\u2019s zombie drama.\n\n\u2014\n\nABC Television Network\n\n\u2018Roseanne\u2019\n\nStarts: March 27, on ABC.\n\nMarch 27, on ABC. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the more unlikely \u201990s TV revivals of the current wave, the new \u201cRoseanne\u201d brings back the major characters from the earlier series (yes, even the dead ones) for more sardonically funny stories about life in Middle America\u2019s lower-middle class. The creator and star Roseanne Barr has already raised a few eyebrows with her insistence that the take-no-guff \u201cdomestic goddess\u201d she played 20 years ago would be a Trump supporter now. She has also said that political commentary won\u2019t be much of a factor in this revisit to a sitcom classic, although as with the original, the close-knit but combative Conner family will be willing to talk about anything \u2014 no matter how uncomfortable the subject.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nFX Networks\n\n\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6\n\nStarts: March 28, on FX.\n\nMarch 28, on FX. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of this decade\u2019s best dramas comes to an end, with a final 10 episodes that should reveal the fate of Philip and Elizabeth Jennings, the Soviet spies who have been working (sometimes reluctantly) to sabotage the Reagan-era American agenda. When last we saw these stealthy K.G.B. agents, they had called off plans to move their two teenage kids to the motherland, having realized that one of their spy targets could provide them new access to the highest levels of the C.I.A. Believing their mission might prevent nuclear war, our antiheroes stand ready to risk everything, including their bonds with friends and family. As for the show itself, it reaches the finish line at a time when its six-season study of the never-ending Cold War between the United States and Russia feels newly relevant.\n\n\u2014\n\n\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cOnce Upon a Time\u201d (ABC, March 2), \u201cThe Good Fight\u201d (CBS All Access, March 4), \u201cHap and Leonard: The Two-Bear Mambo\u201d (Sundance, March 7), \u201cHard Sun\u201d (Hulu, March 7), \u201cLife Sentence\u201d (the CW, March 7), \u201cChampions\u201d (NBC, March 8), \u201cLove\u201d (Netflix, March 9), \u201cSneaky Pete\u201d (Amazon, March 9), \u201cAmerican Idol\u201d (ABC, March 11), \u201cDeception\u201d (ABC, March 11), \u201cTimeless\u201d (NBC, March 11), \u201cMary Kills People\u201d (Lifetime, March 12), \u201cOn My Block\u201d (Netflix, March 16), \u201cWild Wild Country\u201d (Netflix, March 16), \u201cInstinct\u201d (CBS, March 18), \u201cAlexa & Katie\u201d (Netflix, March 23), \u201cThe Mechanism\u201d (Netflix, March 23), \u201cBillions\u201d (Showtime, March 25), \u201cSilicon Valley\u201d (HBO, March 25), \u201cThe Zen Diaries of Garry Shandling\u201d (HBO, March 26), \u201cSplitting Up Together\u201d (ABC, March 27), \u201cAlex, Inc.\u201d (ABC, March 28), \u201cEmpire\u201d (Fox, March 28), \u201cSuits\u201d (USA, March 28), \u201cRapture\u201d (Netflix, March 30) and \u201cA Series of Unfortunate Events\u201d (Netflix, March 30).\n\n\u2014", "title": "13 Shows We\u2019ll Be Talking About in March", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Citizens of roughly 40 countries to which the United States ordinarily grants visa-free travel will not be affected by the requirement. Those countries include major allies like Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and South Korea.\n\nIn addition, visitors traveling on diplomatic and official visas will mostly be exempted.\n\nAs news of the plan emerged on Friday, so did criticism.\n\n\u201cThis attempt to collect a massive amount of information on the social media activity of millions of visa applicants is yet another ineffective and deeply problematic Trump administration plan,\u201d said Hina Shamsi, director of the American Civil Liberties Union\u2019s National Security Project. \u201cIt will infringe on the rights of immigrants and U.S. citizens by chilling freedom of speech and association, particularly because people will now have to wonder if what they say online will be misconstrued or misunderstood by a government official.\u201d\n\nAnil Kalhan, an associate professor of law at Drexel University who works on immigration and international human rights, wrote on Twitter, \u201cThis is unnecessarily intrusive and beyond ridiculous.\u201d\n\nFacebook said its position had not changed since last year, when it said: \u201cWe oppose any efforts to force travelers at the border to turn over their private account information, including passwords.\u201d\n\nAlong with the social media information, visa applicants will be asked for past passport numbers, phone numbers and email addresses; for records of international travel; whether they have been deported or removed, or violated immigration law, in the past; and whether relatives have been involved in terrorist activities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cMaintaining robust screening standards for visa applicants is a dynamic practice that must adapt to emerging threats,\u201d the State Department said in a statement. \u201cWe already request limited contact information, travel history, family member information, and previous addresses from all visa applicants. Collecting this additional information from visa applicants will strengthen our process for vetting these applicants and confirming their identity.\u201d\n\nMillions of people each year complete the online application for a nonimmigrant visa, known as the DS-160. It takes about 90 minutes to fill out, according to the department.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe San Bernardino, Calif., terrorist attack in 2015, which killed 14 people, focused attention on immigrants\u2019 social-media use, after officials acknowledged that they had missed signs of online radicalization in an online-messaging platform used by the husband and wife who carried out the attack.\n\nLast year, John F. Kelly, who was then the secretary of homeland security and is now Mr. Trump\u2019s chief of staff, told members of Congress that his department was considering asking visitors for passwords and access to online accounts.\n\n\u201cWe want to get on their social media, with passwords,\u201d Mr. Kelly told members of the House Homeland Security Committee. \u201cIf they don\u2019t want to cooperate, then you don\u2019t come in.\u201d\n\nSo far, the government has stopped short of demanding passwords, though travelers have reported being asked for them, on a sporadic basis, at airports and other ports of entry. By some measures, the number of international visitors to the United States has begun to slip, although foreign tourism to New York City set a record last year.\n\nThe new State Department requirements will not take effect immediately. The proposal set off a 60-day period for public comment, which ends on May 29.\n\nOn Sina Weibo, one of China\u2019s largest social media platforms, several users were critical of the plan.\n\n\u201cDoes it mean someone\u2019s visa application will likely be rejected if he/she has been critical of the U.S.?\u201d one wrote. \u201cWhat about your sacred \u2018freedom of speech?\u2019\u201d\n\nAnother user wrote: \u201cWe Chinese have learned well enough the lessons to be drawn from isolation. Now it\u2019s America\u2019s turn.\u201d", "title": "14 Million Visitors to U.S. Face Social Media Screening", "authors": ["Sewell Chan"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "RAVI COLTRANE at Jazz Standard (March 27-April 1, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Coltrane\u2019s music finds a tottery balance in the space between free-form improvisation and pulsing, onrushing flow. He hasn\u2019t released an album in six years, but he has been busy; most recently he\u2019s put a lot of effort toward furthering the legacy of his mother, the jazz pianist and harpist Alice Coltrane. He appears at Jazz Standard in a trio featuring the bassist Dezron Douglas and the drummer Allan Mednard, as well as a rotation of special guests. On Wednesday, it\u2019s the saxophonist Tomoki Sanders, the son of Pharoah Sanders, an esteemed musician who collaborated in the 1960s and \u201970s with Ms. Coltrane. On March 30, it\u2019ll be the harpist Brandee Younger; and on April 1, the trumpeter Ralph Alessi.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nANDREW CYRILLE QUARTET at the Village Vanguard (March 27-April 1, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). An experimental drummer who can easily balance propulsion and sensitivity, Mr. Cyrille began his career in the 1960s, when he apprenticed with Philly Joe Jones and recorded with the big-band-era eminence Coleman Hawkins. Then he embarked on a 10-year stint with Cecil Taylor, a pioneer of free jazz, establishing himself as a protagonist on the avant-garde. Now 78, Mr. Cyrille has never lost his omnivorous musical appetite; his work ranges from free improvisations to smoldering small-group jazz to a collaboration with Haitian musicians. He performs here with the personnel from his entrancing 2016 release, \u201cThe Declaration of Musical Independence\u201d: Bill Frisell on guitar, Richard Teitelbaum on synthesizers and piano, and Ben Street on bass.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nORRIN EVANS at Mezzrow (March 28, 8 and 9:30 p.m.). It\u2019s been a big year for this Philadelphia-based pianist: He made his leadership debut at the Newport Jazz Festival in August, playing a riveting solo set, and he officially joined the Bad Plus, a renowned power trio, in February. But catch him in a small combo, and he can renew your faith in the vitality of classic, straight-ahead jazz. He works in an argot of amiable swing, punctuated by startling disruptions and occasional shots of seraphic beauty. Mr. Evans celebrates his 43rd birthday at this intimate show in a stalwart quartet with the trumpeter Sean Jones, the bassist Luques Curtis and the drummer Gene Jackson.\n\n646-476-4346, mezzrow.com\n\nBOBBY MCFERRIN SPIRITYOUALL at the Blue Note (March 23-April 1, 8 and 10:30 p.m.). Since the 1980s, audiences have known Mr. McFerrin as a virtuoso vocalist who can deliver entire captivating sets without any accompaniment. But when he\u2019s with his Spirityouall band, Mr. McFerrin discovers untold possibilities in the rootsy, molten arrangements of Gil Goldstein, the ensemble\u2019s pianist and musical director. Spirityouall has a smartly tailored aesthetic, but Mr. McFerrin complicates and provokes it \u2014 sounding shots of vocal percussion, modulating the flow, coaxing kinetics out of languor. Here Mr. Goldstein helms a five-piece band, and Mr. McFerrin is joined on vocals by his daughter, Madison, a notable talent in her own right.\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nTHE SWING COLLECTIVE at Jazz at Lincoln Center (March 23-24, 7 and 9:30 p.m.). The Swing Collective features five young improvisers of growing renown, all hailing from different countries of origin. Out front are Melissa Aldana \u2014 a Chilean-born tenor saxophonist of precise, fine-bore articulation, boasting a vast palette of influences \u2014 and the Trinidadian trumpeter Etienne Charles, who makes a kind of nouveau Afro-Caribbean soul jazz. The formidable rhythm section features the Cuban pianist Elio Villafranca, the Japanese bassist Yasushi Nakamura and the Florida-born drummer Ulysses Owens.\n\n212-721-6500, jazz.org\n\nTHERESA WONG at the Stone (March 27-31, 8:30 p.m.). A singing cellist and an experimentalist of patient, farsighted demeanor, Ms. Wong leaves all options on the table: Most of the time, she plays the instrument in slow swipes and resonant plucks, resisting pattern or repetition. In residence at the Stone, Ms. Wong appears in a duo with the pianist Motoko Honda on Tuesday, alone on Wednesday and in a variety of small-group formations through March 31.\n\nthestonenyc.com\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "LAURA STEVENSON at Sunnyvale (March 31, 8:30 p.m.). Ms. Stevenson hasn\u2019t released an album since \u201cCocksure,\u201d in 2015, but that LP had enough high-wattage power-pop hooks to last \u2014 see \u201cTorch Song\u201d and \u201cJellyfish,\u201d both of which sound as electric as ever three years later. Hear what she has gotten up to since then at this Brooklyn show. With support from Zula and Fern Mayo.\n\n877-987-6487, sunnyvalebk.com\n\nSWEARIN\u2019 at Market Hotel (April 5, 9 p.m.). Alison Crutchfield\u2019s solo career has flourished since the breakup of her pop-punk-tinged group Swearin\u2019 in 2015 \u2014 she released a very good solo LP a little over a year ago \u2014 but fans were delighted all the same when Ms. Crutchfield and her former bandmates announced a reunion in November. Before supporting their indie-rock forebears Superchunk at two New York shows next week, Swearin\u2019 will play a one-off headlining set at this Brooklyn D.I.Y. venue.\n\n877-987-6487, twitter.com/markethotelnyc\n\nTOKIMONSTA at Brooklyn Steel (March 31, 9 p.m.). Jennifer Lee, the well-respected electronic and hip-hop producer who records as Tokimonsta, overcame remarkable odds to make her third album, \u201cLune Rouge\u201d: Its creation followed multiple brain surgeries that threatened her ability to hear and understand music. Dramatic back story aside, it\u2019s a strong set of elegant, danceable psychedelia.\n\n888-929-7849, bowerypresents.com/brooklyn-steel\n\nSIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nJazz\n\nSTEPHAN CRUMP, INGRID LAUBROCK AND CORY SMYTHE at the Jazz Gallery (March 30, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Laubrock has a strong, unflinching tone on the tenor saxophone, but she uses it to outline and define space, not fill it. On the album \u201cPlanktonic Finales,\u201d released last year, she joined Mr. Crump, a bassist whose playing is more embodied and abundant, and Mr. Smythe, a pianist of cogent articulation who comes at improvisation from the perspective of a contemporary classical musician.\n\n646-494-3625, jazzgallery.nyc\n\nTIA FULLER at Smoke (March 30-April 1; 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). Scalding and propulsive, Ms. Fuller always seems to be testing the limits of her own power \u2014 as if seeing if she can single-handedly overload your ear\u2019s switchboard. It\u2019s not every alto saxophonist\u2019s way, but with Ms. Fuller\u2019s blend of impeccable straight-ahead-jazz chops and gospelly inflections, it\u2019s engrossing. Later this spring, she will release \u201cDiamond Cut,\u201d her first album in six years. She plays this weekend with the pianist Shamie Royston, the bassist Mimi Jones and the drummer Tyson Jackson.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nMARY HALVORSON at Jazz Standard (April 3-4, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Halvorson\u2019s fraying, sparkplug style makes her as singular a guitarist as they come. As a bandleader and composer, she\u2019s always changing shape. Her latest project is one to seek out: Code Girl, a quintet in which the vocalist Amirtha Kidambi sings lyrics written by Ms. Halvorson. The band is about to release a fine debut album \u2014 a mix of indie-rock testimonial, noisy convulsion and warped group improvising \u2014 and will celebrate the disc with this two-night run, featuring Ms. Kidambi on vocals, Adam O\u2019Farrill on trumpet (filling in for Ambrose Akinmusire, the group\u2019s regular horn player), Michael Formanek on bass and Tomas Fujiwara on drums.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRENEE ROSNES at the Village Vanguard (April 3-8, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). \u201cBeloved of the Sky,\u201d Ms. Rosnes\u2019s new album, features a handful of originals inspired by the Canadian painter Emily Carr. As a pianist, Ms. Rosnes is known for her breezy swing and limpid touch. The tunes tend to run hot and bright, often recalling the crossed, multidirectional energy of mid-1960s postbop. At the Village Vanguard, she\u2019s joined by most of the personnel from the album: the bassist Peter Washington, the drummer Lenny White and, for all but the last night, the vibraphonist Steve Nelson. From April 6 to 8, the young tenor saxophonist Melissa Aldana climbs aboard, too.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nCAMILLE THURMAN at the Greenwich House Music School (April 5, 8 p.m.). Ms. Thurman doubles as a vocalist and a reeds player, and then she doubles again: She\u2019s proficient on both tenor saxophone and flute. And these aren\u2019t party tricks; her soloing style on the saxophone is swift and purposeful, often moving in dashes and broad harmonic sweeps. As a vocalist, she scats with unshakable aplomb. Ms. Thurman\u2019s repertoire balances jazz standards with a thick book of swinging, blues-driven originals. She will perform \u201cBecause of Them, We Are,\u201d a collection of new compositions inspired by her own reckoning with the effects of sexual harassment and gender discrimination. She appears as part of the Greenwich House Music School\u2019s Uncharted concert series. (This year, all eight of Uncharted\u2019s shows feature female headliners \u2014 a fact that, happily, seems hardly worth mentioning.)\n\n212-242-4770, greenwichhouse.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPATTY WATERS at First Unitarian Congregational Society (April 5, 8 p.m.). Few vocalists possess either the stark intimacy or the darkened mystery of Ms. Waters. She inhabits the territory of singers like Sibylle Baier, Jeanne Lee, Nick Drake, Billie Holiday \u2014 and hardly anyone else. A sylph of a singer, Ms. Waters spent a few potent years on jazz\u2019s avant-garde in the 1960s, then vanished. Her 1965 debut, \u201cPatty Waters Sings,\u201d is still her definitive document. It features seven hushed and haunted originals, with little more than a piano backing her and a 14-minute take on \u201cBlack Is the Color of My True Love\u2019s Hair,\u201d the Appalachian folk song that she pulverizes into noxious dust. Now 72, Ms. Waters plays here in her first New York performance since a brief re-emergence in 2003. She is joined by Burton Greene, the pianist from \u201cSings,\u201d as well as the bassist Mario Pavone and the percussionist Barry Altschul.\n\n718-624-5466, blankforms.org\n\nDAN WEISS at Nublu 151 (April 1, 8 p.m.). Next week, the drummer Mr. Weiss will release \u201cStarebaby,\u201d a seething, spacious album that unites doom and thrash metal with jazz. The band from that record \u2014 Craig Taborn and Matt Mitchell, both on keyboards and electronics; Ben Monder on guitar; and Trevor Dunn on bass \u2014 performs here in a special prerelease concert. The show starts with an opening set from Mick Barr and Brandon Seabrook, guitarists who each have their own idiosyncratic ideas about blending metal and jazz. (If you miss this show \u2014 or decide you haven\u2019t had enough \u2014 Mr. Weiss will also kick off a five-night residency at the Stone on Tuesday.)\n\nnublu.net\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018MS. Ante in.\n\n212-727-2737, irishrep.org\n\n\u2018SYMPHONIE FANTASTIQUE\u2019 at Here (in previews; opens on April 4). The performers in Basil Twist\u2019s puppetry fantasia won\u2019t sign autographs, probably because they are wet feathers. Mr. Twist, a master puppeteer, revives this symbolist theater work, in which he dunks various inanimate objects into an enormous aquarium, conjuring wonder and strong emotions from the interplay of light, texture and color. Reviewing the original production nearly 20 years ago, Ben Brantley called it \u201ctrue magic.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, here.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Getting out of the South Bronx and into a great college isn\u2019t just a matter of geography. In Lucy Thurber\u2019s play, directed by Jackson Gay, two young men are vying for a place in spite of present circumstances and past actions. The production stars Juan Castano and Ato Blankson-Wood, a standout in last summer\u2019s \u201cAs You Like It.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, mcctheater.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018BRIGHT COLORS AND BOLD PATTERNS\u2019 at SoHo Playhouse (closes on April 9). Better RSVP quickly for this solo show about a gay man miffed by the directive on a wedding invitation. In the show\u2019s last week, the playwright Drew Droege will once again put on the Hawaiian shirt and pick up the cocktail glass as gossipy Gerry, a role currently played by Jeff Hiller. The Times called Mr. Droege\u2019s rant \u201ca delight \u2014 a slightly exhausting one, but still a delight.\u201d\n\nbrightcolorsandboldpatterns.com\n\n\u2018IS GOD IS\u2019 at Soho Rep (closes on March 31). An Afropunk revenge tragedy meets its bloody end as Aleshea Harris\u2019s show, directed by Taibi Magar, closes. Ben Brantley praised Ms. Harris\u2019s talent for \u201cnewly contextualizing ages-old themes and motifs into a thoroughly contemporary, divided African-American landscape.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, sohorep.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018JERRY SPRINGER \u2014 THE OPERA\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (closes on April 1). The talk show host stages his final musical face-off when this New Group piece ends its run. Ben Brantley called the show, written by Stewart Lee and Richard Thomas and directed by John Rando, \u201ca divinely wrought, all-American reincarnation.\u201d\n\n212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org\n\n\u2018KINGS\u2019 at the Public Theater (closes on April 1). Audiences have a few more chances to be persuaded by Sarah Burgess\u2019s Washington lobbying drama. Aya Cash and Gillian Jacobs star as K Street queens (well, one is a queen; the other is more the handmaiden type), wooing a straight-arrow politician (Eisa Davis). Jesse Green described it as \u201centertaining and informative, if not surprising theatrically.\u201d\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\n\u2018THE LOW ROAD\u2019 at the Public Theater (closes on April 8). There\u2019s only a little time left to invest in a ticket to Bruce Norris\u2019s picaresque about free market capitalism. Ben Brantley wrote that the show, starring Chris Perfetti as a foundling, offers \u201cbustle, buoyancy and unblinking bawdiness,\u201d at least in its first act. The second is mere \u201caudacity for audacity\u2019s sake.\u201d\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org", "title": "15 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "We doglegged east to Numaniyah, then continued to push northwest on Highway 6. That\u2019s where my friend Brian McPhillips of Second Tank Battalion was fatally shot in the head, but I wouldn\u2019t hear the news for another two weeks. Information rarely travels laterally in war. I was a few miles from the ambush that killed him when I learned that my platoon would lead the battalion over the Diyala River and into Baghdad.\n\nThe bridge was partly destroyed. Two-thirds of the way to the far side, a chunk of the span was gone, leaving pieces of exposed rebar and a clear view to the water below. Combat engineers laid a makeshift bridge over the gap. I asked the engineer lieutenant if it would hold a tank\u2019s weight. \u201cI think so,\u201d he said.\n\nAs the platoon commander, I could dictate which tank went over first, but it wasn\u2019t really a choice. It had barely been a week since Charlie Company\u2019s Marines drowned in the Euphrates; I left the hatch of my cupola all the way open, prepared to jump free of the vehicle if it went in the water.\n\nAs we came over the crest of the bridge, a man on the far side of the river fired an AK-47 at us. This was inconvenient. I was trying to guide our driver onto the engineer\u2019s bridge while scanning the landscape for other threats; being shot at felt gratuitous.\n\n\u201cCo-ax, fire,\u201d I said.\n\n\u201cOn the way,\u201d my gunner replied, and ended someone\u2019s life with the tank\u2019s 7.62-millimeter coaxial machine gun.\n\nAs he fired, I caught sight of a Soviet-made T-72 tank dug into a defensive position. I grabbed the override to rotate the turret while giving a hasty fire command to my gunner. The thunderous boom echoed across the battlefield, and I saw the orange spark of steel on steel. Secondary explosions followed as the T-72\u2019s ammunition cooked off. On the radio, I reported the kills and called off the artillery mission, which was well inside the \u201cdanger close\u201d range of 600 meters. I could feel the overpressure from the bursting shells, a concussive force that shook my cheeks.\n\n\u201cHey, sir?\u201d It was my driver. \u201cAre those mines?\u201d\n\nWe had driven across the bridge into a minefield. It ended up being a long day.", "title": "15 Years Ago, I Helped Start a War That Hasn\u2019t Ended", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRescue operations will be hampered by deteriorating weather conditions and we need to ensure the safety of everyone involved before we move the whales,\u201d Mr. Chick said in a statement. \u201cThe conditions are challenging, but we are doing all we can to give these animals the best chance of survival.\u201d\n\nFurther complicating the whales\u2019 odds is that recently rescued whales tend to beach themselves a second time.\n\n\u201cOnce we have moved the whales out we will monitor the situation closely, as it is possible the whales will come back into shore and re-strand,\u201d Mr. Chick said. \u201cThis has often been the case in previous mass strandings.\u201d\n\nShort-finned pilot whales, which can live in pods of 100 or more, are known to periodically beach in what scientists call mass strandings, though why they do so is unknown. Scientists speculate that illness, navigational errors and human interference may be causes.\n\nIn 2009, more than 80 whales and dolphins died on a beach in Hamelin Bay.\n\nThe biggest mass stranding of whales in Western Australia happened in 1996, when 320 long-finned pilot whales beached themselves in Dunsborough, about 40 miles north of Hamelin Bay.", "title": "150 Whales Beached in Australia, as Rescuers Fight to Save Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018THE LUCKY ONES\u2019 at the Connelly Theater (previews start on March 19; opens on March 31). Let\u2019s hope the Bengsons never need to undergo a painful divorce just to generate more material. The husband-and-wife songwriters, who last gave us the courtship show \u201cHundred Days,\u201d now offer a semi-autobiographical story, written with Sarah Gancher, about their teen years. Anne Kauffman directs.\n\n866-811-4111, arsnovanyc.com\n\n\u2018MISS YOU LIKE HELL\u2019 at the Public Theater (previews start on March 20; opens on April 10). Quiara Alegria Hudes, who wrote the book for \u201cIn the Heights,\u201d takes to the road. In this new musical, with a score by Erin McKeown, Beatriz (Daphne Rubin-Vega), an immigrant from Mexico, attempts to reconnect with her daughter Olivia (Gizel Jim\u00e9nez) on a drive from Philadelphia to Los Angeles. Lear deBessonet directs.\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\n\u2018MS. ESTRADA\u2019 at the Flea Theater (previews start on March 22; opens on April 2). There are not too many rap songs about celibacy, but that may change when the Brothers Q (\u201cOthello: The Remix,\u201d \u201cFunk It Up About Nothin\u2019\u201d) premiere their adaptation of Aristophanes\u2019s \u201cLysistrata,\u201d a raunchy pacifist classic. Under Michelle Tattenbaum\u2019s direction, the members of the Bats acting company play the women and men of Acropolis U.\n\n866-811-4111, theflea.org\n\n\u2018THIS FLAT EARTH\u2019 at Playwrights Horizons (previews start on March 16; opens on April 9). A tragedy can make children grow up fast or it can make them wonder if they\u2019re going to grow up at all. In this new play from Lindsey Ferrentino (\u201cUgly Lies the Bone,\u201d \u201cAmy and the Orphans\u201d), two teenagers try to make sense of their lives following a school shooting. Rebecca Taichman directs.\n\n212-279-4200, playwrightshorizons.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018THE AMATEURS\u2019 at the Vineyard (closes on March 29). A postmodern comedy about making art in premodern times of plague, Jordan Harrison\u2019s play gives its final performances. Jesse Green described this piece, about a troupe of itinerant actors crisscrossing Europe, as a \u201cslightly eggheaded and strangely moving medieval backstager.\u201d\n\n212-353-0303, vineyardtheatre.org\n\n\u2018ATHENA\u2019 at Jack (closes on March 24). A fierce and lovely comedy about two teenage fencers, Gracie Gardner\u2019s play lays down its swords. In Emma Miller\u2019s appealing and stealthily moving production, Abby Awe and Julia Greer play girls who train together for the Junior Olympics and for life, too.\n\njackny.org\n\n\u2018AT HOME AT THE ZOO\u2019 at the Signature Theater (closes on March 25). An armchair and a park bench are safer places now that Edward Albee\u2019s twinned one-acts, \u201cHomelife\u201d and \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d are closing. Jesse Green described the production, directed by Lila Neugebauer, as an improvement on the diptych\u2019s 2007 debut: \u201cmuch freer and funnier and thus more powerful.\u201d\n\n212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org\n\n\u2018FARINELLI AND THE KING\u2019 at the Belasco Theater (closes on March 25). Farinelli, the castrato at the center of Claire van Kampen\u2019s baroque drama about the healing powers of music, sings his final solo. Ben Brantley described this candlelit play, starring Mark Rylance as the monarch and Sam Crane and Iestyn Davis as the countertenor, as a \u201cshimmering fairy tale for grown-ups.\u201d\n\n212-239-6200, farinelliandthekingbroadway.com", "title": "16 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018ROCKTOPIA\u2019 at the Broadway Theater (in previews; opens on March 27). A steroidal iPod Shuffle arrives onstage in this celebration of classical and contemporary music, created by Rob Evan and Randall Craig Fleischer. An orchestra, a rock band and a bevy of vocalists fill the Broadway stage, offering an eclectic mix of stadium acts and classical composers such as Mozart, Styx, Heart and Rachmaninoff.\n\n212-239-6200, rocktopia.com\n\n\u2018SUMMER: THE DONNA SUMMER MUSICAL\u2019 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater (previews start on March 28; opens on April 23). Do you feel love? The director Des McAnuff trades Jersey boys for a Massachusetts girl in this musical with a book by him, Robert Cary and Colman Domingo. LaChanze, Ariana DeBose and Storm Lever perform the chanteuse at different moments in her career: Diva Donna, Disco Donna and Duckling Donna.\n\nthedonnasummermusical.com\n\n\u2018SYMPHONIE FANTASTIQUE\u2019 at Here (previews start on March 29; opens on April 4). The performers in Basil Twist\u2019s puppetry fantasia won\u2019t sign autographs, probably because they are wet feathers. Mr. Twist, a master puppeteer, revives this symbolist theater work, in which he dunks various inanimate objects into an enormous aquarium, conjuring wonder and strong emotions from the interplay of light, texture and color. Reviewing the original production 20 years ago, Ben Brantley called it \u201ctrue magic.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, here.org\n\n\u2018THREE TALL WOMEN\u2019 at the John Golden Theater (in previews; opens on March 29). Edward Albee\u2019s statuesque Pulitzer Prize winner returns to the stage. Glenda Jackson, Laurie Metcalf and Alison Pill star as three distinct women who are also the same woman, a character based on Albee\u2019s adopted mother. Joe Mantello directs this elliptical drama about youth, age and how mortality intervenes.\n\n212-239-6200, threetallwomenbroadway.com\n\n\u2018TRAVESTIES\u2019 at the American Airlines Theater (previews start on March 29; opens on April 24). If you stopped into a Zurich cafe for r\u00f6sti in 1917, you might have run into James Joyce. Or Vladmir Lenin. Or Tristan Tzara. In Tom Stoppard\u2019s wildly erudite historical comedy, great men dash in and out of a Wildean romp loosely based on historical coincidence. When Patrick Marber\u2019s production, starring Tom Hollander, ran in London, Matt Wolf praised its \u201cmind-bending splendor.\u201d\n\n212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org\n\n\u2018THE WINTER\u2019S TALE\u2019 at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center (in previews; opens on March 25). Is it too soon for a story about a political leader who wreaks domestic havoc because of his paranoia and megalomania? Well, Shakespeare\u2019s play is four centuries old, and it\u2019s being revived by Theater for a New Audience. Under Arin Arbus\u2019s direction, Anatol Yusef will play the blinkered king with Kelley Curran as his queen.\n\n866-811-4111, tfana.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018YERMA\u2019 at the Park Avenue Armory (previews start on March 23; opens on March 27). Federico Garcia Lorca\u2019s tragedy of a childless woman in rural Spain receives a modern retelling via the Australian writer and director Simon Stone. The luminous Billie Piper plays Her, a successful journalist unstrung by infertility. Reviewing the production in London, Ben Brantley called it a \u201cmerciless and mesmerizing updating.\u201d\n\n212-933-5812, armoryonpark.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018THE AMATEURS\u2019 at the Vineyard (closes on March 29). A postmodern comedy about making art in premodern times of plague, Jordan Harrison\u2019s play gives its final performances. Jesse Green described this piece, about a troupe of itinerant actors crisscrossing Europe, as a \u201cslightly eggheaded and strangely moving medieval backstager.\u201d\n\n212-353-0303, vineyardtheatre.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018ATHENA\u2019 at Jack (closes on March 24). A fierce and lovely comedy about two teenage fencers, Gracie Gardner\u2019s play lays down its swords. In Emma Miller\u2019s appealing and stealthily moving production, Abby Awe and Julia Greer play girls who train together for the Junior Olympics and for life, too.\n\njackny.org\n\n\u2018AT HOME AT THE ZOO\u2019 at the Signature Theater (closes on March 25). An armchair and a park bench are safer places now that Edward Albee\u2019s twinned one-acts, \u201cHomelife\u201d and \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d are closing. Jesse Green described the production, directed by Lila Neugebauer, as an improvement on the diptych\u2019s 2007 debut: \u201cmuch freer and funnier and thus more powerful.\u201d\n\n212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org\n\n\u2018FARINELLI AND THE KING\u2019 at the Belasco Theater (closes on March 25). Farinelli, the castrato at the center of Claire van Kampen\u2019s baroque drama about the healing powers of music, sings his final solo. Ben Brantley described this candlelit play, starring Mark Rylance as the monarch and Sam Crane and Iestyn Davis as the countertenor, as a \u201cshimmering fairy tale for grown-ups.\u201d\n\n212-239-6200, farinelliandthekingbroadway.com\n\n\u2018IS GOD IS\u2019 at Soho Rep (closes on March 31). An Afropunk revenge tragedy meets its bloody end as Aleshea Harris\u2019s show, directed by Taibi Magar, closes. Ben Brantley praised Ms. Harris\u2019s talent for \u201cnewly contextualizing ages-old themes and motifs into a thoroughly contemporary, divided African-American landscape.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, sohorep.org\n\n\u2018JERRY SPRINGER \u2014 THE OPERA\u2019 at the Pershing Square Signature Center (closes on April 1). The talk show host stages his final musical face-off when this New Group piece ends its run. Ben Brantley called the show, written by Stewart Lee and Richard Thomas and directed by John Rando, \u201ca divinely wrought, all-American reincarnation.\u201d\n\n212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org", "title": "17 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018PETER HUJAR: SPEED OF LIFE\u2019 at the Morgan Library and Museum (through May 20). It\u2019s hard to say which is more surprising: that Peter Hujar\u2019s photographs of underground life in New York in the 1970s and \u201980s have found their way to the Morgan Library and Museum, or that the classically minded institution has become unbuttoned enough to exhibit them in this heartbreaker of a show. Hujar (1934-87) lived most of his professional life in the East Village and, through studio portraits and cityscapes, captured a downtown that has since been all but erased by time, gentrification and AIDS. Although he was little known by the mainstream art world in his lifetime, this show, startlingly tender, reveals him to be one of the major American photographers of the late 20th century. (Holland Cotter)\n\n212-685-0008, themorgan.org\n\n\u2018THE JIM HENSON EXHIBITION\u2019 at the Museum of the Moving Image. The rainbow connection has been established in Astoria, Queens, where this museum has opened a new permanent wing devoted to the career of America\u2019s great puppeteer, who was born in Mississippi in 1936 and died, too young, in 1990. Henson began presenting the short TV program \u201cSam and Friends\u201d before he was out of his teens; one of its characters, the soft-faced Kermit, was crafted from his mother\u2019s old coat and would not mature into a frog for more than a decade. The influence of early variety television, with its succession of skits and songs, runs through \u201cSesame Street\u201d and \u201cThe Muppet Show,\u201d though Henson also spent the late 1960s crafting peace-and-love documentaries and prototyping a psychedelic nightclub. Young visitors will delight in seeing Big Bird, Elmo, Miss Piggy and the Swedish chef; adults can dig deep into sketches and story boards and rediscover some old friends. (Farago)\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were declared landmarks, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-from-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance, the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, more than 16 years after Sept. 11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org\n\nREBEL SPIRITS: ROBERT F. KENNEDY AND MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. at New-York Historical Society (through May 20). Delve into the ties that bound these progressive standard-bearers through photographs that document their rise to the national stage in the 1950s and \u201960s and the struggle for the societal changes they championed, and ephemera such as magazines, campaign buttons, protest placards and an R.F.K.-M.L.K. spinning pendant. You can even listen on a transistor radio to the song Dick Holler wrote after their assassinations in 1968, \u201cAbraham, Martin and John.\u201d (Danielle Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ALBERTO SAVINIO\u2019 at the Center for Italian Modern Art (through June 23). The paintings of this Italian polymath have long been overshadowed by the brilliant work of his older brother, Giorgio de Chirico. This show of more than 20 canvases from the late 1920s to the mid-1930s may not change that, but the mix of landscapes with bright patterns and several eerie portraits based on family photographs are surprisingly of the moment. (Smith)\n\n646-370-3596, italianmodernart.org\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought, refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles 4,000 years of Judaica with modern and contemporary art, by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze. The works are shown in a nimble, nonchronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018STEPHEN SHORE\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through May 28). Not staged, not lit, not cropped, not retouched, the color photographs of this American master are feats of dispassionate representation. This must-see retrospective \u2014 curated with real wit by Quentin Bajac, MoMA\u2019s photo chief \u2014 opens with Mr. Shore\u2019s teenage snaps at Andy Warhol\u2019s Factory. Then it turns to the road-trip imagery of \u201cAmerican Surfaces\u201d and the steely precision of \u201cUncommon Places\u201d \u2014 landmarks in photographic history that scandalized an establishment convinced the camera could find beauty solely in black-and-white. Mr. Shore is revealed not only as a peripatetic explorer but also a restless experimenter with new photographic technologies, from stereoscopic slide shows to print-on-demand books. The only flaw is his recent embrace of Instagram, allowing museumgoers to lazily flick through images on MoMA\u2019s smudged iPads. New technologies are great, but not at the expense of concentration. (Farago)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u20182018 TRIENNIAL: SONGS FOR SABOTAGE\u2019 at the New Museum (through May 27). This Bowery museum\u2019s fourth triennial exhibition, \u201cSongs for Sabotage,\u201d is the smallest, tightest edition of the show so far. Immaculately installed, it\u2019s also the best looking. There\u2019s a lot of good work, which is global in scope and not by a list of prevetted up-and-comers. (Zhenya Machneva, Dalton Paula and Daniela Ortiz are artists to look for.) Less admirably, it\u2019s a safe and unchallenging show. In a politically demanding time, it acts as if ambiguity and discretion were automatically virtues. In an era when the market rules, it puts its money on the kind of art \u2014 easily tradable, displayable, palette-tickling objects \u2014 that art fairs suck up. (Cotter)\n\n212-219-1222, newmuseum.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018TANIA BRUGUERA: UNTITLED (HAVANA, 2000)\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through March 11). Nearly 18 years have passed since the artist and activist Tania Bruguera first mounted \u2014 or attempted to mount \u2014 \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000)\u201d at the Seventh Havana Biennial. Critical of the post-revolutionary politics of Cuba, it was shut down by censors within hours. Now \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000)\u201d is recreated here. In groups of four, you enter a dark space where you walk on sugar cane. As your eyes adjust, you see four naked men along the wall and video propaganda images of Fidel Castro. Borrowing aesthetic motifs from earlier art, like medieval and Renaissance painting, Ms. Bruguera\u2019s tableau vivant asks you to \u201cstop looking and start thinking\u201d about politics, history and violence. (Martha Schwendener)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018CAROLEE SCHNEEMANN: KINETIC PAINTING\u2019 at MoMA PS1 (through March 11). Some say that #MeToo has gone too far. What modern misogynist will be yanked from museums next? Gauguin? Picasso? I say, sure, why not? Set them aside, give them a rest and make room for what we never see, which means art by almost any woman you can name. Carolee Schneemann is one I\u2019d move right into the cleared-out spotlight, not just because she has star quality, which she does, or because she has majorly shaped art history, which she has. I\u2019d put her there because, in a career of some 60 years, she\u2019s been one of the most generous artists around \u2014 generous with her presence, her thinking, her formal and political risk taking, and her embrace of embracing itself. You\u2019ll find evidence of all of this in her first comprehensive retrospective. (Cotter)\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org\n\n\u2018THE SCULPTURE OF GONZALO FONSECA\u2019 at the Noguchi Museum (through March 11). The Uruguayan-American sculptor Gonzalo Fonseca (1922-97) pioneered an architecturally inflected, whimsically literary style of relentless ambiguity. Whether covering large pieces of Italian travertine with incised circles and tiny pyramids, fixing a small red sail to a flat chunk of limestone or titling a tabletop-size pillar of dark gray stone \u201cSelf-Portrait,\u201d Fonseca made his work live by putting it almost entirely in the power of the viewer\u2019s imagination. This modest but jampacked mini retrospective \u2014 aptly sited in the museum built by his friend and fellow stone carver Isamu Noguchi \u2014 is worth taking in slowly. (Will Heinrich)\n\n718-204-7708, noguchi.org\n\n\u2018CATHY WILKES\u2019 at MoMA PS1 (through March 11). A tea-ringed saucer, a discolored hatbox, an unfixed sink or a case of vegetable peelers \u2014 from these humble materials, the Irish-born artist conjures wrenchingly moving tableaus of family, loss and memory. Ms. Wilkes is one of the leading lights of the white-hot Glasgow contemporary art scene, and her unprepossessing sculpture, installations and paintings are shown to advantage here. Works are shown without barriers and often sit directly on the floor, emphasizing their fragility and care. (PS1 limits entry to the galleries to a few dozen at a time.) This show is an invitation to slow down, to look closely, to think and to feel at once. (Farago)\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org", "title": "18 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAn officer in the German Army has been arrested at Rouen, on suspicion of being a German spy.\n\nSome time ago he came to stay at an hotel in the rue Jeanne d\u2019Arc and it was noticed that his movements were of a somewhat suspicious nature. An investigation was commenced and the German officer was made to undergo a long interrogatory at the hands of the Juge d\u2019Instruction.\n\nHe is named Keillard, aged twenty-seven, was born at Stuttgart, and is a reserve veterinary in the German Army. Keillard arrived at Rouen about two months ago, and has twice changed his hotel, and in changing his hotel he changed his name. He made frequent rides and took long walks in the neighborhood of the town and was often seen to stop soldiers and talk for a long time to them.\n\nIn spite of his protestations he has been sent to the Bonne Nouvelle prison. He can show no passport nor can he prove his identity. The magistrates think that he is a German spy, and they are of opinion that Keillard, or Keiller, is not his real name.\n\n\u2014 The New York Herald, European Edition, Mar. 20, 1893", "title": "1893: Arrest of a Suspected German Spy", "authors": ["The International Herald Tribune", "International Herald Tribune"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "It may not have reached the ear-biting level, but a wrestling match between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council over the City Charter is heating up. Council members on Friday took a step toward creating a commission that would propose changes to the charter \u2014 hours after the mayor rushed appointments to his own, separate, charter commission.\n\nThe City Council held a hearing on a bill that would authorize a commission to conduct a top-to-bottom review of the charter, New York City\u2019s equivalent of a constitution. The review could potentially take up issues such as whether to increase public participation in land-use decisions, alter the way budget decisions are made and question the checks and balances between the mayor and the Council. The last time such a broad review occurred was in 1989.\n\nThe bill was drafted last year by the public advocate, Letitia James, and the Manhattan borough president, Gale A. Brewer. It envisions a commission whose members would be appointed by a range of elected officials, including the mayor; Corey Johnson, the City Council speaker; Ms. James; Scott M. Stringer, the comptroller; Ms. Brewer and the four other borough presidents.\n\nBut Mr. de Blasio jumped ahead of them in February when he announced in his State of the City address that he planned to create his own commission. In the mayor\u2019s version, he would appoint the panel and it would have a narrow mandate, limited to charter changes aimed at improving the city\u2019s campaign finance system \u2014 including lowering the maximum levels of campaign contributions to candidates \u2014 and encouraging voter participation in elections.", "title": "2 Charter Commissions? Mayor and Council Are Creating Separate Panels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe hit the mother, she hit the little girl and she took the carriage \u2014 the baby that was in the carriage,\u201d said Jessica Sierra, 43, describing how she saw the Volvo go through the intersection of Ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.\n\nMs. Sierra, who had been walking to a bus stop, said the Volvo appeared to accelerate with the impact. She immediately ran to the girl, who was nearest to her, and used a sweatsuit that she kept in her pack to try to stanch the bleeding.\n\n\u201cThere was blood everywhere,\u201d said Ms. Sierra. \u201cAnd I felt like she was cold, so I covered her with it. She looked lifeless.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe police said the Volvo dragged the carriage, with the child in it, halfway down the block, trailing children\u2019s clothing, including a shoe and socks, behind it. The Volvo could be seen on the street afterward with mangled pieces of a stroller wedged under its right rear fender.\n\nOfficials said the 34-year-old mother of the fatally injured girl, whose name was not released, was taken by ambulance to New York Methodist Hospital, where she was in serious condition. Officials did not say whether her unborn child had survived the collision.\n\nJames Long, a Fire Department spokesman, said that both children were declared dead at the scene. Officials said the boy and girl were not believed to be related. A 46-year-old man suffered minor injuries in the incident, Mr. Long said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
