Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe first 911 calls streamed in at about 12:40 p.m., said Mr. Long, reporting the crash just a few blocks west of Prospect Park.\n\nThe intersection, bustling and often chaotic, has been a focus of traffic-safety advocates because of previous incidents. In 2016, a 41-year-old man was fatally struck by a car along Ninth Street. The car that hit him was traveling north on Fifth Avenue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Monday\u2019s incident, the police said the driver, who was not identified, would undergo a sobriety test. She told investigators after the crash that she has a medical impairment.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a possibility it may have been some kind of medical condition involved here,\u201d said Mr. Davis. \u201cShe did not hit and run.\u201d\n\nHe said there was video of the Volvo, either stopped or rolling very slowly on Ninth Street, \u201cinexplicably\u201d beginning to move forward at Fifth Avenue, though the light was still apparently red.\n\n\u201cAll of a sudden, it looks like it just starts to accelerate, striking the people in the other side of the intersection,\u201d said Mr. Davis. \u201cThey\u2019re going to do a mechanical check of the car; they are doing a physical check of her. It\u2019s going to take a while to figure it out.\u201d", "title": "2 Children Killed by Driver in Brooklyn Intersection", "authors": ["Al Baker", "Sean Piccoli"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "That was in stark contrast to Mr. Skripal, a former military intelligence officer in Russia, who arrived in Britain in 2010 as part of a spy swap and lived quietly in an English cathedral town.\n\n\u201cThis guy is not a big critic,\u201d Marina Litvinenko, the widow of the whistle-blower, said of Mr. Skripal, speaking by telephone from an undisclosed location outside London. \u201cEveryone says he kept a low profile.\u201d\n\nAnd while Russia\u2019s likely involvement in the death of Mr. Litvinenko was documented in a long-running British inquiry, the illness that struck Mr. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, remains mysterious.\n\nThe British inquiry concluded two years ago that an operation by the F.S.B. to kill Mr. Litvinenko, 43, by poisoning him with polonium slipped into his tea in an upscale London hotel, \u201cwas probably approved\u201d by President Putin.\n\nYet Britain took relatively modest countermeasures, and the two men accused of the killing, Andrei K. Lugovoi and Dmitri Kovtun, remain at large in Russia despite British demands for their extradition.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf it was poison, it would mean people are still not protected,\u201d Ms. Litvinenko said, referring Mr. Skripal\u2019s case. \u201cIt\u2019s a very bad message for other people. The lessons from my husband\u2019s death have not been properly learned.\u201d\n\nBill Browder, a wealthy American fund manager clamoring for justice on behalf of his lawyer, Sergei L. Magnitsky, who died in a Russian prison in 2009, told the Press Association news agency that \u201cthe first operating assumption\u201d of the Skripal case should be \u201cthat this was an assassination attempt by the Kremlin against a traitor of Russia.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is not improbable. The latest episode fits a broader pattern of mysterious illnesses \u2014 sometimes deaths \u2014 among Russians seen as enemies of the Kremlin who are living in Britain, where the presence of wealthy, high-rolling Russians has given London one of its newer nicknames: Londongrad.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Skripal, 66, was arrested in 2004 for selling Russian secrets to British intelligence officers, possibly including the identities of Russian spies in Europe. Even after he retired from active duty in 1999, according to British news reports, he continued to tease out salable information from former colleagues.\n\nThe chronology suggests that Mr. Skripal was spying against the F.S.B. at precisely the moment that Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. officer on his rise to supreme power, headed the organization. Treachery was not something he tolerated.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure Putin regards him as a traitor,\u201d said Tony Brenton, the British ambassador in Moscow from 2004 to 2008 \u2014 a period of rapidly deteriorating relations that some compared to the Cold War.\n\nBut, Mr. Brenton added in an interview, \u201cthe evidence isn\u2019t there yet\u201d about why Mr. Skripal fell ill. Investigators in the Litvinenko case discovered shortly before he died that polonium had been used, Mr. Brenton said, noting that if Mr. Litvinenko had passed away earlier, \u201cthey would never have found it.\u201d The killers in that case, he added, \u201ccould have gotten away with it.\u201d\n\nMr. Skripal, once a colonel in Russia\u2019s military intelligence service, the G.R.U., was arrested in 2004 and jailed in 2006, accused of selling the Kremlin\u2019s secrets to Britain\u2019s MI6 overseas intelligence service over a 10-year period in return for $100,000 paid into a bank account in Spain. Mr. Litvinenko\u2019s widow said that he, too, had received a stipend from MI6, but only after the family moved to London in 2000.\n\nThe authorities have rarely moved swiftly to follow suggestions that the Kremlin is actively pursuing a policy of reprisals against adversaries beyond its own borders. In 2012, for instance, Alexander Perepilichnyy, a whistle-blower financier, died near his home outside London. An inquiry by his life insurance company found traces of a rare and toxic plant extract \u2014 gelsemium \u2014 in his stomach, but the British police have insisted that there was nothing suspicious.\n\n\u201cBritish law enforcement doesn\u2019t have a lot of credibility when it comes to poisoned Russians in the U.K. after the complete failure of finding out what happened to Perepilichnyy in 2012,\u201d Mr. Browder said on Twitter.\n\nThe public inquiry into Mr. Litvinenko\u2019s death came even as British officials fought strenuously to block a deeper look into the circumstances, including using security legislation to seal some details from public scrutiny.\n\nThe head of the Home Office at the time was Theresa May, who is now the prime minister of country that must find a response after the death of another Russian on British soil.", "title": "2 Ex-Spies Fell Ill in Britain. That\u2019s Where the Stories Diverge.", "authors": ["Alan Cowell"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The author of the screenplay, Colin Higgins, returned to the well in 1974 to pen a stage adaptation that was successful overseas but not on Broadway, where it closed after 21 performances in 1980. (In Paris, the play ran nearly three years.)\n\n\u201cHarold and Maude\u201d has now arrived at the Charing Cross Theater, through May 12, in a sympathetic production from the director Thom Southerland, who is better known for his work in musicals \u2014 among them \u201cRagtime\u201d and \u201cGrey Gardens,\u201d both of which were very fine. But the play, like the film before it, feels like one elongated life lesson, this time minus the Cat Stevens songs.\n\nLike the movie, the play is a decades-straddling romance packed with fortune cookie bromides about not being \u201cafraid to be human.\u201d The 80-year-old Maude insists at one point that the suicidal Harold, who is pushing 20, \u201creach out, take a chance, get hurt maybe.\u201d\n\nAt the time of the film\u2019s release, Maude must have felt like an eccentric equivalent to Mame Dennis of the Broadway musical \u201cMame,\u201d which similarly urged audiences to \u201copen a new window\u201d and embrace life. Harold\u2019s signature funk presumably spoke to the hangover of the post-\u201960s generation, yearning to break free but not knowing how. The play, by contrast, mostly registers as an exercise in whimsy as the dotty but determined heroine rescues the blank-faced, indrawn Harold from himself. (Francis O\u2019Connor\u2019s airy, Magritte-like set keeps the mood light.)\n\nIt\u2019s to the credit of Bill Milner, the current Harold, that his blossoming in Maude\u2019s company is achieved without ever being cloying, and I doubt there has been a better Maude than the English stage veteran Sheila Hancock, who, at 85, is older than the character as written and seems even more spry. (She leaves the cast on March 31, with Linda Marlowe to replace her for the remainder of the run.)\n\nWhereas the diminutive Ruth Gordon in the film is, to my mind anyway, an acquired taste, the tall and willowy Ms. Hancock is naturally expansive as the self-described European countess who speaks five languages and breaks into pet shops to liberate canaries. (\u201cHow the world does like a cage,\u201d Maude says by way of explanation.)\n\nIt could be argued that Ms. Hancock locates more delicacy in this meeting of soul mates than it probably deserves. But a gift for tossing off head-scratchers like \u201che studied Zen Buddhism at the penitentiary\u201d turns out to be very useful indeed. An audience may have no idea moment to moment where Maude is headed next, but Ms. Hancock ensures that we, like Harold, follow her every step of the way.", "title": "2 Films Come to the London Stage, With Losses and Gains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Presenting the exhibition in the Turner Contemporary, which looks directly onto the sea, gave poignancy to the poem\u2019s motifs of \u201cdrowning, voyages and shipwrecks,\u201d Mr. Tooby said.\n\nEight hours away by train, Tate St. Ives is perched on Cornwall\u2019s toe as it kicks into the Atlantic. It is one of a family of galleries that also includes Tate Modern in London, and a local joke has it that the next art gallery to the west is MoMA. Virginia Woolf took vacations with her family at their holiday home, Talland House, in St. Ives until she was 13, and returned to the town in adulthood. \u201cShe came back here a lot: It\u2019s the place where she locates her aspirations to be a writer,\u201d Laura Smith, the curator of \u201cVirginia Woolf: An Exhibition Inspired by Her Writings,\u201d explained.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a great quote from Woolf about not being able to write and feeling trapped: She runs to the station and gets on the train to Cornwall, \u2018without my checkbook or a change of underwear or my cigarettes,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Smith said.", "title": "2 Literary Greats, in Art Galleries by the Sea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe went by Tripp,\u201d said his father, John Zanetis, 73. \u201cEverybody called him Tripp.\u201d\n\nMr. Zanetis said a military chaplain and an Air Force major came to the home of his wife\u2019s mother in Nashville to convey the news.\n\nImage Christopher Tripp Zanetis Credit\n\nThe parents, speaking together by telephone, said their son grew up in central Indiana and graduated from New York University. He was a sophomore there on Sept. 11, 2001, and, \u201cI think that\u2019s what made him become a New York City fireman,\u201d said his mother, Sarah Zanetis, 63, who said he had lived three blocks from the World Trade Center.\n\nAppointed as a firefighter in 2004, he was assigned to Engine Company 28 on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side. In 2013, Firefighter Zanetis was promoted to fire marshal and the following year was recognized for his bravery as part of an investigative unit. Around then, his parents said, he joined the military and then pursued a career in law while on unpaid leave from the Fire Department.\n\nHe graduated from Stanford Law School and recently started as an associate with the firm Debevoise & Plimpton in New York. The firm issued a statement Friday saying it was \u201cdeeply saddened\u201d by the loss of \u201cour colleague Tripp Zanetis.\u201d\n\nMr. Zanetis said his son left for Iraq in the second week in January for his third tour. His father said his son was \u201ca pilot, flies a rescue helicopter, is a cross-fit trainer and he was in excellent health. He was unbelievable. Unbelievable.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe loved everyone and everyone loved him,\u201d Mr. Zanetis said.\n\nIn a statement, Mayor Bill de Blasio said both firefighters would be mourned. \u201cThey are truly two of New York City\u2019s bravest,\u201d he said. \u201cRunning into danger to protect and defend others, both in New York City and in combat overseas.\u201d\n\nThe New York Fire Department has more than 1,400 members who are either military reservists or veterans, and 62 of them are currently on active duty overseas, said James Long, a department spokesman. Firefighter Engeldrum, who died in 2004, was a sergeant in the First Battalion of the 105th Infantry and was the first New York City employee to die serving in Iraq.", "title": "2 New York City Firefighters Killed in Iraq Helicopter Crash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The mood was decidedly hopeful in August, when Daniel Hahn took over the Police Department as the first black police chief. Mr. Hahn defended his department in an interview on Wednesday and said that every officer had undergone training to discourage race-based discrimination, as well as de-escalation training. Though he said he could not discuss the case, he acknowledged: \u201cRace permeates everything we do in our country. To think anything else would be na\u00efve.\u201d\n\nMr. Hahn said he had asked Xavier Becerra, the California attorney general, for help with the case. Mr. Becerra announced on Tuesday that the state\u2019s Justice Department would join the investigation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe case began with a report of property damage. On the evening of March 18, two officers from the Sacramento Police Department were dispatched to investigate a complaint that someone was breaking vehicle windows.\n\nPhoto\n\nA helicopter from the Sacramento County Sheriff\u2019s Department was also hovering over the scene looking for a potential suspect when it identified a man with a crowbar heading toward a nearby house.\n\nA few minutes after responding to the call, with the apparent guidance from the sheriff\u2019s helicopter, the city police officers spotted Mr. Clark, who they said ran from them. They followed him into the backyard and ordered him to show his hands, police video shows. Seconds later, in the dark, one officer shouted, \u201cgun, gun, gun, gun!\u201d and they shot 20 times at Mr. Clark. The officers believed Mr. Clark had a weapon and opened fire \u201cfearing for their lives,\u201d according to a police statement.\n\nThe entire encounter lasted roughly 10 minutes. The officers looked for a gun but all they found was a cellphone.\n\nVideo\n\nMinutes later more officers arrived and the team handcuffed Mr. Clark, who lay mortally wounded.\n\nAs other officers arrived, the two involved in the shooting muted the audio feeds to their body cameras. One of the officers was black and the other was white. They are both on paid leave, Mr. Hahn said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTimothy Davis, president of the Sacramento Police Officers Association, called the event a tragedy and voiced his support for the officers involved. \u201cNo police officer ever wants to have to take a life,\u201d Mr. Davis said. \u201cOur officers are out there serving this community, leaving their family behind to serve this community.\u201d\n\nIt remains unclear if the decision to mute the cameras went against official protocol, but the act alone has prompted intense suspicion. The Clark family\u2019s lawyer, Benjamin Crump, said that the move \u201creeks of impropriety\u201d and that the Police Department was trying to cover something up. Mr. Crump represented the families of Trayvon Martin, who was shot by a neighborhood watch volunteer in 2012, and Michael Brown, killed by the police in Ferguson two years later.\n\nMr. Hahn said that the department could not explain why the officers muted their cameras, but that the officers\u2019s actions were under investigation. The department had been considering banning muting cameras outright before Mr. Clark was shot, he said.\n\n\u201cIn their training they are told a couple different instances when they can mute their body cameras. The bigger ongoing question that we are already looking into and revising our policy is: Are those reasons acceptable?\u201d Mr. Hahn said. \u201cShould we continue to allow people to mute those cameras for those reasons?\u201d\n\nDozens attended the wake for Mr. Clark on Wednesday and hundreds are expected to attend his funeral on Thursday, including activists from outside the city and from the Black Lives Matters movement, including the Rev. Al Sharpton. More vigils and protests are planned in cities across the country in the coming days.\n\nAnger over Mr. Clark\u2019s death has not let up in the days since the shooting. For four hours on Tuesday night hundreds of residents gathered at a Sacramento City Council meeting to complain that Mr. Clark\u2019s death was just the latest in a long list of injustices against the black residents.\n\nLate last year, a young black man was punched by a county police officer repeatedly during a jaywalking stop. Video of the attack attracted widespread attention on social media and the county later settled a lawsuit in response.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Tuesday, speakers cried as they described the poverty and increasing income inequality between wealthy parts of Sacramento and its poorer neighborhoods.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJust beyond the council chamber\u2019s doors, angry protesters took over City Hall\u2019s main lobby and in one instance skirmished with police officers. \u201cYou shoot us down, we shut you down!\u201d they chanted. Later, they blocked entry to another Sacramento Kings game.\n\nMs. Faison said the body-camera video of Mr. Clark\u2019s death, which the police released in the days after the shooting, painted a damning portrait of the police.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s just disgusting, honestly. That video. I don\u2019t even know. I feel like they started shooting before they even looked at him. It looked like they were coming around the corner shooting and he was walking toward them to see what the noise was,\u201d she said. \u201cWhy would you fly a helicopter for someone breaking into cars?\u201d\n\nMayor Darrell Steinberg of Sacramento, who has received the brunt of the criticism and led the council meeting, said in an interview Wednesday that he was sympathetic to the complaints and that people of color in Sacramento have genuine grievances about the police.\n\n\u201cRegardless of the outcome of the investigation, which will be based on the current laws and the current policies and the current training, what happened here, the outcome, was plain wrong,\u201d he said. \u201cA 22-year-old man should not have died in this way.\u201d", "title": "20 Shots in Sacramento: Stephon Clark Killing Reignites a Furor", "authors": ["Jose A. Del Real"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "I called a friend from the playground, and we talked it through and agreed to march. And it felt good to have something to do on that terrible day, a day when it\u2019s normally hard to even get out of bed. We now had a plan. We would be together in Washington, standing on our grown-up feet and remembering Westside while walking for everyone who\u2019s experienced this. And I thought the Warriors would agree; I thought that would be the clear consensus.\n\nThat\u2019s why my breath was taken away by a post to the Facebook group that denounced the march entirely. Some members were upset that the day was being taken from us, but many were even more upset about the agenda of the event. They thought it was purposely planned to drive a political point home, one that they did not agree with.\n\nPeople posted that the organizers were \u201cagainst all guns,\u201d that they chose \u201cour day of remembrance\u201d for their political agenda. People talked about arming teachers, increasing security, running \u201clockdown drills.\u201d\n\nI understand that some people make an argument for preparedness over prevention, but it is an argument that I can\u2019t accept. If my classmates think back to 1998, I imagine they\u2019ll remember our teachers were white as sheets and frozen with fear. I personally had to shove a grown woman aside in order to dial 911 because she was in understandable shock. One teacher was able to pull a student to cover and safety, but that was the most she could do. She couldn\u2019t have fought off our attackers and I don\u2019t think it would have been right to ask her to. No person knows how he or she would react in a time like that, so the idea of arming teachers lends itself to a false sense of security.\n\nBeyond my lack of confidence in the practicality of arming teachers as a solution, the discussion made me incredibly sad. It meant we accept this as our new norm. Westside was the beginning of an epidemic. It was jarring to find a group of survivors \u2014 my former classmates \u2014 as divided as our country. It felt like they were responding with jaded, grown-up brains instead of the honest, childhood hearts we had when we were younger.\n\nI cannot accept that more guns will solve the issue of more shootings. Some of my classmates wrote that they \u201cdon\u2019t want to be lumped into the gun debate,\u201d but you cannot talk about a shooting without talking about guns.\n\nThey send journals to the newest survivors, encouraging them to write their feelings and begin their healing. But this is a generation that has grown up with many platforms to voice their opinions, and they\u2019re not satisfied with hiding their thoughts in a journal tucked away on a shelf. Standing up, speaking out and marching may be part of their therapy. One of the comments to our Facebook thread read: \u201cIt\u2019s just all different than ours was. These people have a serious agenda: to get rid of guns.\u201d That\u2019s true. It is different than ours. These victims are helping themselves by fighting for common-sense gun laws to save the future.\n\nEach March 24 is harder for me than the last because, as an adult, I\u2019m able to better define how horrific the shooting really was. In less than 10 minutes on that playground, my classmates and I gained a deeper understanding of evil and fear than most people experience in their entire lives. I can\u2019t trade the Warriors for a group that agrees with me, but I can march this weekend in Washington to ensure that in 20 years Emma Gonz\u00e1lez won\u2019t be writing to remind you of her story and her friends. She\u2019ll be writing to commemorate the day we stood up and said never again.", "title": "Opinion | 20 Years After the Shooting on the Playground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Original headline: \u201cThe Man Date,\u201d from April 2005\n\nWow, what a different era: Check the date. Yep, this article is indeed from 2005, not 1965. While some remember the aughts as a time when gay acceptance began to go mainstream (\u201cWill & Grace\u201d dominated sitcom ratings; \u201cBrokeback Mountain\u201d won a handful of Oscars), it apparently still had a ways to go. Look no further than this provocative Styles feature, which still had keyboards clacking more than a decade after the fact . The article probed the putatively awkward social dynamic created when two straight male friends hung out together somewhere other than a hockey game. To dine together, or see a movie one-on-one, it seems, required pretzel-like social contortions to avoid any \u201cundercurrent of homoeroticism.\u201d The dilemmas, according to the author Jennifer 8. Lee, were endless. Is it O.K. to split a bottle of wine over dinner? If you go out to a movie, do you need leave a seat open between the two of you? This article was written only 13 years ago. Was it really that different an era?\n\nDefining the terms: You may not find it in Webster\u2019s, but a \u201cman date,\u201d as defined by Ms. Lee, consists of \u201ctwo heterosexual men socializing without the crutch of business or sports. It is two guys meeting for the kind of outing a straight man might reasonably arrange with a woman. Dining together across a table without the aid of a television is a man date; eating at a bar is not. Taking a walk in the park together is a man date; going for a jog is not. Attending the movie \u2018Friday Night Lights\u2019 is a man date, but going to see the Jets play is definitely not.\u201d\n\nAnd the problem was \u2026 \u201cThe concern about being perceived as gay is one of the major complications of socializing one on one,\u201d according to the \u201cmany straight men\u201d whom Ms. Lee interviewed. One University of Virginia graduate student and his lawyer friend, for example, decided to grab dinner at a buzzy Italian restaurant, only to bolt in horror when they were confronted with cello music, amber lights, a wine list and \u2014 yikes! \u2014 another friend who happened to be dining there. \u201cThis is weird,\u201d the lawyer was quoted as saying. \u201cAnd now there is a witness maybe.\u201d Out of discomfort, the duo high-tailed it out to a fried chicken joint for a proper bro-down. Even the most casual of outings involving two straight men sometimes involved a degree of \u201csocial Stratego,\u201d the author asserted, referencing a board game that now seems as antique as the \u201cman date\u201d itself. \u201cSome men avoid dinner altogether unless the friend is coming from out of town or has a specific problem that he wants advice about,\u201d Ms. Lee wrote. \u201cOtherwise, grabbing beers at a bar will do just fine, thank you.\u201d\n\nIt was not always thus: Ms. Lee\u2019s article posited that straight male anxiety over such social engagements was a relatively recent phenomenon. \u201cBefore women were considered men\u2019s equals, some gender historians say, men routinely confided in and sought advice from one another in ways they did not do with women, even their wives,\u201d Ms. Lee wrote. \u201cThen, these scholars say, two things changed during the last century: an increased public awareness of homosexuality created a stigma around male intimacy, and at the same time women began encroaching on traditionally male spheres, causing men to become more defensive about notions of masculinity.\u201d", "title": "2005: When Two Guys Splitting a Bottle of Wine Became a \u2018Man Date\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The close relationship between Ms. Nixon and Mr. de Blasio is particularly notable because Mr. de Blasio and Mr. Cuomo have been locked in a yearslong battle over the Democratic direction of New York. Mr. Cuomo has even suggested the mayor orchestrated Ms. Nixon\u2019s bid; there is no evidence he did so. But if Ms. Nixon were to overcome Mr. Cuomo\u2019s advantages and prevail, it would certainly represent a triumph for Mr. de Blasio, as well.\n\nAs it is, Ms. Nixon is drawing on some of the same supporting cast from 2013: Bill Hyers and Rebecca Katz, two of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s top former strategists, are guiding Ms. Nixon\u2019s current run.\n\nBack in 2013, the front-runner with an air of inevitability was Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker with an inside track to be New York City\u2019s first female and lesbian mayor. But Ms. Nixon, who is also gay, sided with Mr. de Blasio instead.\n\n\u201cMost people assumed Christine Quinn was going to win that race and one of the lessons is the arrogance of being on top sometimes results in a terrible tumble,\u201d said Billy Easton, a friend of Ms. Nixon and the executive director of the Alliance for Quality Education, an advocacy group that seeks more money for schools, for which she served for years as a spokeswoman.\n\nMr. Easton called the 2013 race \u201can important development\u201d in Ms. Nixon\u2019s political progression. \u201cThat experience gave her a pretty high-profile, practical experience with the day-to-day political world in New York,\u201d he said.\n\nThe wounds are apparently still fresh for Ms. Quinn. This week, she called Ms. Nixon an \u201cunqualified lesbian\u201d who didn\u2019t back a \u201cqualified lesbian\u201d for mayor five years ago. Ms. Quinn quickly apologized for the lesbian jab but not the unqualified part.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, at a campaign launch party at the Stonewall Inn, the gay rights landmark, Ms. Nixon mocked Ms. Quinn\u2019s remark.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI just want to say tonight that she was technically right,\u201d Ms. Nixon said. \u201cThat I don\u2019t have my certificate from the Department of Lesbian Affairs. But, in my defense, there is a lot, a lot of paperwork involved.\u201d\n\nMs. Nixon, an award-winning actress (she has a Grammy, two Tonys and two Emmys), has never run a large organization or held elected office before but has been a vocal political activist for more than 15 years.\n\n\u201cCynthia Nixon has been fighting for better public schools, LGBT equality and women\u2019s health since long before Bill de Blasio ran for mayor,\u201d said Ms. Katz, the Nixon adviser who also worked for Mr. de Blasio five years ago. Ms. Katz said the tipping point that inspired Ms. Nixon\u2019s run was Mr. Cuomo\u2019s comments last year about not seeking higher levels of education funding that she said he campaigned on in 2010.\n\nMs. Nixon became friendly with Mr. de Blasio in the early 2000s, when he was a city councilman and she was still shooting \u201cSex and the City.\u201d They both opposed then-Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg\u2019s education programs and found a common cause.\n\nIn the years after, she has trekked to Albany for schools and same-sex marriage, headlined events for Planned Parenthood and President Barack Obama, campaigned for Al Franken and delivered her own speeches at political rallies.\n\nBut it was the 2013 mayor\u2019s race where she truly dove in, canvassing the city with Mr. de Blasio when even his backers would joke that he was battling for fifth in a five-person field. Her wife, Christine Marinoni, an education activist herself, volunteered extensively on the campaign, too.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere are weeks where four or five days in a row, I\u2019m doing something with Cynthia,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said at the time.\n\nShe would gush about him as \u201cNew York City\u2019s Obama.\u201d And her presence would invariably draw cameras.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCynthia Nixon was the life support for de Blasio\u2019s campaign for many, many months,\u201d said Jon Reinish, a Democratic strategist aligned with Ms. Quinn\u2019s campaign.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn May 2013, Ms. Nixon helped organize an L.G.B.T. benefit for Mr. de Blasio, where Ms. Quinn was skewered to the point where her name drew catcalls and skits mocked her support for extending the city\u2019s term-limits laws.\n\n\u201cChristine Quinn was poised to make history as the first gay woman to lead New York,\u201d Mr. Reinish said. \u201cBut along came another gay woman who wasn\u2019t technically in the race but was a full-time surrogate who could land some pretty devastating punches that Bill de Blasio and Bill Thompson just couldn\u2019t as straight men.\u201d (Mr. Thompson was another mayoral candidate in 2013.)\n\nMs. Nixon helped wrangle celebrity endorsers for Mr. de Blasio, among them Alec Baldwin, Sarah Jessica Parker, Alan Cumming, Tony Kushner, and Sarah Paulson. In August, Ms. Nixon helped produce and appeared in an ad for Mr. de Blasio that starred a mosaic of famous New Yorkers including Harry Belafonte, Lee Daniels and the Lady Bunny.\n\nAfter Mr. de Blasio won in November, Ms. Nixon became his representative with the Public Theater and was given a role on the advisory board for the Mayor\u2019s Fund. She continued to speak about public education and universal prekindergarten. Ms. Marinoni joined the de Blasio administration itself at the Department of Education.\n\nBoth have been spotted around City Hall in the years since, and Ms. Nixon\u2019s name is sprinkled through the public calendars of Mr. de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, whom she joined in a skit at an annual media show in 2014.\n\nNow it is Mr. Cuomo that Ms. Nixon is hoping to slay \u2014 a far taller task than even Mr. de Blasio\u2019s victory in a crowded 2013 mayoral field. Early polls had him down 25 percentage points to Ms. Quinn. Ms. Nixon trails by nearly 40 percentage points, according to one survey.\n\nPeople close to Ms. Nixon, who declined an interview request, say she is undaunted by the challenge ahead.\n\nShe certainly came out swinging on her first day on the stump, calling Mr. Cuomo\u2019s budget \u201cinhumane,\u201d linking him to the Koch brothers and questioning whether he is a \u201creal Democrat.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for Ms. Quinn, now an ally of Mr. Cuomo, she is the one who may play the role of spoiler.\n\nMs. Quinn said in an interview she was \u201ccertainly surprised\u201d that Ms. Nixon backed Mr. de Blasio five years ago.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m equally surprised she\u2019s challenging the governor who has the best record on L.G.B.T. issues of any non-L.G.B.T. politician in the country,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cI think it\u2019s about celebrity and thinking that being a celebrity is enough. But running for office and serving in office is not a flight of fancy.\u201d Ms. Quinn vowed to campaign for Mr. Cuomo ardently: \u201cAs they say, \u2018every day and twice on Sunday.\u2019 \u201d\n\nMs. Nixon, for her part, said five years ago that she was \u201cnot anti-Chris Quinn.\u201d\n\n\u201cI worked alongside her in the marriage fight, and I believe she was incredibly eloquent and incredibly effective,\u201d she said then. \u201cBut apart from that particular gay issue, I don\u2019t see a lot of stuff where I line up with her.\u201d\n\nMore central in the current race is Ms. Nixon\u2019s relationship with Mr. de Blasio, who the governor has charged is behind her campaign. \u201cProbably either the mayor of New York or Vladimir Putin,\u201d Mr. Cuomo laughed earlier this month.\n\nIn fact, Ms. Katz said, Ms. Nixon was first approached about running for governor in 2010, by the late progressive activist Jon Kest \u2014 which would have pitted her against Mr. Cuomo eight years earlier.\n\nAmong those that Ms. Nixon wooed into Mr. de Blasio\u2019s fold in 2013 was the playwright Jon Robin Baitz, who said that, in hindsight, \u201cIt is quite clear that Quinn would\u2019ve been a better choice for this city, tough, fierce, brave and rock solid \u2014 perfect for New York.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt stings to think about,\u201d Mr. Baitz said.\n\nBut that doesn\u2019t mean he has soured on Ms. Nixon, who he said was not to be underestimated.\n\n\u201cIn a race between Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon, I know who I\u2019d bet on,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd it isn\u2019t the guy.\u201d", "title": "2018 Is Cynthia Nixon\u2019s First Race; 2013 Was Her First Political Rodeo", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher", "Jacob Bernstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Taking the step to buy your first home may feel like a leap \u2014 across a canyon. You will probably be spending more money at once than you have ever spent in your life, and committing to spend even more money that you don\u2019t have, all while becoming responsible for something that won\u2019t necessarily love you back.\n\nTo make matters worse, 2018 presents a new set of problems for rookie home buyers: a new tax law whose full effects have yet to be felt on homeowner taxes or property values; record low inventory; tough credit; and rising mortgage rates.\n\nSo should you make that leap?\n\nWhat Will the New Tax Law Do to Home Values?\n\nHow the new Republican tax plan approved late last year will affect housing isn\u2019t completely clear yet, but buying a home in 2018 will likely become more expensive, especially for buyers who live in high-tax states. Taxpayers used to be able to deduct all of their state and local taxes, including property taxes, state income taxes and city income taxes, from their federal taxes. Now those deductions are capped at $10,000 \u2014 and at $5,000 for married taxpayers filing separately.\n\nIn New Jersey, for example, the average 2017 property tax bill was $8,690 across the state, according to the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, and more than $11,000 in counties that make up the suburbs of New York City. Those homeowners are likely to blow past the new deduction cap before they\u2019re even done with their property taxes.", "title": "2018: A Tough Year for First-Time Buyers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018DIAMOND MOUNTAINS: TRAVEL AND NOSTALGIA IN KOREAN ART\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through May 20). Mount Kumgang, or the \u201cDiamond Mountain,\u201d lies about 90 miles from Pyeongchang\u2019s Olympic Stadium, but it\u2019s a world away: The august, multipeaked range lies in North Korea and has been impossible to visit for most of the past seven decades. Featuring stunning loans from the National Museum of Korea and other institutions in Seoul, South Korea, this melancholy beauty of a show assembles three centuries\u2019 worth of paintings of the Diamond Mountain range, and explores how landscapes intermingle nostalgia, nationalism, legend and regret. The unmissable prizes here are the painstaking paintings of Jeong Seon, the 18th-century artist who is perhaps the greatest of all Korean painters. And later impressions of the mountains, including a blotchy vision from the Paris-based modernist Lee Ungno, give a deeper historical weight to very live geopolitics. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). In the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster in its own right. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of Western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE JIM HENSON EXHIBITION\u2019 at the Museum of the Moving Image. The rainbow connection has been established in Astoria, Queens, where this museum has opened a new permanent wing devoted to the career of America\u2019s great puppeteer, who was born in Mississippi in 1936 and died, too young, in 1990. Henson began presenting the short TV program \u201cSam and Friends\u201d before he was out of his teens; one of its characters, the soft-faced Kermit, was crafted from his mother\u2019s old coat and would not mature into a frog for more than a decade. The influence of early variety television, with its succession of skits and songs, runs through \u201cSesame Street\u201d and \u201cThe Muppet Show,\u201d though Henson also spent the late 1960s crafting peace-and-love documentaries and prototyping a psychedelic nightclub. Young visitors will delight in seeing Big Bird, Elmo, Miss Piggy and the Swedish Chef; adults can dig deep into sketches and story boards and rediscover some old friends. (Farago)\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018PETER HUJAR: SPEED OF LIFE\u2019 at the Morgan Library and Museum (through May 20). It\u2019s hard to say which is more surprising: that Peter Hujar\u2019s photographs of underground life in New York in the 1970s and \u201980s have found their way to the Morgan Library and Museum, or that the classically minded institution has become unbuttoned enough to exhibit them in this heartbreaker of a show. Hujar (1934-87) lived most of his professional life in the East Village and, through studio portraits and cityscapes, captured a downtown that has since been all but erased by time, gentrification and AIDS. Although he was little known by the mainstream art world in his lifetime, this show, startlingly tender, reveals him to be one of the major American photographers of the late 20th century. (Holland Cotter)\n\n212-685-0008, themorgan.org\n\n\u2018THE INCOMPLETE ARAKI\u2019 at the Museum of Sex (through Aug. 31). It remains a bit of a tourist trap, but the for-profit Museum of Sex is making its most serious bid yet for artistic credibility with a two-floor exhibition of Japan\u2019s most prominent and controversial photographer. Nobuyoshi Araki has spent decades shooting Tokyo streetscapes, blossoming flowers and, notably, women trussed up in the baroque rope bondage technique known as kinbaku-bi, or \u201cthe beauty of tight binding.\u201d Given the venue, it\u2019s natural that this show concentrates on the erotic side of his art, but less lustful visitors can discover an ambitious cross section of Mr. Araki\u2019s omnivorous photography, including his lastingly moving \u201cSentimental Journey,\u201d picturing his beloved wife, Yoko, from honeymoon to funeral. (Farago)\n\n212-689-6337, museumofsex.com\n\n\u2018ZOE LEONARD: SURVEY\u2019 at the Whitney Museum of American Art (through June 10). Some shows cast a spell. Zoe Leonard\u2019s reverberant retrospective does. Physically ultra-austere, all white walls with a fiercely edited selection of objects \u2014 photographs of clouds taken from airplane windows; a mural collaged from vintage postcards; a scattering of empty fruit skins, each stitched closed with needle and thread \u2014 it\u2019s an extended essay about travel, time passing, political passion and the ineffable daily beauty of the world. (Cotter)\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org\n\n\u2018THE LONG RUN\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through Nov. 4). The museum upends its cherished Modern narrative of ceaseless progress by mostly young (white) men. Instead we see works by artists 45 and older who have just kept on keeping on, regardless of attention or reward, sometimes saving the best for last. Art here is an older person\u2019s game, a pursuit of a deepening personal vision over innovation. Winding through 17 galleries, the installation is alternatively visually or thematically acute and altogether inspiring. (Smith)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018MADE IN ASIA\u2019 at Opera Gallery (through March 27). Running parallel to Asia Week, this exhibition brings together a globe-spanning collection of works from or inspired by Asia. It includes Yue Minjun\u2019s \u201cThe Ressurection\u201d and \u201cEverywhere,\u201d a video robot sculpture by Korean-American artist Nam June Paik and Warhol\u2019s \u201cMao\u201d silkscreen. (Danielle Dowling)\n\n646-707-3299, operagallery.com\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were declared landmarks, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-from-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance, the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, more than 16 years after Sept. 11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org\n\n\u2018OUTLIERS AND AMERICAN VANGUARD ART\u2019 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington (through May 13). Tracing the interaction of taught and untaught artists over the past century, this exhibition tackles an impossibly immense subject and starts stronger than it finishes. But it presents quantities of stunning art in all mediums, revealing the vastness of American creativity and the many attempts by museums to do it justice. It proves more forcefully than ever that the distinction between the works of the self-taught and that of the professionals has outlived its relevance. (Smith)\n\n202-737-4215, nga.gov\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018REBEL SPIRITS: ROBERT F. KENNEDY AND MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through May 20). Delve into the ties that bound these progressive standard-bearers through photographs that document their rise to the national stage in the 1950s and \u201960s and the struggle for the societal changes they championed, and ephemera such as magazines, campaign buttons, protest placards and an R.F.K.-M.L.K. spinning pendant. You can even listen on a transistor radio to the song Dick Holler wrote after their assassinations in 1968, \u201cAbraham, Martin and John.\u201d (Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ALBERTO SAVINIO\u2019 at the Center for Italian Modern Art (through June 23). The paintings of this Italian polymath have long been overshadowed by the brilliant work of his older brother, Giorgio de Chirico. This show of more than 20 canvases from the late 1920s to the mid-1930s may not change that, but the mix of landscapes with bright patterns and several eerie portraits based on family photographs are surprisingly of the moment. (Smith)\n\n646-370-3596, italianmodernart.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought, refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles 4,000 years of Judaica with modern and contemporary art by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze. The works are shown in a nimble, nonchronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\n\u2018STEPHEN SHORE\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through May 28). Not staged, not lit, not cropped, not retouched, the color photographs of this American master are feats of dispassionate representation. This must-see retrospective \u2014 curated with real wit by Quentin Bajac, MoMA\u2019s photo chief \u2014 opens with Mr. Shore\u2019s teenage snaps at Andy Warhol\u2019s Factory. Then it turns to the road-trip imagery of \u201cAmerican Surfaces\u201d and the steely precision of \u201cUncommon Places\u201d \u2014 landmarks in photographic history that scandalized an establishment convinced the camera could find beauty solely in black-and-white. Mr. Shore is revealed not only as a peripatetic explorer but also a restless experimenter with new photographic technologies, from stereoscopic slide shows to print-on-demand books. The only flaw is his recent embrace of Instagram, allowing museumgoers to lazily flick through images on MoMA\u2019s smudged iPads. New technologies are great, but not at the expense of concentration. (Farago)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u20182018 TRIENNIAL: SONGS FOR SABOTAGE\u2019 at the New Museum (through May 27). This Bowery museum\u2019s fourth triennial exhibition, \u201cSongs for Sabotage,\u201d is the smallest, tightest edition of the show so far. Immaculately installed, it\u2019s also the best looking. There\u2019s a lot of good work, which is global in scope and not by a list of prevetted up-and-comers. (Zhenya Machneva, Dalton Paula and Daniela Ortiz are artists to look for.) Less admirably, it\u2019s a safe and unchallenging show. Despite a politically demanding time, it acts as if ambiguity and discretion were automatically virtues. In an era when the market rules, it puts its money on the kind of art \u2014 easily tradable, displayable, palette-tickling objects \u2014 that art fairs suck up. (Cotter)\n\n212-219-1222, newmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018HOTBED\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through March 25). Celebrating the centennial of the passage of women\u2019s voting rights in New York State, this exhibition at the museum\u2019s Joyce B. Cowin Women\u2019s History Gallery assembles more than 100 images and artifacts, including advocative posters; progressive magazines of the time, such as The Woman Voter; and cookbooks and pepper shakers bearing suffragist propaganda. These items tell the story of the women\u2019s rights movement in the early 20th century \u2014 its evolution, its impact and its epicenter in Greenwich Village. (Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org", "title": "21 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). In the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster in its own right. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of Western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE JIM HENSON EXHIBITION\u2019 at the Museum of the Moving Image. The rainbow connection has been established in Astoria, Queens, where this museum has opened a new permanent wing devoted to the career of America\u2019s great puppeteer, who was born in Mississippi in 1936 and died, too young, in 1990. Henson began presenting the short TV program \u201cSam and Friends\u201d before he was out of his teens; one of its characters, the soft-faced Kermit, was crafted from his mother\u2019s old coat and would not mature into a frog for more than a decade. The influence of early variety television, with its succession of skits and songs, runs through \u201cSesame Street\u201d and \u201cThe Muppet Show,\u201d though Henson also spent the late 1960s crafting peace-and-love documentaries and prototyping a psychedelic nightclub. Young visitors will delight in seeing Big Bird, Elmo, Miss Piggy and the Swedish Chef; adults can dig deep into sketches and story boards and rediscover some old friends. (Farago)\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us\n\n\u2018PETER HUJAR: SPEED OF LIFE\u2019 at the Morgan Library and Museum (through May 20). It\u2019s hard to say which is more surprising: that Peter Hujar\u2019s photographs of underground life in New York in the 1970s and \u201980s have found their way to the Morgan Library and Museum, or that the classically minded institution has become unbuttoned enough to exhibit them in this heartbreaker of a show. Hujar (1934-87) lived most of his professional life in the East Village and, through studio portraits and cityscapes, captured a downtown that has since been all but erased by time, gentrification and AIDS. Although he was little known by the mainstream art world in his lifetime, this show, startlingly tender, reveals him to be one of the major American photographers of the late 20th century. (Holland Cotter)\n\n212-685-0008, themorgan.org\n\n\u2018THE INCOMPLETE ARAKI\u2019 at the Museum of Sex (through Aug. 31). It remains a bit of a tourist trap, but the for-profit Museum of Sex is making its most serious bid yet for artistic credibility with a two-floor exhibition of Japan\u2019s most prominent and controversial photographer. Nobuyoshi Araki has spent decades shooting Tokyo streetscapes, blossoming flowers and, notably, women trussed up in the baroque rope bondage technique known as kinbaku-bi, or \u201cthe beauty of tight binding.\u201d Given the venue, it\u2019s natural that this show concentrates on the erotic side of his art, but less lustful visitors can discover an ambitious cross section of Mr. Araki\u2019s omnivorous photography, including his lastingly moving \u201cSentimental Journey,\u201d picturing his beloved wife, Yoko, from honeymoon to funeral. (Farago)\n\n212-689-6337, museumofsex.com\n\n\u2018THE LONG RUN\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through Nov. 4). The museum upends its cherished Modern narrative of ceaseless progress by mostly young (white) men. Instead we see works by artists 45 and older who have just kept on keeping on, regardless of attention or reward, sometimes saving the best for last. Art here is an older person\u2019s game, a pursuit of a deepening personal vision over innovation. Winding through 17 galleries, the installation is alternatively visually or thematically acute and altogether inspiring. (Smith)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were declared landmarks, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-from-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance, the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, more than 16 years after Sept. 11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org\n\n\u2018OUTLIERS AND AMERICAN VANGUARD ART\u2019 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington (through May 13). Tracing the interaction of taught and untaught artists over the past century, this exhibition tackles an impossibly immense subject and starts stronger than it finishes. But it presents quantities of stunning art in all mediums, revealing the vastness of American creativity and the many attempts by museums to do it justice. It proves more forcefully than ever that the distinction between the works of the self-taught and that of the professionals has outlived its relevance. (Smith)\n\n202-737-4215, nga.gov\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018REBEL SPIRITS: ROBERT F. KENNEDY AND MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through May 20). Delve into the ties that bound these progressive standard-bearers through photographs that document their rise to the national stage in the 1950s and \u201960s and the struggle for the societal changes they championed, and ephemera such as magazines, campaign buttons, protest placards and an R.F.K.-M.L.K. spinning pendant. You can even listen on a transistor radio to the song Dick Holler wrote after their assassinations in 1968, \u201cAbraham, Martin and John.\u201d (Danielle Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
