The paintings of this Italian polymath have long been overshadowed by the brilliant work of his older brother, Giorgio de Chirico. This show of more than 20 canvases from the late 1920s to the mid-1930s may not change that, but the mix of landscapes with bright patterns and several eerie portraits based on family photographs are surprisingly of the moment. (Smith)\n\n646-370-3596, italianmodernart.org\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought, refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles 4,000 years of Judaica with modern and contemporary art by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze. The works are shown in a nimble, nonchronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\n\u2018STEPHEN SHORE\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through May 28). Not staged, not lit, not cropped, not retouched, the color photographs of this American master are feats of dispassionate representation. This must-see retrospective \u2014 curated with real wit by Quentin Bajac, MoMA\u2019s photo chief \u2014 opens with Mr. Shore\u2019s teenage snaps at Andy Warhol\u2019s Factory. Then it turns to the road-trip imagery of \u201cAmerican Surfaces\u201d and the steely precision of \u201cUncommon Places\u201d \u2014 landmarks in photographic history that scandalized an establishment convinced the camera could find beauty solely in black-and-white. Mr. Shore is revealed not only as a peripatetic explorer but also a restless experimenter with new photographic technologies, from stereoscopic slide shows to print-on-demand books. The only flaw is his recent embrace of Instagram, allowing museumgoers to lazily flick through images on MoMA\u2019s smudged iPads. New technologies are great, but not at the expense of concentration. (Farago)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u20182018 TRIENNIAL: SONGS FOR SABOTAGE\u2019 at the New Museum (through May 27). This Bowery museum\u2019s fourth triennial exhibition, \u201cSongs for Sabotage,\u201d is the smallest, tightest edition of the show so far. Immaculately installed, it\u2019s also the best looking. There\u2019s a lot of good work, which is global in scope and not by a list of prevetted up-and-comers. (Zhenya Machneva, Dalton Paula and Daniela Ortiz are artists to look for.) Less admirably, it\u2019s a safe and unchallenging show. Despite a politically demanding time, it acts as if ambiguity and discretion were automatically virtues. In an era when the market rules, it puts its money on the kind of art \u2014 easily tradable, displayable, palette-tickling objects \u2014 that art fairs suck up. (Cotter)\n\n212-219-1222, newmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018TANIA BRUGUERA: UNTITLED (HAVANA, 2000)\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through March 11). Nearly 18 years have passed since the artist and activist Tania Bruguera first mounted \u2014 or attempted to mount \u2014 \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000)\u201d at the Seventh Havana Biennial. Critical of the post-revolutionary politics of Cuba, it was shut down by censors within hours. Now \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000)\u201d is recreated here. In groups of four, you enter a dark space where you walk on sugar cane. As your eyes adjust, you see four naked men along the wall and video propaganda images of Fidel Castro. Borrowing aesthetic motifs from earlier art, like medieval and Renaissance painting, Ms. Bruguera\u2019s tableau vivant asks you to \u201cstop looking and start thinking\u201d about politics, history and violence. (Martha Schwendener)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018CAROLEE SCHNEEMANN: KINETIC PAINTING\u2019 at MoMA PS1 (through March 11). Some say that #MeToo has gone too far. What modern misogynist will be yanked from museums next? Gauguin? Picasso? I say, sure, why not? Set them aside, give them a rest and make room for what we never see, which means art by almost any woman you can name. Carolee Schneemann is one I\u2019d move right into the cleared-out spotlight, not just because she has star quality, which she does, or because she has majorly shaped art history, which she has. I\u2019d put her there because, in a career of some 60 years, she\u2019s been one of the most generous artists around \u2014 generous with her presence, her thinking, her formal and political risk taking, and her embrace of embracing itself. You\u2019ll find evidence of all of this in her first comprehensive retrospective. (Cotter)\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org\n\n\u2018THE SCULPTURE OF GONZALO FONSECA\u2019 at the Noguchi Museum (through March 11). The Uruguayan-American sculptor Gonzalo Fonseca (1922-97) pioneered an architecturally inflected, whimsically literary style of relentless ambiguity. Whether covering large pieces of Italian travertine with incised circles and tiny pyramids, fixing a small red sail to a flat chunk of limestone or titling a tabletop-size pillar of dark gray stone \u201cSelf-Portrait,\u201d Fonseca made his work live by putting it almost entirely in the power of the viewer\u2019s imagination. This modest but jampacked mini retrospective \u2014 aptly sited in the museum built by his friend and fellow stone carver Isamu Noguchi \u2014 is worth taking in slowly. (Will Heinrich)\n\n718-204-7708, noguchi.org\n\n\u2018CATHY WILKES\u2019 at MoMA PS1 (through March 11). A tea-ringed saucer, a discolored hatbox, an unfixed sink or a case of vegetable peelers \u2014 from these humble materials, the Irish-born artist conjures wrenchingly moving tableaus of family, loss and memory. Ms. Wilkes is one of the leading lights of the white-hot Glasgow contemporary art scene, and her unprepossessing sculpture, installations and paintings are shown to advantage here. Works are shown without barriers and often sit directly on the floor, emphasizing their fragility and care. (PS1 limits entry to the galleries to a few dozen at a time.) This show is an invitation to slow down, to look closely, to think and to feel at once. (Farago)\n\n718-784-2084, momaps1.org", "title": "22 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.\n\n\u2018TARSILA DO AMARAL: INVENTING MODERN ART IN BRAZIL\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through June 3). The subtitle is no overstatement: In the early 1920s, first in Paris and then back home in S\u00e3o Paulo, Brazil, this painter really did lay the groundwork for the coming of modernism in Latin America\u2019s most populous nation. Tired of the European pretenders in Brazil\u2019s art academies, Tarsila (who was always called by her first name) began to intermingle Western, African and indigenous motifs into flowing, biomorphic paintings, and to theorize a new national culture fueled by the principle of antropofagia, or \u201ccannibalism.\u201d Along with spare, assured drawings of Rio and the Brazilian countryside, this belated but very welcome show assembles Tarsila\u2019s three most important paintings, including the classic \u201cAbaporu\u201d (1928): a semi-human nude with a spindly nose and a comically swollen foot. (Jason Farago)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018BIRDS OF A FEATHER: JOSEPH CORNELL\u2019S HOMAGE TO JUAN GRIS\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through April 15). This small, hyper-specialized, stunning exhibition brings together a grand total of only 13 works \u2014 a dozen shadow boxes by Joseph Cornell, the Queens-based assemblage artist, and the Cubist masterwork that he cited as their direct inspiration, Gris\u2019s \u201cMan at the Caf\u00e9\u201d (1914). It might seem like a surprising obsession for Cornell, who was not a painter nor a Frenchman. He and Gris never met. But Cornell was deeply moved by Gris, the overlooked, tag-along third wheel in the Cubist movement that also included Picasso and Braque, and the show succeeds in tracking the fluttery ways of artistic inspiration. (Deborah Solomon)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018DIAMOND MOUNTAINS: TRAVEL AND NOSTALGIA IN KOREAN ART\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through May 20). Mount Kumgang, or the \u201cDiamond Mountain,\u201d lies about 90 miles from Pyeongchang\u2019s Olympic Stadium, but it\u2019s a world away: The august, multipeaked range lies in North Korea and has been impossible to visit for most of the past seven decades. Featuring stunning loans from the National Museum of Korea and other institutions in Seoul, South Korea, this melancholy beauty of a show assembles three centuries\u2019 worth of paintings of the Diamond Mountain range, and explores how landscapes intermingle nostalgia, nationalism, legend and regret. The unmissable prizes here are the painstaking paintings of Jeong Seon, the 18th-century artist who is perhaps the greatest of all Korean painters. And later impressions of the mountains, including a blotchy vision from the Paris-based modernist Lee Ungno, give a deeper historical weight to very live geopolitics. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE FACE OF DYNASTY: ROYAL CRESTS FROM WESTERN CAMEROON\u2019 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Sept. 3). In the African wing, a show of just four commanding wooden crowns constitutes a blockbuster in its own right. These massive wooden crests \u2014 in the form of stylized human faces with vast vertical brows \u2014 served as markers of royal power among the Bamileke peoples of the Cameroonian grasslands, and the Met\u2019s recent acquisition of an 18th-century specimen is joined here by three later examples, each featuring sharply protruding cheeks, broadly smiling mouths and brows incised with involute geometric patterns. Ritual objects like these were decisive for the development of Western modernist painting, and a Cameroonian crest was even shown at MoMA in the 1930s, as a \u201csculpture\u201d divorced from ethnography. But these crests had legal and diplomatic significance as well as aesthetic appeal, and their anonymous African creators had a political understanding of art not so far from our own. (Farago)\n\n212-535-7710, metmuseum.org", "title": "23 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018THE JIM HENSON EXHIBITION\u2019 at the Museum of the Moving Image. The rainbow connection has been established in Astoria, Queens, where this museum has opened a new permanent wing devoted to the career of America\u2019s great puppeteer, who was born in Mississippi in 1936 and died, too young, in 1990. Henson began presenting the short TV program \u201cSam and Friends\u201d before he was out of his teens; one of its characters, the soft-faced Kermit, was fashioned from his mother\u2019s old coat and would not mature into a frog for more than a decade. The influence of early variety television, with its succession of skits and songs, runs through \u201cSesame Street\u201d and \u201cThe Muppet Show,\u201d though Henson also spent the late 1960s crafting peace-and-love documentaries and prototyping a psychedelic nightclub. Young visitors will delight in seeing Big Bird, Elmo, Miss Piggy and the Swedish Chef; adults can dig deep into sketches and story boards and rediscover some old friends. (Farago)\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us\n\n\u2018PETER HUJAR: SPEED OF LIFE\u2019 at the Morgan Library and Museum (through May 20). It\u2019s hard to say which is more surprising: that Peter Hujar\u2019s photographs of underground life in New York in the 1970s and \u201980s have found their way to the Morgan Library and Museum, or that the classically minded institution has become unbuttoned enough to exhibit them in this heartbreaker of a show. Hujar (1934-87) lived most of his professional life in the East Village and, through studio portraits and cityscapes, captured a downtown that has since been all but erased by time, gentrification and AIDS. Although he was little known by the mainstream art world in his lifetime, this show, startlingly tender, reveals him to be one of the major American photographers of the late 20th century. (Holland Cotter)\n\n212-685-0008, themorgan.org\n\n\u2018THE INCOMPLETE ARAKI\u2019 at the Museum of Sex (through Aug. 31). It remains a bit of a tourist trap, but the for-profit Museum of Sex is making its most serious bid yet for artistic credibility with a two-floor exhibition of Japan\u2019s most prominent and controversial photographer. Nobuyoshi Araki has spent decades shooting Tokyo streetscapes, blossoming flowers and, notably, women trussed up in the baroque rope bondage technique known as kinbaku-bi, or \u201cthe beauty of tight binding.\u201d Given the venue, it\u2019s natural that this show concentrates on the erotic side of his art, but less lustful visitors can discover an ambitious cross section of Mr. Araki\u2019s omnivorous photography, including his lastingly moving \u201cSentimental Journey,\u201d picturing his beloved wife, Yoko, from honeymoon to funeral. (Farago)\n\n212-689-6337, museumofsex.com\n\n\u2018ZOE LEONARD: SURVEY\u2019 at the Whitney Museum of American Art (through June 10). Some shows cast a spell. Zoe Leonard\u2019s reverberant retrospective does. Physically ultra-austere, all white walls with a fiercely edited selection of objects \u2014 photographs of clouds taken from airplane windows; a mural collaged from vintage postcards; a scattering of empty fruit skins, each stitched closed with needle and thread \u2014 it\u2019s an extended essay about travel, time passing, political passion and the ineffable daily beauty of the world. (Cotter)\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org\n\n\u2018THE LONG RUN\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through Nov. 4). The museum upends its cherished Modern narrative of ceaseless progress by mostly young (white) men. Instead we see works by artists 45 and older who have just kept on keeping on, regardless of attention or reward, sometimes saving the best for last. Art here is an older person\u2019s game, a pursuit of a deepening personal vision over innovation. Winding through 17 galleries, the installation is alternatively visually or thematically acute and altogether inspiring. (Roberta Smith)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018MILLENNIUM: LOWER MANHATTAN IN THE 1990S\u2019 at the Skyscraper Museum (through April). This plucky Battery Park institution transports us back to the years of Rudy Giuliani, Lauryn Hill and 128-kilobit modems to reveal the enduring urban legacy of a decade bookended by recession and terror. In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, landlords in the financial district rezoned their old skyscrapers for residential occupancy, and more than 20 towers were declared landmarks, including the ornate Standard Oil building at 26 Broadway and the home of Delmonico\u2019s at 56 Beaver Street. Battery Park City flowered; yuppies priced out of TriBeCa came down to Wall Street; a new Guggenheim, designed by a fresh-from-Bilbao Frank Gehry, nearly arose by South Street Seaport. From this distance, the 1990s can seem almost like a golden age, not least given that, more than 16 years after Sept. 11, construction at the underwhelming new World Trade Center is still not finished. (Farago)\n\nskyscraper.org\n\n\u2018OUTLIERS AND AMERICAN VANGUARD ART\u2019 at the National Gallery of Art, Washington (through May 13). Tracing the interaction of taught and untaught artists over the past century, this exhibition tackles an impossibly immense subject and starts stronger than it finishes. But it presents quantities of stunning art in all mediums, revealing the vastness of American creativity and the many attempts by museums to do it justice. It proves more forcefully than ever that the distinction between the works of the self-taught and that of the professionals has outlived its relevance. (Smith)\n\n202-737-4215, nga.gov\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018REBEL SPIRITS: ROBERT F. KENNEDY AND MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through May 20). Delve into the ties that bound these progressive standard-bearers through photographs that document their rise to the national stage in the 1950s and \u201960s and the struggle for the societal changes they championed, and ephemera such as magazines, campaign buttons, protest placards and an R.F.K.-M.L.K. spinning pendant. You can even listen on a transistor radio to the song Dick Holler wrote after their assassinations in 1968, \u201cAbraham, Martin and John.\u201d (Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ALBERTO SAVINIO\u2019 at the Center for Italian Modern Art (through June 23). The paintings of this Italian polymath have long been overshadowed by the brilliant work of his older brother, Giorgio de Chirico. This show of more than 20 canvases from the late 1920s to the mid-\u201930s may not change that, but the mix of landscapes with bright patterns and several eerie portraits based on family photographs are surprisingly of the moment. (Smith)\n\n646-370-3596, italianmodernart.org\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018SCENES FROM THE COLLECTION\u2019 at the Jewish Museum. After a surgical renovation to its grand pile on Fifth Avenue, the Jewish Museum has reopened its third-floor galleries with a rethought, refreshed display of its permanent collection, which intermingles 4,000 years of Judaica with modern and contemporary art by Jews and gentiles alike \u2014 Mark Rothko, Lee Krasner, Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and the excellent young Nigerian draftswoman Ruby Onyinyechi Amanze. The works are shown in a nimble, nonchronological suite of galleries, and some of its century-spanning juxtapositions are bracing; others feel reductive, even dilletantish. But always, the Jewish Museum conceives of art and religion as interlocking elements of a story of civilization, commendably open to new influences and new interpretations. (Farago)\n\n212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org\n\n\u2018STEPHEN SHORE\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through May 28). Not staged, not lit, not cropped, not retouched, the color photographs of this American master are feats of dispassionate representation. This must-see retrospective \u2014 curated with real wit by Quentin Bajac, MoMA\u2019s photo chief \u2014 opens with Mr. Shore\u2019s teenage snaps at Andy Warhol\u2019s Factory. Then it turns to the road-trip imagery of \u201cAmerican Surfaces\u201d and the steely precision of \u201cUncommon Places\u201d \u2014 landmarks in photographic history that scandalized an establishment convinced the camera could find beauty solely in black-and-white. Mr. Shore is revealed not only as a peripatetic explorer but also a restless experimenter with new photographic technologies, from stereoscopic slide shows to print-on-demand books. The only flaw is his recent embrace of Instagram, allowing museumgoers to lazily flick through images on MoMA\u2019s smudged iPads. New technologies are great, but not at the expense of concentration. (Farago)\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u20182018 TRIENNIAL: SONGS FOR SABOTAGE\u2019 at the New Museum (through May 27). This Bowery museum\u2019s fourth triennial exhibition, \u201cSongs for Sabotage,\u201d is the smallest, tightest edition of the show so far. Immaculately installed, it\u2019s also the best looking. There\u2019s a lot of good work, which is global in scope and not by a list of prevetted up-and-comers. (Zhenya Machneva, Dalton Paula and Daniela Ortiz are artists to look for.) Less admirably, it\u2019s a safe and unchallenging show. Despite a politically demanding time, it acts as if ambiguity and discretion were automatically virtues. In an era when the market rules, it puts its money on the kind of art \u2014 easily tradable, displayable, palette-tickling objects \u2014 that art fairs suck up. (Cotter)\n\n212-219-1222, newmuseum.org\n\n\u2018THE VIETNAM WAR: 1945-1975\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through April 22). In contrast to the PBS series \u201cThe Vietnam War,\u201d this exhibition delivers historical data, a lot of it, quick and dirty, through labels, film and audio clips and objects, some of which fall under a broad definition of art. Along with paintings by contemporary Vietnamese artists, there\u2019s graffiti-style drawings on combat helmets and Zippo lighters, and period design in album covers and protest posters. Words and images work together in murals labeled \u201cHome Front\u201d and \u201cWar Front\u201d that put you in the middle of the war\u2019s primary issues and events. (Cotter)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\n\u2018ZURBAR\u00c1N\u2019S JACOB AND HIS TWELVE SONS: PAINTINGS FROM AUCKLAND CASTLE\u2019 at the Frick Collection (through April 22). More devout than Vel\u00e1zquez, more shadowy than Murillo, Francisco de Zurbar\u00e1n was little known outside Spain until the mid-19th century, when Manet and his friends found the seeds of modernism in his frisky, open brushwork and streamlined form. The Frick is now showing a baker\u2019s dozen of the Spaniard\u2019s biblical portraits, of aged, hunched Jacob and the sons who would become the founders of the Twelve Tribes of Israel, with most of the paintings on loan from a castle that until recently belonged to the Church of England. The gents pose in a startling variety of crisp, supple fabrics, whose glamour or grittiness echoes Jacob\u2019s foretelling of their destinies in Genesis. Two are especially compelling: Judah, child No. 4, decked out in a fur-trimmed coat and vamping alongside a kindly lion, and Joseph, who forgoes the Technicolor dreamcoat for a blue sash and a belt stitched with gold. (Farago)\n\n212-288-0700, frick.org\n\nLast Chance\n\n\u2018THE BEAUTIFUL BRAIN: THE DRAWINGS OF SANTIAGO RAM\u00d3N Y CAJAL\u2019 at Grey Art Gallery (through March 31). The first United States museum exhibition devoted to the scientific illustrations of this Spanish giant of neuroscience is among the year\u2019s best so far. Its 80 freehand renderings of different brain cells, as viewed through a microscope, helped prove that they are unconnected, communicating across tiny gaps called synaptic clefts, which earned Cajal a Nobel Prize in 1906. His exquisite images, still used in textbooks, ignite synaptic charges throughout 20th-century art, from Surrealism onward. (Smith)\n\n212-998-6780, greyartgallery.nyu.edu\n\n\u2018EXPERIMENTS IN ELECTROSTATICS: PHOTOCOPY ART FROM THE WHITNEY\u2019S COLLECTION, 1966-1986\u2019 at the Whitney Museum of American Art (through March 25). The photocopier never gained traction as a popular artistic tool, but this exhibition is an intriguing curiosity, showcasing the work of three artists and a collective who worked seriously with machines that were invented to reproduce office documents. Edward Meneeley, a photographer, embraced the photocopier, making small wallpaperlike abstractions, while Lesley Schiff created deadpan images of everyday objects and Barbara T. Smith generated hazy abstractions with cooking flour (and feminist overtones). The International Society of Copier Artists, which had 500 members at one point, produced work that ranged from still lifes to graphic montages reminiscent of contemporaneous punk rock album covers and zines. (Martha Schwendener)\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org\n\n\u2018HOTBED\u2019 at the New-York Historical Society (through March 25). Celebrating the centennial of the passage of women\u2019s voting rights in New York State, this exhibition at the museum\u2019s Joyce B. Cowin Women\u2019s History Gallery assembles more than 100 images and artifacts, including advocative posters; progressive magazines of the time, such as The Woman Voter; and cookbooks and pepper shakers bearing suffragist propaganda. These items tell the story of the women\u2019s rights movement in the early 20th century \u2014 its evolution, its impact and its epicenter in Greenwich Village. (Dowling)\n\n212-873-3400, nyhistory.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018JOYCE J. SCOTT: HARRIET TUBMAN AND OTHER TRUTHS\u2019 at Grounds for Sculpture (through April 1). The work of this recent MacArthur fellowship winner, Nancy Princenthal wrote in The Times, \u201cproves just how sharp glass can get.\u201d Ms. Scott uses hand-threaded beads and blown glass to create art that is \u201ca revelation, inviting covetous attention to what often turn out, on close inspection, to be brutal subjects: vicious racism, violent misogyny,\u201d Ms. Princenthal added. Among the exhibition\u2019s highlights are three sculptures of Harriet Tubman, including one armed with a flower-embossed rifle and one made of rammed earth that is meant to erode over time at this Hamilton, N.J., sculpture garden. (Dowling)\n\n609-586-0616, groundsforsculpture.org", "title": "23 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The department received more than 80 calls about packages by Monday evening, up from two the previous Monday, and the chief said that officers were prepared to handle all reports, even if it takes officials a while to arrive. The department is receiving support from explosive and canine teams from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and from the Department of Public Safety as well as resources from nearby areas, he said.\n\nNo other nefarious packages had been discovered as of Monday afternoon, he said.\n\nInvestigators do not believe that any of the packages were delivered by the Post Office, UPS, FedEx or DHL. Instead, they think they were dropped off at the homes overnight, to be discovered by residents in the morning.\n\nOfficials did not have descriptions for suspects or vehicles, but Chief Manley said that the person or people involved know how to build an explosive that detonates. He implored the community to come forward with any information.\n\nA $15,000 reward is being offered for information leading to the arrest of those responsible for Austin package bombings, Gov. Greg Abbott announced in a statement on Monday, adding that \u201cthe State of Texas will provide any resources necessary to ensure the safety of our citizens, and quickly bring those guilty to justice.\u201d\n\nAs the gravity of the bombing spree sank in throughout normally tranquil neighborhoods, residents acknowledged a new fear.\n\n\u201cNow everybody\u2019s on edge,\u201d said David Alvarado, 58, as he stood amid scampering grandchildren in his front yard on Vargas Road in south central Austin, just blocks from police barricades around the scene of Monday\u2019s second explosion.\n\nHe pledged to be extremely cautious with the future arrival of packages. \u201cThis one here is waiting on some tennis shoes,\u201d he said, pointing to a 7-year-old grandson. \u201cI told my daughter I\u2019m going to throw them in the middle of the yard to make sure they\u2019re safe.\u201d", "title": "3 Austin Package Explosions, 2 of Them Deadly, Appear to Be Linked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe victims were found to have an inadequate amount of food and were living in an unsuitable and unsafe environment due to the conditions located on the property,\u201d the sheriff\u2019s department said in a statement.\n\nCindy Bachman, a sheriff\u2019s department spokeswoman, said investigators had not found records of the children attending school. The family lived on the property for at least the past four years, Ms. Bachman said, and investigators were looking into where they resided previously.\n\nOfficials with the county\u2019s Children and Family Service department took custody of the children, whose names and genders were not released. The parents were being held on Thursday night in a county jail in lieu of $100,000 bond. It was not clear if they had hired a lawyer.\n\nMs. Bachman said that she did not know whether the children were taken to a hospital but that deputies who responded to the property said the children did not appear to be malnourished.\n\nThe case evoked the rescue of 13 siblings in January from their home in Perris, Calif. The authorities in Riverside County, which is just south of San Bernardino County, said the siblings, some of whom were chained to furniture and beds, told them their parents had held them captive for years.", "title": "3 Children Found Living in a Plywood Box in California, Officials Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump said on Thursday that he had picked John R. Bolton, a Fox News analyst and a former ambassador to the United Nations, as his next national security adviser, choosing a longtime brash, conservative hawk to help shape his foreign policy operation.\n\nMr. Bolton, 69, has been in the public eye, and in Washington, for 30 years. Outspoken and never one to back down from a debate, he served in the administrations of the past three Republican presidents, mostly in the State Department, and has elevated his profile in recent years. Some of his views were once seen as out of the political mainstream \u2014 his harsh criticism of the United Nations, for example \u2014 but his blunt, in-your-face approach now resembles that of Mr. Trump.\n\nOver the years, Mr. Bolton\u2019s uncompromising views on foreign policy have both raised concerns and grabbed headlines. Here are some examples.\n\n\u2018The End of North Korea\u2019\n\nMr. Bolton, who is scheduled to start at the White House on April 9, will take over as a top adviser to Mr. Trump during a critical time. Mr. Trump recently accepted an invitation from North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, to meet for negotiations over its nuclear program. That meeting is expected to take place sometime within the next month and a half.", "title": "3 Examples of John Bolton\u2019s Longtime Hard-Line Views", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nTHE EYES OF WILLIAM KLEIN at the Quad Cinema (through March 13). The Quad celebrates the impending 90th birthday of the photographer and filmmaker William Klein, who has worked in a range of modes \u2014 documentaries, satires and portraits of the fashion world. He parodied that last milieu in \u201cWho Are You, Polly Maggoo?,\u201d screening on Friday and accompanied by the short \u201cBroadway by Light,\u201d in which the lights of Times Square seem to dance to the music of Maurice Le Roux. His documentaries include biographical chronicles of Muhammad Ali (\u201cMuhammad Ali, the Greatest,\u201d showing on Saturday and Tuesday) and Eldridge and Kathleen Cleaver (\u201cEldridge Cleaver, Black Panther,\u201d on Saturday and Sunday).\n\n212-255-2243, quadcinema.com\n\n\u2018POLICE STORY\u2019 at the Metrograph (March 9-18). Jackie Chan directed himself \u2014 and, more important, performed his own stunts and martial arts \u2014 in the first installment of his long-running Hong Kong cop series. Reviewing the film at the New York Film Festival in 1987, Vincent Canby didn\u2019t get the appeal, writing that \u201c\u2018Police Story\u2019 is of principal interest as a souvenir of another culture.\u201d That appraisal hasn\u2019t stood the test of time: This new digital restoration shows that Mr. Chan is peerless when it comes to using an umbrella to latch on to the outside of a moving bus or sliding through multiple stories of glass and wire lights in a shopping mall because taking the escalators would be too slow.\n\n212-660-0312, metrograph.com\n\nRENDEZ-VOUS WITH FRENCH CINEMA at the Film Society of Lincoln Center (through March 18). A serious hunger for French movies, or even a hankering for an aperitif, is the only prerequisite for attending the Film Society\u2019s annual banquet of recent Gallic cinema. The offerings include a Flaubert-alluding, black-and-white portrait of a young filmmaker (Jean-Paul Civeyrac\u2019s \u201cA Paris Education,\u201d showing on Monday); a critique of sexism in the French corporate world (Tonie Marshall\u2019s \u201cNumber One,\u201d with Emmanuelle Devos competing to lead a utility company, screening on Saturday and March 17); multiple World War I movies (like \u201cThe Guardians,\u201d showing on March 16, from the \u201cOf Gods and Men\u201d director Xavier Beauvois); and even some experimental projects that the French might call outr\u00e9. In \u201cJeannette, the Childhood of Joan of Arc\u201d (on Friday and Tuesday), Bruno Dumont (\u201cHadewijch\u201d) cuts loose with a rock opera about the saint in her youth. Eug\u00e8ne Green\u2019s \u201cWaiting for the Barbarians\u201d (on Tuesday and March 16) was made as part of a workshop.\n\n212-875-5601, filmlinc.org", "title": "3 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. Plus, a Times Talks event. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nMICHEL PICCOLI at Film Forum (March 16-22). It\u2019s a tad cute to ascribe symmetry to the career of the French star Michel Piccoli, but one can draw a line from his work in \u201cContempt\u201d (on Saturday) \u2014 the 1964 Jean-Luc Godard masterpiece in which he plays a screenwriter whose marriage disintegrates during a production of \u201cThe Odyssey\u201d \u2014 to \u201cI\u2019m Going Home\u201d (on Thursday), Manoel de Oliveira\u2019s 2002 portrait of a grieving theater actor near the end of his life, vexed after being abruptly cast in a film production of James Joyce\u2019s \u201cUlysses.\u201d Film Forum\u2019s retrospective goes heavy on marquee directors: It features Mr. Piccoli\u2019s collaborations with Luis Bu\u00f1uel (\u201cDiary of a Chambermaid,\u201d showing on Tuesday), Jacques Demy (\u201cUne Chambre en Ville,\u201d on Sunday, and \u201cThe Young Girls of Rochefort,\u201d on Sunday and Tuesday) and Marco Ferreri (\u201cDillinger Is Dead,\u201d on Wednesday and March 23, and \u201cLa Grande Bouffe,\u201d from Saturday to Monday and on Thursday), plus another chance to catch the recent revival of Jacques Rivette\u2019s great \u201cLa Belle Noiseuse\u201d (on Monday).\n\n212-727-8110, filmforum.org", "title": "3 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. Plus, a Times Talks event. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\n\u2018EL INDIO: THE FILMS OF EMILIO FERN\u00c1NDEZ\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (through March 13). In an appraisal of a Mexican noir retrospective at MoMA in 2015, J. Hoberman, writing in The New York Times, quoted the director Emilio Fern\u00e1ndez as saying, \u201cThere is only one Mexico: the one I invented.\u201d But MoMA\u2019s new series on Mr. Fern\u00e1ndez, perhaps the best-known filmmaker from what is often called the Golden Age of Mexican cinema, suggests that his onscreen Mexico was incredibly varied. \u201cEnamorada\u201d (Friday, and March 10 and 12) begins as a sort of western set during the Mexican revolution before turning into a variation on \u201cThe Taming of the Shrew\u201d after a rebel leader (Pedro Armend\u00e1riz) falls for the daughter (Mar\u00eda F\u00e9lix) of a man he had arrested. In a darker register, \u201cSal\u00f3n M\u00e9xico\u201d (Sunday, and March 9 and 13) centers on a nightclub worker (Marga L\u00f3pez) who struggles, Mildred Pierce-like, to save money for her younger sister. She finds the prospect of salvation in a sympathetic, widowed police officer (Miguel Incl\u00e1n). Both films were shot by the great Gabriel Figueroa, Mr. Fern\u00e1ndez\u2019s frequent cinematographer.\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\n\u2018NEIGHBORING SCENES: NEW LATIN AMERICAN CINEMA\u2019 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center (through March 4). The highlights of this annual series include \u201cGabriel and the Mountain\u201d (Saturday), based on the true story of a Brazilian tourist \u2014 a friend of the director\u2019s \u2014 which earned two prizes at last year\u2019s Critics\u2019 Week in Cannes, and \u201cLightning Falls Behind\u201d (Sunday). Set in Costa Rica, it centers on a pair of teenage girls who discover a body in the trunk of a car.\n\n212-875-5601, filmlinc.org\n\n\u2018WOMEN AT WORK: LABOR ACTIVISM\u2019 at BAM Rose Cinemas (March 2-8). In the first part of what is planned as a recurring series on women in the labor force, BAM will focus on movies about union activity. The program opens with \u201cSalt of the Earth\u201d (Friday), an independent production that was controversial in 1954 for having been made by the director Herbert J. Biberman (one of the Hollywood 10) and other blacklisted filmmakers. Cast with a mix of professional and nonprofessional actors \u2014 and partly funded by a union that the Congress of Industrial Organizations had expelled for its politics \u2014 the film revolves around a New Mexico miners\u2019 strike that requires unity not only among the workers, who begin the movie divided, but also between the miners and their wives, who start picketing in place of their husbands when a court forbids the miners from doing so. Other highlights include \u201cNorma Rae\u201d (Sunday), which won Sally Field her first Oscar, and \u201cSilkwood\u201d (Saturday), in which Meryl Streep plays the real-life organizer Karen Silkwood, who raised questions about the conditions at the nuclear processing plant where she worked.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org\n\nTimes Talks\n\nAVA DUVERNAY at the Times Center (March 8, 7 p.m.). Spend an evening with this Oscar- and Golden Globe-nominated director, producer and screenwriter, as she discusses one of the most anticipated films of 2018, \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d (in theaters on March 9). A formidable force in the fight for female voices and intersectionality in film and beyond, Ms. DuVernay was the first African-American women to be nominated for best director at the Academy Awards, and is the first woman of color to direct a film with a budget of over $100 million.\n\ntimestalks.com\n\n", "title": "3 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Three men charged Tuesday with illegally possessing a machine gun are suspected of bombing a mosque in Minnesota and attempting to bomb an abortion clinic in Illinois last year, federal officials said.\n\nWhile the complaint does not charge the men with crimes related to the bombing episodes, the authorities said that they had gathered evidence indicating that the men were responsible for them. The investigation is continuing, they said.\n\nOne of the men, Michael McWhorter, admitted to the police that he participated in the bombing in Bloomington, Minn., on Aug. 5 and the attempted bombing in Illinois on Nov. 7, a federal affidavit said. Mr. McWhorter said that he and the two other men involved did not intend to kill anyone, but had chosen to bomb the mosque to \u201cscare\u201d Muslims \u201cout of the country\u201d and to signal that they were \u201cnot welcome here,\u201d according to the affidavit.\n\nThe men \u2014 Mr. McWhorter, 29, Michael B. Hari, 47, and Joe Morris, 22 \u2014 believed that Muslims \u201cpush their beliefs on everyone else,\u201d the affidavit said. It was unclear whether the men had lawyers.", "title": "3 Suspects in Bombing of Minnesota Mosque Face Weapons Charges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Discussing her career rise \u2014 from a design department assistant at David Yurman to overseeing her own atelier in Germantown, a small town along the Hudson in upstate New York \u2014 Ms. MacGill credits her father as the key motivating figure.\n\nAfter graduating from Brown University, when her friends were taking off for Europe, Mr. MacGill encouraged his daughter to work for Mr. Yurman. Then he lent her his garage when she decided to strike out on her own and design jewelry. And Mr. MacGill provided his daughter with her first big break.\n\nIt was an introduction to Kazuko Oshima. A muse to Mr. Frank, Ms. Oshima, the Japanese-born polymath (who died in 2007), became a darling of the downtown New York art world after Madonna wore a lace veil she had crafted in the video of the 1984 hit single, \u201cLike A Virgin.\u201d Bianca Jagger was among the fashion icons who flocked to Barneys New York to buy the one-off pieces that Ms. Oshima created by twisting gold wire around semiprecious stones. \u201cI was 14,\u201d Ms. MacGill said with a laugh, recalling when she realized, over tea with Ms. Oshima, that jewelry was definitely her calling.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe had a serious conversation,\u201d she added. \u201cKazuko said she would introduce me to her gold vendor and her bead vendor. I still work with them. Kazuko set me up.\u201d\n\nThe path to Venyx, Ms. Niarchos\u2019s opulent fine jewelry brand (she derived its name by merging Venus and onyx) came from her childhood friend, Gaia Repossi. As creative director of Repossi (jeweler to the House of Grimaldi), Ms. Repossi commissioned Ms. Niarchos to create two collections in 2007.\n\nThe experience prompted Ms. Niarchos, who had studied fashion and interned for John Galliano, to apprentice in the fine jewelry department of Christie\u2019s in New York. She also studied at the London branch of the Gemological Institute of America.\n\nWhile the training provided a technical foundation, master paintings and modern art seem to be the creative fuel of Venyx. Ms. Niarchos, however, is somewhat tight-lipped discussing her family\u2019s collection, possibly because of its magnificence and value.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1957 Ms. Niarchos\u2019s grandfather, the shipping tycoon Stavros Niarchos, bought what has been called the greatest collection of French Impressionists ever assembled by an American, the Warner Bros.\u2019 actor Edward G. Robinson \u2014 prompting Vogue to refer to his homes as museums. El Greco\u2019s \u201cPiet\u00e0\u201d and \u201cSt. Peter\u201d hung in Mr. Niarchos\u2019s New York apartment, while Degas\u2019 \u201cDancer\u201d \u2014 along with canvases by Gauguin, Manet, Renoir and Rouault \u2014 were on his three-masted-schooner, the Creole.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Niarchos\u2019s father, Philip Niarchos, has significantly increased the value of the collection with his own additions, including self-portraits by Jean-Michel Basquiat and Van Gogh.\n\n\u201cI never sit down and think about it, but, somehow, there will always be an artistic reference on my mood board,\u201d Ms. Niarchos said, referring to the inspirational images she collects at the start of her design process.\n\nFor example, Van Gogh\u2019s \u201cThe Starry Night,\u201d inspired lustrous star-shaped jewels in her 2014 Theiya collection. A Dan Flavin fluorescent light piece proved the motivation for the glow-in-the-dark enamel that lends an otherworldly quality to Oseanyx, a 2015 collection inspired by aquatic life and outer space.\n\nIn her 2017 Elementa collection, Ms. Niarchos\u2019s credits her admiration of Monet\u2019s shimmering Houses of Parliament series for her use of vibrant stones, including carnelians, fire opals, orange sapphires and amethysts.\n\nAnd a trio of Elementa necklaces, showcasing striking intarsias (polished stones set within marble), appear to be miniature masterpieces.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Ms. Niarchos said she discovered the intarsias at the Tucson Gem, Mineral and Fossil Showcase, an annual trade fair in Arizona that she attends in Arizona, and then created the precious metal and gemstone frames: \u201cI thought it would be nice to wear a little painting around your neck.\u201d\n\nThe first jewelry Ms. Sheibani designed were gold brooches that also resembled picture frames.\n\nThe designs, now a motif in her collection of bold 18-karat pieces, were motivated by her memory of a pin, a small Picasso etching encased in gold. Claude Picasso, the artist\u2019s son and legal administrator of his estate, gave it to Mrs. Sheibani\u2019s mother, Christine Bischofberger.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMrs. Sheibani\u2019s father is Bruno Bischofberger, the Swiss art dealer generally credited with introducing Pop Art and Neo-Expressionism in Europe and propelling the career of Gerhard Richter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe represented Mr. Basquiat (with whom Mrs. Sheibani painted as a child) and Mr. Warhol, with whom he co-founded Interview magazine. And he has opened his own museum outside Zurich to showcase his collection of furniture by Le Corbusier, Alvar Aalto, Frank Lloyd Wright, Eileen Gray and Jean Prouv\u00e9, which W magazine has called the world\u2019s most extensive.\n\n\u201cI loved making jewelry always,\u201d Mrs. Sheibani said. \u201cThe first money I ever earned, from working in my father\u2019s gallery, I put half in the bank and spent the other half on a Roman and Greek bronze ring which I wore every day, for like, five years.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cLooking at art has influenced me \u2014 100 percent,\u201d she added. \u201cBut I\u2019m not copying anything. I just love color and interesting shapes.\u201d\n\nIf there is a forerunner \u2014 or inspirational figurehead \u2014 to this band of designers, it is another Picasso offspring, Paloma Picasso. She once described her childhood with her father: \u201cI used to spend hours drawing next to him.\u201d\n\nChanneling this experience into jewelry making, Ms. Picasso trained as a goldsmith, studied jewelry design and made her first pieces for Yves Saint Laurent, who credited her flair (which relied on inventively mixing vintage flea market finds as well as turbans and red lipstick), for inspiring the \u201840s flair of his spring 1971 Scandal collection.\n\nIn the early \u201970s, Tiffany & Company noticed her after a limited-edition collection of weighty gold necklaces and bracelets for the Greek jeweler Zolotas regenerated the brand.\n\nIn 1979, it introduced her namesake Tiffany line, which continues to thrive.\n\nThis year she turns 69, and her natural successors seem to be among this group of female jewelry powerhouses.\n\nTiffany, take note.", "title": "3 Women Grew Up Surrounded by Art. Guess What Their Jewelry Looks Like.", "authors": ["Bronwyn Cosgrave"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Digital and post-human explorations of the body \u2014 often merged with other creatures and species \u2014 can be seen in Oliver Laric and Aleksandra Domanovic\u2019s hybrid sculptures at Tanya Leighton (F23) and Tabita Rezaire\u2019s wild installation at Goodman Gallery (702, F25), where you can sit in a pink gynecological examination chair and watch a video that mixes Afrofuturism with neo-psychedelic images and musings on sexuality and reproduction.\n\nPainting\n\nPhoto\n\nPainting is always in full force at art fairs. The field is strong this year, with titillating objects like Kehinde Wiley\u2019s first portrait after painting former President Barack Obama, on view at Sean Kelly (501). It\u2019s titled \u201cMargaret, Countess of Blessington\u201d \u2014 in case you\u2019re wondering why when the subject is a man, Mr. Wiley is recalling an original painting of Margaret by Sir Thomas Lawrence, circa 1821.\n\nA knockout newcomer to New York is the Norwegian painter Vanessa Baird, at OSL Contemporary (827). Her dark, erotic, sometimes violent pastels, hung in scroll-like strips papering the booth, are an excellent introduction to this painter, who has also illustrated the work of the Norwegian uber-writer Karl Ove Knausgaard. Pieter Vermeersch, a Belgian painter showing at Perrotin (802), explores color and surface in relation to each other with canvases mounted on painted walls with gently fading edges and gradients.\n\nPhoto\n\nOther discoveries for this critic include Li Yuan-Chia, a conceptual artist and abstract painter at Richard Saltoun (114), and Huang Rui, whose deep red geometric canvases are at 10 Chancery Lane (106). Hackett Mill (212) has works by Milton Avery and the lesser known San Francisco painter David Park, while Ronchini (120) has an exceptional display of work by Katsumi Nakai, an artist who migrated from Japan to Italy after World War II and exhibited with the so-called Spacialists, Milanese artists of whom the best known is Lucio Fontana. Also check out Sarah Cain\u2019s playful, site-specific \u201ctwo day painting\u201d (2018), presented by Galerie Lelong (Booth 604) and Honor Fraser (Booth 914); Mary Corse\u2019s works with glittering highway paint at Kayne Griffin Corcoran (502), a run-up to shows at Dia:Beacon and at the Whitney Museum of American Art; Claire Tabouret\u2019s military-drab-green paintings at Night Gallery (F27), in which women wear gas masks; and Dona Nelson\u2019s fabulous two-sided paintings at Thomas Erben Gallery (F7).\n\nBig", "title": "30 Must-See Artists at the Armory Show", "authors": ["Martha Schwendener"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "KANSAS CITY, Mo. \u2014 One by one, the teams marched onto the court, lining up in rows until they had filled half the floor from baseline to midcourt, roughly 500 men\u2019s college basketball players, coaches and team managers standing shoulder to shoulder.\n\nThe unusual display of hoops humanity is known as the Parade of Champions, and it is a signature moment at the annual N.A.I.A. Basketball Championship, one of the wildest events in college sports.\n\nMany call the more popular \u2014 and more lucrative \u2014 68-team N.C.A.A. basketball tournament \u201cmadness.\u201d But compared with the N.A.I.A. event, that is just a three-week, 14-city corporate show. The N.A.I.A.\u2019s version is truly nuts: 32 teams, seven days and one shared hotel. It is a virtual assembly line of college basketball, and for the true hoops fanatic it is basketball paradise.\n\n\u201cThis is the real March Madness,\u201d Larry Cordaro, the coach of Louisiana State-Alexandria, said during a busy breakfast on Thursday at Kansas City\u2019s Westin hotel, where all 32 teams were billeted. \u201cIt\u2019s a really special time.\u201d", "title": "32 Teams, 7 Days, 1 Gym", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "6) 1 p.m. SKIPPERS IN TRAINING\n\nThe city estimates that one in four Auckland residents owns a boat, and seemingly four in four are sailing fans \u2014 particularly after the Kiwi team won the most recent America\u2019s Cup race versus the American team so decisively. The America\u2019s Cup Sailing experience from the tour company Explore Group (180 dollars) allows amateurs to feel the thrill of a heeling 80-foot boat and the grind of raising the sails on two-hour trips in Waitemata Harbor. The fleet includes a 2003 vintage boat that served as a practice ship for Team New Zealand long before the twin-hulled, hydrofoil catamarans of present-day racing came along. But the older model still provides plenty of speed and the crew encourages all passengers to steer and crank on the grinders to adjust the sails throughout the trip.\n\n7) 3:30 p.m. SHOP LOCAL\n\nThe 16-acre waterfront development Britomart, wedged between the harbor and the Central Business District, or C.B.D., mixes historic and new buildings that are rapidly filling with upscale tenants. A strong contingent of them wave the Kiwi flag for fashion, including boutiques from local designers such as Karen Walker, known for refining street styles in ruffle-edge dresses and cropped stovepipe pants; Trelise Cooper, whose dresses combine bohemian silhouettes with glam touches; and Kathryn Wilson, a women\u2019s shoemaker with a taste for embellishment. Men get equal attention at Zambesi Store which makes progressive fashion for both sexes, and the spirited World which supplements its inventory of colorful, avant-garde looks with boutique beauty brands.\n\n8) 6 p.m. BRITOMART BITES\n\nChic cafes spill into the streets that web the Britomart district, offering convenient respite. The new Amano scales up farm-to-table and nose-to-tail cooking to serve sizable crowds in a former warehouse with rough plaster walls and exposed beams. An open kitchen spans the space, making theater of chefs cutting fresh pasta or roasting chicken. The menu champions New Zealand ingredients from Kaipara oysters (4 dollars each), to grilled lamb chops (34 dollars). Down the street, the similarly seasonal Ortolana offers fewer but no-less-sophisticated choices \u2014 try kingfish crudo (20 dollars) and pasta with clams (29 dollars) \u2014 plus superb people-watching from the patio or the conservatory indoors.", "title": "36 Hours in Auckland", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Friday\n\n1) 5 p.m. ART SEEN\n\nFor years, Hungary\u2019s art scene was known for being relatively unknown, though several new galleries are working to improve things. One of the best is the 2014 arrival Art + Text, housed in an Art Nouveau building whose ornate 1903 architectural details contrast stunningly against the contemporary artworks on display. Exhibitions focusing on emerging artists and modernist works of the post-World War II era change roughly every month. Get here early: Like many other Budapest galleries, Art + Text is not open on weekends, and only welcomes visitors on Fridays until 6 p.m.\n\n2) 6 p.m. LEARNING CURVE\n\nRelax over a glass and a bite at Tasting Table, a cool, casual wine shop and bar that became one of the city\u2019s favorite destinations soon after it opened in an atmospheric Palace Quarter cellar in late 2014. Owned by the American food writer Carolyn Banfalvi and her Hungarian husband, Gabor, Tasting Table stocks over 200 wines, which you can compare in flights of three glasses (3,900 forints, or about $15.40), while you sample local cheeses, charcuterie and other snacks. Placemat-size maps illustrate the geography and varietals of the country\u2019s main wine regions, making it easy to justify another round in the name of your ongoing oenological education.\n\nImage Rudas Baths, one of the city\u2019s most atmospheric thermal pools, was originally built during the Ottoman occupation in the mid-16th century. Credit Akos Stiller for The New York Times\n\n3) 10 p.m. DOMESTIC DISTILLATES\n\nYears ago, Budapest led the way for cocktails in Central Europe, with favorites like Boutiq\u2019 Bar appearing on several global \u201cbest bars\u201d lists. The new hotness: Good Spirit Bar, which opened last year in the Inner City with more than 350 kinds of whiskey and some 700 spirits overall, including takes on the domestic distillate palinka, made with beet, celery root and carrot. Relax at the spacious, L-shaped corner bar over a relatively obscure Japanese whiskey like the 12-year-old Togouchi (3,700 forints for a dram of 4 centiliters, or about 1.35 ounces), or make your way through the cocktail list, which bounds from classics like the Sazerac (2,400 forints) to such custom creations as Fig in Japan (Nikka All Malt whiskey, fig syrup, sherry vinegar and a dash of espresso, tobacco and bacon bitters; 2,400 forints). The list also includes creative, nonalcoholic drinks like the Sage Stage (sage, cardamom, lime, pear and tonic; 1,100 forints).", "title": "36 Hours in Budapest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "6) 12:30 p.m. PO\u2019 BOY FIX\n\nHaving worked up an appetite, sate it with a generous New Orleans-style sandwich at the Second Line in Overton Square, where the popular chef Kelly English pays homage to his Louisiana roots. It resides next to his more formal Restaurant Iris and aims to channel the spirit of musical processions in a destination where, the menu notes, \u201cevery day is a party.\u201d Lodged in an intimate bungalow with exposed brick walls and black-and-white photos, the convivial quarters draw fans from around the city for his substantial po\u2019 boys made with braised chicken thighs and Swiss cheese ($12) or fried oysters ($16), including savory sides such as red beans and rice.\n\n7) 2 p.m. RECORDING SESSION\n\nFor music fans, touring Sun Studio (admission $14) is a Memphis pilgrimage. In this modest two-story brick building, the sound engineer Sam Phillips \u2014 or, as tour guides like to tell it, his secretary Marion Keisker \u2014 discovered a young Elvis Presley. Phillips recorded the future King of Rock \u2018n\u2019 Roll\u2019s first single, \u201cThat\u2019s All Right,\u201d in 1954, but he was a blues fan prior and recorded other legends, including Howlin\u2019 Wolf and the Prisonaires, whose musical clips are played during the tour. In the actual studio, an unglamorous work room where more recent acts like U2 and Bonnie Raitt have recorded, guides invite tour-goers to pose holding the original Shure 55 microphone used by Elvis and other legends.\n\n8) 3:30 p.m. SHOPPING AND BEER\n\nMemphis\u2019s growing microbrewery scene positions beer as shopping break conveniences in a couple of emerging neighborhoods. Near Sun Studio in the Edge District, High Cotton Brewing Company adjoins Edge Alley, home to a few intriguing shops, including B. Collective, selling artist-made housewares, and Paulette\u2019s Closet, a retailer of fine-condition vintage clothing. Roughly five miles east on an industrial corner next to some train tracks, Wiseacre Brewing Co. anchors the shop-filled Broad Avenue Arts District. Pick up some arty accessories at Falling Into Place then grab a Tiny Bomb pilsner ($5) and hit Wiseacre\u2019s outdoor bocce court and music stage in the shade of a pair of grain silos.", "title": "36 Hours in Memphis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Friday\n\n1) 4 p.m. GET CULTURED\n\nOpened in 2011, the Centro Cultural San Pablo is housed in a former 16th-century Dominican convent and set around a tiled patio etched with bright green moss. The beautifully restored center has multiple exhibition and performance spaces, including one in the Rosary Chapel, and showcases everything from Oaxacan crafts \u2014 ornately carved alebrijes (whimsical wooden statues), indigenous textiles and traditional black pottery \u2014 to pop art, photography, string quartet performances and even the odd adults-only marionette show. The complex also has a cafe, an indoor children\u2019s play area, a research library and a terrace restaurant popular with local bigwigs in natty business suits, which makes for excellent people watching.\n\n2) 6 p.m. COMIDA LOCAL\n\nA block east of San Pablo, in a storefront behind a pumpkin-colored facade, Cabuche is a festive restaurant serving reverential interpretations of street food and market staples: huaraches Menonita, edible tablets of sandal-shaped masa topped with tasajo (dried salted beef); Oaxacan string cheese and purslane (130 pesos, or about $7); and deeply flavorful soups, ranging from classic pozoles (choose between the red, green or white version, starting at 60 pesos) and a fiery shrimp caldo called levantamuertos (translation: raises the dead, 130 pesos). Sample the daily selection of guisados (25 pesos) \u2014 the miscellaneous stews that traditionally fill street tacos \u2014 like huitlacoche (corn fungus), potato with chile de agua (a light green pepper popular in the region) and rajas (strips of mild poblano pepper) with cheese. Specials, including house-made craft beer (dark and amber) and pulque (fermented sap from the maguey plant) flavored with celery, mango or oats, are advertised in multicolor chalk around the art-filled, two-room dining room.", "title": "36 Hours in Oaxaca", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "6) 2 P.M. TAKE IT OUTSIDE\n\nS\u00e3o Paulo\u2019s world-renowned street art is everywhere, but most visitors just head to Batman Alley, a traffic-free tangle of passages covered in wildly creative works and surrounded by upscale cafes and galleries in Vila Madalena. A tour with the guide Renato Goes takes you there first, and then to the Outdoor Museum of Urban Art \u2014 where works are spray-painted onto the pylons under an elevated subway line \u2014 and downtown, where creations cover entire sides of buildings. Don\u2019t be surprised if there\u2019s a detour: Mr. Goes follows S\u00e3o Paulo\u2019s best on Instagram, so you never know when you\u2019ll stop on the side of the highway to admire work done the night before. Booked through Around SP, a three-hour tour is 490 reais and up.\n\n7) 8 P.M. NOR\u2019EASTER\n\nWhen northeastern migrants came to S\u00e3o Paulo last century, they brought their down-home cooking with them: dried meats, a rice and beans dish called bai\u00e3o a dois and tapioca in countless forms. You can find all three at the unpretentiously stylish Fit\u00f3, which serves food inspired by the cuisine of Piau\u00ed state. Especially worth your stomach real estate is the pa\u00e7oca, a mix of manioc flour with shredded carne de sol (beef cured for three days, though no longer in the sun as its name implies). A meal for two with drinks will run you around 100 reais.\n\n8) 10 P.M. REFUGEES WELCOME\n\nBrazil\u2019s Arab roots run deep \u2014 two of S\u00e3o Paulo\u2019s last three mayors are of Lebanese descent \u2014 but most families arrived generations ago. Al Janiah is a rare nightspot and restaurant staffed by recent immigrants, largely Syrian refugees. The owner, Hasan Zarif, a native Brazilian born to Palestinian refugee parents, meant the place to be a bar and restaurant but it has morphed into a community center as well, with book launches and Arabic classes. Weekends, though, are all about night life, with live bands and a distinctly underground student vibe. And hummus, incredible hummus. The Palestina Libre cocktail (25 reais) is a delicious mix of anise-flavored arak, zaatar, mild biquino peppers, lime, mint and cacha\u00e7a. If the cocktail\u2019s (or the bar\u2019s) politics bother you, well, as a sign on the wall reads, \u201cA vida transtorna\u201d \u2014 life unsettles, life perplexes, life agitates.", "title": "36 Hours in S\u00e3o Paulo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Stop drinking soda\n\nThis one is a no-brainer. Sweetened beverages account for about 47 percent of added sugar in the American diet, and they are essentially nutrient-free calorie-delivery vehicles. A 16-ounce bottle of Coke contains 52 grams of sugar, more than your entire daily limit.\n\nIf you drink soda for the caffeine, switch to tea or coffee. If it\u2019s the carbonation or the convenience of having a drink in a can handy, try switching to a seltzer like La Croix (my personal beverage of choice \u2014 try the coconut flavor!).\n\nPhoto\n\nWatch your breakfast\n\nSugar is stealthily sneaked into many breakfast foods that are marketed as \u201chealthy\u201d or \u201cnatural.\u201d Flavored yogurts, for example, are loaded with sugar, and fruit juices are an easy way to drink tons of sugar without realizing.\n\nFor your morning meal, try to eat more grain-based foods with low or little sugar, like Cheerios, plain oatmeal, bread and homemade granola, Mr. Leonhardt suggests. And if you want to skip grains altogether, great options include scrambled or fried eggs, whole fruits, plain yogurt and nuts.\n\nFor even more breakfast recipes, check out these breakfast recipes from whole30, a more radical diet that forces out all sugar, in addition to other items. (A personal favorite crash diet of yours truly.)\n\nCheck the sauces\n\nAs with breakfast foods, food producers sneak more sugar into sauces and condiments than you\u2019d guess \u2014 for example, two of the four biggest ingredients in Heinz Ketchup are sweeteners, Mr. Leonhardt writes.\n\nRead the labels on sauces and see how high sugar is listed, and watch out for sugar by another name, like high fructose corn syrup.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome sauces that don\u2019t rely on sugar for flavor are Maille dijon mustard, Gulden\u2019s spicy brown, French\u2019s Yellow Mustard, Prego\u2019s Marinara, and Newman\u2019s Own Classic Oil and Vinegar salad dressing.\n\nTry a diet reset\n\nMr. Leonhardt\u2019s own reckoning with sugar came when he cut sugar out of his diet for an entire month, which he wrote about here. I had a similar experience years ago when I tried Whole30 for the first time (and wrote about it here), and it is truly shocking how much sugar we eat without even realizing it.\n\nIf a full month sounds like too big an undertaking, try this: The next time you\u2019re making a big shopping trip at the grocery store, stop to read the ingredients label of every single thing you buy. Watch out for keywords that are used to disguise sugar \u2014 like dextrose, fructose, saccharose, agave nectar and evaporated cane juice \u2014 and take stock of how much sugar you\u2019ve been eating without even realizing it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life.
