Once a year, the programming teams at the Film Society of Lincoln Center and MoMA come together to offer a joint vision of cinema\u2019s future, with a series composed mostly of first and second features. (Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott posted their picks on Tuesday.) The highlights of the 47th edition include Kantemir Balagov\u2019s \u201cCloseness\u201d (showing on Saturday and Sunday), a Russian feature in which a young woman chafing against the customs of her cloistered Jewish community faces wrenching choices after her brother and his fianc\u00e9e are kidnapped, and Hu Bo\u2019s \u201cAn Elephant Sitting Still\u201d (screening on Sunday and on April 8), a bleak, nearly four-hour look at four intersecting lives over one day in China. The director died from an apparent suicide last year.\n\n212-875-5601, filmlinc.org\n\n212-708-9400, moma.org\n\nTOUGH LOVE: CINEMA BY LYNNE RAMSAY at BAM Rose Cinemas (April 2-5). For a filmmaker who has only made two features in the last 15 years, Ms. Ramsay has remarkably little interest in making up for lost time with long running times. The elliptical revenge odyssey \u201cYou Were Never Really Here,\u201d which opens on April 6, runs about 90 minutes. Nothing more is said in it than is necessary (but what is said was still enough to win the movie a screenplay prize at Cannes). But the Scottish director\u2019s impressionistic cutting style and superbly layered soundtracks are nothing new. This retrospective, which opens with a sold-out sneak preview of \u201cYou Were Never Really Here\u201d on Monday, also includes her shorts (on Monday and Wednesday); her debut feature, \u201cRatcatcher\u201d (on Wednesday); and perhaps her most acclaimed film, \u201cMorvern Callar\u201d (on Thursday), starring Samantha Morton as a woman sent spinning after her boyfriend\u2019s suicide.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org", "title": "4 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 The state budget deadline is looming. Billions in funding for infrastructure, public housing and education are in the air. Lawmakers have given little indication that they are moving any closer to a deal.\n\nBut in these final, frenzied days of negotiations, one of the major questions hanging over the State Capitol is not what will be included in the budget talks, but who.\n\nIn radio interviews, on social media and in hallways between meetings, lawmakers have been bombarded by questions about whether Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the leader of the Senate Democrats, should be part of closed-door budget negotiations in the governor\u2019s office.\n\nHer absence has long been a point of contention: Democrats say she has been robbed of her seat by the Independent Democratic Conference, a group of eight Democrats who collaborate with the Republicans, helping to give them control of the chamber. That point has been made especially stark this year, as discussions of how to crack down on sexual harassment in state government have taken center stage.", "title": "4 Men Walk Into a Room. How Are New York\u2019s Sex Harassment Laws Affected?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 More than half of the Italians who cast ballots on Sunday voted for populist parties, largely abandoning the traditional mainstream parties, especially on the center-left, continuing a European trend.\n\nHere are some other takeaways from a \u201cthrow the bums out\u201d Italian election.\n\nMigration matters\n\nThe issue continues to disrupt and inflame European politics, including in Germany, Greece, the Netherlands and now Italy. With Greece, Italy has borne the brunt of recent large movements of refugees and migrants into Europe from places such as Afghanistan, Libya and Syria.\n\nThere is a strong feeling that the mainstream parties have no answer and that Italy got little help from the European Union in Brussels or from other member states. Once Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany cut off the migrant flow through Central Europe by doing deals with Turkey, neither Berlin nor Brussels seemed to care any more, and a European policy on migration is still unresolved.\n\n\u201cThere was a sense in Italy of total abandonment over migration, which didn\u2019t become a crisis until Germany suffered, and then stopped being one,\u201d said Mark Leonard, director of the European Council on Foreign Relations.", "title": "4 Takeaways From a \u2018Throw the Bums Out\u2019 Italian Election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The \u201ccatastrophic\u201d failure of a storage tank this month at an Ohio fertility clinic caused the apparent loss of more than 4,000 frozen embryos and eggs, the clinic said this week.\n\nAbout 950 patients were affected by the failure, in which the tank\u2019s temperature rose and an alarm did not go off, the University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, which oversees the clinic, said in a letter that was sent to patients on Monday and posted on its website.\n\n\u201cWe are heartbroken to tell you that it\u2019s unlikely any are viable,\u201d the letter said.\n\nThe letter was an update to an announcement on March 8 that the tissue storage bank where eggs and embryos are stored in liquid nitrogen had experienced an unexpected temperature fluctuation the previous weekend. At the time, the hospital said it did not know whether the eggs and embryos were still viable.\n\nIn its letter this week, the organization said that the 4,000 specimens affected were at least twice as many as it had originally estimated.", "title": "4,000 Eggs and Embryos Are Lost in Tank Failure, Ohio Fertility Clinic Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The problem, of course, is that Staub got so much of his on-base production through walks rather than hits. He finished his career with a good-but-not-great 2,716 hits, and a truly spectacular 1,255 walks. Those totals propelled him to a .362 career on-base percentage, which when combined with his .431 slugging percentage, and adjusted for his home parks and era, made him 24 percent better than the average batter for the duration of his career. Only 19 batters in major league history finished their careers with as many at-bats as Staub (9,720) and an adjusted on-base plus slugging percentage higher than his (124).\n\nBut Staub gets overlooked by plenty of people because for the majority of fans a hit will always trump a walk, or even several walks. It was this concept that led to the sabermetrics world coming up with a theoretical conversion to provide context on a player who derives so much value from walks. Popularized by Joe Posnanski, among others, the concept is to trade 500 of a player\u2019s walks for an additional 325 singles to see if that makes you view the player in a different light. It is a slightly inexact application of Pete Palmer\u2019s concept of linear weights, which is a process of assigning point values to various statistics so they can be properly compared.\n\nIf you execute that trade for Staub you are left with a popular player who finished his career with 3,041 hits and 755 walks. As just about anyone with a passing interest in baseball statistics can tell you, the only members of the 3,000-hit club that reached Hall of Fame eligibility without being inducted are Rose and Palmeiro. It is not a stretch to think that if Staub had finished with those totals \u2014 keep in mind, this trade would result in his having reached base 175 fewer times \u2014 he would have sailed into the Hall, especially considering he would have been just the 16th or 17th player to reach 3,000 hits depending on how things shook out between him and Rod Carew.\n\nIn fairness to the voters who went against him, Staub is an exceptional case and by almost every accepted measure he is rightly excluded from the Hall. Jay Jaffe\u2019s useful career evaluation tool, known as JAWS, pegs Staub as the 35th best right fielder in major league history. There are some players ranked below him that managed to make it to Cooperstown, but there are plenty ahead of him who did not.\n\nBut Staub, at the very least, was a curiosity deserving of far more notoriety than he was afforded during and after his career. A remarkably durable player who hit his first home run at 19 and his last at 41, Staub did not look much like an elite athlete, but he managed to turn a fairly brief stint as one of the game\u2019s true stars into an extended career as a guy who simply knew how to get on base. And while the general public may not have appreciated just how gifted he was in that all-important skill, a survey of fans of the Montreal Expos and the Mets would reveal that many of the people who saw him the most knew just how important he was.", "title": "4,050 Reasons to Appreciate Rusty Staub", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman", "Keeping Score"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Eliza May said she was watching a TV show in her home when she heard what sounded like a transformer blowing up in her backyard. \u201cIt sounded like when the transformers go out, but it was five times magnified that,\u201d said Ms. May, who lives about 200 feet from where the explosion was said to have occurred.\n\nAnother neighbor, Lori Goodgame, said the explosion caused her house to shake. Her first thought was that lightning had hit her home. \u201cThere was a huge boom,\u201d Ms. Goodgame said.\n\n\n\nMoments later, dozens of police cars, ambulances and fire trucks swarmed her street, Ms. May said. Police officers ordered neighbors \u2014 who had come outside to see what happened \u2014 to return to their homes, she said.\n\nInvestigators from the F.B.I. and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives also responded to the neighborhood known as Travis Country, which is about five miles southwest of downtown Austin and in a different area from the three previous explosions. Bomb technicians with the A.T.F. were conducting a secondary sweep, officials said.\n\nBecause the device exploded after nightfall, the chief said, the police could not fully inspect the scene and would have to wait until sunrise on Monday to better examine it. It was not immediately clear if Sunday\u2019s explosion was directly connected to the three previous bombings.", "title": "4th Explosion in Austin Only Hours After Televised Appeal to Bomber", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "When 1976 began, the British weekly New Musical Express (NME) was still putting Bad Company and Small Faces on its cover. That fall, the publication inched into the world of punk with two Sex Pistols issues \u2014 placing Rod Stewart in between, just to be cautious \u2014 and discovered its niche: hyping a colorful rock band, preferably British, ideally male, and even if it wasn\u2019t very good. If the photos were fun and the quotes were provocative, who cared? There would always be another issue in six days.\n\nOn Wednesday, however, its publisher, Time Inc. U.K., announced the physical version of the publication\u2019s demise: The print edition that arrives on Friday will be the NME\u2019s last; it will continue to publish online.\n\nThe NME, which was founded in 1952, remained committed until the end to creating its own self-defined galaxy of stars. Some of the bands it championed thrived (the Libertines), and others didn\u2019t (also the Libertines). Some are mostly forgotten \u2014 unless you, alone among your friends, remember Gay Dad. A former NME writer looks back at five of its favorite acts:\n\nOasis", "title": "5 Bands the NME Lovingly, Relentlessly Championed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019re considering a getaway to Mexico, plan your trip before May to get the most for your money, according to Zachary Rabinor, founder and chief executive of Journey Mexico.\n\n\u201cMexico is coming off its peak tourist season, and hotels, tour operators and restaurants lower prices to bring in more business,\u201d Mr. Rabinor said. Besides value, he said that travelers can expect still tolerable temperatures before the heat of summer sets in.\n\nSo whether you\u2019re interested in a sun and sand vacation, a culture-heavy trip or one that includes gastronomy, a spring trip to Mexico is possible without breaking the bank.\n\nAncient Ruins and Waterfalls on the Mayan Trail\n\nMayan Trail from G Adventures is an 11-day trip that begins in Playa del Carmen and ends with a few days in Guatemala. Travelers get guided tours of the ancient Mayan civilization Chich\u00e9n Itz\u00e1, M\u00e9rida, the capital of the Yucat\u00e1n State, and San Cristobal de Las Casas, known for its colonial architecture.", "title": "5 Beautiful Mexican Getaways to Take This Spring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Each week we email readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nHi, everyone! I\u2019m Will Dudding, a friend of Smarter Living and the owner of an elderly golden retriever. I\u2019m here to talk about a few things every new pet owner needs, in collaboration with Wirecutter, a New York Times company that reviews and recommends products.\n\nBeyond the leash, collar, bed and crate, plenty of universal items are not as obvious to a first-time owner. Here are five cheap(ish) accessories that will help you make the most out of your new relationship.\n\nSpill-proof water bowl\n\nIf you\u2019ve ever witnessed a thirsty dog collide with a bowl of water on a hot summer day, you and your floor can both appreciate this essential item. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nWhen was the last time you just sat around and played? You know, turned your phone on Do Not Disturb mode and goofed around for an hour or two like when you were a kid?\n\nIf you can\u2019t remember, it\u2019s time to relive the old days.\n\nResearchers have found that playtime for grown-ups can increase productivity at work, serve as a therapeutic outlet and enhance your overall well-being. Further, playing can even counteract the effects of stress, decreasing inflammation and possibly improving vascular health.\n\nThough it sounds kind of silly, all play really means is engaging in an activity you find pleasure in, something that is deliberately unserious that allows you to disengage from the stress of real life for a while.", "title": "5 Cheap(ish) Things That Will Keep You Entertained for Hours", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Baking sheet\n\nA sheet pan is a pretty useful kitchen tool, and you probably already own one. But it might be time for an upgrade. You want a cookie sheet that\u2019s thick and sturdy enough to give you an even bake. If yours is too warped to sit flat in your oven, or so thin that the bottom of your cookies are constantly burning, consider getting a replacement.\n\nI like a rimmed sheet that will also work for roasting veggies or throwing together a quick sheet-pan supper, and Wirecutter\u2019s pick, the Nordic Ware Baker\u2019s Half Sheet, fits the bill. But if you\u2019re looking for a more traditional rimless cookie sheet, Wirecutter also likes the Vollrath Wear-Ever Cookie Sheet.\n\nMeasuring tools\n\nBaking demands precision, so bakers need measuring tools they can trust. I have taken this principle to the extreme and now bring my own measuring spoons and cups to other people\u2019s kitchens. Your mileage may vary.\n\nWirecutter\u2019s pick for measuring spoons, the Prepworks by Progressive Magnetic Measuring Spoons, are the ones I carry into the homes of others. You also might want measuring cups, so consider these KitchenMade stainless steel ones.\n\nKitchen scale\n\nKitchen scales are the only way to achieve truly consistent baking results. Flour has a notoriously variable weight-to-volume ratio, and that can throw off your finished product. Wirecutter likes the Escali Primo digital scale.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Variety is the spice of life, they say, and by that rule this series is basically sriracha. Each installment of the bimonthly stand-up show features a new lineup, and each installment\u2019s proceeds go to a different charity, too. This time, Aparna Nancherla, Chloe Hilliard and Christi Chiello are on the bill, and She Should Run, a nonprofit that supports women running for office, will benefit.\n\n212-255-5438, theduplex.com\n\nDAF COMEDY FESTIVAL at Caveat (March 30, 8 p.m. and 10 p.m.; March 31, 6 p.m., 8 p.m. and 10 p.m.). This weekend-long event is the comedy equivalent of the word \u201cwoke.\u201d Milly Tamarez, Mamadou N\u2019Diaye and Tiara Francis host this festival, which is billed as one that highlights the \u201cunderrepresented voices in society by creating a safe and supportive space for expression.\u201d The focus is on welcoming people of all races, sexual orientations, religions, abilities and ages to promote the vast diversity in the comedy sphere. The extensive list of performers includes Astronomy Club, Nore Davis, Keisha Zollar, Marcia Belsky and many others.\n\n212-228-2100, caveat.nyc\n\n\u2018THE FORMER TRUMP STAFF SHOW\u2019 at Upright Citizens Brigade Theater Hell\u2019s Kitchen (March 31, 11:59 p.m.). Anthony Scaramucci (played by Andrew Kimler) and Omarosa Manigault (played by Keisha Zollar) host this show, which is populated by the growing list of former Trump staffers. Will Sean Spicer show up, fistfuls of cinnamon gum in tow? Find out.\n\n212-366-9176, hellskitchen.ucbtheatre.com\n\n\u2018NANETTE\u2019 at SoHo Playhouse (through May 13). After winning a number of coveted awards at Edinburgh Festival Fringe and the Melbourne Comedy Festival, Hannah Gadsby has finally brought her one-woman show, \u201cNanette,\u201d to New York for a run that was recently extended. In what The Times described as a \u201criveting\u201d debut, the 40-year-old Australian comic takes on individuals like Louis C.K., Harvey Weinstein, Bill Clinton and Pablo Picasso, while also zeroing in on the broader culture that enables and excuses abuse. Doesn\u2019t sound funny, perhaps, but trust us: Ms. Gadsby is.\n\n212-691-1555, sohoplayhouse.com\n\n\u2018SIDE PONYTAIL\u2019 at Friends and Lovers (March 31 and April 2, 8 p.m.).
