For 40 years, Ms. Comfort has made compelling dance dramas that investigate timely issues while experimenting with ingredients like spoken text and polyrhythms. She celebrates this impressive anniversary with a retrospective that samples from her large repertory, featuring a vast cast of former and current company dancers. Among the works that will be performed are \u201cFour Screaming Women\u201d (1982), which combines speedy gestures and words; \u201cFaith Healing\u201d (1993), a nontraditional take on \u201cThe Glass Menagerie\u201d; and an updated version of the 2016 work \u201cAmazing Grace,\u201d with sign language and a speech by Donald Trump.\n\n212-475-7710, lamama.org\n\nDANCE THEATER OF HARLEM at City Center (April 4, 7 p.m., through April 7). In 1974, the celebrated performer and choreographer Geoffrey Holder created \u201cDougla,\u201d a dance inspired by indigenous wedding rituals in his native Trinidad. The welcome revival of that majestic work is the highlight of Dance Theater of Harlem\u2019s short spring season, which begins with a gala on April 4 that also includes works by Dianne McIntyre, Robert Garland and Marius Petipa. Three additional performances feature \u201cDougla\u201d as well as ballets by George Balanchine and Christopher Wheeldon, plus the New York premiere of Darrell Grand Moultrie\u2019s \u201cHarlem on My Mind,\u201d set to the music of jazz greats.\n\n212-581-1212, nycitycenter.org", "title": "5 Dance Performances to See in NYC in the Week Ahead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Such gatherings involved no educational presentation, and attendance sign-in sheets were often forged to include the names of health care practitioners who were not actually present, the authorities said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThese prominent doctors swore a solemn oath to place their patients\u2019 care above all else,\u201d said Geoffrey S. Berman, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. \u201cInstead, they engaged in a malignant scheme to prescribe fentanyl, a dangerous and potentially fatal narcotic 50 to 100 times more potent than morphine, in exchange for bribes in the form of speaker fees.\u201d\n\nMr. Berman announced the charges along with William F. Sweeney Jr., the head of the F.B.I.\u2019s New York office. The four other doctors charged in the New York case are Jeffrey Goldstein of New Rochelle, N.Y.; Todd Schlifstein of New York City; Dialecti Voudouris of New York City; and Alexandru Burducea of Little Neck, N.Y.\n\nAll five defendants pleaded not guilty in federal court on Friday afternoon and were released on $200,000 bond. None of the five responded to reporters\u2019 requests for comment as they left the courtroom.\n\nMr. Berman\u2019s office also disclosed that two former Insys employees \u2014 Jonathan Roper and Fernando Serrano \u2014 had pleaded guilty and were cooperating with the federal investigation.\n\nInsys, which is based in Arizona, has come under intense scrutiny over its aggressive marketing of Subsys, a form of fentanyl approved in 2012. Subsys is sprayed under the tongue and approved for use only in patients who have cancer and who experience pain even though they are already on round-the-clock painkillers.\n\nFentanyl can be deadly if it is prescribed in large doses to someone who has not already become tolerant to opioids, yet the drug has been widely sold to a variety of patients. An analysis in 2014 for The New York Times by the research firm Symphony Health, for example, found that just 1 percent of prescriptions for Subsys were from oncologists.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlready, the federal authorities in Boston have brought charges against Insys\u2019s founder and former chief executive, John Kapoor, as well as against several other top executives and sales managers. They have all pleaded not guilty.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe New York indictment offers further evidence that investigators have broadened their inquiry into doctors who were prescribing the drug to patients. Earlier this month, another top prescriber, Jerrold Rosenberg of Rhode Island, was sentenced to more than four years in prison after admitting he took kickbacks from Insys.\n\nThe company did not respond to a request for comment on Friday.\n\nThe indictment unsealed on Friday charged that the drug firm had used its speakers program \"to induce a select group of practitioners,\u201d including the five doctors charged in New York, to prescribe large volumes of the fentanyl spray. The selected doctors were often referred to within the company as \u201ctop docs,\u201d the indictment said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe company\u2019s executives meticulously \u201ctracked and circulated statistics for each speaker,\u201d the indictment noted.\n\nIt also said Mr. Roper, then the district sales manager for a territory that included Manhattan, emailed sales representatives, reminding them to repeatedly tell their speakers of \u201cone simple guideline\u201d \u2014 if they did not write prescriptions, there would be no speaking engagements. As he put it, according to the indictment: \u201cNO SCRIPTS. NO PROGRAMS.\u201d\n\nOne of the defendants, Dr. Goldstein, sometimes did not even stay for a meal at the programs where he was the featured speaker, instead ordering food from the restaurant and leaving with it, according to the indictment.\n\nBefore one program in 2014, the indictment added, Dr. Goldstein wrote to an Insys sales representative, asking, \u201cIs dinner take out or we expecting peeps?\u201d", "title": "5 Doctors Are Charged With Taking Kickbacks for Fentanyl Prescriptions", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser", "Katie Thomas"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.\n\nCANADA NOW at IFC Center (through March 25). As usual, this annual series of recent cinema from our neighbor to the north imports some titles that screened at September\u2019s Toronto International Film Festival. \u201cBlack Cop\u201d (on Saturday), starring Ronnie Rowe Jr. as a police officer who faces discrimination and profiling in Halifax, offers a blunt look at Canadian race relations. \u201cMary Goes Round\u201d (on Sunday) features Aya Cash as an addiction treatment counselor who has a drinking problem of her own.\n\n212-924-7771, ifccenter.com\n\n\u2018CHARADE\u2019 at Nitehawk Cinema (March 24-25, 11:15 a.m.). To honor the French couturier Hubert de Givenchy, who died this month, Nitehawk Cinema is hosting two brunch-time screenings of Stanley Donen\u2019s \u201cCharade,\u201d for which Mr. de Givenchy designed Audrey Hepburn\u2019s gowns. It\u2019s a pretty glamorous get-up for her character, a translator whose husband has just been murdered, but this splashy, pseudo-Hitchcockian mystery \u2014 with memorable turns by Cary Grant, Walter Matthau, James Coburn and George Kennedy and a lively Henry Mancini score \u2014 zips along too amiably and fashionably for such pedestrian plausibility concerns.\n\n718-782-8370, nitehawkcinema.com\n\nCINEVARDAUTOPIA: THE FILMS OF AGN\u00c8S VARDA, PART 1 at the Museum of the Moving Image (March 24-April 1). Even if she went home without an Oscar for the documentary \u201cFaces Places,\u201d the 89-year-old Ms. Varda (and the cardboard cutout that stood in her place at the nominees luncheon) was a delight on the awards circuit. \u201cFaces Places,\u201d directed with the artist JR, was her most recent work in a filmmaking career that has spanned more than six decades. The museum\u2019s series \u2014 the first part of a planned recurring retrospective \u2014 opens with \u201cVagabond\u201d (on Saturday and Sunday), a dramatic feature that reconstructs the journey of a French drifter (Sandrine Bonnaire), who, at the film\u2019s start, is found frozen to death.\n\n718-784-0077, movingimage.us\n\nFOROUGH FARROKHZAD ON FILM at Anthology Film Archives (March 23-24, 7:30 p.m.). Anthology honors the Iranian poet Forough Farrokhzad (1935-67) with a double bill of two Persian cinema classics. \u201cThe House Is Black,\u201d Ms. Farrokhzad\u2019s own 21-minute documentary, shot at a leper colony, will screen with \u201cThe Wind Will Carry Us,\u201d Abbas Kiarostami\u2019s 2000 portrait of a production crew\u2019s disruptive arrival in a remote Kurdish village. Ms. Farrokhzad\u2019s poetry is read aloud in the film.\n\n212-505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org\n\nTERENCE STAMP at the Metrograph (March 23-April 1). Many actors grow up onscreen, but Mr. Stamp actually had an early role recycled. In \u201cThe Limey\u201d (on March 31 and April 1), from 1999, he plays Wilson, a laconic criminal who travels from London to Los Angeles to avenge his daughter\u2019s death. The director, Steven Soderbergh, repurposed scenes from Ken Loach\u2019s \u201cPoor Cow\u201d (1968) to suggest Wilson\u2019s younger days. But \u201cPoor Cow\u201d (on Saturday), featuring Mr. Stamp as a good-hearted thief who briefly offers the prospect of happiness for the wife (Carol White) of an imprisoned colleague, is worth seeing on its own; it may come as a surprise to viewers who know only Mr. Loach\u2019s more didactic recent portraits of Britain\u2019s working class. Those craving a more cryptic version of Mr. Stamp can catch him in Pier Paolo Pasolini\u2019s influential \u201cTeorema\u201d (on March 31 and April 1) as an interloper who upends a wealthy household in Milan.\n\n212-660-0312, metrograph.com", "title": "5 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Summer Update on Plaid\n\nPlaid so dominated the fall and winter runways that it may not surprise you that designers weren\u2019t quite ready to let it go. But if the winter plaids were all grays, navies and burgundies, summer plaids, particularly this season, are an explosion of pinks, blues and yellows.\n\nZucca cotton-cupro blend patchwork dress, $710 at La Gar\u00e7onne, lagarconne.com; Rosie Assoulin viscose trousers, $995 at Kirna Zab\u00eate, kirnazabete.com; J. Crew mid-heel gingham mules, $138 at J. Crew, jcrew.com.", "title": "5 Fresh Prints to Wear Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Here is what to watch for.\n\nTrump as Saccone\u2019s Running Mate\n\nMr. Saccone has staked his candidacy on his support for the president, presenting himself as a sure-thing vote for the White House agenda. Mr. Trump, who won the district by about 20 percentage points, campaigned personally for Mr. Saccone, as did Vice President Mike Pence and Kellyanne Conway, a top presidential aide.\n\n\u201cRick is going to vote for us all the time,\u201d Mr. Trump said at a weekend rally, where he called Mr. Saccone\u2019s rival \u201cLamb the Sham.\u201d\n\nBut polling has shown Mr. Trump\u2019s political appeal receding in the district, and a Monmouth University poll published on Monday found that his approval rating there was 49 percent \u2014 identical to his disapproval rating.\n\nMr. Lamb may also benefit from the Democratic enthusiasm seen in special elections since Mr. Trump\u2019s victory, as angry voters on the left turn out to send a message of opposition to the president.\n\nIf Mr. Trump cannot deliver victory for Republicans in a district like this one, there may be few places for him to campaign helpfully in the fall. During a long and unfocused speech on Saturday night, Mr. Trump appeared aware of the personal stakes. \u201cI hate to put this pressure on you, Rick,\u201d he said. \u201cThey are all watching because I won this district, like by 22 points.\u201d\n\n[Read about why The Times decided to bring back \u201cThe Needle\u201d]\n\nPhoto\n\nLamb\u2019s Pelosi Playbook\n\nRepublicans have battered Mr. Lamb with a familiar set of attacks meant to disqualify him with conservative-leaning voters. Most of all, they have tried to tie him to Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, who is intensely unpopular in districts like this one. Should Mr. Saccone prevail, it could be a testament to the enduring power of an attack Republicans have deployed every two years for a decade.\n\nBut Mr. Lamb has said that he would not support Ms. Pelosi for speaker of the House \u2014 and if he wins, other Democrats in Trump country might feel free to make the same pledge. When Republicans began airing Pelosi-themed ads, Mr. Lamb responded with a blunt commercial of his own. \u201cI\u2019ve already said on the front page of the newspaper that I don\u2019t support Nancy Pelosi,\u201d Mr. Lamb said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lamb has broken with the national Democratic Party in other ways, too, declining to support new gun regulations and downplaying his disagreements with Mr. Trump. If that approach works, it would probably embolden other moderate Democrats to go their own way in deep-red areas, and perhaps encourage candidates across the board to distance themselves from Ms. Pelosi as a partisan lightning rod.\n\nTwo Americas in One District\n\nWhile it was historically steel-and-coal country, this district, like much of greater Pittsburgh, is more complex than the caricature drawn from its hard-hat past. Part of the reason this race has become so competitive is that the district includes affluent enclaves, like Upper St. Clair and Mt. Lebanon, that have previously gone Republican but are now uneasy with Mr. Trump, as voters are in other upscale suburbs across the country.\n\nThese communities, home to a swath of Pittsburgh\u2019s professional class and more than a few of the city\u2019s professional athletes and coaches, will have to vote overwhelmingly for Mr. Lamb if he is to have a chance to win. He will need those votes to offset the more rural and Republican-leaning parts of the district, in the counties on the West Virginia border and in areas closer to Johnstown, Pa. This terrain is more unambiguously Trump country, and more closely resembles the western Pennsylvania conjured by the film \u201cThe Deer Hunter.\u201d\n\nThe district is not going to be around much longer. The state Supreme Court threw out the state\u2019s current congressional map as an unfair partisan gerrymander, and issued a new map last month with very different district boundaries. Whoever wins on Tuesday will have to decide soon which new district to run in for the next election in November.\n\nThe Role of Unions\n\nMr. Trump would not have carried Pennsylvania and other parts of the industrial Midwest in 2016 had it not been for the support he drew from rank-and-file union members.\n\nTo try to lure many of those Trump voters, Mr. Lamb has highlighted his military service, voiced support for the president\u2019s steel tariffs, and generally done all he could to avoid the liberal label.\n\nIt was not by happenstance that Mr. Biden, with his ties to organized labor, was the only major national Democrat with whom he campaigned. Laying hands on Mr. Lamb at a union carpenter\u2019s facility recently, Mr. Biden offered a succinct bit of testimony: \u201cHe is not afraid to say the word \u2018union.\u2019 \u201d\n\nIf Mr. Lamb prevails, it will probably be in large measure because he recaptured some of the unionized workers who have been drifting away from the Democrats. And Republicans know it: As part of their final push in the race, the leading House Republican \u201csuper PAC\u201d created a digital ad made to look like a cable television news report portraying Mr. Lamb as supposedly reaching a \u201cboiling point\u201d with labor unions. The headline on the screen says \u201cDemocrat Abandons PA Unions,\u201d as the ad makes note of Mr. Lamb saying he opposes raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Onslaught of Money\n\nIf Mr. Saccone wins, it will probably be because of the district\u2019s Republican lean and the torrent of money from outside conservative groups, an extraordinary investment to protect a safe seat even if it were not being redistricted out of existence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe spending has illustrated both the advantages the political right enjoys and the challenges it faces in the midterm elections.\n\nRepublicans can rely on a constellation of well-financed outside organizations to step in, as they did in this race, when their candidate is unable to match a Democratic opponent\u2019s fund-raising.\n\nBut the groups\u2019 attempts to derail Mr. Lamb\u2019s campaign have also demonstrated how difficult it is for Republicans to find an effective message. Though they have attacked Mr. Lamb on issues ranging from taxes to immigration to his record as a prosecutor, the race has remained competitive.", "title": "5 Key Factors in Pennsylvania\u2019s Special House Election", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin", "Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWe\u2019re thinking big this week: big business, big bureaucracy, big social structures and the place of the individual therein. It\u2019s not always a pretty picture: In T. Christian Miller and Ken Armstrong\u2019s riveting book \u201cA False Report,\u201d an overburdened criminal justice system pressures a rape victim into recanting her story, while in \u201cWe the Corporations,\u201d Adam Winkler pulls the curtain on two centuries of corporate efforts to benefit from political and legal maneuverings. Other books are more hopeful: Jesse Ball\u2019s novel \u201cCensus\u201d may tell the story of a functionary volunteering to carry out a mysterious government project, but at heart it remains a tender exploration of a poignant father-son relationship. And while Dara Horn\u2019s novel \u201cEternal Life\u201d takes organized religion as one theme\u2014 it unfolds against the backdrop of 2,000 years of Jewish history \u2014 it also features a heroine who comes to understand, through love, why everyone around her clings so hard to life.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nCENSUS, by Jesse Ball. (Ecco, $25.99.) In Jesse Ball\u2019s new novel, full of the author\u2019s signature surreal flourishes, a father learns he has a fatal disease and decides to travel across the country with his young son, who has Down syndrome. The book was inspired by Ball\u2019s relationship with his brother, Abram, who had Down syndrome and died at 24 in 1998. \u201cAs a boy, Ball expected that he would grow up to look after his brother, a possibility that brought him anxiety but also quiet contentment. He never had that opportunity,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes, \u201cbut in \u2018Census,\u2019 they are reunited, in a way, as father and son.\u201d\n\nBEHEMOTH: A History of the Factory and the Making of the Modern World, by Joshua B. Freeman. (Norton, $27.95.) In this rich and ambitious history, Joshua B. Freeman depicts a world in retreat that still looms large in the national imagination. He traces the rise of the factory and how it became entwined with Enlightenment ideas of progress. \u201cNow that factory work and stable, blue-collar jobs are such potent sources of nostalgia,\u201d our critic Jennifer Szalai writes, \u201cit can be hard to recall how truly disruptive the manufacturing age was. Freeman does a superb job of reminding us.\u201d\n\nA FALSE REPORT: A True Story of Rape in America, by T. Christian Miller and Ken Armstrong. (Crown, $28.) This is the \u201cJohn Grisham-worthy\u201d true-life account of a rape investigation in which the victim was bullied into recanting her story before evidence surfaced, years later, to prove she was telling the truth all along. \u201cMiller and Armstrong tell their story plainly, expertly and well,\u201d Emily Bazelon writes in her review. \u201cIt\u2019s gripping and needs no dressing up.\u201d Bazelon adds that the case\u2019s resolution helped the victim get on with an interrupted life. \u201cThat\u2019s the larger lesson of a nonfiction narrative like this one,\u201d she writes: \u201cIt continues, beyond a book\u2019s pages.\u201d\n\nWE THE CORPORATIONS: How American Businesses Won Their Civil Rights, by Adam Winkler. (Liveright, $28.95.) A law professor argues that corporations have been inseparable from American culture and government since the nation\u2019s founding \u2014 often to the detriment of individual citizens \u2014 and traces methodical corporate efforts throughout American history and case law to expand the rights and very definition of corporations, with the result, he writes, that today they have \u201cnearly all the same rights as individuals.\u201d Reviewing the book, Zephyr Teachout says it \u201cprovides a masterful retrospective map at a time when people are feeling bewildered and enraged by growing corporate power.\u201d\n\nETERNAL LIFE, by Dara Horn. (Norton, $25.95.) What are the downsides of living forever? Horn explores this idea through the story of Rachel, who has been alive for 2,000 years and is getting a little tired of it. \u201cThe hard part isn\u2019t living forever,\u201d she says. \u201cIt\u2019s making life worth living.\u201d The origins of Rachel\u2019s predicament date back to the days of the Roman occupation of Jerusalem, meaning that Jewish history and the lives of the characters are intertwined \u2014 \u201cas is often the case in Horn\u2019s fiction,\u201d our reviewer, Joshua Max Feldman, notes. \u201cThe question at the heart of this wise and appealing novel is finally not how Rachel finds meaning in her eternal life,\u201d he concludes. \u201cIt is how we, despite our portions of sorrow, tedium and disaster, persist in finding meaning in ours.\u201d", "title": "5 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 Tim Bourne, an auctioneer and watch specialist who previously held senior roles at Sotheby\u2019s and Christie\u2019s, joined Bonhams in late February as the international director of watches for Asia.\n\nMr. Bourne\u2019s appointment comes as the auction house focuses more on the American market, and as Sotheby\u2019s hires new talent in an effort to challenge Phillips\u2019s dominance in watch auctions.\n\nAt the Bonhams gallery in Hong Kong, he talked about the company\u2019s strategic priorities in Asia. The interview has been condensed and edited.\n\nMatthew Girling, the global chief executive of Bonhams, is a jewelry specialist \u2014 and the house is not known for watches. Is your appointment an effort to move that needle?\n\nI think so, yes. I have known Matthew for quite a few years on a professional basis, so it was good to speak with him and then have the opportunity to come to Bonhams. My field is watches, and I\u2019ve been in this field for 20 years \u2014 so it was quite nice to come back to Hong Kong. Back in 1997 was the first time that I came over, obviously with another auction house. I\u2019ve been in England for three years, and it\u2019s nice to come back to where I sort of built my reputation.\n\nMr. Girling moved to New York from London recently to focus on the American market. What are the strategic implications of your appointment here in Hong Kong?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBonhams is well connected logistically \u2014 it has quite a lot of offices within the United States; it has its finger in many different pies \u2014 so all of those need coordinating in the right way. And I think Matthew, as the C.E.O., has gone over to make sure it\u2019s coordinated in the best possible way and to drive increased business and profitability for the company. Over here, my role is limited to watches as such. But I have experience within the art business, and if I can help with the profile of Bonhams in Asia, then I will do that. And I think watches is one medium that\u2019s very good because they connect with so many different people.\n\nAre there regional trends that you\u2019re following or trying to anticipate?\n\nThe other houses have a goal of going online, which is good in some ways: It cuts out a lot of costs involved in auctions. But you are missing out on that connectivity with the clientele. It becomes very much more of a synthetic type of relationship; it\u2019s a name, and a body, but it\u2019s not somebody that you know. You have an address, and they buy, and off you go. So I think that those relationships, perhaps, are being lost.\n\nAre there pockets of Asia that you\u2019re watching, or markets that you find interesting?\n\nIt will be interesting to see the development of places like Vietnam. I quite like following Southeast Asian paintings, and I\u2019ve noticed that now the sales are incorporating artists from Myanmar and places like that. So it\u2019s interesting to see whether, in these countries, there may be pockets of collectors sprouting up. They\u2019re all developing wealth in their own particular ways.\n\nIs that a loaner you\u2019re wearing on your wrist?\n\nNo, this is a Rolex Explorer II that\u2019s been with me for years. It\u2019s been the most reliable watch that I\u2019ve ever had.", "title": "5 Questions for Bonhams\u2019 New Head of Watches, Asia", "authors": ["Mike Ives"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMarch may be the month of the mega-musical on Broadway, what with ticket buyers already queuing for the imminent openings of \u201cFrozen\u201d and \u201cMargaritaville.\u201d But the shows listed here are of a less escapist stripe. That is not to say that they aren\u2019t every bit as tantalizing as the wayward adventures of hard-partying tequila drinkers and snow princesses learning to \u201clet it go.\u201d Among this more provocative group are a portrait of immigrant women in New York, a South African protest play, a searing study of infertility and star-stuffed new incarnations of two towering modern American classics, \u201cAngels in America\u201d and \u201cThree Tall Women.\u201d\n\n\u2018queens\u2019\n\nThe playwright Martyna Majok has a gift for crawling under the skins of characters who feel marginalized in Donald J. Trump\u2019s America. But as was demonstrated last year by her acclaimed \u201cCost of Living,\u201d a cleareyed portrait of two prickly souls with severe physical disabilities, Ms. Majok doesn\u2019t host pity parties. In \u201cqueens,\u201d a Lincoln Center/LCT3 production, she applies her distinctively poetic brand of empathy to the shifting values and aspirations of two generations of immigrant women, who clash and commune in a basement apartment in the New York borough of the title. Danya Taymor directs.\n\nTickets: lct.org/shows/queens\n\n\u2018The Fall\u2019\n\nThe bold title of this docudrama from South Africa\u2019s celebrated Baxter Theater Center, imported by St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse, vibrates with implications \u2014 cosmic, historical, existential. Specifically, though, it refers to the toppling of a statue. Using the hashtag #RhodesMustFall, a group of Cape Town University students led a successful campaign to rid their campus of a bronze effigy of Cecil Rhodes, a British imperialist and Cape Colony prime minister of the late 19th century. Devised by its ensemble members, many of whom had worked on the campaign, this show becomes an animated, protest-driven debate on the legacy of apartheid and colonialism in the South African educational system.\n\nTickets: stannswarehouse.org\n\n\u2018Angels in America\u2019\n\nA quarter of a century after it first knocked Broadway on its ear, Tony Kushner\u2019s era-defining \u201cgay fantasia\u201d about love and loss in the time of AIDS returns in this appropriately epic production from London\u2019s National Theater. Marianne Elliott (\u201cWar Horse\u201d) directs a cast that includes Andrew Garfield (as the drag queen who speaks with angels), Denise Gough (as a pharmaceutically numbed Mormon, at sea in New York and the Antarctic) and, in one of the season\u2019s most anticipated marriages of an actor and a role, Nathan Lane (as the closeted super-lawyer Roy Cohn). This landmark work should initiate plenty of heated conversation about gay identity, political engagement, bad faith and the role of theater itself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTickets: angelsbroadway.com\n\n\u2018Yerma\u2019\n\nThe iconoclastic Australian director and playwright Simon Stone reimagines the epochal Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garc\u00eda Lorca\u2019s 1934 drama as a contemporary tale of one woman\u2019s agonized attempts to conceive a child. The woman is portrayed by Billie Piper with a raw, committed fury that left London critics shocked, awed and rapturous when it opened at the Young Vic in 2016. Ms. Piper won the Olivier Award for her viscerally intense performance. Let\u2019s hope she\u2019s had plenty of time to rest before this production\u2019s New York debut at the Park Avenue Armory.\n\nTickets: armoryonpark.org\n\n\u2018Three Tall Women\u2019\n\nThe play that revitalized Edward Albee\u2019s reputation \u2014 and netted him his third Pulitzer Prize for Drama \u2014 when it was staged Off Broadway in 1994 is only now making its Broadway debut. For such a grand occasion, this production, directed by Joe Mantello, has been packed with star power to burn. Embodying the intimidating trio of the title, all variations on Albee\u2019s own adoptive mother, are Laurie Metcalf, Alison Pill and, in her first Broadway performance in three decades, the great Glenda Jackson.", "title": "5 Shows to See if You\u2019re in New York: \u2018Angels in America,\u2019 \u2018The Fall\u2019 and More", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cApril cried and stepped aside\u201d: So goes one of Oscar Hammerstein\u2019s lovely lyrics for \u201cCarousel.\u201d But apparently Broadway doesn\u2019t listen.\n\nInstead, every April, the theater district reaches a noisy climax as the season crashes into the Tony Awards eligibility deadline. This year, nine shows open between the 8th and the 26th, all of them would-be prize magnets. You probably already know a lot of the titles: Tina Fey\u2019s musicalized \u201cMean Girls,\u201d the two-part \u201cHarry Potter and the Cursed Child\u201d and dueling Golden Age revivals of \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d and, yes, \u201cCarousel.\u201d\n\nIf you\u2019ve got 15 hours and half a grand (or more) to spare, see \u2019em all.\n\nBut you might want to consider some less-buzzy titles, both on and Off Broadway, that are also, as Hammerstein wrote of May, \u201cfull of promises.\u201d\n\n\u2018Children of a Lesser God\u2019\n\nMark Medoff\u2019s drama about the relationship between a smug speech therapist and the pugnacious woman he\u2019s trying to teach is difficult to cast. Not so much because the woman, Sarah, is deaf; there are many excellent deaf actors. But she must also be young and ferocious and profoundly charismatic, which are the right words to describe Lauren Ridloff, a former Miss Deaf America. When I saw her in the Berkshires tryout of the play last summer, I thought she was sensational.", "title": "5 Shows to See in New York: \u2018Children of a Lesser God,\u2019 \u2018Mlima\u2019s Tale\u2019 and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The service at that hotel you just stayed at was so-so. Your friend\u2019s experience at the same property, on the other hand, was spot on. Why the disparity? It may be more than chance.\n\nAccording to Joshua Bush, a hotel industry expert and the chief executive officer of Avenue Two Travel, while good service at a hotel, even a pricey one, isn\u2019t a guarantee, there are a few ways to increase your odds of getting treated well.\n\nSet Realistic Expectations\n\nKeep in mind that most luxury hotels have an ingrained service culture, while budget and mid-tier properties often don\u2019t. \u201cIt\u2019s unreasonable to stay at a three-star property and expect the staff to run around for you because they\u2019re not necessarily trained in providing individualized service,\u201d Mr. Bush said. That doesn\u2019t mean you can\u2019t have a stellar experience at a budget hotel \u2014 you should just be reasonable with your desires and demands before you book.\n\nThe staff at luxury hotels, however, are usually trained in anticipatory service, and the need to please their guests. They may even have a budget to \u201cwow\u201d guests with surprise gifts such as a bottle of their favorite Champagne, complimentary meals or included activities, or other amenities designed to make a stay at a luxury hotel live up to the luxury price tag.", "title": "5 Simple Tips for Getting Stellar Hotel Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "A 200-Year-Old Sushi Counter Arrives in New York\n\nNext Friday, master sushi chef Nozomu Abe (formerly of Sushiden) will open his very first restaurant, Sushi Noz, which will serve traditional omakase on Manhattan\u2019s Upper East Side. Masterminded by the Kyoto-based architecture firm Sankakuya, known for restoring ancient shrines and temples in Japan, the minimalist pale-wood space was constructed exclusively using traditional joinery techniques and centuries-old Japanese timber: hinoki (Japanese cypress) for the eight-person dining room and ash for a smaller six-person private room. The former will also feature a 200-year-old sushi counter that was aged for 40 years in chef Noz\u2019s hometown of Hokkaido.\n\nInside, guests will eat a 17-25 course meal, complete with appetizers, the chef\u2019s choice of sushi and dessert (a sweet tamago dish or seasonal fresh fruit). Originally trained in Tokyo-style Edomae sushi, chef Noz will merge the tradition\u2019s pared-down staples, which focus on the simplicity of the fish and rice, with his own contemporary spin, offering simmered octopus with chickpea paste and nigiri served with boiled Scottish langoustines. \u201cI try not to add or subtract unnecessarily,\u201d Noz says of his approach. The $300-including-gratuity omakase will include seafood flown in from the Tsukiji market in Tokyo, which will be preserved in an Edomae ice chest, a traditional storage container that keeps fish fresh using only blocks of ice. Sushi Noz will be the first restaurant in the United States to have one.\n\n\u201cSo many people have helped us on our way, including many craftsmen in Japan,\u201d chef Noz says of the restaurant, which took four years to conceive and complete alongside his business partners, the restaurateurs Josh and David Foulquier. From the architects to the artisans, the fishermen and farmers, \u201ctheir spirits reside in this restaurant, and it is my job to finally pass their spirits to the diners.\u201d Sushi Noz opens March 30 at 181 East 78th Street, 917-388-1792 \u2014 ALEXIS CHEUNG", "title": "5 Things T Editors Like Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Vases Shaped Like Seashells\n\nThe late Italian design legend Bruno Munari did not think highly of knickknacks: fruit dishes that look like leaves, scissors fashioned after flamingos. \u201cThese are certainly not objects produced by designers,\u201d he wrote in his 1966 book \u201cDesign as Art.\u201d He believed that the form of an item should be \u201cas appropriate as possible to its function.\u201d But in the social media era, practicality often takes a back seat to aesthetics. \u201cFor me, function is not essential,\u201d the contemporary industrial designer Rosa Rubio told T. \u201cI want to create objects that make me happy.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, Rubio founded Los Objetos Decorativos, a Barcelona-based studio that produces objects for the home that are \u201cabstracted from their use.\u201d Inspired by marine fossils, her latest collection consists of whimsical seashell-shaped jewelry boxes, flower vases and totems saturated in dramatic earth tones and Instagram-friendly pastels. \u201cIt\u2019s a contemporary remake of the kinds of souvenirs that we all saw or had at some point in the past,\u201d says the 33-year-old of her sculptural petxines (the Catalan word for \u201cshells\u201d), which are handcrafted by ceramic artisans in her native Valencia. The vases are objects of beauty on their own, but if you also want them to be functional, floral designer Sophia Moreno-Bunge of Los Angeles\u2019s Isa Isa recommends filling them with Iceland poppies and curly allium. $75 to $115, losobjetosdecorativos.tictail.com \u2014 ZIO BARITAUX", "title": "5 Things T Editors Like Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Years later, as Perseus was dying, Mr. Lloyd Webber took the cat for a walk. But by then the traffic system in South Kensington had become dangerously complicated. Perseus hissed at the new traffic lights and turned around back home. The next day he died.\n\nMr. Lloyd Webber wrote that he owes \u201cCats\u201d to two things: his mother\u2019s bedtime reading of T.S. Eliot\u2019s \u201cOld Possum\u2019s Book of Practical Cats,\u201d and Perseus.\n\nHe Owns Part of a Mountain\n\nAs Mr. Lloyd Webber\u2019s career took off, he met an imaginative accountant who persuaded him to buy a mountainside in Wales as part of a \u201csupposedly unbeatable tax efficient forestry scheme.\u201d\n\nCan a tunesmith run a forest? Well, he insisted on planting hardwood rather than baby fir trees, which disrupted the ecosystem and created a sinkhole \u201cof such national importance a large chunk of it had to be roped off.\u201d Then it all burned down.\n\nMr. Lloyd Webber\u2019s tax advice now: \u201cDon\u2019t get into forestry.\u201d\n\nHe Almost Wrote a \u2018Thomas the Tank Engine\u2019\n\nOne of Mr. Lloyd Webber\u2019s favorite books as a child was \u201cThomas the Tank Engine,\u201d which he described as a British \u201cLittle Engine That Could\u201d with the moral that \u201ca properly brung up engine must be Really Useful all the time.\u201d Around the time he was working on \u201cEvita,\u201d Mr. Lloyd Webber decided to make an animated musical TV series of it.\n\nUltimately, though, producers thought \u201cThomas\u201d was too British for an international audience. So nothing happened. Mr. Lloyd Webber relinquished his rights to the show, which then became a worldwide hit narrated by Ringo Starr. But he eventually got his train musical: \u201cStarlight Express.\u201d And the Really Useful Group is now the corporate force behind the Andrew Lloyd Webber empire.\n\nHe Nearly Starred in \u2018Amadeus\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile \u201cCats\u201d was in development, the filmmaker Milos Forman asked Mr. Lloyd Webber to star as Mozart in his movie \u201cAmadeus.\u201d Mr. Lloyd Webber was so shocked, he replied with a burp.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen he learned the offer wasn\u2019t just a passing fancy, a panicked Mr. Lloyd Webber asked Trevor Nunn, the director of \u201cCats,\u201d for an escape plan.\n\nMr. Nunn told him to say he would be honored to accept the role, but then add that he wouldn\u2019t do the movie unless all of Mozart\u2019s music was replaced with his own. (Take a minute to imagine that.)\n\nAt the meeting, Mr. Lloyd Webber played the part of a demanding diva, to which one of the producers replied, \u201cI think we have a deal!\u201d Then Mr. Forman came to the rescue by saying, \u201cI think Andrew is saying he doesn\u2019t want to play the role.\u201d\n\nIn Another Universe, Liza Minnelli Was Evita\n\nPhoto\n\nThe movie adaptation of \u201cEvita\u201d was in the works years before Madonna sang \u201cDon\u2019t Cry For Me Argentina\u201d in Alan Parker\u2019s lavish 1996 version. In its earliest days, the film might have starred Liza Minnelli, whose audition was \u201cremarkable,\u201d Mr. Lloyd Webber wrote.\n\n\u201cUnmasked\u201d is full of what-ifs like this that offer a glimpse into a parallel universe of Mr. Lloyd Webber\u2019s musicals. Bette Midler nearly got her start in \u201cJesus Christ Superstar.\u201d Twyla Tharp could have choreographed \u201cCats,\u201d but she hated the music. Judi Dench was the original Grizabella, before \u201cMemory\u201d was even completed, but she snapped her Achilles\u2019 tendon shortly before previews began.\n\nAnd the Broadway legend Alan Jay Lerner was meant to write lyrics for \u201cThe Phantom of the Opera,\u201d but in 1986, a few days after making plans for work, he was diagnosed with lung cancer. \u201cI will be in touch with you over the summer,\u201d he wrote to Mr. Lloyd Webber, \u201cand I hope with all my heart that one day we will have a chance to work together.\u201d He died that June.", "title": "5 Things We Learned From Andrew Lloyd Webber\u2019s New Memoir", "authors": ["Joshua Barone"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Attacking Trump\u2019s political rivals\n\nIn the run-up to the 2016 presidential election, Mr. Trump was one of 17 candidates who vied to be the Republican candidate, and none of his opponents were safe from ridicule in The Enquirer.\n\nIn October 2015, a headline called Ben Carson a \u201cbungling surgeon.\u201d The article said he had potentially \u201cbutchered one patient\u2019s brain.\u201d A month later, an article called him a \u201cdisgraced doctor\u201d with a \u201cviolent past.\u201d\n\nIn June of that year, an article claimed that Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, had cheated on his wife, citing unnamed reports that linked Mr. Bush to a \u201cPlayboy bunny-turned-lawyer.\u201d\n\nHillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee and a favorite target of Mr. Trump, took the brunt of the scorn. A September 2015 article, using information from \u201csources,\u201d said the \u201cdesperate and deteriorating 67-year-old won\u2019t make it to the White House \u2014 because she\u2019ll be dead in six months.\u201d\n\nIn August 2016, she fired back at Mr. Trump and what she called \u201cfringe media.\u201d Mrs. Clinton said, \u201cThis is what happens when you treat The National Enquirer like gospel.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe 2016 election is over, but the criticism of Mrs. Clinton has continued. In February 2018, an Enquirer cover story claimed she was part of a conspiracy: \u201cObama & Hillary Ordered F.B.I. to Spy on Trump!\u201d\n\nA shared foe: Obama\n\nFor years, Mr. Trump has relentlessly attacked his predecessor, Barack Obama, and The Enquirer is no different.\n\nIn January, an Enquirer headline read, \u201cBarack Obama\u2019s Russian Spy Inside the White House.\u201d\n\nIn February 2017, days after Michael T. Flynn resigned as Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser, the tabloid claimed that Mr. Obama had a secret plot to impeach Mr. Trump. And as recently as March 2017 the tabloid continued to claim that Mr. Obama, who was born in Hawaii, was foreign born, even though Mr. Trump had since let go of the false birther theory that he long promoted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the love, and defense, of Trump\n\nThe National Enquirer and its parent company have not only helped the president by denigrating others, but also repeatedly praised Mr. Trump, his decisions and his character.\n\nIn March 2016, for the first time in its 90 years, The Enquirer endorsed a candidate for president \u2014 Donald J. Trump.\n\nWhile Ms. McDougal and a pornographic-film star, Stephanie Clifford, who is known professionally as Stormy Daniels, have come forward and said they have had affairs with the president, The Enquirer recently ran a favorable cover that blared: \u201cDonald & Melania Fight Back! Exposing the Lies, Leaks & Intimidation. How They\u2019ll Crush Their Enemies!\u201d\n\nSaudi cash and a special edition\n\nMr. Pecker visited the White House in July 2017 and took along with him a special guest, a French businessman who advises one of Saudi Arabia\u2019s richest men. Through an Oval Office visit and at dinner with Mr. Trump, Mr. Pecker showcased his access to the president \u2014 and word got back to Saudi Arabia.\n\nSeveral months later, Mr. Pecker traveled to Saudi Arabia. In January, he sought Saudi investors to help bankroll a possible acquisition of Time magazine, according to two people with direct knowledge of the matter. American Media disputed that. As Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, arrived this month for a tour of the United States, Mr. Pecker\u2019s company published a 97-page magazine about Saudi Arabia that glosses over troubling details about the kingdom.\n\nThere is no mention of the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen, human rights concerns or the crown prince\u2019s arrest last fall of many extended royals.", "title": "5 Times David Pecker and The Enquirer Defended or Championed Trump", "authors": ["Maya Salam", "Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "For those who can\u2019t travel to Rome during off-peak season, Mr. Amorico said that it\u2019s best to stay in hotels in less touristy but still located in well-situated neighborhoods such as Monti, Testaccio and Parioli. The properties in these areas have nightly rates at least 20 percent lower than ones in touristy spots. Or, consider renting a luxury apartment, which can be between 30 and 50 percent less expensive than a luxury hotel. Sites like Access Italy and OneFineStay offer a portfolio of Rome apartment rentals.\n\nDine Smart\n\nStay away from the overpriced, average restaurants situated in Piazza Navona, Pantheon and Campo dei Fiori, Rome\u2019s main squares. You\u2019ll enjoy less expensive and tastier meals and also get more of a local flavor of the city by dining at spots in Monti, especially on Via Urbani, where there are some excellent trattorias. Other areas worth visiting for great local restaurants include Via del Corallo, Piazza del Fico, Via Giulia and Via del Governo Vecchio.\n\nWhen it comes to lunch, Mr. Amorico suggested enjoying a thin-crust pizza (around $10) at a pizzeria or going to a trattoria for a bowl of pasta (around $12) such as his favorite, cacio e pepe. This strategy allows you to save your money for a nice dinner or two with wine in some of Rome\u2019s terrific seafood and fine dining spots. His top recommendations are Assunta Madre for seafood and Ristorante Tullio for classic Italian dishes like cannelloni and Roman-style artichokes.\n\nBook Private Tours on Weekdays\n\nA private guide is a pricey indulgence and worthwhile mainly if you\u2019re interested in learning more about a particular topic, like historic architecture or art. But if you plan to hire one, do it during a weekday. During the week, guides in Rome cost usually around 20 percent less compared with weekends (and during low season, they can be up to 40 percent less).\n\nIf you\u2019re in the city between May and October and want to hire a guide to see the Vatican Museum, do it on a Friday night, when the museum is open late. \u201cA guide will charge a lower price on these Friday nights than during the day because it\u2019s a lot cooler and less crowded,\u201d Mr. Amorico said.", "title": "5 Tips for a Luxury Trip to Rome for Less", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Between the hassle of flying, jet lag and hauling your luggage around, traveling is challenging enough without worrying about looking fashionable while you do it. But Kate Young, a New York-based stylist who counts actresses Margot Robbie and Michelle Williams among her clients, says that it doesn\u2019t take a lot of effort to look stylish on the road.\n\n\u201cAnyone can look chic while traveling, and there\u2019s no need to spend a lot or pack a lot to do it,\u201d Ms. Young said. She noted that she travels several times a month and rarely checks in a bag. Here are her best tips to traveling light and looking good at the same time.\n\nPack Clothes In Three Coordinating Colors\n\nWhen deciding what clothes to pack, choose pieces in three matching colors so you can mix and match each piece to create multiple outfits for different days, or even different occasions. Pick the colors based on where you\u2019re going.\n\nIf you\u2019re headed to Paris or another urban destination, for example, any combination of black, white, navy and charcoal is a good bet. For a beach vacation or outdoors excursion, khaki, off-white (or white) and bright hues like orange or yellow always work. Ms. Young likes white linen in particular because it\u2019s cool in warm weather, can be worn during the day and is also nice for evenings out. And when it comes to the actual articles of clothing to take, Ms. Young said that a pair of jeans, a pair of nice pants, a striped button down, a blazer and a comfortable T-shirt are always good options. \u201cIdeally, you should be wearing each piece two or three times on your trip,\u201d she said. \u201cAnything less is a waste of space.\u201d", "title": "5 Tips to Travel Light and Dress Well at the Same Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Richard Meier, the celebrated architect and Pritzker Prize winner who designed the Getty Center in Los Angeles, established a graduate scholarship in January at his alma mater, Cornell University\u2019s architecture school. Intended to honor the 55th anniversary of his practice, the scholarship was designed to \u201crecruit and retain the most talented women applicants.\u201d\n\nBut four women who have worked for Mr. Meier \u2014 and another who met him when he was working on the Getty \u2014 have described encounters when the architect, now 83, was, in fact, not good to women.\n\nTwo of the women have described incidents over the past 10 years in which they were sent to Mr. Meier\u2019s New York apartment, where he exposed himself, according to interviews with one of the women and several former employees of the firm.\n\nA third woman said in an interview that Mr. Meier grabbed her underwear through her dress at a firm holiday party, and a fourth said he asked her to undress at his apartment so she could be photographed.", "title": "5 Women Accuse the Architect Richard Meier of Sexual Harassment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "POMIGLIANO D\u2019ARCO, Italy \u2014 After leading the anti-establishment Five Star Movement to a stunning result in Italy\u2019s national elections, Luigi Di Maio returned triumphantly to his small hometown near Naples.\n\nThousands of adoring supporters chanted \u201cPres-i-dent\u201d and \u201cLu-i-gi\u201d and gave their local boy a bouquet of yellow flowers. But no one was more ecstatic at his success than his mother, Paola Esposito, who said she was \u201cvery, very proud.\u201d\n\nAnd to think, she added, he was living at home \u201cuntil five years ago.\u201d\n\nNow Mr. Di Maio, 31, a college dropout and former soccer stadium usher, may be first in line to become Italy\u2019s next prime minister after the Five Star Movement won the most votes in the March 4 election.\n\nHis improbable ascent is a measure of Italy\u2019s suddenly turbulent politics. But it also reflects the youthful, new-kid-on-the-block appeal of the Five Star Movement, as well as what critics say is one of its most glaring shortcomings \u2014 a lack of real-world experience.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong his credentials, Gigi, as Mr. Di Maio is often called, was the treasurer of his elementary school class and the president of his high-school student body before he became vice president of the lower house of Parliament at 26, swept along on the coattails of his web-based party.", "title": "5 Years Ago Luigi Di Maio Was Living at Home. Now He May Lead Italy.", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "My guess is that if Martin Luther King Jr. of 1968 were to return to 2018 America, he would be unsurprised by some of what he\u2019d find: the staggering numbers of black men in jail; the recurrent killings of unarmed black youths by police; the emboldened presence of white supremacism. As a leader, he shaped a great humanitarian movement; as a thinker, he came to understand humanism\u2019s deep flaws.\n\nI wonder what he would think about how we engage with the history he helped create. A glance at contemporary art might give him some clues. In 1988, the African-American artist Glenn Ligon took as a subject a foundational civil rights emblem, the \u201cI AM A MAN\u201d strike placard, and did several things to it simultaneously: He replicated it, customized it, and critiqued it.\n\nHe turned it into a painting. In doing so, he paid homage to the mass-printed original; he gave its adamant words a new, queer dimension (Mr. Ligon is gay); and he turned an activist artifact, one that functioned as demand for economic equity, into an elite museum object, its text now done in glossy, light-catching enamel. (The painting is currently on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, in honor of the King anniversary.)\n\nPhoto\n\nOn multiple levels, Mr. Ligon made a piece of civil rights history his own, though attempts by other artists to do something similar have backfired. A recent example is the painting \u201cOpen Casket\u201d by Dana Schutz, in the 2017 Whitney Biennial. The source of the image in this case was also a movement icon: a 1955 post mortem photograph of Emmett Till, a black teenager who, after being accused of whistling at a white woman, was murdered. At his mother\u2019s insistence, Till\u2019s tortured body was put on public view and photographed. The pictures, printed in Jet magazine, are credited with bringing many people into the civil rights movement, among them Dr. King.\n\nAt the Whitney, the painting sparked protests by some black artists who demanded its removal. At issue was that Ms. Schutz is white. Dr. King\u2019s initial vision for the civil rights movement was one of racial harmony; blacks and whites working together to achieve equal lives for all. Possibly in those early days, Ms. Schutz\u2019s painting might have passed as a gesture of solidarity.\n\nBut by 1968, it was clear, even to moderate blacks, that sharing power was not likely to happen. For the Whitney protesters, \u201cOpen Casket\u201d was an emblem of the continuing exercise of white privilege that, in this case, allowed a white-controlled museum and a white artist to lay claim to a sensational image of black pain.\n\nI suspect that the Dr. King of Room 306 would have understood the protesters\u2019 point. In his Nobel Peace Prize acceptance speech, given in 1964, when he was 35, he said that he could not, would not, permit himself to envision a world in which humanity was \u201cso tragically bound to the starless midnight of racism and war that the bright daybreak of peace and brotherhood can never become a reality.\u201d But over the next four years, as Vietnam ground on, civil rights activists met violent ends, and race wars laid waste to American cities, daybreak must have seemed far-off.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo idealists of the 21st century, it may seem that on many social, economic and ethical fronts the country has come to what seems a futureless halt, just as the museum\u2019s civil rights story does. But rather than exit the scene in weariness or frustration, we would do well to go back in time. If we stay alert, we can find instruction there.\n\nThe emphasis of the present-day protest movements is on inclusion: equal salaries, equal education, the right to marry. The goal is to get a share in the system. The civil rights movement began with that goal too, then realized that the system was the problem. Dr. King eventually came to this conviction, and in some ways it made the end of his life hard, complicated and unsettled.\n\nOther people, however, held that view all along, and many of them were women. Sexism was rampant within the movement leadership. Women were expected to make coffee, make nice and stay home. Some, like Ella Baker, a tireless civil rights organizer, refused. True monuments have yet to be raised to enough of these women. One, Fannie Lou Hamer (1917-1977), was a monument herself.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Mississippi Delta field worker, she was jailed and beaten when she tried to register to vote at 46, but went on to run for Congress. Her televised testimony, to determine whether she and her all-black Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party could be seated at the Democratic National Convention, is in the National Civil Rights Museum. Hamer\u2019s unscripted account of her jail experience, with its blunt challenge \u2014 \u201cI question America\u201d \u2014 is overwhelming: dark and incandescent.\n\nIn May 1963, in Birmingham, Ala., Dr. King organized the most brilliant civil disobedience campaigns of his career, when he brought more than a thousand black schoolchildren into the streets to demonstrate against segregation. Hundreds were arrested; others were blasted with fire hoses. When people rebuked Dr. King for putting young people at risk, he said: \u201cDon\u2019t hold them back if they want to go to jail. For they are doing a job not only for themselves, but for all of America and for all mankind.\u201d The world reacted, shamed the city and Birmingham took its first steps toward desegregation.", "title": "50 Years After Dr. King\u2019s Death, New Lessons for Today", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cChronicle of Anna Magdalena Bach,\u201d by Jean-Marie Straub and Dani\u00e8le Huillet, is a recording of magnificent music and a film of equally impressive contradictions. An impossible documentary, at once austere and rhapsodic, it evokes the 18th century while feeling as present as a live concert.\n\nThe movie is being released here on Friday in an excellent new 4K digital restoration on the occasion of its 50th anniversary.\n\nMost simply described, \u201cChronicle\u201d is a feature-length series of recitals, nearly always filmed from a fixed camera in a single, uninterrupted take. The music was recorded from a microphone placed by the camera and the musicians, who play authentic 18th-century instruments and are dressed in clothing from that period. Impressively bewigged, Gustav Leonhardt, the Dutch harpsichordist and conductor, stands in for Bach.\n\nStraub-Huillet, as the couple preferred to be called, are considered among the most rigorous of filmmakers. Their clarity is bracing. Hardly a conventional biopic, \u201cChronicle\u201d was made in the spirit of Robert Bresson\u2019s 1950s adaptation of the Georges Bernanos novel \u201cThe Diary of a Country Priest.\u201d In writing about that film, the critic Andr\u00e9 Bazin said, \u201cthe cast is not being asked to act out a text, or even to live it out, just to speak it.\u201d In \u201cChronicle,\u201d the major text is Bach\u2019s music.", "title": "50 Years On, This Film Still Brings Clarity to Bach\u2019s Glorious Compositions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "But telecommunications companies \u2014 hoping to cash in on what is predicted to be $250 billion in annual service revenue from 5G by 2025 \u2014 are pushing to build the system as quickly and cheaply as possible. And they have the federal government on their side.\n\nThe companies, like Verizon Communications and AT&T, say that the equipment will be safe and unobtrusive, and that it is needed to support future applications like driverless cars. Dotting them throughout neighborhoods is necessary for full coverage, they say, because the new 5G signals do not travel as far as the radio frequencies now in use.\n\nThe new equipment, AT&T told the Federal Communications Commission last year, \u201cwill revolutionize the way consumers and businesses use mobile broadband services, and of the emerging internet of things.\u201d\n\nTo get their way, the telecom firms have lobbyists working state legislatures, advocating laws that restrict local oversight of 5G. Since 2016, 13 states have passed bills that limit local control, and several other states are considering similar laws. Wireless companies are also lobbying Congress, which is considering several bills on the issue.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd the F.C.C., under the leadership of Ajit Pai, its Republican chairman, has strongly encouraged weakening regulations to accelerate the deployment of new 5G technology \u2014 including reducing the role of local governments.\n\nThis week, another Republican F.C.C. commissioner, Brendan Carr, announced details of a plan to streamline the environmental and historic review process for 5G infrastructure, saying it could cut costs by 80 percent. The agency will vote on the measure this month.\n\nMr. Pai and Mr. Carr have said regulatory changes are necessary to keep pace with global competitors. But bringing high-speed service to underserved areas \u2014 closing the digital divide \u2014 has also been one of Mr. Pai\u2019s central arguments for reining in local regulations. The money companies save from fewer regulations, he says, can be used to expand broadband into rural areas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCity officials are not buying it. Mobilitie, one of the nation\u2019s largest cell-tower operators, submitted an unofficial plan in Montgomery County, Md., in the fall, designating where the company might want to place small cells. Of the 215 small-cell sites in that plan, only 11 were in areas with fewer than 1,000 people per square mile.\n\n\u201cIt is deeply disingenuous to suggest that the need to pre-empt urban areas\u2019 ordinances is so we can bring broadband to rural areas,\u201d said Mitsuko R. Herrera, the county\u2019s technology special projects director. \u201cThere is zero evidence to support that premise.\u201d\n\nJason Caliento, a Mobilitie senior vice president, agreed. \u201cSmall cells are a tool in the toolbox, but alone are not going to solve the rural divide,\u201d he said.\n\nIn January, Mayor Sam Liccardo of San Jose, Calif., resigned his seat on an F.C.C. 5G advisory committee, saying it was rigged to give industry what it wanted \u201cwithout any obligation to provide broadband access to underserved residents.\u201d\n\nIn response, Mr. Pai said the F.C.C. looked forward to working with the committee \u201cto remove regulatory barriers to broadband deployment and to extend digital opportunity to all Americans.\u201d\n\nThe wireless industry has filed multiple comments to the F.C.C. complaining about delays from local governments. AT&T executives said officials in California, whom they did not identify, had delayed deployment of small cells by more than 800 days because they \u201cscrutinized\u201d antenna designs, radio-frequency exposure and effects on property values, among other things. Companies have suggested cutting local approval windows by a month or more.\n\nCities and counties argue the delays are caused by the wireless companies themselves. Officials in Montgomery County said Mobilitie had routinely filed incomplete applications that caused months of setbacks.\n\nPhoto\n\nMobilitie officials said their relationship with local governments was \u201cevolving\u201d and leading to better collaboration. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019ve ever seen more progress\u201d than has occurred lately, Mr. Caliento said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCity officials say shortening reviews risks small-cell facilities becoming unsightly and unsafe.\n\nThat is what worries Donna Baron, a 75-year-old retiree who learned a streetlight near her home on DuFief Drive in North Potomac, Md., was marked to become a small cell, as were dozens more nearby. She held up an image of a possible cell station that might replace the light.\n\n\u201cThe pole is a lot rounder, it has boxes on it and a huge fake mailbox at the bottom,\u201d Ms. Baron said. If the F.C.C. pre-empts local rules, \u201cyou\u2019re going to end up with a Medusa, with a bunch more stuff attached.\u201d\n\nWireless companies are also asking the F.C.C. to cap local fees. AT&T says that three California cities assess fees of $2,600 to $8,000 a year per attachment, and that a \u201cGeorgia municipality is considering an annual fee of $6,000 per node.\u201d\n\nDavid Young, who manages infrastructure leases for Lincoln, Neb., said he understood the carriers\u2019 frustration. But he said cities had a responsibility to charge fair rates. He has negotiated with wireless companies to pay $1,995 a year per pole. He set the rate based on market analysis, which he discussed with the companies. \u201cThey were quite happy to pay the price that we asked,\u201d Mr. Young said.\n\nTexas cities can\u2019t negotiate rates. Last year, the State Legislature passed a law pushed by AT&T that allows cities to charge carriers no more than $250 per pole each year. Before the law, cities often charged $1,500 to $2,500 a year per pole, and the change will cost Texas cities as much as $1 billion over eight years, the Texas Municipal League estimated.\n\nAT&T argues that charging fees not based on cost violates the federal Communications Act, which blocks local governments from prohibiting broadband services.\n\nA group of Texas cities led by the city of McAllen, near the Mexico border, filed a lawsuit last year against the state, arguing that the new cell-site law violated the state Constitution, which prohibits the Legislature from forcing cities to grant something of value to corporations.\n\nLawyers representing Texas argue the state has the authority to cap municipalities\u2019 pole rental fees. During oral arguments in December, a judge denied the state\u2019s motion for dismissal, and last month denied the cities\u2019 request for a temporary injunction. The case is expected to go to trial this year.\n\nThe maneuvering in Washington has left people like Marc King, 71, a longtime resident of Germantown, Md., feeling resigned.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA Russian woman stood up to speak at one of these public meetings, and she said that when she lived in Russia, the government slam dunked her and she had no say,\u201d Mr. King said. \u201cNow she lives in the United States of America, where she\u2019s getting slam dunked by the government and she has no say. That gives you a window into what\u2019s going on here.\u201d", "title": "5G Cell Service Is Coming. Who Decides Where It Goes?", "authors": ["Allan Holmes"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nCONTACT! at National Sawdust (April 2, 7:30 p.m.). Esa-Pekka Salonen is doing double duty at the New York Philharmonic this week, in his role as a valued guest conductor and as the orchestra\u2019s composer in residence. First up, he hosts what may well be the last concert of the Contact! series, Alan Gilbert\u2019s important yet ill-fated contemporary music endeavor. It had to be saved from oblivion once and will be retired under the new music director, Jaap van Zweden. This program looks at current Russian composers, including music by Nikolay Popov, Denis Khorov, Marina Khorkova, Dmitri Kourliandski and Alexander Khubeev.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nJENNIFER KOH at National Sawdust (March 31, 7 p.m.). \u201cLimitless\u201d is the latest of Ms. Koh\u2019s pioneering commissioning projects, in which the violinist plays newly written duets with their composers, who have deliberately been chosen to present an inclusive vision of classical music\u2019s present and future. On this second program of two, there is music by Lisa Bielawa, Vijay Iyer, Tyshawn Sorey, Nina Young and Du Yun.\n\n646-779-8455, nationalsawdust.org\n\nJUILLIARD ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (April 2, 8 p.m.). David Robertson leads the superb young players of the famous conservatory\u2019s leading ensemble in Dvorak\u2019s Symphony No. 9, \u201cFrom the New World\u201d; Ives\u2019s \u201cThree Places in New England\u201d; and Bartok\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 3. The soloist is Tomer Gewirtzman.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMATA FESTIVAL at the Church of the Epiphany (April 2, 7 p.m.). Now in its 20th iteration, this festival has done a great deal for young composers, as any glance through its alumni will testify. This year\u2019s concerts kick off with a new focus on sacred music, featuring works by Shawn Jaeger, Lydia Winsor Brindamour, David M. Gordon and Nico Muhly, and performers including Miranda Cuckson and Blair McMillen.\n\nmatafestival.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (April 4, 7:30 p.m., through April 6). Mr. Salonen conducts what is for him a relatively standard program among his other Philharmonic dates this week. The bulk is Beethoven: the \u201cEroica\u201d Symphony and the Piano Concerto No. 3, with the sublime soloist Benjamin Grosvenor. Novelty comes with the premiere of Anna Thorvaldsdottir\u2019s \u201cMetacosmos,\u201d a new work from a composer with a distinctive idiom.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org", "title": "6 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nTIMO ANDRES at Bargemusic (March 9, 8 p.m.). The composer and pianist gives a solo recital showcasing his own music \u2014 \u201cHow Can I Live in Your World of Ideas?\u201d \u2014 and that of three of his peers, Caroline Shaw, Christopher Cerrone and Eric Shanfield. Also on the bill is a selection of movements from Janacek\u2019s \u201cOn an Overgrown Path.\u201d\n\n800-838-3006, bargemusic.org\n\n\u2018CELLULAR SONGS\u2019 at BAM Harvey Theater (March 14-17, 7:30 p.m., through March 18). A new work by Meredith Monk, still an essential artist after all these years, has its premiere. It is inspired by biological processes \u2014 mutation, division \u2014 and is performed by Ms. Monk and four singers from her ensemble.\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org\n\n\u2018COS\u00cc FAN TUTTE\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (March 15, 7:30 p.m., through April 19). Phelim McDermott\u2019s new production of Mozart\u2019s dark comedy emphasizes its fantasy and its playfulness, setting it in a 1950s Coney Island-style fairground. David Robertson conducts a cast most notable for the Despina of Kelli O\u2019Hara, the Broadway star, as well as Amanda Majeski (Fiordiligi), Serena Malfi (Dorabella), Ben Bliss (Ferrando), Adam Plachetka (Guglielmo) and Christopher Maltman (Don Alfonso).\n\n212-362-6000, metopera.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nANGELA HEWITT at the 92nd Street Y (March 14, 7:30 p.m.). Nobody plays Bach quite like Angela Hewitt, whose career has concentrated on the composer above all others. Her \u201cBach Odyssey\u201d continues, in its second season of four, with a performance of the complete first book of \u201cThe Well-Tempered Clavier.\u201d\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org\n\nPHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (March 13, 8 p.m.). The last concert in Janine Jansen\u2019s Perspectives series coincides with a rare outing for this venerable orchestra in contemporary music, as together they play Michel van der Aa\u2019s Violin Concerto, written for the soloist in 2014. As if he were not busy enough at the moment, Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin also conducts Rachmaninoff\u2019s Symphony No. 2.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org", "title": "6 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nPIERRE-LAURENT AIMARD at Carnegie Hall (March 8, 8 p.m.). It is not often that one looks at a program and thinks that Beethoven\u2019s titanic \u201cHammerklavier\u201d Sonata might well be the less interesting half of a concert. But Mr. Aimard is always full of surprises. Before that Beethoven, which he will doubtless play with his usual analytical fervor, comes music by Liszt, Messiaen, Scriabin and an oddity: the post-Scriabin avant-gardist Nikolai Obukhov.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nINON BARNATAN at the 92nd Street Y (March 3, 8 p.m.). Sensitive and sophisticated, Mr. Barnatan might be the ideal pianist for the program he has chosen for this recital. Its entirety comprises \u201cMoments musicaux,\u201d and it looks at how the idea of a \u201cmoment\u201d has changed over time. Schubert, the obvious composer in the genre, is here with his reflective set of six pieces, and Rachmaninoff, too, demanding greater virtuosity. Rightly, there is a contemporary take as well, with two pieces by Avner Dorman.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org\n\nCLAIRE CHASE at the Kitchen (March 2, 8 p.m.; March 3, 5 and 8:30 p.m.). The latest installment of the vital flutist\u2019s \u201cDensity 2036\u201d project, which unveils a new set of pieces each year, is Marcos Balter\u2019s \u201cPan,\u201d a reflection on the paradoxical mortality of a god, scored for flute, electronics and community participation. Doug Fitch directs the performances.\n\n212-255-5793, thekitchen.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nANNE-SOPHIE MUTTER AND LAMBERT ORKIS at Carnegie Hall (March 4, 2 p.m.). One immensely satisfying thing about Anne-Sophie Mutter as an artist is her unflinching commitment to new music, in evidence here once more with the premiere of \u201cThe Fifth Season,\u201d by her ex-husband Andr\u00e9 Previn. There are also sonatas by Brahms and Penderecki, as well as the opportunity to hear Ms. Mutter alone, in Bach\u2019s Partita No. 2, with its immense chaconne.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nLISE DE LA SALLE at Town Hall (March 4, 2 p.m.). Bach is cleverly wound through the intriguing young pianist\u2019s recital, as his works are on her most recent recording, available on Na\u00efve. Pure Bach comes in the form of the \u201cItalian\u201d Concerto, but from then on there is an adventure of influences and echoes: Roussel\u2019s \u201cPr\u00e9lude et Fugue\u201d; Liszt\u2019s \u201cFantasy and Fugue on the Theme B-A-C-H\u201d; Liszt\u2019s rewriting of Bach\u2019s Prelude and Fugue in A minor; Kempff\u2019s version of the \u201cSicilienne\u201d; Poulenc\u2019s \u201cValse-improvisation sur le nom de Bach\u201d; and, finally, Busoni\u2019s vast transcription of the Chaconne in D minor.\n\n212-586-4680, pscny.org", "title": "6 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nBAYERISCHES STAATSORCHESTER at Carnegie Hall (March 28, 8 p.m.; March 29, 7 p.m.). Surely the highlight of this spring\u2019s classical music schedule is this rare visit from the orchestra of the Bavarian State Opera, perhaps the world\u2019s finest house. Its music director, Kirill Petrenko, soon off to the Berlin Philharmonic, leads both concerts, the first of which includes Brahms\u2019s Double Concerto, with the soloists Julia Fischer and Daniel M\u00fcller-Schott, and Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cManfred\u201d Symphony. The second is still more appealing: a concert performance of Strauss\u2019s \u201cDer Rosenkavalier,\u201d an opera that is impossible not to love. Adrianne Pieczonka is the Feldmarschallin, Angela Brower is Octavian, Hanna-Elisabeth M\u00fcller is Sophie and Peter Rose is Ochs.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nCHRISTOPHER CERRONE at Miller Theater (March 29, 8 p.m.). Mr. Cerrone is best known for \u201cInvisible Cities,\u201d a seductive opera that was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize.
