This highly popular weekly show, now at its new location, features a rotating cast of veteran U.C.B. performers as well as special guests from TV and movies who deliver monologues that inspire the ensuing improv. The later show is free and the earlier one is not; however, the tickets for the 9:30 time slot are distributed outside the theater that night, and there\u2019s often a long line, so choose wisely.\n\n212-366-9176, hellskitchen.ucbtheatre.com\n\n\u2018EVERY NOW AND THEN I FALL APART\u2019 at Q.E.D. (March 27, 7 p.m.). Karaoke is funny fare: You can discover that the superquiet tech guy at your job sings like Andrea Bocelli, or maybe find out that Angela in accounting knows every word to Salt-N-Pepa\u2019s \u201cNone of Your Business.\u201d This reading series finally seams the two genres of karaoke and comedy together, as performers read a piece they wrote about a particular song, then perform it as karaoke. At the end, the audience is invited to participate in karaoke, too.\n\n347-451-3873, qedastoria.com\n\n50 COMEDIANS TELL JOKES TO BENEFIT GUN CONTROL at Littlefield (March 28, 8 p.m.). At this fund-raising comedy event, several dozen comedians are slated to wax poetic about the male reproductive organ. Comedians Jo Firestone, Josh Gondelman, Roy Wood Jr., Shalewa Sharpe and many others will riff on the night\u2019s anatomic topic. Ticket sales will benefit the gun-control nonprofit Everytown for Gun Safety.\n\n877-435-9849, littlefieldnyc.com\n\n\u2018OH, SUCH A GOOD SHOW, OH!\u2019 at Union Hall (March 24, 7:30 p.m.). Those who are undecided about what kind of comedy they like best may find guidance at this event, a veritable buffet of different styles of laughter-inducing performance. Ethan Beach and Josh Nasser welcome Aparna Nancherla, Django Gold, Milly Tamarez, Ziwe Fumudoh and Eudora Peterson, who will be offering videos, PowerPoints, stories and, allegedly, animals.\n\n718-638-4400, unionhallny.com\n\n\u2018OPEN FLAME\u2019 at Mood Ring (March 26, 8 p.m.). This popular queer-friendly space is home to a brand-new open-mike comedy series that puts the focus on LGBTQ performers. Sans entrance or participation fees and hosted by Sam Campbell, Simone Leitner and Peter Valenti, the show gives each comedian four minutes to do their funniest.\n\n917-818-1738, moodringnyc.com\n\nJAY PHAROAH at Buttenwieser Hall, 92nd Street Y (March 27, 8 p.m.). This versatile performer, a six-season cast member on \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d who stood out for his Kanye West and Barack Obama impressions, currently stars in the Steven Soderbergh thriller \u201cUnsane.\u201d Mr. Pharoah will also headline Madison Square Garden at the end of the month, but audiences can catch him in this more intimate conversation before then.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org", "title": "6 Comedy Shows to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Kasia Pilat"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u2018DEVIANT: A TRUE CRIME COMEDY SHOW\u2019 at Caveat (March 5, 9:30 p.m.). The Lower East Side venue Caveat quickly established itself as a destination for those who like their comedy on the nerdy side, but this particular show also throws a little folie \u00e0 deux into the mix. What exactly is folie \u00e0 deux? A panel of guest comedians will help you find out.\n\n212-228-2100, caveat.nyc\n\n\u2018HANDMAID\u2019S TALE: THE MUSICAL\u2019 at the Bell House (March 8, 8 p.m.). This original performance from the fertile brains of Marcia Belsky and Melissa Stokoski resets the backdrop of the original Margaret Atwood novel and Hulu original series to Brooklyn in the not-too-distant future, populated by millennials (it may be a dystopian future, but some things never change). The show sold out two nights at Union Hall, and this one is likely the last, so catch it while you can.\n\n718-643-6510, thebellhouseny.com", "title": "6 Comedy Shows to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "1977: \u2018Do you know any intelligent women? Why aren\u2019t they ever in films?\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Varda was profiled by Flora Lewis after her film \u201cOne Sings, the Other Doesn\u2019t\u201d was selected to open the New York Film Festival in 1977. At the festival, Ms. Varda introduced her movie by proclaiming that the attendees were going to see \u201ca film about women who were also people.\u201d\n\nMs. Varda discussed gender imbalance in movies. \u201cIs there such a thing as a woman\u2019s film, of special interest to women? We have to see, they haven\u2019t had any choice,\u201d she said. Ms. Varda wanted to portray female relationships on film. \u201cThere are always stories about virile male friendships, Brando and Nicholson, Newman and Redford and so on, but not about friendship between women. The women are always motherly or tarty.\u201d\n\n1986: \u2018She aims to unsettle.\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Varda\u2019s film \u201cVagabond\u201d won the Golden Lion at the 1985 Venice Film Festival, making her the second female director to receive the prize. Annette Insdorf noted that the film had \u201clittle in common with the Parisian farces, American blockbusters and urban thrillers that dominated the French box office.\u201d Ms. Varda said she wanted to \u201cmake a film about the real France \u2014 not Parisian intellectuals \u2014 the France that is completely ignored in contemporary cinema.\u201d\n\nThe film\u2019s star, Sandrine Bonnaire, had become \u201cone of the most sought-after screen artists in her country.\u201d Ms. Varda said she sold Ms. Bonnaire on the film by telling her that the character would be \u201calone, dirty and rebellious, and she dies of the cold. Miss Bonnaire was delighted.\u201d\n\n1997: \u2018I think I was a feminist before being born.\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Museum of Modern Art screened all of Ms. Varda\u2019s films in a retrospective of her work in 1997. When Mel Gussow spoke to Ms. Varda about the tribute, she said, \u201cAt least it doesn\u2019t say posthume.\u201d The story describes her point of view on the art of filmmaking, including her case for the auteur theory. \u201cAuteurs are much attacked nowadays because people say they are selfish and narcissistic, that they don\u2019t want to listen to anybody. It\u2019s true \u2014 and so what?\u201d\n\nShe also speaks to her origins as a feminist. \u201cI think I was a feminist before being born. I had a feminist chromosome somewhere.\u201d She describes hating Snow White as a child. \u201c I could see she was behaving stupidly, cleaning the dishes, brooming everything for these monsters. It was ridiculous \u2014 and waiting for the ugly prince.\u201d\n\n2001: \u2018They called me \u2018The Ancestor of the New Wave,\u2019 but I was only 30.\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Varda spoke to Leslie Camhi in 2001 about her inspiration for the film \u201cThe Gleaners and I,\u201d which focused on people who live off the garbage thrown out by others. Ms. Varda told Ms. Camhi the film was \u201cabout an ill society, that does a poor job of sharing its bounty \u2014 but the very people who are living through that difficulty point the finger and teach us about it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Camhi tied \u201cThe Gleaners and I\u201d to the socially conscious themes of Ms. Varda\u2019s other work and detailed her legacy, including how Ms. Varda, then 72, was crowned \u201cthe ancestor of the New Wave\u201d at the age of 30.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m like those old painters who don\u2019t bother to make sketches or ask permissions. They don\u2019t give explanations. They just go ahead and do it,\u201d Ms. Varda said, reflecting on \u201cGleaners,\u201d which she also produced.\n\n2009: \u2018I am the queen of the margins. But the films are loved.\u2019\n\nThe Times co-chief film critic A. O. Scott spoke to Ms. Varda about her documentary \u201cThe Beaches of Agn\u00e8s.\u201d The film \u201cis a cinematic memoir in two senses,\u201d Mr. Scott wrote. \u201cAn autobiography rendered in carefully chosen, meaning-rich images and the account of a life lived in, through and for cinema.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am the queen of the margins, but the films are loved. The films are remembered,\u201d Ms. Varda said of her career. \u201cAnd this is my aim \u2014 to be loved as a filmmaker because I want to share emotions, to share the pleasure of being a filmmaker.\u201d\n\n2017: \u2018One of the greatest.\u2019\n\nMs. Varda\u2019s Oscar-nominated \u201cFaces Places\u201d was a Times Critic\u2019s Pick, and both chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and Mr. Scott, named it one of the best films of the year. \u201cContemplating some of the sorrows in her own past and the precariousness of the European present, she keeps gloom at bay with her resilient faith in the power of art to conserve and expand human dignity,\u201d Mr. Scott said. \u201cEvery second of this movie proves her right.\u201d\n\nMs. Dargis takes it a step further. \u201cMs. Varda is often described as one of the greatest female directors alive, which is true. She is also one of the greatest.\u201d", "title": "6 Decades of Agn\u00e8s Varda in The Times: \u2018She Aims to Unsettle\u2019", "authors": ["Renan Borelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nStephen Hawking, the acclaimed British theoretical physicist, died on Wednesday at 76. Best known for his groundbreaking work in cosmology, Mr. Hawking also had a significant influence on popular culture.\n\nAs his renown spread, movies were made about him, he made cameos on TV shows, and he inspired composers and songwriters. Here are some memorable cultural moments in which he featured.\n\n\u2018Star Trek: The Next Generation\u2019\n\nMr. Hawking appeared in an episode in 1993, in a scene in which Lieutenant Commander Data plays poker with Mr. Hawking, Albert Einstein and Isaac Newton. When Newton asks him what the point of the game is, Data says, \u201cI was curious to see how three of history\u2019s greatest minds would interact in this setting.\u201d\n\n\u2018Keep Talking\u2019\n\nPink Floyd sampled Mr. Hawking\u2019s voice on this track from the band\u2019s 1994 album, \u201cThe Division Bell.\u201d The sample was taken from a 1993 TV commercial for the British telephone company BT. Pink Floyd used another clip of Mr. Hawking\u2019s synthesized voice from the ad in 2014 on the track \u201cTalkin\u2019 Hawkin\u2019 \u201d on their final studio album \u201cThe Endless River.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018The Simpsons\u2019\n\nIn 1999, Mr. Hawking made a cameo in the episode \u201cThey Saved Lisa\u2019s Brain.\u201d The characters are boasting about their I.Q.s when Mr. Hawking appears and says, \u201cBig deal, my IQ is 280.\u201d Mr. Hawking made three other appearances as himself on the show over the years, in the episodes \u201cDon\u2019t Fear the Roofer\u201d (2005), \u201cStop or My Dog Will Shoot!\u201d (2007) and \u201cElementary School Musical\u201d (2010).", "title": "6 Memorable Cultural Moments Inspired by Stephen Hawking", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Home prices in 20 metropolitan areas across the country dropped at a record rate of 18 percent in October 2008 from a year earlier as the fallout from the financial collapse reverberated through the housing market. The housing market has still not recovered completely or evenly and prices in many cities are still below their pre-recession peak.\n\nHousing bubble aftermath\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s even more incredible is Team Obama\u2019s stubborn refusal to have any faith in the free market. In some of the hardest hit areas of the country, markets are already solving the housing problem. If the government really wants to help, instead of bailing out irresponsible mortgage holders, it should support new and younger families who want to buy starter homes and begin to climb the ladder of prosperity. All this is free-market economics 101. And I say, let free-markets work.\u201d \u2014 February, 2009\n\nAnalysis: The Obama administration\u2019s plan to help homeowners included a litany of programs, including reducing the debt that distressed borrowers owed. The success of these programs was mixed but recent studies show that they did, in fact, help millions of people stay in their homes.\n\nMr. Kudlow\u2019s claim that the markets were already \u201csolving\u201d the housing problem was not accurate, given that the housing market still has not recovered in many areas, including those hardest hit.\n\nIn 2009, banks were \u2014 and in many cases remain \u2014 incredibly reluctant to make loans to all but the highest-quality borrowers. That does not generally include new and younger families, who have little credit history and are considered riskier than those with a track record of on-time payments. Without the government assisting borrowers who were in danger of foreclosure, the economic fallout from the crisis would have been even deeper, more severe and longer-lasting.\n\nBefore the Great Recession\n\n\u201cAt home in the U.S., there are still housing-slump worries and concerns about an inventory correction in autos and factories. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan this week even predicted a recession, naming the budget deficit as the cause. Huh? The deficit is evaporating as record tax revenues are being generated by a solid economy, itself a function of the low marginal tax rates put in place by President Bush.\u201d \u2014 March, 2007\n\nAnalysis: That solid economy was not so solid after all and Mr. Greenspan\u2019s prediction of a recession came true. By December 2007, the United States was officially in the Great Recession. The budget deficit did not evaporate but ballooned and continues to grow today, with the nation approaching a $1 trillion annual deficit.", "title": "6 of Larry Kudlow\u2019s Not-So-on-the-Money Predictions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nEarly on the morning of my father\u2019s funeral, I was standing at the corner of 68th Street and Second Avenue thinking about how much he loved the many surprises and small pleasures that New York City has to offer.\n\nOut of the corner of my eye, I noticed that the man standing next to me was carrying a satchel that was wide open \u2014 an invitation to a skilled pickpocket.\n\nWithout looking directly at the man, I told him his bag was wide open.\n\n\u201cI always carry it this way,\u201d he replied, \u201cbecause it does not hold anything of material value.\u201d\n\nI realized that the man I was speaking to was a friar in a white robe. I could almost hear my father enjoying a hearty chuckle.", "title": "68th Street Surprise", "authors": ["Jon Drucker", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Still, that only lasts until the talks themselves.\n\nPhoto\n\n2. Mismatched signals may have set up the talks to fail.\n\nUsually, before high-level talks like these, both sides spend a long time telegraphing their expected outcomes.\n\nSuch signals serve as public commitments, both to the other side of the negotiation and to citizens back home. It\u2019s a way for both sides to test one another\u2019s demands and offers, reducing the risk of surprise or embarrassment.\n\nThat is not really how things have proceeded with the United States and North Korea. Mr. Trump has already committed to granting North Korea one of its most desired concessions: a high-level meeting between the heads of state.\n\nIn exchange, North Korea has not publicly committed to anything. It has, quite cannily, channeled its public communications through South Korea, making it easier to renege.\n\nFurther, Mr. Trump has declared \u201cdenuclearization\u201d as his minimal acceptable outcome for talks, making it harder for him to accept a more modest (but more achievable!) outcome and costlier for him to walk away.\n\nThe table is now set in such a way that virtually any outcome is a win for North Korea, but only a very narrow and difficult range of outcomes will save the United States from an embarrassing failure.\n\nThe North Koreans can walk away more freely, while the Americans will be more desperate to come home with some sort of win. It\u2019s a formulation that puts the Americans at significant disadvantage before talks even begin.\n\nPhoto\n\n3. The sides do not agree on the point of talking.\n\nIt\u2019s worth belaboring the costs of skipping the usual process of mutual public signaling.\n\nSouth Korean officials have said that Mr. Kim is willing to enter talks for \u201cdenuclearization\u201d \u2014 there\u2019s that word again \u2014 which is perhaps why Mr. Trump seems to believe this will happen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Duyeon Kim, a Seoul-based analyst, writes in a column in the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists that \u201cdenuclearization\u201d means vastly different things to the United States and North Korea.\n\nAmericans understand the word as describing North Korea\u2019s full nuclear disarmament, which is very difficult to imagine happening.\n\nBut North Koreans, she writes, tend to mean it as a kind of mutual and incremental disarmament in which the United States also gives up weapons.\n\nNormally, the United States and North Korea would have issued months, even years, of public statements on their goals for direct talks, to clear all this up.\n\nBut, again, the Americans have made splashy public commitments while letting the North Koreans get by without doing the same.\n\nPhoto\n\n4. The Trump administration has gotten the process backward.\n\nIt\u2019s practically an axiom of international diplomacy that you only bring heads of state together at the very end of talks, after lower-level officials have done the dirty work.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNegotiators need to be free to back down from demands. Or to contradict themselves. Or to play good cop, bad cop. Or to walk away. Lower-level officials can lose face or sacrifice credibility for the sake of talks. Heads of state are much too constrained.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRobert E. Kelly, a professor at South Korea\u2019s Pusan National University, wrote on Twitter that, in a more typical process, \u201cthere would be a series of concessions and counter-concessions building trust and credibility over time (likely years) eventually rising to a serious discussion of denuclearization.\u201d\n\nInstead, the Trump administration is jumping straight to the last step.\n\nThere is little obvious gain in skipping over a process that is intended to lock North Korea into public commitments, test what is achievable and ensure maximum American leverage and flexibility.\n\nThere is potentially significant downside, though. Victor Cha, a well-respected North Korea expert, warns in a New York Times Op-Ed essay, \u201cFailed negotiations at the summit level leave all parties with no other recourse for diplomacy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n5. The State Department is in a shambles.\n\nWouldn\u2019t this be a good moment to have an American ambassador to South Korea? Or an under secretary of state for arms control and international security?\n\nBoth posts are empty. The desk for assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific affairs is occupied by a respected but interim official who has clashed with the White House. Her boss, the under secretary for political affairs, is retiring.\n\nMr. Trump lacks the institutional support and assistance that more experienced presidents found essential. There will be fewer high-level diplomats to run parallel talks, fewer midlevel officials to assist and brief the president, fewer analysts to feel out North Korean intentions and capabilities.\n\nThis is why the emerging conventional wisdom among analysts, as summed up by The Economist, is that \u201cMr. Trump \u2014 a man who boasts about his television ratings, and who is bored by briefings and scornful of foreign alliances \u2014 could end up being played like a gold-plated violin.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Everything could turn on the president\u2019s personality.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s headstrong personalization of North Korea policy may be the most significant aspect of all this.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt means that talks and their outcome will be determined, to an unprecedented degree, by Mr. Trump\u2019s personal biases and impulses. By his mood at the time of talks. By his particular style of negotiation.\n\nMr. Kelly expressed concern over Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cchaotic management style, erratic, moody personality and chronic staffing problems.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cThat\u2019s not ideology talking. I am a registered Republican and worked once for a G.O.P. congressman.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s negotiating record as president, mostly focused on domestic legislative matters, is instructive.\n\nHe has tended to oscillate unpredictably between policies, throwing talks over the budget or health care into chaos. He has set members of his own party against one another, weakening their position against Democrats. And he has offered the Democrats sweeping concessions on a whim, to the surprise of his party.\n\nWhen legislative efforts have stalled, Mr. Trump has at times lashed out. In domestic politics, that can mean publicly denigrating his target or pressuring them to resign. In a heavily militarized standoff between nuclear powers, the stakes would be higher.\n\n\u201cIf Trump gets all valedictory over simple willingness to talk, he may also tack hard in the other direction when hopes are dashed,\u201d Mira Rapp-Hooper, a senior fellow at the Center for New American Security, wrote on Twitter.\n\nPhoto\n\n7. North Korea has already achieved a symbolic victory.\n\nFor North Korea, high-level talks are a big win in their own right. Mr. Kim seeks to transform his country from a rogue pariah into an established nuclear power, a peer to the United States, a player on the international stage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat wins Mr. Kim international acknowledgment and heightened status, as well as significant domestic credibility.\n\n\u201cKim is not inviting Trump so that he can surrender North Korea\u2019s weapons,\u201d Jeffrey Lewis, a Korea expert at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, wrote on Twitter. \u201cKim is inviting Trump to demonstrate that his investment in nuclear and missile capabilities has forced the United States to treat him as an equal.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s been a North Korean priority since the 1990s.\n\nMr. Trump is granting Mr. Kim that victory, thereby surrendering one of the United States\u2019 last remaining opportunities to extract something from North Korea, without getting anything demonstrable in return.\n\nNorth Korea is likely to enter talks with other goals, and the United States does wield other leverage, so it could yet come to something. But with this concession granted and the two parties not even sure of one another\u2019s positions on other matters, that may be the end of it.", "title": "7 Big Things to Understand About Trump\u2019s Talks With North Korea", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\n\u2018APOLOGIES FROM MEN\u2019 at the Peoples Improv Theater Striker (March 9, 9:30 p.m.). The #MeToo fallout brought about a flood of firings, new organizations and pledges to change, but a vast array of apologia from perpetrators also ensued. The comedian Lauren Maul has taken these and graciously turned them into animated videos and original music, a full album of which is available for purchase online.\n\n212-563-7488, thepit-nyc.com\n\nLEWIS BLACK AT CITY WINERY (March 15, 8 p.m.). Those who enjoy their comedy with a hefty helping of cathartic anger punctuated by indignant finger pointing could do no better than this veteran comedian. Mr. Black, a mainstay of \u201cThe Daily Show,\u201d is as dynamic a performer as his talents are varied, with no small number of stand-up specials, books and film roles under his belt.\n\n212-608-0555, citywinery.com\n\n\u2018EMPLOYEE OF THE MONTH\u2019 at the Gramercy Theater (March 15, 8 p.m.). \u201cEmployee of the Month\u201d is a monthly comedy show and podcast in which Catie Lazarus talks with wildly fascinating famous people about their jobs. The hilariously unassuming British actress Emily Mortimer will be one of Ms. Lazarus\u2019s guests, as will the comedian Hannibal Buress, the \u201cHamilton\u201d music director Alex Lacamoire and others.\n\n212-614-6932, venue.thegramercytheatre.com\n\nCHRIS KRAUS AND SHEILA HETI at Murmrr (March 11, 7:30 p.m.). The Murmrr Lit series, a new literature and culture program, kicked off last month with a sold-out show, and the second installment promises to be just as popular. Chris Kraus, the author of \u201cI Love Dick,\u201d the touching and clever epistolary novel that was adapted into a comedy by Jill Soloway for Amazon in 2017, will take the stage this time. She\u2019ll be joined by Sheila Heti, the author of the 2012 novel \u201cHow Should a Person Be?\u201d\n\nmurmrr.com\n\n\u2018OBAMA DAUGHTERS: REQUIEM FOR AMERICA\u2019 AND \u2018IMPROVISED SEINFELD\u2019 at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater Hell\u2019s Kitchen (March 9, 7:30 p.m.). This show boasts two sets of skillful performers and their distinct productions for the price of one particularly extravagant Starbucks order. The first, which features the multitalented Keisha Zollar as a writer and cast member, is set in the year 2036. Trump is still president because term limits have been ignored, and President Obama\u2019s daughters must come to America\u2019s rescue. The second takes the \u201cSeinfeld\u201d we all know and love and improvises an entire episode.\n\n212-366-9176, hellskitchen.ucbtheatre.com\n\n\u2018RUNNING LATE\u2019 at the Gramercy Theater (March 12, 8 p.m.). Savage question: Did you know that before HQ, its superpopular host Scott Rogowsky regularly served as M.C. for \u201cRunning Late,\u201d a general interest comedy talk show he started in October 2011? He has recently resurrected the show, and for this installment, he\u2019ll be joined by the comedian Michael Ian Black, the HQ superfan Dan Rather and others.\n\n212-614-6932, venue.thegramercytheatre.com\n\n\u2018TINDER LIVE!\u2019 at Littlefield (March 10, 8:30 p.m.). The performer Lane Moore hosts this fourth anniversary celebration of her recurring comedy show, in which the audience is treated to Tinder pro tips and tricks, a smattering of swiping and messaging in real time and the occasional live phone call. For this anniversary edition, Ms. Moore has invited Eliot Glazer of \u201cBroad City,\u201d the musician JD Samson of the band Le Tigre and the author Mychal Denzel Smith.\n\nlittlefieldnyc.com", "title": "7 Comedy Shows to Catch in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Kasia Pilat"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Though he left his eponymous label nearly a decade ago, there are few designers as influential today as Martin Margiela. While he aspired to be invisible \u2014 to the point of refusing to be photographed and conducting all interviews by fax or email \u2014 Margiela\u2019s impact is writ large on the contemporary fashion landscape. So many of his innovations \u2014 once radical \u2014 have become accepted norms in the industry (his deconstructed tailoring, his championing of recycling and his pioneering of the see-now buy-now model, to name but a few). Brands as diverse as Vetements, Marques\u2019Almeida and The Row continually mine his archive for inspiration. The conceptual Belgian designer is being celebrated in two separate exhibitions in Paris this month: a retrospective at the Palais Galliera, which examines his career until he retired in 2009, and another at the Mus\u00e9e des Arts D\u00e9coratifs, which premiered in Antwerp last year and catalogs his six-year tenure designing for Herm\u00e8s.\n\nAfter starting his own label in 1988 with his business partner Jenny Meirens, Margiela spent the next two decades establishing an entirely new vocabulary for clothing \u2014 the \u201ccigarette\u201d shoulder, the iconic cloven-footed Tabi boot, the unfinished edges and paint-splattered surfaces, the repurposing of vintage garments into new clothes. He constantly questioned the received norms of luxury \u2014 particularly during his unconventional shows, which upended the traditional catwalk format, taking over abandoned Metro stations and, once, a Salvation Army store.\n\nBut the designer\u2019s fall/winter 2000 collection was perhaps the finest expression of many of his career-long preoccupations. The show was staged inside a disused freight train docked in a loading bay in Paris\u2019s 19th Arrondissement, and models walked to a dissonant instrumental track from David Lynch\u2019s \u201cTwin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me\u201d film soundtrack. The show saw Margiela develop the oversize concept he\u2019d introduced the previous season \u2014 garments came in an Italian size 78 \u2014 but he also experimented with new techniques, such as baking knitwear over an XXXL dummy to retain its voluminous form. While some critics found the show's setting \u201cdisturbing,\u201d the clothes, with their blown-out proportions, achieved a new sculptural elegance. On the occasion of the Galliera exhibition, some of Margiela\u2019s longtime collaborators and fans share their memories of the designer and that radical show.", "title": "7 Martin Margiela Fans and Collaborators Remember His Most Radical Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our recommended titles this week are anchored by a sense of place, both physical and metaphysical. First the physical: John Banville\u2019s \u201cTime Pieces\u201d offers a nostalgist\u2019s reflective tour of Dublin, Mark Whitaker\u2019s \u201cSmoketown\u201d excavates an overlooked bastion of African-American culture in Pittsburgh, and Patricia Vigderman\u2019s \u201cThe Real Life of the Parthenon\u201d surveys sites of classic antiquity in an attempt to puzzle out the relationship between art and its sources. For readers who favor metaphysical wandering \u2014 or wondering \u2014 Marilynne Robinson has an expansive, inquisitive new essay collection whose title pretty much says it all: \u201cWhat Are We Doing Here?\u201d (Mostly reading, I hope.) Finally, we also feature works of fiction exploring marriage and fate, by Tayari Jones; exile and the afterlife, by Ismail Kadare; and notions of evil and the other, in a book that pairs art by Del Samatar with text by his sister, Sofia Samatar.\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nWHAT ARE WE DOING HERE? Essays, by Marilynne Robinson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) In essays that are characteristically rigorous and combative, Robinson wrestles with various points of civics and theology. \u201cIt\u2019s an intellectual autobiography \u2014 a starchy, ardent and, on occasion, surprisingly personal account of what it means to be the custodian of one\u2019s conscience in a world saturated with orthodoxies,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. \u201cIn other words, it\u2019s a passionate treatment of one of Robinson\u2019s longtime preoccupations\u201d and \u201ca dense, eccentric book of profound and generous gifts.\u201d\n\nTIME PIECES: A Dublin Memoir, by John Banville. (Knopf, $26.95.) The Booker Prize-winning novelist wanders Ireland\u2019s capital city, recalling people and places that still live in his memory. Scattered throughout are suitably atmospheric photographs by Paul Joyce. As Roger Rosenblatt notes in his review, Dublin\u2019s pull in the memoir is more or less impressionistic \u2014 \u201cPity the fool who\u2019s reading this book to get a clear and orderly picture\u201d \u2014 but irresistible nonetheless: \u201cTo Banville, an apostle of the ordinary, the deep appeal of city life is that here the ordinary may be made magical.\u201d\n\nTHE REAL LIFE OF THE PARTHENON, by Patricia Vigderman. (Mad Creek/Ohio State University Press, paper, $21.95.) An American scholar visits classic sites of the ancient world in a book that\u2019s part travelogue, part memoir and part musing on our contested cultural heritage. \u201cVigderman approaches her subject evenhandedly, noting that the repatriation of works of art can be seen as a victory for local communities and their sense of identity,\u201d Bruce Boucher writes in his review, \u201cbut she also spots the questionable ties between the handiwork of an ancient Greek vase painter, say, and the inhabitants of modern-day Paestum. \u2026 Behind the examples in this thoughtful book lies the realization that the relationship between the spectator and art is inevitably complex. After all, we can\u2019t return art or history to a lost past.\u201d", "title": "7 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nCITY OF SCIENCE at the APEX Center at Lehman College (March 11, 10 a.m.-4 p.m.). Your children may think they can walk on water, but this free event in the Bronx will allow them to prove it. A satellite fair that takes highlights of the annual World Science Festival and transports them outside Manhattan, this daylong adventure offers more than a few startling demonstrations. In addition to that water feat (which happens courtesy of cornstarch and the principles governing what are known as non-Newtonian fluids), this fest will also invite young science fans to investigate a giant pendulum wave; an astroblaster, also known as a seismic accelerator; a space-time simulator that uses marbles to illustrate the theory of general relativity; and many other exhibits and experiments.\n\n212-348-1400, worldsciencefestival.com/cityofscience\n\nJUNOT D\u00cdAZ PRESENTS \u2018ISLANDBORN\u2019 at the Central Library of the Brooklyn Public Library (March 13, 6-8 p.m.). A fresh work by Mr. D\u00edaz, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, is always an occasion, but this one is especially remarkable for its potential to bring him a whole new generation of fans. \u201cIslandborn,\u201d which will be published simultaneously in English and Spanish by Dial Books for Young Readers, is Mr. D\u00edaz\u2019s first picture book, with illustrations by Leo Espinosa. It chronicles the experiences of Lola, a little New Yorker who, like Mr. D\u00edaz, was born in the Dominican Republic. When asked by her school to draw a picture of her family\u2019s homeland, she seeks out her relatives to weave a story of her roots. Organized by the library and Greenlight Bookstore, this celebration will feature children\u2019s coloring and crafts as well as a reading and book signing by Mr. D\u00edaz.\n\n718-230-2200, bklynlib.org/islandborn\n\n\u2018HATCHED\u2019 at the Ailey Studio Theater (March 9-11, 11 a.m.). Although March has been coming in like a grouchy lion, at least one gentle lamb \u2014 not to mention a host of other baby animals \u2014 will visit New York this weekend. They\u2019re all characters in \u201cHatched,\u201d a dance-theater work for equally young humans: infants to 6-year-olds. Written and directed by Mara McEwin, a founder of the troupe Treehouse Shakers, the show centers on a chick\u2019s hatching and her discovery of her country neighbors, which include a newborn calf, a strutting rooster, cavorting fellow chicks and wild nestlings. These puppet creatures, designed by Patti Gilstrap, will also interact with the audience members, who can \u201cfeed\u201d and play with them. Performed to Anthony Rizzo\u2019s score, the 45-minute production has little dialogue but lots of dance, as the company members show how it feels to fledge and frolic on a farm.\n\n212-715-1914, treehouseshakers.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKIDS FLEADH AT THE CRAIC FEST at Cin\u00e9polis Chelsea (March 10, 11:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m.). The words are Irish, but the concepts are universal: Fleadh, pronounced flah, means festival, and craic is slang for fun. Children can enjoy both at this annual event, part of a larger celebration of Irish film and music. The youth fleadh, expressly for those 5 and older, will consist of a program of award-winning shorts by Irish and Irish-American filmmakers, along with rousing step dancing by the Niall O\u2019Leary Irish Dance Troupe. Movies and movement \u2014 what could be more craic?\n\n917-373-6735, thecraicfest.com", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nALL FOR LOVE ADOPTION RALLY at the North Plaza, Union Square Park (March 25, noon-5 p.m.). If you think you\u2019re ready to add a new member to your family \u2014 a furry one, that is \u2014 this could be the ideal occasion. Presented by the Petco Foundation and supported by groups including the Mayor\u2019s Alliance for NYC Animals, this rally will offer more than 200 adoptable dogs, cats and rabbits, all vaccinated and spayed or neutered. Although the pets aren\u2019t free, admission is, along with expert advice on dog training. The New Jersey-based cartoonist and children\u2019s book author Patrick McDonnell, known for his comic strip \u201cMutts,\u201d will attend, presiding over the assemblage of a huge mosaic mural of photographs of owners and their adopted four-legged friends.\n\nanimalalliancenyc.org\n\n\u2018A FOOL\u2019S ERRAND\u2019 (\u2018ESPI\u00c8GLERIE\u2019) at BAM Fisher (March 24-25, 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.). Don\u2019t judge a show by its title. Although this Montreal-based circus production has plenty of foolishness, it\u2019s unlikely to strike young audiences as a fruitless enterprise. Part of the BAMkids series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it stars Jamie Adkins, a clown and acrobat, and Julie Houle, a composer and musician whose instrument \u2014 the tuba \u2014 comes loaded with comic potential. Mr. Adkins\u2019s instrument is his body, which he uses intriguingly, whether he\u2019s navigating a tightrope or juggling with his mouth as well as his hands. (The Saturday afternoon performance is quieter and more relaxed, with accommodations for children on the autism spectrum.)\n\n718-636-4100, bam.org/kids\n\nINVENTGENUITY FESTIVAL at the Brooklyn New School (March 24-25, 11 a.m.-4 p.m.). Ah, spring. You may not yet smell it in the air, but if you admire its creative energy \u2014 and the power of the nose itself \u2014 visit this fair, which offers immersion in engineering, technology and art for children 7 and older. Its sponsor, the Beam Center, a Brooklyn educational nonprofit, has devoted this year\u2019s event to the theme \u201cNose/Knows.\u201d Participants can collaborate on \u201cThe Ol\u2019Factory Conspiracy\u201d \u2014 a project designed by the artist Tim Fite and the center\u2019s staff, in which they\u2019ll make noses to attach to a massive sculpture of that organ \u2014 or attend individual workshops. Devoted to crafting items like personalized hankies, aromatic soap and noses that literally run (they\u2019re mechanized clay models), the 45-minute sessions each require a small fee, but festival admission and drop-in activities are free. You need only register in advance \u2014 and have a nose for fun.\n\n347-470-6747, beamcenter.org/festival\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJAZZ FOR YOUNG PEOPLE: \u2018WHO IS MARY LOU WILLIAMS?\u2019 at the Rose Theater (March 24, 1 and 3 p.m.). Jazz history was dominated by men, and women often struggled to be heard \u2014 in every sense of that phrase. But the talent and creativity of Mary Lou Williams (1910-81) resounded at an early age. This final family concert in Jazz at Lincoln Center\u2019s season will trace Williams\u2019s life and her career as a pianist, composer and arranger. Fittingly, the jazz singer Catherine Russell will host the program, and an all-female band, led by the drummer LaFrae Sci, will demonstrate Williams\u2019s work.\n\n212-721-6500, jazz.org", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018LET\u2019S GET LOUD!\u2019 at the Children\u2019s Museum of Manhattan (April 2-8, at various times). This series of programs celebrates noise in all its forms. On Monday, the saxophonist, composer and educator Hayes Greenfield will lead young visitors on an exploration of rhythm and tempo, using their own voices and bodies, in \u201cGive Me Sound!\u201d Starting on Tuesday, they can investigate the artist Wassily Kandinsky\u2019s boisterous palette and his notion of visual chords in \u201cKandinsky Creations,\u201d daily sessions during which they\u2019ll also try out his idea of painting music. Other offerings include \u201cRockin\u2019 Rhythms,\u201d percussion concerts on Wednesday given by students at the Manhattan School of Music, and workshops on making shakers and African rattles. (The full schedule is on the website; some programs require sign-up or tickets.)\n\n212-721-1223, cmom.org\n\n\u2018NEVERLAND: PETER RETURNS\u2019 at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater (through mid-September). Peter Pan, the boy who wouldn\u2019t grow up, is continuing his boundless youth onstage in Central Park. Granted, he may be more stiff than fans usually picture him \u2014 he and his fellow characters are all handmade wooden marionettes \u2014 but thanks to the talents of the theater\u2019s puppeteers and its artistic director, Bruce Cannon, he can still nimbly leap and fly. He needs those skills more than ever: In this new production from the City Parks Foundation, the evil Captain Hook has turned Tinker Bell and the Indian princess Tiger Lily against Peter. This musical staging is a revised version of the theater\u2019s original adaptations of J. M. Barrie\u2019s works. Additional performances have been scheduled from Monday through April 6, giving many children ample opportunities to visit Neverland over spring break.\n\n212-988-9093, cityparksfoundation.org\n\n\u2018RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK\u2019 BRUNCH SCREENING at Nitehawk Cinema (March 31-April 1, 11:30 a.m.). To today\u2019s children, Harrison Ford may be just that grizzled old guy who meets an unfortunate end in \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens.\u201d But here\u2019s a chance to see him in his heyday as Indiana Jones, the swashbuckling, Nazi-battling archaeologist who proved that a university professor needn\u2019t be a nerd. (And don\u2019t forget Karen Allen as Marion, his intrepid equal.) Part of the Lil\u2019 Hawk Friendly screenings series, the PG-rated \u201cRaiders\u201d (1981) will be accompanied by a menu more substantial than popcorn and candy: Children\u2019s brunch choices at this Brooklyn theater and restaurant include chicken tenders and breakfast corn dogs.\n\n718-782-8370, nitehawkcinema.com\n\n\u2018A TANGO-DANCING CINDERELLA\u2019 (\u2018CENICIENTA TANGUERA\u2019) at Teatro SEA at the Clemente Soto V\u00e9lez Cultural Center (through May 19). Forget about Rodgers and Hammerstein\u2019s waltz; those magic slippers move to a Latin beat in this Spanish-flavored version of the fairy tale. Produced by Teatro SEA, the Latino theater for children, this bilingual adaptation has a heroine who is not only a beleaguered scullery maid but also the kingdom\u2019s best tango dancer. The show, which plays on Saturdays at 3 p.m. on the Lower East Side, features a benefactor who\u2019s different, too: When Cinderella\u2019s fairy godmother falls ill, a surprise character takes her place.\n\n212-529-1545, teatrosea.org", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018LAYER THE WALLS\u2019 at the Tank (through March 4). Like prehistoric sediment, the walls of a building often contain traces and impressions of lives once lived. Liz Parker and Rachel Sullivan created this Manhattan production, for children 7 and older, after a visit to the Tenement Museum on the Lower East Side, where they learned of the old apartments\u2019 many layers of wallpaper, each applied by an immigrant family. Set within a tenement that is about to be torn down and whose interior is plastered with 40 layers, this show uses masks, toy-theater techniques and puppets designed by Spica Wobbe to imagine the proud and perilous histories of the building\u2019s Italian, Jewish and Irish occupants.\n\n212-563-6269, thetanknyc.org\n\nOPEN STUDIO: GRANT WOOD at the Whitney Museum of American Art (March 3-4, 10:30 a.m.-3 p.m.). The sourpuss farmer and his scowling wife in \u201cAmerican Gothic,\u201d Grant Wood\u2019s best-known painting, don\u2019t look as if they\u2019d appreciate having children running around. The Whitney, however, feels differently and will welcome as many young visitors as possible to this event, which celebrates the opening of its new exhibition \u201cGrant Wood: American Gothic and Other Fables.\u201d Children will collaborate with the artist Stina Puotinen to create an immersive installation evoking Wood\u2019s verdant landscapes. They can also make their own contributions to a large mural of the countryside, use recycled materials to build fantastical plants and construct large sculptural objects based on what they observe in Wood\u2019s work. On Saturday only, the museum will offer family tours of the show as well.\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org\n\nTILT KIDS FESTIVAL at various locations (March 3-18). On Saturday, Little Red Riding Hood will start young audiences on a powerful journey, but what\u2019s ahead includes far more than forbidding woods and a fearsome wolf. She will lead them into the fascinating world of Tilt, the multifarious annual children\u2019s festival from the Cultural Services of the French Embassy and the French Institute Alliance Fran\u00e7aise. Devoted to the theme of watching, the first festival weekend features not only Jo\u00ebl Pommerat\u2019s \u201cLittle Red Riding Hood,\u201d but also a Saturday matinee of the choreographer J\u00e9r\u00f4me Bel\u2019s \u201cGala\u201d and the opening of \u201cOnce Upon a Forest, the Animal Spring,\u201d a free installation by Yto Barrada and Julie Klear. In this interactive work, on view through April 6, children will place magnetic words on the walls and create forests and cities by moving around large cutout squares featuring whimsical creatures, buildings and trees. The rest of the festival explores reading, writing and thinking (March 10-11) and music (March 17-18). Sounds magnifique.\n\ntiltkidsfestival.org\n\n\u2018WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE\u2019S LONG LOST FIRST PLAY (ABRIDGED)\u2019 at the New Victory Theater (March 2-March 11). Something wickedly funny this way comes. Aided by their co-star Teddy Spencer, the writers Austin Tichenor and Reed Martin, who are the principals of the Reduced Shakespeare Company, are presenting what they assert is Shakespeare\u2019s first work, produced at the tender age of 17. Lasting a mere hour and 40 minutes (including an intermission) and recommended for theatergoers 10 and older, this play reveals the master to have been quite a recycler. Expect to see Puck of \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream\u201d pitted against Ariel of \u201cThe Tempest,\u201d along with appearances by such disparate characters as Hamlet, Lady Macbeth and one Dromio and Juliet.\n\n646-223-3010, newvictory.org", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "FAMILY FILMS: TRANSFORMATIONS at the Celeste Bartos Theater, Museum of Modern Art (March 17, noon-1 p.m.). Death and taxes aren\u2019t the world\u2019s only certainties; change is just as inevitable, and these animated shorts celebrate it. Consisting of three American projects and one dialogue-free Russian work, they focus mostly on inner transformations. In Gene Deitch\u2019s \u201cThe Three Robbers,\u201d the thieves discover that stealing a child\u2019s heart is more fulfilling than grabbing gold. The title character of \u201cPishto Goes Away,\u201d by Sonya Kendel, leaves his home in disgust, only to return in joy. The heroine of Tyler J. Kupferer\u2019s \u201cThe Girl and the Fox\u201d comes to see a marauding animal in a new light, while \u201cThe Mantis Parable,\u201d by Josh Staub, teaches a gentle lesson in compassion. Part of a free monthly series, the films will be followed by discussions and recommendations for museum activities. Together, they make up a program that young visitors may find transformative, too.\n\n212-708-9805, moma.org/families\n\nFAMILY PLAY DAY at Brooklyn Historical Society, Dumbo (March 17, 11 a.m.-2 p.m.). The Brooklyn Historical Society has more than a new exhibition to celebrate; it has a whole new site, too. Children can visit both on this occasion, which heralds the opening of \u201cWaterfront,\u201d a show whose title also describes its location. Inside Empire Stores, a converted 19th-century warehouse complex in Brooklyn Bridge Park, this new museum branch and its inaugural display explore the borough\u2019s shoreline history. Among its many activities, \u201cWaterfront\u201d invites children to build a city from magnets; dress up like the female Brooklyn Navy Yard welders from World War II; touch and smell goods from the mercantile trade; and, using technology, make brief films in which they insert themselves into historical scenes. Registration is recommended.\n\n929-258-3699, brooklynhistory.org/dumbo\n\n\u2018MATZAPALOOZA! REIMAGINING PASSOVER\u2019 at the Museum at Eldridge Street (March 18, 11 a.m.-1 p.m.). Seder, the name of the traditional Passover meal, means \u201corder,\u201d but sometimes a little disorder can be just as satisfying. Presented by the museum and the Workmen\u2019s Circle, a progressive Jewish organization, this annual event adds contemporary flourishes to the ancient Passover holiday. Children can make crafts, like a cup for Elijah and a tambourine for Miriam \u2014 both biblical invitees to many modern Seders \u2014 and will even meet Moses himself, portrayed by an actor. The day will include a scavenger hunt, holiday foods and social justice projects devoted to Passover\u2019s theme: freedom.\n\n212-219-0302, circle.org\n\n\u2018SHENANIGANS: IRISH CELEBRATION!\u2019 at the Actors Temple Theater (March 17, 3:30 p.m.; March 18, 10:30 a.m.). Many New Yorkers are all too familiar with St. Patrick\u2019s Day shenanigans. The deeds being honored at this theater, however, involve neither rowdy crowds nor alcohol. Written by Brian Barrentine, the creator of Funikijam World Music, an organization presenting world-music classes and programs for children, \u201cShenanigans\u201d offers Irish songs and stories for theatergoers 10 and younger. The tunes helpfully explain not only the meaning of the show\u2019s title but also elements of Irish folklore like leprechauns, banshees and rainbows. Mr. Barrentine stars, along with his Agents of Jam and guest performers from the Aherne Sheehan School of Irish Dance.\n\n347-913-5267, funikijam.com", "title": "7 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Those young men \u2014 Ezell Blair Jr., 18; Franklin McCain, 19; Joseph McNeil, 17; and David Richmond, 18, all students at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University \u2014 made their stand on Feb. 1, 1960. Within three days, they were joined by some 300 others. By summer, the sit-ins had spread to more than 50 cities, and lunch counters were rapidly desegregating.\n\nThe actions of the so-called Greensboro Four led directly to the creation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, which the civil rights organizer Ella Baker urged students to form in April 1960 to coordinate the continuing sit-ins. Later, SNCC would play a major role in the Freedom Rides and in voter registration efforts across the South. And the momentum that began at the Woolworth\u2019s lunch counter would eventually contribute to the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which outlawed segregation in public spaces.\n\nPerhaps more than anything, the results of the Greensboro sit-ins showed the power of a small group of students prepared to stand alone if necessary.\n\n\u201cInevitably, people ask me, \u2018What can I do?\u2019\u201d Mr. McCain said in an interview in 2005. \u201cWhat kind of question is that? Look around you. Once you identify what you want to do, don\u2019t ask for the masses to help you, because they won\u2019t come.\u201d", "title": "7 Times in History When Students Turned to Activism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Before you dive in, it helps to consider the different sorts of fees that residents pay. Type A contracts, as they\u2019re known, are all inclusive. You pay a one-time entry fee, part or all of which may be refundable, plus a monthly rent. In return you get unlimited access to health care services in the facility for the rest of your life. Type C contracts are less expensive up front, and you pay for health services as you need them, at market rates. Type Bs are hybrids of these two. A fourth option: month-to-month rentals with no entry fee.\n\nIt\u2019s important to compare apples with apples. The financials at a community offering full entrance-fee refunds, for example, may look very different from those at a monthly rental home that does not need to hold cash for refunds in reserve.\n\nHere are seven key items to focus on when considering a community\u2019s finances.\n\n\u25a0 Occupancy. If 90 percent or more of a home\u2019s rooms are full \u2014 and have been that way for the past few years \u2014 that suggests it\u2019s doing something right. This is especially important at C.C.R.C.s promising refunds, because you (or your heirs) often don\u2019t get the money back until someone has moved into your old unit.\n\n\u25a0 Rate increases. Lately, most C.C.R.C.s have been increasing their monthly fees by about 3 to 3.5 percent a year, said Justine Vogel, president of RiverWoods, a New Hampshire retirement community. If you see anything above that, ask for an explanation. Similarly, if you find a home where monthly fees have remained unchanged for several years, it may be struggling to maintain its occupancy rate.\n\n\u25a0 Debt rating. Many communities issue bonds to fund expansions or other capital improvements, and Fitch Ratings evaluates them. Ratings of AAA to BBB are considered \u201cinvestment grade\u201d and should bring a measure of comfort to potential residents.\n\n\u25a0 Profitability. You want a community that usually brings in more cash than it spends. When looking at a retirement home\u2019s financial statements, pay special attention to cash operating expenses as a percentage of cash operating revenue, suggested Amy Castleberry, a director at the investment bank Ziegler and a member of the Financial Advisory Panel of the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities. A number below 100 means the home is generating enough cash to cover expenses. Communities whose debt gets an investment-grade rating from Fitch have a median score of 96.1 percent.\n\n\u25a0 Capital improvements. Is your community spending enough on its upkeep? One way to gauge this: Find the line for capital spending on its annual financial statement and compare this with the line showing depreciation. Ms. Vogel said she generally liked to see spending equal to at least 50 percent of depreciation, though she conceded that could be way too low if the community hadn\u2019t spent anything in previous years. \u201cYou need to combine that info with a visit to the campus,\u201d she said. \u201cHow does it look? Does it look like they haven\u2019t replaced the carpet in a while? Is the dining venue outdated?\u201d", "title": "7 Ways to Judge a Retirement Community\u2019s Financial Health", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "HEATH QUARTET at the David Rubinstein Atrium (March 22, 7:30 p.m.). If it\u2019s slightly odd that this very accomplished quartet \u2014 notable for several recent recordings on Harmonia Mundi \u2014 is not playing in one of Lincoln Center\u2019s more formal spaces, at least you can hear them for free at this concert. Haydn and Tchaikovsky provide the fare.\n\n212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org/great-performers\n\nANGELA HEWITT at the 92nd Street Y (March 18, 3 p.m.). The sixth installment of Ms. Hewitt\u2019s Bach Odyssey comprises a single work, one that she has recorded twice to outstanding effect: the \u201cGoldberg\u201d Variations.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org\n\nJUILLIARD415 at Miller Theater (March 20, 6 p.m.). The students of the Juilliard School\u2019s period-instrument group venture uptown for this intimate, free pop-up concert. The repertoire is unusual chamber music by Leclair, Boismortier, Porpora and Handel.\n\n212-854-7799, millertheatre.com\n\n\u2018LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (March 22, 7:30 p.m., through May 10). Mary Zimmerman\u2019s 2007 production of Donizetti\u2019s tragedy returns, in the first of several permutations of the cast. Olga Peretyatko-Mariotti is the first Lucia (Jessica Pratt and Pretty Yende follow later in the run), with Vittorio Grigolo performing as the first Edgardo (Michael Fabiano appears opposite Ms. Yende toward the end of April). Massimo Cavalletti as Enrico and Vitalij Kowaljow as Raimondo round out the cast, and Roberto Abbado is on the podium.\n\n212-362-6000, metopera.org\n\nNEW YORK YOUTH SYMPHONY at Carnegie Hall (March 18, 2 p.m.). Always lively in performance, this youth orchestra should be admired for its commitment to new music. Thomas Kotcheff\u2019s \u201cGo And\u201d receives its premiere at this matinee, and Demarre McGill joins the group as the soloist for Kevin Puts\u2019s Flute Concerto. Also on the bill are Rimsky-Korsakov\u2019s \u201cCapriccio espagnol\u201d and Dvorak\u2019s Symphony No. 8.
