The flamboyant Ballet Nacional de Espa\u00f1a returns to Midtown for the first time in nearly two decades to open this year\u2019s Flamenco Festival at New York City Center. The large troupe showcases a variety of Spanish dance styles, from bolero to samplings of regional dances to, of course, flamenco. In \u201cSuite Sevilla,\u201d the company director Antonio Najarro also sprinkles in some ballet and contemporary dance, along with the expected fans, castanets and ruffled skirts. The festival continues the following week with Compa\u00f1\u00eda Eva Yerbabuena and Ballet Flamenco Jes\u00fas Carmona.\n\n212-581-1212, nycitycenter.org\n\nBALLETNEXT at New York Live Arts (March 6-9, 7:30 p.m.; March 10, 2 and 7:30 p.m.). Founded in 2011 by the ballerina Michele Wiles, BalletNext takes a collaborative approach to expanding the boundaries of ballet. In \u201cVibrer,\u201d Ms. Wiles and the trumpeter Tom Harrell combine jazz rhythms with classical moves; in \u201cFollin,\u201d she and the deaf dancer Bailey Anne Vincent fuse ballet\u2019s physical vocabulary with sign language. Rounding out the program is \u201cExperience,\u201d a brief duet that draws from Ms. Wiles\u2019s recent pregnancy, and \u201cThe Pianist,\u201d a playful work that features five female dancers in a nod to Edgar Degas\u2019s ballerina paintings.\n\n212-924-0077, newyorklivearts.org\n\n\n\nDANCE HEGINBOTHAM at the 92nd Street Y (March 2, 8 p.m.; March 3, 4 and 8 p.m.). As part of the annual 92nd Street Y\u2019s Harkness Dance Festival, John Heginbotham, a veteran of the Mark Morris Dance Group, presents an intimate evening of solos and duets from his company\u2019s repertory. Among the works performed will be \u201cThrowaway\u201d from 2010, described by the artist as a \u201cdance battle in miniature\u201d and set to music by Daft Punk; and \u201cLulu,\u201d an excerpt from the 2012 work \u201cTwin,\u201d to music by the electronic musician known as Aphex Twin. Included in the mix is \u201cSalty Dog,\u201d choreographed by Maile Okamura, a fellow alum of Mr. Morris\u2019s company and Dance Heginbotham\u2019s costume designer.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org", "title": "8 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nJUILLIARD DANCE at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Lincoln Center (March 21-23, 7:30 p.m., through March 24). For their seasonal showcase, the wunderkinds of this prestigious school present two works from the 1970s by American dance giants and a newer work from an astute contemporary voice. \u201cSpring Dances,\u201d as the program is called, includes Twyla Tharp\u2019s 1973 genre-busting gem \u201cDeuce Coupe\u201d to the music of the Beach Boys, Merce Cunningham\u2019s rigorous 1975 \u201cSounddance\u201d to music by David Tudor, and Crystal Pite\u2019s 2012 \u201cGrace Engine,\u201d which sets her forceful, fluid movement against a moody electronic score by Owen Belton.\n\n212-799-5000, juilliard.edu/calendar\n\nNICK MAUSS at the Whitney Museum of American Art (through May 14). In recent years, art museums have taken note of contemporary dance, curating and commissioning work for their galleries. Ballet has largely been excluded, which the visual and performance artist Nick Mauss attempts to rectify with his exhibition \u201cTransmissions.\u201d It comprises ballet scores, scenic designs and a modernist ballet conceived by Mr. Mauss, and weaves in explorations of gender, history and ballet\u2019s relationship to other art forms. Pieces from the Whitney\u2019s collection and other institutions, like the New York Public Library and the Kinsey Institute, are included as well.\n\n212-570-3600, whitney.org\n\nNEW YORK THEATER BALLET at the 92nd Street Y (March 16, 8 p.m.; March 17, 4 and 8 p.m.). This year marks the centenary of the birth of Jerome Rabinowitz, better known as Jerome Robbins, one of the most influential choreographers of the 20th century, from Broadway (\u201cFiddler on the Roof,\u201d \u201cWest Side Story\u201d) to ballet. To honor his contribution to the latter, New York Theater Ballet presents a trio of some of his lesser-known, more intimate works as part of the Harkness Dance Festival. \u201cRondo,\u201d \u201cSeptet\u201d and \u201cConcertino\u201d are all from the early 1980s; the second two were part of Robbins\u2019s \u201cFour Chamber Works\u201d to music by Igor Stravinsky.\n\n212-415-5500, 92y.org", "title": "8 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.\n\nREID BARTELME AND HARRIET JUNG at Works and Process at the Guggenheim (March 25-26, 7:30 p.m.). The design team of Reid Bartelme and Harriet Jung, who have created sophisticated, understated costumes for dance with increasing frequency over the past few years, mastermind an evening created in collaboration with some of their clients and choreographers: Lar Lubovitch, Pam Tanowitz, Jack Ferver, Gwen Welliver and Burr Johnson. Mr. Bartelme and Ms. Jung met as students at the Fashion Institute of Technology; they formed Reid & Harriet Design in 2011. For this program, they discuss their careers and inspirations \u2014 alongside, of course, some dancing that will bring their costumes to life.\n\n212-423-3587, worksandprocess.org\n\nA CELEBRATION OF ARNIE ZANE at New York Live Arts (March 25, noon-8:30 p.m.). Bill T. Jones directs this day honoring Arnie Zane (1948-88), a founder of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company who would have turned 70 this year. The event, which pays homage to Mr. Zane\u2019s accomplishments in dance and photography, includes afternoon classes exploring his movement influences, like contact improvisation and karate; in addition, former company members Jennifer Nugent and S\u00e9an Curran will teach excerpts from two of his works, \u201cContinuous Replay\u201d and \u201cFreedom of Information.\u201d The finale, starting at 7:30 p.m., is \u201cArnie Zane: An Introduction,\u201d a program of performances and stories.\n\n212-924-0077, newyorklivearts.org\n\nDAVALOIS FEARON at Mabou Mines Theater (March 27 at 7 p.m.; March 28-29 at 9 p.m.). Mabou Mines presents Ms. Fearon\u2019s \u201cTime to Talk,\u201d a multimedia work featuring music by Mike McGinnis that explores race and identity using the frame of both American and dance history. Inspired by her personal experiences within the academic and dance worlds, the work blends movement and talking with live music to shine the spotlight on inequalities in society. In the end, she hopes that spectators will leave the theater considering their own behavior. The engagement is part of Mabou Mine\u2019s Suite/Space, a performance initiative for artists.\n\n866-811-4111, maboumines.org", "title": "8 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRelax. Take a deep breath. In the immortal words of Queen Elsa, let it go. If there\u2019s a theme to this week\u2019s recommended titles, it might be that things aren\u2019t as hopeless as you think. From Lauren Slater\u2019s \u201cBlue Dreams,\u201d about pharmaceutical efforts to battle depression, to Steven Pinker\u2019s \u201cEnlightenment Now\u201d and Gregg Easterbrook\u2019s \u201cIt\u2019s Better Than It Looks,\u201d both of which marshal statistics to argue that life today is pretty O.K., to a study of happiness in old age and a debut novel that challenges Western views of mental illness, we\u2019ve got well-being on the mind. You\u2019ll also find a couple of memoirs \u2014 one from a former Marine, the other from a former denizen of Tokyo\u2019s avant-garde \u2014 and, for readers determined to wallow in the gloom, a look at America\u2019s intractable and increasing political divide. What, us worry?\n\nGregory Cowles\n\nSenior Editor, Books\n\nA TOKYO ROMANCE: A Memoir, by Ian Buruma. (Penguin Press, $26.) In this memoir, the Dutch-born historian and New York Review of Books editor Ian Buruma recounts his intellectual and sexual coming-of-age during several years he spent in Tokyo in his early 20s, in the company of playwrights, dancers, film directors and actors. \u201cBuruma is a keen observer and the owner of a well-provisioned mind,\u201d our critic Dwight Garner writes. \u201cThere are smart little junkets in this book into everything from Japanese movies (Buruma became a film critic for The Japan Times) to the country\u2019s tattooing culture to its female elevator operators, about whom he made a documentary film.\u201d\n\nBLUE DREAMS: The Science and the Story of the Drugs That Changed Our Minds, by Lauren Slater. (Little, Brown, $28.99.) In this capacious and rigorous history of psychopharmacology, the psychologist and writer Lauren Slater says that doctors don\u2019t really understand how psychotropic medications work or how to assess if a patient needs them. \u201c\u2018Blue Dreams,\u2019 like all good histories of medicine, reveals healing to be art as much as science,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. \u201cSlater doesn\u2019t demonize the imperfect remedies of the past or present \u2014 even as she describes their costs with blunt severity.\u201d\n\nENLIGHTENMENT NOW: The Case for Reason, Science, Humanism, and Progress, by Steven Pinker. (Viking, $35.) Pinker continues his recent argument for being happy about the state of the world, despite the rise of authoritarian nationalism, with a rousing defense of the four big ideas named in his subtitle. \u201cOptimism is not generally thought cool, and it is often thought foolish,\u201d Sarah Bakewell writes in her review. Be that as it may, she continues, this \u201cstrikes me as an excellent book, lucidly written, timely, rich in data and eloquent in its championing of a rational humanism that is \u2014 it turns out \u2014 really quite cool.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIT\u2019S BETTER THAN IT LOOKS: Reasons for Optimism in an Age of Fear, by Gregg Easterbrook. (PublicAffairs, $28.) According to Easterbrook, we worry more about threats like climate change and inequality than we recognize our good fortune. People, he says, react with astonishment when told how well we\u2019re doing, so his book sets out to tell them just that. \u201cThe primary causes of a mostly improving life \u2014 progress, both social and technical \u2014 entail a lot of change,\u201d he writes, and \u201ceven universally desirable change may be greeted with trepidation.\u201d But \u201cin the contemporary world most people are better off in most ways when compared to any prior generation.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFRESHWATER, by Akwaeke Emezi. (Grove Atlantic, $24.) This remarkable debut novel traces the course of mental illness in a young Nigerian-born woman from babyhood \u2014 when Ada\u2019s fretful crying cannot be soothed \u2014 through her college years, when multiple personalities begin to bloom inside her mind. Our reviewer, Tariro Mzezewa, praises it as \u201cpoetic and disturbing,\u201d and also groundbreaking. \u201cMore powerful than Emezi\u2019s prose,\u201d she writes, \u201cis what it brings to the real world. \u2026 This novel expands the universe of mental illness to include women of color and other ethnicities. Rooting Ada\u2019s story in Igbo cosmology forces us to further question our paradigm for what causes mental illness.\u201d", "title": "8 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Market report\n\n9 Elegant Trinket Boxes\n\nA place for your most precious possessions.", "title": "9 Elegant Trinket Boxes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Sexual Harassment\n\nCracking down on sexual harassment is that rare Albany unicorn, a priority both parties agree on. Even rarer, they seem to agree on how to make it happen: prohibiting secret settlements, banning forced arbitration, standardizing a definition of harassment for all state employees.\n\nBut when it comes to finalizing the details, disagreement prevails as usual. The Senate\u2019s bill defines sexual harassment as \u201cconduct of a sexual nature,\u201d a definition critics call too narrow. The Assembly\u2019s plan requires a neutral arbitrator, while the governor and Senate Republicans want to create an investigative arm within the Joint Commission on Public Ethics, despite critiques that the body lacks independence.\n\nAnd over it all have loomed new accusations that top state officials mishandled harassment claims, including one against Senator Jeffrey D. Klein, the leader of a breakaway group of Democrats that collaborates with Republicans. Mr. Klein will be one of \u201cfour men in a room\u201d \u2014 and no women \u2014 negotiating the final budget behind closed doors. (The others are Mr. Cuomo; Carl E. Heastie, the Assembly speaker; and John J. Flanagan, the Senate majority leader.)\n\nGun Control\n\nPhoto\n\nThe massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida led to a national student movement demanding gun control, but among Albany\u2019s leaders, the response has been a flurry of symbolic action, party division and not a single new law. Republicans who rule the Senate want more security, supporting armed guards in school, but no further gun control; Democrats who rule the Assembly want bans on possessing bump stocks \u2014 which accelerate the firing speed of semiautomatic weapons \u2014 and think that fewer guns, not more, is the answer.\n\nMr. Cuomo leans heavily toward his fellow Democrats on this issue \u2014 he is credited with a 2013 law that banned the sale of so-called assault weapons in the state \u2014 but may have a tough time convincing Republicans. Still, last week, Mr. Cuomo endorsed an idea floated by state Senator Michael Gianaris to put in place a 10-day waiting period for any gun purchase. The governor has repeatedly called for a bump stock ban, and may have some hope for a bill to bar domestic abusers from having firearms.\n\nTax Overhaul\n\nThe governor\u2019s promises in January to overhaul the state\u2019s tax code and shield New Yorkers from the new federal tax plan raised eyebrows. Academics and tax experts said such complicated proposals \u2014 swapping the income tax for a payroll tax, or funneling tax payments through deductible charitable contributions \u2014 had never been tried and shouldn\u2019t be rushed.\n\nNearly three months later, those fears may not even play out. The Senate has rejected both the payroll-tax plan, which the Assembly accepted, and the charitable-contributions tactic, which the Assembly partially rejected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cuomo, perhaps cognizant of the political points he may score for fiery remarks against the Trump administration, has doubled down on his plans. He has joined with other governors to sue the federal government over the tax plan, and in an appearance on WNYC on Friday, insisted that changing the state\u2019s tax laws was \u201cone of our top priorities.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEducation\n\nEducation is the biggest part of the state budget, and it\u2019s traditionally the last to be negotiated. This year, Mr. Cuomo has proposed increasing school aid by $769 million, or 3 percent. The Assembly countered with an increase almost twice as large, at $1.5 billion. Even the spending-shy Senate proposed a larger increase, of $957 million.\n\nActivists predicted that the state would spend heavily on education in anticipation of the elections this fall. \u201cNo one wants to go into an election year having their school district make cuts,\u201d said Jasmine Gripper, the legislative director for the advocacy group Alliance for Quality Education.\n\nMr. Cuomo may now have extra incentive to ramp up his support for school funding: His newly announced primary challenger, Cynthia Nixon, is a longtime education advocate.\n\nCongestion Pricing\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the battle over how to fund and rehabilitate New York City\u2019s flailing subway system rages on, Mr. Cuomo has thrown his support behind congestion pricing, the idea of charging cars to drive into the busiest part of Manhattan.\n\nBut neither the Senate nor the Assembly included the congestion pricing plan in their budget proposals, although the Assembly did include a fee on for-hire vehicles. Both houses also rejected the governor\u2019s proposal to make New York City pay for subway-related capital costs, though the Senate was open to making the city match state funding in a declared state of emergency. (The Assembly, dominated by members from the city, was not.)\n\nCriminal Justice\n\nIn January, Mr. Cuomo unveiled a plan to eliminate cash bail for many crimes and make several other criminal justice reforms. But such legislation usually dies in the State Senate, where Republicans are often loath to appear soft on crime. (An inverse dynamic is at play in the Assembly, where Democrats generally don\u2019t like bills that increase punishments for criminal offenses.)\n\nStill, Mr. Cuomo has continued to pound on the issue, calling the bail system \u201ca civil-rights abuse\u201d that \u201cfavors the wealthy.\u201d\n\nOpioid Tax\n\nAt first blush, this proposal \u2014 for a 2 cents-per-milligram surcharge for the active opioid ingredient in prescription drugs \u2014 would have seemed to hit a sweet spot in the divided State Legislature, addressing both the need to fight the heroin epidemic (which Senate Republicans have been actively supportive of in past sessions) and raising significant new revenue for the state, a priority for Democrats. But opposition to the plan has been vocal and politically savvy, as analysts questioned how much revenue it would raise. They also noted that because the state itself buys about a third of all opioids sold in the state, via Medicaid, it would essentially be taxing itself. Add in Republicans\u2019 general distaste for new taxes, and the opioid plan may be an impossible pill to swallow.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChild Victims Act\n\n\n\nUnder current state law, victims must bring a case against their abusers by their 23rd birthday, one of the most restrictive statutes of limitations in the country. The Assembly has pushed for more than a decade to extend that timeline, a measure supported by both the governor and nearly 80 percent of New Yorkers. But the measure has always died in the Senate, at the urging of groups such as the Catholic Church and the Boy Scouts of America.\n\n\n\nThis year, Republicans have said they are open to reforming the statute of limitations. But they remain opposed to a \u201clook-back window,\u201d a one-year period in which any victim could bring a claim, no matter how old. (Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the Archbishop of New York, has called a look-back window \u201ctoxic.\u201d)\n\nThat window is shaping up to be the sticking point for negotiations. \u201cThe window is not toxic, and it\u2019s also not up for debate,\u201d said Assemblywoman Linda B. Rosenthal of Manhattan, a longtime sponsor of the Child Victims Act.", "title": "9 Key Issues Await Albany in Final Week of Budget Negotiations", "authors": ["Vivian Wang", "Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOver the years the name and likeness of the Mexican artist Frida Kahlo, a fierce feminist and ardent communist, have been associated with a number of unlikely products.\n\nSneakers. Lipstick. Beer.\n\nBut Barbie doll?\n\nYes, Mattel, which manufactures Barbie, included a Kahlo doll in an inaugural series meant to coincide with International Women\u2019s Day.\n\nShe is part of the line of \u201cInspiring Women\u201d dolls that includes the aviator Amelia Earhart and the NASA mathematician Katherine Johnson, whose life was featured in the movie \u201cHidden Figures.\u201d\n\nKahlo, whom Mattel described as \u201ca celebrated artist, activist and symbol of strength\u201d and who died at the age of 47 in 1954, was known for self-portraits and other works that the Surrealist leader Andr\u00e9 Breton described as \u201ca ribbon around a bomb.\u201d She may not have approved of being cast as a variety of Barbie, the best-selling doll whose image Mattel has updated so as to address criticism that in body type and lifestyle it had perpetuated damaging stereotypes about women.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCertainly one family member took exception to Mattel\u2019s depiction of the artist, which eliminated her signature unibrow, a long single eyebrow that one commentator found emblematic of \u201cher striking and beautiful refusal to give in to certain sexist societal pressures.\u201d", "title": "Frida Kahlo Is a Barbie Doll Now. (Signature Unibrow Not Included.)", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSome said such accusations will taint the revolution, which is false because those two men did not make the revolution famous; rather the revolution made them famous,\u201d said Iman Shukri Abdel-Latif, one of the feminists and activists who criticized an internal investigation by Mr. Ali\u2019s party that exonerated him. \u201cWe can\u2019t truly oppose an oppressive regime with an opposition that is unjust and oppresses women,\u201d she added.\n\nIt\u2019s tempting to call this Egypt\u2019s #MeToo moment. But it may prove just another example of Egyptian women speaking out against sexual violence. In 2005, female journalists and activists exposed the use of systematic sexual violence by the government of Hosni Mubarak to stop them from protesting.\n\nEgypt\u2019s first conviction for street sexual harassment came in 2008, when a 27 year-old named Noha al-Ostaz dragged a man to a police station after he grabbed her breast. Officers refused to file a complaint until the woman\u2019s father arrived. Nobody had intervened to help her, and Egyptian media outlets accused her of cruelly \u201cruining the life\u201d of her assailant, who was sentenced to three years in prison.\n\nLess than a month after the 2011 uprising forced Mr. Mubarak to step down, the military subjected female activists to \u201cvirginity tests\u201d \u2014 a form of sexual assault. Three women exposed the assaults. One tried, in vain, to sue the military.\n\nI too became a victim. In November 2011, the riot police beat me, broke my left arm and right hand, and sexually assaulted me before I was detained by the Interior Ministry and then military intelligence. Later, I went on Egyptian television with both arms in casts and with X-rays of my injuries. I tried unsuccessfully to sue the regime.\n\nSeveral other Egyptian women have shared stories of sexual assault by policemen or mobs during protests since then. Their goal was obvious: to reassert men\u2019s dominance over hundreds of thousands of women now claiming a role in Egypt\u2019s political life.\n\nThe police and the military are not alone in silencing women. A feminist group in Cairo told me that at least 12 other women who were sexually assaulted were too ashamed to speak or were silenced by their families. We still don\u2019t know the name of a woman who was stripped to her bra by soldiers who then stomped on her chest in Tahrir Square in December 2011. That woman deserves a statue for her courage, not a silencing.\n\nFor years, Egyptian women have navigated our way out of the maze of taboo and shame to expose sexual violence by the state and by men in the street. It is slow going. But last December, a lawyer was sentenced to three years in prison for saying that women who wear ripped jeans should be raped as a punishment. And I believe that Email Girl has instigated a revolution against what I call the dictator in the home.", "title": "Opinion | A #MeToo Moment for Egypt? Maybe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs of March 16, Benji, the scruffy box-office sensation of the 1970s and \u201980s, is back and Netflix has got him. A new movie simply titled \u201cBenji,\u201d starring an adorable and agile mutt who\u2019s pretty much the original\u2019s equal in the winsome department, will have its premiere on that date. \u201cBenji\u201d was written and directed by Brandon Camp, whose father, Joe Camp, began making movies about this very good but occasionally mischievous canine back in 1974.\n\nThis was the height of the scrappy \u201cEasy Riders, Raging Bulls\u201d era of Hollywood, so, aptly enough, Mr. Camp\u2019s own career narrative was that of a maverick independent. Writing in 2015, my friend, the critic Vadim Rizov told Mr. Camp\u2019s story \u2014 eventual box-office triumph after multiple rejections from the big bad studios \u2014 for the A.V. Club and assessed all the Benji movies up to that time. Mr. Rizov\u2019s work remains a Baedeker of Benji.\n\nIt is probably fitting that a new \u201cBenji\u201d should find its home on a streaming service. (In an appearance on the \u201cToday\u201d show,\u201d Brandon Camp, appearing with his dad, said that he and one of the movie\u2019s co-producers, Jason Blum, had conducted a nationwide search for a dog to play the role, and found their pooch, whom they named Benji \u2014 the first mutt was actually named Higgins \u2014 after it had been abandoned in a parking lot in Virginia.)\n\nOver the years Mr. Rizov has exposed me to some low-quality live-action cute animal movies featured on video-on-demand and streaming services. In a recent email exchange, he told me of parents on the Amazon movie-review sections bemoaning the existence of such fare \u201cso terrible\u201d not even a 4-year-old could enjoy it. (One such item is titled \u201cA Talking Cat!?!\u201d the punctuation of which should give you an idea of the quality of its special effects, among other things.) At least \u201cBenji\u201d represents a proven, reliable brand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new picture is a remake of the original 1974 \u201cBenji,\u201d with a few variations. It changes the location from a Texas town to New Orleans. The single parent who won\u2019t let the brother and sister adopt the homeless dog is here a mom rather than a dad. The quaint diner that figured in the 1974 story line is now a quaint pawnshop. The kids, the brother and sister Carter and Frankie (played by Gabriel Bateman and Darby Camp, who is no relation to the director), are updated with 21st century savvy.", "title": "A (Shaggy) Star Is Reborn: Netflix Brings Us a New \u2018Benji\u2019", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Think of Egyptian dancers and the first image to come to mind is not likely to be a ballerina.\n\nYet once upon a time, the Egyptian ballerina Magda Saleh danced the dream role of Giselle in Moscow as a guest star with the mighty Bolshoi Ballet. Even more improbably, she danced it in the opera house in her hometown, Cairo \u2014 where to call a woman a \u201cdancer\u201d was an insult \u2014 with a full troupe of Egyptians trained by Russians in an academy established by the Egyptian state.\n\nThis flowering of ballet in Egypt, an East-meets-West tale of Cold War cultural politics, happened long ago, in the 1960s and early \u201970s. But it\u2019s receiving new attention in a documentary archly called \u201cA Footnote in Ballet History\u201d and in the latest installment of the performance series \u201cFrom the Horse\u2019s Mouth\u201d (at the Theater at the 14 Street Y, Thursday to Sunday).\n\nThe \u201cHorse\u2019s Mouth\u201d show, which combines personal anecdotes with structured improvisations, addresses many aspects of Egyptian dance: stick-fighting, whirling dervishes and, the form that probably does come to mind first, belly dance. \u201cBallet is such a tiny part,\u201d said Tina Croll, one of the organizers. Even so, Ms. Saleh is the central hub of the program, as is she is of the documentary.", "title": "A Ballerina\u2019s Story, Once Upon a Time in Egypt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Most Incredible Thing\u201d had its debut at Sadler\u2019s Wells Theater in London in 2011. (Its limited run sold out and received an Evening Standard Theater Award.) But the lavish multimedia production proved too expensive to tour and hasn\u2019t been performed since 2012. Justin Peck, also inspired by the Andersen story, made a one-act dance for New York City Ballet, with a score by Bryce Dessner of the National.\n\nWhen Hope Muir, the new artistic director of Charlotte Ballet (formerly of Scottish Ballet), was looking for interesting family fare, she negotiated the revival, with most of the same creative principals but scaled down slightly. Some changes have been made. Instead of the 60-piece symphonic orchestration, the Pet Shop Boys\u2019 electronic score will be used. And projections of shadows that Mr. de Frutos had conceived as a tribute to Pilobolus Dance Theater now actually have been done by Pilobolus (and will be shown on film).\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a recent Tuesday in Charlotte, a man with a bald head and a mischievous expression slipped off his sneakers to lead two dozen dancers through a rehearsal. This was Mr. de Frutos, 54, who was revising his choreography for the American production. He was working on a scene involving Josh Hall as the clockmaker and Chelsea Dumas as the princess who wins his heart, guiding them through a dance in which they are reunited and the princess proposes marriage.\n\nCaught up in the emotion, Ms. Dumas waited too long to pivot her body and missed a cue. She apologized to Mr. de Frutos, who reassured her: \u201cIt\u2019s absolutely fine. It\u2019s about getting the right feeling.\u201d He grinned. \u201cNow feel it faster.\u201d\n\n\u201cActing is action,\u201d Mr. de Frutos likes to tell the dancers. He has taught them that when their movements tell the story, they don\u2019t have to do anything with their faces.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201dYou write what you want it to be, and then you listen to the actors and they lead you in a different way,\u201d he said on a break from rehearsal. In his studio at the McColl Center for Art + Innovation, where he is an artist in residence, he sat on a couch he had painted with a Maya Angelou quotation. When he\u2019s not busy choreographing, he makes visual art. \u201cLondon is a place where the national sport is pigeonholing,\u201d he said of his dual career. \u201cI don\u2019t like pigeons and I don\u2019t like holes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. de Frutos, born in Venezuela, has worked with one foot in the mainstream (British revivals of \u201cCarousel\u201d and \u201cCabaret,\u201d the pilot for \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d) and one foot in the avant-garde (\u201cLondon Road,\u201d a documentary musical about the murder of five prostitutes, which he largely choreographed to the dialogue). Although he made his reputation dancing in the nude, his most notorious piece was \u201cEternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez\u201d (2009), which depicted pregnant nuns and the electrocution of a deformed pope, leading to audience walkouts and the cancellation of a planned BBC broadcast.\n\n\u201cThose were the works that I needed to make at the time,\u201d he said. Still, he bristled when the worried producers of the British production of \u201cThe Most Incredible Thing\u201d reminded him once too often that it was going to be a family ballet. They \u201cmade me feel like they were putting this in the hands of somebody that didn\u2019t understand what a family was,\u201d he said.\n\nDespite that background, he says he is less cynical than the Pet Shop Boys expected; they learned to respect his romanticism. Mr. Tennant said that the first time he attended a performance of \u201cThe Most Incredible Thing,\u201d he burst into tears, overcome by the emotion of the ballet and the knowledge of how much work had gone into it.\n\nRemembering the moment, Mr. Tennant confessed he was starting to tear up again and said that the Pet Shop Boys found the ballet all the more remarkable because they weren\u2019t onstage for it. \u201cI\u2019m looking forward to sitting in the theater in Charlotte and seeing what it sounds like,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Ballet Score? Not Such a Stretch for the Pet Shop Boys", "authors": ["Gavin Edwards"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Good neighbors\n\nFive years ago we moved from Torrance to two floors near the top of the 801 Tower in downtown Los Angeles.\n\nShortly after we moved here, the woman who at the time at the time was the C.E.O. of Greenland USA, the U.S. subsidiary of a Chinese construction firm, made a formal visit about a skyscraper they were building across the way.\n\nShe asked if we would mind if they built it a little higher, which could obstruct our view. We both knew it was just a courtesy, but I thought her old-world charm was very classy. We\u2019re now one of their preferred mortgage lenders.\n\nAn open-door policy\n\nMy office is just past the reception area as you exit the elevator. I chose that location by design, to be accessible. I also leave my door open since I believe closed doors can appear ominous and threatening.", "title": "A Bank President Bridges Cultures in Downtown Los Angeles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "At least two venues received the notice ordering the limit on foreign customers \u2014 a cafe and bar called Lush, and Pyro, a pizza bar, both owned by the same person. Although the restriction will be lifted after the congress ends next week, some fear the scrutiny will not.\n\nManagers of the two bars, who would not comment for the record, hung the notices outside the entrances. Photos quickly appeared on social media, where they elicited outrage and disappointment.\n\n\u201cI wonder when people are going to start thinking things are getting a bit much,\u201d one person wrote on WeChat, China\u2019s major messaging platform, in a group chat normally devoted to events being hosted at Lush. One website for foreigners made light of the ban: \u201cTen\u2019s a party, eleven\u2019s an offense.\u201d\n\nSome Beijingers advised against reading too much into the notice. The city always makes some efforts to put on a good face during political events in the capital, and staff in at least three other venues in Wudaokou claimed no knowledge of any restrictions on patrons.\n\nOthers, however, saw the edict as an effort to tame a party culture that has become notorious among students.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany saw parallels with a cleanup last year of another thriving night life district in Beijing. The crackdown on \u201cDirty Bar Street\u201d in the central Sanlitun neighborhood, known for its live bands and bikini-clad pole dancers, demolished dozens of structures, ostensibly for violations of building codes or safety regulations. After a makeover, the strip is now a bland pedestrian mall, anchored by fashion boutiques and a new public library.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTavey Lin, co-owner of the bar and restaurant 4Corners in central Beijing, acknowledged that there is more scrutiny from the authorities during important government meetings. He recalled having to cancel one event at his restaurant after the police found out a foreign ambassador was planning to make an appearance. According to Mr. Lin, that sounded too risky to the police, who suddenly launched an inspection.\n\n\u201cWe got inspected for literally everything,\u201d he said. \u201cWe had to close for a few days and spend thousands on remodeling.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Wudaokou, the local authorities have previously used the enforcement of zoning and safety regulations to target certain venues \u2014 not without reason. After a fire killed 19 migrant workers in a Beijing apartment building last November, Lush has not been allowed to hold live music concerts or open-mic nights because of fire safety concerns.\n\nMr. Lin says stronger enforcement of fire codes was probably overdue. Pyro, for instance, had only one exit, despite being in a basement and drawing crowds of more than 200 revelers.\n\n\u201cChina\u2019s just enforcing codes and regulations that should have been done right in the first place,\u201d Mr. Lin said.\n\nAccording to The Beijinger, an online English-language directory and calendar of events, at least five Wudaokou bars and restaurants were forced to temporarily close in January of last year to make mandated upgrades in fire safety. Some never reopened.", "title": "A Bar Street Falls Quiet as Beijing Puts a Limit on Foreigners", "authors": ["Olivia Mitchell Ryan", "Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Yardeni, the author of a coming book, \u201cPredicting the Markets: A Professional Autobiography,\u201d tried, gamely, to handicap the probability that trade tensions would turn virulent conflict and seriously damage the economy and the markets.\n\n\u201cThis trade stuff isn\u2019t good in the short term, we can say that for sure,\u201d he said. \u201cBeyond that, I can\u2019t predict very much with certainty because I don\u2019t really know how far the president is going with this and I\u2019m not sure that he knows either.\u201d\n\nThat uncertainty puts investors in an awkward position.\n\nIt\u2019s not that the specific actions taken by President Trump \u2014 tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum \u2014 will wreak global havoc. Steel and aluminum may not be important enough for that: They accounted for only 2 percent of American imports last year, or 0.2 percent of gross domestic product, as The Economist has pointed out.\n\nFurthermore, on Thursday, Mr. Trump carved out exceptions even to this particular trade restriction. He said that for now, at least, he would not impose tariffs on Mexico and Canada, two of America\u2019s closest allies, pending renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and might not impose them on Australia, either.\n\nStill the president has begun what, if it continues, would be a colossal shift in longstanding United States policy. Instead of relying on multilateral institutions that have been pillars of world trade \u2014 and American power \u2014 since World War II, the president vowed to revise America\u2019s approach, stressing bilateral costs and benefits, and national security, very narrowly defined.\n\nThe Trump tilt has left many people flabbergasted.\n\nMichael Froman, who served as United States trade representative in the Barack Obama administration, said he was troubled by this possible shift. \u201cI don\u2019t really know what it means to enter a global trade war\u201d as government policy, he said on a conference call at the Council on Foreign Relations, where he is a distinguished fellow.\n\nSerious people, he said, have tried to devise ways to \u201cexit trade wars,\u201d not start them. Mr. Froman pointed out that foreign governments \u2014 including close allies \u2014 have already prepared lists of American exports targeted for retaliation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe European Union, for example, says it might begin with American products like Harley-Davidsons, Kentucky bourbon and blue jeans, and go on from there. Once such a process begins, it could spiral downward, with the tit-for-tat tariffs between America and its trading partners during the Great Depression a vivid historical lesson.\n\nThe implications are chilling, in the view of many strategists.\n\nOn Wednesday, for example, Marco Pirondini, head of United States equities at Amundi Pioneer in Boston, declared in a note to investors that President Trump had begun a \u201cdangerous\u201d and \u201crisky\u201d second phase of his economic agenda. The first phase, he said, \u201cfocused on tax cuts and deregulation\u201d with \u201cextremely positive\u201d results for corporate earnings, many taxpayers and investors in the stock market.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow, however, with the resignation of Gary D. Cohn, the president\u2019s top economic adviser, who opposed Mr. Trump\u2019s shift on trade, it is clear that Mr. Trump \u201cis focused on changing trade relations as a means of reducing trade deficits and incentivizing U.S.-based production,\u201d Mr. Pirondini said.\n\nMany global companies will suffer, he said, adding that Mr. Trump\u2019s policy is likely to be accompanied by \u201cincreasing inflationary pressures and margin pressure for corporations, and more volatility for equities.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, he added that Mr. Trump was using \u201ctheatrical\u201d methods to improve his negotiating position. That could have unforeseen negative consequences.\n\nMr. Pirondini said he did not expect that the president would actually embrace a full-scale trade war \u2014 which he defined as a contraction in global trade that exceeds any associated economic contraction. But he said Mr. Trump\u2019s policy tilt might ignite a series of conflicts with America\u2019s trade partners, to say nothing of the Asian giant that appears to be the real focus of Mr. Trump\u2019s ire: China. Until trade tensions are resolved, he said, the stock market is likely to endure episodes of heightened turmoil.\n\nAs if the market needed more drama this year. Mr. Rosenberg of Gluskin Sheff says stocks have entered \u201ca late-stage bull market.\u201d Factors like rising interest rates, soaring debt loads, incipient inflation and stretched valuations have made equities vulnerable, he said.\n\nThe stock market is already in what, in Wall Street jargon, is correction territory: By Feb. 8, stocks had declined more than 10 percent from their Jan. 26 peak and haven\u2019t recovered all their losses.\n\n\u201cThere is a very good chance that we will have another 10 percent correction, below the trough that the market hit in February,\u201d Mr. Rosenberg said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy some definitions, a decline of 20 percent or more would end the bull market. That may be semantics, however. A bear market, in Mr. Rosenberg\u2019s view, would be associated with a \u201cpernicious and protracted decline.\u201d Because the economy is reasonably strong \u2014 and stimulus from the recent tax cut has not had its full effect \u2014 stocks could rebound quickly, he said.\n\nWhatever you call it, Mr. Rosenberg counsels prepare for a coming decline by raising the cash portion of their portfolios.\n\nMany other strategists are more sanguine.\n\nEd Clissold, chief United States strategist with Ned Davis Research Group, said that a technical analysis of the market showed that it had \u201cretested\u201d important support levels. \u201cMarket breadth isn\u2019t what we\u2019d want to see,\u201d he said, \u201cand if the market remains choppy for a very long time, that will be a concern. But so far, so good.\u201d\n\nLaszlo Birinyi, an independent analyst who has weathered decades of crises, said, \u201cI don\u2019t think we will know how important these trade issues are for a long time, so it\u2019s best not to pay too much attention to them. Many big events in the news \u2014 Brexit, the November election \u2014 set off panics but turn out to be fine for the stock market.\u201d\n\nMr. Yardeni points to the benefits of the new tax law, which has nearly doubled Wall Street\u2019s expectations for the earnings growth rate of the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index, to 19 percent from 10.\n\n\u201cThat hasn\u2019t all been factored into stock prices yet,\u201d he said. \u201cWe may have to get through these trade issues first. But I don\u2019t think the bull market is over yet.\u201d", "title": "A Battle Over Trade Crashes the Bull Market\u2019s Birthday Party", "authors": ["Jeff Sommer"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "A large image of Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher and freethinker, stands out among a galaxy of literary posters lining the wall of the entry staircase, a taste of what\u2019s to come.\n\n\u201cChina is not a liberal society, it\u2019s not a free country,\u201d Mr. Liu said, sitting in a quiet corner of the Thinkers Cafe, a mellow hangout within the store that meanders along a side corridor to a small back room furnished with antique Chinese furniture.\n\n\u201cBut the bookstore is a way to express our longing for freedom and our hope for the establishment of a free society,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nA new patron would be forgiven for believing the owner had a lively sense of irony. One of the first books to catch the eye on the front table is an 11th edition of \u201cRobert\u2019s Rules of Order.\u201d\n\nThe book is a recent hot seller. That is not because members of the Communist Party want to introduce parliamentary procedures written by a 19th-century American Army major to their gatherings. Chinese executives and entrepreneurs buy the volume for business reasons: to learn how to conduct a product conference, or manage a sales convention, Mr. Liu said.\n\nA guide to running a democratic legislature, \u201cHow Parliament Works,\u201d by the British politicians Robert Rogers and Rhodri Walters, first published in 1987, is also on the front table.\n\n\u201cThis is more politically sensitive,\u201d Mr. Liu said. \u201cUnfortunately, it is not as popular as Roberts.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll Sages has the feel of a well-ordered, smaller version of the Strand Bookstore in Manhattan, though judging from the photos on the walls, Mr. Liu prefers comparisons with the City Lights bookstore in San Francisco and Shakespeare & Company in Paris. Three cats \u2014 sometimes tiptoeing over the books on the tables \u2014 add some charm.\n\nA People\u2019s Liberation Army veteran is in charge of the floor; he keeps displays in meticulous order and the wood floor noticeably clean. A few canvas bags and T-shirts with snappy slogans are for sale near the front desk, but the focus is on the books. The coffee in the cafe is not for lingering over.\n\nA banner in English under the cash register reads, \u201cI cannot live without books.\u201d A copy of the Declaration of Independence hangs by the front door.\n\nThe clientele seems to be as varied as the books. The store is strategically located, within walking distance of China\u2019s premier university campus, but people from all over the country drop by.\n\nOn a recent weekend, a manager of a chemical company in the southern city of Shenzhen pushed a trolley full of books to the cashier for dispatch home by air courier. High-ranking military officers, party officials, rich society figures and celebrity entrepreneurs are all customers.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a secret what they buy,\u201d Mr. Liu said. \u201cBut take a look at the books, and you will see.\u201d\n\nThe books in All Sages are all in Chinese. That makes the selection dependent not only on Mr. Liu\u2019s broad-ranging tastes, but on the Chinese publishing houses.\n\nThey, in turn, are subject to the Communist Party censors who control what is published by Chinese authors and foreign writers translated into Chinese.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe censorship is not a precise art, but it is a constant presence. Internal party guidelines on what is prohibited are passed from the propaganda apparatus to the bosses of the publishing houses, sometimes on a daily basis. They are never made public. Nor is any list of banned books.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome basic rules prevail, Mr. Liu said. The first motivation of the censors is protection of the Communist Party. \u201cAnything that explains the Communist Party as a threat is a red line,\u201d he said.\n\nThis leads to some striking choices. Books about the Soviet Union\u2019s labor camps are banned, but accounts of the Nazi concentration camps are tolerated. Histories of Castro\u2019s rule in Cuba are not translated much; Cuba\u2019s medical system compared too favorably with China\u2019s overcrowded hospitals.\n\nWith about 600 large, state-run publishing houses and 3,000 smaller publishers attached to government agencies, some titles that annoy the government sometimes slip through the net. Publishers tend to be liberals and lovers of literature, and some of them want to publish good books. Some push the parameters.\n\nSo in an exception to the rule against maligning a Communist Party, one of Mr. Liu\u2019s favorites, Arthur Koestler\u2019s novel \u201cDarkness at Noon,\u201d about the Soviet gulag, was available in China for many years.\n\nIt was last published in 2006, however, and now appears to be banned. Secondhand editions of Koestler\u2019s classic are available online for $50. The original price: $1.50.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmong the steady sellers at All Sages are books on American history and biographies of the early presidents \u2014 Washington and Jefferson in particular \u2014 and of Benjamin Franklin. The interest in America\u2019s founding fathers is tied up with a thirst to know how America became a democratic and global power, Mr. Liu said.\n\nRecent political books about presidential election campaigns do not appeal much to his clientele, Mr. Liu said. He said he would read Michael Wolff\u2019s \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d due out in Chinese soon, before stocking it.\n\nTwo standbys for Western liberals \u2014 Hannah Arendt\u2019s \u201cThe Origins of Totalitarianism\u201d and George Washington\u2019s Farewell Address, which outlines his argument for term limits \u2014 have always sold well.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the last several weeks, both works circulated on the Chinese internet, in a quiet protest against Mr. Xi\u2019s decision to scrap the Chinese Constitution\u2019s two-term limit for presidents. Most likely, the censors never read what Washington had to say, Mr. Liu said.\n\nWeekends are the busiest time at the store, and on a recent Saturday the narrow aisles were packed, especially around the nonfiction shelves. Fiction is not the store\u2019s strength.\n\nThere is plenty of Margaret Atwood and Alice Munro but no Joan Didion. Books on feminism merit only two shelves, a function of slow demand.\n\nIn the philosophy section, Sue Ping, 29, a Tsinghua University M.B.A. student dressed in a white sweater, jeans and a black beret, was searching for Plato\u2019s \u201cThe Republic.\u201d \u201cFor me, it\u2019s paradise,\u201d Ms. Ping said of the store. \u201cI buy online but I come because I like the atmosphere. It\u2019s very open, you feel welcome.\u201d\n\nA few shelves away, Daisy Fu, 45, a primary school science teacher, who came with her husband on their motorbike, was deciding whether to buy a book about North Korea. \u201cA bookstore is a symbol of culture; we need it,\u201d she said. \u201cEven though I don\u2019t come often, it\u2019s important to know I can come and walk among the books.\u201d\n\nOne book that Mr. Liu knows he will never be able to stock stands out. Works critical of Mao Zedong are automatically banned, and a sensational memoir, \u201cA Life of Chairman Mao\u201d by Li Zhisui, Mao\u2019s personal doctor of many years, is considered a particular abomination. The book describes Mao as a tyrannical personality with a fiendish sexual appetite and appalling personal hygiene who suffered from a motor neuron disease in his last years.\n\n\u201cThere is literally no way to get this book in China,\u201d Mr. Liu said. \u201cJust imagine if I put two copies on the shelves. The minimum punishment would be a fine of $3,000. The medium-level punishment would be shutting down the bookstore. And the most extreme would be the bookstore owner jailed for three to five years.\u201d", "title": "A Beijing Bookstore Where George Washington Is on the Shelves", "authors": ["Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "If Mark Zuckerberg and a janitor who works at Facebook\u2019s headquarters each received a speeding ticket while driving home from work, they\u2019d each owe the government the same amount of money. Mr. Zuckerberg wouldn\u2019t bat an eye.\n\nThe janitor is another story.\n\nFor people living on the economic margins, even minor offenses can impose crushing financial obligations, trapping them in a cycle of debt and incarceration for nonpayment. In Ferguson, Mo., for example, a single $151 parking violation sent a black woman struggling with homelessness into a seven-year odyssey of court appearances, arrest warrants and jail time connected to her inability to pay.\n\nAcross America, one-size-fits-all fines are the norm, which I demonstrate in an article for the University of Chicago Law Review. Where judges do have wiggle room to choose the size of a fine, mandatory minimums and maximums often tie their hands. Some states even prohibit consideration of a person\u2019s income. And when courts are allowed to take finances into account, they frequently fail to do so.\n\nOther places have saner methods. Finland and Argentina, for example, have tailored fines to income for almost 100 years. The most common model, the \u201cday fine,\u201d scales sanctions to a person\u2019s daily wage. A small offense like littering might cost a fraction of a day\u2019s pay. A serious crime might swallow a month\u2019s paycheck. Everyone pays the same proportion of their income.", "title": "Opinion | A Billionaire and a Nurse Shouldn\u2019t Pay the Same Fine for Speeding", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Yet many Puerto Ricans fled with plans to return. For them, the leap north was a respite from the immediate chaos after the hurricane: the lack of electricity, unreliable hospitals and long lines for gas and food. It is too early to determine how many may return, but there is little doubt that Puerto Ricans have begun trickling back to the island.\n\nFor many, it is a joyous return to the motherland after months in exile. But the homecoming is still bittersweet. Those returning must come to terms with an island that is still crippled, where power outages are frequent, businesses remain shuttered and hillsides are pocked with blue roof tarps.\n\nOlder people like Enrique and Emma are especially vulnerable to this instability. More than 23 percent of the population in Puerto Rico is over 60, higher than anywhere else in Latin America. And that number is growing as young people abandon the island and leave elders to fend for themselves.\n\nBy returning, Enrique and Emma were taking a precarious leap of faith, given their age and fragile health. They were trading away access to world-class medical care in New York City for the unpredictable conditions on an island they yearned for even though it was ill-equipped to tend to their needs.", "title": "A Bittersweet Journey Back to Puerto Rico After Maria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "After her conviction, Ms. Desmond tried to sue the theater and to have her criminal conviction overturned. Both efforts failed. But Nova Scotia introduced laws banning segregation in 1954 and the province formally apologized to Ms. Desmond and issued a posthumous pardon in 2010. Ms. Desmond died in New York at age 50 and was buried in Halifax.\n\nImage A conceptual image of the front of the new Canadian bank note featuring a portrait of Viola Desmond. Credit Bank of Canada\n\n\u201cHer legal challenge galvanized the black community in Halifax\u2019s north end and paved the way for a broader understanding of human rights across our country,\u201d Bill Morneau, the finance minister who made the final selection for the bills, said at the unveiling of the design last week.\n\nWith Ms. Desmond on its currency, Canada will join several other countries that have moved toward portraying women other than monarchs on their currency.\n\nLast summer, Mark Carney, the Canadian who is the governor of the Bank of England, announced that the novelist Jane Austen would appear on Britain\u2019s 10-pound notes. The United States has plans to put the black abolitionist Harriet Tubman on $20 bills, but the Trump administration may not go forward with them.\n\nTwo years ago, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who describes himself as a feminist and whose government requires departments to examine their programs to ensure gender equality, said the country would introduce a woman who wasn\u2019t the monarch on the front of its bank notes. In a first, the Bank of Canada asked the public for nominations.\n\nMore than 26,000 suggestions poured in. The list was culled to 461 women, and a panel of experts from a variety of fields produced a shorter list for the government.\n\n\u201cIt was amazing,\u201d said Jonathan Rose, a professor of political studies at Queen\u2019s University who is a member of the panel that made the recommendations. \u201cIt\u2019s a reimagining of our currency and the role it plays in defining the country.\u201d\n\nAlthough Ms. Desmond becomes the first woman other than the queen to be featured alone on the front of a Canadian bank note, she is not the first woman on Canadian money. Last year, for Canada\u2019s 150th anniversary, the Bank of Canada issued a small number of special bank notes on which Agnes Macphail, the first woman elected to Parliament, shares the front with three male politicians.", "title": "A Black Woman Who Defied Segregation in Canada Will Appear on Its Currency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "In California, the fight over denser development has been complicated by the state\u2019s housing crisis. About a third of the state\u2019s six million renters pay more than half of their monthly income on rent, according to census figures. Homelessness is rising throughout the state, and about one in five residents in the state lives in poverty once housing costs are factored in \u2014 the highest poverty rate in the nation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Wiener, who has pushed for various housing bills in both the State Senate and in his previous job on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, said his bill would help reduce housing costs by speeding up construction and alleviating a housing shortage that has plagued the state for decades. High housing costs are also a culprit behind the state\u2019s longer commutes. In the Bay Area, about 5 percent of commuters spend more than 90 minutes traveling to work, compared with 3 percent nationwide, according to an analysis of census data by the Brookings Institution.\n\nBut lower- and even middle-income residents fear being evicted or priced out of their neighborhoods, making them resist development. Some of Mr. Wiener\u2019s most vocal opposition has come from anti-gentrification and tenants\u2019 rights groups that see his plan as a socioeconomic makeover backed by the real estate industry. Mr. Wiener said late last month that he was amending the bill to add provisions to restrict demolition and tenant displacement. Hearings are expected in the coming weeks.\n\nIn part because of the vexed politics, states have often taken a lighter approach to promoting density, using carrots rather than sticks. In the Northeast, at least six states \u2014 Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Maine, New Jersey and New York \u2014 have adopted goals of sharply slowing the growth in vehicle miles traveled in the coming decades. Their plans typically envision financial incentives for revitalizing downtown areas and encouraging greater density.\n\nCalifornia tried an incentive approach to density with the Sustainable Communities Act, a sweeping bill passed in 2008. But some experts say it did not go nearly far enough to change the state\u2019s urban sprawl or car culture.\n\nCalifornia has made impressive strides in solar and wind power and its push for electric vehicles. But the combination of high housing costs and rising commute times threatens to keep the state from achieving its ambitious target of cutting emissions 40 percent below 1990 levels by 2030.\n\nLast year, the California Air Resources Board estimated that meeting those goals would require a 7 percent cut in vehicle miles traveled by 2030, compared with levels that the agency projects would otherwise be reached under current policy. That would be 1.5 fewer miles per day for the average person.\n\n\u201cLand use is so fundamental to everything,\u201d said Ethan Elkind, director of the climate program at the Center for Law, Energy and the Environment at the University of California, Berkeley. \u201cAnd it\u2019s one of the areas where California is lagging.\u201d", "title": "A Bold, Divisive Plan to Wean Californians From Cars", "authors": ["Conor Dougherty", "Brad Plumer"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Moser had been an understudy and had been in the chorus. \u201cIt was always in our mind that she would take over when Pamela Charles left the show,\u201d said Jerry Adler, who was a stage manager on \u201cMy Fair Lady.\u201d \u201cIt was done so often in show business, coming out of the chorus, rehearsing and taking over.\u201d\n\nFor some, permitting an American to play Eliza Doolittle was too much. Twenty-five years later, when Mr. Harrison had artistic control over a revival of \u201cMy Fair Lady,\u201d he was adamant about casting a British-born actress for the part \u2014 Cheryl Kennedy. He tangled with Actors\u2019 Equity, getting applause when he appeared on her behalf at a hearing about whether she should be permitted to go on, but Equity said no. The case went to arbitration, and the decision was reversed.\n\nBut she missed opening night because of laryngitis.\n\nSo for all Mr. Harrison\u2019s arguments, the role went to the understudy \u2014 Nancy Ringham, who, like Ms. Moser, was an American.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs for Ms. Moser\u2019s first performance, she could have danced all night, but she did not. She went out with friends after the show, but in many ways, it was just another night. \u201cI just remember going through it,\u201d she said, sitting in her apartment on the Upper West Side.\n\nLike \u201cThe Phantom of the Opera\u201d or \u201cChicago\u201d or other long-running shows of a later generation, \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d was a phenomenon by then, and cast changes did not seem to matter. But the producers would not have wanted to call too much attention to this one. She was not the name her predecessors had been. \u201cThey wanted everyone to believe the English aura was continuing,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Moser remembered a backstage moment with Biff Liff, the production stage manager. \u201cHe said, \u2018Your first word is \u2018Ow!\u2019\u201d \u2014 the actor playing Freddy bumps into her, knocking her flowers to the ground \u2014 \u201c\u2018and after that you\u2019re on your own,\u2019\u201d she recalled.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d been in the show,\u201d she said. \u201cThere was no doubt I could do the lines.\u201d\n\nThe closing night was different. There was a party, paid for by the cast, she said. It took place downstairs in what was then the Mark Hellinger Theater. (In 1991, the building was sold to the Times Square Church, a nondenominational Protestant church that conducts gospel-influenced services from the stage.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI wanted some souvenirs,\u201d Ms. Moser said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t take the clothes.\u201d\n\nShe took the coat hangers the costumes had been hung on. And she walked off with the shoes she had worn as a scruffy flower vendor, before the transformation at the hands of Henry Higgins and Colonel Pickering.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPutting clothes on helps you feel you\u2019re in character,\u201d she said. \u201cThose were so foreign to anything in my life, but they transported me into that first scene. I\u2019d put on the shoes and think, \u2018Yes, that\u2019s Eliza.\u2019 \u201d\n\nMs. Moser had come to New York from Pennsylvania in 1946 to attend the Juilliard School, an intimidating experience. \u201cAll the men were coming back from the war,\u201d she said. \u201cThey were older. They were knowledgeable. They were so far ahead of me in their musical education.\u201d\n\nAs spring break approached in 1947, she did not want to go home to Harrisburg. \u201cA friend said, \u2018I heard you could write a letter to the Theater Guild and get an audition,\u2019\u201d Ms. Moser recalled.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe wrote the letter. Back came instructions on when and where to appear for the audition. \u201cWhen I got finished, they asked if I\u2019d like to go to London,\u201d she recalled. \u201cI said, \u2018Oh, yes.\u2019 I didn\u2019t even know that \u2018Oklahoma!\u2019 was going to London.\u201d\n\nBut that is getting ahead of the story. She did not know that the play she was auditioning for was \u201cOklahoma!\u201d either.\n\nShe heard nothing for weeks, until a telegram arrived. It said to go to the St. James Theater for what turned out to be a second audition.\n\nAnd then she was off to England, arriving in Manchester and going onstage the same night. Later, in London, the show received 14 curtain calls.\n\nBack in New York, where \u201cOklahoma!\u201d was still running, she was called in to play giggling Gertie. Ms. Moser later played Carrie in the 1949 revival of \u201cCarousel,\u201d first on the road and later at the Majestic Theater.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe married \u2014 \u201chuge mistake\u201d \u2014 and moved to England. When \u201cCarousel\u201d went to London, \u201cI was Carrie again.\u201d\n\nTo play Eliza Doolittle, she was sent to a speech teacher for elocution lessons more intense than what she went through onstage with Henry Higgins teaching her to pronounce vowels and H\u2019s the upper-crust way. \u201cCecil Beaton\u201d \u2014 who had designed the costumes for \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d and was British \u2014 \u201ccame to the show and thought I was English,\u201d she said. \u201cObviously, I didn\u2019t screw up a single vowel. We say very flat vowels. In London, you don\u2019t say \u2018I could have da-a-a-anced all night,\u2019 you say, \u2018I could have dahnced all night.\u201d\n\nIf \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d went smoothly, an appearance in 1968 at the San Francisco Opera did not.\n\nShe was cast as Musetta in \u201cLa Boh\u00e8me.\u201d Luciano Pavarotti was Rodolfo. For her entrance in the second act, she was supposed to run down a ramp. There had been no rehearsal on the stage, but she managed. The real trouble came later.\n\n\u201cWe had an earthquake in the third act,\u201d she said. \u201cI heard the curtains clanking. People in the audience must have felt the seats move. They were getting up and standing in the doorways. You know how earthquakes shake you up, and this one wasn\u2019t even centered on San Francisco. It was up in Sonoma.\u201d", "title": "A Broadway Footnote: The American in \u2018My Fair Lady\u2019", "authors": ["James Barron", "Grace Notes"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "SECRETS WE KEPT\n\nThree Women of Trinidad\n\nBy Krystal A. Sital\n\n337 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $25.95.\n\nWhen Krystal Sital\u2019s grandfather Shiva Singh suffers a cerebral hemorrhage, her grandmother Rebecca, after 53 years of marriage, reacts with calm indifference. Sital, who reveres her tall, strong and generous grandfather, with his white hair and \u201cskin the color of a sapphire sky,\u201d spends much of her suspenseful memoir, \u201cSecrets We Kept: Three Women of Trinidad,\u201d elucidating this response.\n\nWith the family patriarch debilitated, Sital\u2019s grandmother and her mother are safe for the first time, able to share their secrets with Sital, who listens, her blood pumping to a \u201cchant I cannot forget.\u201d These vivid memories attack us as they do her, \u201cin waves.\u201d\n\nSital paints a credible and complex portrait of this illiterate, psychopathic man, a landowner of wealth and stature in rural Trinidad, a Hindu who practices his religion at Divali and carries a key to his strongbox at all times. Even his rare gifts to one or the other of his children \u2014 a shiny new bicycle for his young daughter Arya, the author\u2019s mother, who does not know how to ride, and a car for the eldest boy \u2014 cause jealousy and fury.\n\nImage\n\nHe uses a whip soaked in gasoline to beat his wife and takes pleasure in her pain: \u201cHis pencil-thin lips were curved upward in a smile.\u201d In scene after scene, Sital portrays his violent rage, his complete indifference to the suffering of his wife and six children, whom he treats as slaves, with no rights or means of protection.", "title": "A Brutal Heritage Finally Revealed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTEXT ME WHEN YOU GET HOME\n\nThe Evolution and Triumph of Modern Female Friendship\n\nBy Kayleen Schaefer\n\n288 pp. Dutton. $24.\n\nIn \u201cText Me When You Get Home\u201d Kayleen Schaefer recalls a first date \u2014 not with a potential romantic partner but with a potential friend. Describing the emotional rush of an evening spent colluding and conjoining, she sounds as if she has a new crush: \u201cI related to every single thing she said,\u201d Schaefer tells us, reporting that they discussed \u201cthings I don\u2019t typically share with someone I\u2019m just sitting down with for the first time.\u201d She gushes to her mother via text the next day: \u201cI have a new best friend. \u2026 I love her.\u201d\n\nIn a year that has been described as a women\u2019s renaissance, female friendship feels particularly worthy of contemplation. As professional opportunities broaden and cultural attitudes shift, competition between women has given way to allyship. Through the return of women\u2019s social organizations and the formalization of whisper networks, female solidarity is more pervasive than ever, a byproduct of girl power and the cumulation of years of quiet rebellion.\n\n\u201cWomen are stepping up together, loudly and publicly,\u201d writes Schaefer, a journalist whose subjects have ranged from the Korean beauty industry to the occult. It seems the world is finally recognizing the power of female connection, which the poet Adrienne Rich once described as \u201cthe most feared, the most problematic and the most potentially transforming force on the planet.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat girl hasn\u2019t buzzed with the rare thrill of a new friendship? It offers a shared hiding place and a secret understanding outside the reach of men, parents, employers; someone who hates everything you hate, who takes on your causes as her own; someone who, after leaving you at the end of the night, cares that you get home safely.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn many of our lives, friendships matter as much as romantic relationships. Friends are our soul mates \u2014 and, more practically, our emergency contacts. Why then, Schaefer asks, is friendship as an institution not afforded the same benefits and privileges as marriage? It\u2019s a position that has been gaining steam in the legal community, among advocates of so-called friendship law like Rachel Moran, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, who has argued that platonic bonds ought to matter \u201cnot only in my own intimate life, but in the eyes of the law.\u201d", "title": "A Call to Action for Girl Squads Everywhere", "authors": ["Audrey Gelman", "Kayleen Schaefer"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "MEYRIN, Switzerland \u2014 Fabiola Gianotti is one of the most important physicists in the world, and when she gazes at the heavens after dark, she sees more than the moon, the stars and the Milky Way.\n\nFor her, the night sky is a daily reminder of humanity\u2019s ignorance of the origins of the universe.\n\n\u201cWhen you look at the sky at night, you see only 5 percent of what\u2019s out there,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cThe rest we don\u2019t know, so we call it dark energy and dark matter. It\u2019s a bit embarrassing for us physicists to understand only 5 percent of the universe. Come on! We have to solve this problem, O.K.?\u201d\n\nDr. Gianotti, 57, is neither arrogant nor na\u00efve. She is the first female director of the European Organization for Nuclear Research \u2014 or CERN \u2014 where the world\u2019s largest and most powerful particle accelerator is deep underground outside Geneva.\n\nShe led one of the two giant CERN experiments teams that in 2012 resulted in the discovery of the Higgs boson, the particle that explains why some other elementary particles have mass. It is so awe-inspiring that it\u2019s been nicknamed the \u201cGod particle.\u201d She and the leader of the other team announced the discovery to the world.", "title": "A Celebrated Physicist With a Passion for Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 As great restaurants will do, JuneBaby pulled me in from more than one direction. The first of course was the sheer pleasure of the cooking. (Without that, the others wouldn\u2019t matter.) The food is Southern, which I was primed to like before I walked through JuneBaby\u2019s Dutch doors in this city\u2019s Ravenna neighborhood. And whenever Edouardo Jordan\u2019s menu offered a dish I\u2019d expect to see at a Southern restaurant, he gave me something better than I\u2019d imagined.\n\nFried catfish over grits can be better in theory than reality. At JuneBaby, the fish, from an Idaho farm, is firm, tight, fresh and free of bottom-feeder muddiness. The crust is semolina, which stays crisp and unsoggy. The grits are fluffy, yellow, full of corn flavor. Ringing the grits is an orange circle of shrimp bisque. Strictly speaking, shrimp bisque has no business on fish and grits, but if you see the bisque as a tamer, richer stand-in for hot sauce it makes a delicious kind of sense.\n\nThis is the tactic \u2014 find superior ingredients and bring some fancy kitchen tricks to bear on them \u2014 favored by most of the South\u2019s prominent restaurants. If that were all Mr. Jordan had in mind, I would still think JuneBaby is a very good restaurant. But on the menu of this nearly year-old establishment are dishes that I wasn\u2019t expecting, that many of those other restaurants don\u2019t serve, that pulled me in deeper.\n\nLike any good Southern chef, Mr. Jordan loves his pork. But I paid closer attention when I noticed which parts of the pig he\u2019s cooking. He will boil ham hocks with collard greens until the leaves are soft and velvety and wonderfully smoky. He stews pigs\u2019 ears until they surrender their ornery stiffness, then slices and fries them into irresistible, crunchy sticks. He seasons okra and tomatoes with a North African spice mix and stews them with hog maw, otherwise known as the outer wall of the stomach.", "title": "A Celebration of Black Southern Food, at JuneBaby in Seattle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Now It\u2019s a Book\n\nMs. Collins, who lives in Brooklyn Heights in a modish duplex apartment overlooking the East River, is emblematic of a certain demographic: mostly white \u2014 though Ms. Collins is half-black \u2014 expensively educated and housed liberals. You would assume that group would mirror itself online and stay small and homogeneous. But within a year of its founding, WWVWD, to use its colloquial abbreviation, had more than 1,300 members; the week after the presidential election there was an increase of another 1,000, Ms. Collins said, with many seeking a way to marshal themselves for political action.\n\nThe original group, which Ms. Collins changed from \u201csecret\u201d to \u201cclosed\u201d (meaning it can be seen by the public), begot subgroups, for those who wanted to focus on philanthropy, activism, business networking and writing. Woolfers in New York City began meeting in person, as Ms. Collins led field trips to Toys in Babeland, the sex accessories emporium on the Lower East Side, and hosted Scrabble tournaments and clothing swaps.\n\nPhoto\n\nWoolfers have also swapped houses and apartments, rented each other rooms and raised money for groups including the Center for Reproductive Rights and the Trust for Public Land. Recently, four Woolfers spent a day at the Wallkill Correctional Facility, joining a mentorship program for inmates there.\n\nThere are now more than 7,600 Woolfers across the country, from New York City, Boston, San Francisco and Los Angeles, as you might expect, but also from Arkansas, Chicago and Maine. And Ms. Collins, who spent a few weeks last month on a cross-country road trip with a new boyfriend meeting Woolfers in Memphis and Telluride, Colo., among other spots, has a new book, out in April, called \u201cWhat Would Virginia Woolf Do? And Other Questions I Ask Myself as I Attempt to Age Without Apology.\u201d It is a sometimes wince-inducing primer on fashion, sex, marriage, divorce, money and health gleaned from her experience as Woolfer in chief, and with contributions from her Woolfer sisters.\n\nIt also has memoirish elements: Ms. Collins details her adventures in the orgy tent at Burning Man (she and her ex brought their own sheets, and kept to themselves), her struggles with depression and her adherence to an expensive beauty routine that involves fake eyelashes and Botox. She also cops to divorce envy, and notes the benefits of prenups, long-term-care insurance and pharmaceuticals like Xanax.
