In its breezy candor, the book is as appealing and appalling as the conversations of the Woolfers online, though it lacks the tartness and invective that occasionally erupts there, turning a you-go-girl group of self-affirmers into an unruly scrum.\n\nBecause when thousands of women get together on social media, what could possibly go wrong?\n\n\u2018Assume Goodness, Please\u2019\n\n\u201cWe do fight sometimes,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cWe\u2019re talking about super-candid things, and people have strong opinions. If you\u2019re talking about whether or not to let your 16-year-old have sex or whether to have an affair or how to tell your colleague at work that she\u2019s a jerk, people will have strong responses.\u201d\n\nWhen one long-married woman wrote about the heartache she was feeling because her lover of five years had broken up with her, many Woolfers were upset by her adultery, Ms. Collins said, and she had to step in to remove comments that were aggressive, moralistic and vitriolic. When a white Woolfer reported that a black man in a park had exposed himself to her, many in the group were inflamed that she had noted his race.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt first, Ms. Collins read every post herself, to steer the conversation and defuse tension. But when the group swelled to 3,000, she asked some of the early Woolfers to help her moderate; now, about 20 women have oversight of what\u2019s posted. Politics, race and infidelity are topics that reliably lead to problems. \u201cI\u2019ll be out somewhere and I\u2019ll get a text from someone saying basically there\u2019s a huge fight in Aisle 6 and what do we do?\u201d Ms. Collins said.\n\nEarly last year, Ms. Collins chastised the group for what she saw as occasional reflexive pettiness. \u201cThis is not a liberal arts college, circa 2016,\u201d she wrote in part. \u201cWe don\u2019t have to give trigger warnings. Bring on the posts about money concerns and racism concerns and class struggle, but don\u2019t blame fellow members without real cause. Assume goodness, please.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJenny Douglas, an early Woolfer and moderator, said, \u201cIf there\u2019s a post you don\u2019t like, we say, \u2018Scroll on by.\u2019 You don\u2019t need to pick a fight with everything or anyone you disagree with. When we are meeting online and tackling subjects that are so nuanced, you can lose that nuance. Those tender subjects are tricky to tackle in any form.\u201d\n\nJust a few weeks ago, a moderator quit the group after a discussion of moderator practices \u2014 how they vetted posts, for example \u2014 left her feeling bullied, she said.\n\nThere are over-posters, and drunk posters; there are angry, cursing posters \u2014 whose words are promptly removed, Ms. Collins said \u2014 and posters who are a tad self-righteous. And there are the lurkers and the hate readers, along with those who are repelled or bored or disappointed by the particular window into women\u2019s lives that the group affords them.\n\n\u201cI always think that Virginia Woolf would be mortified at having her name associated with this group,\u201d said Daphne Merkin, the memoirist and cultural critic, who is a member of the group but does not post anything. \u201cAt first I thought it was going to be some kind of literary meeting of the minds. That there would be some interesting comments about Jean Rhys. Instead it\u2019s, \u201cWhat do you do with your dildos?\u201d Or this sort of subclinical despair about no longer having a flat stomach.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like that stuff is beneath me,\u201d Ms. Merkin went on. \u201cI mean, I once wrote a story on buffing up the vagina, but these revelations are very cosmeticized. There\u2019s little wit, but maybe wit takes more time than social media allows. This is more like the stuff you tell your girlfriend at the end of the day, the eye-glazing end of intimacy. There\u2019s intimacy that\u2019s thrilling, but this isn\u2019t.\u201d\n\nConversations have leaked outside the group, like the time one woman wrote of her son\u2019s bad behavior, and another Woolfer told her own child, who happened to know the son, who then told the son of his mother\u2019s revelations about his conduct.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was pretty easy to figure out who it was,\u201d Ms. Collins said of the offending member. \u201cI reached out and said, \u2018This is super-uncool,\u2019 and we removed her from the group. The way we dealt with it was to write about it, so everyone knew what had happened. Ironically, and because I\u2019m a bigger personality, I\u2019ve probably suffered more than others for this.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe More Diaspora\n\nMs. Collins is indeed not only confessional, but also confrontational. In 2013, in an article for Elle magazine, she wrote about being arrested three times: for assaulting her first husband, for assaulting his girlfriend and for violating an order of protection he had taken out against her, by overturning a coffee table. A recent Page Six item reported that her second husband had broken her nose during a fight last September.\n\n\u201cWhat does it mean to be \u2018too much,\u2019 as a woman?\u201d she said. \u201cWe talk about this a lot in the group.\u201d\n\nMs. Collins is happy to share her labial regimen (see \u201ccoconut oil,\u201d above), the minutiae of her sex life and the unraveling of her second marriage, which ended in part because of the meddling of a Woolfer, as it happens.\n\n\u201cThe marriage was strained, and I had been wanting a second dog for a while,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cMy husband didn\u2019t, but like most women I do most of the work around the house and pay my fair share.\u201d She asked the Woolfers, in essence, \u201cAm I a jerk if I just go ahead and get the dog?\u201d\n\n\u201cI thought it would be a throwaway thread,\u201d she said. \u201cBut suddenly there were like 600 comments,\u201d evenly divided in opinion. (She didn\u2019t get the dog.)\n\nIt turns out that one Woolfer who read the thread was an old friend of Ms. Collins\u2019s husband, and the woman told him about his wife\u2019s query. \u201cHe came home pretty angry, and the marriage ended pretty much the next day,\u201d Ms. Collins said.\n\nA revenue model for the Woolfers has yet to emerge, though Ms. Collins is working on it. She has built a website to promote her book, created a newsletter and recorded five sample podcasts \u2014 called \u201cRaging Gracefully\u201d \u2014 which she plans to release in April. As Ms. Collins has told the group, she received a $75,000 book advance, which she split with an editor and researcher who worked with her. She is as candid about her entrepreneurial behaviors and aspirations as she is about more intimate matters.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCan we create a digital platform for women over 40?\u201d Ms. Collins said. Fortunes have been lost on the print version of such endeavors, despite economic data that shows the purchasing power of this demographic, decade after decade. And Ms. Collins is not alone in trying to reach them online. Girls of a Certain Age, a six-year-old style site created by Kim France, the founding editor of Lucky magazine, gets about 30,000 unique hits a month and makes over six figures, Ms. France said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLesley Jane Seymour, the editor in chief of More magazine, which folded in 2016 after publishing for 19 years and was reintroduced as an online magazine for millennial women, has spent the last two years working on Covey Club, \u201can online club for women 40+ who want to continue learning, growing and expanding their world by making new friends and deeper connections,\u201d which went live this past Valentine\u2019s Day.\n\nMs. Seymour was promoting the site at the South by Southwest festival a few weeks ago, joining the stage with Tausha Robertson, creator of Ms. X. Factor, a digital space for Gen X women of color. \u201cI know there\u2019s a business here,\u201d Ms. Seymour said. \u201cThe question is how to do it. We can\u2019t just sell content online, it has to be something else. What is clear is that women who are a little bit older feel disenfranchised. They feel no one is listening to them, and they feel invisible.\u201d\n\nMs. Collins said of her group, \u201cI see it as incredible content potential and, though this sounds a little grandiose, possibly culture shifting. These women are powerful, and they have made me feel more powerful.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s a continuing conversation about whether the group is getting too big and how or if to control for privacy. When the news of Facebook\u2019s breaches broke last week, the moderators again discussed restricting new members or moving to a different platform. \u201cMaybe one day we\u2019ll have an app or some other platform for more intimacy,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cBut for now, here we are, basically addicted and not budging.\u201d\n\nDina Seiden is a Brooklyn-based writer and performance artist, a committed Woolfer and, now, a moderator. The group\u2019s foibles, she said, are part of the draw. \u201cThey make aging so much fun. We\u2019re not all saints \u2014 no, we\u2019re perfectly human, and that is ultimately good for the group, too.\u201d\n\nLast Christmas she participated in a Secret Santa gift exchange. In a \u201ccheeky nod,\u201d she said, to a topic the group seems to hold dear, Ms. Seiden sent her recipient a vintage vibrator: a formidable, Machine Age relic called the Vitilator she\u2019d bought on eBay for $15, the price cap the group had set. \u201cI mean, kismet!\u201d Ms. Seiden said, truly delighted by her find.\n\nUnfortunately, the recipient was a germophobe, and was horrified to have received such an intimate, secondhand device, as she explained. Did Ms. Seiden want it back? If so, she\u2019d leave it with her doorman.\n\n\u201cBut it was a schlep and I just wanted to put the incident behind me, so I never did pick it up,\u201d Ms. Seiden said. \u201cMy dream is that the doorman gave it to a woman in his life, or that a slightly awkward exchange ensued in which the doorman had to return the vibrator to its recipient, passing it clumsily to her and in my dream, by the time she gets up to her apartment, she can\u2019t resist, transcends her putative germophobia, and gets herself off like a rock star.\u201d", "title": "A Chat Room of Their Own", "authors": ["Penelope Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "A Brazilian boy\u2019s passion for collecting autographs, ignited almost 50 years ago, has blossomed into one of this year\u2019s most unusual and enchanting exhibitions, \u201cThe Magic of Handwriting: The Pedro Corr\u00eaa do Lago Collection,\u201d at the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan.\n\nOn display from June 1 through Sept. 16, \u201cThe Magic of Handwriting\u201d will feature 140 items \u2014 including handwritten letters, manuscripts and musical compositions, as well as inscribed photographs, drawings and documents \u2014 by, among others, the scientists Newton and Einstein; the artists Michelangelo and van Gogh; the authors Emily Dickinson, Jorge Luis Borges and Marcel Proust; the composers Mozart and Beethoven; and the entertainers Charlie Chaplin and Billie Holiday.\n\nNot coincidentally, Mr. Corr\u00eaa do Lago\u2019s collection was inspired, in part, by the wide-ranging collection of the financier Pierpont Morgan and a visit to the Morgan Library as a teenager.\n\nAt age 11, Mr. Corr\u00eaa do Lago began writing to individuals he admired. The English novelist J. R. R. Tolkien declined to send him anything. The French filmmaker Fran\u00e7ois Truffaut, however, sent an illustrated, signed book about his 1969 film \u201cL\u2019Enfant Sauvage.\u201d", "title": "A Childhood Hobby Matures Into a World-Class Collection", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "We first meet Zhuang in early 2013, when he\u2019s still moored in the village of Wukan, an outpost of booming Guangdong Province, planning his escape. \u201cHe suffered from the occasional lapse in reading social cues and fought it with volume, warmth and a strong handshake,\u201d Hilgers writes, in a characteristically vivid description. His audacity had already made him a hero. A little more than a year before, he started an unlikely rebellion after discovering that local officials had been selling off the villagers\u2019 land without their knowledge. Since then, he anticipated a government crackdown, and if he had to leave his beloved Wukan, there was only one place he wanted to go.\n\nThe United States \u201cwas a country of justice and freedom, a place with values that paralleled his own,\u201d he reasons. \u201cWork would be easy to find there. People would be friendly.\u201d Zhuang could already envision the hearty welcome an ardent democracy advocate like himself would receive. He was so enamored of his chosen destination that \u201che had to whisper when he said it: America.\u201d\n\nNeedless to say, his fantasy of America founders once he reaches its rough shores. And it\u2019s then, when the country frustrates him, that life in America becomes palpable, and exceedingly real.\n\nZhuang and his wife, Little Yan, neither of whom speak any English, wait for their asylum applications to come through while they try to eke out a new life in Flushing after arriving on a tourist visa. Little Yan, unrelentingly practical and resigned to \u201ceating bitter,\u201d immediately starts to work in a nail salon; Zhuang, meanwhile, keeps telling her she should quit her job because he\u2019s perpetually on the verge of something big. Ever entrepreneurial, he pursues a number of moneymaking schemes, including a logistically convoluted and barely profitable personal-shopping business, schlepping to an outlet mall north of the city to buy up discounted designer goods and resell them to moneyed customers back in China.\n\nHilgers observes all of this with a sharp eye and an open heart. She follows Zhuang and Little Yan around, together and separately, becoming privy to their daily routines and their candid thoughts about America and each other. But Hilgers isn\u2019t in this book more than she needs to be. Aside from hosting the couple in her Brooklyn apartment when they first arrive \u2014 the inquisitive Zhuang is curious about everything, including why she owns more than one kitchen knife \u2014 Hilgers recedes into the background, the better to let them speak for themselves.\n\nUnlike a number of other asylum-seekers from China, Zhuang and Little Yan are in a relatively privileged position: They arrive flush with savings from a land sale, and without crushing debts. At the same time, they have no family, no ready-made network to show them how anything is done. Zhuang never finished middle school. Not to mention that New York City is an extraordinarily expensive place to live.", "title": "A Chinese Revolutionary, Reinventing Himself in American Exile", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "A military hotline still operates to avoid clashes between American and Russian forces in Syria, but as tensions rose last week, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, suggested it was time to revive the Cold War channels of communication and control. \u201cThose mechanisms have been dismantled,\u201d he said. \u201cI do believe that mechanisms of this sort are necessary again.\u201d\n\nPost-Communist Russia is not the obvious enemy the Soviet Union was. Throughout Russia\u2019s slow slide into authoritarianism, there has lingered a hope that relations with Moscow can be reset, as Hillary Clinton sought to do and as President Trump seems eager to do. And while Mr. Putin\u2019s drive to restore Russian influence and might \u2014 witness his proud unveiling of an intercontinental missile in March that \u201ccan reach any point in the world\u201d \u2014 is an echo of Soviet behavior, Russia has also undergone a considerable transformation since 1991. Russians travel widely and have nearly unlimited access to information and technology, and the Soviet command economy has given way to far greater consumerism.\n\nMore significantly, there is no Western consensus on Russia of the sort that held against the Soviet Union. European politicians like Prime Minister Viktor Orban in Hungary or Czech President Milos Zeman are open admirers of Mr. Putin, and President Trump\u2019s relations with the Kremlin are a major question mark. Though the United States expelled 60 Russian diplomats and closed the Russian consulate in Seattle, Mr. Trump made no comment on the crisis, either when he called Mr. Putin last week to congratulate him on his re-election or since.\n\nAll that makes the current confrontation less predictable than the showdowns of the Soviet past. Both Britain and the United States have left open further actions against Russia, to which Moscow would inevitably respond, and the deterioration in relations could affect efforts to find common ground on Syria or Islamist terrorism.\n\nThat, however, is not an argument for looking the other way when Russia violates the most elemental norms of international behavior. Russia is not the old Soviet Union, which makes it all the more imperative for the West to send a clear message that the old wiles and subterfuges also belong in the dustbin of history.\n\nThe former K.G.B. agent in Mr. Putin may find it intolerable that a turncoat is living comfortably in Britain, but it must be made clear to him that the West will unite in fury \u2014 yes, including Mr. Trump\u2019s America \u2014 when Russia\u2019s most fearsome weapons are deployed in a peaceful English town.", "title": "Opinion | A Colder War With Russia?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Alagb\u00e9\u2019s book reminded its English translator Donald Nicholson-Smith of the American underground comics of the 1970s such as \u201cInner City Romance.\u201d \u201cNot in the style but the subject matter which were all about people living on the edge in the middle of the ghetto,\u201d Mr. Nicholson-Smith said. The English-language version of \u201cYellow Negroes\u201d is part of New York Review Comics\u2019s drive to unearth foreign gems that have built up a cult following.\n\nThe translation feels timely because \u201cYellow Negroes\u2019\u201d twin themes of undocumented migrant workers and the damaging legacy of European colonialism have not gone away. \u201cRelatively speaking, in France we don\u2019t let any immigrants in anymore,\u201d said Mr. Alagb\u00e9, who provided an illustrated coda to the American version of \u201cYellow Negroes\u201d updating its themes.\n\n\u201cEurope has become a kind of fortress where misfortunates do not have a place. For me that in itself is a kind of hell,\u201d he said.\n\nWhat has added insult to injury for Mr. Alagb\u00e9 is that in the meantime France has continued to shape its former African colonies in its own image by erasing the past as it sees fit. In \u201cYellow Negroes\u201d he reported on a collective of undocumented workers striking in Montreuil who put up a photograph of Thomas Sankara, Burkina Faso\u2019s revolutionary president from 1983 to 1987, in the window of their headquarters.\n\nInserting himself into the narrative, Mr. Alagb\u00e9 remarked that when he once looked up Sankara\u2019s name in France\u2019s famous Larousse dictionary there was no entry for him. However there was an entry for Blaise Compaor\u00e9 who led the 1987 coup d\u2019\u00e9tat during which Sankara was assassinated. \u201cI thought that was incredibly violent,\u201d Mr. Alagb\u00e9 said. \u201cNot only was Sankara assassinated but he was also erased from French history.\u201d\n\nMr. Alagb\u00e9\u2019s other comic books include 2004\u2019s \u201cWho Has Known the Fire\u201d which stages a hypothetical conversation between Sebastian I, who was king of Portugal during the 16th century, and B\u00e9hanzin, who became king of Dahomey (now Benin) during the 19th century. His interest in history extends to making light of his own fraught upbringing: He based a husband who abandons his wife in \u201cYellow Negroes\u201d on his father giving him the name Augustus after the Roman emperor.\n\nMr. Alagb\u00e9 cited the films of Pier Paolo Passolini and Rainer Werner Fassbinder as key influences on his work. \u201cBoth directors showed the harshness of human relationships where mistrustfulness is ever-present,\u201d he said. Their open-mindedness also touches him in a way that some comic book artists struggle to do. \u201cI\u2019ve chatted with illustrators who have told me that they are so used to drawing white people all the time that when they draw a black person it\u2019s a problem for them,\u201d he said.\n\nMaking art for art\u2019s sake has never interested Mr. Alagb\u00e9 and the sheer quantity of comic books on offer nowadays does not necessarily constitute a golden age for him. \u201cWhat I\u2019m interested in is work that renders visible what has previously been invisible,\u201d he said. \u201cBut you need to look long and hard before that can happen.\u201d", "title": "A Comic Book Artist Who Makes the Invisible Visible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The unremitting darkness of \u201cIntercomunicazione\u201d is no bar to extraordinary variety of expression. If its frenetic, sepulchral rumbling on the cello\u2019s lowest string \u2014 or the riotous, frankly impossible cacophony of massed, warring trumpets in \u201cDie Soldaten,\u201d his sole opera \u2014 is not representative of growling hounds of hell, no music ever will be. The cello\u2019s darkly expressive riches seem to have especially appealed to Zimmermann; he also wrote two concertos for the instrument, one relatively early, and revised as \u201cCanto di Speranza,\u201d with formal inspiration derived from Ezra Pound\u2019s cantos, and a second in the mid-1960s.\n\nStylistic pluralism went hand-in-hand with expressionism \u2014 one heightening the other \u2014 nowhere more so than in \u201cDie Soldaten\u201d (\u201cThe Soldiers\u201d), for which Zimmermann wrote a libretto closely built (at least to begin with) on an 18th-century play by Jakob Michael Reinhold Lenz drawing upon his military service. Zimmermann extended Lenz\u2019s multilayered plotlines in every direction, eventually including a vision of the atomic bomb whose return so many in the \u201960s feared. Multiple ensembles, languages, stages, film projections, loudspeakers, musical styles and so on were intended to surround the audience \u2014 originally meant to be seated on swivel chairs in the center of a vast performing space \u2014 to tell in multiple ways the story of a girl\u2019s destruction by a brutal society.\n\nZimmermann\u2019s final version was a simplification of the initial conception, which had been rejected by the Cologne Opera. The libretto and score maintained different levels of staged action, yet could conceivably be performed (abortive first attempts notwithstanding) by traditional opera companies in traditional theaters. Michael Gielen, who conducted the 1965 premiere in Cologne, would later say that Zimmermann\u2019s \u201cimagination was always several stages ahead of current standards of performing practice, and he could never understand why, precisely for that reason, we performers could offer only an approximation of his vision at the first performance.\u201d\n\nWe know, Gielen added, \u201cthat, from Beethoven onward, so-called \u2018unplayable\u2019 pieces become playable with time,\u201d and \u201cDie Soldaten\u201d has seen memorable performances in recent years, including at the 2012 Salzburg Festival and at the Zurich Opera, in 2013, directed by Calixto Bieito. A production that originated at the Ruhrtriennale festival in Germany and came to the Park Avenue Armory in New York in 2008 put the audience on moving risers.", "title": "A Composer of Dark Explosions Turns 100", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Penny\u2019s novels were translated into 23 languages before they were finally translated into Quebec French in 2010, partly reflecting the cultural divide in the province.\n\n\u201cMy books are love letters to Quebec \u2014 the language of my characters is French and I wanted my characters to live in that language,\u201d Ms. Penny, 59, said. \u201cThe translation meant so much to me because I wanted my friends and neighbors to be able to read them.\u201d\n\nThe books have sold well with both English- and French-speaking Quebecers. And legions of Ms. Penny\u2019s fans take a 2.5-hour tour in Quebec City, based on her popular novel \u201cBury Your Dead,\u201d where they can walk in the footsteps of Gamache as he investigates the murder of an amateur archaeologist at the Literary and Historical Society of Qu\u00e9bec.\n\nMs. Penny and I also chatted about Quebec\u2019s culture wars, which she experienced while living in Quebec City during the 1995 referendum on the province\u2019s independence.\n\nShe pointed out that Quebec had an English minority surrounded by a French majority, who were themselves eclipsed by an English majority in the rest of the country. So in Quebec, she noted, everyone defines themselves as \u201cThe Other,\u201d creating a sense of alienation that both inspired and repelled.\n\n\u201cAs much as the English don\u2019t know the French, the French don\u2019t know the English,\u201d she said.\n\nIn multilingual Knowlton, however, she stressed that a love of country living and nature overcame any linguistic differences. Even when she was living in Quebec City, and her French was rudimentary, she said, she was \u201cnever made to feel like I didn\u2019t belong,\u201d even when she would accidentally order \u201cflaming mice\u201d in a restaurant.\n\nMs. Penny, who oozes humor and easy conviviality, has overcome her fair share of adversity. She said she was on the brink of suicide in her late 30s, consumed with fear of failure and an alcohol problem. She had five years of writer\u2019s block, and her first manuscript was rejected by at least 50 publishers.\n\nBut with the encouragement of her husband, Michael Whitehead, a doctor who died in 2016, she refused to give up, eventually coming in second in a British writing contest. Gamache, she noted, came to her fully formed. Now she writes one book a year \u2014 all infused by her many years in Quebec.", "title": "A Conversation With Louise Penny: The Canada Letter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "GEORGE TOWN, Malaysia \u2014 Nine years ago, Robyn Eckhardt, an American journalist, and her husband, David Hagerman, a photographer, traveled here so that she could report a food assignment for a travel magazine.\n\nThe couple had lived in China, Thailand and Vietnam before moving to Kuala Lumpur, the Malaysian capital, in 2005, and had seen much of the region along the way. But they were particularly impressed by George Town\u2019s low-rise historic architecture and lively street food scene.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019d traveled around Asia for a bit by then, and there was no place like George Town,\u201d Ms. Eckhardt said.\n\nThey began driving up from Kuala Lumpur, roughly 185 miles, about once a month to watch a dog for a friend who owns a restaurant in this city on Penang Island, but also to hunt for property.", "title": "A Converted Malaysian Shophouse Stays True to Its 1890s Roots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Alana Chernila, an author, teacher and blogger based in Massachusetts, starts her alluring new vegetable cookbook just the way springtime does, with radishes. She suggests radish butter, made with the tangy little bulbs chopped fine. Having opened the door to such seasonal simplicity, she goes on to explain how to buy, store and use vegetables 100 ways. This is not a vegan book; dairy, eggs and nuggets of meat are involved. Precious new potatoes with salsa verde, caramelized cabbage soup, soft zucchini on toast, and refreshing smashed cucumbers with soba noodles all tempted me. The beautifully photographed recipes are short on eggplant because the author is allergic, but that doesn\u2019t explain why mushrooms figure in only one dish: \u201cEating From the Ground Up: Recipes for Simple, Perfect Vegetables\u201d by Alana Chernila (Clarkson Potter, $28).\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Cookbook That\u2019s All About the Veggies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "VICTORIANS UNDONE\n\nTales of the Flesh in the Age of Decorum\n\nBy Kathryn Hughes\n\nIllustrated. 414 pp. Johns Hopkins University Press. $29.95.\n\nThe average biographer peers into a Great Man\u2019s mind. Kathryn Hughes\u2019s \u201cVictorians Undone: Tales of the Flesh in the Age of Decorum,\u201d in contrast, narrates the lives of five body parts: the stomach of one of Queen Victoria\u2019s ladies-in-waiting, \u201csuspected of expecting\u201d; Charles Darwin\u2019s unfashionable beard, which turns out to provide a key to his theory of sexual selection; George Eliot\u2019s right hand, larger than her left thanks to a youth spent milking cows; the \u201cbee-stung\u201d lips of Dante Gabriel Rossetti\u2019s mistress; and the dismembered corpse of a working-class girl onto whose severed foot a late-19th-century shoemaker stumbled in a Hampshire hop garden.\n\nWhile microhistorians have long zoomed in on individual case studies, Hughes pinpoints her subjects even more narrowly. Her method is laparoscopic, sectioning off bits of bodies as ruthlessly as did the Hampshire murderer. Her ultimate question, though, is a broad one: How did the Victorians understand the interplay between mind and body?\n\nImage\n\nConsider Darwin\u2019s beard \u2014 or, more precisely, beards, since Darwin\u2019s progress through decades and hemispheres was marked by growing, grooming and shaving off a series of different styles. Mustachioed hipsters may be happy to learn that facial hair spent the first half of the 19th century as the marker of rabble-rousers, artists and derelicts. It was only when Crimean War veterans set the fashion that experts began recommending beards to ward off frostbite, sunburn and air pollution, not to mention mumps and toothache. A beard could also hide a man\u2019s unmanly expressions of emotion.", "title": "A Corporeal History of the 19th Century", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "But, anyway, it seems that as secretary of veterans affairs, Dr. Jackson would not be tending to Mr. Trump so much as to the right-wing billionaires Charles and David Koch and others who support privatization of veterans\u2019 health care and other services.\n\nThe man Dr. Jackson would replace as head of this long-troubled department, David Shulkin, whom Mr. Trump fired on Wednesday, was the highest-ranking holdover from the Obama administration and among the few Trump cabinet members with demonstrated ability at their jobs.\n\nDr. Shulkin had strong bipartisan support in Congress \u2014 he was confirmed 100 to 0 by the Senate \u2014 and was backed by almost all veterans groups. He guided important legislation through Congress, a rare accomplishment for this White House. These laws led to an expansion of the G.I. Bill for post-9/11 veterans, an easier process to remove bad employees and quicker appeals on disability benefits.\n\nThe department\u2019s inspector general found \u201cserious derelictions,\u201d though, in the way Dr. Shulkin spent his time and taxpayer money during a European trip, during which he had improperly accepted tickets to Wimbledon. That\u2019s a serious problem. But it\u2019s laughable to think that this would be a disqualification for a president for whom corruption is a continuing business model and who has watched some cabinet members treat self-dealing as a perk.\n\nSo we come back to the Koch brothers. After a year of amity between Dr. Shulkin and the president, there came word last month of behind-the-scenes intrigue inside and outside the department over replacing the secretary. Those supporting such a move had ties to the Kochs and a group they fund called Concerned Veterans of America.\n\nThe group advocates privatizing V.A. care, which Dr. Shulkin has opposed. While the department has increased the role that private doctors play in the treatment of veterans \u2014 which is particularly useful in areas far from V.A. hospitals \u2014 most veterans advocates believe that despite the department\u2019s history of serious problems with access to care and with the quality of care, the solution is more funding and better management. They see privatization as a boon for the private sector, not for veterans. And, as Dr. Shulkin said in an Op-Ed article in The New York Times late Wednesday, the nine million veterans who use the V.A. would overwhelm the private sector. More than 1,200 hospitals and clinics in the V.A. system provide that care now.", "title": "Opinion | A Coup at Veterans Affairs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Designing the cover for Sunday\u2019s special print section devoted to the launch of Overlooked \u2014 a new series that presents obituaries for historically significant women who did not receive them when they died \u2014 proved to be a unique challenge.\n\nSince Overlooked, which debuted Wednesday online, seeks to make amends for a systemic, gendered injustice, spotlighting one particular woman on the cover seemed inappropriate.\n\nThe cover also had to balance the excitement of long-delayed visibility with the sobriety of an obituary.\n\nWhat we landed on took the unusual step of printing most of the design on the second page, which houses a table of contents and portraits of all 12 women in the section.", "title": "A Cover Design That Renders Overlooked Women Visible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAround sunset, faint echoes of chatter and saxophone wails start to leak out of a basement-level steel door on East 53rd Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Customers descend the staircase \u2014 as if the ghostly melodies have summoned them there \u2014 to press a discrete buzzer. Seconds later, the door creaks open, revealing a speakeasy-style Japanese whisky bar and music club called Tomi Jazz.\n\nBehind a wooden counter, bartenders rhythmically rock cocktail shakers. They garnish snow-white cocktails with smoldering cinnamon sticks for off-the-clock diplomats, while I.T. consultants and investment bankers sip Nikka and Yamazaki whisky. More liquor bottles sit on dusty shelves, alongside weathered photos of vintage music acts, a trumpet and woven lamps. After midnight, uninhibited couples get close at an L-shape table, just a foot away from the live music.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the 1980s, Japanese businessmen flocked to Midtown Manhattan, following a surge in Japan\u2019s economy. The East Village largely drew younger, more artistic types from Japan, who patronized restaurants and bars, including the original Tomi Jazz, which was part of a Little Tokyo zone around East 9th Street. But in 2000, the club relocated to cater to those Japanese businessmen in Midtown, many of whom also frequented izakayas and hostess bars in the neighborhood.\n\nRaymond Fasanella, a regular who works in the United Nations\u2019 publishing division, first visited the exclusive bar as a guest of a Japanese friend over 20 years ago at its original East Village location. Back then, Mr. Fasanella said, the scene was mostly a mix of white-collar Japanese men from uptown and students, smoking and drinking single malt whisky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou could walk out there at seven in the morning,\u201d Mr. Fasanella said, \u201cnothing but black cars in the street waiting for the customers.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBy 2010, however, Ken Mukohata, a former nightclub manager and Tomi regular, had taken over the space. He opened the bar to anyone who could find it, began to schedule candlelit jazz performances and decorated the walls with silver Heineken and Southern Comfort plaques and calligraphic tapestries.", "title": "A Cozy Jazz Club, if You Can Find It", "authors": ["Matthew Sedacca", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "As for the beans, freshly cooked dried white beans are preferred \u2014 I always take the opportunity to proselytize for dried beans, which have a better texture and more flavor than canned \u2014 and, with a little advance planning, easy to pull off. Cannellini or gigante beans, covered in cold water just before bedtime, take only about an hour to simmer the next day. Still, beans from a can will suffice. Drain the cooked (or canned) beans, and season them with salt, lemon and plenty of olive oil. (In fact, white beans dressed this way are delicious as an accompaniment to nearly any dish.)\n\nTuna is expensive, but you don\u2019t need much: 2 to 4 ounces per serving is plenty. So your salad can be bean heavy or tuna heavy, depending upon how flush you\u2019re feeling; it will be delicious either way. The main thing is to get the seasoning right. After salting it, I like to coat the fish with a generous amount of crushed fennel seed and black pepper. If I have it on hand, I\u2019ll amp up the floral flavor with a little dried fennel pollen.", "title": "A Crisp Cool-Weather Twist for a Classic Summer Salad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Jonathan Anderson\u2019s Craft Odyssey\n\nThe new capsule collection from Loewe\u2019s Jonathan Anderson was born from the same sense of wonder with which the designer once marveled over his grandmother\u2019s hand-knit quilts. For nearly a year, he and his team searched the globe for the best artisans working with fabric, from manjak weavers in southern Senegal to ribbon embroiderers in New Delhi, eventually partnering with over 100 ateliers to create 50 made-to-order tapestries (plus 12 matching tote bags), which will debut at Salone del Mobile in Milan next month.\n\nEach piece tells its own story: A Kyoto-made patchwork (bottom, second from right), for instance, features sashiko, a centuries-old sewing method originally used by Japanese farmers, characterized by \u201clittle stabs\u201d of white thread against indigo-blue cotton. For several other designs, a father-and-son-run workshop with a single loom in Aubusson, France, used a digital pattern generator to reproduce sepia-toned images from Anderson\u2019s collection of found 19th- and early-20th-century photography. (The hand-dyed, multicolored stripe covering three nude figures\u2019 midsections on one of these came from a mother-and-son business in Mumbai.) For Anderson, it\u2019s a celebration of craftsmanship and a reminder that, in our fast-paced world, time may be the greatest luxury. \u201cThere\u2019s this idea that we can consume everything digitally and we don\u2019t pause,\u201d he says. \u201cHow exciting that in the midst of all that, this sort of artistry is still happening today.\u201d Prices upon request. \u2014 JACOBA URIST", "title": "A Cultural Compendium of What\u2019s New", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSniffing an alcohol pad may be a good cure for nausea.\n\nAlmost five million people go to emergency rooms annually in the United States for severe nausea and vomiting, and it is commonly treated with oral ondansetron (Zofran), a drug used to control the nausea of chemotherapy.\n\nSniffing isopropyl alcohol can also help control chemotherapy nausea, but until now it has not been tested against Zofran for emergency rooms patients, who have a wide variety of causes of nausea. Researchers randomized 120 patients with nausea to use either a sniffed alcohol pad and oral Zofran, alcohol and an oral placebo, or Zofran and sniffed saline solution. The study is in the Annals of Emergency Medicine.\n\nBefore treatment, patients averaged about 50 on a 100-millimeter visual scale of nausea severity, with 100 being the worst. The average decrease a half-hour after treatment was 30 millimeters for those who smelled alcohol and took Zofran, 32 for alcohol and an oral placebo, and 9 for those who took Zofran and sniffed a placebo.\n\nThe lead author, Dr. Michael D. April, of the Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio, said that there is no reason to believe that sniffing alcohol would not work at home.\n\nPrescription medicine is not always the answer, he said. \u201cThere are simple, safe ways to deal with symptoms that are causing discomfort \u2014 that\u2019s a powerful message for people to appreciate.\u201d", "title": "A Cure for Nausea? Try Sniffing Alcohol", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "The new law breaks that peace, by limiting like-kind exchanges to \u201creal property,\u201d which is shorthand for land or other real estate.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think that they thought about baseball when they thought about this change,\u201d said Kari Smoker, an accounting professor at SUNY Brockport who has consulted for the N.B.A. and National Hockey League players\u2019 associations in legislative disputes over sports taxation. \u201cIt raises all kinds of issues, which I think were easier to ignore, probably, when we had a simple rule that it was a like-kind exchange.\u201d\n\nMr. Verlander, for example, was clearly a more immediately valuable asset to the Astros than the three prospects they traded to get him. He gave up only four runs in his five regular-season starts for the team, then won four straight starts to begin the playoffs. In very simple terms, he brought value to the Astros in a trade, and had the new law been in place last year, the team would have owed taxes on that added value.\n\nBut what, exactly, was that value? Was it the size of his contract? Mr. Verlander earned $28 million last year, while the players traded for him drew minor league salaries. Was it the additional wins he brought to the team? Statisticians estimate Mr. Verlander gave the Astros nearly two more wins last season, a value that, depending on the statistician, could reach $20 million. Or was it some calculation of the total future value Mr. Verlander will bring to the team, minus the total future value it gave up in the prospects it traded away \u2014 and possibly adjusted for the amount the team will have to pay Mr. Verlander?\n\nComplicating matters further is that teams value players differently, and one player might help a certain team far more than another team. A struggling club with a surplus of starting pitchers might trade one to a playoff contender in desperate need of one, in exchange for position players who could improve a struggling lineup. In that case, both teams could, reasonably, be considered to have gained value in the trade, and thus would owe taxes on it.\n\nThat is exactly how Adam Guttridge views the trade of Mr. Verlander \u2014 as a win-win for both the Astros and Tigers, which would have resulted in a capital-gains tax bill for each of them. Mr. Guttridge is a former manager of baseball research and development for the Milwaukee Brewers and a co-founder of NEIFI, a consultancy that has developed software to attach a dollar value to every professional ballplayer and his expected future performance.\n\nHow to calculate such value for tax purposes \u201cis the question that somebody has to answer, that nobody in the baseball space has,\u201d Mr. Guttridge said. \u201cThere\u2019s certainly no consensus among the 30 teams.\u201d", "title": "A Curveball From the New Tax Law: It Makes Baseball Trades Harder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Part of what makes the attack on Atlanta so pernicious are the criminals behind it: A group that locks up its victims\u2019 files with encryption, temporarily changes their file names to \u201cI\u2019m sorry\u201d and gives the victims a week to pay up before the files are made permanently inaccessible.\n\nThreat researchers at Dell SecureWorks, the Atlanta-based security firm helping the city respond to the ransomware attack, identified the assailants as the SamSam hacking crew, one of the more prevalent and meticulous of the dozens of active ransomware attack groups. The SamSam group is known for choosing targets that are the most likely to accede to its high ransom demands \u2014 typically the Bitcoin equivalent of about $50,000 \u2014 and for finding and locking up the victims\u2019 most valuable data.\n\nIn Atlanta, where officials said the ransom demand amounted to about $51,000, the group left parts of the city\u2019s network tied in knots. Some major systems were not affected, including those for 911 calls and control of wastewater treatment. But other arms of city government have been scrambled for days.\n\nThe Atlanta Municipal Court has been unable to validate warrants. Police officers have been writing reports by hand. The city has stopped taking employment applications.\n\nAtlanta officials have disclosed few details about the episode or how it happened. They have urged vigilance and tried to reassure employees and residents that their personal information was not believed to have been compromised.\n\nDell SecureWorks and Cisco Security, which are still working to restore the city\u2019s systems, declined to comment on the attacks, citing client confidentiality.\n\nMs. Bottoms, the mayor, has not said whether the city would pay the ransom.\n\nThe SamSam group has been one of the more successful ransomware rings, experts said. It is believed to have extorted more than $1 million from some 30 target organizations in 2018 alone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not ideal to pay up, but in most cases, SamSam\u2019s victims have said that they can more easily afford the $50,000 or so in ransom than the time and cost of restoring their locked data and compromised systems. In the past year, the group has taken to attacking hospitals, police departments and universities \u2014 targets with money but without the luxury of going off-line for days or weeks for restoration work.\n\nInvestigators are not certain who the SamSam hackers are. Judging from the poor English in the group\u2019s ransom notes, security researchers believe they are probably not native English speakers. But they cannot say for sure whether SamSam is a single group of cybercriminals or a loose hacking collective.\n\nRansomware emerged in Eastern Europe in 2009, when cybercriminals started using malicious code to lock up unsuspecting users\u2019 machines and then demanding 100 euros or similar sums to unlock them again. Over the past decade, dozens of online cybercriminal outfits \u2014 and even some nation states, including North Korea and Russia \u2014 have taken up similar tactics on a larger scale, inflicting digital paralysis on victims and demanding increasing amounts of money.\n\nCybersecurity experts estimate that criminals made more than $1 billion from ransomware in 2016, according to the F.B.I. Then, last May, came the largest ransomware assault recorded so far: North Korean hackers went after tens of thousands of victims in more than 70 countries around the world, forcing Britain\u2019s public health system to reject patients, paralyzing computers at Russia\u2019s Interior Ministry, at FedEx in the United States, and at shipping lines and telecommunications companies across Europe.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA month later, Russian state hackers deployed similar ransomware to paralyze computers in Ukraine on the eve of the country\u2019s independence day. That attack shut down automated teller machines in Kiev, froze government agencies and even forced workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant to monitor radiation levels manually. Collateral damage from that attack affected computers at Maersk, the Danish shipping conglomerate; at Merck, the American-based pharmaceutical giant; and even at businesses in Russia.\n\nAttempted ransomware attacks against local governments in the United States have become unnervingly common. A 2016 survey of chief information officers for jurisdictions across the country found that obtaining ransom was the most common purpose of cyberattacks on a city or county government, accounting for nearly one-third of all attacks.\n\nThe survey, conducted by the International City/County Management Association and the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, also found that about one-quarter of local governments reported that they were experiencing attacks of one kind or another, successful or not, at least as often as once an hour.\n\nYet less than half of the local governments surveyed said they had developed a formal cybersecurity policy, and only 34 percent said they had a written strategy to recover from breaches.\n\nExperts said government officials needed to be more aggressive about preventive measures, like training employees to spot and sidestep \u201cphishing\u201d attempts meant to trick them into opening the digital door for ransomware.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be even more important that local governments look for the no-cost/low-cost, but start considering cybersecurity on the same level as public safety,\u201d said David Jordan, the chief information security officer for Arlington County, Va. \u201cA smart local government will have fire, police and cybersecurity at the same level.\u201d\n\nMs. Bottoms, who took office as mayor of Atlanta in January, acknowledged that shoring up the city\u2019s digital defenses had not been a high priority before, but that now \u201cit certainly has gone to the front of the line.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs elected officials, it\u2019s often quite easy for us to focus on the things that people see, because at the end of the day, our residents are our customers,\u201d Ms. Bottoms said. \u201cBut we have to really make sure that we continue to focus on the things that people can\u2019t see, and digital infrastructure is very important.\u201d\n\nDuring the ransomware attack, local leaders have sometimes been able to do little but chuckle at a predicament that was forcing the city to turn the clock back decades.\n\nAsked on Monday how long the city might be able to get by doing its business strictly with ink and paper, Ms. Bottoms replied: \u201cIt was a sustainable model until we got computer systems. It worked for many years. And for some of our younger employees, it will be a nice exercise in good penmanship.\u201d\n\nSecurity researchers trying to combat ransomware have noticed a pattern in SamSam\u2019s attacks this year: Some of the biggest have occurred around the 20th of the month.\n\nAllan Liska, a senior intelligence analyst at Recorded Future who has been tracking the group, said in an interview that he believed that SamSam gains access to its victims\u2019 systems and then waits for weeks before encrypting the victims\u2019 data. That delay, Mr. Liska said, makes it harder for responders to figure out how the group was able to break in \u2014 and easier for SamSam\u2019s hackers to strike twice.\n\nThe Colorado Department of Transportation was able to restore its systems on its own after a SamSam attack, without paying SamSam a dime. But a week later, the hackers struck the department again, with new, more potent ransomware.\n\n\u201cThey are constantly learning from their mistakes, modifying their code and then launching the next round of attacks,\u201d Mr. Liska said.", "title": "A Cyberattack Hobbles Atlanta, and Security Experts Shudder", "authors": ["Alan Blinder", "Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The assault was the most alarming in a string of hacking attacks on petrochemical plants in Saudi Arabia. In January 2017, computers went dark at the National Industrialization Company, Tasnee for short, which is one of the few privately owned Saudi petrochemical companies. Computers also crashed 15 miles away at Sadara Chemical Company, a joint venture between the oil and chemical giants Saudi Aramco and Dow Chemical.\n\nWithin minutes of the attack at Tasnee, the hard drives inside the company\u2019s computers were destroyed and their data wiped clean, replaced with an image of Alan Kurdi, the small Syrian child who drowned off the coast of Turkey during his family\u2019s attempt to flee that country\u2019s civil war.\n\nThe intent of the January attacks, Tasnee officials and researchers at the security company Symantec believe, was to inflict lasting damage on the petrochemical companies and send a political message. Recovery took months.\n\nEnergy experts said the August attack could have been an attempt to complicate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman\u2019s plans to encourage foreign and domestic private investment to diversify the Saudi economy and produce jobs for the country\u2019s growing youth population.\n\n\u201cNot only is it an attack on the private sector, which is being touted to help promote growth in the Saudi economy, but it is also focused on the petrochemical sector, which is a core part of the Saudi economy,\u201d said Amy Myers Jaffe, an expert on Middle East energy at the Council on Foreign Relations.\n\nSaudi Arabia has cut oil exports in recent years to support global oil prices, a strategy central to its efforts to make a potential public offering of shares of government-controlled Saudi Aramco more attractive to international investors. The kingdom has tried to compensate for its lost revenue by expanding its petrochemical and refining industry.\n\nSome technical details of the attack in August have been previously reported, but this is the first time the earlier attacks on Tasnee and other Saudi petrochemical companies have been reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSecurity analysts at Mandiant, a division of the security firm FireEye, are still investigating what happened in August, with the help of several companies in the United States that investigate cyberattacks on industrial control systems.\n\nA team at Schneider Electric, which made the industrial systems that were targeted, called Triconex safety controllers, is also looking into the attack, the people who spoke to The Times said. So are the National Security Agency, the F.B.I., the Department of Homeland Security and the Pentagon\u2019s Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, which has been supporting research into forensic tools designed to assist hacking investigations.\n\nAll of the investigators believe the attack was most likely intended to cause an explosion that would have killed people. In the last few years, explosions at petrochemical plants in China and Mexico \u2014 though not triggered by hackers \u2014 have killed several employees, injured hundreds and forced evacuations of surrounding communities.\n\nWhat worries investigators and intelligence analysts the most is that the attackers compromised Schneider\u2019s Triconex controllers, which keep equipment operating safely by performing tasks like regulating voltage, pressure and temperatures. Those controllers are used in about 18,000 plants around the world, including nuclear and water treatment facilities, oil and gas refineries, and chemical plants.\n\n\u201cIf attackers developed a technique against Schneider equipment in Saudi Arabia, they could very well deploy the same technique here in the United States,\u201d said James A. Lewis, a cybersecurity expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank.\n\nThe Triconex system was believed to be a \u201clock and key operation.\u201d In other words, the safety controllers could be tweaked or dismantled only with physical contact.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo how did the hackers get in? Investigators found an odd digital file in a computer at an engineering workstation that looked like a legitimate part of the Schneider controllers but was designed to sabotage the system. Investigators will not say how it got there, but they do not believe it was an inside job. This was the first time these systems were sabotaged remotely.\n\nThe only thing that prevented significant damage was a bug in the attackers\u2019 computer code that inadvertently shut down the plant\u2019s production systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInvestigators believe that the hackers have probably fixed their mistake by now, and that it is only a matter of time before they deploy the same technique against another industrial control system. A different group could also use those tools for its own attack.\n\nThe August attack was also a significant step up from earlier attacks in Saudi Arabia. Starting on Nov. 17, 2016, computer screens at a number of Saudi government computers went dark and their hard drives were erased, according to researchers at Symantec, which investigated the attacks.\n\nTwo weeks later, the same attackers hit other Saudi targets with the same computer virus. On Jan. 23, 2017, they struck again, at Tasnee and other petrochemical firms, deploying a computer virus known as Shamoon, after a word embedded in its code.\n\nThe Shamoon virus first surfaced five years earlier at Saudi Aramco, wiping out tens of thousands of computers and replacing the data with a partial image of a burning American flag. Leon E. Panetta, the United States defense secretary at the time, said the attack could be a harbinger.\n\n\u201cAn aggressor nation or extremist group could use these kinds of cyber tools to gain control of critical switches,\u201d he said.\n\nGovernment officials and cybersecurity experts in Saudi Arabia and the United States attributed the 2012 Shamoon attack to Iranian hackers.\n\n\u201cAnother attacker could have adopted that code\u201d for the January 2017 attacks, said Vikram Thakur, a senior researcher at Symantec, \u201cbut our analysis showed the likelihood it was the same perpetrator was pretty high.\u201d\n\nThe attack in August was not a Shamoon attack. It was much more dangerous.\n\nInvestigators believe a nation-state was responsible because there was no obvious profit motive, even though the attack would have required significant financial resources. And the computer code had not been seen in any earlier assaults. Every hacking tool had been custom built.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe attackers not only had to figure out how to get into that system, they had to understand its design well enough to know the layout of the facility \u2014 what pipes went where and which valves to turn in order to trigger an explosion.\n\nInvestigators believe someone would have had to buy the same version of the Triconex safety system to figure out how it worked. The components, investigators said, could be purchased for $40,000 on eBay.\n\nThe attack has also shown the challenge of attributing with unquestionable evidence an attack to one country.\n\nSecurity experts said Iran, China, Russia the United States and Israel had the technical sophistication to launch such attacks. But most of those countries had no motivation to do so. China and Russia are increasingly making energy deals with Saudi Arabia, and Israel and the United States have moved to cooperate with the kingdom against Iran.\n\nThat leaves Iran, which experts said had a growing military hacking program, although the Iranian government has denied any involvement in such attacks.\n\nTensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia have steadily escalated in recent years, and the conflict has drifted online.\n\nUnited States officials and security analysts blamed Iranian hackers for a spate of attacks on American banks in 2012 and more recent espionage attacks on the airline industry. Iranian hackers were blamed for the 2012 Aramco attack and are also the leading suspects in the more recent Shamoon attacks.\n\nThe August attack was far more sophisticated than any previous attack originating from Iran, Mr. Thakur of Symantec said, but there is a chance Iran could have improved its hacking abilities or worked with another country, like Russia or North Korea.\n\nTasnee said in an email that it had hired experts from Symantec and IBM to study the attack against it. The company said it had also \u201ccompletely overhauled our security standards\u201d and started using new tools to prevent attacks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBeing a global business,\u201d the company said, \u201cwe believe that cybersecurity is a concern wherever you are in the world.\u201d", "title": "A Cyberattack in Saudi Arabia Had a Deadly Goal. Experts Fear Another Try.", "authors": ["Nicole Perlroth", "Clifford Krauss"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "If approved by the I.T.F. member nations later this year, the new version of the Davis Cup would begin in 2019.\n\nThe World Team Cup was routinely staged in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany, in May before being discontinued in 2012. It was diverting but never considered the premier team test. Now the leadership of the men\u2019s tour, the ATP, is looking to revive it on a grander and more lucrative scale in cooperation with Tennis Australia. It would place this one- or two-week event at the start of the season in early January as part of the lead-up to the Australian Open.\n\nIf approved by the ATP leadership, the new-age World Team Cup could begin in 2020.\n\n\u201cThe Davis Cup has over a hundred years of history, and the I.T.F. are clearly looking to evolve the competition in an attempt to maximize its potential,\u201d the ATP executive chairman, Chris Kermode, said in an email. \u201cThe results of those efforts remain to be seen. Our focus remains on bringing the ATP World Team Cup back into the calendar, an exciting project which we\u2019ve been working on for over 18 months now, with the last few details still to be finalized.\u201d\n\nThe idea appears to be to use an Australian city like Brisbane, which has an ATP event for now, as the site of the new event.\n\n\u201cWe believe we have a strong option in partnership with Tennis Australia in Week 1 of the calendar, utilizing locations which are known to showcase the sport in a very positive way,\u201d Kermode said. \u201cIt\u2019s an option that would cause minimal disruption to existing player scheduling given that the vast majority of players are playing that week already in the Southern Hemisphere.\u201d\n\nSomething clearly has to give, and though Haggerty and Kermode met at Indian Wells last week and agreed to keep each other informed, nothing has given yet.\n\n\u201cThey will compete, but one\u2019s going to end up swallowing the other eventually,\u201d Milos Raonic, the Canadian star, said of the two events. \u201cBecause I don\u2019t think in any sport, two team competitions, other than something as big as soccer, really survive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParticularly when they could be just five weeks apart, and particularly when there is also a third men\u2019s team competition happening nearly every September: the new Laver Cup, created by Roger Federer and his management company, Team8. The event matches a European all-star squad against an international squad; it was a hit in its debut in 2017 in Prague and is set to head to Chicago this year.\n\n\u201cWe take three days out of the year, so don\u2019t worry about us,\u201d Federer said on Wednesday after advancing to the quarterfinals in Indian Wells. \u201cI think it\u2019s a great event. I think the players really enjoyed themselves. I hope it\u2019s going to be forever successful. We have no guarantee, like no tournament really has, except maybe Wimbledon, to be honest.\u201d\n\nTo be just as honest, who knows where sports or grass-court tennis will find themselves on the popularity charts in 100 years? But what is clear is that in the much shorter term, it is pure folly to create a glut of men\u2019s team tennis events that will only end up diluting the interest in all of them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe fans aren\u2019t going to understand,\u201d said Jeremy Chardy, a veteran French player. \u201cIt would seem bizarre to have essentially the same thing twice in a row.\u201d\n\nThis would-be turf war is nothing new: In the 1990s, the I.T.F. backed the creation of an end-of-the-year individual tournament called the Grand Slam Cup, which came after the ATP\u2019s tour finals. The Grand Slam Cup, open to the most successful players in the year\u2019s four major tournaments, offered huge money for the time \u2014 $2 million to the winner \u2014 but no ranking points without ATP support. It lasted until 1999 before reason (and economics) prevailed, and the two events essentially merged.\n\nWhy go through it all again? The current conflict also seems like a late-in-the-game scramble to capitalize on the golden era of Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic before it starts to fade to sepia, which could be very soon.\n\nWhat the sport really needs for the long term is one, just one, clearly defined and fully supported team event, preferably not an annual one. In an ideal world, it would include the women. Combined events, including the Grand Slams, are among tennis\u2019s greatest strengths going forward, with women\u2019s sports set to take on greater importance and market share.\n\nA combined team event of true import \u2014 not the low-key Hopman Cup in Perth, Australia \u2014 would set tennis apart from all the other sports that stage their World Cups for men and women separately.\n\nBadminton already has proved that the combined model works by bringing men\u2019s and women\u2019s national teams together with its biennial Thomas & Uber Cup, which will be in Bangkok in May.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut even a single men\u2019s team event is looking like a pipe dream for tennis at the moment. Part of the problem is that the Kosmos group was deeply involved in negotiations with Kermode and the ATP to revive the World Team Cup before running into resistance from ATP board members representing the tournaments.\n\nKosmos, which is headed by the Barcelona soccer star Gerard Piqu\u00e9 and backed by the Japanese billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani, then resumed negotiating with Haggerty after the I.T.F. had rebuffed an initial approach.\n\nThe bottom line: Kermode, a popular leader so far, is now vulnerable for having let Kosmos get away, and Haggerty and the I.T.F. are now vulnerable because their organization\u2019s cash cow, the Davis Cup, is steadily fading as the major stars decline to make it a consistent priority.\n\nIf the World Team Cup comes into existence, and provides nearly the same prize money as a revamped Davis Cup along with the ranking points that the Davis Cup cannot provide, it is a potential existential threat.\n\nThat would be true whether or not the Davis Cup adopted a new format. Even if the Davis Cup stays put with four weeks of world group competition spread throughout each season, top players, presented with a less-demanding option to represent their nations annually, would be more likely to choose the path of least resistance.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if it would be great to play both competitions in the same year,\u201d said Feliciano L\u00f3pez, the 36-year-old Spanish veteran, conceding that \u201ctwo in five weeks would be too much.\u201d\n\nHear, hear. Clearly, the time for compromise and vision is now. Unfortunately, pro tennis\u2019s numerous governing bodies are better at defending their territory than doing what is best for the sport.", "title": "A Davis Cup Overhaul and a World Team Cup Revival Add Up to Tennis Excess", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Federer\u2019s wife, Mirka, and their four children were set to travel separately to Florida for the Miami Open. But Federer was breaking away for a few hours, catching a private jet to Chicago to promote the Laver Cup, the team event that he helped create with Godsick and played at last year in Prague.\n\nThis was a long-planned detour, but it also ended up serving as a way to quickly change the chip after the final in Indian Wells, Federer\u2019s first loss in 2018.\n\n\u201cRoger\u2019s life, if it\u2019s not hectic, it\u2019s not Roger\u2019s life, because it\u2019s all he knows,\u201d Godsick said.\n\nHe has been with Federer since 2005, leaving IMG with him in 2013 to form Team8. Their families are exceptionally close: Godsick\u2019s wife, the former tennis star Mary Joe Fernandez, is a godmother of Federer\u2019s children.\n\nBut today is about business, and Federer, back at No. 1 at age 36, is clearly pushing himself to make it happen after back-to-back three-set matches on Saturday and Sunday.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s passion and a love for the game,\u201d Federer said. \u201cAnd Laver Cup is something that is very dear to me, so clearly I always have extra energy for the Laver Cup. For my own career, I don\u2019t play as much anymore, and when I am there, it\u2019s all out and full speed, and then I need the time away again.\u201d\n\nAfter takeoff at 7 a.m., there was no shortage of legroom or long yawns. There was an unsuccessful attempt at a nap in his chair, a modest shared breakfast (burritos, steel-cut oatmeal and juice) and plenty of chatter about this being Federer\u2019s first trip to Chicago. He then went into a separate cabin at 8:30 a.m., closed the drapes and took a 45-minute official nap that may or may not have included actual napping.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe would have been up early anyway today because he\u2019s got four kids, and they are still adjusting from European time,\u201d Godsick said. \u201cHe also had to get to Miami. We spend a lot of time maximizing time, because he doesn\u2019t have that much time. This is a four-hour detour. There are worse things to do, but sure it\u2019s hard.\u201d\n\nAs the plane approached Midway International Airport after about three hours in the air, Federer warmed up for chilly Chicago with a quick quiz.\n\nN.F.L. team? \u201cBears,\u201d he answered.\n\nN.H.L. team? \u201cBlackhawks.\u201d\n\nBaseball team? \u201cCubs.\u201d\n\nAnd? \u201cWhite Sox,\u201d he said triumphantly after a pause, dragging out the vowels in his best American accent.\n\nThere was no need to test him on the N.B.A. Federer has been an N.B.A. fan since boyhood and was 16 when Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen won their last title with the Bulls in 1998.\n\nA visit to United Center, the home arena of the Bulls and the Blackhawks and the site of the Laver Cup in September, was a big part of Monday\u2019s dense itinerary, which was focused on building interest for the event and creating social-media content.\n\nFederer walked down the plane\u2019s stairway shortly after 1 p.m. Chicago time after selecting a fresh set of clothes.\n\nHe was soon at a deep-dish pizza parlor downtown for a photo op with the 79-year-old Rod Laver, John McEnroe and the Australian star Nick Kyrgios.\n\nPhoto\n\nA former No. 1-ranked player, McEnroe still wears many a tennis hat and is the captain of the Laver Cup\u2019s Team World, which lost to Federer, Rafael Nadal and Team Europe in last year\u2019s inaugural edition. Kyrgios, 22, was one of the most enthusiastic members of McEnroe\u2019s team in Prague, leading the cheers and nearly defeating Federer in the final and decisive match of the competition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe funnest week of my career so far, better than the Grand Slams,\u201d said Kyrgios, who for all his evident talent has yet to get past the quarterfinals of a Grand Slam tournament.\n\nIf he comes closer to fulfilling his massive potential, he and his generation will be critical to the Laver Cup\u2019s uncertain future.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter proving Laver Cup could be done, Godsick and Federer now must prove it can be sustained, both economically and competitively, in a sport with a full calendar. Any new event that lacks ranking points and mandatory participation is vulnerable to irrelevance.\n\nWith Federer still near the peak of his powers, Chicago should be a success, and Godsick expects to sell out United Center for all three days of competition. Rahm Emanuel, the Chicago mayor, was part of the push to secure the event for the city, which has long been without a men\u2019s or women\u2019s main tour event. Emanuel joined Federer and the others on Monday at a news conference. There were also cameo appearances from Pippen and the German soccer star Bastian Schweinsteiger.\n\nSchweinsteiger plays for the Chicago Fire of M.L.S. and became a parent last week with his wife, the retired tennis player Ana Ivanovic. Pippen, 52, served as chief tour guide for Federer and Co. as they visited the Bulls\u2019 and the Blackhawks\u2019 locker rooms and the statues of Pippen and Jordan at United Center.\n\nFederer said he got goose bumps when he met Pippen and got a few more chills as he walked into the arena for the first time, though not because of the sheet of ice still in place after Sunday night\u2019s N.H.L. game.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a multiple layer cake,\u201d Federer said after gazing up and up. \u201cIn Europe, we don\u2019t have those very often, where you have suites and another layer and another layer. Usually it stops after two or three, but here it keeps going. I think it\u2019s going to be epic.\u201d\n\nThe Laver Cup\u2019s epicness will be determined in large part by who actually decides to play. The competition comes less than two weeks after the United States Open. Might some European and Asian stars \u2014 some of whom, like Hyeon Chung of South Korea, are represented by IMG \u2014 choose to save their energy for other late-season events?\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s going to always be an open question a little bit,\u201d Federer said. \u201cI hope it\u2019s not going to happen. I hope by showcasing and giving them such an amazing platform and being part of something quite unique, being on a team together, that they would not want to miss it. There comes a bit of sacrifice with doing something like this.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Laver Cup offers prize money to the winning team and sizable participation fees on a graduated scale. Team8 has arranged for private-jet travel to and from Europe to encourage European players like Nadal and Alexander Zverev to play again and others, Novak Djokovic in particular, to play for the first time.\n\nDjokovic and Andy Murray, both injured last year, did not take part, and it is unclear whether they would have done so anyway.\n\nFederer, meanwhile, continues to fly improbably high as the oldest No. 1 in ATP history. How long can he defy gravity?\n\n\u201cWhen I started with him, I made many more predictions than I do now, and I was very often wrong,\u201d Luethi said. \u201cI am ready to be surprised by him. I\u2019m actually expecting to be surprised by him, and I think the best thing is to leave it open and not try to put fences around it.\u201d\n\nFor Federer, who will most likely skip the clay-court season for a second straight year, the key is internal at this stage.\n\n\u201cWhen you go to, say, Rotterdam, you need to go there with fire,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you\u2019re not excited at this age, don\u2019t do it. It\u2019s that simple.\u201d\n\nCreating and playing in the Laver Cup, his potential legacy event, has helped feed the fire. But then, so has his personality: extroverted and still curious about new people and new experiences.\n\n\u201cThink about today,\u201d he said on his way back to Midway Airport. \u201cWe left with the sunrise, beautiful weather in Indian Wells, and we get here and it\u2019s cold and a totally different vibe. That\u2019s the beauty of travel, of seeing different places. I love it. I do.
