I still love it.\u201d\n\nWith that, he was soon successfully fighting the Chicago wind to open the car door and heading up the stairway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast stop on this genuinely manic Monday: Miami.", "title": "A Day With Roger Federer: A Tennis Ambassador\u2019s Work Is Never Done", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "CHICAGO \u2014 Up since 5 a.m., Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt was miked up and ready to go inside Loyola-Chicago\u2019s empty basketball arena when the clock struck 6:30 Tuesday morning and the television cameras went live.\n\nTen minutes later, dressed in her Loyola letter winner\u2019s jacket and a maroon and gold scarf that appeared to come straight out of a Harry Potter novel, she looked directly into the lens like a TV pro and greeted a national audience that had fallen hard for her.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really happy to be saying good morning to all of America today,\u201d she said, instantly adding the three \u201cGood Morning America\u201d hosts in New York to her growing legion of admirers.\n\nThe N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball tournament has a knack for creating instant celebrities, and few have fit the mold quite so perfectly as Sister Jean, the 98-year-old nun who serves as the team chaplain for the Loyola men\u2019s basketball team, which upset two opponents last week and will face Nevada in the round of 16 on Thursday. She is cheerful. She is charming. And, lately, she has seemingly been everywhere.", "title": "A Day in the Life of Sister Jean, Media Darling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Lastly, a pot of mirin- and soy-based broth was set bubbling over a flame, to which diners added veggies, mushrooms and paper-thin slices of moose shoulder dipped in raw egg yolk and aged soy. Handmade udon were then swished around the pot to extract flavor, and each diner was handed a microplane and invited to grate the fragrant zest of a yuzu onto the chewy noodles.\n\nThis take on Japanese home cooking is the work of Uvis Janicenko, a Latvian chef who spent two years in Japan before joining the Faviken team. (\u201cUvisan\u201d is a composite of his first name and the Japanese honorific \u201csan.\u201d) \u201cI used some of the classic Japanese dishes but adapted the flavor [to] local ingredients,\u201d he said. \u201cJapanese cuisine is very pure and clean in flavors that are close to me, so it comes naturally.\u201d All the same, Mr. Nilsson\u2019s hallmarks abound: Beds of forest moss, modest wooden spoons, and whimsical dishware suggest a woodsy fairy tale. Sweet flavors slip easily into the savory realm, savory into the sweet.\n\nAfter two nightly seatings, the space transforms into Svartklubb, serving drinks like gin with \u201cforest tonic\u201d and fermented milk known as fjallfil, chilled into a slushy and laced with a liqueur of dill and fennel.\n\nBefore first light (around 9:30 a.m. in December), cocktail bar becomes bakery, serving traditional Swedish saffron buns, floury sourdough loaves, thumbprint cookies, and crisp Pepparkaka gingerbread biscuits. The menu at Krus is like an \u00e0 la carte version of Faviken\u2019s indulgent breakfast, including marbled charcuterie from Mr. Nilsson\u2019s butcher shop in the nearby town of Undersaker, soft-boiled eggs with chilled cod roe, and delicate, just-made yogurt.\n\nUp here this time of year, when the sun\u2019s late rise is followed closely by an early but glorious sunset, it\u2019s enough to get you out of bed in the morning.", "title": "A Destination Restaurant in Remote Sweden Gets a Pop-Up Pairing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The Bugdaycays bought the TriBeCa building \u2014 a long-abandoned cast-iron warehouse built in 1867 \u2014 three years before starting the brand, with the intention of converting it to a townhouse that they would then sell. Beth was still working as CEO of the ready-to-wear label Rebecca Taylor, but feeling, she says, \u201cready to start a new chapter.\u201d And so she, Murat and their two children moved in themselves, leaving room on the ground floor for Foundrae\u2019s offices and an eventual store. \u201cIt was a lifestyle decision that gives us access to our family,\u201d says Murat. \u201cThe kids come after school to give us hugs and say \u2018Hi.\u2019\u201d That homey quality is apparent in the public space as well. There are even shelves lined with books, including those by 20th-century American writer Jessamyn West, Bugdaycay\u2019s ancestor, that visitors can borrow. Nearby is a weighty 1930s dictionary in which a young Bugdaycay was made to look up words, and a playful sculpture by the London-based artist Stephane Godec that shows a young girl in danger of sleepwalking off the edge of a cliff made of books. \u201cPeople use our pieces to tell their own stories,\u201d says Bugdaycay, who has seemingly inherited an instinct for narrative. \u201cIn my former role, I got so removed from the customer. Mr. Mastrangelo hopes the new business will help turn around a city that has been struggling since the Shenango China dinnerware plant closed in the early 1990s.\n\nMr. Mastrangelo, 80, said he had not heard many complaints from local residents about his city\u2019s new business. But the idea doesn\u2019t go down well everywhere. After Jeremy Faison, a Republican state representative from east Tennessee, sponsored a medical marijuana bill, he ran into significant pushback from his own district. The legislative board in Cocke County passed a resolution opposing his bill on the grounds that marijuana was still deemed illegal by the federal government.\n\nmO. 100 miles 55 arkansas TENN. 40 Cotton Plant okla. Little Rock Arkansas R. 30 miss. Mississippi R. tex. LA.\n\nEven so, Mr. Faison said the new industry would be a shot in the arm for rural Cocke County, where more than 24 percent of residents live in poverty and where the illicit cultivation of marijuana has, along with moonshine making, been a historic and notorious fact of economic life.\n\n\u201cSome of the prohibitionists are, like, \u2018I can\u2019t believe you\u2019re bringing pot to Tennessee,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Faison said. \u201cI\u2019m like, \u2018Are you serious?\u2019 \u201d\n\nLast month, the Arkansas Medical Marijuana Commission announced that Bold Team, the company that wants to set up shop in Cotton Plant, was among the companies that would be granted a growing license. On Wednesday, however, the licensing process was declared \u201cnull and void\u201d by a Little Rock circuit judge, who noted, among other things, that two commissioners had professional ties to owners of two other companies that had been picked. The Arkansas attorney general has appealed the ruling to the State Supreme Court.\n\nSuch challenges are common in state medical marijuana rollouts. The Bold Team owners declined to comment for this article, but Mr. Ryland said he was confident they would eventually be setting up shop. In its application, company officials said their facility would initially have 25 employees, some of them locally hired unskilled labor. The company also pledged to contribute 1 percent of its gross sales to the city budget.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ryland, who moved back to Cotton Plant in 2010 after retiring from the United States Department of Agriculture, said that God had called him to fix Cotton Plant. He was elected mayor in 2014 on the slogan \u201cChange Through Restoration.\u201d", "title": "A Dying Southern Town Needed a Miracle. Marijuana Came Calling.", "authors": ["Richard Fausset"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Dunnings, who worked in Lansing, near Michigan State, where Dr. Nassar was a longtime faculty member, had been the county prosecutor for nearly two decades. Known to wear a bow tie, Mr. Dunnings came from a distinguished family of lawyers; friends and associates said that his father had been the first African-American lawyer in the city.\n\n\u201cWhen it came to crime and punishment, he was as high-profile as you can get in Lansing,\u201d Warren Williams said of Mr. Dunnings, whom he has known since they grew up in the same neighborhood in the 1960s. \u201cHe was known as a very hard-nosed, no-nonsense, staunch law-and-order type of guy.\u201d\n\nBut around the time that Mr. Dunnings\u2019s office was considering whether to bring charges against Dr. Nassar, Mr. Dunnings was keeping secrets of his own.\n\nIn March 2016, everything came to a sudden, stunning halt: Mr. Dunnings was arrested outside a Lansing coffee shop and charged with 15 prostitution-related crimes. Law enforcement officials said that between 2010 and 2015, Mr. Dunnings had paid for sex from prostitutes across three counties. Mr. Dunnings soon resigned as Ingham County prosecutor and pleaded guilty to misconduct in office and soliciting a prostitute. He was eventually disbarred and banned from practicing law in Michigan.\n\nMs. Thomashow, 28, said she learned only in recent months that Mr. Dunnings\u2019s office had declined several times to press charges in her case against Dr. Nassar, part of a series of delays that permitted the doctor to continue his behavior for two more years, until women began going public with their accounts of abuse.\n\n\u201cWhen I heard that the police had tried to get charges and that Stuart Dunnings\u2019s office had said no, I was not surprised,\u201d Ms. Thomashow said. \u201cHe was busy doing his own thing.\u201d\n\nA Report, but No Case\n\nIt is not clear whether Mr. Dunnings, then the top prosecutor in the county, was ever personally aware of Ms. Thomashow\u2019s accusations against Dr. Nassar, though they were laid out in detail in a police report sent to his office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the report, Ms. Thomashow, an athlete, went to see Dr. Nassar because of pain in her hip. During the exam, he began to massage her breast, removing his hand only when Ms. Thomashow told him to stop, she told the police.\n\nDr. Nassar then told a female resident in the room to leave and ordered Ms. Thomashow to lie face down on the table, the report said. Without wearing gloves, he put his hand down her pants and massaged her vagina with three of his fingers for one to two minutes. He was \u201cextremely close\u201d to inserting a finger in her vagina, the report said, adding: \u201cShe told him to stop and that he was hurting her.\u201d\n\nMs. Thomashow had told her story in detail to Valerie O\u2019Brien, a university police officer, and Kristine Moore, a Title IX investigator, during an interview that May in a campus building, she said.\n\n\u201cI left feeling like these women had really heard me,\u201d Ms. Thomashow said. \u201cThey seemed really, genuinely concerned, like they were going to make sure it would never happen again.\u201d\n\nMonths later, Ms. Thomashow was informed that her Title IX complaint had been considered and that Dr. Nassar\u2019s conduct was found to be not sexual in nature, leaving her furious and disgusted. But she also learned that the separate investigation by the university police was underway.\n\nBy 2015, the university police had sent a warrant request to the office of the Ingham County prosecutor, and the case was assigned to Steve Kwasnik, an assistant prosecutor in Mr. Dunnings\u2019s office.\n\nMr. Kwasnik, a lawyer in the crimes against children unit, said that he reviewed the report and consulted with several other senior lawyers in the office, a typical practice. The office decided not to pursue charges against Dr. Nassar.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Dunnings was not consulted, Mr. Kwasnik said in an email. Mr. Kwasnik said that to his knowledge, Mr. Dunnings, the head of the office, was not aware of the case. Mr. Dunnings did not respond to requests for comment for this article.\n\n\u201cI determined that we would not be able to sustain our burden at trial,\u201d Mr. Kwasnik said. \u201cGiven the information available to me at the time, this was the correct decision and I stand by that decision.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Prosecutor\u2019s Downfall\n\nBy 2014, Mr. Dunnings, a Democrat, was midway through a fifth four-year term as the elected prosecutor of Ingham County.\n\nFrom the time he was young, it always seemed that Mr. Dunnings would be a lawyer, said Mr. Williams, who has worked in public relations and journalism and knew Mr. Dunnings for decades. There were great expectations for the Dunnings children, Mr. Williams said.\n\n\u201cThey had the nicest place in the neighborhood, and Stuart seemed to be groomed for success,\u201d he said.\n\nIn his early years as a prosecutor, Mr. Dunnings made a name for himself in part by aggressively pursuing prostitution cases, and taking special, public aim at people involved in human trafficking.\n\nIn later years, his team of assistant prosecutors seemed to be juggling cases on their own, according to some who worked around the office.\n\nGretchen Whitmer, a former state senator and Democratic candidate for governor in 2018, stepped in temporarily as Ingham County prosecutor after Mr. Dunnings was removed. After talking to people in the months after he left, Ms. Whitmer said she came away with a sense that Mr. Dunnings had often been gone.\n\n\u201cHe was an absentee prosecutor,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cHe wasn\u2019t around very much.\u201d\n\nRumors sometimes reached local law enforcement about Mr. Dunnings\u2019s behavior. Gene Wriggelsworth, who was the sheriff of Ingham County at the time, said the authorities would occasionally hear that Mr. Dunnings was getting away with misdeeds.\n\n\u201cWe would try to drill down on that, and I have to tell you \u2014 if there was something to it, we couldn\u2019t find it,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen came a new tip. This time, the investigators unraveled the case. They said Mr. Dunnings had paid prostitutes for sex, finding women on websites like Backpage.com and occasionally having sex with prostitutes in his office during working hours, according to court documents. One woman, who was not a prostitute, came to Mr. Dunnings for help with a child custody dispute and he suggested that she have a sexual relationship with him for money; she eventually agreed, afraid that he would use his power as prosecutor to harm her if she refused, the investigators said.\n\nMr. Wriggelsworth said Mr. Dunnings had been a friend and political ally in the decades past; the two men had even done some television advertisements together.\n\n\u201cIt was a huge betrayal to me,\u201d the former sheriff said of Mr. Dunnings\u2019s crimes. \u201cI have not had a word with him since.\u201d\n\nScandals Intertwined\n\nIn the end, Bill Schuette, Michigan\u2019s attorney general, pursued cases against both men \u2014 the doctor and the prosecutor. The two cases, both involving sex crimes, made their way along separate paths that intersected at odd moments. Two scandals, separate but intertwined, were unfolding publicly at once.\n\nIn November 2016, Mr. Dunnings pleaded guilty to a felony charge of misconduct in office and one count of engaging the services of a prostitute, a misdemeanor. Mr. Schuette, who is now seeking the Republican nomination for governor of Michigan, offered Mr. Dunnings a plea deal; he was sentenced to a year in jail and three years of probation.\n\nIt was a stunning fall for the prosecutor, who grew emotional in the courtroom, telling the judge at one point: \u201cI betrayed the trust of the people.\u201d\n\nOn the day of Mr. Dunnings\u2019s sentencing, another man was in the local jail. Appearing in the courtroom via video, Dr. Nassar pleaded not guilty to three counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct. It had taken years since reports of abuse were first made against Dr. Nassar, but the story was finally starting to emerge.", "title": "A Famed Doctor, a Troubled Prosecutor and a Case That Went Untried", "authors": ["Julie Bosman", "Monica Davey"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Despite the distances, locals say Kimba always had a strong sense of community, at least until the nuclear site was proposed. Some said the allure of millions of dollars\u2019 worth of grants and subsidies that the government was offering the host community had blinded people to the risks.\n\n\u201cIf it wasn\u2019t for the money that the government\u2019s offering, we wouldn\u2019t be where we are,\u201d Austin Eatts, 89, said on the large wheat farm just out of town where he has lived all his life.\n\nMr. Eatts, from one of the town\u2019s original families, is a neighboring landowner to Michelle and Brett Rayner, who have nominated their farm as a potential site for the nuclear dump.\n\n\u201cI share a pipeline with them; I don\u2019t want to share a nuclear waste dump with them,\u201d Mr. Eatts said. Looking at a pile of documents about the proposed facility he had collected over the past year or so, he said he worried about the effect of the radioactive waste on the town\u2019s future generations.\n\nThe public battle over where to store Australia\u2019s growing pile of medical nuclear waste \u2014 including low- and intermediate-level waste like contaminated plastic containers and protective clothing from nuclear research \u2014 stretches back years, and several aborted sites. But as the federal government narrows in on this tiny community as one of two potential host communities, fear and outrage about the potential effect of it on Kimba\u2019s farming land has grown.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow the subject of national news coverage, Kimba is so polarized about the debate that families who have been friends for generations now stare at the ground as they walk past each other on the street. Businesses have been boycotted, locals say. Some people have even left the town because of it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite the fractures, residents have one thing in common: They want the best for their town. They just can\u2019t agree on what that might be.\n\nMs. Clements, citing the decreasing number of school children and the fact that Kimba will soon lose its only doctor, said she worried that the town is shrinking along with the vigor of the farming economy.\n\n\u201cBusinesses are struggling,\u201d she said, noting the dozens of empty houses that line the streets here.\n\nThe farms being considered for the proposed site are 10 to 15 miles outside town. Each year, the amount of low-level waste generated in Australia is smaller than one shipping container, according to government figures, along with intermediate-level radioactive waste the size of a Dumpster. The country has no nuclear power plants.\n\nThe site is expected to bring more than a dozen jobs, leading supporters to call it a much needed alternative to agriculture for the local economy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThose against the facility, like Peter Woolford, a third-generation Kimba farmer, and part of the No Radioactive Waste on Agricultural Land in Kimba or South Australia group, say it will hurt the prices of crops and farmland. They also worry that Kimba will forever be known as the nuclear dump town.\n\nThe state of South Australia, where Kimba is located, is no stranger to radiation and radioactive waste. Most of Australia\u2019s uranium mines are here, as is the remote area known as Maralinga where the British tested nuclear weapons in the 1950s.\n\nWith the site selection process in its final stages, the government has opened an office in the center of Kimba to improve communications with the community. Federal government workers roam the town\u2019s main streets and are often seen mingling with locals \u2014 answering questions and trying to assuage fears.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome say their presence has cast a shadow over the town; others say the influx of government officials and the news media has already benefited it.\n\nTo persuade residents to accept the site, the government has also flown some on all-expenses paid trips to Sydney to view a nearby nuclear laboratory.\n\nThe federal government has said that it will not choose any site without broad community support. In early 2016, a vote showed that Kimba was almost split down the middle. Later that year, the number in favor had increased slightly.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo end the sometimes bitter rift in the community, some politicians are urging the government to find another site.\n\n\u201cThis has been a needless point of division in the community for more than 18 months now,\u201d Nick Xenophon, a former senator who used to represent the state of South Australia, said in a statement. \u201cIt\u2019s time for that to stop.\u201d\n\nThe Rayners, who offered land on their farm for the waste repository, said that they were convinced of its safety and that they had made the decision to give Kimba a boost.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s mainly about the benefits for the town and becoming a federal government town,\u201d Ms. Rayner said. She said she hoped an influx of government workers would bring improved hospital facilities, a higher-quality internet connection and even better television and radio service.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re right on the corner of remote,\u201d said her husband, who has been farming the property since 2000.\n\nThe couple said that while they had no regrets about their decision, what has happened in the community has bothered them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think that word nuclear has scared a lot of people,\u201d Ms. Rayner said. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019t know why they don\u2019t want it, they just don\u2019t want it.\u201d", "title": "A Farming Town Divided: Do We Want a Nuclear Site that Brings Jobs?", "authors": ["Jacqueline Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s midday at the Royal Opera House in London and some 12 ballet dancers are rehearsing. The auditorium is dark, the stage is lit and the renowned choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is in the circle, watching with a critical eye as the troupe performs a scene from \u201cCorybantic Games,\u201d a new ballet dedicated to the late American composer Leonard Bernstein. He\u2019s directing over a loudspeaker. \u201cCan we lengthen those extensions?\u201d he says. \u201cAnd orchestra, we need to speed up the tempo a bit.\u201d\n\nSitting in the stalls, dressed in his signature head-to-toe gray with round spectacles, is the British-Canadian designer Erdem Moralioglu. He created the production\u2019s costumes \u2014 Moralioglu\u2019s friend, the ballerina Lauren Cuthbertson, introduced the designer to Wheeldon \u2014 and he\u2019s here to see how the garments move onstage. \"We only have a few tutus,\u201d he notes, \u201cthe rest of them are still being made.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s been a whirlwind few weeks for Moralioglu, whose namesake label Erdem, founded in 2005, is renowned for its exquisite evening dresses and decadent craftsmanship. He has just returned from presenting his fall/winter 2018 collection to buyers in Paris, and only two weeks ago, he staged his London Fashion Week show at the National Portrait Gallery. This week has been tied up with fittings for the ballet \u2014 a five-month project for which he is costuming 24 ballet dancers, including men for the very first time.\n\nBackstage, Moralioglu asks dancers how the costumes feel. The long strands of ribbons need to be sewn down, he decides. \u201cI wanted the ribbons to look like armor \u2014 a contrast to this idea of undressing I was exploring,\u201d he says. \u201cIt\u2019s about flesh, and youth, and life.\u201d The costumes (translucent tutus with white bra tops and briefs) are intimate and ethereal \u2014 a blend of 1950s classicism with ancient Greece: \u201cSerenade,\u201d one of Bernstein\u2019s most famous orchestral works, was inspired by Plato\u2019s \u201cSymposium.\u201d \u201cWe also need to fit those body stockings,\u201d the designer says of the men\u2019s costumes. \u201cWe need to see the ripples of the muscles. They need to be tight, tight, tight.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven before this collaboration, ballet was a well-established part of Moralioglu\u2019s world. He has been fascinated by the dance form since he was young \u2014 his twin sister used to take lessons \u2014 and he\u2019s a regular at the Opera House and a former patron of Sadler\u2019s Wells. He knows ballerinas by name and performance, and he counts some as friends.\n\nHis Royal Ballet costumes are woven with his distinct, romantic handwriting \u2014 the ribbon trims on the pleated skirts, for example, are an idea that Moralioglu first explored for spring/summer 2018 \u2014 but the tutus are starkly sober in relation to his decadent ready-to-wear collections, which brim with color and texture.", "title": "A Fashion Designer\u2019s Otherworldly Costumes for the Royal Ballet", "authors": ["Grace Cook"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The high point of \u201c\u00cdmpetus\u201d is a solo for Mr. Carmona in which he performs with (and for) the singer Jonatan Reyes. The piece is a buler\u00eda, a strongly accented, high-spirited song form. Again and again, Mr. Carmona charges the singer, snapping his fingers, slapping his thighs and chest, feet pattering out fast rhythms. The two, dancer and singer, are locked in a completely private exchange, seemingly oblivious to the world.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what he\u2019s going to sing, and he doesn\u2019t know what I\u2019m going to dance,\u201d Mr. Carmona said. \u201cIt\u2019s that moment of surprise, which is so important in flamenco. Anything can happen.\u201d\n\n\u201c\u00cdmpetus\u201d is a quiet, even pensive show for a dancer known for his extroverted, electrifying stage persona. \u201cI\u2019m a very impetuous person, on and offstage,\u201d he said. His biography bears that out. He left home at 16 to pursue a professional career, after giving his mother an ultimatum: \u201cI told her, either you let me go, or one day, you\u2019ll find a farewell letter on the bed!\u201d he recalled. He joined Nuevo Ballet Espa\u00f1ol and then danced for five years with the Ballet Nacional de Espa\u00f1a, becoming one of its biggest stars.\n\nBut lately he has been trying to corral his energies, to slow things down and build intensity through containment. \u201cI\u2019ve been realizing that I\u2019m comfortable with stillness. You listen to the music, the singing, the guitar. It\u2019s like a battery, slowly charging, and then, boom.\u201d\n\nThis idea of restraint is also the inspiration behind a new experiment at the Flamenco Festival, a workshop entitled \u201cExploring Stillness,\u201d conceived by Mr. Mar\u00edn. \u201cFor me,\u201d Mr. Mar\u00edn said, \u201cthe most powerful moments are when the dancer is still. It can be more exciting than seeing 20 pirouettes.\u201d\n\nThe workshop will involve three dancers from different disciplines: Mr. Carmona, the Madrid-born Joaquin De Luz of New York City Ballet, and the American modern dancer-choreographer David Neumann. (Mr. Carmona and Mr. De Luz are friends: Mr. Carmona stayed with Mr. De Luz when he came to New York to study tap.) The fourth participant is more of a wild card: Ivan Bavcevic, a Reiki master and meditation coach who runs a \u201cschool of awareness\u201d in Spain. After five days of working together, they will present the fruits of the collaboration at an event on Friday at City Center.\n\nNo matter the results, the workshop points to an essential quality of Mr. Carmona\u2019s performance style \u2014 the contrast between wild, almost anarchic energy, and something more distilled. Not content to be simply a fen\u00f3meno, he\u2019s exploring new dimensions in his dancing. Or, as he put it, \u201csoy un t\u00edo que siempre quiere m\u00e1s\u201d \u2014 I always want more.", "title": "A Fen\u00f3meno of the Flamenco World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "In 2013, two biologists named Jamie Voyles and Corinne L. Richards-Zawacki spent weeks slogging up and down mountainsides in Panama. \u201cWe were bug-bitten and beat up,\u201d recalled Dr. Voyles, now an assistant professor at the University of Nevada, Reno.\n\nNear the end of their trek, they came to a stop. In front of them sat the object of their quest: a single gold-and-black frog.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t tell you what that moment was like,\u201d Dr. Voyles said.\n\nShe had feared that variable harlequin frogs had disappeared entirely from Panama. As recently as the early 2000s, they had been easy to find in the country\u2019s high-altitude forests.\n\n\u201cThey used to be so abundant that you could barely walk without stepping on them,\u201d Dr. Voyles said.\n\nBut in recent years, Dr. Voyles and her colleagues started to encounter sick frogs, and then dead ones. And then they couldn\u2019t find any variable harlequin frogs at all.", "title": "A Few Species of Frogs That Vanished May Be on the Rebound", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The result: The change in average sales during the experiment was 7 percent higher at the stores subject to the new policies than at the stores in the control group.\n\n\u201cThey were not operating in the stability sweet spot,\u201d said Joan Williams of the University of California Hastings College of the Law, one of the study\u2019s authors. \u201cWe basically held up a mirror to capitalism\u2019s self-image of efficiency and showed the misaligned incentives that are disserving both workers and the company.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShifting schedules have long been a complaint in the retail industry and other low-wage fields, and the Gap study suggests that they are a lose-lose proposition. But there was one apparent conundrum at the heart of the findings: While the effect on sales was quite large \u2014 the 7 percent increase swamps the 1-to-3 percent improvement that many retailers struggle to achieve \u2014 the overall consistency of schedules improved only marginally.\n\nConsider a part-time worker with an average of 16 shifts per month. At stores that attempted to make the changes, nearly 10 of those shifts were scheduled for a consistent time of day. At stores that had not done so, about nine of the shifts were consistent.\n\nThe explanation for how such modest changes could lead to such unusually large increases in sales may be that managers focused disproportionately on more experienced employees when it came to stabilizing the number of hours worked from week to week. That, in turn, appears to have lowered turnover among experienced workers, who helped their stores perform better.\n\n\u201cIt looks like managers did the rational thing \u2014 they had to improve stability, and so they picked the more experienced people,\u201d said Saravanan Kesavan, another author, who teaches business at the University of North Carolina. \u201cNow you have more experienced people in the store, and the productivity you\u2019re seeing increased, leading to higher sales.\u201d\n\nMr. Kesavan suggested that Gap could reap still greater financial benefits by making schedules even more stable and reducing turnover beyond what the experiment achieved. \u201cThe attrition rate is still high,\u201d he said. (Susan Lambert of the University of Chicago was the third author.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe researchers chose the 28 stores in the study, then randomly selected the 19 where the new policies would take effect for just under a year. Although the managers in those stores had previously agreed to take part, the researchers could not be certain that they carried out all the new policies. The managers were simply urged to do so with the company\u2019s blessing, an approach known as \u201crandomized encouragement design.\u201d\n\nMarshall L. Fisher, a professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania who is an expert on retailing and was not involved in the project, said the study provided compelling evidence that \u201cif you treat people decently, you get better results.\u201d\n\nMr. Fisher cautioned, however, that generalizing from the study to the company writ large, to say nothing of the entire industry, could be complicated. For one thing, he said, it was unclear if the improvement in sales would be as large as the researchers found if the company were to put the new policies in place in all of its stores at once. It is possible that the stores that adopted the new policies became attractive to shoppers, and may have siphoned traffic and sales from other Gap stores.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement, Gap was noncommittal on whether it would introduce most of the changes across all of its stores.\n\nLooming over the study was a gnawing question: Given the effort that went into making workers\u2019 schedules more consistent from day to day and week to week, why wasn\u2019t there more improvement in the actual scheduling?\n\nOne answer, the researchers concluded, is that the biggest cause of disruption in work schedules at Gap stores wasn\u2019t the fluctuation in traffic from customers, as was long assumed to be the case in retailing. Overly narrow decision-making at the corporate headquarters was a major factor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 2015, as the study was beginning, Gap announced it would require schedules to be posted at least 10 days in advance at all its stores in the United States. But schedules can nonetheless change quickly. According to interviews the researchers conducted with workers and managers, sales promotions mandated by corporate headquarters often required a large increase in worker-hours on short notice. So did preparing for store visits by executives.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just been a roller coaster with promo changes,\u201d one manager told the researchers. \u201cThis week alone the window changed three times.\u201d\n\nAnother manager reported having \u201cprobably extended two to three shifts every day in the run up to the visit\u201d by an executive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe researchers also identified inaccurate information about the size and timing of shipments as a key obstacle to predictable scheduling, since processing new inventory is labor-intensive.\n\nMr. Fisher said those findings could have an optimistic interpretation, because they suggested that it was largely within the company\u2019s power to smooth out the peaks and troughs in its workers\u2019 schedules. Some companies, like Costco, are able to provide more regular schedules in part by stocking a smaller range of products or scaling back or eliminating promotions.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement, Gap brand\u2019s top human resources official, C. David Ard, said, \u201cWe are taking a closer look at certain decisions made at headquarters and actively examining changes that could further stabilize the store scheduling process.\u201d\n\nIn the meantime, the fact that an inconveniently timed shipment could derail a store\u2019s schedule may point to a broader issue: Stores like Gap frequently leave little margin for error when it comes to staffing because managers are given targets for labor hours and their ability to meet them figures prominently in their evaluations.\n\n\u201cA lot of the instability comes from managers having tight labor budgets,\u201d said Carrie Gleason, the director of the Fair Workweek Initiative at the Center for Popular Democracy, an advocacy group. \u201cThey\u2019re understaffing to basically meet their numbers from one week to the next. It\u2019s management by the practice of triage.\u201d\n\nAs part of its scheduling changes in 2015, Gap officially eliminated tentative \u201con-call\u201d shifts that could be canceled at the last minute. But Ms. Stephenson, the Gap worker in North Carolina, said it was not uncommon for her managers to cancel a shift on short notice when they believe they can get by without an extra worker.\n\n\u201cThey try to do the best with what they\u2019ve got, and they\u2019re very apologetic,\u201d Ms. Stephenson said. \u201cThey say, \u2018Corporate says we don\u2019t have the hours.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Ard said: \u201cWhile we can\u2019t speak to this particular employee\u2019s experience without further investigation, we will be looking into this issue as we treat such concerns seriously.\u201d\n\nThe most important contribution of the Gap study may be to chip away at a rigid approach to labor costs that may not always reflect a rational calculation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is massively useful,\u201d said Ms. Gleason of the Fair Workweek Initiative. \u201cIt helps make the business case for why stable schedules work.\u201d", "title": "A Find at Gap: Steady Hours Can Help Workers, and Profits", "authors": ["Noam Scheiber"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Qantas Airways has made a giant leap forward in long-haul travel with an inaugural nonstop flight between Australia to Britain in less than 24 hours.\n\nFlight QF9 took off from Perth, in Western Australia, on March 24 and landed in London early the next day. Qantas\u2019s chief executive, Alan Joyce, billed the trip as \u201chistoric\u201d and \u201ca game changer.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s everything you need to know about the trip:\n\nBy the Numbers\n\nThe flight carried more than 200 passengers and 16 crew members.\n\nIt took off around 7 p.m. Saturday and landed at 5.02 a.m. Sunday.\n\nThe trip lasted just over 17 hours and covered about 9,009 miles.\n\nOf the more than 21,000 individual items loaded onto the aircraft for each flight between Perth and London, there are 330 peppermint tea bags and hundreds of chocolate biscuits.\n\nIn 1947, Qantas says, a return flight from Sydney to London cost 525 pounds. Today, a return fare from Perth to London can cost about \u00a3900 in economy, it says.\n\nView From the Cockpit\n\nThe flight was operated by four pilots during the journey, with one or two pilots resting at any one time.", "title": "A First in Flight: Australia to the U.K., in 17 Hours", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. He liked the area; it was less overrun than Brooklyn, and he had a wonderful view from his apartment right by the Hudson.\n\nThen came the developers.\n\n\u201cIt became Condo City,\u201d Mr. Lane said.", "title": "A Fresh Coat for Condo City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nSeated in an animated command and control room in Riyadh, the crown prince of Saudi Arabia directs an invasion of Iran. In scene after he scene, he orders a succession of superior weapons systems to pulverize the enemy. Finally, his forces corner the trembling figure of Qassem Suleimani, the revered commander of Iran\u2019s elite Quds Force, and the people of Tehran acclaim their Saudi liberator.\n\nThe animation, which first appeared on the internet in December and has been viewed more than 1.2 million times, offers a vivid portrait of Saudi Arabia\u2019s increasingly aggressive stance toward its regional rival since the assent to power of the 32-year-old crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman \u2014 M.B.S., for short \u2014 the king\u2019s favorite son and chief adviser.\n\nIs it serious or a satire? The video appeared on YouTube and social media accounts under the name of a group calling itself Saudi Strike Force; the group declined to answer electronic messages to its social media accounts asking about its identity. An official at the Saudi Embassy in Washington said the kingdom\u2019s government had no connection with the video. Bernard Haykel, a Princeton professor who recently published a column explaining the challenges Prince Mohammed faces in the kingdom, suggested in an email that the Iranians themselves might have made the cartoon \u201cto make the Saudis look silly.\u201d\n\nOther experienced observers said the animation showed an insider\u2019s familiarity with the visual details of Saudi Arabian and Iranian weapons. The video was released almost simultaneously in Arabic and English, with subtitles in Farsi, Hebrew, Mandarin, Russian, Turkish and other languages, so its animators probably also had the help of a team of linguists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Saudi news organizations under the control of the Royal Court \u2014 including the Saudi newspapers Al Riyadh and Sabq \u2014 immediately hailed the video as a depiction of the \u201creality\u201d of the kingdom\u2019s armed forces. It is \"A Bintel Brief,\" not \"Binto.\"", "title": "A Graphic Take on \u2018The Real Life of Sebastian Knight\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Eat\n\nBakfickan\n\nIn central Visby, the island\u2019s premier seafood restaurant is a no-frills rustic dining room, filled with mismatched wooden chairs and vintage fish prints, that\u2019s usually packed \u2014 no reservations accepted. The day\u2019s specials are written on a chalkboard at the entrance and often include baked perch with celeriac and truffle vinaigrette, lobster soup with black radish, and fried herring with spring onion butter and mashed potatoes. In warm weather, simple wooden tables are set up on the street outside \u2014 the ideal place to sip a glass of Chardonnay and watch the summer crowds pass by.\n\nKrakas Krog\n\nA 40-minute drive east across Gotland from Visby brings you to this hybrid restaurant and hotel in the middle of the Kr\u00e4klingbo countryside. There\u2019s a highly seasonal tasting menu of six to eight courses \u2014 regular ingredients include grilled beetroot, local lamb, and frogs\u2019 legs sourced from the nearby pond \u2014 all presented by one of the cooks in the spare, minimalist dining room. And with only one seating a night, there\u2019s a sense of special occasion that permeates dinners here. The three guest rooms are similarly simple and refined, all in varying shades of white, with wide-plank wood floors and fluffy down comforters.\n\nLilla Bjers\n\nThis 30-acre family-run farm on the outskirts of Visby is surrounded by vegetable fields and fruit orchards, from which it sources the ingredients for its organic, constantly changing menu. Everything from blueberries and currants to garlic and nine varieties of asparagus, as well as Christmas trees, are grown on the property. Dishes are a simple affair \u2014 think roasted lamb with pickled carrots and potatoes pulled straight from the earth \u2014 and a walk around the grounds before a meal is the best way to fully appreciate what you\u2019re about to eat. You can even meet the chickens that supply the kitchen\u2019s eggs. Dinner in the farm\u2019s atmospheric greenhouse can also be arranged, where you\u2019ll dine amid banana, fig and olive trees.", "title": "A Guide to Gotland, a Rural Paradise Off the Swedish Coast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "It is an unlikely endeavor for a man who is an ardent defender of gun rights. In 2013, after the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., Mr. Cornyn voted against expanding background checks to cover guns sold over the internet and at gun shows. He now says he will consider voting for such a bill, so long as private sellers are exempt.\n\n\u201cIf somebody\u2019s in the business of selling firearms,\u201d he said, \u201cthen I believe they should be covered \u2014 that\u2019s at the gun shows and that\u2019s over the internet.\u201d\n\nHis background-check enforcement bill, backed by the National Rifle Association, now has 68 co-sponsors in addition to Mr. Cornyn \u2014 nine more than the 60 votes necessary to break a Senate filibuster.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet despite his status as the Senate\u2019s second-highest ranking Republican, Mr. Cornyn cannot seem to get his bill to the floor. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, told reporters Tuesday that he was eager to pass it soon, and Mr. Cornyn said he hoped it could pass by next week.\n\nBut neither offered any specifics on a way forward.\n\nAs students plan a nationwide walkout on Wednesday to demand tougher gun laws, the slow progress of Mr. Cornyn\u2019s bill is yet another indication of how ossified the gun debate has become in Washington. The measure, known as the Fix NICS Act \u2014 NICS stands for the National Instant Criminal Background Check System \u2014 is hardly radical and would not do anything to restrict gun ownership. It would simply enforce existing law.\n\nCongress passed a similar measure in 2007 after the shooting at Virginia Tech, hoping to improve the reporting of criminal records and mental health information to the gun purchasing database. It did not head off Sutherland Springs, where a gunman legally bought his firearm despite having been convicted of domestic abuse.\n\nYet at least two, and possibly, three Republican senators are blocking the proposal from quick consideration. And Democrats \u2014 whose leader, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, is a co-sponsor of the measure \u2014 do not want to allow it to move forward for a vote unless it is paired with more far-reaching legislation, like an expansion of background checks and a ban on assault weapons.\n\n\u201cHe comes to the floor every day and says, let\u2019s do the small Fix NICS bill and then we\u2019ll see about other proposals,\u201d Mr. Schumer said Tuesday, referring to Mr. Cornyn. \u201cHe knows, as well as I do, that Fix NICS is not even close to a response to the epidemic of gun violence in the country.\u201d\n\nOn the other side of the Capitol, the House is expected to vote Wednesday on a measure, introduced in response to the Parkland shooting, to beef up safety at the nation\u2019s schools.\n\nThat bill has nothing to do with guns; it would authorize $50 million annually for safety improvements, including training teachers and students in how to prevent violence and developing anonymous reporting systems for threats. A companion measure in the Senate would also give schools money for physical improvements, such as installing metal detectors or bulletproof windows.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m extremely interested in seeing Senator Cornyn\u2019s Fix NICS bill pass, and a significant school safety bill pass,\u201d Mr. McConnell said Tuesday. \u201cThe best way to get that done is still under discussion, but I\u2019m anxious to pass both of them and pass both of them soon.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA former Texas attorney general and justice of the Texas Supreme Court, Mr. Cornyn, 66, grew up around guns. He keeps his license to carry a concealed weapon in his wallet \u2014 \u201cMy wife and I both got it together,\u201d he said \u2014 and recalls learning to shoot as a teenager, with a .22-caliber rifle at target practice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEvery teenage boy that I know of enjoys that sort of thing,\u201d he said.\n\nHe hunted deer for a time, but eventually lost interest. \u201cI\u2019d bring home the venison and my wife and daughters didn\u2019t really care for it,\u201d he said. He now hunts birds, usually quail. He says he likes to \u201cconsider myself an ethical hunter, which is if you shoot it, you\u2019d better eat it.\u201d\n\nWhile not a member of the National Rifle Association, Mr. Cornyn has an \u201cA+\u201d rating from the group, which backed him enthusiastically the last time he ran for re-election. The Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks campaign spending, says gun rights interests have given Mr. Cornyn $191,825 from 1989 to 2018. That is more than all but two other members of Congress \u2014 Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, and Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin.\n\nGun safety advocates are suspicious of Mr. Cornyn. John Feinblatt, the president of Everytown for Gun Safety, which presses for restrictions on gun rights, calls him \u201cthe go-to guy for the N.R.A. in the Senate.\u201d\n\nMr. Cornyn bristled at the suggestion. And he dismissed a recent comment by President Trump, who during a recent White House meeting chided senators for being afraid of the rifle association, with Mr. Cornyn sitting next to him.\n\n\u201cI thought that was a throwaway statement,\u201d Mr. Cornyn said. \u201cI don\u2019t know who he was talking to.\u201d\n\nThe gunman in Sutherland Springs, Devin P. Kelley, had been convicted of assaulting his wife and cracking his infant stepson\u2019s skull while stationed at an Air Force base. But the Air Force never reported the conviction, which would have prevented Mr. Kelley from buying the AR-15 military-style rifle that he used in the mass shooting.\n\nMr. Cornyn says his visit to the church a week after the shooting was profound. The sanctuary had been whitewashed and turned into a memorial. A tent had been set up down the street where the pastor conducted services.\n\n\u201cHe was holding it together in a superhuman kind of way,\u201d Mr. Cornyn recalled. He said he left thinking he \u201cnever wanted to have to confront another grieving family whose loved one\u2019s death may have been prevented by simply making sure that the background check system worked.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cornyn teamed up with Senator Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut and an ardent supporter of gun control, on the measure. Mr. Murphy said he gave Mr. Cornyn credit for being \u201cwilling to entertain a conversation in which there was no guarantee that the N.R.A. would support the bill.\u201d\n\nThe bill would impose penalties on federal agencies that fail to report mandated information to the background check system, and would give states grants to improve reporting.\n\nCritics, including Cal Jillson, a political scientist at Southern Methodist University who has followed Mr. Cornyn\u2019s career, regard it as an attempt by Republicans to curry favor with voters who were demanding action after the Parkland shooting.\n\n\u201cIt might help the Republicans establish themselves after the Florida shootings,\u201d Mr. Jillson said, \u201cbut there\u2019s not a lot of credit, not a lot of honor in that.\u201d\n\nAt that, the usually easygoing Mr. Cornyn showed a rare flash of anger.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s wrong,\u201d the senator said sharply, \u201cand I would ask him to talk to the pastor at Sutherland Springs who lost his 14-year-old daughter because the background check system didn\u2019t work.\u201d", "title": "A Gunman\u2019s Rampage in Texas Leaves Its Mark on a Republican Leader", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Except that even Paul, wary of the label, would probably describe himself instead as a realist, linking himself to the tradition of Dwight Eisenhower, Richard Nixon and George H. W. Bush \u2014 internationalist, stability-oriented, committed to the Pax Americana but skeptical of grand crusades, and open to working out cynical arrangements rather than pushing American power to its limit.\n\nThis cynicism explains why realists have found their chief rivals among the neoconservatives, a group best defined as liberal anti-Communists who moved right in the 1970s as the Democratic Party moved left, becoming more hawkish and unilateralist but retaining a basic view that American power should be used for moral purpose, to spread American ideals.\n\nThus neoconservatives despised the Nixon White House\u2019s realpolitik; they cheered Ronald Reagan\u2019s anti-Communism; they chafed under George H.W. Bush\u2019s realism and backed humanitarian interventions under Democratic presidents; and most famously they regarded the Iraq War as a chance to democratize the Middle East. And then when that war went badly, they became the natural scapegoats \u2026\n\n\u2026 Even though some of the most disastrous Iraq decisions were made by members of the fourth conservative faction, the pure hawks, the group to which John Bolton emphatically belongs. The hawks share the neocons\u2019 aggressiveness and the realists\u2019 wariness of nation building; they also have a touch of paleoconservatism, embracing \u201cAmerica First\u201d without its non-interventionist implications.\n\nBut the hawkish tradition, from Douglas MacArthur down to Dick Cheney (a realist reborn as a hawk post-9/11) and now Bolton, is distinguished by simplicity: The default response to any challenge should be military escalation, the imposition of America\u2019s will by force \u2014 and if one dangerous regime is succeeded by another, you just go in and kill the next round of bad guys, too.", "title": "Opinion | A Hawk Takes Flight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "DES MOINES \u2014 Steve Lacy greeted me in his office as if we were old friends.\n\nA top executive at the Meredith Corporation, he was a main driver of the company\u2019s $2.8 billion acquisition of Time Inc. last November. With that deal, the 116-year-old Meredith Corporation became the largest magazine publisher in America.\n\nWhen he spoke, it was clear Mr. Lacy took pride in Meredith\u2019s unassuming corporate culture, so far removed from the New York magazine scene.\n\n\u201cIn Des Moines, Iowa, we don\u2019t have to prove anything to anybody about the Meredith Corporation,\u201d Mr. Lacy said. \u201cWe don\u2019t have drivers. We\u2019d look silly, and it would be not in keeping with who we are.\u201d He added, \u201cI presume you know that if I want a black car, I can get one.\u201d\n\nMr. Lacy, 63, is a trim man, born and raised in Kansas, with neat white hair. He steered me to a table by a large framed photograph of a bald eagle. Not far from his office on the 14-acre Meredith campus, a 24-foot sculpture of a trowel sticks out of the earth at an angle, as if tossed by a gardening giant.", "title": "A Heartland Company Leads the Media Race", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Bells Beach is renowned for big, raw and challenging southern swells surrounded by rugged cliffs that serve as a natural amphitheater. The nearby town of Torquay is where the surf sportswear companies Quicksilver and Rip Curl were founded, and some locals say it is where the fleece-lined boots known as Uggs came from.\n\nBut Bells Beach is also where Fanning, now 36, shocked the surfing world almost two decades ago, winning his first-ever World Surf League tour event as a low-ranked wild card.\n\nHe would go on to win here three more times.\n\nAside from world titles in 2007, 2009 and 2013, Fanning has countless World Tour wins and top five finishes. His speed on a wave and his white hair make him easy to spot, and have earned him the nickname White Lightning.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s an icon of the sport,\u201d the American surfer Kelly Slater said of Fanning in a telephone interview from Gold Coast, Australia. Slater, himself an 11-time world champ, described Fanning as the fiercest of competitors and one of his greatest rivals.\n\nFanning is also recognized for what he has overcome: the untimely deaths of two brothers, a debilitating and gruesome hamstring injury and, of course, fighting off a shark at Jeffreys Bay in South Africa. (He would return there the next year and win.)\n\nVideo\n\nFanning, who was born in Western Sydney in 1981 and raised on the north coast of New South Wales, started surfing when he was about 5 years old. He made a name for himself in amateur competitions before turning pro in 2002.\n\n\u201cI wake up in the morning and I\u2019ve got to know what the ocean\u2019s doing,\u201d Fanning said. \u201cI\u2019ve got to have some sort of water on me. It\u2019s our Australian lifestyle to be around the water.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost of the country\u2019s 24 million people live in or near coastal areas. Predictably, the country is a surfing powerhouse.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe consistently created this pipeline of champion surfers,\u201d said Layne Beachley, a former world champion Australian surfer.\n\nFanning\u2019s fellow surfers credit him with helping advance the sport and attract a new audience, but those who know him well say his mark extends well beyond the water.\n\n\u201cMick\u2019s one of the true gentlemen of surfing,\u201d Beachley said.\n\nYounger surfers, too, have found in Fanning a model for their own careers and conduct.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s one of those people that\u2019s really able to turn his competitive edge on like a switch,\u201d said John John Florence, 25, of Hawaii who was the World Surf League\u2019s men\u2019s champion last year. \u201cYou\u2019ll have a crazy battle heat with him, and then you\u2019ll get out of the water and he\u2019ll be completely normal and the nicest person in the world.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s something I take away from him and try to do my best at,\u201d Florence said.\n\nFanning credits the ocean with keeping him humble.\n\n\u201cEvery day when you think you\u2019re on top of the world, the ocean would have put you back in your place,\u201d he said.\n\nHe said that he would never lose his love of surfing, but that the motivation and competitive streak he is so well known for have waned recently. He added that he felt he had been missing out on other aspects of life.\n\nAnd because nature has given him so much, providing the platform for his success, he said it was time to give back. Post-surfing, he is planning to focus on conservation work in remote corners of the world.\n\n\u201cI just felt like there was more out there,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s more to life than just being stressed out in crazy waves.\u201d", "title": "Mick Fanning, a Hero of Australian Surfing, Paddles Out One Last Time", "authors": ["Jacqueline Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "A LONG WAY FROM HOME\n\nBy Peter Carey\n\n318 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.\n\nWith his new novel, Peter Carey continues his streak of using titles (\u201cAmnesia,\u201d \u201cThe Chemistry of Tears\u201d) that sound like made-for-TV specials. Thankfully, behind the delicate phrase on the cover of \u201cA Long Way From Home\u201d is a propulsive account of an Australian road race, a \u201cCannonball Run\u201d with sociopolitical commentary lashed to the bumper. If the title conjures polite restraint, the novel itself is reliably free-flowing. And why not? Carey is once again in his happy place, Australia\u2019s past, this time the 1950s, where he\u2019s free to fill the text with all the evocations he savors as an expat, perched overseas in New York. While he isn\u2019t channeling a rough-hewn character like Ned Kelly, as he did in \u201cTrue History of the Kelly Gang,\u201d his second Man Booker Prize-winning novel, his two narrators still like to kink and twist their Aussie phrasing.\n\nIrene Bobs and Willie Bachhuber are neighbors in Bacchus Marsh, Carey\u2019s hometown. It\u2019s a familiar world: The author\u2019s parents sold automobiles when he was young, and at the beginning of the book Irene and her pint-size husband, Titch, are vying to get a dealership of their own. The race they enter, for the sake of publicity, is the Redex Trial, a dusty tour of Australia that will pit the dominance of Ford over \u201cAustralia\u2019s Own Car,\u201d the General Motors Holden: \u201cTwo hundred lunatics circumnavigating the continent of Australia, more than 10,000 miles over outback roads so rough they might crack your chassis clean in half.\u201d It\u2019s an adventure that will trace the \u201cCrystal Highway,\u201d named for all the broken windscreen glass scattered along the verges on a road of \u201crough conditions, corrugations, bulldust, bone-breaking rock\u201d and, in calmer moments, \u201cthe hypnotic undulations of the blacktop.\u201d The landscape is so alive to Carey that it forms a body, from the tip of Darwin down to the desolate Nullarbor Plain, where the wind whips the sand, the \u201cgnarled and stunted scrub, myall and mallee and mulga.\u201d \u201cIf Australia had a bottom,\u201d Carey writes, \u201cthis would be the place it did its business.\u201d\n\nThe land may be a character, but the speaking voices belong to Irene and Willie, the unlikely driver and her navigator. Irene is tough: a driver able to craft inventive solutions, at one point stretching her sister\u2019s dirty stocking over cylindrical mesh to reassemble an air cleaner. \u201cIf I had been so easily discouraged,\u201d she explains, \u201cI would still be a virgin bride. That was not how I did things, by being defeated at the start.\u201d\n\nWillie is the oft-mentioned German bachelor of Bacchus Marsh, a disgraced teacher suspended for holding a student out of a second-story window after being taunted with racial remarks. Raised by a Lutheran pastor in Adelaide, Willie is unaware of the complexity of his heritage. He\u2019s convinced his correct place in the world is \u201celsewhere, located on a map with German names.\u201d As he navigates for Irene and Titch along the Crystal Highway, these internal German maps of his lost identity become less important than those of his own country, just as the race becomes less important than the journey. Their battered Holden crosses land mapped with lines made by whites and Aboriginals, some laid down in the present, some as old as the soil. But Carey isn\u2019t bound by the car-race plot he introduces at the beginning. His plans for the novel flap as they exit out the window. Speed is what\u2019s important.", "title": "A High-Speed Auto Race Across Australia, Past and Present", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Much of the narrative frame concerns high politics, and rightly so. A book like this one is particularly valuable in an age when history undergraduates often startle their teachers by their ignorance of basic facts. So it\u2019s good to be reminded of the personal as well as principled conflicts among Wellington, Melbourne, Peel, Aberdeen, Disraeli and Gladstone, all of whom, one may say, seem towering figures by today\u2019s dismal standards. Against the reforming spirit of the age there were contrary forces, the neoreactionaries of \u201cYoung England\u201d and the high church revival of the Oxford movement.\n\nThat meant little to the victims of the \u201cHungry Forties,\u201d with severe recession throughout the country, and catastrophe in Ireland. Sir Robert Peel was converted to free trade and the repeal of the protectionist Corn Laws, with not much immediate effect on \u201cthe condition of England\u201d about which Thomas Carlyle and many others wrote.\n\nPhoto\n\nToward the end of the century, Sir John Seeley said with smug facetiousness that the British had acquired an empire, which by then extended over much of the globe, in \u201ca fit of absence of mind.\u201d What was true was the reluctance of successive governments for either war or expansion. Prime ministers found themselves \u2014 Lord Aberdeen in the Crimea and Lord Salisbury with the Boers \u2014 dragged into conflicts they didn\u2019t much want. And there was continual tension between the British government and distant settlers from South Africa to Australia, with London trying to restrain the settlers and making at least a pretense of safeguarding the interests of the indigenous peoples.\n\nAnd yet there was an underlying imperialist savagery, seen in the bloody suppression of the Indian Mutiny of 1857, combined with cynicism. The English did not endear themselves to others by combining rapacity with seeming high-mindedness. If the governor of Hong Kong, who claimed that \u201cJesus Christ is free trade, and free trade is Jesus Christ,\u201d was an extreme case, there was nothing \u201cfree\u201d about the monstrous way China was forced to buy opium by the British.\n\nAs in that case, much of British commercial success had nothing to do with formal empire. By midcentury, \u201c1,500 British mercantile houses were trading around the world, and nearly two-thirds of them were based outside the European mainland, with 41 in Buenos Aires alone.\u201d As Cannadine says, the British had found the secret by which they could \u201coperate as a global hegemon on the cheap.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the book\u2019s \u201chalftime,\u201d which Cannadine marks with the triumphant Great Exhibition of 1851, visited in Hyde Park by an astonishing six million people, \u201cthe world was at peace, and England prosperous at home and honored abroad,\u201d according to one complacent contemporary. In some ways it actually was a generous country. Around and about Soho at the time could be found dissidents and revolutionists from half the countries of Europe \u2014 Louis Blanc, Karl Marx, Giuseppe Mazzini, Lajos Kossuth and Alexander Herzen. The Times boasted that \u201cthis country is the asylum of nations,\u201d a contrast indeed to today.\n\nAfter the very unsettled period in domestic politics from the 1840s to the 1860s, a modern party structure took shape, the franchise was widened twice more, and a secret ballot was introduced in 1872, dramatically affecting Ireland. Gladstone tried but failed to pass Home Rule and, as Cannadine grimly says, \u201cthe \u2018Irish question\u2019 was back, and it would not go away for the rest of the 19th century or, indeed, for the whole of the 20th century \u2014 and beyond.\u201d\n\nWhile the empire grew apace, so did production of the coal and ships that ensured British naval supremacy. And yet by the end of the century, a new boastful imperialism was qualified by a mood of apprehension, expressed by the bard of Empire himself. Kipling warned \u201clest we forget,\u201d and imagined the day when \u201call our pomp of yesterday / Is one with Nineveh and Tyre!\u201d\n\nBesides these alarms there was astonishing scientific advance, a steady decline in religion and also something wonderful. The \u201ccondescension of posterity\u201d would be exceptionally misplaced for literature. During the one decade 1811-20 not only were Byron, Keats and Shelley writing and Jane Austen\u2019s novels published, but Thackeray, Dickens, Trollope and George Eliot were all born. Maybe our vaunted contemporary writers will one day be rated as highly. We\u2019ll see.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Cannadine\u2019s lucid account there is the occasional slip (the 1833 Irish Church Temporalities Act suppressed 10 bishoprics, not 18). And there\u2019s one subject that he deals with cursorily at the very end, but that was of the greatest importance in the second part of the century: the growth of organized games. He mentions the publication of Mill\u2019s \u201cUtilitarianism\u201d in 1863, but not another and surely more important event that year, the meeting at a London pub that drew up a common code for association football. As A. J. P. Taylor said, \u201cBy it the mark of England may well remain in the world when the rest of her influence has vanished\u201d \u2014 words that may be given further force this summer.", "title": "A History of the British Empire at Its Peak", "authors": ["Geoffrey Wheatcroft", "David Cannadine"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Not all have led to formal charges and even fewer to convictions, but Dr. H\u00e4nel and other doctors see a trend that they say aims to prevent them from providing a legally allowed medical procedure.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t believe that in this day and age the language and mind-set of the time when abortions were illegal continue to play a role in a country that is otherwise viewed by the rest of the world with respect,\u201d Dr. H\u00e4nel wrote on March 19 in an open letter to Ms. Merkel. \u201cI am ashamed and I hope that we can resolve this problem.\u201d\n\nThis is not the first time Germans have struggled with the issue of abortion. The procedure was illegal in West Germany until the 1970s, when women took to the streets to demand the right to decide what happens with their bodies. In 1974, a law was passed legalizing abortion in the first trimester, but the country\u2019s highest court overturned that ruling the following year.\n\nA compromise requiring permission from a doctor in order to be allowed an abortion was further eased in the 1990s, after East Germany \u2014 where abortion was allowed in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy \u2014 was absorbed into the West, leading to the current legal agreement. Under that arrangement, abortion is a crime, but will not be prosecuted in the first 12 weeks if a woman undergoes counseling and a three-day waiting period.\n\nIn neighboring Austria, Christian Fiala, a gynecologist, has advertised for years that his clinic offers abortions. \u201cUnwanted pregnancy?\u201d reads a billboard in the University station of Vienna\u2019s subway that includes his clinic\u2019s name and telephone number. A decade ago, he began collecting the names of German doctors who perform abortions and publishing them on his website, which is based in Austria and therefore not subject to German restrictions.\n\n\u201cInformation is absolutely essential, because women who find themselves unexpectedly pregnant need information urgently,\u201d Dr. Fiala said. \u201cThis has nothing do with advertising that would make it easier for a woman to decide to have an abortion just because she sees a poster somewhere. That idea is not only completely absurd, it is pretty sexist.\u201d\n\nThe Netherlands requires a five-day waiting period for an abortion to be carried out in the first 12 weeks, while in Belgium that time period is six days. In neighboring France, a woman seeking an abortion must take part in two consultations with a doctor or midwife. But unlike in Germany, this information is publicly available.", "title": "A Hitler-Era Abortion Law Haunts Merkel, and Germany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "But journalists worry that Alibaba, which has become one of the most highly valued companies in the world in part by maintaining good ties with the Chinese government, is abandoning The Post\u2019s history of scrappy reporting to please Beijing.\n\n\u201cBy explicitly stating that its aim is to tell a positive story of China and running questionable stories, management undermines the very attributes that make The S.C.M.P. useful in the first place,\u201d said Yuen Chan, a journalist and senior lecturer at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.\n\nAs businesses and governments around the world look for ways to skirt the traditional news media, The Post has become a test case for how a new owner can co-opt an established brand to promote certain viewpoints. Alibaba executives say they want to present a \u201cfair and balanced\u201d alternative to foreign media, a mission statement that echoes Fox News.\n\nGary Liu, a Harvard-educated technology entrepreneur who is The Post\u2019s chief executive, said the newspaper could offer a more nuanced portrait of China than Western news outlets, with a staff of 350 journalists in Asia, including about 40 in the mainland.\n\n\u201cWe are not here, certainly, to promote the views and wishes of Beijing,\u201d said Mr. Liu, who was previously chief executive of Digg, a news aggregation site in New York.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut a culture of self-censorship at the newspaper predates its purchase by Alibaba, said Wang Feng, who served as The Post\u2019s online editor from 2012 to 2015. He said top editors routinely rewrote, played down or withheld critical stories for fear of offending influential Chinese officials or business executives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was often done in a very hush-hush manner,\u201d said Mr. Wang, now the editor of the Chinese-language website of The Financial Times. \u201cYou could see that people were not exactly free to speak their minds.\u201d\n\nThat timidity has persisted under Alibaba, according to more than a dozen Post journalists who, speaking on condition of anonymity, described how the paper shies away from investigative reporting on Communist Party leaders and contentious subjects such as human rights.\n\nLast year, The Post retracted a business column that suggested an investor in Hong Kong had ties to a trusted adviser to President Xi Jinping and had used his connections to amass wealth. The editors said the column made \u201cinsinuations beyond the facts.\u201d\n\nIts author, Shirley Yam, a well-respected financial commentator, resigned. In a statement, Ms. Yam defended her column, saying that editors had vetted the piece extensively before its publication.\n\nSome critics said the more notable change under Alibaba may be The Post\u2019s ramped-up production of articles that present China in a friendly light.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn February, Post journalists said, the Ministry of Public Security pushed the paper\u2019s top editors to send a reporter to interview Gui Minhai, a political critic and Swedish citizen whom the Chinese police had snatched from a train.\n\nMr. Gui was then quoted saying he had broken Chinese law and did not want help from the outside world. In its coverage, The Post said that the interview with Mr. Gui was \u201cgovernment-arranged.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Post risks being a vehicle in Beijing\u2019s overall propaganda machinery,\u201d said Willy Wo-Lap Lam, a scholar at the Chinese University of Hong Kong and a former Post journalist.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Xi, China\u2019s most powerful leader in decades, has all but eliminated critical reporting in the mainland, placed new pressure on Hong Kong media and ordered a vast expansion of China\u2019s publicity machine, with state broadcasters merged into a single entity called the \u201cVoice of China\u201d to strengthen China\u2019s international messaging.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChow Chung-yan, who oversees coverage of China and Hong Kong, denied The Post yields to pressure from Beijing.\n\n\u201cWe are independent and free,\u201d he said. \u201cWe don\u2019t have people calling into our newsroom asking what we will publish.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Post\u2019s editor in chief, Tammy Tam, a former Hong Kong television broadcaster, declined to be interviewed. \u201cWe believe in reporting freely, fearlessly and in accordance with the highest editorial standards,\u201d she said in a statement.\n\nThe Post\u2019s leaders say that Alibaba executives, who have offices a few floors above the newsroom, are not involved in editorial decisions. But Mr. Tsai, the co-founder who spoke at the celebration last month, maintains a close connection, offering occasional feedback on coverage and new products.\n\nThere has been at least one noticeable change since the sale: an outpouring of coverage of Alibaba and its leader, Jack Ma, one of China\u2019s richest men. Articles mentioning Alibaba reached an average of about 3.5 per day last year online and in print, roughly double the number in 2016, according to an archival search.\n\nAlibaba appears to be willing to lose money on The Post, which is not profitable, according to newsroom leaders. Mr. Tsai has said The Post, with a circulation of about 101,000 and more than 10 million monthly active users on its website, may not become a self-sustaining business for at least five more years.\n\nTraffic to The Post\u2019s website has roughly tripled over the past year, the company said. Alibaba made access free when it took over.\n\nBut Alibaba has abandoned ambitions of expanding the audience for The Post\u2019s journalism in the mainland, where its website is blocked. Even with its pro-China mission, articles in The Post still touch on topics that are off limits to mainland readers, like the 1989 Tiananmen massacre.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile many of its approximately 850 articles a week appear tailored for a Hong Kong or Asian audience, The Post has gone on a hiring spree of journalists from outlets like the BBC and The New York Times to help bring an international tone to its coverage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo cater to young people and readers in the United States, now its largest market, The Post this month launched Inkstone, an app and newsletter that offers a conversational take on China, and Abacus, a multimedia site focused on technology. The new products also help blunt criticism that The Post is a propaganda tool.\n\n\u201cDiss the national anthem? That\u2019s up to three years in the slammer,\u201d read one recent headline on an Inkstone article about penalties for mocking the Chinese national anthem in Hong Kong.\n\nThe Post\u2019s success may hinge on persuading overseas readers that it delivers reliable journalism about China.
