But on the front lines, reporters are grappling with perceptions that the paper is another Chinese state news media outlet.\n\nTom Grundy, editor of the Hong Kong Free Press, a rival news site, said The Post was home to talented reporters. But he said Alibaba\u2019s ownership of the paper and recent editorial missteps risked tarnishing high-quality work.\n\n\u201cNo matter how good their output,\u201d he said, \u201cthere will always be distrust.\u201d\n\nRobert Delaney, a New York-based correspondent for The Post, said he had difficulty lining up interviews with American politicians and other sources because they assumed he worked for a news outlet controlled by the Communist Party.\n\nNow Mr. Delaney, a former China correspondent for Bloomberg News, makes a point of clarifying.\n\n\u201cWithin the first minute, I just want to let them know, \u2018Just so you know, we\u2019re not a mainland Chinese newspaper, even though we have China in our name,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThat gets kind of awkward.\u201d", "title": "A Hong Kong Newspaper on a Mission to Promote China\u2019s Soft Power", "authors": ["Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA horse walked into a club \u2014 no joke.\n\nAnd city officials in Miami Beach were certainly not laughing on Friday when they shut down the nightclub for creating what they said was a threat to public health and opened a criminal investigation into whether it had committed animal cruelty.\n\n\u201cThis morning we heard about and saw an extremely troubling video of what can only be described as insane stupidity,\u201d Mayor Dan Gelber said at a news conference on Friday. \u201cIt was dangerous to this animal, it was dangerous to the public, it was inhumane. It wasn\u2019t silly or sophomoric. It was outrageous.\u201d\n\nThe order issued to the nightclub, Mokai Lounge, says the horse was paraded around the venue sometime Wednesday night or Thursday morning.\n\nVideo of the episode shows a woman in underwear riding a white horse, which appears to slip and then fall. As the horse attempts to regain its footing, the rider falls from its back. The horse then meanders through the crowd for a few seconds before the video ends.\n\nThe city order says that the footage shows that the horse was scared and concludes that the situation was an \u201cactual threat\u201d to public health and safety \u2014 enough to warrant the revocation of the lounge\u2019s business license.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the news conference, Mr. Gelber recalled his first thought after watching footage of the event: \u201cWhat kind of idiot would do something like this?\u201d\n\nThe city manager, Jimmy L. Morales, who issued the order revoking the nightclub\u2019s business license, added, \u201cI was disgusted and offended that any legitimate businessperson would think this was an appropriate action to take.\u201d", "title": "A Horse Walked Into a Miami Beach Nightclub. Now Nobody Else Can.", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHow to Make A.I. Human-Friendly\u201d (Op-Ed, March 8):\n\nFei-fei Li urges that \u201chuman centered\u201d artificial intelligence \u201cmust be guided by human concerns.\u201d\n\nAs long as the unholy alliance of tech and business is in charge, without labor at the table, profit will be the only concern.\n\nMICHAEL SOBEL, BROOKLYN", "title": "Opinion | A Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOnce I saw that, I lost it,\u201d said Edward Santiago, 60. \u201cI kept yelling his name. He was so happy about the apartment, and what a view.\u201d\n\nThe picture window in the living room of Mr. Santiago\u2019s one-bedroom apartment offered a view of his beloved Lower East Side, where he would point out the former locations of Ratner\u2019s delicatessen, Loew\u2019s Apollo Theater, Rosario\u2019s Pizza and the police precinct where the 1970s TV show \u201cMcCloud\u201d was filmed.\n\nMr. Santiago, whose tough-guy persona, tall tales, jokes and uncanny ability to imitate his Italian, Jewish and Mexican neighbors often put him at the center of any gathering, had lived an unusual life since joining the Marines at 16.\n\n\u201cMy brother always liked to take charge,\u201d said Edward Santiago. \u201cHe took care of you. He started working before I did. He was the life of the party and he loved to feed people.\u201d\n\nMr. Santiago got his passion for food from his mother, Dolores Guzman, who still lives in the neighborhood but is ill. Their parents broke up when Mr. Santiago, Edward and their sister Alma were very young.\n\nAt one point, Ms. Guzman had a Spanish restaurant opposite Tompkins Square Park. Later, she opened a restaurant in Brooklyn. She and the children\u2019s stepfather, a bookie, raised the children.\n\nMr. Santiago was barely out of grammar school before he was shining shoes at the Spot Bar, a hangout on Delancey for local mobsters. From there, he made pizzas at Rosario\u2019s, next door to the Apollo Theater, on Clinton Street, where his brother said that the operator, Sal Bartolomeo, treated him like a son.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview in December Mr. Santiago said that he loved the potato leek soup and the cheesecake at Ratner\u2019s. Also on Delancey, he said there was a shop selling the best cuchifritos in New York.\n\nWhen their family was forced to move out of their apartment in 1967, to make way for what was called the Seward Park Urban Renewal Area, the Santiagos moved to Avenue D, \u201cAlphabet City, a war zone in those days,\u201d Mr. Santiago said. Later, they moved to a building on Grand Street built by the Archdiocese of New York.\n\nIn the meantime, the city demolished the buildings in the Seward Park area, leaving parking lots. The land became contested territory, as local housing advocates pushed the city to build apartments, while the mostly Jewish residents of nearby co-ops, backed by the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty and the former Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, opposed housing in favor of retail and commercial space. A succession of proposals collapsed amid the fracas.\n\nIn 1977, Mr. Santiago was 16 when he joined the Marines and went to basic training at Camp Lejeune in North Carolina.\n\nBut after about a year, his mother prevailed on the Marines to send her underage boy home. A couple of years later he moved to San Diego and fell in love with California and the ocean.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe met Trudy Gomes not long afterward, in April 1981. They quickly became a couple. She said she was impressed by his boldness in moving to the West Coast and his desire to make something of himself.\n\n\u201cThe charmer that he was, the rest is history,\u201d Ms. Gomes said. \u201cHe was a character, a schmoozer,\u201d she said, using a distinctly New York term she learned from him. \u201cI thought, how cute, he talks like Barbarino.\u201d\n\nMr. Santiago was off on a commercial fishing boat when his first son, David Jr., was born in March 1982. David still has a photograph of \u201cour first meeting, on the tuna dock.\u201d\n\nBut, Ms. Gomes said, Mr. Santiago was sick for most of his time on the high seas, some of it off the coast of Cuba. Soon, he and a friend opened a market, Ocean Fresh Seafood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy 1990, despite lacking formal training, he was a chef, opening the Picasso restaurant, whose menu mixed Italian and Japanese items, with Phil Rose, a lawyer and a former minor league catcher affiliated with the Los Angeles Angels.\n\nMr. Santiago and Ms. Gomes, who had a second son, Dominic, had broken up by that point.\n\nOver the years, he owned several other restaurants, or helped develop concepts or served as executive chef in both New York and Los Angeles.\n\nAt the time of his death, Mr. Santiago was dreaming of opening his next restaurant, Coqui de Suba, featuring Spanish and Caribbean dishes. This time, his son was going to help.\n\n\u201cI was going to be involved this time, to help make better business decisions,\u201d said David Santiago Jr., a general contractor in San Diego. \u201cHe was real old school. He did a lot of things without contracts, on a handshake. Maybe, here in New York, those type of agreements held up better.\u201d\n\nHis sons and their friends loved his \u201cbig personality.\u201d He wove his experiences from the Lower East Side, the Marines and his work on a fishing boat into his tales.\n\n\u201cThey pictured him as a wise guy,\u201d David Santiago Jr. said. \u201cHe loved that. He\u2019d exaggerate a little bit so his stories were that much more interesting. He\u2019d been around so he had a lot of stories to tell.\u201d\n\nBut in 2010, Mr. Santiago moved back to New York to help his mother. He also looked after his brother, who had been in a near fatal motorcycle accident.\n\nHe occasionally returned to San Diego to dote on his grandchildren and in the process became reacquainted with Ms. Gomes, who he called his best friend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe would always talk about the yuppie people moving to the Lower East Side,\u201d his son Dominic said. \u201cIt was a bittersweet thing because the old neighborhood wasn\u2019t his anymore.\u201d\n\nStill, Mr. Santiago applied for an apartment for \u201creturnees\u201d to Delancey Street last year, after the city finally approved the Essex Crossing project. Mr. Santiago, who had been sleeping on his mother\u2019s sofa for the past seven years, said he was thrilled in December when he got the keys to his apartment.\n\nBetween Thanksgiving and Christmas, he turned out hundreds of pasteles using his secret recipe, serving them to family and selling others for $30 a dozen. One customer bought $300 worth, Edward Santiago said.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t have the business smarts,\u201d David Santiago Jr. said. \u201cBut he definitely knew the kitchen. He was very creative and artistic.\u201d", "title": "A Joyful Homecoming Cut Short", "authors": ["Charles V. Bagli"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Riad Nasr, left, and Lee Hanson at their new restaurant, Frenchette, in TriBeCa. The two chefs have cooked together for 25 years.\n\nCredit Stephen Speranza for The New York Times", "title": "A Kitchen Duo for Decades, Now With Their Own Place", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "With the countdown underway to the end of another dispiriting season, the Knicks had pause to at least imagine brighter days ahead when Kristaps Porzingis made an appearance Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.\n\nPorzingis was upright, without crutches, smiling and vowing before the Knicks lost, 110-97, to the Dallas Mavericks, \u201cI\u2019m going to come back better and stronger.\u201d\n\nPorzingis, the 7-foot-3 Latvian whom the Knicks have been trying to build their team around, tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee on Feb. 6 in a home game against Milwaukee. He was operated on the following week and could be out for up to 12 months.\n\nThe timing of the injury was especially cruel as Porzingis, while averaging a career-best 22.7 points per game and an N.B.A.-leading 2.7 blocked shots, had been selected for his first All-Star Game.", "title": "A Kristaps Porzingis Appearance Reminds the Knicks of Better Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "No bill on divorce has ever made it this far in Congress. The measure is the rare piece of legislation supported by representatives from both the majority and opposition parties in the House. A survey released this month found that 53 percent of Filipinos support legalizing divorce.\n\nAbout 80 percent of Filipinos are Roman Catholic, and previous attempts to pass a divorce bill have faltered under the influence of the Catholic Church here, which vehemently opposes legislation that runs counter to its teachings.\n\nThe divorce bill comes in the wake of a bitter battle over a reproductive health law that provides modern family planning education and free birth control for the poor. It took more than 13 years to pass into law, which occurred in 2012; it then languished in appeals for several years, and has yet to be implemented fully. Politicians who supported that measure were vilified by priests or threatened with excommunication.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just exhausting to be debating with the church all the time,\u201d said the deputy House speaker, Pia Cayetano, a practicing Catholic who advocated both reproductive health and divorce, and was denounced as an agent of the devil during Sunday Masses. \u201cA lot of my colleagues are just too scared\u201d to take on the church, she said.\n\n\u201cWhile divorce may indeed vindicate the rights of women, as congressmen believed,\u201d the Rev. Jerome Secillano, the executive secretary of the Catholic Bishops\u2019 Conference of the Philippines, said in a statement, \u201cit is unfortunately to the detriment of marriage and family as sacred institutions that should otherwise be protected by the state. Divorce is antimarriage and anti-family.\u201d\n\nDespite the bill\u2019s passage in the House, Mr. Sotto has called its prospects in the Senate \u201cdim.\u201d\n\nSenator Risa Hontiveros, chairwoman of the Committee on Women, Children, Family Relations and Gender Equality, says she is meeting with women\u2019s rights and children\u2019s advocacy groups, and is looking for ways the Senate could consider the bill, given the concerns of conservative politicians and many in the broader public.", "title": "A Last Holdout on Divorce, Philippines Tiptoes Toward Legalization", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "These days I spend most of my time writing and working on a documentary series. Though I do love my work, I miss the camaraderie of professional kitchens. So when some chef friends recently invited me to join them for the day, I jumped at the opportunity. Shortly after we turned to peeling and chopping, I noticed two cooks at the other end of the kitchen whispering excitedly to each other. I waited a few minutes, hoping they\u2019d invite the rest of us into their salacious conversation. When they didn\u2019t, I impatiently demanded to know the subject of their gossip. Rolling her eyes, one of them responded, \u201cWe\u2019re talking about a recipe, Samin.\u201d\n\nI blushed. And then I asked for the recipe.\n\nUsually when a friend hands me a beloved recipe, it comes with a warning not to change anything. My inability to follow recipes as written \u2014 without obeying the devil on my shoulder telling me to replace ingredients or change the temperature \u2014 is well documented. But this recipe, for something I\u2019d never tried called butter mochi, was different. Written in cook\u2019s shorthand, it seemed simple enough \u2014 just a few ingredients stirred together in no particular order, then baked. And at the top, a note promised that the cake was \u201ceasy and forgiving\u201d to adaptation.\n\nI decided to make the recipe once as directed before getting creative, but my commitment was tested immediately. The original list of ingredients included evaporated milk, an ingredient I\u2019d never used. I had to suppress the urge to replace it with heavy cream, as I do when I \u201cfollow\u201d the pie recipe on the label of Libby\u2019s canned pumpkin. But I remained strong. Peeling back the lid, I realized evaporated milk is just milk that has been cooked down to a thicker, sweeter version of itself. I stirred it into the batter along with the other ingredients, poured it all into a large cake pan and slipped it into the oven.\n\nButter mochi is the Hawaiian descendant of chewy Asian rice cakes like Japanese mochi, Filipino bibingka and Chinese nian gao. Unlike those versions, though, it\u2019s enriched with a stick of butter. And with a recipe that calls for exactly a can each of coconut and evaporated milks, I suspect it\u2019s the prime hapa example of classic postwar dump-and-stir baking.\n\nWhen I pulled mine from the oven, I was surprised by its still-pale hue. My general opinion about baked goods is that darker is always better, so I was skeptical. But that didn\u2019t keep me from having a taste before the mochi could cool completely. It was so sweet that it burned my throat. Its extraordinary gumminess \u2014 not a quality I generally seek in my food \u2014 overwhelmed me. But I couldn\u2019t stop eating it. Once the mochi cooled, its texture shifted from gummy to addictively chewy. As I picked at it over the next couple of days, it became clear that the outer edge was the best part. The way the slightly caramelized crust contrasted with the gooey center reminded me of my favorite pastry: the canel\u00e9.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat I love most about that small, legendary pastry from Bordeaux is the satisfying contrast between its deeply caramelized crust and tender, custardy center. But I\u2019m far too lazy and stingy to try making it myself. Most canel\u00e9 recipes begin with an instruction to brush $30 copper molds with melted beeswax. Unsurprisingly, I\u2019ve never made it past the internet search for \u201cused canel\u00e9 molds\u201d before giving up.", "title": "A Lazy Woman\u2019s Canel\u00e9", "authors": ["Samin Nosrat"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nConor Lamb, a Democrat, appears to have pulled off a shocking upset in a Pennsylvania congressional election last night.\n\nThe race is still too close to call. But Lamb has a 641-vote lead over the Republican, Rick Saccone, and the remaining uncounted ballots are absentee ballots, which tend to lean Democratic.\n\nIt will be a remarkable win if Lamb holds on. Donald Trump in 2016 and Mitt Romney in 2012 both won this district, in the Pittsburgh area, by almost 20 percentage points. Last night\u2019s result is a sign that, while Trump may be holding onto his base, most voters are unhappy with his presidency. Republicans are looking at a very difficult midterm election.", "title": "Opinion | A Likely Democratic Shocker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor me, saltwater taffy is like a martini: Consuming either one is a slow process. And while martinis evoke Chumley\u2019s back in the day, saltwater taffy always brings to mind family trips to Atlantic City when I was much younger. These days, for saltwater taffy, count on Marisa Wu\u2019s Salty Road. Give her credit for helping to revive this treat, starting seven years ago in Brooklyn. She offers a raft of flavors, the latest of which are sunny banana, made with caramelized fresh banana pur\u00e9e, and tart passion fruit: The Salty Road Salt Water Taffy, $10 for 3.5 ounces or three 3.5-ounce bags for $21, thesaltyroad.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Little Taffy Stretches the Memory", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Now and again, another startling upset occurs that causes people to invoke Chaminade\u2019s name. That happened on Friday, when a school called the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, beat top-ranked Virginia, 74-54. U.M.B.C. became the first 16th-seeded men\u2019s team to beat a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\nChaminade found itself in the conversation again. That it was Virginia, first in 1982, again in 2018, gives the discussion a poetic refrain. \u201cIt amazes me that people don\u2019t forget that game for some crazy reason,\u201d Lopes, now 85, said on Saturday. \u201cWe\u2019re going to see what happens to Maryland and how people talk about them 35 years from now.\u201d\n\nA tiny Catholic university, with fewer than 1,000 students and a shared campus with a high school, about a mile from Waikiki, Chaminade was in the process of changing its name before Dec. 23, 1982. The school wanted something easier to remember, easier to pronounce. It wanted to be the University of Honolulu.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut then its basketball team beat Virginia, the best team in the country. Chaminade \u2014 suddenly famous, forever remembered \u2014 could not change its name. How could you, after people made T-shirts and stickers that read, \u201cYes, Virginia, there is a Chaminade\u201d?\n\n\u201cThe name Chaminade became a household name,\u201d Randolph said. \u201cIt\u2019s so recognizable. We\u2019re very proud of that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMaybe U.M.B.C. will resist the urge, someday, to rename itself something easier to remember, something more phonetically alluring, because of the lingering fame of a basketball game. Maybe those clunky initials will become part of the sporting lexicon, shorthand for a monumental upset, the way that the once unknown, often mispronounced Chaminade has been for 35 years.\n\nFor now, though, it does not seem right to try to compare the two, really. How do you rank upsets, anyway? Who cares? The only sure thing is that Chaminade\u2019s victory came in a different time and a far different place.\n\nOn Friday, U.M.B.C.\u2019s feat unfolded in a full-size, full arena in Charlotte, N.C., in real time everywhere. Countless people around the world, presumably, gathered around television screens and mobile devices to watch it happen. The U.M.B.C. athletic department\u2019s Twitter account played along as color commentator. Its followers grew tenfold in a matter of hours, pushing past 50,000.\n\nIn 1982 in Honolulu, the only people watching were the 3,383 counted in the Neal Blaisdell Center, which was not half full. There were no television cameras. News of the upset, in the middle of the night in the early hours of Christmas Eve for most of the United States, took hours, even days, to spread across the mainland.\n\n(As Sports Illustrated wrote a decade ago in an article titled \u201cThe Greatest Upset Never Seen,\u201d Chaminade\u2019s victory, among other things, \u201cassured that ESPN and its cable spawn would henceforth permit virtually no game to go untelevised.\u201d)\n\nThe culture and the game were different back then. There was no shot clock, no 3-point line. Virginia, with the 7-foot-4 center Ralph Sampson, the two-time player of the year, was undefeated. It had beaten Georgetown about 10 days earlier in what was dubbed, despite occurring just two years into the 1980s, the \u201cgame of the decade.\u201d\n\nVirginia and Sampson arrived in Hawaii from Japan, having just beaten Utah and the University of Houston, which had been gaining steam as a high-flying juggernaut nicknamed Phi Slama Jama. The Virginia Cavaliers were 8-0, and Honolulu was meant as a rest stop on the way home.\n\nChaminade was an N.A.I.A. school that had lost to Wayland Baptist two nights before. At the time, Lopes was a junior high school counselor who coached Chaminade on the side.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe teams were tied at half, 43-43. Unlike what happened on Friday, when U.M.B.C. turned a halftime tie with the Cavaliers into a rout, Chaminade fell behind by 7 midway through the second half. The Silverswords, named after a plant, chipped away at the lead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSampson was guarded mostly by Randolph. They knew each other from Virginia, where they grew up. Randolph spent years guarding Sampson in recreation leagues and in high school, and reportedly even dated Sampson\u2019s sister. (He said on Saturday that they were \u201cgood friends.\u201d)\n\nRandolph, knowing he could not compete with Sampson inside, hit several midrange jump shots that pulled his opponent out from under the basket. Randolph scored 19 points and hauled in five rebounds. Sampson had 12 points and 17 rebounds.\n\n\u201cRalph was so caught up playing those big guys, like Hakeem Olajuwon and Patrick Ewing, that he forgot that his homeboy could shoot jumpers,\u201d said Randolph, now 55, a basketball coach who spent years counseling troubled youth.\n\nWhen Chaminade\u2019s Mark Rodrigues lobbed a pass over Sampson on a backdoor screen to fellow guard Tim Dunham for a dunk, the score was tied.\n\nDunham, who attended high school at St. Louis School, the Catholic school that shares a campus with Chaminade, soon broke the tie for good with a 22-foot jumper, with just over five minutes remaining.\n\nThat was when fans in the building truly began to believe that they were witnessing a game that would resonate across time zones and over the years. Chaminade usually attracted dozens or hundreds of fans, not thousands. Most were there that night to see the best team and the best player in the country, not the scrappy squad of locals.\n\n\u201cAs the game unfolded, they were a little quiet, but all of a sudden when we started pouring it on and getting the lead, the crowd just switched,\u201d Randolph said. \u201cThat\u2019s when they got the chills. \u2018Are they going to beat these guys?\u2019 \u201d\n\nVirginia, down by 2 points, missed three shots in the final minute. Then Chaminade sealed the victory with three free throws. The postgame photograph on the court, taken after fans in the stands called the team out of the locker room for an encore, is on a wall that serves as a Hall of Fame at Chaminade. The 1982-83 team was inducted in 2013.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe victory spawned the Maui Invitational, an early-season tournament that attracts some of the top programs to Hawaii. Chaminade, now in Division II in the Pacific West Conference, plays and occasionally upsets one of them, despite having lost its element of surprise more than three decades ago.\n\n(\u201cDon\u2019t be the next Virginia,\u201d one can hear a coach telling his players. Turns out that, as of Friday night, Virginia might have become the next Virginia, with U.M.B.C. the next Chaminade.)\n\nThese days, Chaminade has 1,157 undergraduates. Seventy percent of them are from Hawaii, and 71 percent of the students are women, the school said. A movie deal about Chaminade\u2019s upset win over Virginia is in the works, said William Villa, the athletic director.\n\n\u201cThat hopefully will help to perpetuate the Chaminade legend to a whole new audience who weren\u2019t in this world in 1982,\u201d Villa said in an email on Saturday.\n\nHe added: \u201cWe\u2019re Chaminade on the rise \u2014 35 years later!\u201d\n\nBack in 1982-83, it was not Virginia\u2019s only upset loss to rock college basketball. North Carolina State beat Virginia in the final of their conference tournament, which got the Wolfpack into the N.C.A.A. tournament, where they beat Virginia again in a regional final. That set up North Carolina State\u2019s dramatic championship victory over Houston, another game that is mentioned in the debate over history\u2019s biggest upset.\n\nIt took Virginia 35 years \u2014 all the way to this February \u2014 to attain the No. 1 ranking again. It took U.M.B.C. a game to take it away, just as Chaminade did in 1982.\n\n\u201cIt seems like every year there\u2019s more and more people who were at that game,\u201d Randolph said. \u201cThere was only 3,000 that night, but now there\u2019s about 80,000.\u201d", "title": "A Little-Known University Stuns No. 1 Virginia? You Must Mean Chaminade", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "She received visitors in a vast library that was originally a monks\u2019 dormitory, filled with padlocked bookshelves dating to 1623.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe abbey was founded as a Benedictine monastery in 960 A.D., and housed a community of monks for more than 600 years. The first major church was built on the site in the mid-11th century; monarchs have been crowned there ever since.\n\nThe abbey is outside the jurisdiction of the Church of England and is responsible only to the monarch. With no state, church or royal funding, it is supported by entry fees (an adult ticket costs about $30, or \u00a322) and donations. Last year, the abbey attracted 1.3 million visitors and 300,000 worshipers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe museum will be accessible only through a Gothic-style tower being built outside the abbey. The entire cost of the museum project, about $31.6 million (\u00a322.9 million), has been raised through donations, including support from the American Fund for Westminster Abbey.\n\nWhen Dean Hall was appointed in 2006, the church archaeologist told him about the great unused space. Three years later, Dean Hall drew up a proposal for a museum, then spoke to the queen about setting it up and naming it to honor her 60th year on the British throne. She agreed.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen work started and floorboards were lifted, \u201cdust and detritus\u201d was found, Dean Hall said, including 30,000 fragments of stained glass from windows \u201cwhich had been blown in at different times,\u201d a church warden\u2019s 18th-century clay pipe, and coronation tickets from the 18th and 19th centuries that people \u201chad just torn up and thrown down.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlso retrieved from another corner of the abbey was a 14th-century monk\u2019s shoe, which will be part of the museum. \u201cIt looked a bit squashed,\u201d Ms. Jenkins said. \u201cIt\u2019s been conserved and humidified, and padded out so it looks shoelike.\u201d\n\nThe queen and her entourage are, naturally, present in the collections. In a huge portrait by the Australian painter Ralph Heimans, she stands on the spot of her coronation in the abbey, looking contemplative.\n\nQueen Victoria is commemorated with the footstool she used during her coronation at the age of 18. The five-hour ceremony had not been rehearsed, and it showed. The coronation ring was squeezed on the wrong finger, an aging peer tripped down the steps as he paid his respects, and Victoria was mistakenly told the ceremony was over when it wasn\u2019t. She left her seat, then returned to it.\n\n\u201cAfter that, there was a decision to rehearse in advance,\u201d Ms. Jenkins said. Starting in 1937, rehearsals used replicas of the crown jewels. Those replicas will be on view in the new galleries.\n\nFar more priceless treasures will also be displayed. They include the Westminster Retable, England\u2019s oldest altarpiece, dating to the 13th century; the Litlyngton Missal, a magnificent illuminated 14th-century service book with instructions on celebrating Mass throughout the year; and a series of effigies of deceased kings and queens: wood or wax sculptures that were made just before or just after their deaths, and placed on their coffins in funeral processions.\n\nWill the museum always be known as the Queen\u2019s Diamond Jubilee Galleries? The name \u201cvery well reflects the queen\u2019s close involvement with the abbey and her patronage, and the ongoing patronage of the House of Windsor,\u201d Ms. Jenkins said, but she added, \u201cIt might evolve over time.\u201d", "title": "A Lofty Perch Fit for a Royal Museum at Westminster Abbey", "authors": ["Farah Nayeri"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "TROY, N.Y. \u2014 Here in the birthplace of \u201cUncle Sam,\u201d a former steel town built by Irish and Italian arrivals, the local sheriff has embraced a federal program designed to catch undocumented immigrants in county jails.\n\nHis decision to do so \u2014 a first for New York State \u2014 in a jail that houses relatively few foreign-born inmates has outraged immigration activists, Democratic lawmakers and, notably, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose Albany statehouse office is in Troy\u2019s backyard.\n\nIn January, the Rensselaer County Sheriff\u2019s Office became one of only 75 in the country to sign an agreement allowing corrections officers to perform the functions of United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers, as part of a program known as 287(g). The number of jurisdictions taking part has more than doubled since President Trump promoted the program in an executive order in January 2017.\n\nThe elected sheriff, Patrick Russo, a Republican with 43 years in local law enforcement, has thus inserted his mostly rural county 150 miles north of New York City into the national immigration debate.", "title": "A Lone New York Sheriff Signs Up to Aid Immigration Crackdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "He returned to New York and enrolled in Queens College, earning a technical degree.\n\n\u201cThen he started having more mental health issues,\u201d Ms. Zwana said. Paranoia, talking to himself, extreme weight gain and loss \u2014 doctors diagnosed him with schizophrenia, and he was in and out of hospitals.\n\nIn April 1990, Mr. Germany was admitted to Elmhurst Hospital Center, and was later transferred to Mount Sinai Hospital. His condition was severe enough that he was placed in a locked psychiatric unit, and his sister said he was taking three medications for anxiety and bipolar disorder.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA month later, the hospital called his family. Mr. Germany had disappeared. He had been assigned to a locked wing, but he had somehow walked away.\n\nSix months passed without word. Then, in November 1990, Mr. Germany called his mother.\n\n\u201cHe called my home, but refused to give me his whereabouts or to come home,\u201d Ms. Davis wrote later in one of her letters to agencies.\n\nMs. Zwana remembers the call. \u201cShe begged him to tell her where he was, but he wouldn\u2019t,\u201d she said.\n\nThen, silence. Months stretched to years. Ms. Davis remained hopeful because she had experience with this kind of absence, Ms. Zwana explained. Her uncle once disappeared for 30 years, starting his own family in Ohio without telling anyone where he was.\n\nThe family wrote to the Department of Veterans Affairs without success. Ms. Davis wrote the state\u2019s Office of Mental Health and the city\u2019s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, keeping copies of all her correspondence in a file. She called Rikers Island to see if he was in jail. She requested searches of shelters. She and her daughter went to the police and were handed that book.\n\nYears after last hearing from Mr. Germany, mother and daughter made the rounds again, in 1997, requesting searches of hospitals, shelters and jails.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Feb. 23, 2014, the day before her 85th birthday, Ms. Davis died. She would never know the truth about her son: He had been located a full two years earlier.\n\nSpotty record-keeping and gaps between agencies that had had contact with Mr. Germany, each in possession of some of his story, kept the news of his discovery from his family.\n\nMr. Germany had been admitted to a Queens hospital in November 1990, within a day or so of his call to his mother. He had given her no indication that he was sick. But on Nov. 9, he died. The cause of death was recorded as hypertensive cardiovascular disease, according to a death certificate provided to his sister last month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Germany died without identification and remained unclaimed. His body made the same journey as more than a million other New Yorkers who died alone or without known names. On Jan. 8, 1991, he was buried by jail inmates in a mass grave on Hart Island, the potter\u2019s field for the city.\n\nThe police had Mr. Germany\u2019s fingerprints on file, but for years, there were no matches. That changed, in his case and in more than 100 others like it, in 2012 and 2013, when new technology led to the identification of bodies buried on Hart Island.\n\nIn these cases, the Office of Chief Medical Examiner routinely took custody of remains on Hart Island and sought to notify family members. In Mr. Germany\u2019s case, the office requested disinterment of his remains in 2013 and attempted to locate his relatives, said Dina Maniotis, the executive deputy commissioner for the medical examiner.\n\nFor reasons unknown, the attempts were unsuccessful, Ms. Maniotis said. It is unclear from the case file how Ms. Davis, who had never moved or changed telephone numbers, might have been overlooked.\n\nThe city\u2019s Department of Correction, which oversees Hart Island, disinterred Mr. Germany in August, four years after the medical examiner\u2019s office requested the action. Disinterments on the island are often difficult because of decomposition, and Mr. Germany\u2019s case was no exception. Attempts in 2013 and 2014 were unsuccessful, a spokeswoman for the correction department said.\n\nFive months later, in January, the office contacted a relative of Mr. Germany\u2019s, and was eventually referred to his sister, Ms. Zwana.\n\n\u201cWe thought it was a scam call,\u201d Ms. Zwana said. It was not. \u201cI talked to my family, my sisters,\u201d she said. In the shock of the news, they misunderstood what had happened and thought Mr. Germany\u2019s body had been stored in a morgue the entire 27 years. \u201cWe were all crying,\u201d she said \u201cWe couldn\u2019t believe it.\u201d\n\nThe family was also contacted by the city\u2019s Department of Veterans\u2019 Services, which helps families bury veterans. The department uses a network of volunteers to help plan ceremonies and burials for about 50 veterans a year who die alone and in poverty. Last year, that number rose to 80.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Germany\u2019s family learned that he is entitled to a proper ceremony and burial, not for having spent 27 years in an unmarked grave, but for his single month of service in the military. He is to be buried at Calverton National Cemetery on Long Island, with a military honor guard.\n\nIt can be seen as a story of a wrong made right, of the validation of a man\u2019s service and his elevation to his rightful place, but Ms. Zwana\u2019s thoughts return to who will not be in attendance.\n\n\u201cI think about my mother every day, and what she went through every day,\u201d she said. \u201cNever getting closure.\u201d", "title": "A Lost Son, a Mother\u2019s Search, and Too Late, the Truth", "authors": ["Michael Wilson"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "THE DANISH-NORWEGIAN WRITER Aksel Sandemose was a minor literary figure, a notorious crank, when he wrote the 1933 novel containing a set of commandments that would become one of Scandinavia\u2019s defining social texts. \u201cA Fugitive Crosses His Tracks\u201d is a barely veiled send-up of his hometown, Nykobing Mors (renamed Jante) and an uncomfortably close-to-the-bone satire of Nordic conformity. Jante is governed by the \u201cLaw of Jante,\u201d rules for living that reflect both Scandinavia\u2019s ethnic homogeneity and its long-held belief that people are happier when both pleasure and pain are spread among all citizens:\n\nYou shall not believe that you are someone.\n\nYou shall not believe that you are as good as we are.\n\nYou shall not believe that you are any wiser than we are.\n\nYou shall never indulge in the conceit of imagining that you are better than we are.\n\nYou shall not believe that you know more than we do.\n\nYou shall not believe that you are more important than we are.\n\nYou shall not believe that you are going to amount to anything.\n\nYou shall not laugh at us.\n\nYou shall not believe that anyone cares about you.\n\nYou shall not believe that you can teach us anything.\n\nThese days, Scandinavians bristle at the mention of the Law of Jante. Such stereotypes, they insist, no longer have such a stronghold in a modern world, one where Stockholm now leads in billion-dollar technology companies per capita, second only to Silicon Valley.\n\nYet it is hard not to think of Sandemose as you drive along the winter-deserted roads of Gotland, Sweden\u2019s largest island, a 40-minute flight south from Stockholm. About the size of Long Island and flat as a soccer field, it is the country\u2019s sunniest locale. (Admittedly, that doesn\u2019t say much in a place that spends most of the year in frigid darkness.) And along with Faro, its companion island off its northern tip, it is forever associated with the director Ingmar Bergman, who set many of his greatest films here and lived in Faro for the last decades of his life. In July and early August, Gotland is a tourist mecca; young professionals, starved for heat and light, party in the beer gardens of Visby, a port town of 24,300. An hour or two away, up and down the coasts, are the summer houses of the country\u2019s politicians and business executives, fronting beaches dotted with rauks \u2014 gigantic, craggy sculptural formations unique to the area, as ghostly as something from Stonehenge, created by ice-age reef erosions. Scarlet poppies and brilliant blue viper\u2019s bugloss carpet the meadows and line the roadside ditches.", "title": "A Low-Key Swedish Island\u2019s Shockingly Modern Architecture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Either way, the first vice president, Mart\u00edn Vizcarra, 55, is expected to take power.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m indignant with the current situation, like the majority of Peruvians, but I\u2019m convinced that together we will show once again that we can move forward,\u201d Mr. Vizcarra wrote on Twitter.\n\nMr. Vizcarra served one term as governor of his home region of Moquegua in southern Peru, which includes parts of the desert coast and the Andes, but did not seek re-election. Instead, two years later, he joined Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s ticket, as his first vice president. During the campaign, Mr. Kuczynski called Mr. Vizcarra one of his two \u201cinsurance policies\u201d in case he died in office.\n\nHe was also a part of Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s first cabinet, becoming minister of transportation and communications, but was forced to resign after opposition lawmakers questioned his plans for a planned airport in Cusco, Peru\u2019s most important tourist destination. After his resignation, he was appointed ambassador to Canada.\n\nEven as Mr. Vizcarra was being summoned home from Ottawa, the scandal over Mr. Kuczynski continued to shake Peru. On Thursday, a Peruvian judge said he would consider a request to bar Mr. Kuczynski from leaving the country if the opposition-controlled Congress decided to accept the resignation, which would end his presidential immunity and make him vulnerable to prosecution.\n\nPeru has a long history of presidents entangled in corruption scandals.\n\nAlberto K. Fujimori diverted tens of millions in government funds in the 1990s to buy politicians and journalists, and until recently was imprisoned in Peru; Alejandro Toledo, was accused of receiving a $20 million bribe in the early 2000s from the construction giant Odebrecht; and Ollanta Humala and his wife were placed in pretrial detention over allegations of laundering $3 million in Odebrecht funds to support his 2011 presidential campaign.", "title": "A Low-Profile Engineer Is Set to Take Power in Peru", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump kept a relatively low profile and did not make any public appearances on Tuesday, but emerged for a rare evening trip outside the White House to meet with deep-pocketed donors at a real estate developer\u2019s home in Virginia.\n\nMr. Trump, who usually prefers a steak served at his own hotel if he leaves the confines of the White House at night, traveled to the McLean, Va., home of Giuseppe Cecchi, according to a person with knowledge of the president\u2019s plans. Mr. Cecchi is a loyalist who previously hosted Mr. Trump for a $10,000-a-couple fund-raising dinner in the final weeks of the 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nSince arriving back in Washington on Sunday from his Florida estate, Mr. Trump\u2019s schedule showed no public appearances and he kept his usual tweeting to a minimum.\n\nHe has opted instead to leave it to his aides to field questions about a continuing investigation into his campaign\u2019s contact with Russia, allegations by a pornographic actress that his lawyer paid her to stay silent about an affair, a move to expel 60 Russian diplomats and his administration\u2019s support for adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census.", "title": "A Low-Profile Trump Travels to Virginia to Meet With Donors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Within a year of putting its initial offerings on the market in December 2015, Forest City had sold 80 percent of all units on the first island. The project is a relatively cheap alternative to property havens in North America, Australia and China itself. A luxury two-bedroom apartment costs only $180,000 in Forest City, about a third of what it would command in Shanghai. Still, the sheer volume in sales means that Forest City raked in more than $3 billion in 2016 alone, according to the company. Much of this money was Chinese flight capital, but Country Garden has tried to make buying into Forest City seem almost patriotic. One Olympic-themed show unit features the gold-medal shooters Du Li and Pang Wei, who have invested here, too. (A sign proclaims in Chinese: \u201cWelcome home, Olympic champions!\u201d) Throughout the sales tour, potential buyers are reminded that Forest City sits in a strategic geographical position for China \u2014 astride a vital maritime route that connects their homeland with the rest of the world.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut after a banner year in 2016, Forest City encountered significant setbacks in 2017 \u2014 revealing some of the fault lines created by the phenomenal growth of Chinese wealth. The uncomfortable fact that hundreds of thousands of Chinese may soon be residents of Malaysia led a former prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, to lash out at the project last year. \u201cWe should realize that once we sell land to others, we no longer have any ownership over it,\u201d he said. The sultan of Johor accused Mahathir of \u201cplaying the politics of fear and race\u201d ahead of nationwide elections in which the former prime minister is running. But Mahathir, 92, railed on. He even compared the situation to the sultanate\u2019s sale of the neighboring island of Temasek to the British nearly two centuries ago. That island is now the wealthy city-state Singapore.\n\nGeopolitics only added to the controversy. Forest City sits just a few miles off the Straits of Malacca, an indispensable channel for commerce ever since the beginning of the global spice trade in the 16th century. Today the straits are China\u2019s Achilles\u2019 heel, a vulnerable choke point through which 80 percent of its oil imports flow. China is building pipelines, ports and railways in Pakistan and Myanmar to relieve its dependence on this waterway. It is also lavishing Malaysia with large investments, like a $7.2 billion port complex in Malacca, to secure its position along the straits. Forest City is not a government infrastructure project, but it is a largely autonomous Chinese outpost in a strategic location. \u201cWhere else in the world has a foreign company created new land in another country, populated it with people from its home country and asserted sovereignty over it?\u201d Moser asks. \u201cThis is a brand-new level of colonial expansion.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd yet the greatest blow to Forest City last year was struck by the Chinese government, through a set of new restrictions that underscore the tension inherent in Beijing\u2019s economic vision, in which it encourages companies to \u201cgo global\u201d yet fears the exodus of its citizens\u2019 new wealth. Over the last decade, China has seen an estimated $3.8 trillion in capital leave the country, much of it going into offshore real estate. In an effort to crack down on rampant capital flight, Beijing tightened its capital controls, making it nearly impossible for investors to send large amounts of money out of the country. The limit on foreign transfers remains $50,000 a year per person, but now senders must sign a pledge that no money will be used to buy property \u2014 and face investigation if they violate the pledge. The tougher controls have strengthened China\u2019s currency and stabilized its foreign reserves, but many Chinese investors, including some Forest City customers, were left stranded: They had made down payments on their tropical idylls, but banks wouldn\u2019t let them send the rest.\n\nSoon after the restrictions were put in place, Country Garden shuttered its Forest City sales offices in China \u2014 \u201cfor renovation,\u201d a notice said \u2014 and scrambled to find new customers in Dubai, Japan, Thailand and beyond. Yu Runze, the president of Country Garden Pacificview, the joint venture that runs Forest City, told Today, a Singapore newspaper, last year that capital controls gave them \u201can opportunity to shift our sales strategy to be more international.\u201d Forest City hasn\u2019t revealed its 2017 sales figures, so it\u2019s hard to tell just how much its business has suffered.\n\nStill, on a recent Saturday, a few hundred visitors \u2014 almost all of them Mandarin speakers \u2014 circulated through the sales gallery. They gaped at the sleek scale model with \u201csold out\u201d towers, tested a facial-recognition camera and ate dumplings at one of the Chinese restaurants. No transactions seemed to be taking place, but outside, the flock of construction cranes kept moving and Forest City continued to rise. \u201cThere are so many permutations on how this project can move ahead that it\u2019s unwise to write it off prematurely,\u201d Yu said. \u201cNever underestimate the resolve of a new China.\u201d /\u2022/", "title": "A Malaysian Insta-City Becomes a Flash Point for Chinese Colonialism \u2014 and Capital Flight", "authors": ["Brook Larmer", "On Money"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. McConnell\u2019s cautious handling of what some fear could become a crisis was no accident; he rarely criticizes the president in public and sees little upside to doing so. But critics \u2014 some in his own party \u2014 say that by not issuing a more direct warning, Mr. McConnell is undermining Congress\u2019s standing as a coequal branch of government \u2014 and inviting Mr. Trump to act on his impulses.\n\nIt is time, they say, for the majority leader to lead.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that we ought to do is be more forceful \u2014 everybody, especially the leadership,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona, who took to Twitter on Tuesday to beg the president not to fire the special counsel and warn that doing so could lead to impeachment. (Mr. Graham issued a similar warning during an interview with the radio host Hugh Hewitt.)\n\nRepublican leaders including Mr. McConnell, Mr. Flake said, should \u201cstand up and forcefully say, \u2018This will not stand.\u2019\u201d\n\nConfrontation is not Mr. McConnell\u2019s style. He is a shrewd politician and a parliamentary tactician who much prefers operating behind the scenes. Complicating matters, his wife, Elaine L. Chao, is the secretary of transportation, in Mr. Trump\u2019s cabinet.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s always viewed his role as more of a legislative craftsman than a moral leader,\u201d said William Kristol, the founding editor of the conservative magazine The Weekly Standard. He sees Mr. McConnell \u2014 and many other Republicans \u2014 as making a purely political calculation in their silence.\n\n\u201cThe Republican primary electorate is pro-Trump, a good chunk of it,\u201d Mr. Kristol said. \u201cWhy pick a fight with them? Why get in the middle of anything?\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s weekend Twitter posts, driven by the ever-widening scope of the Mueller investigation into Russia\u2019s election interference, was the first time he had criticized the special counsel by name, not counting a message he reshared. The president has long insisted that neither he nor his campaign colluded with Russia. He calls the investigation a \u201cwitch hunt.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn fact, Mr. Trump ordered the firing of Mr. Mueller in June, but backed off after the White House counsel threatened to resign rather than carry out the directive.\n\nSuch threats have inspired two bipartisan bills that would add job protections for Mr. Mueller and future special counsels. Both would empower a panel of federal judges to review the case for firing the special counsel and render a judgment about whether there was good cause to do so. Both are stalled in committee.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome lawmakers have questioned whether such legislation would be constitutional, and Mr. McConnell has said repeatedly that additional protections for Mr. Mueller are not necessary.\n\n\u201cI think he will have great credibility with the American people when he reaches a conclusion of this investigation,\u201d Mr. McConnell said of Mr. Mueller on Tuesday.\n\nFor Peter Wehner, who advised President George W. Bush on domestic policy, that is not good enough.\n\nMr. McConnell and other Republican leaders must \u201cmake it clear to Trump and the White House that if he fires Mueller, that is crossing a red line, and there will be consequences,\u201d Mr. Wehner said. One idea: Warn the president that Congress will hire Mr. Mueller to continue his inquiry if Mr. Trump fires him.\n\n\u201cI understand that this is not McConnell\u2019s thing to speak out and challenge people publicly, and maybe he is being extremely effective privately \u2014 and if he is, more power to him,\u201d Mr. Wehner said. \u201cBut on the other hand, what\u2019s said publicly matters, too. And at some point, if what Trump says and does is met with silence, it implies complicity for the party.\u201d\n\nMr. McConnell learned the dangers of criticizing Mr. Trump in August, when he was asked in Kentucky about the Senate\u2019s struggle to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Defending the chamber\u2019s work, Mr. McConnell offered an offhand assessment of how the president appeared to be learning on the job, saying Mr. Trump \u201chad excessive expectations about how quickly things happen in the democratic process.\u201d\n\nIt was hardly inflammatory, but the comment infuriated Mr. Trump, who responded with a Twitter tirade against the leader that lasted six weeks. The two did not speak for a long stretch during that period, and their relationship deteriorated to the point where Mr. McConnell privately expressed doubts that Mr. Trump could salvage his presidency.\n\nIn October, as suddenly as it began, Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter attack ended. In an orchestrated show of togetherness, he brought Mr. McConnell into the Rose Garden to declare that the two were \u201ccloser than ever before.\u201d One person close to Mr. McConnell says he does not want a repeat of what followed the \u201cexcessive expectations\u201d remark.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat caused him six weeks of unrelenting pain of Trump whacking him,\u201d that person said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss Mr. McConnell\u2019s thinking. \u201cI think at that moment, McConnell learned a lesson: There\u2019s nothing to be gained by commenting on his comments because it doesn\u2019t change his behavior.\u201d\n\nMr. McConnell has always been a man of few words, and one who chooses his words carefully. Unlike other senators who linger in the Capitol corridors to talk with reporters, he shuns hallway interviews and rarely takes more than a few questions at his Tuesday briefings. His reticence is integral to his leadership style.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s one of the reasons why he\u2019s a pretty effective leader \u2014 it\u2019s because he economizes words,\u201d said Josh Holmes, a former chief of staff for Mr. McConnell who remains close to him. \u201cWhen he speaks, it generally means something.\u201d\n\nMr. McConnell also makes it a point not to speak out on an issue unless his position has changed. He said in November, and then again in January, that he saw no need for legislation to protect the special counsel; when asked about Mr. Trump\u2019s tweets over the weekend, his advisers simply cited those statements.\n\nAnd the leader routinely advises his conference that it is more effective to deal with concerns internally than debate them through the news media.\n\n\u201cIf he\u2019s got a problem,\u201d Mr. Holmes said, \u201che probably communicates it directly and doesn\u2019t feel the need to pontificate in public.\u201d", "title": "A Man of Few Words, McConnell Tiptoes Around the Issue of Mueller", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "If they gave out Tonys for Broadway\u2019s longest opening night, it would have to go to the new revival of Tony Kushner\u2019s \u201cAngels in America,\u201d which had its debut on Sunday.\n\nPresented in two parts with a running time of more than seven hours, not including four intermissions, a V.I.P. dinner at Orso and an after-party, the day began at noon and was still going at midnight.\n\nCould Jordan Roth, the play\u2019s producer, recall another show where he\u2019d conceived of asking for such a big chunk of time from such a plutocratic and perpetually impatient crowd?\n\n\u201cNever,\u201d he said, sometime around 4 p.m., just as Part 1, \u201cMillennium Approaches,\u201d ended.\n\nThe surprise was that theatergoers like Frances McDormand, who had RSVPed only to Part 1, were now asking for seats for Part 2, \u201cPerestroika.\u201d (Luckily, Mr. Roth found her a seat.)", "title": "A Marathon Opening Day (and Night) for \u2018Angels in America\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music\n\nBook Review A Marine\u2019s Inventive Memoir Matt Young discusses \u201cEat the Apple,\u201d and A. O. Scott talks about Martin Amis\u2019s \u201cThe Rub of Time.\u201d Audio\n\nIn The New York Times Book Review, Mark Bowden reviews Matt Young\u2019s \u201cEat the Apple.\u201d Bowden writes:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe trouble with writing the unvarnished truth in a memoir is that it requires you to be hard not only on others, but also on yourself. Matt Young\u2019s inventive, unsparing, irreverent and consistently entertaining \u201cEat the Apple\u201d is that, but it is also a useful corrective to the current idealization of the American soldier \u2014 or in this case a Marine. Patriotism and respect for the military is so high in this country that we have lately held a national debate over whether professional athletes should be required to stand for the national anthem. Men and women in uniform are given preference in boarding airplanes, and are so routinely thanked for their service that the expression has become rote. Each new season brings a crop of movies and glossy TV serials dramatizing the heroics of our Special Operations. Young sees hollowness and potential harm in this.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Young discusses \u201cEat the Apple\u201d; A. O. Scott talks about Martin Amis\u2019s \u201cThe Rub of Time\u201d; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; and The Times\u2019s staff book critics, Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai, talk about books they\u2019ve recently reviewed. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.\n\n1. Open your podcast app. It\u2019s a pre-loaded app called \u201cPodcasts\u201d with a purple icon.\n\n2. Search for the series.
