You may want to adjust your notifications to be alerted when a new episode arrives.", "title": "A Marine\u2019s Inventive Memoir", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "After Ms. Vargas graduated in May 2009 with a degree in political science, the couple rented an apartment together, but struggled with cultural clashes and communication.\n\nMr. Cheng liked to show his affection by giving Ms. Vargas gifts, or regaling her with an appropriate song. He also nurtured her with food and medicine when she was sick. But he didn\u2019t plan birthdays, anniversaries or Valentine\u2019s Day. \u201cI always write a letter on birthdays,\u201d she said, \u201cand holidays are important so this became an issue.\u201d\n\nMs. Vargas also got jealous when Mr. Cheng, then a busy associate producer at WSVN-TV in Miami, hung out with a close buddy. She preferred that he spend quality time with her by going to dinner and talking. She also liked having him accompany her to places like the grocery store. Mr. Cheng wanted alone time to chill and play his guitar.\n\n\u201cI have a big social personality and need to be away from people to recharge because I get anxious and depressed,\u201d Mr. Cheng said. \u201cRahysa is an adventurer and always wanted to go places.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring one Christmas season when she asked him to help distribute toys at a homeless shelter, he declined, thinking her social interests were honorable but not as important as his television work. \u201cI was super-selfish, and everything was about me,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey are both strong personalities, leaders, opinionated and outspoken,\u201d said her brother, Steven Vargas. Her mother, Constanza Gomez, agreed: \u201cThey are highly dramatic with similar personalities. Each can be sitting in a different room thinking about the same things.\u201d\n\nMs. Vargas became unhappy after Mr. Cheng was overly argumentative. \u201cI didn\u2019t mean it but I was hurting,\u201d he said.\n\nThe couple split in mid-2010, partly because Ms. Vargas was eager to begin law school and Mr. Cheng was focused on becoming a broadcast reporter. \u201cAlthough Chris was the love of my life, and I worried he would meet someone else, I had to let him go,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, while dating others, they kept in touch by sharing the grief of his uncle\u2019s death, divorcing parents, illness and other mercurial moments. In 2013, when Mr. Cheng returned to Miami for a job in marketing after a year in news at a Texas television station, they repeatedly ran into each other.\n\nHe said he was battling depression and anxiety, and wasn\u2019t fulfilled by his career. \u201cEven though I wanted to marry Rahysa and have a family,\u201d Mr. Cheng said, \u201cshe would soon be practicing law and knew I was a storm coming back and couldn\u2019t promise her a stable life.\u201d\n\nThe next two years involved soul-searching for Mr. Cheng. He sought professional help in hopes of finding stability so he could have one more shot with the love of his life. \u201cShe was my moral compass, a together person who liked me more than I liked myself,\u201d he said. \u201cShe made me a better human being.\u201d\n\nIn 2015, when Mr. Cheng randomly spotted Ms. Vargas\u2019s mother in a local lounge and told her that he was desperately in love, she encouraged him to try again. After many conversations, the couple reunited and slowly learned to communicate more and fight less. \u201cWe began to accept each other\u2019s flaws and compromise,\u201d Ms. Vargas said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWithin a year, they bought a house together in Miami, and agreed to take a vacation in Thailand and China. On Nov. 26, 2016, during a layover in Paris that Ms. Vargas planned to relieve Mr. Cheng\u2019s anxiety about long flights, he escorted her to the top of the Eiffel Tower, dropped to one knee and surprised her with a proposal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFinally!\u201d she blurted out, followed by \u201cYes!\u201d\n\nWedding plans were temporarily disrupted last September when Hurricane Irma destroyed their new home, flooding it with 2\u00bd feet of sewage and seawater and forcing them to move five times in four months while commissioning a total rebuild.\n\nThey leaned on each other constantly. When one was weak, the other was strong. Mr. Cheng had left his marketing job earlier that year, then Ms. Vargas quit hers to concentrate on Ms. Esquire.\n\n\u201cWe spoke life into each other, and our church worship helped us endure this stressful time with unusual peace and calm,\u201d Mr. Cheng said.", "title": "A Match That\u2019s Perfectly Imperfect", "authors": ["Linda Marx"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "MY FATHER\u2019S WAKE\n\nHow the Irish Teach Us How to Live, Love and Die\n\nBy Kevin Toolis\n\n275 pp. Da Capo. $26.\n\nIn his 2015 book \u201cThe Work of the Dead,\u201d Thomas W. Laqueur takes up an ancient question: Why do we care for the bodies of the dead when we know that after our loved ones have left them they are empty shells? He begins his query with Diogenes, the eccentric fourth century B.C. philosopher who requested that his dead body be thrown over the city walls to be devoured by beasts. The corpse may be waste, \u201cmeat gone mad,\u201d James Joyce wrote in \u201cUlysses,\u201d but since our beginnings we have endowed corpses with cultural and symbolic significance. \u201cWhatever our religious beliefs, or lack of belief, we share the very deep human desire to live with our ancestors and with their bodies. We mobilize their power,\u201d Laqueur wrote.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe journalist Kevin Toolis does not doubt that corpses have particular superpowers. In his new book, \u201cMy Father\u2019s Wake,\u201d the bodies of our dead are life lessons, moral instructors of how to have satisfying lives and peaceful deaths. The tradition of the Irish wake, with rituals that predate Christianity, is our legend, \u201cthe best guide to life you could ever have,\u201d he writes.\n\n\u201cMy Father\u2019s Wake\u201d is at heart a memoir, chronicling a childhood spent between Edinburgh and remote Achill Island off the western coast of Ireland\u2019s County Mayo, where his parents were born. When Toolis is 19, his brother Bernard dies of leukemia. He is his brother\u2019s keeper, a bone marrow donor, but the transplant fails. The trauma sends Toolis as a young reporter out into the world, from Somalia to Afghanistan, in search of death, disease, famine and war. \u201cI was grieving,\u201d Toolis writes. \u201cNot for my dead brother but for the young man who died with him and lost his mortal innocence. Me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe contrast between young Bernard\u2019s death (in the city, in the care of what Toolis calls the \u201cWestern Death Machine\u201d) and his father Sonny\u2019s death (at home in old age on Achill) sets up Toolis\u2019s castigation of modern medicine and death rites. But it is Toolis\u2019s fine skill at showing the means and aftermath of death rather than his prescription for how to improve dying that most animates \u201cMy Father\u2019s Wake.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cUnder the greenish light of a fluorescent tube, Eliza\u2019s hands writhed involuntarily at her wrist as if seeking to escape their dying host,\u201d he writes of a 20-year-old Malawian girl who dies in the middle of the night of AIDS. In the local dialect, Toolis tells us, the disease is known as matantanda athu omwewa, \u201cthis thing we all have in common.\u201d Toolis\u2019s writing is so visceral and profound when he is near dying bodies that the lessons of such experiences become evident \u2014 so evident, indeed, that the unfortunate framing of \u201cMy Father\u2019s Wake\u201d as a how-to for urban Westerners feels a bit clumsy and redundant.", "title": "A Matter of Life and Death", "authors": ["Ann Neumann"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t supposed to be like this. When a reader sends a tip to The Times, we investigate it, and normally one of two things happens: It becomes a story, or it doesn\u2019t pan out. What\u2019s unusual is when the course of investigating a tip leads a journalist to debunk it, and that becomes the story.\n\nIn my 30 years writing about science and medicine for The Times, it had never happened to me \u2014 until now. And although I wavered for a while about whether to go ahead with the reporting, it ended up as an article about doctors\u2019 hesitations to use tissue plasminogen activator (T.P.A.), a drug for people experiencing a stroke.\n\nIt started with a tip in February from a Canadian emergency medicine doctor, who said in an email that T.P.A., a widely promoted drug, was not only useless but dangerous \u2014 it could cause bleeding in the brain. Yet the drug was advocated by medical societies and continued to be used, he said, because there were powerful corporate interests influencing practice guidelines and encouraging doctors to believe the drug worked.", "title": "A Medical Tip\u2019s Unexpected Outcome", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou might not have thought about it beforehand, in the same way you don\u2019t ask where the nearest firehouse or police station is,\u201d said Nancy Packes, a consultant to residential developers, including some who build in Hudson Yards, but who isn\u2019t involved with any of the Related projects. Renters and buyers will likely \u201ccome to look at it as added benefit,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Mount Sinai clinic, scheduled to open next winter, is not a full-fledged hospital: It will not have a traditional emergency room and will not have any beds for overnight stays.\n\nBut the light-filled space will have exam rooms and will offer consultation spaces. In that way, it will resemble small-scale facilities that Mount Sinai currently operates in neighborhoods throughout New York City.\n\nResidents of buildings like 15 Hudson Yards, a Related condominium that has sold about 50 percent of its 285 market-rate units in 18 months, as well as tenants in office towers like 10 Hudson Yards, home to Coach and other companies, will be able to visit the clinic for checkups or emergencies that are not life-threatening. For those that are, patients would likely have to leave the neighborhood and head to Mount Sinai West, a full-service hospital with a proper emergency room, at Tenth Avenue and West 58th Street.\n\nWhile reduced-service clinics might not be new, Mount Sinai does seem to be trying to create an unusual level of access to medical staff at the facility. Members will be able to call doctors on their cellphones at night and on weekends, said Dr. Evan Flatow, president of Mount Sinai West. And in an expansion of existing programs, Mount Sinai will offer house calls at Hudson Yards, dispatching doctors to offices and apartments as needs arise, Dr. Flatow said.", "title": "A Members-Only Medical Center for Hudson Yards Locals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Nowhere in the city has better food courts than Flushing, Queens. From the dingy, labyrinthine basement of the Golden Shopping Mall, with its anarchy of scents, to the vast gallery of stalls at the New World Mall, sleek and seemingly infinite, they are justly beloved as scenes of equal parts chaos and serendipity.\n\nThe newly renovated food hall at Queens Crossing, a mixed-use development completed in 2007, is smaller and quieter. The dining area was designed to evoke an abstract forest, with a chandelier of birches and grass panels on the walls, sprouting puns like \u201cYou make miso happy.\u201d\n\nThe vendors \u2014 offering the likes of Hawaiian poke and Japanese curry \u2014 were chosen to present an alternative to the food already available in the neighborhood. Most will be familiar to anyone who has seen the food court boom in Manhattan.\n\nBut Ok Lah! is a surprise. (The name is a nod to the ubiquity of the syllable \u201clah\u201d in Singapore and Malaysia, where it\u2019s appended to sentences as a form of tonal modulation.)", "title": "A Menu That Defies Tidy Categorization at Ok Lah!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "It continued that way until 2006. Both were at the Empire State Pride Agenda dinner, when Rabbi Kleinbaum asked Ms. Weingarten to speak at the Gay Pride Shabbat service.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d just turned 50, I\u2019d never publicly come out and said, \u2018I\u2019m a lesbian,\u2019\u201d Ms. Weingarten said. \u201cSharon allowed me to see myself as who I was. It shifted my thinking that it wasn\u2019t simply about having a gay pride speaker. It was about shifting me. I was very moved by it.\u201d\n\nRabbi Kleinbaum recalls the \u201cask\u201d a little differently.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s one of the most significant labor leaders in America,\u201d Rabbi Kleinbaum said. \u201cI didn\u2019t get how dramatic it would be for her. I just thought it would be an amazing coup if she said yes.\u201d\n\nYears went by. They continued to see into each other sporadically until 2012. While Ms. Weingarten was working in Washington and dating, Rabbi Kleinbaum was in New York getting divorced after an 18-year relationship.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d heard Sharon was single, so I emailed her asking if she wanted to have lunch,\u201d Ms. Weingarten said.\n\nRabbi Kleinbaum wrote back the following day. But it was not an easy time in her life.\n\n\u201cMy whole world was falling apart,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was such a difficult time for me. I was carrying the load of a full-time position. I had two daughters. I wasn\u2019t thinking about anyone in that way.\u201d\n\nEight or nine email exchanges later, lunch got parlayed into dinner and a friendly request grew into an actual date.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFlirt entered into the emails,\u201d Ms. Weingarten said. \u201cI was really excited about it. But I almost screwed the whole thing up. I got invited to the state dinner by President Obama for David Cameron.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was a plus-one invitation. \u201cI asked Sharon if she would be willing to have our date at the White House rather than in New York,\u201d Ms. Weingarten said.\n\nRabbi Kleinbaum immediately declined.\n\n\u201cI would never go to the state dinner as a first date,\u201d Rabbi Kleinbaum said. \u201cI\u2019m interested in intimacy. Everyone would think we were on a date. I started wondering if I was ready for that. I wasn\u2019t even sure I wanted to be in a relationship again. I wanted to take things slow.\u201d\n\nSo they did. Ms. Weingarten attended the dinner with a colleague. The next day she and Rabbi Kleinbaum went for Indian food in the West Village. They talked all night.\n\n\u201cThere was no political-speak,\u201d Ms. Weingarten said. \u201cWe talked about our lives and things that were important to us. It was a fantastic first date. I didn\u2019t want the night to end.\u201d\n\nThat same year, Rabbi Kleinbaum moved into an apartment in the Inwood section of Manhattan. Ms. Weingarten commuted back and forth from Washington, spending two nights there, two nights in New York and other days traveling for work.\n\n\u201cMy life had been turned upside down,\u201d Rabbi Kleinbaum said. \u201cHere I was in my 50s with my dogs, and all I had was a mattress on the floor. But Randi never seemed uncomfortable. I thought, this is an incredibly kind person. I value kindness. Slowly I got furniture.\u201d\n\nAs her apartment grew, so did their relationship.\n\nIn 2014, they began looking for an apartment together. Three years later they found one. Their proposal and engagement almost took as long. When Obergefell v. Hodges was decided in 2015, an excited Ms. Weingarten asked if the decision meant they could get married. Rabbi Kleinbaum wanted to wait.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not spring chickens,\u201d Rabbi Kleinbaum said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t believe we would get this kind of love this late in our lives.\u201d\n\nIn June 2017, they both agreed it was time.\n\n\u201cWe have a deepening relationship,\u201d Rabbi Kleinbaum said. \u201cWe\u2019re both astounded we found each other and both astounded we\u2019re making it work. If you live long enough, life is full of surprises.\u201d", "title": "A Merger for the Rabbi and the Labor Leader", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Even though Jurek doesn\u2019t do much, there\u2019s something about the way he blows out a cloud of moist breath and then writes \u201cJoona\u201d on a steamy surface that hints at vengefulness. Sure enough, he holds a grudge. Thirteen years earlier, Joona interfered with the Sandman scheme, which had Jurek spiriting away the wives and children of his enemies. They never came back, and if all went well, their husbands or fathers would be driven to suicide.\n\nPhoto\n\nThese are the memories that warm Jurek\u2019s heart on lonely days. But \u201cThe Sandman\u201d disrupts his peace of mind by allowing one of the kidnapped children to reappear suddenly after years of apparent captivity. The boy\u2019s father, who has descended into Champagne-soaked decadence, suddenly becomes the most doting of parents and hopes Joona can find his missing daughter too.\n\nThe boy\u2019s story is suitably eerie. He was locked up and blindfolded, and he can\u2019t remember much. This fits in with the M.O. of Jurek, whose crime spree ended when he was caught having imprisoned a woman in a coffin for two years, which he found much more satisfying than killing her. You will probably wind up on the fence about whether you needed to know more about him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut is Jurek the Sandman? The latter was a creature right out of children\u2019s fables. He tossed sand at them, clicked porcelain fingers, forced them into a sleep from which they couldn\u2019t awaken. The boy who finally comes home in this novel is certain of those things. And he hasn\u2019t gotten over his fear of them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA prominent, hugely suspenseful part of the book involves embedding Saga Bauer, a brave, smart, beautiful cop whose role many actresses would covet, in the same tiny ward where Jurek is housed. She is to risk her life in hopes of finding out what he\u2019s thinking. \u201cYou\u2019re like a sister to me, Saga, but it would be better if you died than if he got out,\u201d Joona tells her, and the frankness of that somehow makes the detective more lovable than cruel. He himself has already made huge sacrifices to this case, as we find out. He\u2019s being an honest cop by telling Saga the truth, and she doesn\u2019t flinch at it. She\u2019s his peer when it comes to meeting this challenge.\n\nBy this point the book\u2019s greatest tension comes from wondering whether either Joona or Saga is any match for this near-supernatural monster, who can implant thoughts in his victims\u2019 heads or turn up as an apparition just staring into their windows. Scared yet? You will be.\n\nKnopf has taken the trouble of having some of the other books retranslated into English for their rerelease. So Neil Smith, who gives \u201cThe Sandman\u201d its tight, brisk tone, has redone Ann Hall\u2019s more expansive version of \u201cThe Hypnotist.\u201d I\u2019m not sure it\u2019s worth it. Hall\u2019s version of \u201cThe Hypnotist\u201d rambles on, but it has more color, and this series can use it. Joona Linna is a character that you want to know as much about as you can.", "title": "A Monster in the Mold of Hannibal Lecter Haunts \u2018The Sandman\u2019", "authors": ["Janet Maslin", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBRASS\n\nBy Xhenet Aliu\n\n295 pp. Random House. $27.\n\nPicture a place called Waterbury, Conn., and you might, as I did, imagine rows of Victorian houses with wide porches, driveways lined with expensive cars, beloved daughters with bright and easy futures. But Xhenet Aliu\u2019s perceptive debut novel, \u201cBrass,\u201d offers a reminder that assumptions \u2014 whether about a place, or a person as close to you as your mother \u2014 never tell the full story.\n\nIn Aliu\u2019s Waterbury, daughters aren\u2019t exactly wanted. Instead of Victorians, there are triple-deckers, their porches lined with railings that flex against a body\u2019s weight. Meals are sometimes labeled \u201cGRADE D BUT EDIBLE.\u201d The brass factories that had once made the town attractive to waves of Eastern European immigrants have long been closed, though the grandchildren of those hopeful workers remain, largely trapped in dead-end jobs. Aliu\u2019s characters, most of whom have seen little of the world outside of Waterbury, understand at a visceral level that to live costs money; everything in this novel \u2014 the rubber soles on sneakers, bread from the Hostess outlet, an ultrasound \u2014 is quantified. One narrative thread is uneasily resolved when a character upgrades from an air mattress to a bed. For Elsie and Lulu, the mother and daughter at the center of the book, the most valuable thing in Waterbury is a ticket out.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBrass\u201d is their duet, and Elsie sings the opening note. She is the young granddaughter of Lithuanian immigrants, a waitress, with a doomed crush on Bashkim, an Albanian line cook with secrets back home. In an abrupt second chapter shift, their 17-year-old daughter Luljeta takes over, narrating in a second person that feels appropriate for a girl in the middle of crisis. Lulu, a soft-spoken, Honor Roll student, has just been rejected by N.Y.U. and suspended for fighting, all in the course of a single day. The plot advances through each woman\u2019s story; as the symmetries between them pile up, along with misunderstandings, the novel accumulates momentum and emotional power. In Elsie\u2019s storyline, we\u2019re reading for Lulu\u2019s arrival; meanwhile, in the narrative present, Lulu is rejecting her mother to pursue the mystery of the father who left her behind.\n\nAfter Lulu\u2019s suspension, Elsie, switching to the third person, accuses her daughter of not acting like herself: \u201cDon\u2019t try to tell me. I\u2019m her mother. You think I don\u2019t know Luljeta?\u201d It\u2019s one of many funny exchanges in \u201cBrass\u201d \u2014 what daughter hasn\u2019t heard her mother say such a thing \u2014 but it\u2019s also a deft illustration of the way both women are hemmed in by the other\u2019s long-held assumptions. \u201cAnd then it\u2019s infuriating, your mother\u2019s need for you,\u201d Lulu says, later. \u201cIt\u2019s not fair that you should serve as her primary motivation for getting out of bed in the morning, especially considering that you have no idea what the hell you want from your own life, other than to get out of this crap town and figure it out elsewhere.\u201d Reading that, I both wanted Lulu to \u201cget out,\u201d and to shake her for being so ungrateful. They\u2019ll never see each other, or themselves, as clearly as the reader gets to see them both \u2014 that\u2019s the magic trick here. In granting the reader access to both women\u2019s interiority, Aliu brings to life the simple, heartbreaking fact that though our stories can intersect, we\u2019re ourselves alone.\n\nExcept, maybe, when we are still part of our mothers. For fear of spoiling it, all I will say about the moment Elsie and Lulu meet for the first time is that it transformed what was already a unique coming-of-age story and an incisive reckoning with class in America to something unforgettably wise and powerful. From its opening page, \u201cBrass\u201d simmers with anger \u2014 the all too real byproduct of working hard for not enough, of being a woman in a place where women have little value, of getting knocked down one too many times. But when the simmer breaks into a boil, Aliu alchemizes that anger into love, and in doing so creates one of the most potent dramatizations of the bond between mother and daughter that I\u2019ve ever read.\n\nOf course, the ending note is Lulu\u2019s \u2014 as the daughter, she will finish what her mother started. It\u2019s the kind of quiet closing gesture that feels less like an ending than an opening. I left this book with the sure sense that the characters were alive beyond its pages, though I wouldn\u2019t dare try to guess what they are up to \u2014 Elsie and Lulu are too real for that.", "title": "A Mother and Daughter and a Town Made of \u2018Brass\u2019", "authors": ["Julie Buntin", "Xhenet Aliu"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen we started thinking about this year\u2019s Museums section, we asked colleagues and people in the museum business what they thought about the role of museums today. In this time of political discourse, do people want to use them as a respite, to get away from all of the noise? Or should museums be a lens into the world \u2014 with their art and exhibits encouraging conversations across political, ethnic, gender, religious and racial lines?\n\nThey want to be both, of course. But, increasingly we found, they are moving toward the latter.\n\nAs the Special Sections editors, our team is tasked with producing about 200 \u2014 yes, that\u2019s right \u2014 domestic and international sections and special reports a year. On the domestic front, for example, we do retirement, wealth and personal finance, and gay pride, to name just a few. Traditionally, the domestic Museums section and the Fine Arts & Exhibits section, which are each published once a year, have been the largest special sections \u2014 as many as 44 pages in the print paper.\n\nThe Museums section is among the most fun to create. It allows us to take our readers on a cultural road trip. While we admire the museums in large cities like New York and Los Angeles, we also wanted to branch out more. In this section, for example, we included a stop in Indianapolis, and we decided to check in on Puerto Rico to see how the museums are recovering from Hurricane Maria. (We also asked national correspondents to write about their favorite museums in their areas.)\n\nWhen we start the planning process, we meet with people from various museums to find out what exhibitions and shows they have coming up, and also how they are trying to engage their visitors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRecent visits resulted in interesting conversations with people not only from area museums, but with others who came by The Times when they were in town. Charles Venable, the director and chief executive of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, talked about the dramatic evolution during the five years he has been there. The museum started to charge admission, but has also added a number of free events geared toward families. There are mini-golf events and a beer garden, as well as a lights display near the holidays to draw in new people.", "title": "A Museums Special Section That Uproots Expectations", "authors": ["Jane Bornemeier", "Jill Agostino"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic died during his trial for war crimes at The Hague in 2006. So his reincarnation in a glossy tracksuit for an experimental Serbian musical this week in Kosovo has provoked complicated feelings in the majority Albanian country.\n\n\u201cThe Lift: The Slobodan Show\u201d tracks the autocrat\u2019s rise, focusing on his family relationships, particularly with his wife, Mirjana, and ends with his trial in The Hague. It is interspersed with accounts from the Serbian actors of their own memories of life under Milosevic in the 1990s. It premiered on Tuesday to applause, tears, and a few walkouts.\n\n\u201cA lot of people cried yesterday,\u201d said the show\u2019s director, Nenad Todorovic, in a telephone interview on Wednesday. \u201cA few of them left the show very angry. Half of them were delighted.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a weird kind of musical,\u201d he added, \u201cnot like your Broadway musicals.\u201d\n\nMost people living in Kosovo are ethnic Albanians, but the musical is being staged by Serbs in the Serbian-majority town of Gracanica. Milosevic\u2019s shadow still looms large throughout the region, and tensions remain high. Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008, but Serbia and Serbian minority groups within Kosovo refuse to recognize it.", "title": "A Musical About Slobodan Milosevic Stirs Memories in Kosovo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Name Hoda Katebi\n\nAge 23\n\nHometown Edmond, Okla.\n\nNow Lives On the North Side of Chicago, in a two-bedroom apartment that she shares with a roommate.\n\nPhoto\n\nClaim to Fame Ms. Katebi is the brains behind the politically charged fashion blog Joojoo Azad, in which she describes herself as a \u201csarcastic (and angry) Muslim-Iranian creative and community organizer.\u201d The site frequently casts a spotlight on reductive media representations of hijab-wearing Muslim women and the environmental implications of, say, patterned rompers. \u201cThe power of how you dress and submit your body to public consumption really informs the way people engage with you,\u201d she said.\n\nBig Break During a January appearance on WGN News Chicago, to promote her self-published photography book, \u201cTehran Streetstyle,\u201d Ms. Katebi was asked about Iran\u2019s nuclear weapons and told \u201cyou don\u2019t sound like an American\u201d by the show\u2019s hosts. (The anchors later privately called her to apologize.) A clip of the interview became a Twitter phenomenon and was reported on by publications including Glamour and The Guardian. \u201cI think it was refreshing for people to see a person of color having a moment of truth on television,\u201d she said.\n\nLatest Project Her next media venture, Joojoo Journal, which she describes as a \u201cmultilingual, multimedia publication where diasporic, marginalized and \u2018subaltern\u2019 voices are uplifted,\u201d goes live in April. \u201cI want to be able to work directly with people in places like Iraq, Afghanistan and Greece who otherwise don\u2019t have access to outlets,\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNext Thing She is starting a co-op sewing project in Chicago to help immigrant seamstresses team up with small-scale fashion houses. The project\u2019s first client will be herself: a unisex clothing brand that she is designing. \u201cWe always think of androgyny as masculine, so I want to create androgynous clothing that uses a woman\u2019s body as a template,\u201d she said.\n\nAmerican Woman Ms. Katebi has publicly taken issue with the artist Shepard Fairey\u2019s poster of a woman wearing an American flag as a head scarf. \u201cThe only time you see a Muslim woman\u2019s face everywhere is when it is created by a white American man,\u201d she said. \u201cWe as Muslims are constantly trying to prove that we are American enough and that we have to wrap this country\u2019s flag around us to be accepted.\u201d", "title": "A Muslim Fashion Blogger With a Fierce Message", "authors": ["Alex Hawgood", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cTiger Woods\u201d they take special aim at Woods\u2019s parents, especially Earl Woods, Tiger\u2019s father. They raised a champion. They also raised a narcissistic loner who lacked basic decency. \u201cEven the most basic human civilities \u2014 a simple hello or thank you \u2014 routinely went missing from his vocabulary. A nod was too much to expect.\u201d\n\nThis book is littered with the bodies of those Woods cut out of his life without a thank you or goodbye \u2014 girlfriends, coaches, agents, caddies. If you stripped most of the golf out of this book, you might sometimes think you are reading the biography of a sociopath, a nonmurderous Tom Ripley or Patrick Bateman or Svidrigailov from \u201cCrime and Punishment.\u201d\n\nEarl Woods, the worst kind of stage father, profited early and often from his son\u2019s career. He was a liar and an adulterer. The later years of his life were particularly sordid. He hired multiple young women to attend to his needs.\n\nImage Jeff Benedict Credit Jeffrey Shaw\n\n\u201cPornography played steadily on the television,\u201d the authors write. \u201cSex toys were stuffed in drawers, and sexual favors were performed at Earl\u2019s request. \u2018It was a house of horrors,\u2019 recalled a former employee. \u2018Every drawer. Every cabinet.\u2019\u201d\n\nThere is beauty and awe in this perfectly pitched biography, as we watch Woods\u2019s skills blossom. Woods was shy and nerdy in his first years of high school. No one knew of his golf exploits. The moment here in which an early girlfriend, Dina Gravell, watches him play for the first time is terrific. It\u2019s as if she\u2019s discovered that he\u2019s Harry Potter.\n\nLovely too is the scene the authors set when Woods wins his first Masters. Woods looks up \u2014 at this tournament in which the first black man, Lee Elder, played in 1975 \u2014 and \u201cwitnesses the abundance of black people from the Augusta staff who had left their posts and assembled on the lawn and the veranda on the second floor.\u201d\n\nMany other details accrue. The authors tally up the lies Woods has told the media since he was young. There\u2019s little evidence, for example, that he was mugged while at Stanford as he claimed. They marshal evidence that raises questions about whether or not Woods took illegal performance-enhancing drugs. There is good writing here about agents and ad campaigns.", "title": "A New Biography Traces Tiger Woods\u2019s Mythical Rise and Fall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBefore the fruity cherry notes hit the palate, you are confronted with intriguing, dusky bitterness, the kind of taste that drives the best amaros. Cerasum, a new cherry liqueur, made in the United States by Don Ciccio & Figli from Michigan cherries and blossoms from Virginia, plus assorted herbs like juniper, is based on an old Italian recipe. It\u2019s not sweet. I prefer it as a mixer rather than as a straight drink. A splash does admirably in sparkling wine, and can contribute a subtle fruity note to a Manhattan: Cerasum Aperitivo, $46 for 750 milliliters at Mouth Indie Spirits and Wine Gallery, 192 Water Street (Jay Street), Brooklyn, 347-227-7007, mouth.com; $44.99 at Cordial Craft Wine, Beer & Spirits in Washington, 202-548-2450, cordialwine.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A New Cherry Liqueur, Made in America", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "To tell those back stories, the exhibit relied on visitors reading wall placards, which described, for example, Mrs. Madison\u2019s \u201cuncanny ability\u201d to put people at ease and thus, practice soft diplomacy. Visitors not fixated on the clothes might also learn about Jacqueline Kennedy\u2019s politically laden choice to have her daughter attend an integrated kindergarten. Tapping on the exhibit\u2019s interactive video displays, one might discover that Mrs. Johnson held West Wing strategy sessions and lobbied members of Congress on behalf of highway beautification. Or, that Mrs. Roosevelt acted as her disabled husband\u2019s eyes, ears and legs while he was in office.\n\nThe exhibit, which runs through Oct. 1, doesn\u2019t broach how first ladies have coped with their husbands\u2019 infidelities (Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Kennedy, Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Trump among them). Curators also didn\u2019t acknowledge that many, if not most, of these women were reluctant first ladies and felt stifled and suffocated by the role. Indeed, the first first lady, Martha Washington, wrote to her niece, \u201cI think I am more like a state prisoner than anything else.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMore than two centuries later, Michelle Obama told Oprah, \u201cIt\u2019s the little things you miss,\u201d like just walking out the front door without discussing it with anyone. At the White House, \u201cSasha opened her window once and there were calls,\u201d she said. \u201cIt never opened again.\u201d And, of course, there has been much speculation about Melania Trump\u2019s low visibility and what some have interpreted as her miserable demeanor, giving rise to #FreeMelania memes and conspiracy theories that the president has hired a body double for some of her public appearances following reports of his serial philandering.\n\nStill, there were a few first ladies who seemed to relish the role. The Bush Museum\u2019s exhibit tells us that Julia Tyler encouraged publicity and was the first first lady to be photographed. She wore look-at-me feather headdresses and lavish gowns. To receive guests, she sat atop a raised platform with a coterie she called her \u201cmaids of honor.\u201d Likewise, Frances Cleveland, the youngest first lady, and the only one to marry in the White House, seemed to enjoy the attention. She was so popular that a false news report that she was abandoning the bustle hastened the demise of the faux derri\u00e8re.\n\nWhich brings us back to fashion and our fascination with what first ladies choose to wear and not to wear. \u201cFashion is communication,\u201d said Jessica Gavit, 33, a designer and art director, who was at the preview party at the Bush Museusm, wearing glittery block-heeled ankle boots. \u201cIt speaks as much to the interests, thoughts and values of the person as the quotes,\u201d she said, referring to several quotes attributed to first ladies printed on the walls of the exhibit. Upon close inspection of the garments on display, Ms. Gavit noted that some of the seams under the arms appeared a bit stretched and surmised it was due to \u201call the waving.\u201d", "title": "A New Exhibit on First Ladies Plays Down Their Fashion Choices", "authors": ["Kate Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 For the powerful music manager Scooter Braun, there were a few mythic figures who proved influential in his formative years. As a child, he was obsessed with Superman; later he became an intense devotee of the X-Men. But as his eyes began shifting toward moguldom, Mr. Braun\u2019s heroes turned more earthbound.\n\n\u201cI read a book about my mentor David Geffen when I was 19, and he said music was the fastest way in because a song could change your life in a night while film and TV takes years,\u201d Mr. Braun, 36, said recently at his casual home office. \u201cI actually always wanted to be in film.\u201d\n\nBest known for masterminding the career of a onetime YouTube prodigy named Justin Bieber, Mr. Braun, who also manages Kanye West and Ariana Grande, has dabbled over the years in the movie business, executive producing the 2014 adaptation of \u201cThe Giver,\u201d this year\u2019s Sundance drama \u201cBurden\u201d and several concert documentaries for Mr. Bieber, among other projects.\n\nBut Mr. Braun, as is his tendency, wants bigger. For his next Geffen-esque act, he is leaping more fully into film, partnering with David Maisel, the founding chairman of Marvel Studios, to form a new company, Mythos Studios, which aspires to make its own hit comic-book movie franchises in live-action and animated formats. Successes like \u201cBlack Panther\u201d notwithstanding, the venture comes at a challenging time in the film industry, with ticket sales declining last year and competition from streaming services ratcheting up.", "title": "A New Film Studio From the Moguls Behind Justin Bieber and Marvel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Staffs tend to be tiny (often just one or two people), as do circulations (150 to 15,000). But what these titles lack in size or legacy, they make up for in originality and ambition, often zooming in on stories that have been overlooked or misrepresented in traditional magazines, and publishing them on their own terms.\n\n\u201cA lot of the indie folks start out by making something they want to read, that tell stories they want told, that represent their own experiences or their friends\u2019 experiences,\u201d Ms. Chou said. \u201cThey aren\u2019t necessarily pulling in the numbers of Bon App\u00e9tit or Saveur, but the thing is, they aren\u2019t trying to.\u201d\n\nMs. Chammavanijakul considers Dill\u2019s small readership an advantage. \u201cOther publications are limited because they cater to such a large spectrum of people,\u201d she said. \u201cWith us, everything is unreservedly traditional. We don\u2019t hold back.\u201d\n\nNick Muncy, 29, a pastry chef who worked most recently at Coi in San Francisco, watched YouTube videos to teach himself the basics of programs like InDesign, which he now uses to lay out Toothache. He describes his twice-yearly magazine as made for chefs, by chefs. \u201cI can use a food term and not have to explain it,\u201d he said.\n\nInspired by titles like Art Culinaire, in print since 1986, Mr. Muncy assumes that his readers \u2014 mainly professional cooks and others in the restaurant business \u2014 will have a base of food knowledge.\n\nAlmost all measurements in Toothache are metric, with no alternatives. And recipe instructions are technical and brief, with no hand-holding. \u201cIt\u2019s like what you\u2019d see in a professional kitchen,\u201d Mr. Muncy said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMac Malikowski, 30, brings the same kind of uncompromising specificity to Mouthfeel, his magazine about food and gay culture, which he produces in New York.\n\n\u201cMouthfeel is a manifestation of the exact intersection of culture that I exist in,\u201d said Mr. Malikowski, who sells up to 1,000 copies of each annual issue online, and at 10 retailers around the world.\n\nWhen he started in 2015, Mr. Malikowski said he was looking to tell countercultural food stories, the kinds that weren\u2019t already being told in mainstream magazines, with a more punk aesthetic. Mouthfeel has covered the naked dinner parties hosted by the San Francisco drag queen Juanita More, and profiled the New York chef Gerardo Gonzalez of Lalito.", "title": "A New Generation of Food Magazines Thinks Small, and in Ink", "authors": ["Tejal Rao"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "MILAN \u2014 In the prelude to the Italian elections this month, the far-right League party did not distinguish itself for rhetorical subtlety. Its leader, Matteo Salvini, called Islam \u201cincompatible with our values, rights and freedoms.\u201d He characterized the single European currency as a \u201ccrime against humanity.\u201d And the senior League politician Attilio Fontana, after deploring that the \u201cwhite race\u201d could be \u201cwiped out\u201d in Italy, went on to win the presidency of Lombardy, the wealthy northern region that includes this fashionable city, in a landslide.\n\nBut pull up the League\u2019s campaign manifesto, dig past the strident anti-immigration and anti-Muslim rhetoric, and suddenly the tone turns more poetic.\n\n\u201cItaly and its thousand cultures should be the Silicon Valley of cultural heritage,\u201d it sings, one of many flourishes among the party\u2019s proposals for art institutions, churches and heritage sites. Unlike the League\u2019s American cousins \u2014 Mr. Salvini is an avowed fan of President Trump \u2014 these Italian populists like to present themselves as defenders of public cultural institutions, and their \u201cMake Italy Great Again\u201d vision highlights museums as much as migration policy. For Mr. Salvini\u2019s party, the nationalist project goes right through the history of art.\n\nThey are not the first right-wingers to make promises about Italian high culture. A few days after the March 4 elections, as the papers here weighed the likelihood of a populist governing coalition or a new poll, I visited two major exhibitions examining how art and politics informed each other at previous turning points in Italy\u2019s history: in the 1920s and \u201930s, on view at Fondazione Prada in Milan; and in the \u201950s and \u201960s, at Palazzo Strozzi in Florence. Both reaffirmed that questions of culture \u2014 who defines what it is, and who administers it \u2014 have never been far from the surface of Italian political life.", "title": "A New Italy, Imagined by Artists and Demagogues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Boys Are Not All Right,\u201d by Michael Ian Black (Op-Ed, Feb. 22), which links violence by boys and men to our concepts of masculinity:\n\nMr. Black asks how we can help boys. Humans are not born empathetic. Empathy is taught. Parents, caretakers, teachers and coaches must teach boys empathy by showing them affection, compassion and understanding. By responding to their needs. By giving them a safe place to express emotions and an ear to discuss them. By nurturing them.\n\nWhen someone tells my 5-year-old son, \u201cBoys don\u2019t cry,\u201d he answers, \u201cThat\u2019s not true.\u201d Boys cry as much as girls until they\u2019re scolded or insulted when they do. When our son cries, we let him. When he hurts himself, we comfort him. When he\u2019s angry, we try to understand what\u2019s bothering him. The result? His teachers tell us how kind, gentle and thoughtful he is to other children. He is still a confident, outgoing, pirate-loving boy. But we have raised him without false, demeaning, sexist views about what it means to be male or female. To us, it isn\u2019t about gender. It\u2019s about love.\n\nABIGAIL ROSE SOLOMON\n\nNEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI play pool with a friend of mine three to four times a month. Pool is just the excuse \u2014 the vehicle to get together to understand what\u2019s going on in each other\u2019s lives. Implicit in those conversations is the expression of understanding of manhood. It\u2019s all indirect, often subtle, but it\u2019s unquestionably there.\n\nWomen just need to listen to men converse without assumptions. We\u2019ll rarely use such terms as mindfulness, journey, vulnerability etc. They simply do not suit our gender. But we cover these topics all the time. Women and men discuss identity differently. And that\u2019s O.K. Really. But the last thing men want to do is talk about such stuff directly. But it\u2019s being discussed all the time. All the time.", "title": "Opinion | A New Model of Masculinity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s that great line from \u2018The Leopard\u2019 where one of the characters says, \u2018If we want things to stay as they are, things will have to change,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cPublishing has changed radically in the last 15 years, and we need to hold to the core of what we\u2019re doing, but change what we\u2019re publishing and how we publish.\u201d\n\nImage \u201cWe need to hold to the core of what we\u2019re doing, but change what we\u2019re publishing and how we publish,\u201d said Jonathan Galassi, who will stay on as president of FSG. Credit Elena Seibert\n\nIn appointing Ms. Angel, FSG is opting for cultural continuity rather than a radical reinvention. Ms. Angel is in many ways a natural choice for the role. She worked at FSG for seven years before she became the publisher of Faber in 2015. At FSG, she edited acclaimed books like Ben Lerner\u2019s \u201c10:04,\u201d Rachel Cusk\u2019s \u201cOutline\u201d and Donald Antrim\u2019s \u201cThe Emerald Light in the Air.\u201d When she was editorial director of Fourth Estate, she worked with Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Rivka Galchen, James Gleick, Yiyun Li and Siddhartha Mukherjee.\n\n\u201cShe has an independent sensibility, and that\u2019s half the game in publishing,\u201d Mr. Galassi said.\n\nMs. Angel said she aims to maintain FSG\u2019s stature while revitalizing its author ranks by recruiting young, emerging writers. \u201cIt has a unique place in American literary history,\u201d Ms. Angel said. \u201cI hope to continue the excellence but also refresh it with new talent.\u201d\n\nThe literary world will be watching the succession closely. Since its founding in 1946 by Roger W. Straus Jr. and John C. Farrar, FSG has held onto its perch as one of the country\u2019s top literary publishing houses, a home for groundbreaking fiction, award-winning poetry and serious nonfiction. It has published a pantheon of literary icons, Nobel laureates and Pulitzer Prize winners, including Pablo Neruda, Flannery O\u2019Connor, Isaac Bashevis Singer, Susan Sontag, Tom Wolfe, Joan Didion, Seamus Heaney and John McPhee.\n\nBut like all publishing houses, FSG, which is owned by Macmillan, has struggled to adapt to seismic changes in the industry, with the rise of e-books and online retail, and a shifting cultural landscape where social media has eaten into our collective reading habits and attention spans.", "title": "A New Publisher for Farrar, Straus & Giroux", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Galeries Lafayette already has an exhibition space devoted to art, contemporary fashion and design: the Galerie des Galeries, which opened in the store in 2001. Mr. Houz\u00e9, 36, an established collector cherished by commercial galleries around the Marais, said his passion for art drew him to engage more deeply. \u201cIn 2011, I convinced my family to further our commitment and to imagine creating a foundation, but actually I had no idea about what we would do,\u201d he recalled. \u201cParis has a lot of institutions and foundations.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThere is indeed plenty of competition for the art-loving public\u2019s attention. Alongside public institutions like the Pompidou Center and Palais de Tokyo, the city is served by the Cartier Foundation, the Ricard Foundation, and the recently opened Louis Vuitton Foundation and J\u00e9r\u00f4me Seydoux-Path\u00e9 Foundation. Next year, the luxury magnate Fran\u00e7ois Pinault will open a private museum to showcase his art collection in the central Bourse de Commerce, which sits midway between the Pompidou Center and the Louvre.\n\nWhat Mr. Houz\u00e9 hopes will set Lafayette Anticipations apart will be its provisions for production, with exchanges of ideas across disciplines and the ability to fabricate artworks and spectacles on a massive scale, for exhibition both on and off site. Ahead of the building\u2019s completion, well-equipped workshops in the basement were already up and running, assisting in projects destined for the Tate, the New Museum in New York, the Kunsthalle Basel and the Pompidou Center.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn English, Rue du Pl\u00e2tre, the location of the new art space, translates as \u201cplaster street.\u201d Lafayette Anticipations has brought the plaster workers back to one of the most architecturally protected areas of Paris, and with them carpenters, metalworkers, programmers, dressmakers and all else that an artist might need to realize an ambitious work.\n\nMr. Koolhaas\u2019s involvement started in late 2011, when Ms. Finders joined Mr. Koolhaas\u2019s firm, the Office for Metropolitan Architecture. She continued her conversations with Mr. Houz\u00e9 and his team, helping them delve further into the connections between Galeries Lafayette and the Paris art world, not just in terms of patronage and investment but in episodes of historical coincidence. \u201cThe department store was born at the same time as the art salon, and the new urban development of Paris,\u201d Ms. Finders said.\n\nThe following year, Galeries Lafayette invited the Office for Metropolitan Architecture and its research arm to mount a historical exhibition in the Galerie des Galeries. Together with a team in the Koolhaas firm that included the architect Cl\u00e9ment P\u00e9riss\u00e9, Ms. Finders dug into the archives on the ninth floor of the Boulevard Haussmann building. Exploring the family\u2019s history was a process Mr. P\u00e9riss\u00e9 called \u201ca sort of mutual psychoanalysis\u201d between the architects and the Galeries Lafayette group. For Ms. Finders, it was a means, too, of divining how accommodating Mr. Houz\u00e9 and his group might be to radical propositions: \u201cWe needed to know what they could tolerate: What was their breaking point.\u201d\n\nBesides Galeries Lafayette\u2019s innovations in retail, what stood out in Mr. P\u00e9riss\u00e9 and Ms. Finders\u2019 study was the store\u2019s long heritage of production, from apparel making through contemporary design. This tradition of creating and commissioning became foundational to the art space\u2019s identity: The name Lafayette Anticipations was chosen to suggest the start of a process and expectations of things to come.\n\nTHE GOAL to be a nimble platform for creation has been given rather literal physical form in Mr. Koolhaas and the Office for Metropolitan Architecture\u2019s design. A glass box with four movable segments of flooring on vertical tracks now occupies a former courtyard space. These provide adaptable space at the core.\n\nThe movable parts offer 49 possible configurations to accommodate a range of projects. \u201cSince it\u2019s not about a collection, you couldn\u2019t be precise\u201d about what would be exhibited and how, Mr. Koolhaas said. \u201cPerformance, ballet, theater, music, concerts, digital, video, film: Already, those are extremely diverse and can sometimes have opposite demands. We have to accommodate all of those.\u201d\n\nThis is not the Office for Metropolitan Architecture\u2019s first building with a central elevating platform. In 1998, it unveiled the audacious Maison Bordeaux, a home created for a client in a wheelchair. More radical, perhaps, is the discretion of this project: The architect\u2019s intervention is not visible from the street. Mr. Koolhaas, whose firm is responsible for memorable landmarks like the looping CCTV headquarters in Beijing, said there is now a \u201ctotal excess in terms of visibility of architecture.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRather than plan more attention-grabbing buildings, he suggested that architecture insinuate itself into the fabric of a city. Mr. Koolhaas rejects the idea that Paris\u2019s status as a living museum stultifies innovation. \u201cI, myself, would have maybe represented that idea even 10 or 12 years ago,\u201d he conceded. Today, the notion that architectural preservation necessarily causes creative stagnation is, he said, \u201csimply a lack of ambition: a lack of understanding of what you can do within preservation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSo, for me, preservation became a very interesting field,\u201d he continued, suggesting a new urban paradigm in which architects leave the existing architectural language of the street intact and reimagine those portions that are out of sight. \u201cI think it\u2019s also, in a certain way, an interesting, new, metropolitan style,\u201d he said, \u201cold outside but super fresh, new, inside.\u201d\n\nThe Marais is already home to several buildings that hide contemporary glass boxes behind Haussmannian facades. Many, like the Marian Goodman Gallery, are adapted to accommodate contemporary artworks that grow ever larger, in turn, to fill the outsize exhibition spaces of modern museums and galleries.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe hulklike growth is part of a phenomenon Mr. Koolhaas himself once called the \u201cTate effect,\u201d referring to the vast Turbine Hall of Tate Modern in London. While he might not acknowledge it as such, one could view Lafayette Anticipations\u2019 production facility as, in part, an architect and a collector\u2019s solution to an architect- and collector-generated problem: a way to help artists tasked with filling enormous gallery spaces beyond the practical scope of an individual.\n\nLAFAYETTE ANTICIPATIONS itself is of relatively modest dimensions, with 9,400 square feet of exhibition space \u2014 less than a quarter of the Louis Vuitton Foundation\u2019s. It reflects Mr. Houz\u00e9\u2019s positioning of his institution \u201con the side\u201d of Paris\u2019s new art ecosystem. Unlike the huge crowds that attend the Palais de Tokyo openings, Lafayette looks to keep its audiences small and focused.\n\nAsked how he might judge success, if not by audience size, Lafayette Anticipations\u2019 managing director, Fran\u00e7ois Quintin, suggested it might come from the liberated quality that emerges when commercial imperatives are removed.\n\nIn Paris, as in London and New York, the cost of living puts pressure on artists to create work that can be sold. Rising rents have driven artist-run spaces out of the city center and fomented the closing of smaller independent galleries. Lafayette Anticipations \u201cwas not conceived to be an alternative, but of course it is,\u201d Mr. Quintin said. \u201cSometimes we are able to produce things that neither galleries nor museums are able or wanted to produce.\u201d\n\nWorking with three associate curators in programming the art space, among them Charles Aubin of Performa in New York, Mr. Quintin is setting his sights on the international as well as the local scene. The only common criterion that he seeks in artists to work with is \u201cintelligence\u201d: bright minds for a bright new space.\n\nIt\u2019s too soon to say what the impact will be on the Paris scene. Perhaps for this reason, Lafayette Anticipations\u2019 future has been left open: Only two shows have been scheduled, including the opening exhibition, a site-specific installation by the New York artist Lutz Bacher.\n\n\u201cI have an image of where the foundation could be in 25 years,\u201d Mr. Quintin said, smiling. \u201cBut I have no idea of what we\u2019re going to do in two.\u201d", "title": "A Newcomer in the Paris Art Scene Jostles for Position", "authors": ["Hettie Judah"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "How do you tell an alligator from a crocodile? And no, dad joke enthusiasts, the answer isn\u2019t that you see one later and the other after a while.\n\nThe most obvious way to discern the two reptiles is to stare down their sinister snouts. Alligators have U-shaped faces that are wide and short, while crocodiles have slender almost V-shaped muzzles. And if you\u2019re daring enough, take a gander at their chompers. When an alligator closes its mouth, you tend to see only its upper teeth. Crocodiles on the other hand flash a toothy grin with their top and bottom teeth interlacing.\n\nMany of the differences between the two center on their heads and mouths. Now, researchers from Japan have identified what they believe to be another feature that sets the reptiles apart: Alligators tend to have shorter humerus bones in their forelimbs and shorter femurs in their hind limbs than crocodiles, the team reported last week.\n\n\u201cThis information could help explain differences in their ecology and locomotion, including the strange fact that, while small crocodiles have been observed to bound and gallop, alligators have not,\u201d Julia Molnar an evolutionary biologist from the New York Institute of Technology College of Osteopathic Medicine who was not involved in the study. She said the limb differences can affect things like speed and leverage in the animals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe differences are small, and not something you could easily spot in the wild. But the finding may provide insights into the ways in which the two reptiles move. The study was published last week in the journal Royal Society Open Science.", "title": "A Newly Discovered Difference Between Alligators and Crocodiles", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Attorney General Jeff Sessions attended even in the wake of a nasty attack last week by Mr. Trump, who traces many of his woes to Mr. Sessions\u2019s decision to step aside from the Russia inquiry. (Mr. Trump joked that he had offered Mr. Sessions a ride to the event, but that he had \u201crecused himself.\u201d)\n\nAnd Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, was there with his wife, Ivanka Trump, just days after his security clearance was downgraded amid concerns about his F.B.I. background check.\n\n\u201cWe were late tonight because Jared could not get through security,\u201d Mr. Trump joked.\n\nThe dinner features speeches, skits and songs performed by the club\u2019s members and invited political guests. In his opening remarks, David Lightman, the president of the club and a national political reporter for McClatchy, motioned to Mr. Trump, saying, \u201cFor the first time, he is eating at a hotel that he doesn\u2019t own.\u201d\n\nOne skit featured the characters of Vice President Mike Pence and Hope Hicks, Mr. Trump\u2019s closest aide, who is departing. \u201cChaos is his genius,\u201d the Hicks character says.\n\nBut the highlight of the night always comes when the journalists offer the stage to the president for some self-deprecating jokes and good-natured roasting.\n\nFor Mr. Trump, who has spent a lifetime flouting political correctness, his participation in the dinner was striking because the club is the Washington embodiment of political correctness. Its credo is that the roasts at the dinner should \u201csinge but never burn.\u201d\n\nThis year, Mr. Trump leaned into the flame.\n\nHe took aim at his favorite target: \u201cFake News CNN.\u201d He called Fox News the \u201cfourth branch of government.\u201d And he made fun of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., who stepped down in December as publisher of The New York Times, saying: \u201cI inherited millions. Arthur inherited billions of dollars, and he turned it into millions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president also poked fun at Stephen K. Bannon, his former chief strategist, who many inside the White House believe was the source for some of the nastiest parts of the recent book by Michael Wolff.\n\nMr. Bannon, the president said, \u201cleaked more than the Titanic.\u201d\n\nAnd he directed a jab at himself over his infatuation with the size of his inauguration crowd, claiming credit for all the crowds at the recently completed Winter Olympics in South Korea.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
