Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe relationship between any president and the press is fraught. But it is especially true for Mr. Trump, who spent his first year in the Oval Office in a near constant state of agitation about what he views as a media that is unfair and plotting against him.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t always so. As a real estate developer and later a reality TV star, Mr. Trump eagerly sought the media\u2019s attention, basking in the fame and celebrity that produced front page articles and frequent appearances on news programs.\n\nAs president, he remains drawn to the TV lights and the newspaper headlines, often conducting discussions and negotiations live on television. But he also complains bitterly when the stories turn negative or personal.\n\nDuring his remarks on Saturday, he acknowledged one of those story lines: that his administration is in constant chaos.\n\n\u201cI like turnover. I like chaos,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cIt really is good. Who is going to be the next to leave? Steve Miller or Melania?\u201d\n\nAt that point, he looked out to his wife and asked whether she still loved him.\n\nThe Gridiron dinner has long been a bipartisan venue for good-natured ribbing at times when tensions between the media, lawmakers and the president are at their highest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2011, President Barack Obama took a few swipes at the conservative media, saying that he enjoyed doing an interview during the Super Bowl with Bill O\u2019Reilly of Fox News. \u201cI don\u2019t often get a chance to be in a room with an ego that\u2019s bigger than mine,\u201d he joked.\n\nFour years later, Mr. Obama tried a bit of humor at his own expense, noting that \u201cif I did not love America, I wouldn\u2019t have moved here from Kenya.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Trump has not always been a good sport when he is on the receiving end of the roasting. In 2011, when Mr. Obama savaged him at the White House Correspondent\u2019s Dinner, Mr. Trump appeared to take it badly, and some say his decision to run for president was a result in part of his anger at Mr. Obama for the jokes.\n\nThis time, he turned the tables. Saturday\u2019s dinner was a chance for Mr. Trump to enjoy a bit of humor at other people\u2019s expense. After a song mocking Hillary Clinton that was performed by journalists and Democratic lawmakers, Mr. Trump applauded vigorously.\n\nThe president\u2019s appearance at the Gridiron dinner suggests that he may also be planning to attend other events with the media that he has skipped since becoming president.\n\nEarly last year, as the president and his aides repeatedly attacked the White House press corps, Mr. Trump announced that he would not attend the White House Correspondents Association\u2019s annual dinner \u2014 the first time a president had skipped the event in decades.\n\nThe president has also not yet attended the Alfalfa Club dinner, an exclusive black-tie event that often extends an invitation to the president to attend. Club members are politicians, military leaders and business executives who gather each year for a banquet at the Capital Hilton in Washington.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump skipped the dinner in 2017, he became the first president to miss the party in his first year in office since 1993. Mr. Pence attended last year, along with Ms. Trump, the president\u2019s daughter, and Mr. Kushner, her husband.\n\nToward the end of his remarks on Saturday, Mr. Trump apologized that he had to be \u201cup early tomorrow morning\u201d to watch \u201cFox and Friends.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis might be the most fun,\u201d he added, \u201csince watching your faces on election night.\u201d", "title": "A Night of Laughs Between Trump and His Favorite Punching Bag", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn late 2016, a new Bon Jovi album, \u201cThis House Is Not for Sale,\u201d opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, and then promptly fell to No. 43.\n\nNow, almost a year and a half later, \u201cThis House Is Not for Sale\u201d is back at No. 1, bumping the \u201cBlack Panther\u201d soundtrack to second place after a two-week run at the top. But Bon Jovi does not suddenly have a new radio hit or viral video, though it is about to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.\n\nInstead, the band is heading out on tour, and in an example of the music industry\u2019s latest strategy to move CDs \u2014 and seize high chart positions \u2014 at a time of declining sales, it is \u201cbundling\u201d copies of the album with concert tickets. When fans buy tickets to Bon Jovi\u2019s new tour, which opens in Denver next week, they will receive codes that can be redeemed for a CD of \u201cThis House Is Not for Sale.\u201d\n\nOver the last year, as streaming has come to dominate the charts, this same bundling strategy has been used by Kenny Chesney, Katy Perry, Pink, Arcade Fire and LCD Soundsystem, and is a particular favorite of older rock bands.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe prevalence of ticket bundles has raised concerns about chart manipulation. But David Bakula, a senior analyst at Nielsen, called the practice legitimate, since fans must take the affirmative step of redeeming a code to get the album \u2014 even though their ticket costs the same if they do not.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe messaging isn\u2019t, \u2018Oh, we\u2019re just going to throw in a free album,\u2019\u201d Mr. Bakula said.\n\n\u201cThis is the way that people are getting albums in their hands,\u201d he continued. \u201cIf I\u2019m going to a Bon Jovi show, I may or may not go out and buy a copy. But if you offer one to me wrapped in the price of my ticket, then yes, absolutely, I want it.\u201d", "title": "A Not-So-New Bon Jovi Album Returns to No. 1, Thanks to Bundling", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE HOUSE OF BROKEN ANGELS\n\nBy Luis Alberto Urrea\n\n315 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $27.\n\nLuis Alberto Urrea\u2019s sorrowful and funny new novel, \u201cThe House of Broken Angels,\u201d is one of those epic books about a complicated family that typically begin with a family tree to help the reader make sense of the relationships. Fortunately, this novel does not have such a tree. Instead, the reader has to do what any guest visiting such a family for the first time must do: Be alert, be attentive, be appreciative. And there is much to appreciate in Urrea\u2019s highly entertaining story of Big Angel, the de La Cruz family\u2019s patriarch, who buries his mother even as he himself is dying and as his family gathers to celebrate his 70th, and last, birthday.\n\nDispelling the notion held by some Americans that all Mexicans have just crossed the border, Urrea creates a rambunctious de La Cruz family that lives in San Diego and \u201chas been around here since before your grandparents were even born.\u201d Urrea is intent on both celebrating the particularities of Mexican-American life and attacking the anti-Mexican racism that has been a part of American culture ever since the United States conquered quite a bit of Mexico. Well aware that Mexicans are perceived by many, including themselves, as having a flexible relationship with time \u2014 \u201cYou know you\u2019re a Mexican when lunch doesn\u2019t show up till 10 at night\u201d \u2014 Big Angel prides himself on his punctuality. \u201cAs if a Mexican couldn\u2019t be punctual,\u201d he says. \u201cAs if Vicente Fox was late to things, cabrones.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe quips and jokes come fast through a poignant novel that is very much about time itself, especially the passing of time and the inevitability of death. The narrative unfolds in a little over a week, from the funeral of Mam\u00e1 Am\u00e9rica to the passing of Big Angel. The last is hardly a secret, given how his name signals toward heaven. In addition, we know from early in the novel that he is dying of cancer and that his body\u2019s basic functions are nearly beyond him. His wife, Perla, and daughter, Minnie, must help him bathe and relieve himself. \u201cI used to be your father,\u201d Big Angel says to Minnie with a sob. \u201cNow I am your baby.\u201d From the threshold of death back to the beginning of life, Big Angel finds himself in a \u201ctime bubble\u201d and a \u201ctime storm,\u201d immersed in memories of his journey from Mexico to the United States and the complexities of his family drama.\n\nTechnically, Big Angel and Perla are undocumented immigrants, having crossed the border from south to north as teenagers. But Urrea takes care to show how Mexicans and Mexican-Americans \u2014 and Americans as a whole \u2014 are caught in the ever-changing politics and economics of border definitions and labor exploitation. Big Angel\u2019s \u201cgrandfather Don Segundo had come to California after the Mexican Revolution, crossing the border in Sonora.\u201d In the United States, he \u201clearned English and learned to love baseball\u201d during a time when Mexican labor was needed. When that time ended, however, \u201cthe de La Cruz family became Mexican again when they went back south in the great wave of deportations of 1932, joining two million mestizos rounded up and sent across the line in boxcars. The United States had apparently grown weary of hunting down and deporting Chinese people for the moment.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBorder politics have been important to Urrea \u2014 a prolific author of fiction, poetry and nonfiction \u2014 since he began his career with 1993\u2019s \u201cAcross the Wire: Life and Hard Times on the Mexican Border.\u201d During the 10-year struggle to publish his first book, he was told by one New York editor that \u201cnobody cares about starving Mexicans.\u201d Big Angel, his mother and his siblings are among those starving Mexicans who ultimately ascend to the middle and working classes. Big Angel is able to rent and then buy his home in a neighborhood where \u201call the houses had bars on the windows, which scared outsiders but which nobody from there even saw.\u201d Big Angel\u2019s achievement of the (Mexican) American dream is made possible by working multiple jobs \u2014 contrary to the stereotype of lazy Mexicans that irritates him so much \u2014 until he finally lands a position running computers for the gas and electric company, even though \u201che didn\u2019t even like computers. A Mexican doing what these rich Americanos couldn\u2019t do was the point.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor all of his success, however, he cannot protect his family from the things that life might tempt them with. Personal tensions, carnal desires and extramarital affairs inflame his siblings, in-laws, children and grandchildren. One of his stepsons with Perla, Yndio, is a \u201cnon-cisgendered, non-heteronormative cultural liberation warrior.\u201d Another stepson, Braulio, was killed in a gang shooting. His own son, Lalo \u2014 traumatized by a tour in Iraq \u2014 struggles with drug addiction and his undocumented status, a situation unresolved by his military service. After being deported, Lalo had to cross back into the United States. A nephew, Marco, is the lead singer in a heavy metal band and stylizes himself as \u201cthe Satanic Hispanic.\u201d He falls in love with a Dreamer, a young woman brought to the United States as an undocumented infant.", "title": "A Novelist\u2019s Exuberant Love Letter to a Mexican-American Clan", "authors": ["Viet Thanh Nguyen", "Luis Alberto Urrea"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "I had picked up cheese, eggs, vegetables, chicken tenders and ice cream. I stopped by the deli counter for sliced meat when I noticed an older man, some would say very old, with a cap on his head above a checked wool jacket too light for the season. His pants were out of fashion, baggy, rolled up and stained with oil, cinched at the waist with a belt that was too long and hung down one leg.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe was slender and one shoulder was bent down, his face narrow, with stubble that showed the years and the tears of time. His hands were clawed with arthritis and spotted, misshapen nails with dirt under them that could not be scrubbed away. He was a man you would not notice, or if you did, not wish to touch as he shuffled behind the cart. He wore a cap that read in proud gold stitching, \u201cVietnam Veteran U.S.N.\u201d\n\nIt should be said that seeing Vietnam veterans is not unusual in Vermont or any other state, but the generation is declining in number and strength. About 400 die a day of the 2.7 million who served. It was a long time ago, and newer conflicts have taken the stage and headlines. Heroes and graves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe veterans of Vietnam are opaque coming to transparent, like onion paper held to light. Soon they will be crippled relics in homes and memories, photos on a dusty mantel or side table with a yellowed doily. You have passed them unseen a hundred times. You never knew their stories, because they are mostly private and you did not want to ask or know. Beyond the cap or the coat with the same words, they do not share. They wear these things for themselves and to say, I am here, and I was there.\n\nWe stood by the counter waiting for our slices of pastrami and teriyaki chicken. The old man carried in his cart milk, ground coffee, a few cans of stew and soups. I could see that most of the food was ready to eat, or add water and stir. He likely lived by himself, wife dead or gone.\n\nDuring the pause of commerce I asked him where he had served. He responded by telling me simply that he had been in Danang on helicopters, and on a warship off the coast. It was vague and intentional. When he said he had piloted a chopper, I thought most likely a Huey with that iconic whooping sound of the blades biting the air and announcing its flight path, a sound that you know for life and run for the tree line when you hear. He might have flown something larger, a workhorse Chinook, used to carry anything that would fit or be hung, from troops to supplies, small artillery. It went where it was needed; you did what was required.\n\nBetween the cutting of the meats and the wrapping of the cheese, each of us looked at the other. Maybe I had fewer scars in the open. Maybe I had more hair, a down winter coat and better boots, gloves, a wool scarf. It looked as if he had had a hard time after the war. The Kingdom offered a hard life, but easier than what he had done. His boots had uneven soles. His gait was off. He had probably been wounded.\n\nI did not want to ask. Fate had treated me more kindly. But as we used to say, no one gets out of here alive. It could have been my imagination, but our eyes reflected back into ourselves. We were doubled. He did not smile.\n\nHe asked if I had been there. He asked because I had spoken first. He could not tell if I was a flatlander, from out of state, just curious or a fool. He wanted to know if he had to explain that place and the cap. His eyes saw the answer before I spoke. He asked if I knew Danang, Nha Trang, Dong Ha, the Highlands and the Delta. How many words did I use to reply? I said two or three, meaning years or tours. How many words do you need for the rainy season, fighting, the heat, humidity and the smell, fear?\n\nI said yes, remembering the firefights over the hills and low mountains at dusk, surrounding the bay at Danang, the jets coming in and dropping bombs and tumbling napalm. Heard the artillery, a different sound and cadence for every caliber. Beautiful parts in a violent orchestra, with strings, wind instruments and drums.\n\nI watched the earth explode and burn, green to black and dead. A Broadway show sitting on a folding aluminum chair for the afternoon matinee performance with a beer. He chuckled with his eyes, told me about rocket-propelled grenade attacks on the airport, running for cover, strafing runs on the riverbeds and trails, dancing to the music, killing men in the open. He told me about friends on the wall, the memorial we thought was going to be singular, unique, though we learned that was a lie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI told him about flying supplies into fire bases, coming in hot, breaking hard, slowing and throwing off ammunition and water, grabbing the wounded, engines whining to full power and the aircraft shuddering, lifting off short and hoping that the enemy we hardly knew did not have the range or luck. Dust choking, blinding. Laughing as we gained altitude, at the odds beaten, and hoping to go back for another run. Until next time. Every time we did this, the bets went back to even, the clock unwound.\n\nOur purchases were put on the glass counter top. He took his, tipped his head and cap and headed off, nothing else. I glanced as he turned, said, \u201cSo long,\u201d watched him walk to the cash register, pay with bills, and out of the store, leaving his cart at the door. He limped and did not look back. If he had said other than an acknowledgment with his nod, it would have been more than he wanted to say and more than I needed to hear.\n\nWhat was it, two, three minutes of history? Meeting, touching and knowing that there had been a past and that the present was tinged with the gone before. Walking on. Shared survival and the pleasure of release with the conjugation of years. Nothing to be spoken or shared with clerks, cashiers or office workers. A diminishing private world with signals and symbols.\n\nTwo men, strangers, known from and for a thousand years in kind, history buried, burned into the circuits of the brain and whatever passes for the soul. Pushed far back and down, down deep as it is possible to go. For a second, I thought I saw a young man, looking out the door of an aircraft at the jungle and rising flashes of light, soaring, swooping and rocking, smiling, wind in his hair, wind so strong that it made the eyes water and distorted his cheeks.\n\nWhat he saw was something else. Maybe nothing.\n\nWe had validated ourselves at the meat counter in a small rural town under a winter sky. For a day I thought about the man that I would never meet again, except in myself. A man said that in our youths our hearts were touched by fire, and fire is cleansing. I am not sure. Fire leaves ash and scar. And a pale smoke that rises into the heavens and is gone.", "title": "A Pale Smoke", "authors": ["David Gerstel"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "EASTER ISLAND \u2014 This remote speck in the South Pacific is famous for its colossal stone statues, nearly 1,000 of them towering over the landscape like guardians.\n\nWho built them? How did they get there? And who fitted some of them with giant red stone hats weighing up to 12 tons each?\n\nWhen I was a kid, a huge nonfiction best seller by Erich von D\u00e4niken called \u201cChariots of the Gods\u201d argued that they were evidence that U.F.O.s had visited Earth. Von D\u00e4niken, whose nonfiction and fiction books have sold a staggering 63 million copies worldwide, argued that only space aliens could have carved, transported and erected these monuments.\n\nThe puzzle arises because when Jacob Roggeveen discovered the island (on Easter Day, 1722, hence the name), it was a wasteland with no trees and a small, starving population. The Polynesian inhabitants had only small and leaky canoes, so it was unclear how they had ever reached the island, let alone built such colossal figures.", "title": "Opinion | A Parable of Self-Destruction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of \u201cWorn Stories,\u201d interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.\n\nThe artist and performer Justin Vivian Bond, who prefers the pronoun \u2018\u2018they,\u2019\u2019 has been fascinated with Edie Sedgwick for as long as they can remember. When their friend, the music executive Danny Fields, found out, he gifted Bond with Sedgwick\u2019s leopard-skin pillbox hat. Through the hat, which purportedly inspired Bob Dylan\u2019s song \u201cLeopard-Skin Pill-Box Hat,\u201d Bond explains how their fascination with the actress and model has evolved.\n\nI first met Danny Fields when he came to a \u201cKiki and Herb\u201d show at Flamingo East in the \u201990s. Danny was an A & R guy who had signed Iggy and the Stooges to Elektra in the \u201960s. In the \u201970s, he was the editor of 16 Magazine and went on to be the manager of the Ramones for a while.\n\nWe struck up a friendship, and at a certain point we discussed how I was obsessed with Edie Sedgwick. Danny had been quoted heavily in Jean Stein\u2019s book \u201cEdie: An American Biography.\u201d That book was so important to me. I grew up in a lower-middle class family in Hagerstown, Maryland and my job in 1982 \u2014 the summer between my freshman and sophomore years of college \u2014 was at the Waldenbooks at the Valley Mall. I unpacked books for the bookstore and I had unpacked this book. It was very beautiful. I was like, \u201cWho is this Edie person?\u201d I was just a kid in Maryland. I\u2019d heard about Andy Warhol and I\u2019d probably seen him on \u201cThe Love Boat,\u201d but I didn\u2019t know much about that world. I bought the book and from then on I was obsessed with Edie Sedgwick.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn my sophomore year in college at Adelphi University the upperclassman had a Halloween party, and I decided to go as Edie Sedgwick. It was sort of my first coming out as queer, cross-dressing, if you will. I went to the party and pretended I was on acid and got all these people to get in the shower together. I took on the personality of a New York City party girl and I found out how well it worked.\n\nI wanted to be just like Edie. There was a romance in it, a sense of freedom. She sounds glamorous to a young person. But the way she died at age 28, after taking a bunch of downers, wasn\u2019t all that glamorous. It wasn\u2019t until years later, when I was in my 30s, that I was like, \u201cWell, if I was like Edie Sedgwick, I would be dead right now.\u201d\n\nBecause Danny knew about my love for Edie, he presented me with this leopard-skin pillbox hat that had belonged to her. They\u2019d been roommates when she first moved to New York. According to Danny, it\u2019s the hat that inspired Bob Dylan to write the song \u201cLeopard-Skin Pill-Box Hat\u201d because Dylan dated Edie briefly. When Danny gave it to me, he basically said, \u201cIf I don\u2019t give it to you, it\u2019s probably going to be stolen by some hustler someday anyway, so it might as well end up with somebody who will love it and take care of it.\u201d\n\nI\u2019ve never worn the hat. It\u2019s too small for my big head. So it\u2019s usually on display in my living room, whether in my loft in the East Village, my house upstate, or when I did my degree show in London, hanging on a wall hook or in a bookcase. I always keep it with me because it\u2019s a reminder of the power of glamour \u2014 and the danger of it.", "title": "A Performer\u2019s Most Prized Possession: Edie Sedgwick\u2019s Hat", "authors": ["Emily Spivack", "The Story Of A Thing", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Taking destination dining to new heights, a celebrated Peruvian chef has just hung out his shingle 11,706 feet above sea level, where the entirety of his street address is \u201cascending 500 meters from the Archaeological Complex of Moray.\u201d Yet despite the enigmatic coordinates, and the fact that the nearest villages are all but concealed from the outside world, every taxista within a 100-mile radius will soon know these back roads by heart.\n\nThere is, after all, no concealing the resident chef: Virgilio Martinez, who also runs Central, the nine-year-old Lima institution that currently ranks fifth on the closely watched World\u2019s 50 Best Restaurants list. While he\u2019s unassuming in the extreme, the 40-year-old has already left a distinct footprint with his new Andean outpost, Mil, which opened at the end of February.\n\nHaving formed a co-op of sorts with the tiny nearby farming communities of Kacllaraccay and Mullaka\u2019s-Misminay he\u2019s aiming to chronicle and revive ancient local ingredients and food practices that might otherwise be lost to time. Among others in his merry band of preservationists are his wife P\u00eda Le\u00f3n, an acclaimed chef in her own right; his sister Malena Martinez, head of the group\u2019s native ingredient-cataloging operation; and Francesco D\u2019Angelo Piaggio, the staff anthropologist and community outreach consigliere who has the best backstory of the bunch: When he was still working on his thesis in a nearby rural community, his mo ther saw the Virgilio Martinez episode of \u201cChef\u2019s Table\u201d on Netflix and insisted her son do the same, given the gentlemen\u2019s eerily simpatico sensibilities. A series of emails and a job at Mil soon followed.\n\nThe result of the group\u2019s efforts is unlike anything else in my restaurant-going experience: Lunch (there is no dinner service as of yet) consisted of eight courses, a gustatory grand tour of altitudinous ecosystems, each stop an opportunity to use age-old ingredients and techniques to arrestingly modern effect.", "title": "A Peruvian Chef Who Conquered the World Scales Higher Heights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Meryl Meisler arrived in New York in 1975, when she was on the cusp of turning 24 and the city was on the brink of bankruptcy. Times Square had yet to be tamed, streets were dirty and all the federal government could do when asked for help was to tell the city \u2014 in the memorable formation of The New York Daily News \u2014 \u201cDrop dead.\u201d\n\nMs. Meisler loved it.\n\n\u201cI felt like I belonged,\u201d she said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t sure what I wanted to do, even though I had a teaching degree. Maybe because the city itself was out of joint. I had just come out as a lesbian, but I felt like I belonged here. I felt safe.\u201d", "title": "A Photographer\u2019s Search for Joy in Uncertain Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "You have been a commercial pilot for two decades \u2014 at Northwest Airlines and at Delta \u2014 and at both airlines, you have been the first African-American woman with the rank of captain. What kinds of reactions have you gotten from the people you meet?\n\nI often get high-fives and \u201cYou go!\u201d from some passengers. Several times, once I landed the plane, I got applause.\n\nPhoto\n\nEarlier in my career, on the other hand, I had one flight training instructor who made it clear he was not in favor of me moving forward. Also, working for a regional carrier, one time an elderly woman saw me and was very reluctant to fly on our plane, but she boarded and had no complaints.\n\nEventually I hope that seeing an African-American woman pilot is as normal as seeing people of all genders and ethnic backgrounds as passengers on a plane.\n\nWho were your predecessors and how do you help people in the next generation who also want to break glass ceilings?\n\nFirst of all, I have to salute the Tuskegee Airmen, the first black military aviators in the U.S. Army Air Corps. If not for those guys, I would not be a pilot. I am a member of its Cleveland chapter. Now, as the director of the Organization of Black Aerospace Professionals\u2019 Aviation Career Education Academy in Cleveland, I get great pleasure encouraging young people to pursue their dream of flying.\n\nAs the mother of three teenagers with another Delta pilot as a husband, how do you manage to juggle work and life?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy husband, Andr\u00e9 L. Johnson, and I had a nanny who worked for us 12 years. We let her go when the kids grew up.\n\nNow, we have a color-coded system of activity protocols to make sure everything and everyone is covered, just like we do at work. But if it doesn\u2019t get put on the calendar, it\u2019s not going to happen. Being on time counts too, just like at work. While I\u2019m traveling, between flights I\u2019ve done spelling tests with my kids on Skype.\n\nWhat do you like about this career?\n\nJust like when I was a kid, I marvel every time at the fact that I can make more than 100,000 pounds of materials fly \u2014 in my case, it\u2019s the Airbus A321.\n\nWhen we are leveled off cruising and just above the clouds, it still thrills me. You feel the speed of the aircraft because you\u2019re passing stationary clouds at speeds of about 500 miles per hour. And when you make a nice landing, it feels great.", "title": "A Pilot Who Has Broken 2 Glass Ceilings", "authors": ["Perry Garfinkel", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "For Korean New Yorkers of a certain age, there\u2019s a good chance they\u2019ve heard the phrase \u201cLet\u2019s go to Circle\u201d (or \u201cSeokeul-e gaja\u201d in Korean). The raucous club Circle has played an outsize role among young Korean-Americans for 10 years, though it was largely unknown outside of Asian-American circles.\n\nLast month, that phrase was uttered for perhaps the last time.\n\nThe party closed its doors on West 41st Street near Times Square on Feb. 18, after a three-day weekend that ushered in over 3,000 people, including regulars, curious first-timers, nostalgic out-of-towners flying in and celebrities including the Korean-American rapper Dumbfoundead.\n\n\u201cIn terms of Asian-centric clubs in the U.S., Circle is the most consistent, the longest-running and arguably the most successful,\u201d said Jaeki Cho, 28, a Queens native who was a producer of \u201cBad Rap,\u201d a documentary on Asian-American rappers; he is also the creative director of the sneaker boutique Alumni.\n\nDuring the club\u2019s final run, swiveling green laser lights dribbled from the ceiling onto the dance floor, raking over the heads of a well-dressed, inebriated and a predominantly Asian crowd. The D.J. churned out the club\u2019s signature formula of electronic dance music and Top 40 remixes, with the smoke machine expelling mist every couple of songs. Waiters ferried ornate fruit platters and Grey Goose bottles topped with sparklers to the V.I.P. tables.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCircle is a rite of passage for Asians in New York,\u201d said Michelle Choi, 24, a recent graduate from the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health. \u201cThe last weekend, everyone was trying to go and frantically experience it before it closed.\u201d", "title": "A Pioneering Times Square Asian-American Nightclub Closes", "authors": ["Alice Yin"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "She\u2019d had a fever. Our pediatrician told us to give Ruth Tylenol, which we did. The next morning she seemed fine. Her favorite support worker dropped by to read and help her color a birthday card for Asher, who was turning 1 the next day. But when Dana went downstairs to check on Ruth in the morning, her sheets were soaked with sweat and she wasn\u2019t breathing.\n\nIn the horror that followed, we called 911, but it was too late. Ruth was gone. Her neurologist believed that she had kernicterus, a condition that could have been what caused both her cerebral palsy and her deafness. It may have also damaged her hypothalamus, limiting Ruth\u2019s ability to fight the fever.\n\nIn the next aching weeks and months, my thoughts often turned to the safe soil of my childhood. I\u2019d grown up on a farm \u2014 running barefoot through the sheep pasture, riding my fat brown pony around the pond. I longed to plant a garden, something to nurture that would nurture me. But, living in Bath, one of Maine\u2019s most densely populated neighborhoods, our house was pinched between a busy road and a forested backyard.\n\nWhy not volunteer at a local farm, a friend suggested. On a slip of paper, she wrote the name of one where she bought vegetables, and I\u2019d set up this time to stop by.\n\nThe farmer spotted us across a frozen field and tromped over, springy brown hair twisting around her face. \u201cI\u2019m Lucretia,\u201d she said. \u201cYou\u2019re interested in working?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI nodded, telling her of my childhood farm. I didn\u2019t talk about Ruth, or how desperately I was hurting. Chasing a piglet that had escaped under the fence, Lydia and Asher were laughing. But I knew they were hurting too. Especially Lydia, who had been just three weeks older than Ruth. Lucretia invited me to come back in April. For two hours of work each week \u2014 plus a contribution to help with planting \u2014 I\u2019d receive a weekly box of organic vegetables from June through October.\n\nI promised to think about it but wasn\u2019t sure I had the energy. Of all the friends who\u2019d shared advice after Ruth died, not one had warned how exhausting grief could be. Some days, leaving the house was too much. But two weeks later, there I was, standing with Lucretia inside a plastic-covered hoop house at Milkweed Farm.\n\nWind snapped the flimsy walls and blew frozen mist across the fields outside, but inside was warm. Concrete-block-and-wire tables held trays of soil cubes \u2014 each indented with a small dimple. Lucretia cut an envelope to form a spout and sprinkled round, pebble-like eggplant seeds into them. Using the tip of a pencil, she nudged each seed into a hole and covered it with a pinch of soil.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWant to try?\u201d She handed me the envelope.\n\nFor the rest of the morning, all I had to think about was placing one seed into each hole. Two hours later, I felt more at peace than I had in months. The following week I planted meager dots of tomato seeds. Then, even tinier specks of onions. Soon, a miniature forest sprouted from the eggplant trays, tender leaves uncurling toward the light.\n\nAs the temperature rose, the earth came alive, and I worked in the fields while Lydia and Asher raced up the rows, searching for eggs from the few chickens who\u2019d escaped their enclosure to scamper about the garden. By midsummer, the farm had blossomed into a profusion of stalky pink echinacea flowers, sunshiny-yellow calendula buds, beds of ripening strawberries, fragrant mounds of chamomile and an intoxicating blanket of holy basil.\n\nEach week I carried home boxes of sun-ripened tomatoes, Swiss chard, turnips, cabbage, cucumbers, zucchini and flowers. But more than that, I carried home a renewed sense that even when the all the world appears bleak and lifeless, a flourishing future was still possible. I simply had to plant the seeds I\u2019d been given, to feed and water and shelter them, while waiting to discover what new life emerged.\n\nAt first, I\u2019d been fragile, wanting only to curl up and protect myself from any more pain or loss. But as I looked at the rows of vegetables and vines bursting with life around me, I knew the answer to grief was not in locking myself away but in opening myself to whatever came next. If a tiny seed could grow strong by reaching toward the light, maybe I could too.\n\nOne hot morning, Lucretia and I knelt in the garden together. Bees and butterflies flitted between the sunflowers. A stray chicken bobbed down the row as we pulled tough stalks of lamb\u2019s quarters, and I talked about Ruth \u2014 not just the loss of her but the joy of her too. How clever she was. And funny. And how incredibly much we loved her. Lucretia nodded, telling me about a friend who also had a child with disabilities. As she talked, I realized that the boy had gone to preschool with Ruth. Warmth at the memory softened my heart like the sun-warmed soil falling through my fingers.\n\nA burst of laughter made me turn. Lydia raced down a garden path, hand extended. In her outstretched fingers, she cupped the fragile brown shell of an egg. Asher tottered after her, golden light warming his cheeks. And I knew that although I would always carry the grief of losing Ruth, a life full of goodness lay ahead if only I would embrace it. The healing had begun.", "title": "A Place of Healing", "authors": ["Meadow Rue Merrill"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. space, Great Neck North plans to add a 97-spot student parking lot, which has come as welcome news to students like Josh Vilinsky, 17, a junior, who says he has to arrive nearly an hour before school just to find street parking for his $62,000 Mercedes coupe, a gift on his most recent birthday.\n\nThe school\u2019s plan to pave over one of its former athletic fields to create the lot, however, has provoked a backlash from residents who call the $652,000 project too expensive and say it will attract more traffic and deprive the neighborhood of precious green space.\n\nThere is also a philosophical objection: Providing more space to park further encourages a culture of entitlement in which expensive cars have become de facto accessories and help dictate social status among privileged students.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t see any justification for destroying a field to make a parking lot because of this assumption that every kid needs a parking spot,\u201d said Annie Mendelson, a neighbor who opposes the proposed parking lot. \u201cWhat are we teaching our kids?\u2019\u2019\n\nBut Dr. Teresa Prendergast, the superintendent of the Great Neck Public Schools, said that for high school seniors, driving had become a necessity, since many have jobs, internships and other after-school activities.\n\nThe high school has also added 200 students in the last decade \u2014 its enrollment rising to 1,141 students \u2014 as well as teachers and other staff members, and has long outgrown its existing parking capacity of about 100 spots, Dr. Prendergast said.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is a situation familiar to many New York-area schools, where officials, lacking the real estate to expand parking, use different strategies to try to make more room for student drivers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Greenwich High School in Connecticut, parking is in ever-higher demand as \u201cdriving has become more and more a rite of passage\u201d for seniors, said its headmaster, Chris Winters.\n\nThe school has about 650 seniors and 290 student spots, for which the school awarded 380 permits on a first-come, first-served basis this year.\n\n\u201cIt sounds like a recipe for disaster, but not every student drives everyday,\u201d Mr. Winters said. The permits cost $40 a semester and can be revoked for disciplinary reasons.\n\nSome schools do have plenty of parking, like Roslyn High School on Long Island, where nearly all 240 seniors who drive can get their own space.\n\nBut most high schools limit parking to seniors and offer permits by lottery or on a first-come, first-served basis. Further east on Long Island, Massapequa High School has nearly 600 seniors but only about 20 student parking spots that are distributed through a lottery.\n\nFew students even apply because those with driver\u2019s permits can only drive to and from school but cannot use their cars to come and go during free periods, said the Massapequa principal, Patrick DiClemente, citing parking lot safety as the reason the school imposed the rule. Instead, students compete for spots on surrounding residential streets, which has prompted many homeowners to request signs in front of their property forbidding parking during school hours.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCassidy Glum, a senior sitting in her 10-year-old Chrysler 300 near the school, said that one perquisite of being a senior was being able to enjoy some privacy during a free period, to study and use phones, rather than staying in school.\n\nAnother reason many high school upperclassmen would rather drive is to avoid taking a school bus \u2014 that big, yellow abomination known as the \u201closer cruiser\u201d is the ultimate embarrassment. Ms. Glum said she took the school bus recently while her car was being repaired, \u201cand when I told my friend I took the bus, she said, \u2018Are you kidding.\u2019\u201d\n\nRachel Ozari, 17, a senior at Great Neck North who drives a 2018 Jeep Cherokee, said that most conversations among teenagers begin with questions about the type of car they drive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaving a luxury car does not exactly divide the cool from the uncool, Ms. Ozari said, \u201cbut anything you can go fast in and show off with actually boosts your status.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHorace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, N.Y., has 360 seniors and 250 daily spots available to whoever claims them first, said the principal, Robert Rhodes. Some students recently proposed a space-sharing system for 40 coveted spots closest to the school.\n\nRelegated to off-campus parking, juniors at Horace Greeley have turned to \u201ca market solution\u201d by persuading nearby homeowners to rent them daytime driveway space for a small fee, Mr. Rhodes said. Some juniors have even paid seniors for parking, or use expired tags, despite the risk of being towed and fined by a company contracted by the school.\n\nWhen the tow truck is spotted, \u201cThe kids pick up their phones and text each other\u201d a warning, Mr. Rhodes said.\n\nAt Plainview-Old Bethpage John F. Kennedy High School on Long Island, bus ridership is low, with upperclassmen driving and younger students getting rides from parents, said Dr. Lorna Lewis, the district superintendent.\n\nThe school has 120 student parking spaces for 400 seniors. The spaces are administered by lottery to seniors who take a driving safety class, Dr. Lewis said. The idea of decorating student parking spots was floated recently, she said, and one student suggested emblazoning her space with the message: \u201cIf you can read this, I\u2019m late for class.\u201d\n\nAt Great Neck North, the school issues 137 parking passes on a first-come, first-served basis and only to the school\u2019s 285 seniors, of which perhaps 170 drive to school, Dr. Prendergast said. Students who cannot park on school property are left scrambling for street parking, leading to long walks from their cars and sometimes parking tickets.\n\nMs. Mendelson, the neighbor, said the school district did not notify residents about the project, but instead slipped it into a $68 million bond referendum with more than 100 items that was approved last year by voters in the school district.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 450 residents have signed a petition rejecting the parking lot, said Ms. Mendelson, who believes that the district should hold another vote on the project, which has yet to receive necessary approval from state education officials.\n\nBut Dr. Prendergast said the school district publicized the project extensively, including holding more than 30 public presentations.\n\nThe lot would replace a field that is no longer usable for athletics and is often muddy and a breeding ground for mosquitoes, said Dr. Prendergast, adding that a 30-foot-wide undisturbed natural border would remain around the lot, along with 60 new trees and a new drainage system.\n\nAs far as the necessity for the lot, she said, \u201cThe No. 1 issue is student safety.\u201d\n\nFor her part, Ms. Bazon noted that having a spiffy Mercedes does not help her claim a good parking space. She would prefer practicality over luxury any day.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d drive an old Honda,\u201d she said, \u201cas long as it gets me there.\u201d", "title": "A Problem for High Schools: More Cars, and Nowhere to Park Them", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "She also played the recent Armory Party at the Museum of Modern Art, where she wore a yellow jumpsuit by Christian Dior embroidered with mirrors. I\u2019m very close friends with the artist Rashaad Newsome, and his work is filled with all of that ornamentation. And I feel that probably seeped into my subconscious and brought it out of me.\u201d\n\nMs. Hunt grew up in a tightknit family in Chesapeake, Va. She began interning in New York while she was an undergraduate at the University of Virginia, landing an early position in the media relations department of Epic Records.\n\nAfter a stint teaching English in Mexico City and two years doing public relations for the New-York Historical Society, Ms. Hunt joined the communications office of MoMA PS1 in 2007. Who Nurtures Underrepresented Artists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The comic book community is teaming up again to raise money for Hurricane Maria relief efforts in Puerto Rico with the release of the anthology \u201cRicanstruction: Reminiscing and Rebuilding Puerto Rico\u201d on May 23. All profits from the book will benefit relief efforts.\n\nThe contributors to the anthology, published by Somos Arte, include industry stars like Denys Cowan, Gail Simone and Yanick Paquette. It will also include stories written by Rosario Dawson, Rub\u00e9n Blades and Sonia Manzano. The novelist Esmeralda Santiago also contributed a story, illustrated by Jon Woodard, about her grandfather, who lived through a hurricane that hit the island in 1928.\n\nOne of the highlights for Mr. Miranda-Rodriguez is that La Borinque\u00f1a, the Puerto Rican heroine he created in 2016, will be fighting alongside Batman, Superman, Wonder Woman and other DC Comics characters for the betterment of Puerto Rico. DC Comics allowed the use of their heroes because profits from the comic will benefit organizations like El Puente, a Brooklyn-based nonprofit group that will provide solar-powered lamps, clothing, food and other supplies to Puerto Rico.\n\nThe cover price for the 192-page book will be $19.99. Additionally, Lion Forge plans to match the first $25,000 it earns from the project.", "title": "A Puerto Rican Hero Joins With Wonder Woman and Others for Hurricane Relief", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The changes are a rare step back in a country that has moved aggressively to move official interactions online. More than 90 percent of Danes between 16 and 89 can use a government-issued digital ID to gain access to personal records or to communicate with the authorities. The system is often efficient: 1.3 million people logged on to see their annual tax return within 24 hours of release this month.\n\nBut the push to digitalize Denmark may have gone too far by offering a quick fix for marriage problems.\n\n\u201cHuman lives don\u2019t necessarily fit into a public-sector I.T. system,\u201d said Morten Hjelholt, an associate professor at IT University of Copenhagen who has studied how digitalization has affected the Danish society. \u201cIncreased digitalization with efficient communication between the state and its citizens doesn\u2019t always match different life situations.\u201d\n\nMr. Hjelholt sees two major exceptions: \u201cIt doesn\u2019t work in divorce and death.\u201d\n\nDigital death certificates, required in Denmark since 2007, lead to the immediate cancellation of passports, driver\u2019s licenses and digital IDs to prevent fraud.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKirsten Margrethe Kristensen, 69, was mistakenly declared dead by a doctor this month. \u201cMaking mistakes is human,\u201d she told DR, the national broadcaster. \u201cIt\u2019s more that one, just by a click, is out of the system and gone.\u201d\n\nThe quick divorce presents a similar problem, some officials said \u2014 particularly when children are involved.\n\n\u201cTime for reflection is important,\u201d Karin Nodgaard, the spokeswoman on social issues for the populist right-wing Danish People\u2019s Party, which is not a part of the governing coalition, told the news agency Ritzau. \u201cIt never hurts to be thoughtful \u2014 for neither parents nor children.\u201d\n\nNot everyone wants to instill a waiting period.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s patronizing to tell people, \u2018We don\u2019t believe you\u2019ve thought this through. You must think about it for another three months,\u2019 \u201d said Laura Lindahl, the social affairs spokeswoman for the Liberal Alliance, a junior partner in the governing coalition. \u201cMaking the road more tortuous and difficult doesn\u2019t achieve anything positive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSoren Sander, a psychologist who has studied the effects of divorce, said that children and adults alike suffer psychologically and physically from a breakup. His research, which has helped guide the mandatory counseling materials, measures anxiety, depression, visits to doctors and other indicators of distress.\n\n\u201cThere are indications that with intervention their well-being increases,\u201d Mr. Sander said.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say that divorces in Denmark are leaving the internet behind: While some counseling during the three-month reflection period takes place face to face, a mandatory course on the typical challenges of a divorce is available online and through an app.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t see the app as a replacement for consultations, but as a supplement,\u201d Mr. Sander said. \u201cEighty percent of divorces have an acceptable level of conflict. The app is for them.\u201d", "title": "A Quick Online Divorce for $60? Not So Fast, Denmark Says", "authors": ["Martin Selsoe Sorensen"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst: \u201cAs I prepare to leave government, I am struck by a recurring thought: It should not be this hard to serve your country,\u201d writes David J. Shulkin in The Times this morning. President Trump dismissed Shulkin yesterday from his post as secretary of veterans affairs.\n\nThe Russia story. The Times reports that President Trump\u2019s personal lawyer discussed pardoning Michael Flynn, Trump\u2019s former national security adviser, and Paul Manafort, his former campaign chairman. Writing in Just Security, Harvard Law School\u2019s Alex Whiting offers one legal interpretation: If presidential pardons were dangled in an attempt to keep the pair from cooperating with Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation into Trump\u2019s Russia ties, \u201cit should qualify as a potential act of obstruction of justice.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s because the president has the power to issue pardons \u2014 but not to secretly offer them in exchange for silence, argues Asha Rangappa, a former F.B.I. special agent. \u201cEven the immense powers of the president can\u2019t be used as a bargaining chip.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Quick Story About Baseball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "For years, geriatricians and researchers have sounded the alarm about the use of benzodiazepines among older adults. Often called \u201cbenzos,\u201d the problem drugs include Valium (diazepam), Klonopin (clonazepam), Xanax (alprazolam) and Ativan (lorazepam).\n\nThe cautions have had scant effect: Use of the drugs has risen among older people, even though they are particularly vulnerable to the drugs\u2019 ill effects. Like Ms. Falstein, many patients take them for years, though they\u2019re recommended only for short periods. The chemically related \u201cz-drugs\u201d \u2014 Ambien, Sonata and Lunesta \u2014 present similar risks.\n\nNow the opioid epidemic has generated fresh warnings, because pain relievers like Vicodin (hydrocodone with Tylenol) and OxyContin (oxycodone) are also frequently prescribed for older people. When patients take both, they\u2019re at risk for overdosing.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhy are opioids dangerous? They stop you from breathing, and they have more power to do that when you\u2019re also taking a benzo,\u201d said Keith Humphreys, a Stanford University researcher and co-author of a disturbing editorial about overuse and misuse of benzodiazepines last month in the New England Journal of Medicine.\n\nNumbers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention tell the story: In 1999, it tallied just 63 benzodiazepine-related deaths among those aged 65 and older. Almost 29 percent also involved an opioid. By 2015, benzo deaths in that age group had jumped to 431, with more than two-thirds involving an opioid. (Benzo-related deaths in all age groups totaled 8,791.) In 2016, the Food and Drug Administration issued a black-box warning about co-prescribing benzodiazepines and opioids, including those in cough products.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven patients taking the drugs exactly as prescribed can unwittingly wind up in this situation, since both sleep problems and chronic pain occur more frequently at older ages. \u201cA psychiatrist puts a woman on Xanax,\u201d Dr. Humphreys said. \u201cThen she hurts her hip, so her primary care physician prescribes Vicodin.\u201d\n\nBut fatal overdoses \u2014 which are a comparatively tiny number given the size of the older population \u2014 represent just one of many longtime concerns about these medications.\n\n\u201cSet aside the opioid issue,\u201d said Michael Schoenbaum, an epidemiologist at the National Institutes for Health. \u201cWay too many older Americans are getting benzos. And of those, many \u2014 more than half \u2014 are getting them for prolonged periods. That\u2019s just bad practice. They have serious consequences.\u201d\n\nProbably the most serious: falls and fractures, already a common danger for older people, because benzos can cause dizziness. They\u2019re also associated with auto accidents, given that they cause drowsiness and fatigue.\n\nMoreover, \u201cthey have a negative effect on memory and other cognitive function,\u201d says Dr. Donovan Maust, a psychiatrist at the Veterans Affairs Ann Arbor Health Care System. Some studies have shown an association with dementia, though experts call the evidence to date inconclusive.\n\nYet when Dr. Maust and his colleagues looked at a broad national sample of older adults, they found that the proportion of primary care and psychiatry visits that resulted in benzo prescriptions rose from 5.6 percent in 2003 to 2005 to 8.7 percent just seven years later \u2014 including 11.5 percent of visits by patients older than 85.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA study by Dr. Schoenbaum as a co-author and published in JAMA Psychiatry reported nearly nine percent of adults aged 65 to 80 taking benzos in 2008.\n\nIn both studies, women used the drugs more than men.\n\nPersuading older people that benzos can hurt them \u2014 and that alternative treatments like cognitive behavioral therapy and improved sleep hygiene can be as effective for insomnia, though they take longer \u2014 has proved an uphill fight.\n\nSome people take benzos for years without increasing the dose, so describing them as \u201cdependent\u201d or \u201chabituated\u201d \u2014 let alone \u201caddicted\u201d \u2014 often causes angry reactions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDrug problems are deeply stigmatized,\u201d Dr. Humphreys said. \u201cPeople feel it\u2019s insulting to say they might have a problem with a drug.\u201d\n\nNevertheless, even people who have taken benzos for extended periods without noticing any problem face potential harms at older ages, Dr. Humphreys noted.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a parallel with alcohol,\u201d he said. \u201cMaybe you had a double Scotch before dinner without problems through your 50s. In your 60s, you get lightheaded\u201d from the same amount, because older bodies metabolize drugs differently. (Alcohol, by the way, is another substance you don\u2019t want to combine with benzodiazepines.)\n\nPersuading users that they should stop is only the first step, however. \u201cWeaning someone off these things when they\u2019ve become habituated is incredibly difficult,\u201d Dr. Schoenbaum said.\n\nSignificant declines in benzo use among older people in Ontario, Canada, in Australia and in the Veterans Affairs health care system in the United States show that it can be done, with more cautious prescribing and programs to help users become ex-users.\n\nBut it\u2019s not easy.\n\n\u201cYou never, ever recommend that someone stop cold turkey,\u201d Dr. Maust said. That can bring withdrawal symptoms that include nausea, chills, anxiety, even delirium. \u201cYou taper down very gradually.\u201d\n\nCanadian researchers have demonstrated that some older users can taper off with an informational booklet and a 21-week tapering protocol, an approach the Veterans Affairs has begun using. Most patients should expect to spend six to 12 months detoxing, Dr. Maust said.\n\nBut some find it takes much longer, with rebound effects unlike those of other habituating drugs.\n\nWhen Ms. Falstein began experiencing \u201cjelly legs\u201d that left her too weak to stand for long, increased panic attacks, extreme fatigue and other health problems, she and her psychopharmacologist agreed that she should begin tapering off her benzos.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI thought I\u2019d be off them in a year, maybe two,\u201d Ms. Falstein said. But it has taken five so far, with the support of a Facebook group and a \u201ctaper friend\u201d she speaks to almost daily. Using a method called liquid titration, she has been able to discontinue Ativan and cut back to less than a daily milligram of Klonopin.\n\nThough she suffered a variety of debilitating symptoms, \u201cI was determined,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m going as quickly but as safely as I can.\u201d\n\nShe figures she has two years to go.", "title": "A Quiet Drug Problem Among the Elderly", "authors": ["Paula Span", "The New Old Age"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In the summer of 2016, Jeremiah made a cartoon and sent it to church leaders, depicting an elephant sitting on a man, squeezing out his insides. The elephant was labeled \u201cRacism\u201d; the man\u2019s insides were labeled \u201cGateway Church.\u201d\n\nPolitics From the Pulpit\n\nPastor Morris had become aware of the disquiet himself, mainly from listening to black pastors at other churches. Still, while they would meet and talk and pray, not a lot would happen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t talk about it much before because we didn\u2019t know,\u201d he said of whites generally, in a recent interview at one of Gateway\u2019s satellite campuses. \u201cWe just thought, \u2018O.K. there was a tremendous racial problem in America. The civil rights movement came, laws have been passed now and we\u2019re over that now. We passed it.\u2019 What has happened in the last few years is many white pastors are beginning to realize we never dealt with this scripturally. We never truly repented.\u201d\n\nIn July 2016, days after a black man enraged about police brutality shot and killed five Dallas police officers, Jeremiah\u2019s father had breakfast with one of the church\u2019s senior pastors. He spoke to him frankly about race and his frustration with the church\u2019s silence.\n\nAfter that breakfast, church staff began discussing how to face matters directly. In meetings over the coming weeks, black staff members would talk of their own past struggles with racism and the grim parts of American history that still went unacknowledged. A pastor at Ms. Pruitt\u2019s church campus pledged from the pulpit to tear down racism, one conversation at a time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen, the next month, Pastor Morris preached a message entitled \u201cStill.\u201d It began with a series of qualifications. God is still in control. There is no perfect political candidate. Voting is choosing the lesser of evils. Yes, there is gender inequality. And yes, there is a race problem in the country, though racism, implying hate, is not the right word. Pastor Morris said it was a subtler problem of prejudice.\n\nThen he focused attention on the upcoming presidential race.\n\n\u201cThe election,\u201d he said, \u201cis extremely important.\u201d\n\nThe country is in trouble financially; a critical Supreme Court appointment awaits; one of the major parties advocates using \u201ctaxpayer dollars, your dollars,\u201d for abortion. Evangelical Christians sit at home on Election Days, while \u201cthose who are trying to change our Constitution\u201d go to the polls, and look at what happens: Prayer is taken out of the schools.\n\n\u201cWe are going the wrong way,\u201d he concluded. \u201cWe need to get involved, we need to pray and we need to vote.\u201d\n\nHe never said to vote for Mr. Trump. But the implication in the sermon, and in the leaflets that were handed out at church, was lost on no one: that one must vote to uphold Christian values, and that the Republican Party platform reflected those values. And Mr. Trump was the Republican candidate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Pruitt sent messages to several white couples she had befriended at the church, telling them she was going to take some time off. She had become uneasy at a church, she told them, that speaks of overcoming racism on one Sunday \u201cand then turns around later and asks me to support\u201d Trump, who she believed was \u201ca racist candidate.\u201d\n\nOne of the couples invited her to come to their house. Sitting in the living room over a plate of brownies, Ms. Pruitt explained to the wife how disturbed she had been by the clear inference from the pulpit that she should support a candidate whose behavior and rhetoric were so offensive that she could not bring herself even to say his name.\n\nThe woman explained that a Trump victory had been prophesied and handed Ms. Pruitt a two-page printout, which began: \u201cThe Spirit of God says, \u2018I have chosen this man, Donald Trump, for such a time as this.\u2019\u201d Barack Obama, the woman continued, should never have been president, since he was not born a United States citizen. The visit ended with the woman suggesting that Ms. Pruitt\u2019s discomfort at the church was God telling her it was time to move on.\n\nMs. Pruitt never went back.\n\nJeremiah\u2019s family also left for good that summer, though he has heard that pictures of them still show up in church videos. They have not found a church since.\n\nOne young black woman who had been going to Gateway for some years said she has begun exploring Ethiopian Christian traditions. Another woman, a former church staff member who still goes to Gateway, cut back her attendance from five days a week to once a month, if that, and is now praying for guidance on whether to leave altogether.\n\nCarla McKissic Smith stayed until one Sunday in March 2017, when a guest speaker, a messianic rabbi from New Jersey, spoke of the 2016 election from the pulpit, saying that it \u201cthreatened to seal the acceleration of America\u2019s apostasy,\u201d but that Mr. Trump\u2019s victory was the fulfillment of God\u2019s covenant with Israel. \u201cIt was not the Russian intervention that determined it,\u201d he said to a congregation that frequently broke into applause and cheers. \u201cThe intervention was a bit higher.\u201d\n\nThree months later, Ms. Smith\u2019s father, the Rev. Dwight McKissic of Cornerstone Baptist Church in Dallas, would introduce a resolution condemning the alt-right at the annual Southern Baptist Convention in Phoenix. Unlike the resolutions condemning gambling and Planned Parenthood, his alt-right resolution didn\u2019t make it out of committee.\n\nPastor McKissic was told that racism had already been adequately addressed by the Southern Baptists, that the resolution was inflammatory and that sympathy for the alt-right was not an issue in the church. Word leaked, embarrassing the convention, and a new version of the resolution was reintroduced and overwhelmingly passed, albeit with some language changed and with an added tally of the Southern Baptists\u2019 past efforts against racism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt that point,\u201d Ms. Smith said, \u201cI was no longer surprised.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s win, which one elder at Gateway described as a \u201csupernatural answer to prayer,\u201d generated a frisson of excitement at the church. Pastor Morris told the congregation that he was one of Mr. Trump\u2019s faith advisers. The church was a sponsor of an inaugural ball in January 2017.\n\nJelani Lewis, one of the two black campus pastors, knew this was creating unease among many black members of Gateway. A black deacon approached him at one point and asked how he should reconcile his trust in Pastor Morris with \u201csome of the things that I\u2019m seeing from the current president.\u201d We trust in God, Pastor Lewis assured him, and we can trust in the heart of our pastor.\n\n\u2018A Lack of Understanding\u2019\n\nAs a tumultuous 2017 unfolded, Pastor Morris understood that some wanted him to address race directly.\n\n\u201cAs I prayed about it as I talked with black pastor friends of mine, I realized I don\u2019t really understand the depth of the pain they feel,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is personal to them \u2014 it was history to me. I would talk to my friend and it was personal to him because it was his great-grandfather.\u201d\n\nIn October 2017, he preached a message entitled \u201cA Lack of Understanding.\u201d Addressing \u201call the ignorant white people,\u201d and acknowledging his own past grappling with prejudice, the pastor listed reasons that racism was evil \u2014 among them that it was an affront to God\u2019s creation, given that Adam and Eve were probably brown-skinned. A video played of a black pastor talking of the racism he experienced as a child in East St. Louis in the 1960s. Pastor Morris concluded by urging people of color in the congregation to spread out and pray with whites in small groups.", "title": "A Quiet Exodus: Why Black Worshipers Are Leaving White Evangelical Churches", "authors": ["Campbell Robertson"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "These aren\u2019t pesky little errors. Trump \u2014 who can get comprehensive briefings on any subject, just by saying the word, but prefers to watch \u201cFox & Friends\u201d instead \u2014 has a picture of world trade in his head that bears as little resemblance to reality as his vision of an America overrun by violent immigrants.\n\nAnd his notion of what to do about these imaginary problems amounts to no more than a bar stool rant. \u201cTrade wars are good, and easy to win,\u201d he tweeted, where he clearly thinks that \u201cwinning\u201d means selling more to the other guy than he sells to you. That\u2019s not how it works.\n\nIn fact, even if we could eliminate U.S. trade deficits with tariffs, there would be lots of unpleasant side effects: sharply higher interest rates wreaking havoc on real estate and those with large debts (hello, Jared), and a sharply higher dollar inflicting severe harm on exporters, like many of America\u2019s farmers. And a full-scale trade war would disrupt international supply chains, displacing huge numbers of workers: The U.S. government\u2019s own estimates say that exports to the European Union, Canada and Mexico support 2.6 million, 1.6 million and 1.2 million American jobs respectively.\n\nWill Trump actually follow through on his ranting? Nobody knows. Maybe the adults in the administration, if there are any left, will find some bright, shiny objects to distract him \u2014 say, meaningless \u201cconcessions\u201d by Canada and Mexico that convince him that he\u2019s won big. But whether or not the trade war actually happens, Trump\u2019s display of belligerent ignorance ought to worry us a lot.\n\nFor one thing, talking tough and stupid on trade in itself damages U.S. credibility: If we go around threatening our most important allies with retaliation against policies they don\u2019t even have, how can we expect them to trust us \u2014 or support us \u2014 on anything else?\n\nBeyond that, is there any reason to believe that Trump\u2019s belligerent ignorance stops with trade? Actually, we know that he\u2019s just as bombastic and clueless (with added racism) when it comes to crime, and there\u2019s no reason to believe that he\u2019s any better on real national security issues.\n\nListening to a garrulous old guy spout nonsense is annoying in the best of circumstances. But when this particular old guy controls the world\u2019s largest military, nukes included, it\u2019s downright scary.", "title": "Opinion | A Ranting Old Guy With Nukes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "In spite of the changes, \u201cour goal is to keep this area gritty,\u201d Ms. Mackay said. \u201cIt would have been far less costly to demolish all of these old buildings and start new. We want to keep the incredible fabric of the area as it has been for more than 100 years.\u201d\n\nThe city has also made provisions to stimulate real estate development and economic growth. Developers wishing to remodel a warehouse or historic building can apply for local grants. By 2023, an extension to the city\u2019s South Central Light Rail will link the district to downtown and beyond, Ms. Mackay said. And the Warehouse District Council, a coalition of local businesses and supporters, meets regularly to discuss ways to brand the neighborhood.\n\nNew housing will open in a couple of years. JMA Ventures, a real estate investment firm, will break ground this spring on a 276-unit apartment complex. The project will cost $60 million to $80 million and feature a rooftop pool and glass co-working spaces. Developers intend to incorporate recycled brick and wooden trusses to blend in with the historic surroundings, said Todd Chapman, the president and chief executive of JMA Ventures.\n\nSupporters hope the nostalgic back story is attractive enough to lure many to live and work here.\n\nIn the first half of the 20th century, trains stopped at the warehouses to pick up and transport local produce. As trucks and freeways became more widespread, shipping routes were diverted into other communities. By the 1950s, the warehouses were obsolete.\n\nBefore 2000, early developers in the district such as Michael Levine, the owner of Levine Machine and Mike Cowley, the president of Cowley Companies, purchased some of the crusty relics with the mission to preserve the area\u2019s architectural history and reoccupy the warehouses. Mr. Levine, a self-described \u201cbuilding sculptor,\u201d said the warehouses were called \u201cbulldozer bait.\u201d For two decades, he has bought and saved seven warehouses, keeping some while selling others to buyers who shared his vision.\n\nIn 2007, Steve Rosenstein, an entrepreneur, and his wife, Andi, got their hands on a Levine warehouse, once a Budweiser beer distribution center. Both said the brick building had been love at first sight because it reminded them of the ragtag structures in their hometown, Chicago. Three years later, the Rosensteins opened the Duce, a restaurant and lounge with a boxing ring, a vintage camper where the food is cooked and a boutique selling retro-chic merchandise.\n\n\u201cThere was nobody here but us on this little island,\u201d Mr. Rosenstein said. \u201cIt was scary, and business was slow.\u201d", "title": "A Renewal for Phoenix\u2019s Warehouse District: Polished but Gritty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "On Chinese social media, GIFs and other online riffs inspired by Ms. Liang\u2019s epic eye roll quickly proliferated, and by evening they were being deleted by government censors. Ms. Liang\u2019s name became the most-censored term on Weibo, the microblogging platform. On Taobao, the freewheeling online marketplace, vendors began selling T-shirts and cellphone cases bearing her image.\n\nIn one video, three men did a deadpan recreation of the incident. On Ms. Liang\u2019s Weibo account \u2014 which quickly soared to 100,000 followers and kept climbing \u2014 supporters flooded her with jokes and comments of support.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
