Another saluted \u201can eye-rolling representing all people who don\u2019t dare to do so.\u201d\n\nOn the messaging app WeChat, people jokingly separated Ms. Liang and the questioner into two parties based on the color of their clothing. Many said they supported the blue party, in reference to Ms. Liang. The questioner, Zhang Huijun, wore red \u2014 the color of China and the Chinese Communist Party.\n\nBefore posing her question to the government official, Xiao Yaqing, Ms. Zhang had introduced herself as the operating director of American Multimedia Television U.S.A., a Los Angeles-based broadcaster that has had partnerships with Chinese state-run television in the past, according to its website. Its president, Jason Quin, also lists himself on LinkedIn as the president of the Confucius Institute of Education, which describes itself as a nonprofit organization working on entrepreneurial education.\n\nNews outlets with ties to the Chinese government are often chosen to ask questions of China\u2019s rarely available political leaders at the National People\u2019s Congress, while more mainstream local and foreign outlets are seldom called on. Neither Ms. Zhang\u2019s employer nor Ms. Liang\u2019s responded to a request for comment on the incident Tuesday.\n\nFor the record, Ms. Zhang\u2019s question was as follows:\n\n\u201cThe transformation of the responsibility of supervision for state assets is a topic of universal concern. Therefore, as the director of the State-Owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, what new moves will you make in 2018? This year marks the 40th anniversary of the Reform and Opening-up Policy, and our country is going to further extend its openness to foreign countries. With General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party Xi proposing the One Belt One Road Initiative, state-owned enterprises have increased investment to countries along the route of One Belt One Road, so how can the overseas assets of state-owned enterprises be effectively supervised to prevent loss of assets? What mechanisms have we introduced so far, and what\u2019s the result of our supervision? Please summarize for us, thank you.\u201d", "title": "A Reporter Rolled Her Eyes, and China\u2019s Internet Broke", "authors": ["Paul Mozur"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhy shouldn\u2019t Southern food be elevated?\u201d Mr. Jordan said. \u201cI\u2019m trying to give a history lesson .\u201d Mr. Jordan noted that during American slavery, workers ate field food while, at the same time, slave cooks prepared fancy dinners for plantation owners and visiting dignitaries. At JuneBaby, he presents both aspects of the era \u2014 by offering hoe cakes, grits and pig intestines, as well as artisan pork loin and heirloom ingredients \u2014 and focuses on the African roots of Southern cuisine.\n\nDuring a recent visit, we started with cocktails inspired by poems by Langston Hughes \u2014 mine was called Fire-Caught: \u201cShe fell, fire-caught, into the flame.\u201d (The bar menu also features moonshine and classic Southern drinks.) We devoured charred okra with peanuts and strips of fried pig ears over pecan butter and honey \u2014 the dance of sweet and salty was seductive in both starters. A side of applewood-smoked carrots, served atop collard greens and tahini sauce, could have been a pleasing entree of its own.\n\nAfter a bit of a wait (the restaurant was hopping, even early that weekday evening), the mains arrived. A bright ring of shrimp bisque surrounded semolina-crusted catfish on a mound of Geechie Boy grits from South Carolina. Pork loin from local Carlton Farms was brined then grilled, accompanied by grilled leek halves and cabbage that had been charred and braised.\n\nFor dessert, we enjoyed the decadent Kentucky chocolate cake with blackberry jam and a frozen strawberry-lime \u201cflip\u201d (the chef used to make them with Kool-Aid but now uses fresh fruit). Flipping it out of the paper cup and eating it by hand, like Mr. Jordan used to do in his youth, probably would have worked better than using a big spoon.\n\nIntense flavors \u2014 smoky, charred, sweet, salty, nutty, spicy \u2014 fused together in an outstanding meal that evoked images of the American South and Africa. It may have been the tastiest history lesson ever.", "title": "A Restaurant That Marries Seattle Ingredients to Southern Cuisine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s what you need to know about Samsung\u2019s newest flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S9, in five words: The device plays it safe.\n\nThe S9, which arrives in stores this month, looks nearly identical to its immediate predecessor, the Galaxy S8. It is essentially a replay of last year\u2019s big Samsung phone \u2014 with a few tweaks.\n\nThe main differences are an improved camera and a feature called AR Emoji, which uses a photo of your face to create an animated version of yourself making various expressions, like crying in a bathtub or shaking your head. The phone\u2019s price is steep: $720 or, for a version with a slightly larger screen, $840.\n\nThat\u2019s underwhelming when you consider that Samsung, the largest phone maker, has been on the bleeding edge of smartphone innovation. The South Korean company was the first to bring us \u201cphablets,\u201d or big-screen phones, and it popularized phones with digital pens.", "title": "A Review of the Samsung Galaxy S9, in Emoji", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cBring Back Asylums?\u201d (Science Times, March 6) highlights the need for adequate care and treatment for people with serious mental illness. The anti-institutional people quoted have been saying the same thing for many decades. Their observations were true two generations ago.\n\nToday, psychiatric hospitals do not smell foul; patients often have more freedoms day to day than do individuals with similar disorders who live outside hospitals; and patients in hospitals have more \u201ceyes watching\u201d to protect them from abuse than do any people with serious mental illness living outside of hospitals.\n\nWhile hospitals are expensive, community treatment is too. The oft-stated annual cost comparison, repeated in the article \u2014 $150,000 in a hospital and $30,000 in the community \u2014 has never been true. When you add up the total cost of care and treatment for a person with serious mental illness in the community \u2014 housing; food; outpatient psychiatric and medical treatment; dental care; transportation; acute psychiatric hospitalizations; police, sheriff, fire department, ambulance and court costs; leisure activities; and others \u2014 the cost has been shown to be about the same.\n\nI don\u2019t know anyone who is advocating a return to asylums that once housed 1,000 to 16,000 patients each. We need inpatient treatment for those who need that level of care and non-institutional treatment for those who need less intensive services. With the proper balance, we would not need jails and prisons to house people who belong in care settings. And with the proper balance, we might make some inroads into stigma.", "title": "Opinion | A Revived Debate Over Asylums", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Artists not only make the work that is exhibited at museums like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but they also seek out art and historical objects in such collections as a source for inspiration and research. And so we reached out to artists for their views on the new fee policy. Here are edited excerpts from some of their responses.\n\nPhoto\n\nMy concern is that when visitors to the Met are obligated to pay a hefty admission, they will understand their experience as [a commercial] transaction. When public museum collections and exhibitions are free, then the public feels emboldened to experiment with interpretation and meaning. It also allows for repeated viewing. Once money arbitrates the museum experience, we become consumers and not interpreters or storytellers. \u2014 Michelle Grabner, artist, Milwaukee, and artistic director of FRONT International: Cleveland Triennial for Contemporary Art, July 14 through Sept. 30.\n\nPhoto\n\nI understand that people would think the Met should be free, as I do. But in reality, a museum can only squeeze so much out of the Kochs and the Sacklers and then you\u2019re on your own. It\u2019s a symptom of a systemic problem: monetizing things that should be a right, like health care, education and, now, culture. Why wouldn\u2019t people expect culture to catch up with the rest of it all, and the mall-ing of New York City? We will get used to it, as we have so much in this last year. And that will be that. Sad but true. \u2014 Ross Bleckner, New York\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen I lived in New York in the 1980s, economically it was very bad for me. But I would come to the Met all the time and pay a penny. And when I could afford to I paid more. When I was back in China, I would very proudly show them this pay-as-you-wish policy as an example of what was positive about the U.S., that even in this capitalistic society, there was a door, a light. To stand in front of a Van Gogh or a Jackson Pollock, or African sculpture, it gave you hope and you were not judged by your economic status but by how much you loved those works. It was a treasure, not a privilege. This new way totally ruins this belief. It\u2019s like taking the jacket off a poor person. If they do this, I will never go to the Met. Am I calling for a boycott? No. But I myself will not go. \u2014 Ai Weiwei, Berlin\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe very artists we are being asked to pay to see, would in today\u2019s time be the least likely to afford the fee for entry. I can distinctly remember visiting the Pompidou and other Paris museums. As a [young] artist, I didn\u2019t have to pay. It was a shock and then a relief when the money I had cobbled together could go back in my pocket. It was not only critical as \u201cresearch\u201d for my craft; that moment empowered me as a human. It said that not only did I matter, but the role of artists also mattered. Artists generally don\u2019t occupy that space in American society. What are we valuing in this difficult political and economic moment? And for young people, especially little black and brown bodies, they are receiving more and more messages that they don\u2019t belong. \u2014 Amanda Williams, Chicago, an artist and architect, will be an exhibitor at the United States pavilion at the 2018 Venice Architecture Biennale in May.\n\nPhoto\n\nPay-what-you-wish, a revered tradition of accessibility that should be a source of pride, is now falling in line with limiting access to health care, restrictive immigration, environmental deregulation, and the ever-increasing economic divide. \u2014 Nari Ward, New York", "title": "A Right or a Privilege? Artists Speak Out on the Met Policy", "authors": ["Laura Van Straaten"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Albertalli, who is also a clinical psychologist, said she based Simon on herself and her high school experiences. Her work with gay and lesbian children also gave her, she said, \u201ca general sense of some of the issues that some kids in the community were grappling with.\u201d But her true inspiration for the novel was the birth of her first son in 2012. \u201cAt the very least, whoever he turns out to be, if he needs this message from his mom, this book will be here,\u201d she said.\n\nL.G.B.T.Q. audiences want to see characters who reflect their lives and experiences. (Forgive the personal aside, but this is the type of movie I\u2019ve been looking for since I was growing up \u2014 my first encounter was a small, tragic gay character in \u201cPump Up the Volume,\u201d from 1990 \u2014 and I\u2019m sure I\u2019m not alone.) Ms. Albertalli made note of the website LGBTQ Reads, curated by the author Dahlia Adler, which suggests books for all ages. \u201cIt\u2019s really exciting seeing the conversations in YA that are happening around representation.\u201d\n\nFor gay readers, one line in Ms. Albertalli\u2019s novel is especially resonant. Simon thinks, \u201cIn reality, I\u2019m not the leading guy. Maybe I\u2019m the best friend,\u201d and Ms. Albertalli said, \u201cIt was almost as if all these creative people read that line and they were like, \u2018O.K., Simon, let me prove you wrong.\u2019\u201d\n\nOne of those creative types is Greg Berlanti, the director of \u201cLove, Simon.\u201d An executive producer of television shows starring DC Comics heroes, Mr. Berlanti remembered telling studio executives in his initial meetings with 20th Century Fox, \u201cI think it\u2019s so cool that you guys are committing to making a movie like this.\u201d He also said, \u201cI\u2019m sort of surprised that one doesn\u2019t already exist.\u201d\n\nWorking on the film was an emotional experience for him. \u201cIt was filling a void I didn\u2019t even know that I needed filled,\u201d Mr. Berlanti said. \u201cIt was making me feel something that I couldn\u2019t quite identify.\u201d", "title": "A Romantic Comedy About a Gay Teenager? What Took So Long?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "By comparison, the United States is still uncertain how to make use of its cyberweapons after spending billions of dollars to build an arsenal. It is concerned that the Russians \u2014 along with the Chinese, the Iranians and the North Koreans \u2014 could easily retaliate against any attack, striking American banks, utilities, stock markets and communications networks.\n\nAnd in the nuclear sphere, the Trump administration has yet to offer a strategy to contain or deter Russia beyond simply matching the weapons buildup. Mr. Trump himself has largely remained silent about his vision to contain Russian power, and has not expressed hope of luring Moscow into new rounds of negotiations to prevent a recurrent arms race.\n\nThe threat that Russia poses on both fronts has helped push the United States to declare a fundamental shift on national security: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis asserted in January that \u201cgreat power competition,\u201d not terrorism, is now the primary American focus.\n\nWashington\u2019s response \u2014 at least in the nuclear realm \u2014 also harks back to the Cold War era: a cycle of move and countermove. This time, however, it involves not just building larger stockpiles, but also developing new types of weapons of greater sophistication, matched with more advanced missile defenses.\n\n\u201cPutin has become the best friend of the U.S. nuclear arms industry,\u201d said nonproliferation expert Gary Samore. He negotiated with the Russians during the Clinton administration, when optimism ran high that the era of nuclear competition was over, and again during the Obama administration, after Mr. Putin had begun Moscow\u2019s current nuclear modernization.\n\nThe Pentagon believes that many of the new plans that Mr. Putin announced last week to bolster his arsenal \u2014 including undersea nuclear torpedoes, nuclear cruise missiles and other new weapons \u2014 are years away from deployment. He has called his new missiles \u201cinvincible,\u201d as some can evade missile defenses, and started a contest to name them.\n\nMr. Putin has blamed the United States\u2019 failure to embrace past arms control treaties as the reason for his buildup. But he has particularly complained about American nuclear defenses, which he said were aimed as much at Russia as they were at North Korea. American officials have said that is a wild misstatement of the technology\u2019s reach.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn his State of the Union speech in January, Mr. Trump demanded that Congress \u201cmodernize and rebuild our nuclear arsenal.\u201d That was followed in February by the administration\u2019s Nuclear Posture Review, which was more specific. It called for new, low-yield nuclear weapons that it justified on the basis of recent Russian advances. It also described in detail a once top-secret Russian autonomous nuclear torpedo that is designed to cross the Pacific.\n\nAdditionally, the nuclear review abandoned earlier promises by the Obama administration that nuclear weapons would be a diminishing part of American security and defense. \u201cPast assumptions that our capability to produce nuclear weapons would not be necessary and that we could permit the required infrastructure to age into obsolescence have proven to be mistaken,\u201d the document said.\n\nPhoto\n\nDrafts of a new missile defense strategy, which may be published later this month, include suggestions that the program may now turn to developing missile defenses against Russia and China, not just countering states like North Korea with smaller arsenals.\n\n\u201cWe must no longer think in terms of building just \u2018limited\u2019 missile defense capabilities,\u201d concluded a report that was issued last year by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank. \u201cThe United States should begin the journey to develop a next-generation missile defense.\u201d\n\nIt called for pursuing a \u201cspace-based kill layer\u201d that would try to shoot down swarms of enemy warheads and missiles \u2014 a step that would go beyond the Reagan administration\u2019s \u201cStar Wars\u201d research on space arms and no doubt prompt new rounds of reaction from Mr. Putin and the Russian military.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nParticularly striking is the absence of much interest in Washington or Moscow for arms control talks.\n\nFrom President John F. Kennedy\u2019s time in office through President Barack Obama\u2019s, new treaties were negotiated that first limited atmospheric testing, then the numbers of weapons that could be deployed. The result was an 85 percent decline in the number of nuclear weapons in the world.\n\nBut the most recent arms reduction treaty, called New Start, expires in early 2021. Mr. Trump has not expressed interest in renewing it. And there is evidence that even before its scheduled sunset, expensive new cycles of technological action and reaction are beginning to take shape.\n\nOver the past few months, most talk of restraint has been cast to the wind as Mr. Putin and Mr. Trump take steps to rebuild their arsenals, according to arms control advocates. Doing so portends a new generation of nuclear weapons, as such moves and countermoves create a rationale for building more.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLisbeth Gronlund, a senior scientist at the Union of Concerned Scientists, based in Cambridge, Mass., said Mr. Putin\u2019s announcement last week \u201cfurther ratchets up what is clearly a new arms race, making the world a more dangerous place.\u201d\n\nBut what worries veterans of that Cold War is less the new technology than the old rhetoric.\n\n\u201cNone of this changes the fundamental picture of what the U.S. and Russia do to each other,\u201d Matthew Bunn, a Harvard professor who is one of the directors of the Managing the Atom project, told a group of journalists at the Nieman Foundation in Cambridge on Friday.\n\nHe said what is changing \u201cis the degree of tension\u201d that revives the dangers of miscalculations that could lead to military action \u2014 the great fear at the height of the Cold War during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s.\n\nThe cyberchallenge is the newest one, and thus is not captive to the strategies of past generations. But in public statements in recent weeks, Mr. Trump\u2019s top intelligence officials have conceded that the president has yet to discuss strategies with them to prevent the Russians from interfering in the midterm elections this year. Mr. Trump has expressed severe doubts that the Russians meddled in 2016, contradicting the conclusions of his intelligence officials.\n\nTwo days before General Nakasone\u2019s hearing last week, the man he would replace at the N.S.A. and Cyber Command \u2014 Adm. Michael S. Rogers \u2014 offered striking testimony in what is likely to be his last public appearance on Capitol Hill before leaving office.\n\nFour years ago, after he took command, Admiral Rogers said one of his goals was to assure that American adversaries would \u201cpay a price\u201d for their cyberactions against the United States that \u201cwill far outweigh the benefit\u201d derived from hacking. He also frequently said that the retaliation might not necessarily be a counter-cyberstrike, but could involve economic sanctions or diplomatic isolation.\n\nHowever, last week Admiral Rogers conceded that his own test had not been met.\n\nPressed about what pressure he had put on the Russians, he said: \u201cWe\u2019re taking steps, but we\u2019re probably not doing enough.\u201d He also dismissed sanctions that Congress approved last year \u2014 and that Mr. Trump has failed to impose \u2014 as insufficient to change \u201cthe calculus or the behavior\u201d of Mr. Putin.\n\nAt General Nakasone\u2019s confirmation hearing two days later, Senator Ben Sasse, a Nebraska Republican, said that \u201cthe problem is not technical,\u201d but political, given the United States\u2019 impressive cyberarsenal.\n\n\u201cWe are not responding in any way that\u2019s adequate to the challenge we face,\u201d Mr. Sasse said.", "title": "A Russian Threat on Two Fronts Meets an American Strategic Void", "authors": ["David E. Sanger", "William J. Broad"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "The Room\n\nMost rooms at the Hotel Californian come with one king bed; my mother and I, visiting midweek in November, were able to reserve one of the few double queen rooms with a view. It wasn\u2019t the best \u2014 those go to the suites that face the beach \u2014 but our spacious third-floor room had a veranda with armchairs from which to watch ducks on a greenish creek . The interior was lavishly decorated with oil-rubbed bronze lamps and patterned tile \u2014 the hotel imported more than one million pieces from Morocco \u2014 but some accents, like the brass snakes above the bed, verged on garish. USB ports by the beds offered an easy way to charge devices; other in-room gadgetry proved more difficult. The Nespresso coffee machine was maddeningly difficult to master, even though I use a similar model at home, and ejected every other espresso capsule without dispensing anything.\n\nThe Bathroom\n\nLaser-cut panels framed the shower, furthering the Moroccan theme, and while the shower stall was large enough, given the considerable floor space, the lack of a bathtub was curious. The double sinks and marble countertops left plenty of space for our toiletries. The best part of the bathroom: the plush, microfiber bathrobes by the Italian manufacturer La Bottega.", "title": "A Santa Barbara Hotel With Ocean Views and Artful Cuisine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBrownsville is a quintessential example of a transitional neighborhood,\u201d he said. \u201cI have Christine to thank for knowing the option to have a three-bedroom for half a million even existed.\u201d\n\nA year ago, the couple began investigating the area\u2019s housing stock \u2014 primarily two-story, three-bedroom rowhouses. \u201cIt was a date type of thing,\u201d Mr. Morris said. \u201cWe would go to open houses, go have brunch somewhere and share notes.\u201d\n\nMr. Morris drives to work at a technology company in Long Island City, so he wanted a parking spot. Ms. Williams, a graduate of Howard University who has a graduate degree from Teachers College, Columbia, wanted a yard so they could adopt a dog. Brownsville\u2019s rowhouses had both.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast summer, they visited a house on Legion Street, flipped by a developer, for $489,000. It included something scarce \u2014 a finished basement.\n\nAt that point, Mr. Morris\u2019s reserves had been depleted by the Danbury purchase, so they did not bid. (He was familiar with Danbury, having worked at Duracell in nearby Bethel.) \u201cI knew how much money we needed to save to do 10 percent down, and we weren\u2019t there yet,\u201d he said.\n\nMonths later, the house returned to the market. \u201cI look at Zillow, StreetEasy, Redfin, Trulia and Realtor every day in the markets that I have properties in,\u201d Mr. Morris said. \u201cI do it out of passion, and I feel it is a duty of mine as a passive real-estate investor.\u201d\n\nBy now the couple were able to make a offer. They eagerly offered the asking price, which had dropped to $475,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is high anxiety,\u201d Mr. Morris said. \u201cWe went from not even thinking we were going to get a home to thinking we might get the home we were drooling over.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo their dismay, the sellers went with someone on a waiting list \u2014 for $475,000.\n\n\u201cI was a little put off that there was no bidding war,\u201d Mr. Morris said. \u201cWe were willing to go higher if given the opportunity, but we were told flat-out no. We might have gone to $505,000 or $510,000 for this house. We mourned that.\u201d\n\nMr. Morris was motivated by the loss. He immediately lined up several places to see.\n\nOne house, for $450,000, on Thomas S. Boyland Street, lacked a basement and was easily dismissed. \u201cIt had something to do with bedrock,\u201d Mr. Morris said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe couple initially liked a rowhouse on Powell Street, for $429,000, with an open layout on the main floor. Then they realized a kitchen renovation had eliminated a half-bathroom.\n\nOne bathroom is common in three-bedroom city apartments, but in a two-story house, \u201cthat is a completely weird layout choice,\u201d Mr. Morris said.\n\nMs. Williams was put off by the clutter in the house and its unfinished basement. \u201cThey had a lot of stuff,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd finishing a basement is an expensive project.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother, similar rowhouse was also priced at $429,000. Many of the rooms had wood paneling. \u201cThat is not a common New York City aesthetic at all,\u201d Mr. Morris said. \u201cI\u2019ve seen log cabins with less wood.\u201d\n\nBut \u201cwe could get everything we liked about Legion Street for less, and Christine didn\u2019t take a lot of convincing.\u201d\n\nIn the winter, the couple bought the house for the asking price. It had been built in the mid-1980s as part of the Nehemiah program, which constructed houses on vacant city land.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey thought the wood could be removed easily, but every plank was securely nailed, so they painted it instead. On the main floor, they added beams and recessed lights to the ceiling.\n\nMr. Morris keeps his drum set in the finished basement. He is happy for a place to leave it out, increasing the likelihood he will play.\n\n\u201cWe have so much space I can\u2019t find anything, relative to everything being within arm\u2019s length before,\u201d he said.\n\nHe is thrilled to no longer be a landlord renting from a landlord. \u201cI finally own the place I live in, and I share it with Christine,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is something I dreamed about. But the region braced for impact all the same.\n\nThe storm was expected to intensify on Wednesday as it moved north from the Mid-Atlantic into New England. The National Weather Service, which issued a winter storm warning for the region, anticipated Tuesday afternoon that the Baltimore area would receive two to five inches of snow, Philadelphia four to six, New York City six to eight and Boston one to two.\n\nLarger accumulations were expected outside the major cities: 12 to 18 inches in New York\u2019s Orange, Putnam and Rockland Counties; Allentown, Pa.; and parts of North Jersey, northwestern Connecticut, and Central and Western Massachusetts.", "title": "A Second Winter Storm Is Coming. How Much Snow? \u00af\\_(\u30c4)_/\u00af", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "As the verdant hills of Wakanda are secretly enriched with the fictional metal vibranium in \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d your average backyard also has hidden superpowers: Its soil can absorb and store a significant amount of carbon from the air, unexpectedly making such green spaces an important asset in the battle against climate change.\n\nBackyard soils can lock in more planet-warming carbon emissions than soils found in native grasslands or urban forests like arboretums, according to Carly Ziter, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\n\nThe results of her research, published Tuesday in the journal Ecological Applications, were something of a surprise, given that those of us who have yards generally don\u2019t think of them as \u201cnature,\u201d or as especially beneficial to the environment. But at least in this case, the things we enjoy for ourselves are also helping the community at large.\n\nMs. Ziter studied the powers of yards by knocking on doors in Madison and asking residents to let her sample their backyard soil. Parents would often send their children outside to observe Ms. Ziter\u2019s work. \u201cThey would say, \u2018Oh, there\u2019s a scientist in the yard, go see what she\u2019s doing,\u2019\u201d she said, laughing. \u201cAll of a sudden there would be three small children and a dog surrounding me when I\u2019m taking soil samples.\u201d", "title": "A Secret Superpower, Right in Your Backyard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "CARPENTRAS, France \u2014 Since Roman times, Jews have lived in this town in northern Provence, which lies on an ancient trade route from Marseille to Bruges, Belgium. This year, about 50 people will hold a communal Passover Seder at the Carpentras Synagogue, built in 1367 and one of the oldest active synagogues in Europe.\n\nToday\u2019s congregation has about 100 members, many with roots in North Africa; their Seder traditions include salmon tagine and a feast of vegetable salads. But Gilberte Levy, who can trace her family tree here back to the 1600s, will also cook some of the kosher recipes that Proven\u00e7al Jews have been making for centuries.\n\nPhoto\n\nHaroseth, the fruit paste that evokes the bricks and mortar used by Jewish slaves in the Passover narrative of the Old Testament, is part of every Seder ritual. Her 13th-century recipe includes dried apricots, figs, raisins and chestnuts, reflecting the sunny climate of this Mediterranean region. And a traditional whole veal breast stuffed with Swiss chard will be the centerpiece of her table.\n\nBecause there is no longer a shochet, a kosher butcher, in Carpentras, Ms. Levy must order the meat from Marseille, about 70 miles (112 kilometers) away. \u201cOnce, the community\u2019s shochet slaughtered chickens, lamb, and goats right inside the synagogue building,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCarpentras became a center of Jewish life after 1306, one of many occasions on which Jews were expelled from the Kingdom of France. Like other nearby sanctuaries such as Avignon and Cavaillon, Carpentras was not in France, but within the Comtat Venaissin, a papal state, where Pope John XXII decreed that refugees would be welcome. With more than 1,000 Jews among its population of about 10,000, Carpentras became known as \u201cla petite Jerusalem,\u201d with a large ghetto arising around its famous synagogue.\n\n200 miles Bruges bel. ger. Paris switz. france Carpentras italy Avignon Marseille spain Mediterrean Sea spain\n\nThe ghetto had kosher butchers and grocers, and for cooking, the residents shared two communal ovens at the synagogue: one used year-round for bread, and the other for Passover matzos.", "title": "A Seder Feast in Provence, With Roots in Ancient Rome", "authors": ["Joan Nathan"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "As Pierpaolo Piccioli said, leaning in with some unexpected urgency before a verdant Valentino show, held on the same day Italy went to the polls: \u201cVery often, if you make clothes you feel are doing something that is not really meaningful for society, but I feel you can use clothes to deliver a message. Italy right now is choosing whether to embrace discrimination and I hate all forms of discrimination.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s why he opened his show with the Sudanese model Adut Akech, and closed it with the Afro-French Assa Baradji, and used his work to prove that romanticism \u2014 not about relationships, but about life \u2014 could be a strength rather than a weakness. The clich\u00e9s of the genre (flowers, pink), were turned into power symbols: Pansies in black and white and caramel appeared as intarsia on wool tunics and capes and knee-high leather boots with stacked heels, so instead of being merely decorative they were built into the structure of the garment.", "title": "A Shades of Gray Show That Was Genuinely Worth Watching", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Sometime during the first year that I was married, when I was teaching myself to cook, I enrolled in a cake-decorating class. A course on how not to turn steaks into hockey pucks might have been more useful at that stage of my life, but I was already in thrall to baking. I bought myself canvas pastry bags marked \u201cMade in France\u201d and outfitted them with a wardrobe of accessories. Each week, I would take my place in front of a ruled board, just as I had when I was learning cursive, and spend two hours squeezing Crisco (cheaper and more forgiving than frosting) into shapes that always fell short of botanical verisimilitude.\n\nEventually I developed a repertoire of pansies, ruffled leaves, shells, swags and roses, never perfect, but nonetheless a source of pride. An ambitious student, I also set myself the task of learning to construct the most complicated desserts in the French canon. I worked my way through the Parisian chef Gaston Len\u00f4tre\u2019s first English-language cookbook, and on any old Tuesday night, I\u2019d serve a g\u00e2teau St. Honor\u00e9 \u2014 puff pastry, cream puffs, two kinds of pastry cream and caramel, some spun. I was learning techniques that I would continue to build on, and I kept at it for a decade or so. Then came the great awakening: I caught myself soaking a dainty cake with rum syrup, layering it with coffee buttercream, frosting it, finishing it with piped rosettes ... and craving a shortbread cookie. I was creating beautiful desserts, but the more elaborate they were, the less I enjoyed eating them.\n\nMy tastes were changing. What I wanted was something trickier to achieve than a bouquet of sugar-paste flowers: simplicity. Like a minimalist architect, I began removing the superfluous and judging what I constructed on its bedrock elements. I always knew that dessert\u2019s only purpose was pleasure. Now I wanted that pleasure to come from the ingredients and how I worked with them, the juxtapositions of texture, the combinations of flavors, the aromas that float into the kitchen when the oven door opens and vanish an instant later.\n\nI haven\u2019t entirely given up on the intricate confections of my early years. I still go over the top on birthday cakes \u2014 it\u2019s my frosting loophole. And I often decorate my desserts, but I try to make sure that what\u2019s outside is never more important than what\u2019s within. The desserts I\u2019ve come to value are unassuming, yet they slyly call you to attention. The texture of a well-made poundcake can pull you in like that. Cookies with intermittent crunch, ice cream with a hard-to-place spice, chocolate cakes with salt, classics resized or reshaped. They all have this power, but the exemplar might be the lemon tart that I\u2019ve been baking for about 20 years.", "title": "A Simple Lemon Tart With Sensuous Surprises", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "When Patrick Ayres first saw the condemned 1918 house that would eventually be home to Cloverdale, he didn\u2019t dare go in. The 31-year-old former executive sous chef of Canlis in Seattle had moved home to Steamboat Springs, Colo., to raise his kids and envisioned opening a restaurant that would cement the state on the culinary map. This place didn\u2019t even have a functioning roof. \u201cIt was a disaster, falling apart,\u201d he said.\n\nBut other options in Steamboat were bland as stale soda crackers, so Mr. Ayres and his wife, Kaylee, ended up buying it, along with a 10.5-acre homestead that sits five miles away. Cloverdale Restaurant and Farm opened in July 2017, featuring a five- and a 10- to 14-course tasting menu. \u201cTasting menus are a way for us to be constantly creative, even in the middle of service,\u201d Mr. Ayres said. They feature an array of produce, 90 percent of which is grown on the farm, with help from a master gardener; each member of the restaurant staff tends the crops at least once a week.\n\nMost new farmers face an uphill battle, but Cloverdale\u2019s were at an elevation of 6,695 feet. Last summer, consecutive frosts in June, July and August throttled the summer squash and bush beans. The solution \u2014 installing four 75-foot low tunnels alongside their greenhouse \u2014 has worked. The restaurant is outstanding.\n\nWe opted for the five-course menu at our recent dinner, though the second I tried the first dish \u2014 a savory parsnip panna cotta topped with a crumbly layer made from baked molasses and rye wheat berries, then studded with tender radish and carrot pickles cut into perfect moons \u2014 I wished I had gone for the longer option. A creamy sunchoke and chestnut soup buoyed seared striped bass, sprinkled with crispy shaved sunchoke chips. Lamb cooked sous vide was light, not gamy, served with fried sweetbreads and grilled preserved eggplants that left a faint whiff of wildfire on the plate.", "title": "A Steamboat Springs Restaurant That Is Truly Farm-to-Table", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Michelle Bachelet, the president of Chile: \u201cWe believe in the value of an open economy and economic integration of countries in order to generate greater prosperity for our people and our nations.\u201d\n\nCredit Meridith Kohut for The New York Times", "title": "A Storm of Reaction to Trump\u2019s Tariffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nManufacturers are looking to the eyewear company Warby Parker as the prototype for selling cooking tools directly to the consumer. Made In for pots and pans is one example. Now, there\u2019s a set of utensils by a company called Material. A generous utility spoon, a sturdy and effective spatula, an angled wooden spoon that\u2019s capable of scooping up grains of risotto from the corners of a pot, and tongs with a cunning one-handed locking system, can all stand in a compact countertop holder. One side of the storage box is magnetic, to grab the 8-inch chef\u2019s knife and 4-inch parer. The drawback is that you have to buy the entire set, reasonable perhaps at $175, but suppose you want only the tongs? The only item sold separately is the chef\u2019s knife ($75): Fundamentals, materialkitchen.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Straight Line to Kitchen Utensils", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Finally, that $350 million fund is finite. While it seems like a lot of money, if 7,000 eligible people with an average debt load of $50,000 get in line for it, it will be gone \u2014 unless Congress allocates more money or makes a permanent fix. And the line cannot form until the Education Department explains how it will administer the fix-it fund. It is supposed to do so by late May, though federal agencies do miss such deadlines sometimes.\n\nAnd what if you\u2019re in Mr. Shafer\u2019s shoes, where you\u2019re short of 120 payments when you suddenly figure out that you are not in the right loan or repayment plan, even though you were adamant about your desire to qualify for the forgiveness program? Do what he did. Complain to the ombudsman at the Department of Education, especially if, like him, you dealt with a particularly problematic servicer called ACS several years ago.\n\nAlso, contact your representative in the House and your two senators and ask to speak with someone in constituent services. Many of the people in those jobs are young and in debt themselves and have contacts with the Department of Education that can be useful. The Senate staff members I spoke to this week echoed this; louder volume can yield more action or at least inject a greater sense of urgency.\n\nAs for Mr. Shafer, he\u2019s just beginning to allow himself to imagine what he will do with the extra money once his loan payments end in 2020. \u201cWhat would anyone do in their hometown if they had an extra $500 a month?\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019d buy furniture in local stores, hire local contractors, buy cars in local car lots.\u201d\n\nHe also expressed some trepidation. In the last two weeks, his loan servicer has sent him inaccurate information about his current payment and about his overall number of payments toward forgiveness. That has him imagining himself back on the negative side of the forgiveness equation. \u201cI would like to be an example of what fighting back can do, and I would not like to be an example of what fighting back can do,\u201d he said, chuckling.\n\nMs. Warren said she was disappointed with the fact that a more permanent or expansive fix for this problem was not politically possible this time around, and vowed to keep watch.\n\n\u201cI certainly intend to keep an eye on Secretary DeVos,\u201d she said, referring to Education Secretary Betsy DeVos. \u201cThe fight isn\u2019t over until every single nurse, teacher, police officer and firefighter gets the student loan forgiveness that they earned.\u201d", "title": "A Student Loan Fix for a Teacher, and Many Other Public Servants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 When we last saw Jim Quinlan, he was making his debut in The New York Times Crossword, and he\u2019s back today for his second time at bat with a nice, tight theme.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nWell, I declare, Mr. Quinlan is offering us a theme where common phrases are turned into new ones using drawled or perhaps casually dragged-out gerunds, where we are supposed to pronounce them as if we were full as a tick and enjoying a pitcher of sweet tea. For example, the phrase LINE DANCERS gets turned into 19A\u2019s LYIN\u2019 DANCERS, which is clued as \u201cDeceitful ballerinas?\u201d and which made me laugh at the visual it evoked.\n\nAt first, I wasn\u2019t sure what that new phrase, LYINDANCERS, was all about, so I kept a suspicious eye on it and moved on. I caught on to the theme at the next phrase, MOOIN\u2019 WALKER, a fun re-forming of MOON WALKER, and clued as \u201cCow as it strolls around the pasture?\u201d\n\nTricky Clues\n\n15A: I laugh every time I see the word UVULA, mainly because I first heard of it during the first season of Saturday Night Live (hi, kids!) in a hilarious sketch with Laraine Newman, Chevy Chase and Gilda Radner. \u201cOne down in the mouth?\u201d is also a very clever clue for it. It was all done by the book, by the rules.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese institutions don\u2019t belong to you,\u201d Mr. Quatremer responded. \u201cThey belong to the European citizens, and it is our perfect right to ask you questions, to repeat the questions as often as we want, without you giving us lessons in morality.\u201d\n\nThe commission\u2019s president normally decides who will be secretary general, but traditionally, those chosen have had high-ranking jobs in the European civil service. Mr. Selmayr came to Brussels in 2004 as a spokesman for Viviane Reding, also from Luxembourg, who was then the commissioner for society and the media. He has never been a deputy director general or director general in any of the commission\u2019s departments.\n\nWhat made the whole business seem slightly shady was that no one had been aware of the vacancy, or that the secretary general, Alexander Italianer, 61, was contemplating retirement. Then it emerged that Mr. Selmayr had been appointed deputy secretary general briefly to qualify him to become secretary general.\n\nAnd then it emerged that rather than an open competition, there had been only one other candidate for the vacancy of deputy secretary general \u2014 and that person withdrew before the selection process was completed. While the commission has refused to name the other candidate, Mr. Quatremer reported that it was Clara Mart\u00ednez Alberola, Mr. Selmayr\u2019s deputy in Mr. Juncker\u2019s office, who has now succeeded him as Mr. Juncker\u2019s chief of staff.\n\nBy the rules, there had to be a minimum of two candidates \u2014 including at least one man and one woman \u2014 for the deputy secretary general\u2019s job. She paid $48 million, which was $9 million more than what it just sold for. The home was put back on the market for $55 million in 2016.\n\nThe buyer was identified as Chen Tianqiao, a Chinese billionaire and a founder of the Shanda Investment Group, whose interests include online game development.\n\nThe 1881 neo-Georgian house of red brick and limestone was once owned by Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, the wife of Cornelius Vanderbilt II and the family matriarch. The 33-foot-wide, five-story structure has around 12,000 square feet of space that features seven bedrooms, including an enormous master suite on the third floor. The home also has five wood-burning fireplaces, a landscaped rear garden and two terraces, including one off the formal dining room on the second level.", "title": "A Surge of High-Priced Closings, Including a Sale by Harvey Weinstein", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "I had no meaty duck leftovers, but it sounded so delicious that I went out and bought a few duck legs and braised them with wine and aromatic vegetables. Then I pulled the meat from the bones, chopped it and simmered it in a quick gravy for a rich and delicious filling. Topped with the earthy blend of fragrant mashed parsnip and potato, and baked until bubbly and browned, it may be the best shepherd\u2019s pie I have ever eaten. I highly recommend it.\n\nBut to be true to the spirit of the recipe, you should feel free to replace the duck with other combinations of leftover braised meats, vegetables or mushrooms. And if some of the ingredients are homegrown, so much the better.\n\nRecipe: Darina\u2019s Shepherd\u2019s Pie\n\nAnd to drink ...\n\nThe combination of braised duck, potatoes and parsnips calls for a hearty red wine that nonetheless is well structured but not oaky. This offers many options. Good Cahors, made with the malbec grape, would be wonderful with this dish, as would Bordeaux from St.-\u00c9milion, Pomerol and their Right Bank satellite appellations. Bandol, especially with some aging, would be delicious, as would a richer Burgundy, like a Nuits-St.-Georges, or a pinot noir. From Italy, a Chianti or other Tuscan sangiovese-based wine would go well, as would an aglianico from Campania or Basilicata. I think a Rioja Reserva would work well if the oak flavors are not too prominent, as would a garnacha-based wine from Montsant or Priorat. As an alternative, you could pretend you are in an Irish pub and drink good dry stout. ERIC ASIMOV\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Later, things grow less enchanting \u2014 anchored in the realities, from dysfunctional to horrific, of Romania in the 1970s and \u201980s. The historical detail is well dosed, and the narrative delivers on its portents. It goes where it must, including a detour to Morocco that only just snags its place at the heart of the story. However, the graver it all gets, the more we miss those initial delights.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA central concern of Rosengaard\u2019s is how lightness turns heavy through loss, but the examples we see up close leave us wondering. Maybe, like the actions of a Romanian dictator, some diversions of the soul have no explanation. \u201cI guess you can\u2019t ever pinpoint a moment,\u201d the intern reflects, \u201cand say: That was how it happened.\u201d Still, we witness these characters and their words in critical moments; we just don\u2019t always know why they\u2019ve changed.\n\nThe intern sees a path for himself in Ana\u2019s stories: They can make him a real writer. \u201cI was just an intern \u2014 white and male and middle class to boot,\u201d he confesses. Ana, by contrast, has something to say. And she\u2019s cooperative, urging him to use as material the first story she tells him, about a near-fatal appendectomy when she was in grade school. As one story leads to another, though, Ana grows more reticent to tell them, and the intern finds he can\u2019t back away. Ana turns his fixation against him: \u201cThere\u2019s a touch of the vampire about you,\u201d she says. \u201cYou like sucking stories out of me. All my exotic stories.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s hardly fair; she cultivated this appetite. But Ana\u2019s accusation underscores the dilemma of anyone hoping to give voice to another\u2019s experience: The stories the intern seeks to make his actually happened to her.\n\nTo tell a story seems a casual thing \u2014 a social offering, a trivial occupation. Ana reminds us that stories complicate one another, and sometimes add up to mysteries. A mystery might be fun to explore, like the human experience of time. In \u201cShipping Out,\u201d a piece by the essayist and novelist David Foster Wallace about a luxury cruise he took, published in Harper\u2019s Magazine in 1996, he described his ship\u2019s departure as \u201ca not untasteful affair of crepes and horns.\u201d Ours, in contrast, was free of such fanfare: Following a safety briefing, we were off.\n\nShip Life\n\nUp until now, our third day into the trip, we hadn\u2019t familiarized ourselves with Symphony . We had also ignored the two newsletters placed outside our door each day \u2014 \u201cReflections\u201d detailed the ship\u2019s movies, classes, guest speakers, nightly shows and other happenings for adults; \u201cSurf Runner\u201d had the lineup for children. I kept busy with work or by hitting the gym. I also used every last second of the hour of daily Wi-Fi included in the cost of the cruise \u2014 all of the line\u2019s voyages now include unlimited Wi-Fi, and if this had been the case on my itinerary, I likely would have spent a lot more time on my computer and phone . I later stopped by for lunch and realized the potential for the story when I saw the selection of food at the cafeteria and the vibrancy of the supermarket.\n\nI lived in Venezuela as a child, so I was immediately drawn to the teque\u00f1os, fried breaded cheese sticks. But I also noticed food from many different countries: Cuban coffee, Puerto Rican mofongo, Dominican oxtail stew. An assortment of people \u2014 from construction workers to families \u2014 waited in line for food. It looked, smelled and sounded like Latin America.\n\nI told the longtime Mets infielder Jose Reyes and the top prospect Amed Rosario, both from the Dominican Republic, about my visit to Bravo, and their eyes lit up. They told me that they ate there often and that other teammates did, too. I first looked at my phone, as I always do, to make sure there were no emergencies. With bleary eyes I read the WhatsApp message from my friend and colleague Gaia Pianigiani, a New York Times journalist with whom I often work in Italy.\n\nThe shoot was supposed to be the next day, Thursday, but the co-working space for moms had given the green light for me to photograph a day earlier, and I knew everyone was anxious to run the story ASAP. My stomach sank as the dreaded question surfaced: What am I going to do with Olivia?\n\nMy partner, Paulo, a fellow photographer, was in Colombia for three weeks, and I had arranged the babysitter for Thursday. She had specifically mentioned to me that she was not available on Wednesday. A few frivolous last-minute attempts at finding a substitute yielded nothing. No time to dwell, with the morning advancing and our 5-year-old son, Rafael, needing to get to school after having been out with the stomach flu for a week. Olivia would have to come with me.\n\nIt wouldn\u2019t be the first time I had brought the kids on assignment. Paulo and I had brought Rafael on various stories we did together, from Florida to Japan, running around with him in the baby carrier when he was as young as four months. Yet those were stories where we had a lot of time, and of course there were two of us. The point being that as a photographer there are stories you can take small children on, and others that would be quite impossible or outright dangerous. Children have needs, and when I\u2019m involved in a shoot I can\u2019t always satisfy them.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe irony of the situation was not lost on me. My assignment, in advance of the elections in Italy, was to portray the lack of services for women \u2014 in particular the continual chipping away at maternity support for working mothers. And here I was again in my all-too-familiar routine of scrambling for child care.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOften on mornings when I\u2019m not shooting and I take Olivia around the neighborhood, Italian grandmothers question why she is not in school. One of the major banks in Mr. Williams\u2019s backyard, Wells Fargo, engaged in aggressive sales practices that resulted in millions of accounts being opened without customers\u2019 knowledge. The San Francisco Fed has recently pushed for major structural changes to Wells Fargo, and the Fed last month announced tough penalties on the company.\n\nOn monetary policy, Mr. Williams has been an influential voice at the Fed, where he has recently pushed for the central bank to rethink its 2 percent inflation target and to consider a new system in which policymakers would sometimes allow prices to rise more quickly to make up for periods when inflation was lower. Had such a policy been in place during the most recent recession, the Fed might have been even more aggressive in its efforts to stimulate the economy.\n\nBut at the Fed\u2019s meeting last week, Mr. Williams voted along with his colleagues to hike interest rates for the sixth time since the financial crisis, and he has generally supported the Fed\u2019s current policy of gradually raising rates to keep a lid on inflation. He has repeatedly said that the United States is at \u201cfull employment,\u201d meaning that joblessness is as low as it can get without triggering inflation over the long term. Qatar called Mr. Broidy\u2019s charges a false \u201cdiversionary tactic to distract from the serious allegations against himself and his client, the United Arab Emirates.\u201d\n\nMr. Broidy and Qatar each threatened legal actions.\n\nThe dispute illustrates how conflicts around the globe can echo through American news media, politics and courts, as rivals compete for the favor of Washington and the sympathies of the West.\n\nQatar and the United Arab Emirates are both small, conservative, oil-rich monarchies and close American allies, but they have been locked for years in an escalating feud. The U.A.E. has accused Qatar of destabilizing the region by supporting political Islam, and, with Saudi Arabia, the Emiratis have led a monthslong campaign to blockade and isolate Qatar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nQatar disputes the charges and accuses the United Arab Emirates of bullying its neighbors.\n\nAt least three sets of documents that appear to have been hacked from Mr. Broidy\u2019s personal email have been passed in recent days to several journalists at multiple news organizations, including The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, in a coordinated attempt to discredit Mr. Broidy. But the town\u2019s many defenders, including social conservatives, said it was merely trying to protect Quebec\u2019s way of life.\n\nThe debate was so loud that the province convened a commission on the extent to which Quebec should accommodate minorities. And so it was that I found myself shivering and walking down H\u00e9rouxville\u2019s Main Street this week in the frigid March cold, curious to see whether attitudes had shifted.\n\nAt first, the reception was equally frosty as local residents glared at me suspiciously. People who eventually talked to me did not want to give their full names.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe message, though, was clear: Even after 10 years, the town was still reeling. One man said the code was the first subject strangers brought up when he said he was from H\u00e9rouxville. A woman said the town was tired of the attention.\n\nBut another woman defended the code, saying immigrants to Quebec had to conform to local custom.\n\nAcross Quebec, on radio shows and on social media, commentators tut-tutted me for going to H\u00e9rouxville, suggesting that there were more interesting places. Others accused me of being out of touch with Quebec.\n\nBut my road trip suggests otherwise.\n\nMore than a decade later, Quebec seems consumed by some of the same questions about identity.\n\nLate last year Quebec introduced Bill 62, a law requiring people to show their faces in order to get public services. The law has upset some Muslims, including women who wear face-covering veils known as niqabs, and say that it stigmatizes them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis week I also met with members of the Quebec City mosque where six people were killed by a Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois gunman more than a year ago, leading to soul-searching about the state of Islamophobia in the province. During a chat at the mosque, which is still pocked with bullet holes, its director, Mohamed Labidi, told me that he feared that the far right combined with right-wing radio was fomenting hatred against Muslims and fear of the other.\n\n\u201cThe situation for us has gotten worse over the past decade,\u201d he said. \u201cIt has taken blood to flow for us to build bridges again.\u201d\n\nAs I travel across Quebec, I am constantly reminded how a province with a French-speaking population surrounded by an Anglophone majority in the rest of the country is understandably sensitive when it comes to preserving Quebec\u2019s culture.\n\nMoreover, because Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois revolted against the strictures of the Roman Catholic Church in the 1960s, secularism is deeply ingrained and outward signs of religion can cause discomfort.\n\nThe Volvo is passing snow-covered mountains as we head to Saguenay, a center for the forestry and aluminum industries. There, I want to explore how globalization and factory closings have affected a region that is among the most separatist in the province.\n\nOn a different note, I also want to sample the region\u2019s vaunted meat pies, known as tourti\u00e8res!\n\nPlease follow me on my journey on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, as well as on The Times\u2019s Reader Center. I will return with the regular Canada Letter this weekend to let you know how the rest of the trip went.", "title": "A Town Quebec Would Rather Forget: The Canada Letter", "authors": ["Dan Bilefsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou\u2019re going to see tit-for-tat actions, but our view of this is that you\u2019re going to get two countries who understand that it is fundamentally more in their interest to cooperate than compete,\u201d Mr. Haines said. \u201cThey\u2019re going to figure out ways to cooperate even in the midst of things that sound like they\u2019re escalating.\u201d\n\nScholars who have studied trade disputes have found that trade skirmishes can end with more mutually satisfactory arrangements. One key is for countries to retaliate carefully against what they consider to be unfair practices, targeting politically sensitive industries in the country with which they are clashing. It is a safe bet that negotiators in the United States, China and elsewhere are well aware of this.\n\nThe implication of this view is not that an all-out trade war is impossible, just that some of the loose talk about the idea in the last week \u2014 including by the president \u2014 is getting far ahead of the facts.\n\nJoe Brusuelas, the chief economist at the accounting firm RSM, sketched out what a true trade war would look like.\n\n\u201cThe first indicator that a trade war has begun would be the announced intention to withdraw from, or abrogate, current trade treaty arrangements,\u201d Mr. Brusuelas wrote recently.\n\nHe contrasts that with \u201ctrade spats,\u201d which take place continually, and tariff actions that are rarer but have been used many times without setting off a major economic dislocation. A recent example was the Obama administration\u2019s 2009 tariff on Chinese tires, which did coincide with a rebound in domestic tire production (though it was costly relative to the number of jobs created).\n\nIf the United States ignored rulings of the World Trade Organization, or pulled out of Nafta, it could trigger a series of steps including not just tariffs but other restrictions on international commerce, and perhaps limits on the flow of capital across borders and even the expropriation of foreign-owned assets. He does not see that dark scenario as imminent.", "title": "A Trade Skirmish Is Underway. That Doesn\u2019t Mean a Trade War Is Near.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHOUSE OF FACT, HOUSE OF RUIN\n\nPoems\n\nBy Tom Sleigh\n\n117 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.\n\nTHE LAND BETWEEN TWO RIVERS\n\nWriting in an Age of Refugees\n\nBy Tom Sleigh\n\n255 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.\n\nIn \u201cBarbarian in the Garden,\u201d the poet Zbigniew Herbert\u2019s collection of essays published in the 1980s, Herbert, fresh out of Cold War Poland, travels around Europe, meditating on food, art and the relationship of culture to torture or violence. He\u2019ll savor Orvieto wine or truffles on village patios before delving into the historic burning of a medieval sect known as the Cathars or the slaughter of bulls commemorated at Lascaux. As Herbert travels across Europe, his essays move in constellation, asking: How do moments of deep human culture relate to moments of deep human violence? How does the history of art relate to the history of torture? These are complex questions. No one would expect a poet to answer straightforwardly. In a world that would like simple answers, Herbert evades simplicity.\n\nThe ingredients of Herbert\u2019s essays rose up for me again as I read Tom Sleigh\u2019s linked and intertwined new books \u2014 one of memoir and reportage (\u201cThe Land Between Two Rivers\u201d), and one of poems (\u201cHouse of Fact, House of Ruin\u201d). Like Herbert, Sleigh is a deliberate traveler in the troubled world. Rather than unearth the deep cruelties of European history, Sleigh leaves the confusions of 21st-century America to visit some of the world\u2019s hot zones: Kurdistan, Mogadishu, rural Lebanon, Nairobi. Sometimes he\u2019s conducting poetry workshops; sometimes he\u2019s dealing with cultural attach\u00e9s or smooth-tongued diplomats; sometimes he\u2019s face to face with refugees in camps. At all times his mission is also to be present with his own body, with others, and with the notebook whose contents he will eventually weave into essays and poems that feed one another, sometimes cannibalizing one another line for line, joke for joke.\n\nIn Herbert\u2019s title, there was a sly pun: Herbert, the Pole, was the barbarian; Europe was the garden. Sleigh\u2019s garden is Qana; the Lebanese town where Jesus is said to have turned water into wine, now the site of two particularly devastating Israeli bombings; and also Baghdad, in the Tigris-Euphrates valley, cradle of civilization, now the violence-ridden capital of Iraq. In writing from parts of the world that are all too often refracted in what Sleigh calls \u201ccrisis chatter\u201d or \u201cdisaster porn,\u201d he wants to investigate what it means to be present among others who are more often than not perched on some precarious verge. Yet as Sleigh makes clear, he\u2019s also uncomfortable with what might be called \u201cthe poetry of witness\u201d or with any overweening formulation of \u201cspeaking for the voiceless.\u201d When called upon to explain what he\u2019s trying to do, Sleigh, who has spent much of his adult life too sick to travel in this way, or to practice the craft of journalism he so admires, talks about wanting to learn from the \u201cnegative capability\u201d of journalism. By this he means getting close enough to a complex thing to suspend any agenda except for detail, observation, texture, note-taking. Obviously, Sleigh cannot help having a vantage, a prejudice, a body, but he also wants to follow both his watching mind and his language where they lead.\n\nLike Herbert, Sleigh often explores the hair-trigger balance between culture and chaos. Like Herbert, who began an essay on human brutality by savoring truffles, Sleigh often lingers over food as the base form of pleasure and culture by which we create and sustain human peace. Sleigh revels in the moment in Jordan when a skilled Syrian refugee finds a new life as the baker of a honeyed bird\u2019s-nest pastry called kenafeh. He\u2019s drawn to the moment when a formerly listless child in Mogadishu perks up and begins \u201cplaying with the shiny wrapper of a nutritional biscuit he\u2019d just eaten\u201d and the moment in the relative calm of Kurdistan when he and a friend \u201cstood in line with everyone else helping themselves to the abundance of local cheeses, baklava and other honeyed pastries.\u201d In Sleigh\u2019s hands these moments of ongoingness mix something of the daily with something of the miraculous. As he points out, \u201cpeople \u2014 even people threatened by drought and starvation \u2014 have to get on with their lives.\u201d Yet he also notes when they can\u2019t, as at a field outside Qana where oranges cannot be harvested because the ground is still seeded with bombs. In a poem called \u201cBefore Rain\u201d (which might as easily have been called \u201cAfter Ruin\u201d), Sleigh writes: \u201cTrees grow up where there once were people, weeds / take over beds of lettuces and coddled flowers, / uprearing mole hills unpopulate the fields.\u201d As he observes in the next line, \u201cthe bricked-in hours of the human have all been knocked down.\u201d Sleigh is after the enormously fragile ways that even in the face of war or famine people do get on, even while at any moment survival, that most fragile of luxuries, might just as easily end.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a poet-journalist traveling through war zones, Sleigh also has a distinct precursor in Walt Whitman, who in traveling to Civil War hospitals and battlefields filled his notebooks with dispatches that would later become the essayistic poems \u201cDrum Taps\u201d as well as the impressionistic essays in \u201cSpecimen Days.\u201d In his poetry and his prose, Whitman was exploring novel forms of writing in a new democracy \u2014 a language of access, of one body witnessing another in shared space. Like Whitman, Sleigh here plays with what the observer\u2019s notebook can become. He embeds lines of poetry in journalistic essays like a rogue reporter; conversely, he\u2019ll forge a sonnet or rhymed tercets out of reported language, as he does in poems that incorporate the testimony of Tony Lagouranis, who witnessed the torture at Abu Ghraib. Sleigh doffs his hat to Whitman expliciitly, noting in one poem that he\u2019s practicing \u201cwith Whitman a raw / form of brinksmanship.\u201d\n\nIf Sleigh\u2019s brinksmanship is about drawing near to lives at the verge, it is also about trying to record the narratives by which lives come to have meaning, and finding the language in which we come to understand what Sleigh calls \u201cthe soul\u2019s vulnerable republic.\u201d Sleigh\u2019s cross-pollinating forms remind us that language, too, is always being deployed to some purpose. In the face of propaganda, political backlash and crisis chatter, which stories allow us to become human to one another? Just outside Qana, Sleigh listens to a man named Joseph, who was asked to recover the shattered bodies of small children after the most recent bombings. At that moment, they see in the rubble the \u201cgleaming, flesh-colored, plastic thigh and leg of a baby doll.\u201d The image is chilling.\n\nPhoto\n\nLater, meditating on this experience, Sleigh mulls the words of Robert Frost, who said that politics is \u201can extravagance about grievances, and poetry is an extravagance about grief.\u201d In Frost\u2019s formulation, the divisions at first seem clean. The politics of grievance face outward, acting publicly, while poetry turns inward to attend to our private landscapes of sorrow. Yet look more closely, and things become murky. To which realm do Joseph\u2019s memories of the shattered bodies of the lost girls and the still-present doll belong? To what realm do they belong when Sleigh tells us Joseph\u2019s story?\n\nMost of us live and breathe between the scales of so-called political and so-called private life; the languages we speak shift depending on circumstances. Late in his essay collection, after Sleigh has recounted his travels, he shifts registers. He describes some of the sources of his own grief \u2014 about his parents, who felt coerced into uncomfortable business dealings in the segregated South, and especially his mother, whose electroshock treatments left her uneasily adrift from the self she\u2019d been before. He describes his own illness. How might these things forge a politics, a poetics, an imagination? Sleigh has made a project of trying to write about other lives under pressure, at the brink. He\u2019s also watching himself watching, wondering how to read the longings and sorrows that urge him, the watcher, on.", "title": "A Traveler to Troubled Lands, Called to Bear Witness", "authors": ["Tess Taylor"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are chocolate people, and there are vanilla people. I am a lemon person.\n\nShow me a dessert menu, and I\u2019ll choose whatever is flavored with puckery lemon or any of her citrus sisters \u2014 lime, tangerine, kumquat, yuzu. Even as a kid, I went for lemon sorbet over the mint chocolate-chip ice cream. The combination of sugar cut with enough acidic citrus juices to make my jaw ache is my confection perfection \u2014 mostly pleasure, pricked with pain.\n\nOf all the lemony desserts one could make, I\u2019ve always leaned hard on the classic, lemon curd tart. But there are times when it pays to branch out. This elegant tart, with tangerine, ginger and a little chocolate, is one of them.\n\nI got the idea at my friend Shawn\u2019s dinner party this past winter. Periodically throughout the meal of fried veal cutlets with capers and potato gratin, I\u2019d turn to gaze at the lemon tart on the counter, glistening daisy bright.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen she sliced though it, there was a surprise: a thin layer of melted chocolate brushed over the crust. The recipe, her take on one by Suzanne Goin at Lucques in Los Angeles, ensures crisp pastry by creating a chocolate barrier between liquid curd and the pre-baked tart shell. The filling was softly gelled, sour and darkly complex from the bittersweet coating, and the crust crumbly and rich.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven before I\u2019d polished off my wedge, I was already adapting the recipe in my head. What would happen if I added tangerine to the lemon, since orange flavors work so well with chocolate?", "title": "A Treat for Lemon Lovers and Beyond", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDISGRACEFUL!\u201d tweeted the president. In another angry posting the president referred to the A.G. as \u201cSession,\u201d which suggested a certain emotional distance.\n\nThen the spelling was revised. What do you think is going on with this Twitter account, people? On Friday morning Trump was ranting about Alec Baldwin, who he called \u201cAlex Baldwin, whose dieing mediocre career was saved by his impersonation of me on SNL.\u201d\n\nThat predawn message, too, got quickly erased and reposted, with Baldwin\u2019s name and \u201cdying\u201d fixed. I used to think Trump was using voice dictation, but Siri knows how to spell.\n\nSessions responded that \u201cas long as I am the attorney general, I will continue to discharge my duties with integrity and honor.\u201d Since he communicated via a traditional press release rather than a Fox interview or social media rant, we may never know if the president saw it.\n\nBut Trump certainly noticed with displeasure that Sessions had failed to go away. Last week, at a meeting on school safety, the president carefully placed Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi between himself and his own A.G. Bondi has been a presidential favorite for a long time. Perhaps you remember that she never joined New York state in its suit against Trump University, a decision which had absolutely nothing to do with the fact that Donald had donated money to support her campaign.\n\nAlthough Sessions was obviously the highest-ranking person in the room besides the president, it was Bondi Trump called upon to speak first, praising her as \u201ca really tremendous attorney general.\u201d Sessions may have been a little hurt by having to wait his turn, but he nevertheless went on to burble some praise for the president\u2019s meeting with members of Congress on guns.\n\nTrump doled out one mini-compliment about Sessions\u2019s work fighting immigrant gangs, then quickly changed the subject to a rant about the state of California. (\u201cThey have the highest taxes in the nation and they don\u2019t know what\u2019s happening out there. Frankly it\u2019s a disgrace.\u201d) Sessions, probably delighted to have somebody else called a disgrace, nodded supportively.", "title": "Opinion | A Trump Fawners Almanac", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to surround myself only with the best and most serious people,\u201d Donald Trump told The Washington Post during his presidential campaign.\n\nOne of the people who\u2019s been surrounding Trump is Sam Nunberg, a conservative political activist and former aide who had a protracted meltdown on live television yesterday, in separate interviews conducted by Gloria Borger, Erin Burnett, Ari Melber, Josh Robin, Jake Tapper and Katy Tur.\n\nThe videos certainly make for good television. Now looking to downsize, he and his wife, Deirdre Lawrence, are putting it on the market for $4 million.\n\nIt was on New Year\u2019s Eve in 1966 that Mr. Labine, a chemical engineer working at an industry magazine, went to a party on the Upper West Side, hoping only to \u201cget sloshed,\u201d as he put it, and enjoy himself. There, he met Evelyn and Everett Ortner, a couple who lived in Park Slope and were passionate about reviving old Brooklyn brownstones that had fallen into disrepair. By the end of the night, Mr. Labine had agreed \u2014 largely out of politeness \u2014 to consider shopping for one.\n\n\u201cI was living in Queens, in Maspeth,\u201d he said recently in the parlor of the home he ended up buying near the Ortners. \u201cEveryone thought I was crazy for moving here because the neighborhood was a bit dicey.\u201d", "title": "A Victorian Wonderland in Park Slope", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "It is the first time the president has come to this state since he campaigned here during the Republican presidential primary nearly two years ago. His appearances at the time set off demonstrations and clashes with the police, including one in which his motorcade was blockaded by protesters as he turned up to speak at a state Republican Party convention outside San Francisco. (Mr. Trump was forced to leave his vehicle and trudge up a hill, climbing over a fence, to get into the venue).\n\nSimilar demonstrations are expected again. Protesters \u2014 and some supporters \u2014 are planning rallies in the San Diego area before the president\u2019s visit on Tuesday. One group, Women\u2019s March San Diego, is planning to erect a large sign in opposition to the border wall that the president would see from the air, should he fly in by helicopter. Another group, which calls itself San Diegans for Secure Borders, is planning a rally on Tuesday in support of the president\u2019s immigration policies. Among those scheduled to attend, the group said, are \u201cparents whose children were murdered by illegal aliens who crossed our unsecured border illegally to kill our citizens.\u201d\n\nLos Angeles is girding for protests as well, though demonstrators may be confused over where to go.
