A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department, Officer Rosario Herrera, said no permits had been issued for major protests as of Monday morning, and that any road closings would be determined later in consultation with the Secret Service.", "title": "A Visit Behind the Lines: President Trump Heads to California", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "ABUJA, Nigeria \u2014 Human traffickers have officially been cursed. On March 9, Oba Ewuare II, the traditional ruler of the kingdom of Benin, in southern Nigeria, put a voodoo curse on anyone who abets illegal migration within his domain. At the same time, he revoked the curses that leave victims of trafficking afraid that their relatives will die if they go to the police or fail to pay off their debt.\n\nBefore being smuggled into Europe, women and girls in the area, which falls in present-day Edo State, are made to sign a contract with the traffickers who finance their journey, promising to pay them thousands of dollars. The agreement is sealed with a voodoo, or juju, ritual, conducted by a spiritual priest, known here as a native doctor. Pieces of their clothing, fingernails or hair are mixed with drops of their blood into a concoction that the women are made to drink.\n\nThe oba has authority over all the spiritual priests in the Benin kingdom (not to be confused with the West African country of Benin). He summoned them to his palace that Friday to make his announcement.\n\nDavid Edebiri, a high-ranking traditional leader, was there, and described to me what happened during the ceremony. First the oba \u201creleased all those bound by juju.\u201d Then he put a curse on the head of any priest who makes \u201cany concoction for anybody with a view to promoting any immigration to any part of the world.\u201d This curse, Mr. Edebiri told me, \u201cmanifests in various ways: Some may die mysteriously, some may go mad in the street.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Voodoo Curse on Human Traffickers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Steavenson cited Arthur Koestler\u2019s \u201cDarkness at Noon,\u201d Truman Capote\u2019s \u201cBreakfast at Tiffany\u2019s\u201d and Graham Greene\u2019s \u201cThe Quiet American\u201d as her \u201ctouchstone\u201d novels. \u201cIn all three each cog of the plot turns the next and everything is just very well organized,\u201d she said. \u201cPsychologically they\u2019re fascinating about how you get from one place to another.\u201d When Ms. Steavenson began to write \u201cParis Metro\u201d she asked her agent to get in touch with Matt Weiland, a senior editor at W.W. Norton & Company. Over a decade earlier, Mr. Weiland had been working for the magazine Granta and had edited three of Ms. Steavenson\u2019s long-form reported pieces from Iraq and Lebanon.\n\n\u201cWhen reporters want to write fiction I usually run for the hills,\u201d Mr. Weiland said in a telephone interview. \u201cBut going back to those Granta pieces, what Wendy\u2019s writing evinced was just an incredibly natural eye for character and a great sense of crafting scenes. Very quickly she got close to the people she was meeting and talking with and you felt as though you knew them and you cared about them. I think that\u2019s a mark of what the finest novels can or should do.\u201d\n\nMs. Steavenson has been lined up to give some readings of \u201cParis Metro\u201d in Washington, Boston and New York. She was born in Manhattan (her mother is a New Yorker and her father, who died two years ago, was British) and lived there for a few years during her 20s. So it will be a homecoming of sorts. \u201cThough I didn\u2019t grow up there I would say that I\u2019m a New Yorker in my heart,\u201d she said. \u201cI want matzo ball soup, and it makes me annoyed when Europeans walk slowly on the sidewalk.\u201d\n\nMs. Steavenson is now working on her second novel, which she said is about \u201cmothers and daughters, genetics, nature and nurture.\u201d The first half is set in Manhattan during the 1960s and the second half in Europe 20 years later. She is also getting an itch to do some reporting again, but \u201cin a different way\u201d than before. \u201cI\u2019m a bit less: Must go to Mosul,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m more scared. I don\u2019t know if it got scarier. I think it did. You just see the toll it takes and you lose too many people. There are too many people close to you kidnapped. I got scareder, no doubt about it.\u201d", "title": "A War Reporter Finds Refuge by Switching to Fiction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Lake Oswego, Ore., is a tiny grid of low, clean buildings wedged into the apex of the Willamette River and the eponymous, oblong lake. It looks like something a model train might trundle through, the crisp white buildings and black rooftops encircled with perfect pine trees. It\u2019s one of the wealthiest and most desirable of Portland\u2019s suburbs, with a population of 38,945 at the 2016 census.\n\nThe little parking lot behind the coffee and pastry shop that opens early is crammed with luxury sedans and S.U.V.s by 7:30 on weekday mornings. Inside, parents on their way to work call out jolly greetings. Women in exercise gear huddle over coffee cups. Anyone who goes for milk or sugar meets the brittle clippings from Lake Oswego\u2019s chatty weekly newspaper taped to the wall above the napkin dispenser. The stories feature local high school athletes or chronicle the cafe\u2019s own growth and its embrace by the community. It seems impossible to remain a stranger in Lake Oswego for long.\n\nI spent less than a week there, reporting a story that ended up on Thursday\u2019s front page, but I quickly began to wonder what living in Lake Oswego felt like for the women whose stories I heard as I gathered information about Douglas Greenberg, a Morgan Stanley wealth manager with a 15-year history of alleged abuse. They lived in that same tiny town. And they each endured similar stretches of instability during which, according to the court records and social media messages I reviewed, there was violence and terror at home. After they fled, there was pounding on their front doors. There were letters and packages left on their front steps. There were surprises \u2014 messes left in their vandalized cars. Wary shopkeepers were warned by an anonymous caller that the women were untrustworthy thieves.\n\nAll of this happened in a place where things look destined to remain orderly and calm. And if they don\u2019t, the town is almost certain to find out about them. I was told over and over again that in Lake Oswego, there are very few secrets.", "title": "A Wealthy Suburban Community\u2019s Disturbing Open Secrets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMany people voted for Trump in order to throw a hand grenade into national politics,\u201d said former Representative Timothy J. Roemer, Democrat of Indiana. \u201cIt seems he has done the same thing to Capitol Hill, and no one knows from a tweet to an exchange in an Oval Office meeting what\u2019s next.\u201d\n\nStruggling to explain his evolving positions, Mr. Trump\u2019s aides chose to emphasize his flexibility. \u201cAt least this president is holding forth for everyone to see in a listening session,\u201d Kellyanne Conway, his counselor, said on Fox Business Network after conservatives expressed uncertainty about his publicly televised session on gun control. \u201cThis is what leaders do so everyone can see how the conversation is unfolding.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has always been something of an ideological shape-shifter, who once backed abortion rights, an assault rifle ban and universal health care but ran for president promising to put \u201cpro-life justices on the court,\u201d defend Second Amendment rights and repeal President Barack Obama\u2019s Affordable Care Act.\n\nSince taking office, Mr. Trump has mostly hewed to conservative policies like repealing environmental regulations, cutting taxes and increasing military spending. Indeed, the Heritage Foundation, the venerable conservative research institution in Washington, concluded that Mr. Trump has carried out 64 percent of its recommendations. Even President Ronald Reagan, revered at Heritage, had completed only 49 percent of its policy proposals by this stage of his administration.\n\nBut as this week demonstrated, Mr. Trump has also tacked against his party\u2019s traditional support for free trade and its genetic suspicion of all things Russian.\n\nOn Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced the development of an \u201cinvincible\u201d nuclear missile and even showed animation of a potential strike on Florida, where Mr. Trump spends many weekends, including this one. But the president had no response to the implicit threat, just as he has resisted condemning Moscow for its interference in the 2016 elections.\n\nMr. Trump has been consistently vocal on trade, pulling out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and threatening to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement if it is not renegotiated to his liking. But he has been on a different page from some of his top aides, like Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, and Gary D. Cohn, the national economics adviser, both formerly at Goldman Sachs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn January, Mr. Mnuchin sought to play down the possibility of a major rupture with trading partners even as he said the president would guard America\u2019s interests. Speaking in Davos, Switzerland, where international corporate chieftains and investors had gathered, Mr. Mnuchin reassured the world that \u201cwe\u2019re not looking to get into trade wars.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFive weeks later, after announcing the stiff new tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, Mr. Trump sounded like someone eagerly looking to do exactly that. \u201cTrade wars are good,\u201d he wrote on Twitter on Friday, \u201cand easy to win.\u201d\n\nThe tariff announcement came before his staff had even come up with a written policy and only then in answer to a reporter\u2019s question. Republicans, including Speaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, were exasperated and even distraught. The editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, owned by Rupert Murdoch, a friend of Mr. Trump\u2019s, called it \u201cthe biggest policy blunder of his presidency.\u201d\n\nDaniel Price, a former international economics adviser to President George W. Bush, said Mr. Trump was \u201cquixotically picking fights\u201d with allies. \u201cThe president\u2019s positions on trade and global engagement place him at right angles with core Republican views, U.S. business and agricultural interests and indeed the traditional Western alliance,\u201d Mr. Price said.\n\nRepublican leaders are more upset about the president\u2019s apostasy on trade than gun control because he has the authority to impose tariffs on his own, and they assume Congress will never impose significant limits on gun rights.\n\nBut the party leaders on Capitol Hill assumed that Mr. Trump\u2019s vow to impose a 25 percent tariff on imported steel and a 10 percent tariff on imported aluminum was not really his final position, and that he could still be steered off his current course before actually signing an order next week. Even White House officials imagined that could happen.\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, seemed to acknowledge the possibility when asked by reporters on Friday about the president\u2019s commitment to following through. \u201cNever say never, but I think he\u2019s pretty committed to moving this forward,\u201d she said. Asked specifically about the rates Mr. Trump threw out, she said, \u201cI wouldn\u2019t expect those to change, but some of the other details need to be finalized.\u201d\n\nLikewise, Mr. Trump\u2019s support for gun control measures, like raising the minimum age for purchases of semiautomatic rifles, seemed fluid. During his session with lawmakers from both parties, the president seemed intent on defying the N.R.A. and fashioning a bipartisan bill with Democrats. Since then, however, he and his staff have been more equivocal, much like he was after a similar televised meeting with lawmakers on immigration that seemed to open the door to a compromise only to lead to more partisan crossfire.\n\n\u201cConceptually, he still supports raising the age to 21,\u201d Ms. Sanders said. \u201cBut he also knows there\u2019s not a lot of broad support for that. But that\u2019s something he would support.\u201d\n\nAnd even as she downgraded his support to \u201cconceptual,\u201d she seemed ready to pass off responsibility for enacting it outside Washington. \u201cI think he thinks it would probably have more potential in the states than it would at the federal level,\u201d she said.", "title": "A Week of Policy Surprises Leaves Even Trump\u2019s Supporters Confused", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Sketchbook\n\nA Well-Read Woman\n\nCelebrating the literary lives of girls with a nod to the illustrator William Steig\u2019s \u2018CDB!\u2019", "title": "A Well-Read Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "In just a few years, what began as a lineup of monochromatic streetwear pieces (emblazoned with the brand\u2019s signature striping) has evolved into full men\u2019s and women\u2019s collections (which launched in 2015), totaling eight collections per year. This season\u2019s inspiration, he explained while scanning a lineup of looks, derives from the West Village \u2014 specifically the Soul Cycle-then-healthy-brunch crowd of young, downtown women with roots in affluent, horse-country suburbs like Greenwich. There were nods to equestrian styles in the form of tall riding boots, reworked with heels and pointy toes, and form-fitting silhouettes to match the tailoring of competition jackets.\n\nPlacing new spins on familiar pieces is a major signifier of both the Off-White brand and Abloh\u2019s method: \u201cIt\u2019s like taking a Yankees logo and flipping it upside down,\u201d he says. \u201cYou\u2019ve taken something that people already wear, and made it so that people who are familiar with it now see in a new way. And now they want it.\u201d Though he admits that \u201cstreetwear\u201d was always an easy identifier for his designs, one might argue that Abloh\u2019s not redefining the concept, so much as undefining it \u2014 untethering streetwear from any and all definitions.\n\nAn hour later, Abloh left Dance, the stylist, to manage the remainder of the fittings, while he traveled to his rented studio in the 18th Arrondissement to paint pieces for his show at Murakami\u2019s Kaikai Kiki Gallery in Tokyo next month. Massive canvases featuring words such as \u201cTelevision\u201d in white script fill the bare-bones space. Ten pieces will make up the show next month, including a video installation and a sculpture mimicking an old Sunoco gas station sign. It\u2019s the first exhibition Abloh has done of this kind, but he\u2019s more daunted by the limited time frame in which to complete and ship all the pieces to Japan than by the work itself. \u201cThere\u2019s no failure in constantly creating,\u201d Abloh said. \u201cThe only failure is if you\u2019re actually not making anything. And so, that\u2019s how, that\u2019s why we\u2019re here, in a whole other studio with paint on it. The way my brain is set \u2014 there\u2019s no box.\u201d\n\nThe following afternoon, Abloh signs sweatshirts, sneakers, even the shirt on a fan\u2019s back, inside the Chrome Hearts store on the tony shopping strip of Avenue de Montaigne. Outside, a line has formed down the block with fans hoping to claim one of just 50 limited-edition Off-White x Chrome Hearts hoodies, all of which sell out in less than two hours. Later that evening at the show\u2019s venue, a pavilion on Rue Cambon, Abloh sits on a plastic-wrapped bench, gazing between his phone and the models\u2019 rehearsal. Clusters of white balloons hover high overhead as \u201cclouds\u201d within a set design he described as \u201cfabricated nature.\u201d There\u2019s already been a fair share of excitement surrounding the show: a last-minute dress addition to the lineup, and just down the street, a feverish mob scene outside the brand\u2019s pop-up, where the newest Off-White x Nike Air Jordan 1 sneaker had gone on sale that day (a situation that required police intervention).\n\nEarlier, Abloh explained why, even as an American, with his home base in Chicago and his brand\u2019s headquarters in Milan, the decision to present his collections in Paris has always been integral to his ambitions for Off-White: \u201cParis is home to the birthplace of this idea. The names: Givenchy, Balenciaga, Dior, Yves Saint Laurent. Of course, clothes have been made everywhere,\u201d he said. \u201cBut this idea, with these principles I\u2019ll still uphold when I\u2019m 50 years old \u2014 I\u2019m only doing it for that. Otherwise I wouldn\u2019t do it. I\u2019d be doing something else.\u201d", "title": "A Whirlwind Paris Fashion Week With Virgil Abloh", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wylie\u2019s time in Ottawa, however, brought to light something that most people have overlooked. Unlike businesses and the federal government itself, federal political parties aren\u2019t subject to Canada\u2019s internet privacy and data protection laws.\n\nSome of those laws date to the 1980s and the federal privacy commissioner, among others, has been calling for a 21st century update. But while Canada lags behind Europe in this area, it\u2019s still well ahead of the United States.\n\nThe political party exemption came about in part because of a parliamentary tradition of not giving bureaucrats or outside bodies control over a party\u2019s affairs. I called Michael Pal, an assistant law professor at the University of Ottawa who studies election laws and related issues like voter suppression, and asked if it\u2019s time for a change.\n\n\u201cEvery other sector is covered by privacy laws but political parties,\u201d he said. \u201cThey are all using data so I don\u2019t think there is a good argument about why they should be under privacy rules.\u201d\n\nAs for concerns about encroaching on Parliament, Professor Pal isn\u2019t buying that either. He noted that parties were already \u201cheavily regulated\u201d through Elections Canada and election fund-raising laws.\n\nSo what\u2019s a Facebook user to do now? My colleague Brian X. Chen, who writes about consumer technology, has offered some guidance on minimizing privacy risks on Facebook, although his overall take on the situation facing Facebook users is a little discouraging:\n\n\u201cWhat, if anything, can they do to protect their data connected to the social network? Here\u2019s the harsh truth: Not much, short of ceasing to browse the web entirely or deleting your Facebook account.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat about deleting old Facebook and Twitter posts? Brian tried it and found that his \u201cdelete-everything approach was probably not worth most people\u2019s time. And even after all that time, my Facebook timeline was still decorated with posts that my friends had published about me \u2014 including photos from my 21st birthday (need I say more?) \u2014 because that content was not mine to delete.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists. Have the last couple of weeks turned your mind toward leaving Facebook or other social media sites? If you\u2019re inclined, do you think it\u2019s possible to leave? Please send your thoughts to nytcanada@nytimes.com.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRead: How Trump Consultants Exploited the Facebook Data of Millions\n\nRead: Cambridge Analytica Whistle-Blower Contends Data-Mining Swung Brexit Vote\n\nRead: How to Protect Yourself (and Your Friends) on Facebook\n\nRead: Want to Purge Your Social Media Timelines? Can You Spare a Few Hours?\n\nHistorical Moment\n\nAbout a year ago, I wrote about how the house where the Dionne quintuplets were born faced an uncertain future. The birth, and survival, of the quints at the height of the Great Depression was both a global sensation and a tale of grave injustice. The girls were taken from their family and made wards of the province of Ontario, ostensibly to protect them from exploitation. But the government turned around and exhibited almost like zoo animals. Millions of visitors viewed them from a special gallery.\n\nOther injustices and misfortune followed the five through their lives. The decision by the City of North Bay to turn over the log house to a village without the obvious means to maintain or restore it looked like the latest one.\n\nBut much has changed in the past year. After a public campaign, North Bay reversed its decision, and the house has been moved to downtown where it will become a museum.\n\nAnd this week, The Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada designated the birth of the quints an event of national historical significance.\n\nCarlo Tarini, a friend who acts as the family\u2019s spokesman, told me this week that Annette and C\u00e9cile, the two surviving sisters, are doing well, although C\u00e9cile was hospitalized for a time in January because of pneumonia.\n\n\u201cIn the pre-internet decades of the 30s and 40s, the worldwide fascination they sparked as children brings shade to the Kardashian kids popularity,\u201d Mr. Tarini wrote in an email.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRead: 2 Survivors of Canada\u2019s First Quintuplet Clan Reluctantly Re-emerge\n\nTrans Canada\n\n\u2014The Protestant churches involved in a system that took Indigenous children away from their families to boarding schools apologized for their role in during the 1990s. While the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has asked Pope Francis to follow suit, he rejected the idea.\n\n\u2014Alexandre Bissonnette, who killed six men at a mosque in Quebec City last year, pleaded guilty to first degree murder this week. While the move brought relief to survivors and the families of victims, the lack of a trial means that questions about his transformation from university student to killer may go unanswered.\n\n\u2014Rusty Staub, le Grand Orange to Montrealers, has died at the age of 73. During his time with the Montreal Expos, Mr. Staub endeared himself to Quebecers on the field.\n\n\u2014Peter Munk, who created one of Canada\u2019s biggest business fiascos at Clairtone and then rebounded to build the world\u2019s largest gold mining company, has died at the age of 90 in Toronto.", "title": "A Whistle-Blower\u2019s Canadian Roots: The Canada Letter", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The novel begins with a father learning he has a fatal disease. He is a widower, whose young son has Down syndrome, and the two decide to travel across the country. Think \u201cThe Road\u201d by Cormac McCarthy with Ball\u2019s signature surreal flourishes \u2014 the father works for an enigmatic census organization that inexplicably has him mark the people he meets with a small tattoo on the low rung of their ribs.\n\nPhoto\n\nItalo Calvino\u2019s influence has always permeated Ball\u2019s work, never more than here. As father and son rove the country, they enact the central observation in \u201cInvisible Cities\u201d: \u201cYou take delight not in a city\u2019s seven or 70 wonders, but in the answer it gives to a question of yours.\u201d The questions propelling the father forward in \u201cCensus\u201d are: To what kind of world is he abandoning his son? What prompts us to kindness or cruelty? Who will be his son\u2019s protector?\n\nThe challenge, Ball said in an interview with Publishers Weekly, was to write about someone with Down syndrome even though \u201cthe use of any of the language associated with disability and handicap immediately forfeits any possibility for a full portrait.\u201d He settled on an ingenious solution: to write a \u201chollow\u201d book. The son is at the center of the story but only portrayed through his effect on other people. We know him through the range of responses he elicits: hostility, mockery, easy camaraderie, guarded acceptance, joyful recognition. \u201cThey came, as I said, out of the house, a man and woman together,\u201d the father notes of one encounter. \u201cPeople come rather quickly towards you, don\u2019t they? And then they stop at a distance they consider safe \u2014 but it is never the same distance.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut we do directly see the father\u2019s admiration for his son, for his ability to \u201cleap out of his heart into some empathy with the thing observed, whether it is a Ferris wheel or a tortoise.\u201d This point \u2014 about the beautiful varieties of perception, of experience \u2014 made without sentimentality, burns at the core of the book, and of much of Ball\u2019s work, which rails against the tedium of consensus, the cruelty of conformity.\n\nIn one home, the father and son come across a couple whose daughter had Down syndrome. \u201cI can see from the way you are with him that you see \u2014 you see what we saw, that they experience the world just as we do, and maybe even, maybe even in a clearer light,\u201d the woman says.\n\nI can think of no higher praise for this novel than to echo what this woman tells the father for traveling with his son, for letting the world experience his gift: \u201cI think you cannot know the good you do.\u201d", "title": "A Widower and His Son Find Kindness and Cruelty on the Road in \u2018Census\u2019", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "In Alabama\u2019s recent special Senate election, the progressive group Priorities USA was looking for ways to lift African-American voter turnout. So Priorities tested several different advertisements, to see which ones made people want to vote.\n\nThere was no shortage of potential ad material in Alabama. Roy Moore, the Republican nominee, had a trail of bigoted statements and alleged sexual molestation. Doug Jones, the Democrat, had prosecuted Ku Klux Klansmen for murder. Priorities tested each of these themes and others, too: Moore\u2019s ties to white supremacists; Moore\u2019s closeness to President Trump; Jones\u2019s endorsements from civil-rights leaders.\n\nYet none of these tested as well as a 15-second ad that never mentioned Moore.\n\n\u201cMy kids are going to do more than just survive the bigotry and hatred,\u201d a female narrator says, as the video shows a Klan march and then a student at a desk. \u201cThey\u2019re going to get an education, start a business, earn a good living, make me proud. Education is my priority. That\u2019s why I\u2019m voting for Doug Jones.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Winning Political Issue Hiding in Plain Sight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "One particularly audacious show at the Mus\u00e9e d\u2019Orsay was \u201cSade: Attacking the Sun.\u201d It focused on how the writings of the Marquis de Sade (who inspired the term \u201csadism\u201d) spurred a revolution in art. Containing works of a violent nature, it featured artists including Goya, Ingres, Rodin and Picasso. Another box-office hit was \u201cAmerican Painting in the 1930s,\u201d held at the Orangerie and organized jointly with the Art Institute of Chicago, which showcased works by Georgia O\u2019Keeffe and Edward Hopper, and Grant Wood\u2019s \u201cAmerican Gothic.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHer seven years in Abu Dhabi were not without challenges. The Louvre Abu Dhabi project \u2014 for which Abu Dhabi agreed to pay around 1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion, to the Louvre and a group of other French museums \u2014 drew howls of disapproval from French art circles when it was announced. Fran\u00e7oise Cachin, the first director of the Mus\u00e9e d\u2019Orsay, co-signed an editorial in Le Monde accusing France\u2019s politicians of selling their soul.\n\n\u201cThere was an extremely violent debate going on in the world of museums at the time. It was like a family feud,\u201d Ms. des Cars said in an interview. \u201cIt was a very painful thing for those who believed in the project. I happened to be one of them, and I\u2019m very pleased about that. I never had any doubts about Louvre Abu Dhabi.\u201d She said that she was \u201cproud\u201d of the museum (which was inaugurated in November), and that she learned a lot there: \u201cI would not be the president of Orsay if I hadn\u2019t had the experience of Louvre Abu Dhabi.\u201d\n\nAs president of two museums \u2014 meaning the equivalent of both chairwoman and director \u2014 she no longer has time to curate. Yet her passion for the art of the late 19th and early 20th centuries remains boundless, and she is determined to communicate that passion to the widest possible audience, taking art off its proverbial pedestal.\n\nThe following conversation with Ms. des Cars has been edited and condensed.\n\nWhat are you focusing on at the museums these days?\n\nWe\u2019re getting ready to rehang the collections of the Mus\u00e9e d\u2019Orsay and of the Mus\u00e9e de l\u2019Orangerie. We\u2019re figuring out what we\u2019re trying to say with these collections, how we\u2019re going to say it, and how we\u2019re going to address today\u2019s audiences. That\u2019s one of my prime concerns: the capacity to address new audiences.\n\nCultural habits have changed a lot in the past 15 to 20 years, with the emergence of digital media and of new communication tools. We\u2019re looking at a new generation of visitors, and of non-visitors: people who don\u2019t come to museums for all sorts of reasons. How do we address these new visitors, and how do we break down the barriers for those who stay away, or who feel distanced from museums?\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite your appointment last year, the French museum world is heavily male, and that\u2019s true of the rest of Europe, too. Why?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a consequence of official institutions not reaching out to women enough, or not giving them enough confidence. We\u2019re talking about cultural habits that are deeply ingrained in our societies.\n\nThere is also a kind of self-censorship on the part of my female peers: a fear of going for a big job, of exposing themselves, because it\u2019s never easy. In the English-speaking world, applicants for big museum jobs are protected. For example, at the present time, we don\u2019t know who the candidates are for the directorship of New York\u2019s Metropolitan Museum of Art. At the Mus\u00e9e d\u2019Orsay, we were four candidates, and our names were immediately leaked to the press. So you find yourself publicly exposed, with everything that entails: You\u2019re judged by the public and the press, you\u2019re talked about in the art milieu.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen there\u2019s the issue of self-censorship \u2014 of women thinking, \u201cI\u2019m not up to that kind of job.\u201d Women need to overcome their personal doubts, and to tell themselves: \u201cI\u2019m capable of this. It\u2019s coming at the right time in my life and in my career. I\u2019m ready for this.\u201d\n\nHas the presidency of Emmanuel Macron changed things?\n\nThe president has made strong statements on the subject. But these things always take time. We\u2019ll see in the months and years ahead \u2014 in the museum world, for example \u2014 whether there will be genuine change whenever there are jobs to fill.\n\nWhat do you think of the #MeToo campaign?\n\nSomething very important is happening in Western societies. This is an absolutely necessary moment. At the same time, we have to reach a point where this whole discourse is digested and completely interiorized. That will be a truly fascinating moment.\n\nWe cannot lose sight of the ultimate objective, which is a peaceful society where men and women enjoy equality in everyday life and in the workplace. We\u2019re clearly not there yet.", "title": "A Woman Who Is a Rare Find Among Museum Leaders", "authors": ["Farah Nayeri"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "In 2008, McCann, by then an established star, was behind the plate when Morton made his major league debut. They joined the Astros before last season \u2014 McCann coming via a trade with the Yankees, Morton arriving from Philadelphia as a free agent.\n\nFor all their shared experiences, they could not be more different.\n\nMcCann, who grew up in Duluth, Ga., outside Atlanta, is bearded, bald and burly, and a seven-time All-Star whose biting wit, keen baseball mind and easy confidence have made him a clubhouse leader. Morton, who grew up in Redding, Conn., is towering and lithe, an introspective journeyman whose talent has often exceeded his confidence, which at times has been as fragile as his health. He has undergone surgeries on his elbow, hip (twice) and hamstring.\n\nBut in each of their voices, there is an appreciation for the path the other has taken. They were the only players on that Area Code Games team, which was run by Pittsburgh Pirates scouts, to ascend to the major leagues. And among the 52 players drafted by the Braves in their class, they are among six who reached the majors and the only ones still there.\n\nMcCann recalls arriving at the Braves\u2019 minor league complex in 2002 after signing and seeing two other players in the clubhouse. One was Morton. Their rooms were across the hall from each other at the hotel where they lived, and they hung out during a stage in a ballplayer\u2019s life that usually involves video games and pizza delivery.\n\n\u201cWhen you sign, you\u2019re going to a place where you don\u2019t know what to expect,\u201d Morton said. \u201cThere are people of different ages, different backgrounds, different nationalities, different cultures and you\u2019re just showing up. You\u2019re all there to begin your career and become acclimated to professional baseball. It\u2019s not even necessarily about baseball. It\u2019s more about adhering to structure and responsibility and then you go from there.\u201d\n\nThree years later, Morton was going nowhere. Still in low Class A in Rome, Ga., \u201ctrying to figure out who I was on the field, off the field,\u201d he said, he went to eat at a Fuddruckers restaurant across the street from the ballpark. On the television, he watched McCann\u2019s second game in the big leagues, on June 11, 2005.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter Braves pitcher John Smoltz finished a complete game, Morton was struck by how emphatic the future Hall of Famer was in congratulating McCann, then 20, after the final out. McCann said he was not sent down to the minors a few days later \u2014 as had been planned \u2014 because Smoltz lobbied Manager Bobby Cox to keep him.\n\nSmoltz recognized then what Morton had gotten a glimpse of in their brief summer together and would get a full viewing of later, when he navigated six innings in a win over the Los Angeles Angels in his major league debut, on June 14, 2008.\n\n\u201cI remember Vladimir Guerrero hitting a ball straight back up the middle,\u201d Morton said. \u201cI\u2019m pretty sure I remember Brian scream, \u2018Watch out,\u2019 even before he hit it.\u201d\n\nMorton described good catchers as having a selfless self-confidence about them.\n\n\u201cIt allows you to feed off their confidence, off their self-determination, off their experience because it\u2019s hard \u2014 especially as a young guy \u2014 to look in and believe in the totality of the decisions you\u2019re making, pitch to pitch, batter to batter,\u201d Morton said. \u201cBut a good catcher, you can see it in their eyes, you can see it in their face \u2014 how they receive the ball, how the game is called \u2014 that quiet, I-know-what-I\u2019m-doing look in their eyes.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt could not have hurt Morton to have such a settling hand when he went to the mound to begin the sixth inning of Game 7 against the Dodgers in November. It was Morton\u2019s first relief appearance in nine years, and it is hard to overstate how desperately Houston was counting on him. Though the Astros led, 5-0, they had already used four pitchers from a threadbare bullpen.\n\nMorton\u2019s outing did not start promisingly: The Dodgers had one run in and two runners on with one out, bringing Dodger Stadium alive and the top of the order to the plate.\n\n\u201cI was just trying to throw as hard as I could,\u201d said Morton, who had one fastball clocked at 99 miles per hour. \u201cI remember thinking: Wow, the ball\u2019s coming out really well, but I don\u2019t know where it\u2019s going because I\u2019m trying to throw it really hard. Then I threw a couple where it\u2019s just, \u2018make a pitch,\u2019 and I look up to see if the ball is coming out well on the radar gun and it was like the same.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe regathering helped. Morton struck out Chris Taylor on three pitches, the final one a sharp-breaking curve. He then shattered Seager\u2019s bat \u2014 a shard hit Morton on the thigh \u2014 to escape. He did not allow another base runner.\n\n\u201cAfter the pitch he made on Seager, I knew from catching him that he was going to finish the game,\u201d McCann said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was an extraordinary show of faith in a pitcher who has a losing record in his career (60-78) and whom the Astros pitching coach Brent Strom described as a glass half-empty guy. Just to be sure, Astros Manager A. J. Hinch had Justin Verlander \u2014 who threw 93 pitches the day before \u2014 warming up in the ninth inning.\n\nBut McCann\u2019s faith was buttressed by his history with Morton, who was 14-7 with a 3.62 earned run average in the best season of his career and even better in the playoffs. He threw five shutout innings in the Astros\u2019 4-0 win over the Yankees in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, and left Game 4 of the World Series with one out in the seventh and a 1-0 lead the bullpen would not hold.\n\n\u201cWhen it\u2019s all synced up, he\u2019s one of the best pitchers in the game,\u201d McCann said.\n\n\u201cI just remember those Game 7s how calm he was, like he had played this moment in his head a million times. Not one moment got too big for him \u2014 he owned it.\u201d\n\nThat is not completely true. Morton said his one anxious moment came at the start of the ninth inning of Game 7 against the Dodgers, when Chase Utley, who was hitless in the postseason but 5 for 10 with a double and a homer in his career against Morton, was called upon to pinch-hit.\n\n\u201cThat was a game within a game for me,\u201d Morton said. \u201cThis isn\u2019t to take away from any other hitters in the game, but over a 10-year stretch, he\u2019s a guy that I felt was really going to give me a hard time. So when Chase Utley steps into the box in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the World Series, you\u2019re like, uh, all right, let\u2019s see how this goes.\u201d\n\nIt went just fine. Morton struck Utley out on three pitches.\n\nThen he retired Taylor and Seager on routine grounders to Altuve.\n\nWhen first baseman Yuli Gurriel gloved Altuve\u2019s final throw, shortstop Carlos Correa hurled his glove in the air, third baseman Alex Bregman sank to his knees and a brigade of pitchers burst through the bullpen gates. Morton checked to make sure it was the third out.\n\n\u201cYou kind of get lost in the moment,\u201d he said. \u201cI think we were on a good roll, we were making pitches and then, just like that, the season\u2019s over. You throw one pitch and the whole thing is over.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt has been a little more than four months since the World Series ended. McCann, who had never advanced in five previous trips to the playoffs, said that time \u2014 and the watching and rewatching of the playoffs from his couch \u2014 had allowed for a deeper appreciation of how hard it is to win and for how remarkable the Series was.\n\nMorton said he had rewatched Game 7 only a handful of times. It was not transformative, he said, or a validation. What if he is back in the same spot this season and ends up losing? But it was, he added, a reminder of why the game matters.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t romanticize baseball as much as people would love us to,\u201d Morton said as he stood inside the clubhouse this month. \u201cAfter a certain amount of time \u2014 I was drafted in 2002 and here we are 16 years later \u2014 and it\u2019s become a job. It\u2019s still appealing in the way that I get to go play baseball for a living, but the utopian idea of it, that\u2019s kind of played out and now I have legitimate responsibilities to the organization, to myself and my family because it\u2019s become about more than just me.\u201d\n\nHe paused to think.\n\n\u201cBut those moments,\u201d Morton continued. \u201cIn baseball, if you\u2019re speaking from in here, in this environment, that\u2019s what we live for.\u201d", "title": "A World Series Embrace Was Only One Stop on a Shared Journey", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat continues to mark this fair is the influx of great galleries coming in from all over the world \u2014 especially the Western world,\u201d said Marc Spiegler, the global director of Art Basel. \u201cIt reflects the potential they see.\u201d He cited two new entries this year: Tanya Bonakdar and Friedrich Petzel, both New York dealers.\n\nIn fact, there is more demand than supply in terms of booth space in the convention center.\n\n\u201cFor the last several years, because the fair is so potentially attractive to galleries, we\u2019ve limited ourselves to half of the total slots for those that are only active in the West,\u201d Mr. Spiegler said, part of an effort to keep some Asian character to the fair.\n\nThey are keeping strict accounts: Of the 28 new galleries this year, 14 have exhibition spaces somewhere in Asia.\n\nFor American and European galleries that want to be admitted, Mr. Spiegler even assigns homework. \u201cFor an established gallery from the West, the beauty and the terror of this fair is that\u2019s it\u2019s a meritocracy,\u201d he said, and not just during the fair. \u201cYou need a strategy. In order to succeed, you will have to put time in and designate someone to show face in person, since that\u2019s important in Asia.\u201d\n\nMr. Spiegler said that such conversations put him in a surprising position at times: \u201cThere are galleries we\u2019d love to have, but once we speak we realize they have work to do before their first appearance. It\u2019s a surreal experience for a fair director to caution big galleries from entering a fair, but it\u2019s the responsible thing to do.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSome of the biggest international galleries have already set down roots in Hong Kong, and one building in particular has proved alluring: the art-focused, 24-story development H Queen\u2019s. So far the tenants that have either opened space or plan to soon include the heavy hitters Pace, Hauser & Wirth, and David Zwirner. It\u2019s also Ms. Lam\u2019s Hong Kong outpost.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s added a new layer of excitement to the Hong Kong art scene,\u201d said Leo Xu, the director of David Zwirner\u2019s gallery there. \u201cThe building is a vertical Chelsea.\u201d\n\nAt the fair, Zwirner will show five recent works by Jeff Koons. The concurrent show in the gallery\u2019s space at H Queen\u2019s features the German photographer Wolfgang Tillmans. And the idea is that the exhibitions bolster each other: \u201cPeople at the fair can get a taste of the gallery program,\u201d said Mr. Xu, who formerly had his own gallery in Shanghai.\n\n[READ MORE: Where to Play (and Eat) in Hong Kong]\n\nH Queen\u2019s is only one facet of the steadily growing Hong Kong art scene. Parts of it have benefited from governmental largess, in particular the West Kowloon Cultural District. The scheduled 2019 debut of M+, a major new art center, is also expected to up the ante.\n\nThe city\u2019s top dealers all want Hong Kong to have strong, leading voices from the noncommercial sphere \u2014 they know that a healthy art ecosystem always features that element, with New York and London as prime examples.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hoping that when M+ opens, they will step up and become that voice,\u201d Ms. Lam said.\n\nAlthough they both try to target some of the same collectors, the auction houses have welcomed other players.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBetween fairs and auctions, I see positive energy,\u201d said Rebecca Wei, the president of Christie\u2019s Asia, who is based in Hong Kong and attends the fair on multiple days.\n\nDiversity of business models helps. Ms. Wei pointed out the difference in approaches from the opening price: \u201cIn auctions, you hammer up, and at fairs, you bargain down.\u201d\n\nThe auction house view is that anything that gets a person to buy art for the first time is good. \u201cLast year, one-third of buyers globally were new to Christie\u2019s,\u201d Ms. Wei said. \u201cAnd 22 percent of them were from Asia.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd the fair, with its focus on cutting-edge artists, brings new blood to the spring and fall contemporary art auctions. \u201cThey have introduced so many artist names to Asia,\u201d Ms. Wei said. \u201cIt\u2019s only four days, but it\u2019s a vast show. They bring a huge supply to Hong Kong.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe global nature of the art world means that a Mexico City-based gallery featuring a renowned Mexican artist is not out of place at an art fair in Hong Kong. The Kurimanzutto gallery will fill its booth with works by Gabriel Orozco, who has had his own solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.\n\nThe gallery made its debut at Art Basel Hong Kong last year. \u201cWe were quite impressed by the response from collectors,\u201d said M\u00f3nica Manzutto, the co-founder. \u201cWe managed to find great contacts.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Orozco is a relatively known quantity among Asian institutions, and is featured in the collection of Tokyo\u2019s Museum of Contemporary Art, among others. He has also been living in the region for the past several years, first in Tokyo and now in Bali.\n\n\u201cHe tries to understand the specifics of the place he\u2019s living,\u201d Ms. Manzutto said. \u201cWe thought collectors from the region would want to see how that has impacted his art.\u201d\n\nShe said that two of the limestone sculptures in the booth, \u201cD\u00e9 Orbital\u201d and \u201cD\u00e9 Fleur,\u201d both from 2018, demonstrate how Mr. Orozco has learned from Balinese carving techniques.\n\nTaking a wider view, Mr. Spiegler pointed out that the idea of talking about Asia as a single market is somewhat absurd, given its geographical vastness and the number of countries and cultures it includes. Ms. Lam said that for her money, South Korea \u2014 about 2,000 miles away \u2014 is actually the continent\u2019s most sophisticated art market.\n\nBut in the eyes of dealers and fair organizers, that means only that there\u2019s room to grow.\n\n\u201cWe claim a certain degree of credit,\u201d Mr. Spiegler said. \u201cThis show not only builds a bridge between East and West, it builds them between different markets in Asia.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cFor Australians, the idea of a great art fair only eight hours away was a godsend.\u201d", "title": "A Worldwide Focus on Hong Kong for Art Basel", "authors": ["Ted Loos"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "MAKHACHKALA, Russia \u2014 Dagestan, a mostly Muslim region in the south of Russia on the northwest coast of the Caspian Sea, is known for the stark beauty of its mountain landscapes, for its many small ethnic groups, for a violent and long-simmering Islamist insurgency \u2014 and for its wrestlers.\n\nThousands of young boys here dream of becoming famous and honored wrestlers, like the many lithe and muscly Olympic champions who came before them. Buvaisar Saitiev won three gold medals, for example, and Mavlet Batirov two.\n\nTowns and villages pour resources into the sport, hiring coaches and transforming movie theaters into gyms. The young boys turn out to stretch and strengthen their muscles, and grapple on the mats before their cheering friends.", "title": "A Wrestling Culture That Helps Keep Boys Away From Fighting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "You seem to have an eye for young artists.\n\nThere\u2019s such good energy here. I went to the School of Visual Arts M.F.A. open studios yesterday, and it was fun and bubbly, and there were a couple of really good artists. You can meet them at a point before it gets too New York and serious. It used to be that young artists weren\u2019t being looked at until they were a bit older.\n\nHow did Times Square Space develop?\n\nI did that as a crazy experiment and it went really well: Basically, when an office moves out, I move into spaces between rentals. It\u2019s quite nice because you get the remnants of their presence.\n\nYour parents are such major collectors, do you have separation between your works and theirs?\n\nIt started off with boundaries, and then it started getting confusing. I would buy something, and then my mum would want it as well, for a show. Now, if it\u2019s purchased by me, I have authority over it, so I can say, \u201cOh, I don\u2019t want it to be in that show.\u201d But it\u2019s still part of the larger collection.\n\nYou\u2019re young. Has the New York art world made space for you?\n\nI\u2019ve made my own space, I like to think. If you come in and you\u2019re genuinely interested, and you want to learn, usually people are welcoming \u2014 as long as you are serious about it, and willing to do the work. Because they can also be quite discerning.\n\nWhat\u2019s the difference between the London and New York art worlds?\n\nLondon\u2019s more intimate, and it feels sometimes more experimental. The spaces are more affordable. Here, there\u2019s amazing work, but I think it can be a bit too much about the market. Maybe a difference is that there\u2019s always six things a night here, whereas in London there would be one or two \u2014 which is maybe better. [laughs]", "title": "A Young Collector Continues the Family Tradition in SoHo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In her novel \u201cAmericanah,\u201d the Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie had a blogger write: \u201cOne great gift for the Zipped-Up Negro is The White Friend Who Gets It.\u201d Niru is as zipped up as a freezer bag. And the sensitive Meredith, who resembles \u201ca younger Anne Hathaway,\u201d gets it.\n\nShe so wants to be useful to her gay friend that she secretly installs Grindr and other dating apps on his phone. When Niru\u2019s father sees his flashing notifications and asks \u201cWho is Ryan?\u201d this novel\u2019s fuse is lit.\n\nBefore long Niru and his father are on their way back to Nigeria for gay conversion therapy of a sort that would warm the ventricles of Mike Pence\u2019s tattletale heart.\n\nPhoto\n\nIweala plays Niru\u2019s story as tragedy, not farce. Indeed, one of this book\u2019s essential points is that reckless fun is only for white teenagers. Niru may be a track star and headed to Harvard (early admission), but he has to be perpetually wary.\n\n\u201cI look at these kids laughing with each other, standing without jackets like even the cold can\u2019t touch them and I don\u2019t understand why there are people for whom rules and norms are fully optional, for whom foolishness is celebrated,\u201d Niru thinks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhite kids smoke weed, ingest cocaine and hook up freely. \u201cAnd there is me,\u201d he says, \u201cblack, sober and scared to death by locker room banter.\u201d\n\n\u201cSpeak No Evil\u201d is a muted, minor-chord novel. The trip to Nigeria and a startling moment of racial violence late in the book aside, it is a fairly mild and conventional gay coming-of-age novel, a sarsaparilla instead of a shot.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s a book about race and gender and identity but not an especially telling book about those things. Its characters are thin. There is no sting in its tail, no joker in its pack, no treble in its sonics. Its two parts, one narrated by Niru, the other by Meredith, fuse awkwardly.\n\nSome writers can smack a genre\u2019s clich\u00e9s and coax them back to life. Iweala in this case is not among them. The \u201cIt Gets Better\u201d movement is a glorious thing, for example, but that phrase is repeated too many times in this novel.\n\nWhen Niru goes to a running event, he says what you somehow know he is going to say: \u201cToday we\u2019re going to leave it all on the track.\u201d The cute boy he begins to date is from central casting.\n\nThere are signs Iweala knew his long-gestating novel had problems. In the acknowledgments he thanks his editor for her \u201ctolerance of tabletops full of index cards instead of pages of text.\u201d\n\nHe thanks another woman for \u201cyour insistence that there was a good book hidden somewhere in the jumble of pages.\u201d A third woman is credited with \u201clistening to me cry about it, whine, try to quit writing, not quit, and then try to quit again.\u201d You begin to feel you are holding less the product of a natural birth than an emergency cesarean.\n\n(Students of effusive acknowledgments will find much to digest in Iweala\u2019s six pages of them. One couple is thanked for \u201cthat wood-smoked salmon,\u201d another for \u201cthat charred kale salad tho.\u201d A woman is thanked \u201cbecause three words: Italian, hot, sauce.\u201d Niru, alas, is a picky eater.)\n\nThere are moments in this novel that hint at Iweala\u2019s freer, more essayistic voice. He is probing on how, back home in Nigeria, Niru\u2019s father is a different man \u2014 larger and louder, he seems to take up more space. Niru\u2019s older brother diagnoses this change as \u201cNigeriatoma, an acute swelling of ego and pride.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNiru goes on: \u201cSymptoms may vary but are exceptionally pronounced upon return to native soil and include hyperactivity, elevated mood, grandiose thinking and increased aggression.\u201d Finally he adds, \u201cThe duration of symptoms may vary, but poor electricity, bad roads and exposure to extreme heat have proven effective as treatment.\u201d\n\nHere is the vivid scene when Niru\u2019s father first confronts him about his apparent homosexuality: \u201cHe grabs my ear. Daddy, I yelp as he twists and pulls me forward. You want to go and do gay marriage, is that what you want, you want to go and carry man, put your thing for his nyash? Abomination. A BOMI NATION. He pushes my face down into the kitchen table.\u201d\n\nNot enough scenes are this alive. Like so many second novels, this one feels like a book Iweala had to get out of the way in order to arrive at what he really wants to write next.", "title": "A Young Man of Strict Nigerian-American Parents Comes of Age While Coming Out", "authors": ["Dwight Garner", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "A 15-year-old girl, Masako Kobayashi, sat alone on a hill a few weeks after Japan was hit by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, a disaster that struck on March 11, killed almost 16,000 people and led to the Fukushima nuclear plant meltdown. She gazed at the devastated land for hours. More than 200 residents of Kesen, her small community within the coastal city of Rikuzentakata, were dead. Of some 550 homes, all but two were destroyed. Most survivors left, but about 15 residents refused to abandon their town, living amid the debris for months without electricity or water.\n\nMasako, now 22, was one of them. She had survived the disaster along with her father, Nobuo, the chief monk of the temple; her mother, Kouko; and her older brother, Takamasa. She lost her house and all of her belongings, and the most important thing for her family \u2014 the Kongoji Temple, the historic Buddhist temple according to Nobuo had been established about 1,200 years ago and had been the heart of the community for centuries \u2014 had washed away.", "title": "Opinion | A Young Monk Finds Her Calling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "A \u2018Really Bright Light\u2019\n\nAs a student at Woodrow Wilson High School in Camden, N.J., Nakesha had excelled. She was class president and a member of the National Honor Society; she sang in two choirs and worked on the school newspaper.\n\nThe yearbook described her as one of two students who \u201cdid the most\u201d for their class and school. She graduated in 1988 third in her class of more than 200 seniors, and her college tuition was covered by scholarships, some from local churches.\n\nTo Nakesha, Williams College, a competitive private liberal arts school in pastoral Berkshire County, must have seemed a world away from home.\n\nYet she adjusted easily. A former classmate, Valda Clark Christian, now a health care executive in Maryland, recalled how Nakesha had warmly introduced her to the relatives who accompanied her to campus. \u201cI can\u2019t think of anybody who met her and didn\u2019t fall right into some comfort and familiarity,\u201d Ms. Clark Christian said.\n\nPart of a close-knit group of students of color, Nakesha joined the college\u2019s gospel choir and a traditional African dance troupe called Kusika, which Ms. Burton directed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNakesha, Ms. Clark Christian and two other students were seen together so often that they became known on campus as the Four Musketeers.\n\n\u201cThey were like the women you looked up to, that you admired,\u201d said Tanya Nicholson Miller, another former classmate and now an educational consultant in New Jersey. \u201cIt was just like the way they carried themselves on campus, their sense of self-esteem.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNakesha was also a source of support for other students \u2014 a \u201creally bright light to all of the faculty and her peers,\u201d Ms. Burton recalled.\n\nBecky Dickinson, who had felt self-conscious about performing, said she joined Kusika only after Nakesha encouraged her.\n\n\u201cI do remember her saying like, \u2018You can do this,\u2019\u201d Ms. Dickinson said. \u201cI admired her. She was inspiring.\u201d\n\nIn her dorm room, Nakesha kept a photograph of her mother, Geraldine Williams, and she had saved her mother\u2019s cards and letters, which often bore an imprint of a lipstick kiss.\n\nIn the fall of 1990, several weeks into her junior year, Nakesha learned that her mother, who had breast cancer, had become gravely ill. Nakesha withdrew from school and returned to New Jersey, moving into the Willingboro home of her aunt, Jacqueline Fattore, who was caring for Geraldine.\n\nNakesha slept in a recliner at the foot of her mother\u2019s bed in the den. \u201cI spent every moment I could at her side,\u201d Nakesha later wrote in an essay about her mother\u2019s final days.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGeraldine was an unwed teenager when Nakesha was born in 1970. Although she soon married Nakesha\u2019s father, Marvin Rothmiller, they divorced several years later. Geraldine became involved with an abusive man who repeatedly molested Nakesha when she was just a child, as Nakesha eventually confided to Ms. Burton and others. (The man was later convicted in a drug case and has since died.)\n\nNakesha was sent to live with her maternal grandmother, with whom she stayed until leaving for college. But she remained close to her mother, and was devastated by her death in February 1991, at the age of 37.\n\n\u201cI looked at her face,\u201d Nakesha wrote. \u201cFor the first time in my life, I saw a calm that wasn\u2019t clouded by bitterness, hurt or anger.\u201d\n\nNakesha enrolled for the spring semester at Rutgers University\u2019s Camden campus, and in the fall, returned to Williams College, with a renewed sense of dedication and seriousness, Ms. Burton recalled.\n\nPhoto\n\nOver the next two years, Nakesha focused on researching, writing, choreographing and directing an ambitious senior project \u2014 a panoramic performance of black dance, from its origins in Africa through contemporary hip-hop.\n\nNakesha, lithe and petite, also performed in the two-hour show in March 1993 which involved some 20 dancers and musicians. It was called \u201cIf You Can Walk, You Can Dance, If You Can Talk, You Can Sing.\u201d\n\nNavin Girishankar, a drummer, remembered the hours they had spent rehearsing in a campus studio.\n\n\u201cEverything I would throw at her, with these little drumming moves, she\u2019d come up with something even more brilliant,\u201d he said.\n\nThe show was a sensation.\n\n\u201cThe audience was immediately aware of the great care and love that went into the production,\u201d the college newspaper, The Williams Record, said in a review.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNakesha was awarded a prize established in memory of the college\u2019s first black graduate for the \u201cbest scholarly work submitted by a Williams undergraduate in the field of Africana studies.\u201d\n\nReginald Hildebrand, who taught Nakesha African-American history, said he had \u201cexpected her to be one of the leading individuals in whatever she was going to do in her generation.\u201d\n\n\u2018A Wandering, Unstable State\u2019\n\nAfter graduation, Nakesha went to work at Sewickley Academy, a private school near Pittsburgh that at the time enrolled about 700 students. One former student, Lisa Bevevino, to whom Nakesha taught sixth-grade history, remembered Nakesha as beloved by students, often sitting on the floor with them, talking through their problems and assigning projects that provoked creativity.\n\nOnce, she said, Nakesha had each student invent a holiday and write about how it would be celebrated, the values it promoted and what artifacts would be involved.\n\n\u201cShe was one of the foundational people,\u201d said Ms. Bevevino, now an assistant professor of French and Latin at the University of Minnesota, Morris, \u201cthat really cared about how we were doing and how we thought about the world.\u201d\n\nIn 1996, after three years, Nakesha abruptly left Sewickley. Neither Ms. Bevevino nor anyone else could recall her giving a clear reason for her departure.\n\nPhoto\n\nNakesha drifted over the next decade, moving among family members and friends and holding odd jobs, working as a sales clerk at Victoria\u2019s Secret and as a bridge toll collector. She took computer software courses, and a writing class at Temple University in Philadelphia, where she wrote the essay about her mother\u2019s death. Hints of her mental illness began to surface.\n\nIn 1997, Ms. Burton and her husband invited Nakesha to live with them in Hancock, Mass., a short distance from Williams College, where Nakesha found administrative work in the dance department. The couple had been concerned that Nakesha had quit her teaching job, and they sensed that something was not right. One day, Ms. Burton said, she arrived home to find all the curtains drawn. Nakesha said she believed someone had followed her home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a few months, Nakesha decided to move to New York, against the advice of Ms. Burton and her husband. \u201cWhat could we do?\u201d Ms. Burton said. \u201cShe was an adult.\u201d\n\nBy the summer of 1998, Nakesha was living in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, with Anim Steel, a former college classmate. Mr. Steel had been captivated by Nakesha when they first met at Williams, writing in his journal, \u201cI\u2019ve never met anyone like her.\u201d\n\nIn Brooklyn, they shopped together, played kickball and visited the Statue of Liberty for Nakesha\u2019s birthday. But Nakesha was having bouts of anxiety, Mr. Steel said, and he found a therapist who agreed to see her on a pro bono basis.\n\nThe therapy did not last; Mr. Steel moved to Boston at the end of the summer, and Nakesha stopped seeing the doctor. She moved in with another friend, Greg Holland, a paralegal and friend from high school, who she once described as being \u201clike a brother.\u201d\n\nAfter about two years, Mr. Holland recalled, Nakesha began claiming that the C.I.A. was looking for her. She stopped working and paying her share of the rent. She moved back to New Jersey, first staying with her father and then with other relatives. Her erratic behavior continued, and she began to cut off family members.\n\nIn the summer of 2001, a former college classmate, Joan Rocklin, invited Nakesha to dinner in Manhattan. As first-year students at Williams, they lived across the hall from each other, and had remained friends. Ms. Rocklin was planning to move to teach at the University of Oregon School of Law and wanted to see Nakesha before leaving.\n\nAs they relaxed in Ms. Rocklin\u2019s apartment, Nakesha mentioned that she had found messages in books she was reading. Ms. Rocklin assumed Nakesha meant certain books had seemed meaningful to her; she was disturbed to learn that Nakesha meant actual written messages.\n\nNakesha moved a few years later to Philadelphia, where she taught at an adult literacy center. Her supervisor recalled her as a talented teacher but said she began talking to herself and complaining that people were stealing from her, and she eventually left the job without collecting her last paycheck.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was in November 2006 that Ms. Rocklin received the first in a stream of emails from Nakesha.\n\n\u201cHey Joan, What\u2019s going on?\u201d Nakesha wrote. \u201cI\u2019m stuck in California right now.\u201d\n\nNakesha said she was \u201cstranded\u201d with no address and could be reached through the Los Angeles library system.\n\nMs. Rocklin responded that she cared about Nakesha and was worried \u201cwhether you have shelter at night and whether you are getting enough food.\u201d\n\nNakesha, then 36, replied that she was \u201cnot exactly homeless,\u201d but was in \u201ca wandering, unstable state that is sad at best.\u201d", "title": "A \u2018Bright Light,\u2019 Dimmed in the Shadows of Homelessness", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "When it comes to our weight, is there a \u201csweet spot\u201d for heart health?\n\nA large prospective study in the European Heart Journal collected data on almost 300,000 healthy men and women ages 40 to 69 and followed them for an average of five years. Researchers measured obesity in five ways: body mass index, waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, waist-to-height ratio and percentage body fat mass.\n\nThey found that a B.M.I. lower than 18.5 was associated with a higher risk for cardiovascular disease, but the association almost disappeared in people who were nonsmokers or had other diseases. The lowest risk was associated with a B.M.I. between 22 and 23. Beyond that, the risk of cardiovascular disease increased with B.M.I.\n\nWith the four other measures of adiposity, the associations with cardiovascular disease risk were consistent even after controlling for other factors: As those measures increased, so did the risk for cardiovascular disease.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re healthy, you can lower your risk of cardiovascular disease by being as slim as possible within the normal range of B.M.I.,\u201d said the lead author, Dr. Stamatina Iliodromiti, a lecturer in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Glasgow. \u201cThere is no evidence that extra weight or fat is protective for people without pre-existing disease.\u201d", "title": "A \u2018Sweet Spot\u2019 for Heart Health", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Astros also kept their soul this month by rewarding Jose Altuve with a five-year, $151 million contract extension, through 2024. Altuve, the A.L. most valuable player, said the Cole trade told the team that Luhnow wanted to add another trophy immediately.\n\n\u2014\u2014\n\nRead our National League preview here.\n\n\u2014\u2014\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re aware of everything, how hard it is to win back to back,\u201d Altuve said. \u201cBut it\u2019s not impossible. We\u2019re going to do the best we can to make it happen.\u201d\n\nNo team has repeated since the Yankees won three titles in a row from 1998 through 2000. This is the longest stretch in major league history without a repeat champion, but the Astros have everything they need to change that. Only two of their starters exceeded 200 innings last season: Verlander (242\u2154, including the postseason) and Cole (203). Only two position players, Altuve and third baseman Alex Bregman, played more than 140 games in the regular season.\n\n\u201cPhysically, our guys are fine,\u201d Manager A.J. Hinch said. \u201cThe mental part of it will be our biggest challenge.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cI watched this last season when the Indians and the Cubs \u2014 both World Series teams \u2014 struggled the first month of the season. They were told they were struggling. They were told they were having a hangover. They were told they weren\u2019t playing up to expectations. That has to lead to a ton more anxiety and a ton more tension around a team that you don\u2019t normally have to deal with. You carry a lot of baggage around the following season from winning, and that type of attention isn\u2019t always good attention.\u201d\n\nIf any team is immune to prolonged struggles, though, this should be the one. The Astros, who return almost everyone, led the majors in slugging percentage in 2017 while finishing last in strikeouts. They have mastered the modern power game without the trade-off most teams must make \u2014 like drinking all the Champagne at a party yet feeling just fine the next morning.\n\nExpect no hangover for the 2018 Astros, just another championship banner at Minute Maid Park.\n\nThe rest of the West division should not pose much of a challenge. The game\u2019s best player, Mike Trout, begins his seventh full season with the Los Angeles Angels still seeking his first playoff victory. The Angels will try a six-man rotation behind him, being careful not to ask much from a group that includes no starting candidates who worked even 150 innings last season.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to allow us to use depth,\u201d starter Matt Shoemaker said. \u201cAnd if it gives us extra days to help us stay fresh, it\u2019s just going to help the team, and us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a trying spring training, Shohei Ohtani, the pitching and hitting sensation from Japan, is the great unknown. The Angels upgraded their infield with Ian Kinsler at second base and Zack Cozart at third, and they begin their first full season with left fielder Justin Upton. But designated hitter Albert Pujols, 38, regressed markedly last season and still has four years left on his contract.\n\nDespite a rash of late-spring pitching injuries, the Oakland Athletics don\u2019t feel like a last-place team anymore. They found long-term solutions by putting Matts on their infield corners \u2014 Matt Olson at first base and Matt Chapman at third. And the newcomers Stephen Piscotty and Jonathan Lucroy will help a lineup whose designated hitter, Khris Davis, hit 85 homers the last two seasons. (Only Giancarlo Stanton, with 86, had more.)\n\nCould the A\u2019s sneak up on the field and snag a playoff berth, as they did six years ago? It\u2019s unlikely, but you never know.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s putting pretty high expectations on them, but it is something we\u2019ve discussed, certainly internally but also publicly,\u201d General Manager David Forst said. \u201cThe ideal situation for this team would be to be like the \u201912 team, and be better than expected now and then continue to get better going forward.\u201d\n\nBaseball 2018 Predictions Tyler Kepner makes his picks for the season. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. American League East: Yankees, Orioles (wild card), Red Sox, Blue Jays, Rays A.L. Central: Indians, Twins (wild card), Royals, White Sox, Tigers A.L. West: Astros, Angels, Athletics, Mariners, Rangers National League East: Nationals, Phillies, Mets, Braves, Marlins N.L. Central: Cubs, Cardinals (wild card), Brewers, Pirates, Reds N.L. West: Dodgers, Diamondbacks (wild card), Rockies, Padres, Giants World Series: Astros over Cubs A.L. M.V.P.: Carlos Correa, Astros A.L. Cy Young: Chris Sale, Red Sox A.L. Rookie of the Year: Shohei Ohtani, Angels N.L. M.V.P.: Paul Goldschmidt, Diamondbacks N.L. Cy Young: Stephen Strasburg, Nationals N.L. Rookie of the Year: Ronald Acuna, Braves\n\nThe Seattle Mariners keep trying, but seem destined to miss the playoffs for the 17th season in a row. Even if Nelson Cruz, 37, and Robinson Cano, 35, continue their elite offensive production, a thin rotation dooms this team. The ace James Paxton has pitched parts of five seasons but never made 25 starts, and there\u2019s only mediocrity behind him, including Felix Hernandez, who has a 4.08 earned run average since turning 30 in early 2016.\n\nIf a hitter\u2019s job is to get on base and avoid making outs, the Texas Rangers\u2019 Rougned Odor had a historic performance in 2017: Of all the players to make 500 outs in a season, Odor had the lowest on-base percentage, at .252. He did have 30 homers, but also 162 strikeouts, and symbolized the Rangers\u2019 all-or-nothing offense. They took no steps to improve it, and went bargain-hunting (Mike Minor, Matt Moore, Doug Fister) to address a wobbly rotation.\n\nThe Central\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Cleveland Indians finished 17 games ahead of the Minnesota Twins in the A.L. Central last season, and the gap has narrowed significantly. The Indians lost first baseman Carlos Santana, right fielder Jay Bruce and the setup man Bryan Shaw in free agency, while the Twins added starters Jake Odorizzi and Lance Lynn, relievers Addison Reed and Fernando Rodney, and designated hitter Logan Morrison, among others.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe more or less returned the entire position-player club from last year, which in the second half really performed,\u201d said Derek Falvey, the Twins\u2019 chief baseball officer. \u201cThey\u2019re young and they\u2019re growing. We knew on the pitching side we could add some experience and some depth.\u201d\n\nThe Indians \u2014 a team Falvey helped build \u2014 still have more star power than the Twins, with starters Corey Kluber and Carlos Carrasco, relievers Cody Allen and Andrew Miller and the lineup mainstays Francisco Lindor and Edwin Encarnacion. But this could be the closest division race of them all, with both teams qualifying for the postseason as they batter their three division neighbors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter failing to find a new home in free agency, third baseman Mike Moustakas made a surprise return to the Kansas City Royals, signing on for another year with championship teammates from 2015 like Salvador Perez, Alcides Escobar and Alex Gordon. But with Lorenzo Cain and Eric Hosmer gone via free agency \u2014 and no additions to a weak rotation \u2014 the Royals may slip back to 90 losses and trade whoever they can in July.\n\nThe Chicago White Sox are finished with their tear-down trades, but waiting for their high-end prospects to arrive before adding veterans. In the meantime, they\u2019ll enjoy watching second baseman Yoan Moncada break through as a star beside first baseman Jose Abreu, his fellow Cuban and the team\u2019s steady leader.\n\nAfter going 64-98, the Detroit Tigers hold the No. 1 overall draft pick for just the second time in franchise history. They might do so again in 2019 because this could be the worst team in baseball. The Tigers have three fading veterans combining for $72 million in salaries (Miguel Cabrera, Jordan Zimmermann and Victor Martinez), with nobody else making more than $6.5 million.\n\n\u201cThey might take some lumps, but it\u2019s going to be a learning process and we have to let it unfold in front of our eyes,\u201d said Ron Gardenhire, the veteran manager who replaces Brad Ausmus. \u201cYou can\u2019t force it, you can\u2019t beat \u2019em up. It\u2019s all going to be about patience here.\u201d\n\nThe East\n\nSince the last time the Yankees won the A.L. East, the Boston Red Sox have won it three times and the Baltimore Orioles and the Toronto Blue Jays have each had a turn.
