The Yankees should take back the division for the first time since 2012, and could do it with relative ease.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got a lot of coverage in the infield and outfield side,\u201d General Manager Brian Cashman said. \u201cIn the bullpen, we\u2019ve got a lot of high-leverage guys. The rotation\u2019s the area, like any team, mostly you get affected. You lose some key guys in that rotation, it could be really challenging to your season.\u201d\n\nFair enough, but the Yankees\u2019 group of Luis Severino, Masahiro Tanaka, Sonny Gray, C.C. Sabathia and Jordan Montgomery looks a lot stronger than Boston\u2019s starting staff, which falls off sharply after the left-handers Chris Sale and David Price. And that\u2019s assuming Price\u2019s elbow allows him to make more than the 11 starts he made last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat, then, about the Baltimore Orioles as the second wild-card team, with the Twins? The Red Sox will score a lot of runs, but so could the Orioles, especially if shortstop Manny Machado has a big platform year before free agency and third baseman Tim Beckham builds off his first full season as an everyday player.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe homegrown starters Dylan Bundy and Kevin Gausman may never develop into All-Stars. But they are solid, and remember, the Orioles contended into September last year despite giving 300 innings to Wade Miley and Ubaldo Jimenez, who combined for a 6.18 E.R.A. The newcomers Andrew Cashner and Alex Cobb are bound to do better.\n\nThe Orioles will miss closer Zach Britton for half the season as he recovers from a ruptured Achilles. But it should be no surprise if Manager Buck Showalter finds a way to squeeze this team into the playoffs for the fourth time in seven seasons.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t question the end goal playing for Buck Showalter,\u201d Beckham said. \u201cThe end goal is winning. As a player, with some organizations, you question that.\u201d\n\nThe Toronto Blue Jays seemed to make a halfhearted effort at winning this off-season, opting for complementary moves instead of reloading in Josh Donaldson\u2019s final season before free agency. The Blue Jays wanted to give themselves a chance to contend without touching a farm system they have worked hard to revive. A decent rotation does give them a chance, but only a small one. If the Blue Jays struggle early, expect a major roster overhaul.\n\nThat process is well underway for the Tampa Bay Rays, who plan to use only four starting pitchers this season, using days off and mixing in occasional bullpen games. The Rays\u2019 offense, which strikes out prodigiously, has lost four players who combined for 115 homers last season: Logan Morrison, Corey Dickerson, Evan Longoria and Steven Souza Jr.\n\nThe franchise has finished in last place just once since 2007, the last year it was known as the Devil Rays. The Rays are not changing their name again, but they are searching for a new identity.", "title": "A.L. Preview: Watch Out, the Houston Astros Got Better", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "The ABC family sitcom \u201cblack-ish\u201d has not been shy about plunging into difficult and controversial issues, like the 2016 election, racial slurs and police brutality. But a recent politically charged episode was pulled after a dispute between the network and Kenya Barris, the show\u2019s creator.\n\n\u201cGiven our creative differences, neither ABC nor I were happy with the direction of the episode and mutually agreed not to air it,\u201d Mr. Barris said in a statement.\n\nThe episode, titled \u201cPlease, Baby, Please,\u201d was slated to air on Feb. 27 but was replaced by a rerun. According to Variety, the episode centers on Dre (Anthony Anderson) telling an improvised bedtime story to his infant son that touches on social and political issues in the United States, including a debate over the right of athletes to kneel during the national anthem.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that has always made \u2018black-ish\u2019 so special is how it deftly examines delicate social issues in a way that simultaneously entertains and educates,\u201d a network representative said in a statement to Variety. \u201cHowever, on this episode there were creative differences we were unable to resolve.\u201d ABC did not immediately respond to a request for comment.", "title": "ABC Pulls \u2018black-ish\u2019 Episode Over \u2018Creative Differences\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The ADAA Art Show has made a smart move, scheduling its annual occupation of the Park Avenue Armory a week before the March Madness of New York\u2019s art fairs. Those who give it their undivided attention, without pressure of competing events, will be richly rewarded. This year\u2019s incarnation is the 30th gathering organized by the Art Dealers Association of America and it overflows with interesting material, new and not, in solo and group presentations. Herewith, some tips to help you navigate your way.\n\nThe New New\n\nPhoto\n\nThe latest work by several artists shines in solo shows. At Casey Kaplan Jonathan Gardner continues to cultivate his stylized figurative, still life and landscape painting, in beautiful colors and multiple spatial shifts. He could be our Fernand L\u00e9ger. At David Nolan the artist Wardell Milan reprises his recent breakthrough into panoramic, subtly dystopian paintings of figures in gardens, building on his drawing skill with color, collage and a touches of Cubism. At Van Doren Waxter, Jackie Saccoccio\u2019s latest abstractions effervesce more than ever with dots and carefully directed drips, suggesting windows onto worlds of atomized color. Marian Goodman is showing the exquisitely pastel pods of the sculptor Nairy Baghramian, each fastened to the floor or wall by a black stem, creating a delicious distortion of scale. Sperone Westwater is spotlighting the work of Otto Piene (1928-2014), a founder of Germany\u2019s Zero group, who made his minimalist forms in glamorous glazed ceramic during his last years.\n\nThe New Old\n\nSeveral galleries have solo shows of older material often never seen before (or not lately). In three instances works from the 1960s or \u201970s underscore the achievements of distinguished female artists. Anglim Gilbert has an extraordinary trove of mostly delicate drawings of women\u2019s bodies by the pioneering Lynn Hershman Leeson; all were discovered when the artist recently moved house. At Paul Kasmin: Jane Freilicher\u2019s silken paintings of self-possessed nudes add stunningly to her excursions still life and landscape. Fergus McCaffrey has brought back a series of painting-reliefs by the Italian artist Carol Rama from her recent show at the New Museum, where their truth-to-materials toughness was sometimes lost in the sexual extravagance of her watercolors and etchings.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of the standouts in this group is Hirschl & Adler\u2019s tribute to Frank Walter, the polymorphous, self-taught Antiguan genius \u2014 painter, sculptor, composer, writer \u2014 included in Antigua and Barbuda\u2019s inaugural participation in the 2017 Venice Biennale. This display touches all bases and includes a family tree, with the artist tracing his ancestry back to Charlemagne. Other don\u2019t-miss moments include, at Washburn, some newly discovered drawings by Myron Stout from the early \u201950s showing Provincetown dunes and trees in quick jagged lines. Pavel Zoubok is showing little-known collages from the late 1950s and early \u201960s by the American expatriate painter Janice Biala (1903-2000) that ambitiously conjure Abstract Expressionist gestures in collages incorporating cut paper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Alexander Gray, Harmony Hammond\u2019s prescient Weave paintings of the mid-1970s add a subversive domestic twist to the modernist monochrome. And three dealers present distinctive abstract paintings from the late 1980s and early \u201990s: at Michael Rosenfeld, William T. Williams achieves the colors of Byzantine icons and the solidity of fortress walls; at Lelong, the fiery compositions of Mildred Thompson (1936-2003) spin Kandinsky toward still-unknown galaxies; and at Peter Freeman, Mel Bochner\u2019s early post-conceptual forays into (shaped) painting build intensity with jousting, improvised lines, rather than \u2014 as currently \u2014 with words.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmerican Modernism\n\nThis year\u2019s most plentiful American modernists include Marsden Hartley, Milton Avery, Oscar Bluemner and Charles Burchfield. Start with one of the show\u2019s stars: Hartley\u2019s magnificent 1932 Mexican landscape, \u201cLost Country \u2014 Petrified Sand Hills\u201d at Menconi + Schoelkopf; its ocher hills, blue sky and white clouds have the simple force of a bull\u2019s-eye. Additional works by these masters await at Meredith Ward Fine Art, Donald Morris and Yares Art, whose all-Avery display starts with a view of white waves and azure ocean that registers even from a distance.", "title": "ADAA: A Fair to Remember Starts a Month of Art Show Madness", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The C.D.C. was recently in the spotlight when Mr. Azar said he believed the agency should resume research on gun violence, which it drastically cut more than 20 years ago. Dr. Redfield\u2019s views on gun violence research and other contentious issues such as access to abortion and sexual health education are not yet known.\n\nHis work in AIDS research and policy has generated concern over the years, in particular for his call in the mid-1980s to late 1980s for widespread AIDS testing and screening of military recruits for H.I.V.\n\nWhile pushing for broader AIDS testing during routine exams as a means to contain the epidemic, Dr. Redfield also called for reducing the stigma associated with the disease. At a congressional hearing in August 1987, Dr. Redfield recommended regular testing, at doctor\u2019s appointments and hospitalizations, as well as for marriage license applicants, and incorporating the test into the practice of medicine, according to news reports. But he also said, \u201cWe have to tell people it\u2019s anti-American to discriminate against people who have the AIDS virus.\u201d\n\nIn the early 1990s, Dr. Redfield was the subject of a military investigation after colleagues suspected that he overstated the therapeutic effects of an experimental AIDS vaccine at presentations and in a report. The investigation led to a correction in some published data, according to documents.\n\nSeveral high-level colleagues, however, felt the military should have been tougher on Dr. Redfield, who they felt raised false hopes about the efficacy of a treatment vaccine he was developing. At the time, Public Citizen\u2019s Health Research Group sued to gain the records, and made them public.\n\nIn a 1992 letter to Col. Donald Burke, the director of the division of retrovirology, Major Craig W. Hendrix, director of the Air Force HIV program, wrote that the credibility of the military\u2019s efforts on retroviral research was at risk and under scrutiny. \u201cSevere, painful steps must be taken less we dishonor the honest labors of so many colleagues and patients within our research consortium. We cannot continue to deceive.\u201d\n\nIn an interview Tuesday, Dr. Hendrix, now a professor at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, recalled the incident, which he now uses as a case study in ethics.", "title": "AIDS Researcher Robert R. Redfield Named to Lead the C.D.C.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOne of the nation\u2019s leading AIDS researchers and an expert in the treatment of heroin addiction is the leading candidate to oversee the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nA formal announcement about the candidate, Dr. Robert R. Redfield, could come as early as Tuesday, once the vetting has been finished, said an administration official with knowledge of the appointment, who was not authorized to speak publicly.\n\nThe review process is likely to be thorough. President Trump\u2019s first C.D.C. director, Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, resigned in January after about six months amid reports that she held investments in tobacco and health care companies that posed potential conflicts of interest.\n\nA professor at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, Dr. Redfield founded the Institute of Human Virology along with Dr. Robert C. Gallo, who developed the blood test for the human immunodeficiency virus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBest known for his years as an AIDS researcher, Dr. Redfield, 66, oversees an extensive program providing H.I.V. care and treatment to more than 6,000 patients in the Baltimore-Washington area, according to the university\u2019s website. The institute has received more than $138 million in C.D.C. grants to combat H.I.V./AIDS and other health issues in Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania and Zambia.", "title": "AIDS Researcher Top Candidate to Lead the C.D.C.", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Noticeably absent in AT&T\u2019s filing was an earlier argument it had made: that the government singled out the company\u2019s deal because of presidential politics. President Trump was a vocal critic of the deal during his presidential campaign, and while in office, he has consistently blamed CNN, a channel owned by Turner and part of Time Warner\u2019s television business, for unfair coverage of his administration.\n\nAT&T originally argued to the court that the Justice Department\u2019s suit was a case of \u201cselective enforcement\u201d \u2014 that the government was essentially blocking the deal because the president was against it.\n\nBut late last month, Judge Richard J. Leon, who is overseeing the trial, rejected demands by AT&T for detailed email and phone logs between the White House and the Justice Department related to the deal. AT&T and Time Warner has dropped \u201cselective enforcement\u201d as a defense, according to the new filings.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven absent the question of presidential interference in the deal, the trial is pivotal for the telecom and media industries, providing a clue about the chances of other industry deals, like Disney\u2019s bid for 21st Century Fox. AT&T\u2019s chief executive, Randall Stephenson, and Time Warner\u2019s chief executive, Jeffrey Bewkes, are expected to take the stand.\n\n\u201cThis is the single most important decision this year\u201d for technology, telecom and media firms, said Amy Yong, a research analyst at Macquarie Group in New York. \u201cIt will frame regulation and mergers and acquisitions going forward and raise questions about all the consolidation in the past, too.\u201d\n\nIf the judge sides with AT&T and Time Warner, he would usher in the creation of a new kind of corporate behemoth \u2014 one with nationwide reach via wireless and satellite television service that would also have control over a movie studio and channels like HBO, CNN and TNT, which has valuable basketball sports rights.\n\nThe company would have a leading position to negotiate licensing deals with rival telecom and media firms. It would also be in a stronger position against fast-growing streaming video services like Netflix and Amazon Prime Video.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf the Justice Department prevails in this suit, it would signal a new era of scrutiny for the media and telecom industries. In 2011, Comcast won approval for its purchase of NBCUniversal that also created an enormous telecom and media company. The Justice Department insisted on several conditions that restricted Comcast from anti-competitive business practices.\n\nThe trial will also reveal much about the state of the industry. Rivals such as Comcast, Dish and Sony are expected to be called as witnesses to reveal details about their business dealings with AT&T and Time Warner in the past. The Justice Department is expected to argue that a combined AT&T and Time Warner would have the incentive to make it harder for competing media companies to distribute their programming through AT&T, and for Time Warner brands to limit their distribution outside of AT&T.\n\nThe Justice Department will also present economic analysis suggesting that the new company is likely to raise prices for consumers.\n\n\u201cAs will be shown at trial, the government is challenging this merger to address the real concerns of real people who populate the real marketplace today,\u201d the Justice Department said in its brief.\n\nAT&T said it would challenge the government\u2019s arguments that the merger would increase consumer prices and hamper competition by raising licensing fees for Time Warner content. The company said it would argue that the merger of two companies that do not compete would be a stronger competitor in a market that had many new companies from Silicon Valley, like Facebook and Netflix.\n\n\u201cAs will be demonstrated at trial, the new video revolution is defined by the spectacular rise of Netflix, Amazon, Google, and other vertically integrated, direct-to-consumer technology companies as market leaders in both video programming and video distribution,\u201d AT&T said in its brief.", "title": "AT&T Backs Off Political Argument in Antitrust Case", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe government\u2019s theory is fundamentally stuck in the past,\u201d said Daniel Petrocelli, the lead lawyer for AT&T and Time Warner. He said the merger would do the opposite of what the government asserts: The company would have no incentive to withhold Turner channels, which are owned by Time Warner.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt would be financially ruinous if Turner were not as widely distributed as possible,\u201d Mr. Petrocelli said.\n\nThe opening statements previewed the fierce legal battle that will play out before Judge Richard Leon of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. His decision in the case will help set the direction for antitrust law for years to come. It will also frame the shape of the media industry, which is facing major shifts as more people move from cable television to viewing streaming entertainment over the internet.\n\nHundreds of company officials, reporters, hedge fund investors, antitrust scholars and industry analysts stood in line for hours to get a seat at the trial. Randall Stephenson, AT&T\u2019s chief executive, and Jeffrey Bewkes, Time Warner\u2019s chief executive, sat together during the 90 minutes of opening remarks. Makan Delrahim, the Justice Department\u2019s top antitrust official, watched from the front row on the other side of the room. The chief executives and Mr. Delrahim did not interact.\n\nThe case has drawn unusual public attention partly because of questions about whether it had a tinge of political interference. The Justice Department\u2019s opposition came as a surprise when it was announced in November, and AT&T suggested it had been instigated by President Trump, who has said that he opposed the deal. The government said that Mr. Trump did not communicate with antitrust officials on the deal and that their decision to oppose the merger had not been ordered by the White House.\n\nJudge Leon has rejected many of AT&T\u2019s efforts to introduce evidence about political interference into the case. Instead, the trial, which is expected to last six to eight weeks, will largely focus on fundamental principles of antitrust law: whether the merger would cause prices to increase and competition to decrease.\n\nThe court\u2019s decision will determine what sort of media mergers will be permitted between the creators and the distributors of content. Such deals, called \u201cvertical mergers,\u201d generally pass regulatory scrutiny because they don\u2019t make a company dominant in one specific market area. Judge Leon has noted the unusual case is like a \u201crare horse\u201d but not a \u201cunicorn.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBlair Levin, an analyst for New Street Research, a firm focused on the telecommunications industry, wrote in a research note that a Justice Department victory would \u201cset a standard for what constitutes substantial harm that would call into question a number of other potential and pending mergers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 60 witnesses are expected to take the stand over the course of the trial, including Mr. Stephenson of AT&T and Mr. Bewkes of Time Warner, and executives from digital services like SlingTV and YouTube.\n\nThe Justice Department said it would present internal documents from Time Warner and AT&T to show that the merged company would have the incentive to raise prices on rivals and consumers. In one email Mr. Conrath mentioned on Thursday, a Turner executive explained how Dish TV, AT&T\u2019s top rival in satellite TV service, would be weakened without his company\u2019s channels.\n\n\u201cTime Warner,\u201d Mr. Conrath said, \u201cwould be a weapon for AT&T because AT&T\u2019s competitors need Time Warner programming.\u201d The government said consumers would have to pay an extra $436 million a year because of the deal.\n\nMr. Petrocelli foreshadowed a plan to attack that economic analysis. He said the Justice Department\u2019s calculations, made by the antitrust economist Carl Shapiro, had omitted key information and were therefore flawed.\n\nMr. Petrocelli promised to show Judge Leon that cable consumers could end up paying about 50 cents less a month if the deal goes through.\n\n\u201cThis is what I call the government\u2019s shrinking case,\u201d he said.", "title": "AT&T Would Use Time Warner as a \u2018Weapon,\u2019 Justice Dept. Says", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Justice Department\u2019s case to block AT&T and Time Warner\u2019s $85 billion blockbuster merger heads to trial this week, with opening statements expected on Thursday. The case is being billed as one of the most important antitrust trials in years.\n\nThe deal, if approved, would create a media giant that combines AT&T\u2019s nationwide mobile and satellite distribution networks with Time Warner\u2019s huge collection of popular movies and television offerings, including \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d on HBO, news on CNN, and college and professional basketball on TNT. The central question of the trial: Would that combination hurt consumers or help them?\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know.\n\nWhen does it start, how long will it go and when will there be a decision?\n\nOpening statements are scheduled for Thursday, with the Justice Department and AT&T getting 45 minutes each to lay out their main arguments. Expect lots of colorful claims and defenses from both sides. Top officials from the Justice Department, including the head of its antitrust division, Makan Delrahim, are expected to show up in United States District Court in Washington to watch. AT&T\u2019s chief executive, Randall Stephenson, and Time Warner\u2019s chief executive, Jeff Bewkes, will be there, too \u2014 as will scores of other media, telecom and tech executives, as the outcome of the trial could reshape the media industry.\n\nThe trial is expected to last six to eight weeks \u2014 unless there is a settlement \u2014 with each side calling about 30 witnesses and presenting reams of evidence. The Justice Department alone plans to show 519 exhibits. It could take many weeks longer for Judge Richard J. Leon to make a decision on the $85 billion merger.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat are the main arguments of both sides?\n\nThe Justice Department sued to block the merger because it believes the combination of AT&T with Time Warner would hurt competition and lead to higher prices for consumers.", "title": "AT&T-Time Warner Case: How the Biggest Antitrust Trial in Years Could Play Out", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "When the Yankees hired Aaron Boone out of the broadcast booth to be their manager, he had never held a job in baseball as a coach or manager, or even as a scout or executive.\n\nBut it is not quite true that Boone, 45, is completely bereft of coaching experience. For the last five years, he was the defensive coordinator of the mighty Steelers, a youth flag football juggernaut in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he makes his home.\n\n\u201cWe used to joke with him when he was interviewing for the Yankees\u2019 job,\u201d said DeAndre Wadlington, a parent of one of the team\u2019s players. \u201cWe\u2019d read all this about him not having coaching experience and we\u2019d be: \u2018C\u2019mon, man. He coached the Steelers.\u2019 All he had to do was show his r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\u201d\n\nWadlington paused to laugh.\n\n\u201cI told him when he got the job: \u2018The Steelers prepared you for this.\u2019\u201d\n\nWadlington laughed some more, but he might have been on to something. Many of the qualities that parents say they saw Boone exhibit with their boys \u2014 upbeat, confident, calm and able to connect with players \u2014 are among the reasons the Yankees chose him.", "title": "Aaron Boone Has No Coaching Experience? "title": "Aaron Judge Isn\u2019t Interested in a Home Run Derby Repeat", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "TAMPA, Fla. \u2014 As Aaron Judge saw a group of reporters approaching his locker on Thursday morning, he smiled sheepishly and asked: What do you got?\n\nLike a 3-0 fastball, he knew what was coming.\n\nThe day before, Judge had remarked after the Yankees\u2019 game against Baltimore that he had done some lobbying of Orioles star Manny Machado, who grew up admiring Alex Rodriguez and will be a headliner of next winter\u2019s free-agent class.\n\nAfter making small talk with Machado about how his off-season went and how his move to shortstop from third base is progressing, Judge hit him with a pitch: \u201cI told him, \u2018You\u2019d look pretty good in pinstripes, too.\u2019\u201d\n\nThat drew some finger-wagging from Major League Baseball, which pointed out that players \u2014 like managers, general managers and other team officials \u2014 are prohibited from tampering with players under contract to another team.", "title": "Aaron Judge\u2019s Chat With Manny Machado Earns a Warning from M.L.B.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNearly three out of four teachers oppose letting staff members carry guns in schools, according to a new poll that shows little support for a proposal that has become central to President Trump\u2019s response to the school shooting last month in Parkland, Fla.\n\nSeventy-three percent of teachers oppose the idea of arming staff members, while 20 percent support it, according to the nationwide survey of almost 500 teachers of kindergarten through 12th grade conducted by Gallup and released on Friday.\n\nA majority of the public, 56 percent, also opposes the idea, according to a separate Gallup poll, though attitudes diverge greatly along partisan lines.\n\nTeachers Oppose Arming Staff Nearly two thirds of teachers strongly oppose special training for teachers and staff to carry guns in schools. Strongly oppose Strongly favor Somewhat oppose Somewhat favor Neutral 63% 11 10 9 7\n\nAfter the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, which left 17 people dead, Mr. Trump stunned lawmakers by backing comprehensive gun control.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that support was short-lived. Mr. Trump eventually reversed course, instead embracing the National Rifle Association-backed policies of arming teachers and making incremental improvements to the background check system.", "title": "About 3 in 4 Teachers Oppose Arming School Staff, Survey Finds", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "But just as important, if not more so, there were marked differences between the parties in terms of the tone of their primaries.\n\nOn the Democratic side, there was bitter internal strife, dating back to the previous election cycle, between the \u201cestablishment\u201d Democrats and the populist \u201cBerniecrats.\u201d Many of the latter are not committed partisans: While they are highly motivated to support populists, many refuse to lend their support to more conventional Democratic candidates. As we saw in 2016, many former Sanders supporters sat out the general election, voted for a third-party candidate or voted for Donald Trump.\n\nDemocrats should be concerned about their ability to mobilize populists in the races \u201cestablishment\u201d figures won. So the party could find itself facing another enthusiasm deficit for many key races, even with Mr. Trump in the White House.\n\nOn the Republican side, there was clear unity behind the president and his party. The races were mostly about which candidate was most supportive of President Trump. As a result, it seems likely that Republican voters will support whoever is on their ticket in the general election.\n\nWe can count on Republican primary voters to turn out in November as well. Republicans reliably vote in midterms, and again it is important to note that primary patterns suggest that enthusiasm is particularly high in the Republican base this year, too.\n\nRepublicans are motivated, in part, to act as a bulwark against any \u201cblue wave\u201d that might be coming their way. Following Mr. Abbott\u2019s lead, candidates like Senator Ted Cruz have been doing their best to reinforce expectations of a possible Democratic surge in order to get his voters fired up: \u201cWe know that the left is going to show up,\u201d Mr. Cruz said on Tuesday. \u201cThe extreme left, they\u2019re angry. They\u2019re filled with rage. They hate the president.\u201d\n\nThe Republicans\u2019 record primary turnout suggests this is an effective mobilization strategy. In contrast, for the Democrats, raising expectations of a wave could be dangerous. Democratic constituents are generally disinclined to vote in midterms in the first place. To the extent that they are not particularly excited about the candidate their party fielded and believe that Democrats will most likely make major gains with or without them, it becomes more likely that a significant number will stay home on Election Day.\n\nIn other words, not only can the blue wave narrative distract us from what is happening on the ground, it can also help drive Republican enthusiasm and undermine Democratic turnout \u2014 not quite the double whammy Democratic strategists are looking for.", "title": "Opinion | About That Blue Wave \u2026", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "AT 8 MINUTES 40 SECONDS\n\nRevelatory Madness\n\nOf the many things to admire about the Bavarian State Opera\u2019s concert performance of Strauss\u2019s \u201cDer Rosenkavalier\u201d on Thursday at Carnegie Hall, I was especially captivated by the surprising details Kirill Petrenko drew from the orchestra. His conducting brought out sophisticated comedy, as well as romance and heroism, that I didn\u2019t even know existed in the score. Similar thoughtfulness is on display in this video of him leading the overture to Wagner\u2019s \u201cTannh\u00e4user\u201d in a production by Romeo Castellucci that had its premiere last year in Munich. There\u2019s a flash \u2014 just one measure \u2014 of revelatory madness in the theme from Tannha\u00fcser\u2019s song of love to Venus. The violas and cellos have a run of 16th notes full of accidentals that break free from the key signature. With heavy bowing and accents that rise above the rest of the orchestra, the measure suddenly colors the ecstatic passage with a touch of lunacy. JOSHUA BARONE\n\nRead our review of the Bavarian State Orchestra.\n\nRead our review of the \u201cTannh\u00e4user.\u201d", "title": "Abreu\u2019s Legacy: The Best Classical Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Carroll recalls the rigid authority wielded by Cardinal Francis Spellman; the lavish chancery of the Archdiocese on Madison Avenue, which the author justly views as \u201can immigrant\u2019s revenge\u201d on the city\u2019s Protestants and which, for good reason, was known as the Powerhouse; the jovial, candlelit dinners the clergy enjoyed at Patricia Murphy\u2019s restaurant; the muffled culture of sexual abuse that clerics only winked at then; and the \u201cthe heresy called \u2018Modernism\u2019\u201d that is resonating so publicly and powerfully today.\n\nIn \u201cThe Cloister,\u201d Mr. Carroll, a former priest himself, draws again on the suppressed teachings of Ab\u00e9lard, the theologian whom he invoked in 2001 in his monumental \u201cConstantine\u2019s Sword: The Church and the Jews \u2014 a History,\u201d his deeply disturbing exploration of Christian anti-Semitism and intolerance.\n\nMr. Carroll\u2019s latest novel begins with Father Kavanagh\u2019s chance encounter with Rachel Vedette, a docent at the Metropolitan Museum\u2019s composite of several individual cloisters transplanted from Europe to Fort Tryon Park.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTheir awkward convergence becomes an incandescent, allegorical outgrowth of the agonizing introspection that Ab\u00e9lard and H\u00e9lo\u00efse undergo in their search for self-awareness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTheir letters \u201cshow a great contest between two people but also a contest of the two people against the whole rest of their age,\u201d Rachel says, adding: \u201cThey are humanists. The first humanists.\u201d\n\nComplicated is a word that Mr. Carroll often repeats to describe the protagonists\u2019 past relationships and current conflicts. They both look to Ab\u00e9lard in their soul-searching for a lesson on love and life. \u201cThe key to wisdom is this,\u201d he wrote. \u201cConstant and frequent questioning, for by doubting we are led to question and by questioning we arrive at the truth.\u201d\n\n.\n\nLooking for another provocative porthole to the past? On this day in 1839, Charlotte Bront\u00eb wrote what might be considered a classic rejection letter (eight years before the publication of her best-known work, \u201cJane Eyre\u201d).\n\nPhoto\n\nHer suitor was the Rev. Henry Nussey, the brother of her close friend Ellen. He proposed by letter, shortly before Bront\u00eb\u2019s 23rd birthday. She responded a few days later:\n\n\u201cBefore answering your letter, I might have spent a long time in consideration of its subject; but as from the first moment of its reception and perusal I determined on which course to pursue, it seemed to me that delay was wholly unnecessary.\u201d\n\nShe offered a face-saving explanation: \u201cI have no personal repugnance to the idea of a union with you \u2014 but I feel convinced that mine is not the sort of disposition calculated to form the happiness of a man like you.\u201d\n\nBront\u00eb went on to publish a collection of poetry with her sisters Emily and Anne, in 1846. \u201cJane Eyre\u201d was published the next year under the pseudonym Currer Bell, which was based partly on the name of the man whose marriage proposal she did accept (after two tries), Arthur Bell Nicholls.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheck out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Academy Awards, Xi Jinping, Italy: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "He also arranged for a group of seriously ill children to visit a police base at Floyd Bennett Field, in Brooklyn, to see police training as part of their Camp Simcha activities in the summer of 2013. And he extended the police escort of a funeral procession \u201cfor a deceased person that I understood was a prominent member of the Jewish community,\u201d he told the court.\n\nHe also arranged for a police helicopter to fly over a party Mr. Reichberg was hosting on a boat in the East River in 2015, and secured the use of a police boat for private rides at another event.\n\nAll of the moves are encompassed by a new federal charge \u2014 the misapplication of police property \u2014 that Mr. Harrington, between 2011 and June 2016, dispatched officers and resources to handle certain matters without obtaining authorization.\n\n\u201cDuring this time period I understood Mr. Reichberg to be a leader within the Jewish community, and also considered him a friend,\u201d Mr. Harrington, 52, who was dressed in a blue, pinstriped suit, told the judge as his wife, Tara, and others looked on.\n\nWhen Judge Woods asked whether he knew at the time what he was doing was wrong and illegal, Mr. Harrington said that he knew it was wrong, but that he did not appreciate \u201cuntil much later\u201d that it was illegal.\n\nBefore the original charges were filed against the police commanders, Mr. Rechnitz had already pleaded guilty and provided information in separate fund-raising inquiries that were focused on Mayor Bill de Blasio \u2014 before the mayor won a second term.\n\nIn March 2017, however, despite federal prosecutors spending months investigating numerous donations to advance Mr. de Blasio\u2019s policy agenda, federal and state prosecutors announced that they would not bring criminal charges against the mayor or his aides.", "title": "Accused of Corruption, Former N.Y.P.D. Chief Pleads Guilty to Lesser Charge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "William A. Ackman has officially hoisted the white flag in his boisterous and costly five-year campaign against Herbalife, the nutritional food supplement company, which he claimed was an outright fraud.\n\nMr. Ackman, one of Wall Street\u2019s most outspoken hedge fund managers, disclosed on CNBC on Wednesday that he had quietly unloaded his remaining positions in Herbalife \u2014 a bet that at one time had been valued at $1 billion by his Pershing Square Capital Management.\n\nIn the annals of Wall Street, investors have lost more on trades. But Mr. Ackman\u2019s bearish bet on Herbalife was a signature event given how much time, effort and money he devoted to making his case \u2014 all in the hopes that the federal authorities would take action against Herbalife.\n\nIn fact, the Federal Trade Commission did. But its enforcement action against Herbalife in July 2016 was not the death knell that Mr. Ackman had been counting on. The commission\u2019s settlement with Herbalife required the company to pay $200 million in consumer relief, hire an outside monitor and make substantial changes to its business practices, but it let the company continue to operate.", "title": "Ackman Ends His 5-Year Fight With Herbalife", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "And in New Jersey, the Red Bulls in January took the extraordinary step of revoking official recognition of one of their oldest supporters groups, the Garden State Ultras. The Red Bulls said the decision \u2014 the G.S.U. claimed it was a first for the league \u2014 followed repeated disciplinary infractions, culminating in an episode on the last day of the 2017 season in which the team said a G.S.U. member dropped a flare into the family section of a rival team\u2019s stadium.\n\nThe G.S.U. disputed the team\u2019s account, and noted acidly in a statement on Facebook that, \u201cWe, along with billions of other soccer fans, are impassioned in both our love for our team and dislike of our opponents, and we disagree with attempts to mold a passive fan base that sits quietly, eating and drinking its overpriced concessions.\u201d\n\nEvery M.L.S. team has at least one official supporters group. Most have several. Often, the groups are run by an elected committee, and they enjoy exclusive privileges: block seating behind the goals; allotments of tickets for away matches; and the right to bring nominally banned items like flags, musical instruments and giant banners into stadiums.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a few of the league\u2019s newest arenas, even the architecture itself \u2014 steep banks of seats, safe-standing areas, roofs pitched to amplify chants \u2014 has the hard-core fan experience in mind, often in consultation with supporter groups.\n\nYet the relationships between teams and their supporters have always had a certain tension built into them. The supporters groups of the original M.L.S. teams in particular \u2014 a group that includes Columbus, D.C. United and the Red Bulls team originally known as the MetroStars \u2014 are proud of their independent histories.\n\nAs the league plants its flag in new markets \u2014 a 23rd franchise, Los Angeles F.C., will join M.L.S. this season, and expansion teams in Nashville and Miami were recently approved \u2014 many of the oldest groups see themselves as the true keepers of the institutional memories of their teams, and even of the league itself.\n\nThe Columbus story in particular highlighted that sense of ownership. When it was revealed on the eve of last season\u2019s playoffs that the team\u2019s owner, Anthony Precourt, was working behind the scenes \u2014 with the league\u2019s aid, if not blessing \u2014 to move the club to Austin, Tex., Crew fans mutinied. A grass-roots opposition was formed to lobby city and state leaders to keep the team in Ohio, and a hashtag campaign \u2014 #SaveTheCrew \u2014 quickly spread from social media to banners in other M.L.S. cities, and even in other sports.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe message to Precourt and the league was clear: Columbus fans would not abandon the decades of cultural capital they had expended without a fight.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the basis of my longest standing friendships in this country,\u201d Graham Randall, an English expatriate member of the Crew Union supporters group, said of his relationship with the team. \u201cNow I see it through the eyes of my 11-year-old son. The news that the team might not be here at some point made me realize I would lose a huge thread in my life in the last 13 years.\u201d\n\nSince the missteps of the league\u2019s early days, when M.L.S. acquired a reputation for gimmickry that it struggled to shake, the emergence of a genuine independent supporters culture has been viewed as a necessary step toward credibility, and it remains vital to the league\u2019s vision of itself. But managing the dance between \u201corganic\u201d support and a strong league office can be delicate.\n\n\u201cThe supporters groups are really smart and creative \u2014 I mean, you see the work that goes into the giant tifo displays alone \u2014 and they have smart leaders who communicate really well with the clubs and basically police themselves,\u201d said Mark Abbott, the league\u2019s deputy commissioner. \u201cWe don\u2019t have to do much, though we do set down guidelines for acceptable behavior.\u201d\n\nYet that desire for authenticity and passion often yields only symbolic displays of these qualities. It is one thing for fans to emulate a banner style imported from Italy, or the capo-led nonstop singing of South America, or the pop-parody chants of English soccer. But any organized fan groups that might actually feel and act on any of the enmity toward their rivals swiftly comes up against the realities of how the American sporting experience is managed and policed.\n\nIt also can make for absurdities on both sides, with teams who cultivate an \u201cultras\u201d culture punishing anyone who runs afoul of an explicit code of conduct published on the league\u2019s website. (\u201cThe use of streamers and confetti as an expression of fan enthusiasm is not prohibited,\u201d one section of the code reads, \u201cbut will be kept under review.\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd it doesn\u2019t help that even notionally unified fan sections can end up Balkanized. The Garden State Ultras, for example, were one of three main Red Bulls supporters groups housed in what is known as the South Ward at the team\u2019s stadium, Red Bull Arena. Yet collective sympathy for the G.S.U.\u2019s loss of its official status was tempered by the differing flavors of support that make the adjacent Empire Supporters Club and Viking Army as much rivals for attention as natural allies.\n\nStill, where there is a point of agreement among league, teams and fans, it is that there is little desire for fan groups to emulate the worst types of hooliganism seen in other parts of the world. If anything, today\u2019s M.L.S. fan groups emphasize a positivity that would look gauche to some of the groups they notionally emulate: charity fund-raisers, clothing drives and events supporting social issues from anti-racism initiatives to gay rights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven studiedly provocative groups like Philadelphia\u2019s long-suffering Sons of Ben, known for their occasional contempt for their team\u2019s management but also for a \u201cNo one likes us, we don\u2019t care\u201d chant borrowed from the infamously hostile supporters of the London club Millwall, regularly show a softer side. The group maintains a philanthropy tab on its website that charts, among other initiatives, money and goods raised in an annual community food drive for the residents of Chester, Pa., which is home to the Union\u2019s stadium.\n\nCorey Furlan, one of the Sons of Ben founders, said of the apparent paradox: \u201cLook, we\u2019re Philadelphia sports fans \u2014 loud, obnoxious, whatever \u2014 but the type of people who care deeply about our team also give their energy, care and passion in other aspects of their life. We didn\u2019t just want to drop into Chester for 17 home games a year. We wanted to put down roots.\n\n\u201cI mean, players and coaches come and go, but we\u2019re the people who are going to be here forever.\u201d", "title": "Acrimony F.C.: M.L.S. Teams and Fan Groups Navigate a Rocky Marriage", "authors": ["Graham Parker"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "COPENHAGEN \u2014 While many companies across the globe have art collections and some even hold art exhibitions within their public spaces, what is happening at Denmark\u2019s Aquaporin is unique. Since June, the water technology purification company \u2014 in collaboration with the Danish artistic, curatorial and research collective Diakron \u2014 has hosted Primer, an exhibition space that is within its open-plan factory, laboratory and offices.\n\nAnyone interested in seeing a free exhibition (\u201cLife Without,\u201d the current show by Michala Paludan, is on view until June 3) must first book an appointment. Then they are guided around the high-ceilinged building by a member of Diakron, walking past scientists conducting research, receptionists signing for deliveries and employees holding meetings on the factory floor.\n\nPeter Holme Jensen, the chief executive and a co-founder of Aquaporin, said that the company was interested in using its large space for art but that it did not know how best to go about it.\n\n\u201cWe are a very small start-up and we do not have a lot of money to go out and buy, so maybe that was our luck,\u201d he said, adding that the Copenhagen-based art consultant Christina Wilson linked him up with Diakron. \u201cWe had no idea what would come out of it other than making daily life a little more fun, and instead of listening to our footsteps we could talk to artists and look at what we do from a different angle.\u201d", "title": "Across Copenhagen, Artists Are in Charge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Daily\u201d\n\nWe typically use short segments of this 20-minute podcast about the day\u2019s news, new editions of which post every Monday through Friday. Though a transcript is not available, the host and guests generally speak slowly and clearly enough for English Language Learners to understand. The example embedded above, which can also be found here, is from March 5, 2018. (The Learning Network also has a lesson plan on teaching with this podcast: Experimenting With Sound and Story: Teaching and Learning With \u2018The Daily\u2019 Podcast.)\n\nTimes Video\n\nThis page has a huge selection of short films on various topics. Many of the more recent ones now also have closed captioning, which makes them accessible to E.L.L.s. ((When the videos on The Times site do not have closed captioning, you can often find them on The New York Times YouTube Channel. You can also change the speed of the videos there so that the words are spoken at a slightly slower speed. We often will set it at .75)\n\nIn our classroom, we usually show videos from the Science, Sports and Op-Docs sections because they are short and engaging for adolescents. We also use clips from the Movie Trailers section, though they do not include closed captioning.\n\nGreat Read-Alouds From The New York Times\n\nThis is a classic Learning Network list of categorized, evergreen articles and essays from The Times that can be read aloud to students, on topics like \u201cteenagehood,\u201d \u201cmishaps,\u201d \u201canimals and insects,\u201d \u201ccrime and punishment,\u201d \u201cinspiration,\u201d \u201cidentity\u201d and \u201cfood.\u201d\n\n_________\n\nMetacognitive Listening Strategies\n\nVideo\n\nStudents who are learning English will make more progress if they are aware of how listening processes work and how those processes apply to their own experiences. To foster this awareness, we set up listening practice sessions where students have an opportunity to learn, use and evaluate different metacognitive listening strategies.\n\nWe start by emphasizing to students that they are constantly employing these skills in their daily lives and that they probably use many of them in their native languages automatically. This practice activity is designed to help them develop this same automaticity in English.\n\nBefore our students start a session, we give them a listening practice sheet to fill out, guided by the questions below.\n\nBefore Listening: What do I already know? What predictions can I make? While Listening: What strategies can I use to help me understand what I\u2019m listening to? After Listening: Which strategies helped me the most? What will I do next time?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou can use these questions with almost any audio text, whether podcasts, speeches, videos, movie clips, dialogues or news reports. The first time we do this as a class, however, we model our own listening strategies while filling it out. Here\u2019s how:\n\nBefore listening: What do I already know? What predictions can I make?\n\nWe start by writing the title of the audio text on the board and telling students what type of text it is. For example, we might have students watch the above Times video, \u201cWhy Do Bees Buzz?\u201d\n\nIn the first section of our listening practice sheet, we ask them to write what they already know about the title \u2014 if anything. In the \u201cWhy Do Bees Buzz?\u201d example, they might say that bees fly, make a buzzing sound and sting people. Students then share their writing with a partner or in a small group to generate more ideas.\n\nThen, based on this knowledge, students write their predictions about the content of the text. For instance, they might predict that the video will say that bees buzz to talk with each other. Students share these predictions with a partner and add any new ones they hear.\n\nWhile listening: What strategies can I use to help me understand what I\u2019m listening to?\n\nNext, we ask students to list strategies that might help them understand the text while they listen to it. We remind them that many of the strategies they use for reading can also be applied to listening. Students might come up with things like summarizing, using context clues to guess word meanings, asking questions or visualizing.\n\nThen, we play the text and, while they listen, students practice using one or more of these strategies.\n\nNote: If you are playing a text for the whole class either on speakers or on a screen, you might pause it every so often and replay it so students can practice these strategies. If you have the resources, you can also have students listen to the text using their own devices and headphones so they can pause and replay as needed.\n\nAfter listening: Which strategies helped me the most? What will I do next time?\n\nAfter they are finished, we have students use the third section of our listening practice sheet to reflect on which strategies were most helpful and what was particularly difficult about the task. Then, we ask them to share their reflections and how they might improve their skills.\n\nThis activity focuses on helping students name what they do while they listen \u2014 strategies that are often invisible. The emphasis in this type of practice is less about teaching new content than it is about teaching students how to listen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen students do engage in a listening activity to learn new content, we often ask them first to review which strategies might be most helpful for their listening. You will find more of those activities below.\n\n_________\n\nExercises to Improve Listening for Content\n\nVideo\n\nHere are a few interactive listening lessons in which students can use the above metacognitive strategies to learn new content:\n\nInteractive Read-Alouds\n\nIn this strategy, a teacher reads written content aloud, but stops every few paragraphs or pages (depending on your goals and the density and level of your text) to ask questions or give prompts. These can either be classic literacy-skills questions like \u201cWhat predictions can you make about what happens next?\u201d or \u201cWhat do you think is the main idea of this article so far?\u201d or they can be more whimsical prompts, like \u201cDraw a quick illustration that could accompany this part of the text.\u201d\n\nInvite students to turn to a partner and share what they\u2019ve written or created, then have a very brief whole-class share before you continue reading.\n\nChronology\n\nHave students write a chronology of what they saw and heard in a video or podcast. For example, this edition of an older Learning Network feature, E.L.L. Practice, invites students to watch a short scene from \u201cThe Desolation of Smaug\u201d; a Science Take video on the physics of ants; or clips from The Times feature \u201cVideos That Creep and Crawl Toward Viral.\u201d Then, they work with a partner to write a description or chronology of what happened in the video.\n\nEvent Sort\n\nAs a class, view a video or listen to a podcast together. Then, give students a sheet with a list of events in the wrong sequence. Have them cut out the events and sort them into the correct order.\n\nEven better, invite students to find a short movie clip or podcast of their own. Have them identify three or four major events and make a sheet for the class with the events out of order. Then, let them play the clip and challenge the class to put the events in a chronological sequence. If you have access to multiple devices, students can do this kind of activity in pairs.\n\nComprehension Quiz\n\nGive a simple comprehension quiz on a video or podcast. This can be used as a formative assessment by having students write out and show their answers on mini-whiteboards or by using an online tool like Poll Everywhere. Students can also form teams to turn the activity into a game.\n\nTwo Predictions, Three Questions\n\nStudents themselves can create questions about what they saw and heard, which they can exchange with a classmate to answer. We give our students a work sheet that looks like this:\n\nThe title of today\u2019s episode or film is ______________________________ Write two predictions about this episode based on the title: 1. 2. While you watch the episode or film, write three questions about this episode for a classmate to answer. After the episode or film, give your paper to a classmate so that he or she can write the answers to your questions. Question 1: Answer: Question 2: Answer: Question 3: Answer: After watching the episode: Were your predictions correct? Explain why or why not. 1. 2.\n\nWhat strategies do you use to practice active listening with your students? Tell us in the comments.\n\n_________\n\nRelated\n\nExperimenting With Sound and Story: Teaching and Learning With \u2018The Daily\u2019 Podcast\n\nSkills Practice | Listening and Taking Notes, Via Times Podcasts", "title": "Active Listening: Using Times Videos, Podcasts and Articles to Practice a Key Skill", "authors": ["Larry Ferlazzo"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The awakening started with the revulsion of women \u2014 at a president who is credibly accused of sleeping with porn stars while his wife nursed their newborn child and who bragged of sexual assault, and at his daily slights to truth, dignity and other values that mothers teach their children.\n\nAnd now it\u2019s the young\u2019s turn. Critical thinking has arrived at a critical time. They\u2019re not afraid of trolls; they grew up with snark from a screen. So after Laura Ingraham at Fox taunted a Parkland shooting survivor for not getting into his college of choice, the student immediately tweeted out a list of her advertisers. When they threatened to bail, she apologized.\n\n\u201cThese self-righteous kids screaming at you on television over the weekend aren\u2019t helping out at all,\u201d said Tucker Carlson, another Fox scold. As he knows, they are helping \u2014 but just not his side. \u201cFirst we march, then we vote,\u201d was a leading slogan of the demonstrations.\n\nThe problem is that Americans are among the least-active voters in developed countries \u2014 another consequence, I would argue, of not teaching the manual of democracy in school. And young people are the least likely to vote.\n\n\u201cAdults mess up a lot,\u201d Sotomayor told the high school kids in her audience in Seattle. \u201cWe don\u2019t have all the answers. We need you to come up with fresher and better ideas.\u201d\n\nSo today, these young people wonder why even the most obvious legislation, universal background checks on all gun purchases, can\u2019t pass in Congress despite support from 90 percent of the public. They learn quickly that it\u2019s because a single lobby owns the politicians. The obvious solution, which jaded political minds often forget, is to vote the bums out. It\u2019s not complicated.\n\nAnd again, it shouldn\u2019t be a D.I.Y. thing. Let\u2019s teach people how to tell fake news from real news. They do this in Italy, and many universities in the United States have taken it up as well. It should be, like learning road signs before you can get a driver\u2019s license, one of the courses that everyone takes before getting out of high school.\n\nDemocracies die when citizens feel powerless. The biggest stress test will come if Trump fires the special counsel Robert Mueller. Then, all the people new to the process will see what a constitutional crisis looks like. But thanks to recent, real-life lessons, they\u2019ll recognize it for what it is. And they won\u2019t feel powerless to do something about it.", "title": "Opinion | Actually, You Can Fix Stupid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The advertising industry, expert in the art of attention getting, has found itself riveted in recent months by an anonymously run Instagram account dedicated to exposing sexual harassment on Madison Avenue.\n\nThe account, @DietMadisonAve, is advertising\u2019s visual version of the Google spreadsheet that circulated last fall with the names of men in the media industry who had been accused of sexually inappropriate behavior.\n\nCreated in October, the account has more than 19,000 followers and says it is now run by 17 people. JUST DO IT.\u201d", "title": "Adam Rippon Wore a Harness, Breaking the Oscars Mold", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSupplementing breast-feeding with formula may be good for some babies in the early days of life.\n\nExclusive breast-feeding is widely recommended by experts, and rates of breast-feeding have risen. But so have rates of readmission for dehydration and jaundice attributable to inadequate nutrition.\n\nResearchers studied 164 infants who exclusively breast-fed one to three days after birth but whose weight loss was greater than the 75th percentile for their age. Their mothers had not yet begun mature milk production.\n\nHalf were randomly assigned to exclusive breast-feeding. The other half got 10 milliliters of formula at the end of each breast-feeding session, which was discontinued when the mothers\u2019 milk came in two to seven days later.\n\nThe study, in The Journal of Pediatrics, found that breast-feeding rates at one week and at one month did not differ between the two groups, and there was no significant difference between the intestinal microbiomes of the two groups of babies. Five babies in the control group and one in the formula group were rehospitalized.\n\nThe lead author, Dr. Valerie J. Flaherman, an associate professor of pediatrics at the University of California at San Francisco, said that the intervention could potentially reduce early newborn morbidity.\n\n\u201cUsing formula should be guided by science,\u201d she said. \u201cI think the bias against formula is preventing its use in situations where it might be beneficial.\u201d", "title": "Adding Formula to Breast-Feeding May Help Some Newborns", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Britain\u2019s retaliation against Russia in their spy-poisoning brawl includes a small but symbolic slap: No ministers or members of the royal family will attend the World Cup this summer.\n\nThe announcement, part of Prime Minister Theresa May\u2019s list of measures announced Wednesday to penalize the Russians, comes three months before England\u2019s team will play in the tournament hosted by Russia, which starts June 14 and lasts through July 15.\n\nShe did not call for Britons to boycott the World Cup, one of the most popular global sporting events. For nearly half a century, that has involved the serial ordeal of men in the Mafia clan being sent to federal prison.\n\nOn Wednesday, John J. Gotti, the grandson of the infamous Gambino family don who shares his name, was sentenced to five years in prison, following in the footsteps of two of his uncles, two great-uncles and both grandfathers. For three generations, members of the gangland dynasty have been imprisoned for crimes that have included shaking down construction sites, murdering a mob boss at a steakhouse and trying to extort the action-movie hero Steven Seagal.\n\nThe crimes that led this latest Gotti scion to be sent away were, according to the government, also entangled in the business that has occupied the family almost since the start of the Civil Rights era. Last June, Mr. Gotti, now 24, pleaded guilty to torching the car of an unwitting motorist who made the mistake of cutting off an aging Bonnano family figure on Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Gotti also admitted that two weeks after the road-rage episode, he and two associates \u2014 presenting a note that said they had a bomb \u2014 robbed $6,000 from a bank in Maspeth, Queens.\n\nHis sentencing, in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, had the feeling of a familiar family dinner as several Gotti parents, grandparents, cousins, aunts and uncles converged on the eighth-floor courtroom, kissing each other\u2019s cheeks and showing their support for the defendant. John A. Gotti, the son of the former boss (who was serving a life sentence for murder when he died in prison in 2002), embraced one of the court sketch artists with genuine affection, telling his younger relatives that the woman had not only covered his trials (plural), but had also covered \u201cgrandpa\u2019s.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInside the room, the younger Mr. Gotti \u2014 bespectacled, his hair slicked, both arms sleeved with tattoos \u2014 sat beside his lawyer, Charles Carnesi, who had once defended his uncle. We desperately need black foster parents. And this isn\u2019t \u2018nonsense\u2019 when children are growing up in orphanages and foster homes. It\u2019s easy to criticize from the sidelines. It\u2019s much harder to get in the fight.\u201d\n\n\u2014Shannan Burke\n\nA commenter talked about her commitment to helping her soon-to-be-adopted daughter from India learn about her culture.\n\n\u201cI am leaving in a few weeks to pick up our daughter from India.
