They chatted for a week about her personal problems in the military. Ms. Manning admitted that she had leaked classified video of a helicopter attack in Baghdad that left 12 people dead, including two Reuters employees, to WikiLeaks.org, which published the video online under the title \u201cCollateral Murder.\u201d\n\nMr. Lamo said Ms. Manning had also admitted leaking to WikiLeaks 260,000 classified diplomatic cables and video of a 2009 Afghanistan airstrike that left 96 people dead.\n\n\u201cHe was just grabbing information from where he could get it and trying to leak it,\u201d Mr. Lamo told The Times in 2010 about Ms. Manning, a transgender woman who was then known as Bradley Manning.\n\nMr. Lamo called the F.B.I. and relayed Ms. Manning\u2019s admissions. She was arrested and eventually sentenced to 35 years in prison for leaking over 700,000 government records, the longest punishment ever imposed for a leak conviction. President Barack Obama commuted Ms. Manning\u2019s sentence in January 2017, and she recently filed to run for the United States Senate in Maryland.\n\nMr. Lamo said he was worried that the leaks provided by Ms. Manning would endanger people\u2019s lives.\n\n\u201cI thought to myself, \u2018What if somebody dies because this information is leaked?\u2019\u201d he said in 2010.\n\nWikiLeaks and others condemned Mr. Lamo for turning Ms. Manning in to the federal authorities.\n\nJulian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, called Mr. Lamo a \u201cserial F.B.I. snitch\u201d on Twitter. In comments on the Facebook post announcing Mr. Lamo\u2019s death, some called him a \u201creal hero\u201d and \u201ctrue patriot.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMario Lamo said his son went through a difficult period after reporting Ms. Manning to the authorities.\n\n\u201cHe was vilified by many people by his position about the Manning affair,\u201d he said. \u201cI was with him when this happened and understood that he lived by some principles and he stood for them.\u201d\n\nAdri\u00e1n Alfonso Lamo Atwood was born in Malden, Mass., on Feb. 20, 1981. He attended high school in San Francisco before being expelled after altercations with his computer teacher.\n\nMario Lamo said his son went on to obtain his high school equivalency diploma and later became friends with the computer teacher.\n\nMr. Lamo first became interested in computers after receiving a hand-me-down Commodore 64. He became familiar with software after gaining access to the coding used to create the video games that he played.\n\nAfter receiving his first laptop computer in high school, Mr. Lamo began using a simple web browser to find holes in security. Mr. Lamo would report the security holes he uncovered to the affected companies. Until his death, Mario Lamo said, his son worked as a computer security consultant.\n\nIn addition to his father, Mr. Lamo is survived by his mother, Mary Atwood, and two siblings, Andrea Lamo Atwood and Juli\u00e1n Lamo Atwood.", "title": "Adri\u00e1n Lamo, Hacker Who Reported Chelsea Manning to the F.B.I., Dies at 37", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Nutrish, a pet food brand owned by Rachael Ray, said it was \u201cin the process of removing our ads from Laura Ingraham\u2019s program.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe comments she has made are not consistent with how we feel people should be treated,\u201d the company said.\n\nWayfair, an e-commerce company, said in a statement that it supports \u201copen dialogue and debate on issues,\u201d but that it would stop advertising on Ms. Ingraham\u2019s show.\n\n\u201cThe decision of an adult to personally criticize a high school student who has lost his classmates in an unspeakable tragedy is not consistent with our values,\u201d the company said.\n\nNestle said it had \u201cno plans to buy ads on the show in the future,\u201d while Stitch Fix, a clothing box subscription service, said it had pulled its advertisements. Johnson & Johnson said it had done so as well, while Hulu said on Twitter, \u201cWe are no longer advertising on Laura Ingraham\u2019s show and are monitoring all of our ad placements carefully.\u201d\n\nExpedia said it had \u201crecently pulled the advertising\u201d from Ms. Ingraham\u2019s show, but it did not elaborate on timing or whether the decision was related to her comments.\n\nConsumers have increasingly used social media to demand that advertisers respond to a series of controversies, particularly those involving Fox News hosts. Last year, more than 50 brands pulled ads from \u201cThe O\u2019Reilly Factor\u201d after The New York Times reported on settlements that the show\u2019s host, Bill O\u2019Reilly, had made with women who accused him of sexual harassment or other inappropriate behavior, which contributed to his ouster.", "title": "Advertisers Drop Laura Ingraham After She Taunts Parkland Survivor David Hogg", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "If you only watched the commercials and not the awards part of the Oscars telecast, you might have thought for a moment you were watching the Super Bowl.\n\nSeveral advertisers offered cinematic spots that went beyond the usual fare, while others used it for unveilings.", "title": "Advertisers Turn the Oscars Into a Super Bowl-Like Platform", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cDemocrat\u2019s Win on Trump\u2019s Turf Offers Road Map\u201d (front page, March 15):\n\nThere is a lesson of overriding importance for Democrats in Conor Lamb\u2019s stellar result in the special House election in a red district in which the party sometimes did not even bother to field candidates. Democrats should run candidates who reflect the tenor of the local district or state, not those who strictly adhere to some fixed ideological template.\n\nGiven President Trump\u2019s great unpopularity and how well Democrats have done in recent elections, it looks increasingly likely that Democrats can recapture the House in 2018. Retaking the Senate will be a much more difficult challenge because several Democratic senators are running for re-election in red states.\n\nThe stakes here are of enormous historic importance. Mr. Trump and Senate Republicans are zealously intent on stacking the federal judiciary \u2014 including the Supreme Court \u2014 with right-wing judges. It is the Senate that confirms these potentially lifetime appointments. Let the wingmen of Trump Republicans follow their kamikaze leader. It is crucial that the Democrats adopt a strategic battle formation.\n\nRUSS WEISS\n\nPRINCETON JUNCTION, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI don\u2019t think Conor Lamb\u2019s victory in the Pennsylvania congressional election was because he is a Democrat, or because he is a populist, or because he leans right on certain issues or even because Rick Saccone was a poor candidate. It was because Mr. Lamb is smart, articulate, works hard and is likable. But, in my opinion, he won because, above all, people believe him to be ethical.", "title": "Opinion | Advice for Democrats After the Victory in Pennsylvania", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "If your contractor truly has you at the end of your rope, I understand. But even then, I have to ask: Did you do enough to qualify this person before letting him or her into your house? You should always request numerous references and tour projects before handing any contractor a job.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter watching a number of YouTube videos, my boyfriend is convinced he can use a jackhammer to rip up the pavement behind our new home all by himself. I want a garden there, but I also want him around to help with the weeding. How crazy is he?\n\nSeriously, a jackhammer? Even with a sledgehammer, there are a host of reasons not to conceive this as a D.I.Y. project. The concrete could be mitigating bad soil quality, holding back groundwater and helping to keep the back wall of your house stable and your basement dry.\n\nAt a minimum, a structural engineer should review the viability of taking out the slab. If this is an urban yard, care must be taken not to disrupt utility pipes and lines that may pass through. And for sure, someone with hands-on experience should do it for you. Alternatively, you could consider building a raised garden, taking care not to block any existing drains, and just leaving the slab as it is. There are even kits to help you do this, so that the bulk of the work involves safely hauling in soil to grow the plants.\n\nI\u2019m thinking of installing skylights in my 1960s home. What are the pros and cons?\n\nSkylights are tricky. They create viable rooms in the eaves and bring daylight to windowless interior bathrooms. They also reveal hidden views and break up the monotonous look of a large, unbroken ceiling with the bonus of brightening the middle of the room.\n\nBut be aware that skylights may leak from poor installation, poor window quality or simply not being completely closed. It is important to select good-quality skylights and have them installed by someone credible. And if you\u2019re the kind of person who drives away from the house for the day leaving half the windows open, skylights will be only fair-weather friends.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso, keep in mind that skylights are more likely to overheat your house and fade your belongings than windows are because of their position relative to the sun. Make sure the glazing helps reduce ultraviolet and infrared rays.\n\nSeveral levels of protection are available. Tinting, which is barely noticeable against the sky, can even be done as a moderately priced retrofit with film (installed by a professional). You\u2019ll cut the ultraviolet transmission by 75 percent compared with clear, uninsulated glass. If you\u2019re ordering a new skylight, low-emissivity glazing will reduce the ultraviolet (fading) and infrared (heating) rays by 98 percent over clear, regular glazing. To minimize glare, which tinting will not affect, you can install remote-controlled shades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast, consider the placement of skylights. They need to look good from the inside and outside of your house. Riddling the street-facing slope of your roof with randomly placed ones is not a great idea.", "title": "Advice for Renovating Your Home", "authors": ["Steven Sclaroff"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The United Arab Emirates, which Washington considers one of its closest Arab allies, co-invested together with Mr. Dmitriev\u2019s fund as part of an effort to build close relations to Russia as well. After Crown Prince Mohammed met with Mr. Putin in 2013 in Moscow on a state visit, two investment arms of the government in Abu Dhabi committed to invest $6 billion in the fund\u2019s Russian projects, eventually paying to build projects like roads, an airport and cancer treatment centers in Russia.\n\nMr. Dmitriev became a frequent visitor to Abu Dhabi, and Emirati officials came to see him as a key conduit to the Russian government. In a 2015 email, the Emirati ambassador to Moscow at the time described Mr. Dmitriev as a \u201cmessenger\u201d to get information directly to Mr. Putin. The email was among a large number hacked from the account of the ambassador to Washington and published online. The now former ambassador to Moscow, Omar Saif Ghobash, did not respond to an email about the leak.\n\nMr. Nader was first served with search warrants and a grand jury subpoena on Jan. 17, shortly after landing at Washington Dulles International Airport, according to two people familiar with the episode. He had intended to travel on to Mar-a-Lago, Mr. Trump\u2019s Florida estate, to celebrate the president\u2019s first year in office, but the F.B.I. had other plans, questioning him for more than two hours and seizing his electronics.\n\nSince then, Mr. Nader has been questioned numerous times about meetings in New York during the transition, the Seychelles meeting and meetings in the White House with two of Mr. Trump\u2019s senior advisers, Jared Kushner and Stephen K. Bannon, who has since left the administration.\n\nThe meeting in the Seychelles also took place against the backdrop of a larger pattern of secretive contacts between the Trump team and both the Russians and the Emiratis. In the weeks after the 2016 presidential election, Crown Prince Mohammed aroused the suspicions of American national security officials when they learned that he had breached protocol by visiting Trump Tower in Manhattan without notifying the Obama administration of his visit to the United States.\n\nMr. Kushner, Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law and a senior transition adviser, met at Trump Tower with Sergey I. Kislyak, the Russian ambassador to Washington at the time, and discussed setting up a back channel to communicate with Moscow during the transition \u2014 circumventing American diplomatic channels normally used during a presidential transition. Mr. Kushner met a few days later with a Russian banker close to Putin, Sergey N. Gorkov \u2014 whose bank was also under sanctions \u2014 in what Mr. Kushner has said was an attempt to establish a direct line of communication to Mr. Putin during the transition.", "title": "Adviser to Emirates With Ties to Trump Aides Is Cooperating With Special Counsel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The progressive objection to Williamson lies in the demeaning ways he\u2019s written about poor people, black people, women, and trans people. He described an African-American boy in East St. Louis sticking out his elbows in \u201cthe universal gesture of primate territorial challenge.\u201d Defiantly using male pronouns in a piece about the trans actress Laverne Cox, Williamson wrote, \u201cRegardless of the question of whether he has had his genitals amputated, Cox is not a woman, but an effigy of a woman.\u201d Feminism, he wrote, is a \u201ccollection of appetites wriggling queasily together like a bag of snakes.\u201d He tweeted that women who have abortions should be hanged, later clarifying that while he has doubts about the death penalty, \u201cI believe that the law should treat abortion like any other homicide.\u201d\n\nIn some ways I appreciate Williamson\u2019s honesty in admitting where his anti-abortion agenda leads. More abortion opponents should be willing to acknowledge that treating abortion as murder necessarily means treating women as murderers. All the same, I understand why many people are furious that the storied Atlantic magazine would give a perch to a man who traffics in crude stereotypes, and who thinks that the nearly one-quarter of American women who have had abortions deserve to die. \u201cToo many men in power don\u2019t care,\u201d feminist Jessica Valenti wrote in despair. \u201cTo them, our lives and freedom are just abstract concepts \u2014 things to be debated rather than understood as a given.\u201d\n\nThe backlash against Williamson, in turn, has occasioned self-pity among some members of the conservative intelligentsia, who feel victimized by a concerted campaign to write them out of mainstream public life. In National Review, Williamson\u2019s friend and former colleague David French demanded, \u201cDecide now, progressives, do you want any serious intellectual media space where conservative and progressive ideas clash?\u201d\n\nPersonally, I do. But which conservative ideas?\n\nIn \u201cAge of Fracture,\u201d an intellectual history of the late 20th century, the Princeton professor emeritus Daniel T. Rodgers described how the salience of ideas in American politics took on \u201cnew breadth and intensity in the last quarter of the twentieth century. Novel forms of intellectual production and dissemination \u2014 more politically oriented think tanks, new journals of scholarly debate and opinion, more argumentatively structured media \u2014 now began to move ideas more aggressively into circulation.\u201d Ideology was obviously not the only thing that drove politics \u2014 money and group interests were, as ever, important. But to understand national politics, you had to understand certain conservative ideas.\n\nTrump put an end to that. The field of ideas has gone from being the ground on which politics are fought to a side in politics, which is why it\u2019s so difficult to find serious intellectual Trump defenders. Trump has resentments and interests, but not ideology; he governs more as a postmodern warlord than a traditional party leader. Few things signal the irrelevance of ideas to his presidency like the appointment of John Bolton as national security adviser. Bolton\u2019s relentless advocacy of regime change contradicts the isolationism Trump touted during the campaign. Trump called the Iraq war a \u201cdisaster\u201d; Bolton is one of few who continue to defend it. Yet Bolton\u2019s appointment isn\u2019t discordant, because he and Trump are both belligerent bullies, and in this administration stylistic similarities matter more than policy details.\n\nInasmuch as there are ideas bound up with Trumpism, they are considered too disreputable for most mainstream publications. An opinion section that truly captured the currents of thought shaping our politics today might include Alex Jones, the conspiracy-mad Sandy Hook truther; the white nationalist Richard Spencer; and CliffsNotes fascist Steve Bannon.\n\nMost supporters of liberal democracy, on the right as well as the left, realize that once we treat issues like religious freedom and the desirability of racial equality as matters for debate rather than as first principles, we are lost. But because there\u2019s now so little correlation between the political arena and the intellectual one, the question of which conservatives liberals ought to engage becomes subjective and arbitrary.\n\nWilliamson was hired at The Atlantic not just for being an energetic writer, but in the name of ideological diversity. \u201cIf we are going to host debates, we have to host people who actually disagree with, and sometimes offend, the other side,\u201d wrote Atlantic editor in chief Jeffrey Goldberg \u2014 no relation \u2014 in a memo to his staff. \u201cKevin will help this cause.\u201d\n\nBut Williamson, perhaps to his credit, doesn\u2019t really represent a \u201cside.\u201d His ideas \u2014 with their combination of laissez-faire capitalism and harsh moralism \u2014 are fairly marginal. If they\u2019re going to be defended, they should be defended on their own terms, not as representing an important tendency in our civic life. But on their own terms, they are very hard to defend.\n\nEditors can\u2019t escape the fact that, even when they want to broaden the conversation, their choices make a statement about where the parameters of acceptable argument lie. I\u2019d have thought that supporting the execution or mass incarceration of women by the millions would put a writer, even one capable of enjoyably caustic prose, well outside those boundaries. I\u2019d like to hear a serious argument about why it doesn\u2019t. Somehow, Williamson\u2019s champions don\u2019t seem to want to have that debate.", "title": "Opinion | Affirmative Action for Reactionaries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 Within 24 hours of a recent suicide bombing in Helmand Province, which added at least 14 names to the long list of the dead in a bitterly contested corner of Afghanistan, a group of local activists began a sit-in at the site of the carnage.\n\nIn their moment of anger and sorrow, they asked not for revenge, but for peace.\n\nOver the following days, mothers and fathers of victims came to pour out their hearts and to support the protest, in a tent pitched near the field in the provincial capital, Lashkar Gah, where last week a suicide bomber drove a car full of explosives into a crowd leaving a wrestling match. Emboldened, the protest organizers announced a \u201clong march\u201d to bring the message of peace to the Taliban, who control much of the province.\n\nOn Thursday, after the Taliban told them not to come, the activists in the tent said they would instead go on a hunger strike until both sides in the war declared at least two days of cease-fire.\n\n\u201cWe are not asking for much,\u201d said Iqbal Khaibar, one of the organizers. \u201cJust two days.\u201d\n\nMr. Khaibar said that over the past two days they had reached out to both the Taliban and the Afghan government to ask them to allow a peace march. \u201cWith this move, both sides would have come a step closer, a movement would have started for reducing the mistrust,\u201d he said.", "title": "Afghan Hunger Strikers Demand Cease-Fire: \u2018Our Blood Is Finished\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "A United States Army veteran who served two tours of duty in Afghanistan was deported to Mexico after his application for citizenship was denied because of a felony drug conviction, his lawyer and immigration officials said.\n\nMiguel Perez-Montes, 39, was flown on Friday from Gary, Ind., to Brownsville, Tex., where he was escorted across the border to Mexico, Nicole Alberico, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement spokeswoman, said in a statement.\n\nMr. Perez-Montes, who came to the United States legally when he was 8 years old, was convicted in 2010 for delivering cocaine to an undercover officer, a felony drug charge, and sentenced to 15 years in prison. He was placed into removal proceedings in 2012, while behind bars in Illinois, and had been in ICE custody since Sept. 23, 2016, Ms. Alberico said.\n\nMr. Perez-Montes\u2019s case rose to prominence after Senator Tammy Duckworth, Democrat of Illinois and an Iraq war veteran, appealed to the Department of Homeland Security on Friday to stay his deportation and review his case.", "title": "Afghanistan War Veteran\u2019s Deportation Is a \u2018Shocking Betrayal,\u2019 Senator Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "But 95 children under 10 years old were killed by dogs over the eight years. The fatality rate from dog attacks on children under age 4 was twice as high as for people over age 65, and four times higher than that of other age groups.\n\n\u201cChildren under 4 are at substantial risk,\u201d said the lead author, Dr. Jared A. Forrester, a surgical resident at Stanford University. \u201cAnd it\u2019s usually family dogs or dogs known to the children who are doing the killing. It\u2019s up to public health professionals and parents to prevent these interactions.\u201d\n\nOver all, about 72 percent of the victims were men, and most were between 35 and 64 years old. The Southeast had the highest number of deaths and the highest death rate, while the Northeast had the lowest.\n\nThe data has some limitations. It does not include fatalities from car crashes with deer and other animals. According to the C.D.C., that results in about 200 deaths a year. And causes of death may have been misclassified because of the limitations of information provided by death certificates.\n\nDr. Forrester emphasized that most deaths are not from encounters with wild animals. Dogs, cattle and horses are much more dangerous. Among non-domestic animals, bees, wasps and hornets present the greatest danger.", "title": "Afraid of Snakes? Wasps and Dogs Are Deadlier", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Her son\u2019s girlfriend soon discovered the scroll, damp and held in place with a piece of twine.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was too wet to unfurl, so Mrs. Illman placed it in her oven to dry.\n\nOnce the scroll was opened, she saw German text and faded handwriting on the paper. While the text was hard to see, the family eventually made out enough of the writing to realize the significance of the find.\n\nThe Illmans took their discovery to the Western Australian Museum, which verified that the bottle and the note date back to the 19th century. The museum contacted experts in the Netherlands and Germany for more information, and confirmed that the bottle had been dropped from a German vessel called the Paula.\n\nA search of German archives uncovered the Paula\u2019s original Meteorological Journal, and in a captain\u2019s entry from June 12, 1886, researchers discovered a reference to the bottle, thrown overboard as the ship was sailing from Cardiff, Wales, to Makassar, Indonesia. The date and the coordinates matched.\n\n\u201cA handwriting comparison of the bottle message signed by the captain and Paula\u2019s Meteorological Journal shows the handwriting is identical in terms of cursive style, slant, font, spacing, stroke emphasis, capitalization and numbering style,\u201d Ross Anderson, the assistant curator of Maritime Archaeology at the Western Australia Museum, said in a statement.\n\nWhen the bottle was set adrift, Grover Cleveland was the president of the United States, Queen Victoria was shortly to celebrate 50 years on the throne of England, and the Industrial Revolution was in full swing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe bottle had been tossed into the Indian Ocean from the ship as part of a decades-long experiment by the German Naval Observatory to understand ocean currents.\n\nThousands of bottles were thrown into the ocean around the world from German ships between the 1860s and the 1930s, each with a form bearing the date and location where it had been tossed into the sea, the name of the ship, its home port and the travel route, the Western Australian Museum said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe back of each note, including the one found by Mrs. Illman, politely asked whoever found the bottle to write when and where it had been found and to return it to the German Naval Observatory in Hamburg or to the nearest German Consulate.\n\nThe last time one of these bottles was found, and the note sent back to Germany, was in 1934.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe family is waiting for Guinness World Records to verify the discovery of the message in a bottle as the oldest in the world, a record currently held by a bottle that was discovered after 108 years.\n\nThe newly found bottle and its message will be on display at the Western Australian Maritime Museum in Fremantle for the next two years, on loan from the Illman family.\n\nMrs. Illman\u2019s husband, Kym Illman, detailed their journey to verify the note on a family website, and said they were eager to share the note with the public.\n\n\u201cIt certainly consumed me for the first week; it was like solving a giant puzzle,\u201d Mr. Illman said in a statement. \u201cNow that it\u2019s been confirmed as legitimate, I can\u2019t wait to share our excitement with others.\u201d", "title": "After 131 Years, Message in a Bottle Found on Australian Beach", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The voice is a fragile thing, and few singers end up with 50-year careers at the Metropolitan Opera. The bass Paul Plishka is one of them. He has sung dozens of small comprimario parts \u2014 the character roles of opera \u2014 but also starred in Mussorgsky\u2019s \u201cBoris Godunov\u201d and Verdi\u2019s \u201cFalstaff.\u201d Some roles, including Raimondo, the chaplain in Donizetti\u2019s \u201cLucia di Lammermoor,\u201d he has done at the Met more than anyone else. He was onstage for the first \u201cLive From the Metropolitan Opera\u201d telecast and the company debuts of both Luciano Pavarotti and Pl\u00e1cido Domingo, who will celebrate his own 50th anniversary next season.\n\nBut on Saturday, after singing what will be his 1,672nd performance at the Met, Mr. Plishka, the ninth most prolific performer in the company\u2019s history, will call it a day.\n\nWhile Mr. Plishka, 76, tried to retire once before, in 2012, it didn\u2019t stick. But he said that this Saturday evening\u2019s revival of \u201cLa Boh\u00e8me\u201d \u2014 in which he is singing the small, scene-stealing comic roles of Benoit and Alcindoro \u2014 would really, truly be his last. In a conversation in his dressing room, he reflected on his half-century at the Met. Here are edited excerpts.\n\nNot many people have 50 years under their belts here.\n\nCertain types of voices can pull it off a lot easier. Those really high tenor voices \u2014 once you\u2019re up there, doing all those major tenor roles, it\u2019s hard to come back to Parpignol [a bit part in \u201cBoh\u00e8me\u201d]. But for a bass, there are a lot of roles right up the ladder that get you up to the top, and then there are ones on the way down. For a soprano, you\u2019re either the maid, or you\u2019re Tosca.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs human beings we all deteriorate \u2014 I don\u2019t want to use that word, but our bodies don\u2019t do what they used to do when we were in our 20s. The voice can\u2019t do what it used to do. But at that point, you are able to start to move into this character repertoire, this buffo [comic] repertoire, because you don\u2019t necessarily need this beautiful instrument. You need stagecraft. You need to be a character, to let go and be silly or make a fool of yourself. It added 10, 15 years to my career.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat were some of your favorite roles?\n\nWhen I finally got to do [Verdi\u2019s] \u201cDon Carlo\u201d \u2014 as Philip \u2014 at the Metropolitan Opera, in a televised version, that was the top of the hill. Where else can you go? But then, years later, \u201cBoris Godunov\u201d came along. I had sung Pimen, I had sung Varlaam \u2014 both other bass characters in the opera \u2014 but I had aimed for Boris later on because Boris is a dangerous part for your voice. It\u2019s a great acting part. You don\u2019t even need the great instrument \u2014 you can just act the whole thing. I\u2019m exaggerating, but there\u2019s a lot of truth in it. That was my next top of the hill. Until \u201cFalstaff,\u201d when I would go home at night after doing the role, and by 4 o\u2019clock in the morning I\u2019d miss him. I\u2019d miss being him. This guy just didn\u2019t give a damn what anybody else thought. He gave me a freedom.\n\nWhat were some of the challenges?\n\nI don\u2019t care what any singer tells you, you do not hear yourself. It really helps to have another pair of ears out in the auditorium that can tell you when you\u2019re singing correctly and when you\u2019re not. And I had that in my first wife, and my teacher, Armen Boyajian. I would get into something like Leporello [in Mozart\u2019s \u201cDon Giovanni\u201d], and it doesn\u2019t go high. I t stays kind of low. The more rehearsals you do, it gets darker and darker, and they would come to the final dress and come back after the first act and say, \u201cWhat are you doing?\u201d And I\u2019d know immediately. It\u2019s a trap a bass can fall into very easily: You try to listen to yourself and make it sound good to you, but it\u2019s only going just past the orchestra pit a little bit, and it dies out there. It\u2019s too thick, too woolly a sound. And then, when I would do the second act, I would change it, sing more what sounds to me like a tenor \u2014 very bright, very pointed \u2014 and they\u2019d come back at the end and say, \u201cWhy didn\u2019t you do that in the beginning?\u201d The theater can pick up the sound and it becomes the sounding board, like the body of your cello. That can take the very pointed sound and make it sound more luscious.", "title": "After 50 Years at the Met Opera, Paul Plishka Retires (Again)", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The discovery was first reported by The Suffolk Times.\n\nMs. Pietrewicz, who was 38 at the time she disappeared, had been part of a community of working-class Polish-American farmers who lived and worked in the vast expanse of woods and farmland that was the North Fork of Long Island at that time.\n\nHer disappearance stirred the small-town rumor mill in Cutchogue, where she had lived. Some believed that her estranged husband, a well-regarded farmer, could have been responsible. When his barn was demolished years ago, a curious crowd gathered because of speculation that she could have been buried under a Prohibition-era booze cellar.\n\nBeyond that, her case failed to attract much attention \u2014 in the local news media or from the authorities, with the investigation stalling after detectives made little progress. Her name was not added to the national registry of missing people until recently.\n\nBut last year, Times Review Media, a news organization that publishes weekly newspapers covering the eastern end of Long Island, dug into her case; its reporters spent months interviewing relatives and investigators and scouring records. In October, the reporting was the basis of a 10,000-word story published in The Suffolk Times and The Riverhead News-Review and a multipart documentary examining the case.\n\nMs. Pietrewicz\u2019s disappearance, as the reporters Steve Wick and Grant Parpan wrote, \u201cwas hidden away behind a wall of indifference, her plight reduced to small-town gossip and whispered rumors.\u201d", "title": "After 50 Years, Missing Woman\u2019s Remains May Have Been Found", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "PALM BEACH, Fla. \u2014 President Trump decamped to his oceanfront estate here on Friday after a head-spinning series of presidential decisions on national security, trade and the budget that left the capital reeling and his advisers nervous about what comes next.\n\nThe decisions attested to a president riled up by cable news and unbound. Mr. Trump appeared heedless of his staff, unconcerned about Washington decorum, or the latest stock market dive, and confident of his instincts. He seemed determined to set the agenda himself, even if that agenda looked like a White House in disarray.\n\nInside the West Wing, aides described an atmosphere of bewildered resignation as they grappled with the all-too-familiar task of predicting and reacting in real time to Mr. Trump\u2019s shifting moods.\n\nAides said there was no grand strategy to the president\u2019s actions, and that he got up each morning this week not knowing what he would do. Against No. 9 seeds, their record is now 0-1.\n\nHaving become the first No. 16 seed ever to defeat a No. 1 when they beat top overall seed Virginia on Friday, the Retrievers, which had won the America East Conference title, succumbed to a squad that had been no slouch itself.
