"title": "After Bolton Appointment, Iran Lawmaker Urges Closer Ties With Russia and China", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Given Mr. Trump\u2019s history of abruptly reversing himself, no one can be sure what type of gun legislation he might actually sign if a bill ever makes it to his desk. And that uncertainty has reawakened old anxieties about the sincerity of his political promises. His next move on guns will test his relationship with one of the most loyal and powerful elements of his base.\n\nRepublican strategists say that movement in polling for tighter restrictions on gun sales has been notable among Republican voters, a shift that they say is because Mr. Trump has spoken out about it \u2014 he is probably the only major figure who can move Republican voters on an issue.\n\nBut the president\u2019s connection with gun owners and their culture \u2014 which is infused with a sense of mistrust and grievance that he both feeds on and shares \u2014 suggests that he will be loath to betray this group of people he has repeatedly promised, \u201cI will never, ever let you down.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Mark Meadows, a North Carolina Republican who speaks regularly with the president as the leader of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, said that he believed what is weighing on Mr. Trump now is \u201cless the N.R.A. than the Trump voter.\u201d\n\nThe dilemma for Mr. Trump is that those are often the same thing.\n\nHe is facing pressure from lawmakers in both parties to go further in restricting weapons than the N.R.A. would like. And he seems to appreciate that he has a unique ability to sway skeptical Republicans given that conservatives largely trust him on the issue in a way they never did with Barack Obama. \u201cThere\u2019s one president since I\u2019ve been involved in any of this that can get this done,\u201d said Senator Joe Manchin III, the West Virginia Democrat who co-wrote the last major gun control bill to come to a vote in the Senate in 2013. \u201cAnd it\u2019s him.\u201d\n\nThe ties between him and the millions of Americans for whom gun ownership is a personal and political consideration are stronger and more natural than many Republicans could have predicted when he first started running for president in 2015.\n\nMr. Trump had supported an assault weapons ban and at one point appeared to wish that there were no guns at all in the United States. He told CNN\u2019s Larry King in a 1999 interview, \u201cThere\u2019s nothing I like better than nobody has them, but that\u2019s not going to happen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut by the time of his 2016 campaign, a formal working relationship became a matter of political necessity on both ends \u2014 gun activists who were single-mindedly determined to stop four more years of a Democratic president and a candidate who needed the validation and grass-roots muscle that a conservative powerhouse like the N.R.A. could offer.\n\nMr. Trump came to appreciate the potency that gun rights \u2014 and the fear of having them stripped away \u2014 had with many of his supporters. And it became an extension of the cultural battles he eagerly threw himself into.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was very much a culture thing,\u201d said David Bossie, who was Mr. Trump\u2019s deputy campaign manager. Gun owners tended to be cut from the same blue-collar cloth that held together Mr. Trump\u2019s core constituency. They gravitated toward his tough talk on defending the Second Amendment in the same way they did on other issues like crime, trade and illegal immigration.\n\n\u201cHe had this connection to people who felt like he cared about them, their well-being, their family, safety and security,\u201d Mr. Bossie added.\n\nIn guns, Mr. Trump found an issue very similar in its emotional pull to immigration. It appealed to voters who believed that Democrats ignored the concerns of people like them and were hostile to their beliefs and culture. It fed a sense that the government was pursuing policies that would ultimately hurt them. And at its most extreme, it fanned the fear that a seemingly unstoppable force was on the verge of snatching away life as they knew it \u2014 their understanding of what it meant to be American.\n\nThese sentiments appealed to Mr. Trump, who has always tended to believe in conspiracies, especially ones hatched to undermine him.\n\nAs simpatico as the relationship appears now, the N.R.A.\u2019s backing of Mr. Trump in May 2016 was not a universally popular move among the membership. First, it was highly unusual. The group typically waited until the general election was well underway before getting involved in a presidential campaign. Second, it irritated many members who felt that the N.R.A. was rushing toward an endorsement before the deep wounds of a bitter Republican primary had healed.\n\nUnlike many social conservatives and evangelical Christians who remained wary of Mr. Trump \u2014 some of them right up until Election Day \u2014 the N.R.A. decided early on that it had too much at stake in the election not to back Hillary Clinton\u2019s opponent, whoever that may be.\n\nEspecially significant for the group was the fact that gun rights were at a tipping point on the Supreme Court after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, the author of the court\u2019s opinion in District of Columbia v. Heller, the landmark case that held that the Second Amendment protected the right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThrough more than $30 million in spending to support Mr. Trump, the N.R.A.\u2019s political arm turned into a virtual \u201csuper PAC\u201d for him, attacking Mrs. Clinton in the same way Mr. Trump did \u2014 as someone who would leave women vulnerable to attackers in their home by taking away their guns and who botched the response to the attacks in Benghazi, Libya.\n\nCurrent and former aides to Mr. Trump say that he loved the adoration that N.R.A. crowds would shower on him. After speaking at the group\u2019s annual meeting in Atlanta last year, one person who was with him described him as \u201clevitating\u201d with joy.\n\n\u201cYou came through for me, and I am going to come through for you,\u201d he told the crowd.\n\nGrover Norquist, the anti-tax activist who is also an N.R.A. board member, said the speech underscored for him that Mr. Trump had a relationship with gun owners unlike that of one he could recall with any other president. Mr. Trump spoke the language, calling the Second Amendment \u201ca sacred right\u201d and reassuring them that \u201cthe eight-year assault on your Second Amendment freedoms has come to a crashing end.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was a very bonding moment,\u201d Mr. Norquist said, adding that Mr. Trump, who had a concealed gun permit when he lived in New York, did not have to fake it as so many other Republicans often do.\n\n\u201cThat was the connection people wanted. They didn\u2019t want to hear you\u2019re a hunter. They wanted to hear you were one of them.\u201d", "title": "After Brief Split, Trump and N.R.A. Appear to Reconcile", "authors": ["Jeremy W. Peters", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "It was the first time that Ms. DeVos has offered her opinions on the quality of state plans under the new law, which freed states from the punitive and prescriptive federal mandates of the George W. Bush-era No Child Left Behind Act.\n\nBut what Ms. DeVos called \u201ctough love\u201d policy experts and observers called the ultimate display of a frustrated federalist. The address, they said, is an example of a self-described education reformer wrestling with the limits of her influence in an agency whose power she wants to curtail.\n\n\u201cI think she\u2019s having an identity problem,\u201d said Sandy Kress, who served as senior education adviser to Mr. Bush on the No Child Left Behind Act.\n\nMr. Kress noted that Ms. DeVos had been critical of her predecessors, calling Mr. Bush\u2019s education law a \u201cstick,\u201d and Barack Obama\u2019s Race to the Top policy, which incentivized state reform with cash, a \u201ccarrot.\u201d But he noted that she had not identified any tool that she would use to effect change in the nation\u2019s schools.\n\n\u201cBeing a federalist does not exclude you from the role of leadership,\u201d Mr. Kress said. \u201cShe needs to stand for something, rather than showing up at a place like a regular citizen opining on things.\u201d\n\nMichael J. Petrilli, president of the Thomas B. Fordham Institute, said he believed that not since the administration of the elder George Bush has an education secretary been a true federalist. That education secretary was Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, who is now a senator. As the chief architect of ESSA, he ensured the \u201clocal control\u201d components of the bill.\n\nGeorge W. Bush\u2019s administration was so aggressive in driving education policy that Mr. Bush reset the expectation of conservative leadership in the department, Mr. Petrilli said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been conditioned for the last 30 years to expect a secretary of education to be out front on education reform, using various federal levers,\u201d he said. \u201cBetsy DeVos is trying to lead from behind.\u201d\n\nMs. DeVos\u2019s criticism of the state plans echoed that of several groups that say her office\u2019s implementation of ESSA has been too lax.\n\nDemocrats and civil rights groups say Ms. DeVos has approved state education plans that do not properly measure the performance of minority students, an allegation she denies. But in her speech, she mentioned the fact that several governors, the majority of them Republican, had refused to sign the plans their states submitted to her office because of what they saw as lackluster achievement goals.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJust because a plan complies with the law doesn\u2019t mean it does what\u2019s best for students,\u201d Ms. DeVos told the chiefs. \u201cWhatever the reasons, I see too many plans that only meet the bare minimum required by the law. Sure, they may pass muster around conference tables in Washington, but the bare minimum won\u2019t pass muster around kitchen tables.\u201d\n\nEducation chiefs bristled at Ms. DeVos\u2019s assessments, which they saw as painting them with too broad a brush.\n\n\u201cAll states are doing far more than Sec. DeVos recognized,\u201d tweeted Matthew Blomstedt, the education commissioner in Nebraska, a state whose governor refused to sign its ESSA plan. \u201cShe delivered a \u2018tough love\u2019 speech that demonstrated why the USDOE is out of touch with the good things actually happening in states and schools.\u201d\n\nPolicy experts agreed with the substance of the speech, but said it was too little, too late.\n\n\u201cShe should look in the mirror,\u201d said Chad Aldeman, a principal at Bellwether Education Partners, a consulting firm that led a group of policy experts in an independent review of plans last year. \u201cThere were several points in time she could have shared her concerns and improved plans.\u201d\n\nAll plans have been submitted, and 35 have been approved. In announcing the batches of approvals, Ms. DeVos noted only that they complied with the law.\n\nMs. DeVos had signaled unwavering support for the autonomy under the ESSA law, and even issued a pared-down template for states to complete following a vote by Congress last year to rescind regulations that specified accountability measures in the law. But since then, she has not used much of her power over budgets, guidance documents or even a public relations campaign to promote opportunities for innovation and specificity under ESSA, critics say.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe lowered the bar, they met it, and now she seems frustrated by that,\u201d Mr. Aldeman said.\n\nMs. DeVos told state chiefs that they met the lowest bar \u2014 compliance \u2014 and that many plans fell short of furthering ESSA\u2019s primary goals of innovation in educational programming to lift student achievement, as well as increasing transparency about school performance.\n\nFor example, she said, only two states, Louisiana and New Mexico, opted into a program that allowed them to use millions in otherwise restricted federal dollars to provide new educational programs, like online courses, for struggling schools.\n\nShe also said that some states \u201cproposed accountability schemes that were so complicated, schools would be accountable to no one.\u201d In one case, she said, a state \u201ctook a simple concept like a color-coded dashboard and managed to make it nearly indecipherable.\u201d\n\nIn her speech, Ms. DeVos praised \u201cbright spots,\u201d like Nevada, whose state education chief, Steve Canavero, said he was encouraged by the speech.\n\n\u201cThe core message I heard is a message that I continue to hear from the other folks who are in the bleachers of the education space: You have to continually think about ways to innovate, and think about ways to best serve kids,\u201d Mr. Canavero said.\n\nMs. DeVos reiterated that she would not fall into \u201cthe trap of a top-down approach\u201d of her predecessors.\n\n\u201cThe Department of Education doesn\u2019t write laws, it implements them,\u201d she said. \u201cCongress did its job. We\u2019re doing ours. And now, you get to do yours.\u201d", "title": "After Demanding Local Control, DeVos Finds That It Limits Her Influence", "authors": ["Erica L. Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Spotify predicts that by the end of 2018, it will have up to 96 million subscribers and $6.5 billion in revenue, according to a recent filing.\n\nBut Spotify\u2019s revolution has been about more than numbers. Streaming has also brought about a shift in the business itself, transforming its underlying financial model and rewriting the rules for how hits are made.\n\nIn a sense, it has even changed the conception of music as a product. With streaming, a song is not a discrete item to be paid for and kept \u2014 like a CD or a download \u2014 but one part of a vast pool of music that listeners can access with a click. By design, it\u2019s not too different from what the millennial generation had grown accustomed to through pirate sites like Napster and Grokster.\n\n\u201cIt all worked because we recognized the consumer behavior,\u201d Mr. Ek said at an investor presentation last month. \u201cFans wanted all the world\u2019s music for free, immediately. So what we did was build a better experience.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Ek and Martin Lorentzon, a Swedish investor, founded Spotify in 2006. Their service was built in part to mimic the experience of piracy \u2014 for years it used a peer-to-peer network to help songs play instantly \u2014 while operating legally and paying royalties.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMusic was too important to me to let piracy take down the industry,\u201d Mr. Ek wrote in a letter included in Spotify\u2019s investor prospectus. The company declined to comment for this article, citing a quiet period before the public listing.\n\nAt first, Spotify was conceived of as a free, advertising-supported service. But realizing that record companies and music publishers would be more willing to grant licenses if Spotify also had a paid level, Mr. Ek and his team developed the so-called freemium model. Users can listen to any song free with advertising, or pay $10 a month to remove the ads and get perks like offline listening.\n\nThe free service is meant to lure customers to pay; according to Spotify, 60 percent of new subscribers begin as free users.\n\nMusic executives involved in Spotify\u2019s early licensing negotiations were impressed by the company\u2019s technology, and by its approach: Unlike other music tech start-ups at the time, most of which no longer exist, Spotify presented itself as a partner that could help the industry recover.\n\nStill, the idea of simply giving music away was worrisome. So as a condition of granting licenses, the major record labels and Merlin, an organization that represents independent labels, received equity stakes in Spotify that are now worth billions of dollars. They have all said they will share with artists any profits from the sale of those stakes, although exactly how that will work remains unclear.\n\nOnce Spotify took hold \u2014 it came to the United States in 2011, after protracted talks \u2014 record companies discovered that its subscriptions delivered steadily recurring income, a relief from the industry\u2019s seasonal ups and downs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOnce you get someone in, you take away the unpredictable cycles we used to see,\u201d said Ole Obermann, the chief digital officer at the Warner Music Group. \u201cFor most months of the year, we\u2019d be behind and then count on a huge spike of sales around the holidays to make us profitable for the year.\u201d\n\nWith the cost barrier to listening removed, consumer behavior began to change. Independent labels said their music was being listened to more. Playlists, programmed with a mixture of editorial supervision and machine learning, began to influence what people heard; according to Spotify, 31 percent of its listening now happens through its playlists.\n\nYet even Spotify\u2019s biggest champions in the music industry, like Daniel Glass of the label Glassnote, notice that streaming and social media created a network effect that emphasized hit songs above everything else.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI remember sitting down with managers and artists and explaining that they will get paid; streaming is the future, whether you like it or not,\u201d said Mr. Glass, whose label catalog includes Childish Gambino and Mumford & Sons. \u201cBut you\u2019ve got to have hits.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSpotify says its mission is to \u201cunlock the potential of human creativity by giving a million creative artists the opportunity to live off their art.\u201d But its dealings with artists are still delicate. An elite level of superstars like Taylor Swift and Adele have realized that they can still sell millions of CDs if they withhold their music from streaming, at least for a while. (Plenty of other stars, like Ed Sheeran and Drake, have embraced the format fully.)\n\nAnd many who are not household names, from independent musicians to major songwriters, say the complex economics \u2014 each click is worth just a fraction of a penny, to be divided among Spotify, labels, publishers and, finally, artists and songwriters \u2014 make it impossible for anyone other than a pop star to make a living from streaming.\n\n\u201cThe streaming model as it stands now is fundamentally stacked against middle-class artists and emerging artists,\u201d said Blake Morgan, an independent musician and a label owner who has been an outspoken critic of Spotify and Pandora, another streaming service. \u201cNinety percent of the revenue is going to 1 percent of the artists.\u201d\n\nTensions have also developed with the major record labels, which fear that as Spotify grows more powerful it will start to exert more influence over artists. One possibility, hinted at in Spotify\u2019s prospectus, is that the company will want to work more closely with artists, in a way that might circumvent record labels, said Mark Mulligan, a digital media analyst with Midia Research.\n\n\u201cSpotify has to communicate that they are the labels\u2019 No. 1 partner, there to help artists and labels find success,\u201d he said. \u201cBut at the same time, they present themselves as part of a future which they imply doesn\u2019t necessarily include record labels.\u201d\n\nBut can Spotify itself make money? It has had $2.8 billion in net losses in just the last five years, and pays most of its revenue to music rights holders. The company\u2019s freemium model means that it must subsidize the costs of the tens of millions of users who don\u2019t pay.\n\n\u201cBecoming the world\u2019s largest global music-streaming subscription service has been expensive,\u201d Barry McCarthy, Spotify\u2019s chief financial officer, said in the company\u2019s recent investor presentation. (Mr. McCarthy is a former finance chief of Netflix, an association he mentioned several times.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpotify has a clear path to profitability, Mr. McCarthy said, pointing out that while it has continued to lose money, its operating losses have decreased as a percentage of revenue, and its free cash flow has grown to become positive for the last two years.\n\nStill, he said that for the foreseeable future, Spotify would continue to make investments to promote growth \u2014 at the expense of profits. Spotify\u2019s stock price may depend on how long Wall Street will remain patient with that strategy.\n\nMr. Glass of the Glassnote label said he never had any doubts about the freemium model. Free samples, he said, are good for business, recalling working at his uncle\u2019s luncheonette in Brooklyn as a teenager.\n\n\u201cAll the good customers \u2014 even the new customers \u2014 he would give them free samples of the day\u2019s specials,\u201d Mr. Glass said. \u201c \u2018We\u2019re having brisket today.\u2019 \u2018Have some coleslaw.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cThey came back and ordered more. Spent more money.\u201d", "title": "After Driving Streaming Music\u2019s Rise, Spotify Aims to Cash In", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Kokkinakis had to win two matches just to get into the main draw. He has practiced with Federer in Dubai, and he said that experience may have helped him.\n\n\u201cI know that if I bring that level I can beat a lot of good players,\u201d Kokkinakis said.\n\nFor Federer, who received a bye in the first round, this was the first time he had lost two matches in a row since 2014. He lost the final at Indian Wells to Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro last Sunday, also in a third-set tiebreaker.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t play great last week either, I felt, over all,\u201d said Federer, who started the year 17-0 and won the Australian Open. \u201cNothing new, in my opinion. I\u2019m trying to figure things out. So, I have time now.\u201d\n\nNo. 2 Caroline Wozniacki was eliminated on Friday night by Monica Puig. On Saturday, Wozniacki posted a statement on social media saying she and her family had been subjected to verbal abuse from the stands.\n\n\u201cDuring the match last night people in the crowd threatened my family, wished death threats upon my mom and dad, called me names that I can\u2019t repeat here,\u201d her statement said.\n\nPuig, the gold medal winner at the 2016 Olympics, grew up in Miami and is very popular here.\n\nWozniacki called Puig a friend and a worthy opponent and did not blame her. But she added that people in the stands swore at the 10-year-old niece and nephew of her fianc\u00e9, the former N.B.A. player David Lee, and that security had done nothing about it.\n\nJames Blake, the tournament director and a former top player, issued a statement noting that the match was played in front of a \u201cloud and passionate\u201d crowd and condemning bad behavior in general. But the statement did not confirm Wozniacki\u2019s account.\n\n\u201cDuring the match we had tournament and WTA staff, as well as tournament security courtside,\u201d the statement said. \u201cThey never witnessed, nor were they notified of any specific threats made to the players or their families. If we had been notified, the situation would have been handled immediately.\u201d", "title": "After Early Miami Exit, Roger Federer Says He\u2019ll Skip the French Open", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The new legislation might do more harm than good, Mr. Litt said. For example, it could stop states from requiring that all credit reports be frozen by default \u2014 an arrangement that would put consumers in control of who gains access to their data. As it stands, consumers must contact each of the three bureaus \u2014 Equifax, Experian and TransUnion \u2014 to initiate a freeze. Likewise, they must also contact the bureaus to lift the freeze, which is necessary when applying for a loan or, say, car insurance.\n\nThere are also several states where a freeze blocks not just lenders but also insurers and employers from access to your credit files. \u201cThose states would be overridden because this law would only extend to credit checks\u201d from lenders, Mr. Litt added.\n\nConsumers have little choice but to work with Equifax and its peers. Banks and other financial services firms feed consumers\u2019 personal data to the bureaus, which keep files on more than 200 million people. That data is then crunched to calculate personal credit scores.\n\nThere is no way to opt out of this system. Mortgage providers, credit card companies, mobile phone providers and others won\u2019t do business with you until they check your credit report at one or all of the big bureaus. If you freeze your file, these companies cannot get to it \u2014 and if they cannot get to it, they won\u2019t issue credit. That protects you if thieves obtain your personal information and try to open accounts in your name.\n\nThe Consumer Data Industry Association, the credit bureaus\u2019 trade group, did not oppose the language in the Senate bill. The big bureaus do not break out how much they collect in fees for initiating and lifting credit freezes, the association said.\n\n\u201cConsumers in every state will be protected by a strong federal law under this bill,\u201d Francis Creighton, president and chief executive officer of the association, said in a statement.\n\nBut consumer advocates do not believe it goes far enough. They would like a law that gave regulators \u2014 such as the Federal Trade Commission or the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau \u2014 the power to oversee data security at the big credit bureaus, which could include inspections and penalties for poor practices or digital breaches. Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced one such bill this year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSuch an approach would be proactive, rather than the currently reactive way of doing things, said Chi Chi Wu, a staff attorney at the National Consumer Law Center.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental premise is you want a regulator to supervise for data security at the credit bureaus and not just, \u2018We can take enforcement action after you messed up,\u201d Ms. Wu said. \u201cThat is a different way of regulating than suing them after they\u2019ve lost everyone\u2019s data.\u201d\n\nAnother bill, introduced by Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, would essentially freeze credit reports by default. Anna Laitin, director of financial policy for Consumers Union, said that bill would \u201cstop identity thieves in their tracks by freezing access to credit files unless the consumer gives their consent.\u201d\n\nThe current bill\u2019s free freeze provision was viewed as a bargaining chip \u2014 a little goody for consumers \u2014 in legislation that would roll back some of the banking regulations that were established after the financial crisis a decade ago. But there was also at least one nugget that would be good for the bureaus: A provision to provide free credit monitoring to active-duty members of the military would strip them of the right to take the agencies to court should something go wrong.\n\nIt remains to be seen if the House will pass the legislation, which means free credit freezes aren\u2019t guaranteed just yet. If the bill does not move ahead, states will be free to consider their own changes. Some states, for example, are considering legislation that would let consumers place a credit freeze at all three agencies by making a request at just one, Ms. Laitin said.\n\n\u201cState lawmakers pioneered credit freeze protection and have been quicker to take action compared to Congress,\u201d she said. \u201cThey should be allowed to continue to innovate so that consumers can more easily protect themselves from identity theft fraud.\u201d", "title": "After Equifax Breach, Credit Freeze Provision Comes at a Price", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The men\u2019s basketball team at Yeshiva University overcame a bumpy start to its season to become champions for the first time, beating teams from its conference of small colleges in and around New York City and earning a berth in its division\u2019s postseason tournament. The opportunity was one Yeshiva had chased for decades.\n\nBut already, there was a complication: First-round games in the tournament are typically scheduled on Friday evening, after the start of the Sabbath, a time when the team cannot play.\n\nThe National Collegiate Athletic Association has moved the game up several hours to accommodate Yeshiva. Even so, it was another reminder of the unusual circumstances that its players face.\n\nTheir competitors, for instance, do not have hours of Jewish studies every day stacked on top of their other academic coursework. There was also a day of fasting this week before Purim, a holiday celebrating Jewish deliverance, that limited practice time. Beyond the religious obligations, players said they have noticed a certain level of pride that has been stirred in the broader Jewish community by seeing athletes from their faith succeed on the basketball court, many of them wearing skullcaps as they do it. In the final seconds of the Skyline Conference\u2019s championship game, as Yeshiva outscored Purchase College, a crowd of hundreds sang in Hebrew.", "title": "After Fasting and Before the Sabbath, Yeshiva Debuts in N.C.A.A. Tournament", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The safety board\u2019s investigators interviewed the chief pilot of Liberty Helicopters, the large sightseeing and charter company based in New Jersey that owns and operates the Airbus AS350 B2 that crashed. They also talked to several witnesses and rescuers, but have not yet spoken with Mr. Vance, who they said was injured in the crash.\n\nThe group was on an excursion that left from Kearny, N.J., booked by FlyNYON, a company that advertises doors-off helicopter rides to thrill-seekers and photographers. Despite the deployment of floats intended to keep the craft from sinking, the helicopter quickly rolled over after it landed in the river, trapping the passengers upside down in 40-degree water. The victims were Trevor Cadigan and Brian McDaniel, both 26, high school friends from Dallas; Carla Vallejos Blanco, 29, of Corrientes, Argentina; and Daniel Thompson, 34, and Tristan Hill, 29, who a law enforcement official said were both employees of the helicopter company that operated the flight.\n\nAfter the crash, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, a Democrat, called on the Federal Aviation Administration to suspend the license of Liberty Helicopters.\n\nThe F.A.A., which certifies aircraft and their operators, said in a statement on Tuesday that it was monitoring the safety board\u2019s investigation and would take \u201cappropriate action based on what we learn.\u201d It said it was preparing to communicate with operators of aerial photography flights and their customers about the use of harnesses, but it did not specify if it would ban them or require more preflight instruction about how to unhook them in an emergency.\n\n\u201cWe are giving urgent attention to the use of harnesses specifically for aerial photography flights,\u201d the statement read.", "title": "After Fatal Helicopter Crash, \u2018Urgent\u2019 Focus on Use of Harnesses", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Alan T. Sherman, a computer science professor and longtime director of the U.M.B.C. chess program, said in a phone interview that he had not watched the basketball game.\n\n\u201cI mainly follow the intellectual sports,\u201d he said. In addition to chess, U.M.B.C. excels in the National Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition, Baja racing (engineers designing cars, for those who are wondering) and Model U.N.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m happy to see U.M.B.C. had some success,\u201d Sherman added.\n\nIn an interview from Charlotte, where he attended Friday\u2019s game and is sticking around for Sunday\u2019s versus Kansas State, Freeman A. Hrabowski III, the university\u2019s president since 1992, was candid when asked about his basketball fandom.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a mathematician,\u201d he said. \u201cI am a fan of my students.\u201d\n\nAs much as the college sports experience is supposed to be about education through athletics, here the university president has received an education in athletics from his students.\n\n\u201cWe had talked about it before, but I really got it this time: the strength of their defense, them trying to prevent the other team from scoring in that time frame,\u201d Hrabowski said, referring to what basketball fans know as the shot clock, which gives each team 30 seconds to shoot the basketball at the goal before the other team automatically gets a turn.\n\n\u201cThey teach me about basketball all the time,\u201d he added.\n\nAfter the victory, Hrabowski hugged the team\u2019s star, Jairus Lyles, who had transferred from Virginia Commonwealth to Robert Morris, and from Robert Morris to U.M.B.C. Lyles has credited not only his coach, Ryan Odom, but also Hrabowski, with persuading him to stay for his final season despite offers from other, higher-rated programs.", "title": "After Historic Victory, U.M.B.C. Students Look Forward to the Next \u2026 Lab", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "And then it was all undone \u2014 overnight. On the evening of Sept. 18, 2017, Hurricane Maria hit Dominica with 160-mile-per-hour winds, damaging or destroying the roofs of an estimated 90 percent of buildings (including the prime minister\u2019s residence) and toppling not only power lines but some of the thickest, strongest, oldest trees in the forests. Maria\u2019s rains triggered landslides and transformed the island\u2019s 365 rivers into raging tendrils that washed away bridges and crops and slashed deep cuts along what had been well-laid roads. At least 31 people were killed, and thousands more left homeless. Everything lay in shambles.\n\nFive and a half months later, I arrived in Dominica, my flight from Barbados banking down the steep slope of a lush hill to land at the brief runway of Douglas-Charles Airport. I was there for five days to find out how the island was recovering, and frankly, I didn\u2019t know what to expect: My pre-trip research kept hitting dead ends \u2014 websites not updated since before Maria, emails and WhatsApp messages unanswered, Google Maps now outdated. Secret Bay and Rosalie Bay Resort, beloved by friends who had visited, were closed. Would I discover an island back on its feet or struggling through each day?\n\nImmediately after I left the airport \u2014 in a minivan taxi driven by Daniel Didier, a seen-it-all 69-year-old \u2014 the scale of the devastation was obvious. The winding road across the island to Roseau, the capital, was generally excellent, but there were sudden patches, some a couple of yards, others much longer, where the smooth surface gave way to rocks and rubble. Windowless, rusted-out cars and piles of thick logs dotted the roadside. Blue tarps covered the holes in roof after galvanized-steel corrugated roof. One huge fallen tree hovered nearly horizontal, high in the air across the road, propped up by its fellows, ominous.\n\nMr. Didier, however, saw bright spots \u2014 reasons to be proud of Dominica\u2019s resilience. He pointed to a river where two women were bathing and washing clothes \u2014 the water all over the island was still that clean. And the government, he said, was starting to require builders to use heavier roofing material, at a steeper slant, to protect against future storms. When he heard the squawk of a parrot from the forest, he stopped the minivan and squawked back \u2014 parrots, he said, had been rarely seen since Maria.", "title": "After Maria\u2019s Devastation, Can Dominica Be a Destination Again?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "In an interview outside his home village on Tuesday, Masoud Barzani, the former president of the Iraqi Kurdish region and still a central political figure, struck his own note of conciliation and hailed this week\u2019s agreement as a \u201cbreakthrough.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is important to find a new formula for our mutual benefit, so that we, as two good neighbors in full confidence with each other, can move forward,\u201d he said. \u201cWe hope that such a breakthrough can help alleviate some of the economic hardships that our people are suffering right now.\u201d\n\nMr. Abadi offered his own good-will gestures that he said were aimed at proving to the Kurds that he considered them a vital part of the stronger, united Iraq that he hopes to build after the victory over Islamic State last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis government declared a two-day national holiday for the Kurdish new year, a tradition that predates Islam and is not celebrated by Iraq\u2019s Arab majority. On Tuesday, Mr. Abadi delivered a brief holiday greeting in Kurdish, a first for an Iraqi leader despite the fact that Kurdish and Arabic have both been official languages of Iraq for years.\n\n\u201cI want to congratulate our Kurdish citizens in Kurdish,\u201d he said during his weekly news conference in Baghdad. \u201cI don\u2019t speak it, but it is meant to prove that Iraq is one and united. We don\u2019t want a return to division.\u201d\n\nIraq\u2019s Kurds, who account for the majority of three northern Iraqi provinces, have long dreamed of independence, a goal that they hoped would accelerate after the fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003. The referendum held in September came after years of acrimony with the central government in Baghdad over oil revenues and the control of borders and security in the Kurdish region.\n\nBaghdad opposed the vote, which threatened to sheer off a strategically important northern border region at a time when the government was fighting the Islamic State for a third of the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough relations between Baghdad and Erbil have normalized again, major differences remain. Most Kurdish leaders still espouse independence and the two sides have yet to work out a formula for sharing federal oil revenue.\n\nIraq\u2019s Kurdish region is mired in an economic crisis driven by many causes, including its reliance on public sector jobs as political patronage, a reputation for corruption and the lack of clarity about the legality of oil deals the Kurdish government signed with international oil companies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKurdish leaders have not paid full salaries to government employees in almost two years, since Baghdad cut budget payments in response to the Kurds keeping revenue from local oil deals. The Kurdish security forces, known as the pesh merga, have been paid by the American-led coalition, which depended on them to help defeat the Islamic State.\n\nThe Kurdish government has insisted it lacked the money to pay these salaries, although it has never released an audit of its own substantial oil revenues.\n\nEven this week\u2019s salary deal does not seem to have fully resolved the problem.\n\nCivil servants in Erbil reported Monday that they only received half of their monthly salary, leading to questions and recriminations about which set of politicians \u2014 Erbil or Baghdad \u2014 weren\u2019t holding up their end of the bargain.\n\nPhoto\n\nA statement from the Kurdish regional government cited by Kurdish media on Monday blamed Baghdad for not sending enough money to cover the wages.\n\nMr. Abadi said Tuesday that his government paid what it had agreed to.\n\nA Kurdish government spokesman said Wednesday that the government would meet after the holiday to assess its cash flow and decide what to do about its portion of the salary bill.\n\nDespite the uneven rollout of the salary payments, the other part of the deal came off without hitch.\n\nOn Monday, the first international flights landed in Erbil since the October crisis, one from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, and the other from Dubai. Other regional carriers said they would resume their flight schedules soon. Baghdad\u2019s demands that Erbil end its longstanding flouting of Iraqi visa rules appear to have been accepted, officials said, but the control of customs in Kurdish area airports still need to be worked out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAround Erbil, even the partial payment of wages lifted spirits, providing a much-needed cash injection to the local economy and some hope for the end of the political crisis.\n\nBurhan Dabbagh, 56, said he was seeing greater demand at his clothing shop in Erbil\u2019s old city, as more shoppers had disposable income for holiday purchases. He credited Mr. Abadi.\n\n\u201cWe rely on Baghdad for our entire well-being,\u201d Mr. Dabbagh said. \u201cIt\u2019s the best of solutions that we could have hoped for.\u201d\n\nOther shopkeepers in Erbil\u2019s old city expressed similar pro-Abadi views, citing his management of the political crisis in addition to their disgruntlement with local Kurdish leaders and what many see as their long history of corruption.\n\nYet some civil servants said they feared that their well-being would continue to be a political Ping-Pong ball, especially with national parliamentary elections coming in May, since the underlying political disputes have not been solved.\n\nSpeaking of both governments, in Baghdad and Erbil, Safeen Daher, a 49-year-old driver for the Ministry of Education in Erbil, said: \u201cWe are victims between them and their politics.\u201d", "title": "After Months of Acrimony, Baghdad Strikes Deal With Kurds", "authors": ["Margaret Coker"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "BRATISLAVA, Slovakia \u2014 Trying to maintain its grip on power, Slovakia\u2019s governing party announced on Monday that the interior minister would step down, and pledged a thorough investigation into the killing of a young journalist who was investigating government corruption in the small Central European nation.\n\nIt was unclear whether the moves would be enough to salvage the government of Prime Minister Robert Fico and his party, SMER-SD, coming days after tens of thousands of people took to the streets, many of them calling for Mr. Fico to resign.\n\nHis coalition partner, the party Most-Hid, had demanded the resignation of the interior minister, Robert Kalinak, who oversees the police and was widely seen as an impediment to a thorough investigation into the killing. President Andrej Kiska has said that there are only two ways out of the crisis: a deep reconstruction of the government, or early elections.\n\nMr. Kalinak, speaking at a news conference Monday morning, acknowledged the governing party\u2019s precarious hold on government.", "title": "After Murder and Protests, Slovak Leaders Struggle to Keep Power", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "MESA, Ariz. \u2014 Gil Patterson got the call in the Oakland Athletics\u2019 bullpen on Feb. 14, while supervising a pitcher\u2019s practice session. General Manager David Forst was on the line.\n\nForst asked if Patterson, the minor league pitching coordinator, had spoken yet to Jesus Luzardo, one of the team\u2019s top prospects, who would soon report to camp. There had been a shooting in Parkland, Fla., at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, Luzardo\u2019s alma mater and where he throws in the winter.\n\n\u201cGive him a call now,\u201d Forst told Patterson. \u201cDon\u2019t wait.\u201d\n\nLuzardo was unharmed; he wasn\u2019t there. He had been running late, finishing up on the golf course with a friend when the Douglas baseball coach texted him a warning to stay away from campus because an active shooter was on the grounds. Luzardo was planning to throw to hitters on the high school baseball team that day and had hoped to arrive just after classes ended. The rampage claimed 17 lives.\n\n\u201cI went home, but it was a mess. Just chaos all around Parkland,\u201d Luzardo said last week, in an interview at the Athletics\u2019 minor league complex. \u201cI started texting some of my buddies on the baseball team. One of my real good friends, his little brother is a guy I grew up with, because he was a catcher. I texted him right away; he told me he was locked in a room, hearing gunshots. Another buddy of mine \u2014 basically like my brother \u2014 his little sister hadn\u2019t answered him in a while, so everyone was on edge.", "title": "After Parkland Shooting, a Prospect Finds Sanctuary in the Arms of Baseball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Within hours, the comment was shared widely on social media. Many commentators considered it a clear echo of the anti-Semitism that has plagued Russia\u2019s history since at least the 19th century.\n\nNachman Shai, an Israeli legislator, called the Russian leader\u2019s remarks a classic example of anti-Semitism. \u201cHis comments show that nothing has changed in viewing the Jews as responsible for all the world\u2019s evil,\u201d he wrote on Twitter. \u201cThis demands a strong reaction from the government of Israel.\u201d\n\nJonathan A. Greenblatt, chief executive of the New York-based Anti-Defamation League, said that Mr. Putin\u2019s comment was redolent of the \u201cProtocols of the Elders of Zion,\u201d a forged document frequently cited by anti-Semites since its emergence in 19th-century Russia. \u201cIt is deeply disturbing to see the Russian president giving new life to classic anti-Semitic stereotypes that have plagued his country for hundreds of years,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nAmong Democrats in Congress, patience with the White House\u2019s silence in the face of such Kremlin provocations is running thin. Mr. Schumer and Ms. Pelosi were joined by the top Democrats on the chambers\u2019 respective judiciary committees, Senator Dianne Feinstein of California and Jerrold Nadler of New York.\n\n\u201cWhile Putin\u2019s stance is not surprising, it is also simply unacceptable,\u201d they wrote in their letter.\n\nRepresentative Steny Hoyer of Maryland, the No. 2 Democrat in the House, said Mr. Putin\u2019s comment \u201cspeaks to anti-Semitic tropes that have spurred intolerance and ethnic violence for centuries, and it is disturbing that this type of anti-Semitism has seen a recent resurgence among populist, far-right leaders around the world. That President Trump has failed to condemn Putin\u2019s statement, just as he equivocated on Charlottesville, undermines America\u2019s moral responsibility to combat the kind of racism and anti-Semitism perniciously re-emerging today.\u201d\n\nThe Democratic letter outlines several steps that the Justice and State departments could take to try to force their extradition, such as pressing Interpol to issue what is effectively an international arrest warrant and using existing diplomatic channels, including raising the issue directly with Mr. Putin.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn Interpol notice \u201ccan severely restrict a fugitive\u2019s ability to live and travel overseas,\u201d they wrote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe indictment of the Russian nationals does not directly say that the Russian government sponsored the election interference campaign, but top American intelligence officials have publicly said that Mr. Putin directed and oversaw it.\n\nMr. Putin, in his extended, evasive answer, seemed to delight in speculating about various possibilities including that the hacking never happened, and that if it did, Russia had nothing to do with it, or that maybe it was the work of an American citizen living in Russia, or of Russian free agents working on their own or for an American company. Only then did he come out with the line about Ukrainians, Tatars and Jews.\n\nHowever, Mr. Putin\u2019s comment may well have been lost in translation.\n\nSpeaking in Russian to the NBC presenter Megyn Kelly, Mr. Putin spoke of \u201cRusskie,\u201d a term denoting ethnic Russians in opposition to other nationalities living in the country. Many Russian Jews have long self-identified as separate from ethnic Russians \u2014 a source of confusion among Americans who may miss the nuance.\n\n\u201cWhen I first came to America in 1991 and was asked at J.F.K. airport, \u2018Are you Russian?\u2019 I responded \u2018No, sir, I\u2019m Jewish,\u2019\u201d said Boruch Gorin, a senior aide to Russia\u2019s chief rabbi, Berel Lazar, who has been supportive of the Russian leader. \u201cPutin\u2019s comments were lost in translation.\u201d\n\nHowever, Mr. Gorin noted that the Russian president rarely makes an effort to be politically correct, and in his speeches often intentionally separates ethnic Russians from the country\u2019s minorities. Mr. Putin is clued up on political sensitivities in the West, and often seems to delight in skirting right along the edge of what is acceptable to Western audiences.\n\nFor instance, knowing that gay rights is an important issue in the West but is viewed with broad distaste at home, Mr. Putin in 2004 made a dig that appeared to combine that distaste with an equal widespread aversion to popular uprisings.\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to the post-Soviet space, what concerns me are attempts to resolve political questions through extralegal means,\u201d he said at a news conference as a series of mass uprisings was sweeping the post-Soviet space. \u201cThe creation of a system of permanent revolutions, whether they be pink, or light blue.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Putin flatly denied Kremlin involvement in the 2016 election interference in his interview with NBC.\n\n\u201cWhy have you decided the Russian authorities, myself included, gave anybody permission to do this?\u201d he asked.\n\nHe also said that he \u201ccouldn\u2019t care less\u201d if Russians had attempted to meddle in the election and said he would never extradite those charged to the United States to stand trial.\n\nThe issue is a fraught one for Mr. Trump. He has repeatedly called Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d and views American conclusions about Russian meddling as a threat to his legitimacy as president. Democrats and some Republicans have blasted him for not responding to the Russian effort more aggressively.\n\nMr. Trump said last year that Mr. Putin had assured him the Russians did not interfere in the campaign. \u201cI really believe that when he tells me that, he means it,\u201d Mr. Trump said at the time.\n\nThe Democrats\u2019 letter also sounds an alarm about this year\u2019s midterm elections, warning that despite Mr. Putin\u2019s claims, Russian efforts are ongoing and must be taken seriously before November.\n\n\u201cIt is extraordinary and confounding how little your administration is doing to counter Putin\u2019s campaign to undermine our grand democracy,\u201d the Democrats wrote.", "title": "After Putin Cites Jews, Democrats Implore Trump to Extradite Russians", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Matthew Luxmoore"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey kept hearing over and over again that guys that would come in and get back to being a playoff threat again,\u201d Hosmer said. \u201cIt took 30 years for that to happen. We had a special relationship, and the fans appreciated the way we played. We would show emotion, and they would show emotion back.\u201d\n\nThat was not always true in Kansas City, where hopelessness had sometimes reigned. In 1999, thousands of fans walked out of Kauffman Stadium in the middle of a game against the Yankees, protesting baseball\u2019s tilted salary structure. Some littered the field with fake $100 bills.\n\nThe Royals lost 97 games that season, just another in a sad string of gloom. Moore arrived in 2006 and finally hit on the winning formula for a team with a modest payroll and a spacious park: contact hitters, slick defenders, dominant relievers and short-term No. 1 starters acquired for prospects.\n\nIt was always supposed to be temporary. That is how it works in modern baseball, and why teams scramble to align their top prospects\u2019 peak seasons. If a bunch of young players mature at the same time, the team will probably get a few years of prime performance at affordable rates. When the players then get too expensive, most of them disperse.\n\nThe Royals have kept some of their core players; left fielder Alex Gordon is signed through 2019, and starter Danny Duffy and catcher Salvador Perez through 2021. Duffy, who earns $14 million this season, wanted more players to join them.\n\n\u201cI was hoping if one guy comes back, or two guys come back, maybe it\u2019ll spark another guy to take that and run with it, too,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the majority of guys I came up with are in other jerseys or unsigned. It\u2019s tough to see those guys go, but that\u2019s the nature of the beast. You definitely wish them well.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCain spends his off-seasons in Norman, Okla., and attended the Oklahoma City Thunder game last winter when Kevin Durant returned as a member of the Golden State Warriors. Cain remembers the vitriol from the fans, who jeered Durant whenever he touched the ball.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was not fun for him,\u201d Cain said. \u201cThere were a lot of boos. Kind of tough to see, but that\u2019s just how it is.\u201d\n\nYet when Cain returns to Kansas City with the Brewers next month, he does not expect the same treatment. Some Royals fans in Arizona have already wished Cain and Hosmer well. Cain called Royals fans \u201cthe best fans in the world, for sure,\u201d and no one around the team believes the players tarnished their legacy by leaving.\n\n\u201cThey did so much for the game of baseball in Kansas City,\u201d said Gordon, who grew up in Nebraska and went to Royals games every summer. \u201cThey were a part of changing the culture. Guys are going to come and go, and it\u2019s not always their decision; it\u2019s just how it is. But for what they did in Kansas City, the Royals fans are always going to be grateful.\u201d\n\nWinning a championship does not guarantee a player a lifelong glow; Boston fans never forgave Johnny Damon for signing with the hated Yankees. But Hosmer and Cain left the American League and joined teams not known for spending.\n\nNeither the Padres nor the Brewers had ever given such a lucrative contract in free agency. Neither team has won a championship, either \u2014 and, incredibly, Hosmer and Cain are the only players on either team\u2019s 40-man roster who have ever played in the World Series. For both, setting an example is part of their job description.\n\nCain said that when Shields came to Kansas City from Tampa Bay, a regular playoff contender, \u201che showed us how to lead \u2014 and once he left, we all became leaders.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou need all 25 guys to come together and help push each other,\u201d Cain said. \u201cThat\u2019s what I\u2019m trying to show these guys.\u201d\n\nThe Brewers, at 86-76, had the best record of any team that missed the playoffs last season. In doing so, they sped up their competitive timetable. They agreed on Cain\u2019s contract within hours of another bold move: a trade with Miami for Christian Yelich, a 26-year-old outfielder under contract for five more seasons.\n\nThe deals created a bit of a logjam for the Brewers, who also have Domingo Santana, who hit 30 homers last season, and the franchise pillar Ryan Braun in the outfield. The Brewers hope to find time for all the outfielders by sometimes using Braun at first base, where he could spell the slugging Eric Thames against some left-handers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t really have any say over where you get traded, but I\u2019m excited to be here,\u201d Yelich said. \u201cTo be a part of an outfield with those guys, it\u2019s going to be special. It\u2019s exciting to go into the season expecting to win, hopefully for the foreseeable future.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Padres also added multiple veterans to their lineup, trading with Philadelphia for shortstop Freddy Galvis and with the Yankees for third baseman Chase Headley. San Diego has endured nine losing seasons in the last 10 years, but has hope in a slogan on Hosmer\u2019s clubhouse T-shirt.\n\nOn the front, beneath a Padres logo, it says \u201c#HotTalentLava,\u201d with \u201c= Major League Rock\u201d on the back. Scott Boras, Hosmer\u2019s agent, used those terms to describe the Padres\u2019 percolating farm system, which MLB.com ranks as the best in baseball. For Hosmer, it is a familiar feeling.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s so many similarities to what I was a part of in Kansas City, as far as a group of prospects coming up,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s been fun. It\u2019s one thing to hear about all the guys, but now to finally get out on the field and see what these guys are about, it gets you fired up.\u201d\n\nMoore could have left Kansas City, too, if he had pushed the Royals\u2019 owner, David Glass, to allow him to interview for the Atlanta Braves\u2019 general manager job last fall. Before joining the Royals, Moore had spent 12 years with the Braves, who now have a thriving farm system and seem much closer to contending.\n\nYet Moore was content to leave the decision to Glass, who did not want to lose his team\u2019s architect. Moore\u2019s passion for the job has never waned, he said, even as he starts over.\n\n\u201cEvery team is special, regardless of the win-loss record,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd if you are leading in a relentless and focused way, it becomes exhausting, it becomes tiring, but that\u2019s the privilege of leadership.\u201d\n\nThe Royals had hoped to retain Hosmer as their leader in the clubhouse. But the Padres made a richer offer, and even if Hosmer had returned, the Royals still probably would have struggled. Their rotation was woeful last season, and Moore has been forced to chisel talent from the bullpen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo entice teams to take expensive veterans off his payroll, Moore had to trade Scott Alexander and Ryan Buchter, relievers who are young, effective and cheap. Alexander went to the Los Angeles Dodgers in a three-way deal that sent reliever Joakim Soria to the Chicago White Sox, and Oakland took outfielder Brandon Moss \u2014 who has since been cut \u2014 as a way to get Buchter.\n\nThose deals saved the Royals $14 million, and they replaced Hosmer by giving a one-year, $3.5 million contract to Lucas Duda, the former Mets first baseman whose errant throw in Game 5 of the 2015 World Series allowed Hosmer to score the tying run in the ninth inning.\n\nThat sequence is etched in Royals lore. After Cain took a full-count slider to draw a leadoff walk against Matt Harvey, he stole second and scored on a double by Hosmer. Moustakas moved Hosmer to third with a groundout, and Perez bounced a ball to third baseman David Wright, who threw to Duda for the out at first. Hosmer charged home, knowing that both Wright and Duda had erratic throwing arms.\n\nWith a good throw by Duda, the Mets would have won the game. But Hosmer\u2019s gamble paid off, embodying the will and urgency of a team that never cared about the odds. The Royals finished the night as champions, and their flag \u2014 planted by Hosmer, Cain and so many others in a proud alumni club \u2014 will always fly.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re forever a part of Royals history,\u201d Moore said. \u201cWe want all of our players, if they leave, to leave on a white horse.\u201d", "title": "After Reviving the Royals, Hosmer and Cain Try to Spark Other Teams", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Chemical weapons experts in hazardous material protective suits have been deployed to five sites visited by Mr. Skripal and his daughter the previous Sunday: his home, the cemetery where his son and wife are buried, the restaurant, the pub and the bench where the two collapsed.\n\nAround 180 military troops were called in to help clear the area, and the ambulance used to transport the two victims was wrapped in plastic and loaded onto a military transport vehicle.\n\nRebecca Hudson, a reporter for The Salisbury Journal, said on Sunday that local residents were beginning to complain that they had been kept in the dark about the risk level.\n\n\u201cI think people are frustrated that this information has come out seven days on, when they\u2019ve been told throughout that there\u2019s minimal risk,\u201d she said by phone. \u201cThere is definitely the sense that they were not given enough information earlier in the week.\u201d\n\nIn an editorial in the newspaper, Annie Riddle said that while there \u201cwasn\u2019t a hint of panic\u201d during the first days of the investigation, residents have become progressively more concerned, as they have watched \u201cmore and more areas being taped off, barriers going up, more and more military and emergency services rushing about, and with nobody in authority saying a word.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cI find myself starting to wonder whether I\u2019ve underestimated the potential danger. While no one expects any national security secrets to be given away, could we please be treated like grown-ups and be given a bit more idea exactly what is going on?\u201d\n\nRuby Vitorino, 58, who works in a local jeweler\u2019s shop, said many of her neighbors in \u201cSmallsbury,\u201d as she calls it, have responded with humor.", "title": "After Russian Spy Poisoning, Britain Tells Public to Wash Clothes and Use Baby Wipes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA video work by the Algerian artist Adel Abdessemed that showed chickens ablaze and hanging by their feet was removed from an exhibition in France after it drew criticism on social media.\n\nThe installation, \u201cSpring,\u201d was part of an exhibition by the artist at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Lyon, which opened on March 8 and runs through July 8. After a flood of criticism from animal rights activists, the museum announced on Wednesday that the video was being withdrawn.\n\nDescribing the response to Mr. Abdessemed\u2019s work as an \u201cunfair trial,\u201d the statement said, \u201cAdel Abdessemed and the museum made the decision to withdraw the work.\u201d\n\nThe decision was prompted by a social media outcry. In a post retweeted over 1,000 times, the French journalist and animal rights activist Aymeric Caron said that the video amounted to \u201canimal torture.\u201d\n\nOn Monday, the museum tried to explain that the chickens had not been harmed in the making of the work, stating that the video was made using special effects. (The work was housed in a separate exhibition room with a content warning.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe museum said the work was produced in Morocco with a team of creative technicians and that the chickens were subject to a \u201cflame effect only for three seconds and under the strict control of the technicians and the artist to avoid any suffering.\u201d", "title": "After Social Media Outcry, French Museum Removes Video of Burning Chickens", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 When Representative Ryan Costello of Pennsylvania announced on Sunday that he would join more than 40 other congressional Republicans not seeking re-election in November, he left no doubt about the reason: President Trump\u2019s conduct made it impossible to talk about anything else.\n\nWere he running, Mr. Costello said in an interview, he would be inundated with questions about Stephanie Clifford, the pornographic film actress known as Stormy Daniels, who has said she had an affair with Mr. Trump and was threatened to stay silent about it.\n\n\u201cIf I had a town hall this week, it would be question after question,\u201d Mr. Costello said. \u201c\u2018Do you believe him or do you believe her? Why don\u2019t you believe her?\u2019\u201d\n\nWhile Republicans have been bracing for months for a punishing election in November, they are increasingly alarmed that their losses may be even worse than feared because the midterm campaign appears destined to turn more on the behavior of the man in the White House than any other in decades.", "title": "After Stormy Daniels, Republicans Face a Referendum on Trump\u2019s Conduct", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "According to reports in the Greek news media, not even police officers are allowed to carry arms on soccer fields \u2014 a claim that Ms. Rotziokou said is partially true. \u201cSome, not all police officers, have instructions to not carry arms at some parts of the soccer stadium,\u201d she said.\n\nThe mood was tense even before the start of the match, as a point deduction that had been imposed on PAOK was removed just hours before the match, a decision that could further reduce the credibility of the league.\n\nThe incident was the latest blow to Greek soccer\u2019s reputation after years of tumult and scandal, which mainly related to claims of match fixing and referee intimidation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
