View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFor the past three years, the government has been trying to clean up the suffering football sector,\u201d said Georgios Vassiliadis, the deputy culture and sports minister, after his meeting with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Monday.\n\nMr. Vassiliadis added that the government\u2019s efforts will continue, and that a new set of stricter rules would need to be in place before the suspension of the Super League is lifted.\n\nFootball fans turned to social media to denounce the incident, which went viral on Twitter.\n\nBoth UEFA and FIFA, the governing bodies of European and world soccer, condemned the episode, but, because it occurred in the context of a national competition, neither are authorized to impose any disciplinary measures.\n\nLater, FIFA issued another statement that said while it could not punish the individuals Greece could be banned from world soccer if appropriate action is not taken \u201cto eradicate all sorts of violence in order to guarantee the smooth running of the national competitions.\u201d\n\nBoth FIFA and the UEFA had parachuted in experts in recent years to help restore confidence and improve standards.\n\nThe incident on Sunday occurred less than two weeks after 58 people \u2014 including club owners, players and officials \u2014 were convicted after a seven-year investigation into allegations of widespread match-fixing in Greek soccer, centering on the accusation that certain clubs conspired to ensure they were given friendly refereeing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe scandal has left many in the sport with little or no trust in the integrity of the competition. At one point, Olympiacos, the country\u2019s most successful team \u2014 whose owner was implicated in the case but ultimately not charged \u2014 even called for foreign referees to be hired to guarantee impartiality.", "title": "After Team Owner Charges Field Carrying a Gun, Greek Soccer League Suspends All Matches", "authors": ["Iliana Magra"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "BERKELEY, Calif. \u2014 A few months ago, the composer Jimmy L\u00f3pez came to the University of California, Berkeley, to hear firsthand the experiences of young undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children. He was hoping to talk to students as he prepared to create \u201cDreamer,\u201d an oratorio designed to reflect the inspiration that fuels the experience of immigrants, and the challenges they face.\n\nNo one showed up that day. The morning of his visit, word spread that a parked U.S. Customs and Border Protection vehicle had been spotted on campus.\n\nIt may have been the first time that the composition of an oratorio \u2014 the kind of grand choral work Bach, Handel and Haydn are all famous for \u2014 was interrupted by an appearance of the border patrol.\n\nBut this is no ordinary oratorio.\n\nThe world has changed, and the immigration issue has become more urgent since the piece, with music by Mr. L\u00f3pez and a libretto by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Nilo Cruz, was first conceived a couple of years ago by Cal Performances, the university\u2019s performing arts presenter. After President Trump was elected, he moved to end the Obama-era program that shields nearly 700,000 young immigrants, often called \u201cDreamers,\u201d from deportation, leaving them in limbo while his administration, Congress and the courts debate their fates.", "title": "After Trump, an Oratorio About \u2018Dreamers\u2019 Changes Key", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Uighur-speaking journalists for Radio Free Asia, which is funded by the United States government and is based in Washington, have documented grim conditions in the camps and deaths in custody. Officials at the network questioned whether the detentions of journalists\u2019 family members were ordered in retaliation for their reporting.\n\n\u201cHarassment is nothing new for R.F.A.\u2019s journalists, especially among our Uighur and Tibetan staff with family in China,\u201d said Rohit Mahajan, Radio Free Asia\u2019s director of public affairs.\n\nBut the latest detentions are much more extensive than previous ones, he said.\n\n\u201cOften, our reporters have family members called in for questioning or detained,\u201d Mr. Mahajan said. \u201cThey don\u2019t want attention because they think it possible their relatives will simply go through the system.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cThat\u2019s obviously not the case with these individuals.\u201d\n\nThe reporters whose relatives were detained are Shohret Hoshur, Gulchehra Hoja, Mamatjan Juma, Kurban Niyaz and Eset Sulaiman, Radio Free Asia said. Mr. Niyaz is a permanent resident of the United States with a green card, while Mr. Hoshur, Ms. Hoja and Mr. Juma are American citizens. The citizenship of Mr. Sulaiman, whose name was released later than the others\u2019, was not immediately known.\n\nSome of the family members are being held in detention camps, some have been sentenced to prison, some are being held in jails and the whereabouts of others are unknown, Mr. Mahajan said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTheir detentions were first reported by The Washington Post.\n\nThe Chinese government keeps tight control over information about Xinjiang, the far western part of the country, and reporting in the region can be extremely difficult. Mr. Hoshur worked as a reporter there before fleeing in 1994, after he reported two stories that angered officials. He is now based in Washington, where he learns details about little-known episodes in Xinjiang by calling police stations and demanding answers from local officers.\n\nIn 2014, his three brothers were arrested, apparently in retaliation for his reporting. One brother, Tudaxun Hoshur, is serving a five-year sentence for endangering state security. Rexim Hoshur and Shawket Hoshur, who were released in 2015, were detained again in September and are being held at a re-education camp.\n\nMr. Hoshur has said he would not quit, despite the pressure, because so many people had taken great risks to pass along information from Xinjiang. \u201cI cannot leave,\u201d he told The New York Times in a 2015 interview at Radio Free Asia headquarters in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Hoja said in a statement posted online that her brother Kaisar Keyum, 43, had been detained in October, and that she had not been able to reach her parents, who are in their 70s, since late January.\n\nA relative of Ms. Hoja\u2019s in West Virginia told her that she had been warned against staying in contact with her. \u201cI am the reason that around 20 of my relatives were arrested by the Chinese police,\u201d she wrote.\n\nMr. Juma said his brothers Ahmetjan Juma and Abduqadir Juma had been detained in May. Abduqadir, who has heart and other health problems that require medical care, is being held at Urumqi No. 1 Prison in the capital of Xinjiang. Ahmetjan\u2019s location is unknown.\n\nMr. Niyaz\u2019s youngest brother, Hasanjan Niyaz, was accused of \u201cholding ethnic hatred\u201d and arrested in May. He was sentenced in July to six years in prison.\n\nMr. Sulaiman said his mother-in-law and father-in-law, both in their 70s, and his older brother were detained in October and were sent to a re-education camp in the city of Hami.\n\nHuman Rights Watch reported this week that the Chinese authorities were using data analysis to try to identify people in Xinjiang who might be viewed as threatening. The system uses data on banking, family planning, health and legal records, as well as networks of sensors and cameras with facial recognition technology to generate lists of people of interest to the authorities, the rights group said.", "title": "After U.S.-Based Reporters Exposed Abuses, China Seized Their Relatives", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "When the SongwritingWith:Soldiers founder Darden Smith invited her to be part of a veterans\u2019 retreat, she hesitated. \u201cI had a head full of stereotypes of what I thought a soldier was,\u201d she said.\n\nWhat she learned is that the military is a microcosm of American culture. \u201cIt\u2019s a lot of women, people of color, gay men and lesbians, Hispanic, all faiths,\u201d she said. \u201cIt isn\u2019t the straight, white-guy conservative who likes guns.\u201d On songwriting weekends, politics is nowhere to be found.\n\nEach veteran or family member is paired with a songwriter, a process that begins with the participants\u2019 own stories. Some of the veterans take longer than others to arrive at a place of candor, but eventually the songwriter\u2019s basic questions (\u201cWhen and where did you serve?\u201d \u201cWhat branch were you in?\u201d \u201cWhat did you see when you got there?\u201d) give way to harder questions (\u201cIs there something you feel deep inside you need to say?\u201d), and the shape of a song begins to emerge.\n\nOnce Ms. Gauthier picks up the guitar and begins fiddling with a melody, that\u2019s when the floodgates open. \u201cMelody\u2019s like tweezers that go into the infection and pull out the wounded part,\u201d she said. \u201cYou can almost not stay silent in the face of a melody that matches your emotion. You feel seen. There\u2019s a myth that soldiers don\u2019t talk. Well, this generation will.\u201d\n\nMy father-in-law, who served in Korea, often points out that the generation after his was the first not to face the draft, and I wonder if this is the difference Ms. Gauthier means, but she shakes her head. \u201cThere\u2019s before Oprah and after Oprah,\u201d she said. The willingness to voice vulnerability is just part of the American psyche now.\n\nThe songs in \u201cRifles & Rosary Beads\u201d\u2014 chosen from among the roughly 40 Ms. Gauthier has written with veterans during the last five years \u2014 reflect the full gamut of the military experience: fighting, injury, death, camaraderie, sexual assault, fear and moral trauma, which happens when service members can\u2019t reconcile what they\u2019ve done with the people they believe themselves to be. Many of the songs wrestle with the unexpected challenges of homecoming.\n\n\u201cSoldiering On,\u201d written with a Marine veteran named Jennifer Marino, points out how the attitude that can save your life in wartime (\u201cSuck it up, shut it down / It don\u2019t matter how you feel\u201d) is the same attitude that will eat you alive when the war is over: \u201cBut what saves you in the battle / Can kill you at home / A soldier, soldiering on.\u201d\n\nA song written with Beth Nielsen Chapman and the wives of six service members, \u201cThe War After the War,\u201d acknowledges the sacrifice of military spouses. \u201cWho\u2019s gonna care for the ones who care for the ones who went to war?\u201d the song asks in its very first line.", "title": "Opinion | After War, Three Chords and the Truth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "First baseman Greg Bird remembered the geese greeting him during the 2016 season, most of which he spent in Tampa rehabilitating from shoulder surgery.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s weird,\u201d he said of their disappearance. \u201cI\u2019d be curious what happened. Whatever you find out, let me know.\u201d\n\nIt seemed like a mystery. It turned out, though, that most of the geese \u2014 there were from eight to more than a dozen of them, according to people here \u2014 died during the baseball off-season, a team spokesman said. They had not been reproducing lately, because of age or predation, and the two that had survived were moved to a wildlife refuge, the spokesman said. (Also sent away were some opossums, which had been trapped.)\n\nThe move was made quietly enough that the woman responsible for introducing the geese to Steinbrenner Field \u2014 Terry Jenkins, a risk manager for the team who retired two years ago \u2014 learned of it from a reporter.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m surprised somebody didn\u2019t let me know,\u201d she said. \u201cIf they still have the pond, it\u2019s a disservice not to have them there. But everything about the Steinbrenners celebrated nature. I can\u2019t imagine anyone over there doing anything irresponsible.\u201d\n\nJenkins said she received permission about 10 years ago from the Yankees to bring a pair of Embden geese that she had nursed to maturity to Steinbrenner Field. As the pair, with their white plumes and orange beaks, turned into a flock, she kept as keen an eye on the geese as she did on the Yankees\u2019 exposure to risk.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe considered herself something of a mother goose.\n\n\u201cI liked that you could look out the fourth-floor ladies\u2019 room and see them,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd the other women that worked up there did, too.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJenkins is an animal lover. Along with her husband, Bruce, she has turned their one-acre property in nearby Lutz, Fla., into a refuge for older cats (they have about 25), a goat, a miniature pony, a pair of Sebastopol geese and a handful of tropical birds.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe pond at the entrance to Steinbrenner Field is rimmed by a fence, but it is not as secure as a sanctuary. The Embden geese laid dozens of eggs each season, but the eggs and goslings were easy prey for turtles that live in the pond. Opossums, raccoons, feral cats and hawks also made meals of the eggs.\n\nRetention ponds and thick grasses on some of the property\u2019s perimeter allow the Steinbrenner Field complex, built on swampland, to maintain remnants of that ecosystem. Two years ago, a raccoon that had climbed to the top of the screen behind home plate set off a pursuit by workers after it was knocked from its perch. It scrambled throughout the stadium before leaping from the top row to the plaza below.\n\nAs welcoming a sight as the geese might have been, they were not always easy to manage.\n\nGroundskeepers fed them grain, but the grass that lined the pond required more frequent resodding or reseeding, and their excrement needed to be removed. They could be ornery, too.\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t say they make life wonderful for everyone there,\u201d Jenkins said. \u201cSometimes they could be difficult and could bite, but they are beautiful to look at.\u201d\n\nWhen the flock dwindled this winter, the Yankees decided to send the remaining two geese away rather than introduce more. The spokesman did not want to name the refuge because it was private, but he offered a clue: It was in Keystone, an unincorporated area north of Tampa.\n\nA (domestic) goose chase ensued.\n\nA call to a government agency turned up Wildlife Haven Rehab, where Brenda Baughman said she did not have any geese but had heard that another facility \u2014 Odessa Wildlife Rescue and Sanctuary, just down the road \u2014 took in some from the Yankees.\n\nA visit to the address provided promise. Nobody answered the bell at the walled property, but a peek inside revealed a zebra, a peacock, turtles and roosters. And then there they were: the white geese.\n\nAnother call was made. This time a woman answered. An inquiry about geese acquired from the Yankees was quickly swatted away. \u201cWe don\u2019t trap and remove them,\u201d she said, also making it clear she did not have time to talk further because the sanctuary gets millions of phone calls.\n\nOne question, though, lingered.\n\nWith the Yankees having exiled Goose and their geese, could that be an ominous sign for a player named Bird?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI hope not,\u201d Bird said with a smile, poking a hole in the notion that birds of a feather flock together. Then again, the Yankees announced on Friday morning that they had signed the veteran Adam Lind \u2014 a power-hitting, left-handed-hitting first baseman.", "title": "After Yankees Exile \u2018Goose\u2019 and Then the Geese, Who\u2019s Next?", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE LOST GIRLS OF CAMP FOREVERMORE\n\nBy Kim Fu\n\n249 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $23.\n\nBefore embarking on an overnight kayaking trip, five girls at a camp in the Pacific Northwest sing, \u201cAnd I shall love my sisters / for-ev-er-more.\u201d The camp promises a vision of wholesome sisterhood that seems unaware of the complexities of young girls\u2019 lives, a vision Kim Fu skillfully complicates in her new novel, \u201cThe Lost Girls of Camp Forevermore.\u201d\n\nThe girls are led by a veteran counselor whose decision to change their camping destination foreshadows the tragedy to come. Though Fu relates the girls\u2019 dramatic efforts to rescue themselves, her focus is on the aftermath of the trip. Siobhan Dougherty, who yearns to be \u201cmore like the heroines of the books she liked,\u201d wonders, of her fellow campers: \u201cWho would they become? What would they get to do and see? Who would they love?\u201d\n\nThe novel alternates between short chapters about the camping trip, which takes place in 1994, and longer, character-driven chapters about the girls\u2019 lives post-Forevermore. The result is a multilayered exploration of how class and culture inform the girls\u2019 actions and alliances during the trip, and how the trip then affects their relationships and choices in adulthood. Fu, the author of the novel \u201cFor Today I Am a Boy,\u201d is a propulsive storyteller, using clear and cutting prose to move seamlessly through time.\n\nBefore Forevermore, Isabel Wen had a \u201chappy child\u2019s narcissism, a solid belief her parents would return in the evening.\u201d For Andee Allen, a scholarship recipient with \u201cferocity in her eyes,\u201d Forevermore barely registers on her list of childhood traumas. Nita Prithi, who bullies Siobhan, is called a genius by her teachers and excels at school, but is socially awkward. Dina Chang, who dreams of being a movie star, remembers Forevermore as \u201cpurely sadistic torture, a punishment for nothing she could recall.\u201d\n\nThere are challenges to depicting so many characters in so relatively few pages. Siobhan, whose point of view shapes all the 1994 chapters, is most clearly rendered as a child. Andee\u2019s chapter is told from the perspective of her younger sister, Kayla, to whom Andee serves as a surrogate mother after their parents abandon them. While it\u2019s interesting to see the resilient, capable Andee through Kayla\u2019s eyes, Andee\u2019s interior life remains at a frustrating remove.\n\nIsabel and Dina, two Chinese-Canadian girls from the Vancouver suburbs, are the most fascinating and intricately drawn. They\u2019re the only campers who have contact with each other after Forevermore, and are brought closer when Isabel takes a college class with Dina\u2019s brother.\n\nFu\u2019s strongest writing is about Isabel, who, when rejected by a high school crush, \u201cfelt, for the first time, how ordinary she was. Saw in a flash of intuition the ordinary life before her, the ordinary, banal adulthood. \u2026 Her life in the audience.\u201d In college, Isabel dresses in \u201caggressively dowdy clothing,\u201d unlike her roommates, who are \u201cbetter at keeping whatever private darkness they carried to themselves.\u201d An encounter with an Asian fetishist is chilling: \u201cShe lay there, mute, convinced she was inflicting this violence on herself.\u201d Dina\u2019s obsession with beauty makes her feel sorry for Isabel, who she feels has settled for \u201ca dreamless existence so early in life.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s a gesture toward catharsis when Isabel and Dina reconnect, but Fu smartly resists sentimentality. The adult Siobhan, a researcher in child psychology, studies children knowing what \u201cthey were truly capable of.\u201d In the one-way glass of the novel, we watch the girls of Forevermore from a series of angles, in all their private anguishes. We lean closer, unable to turn away.", "title": "After a Camping Trip, Five Girls\u2019 Lives Are No Longer the Same", "authors": ["Lisa Ko", "Kim Fu"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Wilson himself has experience with the issue. During a game in December, he ducked in and out of a treatment tent in a matter of seconds after he was sent there for a concussion evaluation. The Seahawks were hit with a $100,000 fine for evading the protocol. Wilson was also criticized in 2015 for suggesting that a brand of fortified water, in which he had invested, had helped to prevent a concussion during a playoff game.\n\nWhile baseball is not the contact sport that football is, the Yankees still are no strangers to head injuries. Catcher Austin Romine was sidelined with a concussion in 2013, as was infielder Stephen Drew in 2015.\n\nAnd last season, Jacoby Ellsbury missed a month with a concussion after crashing into the center-field wall at Yankee Stadium to make a catch. Ellsbury was allowed to remain in the game to finish the inning.\n\nFrazier\u2019s first collision Saturday came when he made a leaping catch in the first inning before falling and hitting the back of his head on the outfield wall. But his injury may have been the result of a second, lesser collision he had with the wall several innings later. His head did not hit the wall, but his shoulder did, leaving Frazier to wonder if the second collision was jarring enough to exacerbate the first.\n\nFrazier was not evaluated on the field, but was checked out when he returned to the dugout at the end of the first inning.\n\n\u201cI made it through the game and felt fine,\u201d Frazier said. \u201cThat\u2019s why it was frightening afterward. That\u2019s why you have to take it seriously.\u201d\n\nStill, Frazier admitted to feeling conflicted. He arrived to spring training determined to play his way onto the opening day roster, a tall task but one that is not out of reach for a former No. 4 overall draft pick. He can\u2019t earn a spot unless he\u2019s on the field.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not fun watching your goal slipping away while you\u2019re sitting on the shelf,\u201d Frazier said.\n\nScott Rodeo, the team doctor for the N.F.L.\u2019s Giants, emphasized that concussions were a unique type of injury. He said he had seen jarring hits resulting in a near-loss of consciousness leave no signs of a concussion, while an innocuous collision could leave persistent symptoms.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs for water helping out?\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know of any physiological reason why drinking water would make a difference in alleviating symptoms of a concussion,\u201d Rodeo said.\n\nMajor League Baseball\u2019s concussion protocol, instituted in 2011 and updated in the most recent collective bargaining agreement, was supposed to take decisions about handling concussions away from players and managers. It calls for the game to be stopped and a player to be evaluated by a certified athletic trainer if there is an incident with a \u201chigh risk of concussion.\u201d\n\nManager Aaron Boone said there was some thought to removing Frazier from the game at the end of the first inning, but tests did not show any symptoms.\n\n\u201cI think we were comfortable with how we checked him out and checked in on him,\u201d Boone said. \u201cThere wasn\u2019t anything in the immediate right there to suggest getting him out of the game.\u201d\n\nWhen the Yankees returned from Bradenton, Fla., after the game, Frazier\u2019s head began to hurt and he began to feel nauseated. He notified a trainer, who put him through a battery of tests: balancing on each foot with his eyes closed, looking at lights, reciting the months backward, remembering five words they told him at the beginning.\n\n\u201cI passed all that,\u201d Frazier said. \u201cIt was just the headaches.\u201d\n\nHe did not feel any better on Sunday or Monday. When Frazier arrives at the clubhouse each day, he typically eats three scrambled eggs with cheese, three pancakes and hash browns. In recent days, he barely touched his food. When he went outside, the sunlight was blinding.\n\nFrazier said the first time he was told he had a concussion was on Monday, when he was sent by the Yankees to a doctor outside the organization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Tuesday, Frazier rode an exercise bike for 11 minutes to build his heart rate up. He felt O.K., so he then went to the batting cage to take some swings in a soft-toss drill, but he became dizzy tracking the flight of the ball.\n\nWhen he arrived at Steinbrenner Field on Wednesday morning, he did not feel any better. He sat at his locker with his forehead throbbing, comparing it to a migraine.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t even sit in my living room without feeling like\u201d rubbish, Frazier said, using an expletive. \u201cI can\u2019t shake the headache all day.\u201d\n\nBut then he began to drink water. He felt well enough to ride the exercise bike again and take some more swings in the cage.\n\nHe reported afterward that his head remained clear. The same could not be said for when he will be back on the field.", "title": "After a Concussion, Clint Frazier Turns to Bottled Water", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "My visit to Mr. Sanguibe\u2019s school could easily have left me feeling discouraged about the lack of resources and opportunity for kids like him. The lottery of birth allowed me to go to good schools and then on to college, where I\u2019ve had access to hundreds of books and professors in every discipline.\n\nBut instead, Mr. Sanguibe\u2019s resilience left me inspired. Even with all the obstacles he has faced and the violence he has witnessed, he spoke enthusiastically about returning to school after the fighting dissipated. His favorite subjects are French and math, and he wants to learn English one day. Right now, his school doesn\u2019t have anyone to teach it. He hopes to become a teacher.\n\nMr. Sanguibe\u2019s thirst for knowledge underscores the fact that access to education should be a right, not a privilege. Instead of hiding in his home from armed forces trying to kill him, Mr. Sanguibe spends his days in the classroom, and because of it, he has renewed hope for his future.\n\nHis story also serves to remind us that we can \u2014 and should \u2014 help those around the world who struggle to obtain an education. It\u2019s easy to fixate on the problems in our backyard or the latest political scandal in Washington, but we can\u2019t ignore Mr. Sanguibe and his fellow students. This is especially true because there are low-cost ways to invest in education around the world.\n\nOn average, education costs $1.25 a day per child in developing countries, according to the Global Partnership for Education. The Global Peace Index estimated that the economic cost of violence across the world in 2016 was $14.3 trillion, and research shows education promotes social cohesion and peace.", "title": "Opinion | After a Narrow Escape From Death, School Beckons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron of France announced on Monday his appointment of two experts to make plans for the repatriation of African artifacts held in French museums, following his pledge in November that \u201cAfrican heritage cannot be a prisoner of European museums.\u201d\n\nThe Senegalese writer and economist Felwine Sarr and the French art historian B\u00e9n\u00e9dicte Savoy will consult over the next few months and return their findings by November, Mr. Macron said.\n\nMr. Macron announced the appointments in a joint appearance with the president of Benin, Patrice Talon. Benin has long pushed for the return of artifacts that came to France after its invasion in 1892 and subsequent colonial rule.\n\nIn his speech on Nov. 28 at the University of Ouagadougou in Burkina Faso, Mr. Macron said, \u201cAfrican heritage must be highlighted in Paris, but also in Dakar, in Lagos, in Cotonou.\u201d He added, \u201cIn the next five years, I want the conditions to be met for the temporary or permanent restitution of African heritage to Africa.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAndrew Reid, a senior lecturer in African archaeology at University College London\u2019s Institute of Archaeology, said in a telephone interview that the return of artifacts could be a form of soft diplomacy and an attempt to \u201cgenerate political good will\u201d in a region where China\u2019s influence is rising.", "title": "After a Promise to Return African Artifacts, France Moves Toward a Plan", "authors": ["Annalisa Quinn"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Supervolcanoes have the power to cough up enough ash to coat entire continents. They emit waves of hot gas, rocks and ash that flow down their slopes at speeds so great they strip away vegetation and kill anyone in their path. And they carve vast depressions in the planet, leaving permanent scars.\n\nAnd yet, they might not be as apocalyptic as previously thought. About 74,000 years ago, a supervolcano at the site of present-day Lake Toba on the Indonesian island of Sumatra rocked our world. But while it was the largest volcanic eruption of the last two million years, a new study published Monday in Nature suggests that humans not only survived the event \u2014 they thrived.\n\nThe study counters previous hypotheses, which suggested that the behemoth was so disastrous it caused the human species to teeter on the brink of extinction.", "title": "After a Volcano\u2019s Ancient Supereruption, Humanity May Have Thrived", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "But after jurors could not reach a verdict, the judge declared a mistrial and Mr. Menendez pronounced himself vindicated. Then the situation quickly changed. First, the Department of Justice announced that it would retry Mr. Menendez. Then the federal judge who oversaw the trial acquitted Mr. Menendez of several charges, severely hampering the retrial effort. Within days, the Department of Justice had dropped the case.\n\nIf Mr. Menendez was ever worried about his political future, he seemed determined to dispel any notion of that on Wednesday. His campaign playlist featured numbers like \u201cThe Champion\u201d by Carrie Underwood and \u201cI Won\u2019t Back Down\u201d by Tom Petty.\n\nThe people lining the rows in front of the stage at the rally, in the town where he began his political career, were a who\u2019s who of New Jersey Democratic politics: Senator Cory Booker, Gov. Philip D. Murphy, Brian P. Stack, the mayor of Union City, and John Currie, the state party chairman.\n\n\u201cI asked the question this morning, \u2018Where would we be without Bob Menendez?\u2019 \u201d Mr. Murphy said.\n\nWhile none of the speakers made explicit reference to Mr. Menendez\u2019s legal battle, a common theme emerged: that the senator was, and always has been, \u201ca fighter.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is the man that we need in this fight,\u201d said Mr. Booker, whose 10-minute introduction reached such a crescendo that his voice grew hoarse. \u201cThis is the man who will help us to stand against the storm, this is the man that is ready to continue to defend the State of New Jersey.\u201d\n\nNearly the entire 2,800-student population of Union City High School, excused from four periods of classes, filled the gymnasium, waving campaign fliers and bopping to the music of Marc Anthony and Luis Fonsi.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Menendez focused much of his speech on the youth in the crowd, recalling the nationwide protests for stronger gun laws and how the students at the School had their own protest. It was the youth, he said, that motivated him to run again.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhile some of you are not old enough to vote, I am not here to ask for your vote, I am here because I am your vote in the United States Senate,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Menendez\u2019s path to the Democratic nomination is fairly clear. If successful, his likely Republican opponent in the general election will be Bob Hugin, a former pharmaceutical executive with ties to former Gov. Chris Christie. Mr. Hugin\u2019s ability to tap his fortune to finance his campaign could make the contest expensive and possibly more competitive than expected.\n\nThe race could also turn nasty. At the rally, members of the state Republican Party handed out Monopoly-like cards with Mr. Menendez\u2019s face on a cartoon prisoner and a photo of Mr. Menendez and Mr. Melgen vacationing together.\n\nIf Mr. Menendez\u2019s corruption trial dampened enthusiasm among Democrats it could spell trouble for other Democratic candidates in November. Democrats across the country are looking to House races in New Jersey as opportunities to pick up seats as they seek to wrest control from Republicans, but Democrats in those races will need a strong turnout to stand a chance.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Menendez has a keen understanding of local politics, having climbed nearly every rung on the political ladder, from school board member to mayor to state senator to congressman to United States senator, a position he assumed in 2005, when he was appointed by Gov. Jon S. Corzine.\n\nHe has been re-elected twice, in 2006 and 2012, and has been a prolific fund-raiser, having raised $17 million for his 2012 re-election, according to Federal Election Commission records.\n\nMr. Menendez on Wednesday referred to his roots and a career that started in this city\u2019s school district as evidence of an American dream fulfilled.\n\n\u201cThat is the promise of America,\u201d he said, offering a subtle dig at Mr. Trump\u2019s immigration policies. \u201cThat is the American dream. The idea that anything is possible because everyone is welcome.\u201d", "title": "After a Year of Turmoil, Menendez Announces He Is Seeking Re-Election", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "It has been 38 days since the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.; 174 days since the shooting at a concert in Las Vegas; 1,011 days since the killings at a church in Charleston, S.C.; and 1,926 since the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Ten days ago, students organized a nationwide school walkout to demonstrate their outrage about these and other shootings.\n\nOn Saturday they plan to amass in Washington to pressure a Congress that has done nothing meaningful to protect American children in classrooms, movie theaters, churches, malls \u2014 because, thanks to the National Rifle Association, many of their elected representatives are too busy protecting their re-election.\n\nMy advice to the students? When you finish marching on the mall, march into the specific congressional districts where you can actually make a difference.\n\nThe midterm elections are in eight months. A vast majority of congressional districts have been gerrymandered bright blue or ruby red. In those deep-red districts, the only threat that far-right members of Congress face is a primary challenge from someone farther to the right. You may regard voting for universal background checks as a no-brainer, but they see it as a blemish on their N.R.A. rating \u2014 an open door to a primary challenge. He took over as president in 2000, after a decade in which Russia was devastated by financial crisis, twice. With his country\u2019s back against the wall, Mr. Putin in his early years pushed major economic reforms, including a simple flat tax and opening Russia to the world. His stated goal was to make Russia feel like any other European country. By the end of the decade, boosted by soaring oil prices, Russian per capita income had more than quintupled to over $11,000.\n\nThen, as so often happens to even the best reformers, success made Mr. Putin complacent if not arrogant. By 2010 Russia was a middle-income country, and to make the next step in development it needed to reduce its reliance on oil, which had provided $1.5 trillion in revenue over the previous decade. And it needed dynamic new private companies to replace the doddering state-owned oil and gas giants that still dominated the economy.\n\nInstead, the economic reformer of the early 2000s gave way to Putin the hyper-nationalist, stirring fears of a new Cold War. He is now widely seen as a geopolitical provocateur who has dispatched disguised soldiers to invade Ukraine and internet trolls to disrupt American and European elections, and who this month boasted of a new intercontinental missile capable of piercing Western air defenses \u201clike a meteorite.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Aggressive Abroad, Putin Is Cautious at Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "The motion filed on Monday continued the attacks against the woman\u2019s truthfulness, pointing out that her grand jury testimony in many ways contradicted the early interviews she gave to officers from the 60th Precinct, the 66th Precinct and from the Police Department\u2019s Internal Affairs Bureau. As for her admission of being intoxicated during the encounter, legal experts said that it could cut both ways if the case goes to trial. On the one hand, the image of police detectives taking advantage of a young woman under the influence of drugs might build sympathy for her with a jury; on the other, her condition could easily be used during cross-examination to sow doubts about her story.\n\nThe woman\u2019s lawyer, Michael David, said the motion focused on minutiae, not the issues at the heart of the case. \u201cThey brutally raped her,\u201d Mr. David added. \u201cNow they\u2019re attacking her for points on the periphery.\u201d\n\nMuch of the filing\u2019s angry language was directed at the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office, which, defense lawyers said, improperly suggested to the grand jury that the woman was a credible witness even though prosecutors knew she had altered her account several times. Palestinians, while showering Ms. Tamimi with praise, asked whether publicizing the video might have been counterproductive, by showing the soldiers behaving with restraint, or helpful, by showing that even unarmed resistance can be effective.\n\nBut Ms. Tamimi, whose family is well known for its protests against the Israeli occupation of the West Bank, also quickly became a symbol of how harshly the military justice system can treat young Palestinians. She was arrested in the middle of the night after the video\u2019s broadcast on television. Her mother and a 20-year-old cousin, Nour Tamimi, were also charged. And their trial in a military prison was closed to the news media to protect Ms. Tamimi\u2019s privacy, according to Israeli officials, though her defense lawyer, Gabi Lasky, asked to waive that, insisting that publicity would provide far better protection.\n\nAll three women agreed to plea bargains on Wednesday. It said airstrikes and shelling had caused at least 80 casualties, pushing the death toll over the past two weeks to 745, including 172 children.\n\nThe casualties on Monday reportedly included 12 victims of an attack with chlorine gas on the Hamourieh area of eastern Ghouta. Syrian state television dismissed the claims as a \u201cchlorine play\u201d by terrorist groups trying to provide Western countries a pretext to attack Syria.\n\nSyrian state media said seven people were injured on Monday morning in a mortar attack on a military hospital in Damascus by fighters holed up in eastern Ghouta who belong to the Nusra Front, a group affiliated with Al Qaeda, and their allies.\n\nThe Human Rights Council condemned abuses by all parties, but focused particularly on the intensive bombardment by Syrian government forces and their allies, including alleged use of chemical weapons. Those responsible for the offensive should be held to account, it said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe council\u2019s resolution represented deepening international frustration and indignation at the assault on eastern Ghouta by the government and its allies, including Russia. The offensive is one of the most ferocious in Syria\u2019s seven-year civil war, despite a Feb. 24 United Nations Security Council resolution calling for a 30-day cease-fire and immediate access for humanitarian agencies. There are suspicions that the government once again used chemical weapons, in the face of international condemnation.\n\nSyria\u2019s state news agency, Sana, said on Monday that advancing government troops had taken control of around one-third of eastern Ghouta, after capturing farmland and several villages in the east of the enclave, and the towns of Utaya, Al Shifouniyah and Al Nashabiyah.\n\nLoopholes in the Security Council resolution allowed for military operations to continue against terrorist groups. Syria and Russia both made clear they were determined to continue their assault to crush jihadist forces holding out in the enclave.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussian aircraft alone bombed eastern Ghouta and Damascus at least 20 times a day from Feb. 14 to 18, Jason Mack, a senior official of the United States mission in Geneva, told the Human Rights Council on Monday.\n\nLast week, Russia unilaterally announced a daily five-hour cease-fire to allow aid to enter eastern Ghouta along a designated \u201chumanitarian corridor,\u201d but for several days, no supply trucks entered the region and the fighting continued. Syria and Russia said that opposition shelling and sniper fire along the route were preventing aid deliveries; United Nations officials said the time allowed was insufficient to get aid past all the checkpoints, and accused Syrian officials of stalling approvals for aid convoys.\n\nIf Monday\u2019s convoy to the town of Douma was a breakthrough after months of siege, it also underscored the continued obstacles and uncertainty surrounding aid deliveries. The 46 trucks carried food parcels, flour and medical supplies, but only enough for 27,500 people, out of Douma\u2019s population of 100,000.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInternational aid agencies are demanding unhindered and sustained access to be able to respond to the needs of the nearly 400,000 people in an enclave that has been largely isolated for years, and completely cut off for months.\n\n\u201cWe have some positive indications from all parties that we can go back with aid soon,\u201d an International Red Cross spokeswoman, Ingy Sedky, said in a phone interview, but she cautioned that there was no official confirmation of further access.\n\nSyrian government inspectors had stripped the convoy of many of the medical supplies that aid agencies had loaded. World Health Organization officials reported the items removed included all the trauma kits, surgical supplies, dialysis equipment and insulin.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd while the convoy brought medical staff into Douma, relief agency officials said there were no plans to bring any sick or injured patients out of eastern Ghouta. The United Nations lists more than 1,200 people as being in urgent need of evacuation for medical care that the enclave\u2019s heavily bombed clinics can no longer provide.\n\nAny satisfaction at the arrival of desperately needed aid was overshadowed by the enduring terror of bombardment. It was \u201cas if you\u2019re adding sugar to death,\u201d said Hassan Takieddine, a Douma resident, reached on social media as he emerged briefly from a basement where he and his neighbors had hidden.\n\n\u201cWhat is the benefit of this relief aid, if the regime continues bombing us?\u201d he asked. \u201cI don\u2019t see anything positive from these convoys. We need the shelling to stop. Stop the shelling!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPresident Bashar al-Assad has responded dismissively to the Security Council resolution and to talk of a humanitarian crisis, suggesting there is little immediate prospect of a pause in operations designed to wipe out the last major redoubt of opposition resistance near the capital.\n\n\u201cThe humanitarian situation that the West is constantly talking about is a very silly lie,\u201d he said on state television over the weekend. Talk of humanity and humanitarian need by Western officials and media meant only that the Syrian army was advancing, and that \u201cthings are going in the right direction on the ground.\u201d\n\nRussian and Syrian diplomats took much the same line at the Human Rights Council. Syria\u2019s ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Hussam Edin Aala, brushed the resolution off as \u201cpoliticized and selective,\u201d ignoring the indiscriminate shelling of Damascus by opposition groups in eastern Ghouta.\n\nThe urgent debate called at the request of Britain was \u201cuseless,\u201d its debate was shaped by media coverage that was \u201csaturated with lies\u201d and the resolution had nothing to do with human rights, Aleksei Goltiaev, a senior member of the Russian mission in Geneva, told the council.\n\nThe council resolution came on the eve of a report by the United Nations Commission of Inquiry into the conduct of the war by all parties. The council instructed the panel to investigate and report back on the offensive in eastern Ghouta, and to provide evidence of human rights abuses to the United Nations mechanism set up in Geneva to prepare cases for prosecution.\n\nThe government\u2019s attacks on eastern Ghouta were likely to meet the definitions of war crimes and crimes against humanity, Zeid Ra\u2019ad al-Hussein, the United Nations\u2019 top human rights official, told the council on Friday. Civilians there are being \u201cpounded into submission or death,\u201d he said, by a government assault that cannot be justified on the basis of targeting terrorists.\n\n\u201cThe perpetrators of these crimes must know they are being identified, that dossiers are being built up with a view to their prosecution,\u201d he said. \u201cThe wheels of justice may be slow, but they do grind.\u201d", "title": "Aid Convoy Reaches Syria Town, but Fighting Forces Some Trucks to Return Full", "authors": ["Nick Cumming-Bruce", "Nada Homsi"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "And, Ms. Wood said, those ultralow fares are not always as cheap as they seem.\n\n\u201cWe are quite convinced that most of the low-cost carrier\u2019s clients don\u2019t know that they pay nearly the same price when they travel with the low-cost company because when they have the luggage, the meal, the drinks, the entertainment, at the end of the day it\u2019s very similar to the all-included price they could pay with Air France,\u201d Ms. Wood said.\n\nThe Air France campaign will mostly be a digital one, but visitors to the Grove mall in Los Angeles on Saturday can win pairs of round-trip economy tickets. The care packages will also be given away, and will be available in an online sweepstakes.\n\nAmerican low-cost airlines do not compete directly with Air France, but they use some of the same advertising techniques that its less-expensive international competitors do.\n\n\u201cObviously, we promote our low fares heavily \u2014 it\u2019s the price point that will be successful at getting attention,\u201d Tyri Squyres, the vice president of marketing at Frontier Airlines, said in an email. \u201cAnd then we educate customers on all the options they have with us.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cOur goal is to simply let people get off the couch and go. Our low fares enable more people to travel and do it more often.\u201d\n\nFare-based advertising has been a popular tactic for decades, but as travelers have become more price conscious, in part because researching cheap tickets has never been easier, they sometimes gloss over the fine print. Many ultra-low-cost carriers charge extra fees for services like selecting a seat before departure, checking a bag and receiving onboard drinks and snacks.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis, Ms. Squyres said, is where the company\u2019s branding becomes even more important.\n\n\u201cThe last thing we want to do is have a customer surprised at the airport,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have invested heavily in all of our touch points to ensure customers understand our product and all of their options.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrontier\u2019s website was recently overhauled to make the fee structure more clear.\n\nHenry Harteveldt, the founder of Atmosphere Research Group and a former marketer at a number of airlines, said Air France\u2019s and Frontier\u2019s marketing strategies were both good examples of how airline advertising has changed over the decades.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAirlines don\u2019t do a lot of advertising anymore,\u201d Mr. Harteveldt said. \u201cThey focus a substantial amount of their media investment now in search engine optimization.\u201d\n\nHe noted that American carriers were some of the least likely to advertise. \u201cWhen you have four very large airlines, they don\u2019t have to market as aggressively as they once did,\u201d he added.\n\nThat\u2019s a big change from a few decades ago. From T.W.A.\u2019s \u201cUp, Up and Away\u201d to United\u2019s \u201cFriendly Skies,\u201d commercial branding was central to an airline\u2019s image.\n\nOne of Mr. Harteveldt\u2019s favorite ads was British Airways\u2019 \u201cManhattan\u201d commercial, which emphasized how each year the company flew more people across the Atlantic than the population of Manhattan.\n\nThat kind of creativity can still be fun to see in retrospect, but it\u2019s no longer necessarily the best way to attract customers.\n\n\u201cThe challenge is that an airline today, with its advertising, needs to think beyond just the media portion of it,\u201d Mr. Harteveldt said. \u201cWill they be running the ads on price comparison sites and on social media? Those are critical now \u2014 to reach travelers of all ages, frankly \u2014 when people are in that phase of dreaming of travel before they have selected an airline.\u201d\n\nAnd when carriers do choose to advertise more traditionally, they have to pick their message carefully. \u201cAirlines have to strike the balance between image-based advertising and very hard-hitting retail or tactical advertising,\u201d Mr. Harteveldt said.\n\nBut it makes sense, he said, for Air France to be investing more in advertising in the United States than some of its American competitors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe foreign-flag airlines tend to be more aggressive in advertising because they\u2019re not as well known and in many cases are promoting destinations beyond their home market,\u201d he said.\n\nThe \u201ctake a chance or fly Air France\u201d campaign stands out because of its emphasis on in-flight service.\n\n\u201cAs airlines have unbundled their product, they almost don\u2019t want to remind you of what it\u2019s like to fly them,\u201d Mr. Harteveldt said. \u201cWhat Air France is doing is a smart marketing move, but it\u2019s also a brave marketing move.\u201d", "title": "Air France Reminds Travelers What Their Flight Could Be Like", "authors": ["Zach Wichter"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "But as the theater filled up, the seats proved a bit challenging for some of the guests. No matter which way she turned, something more interesting was happening in the other direction. But he has used his entire career to tell America a story about itself that it does not want to hear: that racism exists today, and is pervasive outside of the Deep South. And he has worked ceaselessly toward two intertwined, impossible goals. First, the demand for equal rights for all. The second is about securing his legacy as the Martin Luther King of the North.\n\n\u201cWhat I want it to be is I helped urbanize the King movement,\u201d Mr. Sharpton said. \u201cI was the one that could bring the King movement into the Northern, urban centers.\u201d But where Dr. King\u2019s activism led to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, Mr. Sharpton\u2019s efforts haven\u2019t amounted to national reform.\n\nMr. Sharpton, 63, figured he\u2019d be retired by now. He thought he\u2019d keep his Sunday-morning MSNBC program, \u201cPoliticsNation,\u201d and his daily radio show, \u201cKeepin\u2019 It Real.\u201d He said he was ready to name a successor to his civil rights organization, the National Action Network, and the marching, strategizing and agitating that came with it. All that was left to do was build a civil rights museum in Harlem. But riding off into a life of punditry isn\u2019t an option with Mr. Trump in office. Mr. Sharpton said he and his allies thought they were poised to help a President Hillary Clinton pass national police reform legislation. His mission is now different, and more modest.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got to preserve what you\u2019ve got done,\u201d he said. \u201cIt will not matter if he revokes the Voting Rights Act, and the Civil Rights Act of Dr. King. You need to preserve the racial profiling laws, and police reform like stop and frisk,\u201d he continued. \u201cOtherwise, it\u2019ll be a bygone era.\u201d", "title": "Al Sharpton, Reconsidered", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Why has it taken so long for network television to catch up to cable?\n\nI joke that what we do on a network drama is basically fill the gaps between commercials. Therefore, when you have a winning formula, why change it? I think that\u2019s why most of the risk is usually taken on cable. That\u2019s a sweeping generalization, of course. But a network is about such large audiences and large amounts of money that shows don\u2019t really get a chance to fail. It\u2019s scary because obviously we\u2019re going into the unknown. I truly believe that when there are preconceptions that are faced and dealt with that people are not scared anymore. And then the world becomes a better place.\n\nIs CBS anticipating a backlash?\n\nI don\u2019t know what CBS is thinking. I do know they\u2019ve been accused over the last couple of years of being not very diverse, with a lot of white men leading their shows. And I think they\u2019re going to start using this show as an example [of increased diversity]. It\u2019s not just that they\u2019ve got a gay lead and a gay couple, but the mayor of New York is an Indian woman, and there\u2019s an African-American woman who\u2019s the boss of the precinct. I mean, yeah, possibly some people won\u2019t like it, but hopefully there will be more people who do. But we live in a funny time. People voted in Trump. They could do anything.\n\nCop shows thrive on the will they-won\u2019t they tension between partners. What\u2019s standing in for that here?\n\nHe\u2019s a rule breaker and she\u2019s very much by the book. He\u2019s idiosyncratic and she\u2019s very ordered. So there\u2019s that straight lines and curvy lines kind of conflict. We did talk about how wouldn\u2019t it be funny if in the future an ex-girlfriend of mine appears and [Lizzie] will be, \u201cOh, I thought you were gay.\u201d And I go, \u201cOh, well, you know \u2014 college.\u201d That changes the whole idea that our sexuality is black and white. And that\u2019s another thing hopefully we can present to America. It would be hilarious if they made out at the office party.\n\nYou\u2019re a vocal supporter of L.G.B.T. causes, you\u2019ve volunteered for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and now you\u2019re going to bat for gun regulations and wider health care by supporting an upstate New York candidate.\n\nI have a home in the Catskills and I\u2019ve changed my vote from New York City so I can [help] swing that district. I don\u2019t think the Democratic Party has done the thing that most political organizations do after a crushing defeat and reinvented itself. I did an ad for Bernie Sanders that Spike Lee made. I said I come from Scotland, it\u2019s a small, relatively poor country, nowhere as affluent as America, yet we have free further education and free health care. Why is it possible for Scotland to do it and not possible for America?", "title": "Alan Cumming Helps CBS Unfurl Its Rainbow Flag With \u2018Instinct\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "As Alan Gershwin told the story \u2014 often \u2014 he was hidden away at his Uncle Ira and Aunt Leonore\u2019s house on North Roxbury Drive in Beverly Hills in late 1945, right after his discharge from the Navy. Ignoring the orders of his hosts, he headed downstairs to join one of the parties the Gershwins regularly gave. When a guest spotted him on the landing, he dropped his glass of Scotch in shock. Or maybe two guests did.\n\nBy then, seven years had passed since the man Alan Gershwin called his father had died. But all anyone eyeing 19-year-old Alan that night saw was George Gershwin, reincarnated.\n\nFor 70 years or so, Alan Gershwin insisted he was George Gershwin\u2019s long-lost son. And with his death on Feb. 27 at 91 in a Bronx hospital, the curtain came down on what was surely the Gershwins\u2019 most bizarre show ever, revolving around whether this affable but monomaniacal man was one of the greatest victims in American musical history, or a grifter running a long-term con, or someone suffering decades of delusion.\n\nMr. Gershwin contended that sometime in the mid-1920s \u2014 the year and place varied in the telling, but once it was tracked down his birth certificate stated May 18, 1926, and the Brooklyn Hebrew Maternity Hospital, respectively \u2014 he was born Albert Schneider to a sultry dancer named Mollie Charleston, who went by the stage name Margaret Manners. It claims that the airline has failed to hold the male pilot accountable and that he poses a \u201cthreat to other employees.\u201d\n\nCourts in the United States have previously tackled the issue of sexual harassment of flight crews during layovers, expanding the definition of a work site. In 2001, a federal appeals court in New York ruled that Delta Air Lines was potentially liable for not doing enough to stop what a flight attendant said was a rape by another attendant, even though the events occurred when the two were off duty in a hotel room.\n\nIn a statement, Alaska Airlines said it was taking the matter seriously.\n\n\u201cOur policy is to withhold an employee from work during this type of investigation,\u201d it said. \u201cHe was immediately removed from flying back in June and remains on leave pending the outcome of the investigation.\u201d\n\nThe pilot, who is not named as a defendant, could not be reached on Friday. He has not been charged with a crime.\n\nMs. Pina has been flying for 17 years, including seven years of active duty military service that included flying Chinook helicopters in Afghanistan, for which she was featured in a PBS documentary series \u201cKansas to Kandahar: Citizen Soldiers at War.\u201d\n\nShe started working for Alaska Airlines in 2016. She said that after years in the military, she was accustomed to reporting problems only to her superiors. As budget negotiations \u2014 which are conducted behind closed doors among the governor and three top legislative leaders, out of sight of even other lawmakers \u2014 unfolded over the past week, it became increasingly clear that the Legislature would punt policy issues such as gun control or bail reform to after the budget\u2019s April 1 deadline, in favor of financial considerations.\n\nRepublicans in the State Senate had fought hard against any new taxes and fees and were able to claim a win on that account, as well as on many deferred social policies.\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, the spending plan had much to celebrate for the governor, coming in on time amid a $4 billion state deficit and the prospect of additional federal cuts. The Legislature began passing the key bills late Friday and into Saturday morning, before the looming deadline on a holiday weekend..\n\nInside the budget deal are some critical practical \u2014 and political \u2014 demands from Mr. Cuomo.\n\nTax experts had viewed Mr. Cuomo\u2019s proposed workarounds with skepticism, warning that many of the ideas were purely academic and had never been tried in practice. Others worried that the payroll tax workaround would be unpopular with New Yorkers, as it would result in lower gross pay, even if their take-home pay would ultimately remain the same.\n\nStill, the new tax policies \u2014 while limited \u2014 will allow the governor a credible argument that he is fighting for New York in the face of the White House and Republicans in Washington.\n\nThe governor also secured $250 million in new funding for the troubled New York City Housing Authority, making good on a promise he had loudly and repeatedly declared over the past few weeks. After three visits to public housing projects, he vowed not to sign the budget unless it included a \u201creal remedy\u201d for repairs at Nycha, where residents have faulted Mr. Cuomo\u2019s intraparty rival, Mayor Bill de Blasio, for deteriorating conditions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn an issue of vital local importance, the budget also includes $26.7 billion in school funding \u2014 a higher figure than either Mr. Cuomo or the Republican-controlled Senate had proposed in their own preliminary budgets.\n\nMr. Cuomo is facing particular pressure to burnish his progressive credentials: The actress and education advocate Cynthia Nixon, who is challenging him for the Democratic nomination for governor, has blasted him for what she called his \u201cmassive disinvestment\u201d in schools and in other areas that affect black and Hispanic residents.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn that account, Friday was a mixed success for the governor, with pledges to introduce early voting, end cash bail for low-level offenses and codify the Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion all failing to make it into the final budget deal.\n\nOne major exception was reforming language on sexual harassment, a rare shared priority among both Democrats and Republicans and a political demand during the national reckoning known as the #MeToo movement.\n\nThe new language, which would ban most nondisclosure agreements and mandatory arbitration clauses, extended to both the public and private sectors. But the policies still drew criticism, with some women\u2019s rights advocates and employment lawyers calling their scope too narrow.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother policy agreement would ease state oversight of yeshivas, despite concerns among education advocates that the schools for ultra-Orthodox Jews, which offer both secular and religious education, leave their students with poor to nonexistent English and math skills.\n\nAssembly Democrats, who opposed easing state control, had cast the issue as the only one holding up a budget deal. The Assembly speaker, Carl E. Heastie, on Friday morning accused Senator Simcha Felder, who represents a large Orthodox Jewish constituency in Brooklyn, of essentially holding the negotiations hostage. Mr. Felder, a Democrat who caucuses with the Republicans and therefore allows them to sit in the majority in the Senate, often wields disproportionate influence in the Legislature.\n\nThe final compromise allowed for yeshivas, and other nonpublic schools, to argue that long hours of instruction \u2014 no matter the topic \u2014 could be used to satisfy state educational requirements.\n\nAssembly Democrats, meanwhile, had secured the governor\u2019s promise of another commission to consider a possible pay raise, a longstanding issue of contention for lawmakers who have not had a raise in nearly two decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHopes for a congestion pricing plan, which has long been floated as a possible source of long-term funding for the sputtering subway system, were largely dashed. While Mr. Cuomo had commissioned a task force to develop a framework for charging cars that drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan, Friday\u2019s budget deal included only the first phase: a $2.75 fee on for-hire vehicles and a $2.50 fee on yellow cabs below 96th Street.\n\nLawmakers may still address issues that were left out of the budget, such as new protections for victims of childhood sexual abuse, during the remainder of the session, which runs through June. But the budget process is often regarded as the time of maximum urgency and leverage, when the continued operation of state government \u2014 and legislators\u2019 continued paychecks \u2014 hang in the balance.\n\nStill, Mr. Cuomo defended introducing even those social or policy measures that failed to gain traction during the budget process \u2014 including any major ethics changes, despite the recent conviction of his former friend and aide, Joseph Percoco, on federal corruption charges \u2014 saying he wanted to \u201cstart the conversation\u201d on things like early voting.\n\nThe pressures of an election year, when officials are wary of alienating key lobbyists and constituencies and seek to balance fiscal responsibility with flashy campaign promises, may also soon be brought to bear.\n\nA special election in April is also looming, which could allow Democrats in the Senate \u2014 where Republicans rule thanks to a collaboration with Mr. Felder and a group of eight rogue Democrats \u2014 to take a numerical majority. Mr. Cuomo has said in the past that he would work to unify Democrats to rule the Senate.\n\nBut on Friday night, he demurred on that promise, too, until after the Senate votes on the budget.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s talk politics after the votes are taken tonight,\u201d he said.", "title": "Albany Strikes Budget Deal That Sidesteps Trump\u2019s Tax Plan", "authors": ["Vivian Wang", "Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "While Mr. Heastie indicated support for the idea of more school security, he offered little for any for the 15 bills that passed Monday in the Senate, including a proposal to create a program for \u201cschool resource officers\u201d \u2014 either a retired or active-duty police officer, sheriff deputy or state trooper, who would be authorized to carry a firearm in schools across New York. In the 1950s, before vaccination became available, there were at least 319,000 infections and 345 deaths from measles each year. More recently there was a measles outbreak at Disneyland in 2014. The 667 cases of measles in the United States that year occurred largely because of anti-vaxxers. Fortunately, no one died. Indeed, in the past 15 years there has been only one confirmed death from measles in the entire country. The Disneyland episode propelled states to change their laws to make it much harder for parents to refuse vaccinations for their children.\n\nPartly as a result, today the flu is much more dangerous than measles. Indeed, every year since 2004 there have been a minimum of 37, and as many as 171, pediatric deaths from the flu. In fact, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lists flu and pneumonia as the eighth leading causes of death in the United States, immediately after diabetes.\n\nSo why do we mandate the measles vaccine but not the flu vaccine? Perhaps because the flu vaccine must be given every year and is sometimes, like this year, not that effective. However, this is all the more reason to impose a mandate.\n\nThe relationship between the effectiveness of the vaccine, the number of people who need to be treated and herd immunity is complex \u2014 and perhaps counterintuitive. The less effective a vaccine is, the more people you need to treat to produce herd immunity. For instance, if the vaccine is 80 percent effective, then vaccinating just 25 percent of the population provides effective herd immunity. But if the vaccine is only 30 percent effective \u2014 just short of this year\u2019s level \u2014 around 70 percent of the population must be vaccinated.\n\nOf course, some Americans hate government mandates, even when they are demonstrably beneficial. Rand Paul \u2014 a physician, no less \u2014 argued that mandatory vaccination is a violation of individual rights, claiming, \u201cthe state doesn\u2019t own your children.\u201d He called it \u201can issue of freedom.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | All Children Should Have to Get the Flu Shot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWell, this is a first,\u201d she said.\n\nOne traffic officer on the scene said he had taped off the sidewalk next to the sinkhole, not to protect people from the pit, but because a woman gaping at it almost got hit on the head by pieces of stucco falling from the building above it.\n\nAs he explained, Thomasz Sobieszek, 47, pulled up on his scooter. \u201cI want to show you something,\u201d he said, showing the officer an illustration on his smartphone of men in togas building roads. \u201cThis is how the ancient Romans built their streets. With three levels!\u201d\n\nEarlier, and the earliest, Roman administrations seemed to care more about road maintenance. The Laws of the Twelve Tables, Rome\u2019s first set of rules dating back to 450 B.C., included instructions to make straight roads eight feet wide, stipulated what to do in case of water damage and decreed who \u201cshall build and repair the road.\u201d\n\nAround 300 B.C., Romans started building roads to move their troops, citizens and goods. Starting with the Appian Way, named after the censor who ordered its construction, Romans paved an empire. The revolutionary populist Gaius Gracchus helped build public streets because he understood the junction between a road and the rabble\u2019s heart.\n\nRome protected its streets by limiting chariot traffic and put a daytime ban on commercial carts. Julius Caesar fought to procure the position of temporary commissioner on the Appian Way, ancient stretches of which still stand. (Parts of the modern counterpart, the New Appia, don\u2019t. On Thursday, another sinkhole opened up under a couple of cars.)", "title": "All Roads Lead to Rome, Where Potholes Will Destroy Your Tires", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Last year, BuzzFeed News reported that in 2009, a lawyer representing investors at risk of losing more than $1 billion in a Trump casino bankruptcy got a frightening phone call from a man who called himself Carmine. So, Mr. Dietl said, Mr. Trump had him dig up dirt about the lawyer.\n\nIn 1982, after the New York City housing commissioner, Anthony Gliedman, declined to grant a $20 million tax abatement for Trump Tower, Mr. Gliedman told the New York City police commissioner that he had received a call \u201cthreatening his life\u201d over the abatement, according to BuzzFeed. (Mr. Gliedman later went to work for Mr. Trump.)\n\nBrent Blakely, a lawyer for Mr. Cohen \u2014 a lawyer for a lawyer, that\u2019s how this crew rolls \u2014 demanded an apology from Ms. Clifford and said of her accusation, \u201cMr. Cohen had absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with any such person or incident, and does not even believe that any such person exists, or that such incident ever occurred.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | All the President\u2019s Thugs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "I know this because I listen, sometimes for two or three hours straight, to the brides and grooms as they reveal every moment of their relationship, often sharing things so private, so raw and honest, that they would usually be reserved for siblings, best friends and maybe parents.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI\u2019ve been sent photos of the dress, the venue, the menu and invitation. I\u2019ve arrived before the weddings start. I\u2019ve been the only one in the room with the bride to get pre-wedding thoughts. I\u2019ve watched first dances, the couple moving so closely together that they are one entity, and I\u2019ve listened to eloquent and emotional speeches and toasts.\n\nI\u2019ve interviewed parents, relatives and the person who introduced the couple. Couples have cried on the phone in retelling their story. They have longed for a deceased parent who can\u2019t witness this moment or have despaired about the once-best friend or stepsibling they want to invite but for a number of reasons can\u2019t. And I\u2019ve witnessed families come together in ways my own never has.\n\nWith strangers, I have somehow gotten to share in something that was never mine.\n\nEvery happy couple has made me ask myself the \u2018What if?\u201d The \u201cCan\u2019t we give it one more shot?\u201d But the intense desire to make our once-intoxicating love work is hit with the reality of knowing it can\u2019t because I know my true soul mate wouldn\u2019t treat me the way I was treated.\n\nSo, I cover these weddings and as I watch these couples interact, I soak in the simple but significant gestures I long for: a shared knowing glance, hands that magnetically clasp together, kisses that silently tell their stories. I still look around the room, taking stock of the guests, briefly wondering who else may be looking for their person.\n\nThe couple\u2019s cherished moments remind me of the commitment my person couldn\u2019t keep and the broken promises yet to be fixed. That longing is so thick and real that it rides home in the cab with me, a lump in my throat, and is still with me when I enter my apartment.\n\nExperiencing other people\u2019s lives move forward together, their dreams solidified while I\u2019m standing on the sidelines, is often lonely and isolating. Even though I\u2019m working at these weddings, I feel the very heavy presence of knowing I\u2019m alone \u2014 not just at this event, but I am alone, as I see so many others partnered or surrounded by family members and friends. And so I can\u2019t help the moments when tears creep to the surface, thinking of the future and the happiness that await these strangers I\u2019ve grown to care about.\n\nI cry for the vows I\u2019ve not had the opportunity to exchange yet. And sometimes, when the bride or groom says, \u201cI do,\u201d I utter the same words ever so softly, a dress rehearsal for the words and sentiments I hope one day someone will say to me. I know it isn\u2019t the wedding I need. It\u2019s the person. The one I\u2019m still waiting to meet. The one waiting to meet me.", "title": "Always the Reporter, Never the Bride", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "She also said she had lost money and her earning capacity.\n\nThe abuse occurred during competitions and training, at events where the organizations were responsible for Ms. Raisman\u2019s safety and making sure that protocols were followed, the lawsuit said.\n\n\u201cThousands of young athletes continue to train and compete every day in this same broken system,\u201d Ms. Raisman said. \u201cI refuse to wait any longer for these organizations to do the right thing.
