It is scheduled to open in November, around the centennial of the Austrian republic\u2019s birth from the horrors of World War I and the collapse of the Hapsburg Empire.\n\nMonika Sommer, the museum\u2019s director, said the \u201csubtlety and fragility\u201d of \u201cThe Voices\u201d matched how her museum wanted to help the country look at the past: \u201cWe don\u2019t want any finger-pointing,\u201d she said. \u201cWe want to take a sober look at Austrian history.\u201d\n\nBut she added the task of doing that was getting harder. \u201cWe are seeing anti-Semitism, and xenophobia more generally, becoming more widespread again.\u201d\n\nIn December, the conservative People\u2019s Party and the far-right Freedom Party formed a government in Austria. They were elected on an anti-immigration agenda in reaction to Europe\u2019s refugee crisis. The parties\u2019 coalition agreement officially states that Austria was a perpetrator of Nazi crimes, and decries anti-Semitism. But a Freedom Party politician quit in February in a scandal over an anti-Semitic songbook used by his old university fraternity, and Facebook followers of the party\u2019s leader, Heinz-Christian Strache, recently criticized him for speaking about Austria\u2019s complicity in Nazi rule.\n\nPointedly, the government of Chancellor Sebastian Kurz has reserved judgment about whether it will keep financing the House of History \u2014 initiated by the left-leaning Social Democratic Party after decades of debate \u2014 when the museum\u2019s current budget runs out in December 2019. \u201cThe ongoing discussion about the future of the museum shows it\u2019s still difficult to talk about and reappraise the country\u2019s history,\u201d said Ms. Sommer.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cSusan\u2019s art isn\u2019t overtly political, but that doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s unpolitical,\u201d said Kasper K\u00f6nig, a German museum director and curator who advised the museum about the installation. Ms. Philipsz said she never expressly set out to be a public artist. Having sung in a choir as a child and trained as a sculptor, she said she was interested \u201cin what happens when you project sound into a space\u201d \u2014 what happens to the person projecting, the space, and the listener.\n\nSome of her most notable works \u2014 like \u201cLowlands,\u201d placed under bridges in Glasgow in 2010; \u201cStudy for Strings\u201d at the main railway station in Kassel, Germany, as part of the 2012 Documenta art exhibition; and \u201cWar Damaged Musical Instruments\u201d at London\u2019s Tate Britain in 2015-2016 \u2014 have used voices or instruments to evoke a sense of loss and separation in public spaces.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYour feelings of longing or melancholy are often battling ambient sounds,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s exactly through these ambient sounds that you become very aware of where you are and who you\u2019re beside.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Philipsz praised the museum for dealing with the behind-the-scenes politics and letting her get on with her work. She first visited the site last October and quickly struck upon the lead crystal motif, in part thanks to some imposing chandeliers in the palace.\n\n\u201cMozart spent a lot of time in Vienna and composed works for the lead-crystal glass harmonica,\u201d Ms. Philipsz said. Radio sets had crystal elements in the 1930s, and the radio was a vital propaganda tool for Hitler. \u201cAnd, of course, there was Kristallnacht,\u201d Ms. Philipsz said, referring to the night of Nov. 9, 1938, when synagogues and Jewish businesses in Germany and Austria were ransacked. It was an eruption of hate she also wants \u201cThe Voices\u201d to memorialize.\n\nThe museum wanted a work of art to make the public reflect on Hitler\u2019s speech from the balcony, but was wary of putting a sculpture there. Commissioning a sound artist solved the problem, but the museum\u2019s original idea of placing all of the speakers where Hitler spoke did not work for Ms. Philipsz, as it kept too much attention on the balcony.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThat felt wrong \u2014 I didn\u2019t want this to be about Hitler, but about the voices of all the people who had gathered there over the decades.\u201d So she also had speakers placed on the other side of the square. This, however, meant \u201cThe Voices\u201d could be heard only for 10 minutes twice a day, at 12:30 p.m. and 6:30 p.m, in deference to the neighbors.\n\n\u201cI personally find the work a bit underwhelming, but it would have been unimaginable in Austria until the 1990s,\u201d said G. Daniel Cohen, a historian from Rice University in Houston currently in Vienna to write a book about attitudes toward Jews in postwar Europe. \u201cSuch attempts at national reflection have at the very least forced the far right to accept the existence of a taboo against anti-Semitism and Holocaust denial.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday lunchtime, around 50 people were listening by the statue of Archduke Karl, one of the heroes the Heldenplatz honors. \u201cIt is a stirring experience,\u201d said Dagmar Friedl-Preyer, 57, a social worker, who had come to the square to hear the work. \u201cYou see the balcony and think of all that \u2018Anschluss\u2019 delirium, the sound makes all that well up.\u201d Her friend Josef Huber, a retiree, said he thought many Austrians would come to hear \u201cThe Voices.\u201d \u201cThe problem, of course, is those who want nothing to do with any of this \u2014 they won\u2019t come to listen.\u201d", "title": "An Invisible Artwork Reminds Austria of Its Nazi Past", "authors": ["Gerrit Wiesmann"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Left: Mulberry\u2019s Large Face pearl and crystal earring. Right: \ufffcCreated by the artist Angelica Hicks, a Kartell cabinet featuring the face of Frida Kahlo.\n\nImage Credit Leemage/Corbis via Getty Images\n\n\u201cChild With Doll\u201d (1892) by Henri Rousseau, known as \u201cLe Douanier\u201d for his day job as a customs officer.", "title": "An Ode to Joyful, Self-consciously Nai\u0308ve Design", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Officials are negotiating the details of a face-to-face meeting between President Trump and leader Kim Jong-un of North Korea. Mr. Trump turned the heads of even his own advisers earlier this month when he spontaneously agreed to sit down and hash out relations with Mr. Kim. A place and date have yet to be determined.", "title": "Opinion | An Offer Trump Couldn\u2019t Resist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "How\u2019s that for pro-life?\n\nIf this all sounds legally unsound, that\u2019s because it is. The Ohio bill is \u201cblatantly unconstitutional,\u201d said Brigitte Amiri, a senior staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union\u2019s Reproductive Freedom Project, which has challenged anti-abortion laws in the state. \u201cThis isn\u2019t a hard one.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s because the Supreme Court\u2019s Roe v. Wade decision made abortion legal up to the point of fetal viability, which has shifted over time due to medical advancements in treating premature babies, but now occurs at about 24 weeks of pregnancy. Any ban on abortion before that time \u2014 say, at 15 weeks, as would be the case under a law that was passed and legally blocked in Mississippi last week \u2014 is generally considered unconstitutional.\n\nThis rash of radically unconstitutional bills is appearing by design. The anti-abortion movement has been trying to pass pre-viability abortion bans, like the Ohio bill, hoping that efforts to overturn them would lead to a challenge of Roe v. Wade that would end with the 45-year-old decision\u2019s reversal in the Supreme Court.\n\nReproductive rights advocates say the various pieces of legislation are in keeping with the anti-abortion crowd\u2019s newfound optimism under President Trump, who has said he wants Supreme Court justices who would overturn Roe. Mr. Trump may get the chance to appoint a judge who will cast the deciding vote.\n\nAs Mr. Trump himself acknowledged during his 2016 town hall, banning abortions does not stop women from getting them \u2014 it just makes it harder for them to do so safely. If abortion were banned, \u201cYou go back to a position like they had where they would perhaps go to illegal places,\u201d Mr. Trump said, inarticulately but correctly noting that some women would be driven to back-alley providers.\n\nThat\u2019s one reason abortion rights supporters are so concerned about the Ohio bill. Another is that, even if the bill doesn\u2019t become law, it could pave the way for other, somewhat less extreme measures to pass, seeming reasonable by comparison. For instance, in 2016 John Kasich, the state\u2019s Republican governor, vetoed a bill that would have banned abortion when a fetal heartbeat can be detected, which could have effectively outlawed the procedure as early as six weeks into a pregnancy. But the same day he signed a bill banning abortion at 20 weeks.", "title": "Opinion | An Ohio Bill Would Ban All Abortions. It\u2019s Part of a Bigger Plan.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The Mus\u00e9e des Arts D\u00e9coratifs has long had an identity crisis.\n\nIt is in a 19th-century wing of the Louvre building on the Rue de Rivoli, but it does not belong to the Louvre.\n\nIt gets confused with the \u00c9cole Nationale Sup\u00e9rieure des Arts D\u00e9coratifs, the elite national school for art and design on the other side of the Seine River, even though there is no connection between the two institutions.\n\nAnd it is not a museum dedicated to the early 20th-century Art Deco movement, even though \u201cArt Deco\u201d is shorthand for \u201cArts D\u00e9coratifs.\u201d", "title": "An Old Paris Museum Makes a New Name for Itself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nRed Hook, Brooklyn, 1957. Public School 30, first grade, Miss Donovan\u2019s class.\n\nShortly after Thanksgiving, we were each given supplies for an arts-and-crafts project: making Christmas wreaths.\n\nEach student got a four-inch rim of stiff cardboard; several feet of heavy, green shoelaces to wrap around the cardboard; and piles of newspaper, magazine and box-top illustrations to cut out and glue to the center of the wreaths.\n\nMine was a masterpiece. I scrawled my name (and a nice red rose) across the back of the illustration, and my mother added the year. \u201cGary 1957.\u201d That little wreath has had pride-of-place on our Christmas trees for 60 years.\n\nIn November, my husband returned home from three days of closing up his recently deceased parents\u2019 apartment in Queens. There, in a folder of material from his father\u2019s childhood in the Bronx: a school-crossing-guard badge, class pictures and a four-inch wreath my father-in-law made in first grade.", "title": "An Old-School Tradition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Ren\u00e9e, Obviously no one\u2019s expecting you to become Ethel Merman. Nettie Fowler, your character in \u201cCarousel,\u201d has often been sung by people with experience on the opera stage.\n\nREN\u00c9E FLEMING Well, I\u2019m the first soprano I\u2019ve been able to find to do this. One of the interesting things to talk about is what\u2019s been surprising to us. I knew that eight shows a week would be a challenge \u2014 and I\u2019ve had two performances so far, so I can\u2019t really say what that\u2019s like yet. But there are so many things that have shocked me about the process. The first preview is like a draft of the show, and we have six weeks to make it into a real show. So that really surprised me \u2014 the degree to which there will be changes.\n\nPhoto\n\nKELLI O\u2019HARA I\u2019m so used to the comfort of that. It\u2019s like a film actor is fine, because they have many, many takes of something. Preview period for me was: I\u2019m still working on it, I\u2019m still trying to figure out what this is, even though we had an audience. Here, it\u2019s just hit the road and go!\n\nFLEMING I keep saying that to my colleagues! The first preview, I said, \u201cWell, [in opera] we would have opened by now, all the critics would be here tonight.\u201d Another thing that shocked me is the rehearsal process. There\u2019s a huge number of people in rehearsal, and evidently when we start running the show there\u2019ll be hardly anybody backstage. Whereas at the Met it\u2019s the opposite.\n\nO\u2019HARA Right! That was one of the biggest things here [at the Met] during \u201cMerry Widow,\u201d arriving in a dressing room that wasn\u2019t my home. On Broadway you make it your home, because you\u2019re there so much: You decorate, you bring your things from home, you put your pictures out. No one comes to that door. You walk yourself to the stage and you stand alone. You don\u2019t want to be touched. And you wait, and you prepare, and you focus.\n\nHere, I remember getting my makeup. Knock-knock-knock. \u201cI want to introduce you to \u2026\u201d or \u201cWe have this person here. \u2026\u201d Finally the show\u2019s going to start. I\u2019m a little frazzled. Then it\u2019s \u201cKelli O\u2019Hara to the stage.\u201d They walk me to the stage. Then it\u2019s a person standing behind me saying, \u201cGo!\u201d It\u2019s so huge, there are about a gazillion stagehands and about 17 stage managers.\n\nWhat\u2019s it like, coming from here to a Broadway-size theater, and trying to adjust to Rodgers and Hammerstein?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFLEMING For opera, we are the amplification. So the body amplifies the voice, with this kind of projection, and also breath pressure and support. And in music theater, it\u2019s the opposite. You really want the microphone to do that work of amplification, so you save yourself. You just couldn\u2019t do it eight shows a week.\n\nO\u2019HARA I don\u2019t think that I\u2019ve ever adjusted my singing much [for microphones]. But I still try to sing with all of my body, and they adjust the mic down if they need to for me.\n\nFLEMING One good thing about the Met is the house absolutely favors high voices. It\u2019s something about the overtones, I think, that really carry in the house. So I always tell people don\u2019t be afraid, because if you allow the overtones to do their work, you\u2019re safe.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou can never sing to the wings, you can never turn away and sing on the stage of the Met. You always have to cheat out. And so that\u2019s something I love \u2014 not having to do that now. I can talk to someone on stage, and it will be heard!\n\nO\u2019HARA Even though I feel like I\u2019ve been singing in a healthy way on Broadway for the last 20 years, it doesn\u2019t compare. I have to trust that you don\u2019t have to scream to be heard.\n\nFLEMING Is there anything I need to worry about? People keep talking about this Tony Award voting period.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nO\u2019HARA Well, that will get in your head. So you could actually ask your company, you could say: \u201cO.K., this is new for me \u2014 in that week before we open, I don\u2019t want to hear about the press. I don\u2019t want to hear about who\u2019s here.\u201d\n\nFLEMING I went to a sports psychologist years ago, who just said you must protect yourself: You don\u2019t go on the internet.\n\nO\u2019HARA The one thing I do know is that when I step on the stage \u2014 and you step on the stage \u2014 we know how to be on the stage. It doesn\u2019t matter what the stage is. The audience is an audience, the stage is a stage, the story is the story, and the singing is your singing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFLEMING People tend to think of opera as a very separate sort of genre. In fact the lineage between Rodgers and Hammerstein, for instance, and what I\u2019ve grown up in is very powerful. When operetta first came to New York that had a huge influence on music theater. One thing that I love is this notion that an opera house now, particularly around the country, can also perform these artistically aspirational music theater pieces. Those should be folded into what we present in an opera house because otherwise, frankly, we\u2019ve been presenting the same titles, the same small body of work, for literally a century. So we need to kind of get audiences interested more in new work. And this is a good way to do it.\n\nO\u2019HARA This is the other thing, and I\u2019ll just say it: In opera I\u2019m still playing the young girl. In musical theater, I\u2019m too old to play some of these roles. Which is heartbreaking for me.\n\nPhoto\n\nFLEMING But I think of Broadway as really loving its divas, and really celebrating women. You think of Patti LuPone, and some of the great artists who just continually go on \u2014 Bernadette Peters is taking over \u201cHello Dolly.\u201d And the audiences just crave these great leading women. It\u2019s a little harder in opera. It\u2019s a little bit to do with the voice and how it changes. But sometimes the repertoire that\u2019s left is sort of the roles that aren\u2019t the most sympathetic \u2014 you have the sorceress and the witch, and many comic roles.\n\nO\u2019HARA I think we\u2019re seeing it in movies, television, and we\u2019ll see it more in the writing on Broadway: that women of a certain age are going to start to have real stories, just like they\u2019re having in real life. As opposed to these kind of clich\u00e9d ones.\n\nRen\u00e9e, how did you find it going from that heightened opera talk, projecting and enunciating, to trying to be more natural and funny on Broadway?\n\nFLEMING I always said that I never could manage spoken accents \u2014 but I could sing in any language. I don\u2019t know what the disconnect was. But in fact I have really enjoyed working with this Maine accent [in \u201cCarousel\u201d], and trying to kind of fine-tune it and really find the colors in her voice.\n\nKelli, how is it to sing in Italian, instead of Oscar Hammerstein in English?\n\nO\u2019HARA I think that\u2019s the most difficult part for me. I haven\u2019t been perfecting these languages over the years. I think the accent is O.K. I\u2019m getting it, but it\u2019s just the agility with it.\n\nFLEMING You have the barrier of understanding, and being able to know, not just what you\u2019re saying but everyone else. You have to memorize everyone\u2019s texts, unless you speak the language.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI remember so well my first really major professional operatic experience, at Houston Grand Opera, and it was \u201cThe Marriage of Figaro.\u201d I had sung it in English, and this was the first time I had sung it in Italian. The problem was that my colleagues were so fabulous and so schooled and so experienced. I really just thought I was going to faint on stage.\n\nO\u2019HARA That\u2019s what\u2019s happening right now! They know the show like I would know \u201cMusic Man.\u201d It\u2019s humbling, after all this time of trying to build yourself a career and a bit of backbone. You think: Why have I done this to myself? And then you think, well, if I get through it and I can succeed in any form, well, those are the things you have to do in life.\n\nFLEMING Challenges, right?\n\nO\u2019HARA I think we both love what we\u2019re doing in a way that makes us want tastier versions all the time \u2014 you know, never just laying back.", "title": "An Opera Diva and a Broadway Star Trade Places, and Advice", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "One of opera\u2019s great recent success stories has been the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, which regularly assembles some of the best casts imaginable for edgy productions that frequently generate more buzz than the offerings of opera houses in bigger world capitals.\n\nNow the company is preparing for a changing of the guard. It announced Tuesday that its next artistic director would be the Belgian impresario Serge Dorny, and its next music director would be Vladimir Jurowski, a Moscow-born conductor who is currently the principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra. The two men are set to begin in the 2020-21 season.", "title": "An Opera Powerhouse, Munich, Picks Its Next Leaders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe market is very big because the demand is huge,\u201d said Rob Johnson, chief executive of Vertiv, a $4 billion global technology company in Columbus, Ohio, that designs, builds and supplies equipment to data centers. \u201cData centers serve the requirements for all the smartphones, streaming, high-definition video and all the new applications like autonomous vehicles. The technology is driving immense amounts of data and traffic.\u201d\n\nLucrative tax incentives are the rare area of data center development that has come under criticism. Iowa last year awarded Apple $208 million in tax breaks to build a $1.3 billion center in rural Waukee that would employ 50 people.\n\n\u201cThe big tech companies are getting huge tax breaks to build things they would build anyway,\u201d said Greg LeRoy, executive director of Good Jobs First, a research group in Washington. \u201cThe cost to taxpayers is enormous for data centers that create very few permanent jobs.\u201d\n\nOregon\u2019s incentive package allows both companies to avoid property taxes for 15 years, saving Facebook and Apple roughly $45 million each over that period. State law also has a sweetener for cities. Companies receiving the tax break are required to pay employees 150 percent of the median regional wage. Prineville data center workers earn at least $60,000 a year.\n\nPrineville counts 400 permanent jobs in the data centers, influencing its small-town culture, filling the municipal treasury and transforming its sagebrush and juniper landscape.\n\nMayor Betty Roppe noted that Facebook and Apple provided Prineville with income from other municipal accounts. For instance, the city receives a 5 percent \u201cfranchise\u201d fee on all electricity sales in its jurisdiction. Because Facebook\u2019s and Apple\u2019s centers consume nearly $40 million in electricity annually, total franchise fees last year reached $2.2 million, up from $340,000 in 2010.\n\nWhen the abatements expire midway through the 2020s, the value of Prineville\u2019s taxable property will increase by roughly $2 billion, more than doubling the total from the $1.5 billion in property currently assessed by the city. Revenue is projected to reach $9 million annually, up from $4 million currently.", "title": "An Oregon Mill Town Learns to Love Facebook and Apple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSmooth, complex, soft, salty and strong \u2014 yet delicate, luscious and elegant.\n\nThose are just a few of the adjectives used to describe Westvleteren beer, which is often hailed by aficionados as one of the best in the world.\n\nPart of the mystique rested in its exclusivity. For more than 170 years, the beer has been produced and distributed solely by the Trappist monks of St. Sixtus Abbey in Westvleteren, a village in western Belgium.\n\nBut that changed last week when a branch of Jan Linders, a Dutch supermarket chain, sold more than 7,000 bottles without the monks\u2019 permission, and at 10 euros each, several times higher than the original price.\n\nThe supermarket said it had obtained the beer through \u201ca number of links,\u201d according to Gineke Wilms, its marketing manager, in comments cited by a Dutch daily.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe supermarket sold 300 crates of 24 bottles, Ms. Wilms said, but did not make a significant profit despite the markup. The third-party sellers had all wanted to make a profit, too, she said, and that was what had driven up the final sale price.", "title": "An Unholy Fight Over a Saintly Beer", "authors": ["Iliana Magra"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 On Feb. 28, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan made the most comprehensive offer inviting the Taliban to join direct, formal peace talks with the Afghan government. The offer, made without preconditions, recognizes the role of the Taliban in Afghan politics and seeks to proceed toward a comprehensive peace agreement.\n\nPresident Ghani\u2019s offer is the result of the Kabul Process, which saw delegates from 30 countries and international organizations \u2014 including the United Nations, NATO and the European Union \u2014 gather and deliberate in Kabul.\n\nThe announcement of the peace initiative was preceded by months of national consensus building in Afghanistan. Members of the High Peace Council, the inclusive body of Afghan elders formed to steer efforts for peace and dialogue; the government\u2019s chief executive, Abdullah Abdullah; and President Ghani had long deliberations and consultations with Afghan political figures, members of civil society, clergy, women and youth. They found overwhelming support for the initiative to reach a political settlement with the Taliban.\n\nThe peace offer is underpinned by our belief in the common equality of all Afghans and their right to live in peace and dignity. We believe that this offer will give the Taliban the opportunity to organize as a legitimate political force, pursue their goals through peaceful means and join the political process.", "title": "Opinion | An Unprecedented Peace Offer to the Taliban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen Benjamin Glaze, at the time a 19-year-old cashier from Enid, Okla., auditioned for \u201cAmerican Idol,\u201d he had hoped his big moment would come as he belted out \u201cStadium,\u201d a song he wrote himself. That or Nick Jonas\u2019s 2015 single \u201cLevels.\u201d\n\nInstead, it came when the pop star Katy Perry, a judge on the show, surprised him by kissing him smack on the lips, moments before his audition. He had never been kissed before.\n\n\u201cI was a tad bit uncomfortable,\u201d Mr. Glaze said by phone this week, after the incident aired on the season premiere. His first kiss was a rite of passage he had been putting off with consideration. \u201cI wanted to save it for my first relationship,\u201d he said. \u201cI wanted it to be special.\u201d\n\n\u201cWould I have done it if she said, \u2018Would you kiss me?\u2019 No, I would have said no,\u201d he said. \u201cI know a lot of guys would be like, \u2018Heck yeah!\u2019 But for me, I was raised in a conservative family and I was uncomfortable immediately. I wanted my first kiss to be special.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe scene with the kiss was part of the two-night season opener for the new \u201cAmerican Idol,\u201d which is now airing on ABC after a 15-year run on Fox. Diego Segalini, who has been serving as interim executive director, will be the organization\u2019s leader for finance and administration.\n\nMs. Chopra will oversee the council\u2019s annual River to River Festival, a sprawling series of innovative theater, dance and music performances, as well as art exhibitions, throughout Lower Manhattan and Governors Island \u2014 where she will also be at the helm of efforts to finish the renovation and expansion of the organization\u2019s Arts Center.\n\nThe festival and other cultural council programs, she said in a statement, \u201cengage and inspire audiences across New York City with new ideas and ways of seeing the world.\u201d", "title": "An Uptown Artistic Director Moves Downtown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "That\u2019s exactly what Cult Gaia tried to do. But the United States Patent and Trademark Office has refused to register the design, calling the Ark bag \u201can iteration or appropriation of a style of bag from the Japanese culture.\u201d The design, the Trademark Office said, \u201cis a classic shape and style of carrying bag for personal use.\u201d (The company has additional time to present its case.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe founder of Cult Gaia, Jasmin Larian, has said she was inspired by bamboo bags made in Japan. \u201cI used to collect them,\u201d she told Who What Wear Australia in 2016. But she still may have a case for a trademark.\n\nUsually \u201ctrademarks consist of words or symbols that indicate source \u2014 in fashion, things like the designer\u2019s name on the label, the Nike swoosh or Adidas\u2019s three stripes,\u201d said Susan Scafidi, the founder of the Fashion Law Institute at Fordham University. Yet, the shape of an item can also serve as a trademark, she said, especially if shoppers associate it with a specific brand.\n\nMs. Larian is \u201ctrying to register the shape of the Ark bag as a trademark, arguing that, like the Herm\u00e8s Birkin, U.S. customers immediately associate that style with her and Cult Gaia,\u201d Ms. Scafidi said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn February, Cult Gaia\u2019s lawyer at Mitchell Silberberg & Knupp sent a letter to Steve Madden threatening to \u201cfile a lawsuit seeking any and all available legal and equitable remedies, including injunctive relief, monetary damages, restitution, and attorneys\u2019 fees,\u201d if the company did not cease and desist advertising and selling its version of the Japanese basket bag, among other demands.\n\nSteve Madden has been accused in the past of imitating designs by Valentino, Doc Martens, Allbirds, Aquazzura, Alexander McQueen and Balenciaga. But this time, Steve Madden responded by suing the company it may have copied. Forever 21, the fast-fashion behemoth, has tried a similar tack: Last summer it filed a pre-emptive lawsuit against Gucci after being threatened with what it says was overaggressive trademark litigation by Gucci.\n\nMs. Larian was unavailable for comment on the lawsuit against her company, but Aaron M. Wais, a lawyer for Cult Gaia, told The New York Times, \u201cWe believe it is our duty to protect our hard-earned I.P. assets on behalf of our retail partners \u2014 and customers who shop our website directly.\u201d A spokesperson for Steve Madden said the attempt by Cult Gaia to claim trademark rights in this case \u201cunnecessarily limits the consumer\u2019s right to make choices and stifles healthy competition.\u201d\n\nThe fight isn\u2019t over. Ms. Larian \u201ccould still bag a trademark on the Ark design and hit Steve Madden over the head with it, but she\u2019ll have to get past the U.S.P.T.O. first,\u201d Ms. Scafidi said, referring to the patent office.\n\nUntil then, consumers can buy any imitation they like.\n\nCorrection: March 21, 2018\n\nAn earlier version of this article misstated the name of the first news outlet to report on a lawsuit filed by Steve Madden. It is The Fashion Law, not the Fashion Law Institute.", "title": "An \u2018It\u2019 Bag Faces Its Imitators", "authors": ["Tariro Mzezewa"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Anatoly Lein, a Russian-born American chess grandmaster who was among the world\u2019s top 30 players at his peak, won two of the most prestigious tournaments in the United States and recorded victories against some of the game\u2019s greatest players, died on March 1 in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 86.\n\nA notice of his death was published by his family on Legacy.com. He died 13 days after the death of his wife.\n\nMr. Lein (pronounced lane) was born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg) on March 31, 1931. He learned to play chess at a young age and was inspired to get better after losing repeatedly to an older local boy. In a 2004 interview, he told The Cleveland Jewish News that he had taught himself to play by studying the intricacies of the game on his own.\n\nDespite his passion for chess, Mr. Lein decided to pursue a standard education, studying math and physics in college and becoming an engineer. But chess continued to call, and he began to pursue it more seriously as an adult. There were certainly financial and social incentives.", "title": "Anatoly Lein, an \u00c9migr\u00e9 Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 86", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Anthony Weber\u2019s death may not fit neatly into the familiar narrative of racially tinged police violence \u2014 of a white cop shooting a black man \u2014 but his case does fit the narrative of modern Los Angeles. Areas like South Los Angeles that were once predominantly African-American \u2014 and were the epicenter of uprisings against police abuses in 1965 and 1992 \u2014 have become increasingly Latino, and increasingly diverse. Anthony had a white father, a black mother and a Latino girlfriend.\n\nLaw enforcement in Los Angeles has also become more diverse: White males are now in the minority in both the police and the sheriff\u2019s department, and Latino and black officers are represented on the force in proportions roughly mirroring the population at large.\n\nBut greater diversity has not ended longstanding police biases against black men, according to the shooting data as well as the perceptions of activists. \u201cThey shot him because he\u2019s black!\u201d was chanted by protesters at the first rally after Anthony Weber was killed.\n\n\u201cThe last cop who put a boot in Rodney King\u2019s face was black,\u201d said Steven A. Lerman, a lawyer who represented Mr. King. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t seem to be white versus black, but blue versus take-your-pick.\u201d\n\nThe sheriff\u2019s department has not disclosed the race or identity of the deputy who shot Anthony.\n\nSitting in the Weber family\u2019s living room on a recent afternoon, surrounded by photographs of Anthony, were four generations of women. Mattie Johnson, Anthony\u2019s grandmother, moved to Los Angeles in 1964 \u2014 a year before the Watts riots \u2014 hoping to escape the cruelties of segregation and racism in Birmingham, Ala. She recalled Ku Klux Klan marches and a church bombing there that killed four young black girls.\n\nThe women all considered Anthony\u2019s death to be of a piece with the long arc of America\u2019s history of racism.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf things had been different, Anthony Weber might have been the one behind the pulpit at the funeral the other day in South Los Angeles. He loved the music of the church, and he sure loved the spotlight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was just a natural charmer,\u201d said his mother, Demetra. \u201cHe wanted attention. Which could make him difficult, too. Trust me, I gave him attention. But he always wanted more.\u201d\n\nAt his funeral, a former teacher called him her \u201cwonder boy,\u201d who worked hard to reach age 16. His sister spoke about the unfairness that \u201che never got the chance to be a man.\u201d\n\nMixed with the grief and the music of R. Kelly and the O\u2019Jays at the service, there were hints of anger, too.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re having trouble finding out what happened to him,\u201d his father said. \u201cThey\u2019re not being transparent.\u201d\n\nRodney Hilson, speaking from long experience as a pastor in South Los Angeles, said simply, \u201cI\u2019m tired of this.\u201d", "title": "Anatomy of a Los Angeles Police Shooting: A Black Teenager, a Missing Gun, Protests, Grief", "authors": ["Tim Arango"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Since the mass shooting last month that killed 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla, scenes of gun threats, scares and lockdowns have played out around the country dozens of times each day. Schools in New Jersey, Michigan, California and Texas have reported a threat of violence, a scramble by police, a rush by school officials to secure a school and the ripples of fear that follow.\n\nCommunities find themselves navigating a fine, sometimes blurred, line between vigilance and overreaction. A high school in Westport, Conn., was evacuated after a student was overheard threatening a teacher. Worries over a toy gun caused a lockdown at three schools in Arlington, Tex. In Pensacola, Fla., a middle school went into lockdown after a rumor spread that there was a gun inside the school, terrifying students; the rumor turned out to be false.\n\nAttentive school administrators are facing a daily dilemma: Take every possible threat seriously and risk a needless disruption to the school day, a noisy police response and a crush of worried parents. Or, ignore what could be a real threat and risk the nightmare of your school becoming the next Parkland.\n\n\u2018The World Had Changed\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Fulton, a city of 3,300 people just across the river from Iowa, Tuesday morning began like any other.\n\nStudents showed up for classes at Fulton High, a low-slung brick building where a red sign in front heralds its team name, the Steamers.\n\nMr. Tennyson, a burly, gregarious former police officer known to his students as \u201cMr. T,\u201d was making his usual rounds through the hallways, passing rows of shiny lockers where students had fastened Post-its with inspirational messages. (\u201cTry to be a rainbow in someone\u2019s cloud,\u201d one read.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore he became a principal, Mr. Tennyson, 48, spent years as a school resource officer in suburban Chicago. He vividly remembers the day of the Columbine massacre in 1999, when he watched news reports from the high school where he was responsible for student safety.\n\n\u201cWe just thought, \u2018Oh my goodness, how could this ever happen in a school?\u2019\u201d Mr. Tennyson recalled. \u201cI knew that the world had changed.\u201d\n\nSince the Florida shooting, schools around the country have seen an uptick in threats, incidents of violence and false alarms reported in the media. A group that tracks such reports, the Educator\u2019s School Safety Network, says an average of 70 incidents have occurred daily in the weeks since the Florida shooting, as compared to a more typical pace, of about 10 to 12 incidents a day. Hard to measure, though, is how many of these incidents represent an increase in false alarms, due in part to heightened vigilance, and how many reflect a new surge in truly dangerous threats.\n\nOn Tuesday morning, when Mr. Tennyson read the messages on the worried Fulton High student\u2019s phone, he instantly knew who was involved. This high school is small \u2014 288 students \u2014 and the student who had handed over her phone told him that the messages were from Blake Dornbush, an 18-year-old who graduated from Fulton High last year and had played on the football team.\n\nIn the eyes of Mr. Tennyson, who knows all of his students, he and Mr. Dornbush had a great relationship. But it had been almost a year since they talked.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what\u2019s going on with his life,\u201d Mr. Tennyson said. \u201cI don\u2019t know what\u2019s changed. I don\u2019t know the stressors in his life. There\u2019s no way for me to determine anything that\u2019s going on with Blake in the last year.\u201d\n\nHe picked up the phone and called the police.\n\nIn Lockdown, Waiting\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Fulton Police Department is housed in a former bank, eight blocks from the high school.\n\nLt. Donnie R. Pridemore was on duty Tuesday morning. At 11:05 a.m., he got word of a threat at the high school, and when he heard the name of the suspect, Mr. Dornbush, he made an instant connection. This was Fulton. The lieutenant knew Mr. Dornbush\u2019s parents.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLieutenant Pridemore immediately told school administrators that if they had not yet gone into lockdown, they should now. The elementary, middle and high schools in Fulton instituted a \u201csoft lockdown,\u201d where students are kept in their classrooms and out of hallways.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJenna Schrader, 18 and a senior, was in the library. She was calm, she said later, reasoning that if the situation was truly dire, the school would have gone into full lockdown with even more extreme measures.\n\nAfter 45 minutes, though, other students began to grow nervous, she said.\n\n\u201cYou always think about what could happen,\u201d she said.\n\nAs the students waited, police went to Mr. Dornbush\u2019s home, a pale yellow house with burgundy shutters, where he lived with his parents. Nobody was home.\n\nMr. Dornbush\u2019s parents, called by police, told them that their son was at school. The Midwest Technical Institute in Moline, Ill., where he is studying welding, was a short drive down the river.\n\nAfter a while, Mr. Dornbush returned a call from police on his phone and drove up Route 84 from Moline under strict instructions from the officers. Trailed by unmarked police cars, he drove directly to the Fulton Police Department, where he was interviewed about the Snapchat messages, the police said. Lieutenant Pridemore said he arrested Mr. Dornbush, who was charged with two counts of felony disorderly conduct.\n\nMr. Dornbush was booked into the Whiteside County Jail, where he would remain until Wednesday afternoon, the authorities said, when he was released on $25,000 bond. Mr. Dornbush did not respond to messages, and a woman who answered the door at Mr. Dornbush\u2019s house on Thursday declined to talk. He has yet to enter a plea in the case.\n\nLieutenant Pridemore said that a recent breakup with the student who got the Snapchat messages may have been behind what had happened.\n\n\u201cHe knew what he did was wrong,\u201d Lieutenant Pridemore said. \u201cHe didn\u2019t have a great explanation for why he did it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018Threat Enough\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the Sunrise diner in Fulton on Thursday morning, as a waitress made the rounds and refilled coffee cups, one topic of conversation briefly dominated the room: the lockdown at the schools.\n\nMelissa Werner, sitting in a booth by a window, said that her son, Blake, is a 15-year-old sophomore at Fulton High. He seemed to be fine once the lockdown was over, she said, though he was shaken while it was happening. After what occurred on Tuesday, she gave him a stern reminder.\n\n\u201cI told my son, \u2018You have to watch every little thing that you say,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201c\u2018People don\u2019t know if you\u2019re being serious.\u2019\u201d\n\nPolice said that before Tuesday, they had not had any contact with Mr. Dornbush, aside from a few traffic stops. They searched the Dornbush home and found no weapons.\n\nTod Goodell, a friend and former classmate from Fulton High, said he believed that Mr. Dornbush was harmless.\n\n\u201cI know Blake and I also know he would not hurt anyone,\u201d he said in a Facebook message. \u201cHe said what he said out of anger and I know he regrets it. He wasn\u2019t going to do anything he said he\u2019d do.\u201d\n\nThe uncertainty of that \u2014 whether a threat will result in violence or amount to frightening, rash talk \u2014 has sent schools into lockdowns, again and again. Belligerent claims and rumors of violence spread instantaneously in the never-slowing flood of social media. In light of the Parkland attack and other school shootings, Lieutenant Pridemore said, there is no way that police now can risk overlooking a detailed threat.\n\n\u201cWe can no longer say, \u2018Aww, he didn\u2019t mean it,\u2019\u201d Lieutenant Pridemore said. \u201cTimes have changed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDarryl Hogue, the superintendent of the school district, said he was satisfied that the incident at Fulton High was \u201cisolated, independent and definitely over.\u201d\n\nHe said he has no way of knowing whether someone will follow through on a promise of violence or not.\n\n\u201cI think of that all the time,\u201d Mr. Hogue said. \u201cWas it a real threat? It was a threat enough that we had to act upon it. I don\u2019t know the intentions of the young man.\u201d", "title": "Anatomy of a School Lockdown: A Threat, Then the Anxious Wait", "authors": ["Julie Bosman"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The government \u201cwould think of solutions,\u201d Ms. Cheng said. \u201cSince they allowed this indulgence, they should be there to clean up the mess.\u201d\n\nChina has a problem with debt. Shadowy, underground lenders have flooded the country with a staggering $15 trillion in credit, which threatens to hobble its economy.\n\nBeijing now appears to be taking a harder stance with the companies in need of a bail out. On Wednesday, Chinese authorities accused a founder of Anbang, who was the deal maker who bought the Waldorf Astoria, of bilking investors of more than $10 billion. In a country where courts tend to convict, the accusations raised the likelihood that the executive, Wu Xiaohui, could face life in prison.\n\nOfficials have also spent the past two years trying to contain the risk. Earlier this month, the Chinese government said it would merge the country\u2019s banking and insurance regulators in an effort to close regulatory loopholes.\n\nCentral to that effort is keeping a tighter rein on products like Anbang\u2019s Abundant Stability No. 10. Many small investors believe that means the government backs them. Anbang also calls them \u201cuniversal insurance products,\u201d making them sound conservative.\n\nThe truth is more complicated.\n\nAbundant Stability No. 10 is closer to what in China is called a wealth management product. Wealth management products on paper are not backed by the government, but state-run banks act as middlemen and sell them to small investors, giving many people the perception that they are. The salespeople often know little about what is backing them \u2014 or how the people ultimately behind them will pay the money back.\n\nAbundant Stability No. 10, for example, requires only a $4,600 investment over three years. In return, investors are promised a payout that is triple what Chinese savers might get by parking their money in a savings account. On the phone, salespeople at one state-run Chinese bank, China Merchants, said the payout could be even higher, perhaps 10 times what a savings account pays out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShen Gang, an Anbang spokesman, said that banks were an important channel for the company\u2019s insurance products and that the government takeover had not changed the operations of Anbang at all. \u201cAnbang has always been very stable on the financial front,\u201d he said. \u201cAs such, the selling of our products is a normal business activity.\u201d\n\nLi Yan, 48, a founder of a technology company, bought a universal insurance product from Taikang Insurance, an Anbang rival. She said she was a \u201cteeny bit\u201d concerned about the government takeover of Anbang but \u201cdidn\u2019t think it\u2019s a huge problem,\u201d citing the two insurers\u2019 political connections.\n\n\n\n\u201cAren\u2019t insurance companies not allowed to go bankrupt?\u201d she said.\n\nThe Chinese authorities have pressured big issuers to slow down. In November, they proposed tightening disclosure rules and stopping firms from guaranteeing payments to investors, among other steps.\n\nPhoto\n\nData suggest China is making some headway. The total outstanding balance of wealth management products issued by Chinese banks was about $4.7 trillion in 2017, up just 1.7 percent from a year before, according to China Wealth, a state-backed company that tracks China\u2019s wealth management products. Two years ago, sales were growing at roughly 50 percent.\n\n\u201cI would say that the risk of the debt crisis has come down because of what the government has done,\u201d said Wang Tao, head of Asia economics for UBS Investment Bank. \u201cThe problem is not entirely resolved but it\u2019s moving in the right direction.\u201d\n\nStill, the government has a lot of work to do before investors shake the notion that the government amounts to an eternal safety net.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his last news conference as China\u2019s central bank governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, long a proponent of Chinese financial overhauls, said on March 9 that the country had to strengthen investor education. He said investors had to \u201cfully learn\u201d about new financial products before they bought them.\n\n\u201cIf you want to use them, you have to take your own risks and find out for yourselves,\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t leave it entirely to the regulators to manage them.\u201d\n\nZhu Ning, a Tsinghua University economist, said the only way the government can prevent investors from taking on more risk that they can handle is to allow for \u201csome real failures.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChina has been reluctant to allow for failures. Fearing mass unrest, the ruling Communist Party has repeatedly instructed Chinese banks and local officials to cave in to angry investors, who have protested outside government offices after losing their investments.\n\nThe real test, according to Mr. Zhu, could come later this year, when wealth management products issued years earlier have to be paid back.\n\n\u201cNonperforming loans are going to be so severe that some of the weaker banks will be forced to face their Judgment Day \u2014 whether they are going to be bailed out or whether they are going to die,\u201d he said.\n\nIn the last five years or so, retail investors have poured money into wealth management products that enabled China\u2019s developers to circumvent laws to buy land, \u201czombie\u201d state-owned enterprises facing overcapacity problems to borrow, and debt-laden local government financing vehicles to take on more leverage.\n\nIn the case of Anbang, it helped the company raise money for trophy acquisitions such as the Waldorf Astoria.\n\n\u201cThey were just buying up assets, playing the markets and investing overseas, which, of course, isn\u2019t really beneficial to China\u2019s economy,\u201d said Christopher Aston, an associate consultant in Shanghai at Control Risks, a global risk consultancy, who is writing a book on his experience in a Chinese shadow bank.\n\nThe market is still booming for Anbang. According to data from China\u2019s insurance regulator, Anbang earned $9.2 billion in income derived mostly from universal life insurance products in January, compared with just $1.3 million a year before.\n\nVery few investors in China tend to ask where the money is going. Part of the problem is that many people became cash-rich in a relatively short period of time without an industry of financial advisers that is common in the West.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe investment mentality really has not evolved,\u201d said Lester Ross, chair of the insurance forum of the American Chamber of Commerce in China. \u201cIt\u2019s rather recent.\u201d\n\nMeng Hongxia, a hotel employee who says she earns $480 a month, was considering such a product while inside a branch of China Merchants. She said she was mulling putting her entire savings of nearly $8,000 in a wealth management product because it promised a yield of more than 4 percent and guaranteed repayment.\n\n\u201cWhat do you think?\u201d she said, when asked about the product. \u201cShould I invest?\u201d", "title": "Anbang Was Seized by China. Now, It Has a Deal for You.", "authors": ["Sui-Lee Wee", "Zhang Tiantian"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "So, what about Nancy Pelosi?\n\nOne of the more dramatic sidelights in that dramatic congressional election in Pennsylvania was the way Republicans attempted to turn the whole campaign into a Pelosi referendum.\n\nIf you lived in the Pittsburgh area, you saw multitudinous ads warning that Democrat Conor Lamb would \u201cjoin Pelosi\u2019s liberal flock\u201d if he won. People there will probably spend the spring wandering around muttering \u201cNancy Pelosi and Conor Lamb Are Still Opposing Your Tax Cut.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou cannot watch TV at any time of the day or night without seeing the \u2018mudslinging\u2019 campaigns,\u201d one reader complained to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. It\u2019s tough, all the advertising overkill that comes with a tight election. Those of us who live in districts where the typical contest is a 12-term incumbent versus anything the opposition can dig up \u2014 a woman who just moved into the state, a guy who just got out of prison on an arson conviction, a 12-year-old Chihuahua \u2014 are so lucky.\n\nFor Pelosi, the only downside to Lamb\u2019s victory was the part where he promised he\u2019d never vote to keep her on as leader. (\u201cMy take is, if these people have been around for several years and they haven\u2019t solved these problems that have been hanging around, it\u2019s time for someone new to step up and get it done.\u201d)", "title": "Opinion | And Now, the Nancy Pelosi Drama", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "New Japan is out to loosen its grip.\n\nInside New Japan\u2019s headquarters in Tokyo, Katsuhiko Harada, the company president, has a classroom-sized Rand McNally map of the United States. Dozens of cities, including New York and Chicago \u2014 now W.W.E. strongholds \u2014 are circled like targets.\n\n\u201cI believe there are people who want a different type of way from W.W.E., some fans who prefer other kinds of pro wrestling,\u201d Mr. Harada said, with that map behind him. \u201cFor those people, we just want to show another option and for them to see New Japan.\u201d\n\nNew Japan\u2019s growth has been fueled in part by Bushiroad, a Japanese card gaming company, which became its majority shareholder in 2012 and emphasized appealing to wider audiences, Mr. Haruda said.\n\nPhoto\n\nIntense bouts with layered storytelling and spectacular ring entrances has made New Japan a darling among die-hard fans who sometimes bemoan W.W.E.\u2019s booking, which has become increasingly tailored for mass consumption.\n\nNew Japan\u2019s growth has been helped by YouTube, which has made New Japan\u2019s matches more accessible to an audience outside of Asia, said Dave Meltzer, publisher of the Wrestling Observer Newsletter, which has followed the sport since 1983. Capitalizing on this rise, New Japan launched an online streaming service \u2014 similar to the W.W.E. Network \u2014 in December 2014.\n\n\u201cW.W.E. does the \u2018entertainment\u2019 part of \u2018sports entertainment\u2019 so, so well,\u201d said Cody Rhodes, a New Japan star who left W.W.E. in 2016. \u201cNew Japan does the \u2018sports\u2019 part of \u2018sports entertainment\u2019 like nobody else.\u201d\n\nLast year, New Japan sold out its first two shows in the United States, and all the seats for an event on Sunday in Long Beach, Calif., were gone shortly after going on sale in January.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut evolving from a buzz-worthy niche to mainstream acceptance remains a daunting task.\n\nProfessional wrestling has historically been colored by fierce territorial wars, with promoters battling over in-ring talent and the audience that pays to see it. Without serious competition, W.W.E. has built a business that allows its stars to reach levels of opulence never before associated with wrestling, both in income and crossover appeal. A top star like John Cena can appear with W.W.E. one night and guest-host NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d show the next morning. There are, however, only so many Cena-level spots available.\n\nNew Japan\u2019s rise has come, in part, from offering its performers more artistic freedom as well as additional avenues for income that are not always available to those working for W.W.E. For example, some wrestlers can negotiate with New Japan to also work for other promotions and to sell their own branded merchandise.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important to play your music how you want to play it,\u201d Mr. Rhodes said. \u201cTo be the writer, director, cameraman, and actor all at once. A company like New Japan builds the set, fills the seats, but allows us to do what we do how we want to do it.\u201d\n\nFor years, wrestling in Japan was seen as a rite of passage for foreigners. Mr. Rhodes, the son of Dusty Rhodes, one of the most popular pro wrestlers of the 20th century, always found Japan appealing because of his father\u2019s trips there.\n\nNow with Japan as their base, Mr. Rhodes and his North American colleagues Matt and Nick Jackson and Kenny Omega \u2014 collectively known as The Bullet Club \u2014 have become among the most popular wrestlers in the industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nRyan Barkan, whose company prowrestlingtees.com is the official U.S. seller of New Japan apparel, began producing Bullet Club shirts in 2014, and they immediately became his best seller. The classic Bullet Club logo shirt was also the top-selling T-shirt at retailer Hot Topic in 2017, according to Barkan, who has supplied 470,000 units of New Japan products to the store since brokering a deal with them last June.\n\nNew Japan\u2019s entrepreneurial spirit calls to mind how Mr. Cuban amassed his fortune through a series of business deals that started with a tech firm he started in the 1980s. (Since Mr. Cuban has gone into partnershop with New Japan, published reports have cited a history of alleged sexual harassment in the Dallas Mavericks organization. Mr. Cuban has denied those allegations and New Japan declined to comment on them.)\n\nDespite New Japan\u2019s ability to present critically-acclaimed matches and the company\u2019s impressive tally of T-shirts sold, television remains a key to mainstream visibility.\n\nAXS has less reach than USA Network, which broadcasts W.W.E. programming, but Andrew Simon, chief executive officer of AXS TV Fights, said viewership for New Japan is \u201cup tremendously year over year,\u201d although he did not disclose exact ratings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis month, New Japan\u2019s exposure continued to grow with an English-language DVD distribution deal and the opening of a training center in Southern California. When Chris Jericho, one of W.W.E.\u2019s biggest stars, performed for New Japan in January, the announcement received coverage in Forbes and Rolling Stone.\n\nNew Japan\u2019s quick ascent has impressed many in the business, but comparisons to W.W.E. might be premature.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a great foreign film coming to the U.S.,\u201d Mr. Meltzer said. \u201cIt\u2019s not going to be competition for the blockbusters, but it could be a better movie and often is.\u201d\n\nStill, New Japan\u2019s influence has even reached W.W.E. On April 8, at W.W.E.\u2019s signature \u201cWrestleMania\u201d spectacular, the bill\u2019s main event will feature Shinsuke Nakamura against A.J. Styles, an American who reinvented his career overseas.\n\nBoth are former New Japan champions.", "title": "And in This Corner: A Rival From Japan Takes On the Pro Wrestling Establishment", "authors": ["Seth Berkman"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How many Best Picture Oscar winners were either set or filmed in New York?\n\nA. A casual look through the Academy Awards Database reveals that more than 20 of the 89 films that have won Best Picture have directly involved New York.\n\nIn the early days of Hollywood, many of the films supposedly set in New York were filmed on studio lots, like \u201cThe Broadway Melody\u201d (1929), \u201cThe Great Ziegfeld\u201d (1936), \u201cYou Can\u2019t Take It With You\u201d (1938) and \u201cGoing My Way\u201d (1944).\n\nThat trend changed in 1945, when the director Billy Wilder decided to film much of \u201cThe Lost Weekend\u201d on location, in part to convey \u201cthe grim relation of the individual to the vast, unknowing mass,\u201d according to a contemporary Times review.\n\nSet at P.J. Clarke\u2019s, the legendary Third Avenue bar \u2014 the rattle from the since-demolished Third Avenue El forced Wilder to reshoot interior scenes at a California soundstage \u2014 \u201cThe Lost Weekend\u201d also features a rare look inside the alcoholic ward at Bellevue Hospital.", "title": "And the Oscar for Best City as a Movie Setting Goes to \u2026", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Balducci\u2019s flagship store, across the street from the original, opened in 1972 at West Ninth Street and Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan. Word of mouth made it a destination of choice for gastronomes in an era when tracking down what today is standard fare, like Italian parsley, would have required a dragnet of the city\u2019s greenmarkets.\n\nCulinarians could find red chicory there, five different kinds of eggplant, direct imports of prosciutto di Parma, custom-grown broccoli rabe from Italy and, later, from California, pitahaya (a sweet pink fruit shaped like a mango) and trevigiano (a variety of radicchio) \u2014 to say nothing of arugula.\n\nJames Beard lived around the corner and shopped there for extra-virgin olive oil and Italian bread. Lou Reed bought linguine; Anna Wintour, pecorino; Uma Thurman, pesto. The conductor Michael Tilson Thomas, another regular for a time, once spotted Greta Garbo there.\n\nBalducci\u2019s topped the Zagat Survey of New York City\u2019s food specialty shops, and the celebrity butcher and broadcaster Merle Ellis exclaimed in The Chicago Tribune in 1989 that the store was \u201cas close to heaven as this butcher is likely to get.\u201d (The night meat manager was homonymously named Louis Porco.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAndy and Nina really taught New York how to eat and cook genuine Italian food at a time when it was perceived as little more than pizza and pasta covered with red sauce and gooey cheese,\u201d the food writer and cooking teacher Julia della Croce wrote in an email.\n\n\u201cTheirs,\u201d she said, \u201cwas a place where for the first time, New Yorkers found authentic Italian cooking and could buy the ingredients they would need to make it at home.\u201d\n\nAndrew Balducci was born in Greenpoint on Aug. 3, 1925. His mother was the former Maria Miscioscia. His father, Louis Balducci, arrived from Bari, Italy, in 1914 and began selling fruits and vegetables from his pushcart two years later, earning $5 a week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis parents returned to Italy with Andy when he was 2 months old, remaining there until 1939, when they went back to New York on the eve of World War II. Andy was 14.\n\nHe later took courses at the State Institute of Agriculture at Farmingdale on Long Island (now Farmingdale State College) and, not yet 20, enlisted in the Navy. He was injured during the Normandy invasion and hospitalized for six months.\n\nAfter his discharge, he joined his father, who had lately been selling fish and delivering ice, in a new sidewalk fruit and vegetable stall at Greenwich Avenue and Christopher Street (with a bathtub out back for rinsing the produce as it was delivered).\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1952, the younger Mr. Balducci married the former Nina D\u2019Amelio, who survives him, along with two of his four daughters, Marta and Andrea Balducci; his sister, Grace Doria; six grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. His daughter Maria Murphy, who was known as Ria, died in 2006, and his daughter Dena Balducci died in a car accident in 1991.\n\nMr. Balducci took a hiatus from the food business in the mid-1950s to work for his father-in-law\u2019s Long Island masonry contracting firm, in Great Neck. He returned to his father\u2019s store in 1968. In 1972, when the rent was about to be quadrupled, they opened a 5,000-square-foot market across the street.\n\nThe kitchen was staffed by Andy Balducci\u2019s sister and his mother, and his wife conceived a mail order catalog that soon thrived. Despite their booming business, though, the Balducci clan was as mismatched as bread and butter on an authentic Italian table.\n\nPhoto\n\nRancor between Andy and the store\u2019s co-owners \u2014 his sister, Grace, and her husband, Joe Doria \u2014 as well as between Andy and his father and his older brother, Charles, a physician who was known in the family as The Doctor, began boiling over in the late 1980s, leading to lawsuits.\n\nAndy was accused by his father, by Charles and by the Dorias of cheating them out of their fair share of the ownership. When the Dorias opened their own market on the Upper East Side and called it Grace Balducci\u2019s, Andy countersued over the use of the Balducci name. (That establishment became Grace\u2019s Marketplace.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Guardian called all the acrimony \u201ca grand opera of sibling rivalry, jealousy, alleged swindling and lawsuits more piquant than the spiciest olives on the deli counter.\u201d\n\nWhen his relatives accused Mr. Balducci of having a volatile temper, he told The Times in 2000, \u201cI\u2019m opinionated, but so far I haven\u2019t killed anyone.\u201d\n\nThe family eventually reached a financial settlement.\n\nAnother family member long involved in running the store, Andy\u2019s nephew Louis, Charles\u2019s son, left to become a partner in Agata & Valentina, another Upper East Side food market.\n\nBy 1999, the real estate Balducci\u2019s occupied was worth more than the business itself (which none of his daughters were keen to inherit), and so Mr. Balducci sold the store for $26.5 million. He and his wife retired to East Williston on Long Island and Paradise Island in the Bahamas.\n\nThe new owners closed the store in 2003 \u201cafter 54 years of selling perfect produce and overpriced provender,\u201d The New Yorker wrote.\n\nAnother version of the store opened briefly a few blocks away as Balducci\u2019s Food Lover\u2019s Market, but it was shuttered in 2009 \u2014 although branches of it remained open in 10 locations outside New York, including Greenwich, Conn.\n\nToday, Andy\u2019s grandson T. J. Murphy is the chief executive of the family\u2019s wholesale spinoff, Baldor Specialty Foods. (The name is a hybrid of Balducci and Doria.)\n\nDespite the family feud, Louis Balducci gave his uncle due credit for the store\u2019s success.\n\n\u201cAndy was the creative and driving force, but he also had an incredible team behind him,\u201d he said in 2000. \u201cIn the \u201970s and \u201980s, you couldn\u2019t touch Balducci\u2019s.\u201d", "title": "Andrew Balducci, Who Turned a Market Into a Food Mecca, Dies at 92", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Andrew Liveris will step down as executive chairman of DowDuPont in April, less than a year after completing a merger that created what is now one of the world\u2019s largest chemicals companies, DowDuPont said on Monday.\n\nThe merger of DowDuPont \u2014 combining the inventor of Kevlar in DuPont and a giant maker of plastics and chemicals in Dow \u2014 was announced in December 2015 and took more than a year to complete. But the combined business is set to split next year into three companies based around its materials sciences, agriculture and specialty products divisions. The company agreed to revise its breakup plan last year after pressure from shareholders.\n\nMr. Liveris, 63, had previously said that he would most likely leave the company this year. He is set to relinquish the role of executive chairman on April 1 and step down from the company\u2019s board in July.\n\nAfter the departure of Mr. Liveris, Jeff Fettig, the company\u2019s co-lead independent director, will assume the role as a nonemployee executive chairman.", "title": "Andrew Liveris to Step Down as DowDuPont\u2019s Executive Chairman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "UNMASKED\n\nBy Andrew Lloyd Webber\n\nIllustrated. 517 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $28.99.\n\nUntil recently, I would have said the three most painful hours I spent in a Broadway theater in 2017 were the ones watching Glenn Close gamely rasp her way through the lugubrious revival of \u201cSunset Boulevard,\u201d Andrew Lloyd Webber\u2019s musical version of the classic Billy Wilder movie. (Close had starred in the original Broadway production 22 years earlier, and time had not been kind to either her singing voice or the show itself.) But then, on the second-to-last day of the year, I went to a matinee of the recent revival of \u201cCats,\u201d also by Lloyd Webber, ending its year-and-a-half run that night. (The original Broadway production of \u201cCats\u201d ran for 18 years, making it the longest-running musical in Broadway history until it was eclipsed by the still-running \u201cPhantom of the Opera,\u201d written by \u2014 who else? \u2014 Andrew Lloyd Webber.) Surrounded by enthusiastic fans, some of whom had come in costume, I sat through the frantically charmless first act before bolting for the exit at intermission. At least I got to hear \u201cMemory.\u201d\n\nSo perhaps I am not the ideal reader for Lloyd Webber\u2019s memoir, \u201cUnmasked,\u201d the first of what the composer suggests will be two volumes. But as someone who has long been a devoted theatergoer (and can knowledgeably debate, for instance, the finer points of the Angela Lansbury versus Tyne Daly versus Bernadette Peters productions of \u201cGypsy\u201d), I have a grudging admiration for someone who once had four shows running simultaneously on Broadway, tying a record that had been held by the legendary Rodgers and Hammerstein. And the original cast album of Lloyd Webber\u2019s \u201cJesus Christ Superstar\u201d was certainly in heavy rotation during my youth, as was its hit single, \u201cI Don\u2019t Know How to Love Him.\u201d\n\nMoreover, Lloyd Webber has worked over the years with some of the most compelling characters in musical theater \u2014 among them Harold Prince, Patti LuPone and Cameron Mackintosh \u2014 and I was hoping for some good dish, particularly on LuPone, the \u201cEvita\u201d star with whom Lloyd Webber later had a famous feud after he fired her from the Broadway production of \u201cSunset Boulevard\u201d and replaced her with Close.\n\nBut, alas, Lloyd Webber doesn\u2019t appear to be much interested in dishing the dirt in this volume \u2014 at least not in the tradition of most kiss-and-tell theatrical memoirs, including LuPone\u2019s own, which doesn\u2019t shy away from naming names and settling scores. (LuPone spends two full chapters bitterly recounting the \u201cSunset Boulevard\u201d tale, and Lloyd Webber points out that she once said \u201cEvita\u201d was clearly written by a composer \u201cwho hates women.\u201d)", "title": "Andrew Lloyd Webber, Hotheaded Perfectionist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "A spokesman for Mr. Horowitz declined to comment. Mr. McCabe also declined to comment. He and his allies have steadfastly maintained that he did nothing improper and cooperated fully with the inspector general.\n\nIn October 2016, The Wall Street Journal revealed a dispute between F.B.I. and Justice Department officials over how to proceed in an investigation into the financial dealings of the Clinton family\u2019s foundation. The article revealed a closed-door meeting during which senior Justice Department officials were dismissive of the evidence and declined to authorize subpoenas or grand jury activity. Some F.B.I. agents, the article said, believed that Mr. McCabe had put the brakes on the investigation.\n\nOthers rejected that notion. The Journal, citing sources including \u201cone person close to Mr. McCabe,\u201d revealed a tense conversation with a senior Justice Department official in which Mr. McCabe insisted that the F.B.I. had the authority to press ahead with the investigation into the Clinton Foundation.\n\nThe inspector general has concluded that Mr. McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to provide information for that article, according to the four people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the report before it is published. The public affairs office had arranged a phone call to discuss the case, the people said. Mr. McCabe, as deputy director, had the authority to engage the news media.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSuch calls are common practice across the federal government when officials believe that journalists have only part of the story. Rather than let incomplete or inaccurate coverage circulate, officials often try to fill out the picture or provide a defense. But Justice Department rules prohibit the dissemination of confidential information, and the inspector general\u2019s report is expected to criticize Mr. McCabe for disclosing the existence of a continuing investigation to The Journal.\n\nWhen an inquiry uncovers evidence that an agent has violated Justice Department regulations, the inspector general typically refers the matter to the F.B.I.\u2019s Office of Professional Responsibility, which handles questions of punishment.\n\nIt is unclear whether the inspector general will identify others who spoke about the Clinton investigation. But Mr. McCabe is by far the most prominent subject. Mr. Trump has taunted him on Twitter, writing in December that he \u201cis racing the clock to retire with full benefits. 90 days to go?!!!\u201d Mr. McCabe is eligible to retire March 18.\n\nMr. Trump has animosity toward Mr. McCabe for several reasons, including his close ties to the former F.B.I. director James B. Comey, whom Mr. Trump fired last year. But the president is particularly bothered by the fact that Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife, Jill, ran as a Democrat in a failed campaign for a State Senate seat in Virginia. Her campaign received hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from a political committee run by Terry McAuliffe, the Virginia governor at the time and a longtime ally of the Clintons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLater, after Mrs. McCabe lost the race, Mr. McCabe was promoted to deputy director and oversaw the Clinton investigation. Though Mr. McCabe sought ethics and legal advice about whether to recuse himself, some in the F.B.I. considered his involvement a conflict of interest. Ultimately, amid scrutiny from the news media, Mr. Comey pressured Mr. McCabe to recuse himself. The inspector general is examining whether Mr. McCabe should have done so earlier.\n\nMr. Trump has seized on that issue in repeatedly criticizing Mr. McCabe, a lifelong Republican who did not vote in the 2016 election. In face-to-face meetings with Mr. McCabe, the president questioned how he had voted and needled him about his wife. In one instance, he called Mrs. McCabe \u201ca loser,\u201d according to people familiar with the conversation, which was first reported by NBC News.\n\nMr. McCabe\u2019s allies at the F.B.I. say that Mr. Trump is also eager to discredit Mr. McCabe because he can corroborate Mr. Comey\u2019s accounts of meetings with Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. McCabe rose quickly through the F.B.I. ranks and was seen as a new model for the second-in-command when he was promoted in 2016. The F.B.I. had transformed from a law-and-order agency to an integral part of the nation\u2019s intelligence apparatus, and Mr. McCabe, who graduated from Duke and Washington University School of Law in St. Louis, was picked not based on a career of street work but based on his intellect and decision-making.\n\nThat won him equal parts praise and disdain inside the F.B.I., with longtime agents accusing him of having ascended too quickly.\n\nMr. McCabe is on leave while he awaits retirement. He was succeeded by David L. Bowdich, the acting F.B.I. deputy director.", "title": "Andrew McCabe, Ex-Deputy Director of F.B.I., Will Be Faulted for Leaks", "authors": ["Matt Apuzzo", "Adam Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Andrew G. McCabe, the former deputy F.B.I. director who was fired late Friday, kept contemporaneous memos about his interactions with President Trump and his conversations with the former director James B. Comey, a person close to Mr. McCabe said on Saturday.\n\nThe memos could bolster the account of Mr. Comey, whose own memos and testimony describe repeated requests by Mr. Trump to clear his name.
