Mr. Comey said Mr. Trump also asked him to shut down a criminal investigation into his former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn. Both matters are under investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, who is considering whether Mr. Trump tried to obstruct justice.\n\nMr. McCabe\u2019s memos were left at the F.B.I., which means that Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have access to them as they work to corroborate Mr. Comey\u2019s account. Mr. Trump has denied pressuring Mr. Comey to end the Flynn investigation. Mr. Comey was fired last spring, and the revelation of his conversations with Mr. Trump helped lead to the special counsel\u2019s appointment.\n\nMr. McCabe is known to have had at least three meetings with the president. In one, he asked Mr. McCabe how he had voted in the presidential election. In each, he asked about Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife, Jill, who ran a failed campaign as a Democrat for the Virginia State Senate. Mr. McCabe has identified as a lifelong Republican but did not vote in the 2016 presidential race.", "title": "Andrew McCabe, Fired F.B.I. Deputy, Is Said to Have Kept Memos on Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Under F.B.I. rules, internal reports are referred to the bureau\u2019s Office of Professional Responsibility, which makes disciplinary recommendations. Mr. McCabe can appeal that recommendation to the attorney general. A Justice Department spokeswoman declined to say whether Mr. McCabe would be fired.\n\n\u201cThe department follows a prescribed process by which an employee may be terminated,\u201d said the spokeswoman, Sarah Isgur Flores. \u201cThat process includes recommendations from career employees, and no termination decision is final until the conclusion of that process. We have no personnel announcements at this time.\u201d\n\nMr. McCabe declined to comment. His friends and allies have said that he denies any wrongdoing in his dealings with journalists or the inspector general. He stepped down in January and took a leave of absence under pressure over the looming inspector general\u2019s report.\n\nMr. McCabe is a career agent, not a political appointee, so Mr. Trump has no direct say in his fate. The decision nonetheless comes at a moment of turnover in Mr. Trump\u2019s national security team. On Tuesday, the president fired the secretary of state, Rex W. Tillerson, and named the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, to replace him. He tapped a veteran clandestine officer, Gina Haspel, to lead the C.I.A.\n\nFiring Mr. McCabe, even on the recommendation of the disciplinary office, would be controversial. Among Mr. McCabe\u2019s allies, the decision would raise the specter that Mr. Sessions was influenced by Mr. Trump\u2019s frequent derisive comments. No deputy director in the history of the F.B.I. has been fired.\n\nBut Mr. Sessions would be able to point to a critical inspector general\u2019s report and say he followed Justice Department protocol. The details of why the inspector general viewed Mr. McCabe as not forthcoming are not clear. Though F.B.I. disciplinary records show that drunken driving, domestic violence and assaults have been punished by suspension, when agents are found to have shown a lack of candor under oath, they are commonly fired.\n\nThe inspector general, Michael Horowitz, announced last year that he would investigate several contentious decisions made at the F.B.I. and Justice Department during the 2016 presidential campaign. In November, Mr. Horowitz indicated that he planned to issue a single report this spring encompassing his entire review, on matters including the F.B.I.\u2019s investigation of Hillary Clinton\u2019s use of a private email server.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are no indications that Mr. Horowitz is prepared to release a broad report this week. It is not clear why he opted to handle Mr. McCabe separately and refer him for discipline before the release of the full report. A spokesman for Mr. Horowitz has declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has attacked members of the F.B.I. and the Justice Department for much of his first year in office. But few have been the target of presidential ire like Mr. McCabe. Mr. Trump has repeatedly remarked on the fact that Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife, Jill, ran as a Democrat for a State Senate seat in Virginia. Her campaign received hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from a political committee run by Terry McAuliffe, the Virginia governor at the time and a longtime ally of the Clintons.\n\nMrs. McCabe lost the race and Mr. McCabe was later promoted to deputy director, where he oversaw the investigation into Mrs. Clinton. No charges were filed in that case, and Mr. Trump has pointed to the donations to Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife\u2019s campaign as evidence of F.B.I. bias.\n\nIn meetings with Mr. McCabe, the president questioned how he had voted and needled him about his wife, calling her a \u201closer,\u201d according to people familiar with the conversations.\n\nThe precise allegations against Mr. McCabe will not be clear until the full report is released. But what is publicly known does not fit neatly into Mr. Trump\u2019s theory of Mr. McCabe as a Democratic operator. Mr. McCabe has described himself to friends as a lifelong Republican voter.\n\nThe allegations revolve around disclosures to The Wall Street Journal, which revealed in October 2016 a dispute between the F.B.I. and Justice Department over how to proceed in an investigation into the Clinton family\u2019s foundation. The article said that the Justice Department would not authorize subpoenas in the case. Some F.B.I. agents, the article said, believed that Mr. McCabe had put the brakes on the investigation. Others rejected that notion.\n\nThe inspector general has concluded that Mr. McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to provide information for that article. The public affairs office arranged a phone call to discuss the case, a common practice in the federal government when officials believe that a journalist has only part of the story.\n\nIn the Journal story, a person described as close to Mr. McCabe pushed back on the notion that he had tried to shut down the Clinton Foundation investigation. To the contrary, the person described a tense conversation with the Justice Department in which Mr. McCabe insisted his agents had the authority to keep investigating.\n\nThe article was a negative one for the Clinton campaign \u2014 not Mr. Trump. It was published just days before the election, after the F.B.I. reopened its investigation into Mrs. Clinton\u2019s email practices. The article, including the F.B.I. disclosures, made it clear that some agents saw evidence of wrongdoing by the Clinton Foundation that was worth investigating.\n\nMr. McCabe joined the F.B.I. after law school and rose quickly through the ranks. Under the former F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, he ascended through several senior leadership jobs, and it was clear that he was being groomed for the bureau\u2019s No. 2 position. His rise angered some rank-and-file agents. But supporters viewed him as a sophisticated, intellectual choice for a job that has become an integral part of the nation\u2019s intelligence community.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deputy director is the chief operations officer at the F.B.I., a job that requires managing relationships with the White House and Congress. That task became unusually difficult as agents investigated the Trump campaign, straining relationships with Mr. Trump. Democrats in Congress, meanwhile, criticized the F.B.I. for failing to do enough in that inquiry, while Republicans accused agents of drumming up an investigation based on shoddy evidence.", "title": "Andrew McCabe, a Symbol of Trump\u2019s F.B.I. Ire, Faces Possible Firing", "authors": ["Katie Benner", "Matt Apuzzo", "Adam Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement released by his lawyers, Mr. McCabe said his firing was part of Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201congoing war on the F.B.I.\u201d and Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel. He said he answered questions truthfully in the internal investigation and contacted investigators to correct the record when he believed they misunderstood him.\n\n\u201cI am being singled out and treated this way because of the role I played, the actions I took and the events I witnessed in the aftermath of the firing of James Comey,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. McCabe, a 21-year F.B.I. veteran, was eligible for a government pension if he retired on Sunday. The firing jeopardizes that benefit, though it was not immediately clear how much he might lose.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s incredibly unfair to my reputation after a 21-year career,\u201d Mr. McCabe said. He said the president\u2019s public attacks were aimed at several targets. \u201cThe real damage is being done to the F.B.I., law enforcement and the special counsel,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. McCabe was the F.B.I.\u2019s second in command during one of the most tumultuous periods in the bureau\u2019s history. He oversaw investigations into both the Trump campaign and Hillary Clinton\u2019s use of a private email server \u2014 and he dealt with the fallout from both. He became the acting F.B.I. director after the sudden firing of his boss, Mr. Comey, and he publicly contradicted the White House on national television over whether Mr. Comey had lost the support of rank-and-file F.B.I. agents.", "title": "Andrew McCabe, a Target of Trump\u2019s F.B.I. Scorn, Is Fired Over Candor Questions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Was he leaking information to damage Mr. Trump?\n\nNot as far as anyone can tell. The story at the heart of the case was published in The Wall Street Journal in October 2016, just days before the election as the F.B.I. raced to review newly discovered emails from Mrs. Clinton\u2019s server. The Journal revealed a dispute between the F.B.I. and the Justice Department over how to handle a separate Clinton investigation, one into her family\u2019s foundation.\n\nMr. McCabe authorized an F.B.I. spokesman and lawyer to speak to The Journal to rebut suggestions that he had put the brakes on the investigation. These types of interactions between journalists and government officials \u2014 known as \u201cbackground calls\u201d \u2014 are common in all federal agencies and administrations as officials try to correct inaccuracies or provide details and nuance before reporters publish information.\n\nThe Journal ultimately reported that while Justice Department officials did not authorize subpoenas, the F.B.I. in fact had pressed ahead with the case \u2014 a detail that if anything was damaging to Mrs. Clinton, not Mr. Trump.\n\nDid the White House fire Mr. McCabe?\n\nNo. As a career civil servant, Mr. McCabe is not a political appointee who can be summarily dismissed by the president. But this is where the situation gets complicated. Mr. Trump has repeatedly used his Twitter account to attack Mr. McCabe. Months before the firing, he taunted Mr. McCabe about his pension.\n\nAnd he goaded Mr. Sessions into taking action against Mr. McCabe.\n\nOn the eve of Mr. McCabe\u2019s firing, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, called him a \u201cbad actor.\u201d Taken together, this unusual level of White House commentary created a political backdrop to what should have been an independent government personnel decision. Mr. McCabe\u2019s lawyers seized on that as evidence of improper influence.\n\n\u201cThis distortion of the process begins at the very top, with the president\u2019s repeated offensive, drive-by Twitter attacks on Mr. McCabe.\u201d \u2014 Michael R. Bromwich, a lawyer for Mr. McCabe\n\nWhy was he fired so quickly?\n\nThat is one of the big unknowns. F.B.I. disciplinary matters can drag out for extended periods, and it is not uncommon for officials to retire during that process. That did not happen here, and it is not clear why. The workings of the F.B.I.\u2019s disciplinary office are kept confidential.\n\nMr. McCabe\u2019s lawyers say they were given little time to read and respond to the final report and were still receiving new evidence two days before his firing. Why the rush, they ask, if not to make sure that Mr. McCabe was fired?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis concerted effort to accelerate the process, in order to beat the ticking clock of his scheduled retirement, violates any sense of decency and basic principles of fairness,\u201d Mr. Bromwich said.\n\nWhat\u2019s the president\u2019s beef with Mr. McCabe?\n\nMr. Trump has seized on the fact that Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife, Jill, ran for a Virginia State Senate seat as a Democrat and received hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations from a political ally of Mrs. Clinton. He says Mr. McCabe never should have been allowed to oversee the Clinton investigation. He says the campaign donations are proof that a pro-Clinton bias within the F.B.I. explains why Mrs. Clinton was never charged.\n\nMr. Trump brought up Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife on several occasions, including a face-to-face meeting in which the president called her a \u201closer.\u201d\n\nDoes Mr. Trump\u2019s criticism have merit?\n\nYes and no. Mr. McCabe did not begin supervising the Clinton investigation until after his wife had lost the race, and records show that he sought ethics and legal advice inside the F.B.I. before deciding not to recuse himself. But some in the F.B.I. believe he should never have been involved because of his wife\u2019s campaign donations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen he ultimately recused himself, late in the investigation, it only fueled the argument that he should have stepped aside from the beginning.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s theory of Mr. McCabe as a pro-Clinton partisan, however, is on far shakier ground. Mr. McCabe has identified himself as a lifelong Republican and did not vote in the 2016 election. The newspaper story that Mr. McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials speak about was not a positive one for Mrs. Clinton.\n\nAnd, perhaps most importantly, in the months before the election, when the F.B.I. publicly disclosed information about its work on the Clinton investigation, it never revealed the existence and scope of a full-throated investigation into the Trump campaign\u2019s Russia ties.\n\nWhat does this possibly have to do with Russia?\n\nLike so much at the F.B.I., Mr. McCabe\u2019s firing has become inextricably entangled in presidential politics and the investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\nMr. McCabe was one of only a handful of F.B.I. officials involved in the Russia investigation from the first days. He supervised it at every step and was involved in the decision to seek a wiretap on Carter Page, a former Trump foreign adviser. That wiretap application was approved by senior Justice Department officials, was reapproved by Mr. Trump\u2019s own Justice Department and was signed by a federal judge based on evidence that Mr. Page was a Russian agent. Mr. Trump has declared that wiretap to be improper, however, and points to it as evidence of political surveillance by the F.B.I.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. McCabe also worked alongside the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, who accused Mr. Trump of seeking a loyalty oath and pressing him to end the investigation. Those conversations are now part of an obstruction investigation. Mr. McCabe kept memos on his conversations with Mr. Comey, which could help investigators corroborate Mr. Comey\u2019s account.\n\nMr. McCabe argues that the Trump administration is trying to discredit him as a potential witness. The real target, Mr. McCabe said, is Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation. Mr. Trump\u2019s team seemingly gave credence to that argument last weekend when the Daily Beast asked for Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer for a comment on Mr. McCabe\u2019s firing and he responded with a call to end the Mueller investigation.\n\nFrom a political standpoint, if Mr. Trump discredits Mr. McCabe, he can raise questions about everything Mr. McCabe has touched \u2014 including the Russia investigation. Mr. McCabe\u2019s allies have come to his defense.\n\nWell, he did lie, right?\n\nWhat we know right now is that Mr. Sessions found repeated examples in which Mr. McCabe \u201clacked candor.\u201d And career officials \u2014 not Trump appointees \u2014 recommended dismissal. Mr. Sessions accepted that recommendation.\n\n\u201cThe F.B.I. expects every employee to adhere to the highest standards of honesty, integrity, and accountability,\u201d Mr. Sessions said.\n\nMr. McCabe denies being untruthful. He says he answered every question honestly and, when he was misunderstood, he reached out to the investigators to correct the record.\n\nWhat\u2019s next?\n\nWe won\u2019t be able to assess the allegations, or Mr. McCabe\u2019s defense, until the inspector general\u2019s report is released. That is expected sometime this spring. Mr. McCabe has seen it but cannot discuss it until it is public. When it is released, his lawyers say, he has a point-by-point rebuttal to offer.", "title": "Andrew McCabe\u2019s Firing: Here\u2019s What We Know", "authors": ["Matt Apuzzo"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Griffiths\u2019 work is both witty and fantastical, with a dark edge not dissimilar to Roald Dahl. In person, however, he is humble and thoughtful, if tightly coiled, with the taut, sinewy body of a long-distance runner and zany green eyes.\n\nWe meet at Mr. Griffiths\u2019 airy beachside home in Williamstown, a suburb of Melbourne, Australia, where he lives with his wife, Jill, 56, who co-writes and edits his books, and their daughter, Sarah, 17. (He also has a daughter, 24-year-old Jasmine, from a previous marriage.)\n\nWith its sweeping views over the ocean, the house is built in a familiar Australian style \u2014 floor-to-ceiling glass windows leading out to a terrace and lap pool \u2014 but there are hints that this isn\u2019t just any suburban abode. On the mantel sits an eclectic assortment of oversized toys: a Bambi; a retro red clown, mouth agape; and a giant Kewpie doll.\n\nPhoto\n\nThese knickknacks are important imagination kickers; much of Mr. Griffiths\u2019 time is spent trawling junk stores. \u201cThere\u2019s got to be something slightly creepy. Like that frog,\u201d he points to a manically grinning frog sitting between the Bambi and the clown.\n\nHis garden studio is a child\u2019s paradise, albeit with a warped sense of humor. There are compact plastic dinosaurs whose heads have been ripped off and replaced with those of baby dolls; a full-sized skeleton dressed in a mortarboard cap and gown; and several, as Mr. Griffiths puts it, \u201ckiller\u201d koalas \u2014 soft toys adorned with fangs, bloodshot googly eyes and crimson claws, created from hairclips. Towering over it all is a 6-foot-high model of a tree house.\n\n\u201cA lot of kids entertainment is pitched down. It\u2019s pretty tedious,\u201d Mr. Griffiths scoffed, shaking his head. By contrast, he begins with an idea that amuses him as an adult. \u201cWe credit the children with intelligence,\u201d he said, speaking of himself and Treehouse illustrator, Mr. Denton, \u201cwriting to them as equals and saying, in effect, \u2018Hey, we think this is really funny and want to share it with you!\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Griffiths chafes at the idea that children\u2019s books need to have purpose or be instructive. \u201cWhat\u2019s the point of our stories?\u201d he said. \u201cThere is no point. That\u2019s the point. To read a book and enjoy it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the past he has courted controversy and a fair amount of poo-pooing (pun intended) of his work, which at times has been seen by some at best as noneducational and at worst as dangerous.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis books have been removed from libraries, schools and shops over fears that children might copy behavior in them. There was \u201cThe Day My Butt Went Psycho!,\u201d about an army of backsides that aim for world domination via a toxic giant fart. That one was, he remarked, \u201crude enough to get people hot under the collar,\u201d and a deliberate reaction to the conservatism Mr. Griffiths felt was devouring children\u2019s literature at the time. \u201cI was delighted,\u201d he said of the fuss. \u201cKids do not read fiction as if they\u2019re a manual for living. They go to books because they\u2019re the opposite.\u201d\n\nMr. Griffiths is culturally astute: He counts Kafka\u2019s \u201cThe Metamorphosis\u201d as a major influence, alongside \u201cAlice\u2019s Adventures in Wonderland,\u201d Salvador Dal\u00ed, \u201cPunch and Judy\u201d (\u201cit\u2019s so transgressive, so violent\u201d) and \u201cThe Magic Pudding,\u201d a tale of \u201cchaos and anarchy.\u201d His love of literature is (literally) imprinted on his body. Both arms are tattooed heavily with characters from the books he has read and loved, including his own.\n\nAs such, he can sound a bit defensive about his reputation. \u201cYou know,\u201d he said of the butt books, it\u2019s \u201ca hero\u2019s journey. There are a lot of literary references. It\u2019s quite sophisticated absurdist fiction.\u201d But, he added, all critics see are \u201cbums and farts.\u201d\n\nThe Treehouse series was an attempt to \u201cget away\u201d from the bum genre, he admitted. \u201cWe had done every possible violation. So we said we\u2019ll just write a book about not being able to write a book \u2014 and we\u2019ll live in a tree house.\u201d\n\nThe result is what can only be described as the dream home for 9- and 10-year-olds. There are no parents (or rules). Terry and Andy spend their days eating ice cream served by a robot called Edward Scooperhands, getting tattoos in the A.T.M. (Automatic Tattoo Machine), or performing \u201copen shark surgery\u201d on their pet fish. Less crude than earlier books, there are still plenty of adult allusions to keep parents amused.\n\nPhoto\n\nBorn in 1961, Mr. Griffiths was raised in Melbourne by his midwife mother and industrial chemist father. Growing up a \u201cwild, dissolute youth\u201d he devoured horror comics, listened to David Bowie and took long bush walks.\n\n\u201cI remember my dad asking: \u2018Why do you always have to be different?\u2019 He wanted me to be interested in football and cricket,\u201d he recalled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis sense of agency changed when he was 10 and was given a rusty typewriter, which he still prizes today. The ability to make words out of nothing \u2014 to \u201ctake any silly idea you\u2019ve got and make a book\u201d \u2014 fascinated him. Soon, he was selling a \u201cjoke magazine\u201d to other kids for 3 Australian cents a pop. As an adult, he had stints as a punk singer and a taxi driver. When he gave up teaching, \u201cmy parents went: \u2018Ugh, we almost had a respectable son!\u2019\u201d\n\nFor the last two decades, Mr. Griffiths has worked closely with Mr. Denton (\u201cwe\u2019re like long lost brothers\u201d) and his wife, Jill, whom he met in 1996. The fictional Treehouse series reflects their roles in real life. \u201cTerry is always off with the fairies or painting a cat yellow, and Jill solves problems. There is,\u201d he said with admiration, \u201cno hiding from Jill,\u201d who is down-to-earth, warm and nurturing.\n\nThe series still touches on bodily functions, such as bubbles made of burps, but Mr. Griffiths also explores bigger ideas that appeal to him. Many are existential: In one book, Professor Stupido, the world\u2019s greatest un-inventor, un-invents the universe (Terry, thankfully, draws it back). In another, Terry and Andy travel back in time to different eons.\n\nAs his Treehouse books make their way into the lives of a generation of children around the world Mr. Griffiths himself may seem to have grown up. But he remains at once wickedly puerile and endlessly curious. \u201cThe child inside never went away,\u201d he said, gazing lovingly around his studio.", "title": "Andy Griffiths, the Down-Under Kids\u2019 Author Known for His Butt Jokes, Now Builds and Builds on His Hit \u2018Treehouse\u2019 Series", "authors": ["Clarissa Sebag-Montefiore"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "By now, the \u201cgrand coalition,\u201d as the tie-up is known, looks anything but grand: In polls, it no longer commands a majority. And the far-right Alternative for Germany party, AfD, now the official main opposition in Parliament, has been gaining momentum.\n\n\u201cThis episode will mark German politics for a long time,\u201d said Henrik Enderlein, a professor of political economy at the Hertie School of Governance in Berlin. \u201cThe two large parties will have to fight hard to win back control.\u201d\n\nSo unpopular was the prospect of another stint in government with Ms. Merkel that the Social Democrats had promised their 463,000 members a vote on the coalition treaty, effectively making them the arbiters of whether their nation of 82 million people would finally have a government. Some 78 percent of party members voted, of which more than 66 percent supported the new government.\n\n\u201cThe members of the Social Democrats did not take this vote lightly,\u201d said Olaf Scholz, the party\u2019s acting leader, after Dietmar Nietan, treasurer of the Social Democrats, announced the decision.\n\nThe vote came four months after Ms. Merkel failed in her first attempt to build a coalition. It also came after Martin Schulz was forced to hand over the reins as leader of the Social Democratic Party.\n\nThe result means a new German government could be sworn in as early as March 14. The new administration, however, will lack the strength of its predecessor, formed after a similar nail-biting vote by the Social Democrats in 2013.\n\nMs. Merkel has noted that she needs to focus more on domestic issues as the country grapples with the challenges of integrating the roughly one million migrants who arrived in Germany in recent years.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the prelude to the vote, Social Democratic leaders crisscrossed the country, holding a series of town-hall-style meetings in a bid to persuade members to either support or reject a new coalition government with the Christian Democrats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGoverning with their traditional rivals has blurred the lines between the two camps. When the Social Democrats first joined Ms. Merkel\u2019s conservatives in government, in 2005, they received 34 percent of the vote. After the S.P.D.\u2019s second stint as a junior coalition partner, over the past four years, that share fell to 20 percent.\n\nBoth the Social Democrats and the Christian Democratic Union have lost ground to the political extremes in recent years. The arrival of the anti-immigration AfD party in the national Parliament after the September vote has made forming a government much harder.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nParliament now includes lawmakers from seven political parties, spanning the full political spectrum, and traditional postwar coalitions on the left or right no longer have a majority. With the S.P.D.\u2019s decision to enter the government, the AfD will now become the strongest opposition force in Parliament, a largely symbolic but important position that is viewed as providing a check on those in power.\n\nThe past weeks have seen the S.P.D.\u2019s popularity plunge even further, with the party losing as much as another five percentage points in some surveys and dropping behind the AfD in popularity in the eastern states. In addition, infighting over leadership and ministerial posts further frustrated supporters.\n\nS.P.D. leaders were quick on Sunday to highlight the need to reach out to the one-third of members who voted against the coalition, while also regaining the trust of lost voters.\n\n\u201cAbove all, we must reach out to those who believe the voices telling them that \u2018You have been left behind,\u2019 and show them that we are there for them,\u201d said Dietmar Woidke, the Social Democratic governor of the eastern state of Brandenburg.\n\nThere has been much talk about the lack of a minister from eastern Germany among the cabinet nominees from Ms. Merkel\u2019s conservative party, which bled support to the far-right. Although the Social Democrats have not yet named their candidates for ministerial positions, Mr. Woidke emphasized the importance of including someone from the east, while conceding that one minister alone would not suffice to solve the party\u2019s problem of weakening support there.\n\n\u201cIt would be largely symbolic,\u201d Mr. Woidke said. \u201cBut politics is all about symbolism.\u201d\n\nAfter the election, Ms. Merkel first tried to form a coalition government with the free-market Free Democrats and the Greens, but efforts failed after four weeks of discussions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Christian Democrats took up new negotiations with the Social Democrats, and a coalition agreement emerged in early February. The 179-page document details the main issues to be addressed, such as spending and which party will name ministers to take cabinet posts in the government.\n\nThe Social Democrats walked away with three key portfolios \u2014 the foreign, labor and finance ministries \u2014 which will play a crucial role in coming negotiations over the issue of overhauling the euro currency union.\n\nThose ministries could also offer the Social Democrats a chance to regroup and define their positions in the coming years, after which they would face an election without Ms. Merkel, who has said this term in office will be her last.\n\nBerlin\u2019s neighbors, in the meantime, have been waiting for it to return its focus to the world. Mr. Macron, the French leader, needs Ms. Merkel\u2019s support if he is to help push through ambitious overhauls to protect the euro area against another financial crisis.\n\nBritain wants the chancellor\u2019s attention on talks about the country\u2019s negotiations to leave the European Union, a process known as Brexit. And across Europe, countries rely on German leadership on issues as far-ranging as migration and defense.", "title": "Angela Merkel Averts Crisis, Forming Government With S.P.D. Again", "authors": ["Melissa Eddy", "Katrin Bennhold"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Although Germany is nowhere near the 2 percent of gross domestic product that all NATO countries have agreed to spend on defense (for Germany, about $72 billion), and despite a decaying army at home, Berlin has decided to increase military spending by just $304 million, to about $47 billion a year. \u201cThat money will melt away in maintenance, upgrades, personnel costs and inflation,\u201d said Jan Techau, a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund in Berlin.\n\nAt this year\u2019s Munich Security Conference, Germany\u2019s defense minister, Ursula von der Leyen, tried to assure attendees that Germany was prepared to increase military spending further. But with the Social Democrats who campaigned against more money for the military set to take over the finance ministry in the new government, there is little hope that this will come to pass. What\u2019s more, the coalition agreement also demands that every additional euro spent on defense be matched by foreign development assistance, which further narrows the wiggle room to beef up the military.\n\nTo be fair, in recent years Berlin has shown more readiness to deploy its army abroad, sending it into Mali, Iraq and the Baltics. But after two decades of spending cuts, the German military has reached a breaking point. Four years ago, it drew global derision when soldiers carried broomsticks instead of machine guns during a NATO exercise because of a shortage of equipment.\n\nThe situation is no better today. The German Navy is running out of ships; all but one of its submarines are grounded for lack of replacement parts. A new internal report notes that of the army\u2019s 244 main battle tanks \u2014 already a small number \u2014 only 105 are in working order. The air force is even worse \u2014 it can put only a fourth of its small fleet of Eurofighters and Tornado jets in the air.\n\nGermans like to say the reluctance of Berlin to pull its military weight is a reaction to the horrors of World War II and the subsequent backlash against German militarism. But many Western partners increasingly see this as an easy excuse. In a speech in Berlin in 2011, the foreign minister of Poland, Radoslaw Sikorski, remarked, \u201cI fear German power less than I am beginning to fear German inactivity.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Angela Merkel Is Not the \u2018Leader of the Free World\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "VALENCIA, Venezuela \u2014 The cemetery did not look or smell like a peaceful resting ground for the dead. It felt more like a mass grave, populated with white crosses, buzzing flies, dirt piles and mourners, some wailing, \u201cWhy, why?\u201d\n\nAt least 40 wooden coffins, according to workers, were interred at the cemetery on the outskirts of the industrial city of Valencia in Carabobo State on Friday in hastily organized funerals for victims of one of Venezuela\u2019s most horrific jail fires.\n\nThere were no priests, no religious rituals, few comforting words from Venezuelan officials, who have yet to explain how such carnage could have happened. President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro has not even mentioned it.\n\nAnguished relatives conducted their own makeshift funerals, which were staggered through the day. Cemetery workers and family members lowered coffins three-deep into trenches lined with gray cinderblocks and brown bricks, covering each coffin with concrete like a layer cake.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt least 68 people \u2014 mostly prisoners but some relatives who had been visiting \u2014 died in the police jailhouse fire, which had started as a party run by inmate gangs that got out of control. Precisely who set the fire remains unclear. Many victims, some barely out of their teens, were burned or asphyxiated. Others showed signs that they had been beaten.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFamily members who rushed to the overcrowded jail at news of the fire on Thursday were sprayed with tear gas by security forces, adding outrage to the inexplicable.", "title": "Anguished Mourners Beg for Answers After Jail Fire in Venezuela", "authors": ["Ana Vanessa Herrero"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Anita Shreve, a best-selling author whose novels explored change, loss and troubled marriages, often against the backdrop of a real historical event, died on Thursday at her home in Newfields, N.H. She was 71.\n\nHer publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, said the cause was cancer.\n\nMs. Shreve drew critical acclaim and a large following with books like \u201cThe Weight of Water\u201d (1997), an intricate story involving a long-ago crime and present-day dramas. Susan Kenney, reviewing that book in The New York Times, described it as \u201ca cryptic long-lost narrative inside an impending family tragedy wrapped in a true-crime murder mystery framed by the aftermath of all of the above.\u201d\n\nThe review continued, \u201cMs. Shreve unravels themes of adultery, jealousy, crimes of passion, incest, negligence, loss and guilt, and then manages somehow to knit them all together into an engrossing tale. The book became a 2000 film directed by Kathryn Bigelow.\n\nMany of her books featured women in stressful situations, a setup she found rich in possibilities.\n\n\u201cIn \u2018The Weight of Water\u2019 there\u2019s a line,\u201d she said in an interview last year with WBUR radio, \u201cand it says, \u2018If you push a woman to the edge, how will she behave?\u2019 And that, to me, is a fascinating question.\u201d", "title": "Anita Shreve, 71, Best-Selling Novelist Who Wrote \u2018Weight of Water,\u2019 Is Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Bruni: Does Trump have anywhere, politically, to go? Look at his loss of the popular vote. We\u2019re talking about 77,000 votes in three states. I could argue it\u2019s a fluke he was elected. If he pleases those who elected him, I\u2019m not sure that he gets re-elected, but if he moves as far away from you as you say he has, I still don\u2019t think he can get the people in the middle. Does he really have a political path to survival?\n\nCoulter: That\u2019s a really good point. The hate for him on the left is visceral. Graydon Carter is never going to say, \u201cWell, I have to admit he\u2019s done something right.\u201d The only way he has to go is to go back to the #MAGA agenda.\n\nBruni: But I don\u2019t think that\u2019s enough either.\n\nCoulter: I disagree. I think it would be. A, it\u2019s his only chance, although it may not help Jared and Ivanka be popular in the Hamptons. B, I think he can win independents over. He has not been a fascist. When a court unconstitutionally says he can\u2019t ban immigrants on the basis of national security or what\u2019s good for the country, he complies.\n\nBruni: We have heard and we have written endlessly about Never Trumpers. What are Former Trumpers? If he loses you Former Trumpers permanently, what\u2019s he left with?\n\nCoulter: This is not Never Trumpers. It was very easy to brush aside Jeb Exclamation Point. Charlie Sykes. Bill Kristol. The Former Trumpers are the ones who would die for Trump, who would defend him from anything, who did defend him and blew off the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape \u2014 blew off everything. We kept coming back. He could sell Ivanka Trump merchandise from the Oval Office if he would just build the wall.\n\nIf he doesn\u2019t have us anymore \u2014 that\u2019s what he should be worried about, because, you play those people for suckers? The ones who stood by him through thick and thin and thought this was finally something different? Former Trumpers should put the fear of God in him.", "title": "Opinion | Ann Coulter to Donald Trump: Beware the Former Trumpers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "His mother had had what was then labeled a \u201cnervous breakdown.\u201d Johns Hopkins Hospital didn\u2019t accept Negroes for inpatient psychiatric treatment in the early \u201960s. Crownsville, where gravestones bore numbers, not names, housed Negroes, but that didn\u2019t ring a bell when we talked. Ken did not remember where his mother was treated, just that she was gone for a long time. His father, seldom home, was involved in politics. One night, alone at his dining room table, staring hopelessly at a linear equation, Ken was overwhelmed by a vision: He was on a dock. His white classmates were in a boat. If he could not solve that problem, that very night, the boat would sail off, leaving him behind. He burst into tears. Before dawn, he taught himself the logic of the equation. From then on, he was always top of his class in mathematics. He is a successful scientist now, who in addition to his professional obligations teaches astrophysics to at-risk girls.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBrown v. Board of Education, a recent ruling when I was at Garrison, had been received with ambivalence across the nation. In the South, private religious schools emerged so that white families could dodge sending their children to learn with blacks. At newly integrated schools, fostering collegiality and visibility among students and working toward a more inclusive future was rarely a passionately promoted agenda. You cannot get a good education if you disappear from yourself. Being visible and present is crucial to embracing knowledge.\n\nI graduated from Garrison relatively invisible. I don\u2019t even remember my junior high graduation dress. And then it was time to go to high school.\n\nWestern High School was an all-girls public school near Baltimore\u2019s most cherished historic buildings. When I crossed the threshold for the first time, I saw down the long hallway a petite, elegantly dressed woman with perfect posture. Her diction, as she called out directives, could have cracked crystal. Moving a few steps closer, I saw that she was a Negro and later learned that she was a vice principal. Not unusual now, very unusual then. As I walked a few steps beyond her, I heard, \u201cAren\u2019t you a Smith?\u201d I turned. \u201cYou look just like your mother \u2026 and your father.\u201d\n\nThat was the legendary Essie M. Hughes. She\u2019d been a Latin teacher and had taught generations of Negro children, including my parents and aunts and uncles, in one of the two Negro high schools during the \u201940s and \u201950s. She saw me. I saw her seeing me. Within five minutes of my entering the new school, my invisibility in education was over.\n\nHomeroom seating was alphabetical. In front of me sat a white Jewish girl whose mother was a violinist in the Baltimore Symphony. Until then, the symphony\u2019s musicians were, to me, white and black dots I\u2019d struggled to magnify through binoculars. Yet, when my new classmate and I glanced at each other for the first time, I felt as though I\u2019d known her for a lifetime. The girl behind me, also white (and Catholic), was hilarious. As far as I was concerned, undiscovered forms of hilarity were always welcome.\n\nI like September. Even though it required going back to school, it always filled me with optimism. And my birthday falls in that month. That first year, the violinist\u2019s daughter gave me a book of poems and a card. She signed the card \u201cLove, Ruthie.\u201d She was the first white person in my life who used the word \u201clove\u201d in relation to me. We became close friends, counseling each other until our last gasps of adolescence.\n\nUnlike Garrison, Western was not toxic. I credit its leadership. A commanding triumvirate indeed: Miss Kell, the principal, was a white woman over six feet tall who looked like a mix of George Washington and a Eudora Welty character. Mr. DeWolff, the other vice principal, was a white man with a disability at a time when there were no sloping curbs or much else to aid mobility. Miss Hughes was well traveled, fluent in several languages. She\u2019d grown up when segregation was the norm in much of Baltimore and the surrounding areas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn spite of their personal battles, or perhaps because of them, they provided contours around which dividing lines melted. I experienced the fractured and often bloody \u201960s in an intellectual environment where many voices were heard, many cultures seen. It wasn\u2019t just being visible to myself that made education intoxicating. It was paying attention to the world in the company of those who had different histories, and who followed different paths, that turned on the lights for me.", "title": "Anna Deavere Smith: The First Time a White Person Wrote \u2018Love\u2019 to Me", "authors": ["Anna Deavere Smith", "The First Time"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAnnemarie Lehrmann Hillman and Douglas Joseph Rosenthal were married March 17 at the District Winery in Washington. Judge Amit P. Mehta of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, for whom the bride served as a law clerk, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 32, is a litigation associate in the Washington office of Sidley Austin, the Chicago-based law firm. She graduated cum laude from Yale, and received a law degree, cum laude, from N.Y.U.\n\nShe is a daughter of Ingrid H. Lehrmann of Clifton Park, N.Y., and Paul L. Hillman of Cleverdale, N.Y. The bride\u2019s father owns a group of transportation companies based in Glens Falls, N.Y., bearing his name.\n\nThe groom, 35, is a trial lawyer at the Justice Department in Washington. He graduated from Princeton and received a law degree from Harvard.\n\nHe is the son of Joan K. Rosenthal and Barry P. Rosenthal of Washington. The groom\u2019s mother is a retired social worker in Washington. His father, also a lawyer, retired as the general counsel of the JBG Companies, a real estate investment trust, now known as JBG Smith, based in Washington.\n\nThe couple met in December 2014 at a party given by a mutual friend in Washington, and though they liked each other, they did not act on those feelings. Two months later, on Valentine\u2019s Day 2015, they reconnected in a familiar place: the home of the same mutual friend in Washington who was having yet another party.", "title": "Annemarie Hillman, Douglas Rosenthal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Building owners can, for example, raise rents by charging tenants for buildingwide improvements. Or, if improvements to an individual apartment increase the rent beyond a legal threshold \u2014 currently $2,733.75 \u2014 the apartment can be deregulated. Landlords can also raise so-called preferential rents, a rent below the legal maximum allowed under rent stabilization. Increases in preferential rents don\u2019t fall under city-set limits.\n\n\u201cPreferential rents are very helpful for tenants, but owners have the right to raise those rents,\u201d said Vito Signorile, a spokesman for the Rent Stabilization Association, the biggest landlord lobbyist group in the city.\n\n\u201cFor smaller buildings, it\u2019s very possible that, because of the rent freeze, they couldn\u2019t pay their operating costs, and so they found another way to raise the rents on tenants,\u201d Mr. Signorile said. He said that the 3.1 percent rent growth in 2016 was most likely the result of rent increases on two-year leases, which were not affected by the freeze.\n\nMr. Signorile said that the association would push for an \u201cadequate\u201d rent increase this year that \u201cmakes up for the minor increases and lack thereof\u201d during the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio.\n\nThe board is composed of nine members appointed by the mayor. There are currently three vacant seats, which the mayor aims to fill by the next board meeting on April 5, city officials said.\n\nMayor de Blasio did not publicly back a rent freeze last year, but he advocated freezes in previous years. On Thursday, a spokeswoman for the mayor did not offer any indication of where the mayor stands on a freeze for the coming year.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a data-driven process that is just starting,\u201d Melissa Grace, the spokeswoman, said.\n\nThe median rent for a rent-stabilized apartment in 2016 was $1,182, and the median cost for the landlord to operate the unit was $847, according to the study.", "title": "Annual Battle Over Raising Rents in New York Begins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe N.F.L. is under pressure from falling television ratings, lawsuits over its handling of concussions, and fan opposition to player protests during the national anthem.\n\nYet investors keep lining up to help start new football leagues. On Tuesday, the longtime N.F.L. executive Bill Polian and the television and movie producer Charlie Ebersol became the latest entrepreneurs to join the fray when they unveiled plans for the Alliance of American Football.\n\nThere have been several short-lived football leagues before, including the United Football League, United States Football League and XFL. Like others before them, Polian and Ebersol say they have a formula for success. They have acquired investments from Silicon Valley firms that will allow their eight-team league to start playing a week after the Super Bowl in February 2019. Their partners include CBS, which will show a few games on its main channel and some on its cable network. They will also launch a smartphone app on which fans will be able to stream games and play fantasy football.\n\nThe league will also aim for two-and-a-half hour games (N.F.L. games generally last at least three hours). To achieve that, there will be no kickoffs or extra points \u2014 only 2-point plays \u2014 and a 30-second play clock, as opposed to the N.F.L.\u2019s 45-second clock. There will also be no television timeouts, which will lead to about 60 percent fewer commercials.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEbersol, whose father, Dick Ebersol, ran NBC Sports for many years and was involved in the old XFL, said each team would be owned by the league, which would reduce the likelihood of teams being sold and of infighting among owners about the direction of the business. The league will also draw from the pool of undrafted college players and others who are not on an N.F.L. roster.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is not a development league,\u201d Ebersol said. \u201cThere are tens of thousands of players who don\u2019t have a job, which translates into hundreds of Kurt Warners\u201d \u2014 a reference to the quarterback who spent time playing in the indoor Arena Football League before putting together a Hall of Famer career in the N.F.L.\n\nEbersol declined to say whether the league would receive a media rights fee from CBS. But he said there was enough funding to get the league on its feet. He said the league would appeal to the tens of millions of fans who play fantasy football but must stop playing once the N.F.L. season ends.", "title": "Another New Football League Says It Will Start Play in 2019", "authors": ["Ken Belson"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Anselm Kiefer, the German artist known for his monumental paintings and installations layering history, culture, religion and mythology, will create his first ever site-specific outdoor public sculpture in the United States this spring at Rockefeller Center in New York.\n\nThe piece, commissioned by the Public Art Fund and the real-estate company Tishman Speyer, will open on May 2. \u201cAn artist of his stature \u2014 you almost don\u2019t think to even ask,\u201d said Nicholas Baume, the fund\u2019s director and chief curator.\n\nAfter initiating a conversation in 2010, Mr. Baume spent several years scouting locations across New York with Mr. Kiefer, now 73 and based in France, before the artist decided on the well-trafficked spot just off Fifth Avenue at the head of the Channel Gardens \u2014 with a backdrop of 30 Rockefeller Plaza and diagonal to St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral.\n\n\u201cKiefer\u2019s work is very much about the mythic, and Rockefeller Center \u2014 born out of the ashes of the Depression \u2014 has that dimension,\u201d said Mr. Baume.", "title": "Anselm Kiefer Sculpture Will Go Up at Rockefeller Center", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "THE CRACKLING CURRENT of private anxiety running through all of Pope.L\u2019s work is most evident in the Flint project. \u201cI grew up in the welfare system, and there was a lot of shame involved,\u201d he says, as we stop by the Greater Holy Temple church, one of Flint\u2019s water crisis help centers, which is managed by Williams\u2019s aunt Sandra Jones. \u201cThere was a lot of not wanting to look at your condition \u2014 and nobody else wants to look at it, so there\u2019s a lot of isolation. There\u2019s a blindness there too, because back then I only thought black people did welfare. But everybody is hiding stuff.\u201d Flint\u2019s population is more than half African-American, but many of the families we see lined up for water that day are white. \u201cThe shame, and the lack of agency, because you don\u2019t think you can change your situation \u2014 that part really sticks out at me. They drive up to the water, and even if they\u2019ve got a smile on their faces, they\u2019re kind of beaten down.\u201d\n\nPope.L was raised by a single mother in and around Newark; his distinctive last name melds his father\u2019s surname with her initial, L, for Lancaster \u2014 a feminist gesture before hyphenating became a norm. A nurse who had once aspired to a career in journalism (he recalls finding her press credentials once, for a Galveston newspaper), she lugged a massive bookcase packed with books whenever they moved, which was often. \u201cI really admire her,\u201d he says. \u201cShe was an alcoholic and an addict, and I guess there are a lot of things you could say made her not likable, but she was really smart \u2014 and with some guys, that could be a problem,\u201d alluding to the sounds of violence coming from behind closed bedroom doors that he\u2019d hear as a child at night.\n\nIt was his grandmother who decided he should become an artist, buying him used art supplies and taking him and his older brother to Manhattan\u2019s art museums for shows, most memorably, Jacob Lawrence\u2019s 1940-41 \u201cMigration\u201d series, which depicts the mass movement of African-Americans from the rural south to northern cities. \u201cI think she really wanted to go and we were her excuse,\u201d he says. \u201cIt\u2019s scary going in those places by yourself, but with two little kids . . .\u201d As he tells it, his grandmother never thought of herself as an artist, but she showed her Rousseau-inspired appliqu\u00e9s of birds and flora at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 1973. She did installation work too, of a kind, maintaining a garden in the lot across the street from her home on West 136th Street. One summer, she decided to grow cotton, which seems in retrospect the kind of installation Pope.L himself might make, and in fact it became something of a local attraction: Schoolchildren would come to see the plant they\u2019d read about in history books, the one their ancestors had been brought to this country in shackles to pick.\n\nOver lunch at a Detroit diner, I ask Pope.L if he considers himself a provocateur, and he immediately says no, then reconsiders. \u201cMaybe there is a kind of strategic use to provocation. People are so dulled by what they have to put themselves through to get through the day, maybe you do have to mess with them. But after that, what is there?\u201d He\u2019s taught performance since the early \u201990s \u2014 he\u2019s currently an assistant professor in the department of visual arts at the University of Chicago, a job he took in 2010 to be closer to his son, whose mother is a professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago \u2014 and tells his students, \u201cIf you\u2019re going to cut off your big toe, just cut off the other one while you\u2019re at it. You have to be able to think beyond the immediate impulse to do the far-out thing. You should be able to answer the question: Why do you want to do that?\u201d", "title": "Answering Society\u2019s Thorniest Questions, With Performance Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The rumors were true. Mr. Acevedo and about 280 of his fellow prisoners were soon evacuated and taken on a forced march south \u2014 \u201cthe death march from Bataan couldn\u2019t be worse than this,\u201d he wrote \u2014 with artillery fire exploding around them and fighters of the Army Air Forces dropping bombs. The war in Europe was near its end. But the P.O.W.s appeared no closer to freedom.\n\nApril 13 \u2014 Bad news for us. \u2014 President Roosevelt\u2019s death \u2014 We all felt bad about it \u2014 We held a prayer service for the Repose of his Soul. \u2014 Burdeski died today.\n\nApril 19 \u2014 More of our men died \u2014 so fast that you couldn\u2019t keep track of their numbers. We kept on marching.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Acevedo was liberated later that month but suffered for decades from night terrors and post-traumatic stress syndrome. On Feb. 11, he died at the Veterans Affairs hospital in Loma Linda, Calif., having bequeathed his written testimony to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in 2010. He was 93.\n\nMr. Acevedo appears to be the first Mexican-American registered in the museum\u2019s database of survivors and victims.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis son Fernando, who confirmed the death, said that Mr. Acevedo had had congestive heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. But the torture he endured at Berga, he added, had left a lasting impact on his father\u2019s health.\n\nIn December, Fernando Acevedo said, he found in his father\u2019s military records a psychiatric evaluation that further confirmed his suffering. After an initial interrogation at Berga, he was raped while other captors laughed at him.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Papi, I found this,\u2019 \u201d Fernando recalled telling his father. \u201cHe looked at it and his eyes got big. He said: \u2018I\u2019m glad you did. I want you to tell everybody about it.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAnthony Claude Acevedo was born in San Bernardino, Calif., on July 31, 1924. His father, Francisco Guillermo Acevedo, was an engineer. His mother, the former Maria Louisa Contreras Limantur, a homemaker, died when Anthony was 2 years old.\n\nYoung Anthony attended a segregated school in Pasadena with other Mexican-American children until he was 13; he and his five siblings then left for the state of Durango, Mexico, when his father and stepmother, the former Maria Louisa Morgan, were deported because they had lacked the proper immigration papers.\n\nAnthony\u2019s father found success in Durango, where he became the director of public works. But he was physically and emotionally abusive to Anthony, Fernando Acevedo said in a telephone interview. And after a United States government representative contacted him to serve in the war, Anthony, who \u201cwanted to get away from his father,\u201d crossed the border and was inducted into the Army.\n\nInterested in being a doctor, he trained as a medic at Camp Adair, near Corvallis, Ore., before shipping to Europe with the 70th Infantry Division to fight the Germans in the Battle of the Bulge. Among the \u201crepair jobs\u201d he performed in combat were \u201csewing thumbs, cutting a leg off, putting on tourniquets and sewing up the stump of a leg,\u201d he told the Holocaust museum in a 2010 oral history interview.\n\nOn Jan. 6, 1945, he and other men from his unit were captured by German troops. \u201cThey forced us to take our shoes off \u2014 boots off \u2014 and walk down the slope, barefoot in the snow, and march for a mile to the trucks,\u201d he told the museum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was taken to Stalag IX-B, an overcrowded and notoriously unhygienic P.O.W. camp near the spa town of Bad Orb, Germany. Not long after his arrival, Mr. Acevedo was among 350 Jews and so-called undesirables selected for shipment to Berga.\n\n\u201cThey put us on a train, and we traveled six days and six nights,\u201d he told CNN in 2008. \u201cIt was a boxcar that would fit heads of cattle. They had us 80 to a boxcar.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThey arrived at Berga on Feb. 8. The P.O.W.s were fed tiny rations of bread made of sawdust, ground glass and barley, and soup made from cats and rats. Prisoners who tried to escape were shot in their foreheads with wooden bullets. He and the other medics in the barracks were told to fill the bullet holes with wax.\n\nMr. Acevedo began writing in the diary on March 20 (\u201cYesterday our planes dropped leaflets as well as bombs\u201d), and he alternated accounts of horrors with quotidian observations (\u201cThe weather is beautiful and it looks like spring, which has finally come to Germany\u201d), good news (\u201cThis morning us medics got together and ate Scrambled Eggs & Sausage from our Red Cross Boxes\u201d) and biting humor (\u201cLenten Fast ends at Noon today \u2014 But does not apply to us we have been fasting since December 31, 1944\u201d).\n\nHe extended the ink in his pen by adding snow and urine. He hid the diary in his pants or under hay in the barracks.\n\nAnd, as dozens of prisoners died on the terrifying three-week-long march, Mr. Acevedo continued to write.\n\nIn one entry, he wrote about Burdeski, a 41-year-old prisoner who had diphtheria. Mr. Acevedo wanted to use his pen as a tracheotomy tube to save him.\n\n\u201cThe Germans did not let us so we got upset,\u201d he wrote on April 13. \u201cWe said they were going to kill him and the German guard swung his rifle at me and my buddy hitting us with the butt in the face\u201d and \u201ccracked one of my jaw\u2019s tooth and swung back at my buddy his glasses dropped. The German guard crushed them with his foot \u2014 Burdeski did not survive to the hospital.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn April 23, Mr. Acevedo and other prisoners were freed; he weighed just 87 pounds. They had been in a barn, and most of the guards had fled. But one \u201ccame up to us and gave himself up and saying that we were free,\u201d he wrote. \u201cBoy everything looked to exciting that morning.\u201d\n\nAnd, he added, \u201cour last death was announced.\u201d\n\nThe diary was not a secret to his family, and neither were his struggles with PTSD. The book, with its yellowing pages, became a sort of plaything at home, with crayon scribblings by his children on the last page. But it was a major acquisition for the Holocaust museum, which has more than 200 diaries in its collection from various locations, written in 18 languages.\n\n\u201cIt was the first written by an American citizen held in a concentration camp,\u201d Kyra Schuster, a museum curator, said in a telephone interview. Publicity from Mr. Acevedo\u2019s donation led three other Berga P.O.W.s, or their families, to give their wartime diaries to the museum.\n\n\u201cThe four men had four different experiences that cover different things,\u201d Ms. Schuster said. One was written on scraps of paper, another behind family photographs, and the other was a second diary that had arrived in the same Red Cross package as Mr. Acevedo\u2019s.\n\nMr. Acevedo aspired to become a doctor after his discharge \u2014 and he sutured his children\u2019s wounds at home with supplies from an old-fashioned black doctor\u2019s bag \u2014 but he never did. He worked for North American Rockwell, McDonnell Douglas and Hughes Aircraft as a design engineer.\n\nIn addition to Fernando, Mr. Acevedo is survived by two other sons, Ernesto and Anthony; a daughter, Rebeca Acevedo-Carlin; six grandchildren; a sister, Estella; and two brothers, Billy and Augustin. His first marriage, to Amparo Martinez, ended in divorce. His second wife, the former Maria Dolores Lamb, died in 2014.\n\nMr. Acevedo risked his life by keeping his diary. But, he said, he had an obligation to maintain it.\n\n\u201cHe said he had faith that he\u2019d make it,\u201d Fernando Acevedo said, \u201cand that hopefully one day people would see what the men went through.\u201d", "title": "Anthony Acevedo, Who Documented His Holocaust Ordeal, Dies at 93", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThousands Walk Out of Class, Urging Action on Gun Control\u201d (front page, March 15):\n\nI am filled with hope. I cheer you, our children, as you shame us into addressing the increasing gun violence that is taking your lives. Stay strong.\n\nIn 1980 one mother got MADD. She could make sense of the death of her child only by fighting to stop drunken driving. In a few years it became unacceptable to drive drunk.\n\nYour voices will make a difference. Students from one school, then from one state and on Wednesday from across the country stood up and demanded action. Your voices, and soon your votes, will give members of Congress the support they need to act for the benefit of their constituents rather than for the benefit of their gun lobby donors.\n\nYou, the youth of America, are fighting for your lives. Fight now with your voices and soon with your votes, in every election, local and national. We, your hapless elders, can only stand in awe and support you as you achieve what we cannot.", "title": "Opinion | Anti-Gun Protest: Elders, Time to Listen and to Act", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The leaders of an anti-Muslim extremist group in Britain have been found guilty of hate crimes and sentenced to prison, months after they drew international attention for helping President Trump get entangled in a diplomatic dispute with British leaders.\n\nA judge in Folkestone Magistrates\u2019 Court on Wednesday convicted Paul Golding, the leader of the group, Britain First, of one count of religiously aggravated harassment, and Jayda Fransen, the deputy leader, of three counts of the same offense. Mr. Golding was sentenced to 18 weeks in prison, and Ms. Fransen to 36 weeks.\n\nThe two were convicted over posting videos online of their harassment of Muslims in May 2017, at the same time as a trial of three Muslim men and a teenager who were accused and later convicted of raping a 16-year-old girl.\n\nBritain First, estimated to have about 1,000 members, was little known outside the country until November, when Mr. Trump tweeted links to anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim videos made by the group, some of which were misleading.", "title": "Anti-Muslim Extremists Retweeted by Trump Are Convicted of Hate Crimes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Other Labour lawmakers seemed worried, too.\n\nThe crisis deepened with news on Thursday of the resignation of Christine Shawcroft, the chair of Labour\u2019s internal disputes panel, after the leak of an email suggesting that she had lent support to a council candidate suspended after accusations of anti-Semitism.\n\nComing after criticism of Mr. Corbyn\u2019s reluctance to blame Moscow for the poisoning attack on a Russian former spy and his daughter in Salisbury, England, the issue has recharged a bitter argument about his leadership. That, in turn, has led Mr. Corbyn\u2019s supporters to complain of a politically motivated plot to destabilize his position because of his left-wing politics.\n\nBut there is little doubt that the atmosphere in the Labour Party has changed. A veteran of left-wing struggles, Mr. Corbyn learned his politics fighting apartheid in South Africa and campaigning against what he saw as Western militarism and neo-imperialism. While many of those battles have been won, the plight of the Palestinians remains a sore point on the left, one deepened by the hard-line policies of the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\nAt the same time, the Labour Party\u2019s membership has grown bigger and more diverse, while Momentum, a campaign that promotes Mr. Corbyn\u2019s radical brand of politics, has emerged as a powerful force, tilting the political balance further to the left.\n\nThis is not the first time that Mr. Corbyn\u2019s party has faced allegations of anti-Semitism. In 2016, one lawmaker, Naz Shah, was temporarily suspended for sharing a graphic showing an outline of Israel superimposed on a map of the United States, suggesting the relocation of Israel to North America.\n\nWhen the former mayor of London, Ken Livingstone \u2014 a longstanding ally of Mr. Corbyn \u2014 tried to defend Ms. Shah, he instead poured gasoline on the flames by arguing that, in 1932, Adolf Hitler \u201cwas supporting Zionism before he went mad and ended up killing six million Jews.\u201d\n\nAfter that crisis, Mr. Corbyn commissioned an inquiry, led by Shami Chakrabarti, a leading human rights campaigner, which concluded that Labour was not overrun by anti-Semitism but acknowledged that there was an \u201coccasionally toxic atmosphere\u201d in the party.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe mere fact that the party was having such a discussion would have been all but unthinkable in days past.\n\n\u201cLabour has a very strong tradition of support for Zionism and Israel,\u201d said June Edmunds, a lecturer in sociology at the University of Sussex. That, she added, was \u201cbased on the formative impact of the genocide of the Jews on the postwar generation as well as the view that Jewish nationalism represented a form of anti-colonialism.\u201d\n\nOpinion began shifting after the Arab-Israeli War in 1967, though it was the Sabra and Shatila massacre in 1982 that generated sharper criticism of Israel alongside growing sympathy for Palestinian refugees in Lebanon, Ms. Edmunds said. Events in Gaza and Israeli settlement policy have only added to those feelings.\n\nCriticism of Israeli policy is, of course, not the same thing as anti-Semitism, though, as Ms. Edmunds put it, \u201cthere can be overlaps \u2014 within Labour and other parties \u2014 between anti-Zionism and anti-Semitism.\u201d\n\nAnd anti-Semitism in wider society has deep roots, as the archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, acknowledged in evidence to a parliamentary select committee inquiry into the issue.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe had a shameful record until very recently, in historical terms,\u201d he said, \u201cEngland was the first European country to expel Jewish people, in 1290, with their exile lasting for 350 years.\u201d\n\nNowadays, the insidious anti-Semitism of the British establishment has given way to something more overt. Reported anti-Semitic incidents in Britain have increased, the select committee report noted, accelerated by social media. Ms. Berger has released a snapshot of some of the abuse she has received, including Twitter posts likening her to a pig and calling for her head to be put on a spike. One read, \u201cwaking up and remembering you\u2019re a Jew must be a horrid start to one\u2019s day.\u201d\n\nNevertheless, the majority of anti-Semitic abuse and crime \u201chas historically been, and continues to be, committed by individuals associated with (or motivated by) far right-wing parties and political activity,\u201d the report said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
