View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nROWLEY Tom Sachs is another person that we met after I had known his work. We have a mutual love of Sharpies and Foamcore and making everything yourself.\n\nPOWERS These are Tom Sachs sneakers he did as the \u201cMars Yard Shoe,\u201d and his Tiffany handgun [on the bookshelf]. This is a Tom Sachs Leica camera, but it\u2019s cast bronze. He said when he was a kid, the first piece of art he made was a Nikon camera in shop class because he couldn\u2019t afford a real Nikon. It was an artist inventing something they wanted.\n\nThere\u2019s probably a Richard Prince on every floor. He\u2019s a friend. I gave this bra painting [on the shelf] by him to Cynthia for Valentine\u2019s Day two years ago \u2014 it\u2019s lingerie but you can\u2019t ever wear it. It\u2019s an actual bra.\n\nROWLEY It\u2019s my size, too!", "title": "Art Was There, Through Courtship, Love and Labor", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets", "Show Us Your Wall"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "It is a hot ticket. Admission costs $15 and there is timed entry to control the influx to 60 people per session and not exceed the gallery\u2019s 400-person capacity. Sessions are typically sold out with a waiting list. An immersive-interactive installation featuring Noirflux celebrating traditional Japanese themes, such as cherry blossoms and Koi, will be presented at the museum starting on March 15 to coincide with the National Cherry Blossom Festival in the city.\n\nArtechouse is open during installations until 10:30 p.m. on weekdays and 11:30 p.m. on weekends. The after-hours appeal is a bar area overlooking the exhibits that teems with millennials taking selfies and posting to Instagram, often holding an augmented reality cocktail \u2014 one that superimposes a computer-generated image above the rim of the glass \u2014 using their smartphones and the Artechouse app.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cA lot of museums close up at 5, but we wanted to create an evening environment where you can come on a date, like you would performing arts, or the theater,\u201d Mr. Kereselidze said. \u201cMuseums are there to preserve. We are here to present. The exhibit is exactly the same in the evening, only you see the adults acting like kids.\u201d\n\nAt Artechouse, art has \u201cno limits and takes all forms,\u201d Ms. Pastukhova said. \u201cWe wanted to create an environment where artists can push the limits and are inspired to create new artworks.\u201d This year, there will be a revolving stream of eight major immersive, multimedia installations exhibited for one to two months each, in addition to side-gallery ones.\n\nArtechouse\u2019s space is designed and configured to make it easy for artists to help pull the visitor in. \u201cThe magic is what the person experiences interacting with the art,\u201d said Lorne Covington, Noirflux\u2019s creative director and principal. \u201cMost art is an object or a thing. We work with something that is intangible \u2014 that direct experience.\u201d\n\nVisitors to Artechouse become part of the display. \u201cIf it\u2019s working right, it\u2019s working like a good dance partner,\u201d Mr. Covington said. \u201cYou don\u2019t want someone just mimicking your moves, but to respond to you and surprise you back, so you wind up in a give-and-take dance.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis kind of activity demands a big space like Artechouse, which provides lighting systems and 17 hanging projectors hidden carefully from the public eye.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe elusive combination of art and technology is enticing in this era of the selfie. \u201cThese big, bold, immersive installations are ones that have a sense of wonderment about them and that notion of spectacle, that sense of being overwhelmed by the work, is very conducive to a social media presence,\u201d said Edward Saywell, chief of exhibitions strategy and gallery displays at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.\n\nAs museums around the world are grappling with what their role is and how to attract new audiences, it comes down to making connections with visitors, he said. \u201cThe power of art is to wake us up \u2014 it is to change us.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, art schools have exploded with a new group of artists who are doing interactive art of a digital nature, said George Fifield, director of Boston Cyberarts, a gallery that regularly includes interactive art in its exhibitions. \u201cAt its best, with this art form, the audience never knows about the computer,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is not about the computer. The art is interacting with your own body and making magic happen.\u201d\n\nMuseums should be \u201ccreating a sense of wonder not just conveying information,\u201d Mr. Covington said. \u201cWe think that is the future of all museums \u2014 not just Artechouse.\u201d", "title": "Artechouse Lights Up Washington\u2019s Museum Scene", "authors": ["Kerry Hannon"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s just a direct price advantage that shows up on customers\u2019 receipts,\u201d Mr. Davis said. \u201cYou never want to end up in the situation where the companies you\u2019re offering better deals to are the ones that don\u2019t even have roots in your community.\u201d\n\nAmazon says it collects taxes in every jurisdiction where it is required to do so, and Mr. Davis\u2019s report found that the company does collect local taxes in most states. But a hodgepodge of state laws govern tax collection, meaning there isn\u2019t a simple solution for municipalities that are now left out.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor example, sales tax rules based on the location of the seller may be impossible to enforce if the company has no physical presence in that jurisdiction. And smaller online retailers can escape collecting sales taxes in more places than Amazon does \u2014 even when they use Amazon to sell their products.\n\nAmazon is facing increasing scrutiny over its tax policies. Despite being one of the largest retailers in the country by revenue, Amazon pays relatively little in federal income tax, largely because of its low profit margins. Until several years ago, Amazon also collected little in state sales taxes, and in most states still does not collect taxes on goods sold on its platform by third parties. (Amazon collects taxes on such third-party sales in Washington State, and agreed this month to begin doing so in Pennsylvania.) The company has also faced criticism for requesting tax incentives from state and local governments to lure Amazon facilities, including its planned second headquarters.\n\nMr. Davis, however, said his findings were less the fault of Amazon than of state tax systems that don\u2019t require, and in some cases don\u2019t allow, online retailers to collect local taxes. He said states rushed to strike deals with Amazon without always ensuring that local governments would benefit as well.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just been overshadowed by the state issue,\u201d Mr. Davis said. \u201cIt\u2019s smaller dollars at play, but for these communities, it\u2019s dollars that matter.\u201d\n\nAmazon sometimes collects taxes where other online retailers do not. In Chicago, for example, Amazon collects local taxes because it has warehouses and other facilities in Illinois; online retailers that don\u2019t have a physical presence in the state generally don\u2019t have to collect taxes there.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUsually it is states \u2014 not cities or counties \u2014 that decide who has to collect local sales taxes. In most states, taxes are based on the location of the buyer, and retailers are required to collect local sales taxes alongside state taxes. But in some states, including New Mexico, taxes are based on the location of the seller, meaning there is no mechanism for collecting taxes from sellers that don\u2019t have a physical presence in the area. Other states have other legal quirks that affect local tax collections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThose loopholes have existed for years, but their significance has grown greatly with the rise of online retail, said Scott Peterson, vice president of government relations as Avalara, a company that helps retailers calculate and collect sales taxes.\n\n\u201cThis huge hole that exists in the sales tax structure has been known for a long time,\u201d Mr. Peterson said. \u201cTheir laws have not kept up.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA pending Supreme Court case, South Dakota v. Wayfair Inc., could change the legal landscape, but not necessarily simplify it. Depending on the outcome, the case could pave the way for states to require companies to collect sales taxes even if they don\u2019t have a location in the state. But local governments in Pennsylvania, New Mexico and other states still wouldn\u2019t be able to collect taxes without help from their legislatures.\n\nLocal government officials in many parts of the country say the rise of tax-free online shopping has had a big impact on their budgets. Albuquerque, for example, relies on the sales tax \u2014 or what is known in New Mexico as a gross receipts tax \u2014 for nearly two-thirds of its general fund revenue, which totaled about $500 million last year. The city\u2019s finance department estimates that it lost out on $5 million in tax revenue on Amazon purchases in 2016, although calculations are difficult because of a lack of available data. Lost revenue from other online retailers adds millions of dollars more.\n\nMr. Keller, the mayor, said Amazon benefited from city services, such as the roads used by delivery trucks carrying its packages and the police officers who makes sure packages aren\u2019t stolen. But unlike local retailers, the company doesn\u2019t chip in.\n\n\u201cThis is the fundamental way we fund American society, and thanks to technology they found a way to opt out of that,\u201d Mr. Keller said. \u201cThey\u2019re getting a free ride.\u201d\n\nFor businesses, the practical effect of that free ride is probably small, at least outside of a handful of high-tax jurisdictions. Local sales taxes add just 1 or 2 percent to prices in most cities, not enough to sway most shoppers\u2019 decisions. But retailers said the tax was a matter of fairness: Why should local businesses be at a disadvantage, however small, against a much larger, out-of-town rival?\n\n\u201cThe 2 percent doesn\u2019t drive someone from my place to Amazon, but it doesn\u2019t help,\u201d said Richard de Wyngaert, owner of Head House Books, an independent bookstore in Philadelphia. \u201cI just feel that if not all businesses, why any business? If we don\u2019t all pay taxes, why should any of us? To me, it\u2019s ludicrous. There is a social contract with your citizens.\u201d\n\nCandelora Versace, who with her husband runs a custom jewelry shop in Santa Fe, N.M., said that her customers frequently buy gemstones online, then come into the store to have them put into settings. She said that she doubted they were explicitly trying to avoid paying Santa Fe\u2019s roughly 3 percent sales, but that regardless of their intent, the effect on the community was the same.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe roads don\u2019t pay themselves. The schools don\u2019t fund themselves,\u201d Ms. Versace said. \u201cWhen they don\u2019t want to pay the tax, it cheats us. It cheats those of us who live here and have businesses here.\u201d", "title": "As Amazon Steps Up Tax Collections, Some Cities Are Left Out", "authors": ["Ben Casselman"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The incentives were most common in three of the borough\u2019s most expensive neighborhoods \u2014 Dumbo, Downtown Brooklyn and Fort Greene \u2014 each of which offered concessions on more than 80 percent of known leases in January. The analysis doesn\u2019t capture the whole market, Mr. Miller said, because unlike sales, leases are not public record and developers are motivated to keep their numbers close to the vest.\n\n\u201cDevelopers want to maintain their listing prices, and then futz with the numbers behind the scenes,\u201d said Paul Johansen, an associate broker with CORE Real Estate. \u201cA couple years ago, there were no concessions whatsoever.\u201d\n\nThat hasn\u2019t deterred builders from moving forward with thousands of new units, most of them geared toward the luxury market. In 2017, more than 5,700 rentals hit the market \u2014 the most units in a year since 2008, said Nancy Packes, the real estate consultant. And the future pipeline shows no signs of slowing: About 6,100 units are expected this year, followed by almost 9,600 in 2019.\n\nMs. Packes, whose clients include Brooklyn developers, said the surge in supply is cyclic, with the glut clearing out by 2019 or 2020. \u201cThey\u2019re looking at the trees, not the forest,\u201d she said about growth skeptics, noting that demand remains strong, fueled by a strong job market and population growth.\n\nFor renters accustomed to Manhattan prices, Brooklyn can still seem like a relative bargain. After concessions, the median rent price in Manhattan was $3,168 in February, Mr. Miller said; in Brooklyn, it was $2,632.\n\nEileen Norton, 28, who works for IBM\u2019s Watson Health division, is in a two-year lease at the Hub for a one-bedroom apartment, where she lives with her boyfriend Kevin Gallagher, 29, an accountant. The couple effectively pays around $3,350 a month, after calculating the two free months of rent. (Smaller one-beds started at $3,000.) They also received five months of free amenities \u2014 including the pool and gym \u2014 that typically cost $75 a month, per person. Almost 90 percent of the Hub\u2019s market-rate apartments are studios or one-bedrooms and seem geared toward young professionals, which could explain why the children\u2019s playroom was impeccably clean, and empty, on a recent tour.", "title": "As Brooklyn Towers Soar, a Sinking Feeling for Developers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Cut out of five blocks of corundum, the watch case and caseback took a month to machine, Mr. Rosillo said. Sandwiched between those two sapphire elements, the components of the skeleton movement, made of solid gold or colored brass, are visible from all angles.\n\n\u201cThe sapphire elements are cut like a gemstone to let the light bounce off their facets,\u201d Mr. Rosillo said. \u201cThis is the closest a watch case has come to a princess-cut diamond.\u201d\n\nThe BR-X1 Skeleton is the fourth in a series of sapphire watches that Bell & Ross has produced, \u201cfor the love of the art,\u201d as Mr. Rosillo put it. The experiments appear to have paid off, as all the previous models have sold out, even though prices ranged from 450,000 euros (today, $551,180) for the BR-X1 Chronograph Tourbillon Sapphire produced in 2016, to \u20ac59,000 for the BR-X2 Tourbillon Micro-Rotor.\n\n\u201cWe were surprised to see the watches sell at these price points because that is not our core business,\u201d Mr. Rosillo said. \u201cBut we were addressing a new type of client who wants a watch that is unique and yet is discreet about how much is on his wrist.\u201d The brand\u2019s watches generally sell for less than \u20ac5,000.\n\nThe new BR-X1 Skeleton is available in an edition of six, the single rose-gold version priced at \u20ac450,000, and five with brass movement components in different colors, priced at \u20ac350,000 euros each.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe blue version of the watch will be displayed at Baselworld but is available exclusively online at Mr. Porter, and its buyer may have the option of being flown privately to Geneva to collect the watch and meet Mr. Rosillo and the watchmaker who worked on the timepiece.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOwning this watch will be a complete experience in luxury from start to finish,\u201d Mr. Rosillo said.\n\n\n\nOther watchmakers also hope to impress buyers and collectors with their creations using the translucent material.\n\nCartier\u2019s R\u00e9v\u00e9lation d\u2019une Panth\u00e8re, introduced in January, has 900 loose beads suspended in oil inside a watch case made of its patented sapphire glass. When the watch is tilted, the beads slowly slide down, mimicking the action of an hourglass, to reveal the panther\u2019s head image against the black, red or green lacquer dial.\n\n\n\n\u201cThis watch was five years in development to achieve the falling of the beads in reaction to the movement of the wearer\u2019s wrist,\u201d said Pierre Rainero, Cartier\u2019s director of image, style and heritage. \u201cWe obtained two patents for this piece: one for the sapphire and the other for the fluid inside that is completely invisible and regulates the speed with which the beads drop inside the case.\u201d\n\nIn the 1930s and \u201940s, Cartier was admired for its desk clocks in which the mechanism seemed to float inside a sapphire case, using a technique invented in the 19th century. This year, Louis Vuitton took that technical prowess a step further with its Tambour Moon Myst\u00e9rieuse Flying Tourbillon, in which the tourbillon seems to float inside the clear case and the crown has no visible connection to the winding mechanism.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat is new here is that both the movement and the winding mechanism are invisible,\u201d said Hamdi Chatti, vice president of the house\u2019s watches and jewelry division. \u201cAll their components are made of sapphire. Inside, five separate sapphire discs, all perfectly fitted together, operate the movement, two of which support the hands, and nothing about this mechanism is visible.\n\n\u201cThe result is magical and our watchmakers had a lot of fun with this very complex assembly,\u201d he said.\n\nAlso this year, HYT, the independent Swiss watch brand known for the liquid activity inside its watches, reshaped its flat sapphire crystal to a bell-jar shaped dome. The brand said the shape, which now sits atop both the H0 Gold and H2O models, improved the view of the flow of fluids that indicate the passage of time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe revisited the design of the sapphire glass to give a fuller, three-dimensional view of time\u201d and better reflect the brand\u2019s aesthetics, said HYT\u2019s chief executive, Gr\u00e9gory Dourde. \u201cThe sapphire glass now fits over the watch like a laboratory bell jar.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGreubel Forsey wanted an unimpeded view of the titanium globe that is part of their watch, so the Swiss independent watchmaking duo designed a sapphire glass that combines the bezel and the glass into a single oddly shaped piece.\n\n\u201cWe now have full visibility of the globe thanks to this complex piece of sapphire that allows the wearer to track the globe\u2019s full revolution in 24 hours,\u201d said Stephen Forsey, co-founder of the brand. \u201cWe have been testing sapphire elements for over a decade now and have a real savoir-faire in the subject.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn addition to the globe and its universal time indication, the watch displays three time zones on its face, and 24 cities with summer and winter times on the reverse.\n\nAt MB&F, a sapphire case and internal sapphire discs were used in its MoonMachine 2. The timepiece, introduced in January, was inspired by the Can-Am racecars of the 1960s and \u201970s and made in collaboration with the Finnish watchmaker Stepan Sarpaneva.\n\n\u201cThe sapphire glass was designed like the windshield of a car,\u201d said Charris Yadigaroglou, head of communication at the Swiss watchmaker. \u201cIt is an intrinsic element of the case; it is cut flush with the sides and not encased, so that it can be integral part of the timepiece.\u201d\n\nAnd, he added, \u201cthe sapphire inside works as an optical prism to transmit the reading of the hours and minutes onto the \u2018headlights\u2019 display of the watch and not the face.\u201d\n\nOne pioneer in sapphire use, Richard Mille, has long been working on improving the shock resistance of the crystals and lessening their weight, as seen in his RM 056 Sapphire Tourbillon Split Seconds Chronograph, introduced in 2012, and both the RM 56-01 and RM 56-02 models. The sapphire in the latter required more than 1,000 hours of machining and polishing, a process that caused so many crystals to crack that it was limited to 10 pieces, priced at $2.02 million each.\n\nThis year, Mr. Mille has tackled a new challenge with the RM 53-01, designed in partnership with the Argentine polo player Pablo Mac Donough.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mac Donough was in Geneva in January for the introduction of the RM 53-01 at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie. With an X-ray image of his skull projected on a screen behind him, Mr. Mac Donough explained that he was once hit above the eye with a polo mallet.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn polo, you can get hit by a mallet, a flying ball or fall under a horse,\u201d Mr. Mac Donough said. \u201cYou forget who you are when you take a hit.\u201d\n\nAfter two years of research and testing in collaboration with Stettler Sapphire, a Swiss sapphire maker, Mr. Mille came up with a laminated sapphire crystal that promises to keep the watch\u2019s mechanism visible and shield the delicate tourbillon inside its Carbon TPT (thin ply technology) case against the impact of a mallet or a polo ball hitting it at 200 miles per hour.\n\n\u201cWe wanted a watch capable of resisting all types of shock in a polo match while leaving the movement visible,\u201d said Salvador Arbona, the brand\u2019s technical director for movements, who described how the sapphire crystal was tested with a pendulum using a 10-pound weight.\n\n\u201cThis glass is basically indestructible,\u201d Mr. Arbona said. \u201cIt is made of two layers of sapphire assembled with a thin sheet of polyvinyl. The sapphire could crack but it will not shatter and the watch will remain intact.\u201d\n\nThe RM 53-01, priced \u20ac941,500, is limited to 30 pieces.\n\n\u201cNext time I play,\u201d Mr. Mac Donough said. \u201cI know the safest part of my body will be my watch.\u201d", "title": "As Clear as \u2014 Industrial Sapphire", "authors": ["Nazanin Lankarani"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Though the plan presents a long-term vision, through 2022, some of its contents were presented in a 14-page presentation to employees in February shortly after the department\u2019s budget requests were released. And last week, the department announced it would reassign its budget director, the first move toward disbanding the budget office. The decision was made over the opposition of the White House\u2019s Office of Management and Budget, according to Politico. Several other staff changes were announced for 2019.\n\nSome department employees denounced the move as an effort to dismantle an agency that would provide a critical check on the department\u2019s overhaul plans, but other experts said it made sense.\n\n\u201cBudget offices, because they have so much power and institutional knowledge, can be seen as obstacles by reform-minded government leaders,\u201d said Andy Smarick, a fellow at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. \u201cMany new government officials think they\u2019ll only have to fight policy battles, when in fact there are lots of ways, including in the budget process, for their efforts to get scuttled.\u201d\n\nThe plan aligns with measures Ms. DeVos has taken to shrink her agency, which she has described as bloated. She has shed hundreds of regulations, and hundreds of staff through attrition and buyouts.\n\nFor the most part, Ms. DeVos\u2019s restructuring plan involves consolidating offices, such as merging the office that oversees charter and private schools with the main office that oversees elementary and secondary education in public schools. The plan would eliminate the Office of the Under Secretary, a position that has helped shape higher education policy, and create a new Office of Lifelong Learning. It would also reduce the number of political appointees.\n\nThe proposal also seeks to acquire several programs run by the Department of Labor. The department proposed to take over adult and unemployed worker programs run by the Labor Department, and to redirect the funding for those programs to federal Pell grants so that unemployed workers can enroll in higher education and vocational programs. The department would acquire an \u201cout-of-school youth\u201d program from the Labor Department, as well as a program that helps reintegrate ex-prisoners.\n\nDetails of the plan surfaced amid a bitter contract dispute between the DeVos administration and the union that represents the department\u2019s 3,900 employees. Union leaders believe the contract gutted all protections that would allow its members to defend themselves in the department\u2019s overhaul.", "title": "As DeVos Faces Congress, Officials Say She Hid Plans to Overhaul Department", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Her mother said on Tuesday that the woman had been coerced into giving a false statement to the local station. A day later, the mother was reported to have been arrested.\n\nThe BBC said in a statement: \u201cWe stand by the integrity of our reporting teams.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Sisi has long treated Egyptian news outlets harshly, jailing dozens of reporters and blocking about 500 websites, he has generally spared foreign reporters the worst measures. That appears to have changed with the presidential election campaign.\n\nA long list of rules announced by the national election commission in February seeks to dictate the questions journalists can ask voters, prohibits them from using photographs or headlines \u201cnot related to the topic\u201d and forbids them from making \u201cany observations about the voting process.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese rules made me laugh, and scared the hell out of me at the same time,\u201d said Gamal Eid, a leading lawyer and human rights activist. \u201cThe rules are purposefully vague so they can decide to let their friends go, and punish their critics. It seems tailor-made for the foreign media.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough the presidential vote, scheduled for March 26-28, is widely seen as a charade \u2014 Mr. Sisi\u2019s sole opponent is an obscure politician who until recently backed him \u2014 the government has given no quarter to potential rivals.\n\nFour serious candidates who might have challenged Mr. Sisi were sidelined, jailed or threatened with prosecution before they could even get on the ballot, and on Feb. 14 the authorities arrested Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, an opposition leader who contested the 2012 election but is not running this time.\n\nMr. Fotouh, 66, who publicly supported calls for an election boycott, now faces charges of conspiring to incite revolt and has been placed on a list of \u201cterrorists\u201d linked to the Muslim Brotherhood.\n\nLast week, 14 international and Egyptian rights organizations urged Mr. Sisi\u2019s American and European allies to publicly denounce the \u201cfarcical elections,\u201d but that seems unlikely. Once hailed as a \u201cfantastic guy\u201d by President Trump, Mr. Sisi has avoided censure from allies who see him as a staunch ally in a region awash with Islamist violence and political turbulence. Several European countries have negotiated large arms and energy deals with Egypt in the past year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJournalists have been regularly detained and prosecuted under Mr. Sisi \u2014 Reporters Without Borders ranked Egypt 161st out of 180 countries in its 2017 Press Freedom Index \u2014 but the pace of arrests has quickened in recent weeks.\n\nThe New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists said it was concerned about Moataz Wadnan, a reporter with HuffPost Arabi, who was detained on Feb. 16 after he published an interview with a prominent Sisi critic. On Feb. 4, the journalists Moustafa el-Asar and Hassan el-Banna were detained on their way to work.\n\nSince May 2017, Egypt has blocked about 500 news websites, including HuffPost Arabi and the country\u2019s few remaining independent news websites.\n\nEven one of Egypt\u2019s best-loved entertainers has become a casualty of the relentless assault on free speech. On Tuesday a court sentenced the pop star Sherine to six months in prison over comments she made that were interpreted as an insult to the state when she suggested that the Nile River was dirty. The verdict was not final, and the singer is free on bail pending an appeal.", "title": "As Elections Near, Egypt Finds a New Target: Foreign News Media", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "In the six months since Harvey, The New York Times followed several families as they struggled to rebuild their lives. Some residents chose to leave their ruined homes, others to stay and rebuild in a neighborhood that almost certainly will be flooded again.\n\nThese pieces are the first in a series about the residents in the Cinco Ranch area. Their stories offer a look at how people are confronting an increasingly stark fact: many of the places we call home should never have been built in the first place\n\nRead a story about the brutal choices made and who benefits.", "title": "As Harvey Raged, Their Homes Were Swamped on Purpose. Six Months Later, They Face a Terrible Choice.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "The opposition parties say the backers of B.J.P. and its allies foster a climate of intolerance and target other Hindus who oppose them, as well as religious minorities such as Muslims.\n\nBut the B.J.P., which says the party is inclusive, denied its supporters were behind the attacks and dismissed the accusations as part of a political smear campaign. It noted that someone had taken a hammer to a bust of its own founder.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi, who heads the B.J.P.-led government, issued a strong condemnation on Wednesday of the vandalism, promising swift retribution against the vandals, no matter their affiliation.\n\nBut the vandalism appeared to be aimed mostly at figures who are important to Dalits, whom some B.J.P. supporters disdain. Discrimination, although forbidden by law, is widespread in India\u2019s stratified society.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, district officials in Meerut discovered a statue of B.R. Ambedkar in pieces. The Dalits revere Mr. Ambedkar for enshrining their rights in the Indian Constitution.\n\nOfficials, hoping to avert anger from the local Dalits, moved within hours to replace the statue, erecting a new one so hastily that most of the fingernails chiseled into the hand clutching India\u2019s Constitution were missing. The ears were rendered as blocklike ovals on either side of the head.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s like our god,\u201d said Kapil Kumar, 25, who helped replace the statue. \u201cWhat we have today is because of him. Whatever respect and chances in life we have, is because of him.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe violence began in the town of Belonia in Tripura State, after the B.J.P. swept local elections, ending more than two decades of Communist control. The Tripura branch of the Communist Party of India says B.J.P. supporters had celebrated their victory by ransacking and burning the party\u2019s offices.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen, on Monday, a crowd chanting B.J.P. slogans surrounded a statue of Lenin in Belonia. Using a construction vehicle with a hydraulic jackhammer, they destroyed the monument \u2014 an episode captured on a cellphone camera and shared widely.\n\n\u201cVictory to mother India,\u201d protesters can be heard chanting on the video.\n\nVictor Shome, the media officer for B.J.P. in Tripura, said the Communists had destroyed the statue. \u201cWe are a responsible party,\u201d Mr. Shome said on Friday. \u201cWith the help of the local administration, we are looking seriously into this incident to see how it happened.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Communists claim otherwise. \u201cThe statue\u2019s destruction was symbolic of the victory of the right over the left,\u201d said Tapas Datta, the secretary for the local Communist Party branch in Belonia.\n\nBelonia\u2019s police say B.J.P. celebrations got out of hand but did not explicitly blame the party.\n\n\u201cIt seemed some criminal elements took over a bulldozer, parked on the side of the street,\u201d said Manchak Ipper, the superintendent of the police in the south Tripura district, which includes Belonia.\n\n\u201cThey forced the driver to bring down the statue,\u201d Mr. Ipper said by telephone. \u201cI would say it was overenthusiasm.\u201d\n\nBut the vandalism spread across India.\n\nOn Wednesday, residents of Kolkata found the damaged bust of the B.J.P. founder, Syama Prasad Mookerjee, a hammer taken to the eyes and the face blackened with paint.\n\nOn Thursday, the glasses on the giant statue of Gandhi in Kerala were broken. Mr. Gandhi was assassinated in 1948 by a member of the far-right Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, which was outlawed after the assassination for a period but is active today and allied with the B.J.P.\n\nIn Meerut on Friday, the Dalits were seething, blaming upper-caste Tyagis for defacing Mr. Ambedkar\u2019s statue. The Tyagis are jealous and angry, they say, about the Dalits\u2019 progression. Mr. Ambedkar was a founding father of postcolonial India and helped elevate Dalits socially, economically and politically, moving the community away from their more commonly known moniker, \u201cthe untouchables.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDalit groups in Meerut are promising to replace the statue with an even bigger one, double the height of the current rendering.\n\nBut several villagers from the Tyagis caste have accused the Dalits of destroying the statue themselves in order to rally their voters in coming by-elections in Uttar Pradesh, which includes Meerut.\n\nMr. Kumar expects the tensions to worsen.\n\n\u201cIn the future, this won\u2019t calm down. Tensions will go up. The Tyagis try to suppress us. They don\u2019t like our progress. They don\u2019t like our politics,\u201d Mr. Kumar said. \u201cTo the Tyagis, we are all still \u2018untouchables.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe opposition parties, meanwhile, say that the proof of B.J.P.\u2019s culpability lies in the calls on Tuesday from the party\u2019s leader, H. Raja, for supporters to destroy a statue of an activist admired by lower castes, Periyar Ramasamy, in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.\n\nHours later, the statue was defaced.\n\nMr. Raja said the call to action \u2014 published on his Facebook page \u2014 had been an administrator\u2019s error, and the post has been deleted.", "title": "As India\u2019s Tensions Boil, Even a Statue of Gandhi Isn\u2019t Safe", "authors": ["Maria Abi-Habib", "Hari Kumar"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the age-old debates around abortion \u2014 including questions of when life begins and of women\u2019s control over their reproductive rights \u2014 the referendum has added a new dimension of concern about potential outside interference in the vote.\n\nAn ethics regulator recently ordered two abortion-rights groups, Amnesty International Ireland and the Abortion Rights Campaign, to return grants of $150,000 and $25,000 to George Soros\u2019s Open Society Foundations. It said the money was a foreign political donation intended to affect the outcome of a referendum or election, and therefore banned.\n\nBut so far it does not appear that any anti-abortion groups have been asked to return overseas donations, despite reports that money is being openly raised on their behalf, particularly in the United States.\n\nOne American group, the Pro-Life Action League, told an Irish newspaper in 2012 that anti-abortion groups were raising hundreds of thousands of dollars to support Irish anti-abortion groups like Youth Defence, which has been linked to far-right movements in Europe.\n\nYouth Defence did not respond to a request for comment. The Pro-Life Action League\u2019s executive director, Eric J. Scheidler, said that the remarks concerned American support for the Irish anti-abortion movement over several decades, and said his group had not raised money for the current campaign.\n\nThe Irish Center for Bio-Ethical Reform, which picketed The Irish Times, receives foreign funding but claims to be exempt from government oversight. \u201cWe are an educational body,\u201d Dr. Engela said.\n\nHe denied that the protest had anything to do with the coming vote, and asserted that some of the volunteers were full-time activists with their own sources of funding.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome commentators argue that anti-abortion groups are not being held to the same stringent standard as abortion-rights groups.\n\nTheresa Reidy, a political scientist at University College Cork, said that there was a long history of overseas interests taking sides in Irish referendums, particularly on issues like the European Union. Over the last decade, even as support for the abortion ban has waned, concerns about possible outside interference have risen, she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nSiobhan Mullally, of the Irish Center for Human Rights at the National University of Ireland, Galway, said the problem of undeclared foreign funding went beyond the abortion debate, and was \u201calso a question about how charities are funded in general.\u201d\n\nThe Roman Catholic Church, long a major power in Ireland, was the main driver in the 1983 referendum. The church also opposed, successfully, a referendum in 1986 that would have legalized divorce. In the decades since, however, its social and moral authority has been gravely weakened by a number of scandals, most notably clerical child sex abuse.\n\nThe church could not prevent the legalization of contraception and was on the losing side in referendums that legalized divorce in 1995 and same-sex marriage in 2015.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a result, today\u2019s anti-abortion activists are less overtly religious in their arguments. Instead, they are turning to arguments that abortion harms women\u2019s health. They are also turning to social media tools.\n\nAfter recent revelations about the misuse of Facebook data to sway Britain\u2019s referendum on European Union membership in 2016, and the United States presidential election later that year, fears are growing similar tactics might be used in the referendum campaign.\n\nThe Save the 8th Campaign, an anti-abortion group, has hired Kanto Systems, a London-based political consultancy, to help run its campaign.\n\nKanto Systems\u2019s founder, Thomas Borwick, was chief technology officer for the Vote Leave campaign in Britain, and developed a canvassing app for Cambridge Analytica, the data-mining organization that exploited Facebook data on behalf of the 2016 Trump campaign.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Borwick said that he himself had not worked for the Trump campaign, and referred a reporter to a statement from Save the 8th, which said that Kanto would be performing \u201csome data analytics for us\u201d but would not be engaged in \u201cany voter profiling or voter targeting.\u201d\n\nJohn McGuirk, a spokesman for Save the 8th, said that in the Irish electoral system, which does not have online voter rolls, individually targeted advertising of the sort practiced by Cambridge Analytica would not be possible. \u201cIn terms of targeting advertising at individual voters, we couldn\u2019t do that even if we wanted to, which we don\u2019t,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Times of London reported that the Pro Life Campaign, Ireland\u2019s largest umbrella anti-abortion group, has retained uCampaign, a Washington firm that has developed apps for the Trump campaign, the National Rifle Association, the Republican National Committee and Vote Leave. (Neither uCampaign nor the Pro Life Campaign responded to requests for comment.)\n\nThe Transparent Referendum Initiative, a small group of Irish technology advocates, said it had already detected paid social media campaigns stealthily targeting Irish voters. This month, the group introduced a crowdsourced monitoring tool to detect and investigate anonymous or vaguely sourced paid advertising on Facebook. It has already identified 92 such ads relating to the Irish referendum, 55 with anti-abortion messages and 37 in support of abortion rights.\n\nPolitical advertising is banned on Irish television and radio, but the online world is a different matter.\n\n\u201cThere is no law against someone anywhere else in the world signing a commercial contract with a British company to use foreign money or unknown money, that is not going through any official regulated campaign, in order to influence an Irish vote,\u201d said Liz Carolan of the Transparent Referendum Initiative. \u201cThere\u2019s a serious vulnerability in our democratic system. And it\u2019s now being exploited by incredibly sophisticated campaign techniques, and Facebook doesn\u2019t have to tell us who\u2019s doing it.\u201d\n\nResponding to the Cambridge Analytica revelations, the Irish government announced last week that it planned to give Irish regulators new powers to curb external influence on Irish voters.\n\nA spokeswoman for Facebook\u2019s Dublin office said that the company agreed with the need for more transparency in advertising, and that it was developing a new tool to help people identify paid ads in their timelines and to identify and label political content. However, she said, the tools will not be ready in time for the May referendum.", "title": "As Irish Abortion Vote Nears, Fears of Foreign Influence Rise", "authors": ["Ed O Loughlin"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Other major Albany corruption trials will soon follow, including those of Sheldon Silver, a Democrat who was the longtime Assembly speaker, and Dean G. Skelos, a Republican who was the Senate majority leader. Both men are being retried after their convictions were overturned on appeal last year.\n\nIn June, another former Cuomo ally, Alain E. Kaloyeros, the former president of the State University\u2019s Polytechnic Institute, is to go on trial in yet another corruption case. The trial of Mr. Kaloyeros, who the governor once said was \u201cas close as I\u2019ve ever come to dealing with a genius,\u201d involves bid-rigging in Mr. Cuomo\u2019s signature upstate economic plan, the Buffalo Billion.\n\nThere are some indications that the Percoco trial has hurt Mr. Cuomo\u2019s popularity. A Quinnipiac University poll in mid-February found him with an approval rating of 47 percent. A whopping 63 percent said Mr. Cuomo should not run for president, including almost half the respondents from his own party.\n\nMr. Cuomo has scrupulously avoided talking about the trial, saying he respects the legal process. He has held noticeably few public events in recent weeks, and has mostly avoided unscripted questions from the press.\n\nDemocratic strategists said the corruption case was all but assured to be part of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s national introduction, should he run for president, especially if Mr. Percoco were to be found guilty.\n\nThose looking to paint Mr. Cuomo as being ethically challenged have the benefit of an indelible catchword from the trial: \u201cziti,\u201d the much-used code word that the prosecution contends Mr. Percoco and his fellow conspirator used to describe the under-the-table payments he received while serving as Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign manager and senior aide.\n\nHere in New York, even before the jury returns its verdict, a collection of government watchdog groups have issued a scathing assessment of what-we-learned-at-trial, calling out \u201cstunning failures in New York\u2019s ethics oversight system\u201d under Governor Cuomo. The groups also demanded answers to a series of questions raised by the trial, including why \u201cso many high ranking officials were allowed to conduct business through personal emails,\u201d something illustrated, again and again, during testimony.\n\nPhoto\n\nIndeed, the trial reinforced the Capitol\u2019s shoddy reputation for ethics, something Mr. Cuomo promised to fix when he first ran for governor in 2010. Even then, however, the governor seemed willing to take advantage of donor\u2019s generosity: testimony at trial showed that Mr. Cuomo, in the closing days of that campaign, used a private plane from a company, Competitive Power Ventures, r later accused of bribing Mr. Percoco. An executive with another company involved in the scandal, COR Development, a Syracuse-area developer, wooed Mr. Cuomo with talk of Corvettes at a fund-raiser for him, knowing his affinity for those sports cars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Percoco trial also shed light on the use of sometimes shadowy limited liability companies to flood money into state campaigns, including those of Mr. Cuomo, who has been a major beneficiary of the so-called \u201cL.L.C. loophole.\u201d In one instance, the government\u2019s star witness, Todd R. Howe, showed how COR, a company with business before the state, purposefully split contributions \u2014 and used nondescript names on the L.L.C.s \u2014 to hide their origin.\n\nWhile those activities were legal, the disclosures have been met with glee by the governor\u2019s opponents, in particular the beleaguered state Republican Party.\n\nIn a post on Twitter, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s most outspoken Republican opponent, State Senator John DeFrancisco, said the trial illustrated how Mr. Cuomo \u201chas sold his office to the highest bidder, engaging in shakedown schemes, exchanging government contracts for millions in campaign donations.\u201d Mr. DeFrancisco wrote last week, \u201cSo pathetic, it would make Boss Tweed blush.\u201d\n\nThe chairman of the state Republican Party, Edward F. Cox, has asked a state ethics panel to investigate Mr. Cuomo, saying the governor has violated New York Public Officers Law, and has requested the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to also investigate.\n\nMr. Cox, whose party has not won a statewide election in New York since 2002, saw parallels between Mr. Cuomo\u2019s guilt-by-association and that of former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, whose proximity to the bridge-closing scandal known as Bridgegate helped dent his national profile.\n\n\u201cThis is the end of Governor Cuomo\u2019s political future,\u201d Mr. Cox said at a news conference last month before the steps of Federal District Court in Manhattan, where Mr. Percoco is being tried.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat may be an overstatement; unlike Mr. Christie, whose former aides implicated him at trial for knowing of the decision to close bridge lanes, Mr. Cuomo has not been similarly besmirched.\n\nAnd officials with the state Democratic party, controlled by Mr. Cuomo, shot back at any suggestion that the governor would be hurt by the Percoco trial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAfter years of investigation, there has never been a suggestion that the Governor or anyone else besides the people on trial did anything wrong,\u201d said Geoff Berman, the party\u2019s executive director, calling Mr. DeFrancisco \u201cthe Boss Tweed of Albany.\u201d\n\nIndeed, with $30 million in the bank and no top-tier opponent in the contest, Mr. Cuomo remains a heavy favorite to win re-election this year. Among Democrats, no serious primary challenger has yet emerged, though two women, the former Syracuse mayor, Stephanie Miner, and the actress Cynthia Nixon, have publicly toyed with running.\n\nBut if his ambitions extend to the White House in 2020 \u2014 and Mr. Cuomo has increasingly framed his agenda in national terms \u2014 the trial, especially if it ends in a conviction, threatens to muddy his core argument that he can be a capable and trusted custodian of the state, or especially, the country.\n\n\u201cThese kinds of things typically emerge either soon after he first announces or soon after he gains traction,\u201d Mr. Tulchin said. \u201cAssuming he gains any.\u201d", "title": "As Jurors Decide Fate of Key Cuomo Ally, Political Verdict May Be In", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Shane Goldmacher"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "On Thursday, the jurors seemed re-energized \u2014 and all in attendance, which was far from a sure thing.\n\nJuror No. 7 had written that both of her children were sick and she needed to leave to care for them. \u201cI really need to be excused,\u201d she wrote.\n\nJudge Caproni had raised two possible options to the prosecutors and the lawyers for Mr. Percoco and his three co-defendants. One was to excuse Juror No. 7 and replace her with an alternate juror. But such a step would mean the newly constituted 12-member panel would need to restart deliberations, further slowing the trial.\n\nOr, the judge could take the highly unusual step of excusing Juror No. 7 and not replacing her. \u201cAre you prepared to proceed with 11?\u201d Judge Caproni asked.\n\nUnder the federal rules of criminal procedure, a judge may allow a jury of 11 persons to return a verdict, even over the objection of a party, if the judge finds \u201cgood cause,\u201d said Stephen Gillers, a legal ethics expert at New York University School of Law.\n\nGood cause may be a juror\u2019s illness or refusal to deliberate, but it may not be because a juror is a holdout and disagrees with a majority of the panel, Professor Gillers said.\n\n\u201cThe Constitution\u2019s guarantee of a jury trial does not require a jury of 12,\u201d Professor Gillers added. \u201cThe Constitution only guarantees a jury trial.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe issue appeared to solve itself, however. Between Thursday and Friday, the jury sent a flurry of notes to Judge Caproni and sat attentively in the courtroom as witness testimony was read back to them.\n\nAnd there was no further talk of proceeding with 11 jurors in the trial, which has completed its seventh week.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n* * *\n\nTwo notes sent to the judge on Friday concerned a key character in the trial narrative: Lisa Toscano-Percoco, the wife of Mr. Percoco, and the teaching job she held for three years at a Maryland-based energy company, Competitive Power Ventures.\n\nProsecutors have charged that CPV paid Ms. Toscano-Percoco a yearly salary of $90,000 \u2014 a total of about $285,000 \u2014 for what they called a \u201clow-show job,\u201d in which she was to teach schoolchildren about energy. She was given the job by a CPV executive, Peter Galbraith Kelly Jr., one of Mr. Percoco\u2019s co-defendants in the trial.\n\nThe government has said the job was actually a bribe for Mr. Percoco in exchange for his help with state business. Prosecutors have cast Ms. Toscano-Percoco as an absentee employee who would forget to take phone calls and shirk duties she found beneath her.\n\nYanina Daigle, a former supervisor of Ms. Toscano-Percoco, was unsparing in her criticism of her work ethic. \u201cIt was really subpar to what my expectations were and often sloppy,\u201d Ms. Daigle testified.\n\nThe defense has portrayed the job given to Ms. Toscano-Percoco \u2014 part of a company program called CPV Educates \u2014 as a legitimate gesture of good will, not a bribe.\n\n\u201cLisa was hired to do a real job, an important job, a job that had real value to the company,\u201d Mr. Kelly\u2019s lawyer, Daniel M. Gitner, said in his summation.\n\nThe jurors, in their notes on Friday, suggested they were seeking corroboration for the defense\u2019s argument. In one note, for example, they asked for one CPV executive\u2019s testimony \u201csaying that CPV Educates was a good project to have.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n* * *\n\nOne of the jurors in the case was able to escape jury duty last week \u2014 just not in the Percoco trial.\n\n\u201cYour Honor,\u201d the juror wrote to Judge Caproni on Thursday. \u201cI am very popular with the justice system.\u201d\n\nThe juror explained that she had been summoned to another jury, for which she was to have reported that morning. \u201cIs it possible to get a note to explain my absence?\u201d she asked.\n\nLater, when the jurors were called into the courtroom before being dismissed for the day, Judge Caproni addressed the juror.\n\n\u201cI hope you weren\u2019t supposed to be there at 9:00 this morning,\u201d the judge said.\n\n\u201cI was,\u201d the juror replied sheepishly. She had tried unsuccessfully to get a delay, she said. (Neither the court nor the case in which she had been summoned was revealed publicly.)\n\nShe remained on the Percoco jury on Friday, still doing her civic duty, apparently excused from the other case with a solid-gold get-out-of-jury-duty card: a letter from Judge Caproni explaining that she was on the Percoco jury. Deliberations resume on Monday.", "title": "As Jury Meltdown Subsides, Focus Falls on Percoco\u2019s Wife", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The German economy could hardly be in better shape as Angela Merkel formally began her fourth term as chancellor Wednesday. Unemployment is almost nonexistent, stock prices are at record highs, and there is almost no inflation.\n\nBut the political compromise that allowed Ms. Merkel to remain in power could bring that boom to an end. She had to bend to demands from her party\u2019s junior coalition partner, and agree to roll back deregulation that, since 2005, has unleashed the country\u2019s economy.\n\nNow, with Europe\u2019s economy gaining momentum after a prolonged slump, Germany \u2014 the Continent\u2019s economic powerhouse and de facto leader \u2014 risks heading in the opposite direction.\n\nMs. Merkel, who finally took the oath of office Wednesday along with her cabinet, faces the same political quandary afflicting many industrialized nations, including the United States. Life should feel great, but to many people, it doesn\u2019t. Their wages haven\u2019t budged, their jobs seem less secure, and they believe the good times have passed them by.", "title": "As Merkel Begins New Term, Compromises Could Undo Economic Boom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "But what if Louisville, or Southern California, or Oklahoma State \u2014 all implicated by the feds in their investigation \u2014 goes from an N.C.A.A. bubble team to the National Invitation Tournament? Will its fans believe the committee really did keep its blinders on?\n\nWe\u2019ll know by the end of Sunday, but what we know now (and always) is that the N.C.A.A. has a billion reasons to look the other way. The organization clocked $1.06 billion in revenue and a $105 million in profit for its 2017 fiscal year, according to a financial statement released recently.\n\nTelevision rights packages with CBS and Turner accounted for more than $800 million of its revenue, so do not expect Jim Nantz, Charles Barkley or their broadcast colleagues dispatched to the tournament sites over the next three weeks to harp on how college basketball isn\u2019t perfect. The networks have agreed to pay $8.8 billion to be the mouthpiece of the Division I men\u2019s basketball tournament through 2032.\n\nPhoto\n\nMoney like that buys an awful lot of silence.\n\n\u201cUnless your coach and program are dealing with it, nobody cares,\u201d said Jay Bilas, an ESPN analyst and frequent critic of the N.C.A.A. \u201cThey want the games. They want to fill out their brackets. It\u2019s like steroids in baseball. We\u2019ve been paying players in basketball and football, and the N.C.A.A. continues to fiddle.\u201d\n\nAs evidence, Bilas cited the herculean effort the organization put in to clear players in record time when the pay-to-play investigation indicated that some of them were from the country\u2019s most prominent programs, including Duke, North Carolina, Kentucky and Michigan State. According to documents uncovered by investigators, dozens of top players received financial and other benefits that could violate N.C.A.A. rules.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey got it done in a day because the tournament was coming,\u201d Bilas said of sorting the players\u2019 eligibility. \u201cThey\u2019ve never done anything in a day but sign contracts.\u201d\n\nSo if broadcasters are not going to talk about the ills of the college game, can they at least refrain from the big wet kisses they shower on the coaches?\n\nOften, those coaches are the highest-paid people on the court, sometimes the highest on their state\u2019s payroll. They are crowned as geniuses, talked up as role models, about how they do things \u201cthe right way.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf you drank a shot of whiskey every time you heard a broadcaster or analyst extol the virtues of a coach, you wouldn\u2019t make it to the night session of Thursday\u2019s first-round games.\n\nWhat is never said, however, is that the \u201cright way\u201d increasingly means runners and shoe representatives and envelopes stuffed with cash. It means no-show classes for the one-and-dones, who quit going to class in January anyway, knowing that they will leave campus shortly after their final tournament game.\n\nMaybe Bilas is right. Maybe no one cares about anything but the games and picking brackets. Maybe the N.C.A.A. tournament is nothing more than a basketball version of \u201cThe Bachelor\u201d \u2014 a few weeks of outrage and heartbreak, with a sappy theme song.\n\nThe tournament certainly never lacks for drama. But what if this year\u2019s edition gives the recent finale of \u201cThe Bachelor\u201d a run for its money? What if the programs at the center of the federal investigation \u2014 Louisville, Arizona, Auburn and Oklahoma State \u2014 all make it to the Final Four in San Antonio?\n\nThat would be the \u201cOne Shining Moment\u201d that college basketball deserves.", "title": "As N.C.A.A. Field Comes Together, Integrity Is on the Bubble", "authors": ["Joe Drape", "On College Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "MARJORIE IVES, JUPITER, FLA.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFrancis, the Anti-Strongman,\u201d by Paul Elie (Sunday Review, March 25):\n\nPope Francis\u2019s persona belies a dictatorial penchant. He deals with challenges by removing those who disagree with him. The peremptory dismissal of members of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, for no apparent reason, is a case in point.\n\nHis rigging of the Synod on the Family and dubious editing of its summation in \u201cAmoris Laetitia\u201d (\u201cThe Joy of Love\u201d) \u2014 an incomplete citation from John Paul II \u2014 is nothing short of dictatorial. And his circumventing of canonical process to initiate change \u2014 for example, changing the rite of foot washing on Holy Thursday, from a recognition of the uninterrupted transmission of spiritual authority from the apostles to succeeding generations of bishops, to an open-to-all act of charity \u2014 certainly seems autocratic.\n\nMICHAEL P. ORSI, NAPLES, FLA.\n\nThe writer is a Catholic priest.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Good Pope and His Critics\u201d (column, March 18):\n\nRoss Douthat blames Pope Francis for worsening the divisions in the church by glossing over the differences and allowing for more robust debate in local churches. Francis\u2019s approach is not a truce.\n\nRather, he trusts that local churches are better suited to allow for the internal forum or conscience to help people live the faith in a realistic way. It seems that Mr. Douthat would rather that some abstract dogmas continue to drive Catholics away. Francis holds the center and reaches out to those disenfranchised as Jesus did as an itinerant preacher.\n\nAs the vicar of Christ, Francis allows for Catholics to be universal while at the same time particular in their cultural expressions of faith. Francis trusts that any coming changes in the church will arise out of people\u2019s embrace of the faith. He is more hopeful than Mr. Douthat.", "title": "Opinion | As Pope Francis Changes the Church", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "PALOS HILLS, Ill. \u2014 When Representative Daniel Lipinski, a conservative-leaning Democrat and scion of Chicago\u2019s political machine, agreed to one joint appearance last month with his liberal primary challenger, the divide in the Democratic Party was evident in the audience that showed up.\n\nMr. Lipinski\u2019s outnumbered supporters were the diminished lunch-pail Democrats that once dominated his Southside district. Ashurkov breathed a sigh of relief when he fled Moscow for London in 2014. After months of being followed by the Kremlin\u2019s intelligence agents to meetings, culminating in a televised raid of his apartment, he finally let his guard down, disappearing into the elegant, polyglot streets of Kensington.\n\nSix months passed before he realized that he was still being followed.\n\nAn old friend returned from a trip to Russia with unnerving news: In Moscow, security officials had asked detailed questions about a private conversation he had with Mr. Ashurkov in a London cafe. As he built his life in London, Mr. Ashurkov learned to look for Russian agents reflexively \u2014 men in dark suits sitting alone at \u00e9migr\u00e9 gatherings, dinner-party acquaintances rumored to be informants.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t do much about it,\u201d he said. \u201cEven after you escape from Moscow to London, you know they have long hands.\u201d\n\nRussia now has more intelligence agents deployed in London than at the height of the Cold War, former British intelligence officials have said. They serve a variety of functions, including building contacts among British politicians. But he has since moderated his stance, outlining a more piecemeal approach. Any changes, he said in a recent interview, would rely on money that the M.T.A. already has in its budget, rather than an infusion of cash from the city or state, as is the case with the subway.\n\nMr. Byford has convened a working group inside the M.T.A. to develop strategies to improve bus service and promised to provide specifics in the coming weeks. \u201cWe have to get it right,\u201d he said.\n\nOne of the most significant bus initiatives in recent years has been the introduction of buses with designated lanes, all-door boarding and kiosks to pay at before boarding. The service, known as select bus, has been installed on 15 routes over the past decade, where travel times have dropped as much as 25 percent, according to the city. Twenty new routes are planned over the next 10 years, a pace that frustrates advocates.\n\n\u201cThe city and the M.T.A. together lay siege to a bus route, and they spend two or three years doing that and the need for better bus service is much more urgent,\u201d said Jon Orcutt, a spokesman for the Transit Center, a research group.\n\nShowing his interest in buses and how they work, Mr. Byford rode one recently as it lurched down Lexington Avenue and outlined his priorities for the system. They include expanding the traffic light syncing program, encouraging the police to step up enforcement to keep bus lanes clear, dispatching buses in a more even and rapid succession and allowing more riders to pay before they board. White House officials said that in the coming weeks, the Department of Homeland Security and several other agencies would announce more agreements on energy cooperation, infrastructure and economic development in Central American countries, aiming at stemming the flow of migrants, through Mexico, into the United States.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s true \u2014 Jared has been a positive influence,\u201d said Ger\u00f3nimo Guti\u00e9rrez, Mexico\u2019s ambassador to Washington. \u201cOur dialogue is not limited to the White House. However, if we didn\u2019t have that dialogue with Mr. Kushner, the relationship would be much worse off.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Kushner, progress on Mexico would be a bright spot in what has been a difficult stretch. He was recently stripped of his top-secret security clearance and faces a hostile reception from Palestinians to his Middle East peace plan after Mr. Trump recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. His future in the White House is regularly scrutinized, though he has told colleagues he is not going anywhere.\n\nMr. Kushner\u2019s aides acknowledge his work could be overshadowed by a breakdown in talks over Nafta. The two countries are in the final stages of negotiations, with officials from both sides putting the odds of a deal at no better than 50-50. Then there is the relationship between Mr. Trump and Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto, which has fallen apart twice during angry telephone exchanges over who should pay for the wall.\n\nThis month, Mr. Trump dispatched Mr. Kushner to Mexico City to mend fences with Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto after their latest clash prompted the Mexican leader to cancel a visit to Washington. It went less well for Mr. Videgaray, who was forced to resign after the Mexican news media savaged the meeting and his role in arranging it. (He later returned as foreign minister.)\n\nMr. Kushner and Mr. Videgaray got to know each other during the transition and have talked regularly since. During Mr. Trump\u2019s first phone call with Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto, the two leaders had a rancorous exchange over trade and the wall but agreed that Mr. Kushner and Mr. Videgaray should draft a statement putting a positive spin on their conversation, according to a transcript that was leaked to The Washington Post.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision to hand the Mexico portfolio to Mr. Kushner generated tension with the secretary of state at the time, Rex W. Tillerson, who objected to the president\u2019s 37-year-old son-in-law taking on what he saw as his duties. On his most recent trip to Mexico, Mr. Kushner raised more hackles in the State Department by excluding the American ambassador, Roberta S. Jacobson, from his meeting with the president.\n\nMr. Kushner, aides said, wanted to have a more intimate meeting and besides, they noted, Ms. Jacobson, who was appointed by President Barack Obama, is stepping down. He did include Kimberly Breier, a State Department official recently nominated as assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs.\n\nGiven Mr. Tillerson\u2019s dismissal and the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, who has been nominated to replace him, Mr. Kushner will have to contend with a forceful new player in the diplomatic ranks. But his biggest hurdle to improved relations between Mexico and the United States may be the political calendar in both countries.\n\nMexicans will vote for a new president on July 1, likely removing Mr. Kushner\u2019s friend, Mr. Videgaray, from office. Americans will vote in midterm elections in the fall \u2014 the pressure of which, analysts said, could lead Mr. Trump to revive the disparaging language about Mexico that first necessitated Mr. Kushner\u2019s diplomatic rescue mission.", "title": "As Ties With Mexico Fray, Kushner Works Quietly to Mend Them", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "The study, requested in late 2015 by five senior Republican members of Congress, comes at a possible turning point in the 53-year history of Medicaid.\n\nThe Trump administration has been flooded with requests from states seeking Medicaid waivers. They want to impose work requirements, charge premiums, suspend coverage for people who fail to pay premiums, and restrict eligibility or benefits in other ways. A few states would like to impose time limits on Medicaid coverage for some beneficiaries.\n\nConcern about waivers is bipartisan. Republicans were worried about the cost of some demonstration projects approved by the Obama administration. Democrats are alarmed at work requirements and other policy changes that the Trump administration has approved.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Government Accountability Office found particular problems in the evaluation of a Medicaid waiver granted to Indiana. The state expanded Medicaid, as permitted under the Affordable Care Act, but obtained a federal waiver for policies emphasizing \u201cpersonal responsibility,\u201d including monthly premiums and incentives for healthy behavior.\n\nThe federal government wanted to know how Medicaid beneficiaries were affected by those changes, but it could not get the data it needed from the state, so its evaluation was severely limited, the Government Accountability Office said.\n\nConservatives see Indiana\u2019s Medicaid program as a model, and other states are following suit. The architects of the Indiana plan include Vice President Mike Pence, who was the governor of Indiana from 2013 to January 2017, and Seema Verma, a consultant to the state who is now the administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSimilar problems have stymied the evaluation of an important experiment in Arkansas, which is using federal Medicaid funds to help pay premiums for low-income people who buy private coverage in a health insurance exchange established under the Affordable Care Act.\n\nFederal and state officials wanted to know whether consumers would have better access to care under this arrangement than in the traditional Medicaid program. But, the report said, \u201cArkansas officials told us that the state was not collecting the specific data from exchange plans requested by the federal evaluator, and that collecting those data would result in additional cost.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn its report, the G.A.O. said federal officials had \u201cno standard policy\u201d for the public release of findings from the evaluation of Medicaid demonstration projects. As a result, it said, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services \u201cis missing an opportunity to inform important federal and state policy discussions.\u201d\n\nMedicaid has spent increasing amounts on demonstration projects in the past decade. Federal spending under Medicaid waivers now exceeds $100 billion a year, up from $29 billion in 2005 and $49 billion in 2010.\n\nWaivers are typically approved for an initial five-year period, but federal officials often renew and extend waivers without waiting for an evaluation to show whether the project was worthwhile, the Government Accountability Office said.\n\nThe auditors made three recommendations and the Trump administration accepted all of them, saying it recognized the need to conduct rigorous independent evaluations and release the results in a more timely way.\n\nIn granting Medicaid waivers, federal officials typically require states to measure the effects of a policy change on costs and the health of beneficiaries. But, the report said, it is often difficult to isolate those consequences because the overall health care system is changing so fast.", "title": "As Trump Pushes Medicaid Testing, the Grading Falls Short", "authors": ["Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The content of the films, he said, might be less of a factor in the funding cut than the festival\u2019s premise \u2014 which he said was \u201cto support the intercultural exchange between two cultures\u201d \u2014 at a moment when Turkey is increasingly suspicious of the West. The Turkish Culture Ministry declined to comment for this article, explaining that the minister was traveling abroad.\n\nWithout the expected support from Turkey, the festival scrambled for funding, making up its shortfall through various organizations including the German Foreign Ministry and the Goethe Institut, a worldwide organization that promotes the German language and culture.\n\nCultural events have often been used as chess pieces in diplomacy between the two countries. Turkey withdrew from the arts funding body Creative Europe in November 2016 to protest money being used to fund a concert at the German embassy in Istanbul that dealt with the 1915 massacre of Armenians by the Ottoman government. Germany had passed a resolution earlier that year labeling the killings a \u201cgenocide,\u201d which angered Turkey.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSinan Ciddi, the director of Georgetown University\u2019s Institute of Turkish Studies, said in a telephone interview that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey \u201cmakes quite a lot of electoral gain out of vilifying the West,\u201d adding that Mr. Erdogan believes that \u201cWestern cultural norms are imports alien to Turkish culture.\u201d\n\nAt the end of February, the Turkish state broadcaster TRT was revealed after an inquiry by an opposition politician to have blacklisted 208 Turkish and Kurdish pop songs. In a statement on Twitter, TRT denied censorship, and said it was blacklisting songs that promoted alcohol, tobacco or terrorism.\n\nThe Turkish government has in the past declared support for cinema, and funds feature films and other work at home, but has reduced funding for some film festivals in recent years. In 2014 the government said it was doubling state funding for domestic films, spending almost $7 million. It announced $1.5 million in funding for the first quarter of 2018 for 155 film projects, the bulk of it for documentaries, but also including support for cartoons, short movies and script writing.\n\nMr. Ciddi said Mr. Erdogan had always sought to promote an Islamic culture in Turkey, separate from foreign influence.\n\nMr. Erdogan has been explicit about wanting to uncouple Turkish and Western culture: he gave a speech in January decrying foreign influence at Turkish universities. The country\u2019s culture and tourism minister, Numan Kurtulmus, said in a speech at a short film contest in February that Turkey\u2019s main problem for the last two centuries \u201cin culture, art and literature, even in thought, politics, and economics\u201d had been \u201cachieving cultural independence.\u201d\n\nHe said that Turkey\u2019s artists needed to stop thinking that \u201cby using and imitating products from Western civilizations we are going to become men and get stronger and somehow join the race of civilizations.\u201d Artists who departed from Turkish tradition, he said, were like branches who believed they could grow when broken off from a tree.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kaya said that the ministry had given no reason for no longer sponsoring the film festival in Germany.
