Gary D. Cohn, the economics adviser, announced last week that he would step down, following Hope Hicks, the communications director, and Rob Porter, the staff secretary.\n\nIt is tempting to look for larger meaning in the shifting personnel, but the momentum seems to shift by the week or even the day. One faction has the upper hand and then it does not. Mr. Cohn was the \u201cit boy\u201d of the Trump White House early on until he mildly criticized the president\u2019s response to the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va. Then he was on the outs. Then he helped pass Mr. Trump\u2019s tax cut plan and his stock was high again. Then he lost last week\u2019s battle over tariffs and he quit.\n\nNot to worry \u2014 even when Mr. Cohn, a former Goldman Sachs banker, announced his departure, Mr. Trump publicly predicted that he would simply go off to make a few hundred million dollars more and then rejoin the administration in one capacity or another.\n\nMr. Tillerson had yet to turn in his State Department decoder ring before speculation turned to who else would be gone soon. What about John F. Kelly, the forever-on-the-bubble White House chief of staff? Or Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, the perpetually on-the-way-out national security adviser?\n\nPhoto\n\nMaybe it depends on whom the president can convince to replace them. He said the other day that he could find 10 people for any job opening, but many first-tier Republicans are staying away from this White House or are banned from its premises because of past opposition to Mr. Trump.\n\nStill, he is not wedded to traditional choices as he scans the horizon for fresh staff members. It helps to be good on television, as Mr. Kudlow is, but not to be too good on television, because it might irritate the boss to be shown up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong those Mr. Trump enjoys on Fox News is John R. Bolton, the conservative firebrand who served as ambassador to the United Nations under President George W. Bush. Tongues wagged when Mr. Trump met with Mr. Bolton in the White House recently, prompting speculation that he could replace General McMaster.\n\nBut would Mr. Trump bring in Mr. Bolton, among the nation\u2019s leading hawks on North Korea, at the very moment he plans to sit down with Kim Jong-un, the country\u2019s mercurial dictator, for talks aimed at eliminating its nuclear program peacefully? And then there is Mr. Bolton\u2019s famous mustache. Some around Mr. Trump say it bothers him. Can he get over the facial hair?\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s choice of Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, to replace Mr. Tillerson offers something of a window into his approach. Mr. Pompeo found that the key to favor in the Oval Office was engaging Mr. Trump. The president enjoyed his near daily interactions with Mr. Pompeo at his intelligence briefings.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy contrast, he never really connected with Mr. Tillerson, who was used to being a chief executive rather than a glorified staff member. It probably did not help that Mr. Tillerson was overheard after a meeting last summer calling the president a \u201cmoron,\u201d a comment he never denied, although he had a spokeswoman deny it for him. Mr. Trump has likewise been said not to click personally with General McMaster.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides said he acted now because he wanted to get a new team in place before the talks with Mr. Kim. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was a different mind-set. It was a different thinking,\u201d he explained. \u201cWe disagreed on things.\u201d\n\nJust a minute or two later, a reporter asked if it was true that Mr. Kudlow was his top choice to replace Mr. Cohn as director of the National Economic Council. Such a selection would be striking given that Mr. Kudlow, a CNBC commentator, has criticized Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to slap tariffs on imported steel and aluminum.\n\nBut Mr. Trump shrugged that off and praised Mr. Kudlow. \u201cWe don\u2019t agree on everything, but in this case I think that\u2019s good,\u201d he said. \u201cI want to have a divergent opinion.\u201d\n\nAt least for now.", "title": "As White House\u2019s Revolving Door Whirls, Chaos Is the Only Constant", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Graham died at his mountain home in Montreat, N.C., on Feb. 21. His body was carried in a motorcade down the mountain and 130 miles east to Charlotte, as thousands waved farewell from overpasses along the interstate.\n\nThe funeral on Friday, under a 28,000-square-foot tent that shuddered in a stiff wind, drew other political dignitaries besides the president and vice president, including Ben Carson, the housing secretary, the former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina and his predecessor, Pat McCrory.\n\nSome attendees remarked that it was an unprecedented gathering of evangelical luminaries. They included the megachurch leaders Joel Osteen, Rick Warren and A.R. Bernard, the best-selling author and speaker Beth Moore, the radio and television host David Jeremiah, and the Rev. Jim Bakker, who has returned to television ministry after a corruption scandal that sent him to prison.\n\nThe evangelical movement is now far more divided than it was under Mr. Graham, mostly because of politics. One wing makes no apology for having linked the evangelical church so closely with the Republican Party and President Trump. Another wing sees it as undermining the Gospel message.\n\nThe Rev. Ed Stetzer, executive director of the Billy Graham Center at Wheaton College, said before the service started: \u201cMy hope is that this funeral will remind us to put the evangelism back in evangelical.\u201d\n\nFranklin Graham, Mr. Graham\u2019s eldest son and designated heir of the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association, did not veer into politics, though he has served as a frequent champion of Mr. Trump in the media. But he did include the kind of explicit, exclusivist claim of Christian faith that he has consistently used in his public appearances, including presidential inaugurations, when he insisted on giving his prayer \u201cin the name of Jesus.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe world with all its political correctness would want you to believe that there are many roads to God. (She was previously represented by another California attorney, Keith Davidson.) Within days Mr. Avenatti prepared to challenge the deal \u2014 which stipulated that disagreements would be argued in secret before a confidential arbitrator \u2014 arguing it was not valid because Mr. Trump did not sign it. (Mr. Avenatti on Sunday pointed to a clause that said the agreement was \u201cvalid and binding\u201d when \u201csigned by all parties.\u201d)\n\nA suit that Mr. Avenatti filed on Tuesday evening in Los Angeles County Superior Court included a nugget of news: Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer had initiated \u201ca bogus arbitration proceeding\u201d against Ms. Clifford to \u201cshut her up.\u201d\n\nThat appeared to force an error at the White House the next day, when the president\u2019s press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, who had been avoiding engagement in Ms. Clifford\u2019s story, said that an arbitration proceeding \u201cwas won in the president\u2019s favor.\u201d That led to news that Mr. Cohen had acquired a temporary restraining order against Ms. Clifford in late February.\n\nMr. Avenatti has been a regular presence on television, arguing that the restraining order and the original deal are both legally flawed, and making allegations aimed at undermining Mr. Cohen and Mr. Trump.\n\nFor instance, on Friday, Mr. Avenatti shared with NBC News and then ABC News that Mr. Cohen had conducted some negotiations with Ms. Clifford in 2016 on his Trump Organization email account. That, Mr. Avenatti told NBC, was at variance with Mr. Cohen\u2019s previous statement that neither the Trump Organization nor the Trump campaign were \u201cparty to\u201d the agreement with Ms. Clifford. Mr. Avenatti also suggested that the email cast doubt on Mr. Cohen\u2019s assertion that he paid Ms. Clifford out of his own pocket.\n\nWhether Mr. Trump ever reimbursed Mr. Cohen, and the extent to which he struck the deal in consultation with Mr. Trump, goes to the center of complaints the watchdog group Common Cause has made to the Federal Election Commission and the Justice Department alleging that the payment was an illegal campaign contribution.\n\nAfter Mr. Avenatti\u2019s comments, Mr. Cohen broke his relative silence about the case by telling ABC News that he drew on his own home equity line of credit to secure the $130,000 for Ms. Clifford. And The Washington Post quoted him over the weekend as saying, \u201cMr. Avenatti\u2019s actions and behavior has been both reckless and imprudent as it opens Ms. Clifford to substantial monetary liability, which I intend to pursue.\u201d", "title": "As \u201860 Minutes\u2019 Prepares Stormy Daniels Interview, Lawyers Wrangle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "More than half a century since it was published, \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d the classic children\u2019s book by Madeleine L\u2019Engle, is finally hitting the big screen on Friday. If you\u2019d like to immerse yourself further into L\u2019Engle\u2019s world, here are three recommendations: her biography, the original story and a third book with a wholly different magical world that also places women at its center.\n\nPhoto\n\nA WRINKLE IN TIME\n\nBy Madeleine L\u2019Engle\n\n216 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. (1962)\n\nIt is worth revisiting the classic story of Meg Murry, a young, bright girl who travels across the universe to find her missing scientist father. She is accompanied by her younger brother, Charles Wallace, and a high school boy, Calvin O\u2019Keefe. Together, they traverse the universe via a tesseract, which is \u201ca way to travel through time and space using a fifth dimension,\u201d and along the way, they encounter celestial beings named Mrs Who, Mrs Which and Mrs Whatsit, who help them on their journey. In an essay, Pamela Paul, the editor of The Times Book Review, wrote that Meg \u201cwas a departure from the typical \u2018girls\u2019 book\u2019 protagonist,\u201d and that though she suffered through \u201cflyaway hair, braces and glasses,\u201d she was \u201cto a much greater degree concerned with the extent of her own intelligence, the whereabouts of her missing scientist father, the looming threat of conformity and, ultimately, the fate of the universe.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLISTENING FOR MADELEINE\n\nA Portrait of Madeleine L\u2019Engle in Many Voices\n\nBy Leonard S. Marcus\n\n363 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. (2012)\n\nThis unconventional biography brings together a cacophony of voices to speak on L\u2019Engle \u2014 family members like her daughter and two grandchildren; writers like Judy Blume and T. A. Barron; and L\u2019Engle\u2019s editors and students. The writer, who was beloved by many and poured much time into leading writing workshops and giving speaking engagements, found it difficult to relate to her children, who resented aspects of their lives being fictionalized in L\u2019Engle\u2019s stories. \u201cListening for Madeleine\u201d is a collection of interviews that paint a contradictory picture of a woman grappling with motherhood, her career and the fame it afforded her.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE FIFTH SEASON\n\nThe Broken Earth: Book One\n\nBy N. K. Jemisin\n\n498 pp. Orbit. (2015)\n\nThis Hugo Award-winning novel \u2014 the first in a trilogy \u2014 centers on three women who, in the beginning of the book, find their worlds unraveling in various ways. Damaya, Syenite and Essun live in the Stillness, a land in constant flux, prone to destructive tectonic catastrophes. Essun is a small-town schoolteacher whose husband kills their son and kidnaps their daughter, leaving her to embark on a rescue mission. Damaya is a young girl and orogene, meaning that she has the power to manipulate the elements; this renders her both a target and a desirable object, and she is taken from her home for training to serve the empire. Syenite is an orogene, too, sent on a mission with her mentor that leads her to discover truths she was never meant to know. Our reviewer praised Jemisin\u2019s \u201cintricate and extraordinary world-building,\u201d and wrote that her heroes\u2019 escapes are not merely personal victories: \u201cHer heroes achieve escape velocity, smashing through oppressive systems and leaving them behind like shed skins.\u201d", "title": "As \u2018A Wrinkle in Time\u2019 Hits Screens, Read These Books", "authors": ["Concepci\u00f3n De Le\u00f3n"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.\n\nLast week, the Popcast battled the historical record in defense of Ashlee Simpson \u2014 the younger sister of Jessica, an early pop-punk and scene kid and an edgier pop product than Hilary Duff. Ms. Simpson was a platinum-selling star who burned bright and fast, and has largely been consigned to pop music history\u2019s dustbins.", "title": "Ashlee Simpson: You Asked, We Answered", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Like most sharp songwriters, Ms. McBryde has a keen sense of whom she is writing for. \u201cFat and Famous,\u201d an uproarious song from her 2016 EP, was written for her 10th high school reunion and targeted the mean girls. An old loosie, \u201cBurning Down Chicago,\u201d was partly inspired by a woman who, in the middle of one of Ms. McBryde\u2019s bar performances, pulled a photo out of her wallet, laid it in an ashtray and set it ablaze.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a few people that I write with that we don\u2019t stop until one of us cries,\u201d she said.\n\nBut in Nashville especially, there is a chasm between songwriter and performer, and Ms. McBryde is still smarting at the fact that her songwriting career never took flight. (She\u2019s had a publishing deal for three years.) In a two-hour conversation, she only blanched once, at the fact that until the end of last year no one had recorded one of her songs. \u201cWow, I wish we could smoke in here,\u201d she said.\n\nBut perhaps if Ms. McBryde had found songwriting lucrative, she would have missed out on becoming the artist she is today. (Before \u201cGirl Going Nowhere,\u201d she self-released two albums and an EP; the first of those albums is largely gone from the internet, the victim of \u201cnatural selection,\u201d she joked.) In that slow-moving country radio way, \u201cDahlonega,\u201d which initially came out 10 months ago, is only just now gaining traction; it\u2019s currently at No. 33 on the Billboard country airplay chart.\n\nIn the past year, she\u2019s sung with Eric Church, performed at the Ryman and recently toured as an opening act for Miranda Lambert. \u201cShe\u2019s got brass balls,\u201d Ms. McBryde said of Ms. Lambert. \u201cShe is a strong-personality female and chose to let a strong-personality female open the show.\u201d\n\nBut she is still living on the stipend from her publishing contract, and she has yet to pay herself for a concert. She resides in Watertown, a city of about 1,500 an hour east of Nashville, in a cabin on a 27-acre lot that also includes a horse barn. She\u2019s craving a new bed, and wants to replace the ceiling fan that kicks out a spark every time it turns on. But when she goes to the local bar \u2014 the one where no one knew she was a professional singer before she recorded the \u201cDahlonega\u201d video there \u2014 she orders a double Jim Beam and ginger ale and the Texas Pete hot wings, and doesn\u2019t have to worry about being anyone but herself.", "title": "Ashley McBryde Takes Nashville, No Gimmicks Required", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Equal parts trade fair, arts festival and synergistic marketing opportunity, New York\u2019s Asia Week, March 15-24, involves auctions at Bonhams, Christie\u2019s, Doyle and Sotheby\u2019s; scores of appointment-only private dealers opening their doors to the public; and tied-in museum shows as far afield as Newark, Princeton, N.J., and Stony Brook, N.Y.\n\nThe Metropolitan Museum alone has seven related shows (one of which Jason Farago of The New York Times recently reviewed). The week\u2019s overall vibe is more collectible than critical, but that\u2019s not a disparagement \u2014 the city is briefly full of rare and unusual objects you might never get to see again. The extremely partial list that follows contains two of the most important exhibitions and a handful of interesting gallery shows to pique your interest \u2014 but do yourself a favor and pick up a map.\n\nJAPAN SOCIETY", "title": "Asia Week\u2019s Rare and Unusual Objects for Art Lovers and Collectors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "After wobbling throughout the day, the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index turned decisively lower in the last hour of trading, closing down by 2.5 percent. That put the index into negative territory for the year.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nThe trade measures against China were the latest demonstration of Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cAmerica First\u201d agenda, and they were announced a day before tariffs on global steel and aluminum imports were expected to take effect.\n\nThe potential ripples of the trade actions have unsettled investors.\n\nTensions escalated on Friday as Beijing responded to Washington with its own tariffs and a warning to \u201cavoid damage to the broader picture of Chinese-U.S. cooperation.\u201d The Ministry of Commerce announced plans to slap tariffs on 128 products that would collectively be worth $3 billion in imports from the United States, including a 15 percent tariff on steel pipes, wine and fresh fruit, and a 25 percent tariff on pork.\n\nThe war of words spilled over into China\u2019s state-controlled media, as the Global Times newspaper warned in an editorial that Chinese citizens would likely start campaigns to boycott American cars and other products.\n\nSome American businesses in China also voiced concern. \u201cOur members do not want to see a trade war,\u201d said Kenneth Jarrett, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai. \u201cThe stakes are too high and there would be no winner,\u201d Mr. Jarrett said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut he added that American businesses in China wanted \u201cfairer treatment and improved market access in China. The Chinese government has the ability to deliver against that reasonable expectation.\u201d\n\nIn the United States, shares of large exporters, whose fortunes could be harmed by a trade war, were hit especially hard on Thursday and looked ready to bear the brunt of more selling on Friday. Shares of Boeing, one of the country\u2019s largest exporters, and Caterpillar, which counts China as an important market, both fell by more than 5 percent.\n\nShares of large technology companies, which had already been reeling in anticipation of tougher government oversight, also took a hit. Facebook, which has been contending with a crisis over data privacy, slumped by more than 2 percent. Alphabet, Google\u2019s parent company, dropped by more than 3.7 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmid the dip in stocks, money flowed to government bonds as investors sought safety, briefly driving yields on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note below 2.8 percent. Yields move in the opposite direction of bond prices. Commodities heavily geared toward global growth also fell. The price of West Texas intermediate crude oil, the American benchmark, slipped 1.2 percent. Copper, an important industrial metal, dropped 0.9 percent.\n\nThursday\u2019s decline is the latest in a series of jolts to stock markets in the past two months.\n\nAfter more than a year of calm, in which stock markets glided to one record high after another, a wave of volatility is suddenly cresting. There have been many causes of the turbulence this month and last. Investors initially were fearful that the economy was getting too strong, and that rising wages might cause inflation, which would push the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates faster than investors previously had expected. Those concerns have partly faded as recent economic data showed that inflation remained in check.\n\nMore recently, market anxiety has shifted toward worries about geopolitics.\n\nA growing public backlash against technology companies has increased the chances that lawmakers and regulators in the United States and elsewhere will intensify their scrutiny of them. Shares of those companies have helped propel markets to record highs, and their recent declines have led markets lower.\n\nNow, the prospect of a trade war between China and the United States, the two largest economies, has added to the gloomy sentiment. Among the concerns is that protectionism poses a risk to the health of the world economy. On Thursday, for example, the Bank of England warned that the erection of international trade barriers could have a \u201csignificant negative impact\u201d on global growth.\n\nStock markets around the world have reflected the worries. A leading European index, the Stoxx 600, fell more than 1.5 percent on Thursday. In Germany, whose economy is dependent on exporting products all over the world, the DAX index dropped 1.7 percent.", "title": "Asian Stocks Tumble as Sell-Off Over Trade Fears Continues", "authors": ["Alexandra Stevenson", "Matt Phillips"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Watching,\n\nMy husband and I, newly retired baby boomers, haven\u2019t watched much TV since college. We had no TV in the house when the kids were little (1967-1985), begrudgingly got one and kept it in the basement when they were teens, and then abandoned it when they left the nest.\n\nBut now \u2026 with more time on our hands and (we like to think) some great things to watch, we want to make up for lost time. A 30-60 minute show is a great interlude before bedtime! But we simply do not know where to begin.\n\nWe are torn between \u201ccatching up\u201d with shows that portray our generation (like \u201cMad Men,\u201d \u201cCurb Your Enthusiasm\u201d) or \u201cmoving forward\u201d with shows that are popular with younger folks now \u2014 like \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d which would require a great deal of watching if we wanted to catch up.\n\nIn summary: Advice, please, for formerly TV-averse baby boomers.\n\nDear Formerly TV-Averse,\n\nI don\u2019t even like \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d that much, but I think you should give it a try, especially if you\u2019re inclined toward fantasy stuff in general. There are currently 67 episodes, which maybe sounds like a lot, but even if you only did a few a week, that\u2019s barely a trimester\u2019s worth of viewing.\n\n0\n\nThe best reason to watch \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d isn\u2019t that it\u2019s good, it\u2019s that it\u2019s often fun to engage with. When it\u2019s in season, it is the show people want to talk about, and trading theories and gripes and hopes is like being in a large, joyous, dorky club. Water cooler shows barely exist anymore, but this is one of them. I like the discourse; I like the disagreements; I like pestering my one friend who is a \u201cSong of Ice and Fire\u201d obsessive with my questions about exactly who everyone is.\n\nIf you care not at all about ephemera, or you dislike gruesome violence, then I hereby grant you total dispensation from having to care at all about \u201cGame of Thrones.\u201d\n\nThe good news is that there\u2019s never been a better time to catch up on TV, and the great news is that we\u2019re all doing it. Younger folks are watching \u201cCurb Your Enthusiasm\u201d and \u201cMad Men\u201d for the first time, too. \u201cThe Office\u201d is somehow popular with teenagers. People tell me all the time that they\u2019re finally getting around to watching \u201cThe Wire.\u201d I can\u2019t stop talking about \u201cER\u201d and recommending it to every person I know who hasn\u2019t seen it before. (And even to those who have.)\n\nSo where should you start?\n\nStart with \u201cFrasier.\u201d \u201cFrasier\u201d is smart and funny and easy to watch, and even though it debuted in 1993, it\u2019s remarkably timeless. You can also come and go from it as you please; if you get tired of it, just move on to different show \u2014 it\u2019s not as if some lingering cliffhanger will haunt you. It\u2019s also weirdly zeitgeisty, with a surprisingly robust Twitter presence.\n\nBuild yourself a balanced breakfast. \u201cFrasier\u201d is the comedy to start with, but you need a drama, too. For that, let\u2019s move ahead in time a little to \u201cThe Good Wife,\u201d a superb lawyer show that debuted in 2009. Its spinoff, \u201cThe Good Fight,\u201d is currently airing (well, streaming on CBS All Access), and it is pretty good, too.\n\nFrom there, you\u2019ll be able to tell if you want more of the same, or something different. More shows like \u201cFrasier\u201d? Well, \u201cCheers\u201d for starters (it\u2019s where Kelsey Grammer\u2019s Frasier character was introduced), and then \u201cSeinfeld.\u201d Other good lawyer shows? Try \u201cDamages,\u201d or if you want something quicker, \u201cGoliath.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s never a bad idea to visit the HBO catalog: \u201cThe Sopranos,\u201d \u201cDeadwood,\u201d \u201cEnlightened,\u201d \u201cThe Larry Sanders Show,\u201d \u201cIn Treatment,\u201d \u201cSix Feet Under.\u201d\n\nIf what you really want is series you can start and finish in a short period of time, embrace the mini-series. Watch the classic 1981 \u201cBrideshead Revisited,\u201d which is 11 episodes. Or try the recent British mini-series \u201cNational Treasure,\u201d which is just four. If you like documentaries, you have to watch both \u201cPlanet Earth\u201d series.\n\nFinally, free yourself of any kind of pressure or worry that there\u2019s a single \u201cbest\u201d way that you\u2019re in danger of not following. Did you watch something you liked? Then congratulations, you won.\n\nRead more: I Grew Up Without TV. What Have I Missed?", "title": "Ask Watching: We\u2019re Baby Boomers Who Never Really Watched TV. Where Do We Start?", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Right after that scene, my television cut to a commercial for Victoza, a diabetes treatment from Novo Nordisk. There were scenes of a woman in a doctor\u2019s office, an older couple gardening, women painting sunflowers. There were side effects: \u201cnausea, diarrhea, vomiting, decreased appetite, indigestion and constipation.\u201d At 90 seconds, it felt almost infomercial length, until the next commercial came on. For Victoria\u2019s Secret.\n\nMy family are faithful \u201cblack-ish\u201d viewers \u2014 funny show, great cast. But a season earlier we had endured what Vulture called \u201cessentially a long commercial for Disney World,\u201d the obligatory episode where a Disney sitcom goes to Disney World.\n\nNow it was time for Diabetes World, brought to you by Novo Nordisk.\n\nIn the United States, when the Food and Drug Administration eased the advertising rules in 1997, it paved the way for an explosion of TV commercials pitching prescription drugs. Drug makers have had less success lobbying in other parts of the world.\n\nI asked Novo Nordisk about this. Anthony Anderson, who plays Dre, has diabetes in real life and is the company\u2019s paid spokesman. His story is compelling. Not only did he struggle coming to grips with the disease, but his father died of complications from diabetes a decade ago.\n\n\u201cOne of the things we felt was important was it needed to be natural and it needed to tell his story, but it also needed to be medically accurate,\u201d said David Moore, a senior vice president at Novo Nordisk. \u201cWe had individuals from our medical affairs really review the script, in the context of this is what a conversation would really sound like with a clinician.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nABC declined to comment.\n\nI don\u2019t know how I feel about a drug company\u2019s collaborating on a sitcom script, though it\u2019s a little weird that the story and the commercials ran together. More important, it probably doesn\u2019t help the soaring cost of prescription drugs. Companies spend more than $6 billion a year on this kind of advertising, according to Kantar Media.\n\nAdvertising budgets are by no means the biggest factor in drug costs. There is blame to go around.\n\nDrug companies are stretching out their patent protections by seeking approvals for existing drugs to treat different diseases. There is also no nationwide body negotiating drug prices as you\u2019ll find in other countries, and insurers are often looking out for themselves rather than patients. Sometimes buying a drug with insurance is even more expensive than without it, or insurers refuse to cover the cost of a generic drug.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis past week, UnitedHealthcare, one of the largest insurers, said it would stop keeping the rebates it got from drug companies, an issue that is of particular concern to the Type 1 Diabetes Defense Foundation, an advocacy group. \u201cAny serious political conversation on economic incentives and prescription drug cost must begin from the market distortions created when insurers and other payers negotiate rebates\u201d but don\u2019t pass them through to patients, said Charles Fournier, the foundation\u2019s vice president.\n\nIf nothing else, advertising brings us closer to how the drug business works, even if on a subliminal level.\n\n\u201cThe conditions that are being promoted change over time in conjunction with the patent cycle,\u201d Jon Swallen, chief research officer at Kantar, said. They also change with public health trends and research and development investments.\n\nThe closer a patent gets to expiring, the less enthusiastic companies can get about advertising. Hence the era of erectile dysfunction commercials for Viagra and Cialis yielded to omnipresent spots for Humira and Enbrel, used for rheumatoid arthritis and a range of other conditions.\n\nGroups like the World Health Organization and Public Citizen have raised concerns. The drug industry, as you might imagine, wants to keep advertising.\n\nCommercials \u201ccan benefit health care professionals, as well as patients,\u201d said Holly Campbell, a spokeswoman for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, an industry trade group, in an email. She cited a Harvard University/Massachusetts General Hospital survey from 2004 that found that \u201cone-quarter of adult patients who visited their physician after seeing\u201d a commercial \u201creceived a new diagnosis of a condition,\u201d and \u201cnearly half of the diagnoses were for \u2018high priority\u2019 conditions.\u201d\n\nBack to \u201cblack-ish.\u201d\n\nHard lessons were indeed learned on the show. Dre\u2019s venture into natural healing led him to pass out at a party, crushing a tower of champagne glasses. His wife, Rainbow, a doctor, explained to him that he had to take the medicine. \u201cLook, Dre,\u201d she said, \u201cthe important thing to know is that diabetes is not going to dia-beat us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHow long have you been holding on to that one?\u201d Dre asked, rolling his eyes.\n\nShe had a lot more in her pocket: \u201cIt\u2019s do or dia-beat-us!\u201d\n\nThe show promptly cut to a commercial for a Novo Nordisk long-acting insulin called Tresiba, which had a snappy jingle refrain \u2014 \u201cTre-siba ready!\u201d\n\nI\u2019m not going to stop watching \u201cblack-ish,\u201d but could we stick to the show, people?", "title": "Ask Your Doctor. Until Then, Here\u2019s a Word From Our Sitcom.", "authors": ["Danny Hakim"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "In March 2016 alone, a Trump rally in Chicago was called off after violent clashes broke out, while an anti-Trump protester was punched at a rally in North Carolina and another was punched and kicked at a rally in Arizona. The following month, several Trump supporters were assaulted at a California rally.\n\nMr. Trump himself repeatedly seemed to endorse attacks on his detractors, too.\n\n\u201cMaybe he should have been roughed up,\u201d he said of one protester who was reportedly punched and kicked in November 2015. \u201cI\u2019d like to punch him in the face, I\u2019ll tell ya,\u201d he said of another a few months later. He even offered to pay legal fees for his supporters if they became too aggressive.\n\nThe supporters also often aimed offensive and violent rhetoric at Mrs. Clinton, suggesting she be killed.\n\nTo determine whether those words and news reports corresponded with an actual shift in violence, the researchers compiled a list of 31 Trump rallies and 38 Clinton rallies held in cities with assault data available online.\n\nThey compared the number of assaults reported on the day of the rally to the number reported on the corresponding day of the week, for each of the four weeks before and after the event.", "title": "Assaults Increased When Cities Hosted Trump Rallies, Study Finds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "In the last 25 years, international cricketers have been punished for tampering with the ball in many ways \u2014 including keeping dirt in their pockets, rubbing a cough lozenge on the surface, scuffing the ball on the zips of their trousers and even biting the ball, which the Pakistan captain Shahid Afridi was found guilty of in 2010.\n\nEven mints and sweets can be used for nefarious ends. When England won the Ashes, a competition between England and Australia, in 2005, the English player Marcus Trescothick later admitted that he had applied saliva to one side of the ball after sucking mints. That tactic is thought to affect the flight of the ball by making one side slightly shinier.\n\nAnd when Australia last hosted South Africa in a series in 2016, the South Africa captain Faf du Plessis was caught sucking mints and then using his saliva to polish the ball on one side, again to try to alter the flight and bounce. He was later fined his match fee.\n\nThe incidents highlight how hard it is to eliminate ball-tampering, which is notoriously difficult to prove \u2014 adding saliva is legal, but doing so while sucking mints is not.\n\nSome have suggested that the laws should be revised, perhaps by legalizing some aspects of treating the ball, like using saliva after sucking candy or mints, that are especially hard to police.\n\nYet the actions of Bancroft \u2014 and, especially, Smith in instructing him \u2014 are seen as falling well beyond the normal ambiguity of the law. The Australians\u2019 actions amounted to nothing less than flagrant cheating.\n\nEven worse, perhaps, is the sense of what it revealed about the team, adding to simmering concerns about how far the Australian side are prepared to go in pursuit of an edge. During the recent Ashes victory against England, Australia came under criticism for what is known as sledging \u2014 the cricket equivalent of trash-talking \u2014 and for bowling the ball hard into the ground to make it bounce in the direction of the opponent\u2019s head.", "title": "Astonishing Admission of Cheating Rocks Australian Cricket", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat story could this image tell?\n\nUse your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration and post it in the comments.\n\nThen read the related article to find out what this picture is all about.", "title": "Astronaut and Spider", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cScott\u2019s DNA did not fundamentally change,\u201d the space agency said. \u201cWhat researchers did observe are changes in gene expression, which is how your body reacts to your environment. This likely is within the range for humans under stress, such as mountain climbing or SCUBA diving.\u201d\n\nIt continued: \u201cThe change related to only 7 percent of the gene expression that changed during spaceflight that had not returned to preflight after six months on Earth. This change of gene expression is very minimal.\u201d\n\nResearchers believe there is a lot to learn from the continuing twins study, which, using multiple independent researchers, measured Scott Kelly after his 340-day trip to the International Space Station in 2015 and 2016 against his twin brother, Mark, who is a retired astronaut. Scientists hope to better understand the effects of long-term space travel in preparation for trips to Mars, and the comparison with his twin offers scientists additional context.", "title": "Astronauts Mark and Scott Kelly Are Still Identical Twins, Despite What You May Have Read", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Herself the recipient of two Best Actress Oscars, for \u201cTo Each His Own\u201d (1946) and \u201cThe Heiress\u201d (1949), Ms. de Havilland filed the suit last June, right after \u201cFeud\u201d aired to widespread critical acclaim, and a day before she turned 101. It was also just a few weeks after the queen of England bestowed upon Ms. de Havilland, whose estranged and equally famous sister Joan Fontaine died in 2013, the title of dame for her service to drama.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhen \u2018Feud\u2019 was first being publicized, but before it went on the air, I was interested to see how it would portray my dear friend Bette Davis,\u201d Ms. de Havilland wrote in an email. \u201cThen friends and family started getting in touch with me, informing me that my identity was actually being represented on the program. No one from Fox had contacted me about this to ask my permission, to request my input, or to see how I felt about it. When I then learned that the Olivia de Havilland character called my sister Joan \u2018a bitch\u2019 and gossiped about Bette Davis and Joan Crawford\u2019s personal and private relationship, I was deeply offended.\u201d\n\nThe last time Ms. de Havilland had a case before the California Court of Appeals was in 1944. Risking her career, she sued Warner Bros. to get out of her contract, which she had signed in 1936. She had been suspended for refusing parts assigned to her, a common ploy among studio bosses to keep their stars in line, with the missed time tacked on to the length of her deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe was 28, a brunet ing\u00e9nue from English stock, raised in what she has wryly called \u201cthe most aristocratic village in the prune belt\u201d of Northern California. In the 1930s alone, she had starred with the swashbuckling Errol Flynn in six films, including \u201cThe Adventures of Robin Hood,\u201d and was lent out to David O. Selznick for the role that would make her an American treasure: Melanie Hamilton in \u201cGone With the Wind.\u201d\n\nShe won then, tipping the scales of studio autocracy and strengthening a California labor statute. The so-named De Havilland Law prohibits the enforcement of a personal services contract beyond seven years.\n\nThree quarters of a century later, Ms. de Havilland is hoping for another victory. \u201cFeud,\u201d she claims, as a work of historically convincing fiction, falsely exposes her as a hypocrite \u2014 \u201cwith a public image of being a lady and a private one as a vulgarity-using gossip,\u201d violating Ms. de Havilland\u2019s hard-earned reputation for \u201chonesty, integrity and good manners.\u201d\n\nThese are qualities that may seem quaint in the age of Twitter. But the legal action arrives during a content boom that has sent writers \u2014 and big-league actors and producers \u2014 raiding recent history sometimes before it has pickled, looking for figures and epochs to refashion as entertainment.\n\nPhoto\n\nCourts have overwhelmingly supported First Amendment protections for movies and TV shows about figures and subjects in the public interest. But Ms. de Havilland is undaunted.\n\n\u201cA large part of the reason I decided to move forward with my action against Fox is that I realize that at this stage of my life and career I am in a unique position to stand up and speak truth to power \u2014 an action that would be very difficult for a young actor to undertake,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI believe in the right to free speech, but it certainly must not be abused by using it to protect published falsehoods or to improperly benefit from the use of someone\u2019s name and reputation without their consent. Fox crossed both of these lines with \u2018Feud,\u2019 and if it is allowed to do this without any consequences, then the use of lies about well-known public figures masquerading as the truth will become more and more common. This is not moral and it should not be permitted.\u201d\n\nMs. de Havilland agrees to interviews sparingly, often mentioning her love of Champagne, and has never cooperated with an official biography. Hollywood chroniclers have described relationships with Mr. Flynn, John Huston and Howard Hughes, but she has remained regally mum, in contrast to her voluble friend Ms. Davis, who died in 1989.\n\nMs. de Havilland\u2019s memoir, \u201cEvery Frenchman Has One,\u201d published in 1962, is about being an American new to France, where she moved in 1955 after marrying her second husband, Pierre Galante, then the editor of Paris Match. She continued to work in movies while raising two children: a daughter Gisele, her child with Mr. Galante; and a son, Benjamin, from her first marriage to the novelist and screenwriter Marcus Goodrich. Tracey Jackson, a longtime friend, calls her \u201calmost Garboesque\u201d in her protectiveness over her private life.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen came \u201cFeud.\u201d\n\nA lavish piece of early 1960s period dish, it had considerable pedigree in its Oscar-winning leading ladies, Susan Sarandon as Bette Davis and Jessica Lange as Joan Crawford, and Mr. Murphy, whose portfolio of prestigious docudramas includes \u201cThe People v. O. J. Simpson\u201d and \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace,\u201d both part of his \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d serial.\n\n\u201cFeud\u201d explores Ms. Davis\u2019s and Ms. Crawford\u2019s longtime hatred for each other and their uneasy alliance during the making of \u201cWhat Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,\u201d the 1962 horror movie that finally united them onscreen. Directed by Robert Aldrich, it was a surprise hit in a Hollywood being slowly subsumed by the counterculture, featuring a sadistic Ms. Davis in Kabuki makeup mentally torturing her paraplegic sister, played by Ms. Crawford.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor her performance, Ms. Davis received her final Best Actress nomination, evidently sending the spurned Ms. Crawford on a furious campaign of Oscar-night, anti-Bette subterfuge. (One cannot imagine Frances McDormand and Meryl Streep clashing like this.) In the end, Ms. Davis lost to the absent Anne Bancroft for \u201cThe Miracle Worker,\u201d and a triumphant Ms. Crawford strode onto the stage to accept the statuette in Ms. Bancroft\u2019s honor.\n\nMs. de Havilland\u2019s character is used as a framing device for the Davis-Crawford cage match that unfolds in \u201cFeud,\u201d opening the series with the lines: \u201cFor nearly half a century, they hated each other, and we loved them for it.\u201d Ms. Zeta-Jones is posed on a love seat at the 1978 Oscars, giving an interview. \u201cFeud\u201d meticulously copied the black dress and sheer caftan the real Ms. de Havilland wore to the Oscars that night, as well as her glittering pendant and blond coif. This physical copycatting is behind Ms. de Havilland\u2019s right-of-publicity claim. Her claims of false light relate to the interview itself, which she says she never gave.\n\nTo prevail, Ms. de Havilland will have to convince a jury not only that the interview was fabricated, but also that it includes sentiments that the writers of \u201cFeud\u201d either knew were false or profferred in reckless disregard for the truth, causing economic damage to her reputation and \u201cemotional distress.\u201d Lawyers for Ms. de Havilland and FX are also engaged in a byzantine fact-check over Ms. de Havilland\u2019s use of coarse language in other scenes, most notably in reference to her sister, Ms. Fontaine.\n\nMs. Smith maintains that her client, at a minimum, should have been consulted about the project ahead of time. \u201cShe would have considered, what was their proposal?\u201d the lawyer said. \u201cAre they proposing to compensate her? They would have found out that certain things were not true. Because they didn\u2019t even try, in their arrogance and hubris, they didn\u2019t take what we would argue are reasonable steps to find out what was true, and what wasn\u2019t true.\u201d\n\nThe network says that Ms. de Havilland\u2019s consent was not needed, because \u201cFeud\u201d falls squarely under protected speech around fictional works in the public interest. Additionally, it contends that her portrayal is positive. \u201cWhile I understand Ms. de Havilland alleges that she was portrayed as a gossip, the opposite is true,\u201d said Mr. Murphy, who declined to comment for this article, in a declaration attached to FX\u2019s defense. \u201cShe is portrayed as a wise, respectful friend and counselor to Bette Davis, and a Hollywood icon with a unique perspective on the past.\u201d\n\nLast August, the network filed a motion to dismiss the case under California\u2019s anti-Slapp (Strategic Lawsuit Against Public Participation) statute, which allows for the quick dismissal of lawsuits that want to chill free speech. One month later, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Holly Kendig issued her ruling: While \u201cFeud\u201d arose from protected speech, Ms. de Havilland had adequately shown enough cause to deserve her day in court, with the suit fast-tracked because of the plaintiff\u2019s advanced age.\n\nPhoto\n\nLegal observers were surprised.\n\n\u201cIt is unusual for this type of case to proceed past anti-Slaap,\u201d said Jennifer Rothman, a professor at Loyola Law School and the author of a forthcoming book called \u201cThe Right of Publicity: Privacy Reimagined for a Public World.\u201d If the de Havilland decision were allowed to stand, Ms. Rothman said, \u201cthen that upends the film industry, the TV industry, the video game industry. Anyone who is trying to make stories based on true events with real people are not going to be able to do so without permission.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Ms. de Havilland has the backing of the Screen Actors Guild, considerable forces have amassed against her. The Motion Picture Association of America and the streaming behemoth Netflix, which just signed Mr. Murphy to an exclusive producing deal reportedly worth $300 million, filed an amicus brief urging the appellate court to reverse the trial judge\u2019s decision\u2014an unusual alliance in a universe of legacy companies fending off big-monied new media, but perhaps necessary to squash a uniquely sympathetic plaintiff.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe type of claims pursued by a celebrity like Olivia de Havilland here deserve especially heightened scrutiny because docudramas, biopics and historical dramas \u2014 which by design do not portray individuals or events literally or with obedience to historical fact \u2014 often depict real people who may not like, and may even be offended or embarrassed by, how they are portrayed,\u201d the M.P.A.A.-Netflix brief says.\n\nTo suggest that producers must purchase consent or life rights encourages only whitewashed portrayals, is the thinking.\n\nMoreover, according to Mr. Murphy, the five credited \u201cFeud\u201d writers \u201cendeavored in good faith to ensure that the dialogue from Zeta-Jones\u2019 characterization of de Havilland was based on comments, sentiments and tonal emotions expressed through the years by Ms. de Havilland herself.\u201d\n\nIt is common knowledge that Ms. de Havilland had her own feud with Ms. Fontaine; what\u2019s at issue is how it was conducted. \u201cDragon Lady, as I eventually decided to call her, was a brilliant, multitalented person, but with an astigmatism in her perception of people and events which often caused her to react in an unfair and even injurious way,\u201d Ms. de Havilland told The Associated Press in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFeud\u201d is more succinct. \u201cYou know what my bitch sister has taken to telling the press?\u201d Ms. de Havilland\u2019s character says to Ms. Davis in \u201cFeud.\u201d \u201cThat I broke her collarbone when we were children.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe thought \u2018bitch\u2019 was more mainstream and would be better understood by the modern audience than \u2018Dragon Lady,\u2019\u201d Tim Minear, a writer on the show, explained in court documents.\n\nLawyers for FX argue that the descriptors are synonyms. Further, they cite a vintage Warner Bros. blooper reel in which Ms. de Havilland lets forth with, \u201cOh, Christ, son of a bitch,\u201d after flubbing a line on the set of the 1946 film \u201cDevotion,\u201d in which she played the author Charlotte Bront\u00eb.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. de Havilland insists that the clip and others like it, which live on via YouTube, are exceptions. \u201cLooking back at my younger self, I wish I had been more guarded in my language,\u201d she told the court. \u201cBut these outtakes or bloopers are just that, mistakes and errors, not language that I did or would use in discussing other friends or family in a normal, polite, private or public forum.\u201d\n\nAs for the suggestion that Ms. de Havilland never publicly gossiped: \u201cPlaintiff gave many other television and print interviews in which she commented on other actors,\u201d according to FX\u2019s defense. \u201cIn an Academy of Achievement video interview, she criticized British actor Ralph Richardson: \u2018He would do rather naughty things. He was a glove flapper.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn its clearest form, the right of publicity, an offshoot of privacy law, is meant not as a tool of censorship but to enable celebrities and other public figures to protect their images from false or unauthorized endorsements of products. In California, a hub of entertainment where the law is most hotly contested, the issue hinges on whether the person\u2019s identity has been transformed \u2014 in other words, used as \u201cthe raw materials\u201d for creative expression \u2014 or merely co-opts the \u201csum and substance\u201d of the person wholesale.\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause the makers of \u201cFeud\u201d admitted that they wanted to make the appearance of the de Havilland character as real as possible, Judge Kendig said, her likeness was not transformed, leaving the mini-series open to a right of publicity claim.\n\nOn her right-of-publicity website in the last month alone, Ms. Rothman has tracked claims against \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d brought by an actor from the movie \u201cGoodfellas,\u201d and one by the estate of the jazz legend Thelonious Monk against a microbrewery making Brother Thelonious beer. In California cases like Ms. de Havilland\u2019s, are measured against a 2001 state Supreme Court ruling that established the transformative test to begin with.\n\nIn that case, the owners of the post-mortem rights of the Three Stooges sued a celebrity lithographer, Gary Saderup, for selling T-shirts bearing the comedy trio\u2019s images. The court found that Mr. Saderup was liable because his drawings were too imitative, failing to \u201ctransform\u201d the Stooges\u2019 likeness. (In its ruling, the court drew a distinction between Mr. Saderup\u2019s literal depiction of the Stooges and Andy Warhol\u2019s transformative screen prints of Marilyn Monroe.)\n\nMs. Rothman believes right-of-publicity law is more urgently needed in cases of catfishing and revenge porn, where the victims aren\u2019t celebrities or inherent publicity seekers.\n\nThere is precedent on both sides. Lawyers for Ms. de Havilland point to the Stooges case as well as a 2011 California appellate court ruling that found in favor of the band No Doubt, which sued the video game publisher Activision for violating the terms of a licensing agreement in the game Band Hero.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawyers for FX are more partial to a 1979 State Supreme Court decision disallowing a post-mortem right-of-publicity claim against a fictionalized TV movie about the life of Rudolph Valentino. Or an appellate court\u2019s 2016 denial of a claim brought by former Army Sgt. Jeffrey Sarver, an explosive ordnance disposal technician who sued the makers of the Oscar-winning film \u201cThe Hurt Locker.\u201d\n\nAs in \u201cThe Hurt Locker\u201d case, \u201cFeud\u201d \u201cis a docudrama, and therefore scenes are dramatized \u2014 i.e. transformed,\u201d the defense motion in de Havilland reads. Besides, Ms. Zeta-Jones wasn\u2019t even in enough of the mini-series to merit inclusion in the show\u2019s opening credits.\n\nAsked via email if her retirement from acting was a decision she came to with ease or difficulty, Ms. de Havilland said: \u201cI would like to answer your question with another: How many roles of significance are written for women of advanced years?\u201d\n\nAs \u201cFeud\u201d chronicles, she replaced Ms. Crawford on the \u201cBaby Jane\u201d follow-up, \u201cHush \u2026 Hush, Sweet Charlotte\u201d (though not before she either did or didn\u2019t tell the director, Mr. Aldrich: \u201c\u201cDarling, you know how much I hate to play bitches. They make me so unhappy.\u201d).\n\nBy the \u201970s, and \u201980s, Ms. de Havilland was down to sporadic mini-series, disaster movies and TV guest spots. In 1981 came an episode of \u201cThe Love Boat.\u201d The last movie she appeared in, for British TV, was in 1988.\n\nIt\u2019s a sadly familiar story about how Hollywood treats its female elders, something that Mr. Murphy kept pointing to as motivation for covering the Crawford-Davis story. As Ms. de Havilland awaits her public hearing, he has moved on to the next subjects in the \u201cFeud\u201d anthology: Prince Charles and Princess Diana.", "title": "At 101, a Survivor of Hollywood\u2019s Golden Age Throws Down the Gauntlet", "authors": ["Paul Brownfield"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Marina Stefanoni had barely stepped off the court when she was besieged by autograph seekers. One wanted her to sign a giant replica of a squash ball while another handed her a marker and his hand for her to write on.\n\nStefanoni had just lost her opening-round match at the Tournament of Champions, a $300,000 professional event played at Grand Central Terminal every January. But that did not matter to the gaggle of supporters who suffocated her with hugs and pieces of paper to sign. That\u2019s because, for the most part, they were Stefanoni\u2019s fellow junior squash players and her high school friends from Darien, Conn.\n\nJust 15, Stefanoni is a rare squash phenom. Unlike prodigies in tennis, like Tracy Austin, Monica Seles, Jennifer Capriati and Martina Hingis, teenagers in squash do not turn pro, partly because there is not a financial incentive to do so.\n\nBut Stefanoni is advanced for her years. In 2013, barely a year after she began playing squash, she won the national girls\u2019 under-11 title. Three years later, after winning back-to-back under-13 national championships, she became, at 13, the youngest winner of the under-19 national title, which she successfully defended last year. Stefanoni has won the United States Junior Open four times, including in the under-19 division in December. She has been ranked No. 1 in the under-19 division since March 2016, when she was just 13. She was granted a wild card to play in the Tournament of Champions, becoming the youngest competitor ever in the field.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAs soon as Marina came up through the pipeline, you knew there was something special about her,\u201d said the United States national team coach, Paul Assaiante, who has also coached Trinity College in Hartford to 15 national championships and a staggering 252-match win streak. \u201cFour years ago, she was running five-minute miles. And you could always see her zest for the game. During the breaks between games, you\u2019d see this little peanut jumping on a court somewhere just to hit for two minutes.\u201d", "title": "At 15, Juggling Freshman Year and an International Squash Career", "authors": ["Cindy Shmerler"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Earlier this year, both David Zwirner and Hauser & Wirth opened outposts in Hong Kong, joining other major dealers like Gagosian and White Cube, which already have spaces in the city. Galleries like Galerie Perrotin and Pace Gallery, which have a foot in the door, have been expanding their sizable presence in Asia, while L\u00e9vy Gorvy has opened offices in the region and is looking for an exhibition space here.\n\nTo the extent that art follows money, the tilt toward Asia comes as no surprise. A report released last year revealed that, for the first time, there are now more billionaires in Asia than in the United States. And that increase in wealth appears to be translating into more art sales. Last year, the Asian market accounted for 23 percent of global sales and Asian buyers accounted for 15 percent of dealer sales, according to an annual art market report commissioned by Art Basel and UBS released this month.\n\nMore and more Asian collectors are going to fairs like Art Basel in Basel, Switzerland, and Frieze, in New York, and coming back expecting to see works of comparable quality. \u2018\u2018The reason why galleries are starting to take Asian collectors more seriously is because the whole art ecosystem here \u2014 including the museums, collectors, and the local art fairs \u2014 is maturing very quickly,\u201d said Du Jie, 47, a Beijing-based collector. Mr. Du started collecting after taking an art appreciation class at the Central Academy of Fine Arts in Beijing three years ago. Since then, he has quickly amassed a collection of both Chinese and Western artists.", "title": "At Art Basel Hong Kong, Local Galleries Seek a Bigger Piece of the Action", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The pull that fairs exercise over attendees\u2019 minds and wallets is substantial. Just as the fairs can educate visitors about artists, they can seduce them into paying too much or buying too quickly. But experienced collectors advise caution for newcomers, saying it\u2019s better to wade in slowly.\n\nOn the other side, the mix of money and a broad audience has made fairs important not just to young artists and gallery owners but to some of the top artists and dealers in the world.\n\nThe David Zwirner Gallery, with spaces in New York, London and now Hong Kong, will show and sell work at 20 fairs around the world this year.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re educating the world about our program, but we\u2019re also getting to know the buyers in each market,\u201d Kristine Bell, a senior partner at Zwirner, said.\n\nThaddaeus Ropac, who operates five galleries in Europe, said he often used fairs to highlight different works by an artist he was showing in one of his galleries. Last year, he mounted a show of works by Georg Baselitz, a German painter and sculptor, in one of his Paris galleries. At the same time, he sold pieces by the artist from different points in his career at several fairs. The idea was to reinforce, not cannibalize, what was being sold in the gallery.\n\n\u201cThe important thing is, you always treat art fairs like a show,\u201d Mr. Ropac said.\n\nThat is as much a business decision as an aesthetic one. Even if the vast majority of fairgoers cannot or will not buy an expensive piece of art this week, a few will, and that\u2019s what matters to even the most successful gallery owners.\n\n\u201cWe have one of the largest galleries in New York, and we do all the things we\u2019re supposed to do,\u201d said Sean Kelly, a gallery owner who represents about 30 artists, including Kehinde Wiley, who painted former President Barack Obama\u2019s portrait and will have a booth at the Amory Show. \u201cBut the fact of the matter is, if you go to an art fair and get 60,000 people through in five days, we\u2019d never get that in the gallery. It\u2019s a very simple statistical game.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fairs are circuslike endeavors, with scores of galleries rolling into town and setting up displays of millions of dollars\u2019 worth of art for a multiday spectacle. And then everyone departs, as if leaving town at night with the big top.\n\n\u201cWhen we started, there were maybe six fairs,\u201d said Nicole Berry, executive director of the Armory Show, which is in its 24th year. \u201cNow, there\u2019s a fair somewhere in the world every weekend.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Armory Show, spread over more than 250,000 square feet, will include about 200 galleries from 31 countries and sell art priced from several thousands of dollars up to millions, Ms. Berry said.\n\nOpinion about fairs among art advisers \u2014 those people who guide the hearts, minds and wallets of top collectors \u2014 is split.\n\n\u201cA fair offers the opportunity to see as much work as possible in a short amount of time,\u201d said Ashley Carr, a co-founder of the Modica Carr Art Advisory in New York. \u201cThat has its benefits for people who are incredibly busy and can\u2019t go to galleries every weekend or can\u2019t travel to shows.\u201d\n\nShe creates a plan for her clients so they can make the most of their time, looking at art, talking to the gallery owners and sometimes meeting the artists.\n\nBut Lisa Schiff, an international art adviser who has consulted for the actor Leonardo DiCaprio\u2019s foundation, takes a different view. \u201cI don\u2019t like fairs because it\u2019s a pileup of merchandise,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Schiff cautioned collectors, particularly new ones, not to buy at an art fair. That same atmosphere that creates excitement makes it hard to properly assess an artist, she said. But she acknowledged the convenience, comparing the experience to ordering online as opposed to shopping at a smaller business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI usually end up doing a lot of business at fairs even though it\u2019s not my intention,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Lumpkin, who sits on the board of the Studio Museum in Harlem, had several pieces of advice for a first-time fairgoer or buyer. Avoid being taken in by any hype around an individual artist, he said: \u201cBuy with your eyes and not with your ears.\u201d\n\nAttendees also need to strike a balance between impulse and hesitation. On the one hand, he said, people should not be afraid to wait and follow up after the fair if they see something they like. On the other hand, he said, \u201cif you see something good and like it, jump on it before it\u2019s gone.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s those types of conflicting emotions that make fairs exciting but also risky for buyers prone to quick decisions. The lead sponsor of this year\u2019s Armory Show is Athena Art Finance, which specializes in lending quickly to collectors buying art.\n\n\u201cClients, literally in front of the painting, text me a picture and say, \u2018How much would you lend me if I bought this painting?\u2019\u201d said G. Andrea Danese, president and chief executive of Athena.\n\nThe answer is less than the purchase price. \u201cThe sale price isn\u2019t so relevant to us \u2014 it\u2019s inflated,\u201d Mr. Danese said. Generally, if the work is by a known artist with a sales history, the firm takes 20 to 25 percent off the price and then lends about half that amount.\n\nThe company, which has been open for about three years, has $180 million in loans outstanding, ranging from four months to five years.\n\nBut that type of financial engineering is at the top of the art fair market.\n\nMr. Lumpkin, who attended a private reception on the opening night of the Art Show this week, said he still appreciated the fairs for the openness they projected in the otherwise rarefied world of high-priced art. He called them \u201cone of the few democratic arenas where anyone can, in theory, walk in and buy something.\u201d\n\n\u201cOf course, the reality is that a lot of the best work is already presold or on reserve when the fair opens,\u201d he added. \u201cAnd just because you can afford to buy a work of art doesn\u2019t mean the gallery will sell it to you,\u201d because galleries often want their artists\u2019 work in the hands of respected collectors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for an afternoon, at least, an art fair lets you dream. \u201cEnjoy the people-watching,\u201d Ms. Schiff said, \u201cand the food.\u201d", "title": "At Art Fairs, Keep an Open Mind, but Watch the Wallet", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "When the police arrested Mr. St. Hubert, he had recently been released from prison, where he had served a five-year term for trying to kill his mother. He had long a criminal record and a history of mental illness. He told the first investigators who questioned him, \u201cSatan has powers and controls things.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the days that followed his arrest, a public debate emerged about how the city treated prisoners with psychiatric problems. It seemed at first that Mr. St. Hubert might mount an insanity defense, but two psychiatric evaluations concluded that he was competent for trial. He is charged with second-degree murder and with attempted murder.\n\nAt the trial, in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Mr. St. Hubert, 31, sat beside his lawyer each day, mostly stone-faced and wearing a rosary. It was the victim\u2019s loved ones who often showed emotion. When gory photographs of P.J.\u2019s body and the elevator\u2019s bloody floor were introduced as evidence, the children\u2019s relatives gasped aloud and wept.\n\nThough the early investigation progressed in fits and starts, by the time the trial began, the prosecution had amassed a trove of evidence. That included four separate witnesses who claimed they had seen Mr. St. Hubert leaving the building where the stabbings occurred and cellphone records that placed him in the area at the time of the attacks. There was also the DNA connecting him to the knife and the testimony of Mikayla, now 11, who said that Mr. St. Hubert had suddenly assaulted her and P.J. after they were chatting in the elevator and refused his order to shut up.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
