View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his closing argument on Thursday, Mr. Greenberg took the risky tack of going after Mikayla, telling the jury that she was \u201cdelusional\u201d and \u201ca pathological liar.\u201d The girl had not been completely truthful on the stand, having testified that she had picked out Mr. St. Hubert in a photograph while she was in the hospital, when in fact the first time she identified him was in court.\n\nAddressing the jury with notes scrawled on napkins and loose scraps from a legal pad, Mr. Greenberg also sought to discredit the DNA evidence, which he described as \u201cstatistical lies.\u201d He claimed his client was a \u201cpatsy\u201d who was \u201cconvicted\u201d by the media after being framed by the police.\n\nIn his own summation, the lead prosecutor, Patrick O\u2019Connor, led the jury through what each witness had seen and included Mr. St. Hubert\u2019s movements on the day of the attacks. He reminded the panel not only that the defendant\u2019s DNA had been discovered on the handle of the weapon, but also that a set of matching knives had been found at the homeless shelter where he had been living when the children were attacked.\n\nBut it was only toward the end of his presentation that Mr. O\u2019Connor addressed the issue of a motive. The jurors, who will be on a break next week, will not begin deliberations until April 9, but as Mr. O\u2019Connor prepared to leave the case in their hands, he said that Mr. St. Hubert had \u201ca generalized intent to harm society\u201d and wanted \u201cto put the fear of God in Brooklyn.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe was out there to kill,\u201d he said.", "title": "At Brooklyn Trial, a Motive in Child\u2019s Murder Remains Elusive", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Cheese plays a tempting role in the Aesop\u2019s fable \u201cThe City Mouse and the Country Mouse,\u201d so it only stands to reason that a restaurant that takes its name from the tale does so well by dairy: lush feta-style cheese from France, burrata from California that smoothly buddies up with crisp brussels sprouts, bold Cheddar in a bite called Country Mouse.\n\nThe location may have played a part as well: City Mouse is in the dapper new Ace Hotel Chicago in a space that for decades was an Italian cheese factory called Anona. Ace has earned a reputation for showcasing standout local chefs at its properties; for its hotel in the West Loop neighborhood, the choice was the team from the restaurant Giant, including one of its chefs, Jason Vincent.\n\nGiant is actually pretty small \u2014 it has 44 seats in a Logan Square storefront \u2014 whereas City Mouse has more than 2 50 when its patio is open. But, Mr. Vincent said, the operating principle behind the menus is similar: \u201cFood tastes better when it has something bitter, something sour, something salty, something sweet and something funky and it\u2019s got some texture.\u201d\n\nTo make that happen at City Mouse, the Giant crew enlisted the chef Pat Sheerin, formerly of the city\u2019s much-praised Trenchermen and, before that, the Signature Room on the 95th floor of the John Hancock Center.", "title": "At City Mouse in Chicago, It Starts With Cheese (of Course)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The campus of Columbia University is dotted with monuments to illustrious alumni and high-minded ideals. But on a sunny afternoon earlier this week, about two dozen people gathered around the sundial in its central plaza to pay tribute to a momentous event that has gone uncommemorated in stone.\n\n\u201cHoram expecta veniet \u2014 await the hour, it shall come,\u201d Frank Guridy, an associate professor of history at the university, proclaimed, reading a Latin inscription on the sundial. \u201cI think it\u2019s sort of poetic that things began here.\u201d\n\n\u201cThings\u201d is an understatement for what began at Columbia around noon on April 23, 1968, when students, united by opposition to plans to build a university gym in a nearby public park and by Columbia\u2019s involvement in weapons research, converged on that spot. A week later, nearly a thousand activists had occupied five buildings (including the president\u2019s office), taken the dean hostage and shut down the campus, before being removed by the police in a violent melee that ended with one of the largest mass arrests in New York City history.\n\nAnniversaries of Columbia 1968 tend to arrive like a classic rock hit, replayed nostalgically by those who were there. But it\u2019s a story, Professor Guridy told the group of current students and former strikers who had gathered for a walking tour of sites relating to the protests, that is only now, as the 50th anniversary approaches, being fully understood.", "title": "At Columbia, Revisiting the Revolutionary Students of 1968", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Every so often, I\u2019ll wake up to an inbox full of friendly emails from people volunteering to help me do my job. The specific assistance they are offering is to meet me at some forthcoming restaurant, their stomachs empty and ready to contain at least half the menu. When I get three or four of these volunteers on the same morning, it invariably means that while I was sleeping other people were reading the advance press on an incipient opening that sounds both unusually enticing and intimidatingly expensive.\n\nThe most recent rush of volunteers, it turned out, was inspired by the arrival in December of a Manhattan branch of the Beijing-based restaurant DaDong. While the Beijingese have excelled at the art of duck roasting for centuries, DaDong, I learned, is a relative newcomer, founded in the 1990s by the chef Dong Zhenxiang.\n\nAt the restaurants \u2014 there are 10 in Beijing and six in other Chinese cities, not counting casual spinoffs \u2014 the birds revolve, a dozen at a time, inside a circular wood-fueled oven that Mr. Dong has patented. The result is what some people consider Beijing\u2019s best Peking duck. This is a magical combination of words. \u201cBeijing\u2019s best Peking duck\u201d suggests a mandatory eating experience in a way that, say, \u201cRussia\u2019s best Russian dressing\u201d does not.\n\nIt took me and my first corps of volunteers some time to find one another because the restaurant\u2019s address, 3 Bryant Park, implied that the entrance would be somewhere around Bryant Park. DaDong is inside a stack of glass-and-steel blocks that has somehow been plunked down west of the park between 42nd and 41st Streets, beside a pocket plaza that was new to me, although the skateboarders seemed to know all about it.", "title": "At DaDong in Midtown, Modern Art and Lame Duck", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The meatballs alone made me jealous of Ms. Lee\u2019s childhood. Called dong-gue-rang-taeng, they\u2019re part of a beloved category of battered and fried foods often prepared for Korean holidays and jesa, the annual ceremony to honor one\u2019s ancestors. Here, they\u2019re a tender meld of ground pork flecked with carrots and green onion, slightly flattened into a kind of carnal currency.\n\nThe breading \u2014 a dredge in flour, a dip in egg wash \u2014 is so light as to be barely noticeable, beyond the richness it brings. But note the high gloss, like a candy apple\u2019s: At the last moment, the meatballs are anointed with a glaze of salty and sweet held in perfect suspension, neither flavor dominating the other.\n\nWhat goes into the glaze the younger Ms. Lee would not say. \u201cMy mother is very secretive,\u201d she said. (Once she took a picture of a dish in progress and the elder Ms. Lee admonished her: \u201cDon\u2019t put that on Instagram!\u201d)\n\nBalance is a theme, notably in pork bulgogi, which unlike some versions in town doesn\u2019t capitulate to sugar. Dumplings, packed with lush pork and cabbage, are steamed before frying so the skin takes on a faint crackle while the meat says juicy within.\n\nThere is a graceful economy to the small kitchen, with vegetables seasoned one by one and recurring as a steady motif. For japchae, chewy sweet-potato glass noodles the color of fading photographs are tangled with wood ear mushrooms, skinny strips of carrot, darkened spinach and cabbage still holding its crunch. Typically each ingredient is fried separately, but the elder Ms. Lee flings them together in the pan, on the theory that the brief skirmish draws out more flavor. She\u2019s right.", "title": "At Ejen in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a Mother\u2019s Touch Infuses the Menu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s comfortable,\u201d he said before taking a seat at a table. \u201cYou\u2019re not going in here for ambience. I\u2019m not going in for the d\u00e9cor. I\u2019m not looking at the colors. You\u2019re not looking at that. You\u2019re going here for the food.\u201d\n\nEl Quijote opened in 1930, according to its website, and carried on through the decades. The restaurant consultant Michael Whiteman \u2014 \u201cthe last time I was there, I think, was 100 years ago\u201d \u2014 called it a time capsule. \u201cThat stretch of 23rd Street kind of fell off the radar,\u201d he said. \u201cIt got seedy,\u201d while new restaurants opened on blocks to the north and south.\n\nThe 23rd Street block was dominated by the Chelsea Hotel, \u201ca cross,\u201d as someone once described it, \u201cbetween the Plaza and the Port Authority Bus Terminal.\u201d It was famous for its habitu\u00e9s \u2014 Mark Twain, O. Henry, Dylan Thomas, Bob Dylan and Janis Joplin crossed the threshold at onetime or another. And there was the room in which 20-year-old Nancy Spungen lived with her boyfriend, Sid Vicious, of the punk rock group Sex Pistols. She was found stabbed to death there in 1978.\n\nBut the Chelsea, with new owners, is undergoing renovations. There is scaffolding and netting outside, and one of the owners, Ira Drukier, said it was structural work that forced the closing of the restaurant.\n\n\u201cThe issue was simply that we had work to do in the basement for the renovation of the building,\u201d he said.\n\nAs for El Quijote, he said, \u201cWe\u2019re trying to maintain what it is.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to dramatically change it in any crazy way,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a Spanish restaurant that people have fallen in love with over the years, and we\u2019d like to maintain that feeling after we open. It won\u2019t be spic and span and cleaned up to be pristine. It will try to maintain its character as much as we can.\u201d\n\nHe said El Quijote had been \u201cstruggling along\u201d until the closing was announced.\n\n\u201cIt wasn\u2019t making enough to support itself,\u201d he said, though he added, \u201cIt wasn\u2019t losing a lot.\u201d He said the goal was to complete the renovations and reopen in about six months, though the project might take longer.", "title": "At El Quijote, One Last Helping of Charm, Kitsch and Memories", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The audience loved everything \u2014 and loved Ms. Yerbabuena most. The production\u2019s choreographer and the only woman onstage, she used five supporting male dancers who often appeared bare-chested. She, at her most gracious and skillful, did a great deal with shawls. But you could believe that, as the program says, she first formed an independent flamenco company in 1998. For her, everything seemed to be happening for the thousandth time.\n\nMr. Carmona\u2019s show, \u201c\u00cdmpetus,\u201d suffered from the same overproduction. Some sections featured a scrim, with Mr. Carmona in front and his colleagues behind; others presented Mr. Carmona as just one of the troupe. Lighting, by David P\u00e9rez, often gave absurd emphasis to the slightest change of personnel onstage, as when one woman left the stage (sudden darkness on that side before her exit) and then, a few seconds later, returned with castanets (whereupon the stage light was transformed).\n\nBut whereas Ms. Yerbabuena\u2019s production values express the often synthetic nature of her presentation, Mr. Carmona\u2019s merely distract from the force of his dance theater. In his early 30s, he contains a number of contradictions. His troupe is called Ballet Flamenco Jes\u00fas Carmona, and it\u2019s not hard to identify several ballet-derived ingredients \u2014 as in the partnering, arm positions and lightness of one male-female pas de deux. Nonetheless, Mr. Carmona\u2019s general emphasis is brilliantly percussive, his rhythms often develop an exciting irregularity, and, though he uses the upper body well (both in his own dancing and his colleagues\u2019), he usually avoids any balletic refinement. He\u2019s fond of series of rapid single pirouettes, but one of his fortes is the way he does these with his torso thrillingly angled way off the vertical.\n\nA detail that increasingly entranced me was the simplicity of Mr. Carmona\u2019s hands. Often, keeping wrists, thumbs and palms still, he would just move the four fingers softly to the beat: a wonderfully gentle effect from a dancer who at first seemed so flamboyant. Too many flamenco dancers keep proclaiming themselves, but Mr. Carmona mainly dances as if driven by a larger \u2014 and sometimes sweet \u2014 force. His dancing contains both thunder and fire; yet he and his colleagues can also be blithe, like a breeze on a sunny spring day.", "title": "At Flamenco Festival, Finding the Force Beneath the Glitz", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Palestinian health officials said 15 Palestinians were killed by Israeli fire and more than 750 hit by live rounds Friday, making it the bloodiest day in Gaza since the 2014 cross-border war between Israel and Hamas.\n\nIn Friday\u2019s confrontations, large crowds gathered near the fence, with smaller groups of protesters rushing forward, throwing stones and burning tires.\n\nPhoto\n\nIsraeli troops responded with live fire and rubber-coated steel pellets, while drones dropped tear gas from above.\n\nOn Saturday, the chief army spokesman, Brig. Gen. He said Gaza health officials exaggerated the number of wounded, and that several dozen at most had been injured by live fire, with others suffering from tear gas inhalation or other types of injuries.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. That\u2019s its own kind of technology but it\u2019s more human: the making of a watch versus new technology.\n\nImage Graff Floral, introduced at Baselworld 2018.\n\nWhat are clients looking for now?\n\nOur clients are the V.V.I.P.s, so they expect something unique. They have the amazing boat, the amazing house, the amazing plane \u2014 and they want the same from jewelry. Through our stores, we have direct contact with our clients, and the ability to quickly tailor-make something for them in our workshops. We can produce a custom piece in just three months. This to me is the new definition of luxury.\n\nHow are Graff\u2019s watches changing to suit modern tastes?\n\nWe\u2019re not thinking about ceramic or some high-tech material \u2014 we have to stay true to our DNA, which is our expertise in diamonds and high jewelry. When I arrived at the company two years ago, I transferred our women\u2019s watch designs from the watchmaking office in Geneva to our jewelry design department in London. The designers complained \u2014 \u201cwe don\u2019t know anything about watches!\u201d \u2014 but they have the perfect touch, the femininity, the sense of jewelry. They think about the product without the technical restraints of a watch, so you get these designs that are very innovative and beautiful as jewelry, and recognizable as Graff pieces.\n\nWill the economic downturn continue to be a factor in your industry?\n\nOur watch sales are growing but, since we only started a decade ago, we\u2019re up from zero; now it\u2019s probably 8 percent to 9 percent of our business. Overall, it appears we\u2019ve passed the period of turmoil. I\u2019d like to see numbers from all of my colleagues but it seems the trouble in the watch business is starting to change slightly.\n\nWhat other factors do you see changing the market?\n\nThe way you purchase: Before, you\u2019d go to the store, now you go to e-commerce even for watches, which is a very conservative market. One day, but not quite yet, online will have to become part of Graff\u2019s retail network, too, and that will accelerate sales to the new generation because, for them, it\u2019s natural to click on their iPad and buy.", "title": "At Graff, Diamonds Are Fine With Sneakers and Jeans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "A visiting Chinese scholar studies obesity and antibiotics. Two more researchers, Dr. Blaser said, are looking at \u201can organism that many people have in their gut that may be protective against kidney stones.\u201d\n\nSome microbes are misunderstood. Take Helicobacter pylori, a passenger in the human gut for thousands of years linked in the last century to certain cancers.\n\n\u201cBecause of ulcer and stomach cancer, doctors, mostly gastroenterologists, said we should just get rid of H. pylori from everybody,\u201d Dr. Blaser said. \u201cBut I began to think differently.\u201d\n\nResearch from the National Cancer Institute published in January found a potential downside to its disappearance, linking its loss to a new gastric cancer more likely in younger patients and women.\n\n\u201cNature abhors a vacuum, and if Helicobacter, which was dominant, is gone, something is replacing it, or some things are replacing it, and that has consequences,\u201d Dr. Blaser said.\n\nScientists like Dr. Blaser worry that we are too often exposed to antibiotics, beyond when we actually need them. But the United States has resisted more aggressive restrictions on livestock antibiotics that countries like the Netherlands have taken. As of last year, the Food and Drug Administration barred meat producers from using antibiotics to increase the growth of animals, rather than to treat disease. Veterinary prescriptions are now required for farm antibiotics.\n\nBut the new rules were designed in cooperation with drug companies and industrial farm groups.\n\n\u201cThat didn\u2019t affect us,\u201d Mr. Defoor of Cactus said of the ban; his company sees the antibiotics added to feed as a preventive health measure. Similarly, Zoetis, a major livestock drugmaker, said on its website that farmers \u201cwill see little difference\u201d in its tetracycline feed additives, beyond needing the appropriate paperwork from veterinarians.", "title": "At Hamburger Central, Antibiotics for Cattle That Aren\u2019t Sick", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "HANCOCK, Mass. \u2014 Jennifer Trainer Thompson visited Hancock Shaker Village after moving to the Berkshires in the mid-1980s. She wandered around the pastoral landscape and through the 19th-century Round Stone Barn and learned about the industrious lifestyle of the religious sect that had lived there.\n\nThen, like many village visitors, she mostly forgot about the place.\n\n\u201cI came once because I was intrigued,\u201d she said. \u201cI came back the next time when I had little kids because I wanted to see baby animals. But there was no reason to return, because especially in this day and age, so many other things beckon: your phone, your activities, your friends, your life.\u201d", "title": "At Hancock Shaker Village, Concerts, a Farm-to-Table Menu and Goat Yoga", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "For years they had skirted tubs full of the stamps that were stored in the cellar of the workshop, not far from the boutique.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was only when they thought about making the medal designs the basis of the anniversary collection that they hired a historian.\n\nThe historian, who did not want to be named, said he had been collecting Hemmerle medals since he was 7 years old. He told them to look for a ledger, noting which stamps were used for which decorations, as well as proof sheets of the stamps\u2019 designs.\n\nA treasure hunt followed and, along with the ledger, they finally discovered a large box full of cards listing the medals and the corresponding stamps attached with wire. \u201cIt felt like Christmas,\u201d Ms. Hemmerle, 34, said with a smile.\n\nThe most striking jewels in the anniversary collection \u2014 which has nine earring designs, a bangle and a brooch \u2014 are the Pegasus earrings. They depict the winged horse of Greek mythology in pav\u00e9 diamonds, flying gracefully across a night sky of midnight-blue anodized aluminum.\n\nThe Pegasus motif originated with a tiny iron stamp once used for the arts medal of the Maximiliansorden, an order established in the 1800s by King Maximilian II of Bavaria to recognize outstanding achievements in science and art. Hemmerle started making the decoration in 1905, and the medal, held by a maximum of 100 people at any time, is one of only two it still produces for the Bavarian government.\n\nLike most of Hemmerle\u2019s creations, the earrings started with a rudimentary sketch. Despite the modernity of its aesthetic, Hemmerle rejects computer-aided design. \u201cThe lines all look the same if created by computer, no matter the house designing them,\u201d said Christian Hemmerle, 37.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, the Hemmerles trust their 22 artisans to interpret what they want into hard metals and gemstones. \u201cOur sketches are a language that the goldsmiths must decipher. They\u2019re our hieroglyphics,\u201d said Ms. Hemmerle, who was born in Egypt.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer birthplace inspired an Egyptian collection by Hemmerle in 2012, and, in October, the house will present a second anniversary collection based on its hoard of ancient Egyptian faiences, at the art and jewelry event Tefaf New York Fall.\n\nSince 1904, Hemmerle\u2019s headquarters and shop has been on Maximilianstrasse, which commands some of the highest commercial rents in Germany and is home to international luxury companies including Cartier, Gucci and Dior.\n\nThe workshop, on a quiet street nearby, houses its goldsmiths and stone setters. Inside, the jewelers\u2019 benches were designed to be broader than traditional ones to maximize their flexibility for work, and drills can be attached with magnets for easy use.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOutside the main workshop, along a corridor of whitewashed walls and checkerboard floor tiles, stands a wire puller, an apparatus used to create gold wire that might be found in any jewelry studio. The difference here is that the tool was created by Sebastian Hepp, a Munich-based artist and metalsmith who creates only one such piece every four years. Its elongated, rigorously minimalistic lines resemble a Donald Judd sculpture, but then, Mr. Hemmerle said, \u201cbeauty has no limitations.\u201d\n\nThere is a close relationship between the Hemmerles and their craftsmen. \u201cHow our creations come to life depends heavily on the talent in the workshop,\u201d Mr. Hemmerle said.\n\nGoldsmiths are assigned to create pieces of jewelry, depending on their skills in such areas as intricate filigree or working with a particular metal or kind of wood. And they work on pieces from beginning to end, rather than passing them along a production line.\n\nDiscussions between the artisans and the Hemmerles are constant, so designs evolve along the way (\u201cCreation is a process,\u201d Ms. Hemmerle said.)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen it came to fixing the diamond-studded Pegasus to the rear of the earring, for example, questions arose about how to disguise the connection. The solution was to depict the constellation of Pegasus on the reverse, blending the connection into the star pattern.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile this collection was linked to the anniversary, the Hemmerles usually stand by the tenet that creativity cannot be forced and don\u2019t approach their output from a seasonal or commercial point of view.\n\nWhatever is ready goes to the next show they are presenting at, whether in March at the European Fine Art Fair in Maastricht; the Netherlands, best known as Tefaf; or in October at the London design show PAD. Mr. Hemmerle recently became the only jeweler appointed to Tefaf\u2019s board of trustees, following some restructuring.\n\nMr. Hemmerle, who trained at the Gemological Institute of America in New York and as a diamond cutter, said the company had long benefited from the German system of apprenticeship, which involves a three-and-a-half-year placement. Hemmerle\u2019s head work-master joined as an apprentice and he now sits alongside the latest apprentice, who has been learning all aspects of goldsmithing and Hemmerle\u2019s signature techniques.\n\n\u201cWe invest in our trainees so we want to keep them,\u201d Mr. Hemmerle said, noting that an advantage of creating one-of-a-kind jewels was that the job continued to be stimulating, so they were more likely to stay.\n\nHemmerle has come a long way from its founding in 1893 by Josef and Anton Hemmerle, brothers who took over a goldsmith\u2019s company that specialized in medals and dealt in antique jewelry. Despite having only the Munich shop, it has many private collectors around the world because, in part, of its participation in the international art shows.\n\nMr. Hemmerle said the critical thing was to have a vision shared by the entire family. \u201cWe\u2019ve always agreed that we want to create one-of-a-kind jewelry that will hopefully one day be exhibited in museums,\u201d he said \u2014 and the house\u2019s works are part of the permanent collections at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum in New York and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.\n\nHe added with a smile, \u201cI found an old advertising card that said, \u2018We produce ornaments; we work in enamel; and we make repairs for cheap prices.\u2019 We\u2019ve pivoted a little bit since then.\u201d", "title": "At Hemmerle, Medals Inspire an Anniversary Collection of Jewelry", "authors": ["Rachel Garrahan"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 You know when you go to a friend\u2019s house for dinner, and you wish you could buy their lifestyle: the furniture, the art, the clothes, everything?\n\nAt Society Room, one of the most exclusive shopping destinations in Paris, that\u2019s the idea.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no question that e-commerce is the future,\u201d said Yvan Benbanaste, the gregarious 46-year-old founder and creative director of Society Room, \u201cbut ultimately I wanted to give my friends a good reason to get out of the house and shop.\u201d\n\nLocated in a 19th-century brick maisonette tucked in a courtyard near the Madeleine, the store, for want of a better word, initially appears to be just an enviably appointed Parisian home, with a 1980s Italian gold and glass console in the foyer, custom-made alabaster light fixtures by Ruben Glustin in the stairwell and, in the living room, a black-and-white portrait of Naomi Campbell by the photographer Albert Watson.\n\nExcept everything is for sale. And along with the flea market finds, the art dealer loaners and the Pierre Frey curtains, there are the tailored suits, little black dresses and cocktail jumpsuits designed by Mr. Benbanaste.", "title": "At Home, With Society Room", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "ATHENS \u2014 The bodies of 16 people, including at least five children, were recovered from the sea off a Greek island on Saturday after a boat smuggling migrants sank in the eastern Aegean, a spokeswoman for the Greek coast guard said.\n\nThe drownings \u2014 the first such mass casualty in several months \u2014 came almost exactly two years after Turkey and the European Union signed a deal to curb the flow of migrants trying to reach Europe via the Aegean Sea.\n\nAlthough the influx has been limited drastically since that time, when daily crossings were often in the thousands, hundreds continue to reach Greek islands in smuggling vessels that are often old, flimsy and unseaworthy.\n\nThe Greek authorities were alerted to the latest episode shortly after 8 a.m., when three survivors \u2014 two women and a man \u2014 swam to the island of Agathonissi and said that a boat carrying 21 people had sunk, the coast guard spokeswoman said.", "title": "At Least 16 Migrants Drown Off Greek Island, Including 5 Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Though the operation is a slight setback for Vargas, it also could provide a fleeting but symbolic moment for the Mets.\n\n\u201cSomething that I\u2019ve been thinking about and wanting to do for a while,\u201d Wheeler, who was fighting to make the opening day roster, said of the five starters all pitching at once. \u201cFans have, too.\u201d\n\nThe Mets did not initially plan to build around their five talented starters, all of whom have fastballs in excess of 94 miles per hour. While Harvey (in 2010) and Matz (in 2009) were drafted in the first and second rounds, the Mets traded for Wheeler in 2011 and for Syndergaard a year later.\n\nCatcher Travis d\u2019Arnaud, not Syndergaard, was the centerpiece of a 2012 trade with Toronto. DeGrom, a ninth-round pick, blossomed into a top prospect for the Mets after converting from shortstop to pitcher.\n\nBut once Syndergaard and Matz reached the major leagues in 2015, the Mets dreamed big. Harvey was having a dominant season. DeGrom had been named the National League Rookie of the Year the season before. The only one missing was Wheeler, who had debuted in 2013 and was still recovering from Tommy John surgery in 2015.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBut we\u2019ve all been hurt at different times, so it hasn\u2019t come to fruition,\u201d said Wheeler, who will start in Vargas\u2019s place on Thursday in spring training.\n\nWhen the Mets lost the World Series to the Kansas City Royals at the end of that 2015 season, many believed the Mets\u2019 potent rotation would keep them in contention for years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re here to stay,\u201d Harvey said after the Mets clinched the 2015 N.L. East division crown. \u201cWe\u2019re here to do this more often.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInjuries scuttled that plan. Harvey, a free agent after this season, hasn\u2019t been the same since that World Series. Wheeler, 27, was supposed to return for the second half of the 2016 season but endured several setbacks. The Mets reached the 2016 wild card game despite DeGrom, Matz and Harvey having had surgery that year.\n\nThe closest the Mets ever got to having all five starters in the same rotation was last season, but Matz, now 26, landed on the disabled list with an elbow injury a week before the season began. Syndergaard, Wheeler and Harvey joined him there later in the season. DeGrom was the only Mets starter to play through the entire disappointing 2017 season.\n\nAnd now, some of them aren\u2019t so young by baseball standards: Harvey will be 29 soon and deGrom will turn 30 in June.\n\nVargas, 35, was signed last month to a two-year $16 million contract to provide stability, but he was hit by a line drive on his right hand during a start in a minor league game last week. Doctors recommend the removal of the broken bone.\n\n\u201cThis was the fastest way to get better,\u201d Vargas said on Monday after throwing a bullpen session with the laces of his glove loosened to fit his taped-up right hand. He then packed his bags to fly to New York for the operation.\n\n\u201cBeing my glove hand, hopefully we can get moving a little bit quicker and know I won\u2019t have any issues when I go to catch a ball,\u201d he added.\n\nThe specter of seeing all five starters in the same rotation, even once, elicited no nicknames or fanfare from Alderson.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re past that,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s about winning games and being competitive.\u201d", "title": "At Least Briefly, the Mets Can Finally Field Their Big Five", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Sanders also said the citizenship question had \u201cbeen included in every census since 1965, with the exception of 2010, when it was removed.\u201d\n\nIn fact, various citizenship questions have appeared in many censuses since 1850, especially during periods of high immigration. But it was dropped from the 1960 general census (there was no census in 1965) and relegated in 1970 to a longer list of questions that were asked of a small minority of residents. After 2000, the question was asked only on the American Community Survey, a separate mandatory poll of a fraction of the population that is conducted more frequently than the census.\n\nCritics noted that the citizenship question was added at the last minute \u2014 the deadline for proposing new questions for the 2020 head count is April 1 \u2014 and that it sidestepped the years of vetting undergone by every other question that will be asked. This month, they added, President Trump\u2019s re-election campaign used the addition of a citizenship question in an emailed fund-raising appeal.\n\nMr. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, said that adding the question was a \u201creckless decision to suddenly abandon nearly 70 years of practice.\u201d He argued that the move \u201cwill create an environment of fear and distrust in immigrant communities that would make impossible both an accurate census and the fair distribution of federal tax dollars.\u201d\n\nIn a seven-page announcement released late Monday, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the secretary of commerce, foresaw those concerns, and sought to allay them. Decades of experience with citizenship questions on earlier censuses and other surveys, he stated, indicate that including it on the 2020 form would not deter people from volunteering to be counted. And he noted that other democracies, from Australia to the United Kingdom, routinely ask about citizenship in their head counts without any difficulty.\n\nMr. Ross, whose department oversees the Census Bureau, acknowledged that both outside experts and leaders within the bureau had been opposed to the change. But he said that \u201cneither the Census Bureau nor the concerned stakeholders could document that the response rate would in fact decline materially.\u201d\n\nAnd although the citizenship question was not tested for inclusion on the 2020 form, he said, it is used in the American Community Survey.", "title": "At Least Twelve States to Sue Trump Administration Over Census Citizenship Question", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "PALM SPRINGS, Calif. \u2014 \u201cI get invited to everything, and everywhere I go, everyone wishes they had my job. But that\u2019s not true here,\u201d said Pablos Holman, a self-described futurist and inventor who has worked on lasers that kill mosquitoes and machines that suppress hurricanes.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s geniuses everywhere,\u201d he said, motioning to the pair talking next to him, the theoretical physicist Lisa Randall and the computer scientist Stephen Wolfram. \u201cI don\u2019t even register on this scale.\u201d\n\nWe\u2019re at Mars, an exclusive three-day conference at a midcentury-modern hotel here in the California desert run by Amazon and its founder, Jeff Bezos, for some of the world\u2019s most successful geeks. For its first two years, Mars was largely secret; the most prominent image that leaked was a photo of Mr. Bezos piloting a 13-foot robot last year. This year, Amazon lifted the veil and invited a handful of reporters into Mr. Bezos\u2019s brainiac pow-wow.", "title": "At Mars, Jeff Bezos Hosted Roboticists, Astronauts, Other Brainiacs and Me", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNamouna, a Grand Divertissement\u201d is more than a ballet: It\u2019s an hour spent in an enchanted imagination. Not everything matched that spirit at New York City Ballet last week, the final one of its winter season, but it was little surprise that the imagination belonged to Alexei Ratmansky.\n\n\u201cNamouna\u201d is one of Mr. Ratmansky\u2019s finest works for New York City Ballet, where, it should be noted, he has choreographed several transcendent ballets, though he is the artist in residence at American Ballet Theater. To have two Ratmanskys this winter \u2014 the other was the spellbinding \u201cRussian Seasons,\u201d his first work for the company and the one that put him on the American map \u2014 felt both correct and calming: a lift in what must be trying times for the company. Mr. Ratmansky\u2019s job may be at Ballet Theater, but judging from his works, his joy is at City Ballet.\n\n\u201cNamouna\u201d is by turns comic, tender and full of whimsy. Where else do members of a corps de ballet high-five as they pass one another onstage? The action involves three muses \u2014 a chain-smoking temptress, an overheated diva and a fanciful kook \u2014 who each capture the attention of our hero.", "title": "At New York City Ballet, Hits, Misses and Daring Dancers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pruitt has been averse to science and fact from Day 1. Last fall, he announced that scientists who receive or had received federal research grants would be barred from serving on the agency\u2019s nearly two dozen scientific advisory committees. The purpose, he said, was to eliminate conflicts of interest; the real purpose, it soon became clear, was to create vacancies that he could fill with industry experts and state officials pushing for lax regulations \u2014 people whose own conflicts of interest would be left unexamined. As Andrew Rosenberg, director of the Center for Science and Democracy at the Union of Concerned Scientists noted at the time, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s claim that federal funding should exclude scientists from an E.P.A. advisory board while industry funding should not exclude them was on its face absurd.\n\nThough the E.P.A. is the epicenter of denial, avoiding inconvenient truths is common practice elsewhere in the administration. Last year, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke reassigned Joel Clement, the department\u2019s director of policy analysis and top expert on the impact of climate change in the Arctic, to an accounting job (Mr. Clement resigned in protest). Mr. Zinke also ordered the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine to cancel two studies that conflicted with the administration\u2019s goal of expanding domestic fossil fuel production. One was examining the health risks of people living near surface coal mining sites in Appalachia; the other sought ways of strengthening the department\u2019s oil and gas safety inspection program.\n\nEven the official vocabulary of global warming has changed, as if problems can be made to evaporate simply by describing them in more benign terms. At the Agriculture Department, for instance, staff members are encouraged to use terms like \u201cweather extremes\u201d instead of \u201cclimate change.\u201d Web pages about global warning have been removed, edited or buried throughout the government. Last week, lest there be any confusion in the hinterlands, E.P.A. staff members in regional offices received a list of talking points instructing them to tell people that \u201cclear gaps remain including our understanding of the role of human activity\u201d on global warming. This is vintage Pruitt: Sow doubt whenever possible about established science.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s economic advisers have reinforced this bias. His latest budget called for big funding cuts and in some cases elimination of programs aimed at protecting human health and building resilience against the effects of climate change \u2014 among them the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration\u2019s coastal research program and the Energy Department\u2019s energy efficiency and advanced technology programs. Congress wisely denied these cuts, thanks to hard work by Charles Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leaders of the Senate and House. Whether their efforts do anything to change the mind-set of Mr. Trump and his lieutenants remains to be seen.\n\nMr. Pruitt is widely believed to be positioning himself for a run for governor in his home state, Oklahoma; he also seems to covet the attorney general\u2019s office, and, astoundingly, is said to harbor presidential ambitions. But he and Mr. Zinke are unlikely to go anywhere soon, and as long as they have the support of the denier in chief, we can expect more disrespect for science and its practitioners.", "title": "Opinion | At Pruitt\u2019s E.P.A.: No Studies, No Data, No Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Students from Baltimore, as well as young people who attended a rally in Chicago, were vocal on Saturday about the need for steps to reduce gun violence, much in the same way as students from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where a gunman killed 17 people last month. But they had a different idea of the problem.\n\nDestini Philpot, another student at Baltimore City College, was joined on Saturday in Washington by Carrie Zaremba, a student at the Friends School of Baltimore, a predominantly white Quaker institution. The two said they had helped organize a citywide walkout this month that involved both public and private schools.\n\n\u201cIt shouldn\u2019t take a mass shooting in a predominantly white area like Parkland to start caring about gun violence,\u201d Ms. Zaremba said.\n\nMs. Philpot said that many of those at the rally were thinking of gun violence in the only way they knew how: as mass shootings.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cWhen they talk about gun violence, they\u2019re talking about schools,\u201d she said.\n\nPrivate donors paid for 60 buses that carried around 3,000 Baltimore students to the Washington event. Some Baltimore organizers skipped their city\u2019s satellite march to attend the one in the capital, hoping to reach an audience largely unfamiliar with the kind of violence that visits them with gruesome regularity.\n\nOne of those organizers, Erricka Bridgeford, has helped work on a campaign called Baltimore Ceasefire, which holds quarterly \u201ccease-fire\u201d weekends that call for a stop to killings for a three-day period.\n\nOn Saturday, she recalled what had brought her to Washington: the lasting agony from losing her brother, stepson and friends to gun violence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve seen dead bodies and blood,\u201d she said. \u201cThese are things you never recover from. You learn how to live your life differently, because the air looks different once you experience that kind of trauma. I have to do something with the pain. I don\u2019t want to be a prisoner to it.\u201d\n\nMs. Bridgeford said shootings were a never-ending feature of life in her Baltimore neighborhood.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no such thing as post-traumatic stress in a lot of communities in America, because there\u2019s no \u2018post,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cYou don\u2019t get a chance to experience the aftermath before there\u2019s another trauma because of gun violence.\u201d\n\nOne of the students walking with Ms. Bridgeford was Shanika Walker, who attends the Excel Academy at Francis M. Wood High School in Baltimore, which recently lost seven students to homicide in 15 months.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOnly the scared people have guns, and they kill people they\u2019re scared of,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of fear.\u201d\n\nOn Chicago\u2019s Near West Side on Saturday, just a few miles from neighborhoods where shootings are common, thousands filled Union Park to protest a problem just as local.\n\nMany came to the rally bearing personal stories of tragedy and loss, years of frustration with unchanged gun laws and hope replenished by recent student-led activism.\n\n\u201cWe have been fighting for a long, long time,\u201d said Maria Pike, whose son, Ricky, 24, was shot to death in 2012. \u201cAnd their voice is a fresh voice, is a true voice, is a transparent voice. And it comes from the heart.\u201d\n\nSpeaker after speaker at the Chicago rally mentioned relatives or classmates who had been wounded or killed in shootings, frustrated that past calls to action had not led to change.\n\n\u201cChicago has been plagued with gun violence way before the Parkland shooting,\u201d said Juan Reyes, a high school student. \u201cSuddenly, people are talking about students not feeling safe in schools. But in reality, students in our city\u2019s South and West Sides have never felt safe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne high school student, Denzel Russell, told the crowd, \u201cI have watched one of my friends get murdered while we were playing on the basketball court. That experience had me frozen and speechless.\u201d\n\nMr. Russell added: \u201cWe can come together for a march. But are we willing to come together to take action?\u201d\n\nEmerson Toomey, 17, who helped organize the Chicago march, said her mother was grazed by a bullet in a drive-by shooting on the North Side of the city.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s more about the journey to school for some kids than it is about the actual day at school,\u201d she said.\n\nBut for the teachers who believe they must now think as much about school shootings as they do about urban gun violence, Saturday\u2019s rallies in Washington and Chicago felt like the meeting of two threats, now inseparable.\n\n\u201cI see the look on the students\u2019 faces,\u201d said Jeremy McConnell, a special education teacher at Paul Laurence Dunbar High School in Baltimore. \u201cThey come from these communities. They come from these families that engage in this kind of violence. They might be a sibling or neighbor removed.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey know gun violence is real. They see it in the streets,\u201d added Mr. McConnell, who, as the voice behind public address announcements at the school, reminds students to be vigilant after news of shootings in Baltimore and across the country. \u201cBut they haven\u2019t seen it in school. They think any day now it\u2019s coming here.\u201d", "title": "At Rallies, Students With a Different View of Gun Violence: As Urban Reality", "authors": ["Noah Weiland"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 Readings, Luis Alberto Urrea Is Making His Fans Cry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 Hundreds of people lined the streets of the British city of Cambridge on Saturday, breaking into applause as the hearse carrying the remains of the famed scientist Stephen Hawking arrived at a local church for a private funeral for 500 invited guests.\n\nDr. Hawking died on March 14 at age 76 after capturing popular imagination with his writings about space and time.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis book \u201cA Brief History of Time: From the Big Bang to Black Holes,\u201d published in 1988, has sold more than 10 million copies and inspired a documentary film by Errol Morris. His own story was the basis of an award-winning 2014 feature film, \u201cThe Theory of Everything.\u201d\n\nThe actor Eddie Redmayne, who portrayed Hawking in the 2014 biographical drama, gave a reading from Ecclesiastes during the service at St. Mary the Great Church. There was also a reading by Martin Rees, Britain\u2019s Astronomer Royal, and eulogies by one of Hawking\u2019s children and a former student.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe service was officiated by the Rev. Cally Hammond, the dean of Gonville and Caius College at Cambridge University, where Dr. Hawking was a fellow for 52 years.\n\nPhoto\n\nFlags were lowered to half-mast in many parts of Cambridge to pay tribute to him.\n\nDr. Hawking, who suffered from motor neuron disease, was known for his groundbreaking research into black holes and other phenomena.\n\nEven as he gradually lost control of his muscles, he traveled the globe to scientific meetings, visiting every continent, including Antarctica; wrote best-selling books about his work; married twice; fathered three children; and was not above appearing on \u201cThe Simpsons,\u201d \u201cStar Trek: The Next Generation\u201d or \u201cThe Big Bang Theory.\u201d", "title": "At Stephen Hawking Funeral, Eddie Redmayne and Astronomer Royal Give Readings", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "COLUMBUS, Ohio \u2014 Geno Auriemma even hears it from his mother. \u201cIt\u2019s O.K. if you lose,\u201d Marciella Auriemma tells her Hall of Fame son. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to win all the time. You win too much. That\u2019s why people hate you.\u201d\n\nAuriemma tells the story on a conference call and laughs. His mother can bust chops as fiercely as he can.\n\nBut Auriemma is more annoyed than amused by the idea, since it is at the heart of the question he gets asked every spring as he coaches the Huskies to the Final Four: Is UConn\u2019s success good for women\u2019s college basketball? As if excellence can be detrimental, or needs a warning, like a pack of cigarettes.\n\nUConn (36-0) has reached the national semifinals for the 11th consecutive season, in search of its 12th national title. But after Rashaun Mitchell watched members of the Stephen Petronio Company rehearse the sextet from \u201cSignals,\u201d a rarely performed Cunningham dance from 1970, he went there.\n\n\u201cThis should be much more fun,\u201d said Mr. Mitchell, who, with Melissa Toogood, is restaging the work. Both performed excerpts from \u201cSignals\u201d when they were in the Cunningham company as part of his \u201cEvents\u201d \u2014 his brilliant and practical way of recycling his work, in which dances were resequenced, generating wholly new programming.\n\n\u201cListen to each other,\u201d Mr. Mitchell urged the dancers. \u201cSee each other more \u2014 so much more.\u201d\n\nMr. Petronio, observing from the side of the studio at Dance Theater of Harlem, nodded in agreement. \u201cWhen they do look at each other,\u201d he said, \u201cI understand that they\u2019re playing.\u201d\n\nAnd a sense of play is essential for \u201cSignals,\u201d which was named after the choreographic cues that dancers use to communicate the next series of movements or spacing choices. The score, performed by the ensemble Composers Inside Electronics, will change with each presentation as musicians rotate. Cunningham designed the costumes, sweatsuits bound with tape. And since it\u2019s by Cunningham, it\u2019s hard: His steps are a puzzle of rhythm and form.", "title": "At Work in Merce Cunningham\u2019s Playhouse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nFrom 2,400 Danish kroner (about $394).\n\nThe Basics\n\nOpened in September 2017, the Nobis Hotel Copenhagen is a stylish 77-room property in a landmark neoclassical building from 1903 that formerly housed the Royal Danish Conservatory of Music. Handsomely renovated interiors were designed by the in-demand Swedish firm Wingardhs, known for mixing materials \u2014 concrete, marble, oak, leather \u2014 with furnishings both midcentury and modern. The result is a visually stunning mash-up of styles, from the concrete reception desk in the polished marble lobby to the grand central staircase with ornate moldings and a glittering cascade of pendant lamps. This is also the first international property from Sweden\u2019s Nobis Hospitality Group, which has earned acclaim for its buzzy boutique hotels in and around Stockholm.\n\nThe Location\n\nNext to the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek art museum and a block away from Tivoli Gardens, the hotel is less than 10 minutes on foot from Copenhagen\u2019s Central Station.", "title": "At a Copenhagen Hotel, Scandinavian Style and Seasonal Seafood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "That lawyer, Jay Sekulow, is a conservative commentator who made his name on religious freedom cases. Mr. Sekulow is in talks with other lawyers about joining the team, although it is not clear how far those discussions have progressed.\n\nHours before the announcement of Mr. diGenova\u2019s departure, which Mr. Sekulow said was related to a conflict of interest, the president took to Twitter to reject any suggestion that lawyers do not want to work for him.\n\n\u201cMany lawyers and top law firms want to represent me in the Russia case \u2026 don\u2019t believe the Fake News narrative that it is hard to find a lawyer who wants to take this on,\u201d he wrote. \u201cFame & fortune will NEVER be turned down by a lawyer, though some are conflicted.\u201d\n\nAdding new lawyers, he said, would be costly because they would take months \u201cto get up to speed (if for no other reason than they can bill more).\u201d\n\n\u201cI am very happy with my existing team,\u201d he added.\n\nThis month, the president met with the veteran lawyer Emmet Flood about the possibility of joining the legal team. But Mr. Trump was put off by the fact that Mr. Flood, a Republican, had represented Bill Clinton during his impeachment process, and Mr. Flood has made clear that he will not represent the president if Marc E. Kasowitz, his brash longtime personal lawyer, has any role in the effort.\n\nMr. Trump also tried to recruit Theodore B. Olson, a well-known Republican lawyer, but Mr. Olson has said he would not be representing the president.\n\nThe first phase of legal work for Mr. Trump in the inquiry by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, was led by a White House lawyer, Ty Cobb. That work, which in part involved the production of documents and the arrangement of interviews with White House officials, has been largely completed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe second phase, which is now focused on the question of a presidential interview with Mr. Mueller, had been led by Mr. Dowd. One reason Mr. Dowd quit was that, against his advice, Mr. Trump was insistent that he wanted to answer questions under oath from Mr. Mueller, believing that it would help clear him.\n\nMr. Dowd had concluded that there was no upside and that the president, who often does not tell the truth, could increase his legal exposure if his answers were not accurate.\n\nRoger Cossack, a seasoned legal analyst, said the key to successfully defending a high-profile client under immense scrutiny was to have a cohesive legal team with a consistent strategy.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn these types of cases, you need highly competent lawyers and a client who will listen and follow their advice,\u201d Mr. Cossack said. \u201cIf you don\u2019t have both, you have what we\u2019re seeing here: chaos and disaster.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou have a client who clearly thinks he has a better idea of how things should work than the lawyers who, from time to time, have told him things he doesn\u2019t want to hear,\u201d he added. \u201cHe is looking for the guy who can say, \u2018I know how to handle Mueller, I know you think he is bad, and we\u2019ll take care of it.\u2019 Problem is you can\u2019t find that lawyer because no one will be able to do that.\u201d\n\nPeople close to the president say the upheaval in the legal team was inevitable. When Mr. Kasowitz took the lead after Mr. Mueller was appointed in May, he wanted to follow a model used by Mr. Clinton, with a separate team of lawyers and communications professionals handling issues related to the inquiry, so that the White House staff could keep its distance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Mr. Trump, who trusts few people and considers himself his best lawyer, spokesman and strategist, never wanted that type of system. As a result, his legal and public relations strategies have been out of sync, with the president at times publicly contradicting his lawyers, and the White House often finding itself flat-footed in the face of new disclosures about the Russia investigation.\n\nThe president\u2019s decision has also exposed many of his aides, leaving them deeply enmeshed in an inquiry that is likely to cost them tens of thousands of dollars in legal fees.\n\nBut while Mr. Trump has struggled to find lawyers, his family and his close associates are being represented by some of the country\u2019s top legal talent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis son-in-law, Jared Kushner, has hired Abbe Lowell, a longtime Washington lawyer who recently got the Justice Department to drop corruption charges against Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, after a lengthy court fight.\n\nThree prominent current and former White House officials \u2014 the former chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon; the former chief of staff, Reince Priebus; and the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn \u2014 are being represented by William A. Burck, who turned down the chance to represent the president. Mr. Burck, a former federal prosecutor, represented FIFA in its legal problems in the United States and has worked for high-profile witnesses in federal investigations, including Maureen McDonnell, the wife of a former Virginia governor.\n\nThe turmoil in Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team started within weeks of the appointment of Mr. Mueller. Mr. Kasowitz pushed for an adversarial approach to the special counsel, which the president was poised to follow. But Mr. Kasowitz clashed with Mr. Kushner, and he was soon pushed aside after a series of missteps and embarrassing incidents.\n\nThe president then hired Mr. Cobb, a veteran Washington lawyer, to lead efforts within the White House, as well as Mr. Dowd, who was put in charge of his personal legal team. They advocated a strategy of cooperation, telling the president that the sooner he gave Mr. Mueller\u2019s office what it wanted, the sooner his name would be cleared.\n\nWhile Mr. Cobb had told the president that the investigation would be over by now, it seems to be accelerating. Mr. Mueller is still looking into a wide range of matters related to Mr. Trump\u2019s corporate activities, his 2016 campaign, his associates and his time in office.\n\nMr. Trump, hoping to bolster his team, met with Mr. diGenova and Ms. Toensing in recent days but, according to two people told of details about the meeting, did not believe he had personal chemistry with them.\n\nThere were also significant conflict-of-interest issues, but Mr. Trump could have waived them if he wanted. Ms. Toensing is representing Mark Corallo, who was the spokesman for Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team in 2017 before they parted ways. Mr. Corallo has told investigators that he was concerned that a close aide to Mr. Trump, Hope Hicks, may have been planning to obstruct justice during the drafting of a statement about a meeting between a Russian lawyer and Donald Trump Jr. during the campaign.\n\nMs. Hicks\u2019s lawyer has strongly denied that suggestion, and White House aides said Mr. Corallo\u2019s assertion had come up in discussions with the president as he weighed whether to go ahead with Mr. diGenova and Ms. Toensing.\n\nMr. diGenova had been expected to serve as an outspoken voice for the president as Mr. Trump has increased his attacks on Mr. Mueller. Mr. diGenova has endorsed the notion that a secretive group of F.B.I. agents concocted the Russia investigation as a way to keep Mr. Trump from becoming president, a theory with little supporting evidence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere was a brazen plot to illegally exonerate Hillary Clinton and, if she didn\u2019t win the election, to then frame Donald Trump with a falsely created crime,\u201d he had told Fox News in January.", "title": "At a Crucial Juncture, Trump\u2019s Legal Defense Is Largely a One-Man Operation", "authors": ["Michael S. Schmidt", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen we started the program in 2011, we looked at a very large variety of solutions to ensure nothing was discounted,\u201d Laurent Mekies, safety director at the F.I.A., the sport\u2019s governing body, explained in an interview. Mekies, who is to join Ferrari in September in a technical role, added, \u201cIt was an open-minded approach, to look at everything, all possible concepts.\n\n\u201cSo we looked at full canopies \u2014 a fighter-jet style of the canopy; we looked at a roll bar in front of the drivers, and a partial roll bar just in front of the monocoque.\n\n\u201cSome of these concepts made it to the track. For instance, with the GP2 cars, we used a roll bar in front of the drivers, in order to not only protect them but also assess visibility.\u201d\n\nIt was determined that a driver needed to be protected from an object as large as a complete wheel assembly, weighing 44 pounds and traveling at 140 miles an hour.\n\n\u201cThis was the driving factor of all the concepts,\u201d Mekies said. \u201cAll our testing was based around that.\n\n\u201cAs we progressed the work, what we realized is that in asking for a structure to be as strong as what we were looking for, it had massive benefits in a number of other areas and potential accidents, other than a simple wheel strike,\u201d such as car-to-car contact or a car hitting a tire or concrete wall.\n\n\u201cHaving chosen the load, the testing conditions involved a full-scale dynamic test where we projected a wheel assembly at the structure, and observing the behavior, or not, of that structure, in two respects: Does it fail? And is it able to deflect a wheel away from the driver\u2019s head?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThroughout development, and before making a final decision on which device to use, Mekies and the F.I.A. were aware of the impact the structure would have on the sport.\n\nAfter its initial introduction at a preseason test in 2016, the halo was almost universally derided, in particular for its aesthetics.\n\nSo Red Bull developed its own prototype, the aeroscreen, which struggled in tests conducted by the F.I.A. before the team abandoned the idea.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe F.I.A. had planned to introduce the halo for the start of the 2017 season, but decided to look at other options, forcing a delay.\n\nAt last year\u2019s British Grand Prix, and after relatively successful tests, a system known as the shield was fitted to the Ferrari of Sebastian Vettel during a practice session. During that short test, it was discovered that the device offered less protection than the halo.\n\nSo the halo was adopted, but criticism remains.\n\nToto Wolff, the head of the Mercedes team, recently said he was \u201cnot impressed with the whole thing.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf you give me a chain saw, I would take it off,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to look after the driver\u2019s safety, but what we have implemented is aesthetically not appealing.\n\n\u201cWe need to come up with a solution that simply looks better. It\u2019s a massive weight on top of the car, and you screw up the center of gravity massively. As impressive as the statistic is that you could put a bus on top of it, this is a Formula One car.\u201d\n\nMekies said making a decision \u201cwas not an easy process.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe reason why is because you have many different sensitivities when it comes to how safe the sport needs to be; is the danger part of the thrill of watching it?\u201d he said. \u201cThen there were the aesthetic considerations of bolting a new structure on an open cockpit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFrom an aesthetic point of view, it was something so new \u2014 and we didn\u2019t target aesthetics then, we targeted function and maximum safety \u2014 the initial reaction was very mixed.\n\n\u201cBut once we showed it to people \u2014 and perhaps we should have done more, and much earlier \u2014 the ways in which it would be beneficial in an accident scenario, then we started to receive more support.\u201d\n\nBut the device has created difficulties for the teams.\n\nAndrew Green, the technical director of Force India, claims it has cost his team \u201cin the hundreds of thousands, if not the millions\u201d of dollars to put on the car because it has forced teams to make other changes to their cars. The system itself costs just $16,000.\n\nThe team is still working on the aerodynamics of the halo, which has \u201ca significant downstream effect, especially around the wing area,\u201d Green said.\n\nAnother effect has been on weight. While the F.I.A. increased the overall minimum weight of this year\u2019s cars by 13.2 pounds to 1,618 pounds, the weight of the halo, along with the mountings to attach it to the car, totals 26.5 pounds.\n\n\u201cThe weight limit did go up, but by not nearly as much as the installation weight of the halo, which put additional stress on all the other parts of the car.\n\n\u201cThe other area we had to bear in mind is that we have to hit a weight distribution target, so we faced a big challenge, with the architecture of the car changing right up to the last minute.\u201d\n\nWhatever the discontent among teams, the halo is now a fixture in Formula One. Although the halo is the first head protection device approved by the F.I.A., it is unlikely to be the last.\n\n\u201cThere is no direction we will not pursue,\u201d Mekies said. \u201cIt could be a canopy, or maybe automatic deployment of the safety structure, if you want to look further.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn terms of research and development, that is very much our job, to look at different styles of things. Whatever we do, it has to be done for additional safety, and that is the overriding reason why we now have the halo.\u201d", "title": "At the Australian Grand Prix, a New Era of Protecting Drivers", "authors": ["Ian Parkes"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI grew up in a little Baptist church in small-town Alabama. The Baptist part is inherited, like baldness or dimples: Both of my grandfathers and three of my uncles were Baptist preachers, and my parents met as graduate students at Southern Baptist Theological Seminary. Genes aside, the church \u2014 plastic chairs, pilling carpet and grape juice for communion \u2014 was the organizing institution of my childhood, where I met my closest friends and most of the significant adults in my life.\n\nChurch attendance has been in generational decline. I began calling around, exploring whether people in small towns were looking for community elsewhere and, with the white nationalist rallies so often in the news, whether young white people were looking for meaning in the grim sanctuaries of the alt-right.\n\nBut I kept hearing about something different. Pastors, theologians and sociologists were talking of how black worshipers were leaving white-majority churches. They were leaving quietly and not en masse, a family here, a single person there. But it was happening everywhere, a movement large enough for some to see the unraveling of decades of efforts at racial reconciliation.\n\nI would find someone on Facebook, a black worshiper who had posted about leaving her mostly white church, and then I would find someone in the same situation halfway across the country. They would both think they were going through this alone, yet the accounts would be remarkably similar, the timelines nearly identical, even some of the words and phrases the same. There had been, I discovered, some sharp reporting about this, particularly from the writer Deborah Jian Lee, but not as much as you would expect for an experience that seemed to be this broadly shared.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeople spoke to me of being tired, let down, heartbroken. Political and cultural partitions that they had long overlooked at worship time now overshadowed every service. The realizations almost always began with the death of Trayvon Martin in 2012, and a sense that white church leaders or fellow worshipers did not want to talk about how a black teenager walking home from a 7-Eleven could end up dead. Sometimes the preacher would privately express sympathy, but also concern about how his white congregation would take it. Maybe there would be a meeting.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists.
