Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen the Trump election came, with its troubling racial overtones. For many, it wasn\u2019t even complicated at that point. They just stopped going.", "title": "At the Crossroads of Church and Race, a Reporter Glimpses His Childhood", "authors": ["Campbell Robertson"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Leilah Gilligan of the Center for Sex Offender Management \u2014 a project organized by the Department of Justice that was cited in FoxNews.com\u2019s alarm-sounding article in June \u2014 said she was not aware of any data showing that the sexual abuse of male students by female teachers was on the rise.\n\nFewer than 9 percent of reported episodes of child sexual abuse are perpetrated by women, according to the Child Maltreatment Report, an annual survey of crimes against minors produced by the Department of Health and Human Services, when it last released such data in 2013. Franca Cortoni, a professor at the University of Montreal who researches female sexual offenders, said, \u201cThere is no evidence whatsoever that suddenly more women teachers are having sex with their male students.\u201d\n\nMuch of the FoxNews.com coverage coincided with the rise of the #MeToo movement, which prompted a wave of women to disclose past episodes of sexual harassment. Mr. Kotch said that the number of posts on the subject since his arrival was small compared with the volume of articles the site has published on sexual misbehavior by men, including the film mogul Harvey Weinstein.\n\n\u201cWe aren\u2019t shying away from focusing on sexual harassment in the workplace,\u201d Mr. Kotch said.\n\nFoxNews.com\u2019s increased coverage of sex crimes allegedly committed by women began two months after the network ousted one of its prime-time anchors, Bill O\u2019Reilly \u2014 a move made in the wake of a New York Times report that Mr. O\u2019Reilly and the Fox News parent company, 21st Century Fox, had paid $13 million in confidential settlements to women who had complained about his behavior. (A subsequent Times investigation showed that the settlements involving Mr. O\u2019Reilly totaled $45 million. Mr. O\u2019Reilly has denied the allegations.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kotch said that the uptick in stories on the subject was not related to Fox News\u2019s own sexual harassment issues, which burst into the open in 2016 with the forced departure of the Fox News chairman and chief executive Roger E. Ailes.\n\nMr. Ailes, who died in May, left the network he had helped create after Gretchen Carlson, a former Fox News anchor, sued him for sexual harassment. The anchor Megyn Kelly was another prominent Fox News figure to make an exit, when she went to NBC last year. In her memoir, \u201cSettle for More,\u201d Ms. Kelly accused Mr. Ailes of making \u201coffers of professional advancement in exchange for sexual favors.\u201d\n\nWeeks after cutting ties with Mr. O\u2019Reilly, the network said goodbye to its co-president, Bill Shine, who was accused of having dismissed complaints made by women about Mr. Ailes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n(Fox News has made structural changes in response to these incidents, such as hiring a new head of human resources and appointing new leaders for recruiting and diversity.)\n\nMr. Kotch, the website editor, was reportedly recruited personally by Rupert Murdoch, who has been the acting chief executive officer of Fox News since Mr. Ailes\u2019s dismissal. Before joining Fox, Mr. Kotch served as the publisher of Heat Street, a site owned by News Corporation that was absorbed into Dow Jones\u2019s MarketWatch last summer.\n\nThe size of the FoxNews.com staff has approximately doubled since Mr. Kotch started his new job, according to a Fox News spokeswoman. In January, digital operations moved into new quarters built on the site of Mr. Ailes\u2019s old office. Recently, Mr. Kotch sent a celebratory memo to his staff noting that FoxNews.com\u2019s January web traffic had for the first time surpassed that of CNN.com.\n\nMany of the Fox News site\u2019s articles on sex abuse involving female teachers have been republished by The New York Post, the Murdoch-controlled tabloid. The Post published at least 90 stories on the subject last year, 30 of them sourced to Fox News. Its main tabloid rival, The New York Daily News, has also covered the topic heavily.\n\nThe Times could find no reporting on sexual abuse by female teachers on the sites of Fox News\u2019s television competitors MSNBC, CNN, NBC or ABC. CBS has run a few stories on the issue, including a 61-page slide show published in July featuring \u201cnotorious teacher sex scandals,\u201d as has The Washington Post.\n\nAfter FoxNews.com published 10 more articles on the subject in early January, there was a drought. But the site returned to the subject with the Feb. 28 story of a female science teacher in Florida who, according to the police, \u201csent nudes\u201d to and \u201chad sex romps\u201d with a 14-year-old boy. It continued the next day, with a story on a female teacher who was arrested in North Carolina and charged with having sex with a \u201cteen boy.\u201d", "title": "At the Fox News Site, a Sudden Focus on Women as Sex Offenders", "authors": ["Jonathan Galinsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "These stunning images are not artists\u2019 renderings, but computer images and data combined and translated into a stunning travelscape. This hourlong journey is, in fact, also a tour of reams of data collected from spacefaring robot craft. The orbiting Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter gathered the startlingly detailed and three-dimensional images of Mars \u2014 a continuous quilt so vast that Mr. Emmart often finds himself seeing new neighborhoods he hasn\u2019t encountered before.\n\nThe New Horizons spacecraft got us to Pluto, which it blasted past in 2015. The European Space Agency\u2019s Planck satellite provided some of the farthest-out imagery, the heat map of the cosmos that can show us the incubators of tomorrow\u2019s galaxies. And all of it can be displayed by the kind of brawny gaming computer that can be purchased at Best Buy. It\u2019s a lot of data, and the images occasionally stutter. Hollywood, it isn\u2019t. But it\u2019s still, let\u2019s face it, awesome.\n\nThe software that allows the museum to perform this magic is called OpenSpace, and NASA gave the American Museum of Natural History, which houses the planetarium, $6.3 million to develop it. Mr. Emmart, as the museum\u2019s director of astrovisualization \u2014 and how great a title is that? \u2014 gets to use it.", "title": "At the Hayden Planetarium, a Joyride Across the Cosmos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Business\n\nIn late December 2015, about four months after the Swiss authorities had flagged the shipments from Thomas Mann, Al Jazeera released an explosive documentary called \u201cThe Dark Side: Secrets of the Sports Dopers.\u201d A retired professional hurdler from Britain had worked with the news organization to penetrate the world of illicit sports doping while carrying a hidden camera.\n\nAn intriguing name was tucked into the Al Jazeera documentary. Underground chemists spoke with reverence of a Svengali who produced and sold them high-quality sports drugs. His name was Thomas Mann.\n\nA chemist explained in the documentary how fastidious he had to be when ordering performance-enhancing drugs from Mann: \u201cIf you even use the wrong language with him, saying, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m going to use this,\u2019 right away, boom, you\u2019d be kicked off.\u201d\n\nInvestigators pulled at Thomas Mann\u2019s internet veil and found that he was using an alias, a name perhaps borrowed from the famous German novelist. He called his business Authentiquevie (French for \u201cauthentic life\u201d); another forum, DatBTrue, provided a menu of his peptides and hormones, accompanied by detailed explanations of each drug. Four-star customer testimonials piled up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTom carries it and is the only guy I trust to deliver actual peptides and not useless vials,\u201d read one.\n\nHis business model, according to investigators, was clever. They believe he operated the DatBTrue forum, a go-to place for savvy discussion of peptides. When an athlete on the forum would inquire about obtaining peptides, Moorcones, using a different name, would steer the athlete to Thomas Mann. So he was sending potential customers to himself.\n\nMoorcones, in the guise of Thomas Mann, or Tom Mann, would then rigorously vet the customers to make sure they were who they claimed to be and would be trustworthy clients.\n\nIn the one year that Moorcones was under investigation, he had $1 million in sales.\n\nMoorcones\u2019s business was a raging river in a much larger doping ecosystem. The demand for performance-enhancing drugs extends to every corner of professional and amateur sports, and well beyond. Name any sport, and chances are good that someone playing it has been caught doping in the past few months.\n\nThen there are wealthy users who flock to anti-aging medical clinics in search of youthful elixirs. They find doctors who will prescribe peptides and human growth hormone. The patients take all of these in hopes of adding muscle mass, smoothing wrinkles and reclaiming body definition and sexual vitality.\n\nMoorcones served both ends of this market, from athletes to the aging. All came to his online forum in search of the latest wonder drug.\n\nMoorcones purported that his products were intended for lab use only. In a 2014 email, he wrote: \u201cI have the following batches available for in vitro purposes only. Peptides: Modified GRF (1-29) (2mg) @ $35/vial; $31/10 vials.\u201d But a cursory reading of his customers\u2019 online comments indicated that they were not being used that way.\n\nDr. Todd B. Nippoldt, an endocrinologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., spoke to the scientific and health consequences of unregulated and illegal use.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese people are carrying out quite sophisticated experiments on themselves at doses that far exceed anything in a lab,\u201d Nippoldt said. \u201cIt\u2019s quite remarkable and dangerous.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEmergence of Peptides\n\nThe original wonder drug of sports doping was steroids, and it remains the gold standard for athletic cheaters. There is nothing, doctors and athletes say, quite like the muscle-firing boost provided by synthetic testosterone.\n\nSteroid use peaked in the 1980s and 1990s, and records set during that era were Popeye-like. Olympic records usually fall every few Games; some records set during the steroid era have stood untouched for decades. This is no less true of Major League Baseball, where swollen sluggers made a mockery of the record books in recent decades.\n\nThen testing for steroids improved and some sports toughened their rules against doping. Steroids became a riskier play. But that did not stop cheating. Block one back alley, and sophisticated chemists scurry down another. The aim, always, is to find ways to build muscle mass, burn fat, aid recovery and increase the ability of the body to expand its aerobic capacity. This underground world soon turned its eyes toward human growth hormones and peptides, strings of amino acids and the building blocks of proteins.\n\nSome peptides trigger reactions in the body similar to those of anabolic steroids. Others, known as secretagogues, stimulate the human pituitary gland to release excess growth hormone. A well-regarded scientific study in Australia found that growth hormone helped sprinters improve their times by 4 percent. As a typical 100-meter race is won or lost by hundredths of a second, a 4 percent improvement would represent a considerable advantage.\n\nThe Al Jazeera documentary underlined that peptides had become a prime ingredient in a cheater\u2019s performance cocktail. The documentary caught Taylor Teagarden, a major league catcher, saying on hidden camera that he had taken peptides and never been caught. (Major League Baseball remedied that oversight and suspended Teagarden for 80 games a few months after the documentary was released.)\n\nDr. Robert Salvatori, an expert on growth hormone at Johns Hopkins, noted that athletes were quite shrewd about the effects that drugs have on their bodies. History demonstrates that they often recognize the performance-boosting power before the medical community does.\n\n\u201cIt took scientists until 1996 to prove the muscle-boosting powers of steroids \u2014 which athletes knew years earlier,\u201d he said. \u201cWe are running way behind.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeeking to learn more about the latest tactics in sports doping, I went to Phoenix to meet with Cody Bidlow, a former professional sprinter and personal coach. A year ago, the United States Anti-Doping Agency discovered that Bidlow had ordered peptides from Moorcones\u2019s website. He received a four-year suspension.\n\nA lean and muscular fellow, Bidlow described for me how he came to use peptides. He had been a sprinter at Grand Canyon University in 2015 when he sustained a hamstring injury. He was no potential Olympian. He simply wanted to run a few more races, so he asked around at elite gyms for a quick doping fix.\n\n\u201cI had always been around people who used peptides and H.G.H.,\u201d he said, although he declined to name names. \u201cIt sounded like peptides are super-effective.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe wrote down the names of suppliers. He found a lot of fast talkers who excited no trust. (The head of Switzerland\u2019s antidoping organization told me that his agency\u2019s tests have shown that 80 percent of the peptides advertised on the web are adulterated or outright fakes.)\n\nThen Bidlow learned of Thomas Mann\u2019s site, which was refreshingly professional. And Mann\u2019s peptides were real. \u201cThis wasn\u2019t \u2018bro science\u2019; he is a pure brainiac,\u201d Bidlow said. \u201cHe would post scientific studies breaking down how a peptide worked.\u201d\n\nWe sat in a coffee shop as Bidlow gave me a tutorial on peptides. He described which worked, which were difficult to detect and which were not worth the trouble. He said coaches and athletes \u2014 particularly sprinters \u2014 were enamored of something called insulin-like growth factor-1, known as IGF-1. It promotes healing and builds muscle in a fashion similar to anabolic steroids. IGF-1 occurs naturally in the body, and antidoping tests struggle to distinguish the natural from the synthetic.\n\nNo sprinter or baseball player has ever tested positive for IGF-1. Do not take that to mean no sprinter or baseball player has ever used it; they just haven\u2019t been caught.\n\nThe antidoping world has occasional successes. In 2015 and 2016, Dodgers pitcher Josh Ravin, Indians outfielder Marlon Byrd and Braves pitcher Andrew McKirahan tested positive for peptides. Major League Baseball suspended all of them.\n\nBut the case of the retired baseball star Alex Rodriguez is more typical. Anthony Bosch, who said he supplied Rodriguez with drugs, told \u201c60 Minutes\u201d that his witch\u2019s brew included peptides. Rodriguez was suspended by baseball, but not because he failed a drug test. The league connected him to doping through an investigation it started only after a news report broke the story of Bosch\u2019s company, Biogenesis.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018No Legal Foothold\u2019\n\nFaced with the limits of testing technology, antidoping officials and investigators have asked the Food and Drug Administration and Congress to tighten laws and crack down on peptides and growth hormone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Drug Enforcement Administration officials, the problem lies with the weak wording of the laws that currently govern peptides.\n\n\u201cIf I catch you with heroin, it\u2019s a controlled substance and illegal \u2014 that\u2019s easy,\u201d said Douglas W. Coleman, the special agent in charge of the D.E.A.\u2019s Phoenix Division. \u201cIf I find human growth hormone, I have to build a case to show that it\u2019s significantly outside what it can be prescribed for.\n\n\u201cPeptides are more difficult still. There\u2019s really no legal foothold.\u201d\n\nThe F.D.A. holds clearer regulatory authority; its officials could write tougher regulatory language and crack down on peptides and growth hormone. But agency investigators have paid scant attention to this black market. I asked, repeatedly and over many weeks, to speak with an F.D.A. official about the regulation of peptides and growth hormone.\n\nIn the end, an agency spokeswoman sent a boilerplate email.\n\n\u201cThe F.D.A. takes seriously its mission to protect the health of the American public,\u201d wrote the spokeswoman, Theresa Eisenman. \u201cThere are many complex factors involved in how cases involving the sale or distribution of illegal products are investigated and ultimately prosecuted.\u201d\n\nHer email cited three successful peptide prosecutions involving four people during the past three years. Each of the offenders received a light punishment.\n\nSeeking a more detailed explanation, I called a former top F.D.A. official. He spoke on condition of anonymity, as he remains involved with these issues in the private sector. He described the F.D.A.\u2019s stance as defensible. It has a small staff of about 200 agents, and they focus on plagues like tainted and counterfeit drugs, which endanger thousands of unsuspecting customers. The societal impact of peptides and growth hormone is far less severe, clearly.\n\nThe former official described the world of illicit peptide and hormones as caveat emptor \u2014 buyer beware. \u201cIf rich patients and athletes are going to anti-aging clinics or the web in search of unregistered drugs, they know the risk,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe decision to downgrade prosecutions has all but decriminalized the mass distribution and use of powerful and untested drugs for athletes.\n\nThat deeply frustrates those who are trying to stamp out chemical cheating by athletes. Jeff Novitzky once served as a top investigator for the Food and Drug Administration, and he was the lead investigator in the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative case, in which he helped uncover doping by some of the biggest names in American sports.\n\nNovitzky now is a senior official with Ultimate Fighting Championship, the mixed-martial arts circuit. He is charged with cleaning up that sport, and sees governmental foot-dragging everywhere he looks.\n\n\u201cFor officials to complain that these are difficult, high-pressure prosecutions is a cowardly excuse,\u201d Novitzky said. \u201cThe ease with which athletes, teenagers, anyone, can purchase and buy these powerful hormonal substances is mind-boggling.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Athletes\n\nInvestigators discovered that Moorcones was shipping his products from a U.P.S. store wedged between a supermarket and real estate office on the suburban frontier of Queen Creek. Video surveillance revealed that Moorcones\u2019s septuagenarian parents often went with him to mail his parcels.\n\nEventually investigators obtained Moorcones\u2019s customer list of more than 8,000 names. It was a rich hunting ground. Investigators found the names of pro athletes and forwarded the information to their leagues.\n\nMajor League Baseball ended up suspending two minor leaguers. The National Football League was another matter. The Al Jazeera documentary had named six players as likely dopers, and the N.F.L. penalized not a single one. The Moorcones investigation yielded more names, which were shared with the league. The N.F.L. has penalized none of the players.\n\nTrack and field athletes, weight lifters and wrestlers are another matter. The United States Anti-Doping Agency has jurisdiction over these sports and can punish athletes who violate doping protocols.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUsada handed down a raft of penalties to Moorcones\u2019s customers. Jason Young, a 35-year-old discus thrower and coach from Lubbock, Tex., who competed in the 2012 Summer Olympics, was suspended, as was Nick Mossberg, a pole-vaulter who competed at the 2012 United States Olympic trials and planned to try again in 2016. The investigation also netted a wrestler from Colorado and a weight lifter who graduated from M.I.T.\n\nAll acknowledged ordering peptides from Tom Mann. None of these athletes had tested positive.\n\nBidlow and Mossberg, the pole-vaulter, had worked and trained at Altis, an elite athletic training campus in Phoenix. Numerous Olympic athletes train there under the tutelage of coaches with global reputations.\n\nI called the recruiting director at Altis, Andreas Behm, who also coaches the sprinters and hurdlers. Bidlow and Mossberg, he said, had simply \u201cgone rogue.\u201d The elite training center, he insisted, had no larger problem with doping.\n\n\u2018Losing a True Hero\u2019\n\nThe investigation of Moorcones stalled last year. The United States attorney in Phoenix had taken a hard look and given up because a federal agency \u2014 the F.D.A. or the D.E.A. \u2014 was not willing to bring a case. His distribution of peptides, they apparently decided, was not worth prosecuting. A lawyer for Moorcones demanded immunity for his client.\n\nMoorcones shut down his website and claimed online that he was ill. Worried customers speculated that his own drugs had sickened him. \u201cI feel for the guy,\u201d one customer wrote. \u201cThe community of illegal experimental medicine is losing a true hero.\u201d\n\nOther clients speculated correctly that Mann was under investigation; they began to worry that their names had fallen into the hands of law enforcement. They were correct.\n\nMoorcones politely bid everyone goodbye. \u201cI\u2019ve enjoyed serving everyone through the years,\u201d he wrote on his Authentiquevie site.\n\nWithin months, investigators noticed that one of Moorcones\u2019s prominent, high-volume customers had taken his business to a dealer in Florida, where anti-aging clinics peddling peptides and hormones grow like sugar cane. Other clients turned to an oft-investigated but still active peptide trafficker in Louisiana.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere was still much investigators did not understand about Moorcones\u2019s operation. He distributed such massive volumes of illicit substances, but they were never able to determine the source of the drugs. Was he purchasing them from somewhere and reselling to athletes, or was he somehow manufacturing them himself? And were his parents aware of what they were shipping?\n\nBack on the edge of the desert in Arizona, I persuaded Moorcones to keep the door open another minute or two. \u201cPeople all have their own agenda,\u201d he told me.\n\nI allowed that this might be true. Any story grows more complicated when you hear both sides, I said. Why not tell me yours?\n\nHe smiled faintly. \u201cI wouldn\u2019t be the person to give it to you anyway. Thank you.\u201d\n\nThis time, Moorcones shut the door.", "title": "At the Heart of a Vast Doping Network, an Alias", "authors": ["Michael Powell"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Carwile had arrived just before the public learned of the Fast and Furious scandal, a botched operation in which agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives let criminals move guns across the border into Mexico to try to build a bigger case. Many of the firearms were later found at crime scenes. Mr. Carwile incorrectly told superiors that the A.T.F. learned about guns moving illegally only after the fact, according to a subsequent inspector general investigation. He was moved from his post as head of the gangs unit to the much smaller capital punishment division.\n\nImage Kevin Carwile arrived to run the Justice Department\u2019s death penalty division in 2010.\n\nHe quickly gained a reputation as a mercurial manager with a hands-off style that bordered on neglect, according to current and former employees. He rarely responded to emails, four former employees said, and in meetings his questions revealed that he had not read their messages.\n\nBut after his first year, Mr. Carwile received the Excellence in Management award for the criminal division as the section\u2019s lawyers prosecuted more cases.\n\nIn 2013, Jacabed Rodriguez-Coss, a prosecutor who had herself won one of the department\u2019s highest awards, complained to human resources that Mr. Carwile expected her to involuntarily travel far more than her male counterparts.\n\nThough she lived in Connecticut and had cases in Rhode Island and Vermont, he assigned her to one in California. She protested that her family needed her nearby. Her husband, an F.B.I. agent, was one of the first on the scene of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School and was confronting the aftermath of having worked on the case.\n\nMs. Rodriguez-Coss filed a complaint to the E.E.O.C., which notified the Justice Department. Under the agreement the musicians will receive a 4.5 percent increase in wages over the next three years, raising the base salary at the orchestra to $153,504 a year from $146,796; musicians will pay more for health insurance.\n\nThe deal will help prevent the kind of strife between players and management that led to strikes in recent seasons of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra and a lockout at the Minnesota Orchestra and at a moment in which many American orchestras have faced serious financial pressures.\n\nDeborah Borda, president and chief executive of the Philharmonic, said in a statement that the orchestra\u2019s board and administration respect the skill and artistry of the musicians, and \u201cgreatly value the longstanding spirit of partnership that allows the entire organization to move forward and fulfill its artistic mission.\u201d", "title": "At the New York Philharmonic, a Contract Aimed at Labor-Management Harmony", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "But maybe the biggest statement was that it was happening at all: The former co-host of \u201cThe Man Show\u201d \u2014 a Comedy Central show that featured women bouncing on trampolines \u2014 was now kicking off the Oscars with a monologue about sexism.\n\nVideo\n\nThe issue came up early on the red carpet, where Ashley Judd and Mira Sorvino, two of Mr. Weinstein\u2019s accusers, talked about the Time\u2019s Up campaign. \u201cWe are going forward until we have an equitable and safe world for women,\u201d Ms. Sorvino said.\n\nMs. Judd also appeared with two other Weinstein accusers, Salma Hayek and Annabella Sciorra. The hitch, of course, is that every part of the show has its constituency. Cut awards, and someone will be slighted. Cut the musical numbers, and you\u2019d lose Mary J. Blige tearing through \u201cMighty River\u201d and Sufjan Stevens\u2019s whispery \u201cMystery of Love.\u201d\n\nBut one idea: Lose all the \u201cWe love the movies!\u201d montages. (We are watching an Academy Awards. We are already into the movies.) Another: Ditch the stunt gags, like Mr. Kimmel\u2019s leading a parade of stars to crash a movie screening, which are inevitably more fun to think up than to sit through.\n\nThose are all typical issues, though. After what has been an atypical year for Hollywood, the show was mainly notable for acknowledging troubles that are harder to fix than an envelope mixup.\n\n[ See a slide show from the red carpet | read about the after-parties]", "title": "At the Oscars, Some Self-Examination Among the Self-Celebration", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "He manages with what he has, a blend of 30-and-under players who represent the future and spry veterans like Karlsson, who has been playing so long that he won gold for Sweden at the Lillehammer Paralympics in 1994.\n\n\u201cYeah, I know \u2014 I\u2019m old,\u201d Karlsson said.\n\nHe appeared in the next three Paralympics, then missed the last two because work prevented him from training enough. But he was asked to rejoin the Swedish team last year for its qualification pursuit. The sport is far faster, he said, than it used to be, and teams are more competitive, forcing him to compensate for his diminished skill with his understanding of the game.\n\n\u201cThe best would be to combine the speed I had when I was young and the knowledge I have now,\u201d Karlsson said. \u201cThat\u2019s the problem with everything.\u201d\n\nNilsson transitioned to goalie after about a year playing forward because, he said with a laugh, he was too slow. He wears glasses beneath his mask, infusing him with a kindly, studious air. Did it point out that half of all buildings in the South last year went up without proper planning permission (compared to 5 percent in the North)? Not really. It just offered voters a chance to vent their frustration, and \u2014 perhaps most important \u2014 offered a solution from above: more subsidies, more public money, even a reddito di cittadinanza, a salary for every citizen. Professor Roberto Perotti, one of Italy\u2019s most respected economists, in his recent book Falso! (Fake!) claims that this would cost about 45 billion euros, which Italy cannot afford. But this, apparently, didn\u2019t matter to Five Star supporters.\n\nThe North, by contrast, is doing well. So why did it vote in large numbers for Mr. Salvini\u2019s League, choosing him over its former idol, Silvio Berlusconi? Because Mr. Salvini talked about another key issue: immigration from Africa and elsewhere. Mr. Salvini, without offering a solution, stressed over and over that immigration was too high, and also mismanaged. The League campaigned in the roughest parts of Milan and Turin, where newcomers are often involved in petty crime.\n\nIt worked. The League\u2019s vote was higher wherever the number of foreigners grew faster. Today, 58 percent of immigrants live in the North, compared to 26 percent in the Center, 12 percent in the South and 4 percent on the two major islands. In Northern Italy, foreigners represent 11 percent of the population, against 4 percent in the South.\n\nThe Italian North is also worried about taxes and red tape. Mr. Salvini took every opportunity to convince small entrepreneurs that the League is on their side. During the campaign, he mixed common sense and ludicrous promises.\n\nA European rule states that invoices must be settled within 30 days? He\u2019ll make sure it will be enforced (bravo). Mr. Berlusconi, his ally and competitor, promises a 23 percent flat tax, which would cost the Italian public coffers 83 billion euros? Mr. Salvini goes one further, and promises a 15 percent flat tax (huh?). A reform named after Elsa Fornero, a former labor minister, raised the retirement age for both sexes to 67 by 2019 (and kept Italy from going broke in 2011)? He\u2019ll scrap it.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m proud to be called a populist, as I like the people!\u201d said an ebullient Mr. Salvini.\n\n\u201cWe achieved a post-ideological result that goes beyond the right-left divide!,\u201d a euphoric Mr. Di Maio boasted.\n\nNeither commands a majority in Parliament, but they\u2019ll try to put it together. Firmdale\u2019s first New York property, Crosby Street Hotel, in Soho, opened in 2009 and is considered to be among the city\u2019s most fashionable accommodations. The company\u2019s co-owner and design director, Kit Kemp, has a flair for creating unique hotels, and the Whitby, too, is a place with serious design personality: each of the 86 rooms is individually decorated, and original art by contemporary artists from around the world adorns both guest rooms and public spaces.\n\nLocation\n\nThe Whitby is on 56th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Trump Tower, a popular tourist spot ever since Donald J. Trump was elected as the president, is steps away. While this may deter some overnight guests because of the crowds snapping pictures, the property\u2019s central location is undoubtedly appealing: attractions such as Rockefeller Center, Central Park, the Museum of Modern Art, top restaurants and the stores on Fifth Avenue are all within walking distance. Though associated with the earliest artists of the Whitney\u2019s purview, she has also co-curated two Biennials, the museum\u2019s survey of cutting-edge contemporary work, and organized shows on Minimalists like Donald Judd and Agnes Martin.\n\nWhatever the era, she\u2019s been at it so long that her scholarship has deeply shaped her field. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to imagine American art without her,\u201d said the Whitney\u2019s director, Adam D. Weinberg. \u201cHer m\u00e9tier is these great monograph shows.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd she has shaped generations of curators. Among them was Thelma Golden, now the director of the Studio Museum in Harlem. Ms. Golden recalled seeing Ms. Haskell\u2019s Milton Avery show in 1982, when Ms. Golden was a junior at a high school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI was going to the Whitney once a week, but that show stood out for me as a signal moment,\u201d Ms. Golden said. \u201cIt has to do with my sense of what transformative exhibition-making could be.\u201d She added, \u201cI came out of it with a sense of who Avery was, but wanting to know more.\u201d\n\nJust a few years later, Ms. Golden became Ms. Haskell\u2019s Whitney colleague, eventually rising to curator there.\n\n\u201cMost of my career has been with living artists, but she taught me a sense of reverence for the past,\u201d Ms. Golden said.\n\nLike many successful people, Ms. Haskell was in the right place at the right time early on in her career. A native of San Diego, she attended U.C.L.A. and then started working as a registrar at the Pasadena Art Museum; she stayed at the institution for five years.\n\nAt one point a curator was fired, and there were few others to fill in. \u201cIt was a tiny staff, and I just started doing shows,\u201d said Ms. Haskell, who was an assistant curator by then. Altman, between Fifth and Madison Avenues and 34th and 35th Streets, operated a 12th-floor emergency hospital that by 1916 was handling as many as 18,000 cases a year, according to Hospital Management magazine. A 1914 brochure celebrating the store\u2019s expansion said, \u201cThe 12th floor of the new addition has been given over in its entirety to the use of the employees.\u201d Separate dining rooms served men and women, and a physician and two nurses oversaw a large medical suite and surgery. Also, in a sign of those times, there was a men\u2019s smoking room.\n\nThe store, which originally opened in Lower Manhattan in 1865, closed its Midtown flagship in 1989. Ten years later its premises, gutted and rebuilt, were occupied by the City University of New York Graduate Center. Nothing remains of the onetime hospital, said Tanya L. Domi, a spokeswoman for the Graduate Center.\n\nWelfare services for department store workers began with John Wanamaker, a brickmaker\u2019s son born in 1838 who turned a struggling Philadelphia haberdashery into a department store empire built on creative advertising and selling strategies. But Wanamaker was not just focused on making money. He wanted to keep his workers healthy and happy, and so in an era of rapacious capitalism, child labor and male privilege he introduced half-day-Saturdays off, medical benefits and a retirement system. He made sure that the store abided by Pennsylvania\u2019s ban on hiring of boys younger than 13.\n\nHis competitors soon followed with medical facilities, employee exercise and lunchrooms, educational training, vacation programs and medical clinics.\n\nWhen Macy\u2019s on West 34th Street expanded in 1924, the new 16th floor included an employee dental clinic with chairs for six dentists.\n\nThe James McCreery & Co. dry goods store on Broadway at East 11th Street boasted a rooftop restaurant and sun parlor said to be the first of its kind anywhere. Stewart & Company built a similar amenity for workers in Baltimore and stocked it with newspapers, magazines and inspirational books \u2014 and a sewing machine. At the Kaufmann & Baer store in Pittsburgh, women relaxed on the sun roof, while men played basketball in wire cage courts.\n\nAs far back as 1896, the Siegel-Cooper store on Sixth Avenue between West 18th and 19th Streets (then the largest store in the world, now home to TJ Maxx and Bed Bath & Beyond, among others), established an employees association that bought a summer home in Long Branch, N.J., where the 825 female employees could vacation free each year for a week. The innovation drew praise from Gov. Theodore Roosevelt, Mark Twain and Queen Victoria.", "title": "Attention 1916 Shoppers: The Doctor Is In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 In a setback to Trump administration efforts to increase offshore oil production, the industry responded with only modest interest on Wednesday in a federal auction covering a record 77 million acres in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nCompanies bid on only 1 percent of the acreage, and the winning bids yielded a mere $125 million for the government.\n\nThe results reflected broad uncertainty among oil executives that global oil prices can remain at current levels over $60 a barrel, as well as a general preference for drilling in onshore shale fields that require smaller investments and are less risky.\n\nAdministration officials characterized the auction as a success since major oil companies \u2014 Royal Dutch Shell, BP, Chevron and Total \u2014 had placed over 150 bids, and the yield tally was $3 million above a regional lease sale in August.", "title": "Auction of Oil Drilling Tracts in Gulf Draws Tepid Interest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Law enforcement officials have said they found evidence of Mr. Conditt\u2019s potential future targets, a mix of addresses and other locations that appeared to have no common thread to link them. Investigators were continuing on Monday to sort through his computer hard drives and other evidence.\n\nBefore Mr. Conditt died, a federal criminal complaint was filed against him, charging him with unlawful possession and transfer of a destructive device, and a warrant was issued for his arrest. A federal magistrate judge in Austin sealed an affidavit by investigators that would be expected to summarize their reasons for charging Mr. Conditt. It was unclear when that affidavit would be unsealed.\n\nInvestigators have said that Mr. Conditt used his cellphone to record a video in his vehicle after a confrontation with the police in Round Rock, a suburb near Pflugerville. A short time later he detonated one of his bombs inside the vehicle, killing himself. The cellphone survived the explosion.\n\nMr. McCaul, whose district includes parts of Austin and Pflugerville, apparently has seen the video. He described it on Fox News as a visually dark 25-minute confession. \u201cHe said, \u2018I wish I was sorry, but I\u2019m not,\u2019 \u201d Mr. McCaul said. \u201cHe refers to himself as a psychopath. \u2018I\u2019ve been a sociopath all my life.\u2019 And then even more chilling at the end, he says that \u2018maybe I should just blow myself up at a McDonald\u2019s and end the whole thing.\u2019 That\u2019s where he was headed.\u201d\n\nThe authorities said Mr. Conditt placed four fairly sophisticated homemade bombs in Austin, hidden in packages left on doorsteps or, in one case, placed with a tripwire along a sidewalk.\n\nIn total, one of the worst serial bombers in America in decades killed two men; wounded four other people, including a 75-year-old woman; and terrified residents in the Austin and San Antonio regions. In one 24-hour period, the Austin police responded to 420 suspicious-package calls, all false alarms.\n\nHundreds of local, state and federal agents and officers were hunting the serial bomber for days. The state deployed a Pilatus high-altitude surveillance airplane equipped with a thermal imaging system. Mr. Conditt was tracked to a hotel parking lot in Round Rock, and when he drove away in his red Nissan Pathfinder, the police followed him and confronted him; the chase ended in a ditch off Interstate 35, where one Austin SWAT officer fired his weapon and Mr. Conditt set off his bomb.\n\nA justice of the peace in Williamson County, Dain Johnson, said on Monday that Mr. Conditt died by his own hand. \u201cThere is no final report yet, but the cause of death is suicide,\u201d Judge Johnson said. \u201cHe had multiple shrapnel injuries from the bomb.\u201d", "title": "Austin Bombing Suspect\u2019s Housemate Called a Person of Interest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "1. Facebook has lost about $50 billion in market value since the reports were published, and a growing numbers of users are considering deleting their accounts.\n\nOn \u201cThe Daily,\u201d we talk to one of our reporters who broke the story, and discuss how a key data scientist at Cambridge Analytica became a whistleblower.\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 The U.S. Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. Under a new chairman, Jerome Powell, it signaled two more increases this year.\n\n\u2022 Toyota suspended tests of self-driving vehicles on public roads so it could \u201cassess the situation\u201d after an autonomous Uber vehicle fatally struck a pedestrian on Sunday in Arizona.\n\n\u2022 Shares of Crown Resorts slipped after James Packer, the Australian billionaire enmeshed in an Israeli corruption scandal, resigned as director of that huge casino company to deal with \u201cmental health issues.\u201d\n\n\u2022 This year\u2019s Turing Award, often called the Nobel Prize of computing, went to Dave Patterson and John Hennessy for their visionary influence on computer chip design.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Our technology reporter in Mumbai explains how cheap mobile data is changing India, and why WhatsApp is indispensable.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were up. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Afghanistan, a suicide bomber killed at least 31 people among a crowd in Kabul celebrating Nowruz, the Persian New Year. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The ailing president of Myanmar, Htin Kyaw, resigned. Parliament is expected to rapidly choose a successor who will allow Aung San Suu Kyi, officially a state counselor, to continue to exert power. [The Guardian]\n\n\u2022 A U.S. State Department official said American policy would continue \u201cto ensure that Taiwan\u2019s people can continue along their chosen path, free from coercion,\u201d shrugging off a threat from China. The response, she says, has been \u201creally exciting.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Nepal wants to remove 200,000 pounds of trekkers\u2019 garbage in a campaign aimed at \u201csaving the glory of the Everest region.\u201d (They\u2019re going to need more yaks.)\n\n\u2022 And 15 years after the U.S. invasion of Iraq, The Times reintroduces At War, a forum on global conflict that evolved from a renegade blog. The first essay is the tale of a U.S. Marine who led tanks into Baghdad.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nOn this day in 1972, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Eisenstadt v. Baird that it\u2019s unconstitutional for a state to deny unmarried people access to contraception.\n\nThe court had ruled in 1965 that state bans on contraceptives for married couples violated their privacy rights. But a few states still restricted access for single people.\n\nBill Baird, an activist, violated one such law in Massachusetts. He appealed his conviction to the Supreme Court, which struck down the law.\n\nJustice William Brennan held that the law violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment because it discriminated between married and unmarried people.\n\nThe case became an important precedent in subsequent landmark rulings by the Supreme Court, including its 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade that recognized abortion rights, and, more recently, the 2015 decision guaranteeing a right to same-sex marriage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA movie about Mr. Baird\u2019s case is in development. Above, Mr. Baird in 2012.\n\nMr. Baird has continued working as an activist, but his legacy is complicated by what The Times described in 1993 as an \u201cunapologetic zealotry\u201d and a willingness to criticize \u201ceven his ideologic allies.\u201d Planned Parenthood once called him an \u201cembarrassment.\u201d\n\nJillian Rayfield contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. That could complicate efforts by the British government to target the London assets of Russian oligarchs, part of Britain\u2019s retaliation for the nerve-agent attack it blames on Russia.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nToday, we end with a note from the outgoing writer of our European edition, Patrick Boehler:\n\nSince these briefings\u2019 inception over a year ago, this has been the question I have been asked the most:\n\n\u201cHow do you know what Europeans want to read?\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s a fair question for a journalist, albeit a European one, who has spent most of his adult life in Asia, and still is there.\n\nIt is also a legitimate question for a U.S. newspaper at a time in which American news cycles are focused on the twists and turns of a tumultuous presidency.\n\nSo, here\u2019s what we do:\n\nEvery day, we spend hours poring over correspondents\u2019 dispatches and news reports from across Europe, from Northern Ireland to Turkey.\n\nIn conversations with editors, we seek to distill wider trends from the day-to-day politics and give you what you need to know to start your day.\n\nOf course, the result has often been a compromise. Is it flawed? Always.\n\nBut that\u2019s the rule for all early drafts of history.\n\nMy last briefing is tomorrow\u2019s, but I\u2019d like to invite you to keep reading, keep debating and keep challenging assumptions. Thank you for your time! Now enjoy your morning coffee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Austin, Uber, Facebook: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": ["Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 A judge allowed reporters into an Australian courtroom on Wednesday to hear witness testimony during a pretrial hearing for Cardinal George Pell, the Vatican\u2019s third-highest-ranking priest, in a high-profile sexual abuse case that has largely unfolded behind closed doors.\n\nCardinal Pell has been accused of \u201chistorical sexual offenses,\u201d meaning they took place decades ago, but the details of the criminal complaint have not been made public. For the past 10 days the court has been closed to the public as those accusing Cardinal Pell were questioned via video conference.\n\nIn general, Australian law tends to be more favorable to defendants, and proceedings more secretive, than in the United States. Such cases are often subject to the country\u2019s contempt standards, and other legal restrictions, which prohibit journalists from reporting on details of criminal allegations.\n\nThe hearing, which is expected to run for at least another week, will determine if Cardinal Pell, the most senior member of the Catholic Church to face such accusations, will stand trial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCardinal Pell had been accused in hearings before Australia\u2019s Royal Commission Into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse of mishandling misconduct cases against clergy members while he served as the leader of the Archdioceses of Melbourne and Sydney. Then allegations surfaced that he had himself been involved in abuse beginning early in his priesthood and continuing until he became archbishop of Melbourne. He has repeatedly denied the accusations.\n\nPhoto\n\nPope Francis last year gave Cardinal Pell, the Vatican\u2019s de facto finance chief, a leave of absence to return to Australia to mount his defense. The cardinal\u2019s rank and the nature of the allegations could make the case precedent setting, and it threatens to undermine the pope\u2019s promise to weed out sexual abuse in the Church.", "title": "Australian Court Hears Public Testimony in Cardinal Pell Abuse Case", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Allegations later surfaced that the cardinal himself had been involved with abuse decades ago. Pope Francis granted Cardinal Pell a leave of absence to contest the charges, which the cardinal has vehemently denied.\n\nFiery exchanges during witness testimony this week typified the tone of the hearing, and they have shed light on the seriousness of the yet-to-be-detailed charges. On Wednesday, Ms. Wallington asked the cardinal\u2019s attorney Robert Richter to stop shouting at her before she denied his request that she recuse herself from hearing the case.\n\nThe hearings have been punctuated by similarly heated exchanges, many of which have involved Mr. Richter, a lawyer known for a confrontational style of cross-examination and for commanding a five-figure daily fee.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, Mr. Richter told the court that the task force set up to investigate potential offenses by the cardinal was an \u201coperation looking for a crime.\u201d\n\nHe suggested that the police may have avoided specific lines of questioning while collecting evidence and statements that led to the charges against the cardinal.\n\n\u201cIt would be horrible if an investigator decided not to pursue an obvious line of questioning just because he was afraid that the answers might destroy his case,\u201d Mr. Richter said to Superintendent Paul Sheridan, the detective who led the investigation into the cardinal for the last two years.\n\n\u201cI would agree with that,\u201d replied Mr. Sheridan, who stood for the entirety of his cross-examination, angling his body and eyes away from Mr. Richter. At several points, Mr. Richter mentioned that he and Mr. Sheridan had known each other for a long time.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring several hours of testimony, Mr. Richter pressed Mr. Sheridan on apparent inconsistencies in his testimony, at one point suggesting that the cardinal\u2019s robes were made in such a way that events alleged to have taken place at a Melbourne cathedral could not have happened.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also argued that \u201cacts of appalling seriousness\u201d alleged to have occurred on a mountaintop, on an altar and at a 1978 screening of \u201cClose Encounters of the Third Kind\u201d could not have happened, citing inconsistencies in the accuser\u2019s timeline.\n\nIt was on this point that Ms. Wallington questioned Mr. Richter\u2019s own proposed timeline, leading him to further argue his case with her.\n\n\u201cPlease don\u2019t shout at me, Mr. Richter,\u201d Ms. Wallington said softly.\n\nIt was then that Mr. Richter asked the magistrate to \u201cdisqualify herself from further hearing this matter, on the basis of a biased view of the evidence.\u201d\n\n\u201cYour application is refused,\u201d replied Ms. Wallington.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Richter accused the journalist Louise Milligan of omitting key reporting in a television report on the accusations and a book she published last year, \u201cCardinal: The Rise and Fall of George Pell.\u201d\n\nThe court had previously heard that statements some complainants gave to the police differed somewhat from those given to Ms. Milligan during her reporting. As is common in such cases, her book was removed from bookstores in the state of Victoria, where the trial is taking place.\n\n\u201cShe distorted what went to the public,\u201d Mr. Richter said of Ms. Milligan\u2019s coverage. \u201cI would put to her that she distorted it even more in her book, so as to poison the public\u2019s mind against Cardinal Pell,\u201d he added.\n\n\u201cI completely and utterly reject that,\u201d Ms. Milligan said.\n\n\u201cOf course you would,\u201d said Mr. Richter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Milligan later pushed back on Mr. Richter\u2019s characterizations of some accusers, saying that abuse victims were unfairly \u201ctorn apart by people like you\u201d in courts.\n\nMr. Richter later described some of Ms. Milligan\u2019s documented exchanges with her sources as \u201ccharming, if not flirtatious,\u201d which she dismissed as insulting.\n\n\u201cI think that is an absolutely sexist assertion,\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShould the cardinal\u2019s case go to trial, it is unclear how soon there would be a resolution. A pretrial hearing would be held to determine what evidence could be used during the trial, and another hearing would be held to determine a timeline for the proceedings.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to predict how long it will be \u2014 it depends on the law calendars,\u201d said Mark Nolan, a professor of criminal law at the Australian National University.\n\nIf the magistrate rules that there is insufficient evidence to send the case to trial, Victoria\u2019s director of public prosecutions can still decide to try Cardinal Pell.", "title": "Australian Court to Decide Whether Cardinal Pell Faces Trial", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe want people who want to come here, abide by our laws, integrate into our society, work hard, not lead a life on welfare,\u201d Mr. Dutton said. He also cited news reports that white farmers in South Africa were in danger for their lives.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe comments from Mr. Dutton, a member of the center-right governing Liberal Party, also raised eyebrows in Australia, where immigration is a hot-button issue and Liberal Party politicians have been accused of using race as a political tool.\n\nThousands of predominantly Muslim migrants from the Middle East and Southeast Asia have languished in offshore detention facilities for years under a policy that denied asylum seekers traveling by boat entrance to Australia. Last year, Australia agreed to pay $53 million in damages to migrants who said they had suffered abuse in the camps.\n\nMr. Dutton has been a staunch defender of the offshore detention policy, and he has argued that Australia should not accept refugees who would be a burden on the country\u2019s social safety net.\n\nIn January, Mr. Dutton blamed African migrants for a rise in crime in Melbourne, claiming in an interview that residents of the city were afraid even to go to restaurants at night \u201cbecause they\u2019re followed home by these gangs.\u201d\n\nCritics of the government said that those remarks were intended to scare voters before an election and that official crime data showed no such correlation with immigration.\n\nAccording to government statistics, more immigrants to Australia are born in South Africa than in any other African country. As of 2016, 181,400 Australian residents were South African natives, according to the latest census. The government does not break down that figure by race, but white South Africans have been moving to Australia in large numbers for decades.\n\nThe question of redistributing white-owned farmland to blacks in South Africa became an issue again in February when Cyril Ramaphosa was elected president.", "title": "Australian Official Calls for Emergency Visas for White South African Farmers", "authors": ["Russell Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "But it also fits neatly with the Freedom Party\u2019s anti-establishment and quasi-libertarian tilt. \u201cFreedom of choice\u201d is the flip side of a far-right agenda that otherwise seems inclined to dictate to citizens, especially those from minorities, everything from whether they can wear head coverings to whom they should marry.\n\nThe push to upend the smoking ban has stirred more than the usual consternation.\n\nAlthough the European Union does not impose regulations on smoke-free environments, it has made a set of recommendations that has led many members to introduce strict bans on smoking in public places in recent years.\n\nAustria has one of the highest smoking rates among adults in the European Union, and was one of only two member states where the number of adults who smoked regularly did not decrease from 2000 to 2015, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.\n\nPhoto\n\nThomas Szekeres, the president of the Vienna Medical Association, appeared baffled during an interview in his office. Banning indoor smoking, he said, was not an attempt to single out smokers but a move against \u201csmoking and harming the health of people.\u201d\n\n\u201cPeople need an example to see what happens when you smoke and that it could happen to them, too,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Szekeres has been one of the high-profile backers of the \u201cDon\u2019t Smoke\u201d campaign and has promoted a petition asking the government to think again. It gathered more than 500,000 signatures in the month that followed, in a country of about 8.8 million.\n\n\u201cWe want to show the politicians responsible that the people are in favor of a ban on smoking,\u201d Mr. Szekeres said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe conflicting public currents around the smoking ban have intensified scrutiny of the Freedom Party, which was founded partly by former Nazis after World War II, and what it might do now that it has entered government.\n\nLast December, when Mr. Strache\u2019s party received key portfolios in Austria\u2019s new government, an article in the German weekly \u201cDie Zeit\u201d commented: \u201cThey don\u2019t want to bite, just to smoke,\u201d referring to the proverb that barking dogs don\u2019t bite.\n\nThe motto Mr. Strache has repeated since he floated the idea of overturning the ban during last year\u2019s election campaign is \u201cfreedom of choice instead of forceful state regulation.\u201d Responsible citizens, he has said, must be able to make these choices themselves.\n\nOn social media, in between anti-immigrant and nationalistic messages, his party also championed bread-and-butter causes.\n\nIts former presidential candidate, Norbert Hofer, called for \u201chigher tax on motorways for foreigners,\u201d and a regional politician, Gottfried Waldh\u00e4usl, promoted \u201cfreedom of choice\u201d with a picture of a cup of coffee beside a burning cigarette.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a policy which in a certain way is not suspicious of being traditionally right-wing,\u201d said Anton Pelinka, a professor of political science at the Central European University in Budapest. \u201cIt\u2019s a fight against the new enemy, which is called political correctness.\u201d\n\nThe bill that is scheduled to go before parliament is based on the \u201cBerlin model,\u201d named after the German capital, which prohibits smoking in most public places but allows it in smaller establishments and in designated areas.\n\nIt includes protective steps like increasing the minimum age for smoking from 16 to 18 and is due to go in front of the country\u2019s Parliament this week.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnlike in other capitals of Western Europe, in Vienna smoking remains widespread. Not only is the sight of smoking rooms in bars and restaurants common, cigarettes are easily purchased from vending machines in the streets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast December, Mr. Strache appeared at a gathering of restaurant owners in a smoke-filled wine bar near Austria\u2019s Parliament. The rally, hosted by the bar\u2019s owner, Heinz Pollischansky, carried the message that restaurant and bar owners opposed the ban.\n\nBut Vienna\u2019s gastronomy scene is split over the question. The famous coffee houses on the city\u2019s tourist trail have already banned smoking, in anticipation of this year\u2019s deadline.\n\nOthers, like Caf\u00e9 Hummel, a family business, have invested thousands of euros in separating smoking and nonsmoking areas \u2014 and paid fines after complaints from nonsmoking guests for failing to contain the smoke.\n\nChristina Hummel, the manager, is the third generation in her family at the helm of this classic Viennese establishment. \u201cWe\u2019ve been here since 1935, and since 1935 it was smoking,\u201d said Ms. Hummel, who is not a regular smoker but enjoys a cigarette with a glass of wine.\n\nLast year, Ms. Hummel had enough of the complaints and fines and declared her cafe fully nonsmoking. She said she immediately lost many regulars, about 5 percent of the annual clientele, and others cut back on orders. But the decision allowed her to turn to a new clientele.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cTimes change,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have to look toward the future.\u201d\n\nA sign of those changing times is Caf\u00e9 F\u00fcrth, a small venue that shares its central space with two offices and its own coffee roasting operation.\n\nThe owner, Helmut Haller, 30, was on his day off, trying out a new coffee machine and a concoction of iced espresso with blood-orange lemonade. A far cry from the classical coffeehouse proprietor, Mr. Haller said he followed trends in the United States, Australia and Britain and never allowed smoking.\n\n\u201cGlobal coffee culture is a nonsmoking culture,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, he said he placed his business in the Viennese cafe tradition, which provided a meeting point for great figures of fine arts, literature and philosophy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn Austria we\u2019re slower with change,\u201d he said of his country\u2019s position between Germany and the Balkans.\n\nHe said that both some residents and visitors had their minds set on a certain idea of Vienna, described with the German word \u201cGem\u00fctlichkeit,\u201d which translates as a broad feeling of comfort or cosiness.\n\nBut even many smokers who enjoy a chance to light up see in the ban an opportunity to set themselves free.\n\nOne was Philippe Mayer, a 41-year-old musician with blond dreadlocks who had settled into the dimly lit smoking room of Caf\u00e9 Europa, in central Vienna, after dropping off his daughter at kindergarten.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a reward for waking up early,\u201d Mr. Mayer said. But even as he enjoyed his cigarette, he, like his country, had mixed feelings about it.\n\n\u201cSmoking gives me a kind of feeling like slavery,\u201d he said. \u201cIt would be helpful if it were banned.\u201d", "title": "Austria\u2019s Far Right Wants the Freedom to Smoke", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Federal authorities raided two homes near Albany that were associated with a cultlike group called Nxivm, in which women were branded with a symbol that contained its leader\u2019s initials, according to media reports.\n\nThe raids followed the arrest Sunday of Nxivm\u2019s leader, Keith Raniere, on charges that he forced female followers to have sex with him. Mr. Raniere, who is known to his followers as \u201cVanguard,\u201d is expected to be arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on sex-trafficking charges.\n\nOne of the raids on Tuesday took place in Half Moon, N.Y., at the home of a former psychiatric nurse, Nancy Salzman, who founded Nxivm (pronounced Nex-ee-um) along with Mr. Raniere, according to news reports. Another area home was also raided.\n\nNxivm denies it is a cult, and has described itself as a \u201cself-help\u201d organization. But former members have said that Mr. Raniere demands cultlike obedience from followers.", "title": "Authorities Raid Homes Linked to Cultlike Group that Branded Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "What do you say to people who are not convinced by the evidence?\n\nI think about poor Galileo, 500 years ago or so, when he had evidence that Earth is not the center of the universe and was ostracized. Now, we have evidence that we are totally dependent on the natural systems that hold the planet steady within the temperature range that is safe for us. You can measure the shrinking Arctic and Antarctic ice. Half the coral reefs have either gone or are in a state of sharp decline. I think it\u2019s getting easier, because the ocean is beginning to speak for herself.\n\nYou helped persuade President George W. Bush to create an ocean monument 100 times the size of Yosemite. Now, the Trump administration is trying to shrink similar protected areas. How does that make you feel?\n\nQuoting a former Republican president who was not widely celebrated for his environmental ethic, Ronald Reagan: Protecting the environment is not a liberal or conservative thing, it\u2019s just common sense. He at least could see the connection between the economy and the environment. When you lose the quality of a place environmentally \u2014 the trees, the water, the space, the air \u2014 there are economic and human social consequences. It\u2019s taken a longer time for people to realize that the ocean is vast and resilient, but it\u2019s not too big to fail.\n\nWhat do you tell people who tell you that they don\u2019t have hope, or they don\u2019t know what they can do?\n\nThis is the best time ever to be around, because we have the power of knowing. Look in the mirror to recognize your personal power. It\u2019s a matter of using what you\u2019ve got. Take a kid out to some wild place and see the world through that child\u2019s eyes. Look at the future and imagine you\u2019re there, 50 years out. We\u2019ve reached a time when we really have to choose between our wants and our needs, and we need a planet that works.\n\nThe latest spring trends", "title": "Automakers Shift Gears on Climate Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "When executives from the Big Three automakers went to the White House last spring to ask for more lenient emissions rules, their prospects looked rosy. President Trump seemed eager to roll back regulations, and Scott Pruitt \u2014 a friend of industry \u2014 was newly in control at the Environmental Protection Agency.\n\nNow, automakers are coming to terms with a startling reality: Be careful what you ask of President Trump, because he could go further than you expect.\n\nThe E.P.A.\u2019s plan, which is likely to be formally launched in coming days, is widely expected to loosen regulations on greenhouse gas emissions and fuel economy well beyond what the automakers themselves had sought.\n\nIn addition, according to a White House official with knowledge of the plans, the Trump administration is expected to formally urge California \u2014 which has special authority under the Clean Air Act to set its own air pollution laws \u2014 to go along with the rollback, something the state has already said it won\u2019t do. That could spark a legal battle between the federal government and California, potentially dividing the United States into two automobile markets, each with a different rule book governing pollution and gas mileage.", "title": "Automakers Sought Looser Rules but May Get More Than They Bargained For", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Her previous projects \u2014 like the civil rights drama \u201cSelma\u201d and the documentary \u201c13TH,\u201d about mass incarceration \u2014 and her company Array, which distributes films by underserved directors, have given her an activist platform that seems inseparable from her voice. In \u201cWrinkle,\u201d she found a different range: Two weeks before preproduction, her beloved stepfather died, suddenly, and all at once the film became much more personal than she could have realized.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWrinkle,\u201d as anyone associated with it will tell you, is not an easy book to adapt. To rescue her father, Meg Murry, the physics-loving heroine \u2014 played by Storm Reid, now 14 \u2014 skips across galaxies with her little brother and a friend, encountering fantastical creatures and menacing beasts. But her trajectory is elliptical, and when she finally meets the bad guy, it\u2019s a brain. \u201cThe villain is the darkness inside of you,\u201d Ms. DuVernay said. \u201cThere\u2019s no Darth Vader, no battle scene. Her action is progressive, and it\u2019s internal.\u201d\n\nTo translate that to the screen, \u201cit has to be lyrical, and intimate,\u201d while also balancing a coming-of-age saga, an adventure tale and a story that has been beloved by middle-schoolers for more than half a century, Ms. DuVernay said. \u201cThat\u2019s why I frigging did it, because it was hard.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe had a notable pep squad, though: \u201cI signed on because I thought it would be fun to have the experience with Ava,\u201d said her friend Oprah Winfrey, who plays Mrs. Which, one of the kids\u2019 guiding spirits. Reese Witherspoon, as the impatient Mrs. Whatsit, and Mindy Kaling, who quotes Rumi and OutKast as Mrs. Who, are the others; they were chosen partly for their offscreen acumen as producers reshaping Hollywood.\n\nIt was Ms. DuVernay\u2019s multicultural casting ideas \u2014 \u201cHamilton\u201d was a reference \u2014 that helped sell her vision to Disney. \u201cOnce she presented it like that, it was one of those things where you couldn\u2019t see the film any other way,\u201d said Tendo Nagenda, the executive vice president for production for Walt Disney Studios, who sent Ms. DuVernay the script. \u201cAnd little did she know that the desperation on my part to make sure she did it went to an all-time high.\u201d\n\nMr. Nagenda \u2014 who was raised in Los Angeles by a Ugandan father and a mother from Belize \u2014 added that he saw it as part of his mission at Disney to broaden the narrative. When he realized the film would be the first big-budget, sci-fi fantasy to feature a young girl of color as the lead, \u201cit made me ask the question, why is that?\u201d\n\nThat \u201cWrinkle\u201d is arriving on March 9, after Ryan Coogler\u2019s \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d another Disney film, has seemingly rewritten the cultural code of Hollywood, either sets it up for blockbuster success or makes any disappointing box office all the more bitter. There\u2019s little chance it will be a phenomenon like \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d Mr. Nagenda said, but that film \u2014 and the marketing lessons it taught \u2014 may unlock new theatergoers. \u201cAudiences are responding to stories in which they feel they are represented and have a voice, and where the film itself is cognizant of that,\u201d he said, \u201cand I think our film has a lot of that.\u201d\n\nMs. DuVernay was careful to note that \u201cWrinkle\u201d is not broad fare like a Marvel superhero movie; it\u2019s intended for 8- to 12-year-olds. \u201cI don\u2019t know if I\u2019ll ever do anything like this again,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd so, given the chance, she put her stamp on it, using locations not far from where she grew up in Lynwood, Calif.: She shot in West Adams, a historic black district in Los Angeles; and Crenshaw High School, nearby, stands in for Meg\u2019s James Baldwin Middle School in the movie.\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Coogler did something similar, setting part of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d in Oakland, Calif., near his home. It\u2019s a way, Ms. DuVernay said, of claiming a bit of identity in a studio film, a move that directors \u201cwho are privileged enough to see themselves in films all the time\u201d may not need to make. In her hairstyle and clothes, Meg is based on Ms. DuVernay\u2019s niece, a K-pop fan and skateboard-loving 13-year-old in Alabama. And a new character, a bully, was created out of the memories that Ms. DuVernay and Jennifer Lee, the screenwriter, had of their own childhood tormentors.\n\n\u201cThe best part of working with Ava, she wanted this to be an emotional adventure,\u201d said Ms. Lee, the writer and co-director of \u201cFrozen,\u201d the animated megahit. Putting it on the page was almost therapeutic, she said: \u201cThere are always the heroes you wish you had as a kid, the ones you wish spoke to you, that say, \u2018You\u2019re more than you think you are.\u2019\u201d More than any character she\u2019s created, Meg embodies that leap in confidence \u201cwith the most sincerity.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Reid, the star, booked the part in eighth grade, having read the book in sixth. She kept a journal chronicling Meg\u2019s feelings. She came as prepared, Ms. DuVernay said, as David Oyelowo, playing Martin Luther King Jr. in \u201cSelma.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Reid, who has been acting since she was 3, understood the impact this role could have on other girls. \u201cI do a feel a sense of responsibility, like that I have to keep them uplifted and I have to keep inspiring them,\u201d she said. Ms. DuVernay thought of Meg as just a regular kid who finds her potential, but to Ms. Reid, she is a superhero: \u201cShe is an African-American girl that is smart, that is beautiful and that basically realizes that she is enough,\u201d she said. With that realization, \u201cshe just taps into her superpowers to be able to save her dad, her brother and save the world.\u201d\n\nThe inclusive casting of Meg and the three guides got the attention, but Ms. DuVernay spent as much time obsessing over the role of Calvin, Meg\u2019s friend, played by the Australian actor Levi Miller. She chose him, in part, she said, \u201cbecause that was so powerful, to show a white boy following a black girl through the movie.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never seen that,\u201d Ms. DuVernay continued. \u201cI mean, I have a crew of thousands of people, and it\u2019s not lost on me that I have white men coming up to me all day long like, \u2018What do I do?\u2019 And in my early career, there\u2019s some white men that have a problem with that, a problem with even asking me what to do, and taking my direction and believing that I know what I\u2019m saying, because they have no context for even seeing it.\u201d\n\nAs the instigator of multiple diversity initiatives in Hollywood, Ms. DuVernay keeps giving them examples. Her ability to shape messages (she started out as a film publicist), her ease and clarion honesty in sharing complicated, personal truths, is rare.\n\nSitting in her new office, she crumpled quickly when the father-daughter part of \u201cWrinkle\u201d came up. Ms. DuVernay\u2019s stepfather, who helped raise her, died after a brief and sudden illness in 2016, as she was about to start work on the movie. It was as if he had disappeared without warning \u2014 just as Alex Murry, the father in \u201cWrinkle\u201d (played by Chris Pine), does.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI felt that so deeply as I was making the film,\u201d she said, \u201cthis girl who literally cannot wrap her mind around the fact that he\u2019s gone, and the moment when they say he could still be here \u2014\u2014.\u201d She broke off, crying.\n\nHer stepfather\u2019s name was Murray Maye. All throughout production, when there was a script note or a lighting change for Mr. Pine\u2019s character, she couldn\u2019t bring herself to say Dr. Murry, as crew members did; she referred to him only as \u201cthe father.\u201d\n\n\u201cI feel like the film is looking for him in a way,\u201d she said, in tears. \u201cAnd that\u2019s why I don\u2019t care what anybody thinks about it. I don\u2019t care. I don\u2019t feel pressure about the whole first, blah blah blah. I know it\u2019s $100 million for the studio. They\u2019ll be fine. Ryan\u2019s made sure of that for me.\u201d (She and the \u201cBlack Panther\u201d director are close.) \u201cSo, you know, this means a lot to me, and I know it\u2019s going to mean something to some people.
