Some people will see it, see all the things we put in there.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Winfrey did. \u201cI grew up in an era where there was absolutely zero, minus, images\u201d of girls like her in pop culture, she said. \u201cSo I do imagine, to be a brown-skinned girl of any race throughout the world, looking up on that screen and seeing Storm, I think that is a capital A, capital W, E, some, AWESOME, experience,\u201d she added by phone. \u201cI think this is going to be a wondrous marvel of an experience for girls that in the future they will just take for granted.\u201d\n\nThe entertainment press made much of the fact that Ms. DuVernay had never worked with special effects (which is rarely belabored when male directors make the same leap). But neither had Ms. Winfrey. \u201cMy first time being hung from the ceiling!\u201d she said. She found getting up and getting down so nerve-racking that she asked the crew to just keep her rigged up. \u201cThe crew\u2019s going to lunch, and they\u2019re like, well we can\u2019t leave you hanging! I go, \u2018Oh yeah, you can!\u2019\u201d she said. (She stayed up there. Just picture it.)\n\nMs. DuVernay, though, \u201cwas in her element,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said, recalling that when she observed the huge cranes with the camera, \u201cand there\u2019s Ava, in her dreads and her sneakers and her vest and her jeans, surrounded by lots of big guys and lots of big machinery, saying, \u2018Cut, stop, let\u2019s take that again,\u2019 it just would make my heart swell, that she had taken on something that was this enormous, and was managing it so well.\u201d\n\n\u201cWrinkle\u201d is a very girlie movie; at one point, a character is saved from a fall by a field of gossipy flowers. And Ms. DuVernay is warm and girlie, too \u2014 at our meeting, we talked about the joys and pitfalls of fake eyelashes; crying, she peeled hers off. \u201cI like clothes, I like makeup, I like looking at pretty dresses,\u201d she said. Onscreen, the Mrs. characters change costumes at every appearance: Ms. Winfrey described her look as \u201cBeyonc\u00e9\u2019s aunt from another planet.\u201d\n\nAnd none of these glitter-tinged fantasies subtract from Ms. DuVernay\u2019s own mission, that cultivation of new perspectives and realities. To her, \u201cSelma\u201d and \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d share a foundational message: \u201cCivil rights work and social justice work take imagination, to imagine a world that isn\u2019t there, and you imagine that it can be there. And that\u2019s the same thing that you do whenever you imagine and insert yourself in a future space, or in a space where you\u2019ve been absent.\u201d\n\nTo imagine a world where a girl like Meg can fly was \u201csuper-emotional to me,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd then to be able to make it so, even on camera for a little while, for two hours \u2014 to change the world for that small amount of time, it\u2019s very powerful. It\u2019s addictive.\u201d", "title": "Ava DuVernay\u2019s Fiercely Feminine Vision for \u2018A Wrinkle in Time\u2019", "authors": ["Melena Ryzik"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nName: Ava Nirui\n\nAge: 26\n\nHometown: Sydney, Australia\n\nNow Lives: In a modern three-bedroom apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn that she shares with two friends.\n\nClaim to Fame: Ms. Nirui is a self-described \u201cluxury remixer\u201d known for putting a D.I.Y. spin on designer labels, like a tank top made from Gucci garment bags and an asthma inhaler bedazzled with the Dior logo. Her high-low creations have won her fashion fans, including Marc Jacobs, who hired her to create a bootleg hoodie that purposely misspelled his name as \u201cMark Jacobes.\u201d The $125 hoodies sold out in a single day last December. Ms. Nirui is also a writer, photographer and the digital editor at Helmut Lang. \u201cI\u2019ve kind of become obsessed with customizing things and the fact that I can pay $5 for a Chinatown hoodie and change the context so it has the same value as a $900 sweatshirt,\u201d she said.\n\nA post shared by ava (@avanope) on Nov 26, 2016 at 2:54pm PST\n\nBig Break: In 2015, the designer Demna Gvasalia was making waves with his Vetements x Champion capsule collection. Not wanting to spend $1,100 on a sweatshirt, Ms. Nirui dreamed up her own version: a black Champion hoodie with the Comme des Gar\u00e7ons logo embroidered using the hoodie\u2019s iconic C. \u201cI remember thinking it was so absurd that it was so expensive,\u201d Ms. Nirui said. \u201cSo I decided, \u2018No way. I\u2019m just going to do my own.\u2019\u201d She posted her creation to Instagram and was flooded with messages from people wanting to buy it, including Chance the Rapper. She declined to sell it, which only stoked demand further. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t about making money,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was about taking a piece of history and reworking it into something nobody else could have.\u201d\n\nLatest Project: In January, the Museum of Modern Art enlisted Ms. Nirui to make a limited-edition hoodie for the closing of its exhibit \u201cItems: Is Fashion Modern?\u201d The hoodies were based on Maison Margiela\u2019s numerical logo, and were given out to museumgoers for free.\n\nNext Thing: While Ms. Nirui is planning more hoodies (she declined to name the designers she is collaborating with), she is branching into zines and other creative forms. Most recently, she created a line of Barbie doll outfits for the Miami street wear brand Stray Rats.\n\nBootleg for the Masses: Ms. Nirui doesn\u2019t consider her work as \u201cripping off other designers,\u201d but as homage. \u201cBrands like Louis Vuitton and Chanel, they\u2019re the pinnacle of luxury, and things like that should be available to everyone,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you can\u2019t afford it, make it. If that\u2019s what you want to wear, do it yourself.\u201d", "title": "Ava Nirui Gives Bootleg a Fashion Twist", "authors": ["Alexandra Weiss", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "A revolution is afoot in space. As the use of satellites transforms from a national and military-led enterprise to one dominated by businesses, governments worldwide are playing catch-up with the rules and regulations that apply. It\u2019s now possible for a private enterprise with headquarters in the United States to launch Argentine satellites from New Zealand\u2019s soil.\n\nThe gaps in international regulations and coordination became clear recently when a California-based start-up, Swarm Technologies, launched four tiny satellites called SpaceBees on an Indian rocket, over the objection of the Federal Communications Commission. Among other things, the F.C.C. is responsible for making sure satellites are trackable by the government\u2019s Space Surveillance Network to minimize the chance of collisions. The SpaceBees were so small (about 4 inches by 4 inches by 1 inch) that the network could not regularly track them, though a private tracking service, LeoLabs, says it has been tracking them since the launch.\n\nSeveral new space start-ups are planning enormous \u201cmega-constellations\u201d of hundreds or even thousands of satellites in low Earth orbit (about 100 miles to 1,250 miles in altitude) in the next decade, and these too will challenge the regulatory framework. Only about a thousand or so operational satellites are in that region now, so the mega-constellation trend portends an increase of more than tenfold in active satellites in low Earth orbit, all within a matter of years.\n\nHow much distance should separate these various constellations so that any collision in one doesn\u2019t create havoc for those in higher or lower orbits? Currently, orbital slots in low Earth orbit are not assigned \u2014 you launch to wherever you like \u2014 but this laissez-faire attitude may soon need revisiting.", "title": "Opinion | Avoiding Collisions in Outer Space", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "WEDNESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 It\u2019s the middle of the week, and we\u2019ve been working hard, burning those mental calories to conquer the puzzles, so it\u2019s time to carbo load. Gotta keep that energy up so we can get to the end of the solving week.\n\nLuckily, Jeff Chen returns with a delicious theme that won\u2019t drive anyone stir-crazy.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nI love a good red sauce, and am always on the hunt for a tasty, homemade MARINARA recipe. If you have one that you are particularly fond of, please put it in the comments. Julia Moskin\u2019s contribution in New York Times Cooking can be found here.\n\nMr. Chen gives us, if not a recipe, a road map for making MARINARA sauce, by indicating the ingredients in the circled letters and stirring them vigorously. I especially liked that if you were solving from top to bottom, the ingredients are actually in the order you might put them in: For example, at 16A, the answer to the clue \u201cTake dead aim at\u201d is ZERO IN ON, which has the mixed up letters for \u201conion\u201d in them, and a cook might saut\u00e9 the onion in a bit of oil before adding anything else (Yes, I realize some cooks would probably add in the \u201cgarlic\u201d from ARTIFICIAL GRASS next, but you don\u2019t want to burn it and the garlic flavor will be more pronounced if you add it after the \u201ctomato,\u201d which is A-O.K. with me.)\n\nIn nontheme news, I liked seeing the debuts of ZORK, O.K. FINE and MAKES BANK.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nI bounced around a lot while solving this puzzle; no starting at 1A and proceeding in an orderly fashion for me. But that\u2019s O.K.: The fill-in-the-blanks provided a good foothold, and the information needed to solve was broad enough so that there was surely something to grasp for everyone.", "title": "Awesome Sauce", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "She laughed.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re on talking terms,\u201d she said.\n\nWilson is now a victory away from a third trip to the Final Four. Second-seeded South Carolina (29-6) and top-seeded Connecticut (35-0) will meet Monday in the highly anticipated final of the Albany Region, the past two national champions vying to reach the national semifinals on Friday in Columbus, Ohio.\n\nHers is an impeccable r\u00e9sum\u00e9 but for one omission: In four tries, Wilson has never defeated UConn, an 11-time champion and the standard by which the women\u2019s game is measured.\n\nOutside of South Carolina, the Gamecocks\u2019 2017 N.C.A.A. championship carried a whiff of anticlimax, coming 48 hours after Mississippi State had stunned UConn in the semifinals, snapping the Huskies\u2019 111-game winning streak on a jumper by Morgan William in the final seconds of overtime.\n\n\u201cI think A\u2019ja\u2019s thunder was a little bit stolen last year because they weren\u2019t the team that took UConn down,\u201d said Lexie Brown, a Duke guard who is friends with Wilson. \u201cIf you weren\u2019t an avid women\u2019s basketball watcher, you probably thought Mississippi State won the national championship.\u201d\n\nFinally defeating UConn in her senior season, Brown said, would ratify Wilson\u2019s stature as the best player in the country \u201cand would be the cherry on top of her amazing career.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nScheduled to graduate in May with a degree in communications, Wilson is gregarious, funny, open, often leading her team in dances. She is the product of a family of preachers, educators and civil-rights activists devoted to helping the less fortunate.\n\nOn Saturday, she revealed an aspect of herself that was not widely known outside her team. In an essay posted on The Players\u2019 Tribune, Wilson wrote that she has long struggled with dyslexia. Once afraid to admit weakness, she said on Sunday that she felt liberated to have acknowledged vulnerability.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s lifted a lot of weight off my shoulders,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s great feeling because it shows people I\u2019m human.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA transformational moment came during her sophomore season at South Carolina, Wilson wrote in her Players\u2019 Tribune essay, when Coach Dawn Staley began having her read aloud from Scripture in the locker room before games.\n\n\u201cIt was definitely humiliating at first, but I kept at it. Just straight brute force, every time she asked,\u201d Wilson wrote. \u201cI don\u2019t know if she thought it would help, or if it would make me play better, or what. But after a while, it really would make me feel better. It was like I could suddenly talk with people about this secret that had been eating at me for years.\u201d\n\nWilson also confronted a separate vulnerability before her teammates this season. On Feb. 1, South Carolina lost at home to UConn, 83-58. Wilson felt distracted and shot only 4 for 18 from the field. Afterward, she apologized publicly to her teammates. It has sometimes been difficult, she said Sunday, to focus on carrying her team while looking ahead to the W.N.B.A. and preparing for graduation.\n\n\u201cI felt awful,\u201d Wilson said of the loss to UConn. \u201cThat was just not me. I didn\u2019t want my teammates to feel like it was their fault.\u201d\n\nHer struggle that night, Wilson said, revealed to herself and her teammates that she was not invincible.\n\n\u201cI kind of think people get caught up in the \u2018basketball A\u2019ja\u2019 and just think she is a robot,\u201d Wilson said. \u201cShe\u2019s far from that. This showed them, dang, she is real.\u201d\n\nSure, she would like to defeat UConn on Monday, she said, not for personal validation but because the Huskies stand as a roadblock to the Final Four. And for those on social media who suggest that South Carolina\u2019s national championship was something lesser because it did not include a victory over UConn, Wilson said, \u201cYou can\u2019t take my banner away from me. You can\u2019t take my ring away from me.\u201d\n\nAsked if defeating UConn on Monday would feel as satisfying as winning a national championship, Wilson laughed and said, \u201cA national championship is a pretty good feeling. I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s going to be the same. I probably won\u2019t cry as much.\u201d", "title": "A\u2019ja Wilson and South Carolina Seek a Title With No Asterisks", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "BMW said on Tuesday that the software that prompted the raids had been installed by mistake, and that the company had not intentionally tried to deceive regulators. None of the vehicle models at issue are in the United States, BMW said.\n\n\u201cIn the course of internal testing, the BMW Group realized that a correctly developed software module had been allocated in error to models for which it was not suited,\u201d the company said in a statement.\n\nBMW said it would recall about 11,400 cars containing the software to fix the problem, a minuscule number considering that Volkswagen has admitted to installing emissions-cheating software in 11 million vehicles around the world.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBMW has nonetheless been stained by the scandal. The company, joined by Volkswagen and Daimler, provided funding for experiments on monkeys that were intended to show that diesel exhaust is not as harmful as many scientists have said. The research caused a furor after The New York Times reported it in January.\n\nThe investigations of German carmakers are chipping away at the companies\u2019 reputations and draining resources that would preferably be spent on developing new products. Public hostility toward automakers is growing in Germany, as they find themselves being blamed for poor urban air quality caused by diesel exhaust.\n\nThis month, prosecutors in Braunschweig, Germany, conducted the latest in a series of raids at Volkswagen\u2019s headquarters in nearby Wolfsburg.\n\nThe authorities were seeking evidence on whether Volkswagen had made false claims about the carbon dioxide emissions of its vehicles, Klaus Ziehe, a spokesman for the Braunschweig state\u2019s attorney, said on Tuesday. The raids were first reported by Wirtschaftswoche, a German magazine.\n\nDaimler, based in Stuttgart, has disclosed that it is under investigation by German prosecutors and by the United States Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency. The authorities may conclude that Daimler vehicles sold in the United States were equipped with illegal emissions software, Daimler said in its 2017 annual report, which was published last month.\n\n\u201cDaimler could be subject to significant monetary penalties,\u201d its report said, adding that it could suffer \u201csignificant collateral damage including reputational harm.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe BMW vehicles being scrutinized are the 750d, a diesel model that is part of the top-of-the-line 7 Series, and the M550d, a diesel variant of the 5 Series line. BMW said it would begin recalling the vehicles to fix the software as soon as German regulators approved the appropriate repair.", "title": "BMW Offices Raided by Authorities in Emissions-Cheating Investigation", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "FRANKFURT \u2014 The German carmakers Daimler and BMW said on Wednesday that they would merge their car-sharing businesses as they try to compete better with Silicon Valley companies out to upend the traditional automotive industry.\n\nDaimler, the maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, and BMW said they would put their respective mobility services \u2014 an array of apps and services that provide transport options for people who may not own cars \u2014 into a joint venture in which they will own equal shares.\n\nThe alliance is a major departure for BMW and Daimler, longtime rivals for the affections of affluent car buyers. Along with Volkswagen\u2019s Audi division, the pair dominate the global market for luxury vehicles. Still, they are in danger of being overwhelmed by the superior financial firepower of new competitors from the tech world. Alphabet, Google\u2019s parent company, which has invested in autonomous car technology, has a stock market value 10 times Daimler\u2019s.\n\nIn addition to BMW\u2019s DriveNow and Daimler\u2019s Car2Go, which are like rental agencies but allow customers to book on short notice and use cars for brief periods, the agreement announced on Wednesday includes services that help customers hail taxis, find parking spots and charge electric vehicles.", "title": "BMW and Daimler, Once Rivals, Join Forces to Fend Off Silicon Valley", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Where does all this science get us? Bach\u2019s notations bear witness to a life of conservative Lutheran observance.\n\nWithin Calov\u2019s scripture verses, there are many small printing errors that would doubtless go undetected by even the most biblically literate reader. Yet time and again Bach has restored text that was far from clearly missing, or has changed perfectly plausible sounding, but in fact unattested, wording to the standard Lutheran rendering. None of these corrections stem from the list of errors printed in Calov\u2019s appendix.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome biblical scholars have concluded from this that Bach acted like an astute textual critic, poring over Calov\u2019s volumes and painstakingly comparing them, line by line, with other Lutheran Bibles. But there\u2019s a simpler and more likely scenario, fully grounded in conservative 18th-century social and religious practices.\n\nPicture the people of Bach\u2019s household on free evenings, gathered in their living room for the activity of reading aloud. The children take turns reciting from a family Bible for practice in reading and elocution, not to mention spiritual edification. The patriarch follows along in his magnificent Study Bible, in part to make sure there\u2019s no passage-skipping from the lectors, and in part to allow him to reach for his inkwell whenever he spots, compared with what he\u2019s just heard, an error in Calov\u2019s scriptural verses.\n\nTellingly, in something akin to what linguists call a mondegreen, Bach at several passages apparently misconstrued what the children \u2014 in this reconstruction of the scene \u2014 had said, and emended a scriptural verse\u2019s legitimate Lutheran rendering to a similar-sounding but unattested wording. At Isaiah 16:8, Luther\u2019s text reads: \u201cits vine-branches are scattered, and over the sea.\u201d Bach caught sight of Calov\u2019s obvious typographical error \u201cFesser,\u201d but he evidently misheard a lector\u2019s utterance of the correct wording, and thus emended Luther\u2019s intended \u201cFeser\u201d (vine-branches) to the biblically unattested \u201cF\u00e4\u00dfer\u201d (wine-casks).\n\nThe Calov volumes also provide insight into Bach\u2019s professional and personal concerns, showing that he understood himself less as a modern artist than as a preacher who was following his religious vocation. An annotation in Latin that the Crocker Laboratory physicists have filed under \u201cdefinite Bach entries\u201d makes for especially poignant reading, as it takes note of manifold passages in the Bible\u2019s Solomonic literature speaking of how to find godly solace in a world that is hostile to people faithfully pursuing their divine callings. Sundry administrative records indicate that Bach often fell into trouble over philosophical differences with his employers about the place of music in worship and in education.\n\nOnly a handful of Bach\u2019s entries in Calov concern music, and these have received the most extensive \u2014 indeed, typically the only \u2014 attention from biographers. Leading writers have striven to explain these marginalia as progressive. In truth, all of them straightforwardly reflect conservative Lutheran thinking. What they share as well is a premodern interpretive approach called \u201ctypology,\u201d whereby events and principles in the era of ancient Israel act as \u201ctypes\u201d or \u201cshadows\u201d for their correlated \u201cantitypes\u201d or \u201csubstances\u201d in the era of Christianity. Typology was looked upon less as a scholarly path to intellectual understanding than as a doctrinal path to spiritual comfort.\n\nPhoto\n\nCiting one of Bach\u2019s annotations on music as key progressivist testimony, John Eliot Gardiner, in his 2013 biography \u201cBach: Music in the Castle of Heaven,\u201d wrote: \u201cBach understood that the more perfectly a composition is realized, both conceptually and through performance, the more God is immanent in the music. \u2018NB,\u2019 he wrote in the margin of his copy of Abraham Calov\u2019s Bible commentary, \u2018Where there is devotional music, God with his grace is always present.\u2019 This strikes me as a tenet that many of us as musicians automatically hold and aspire to whenever we meet to play music, regardless of whatever \u2018God\u2019 we happen to believe in.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat a lovely, modern idea! Alas, no aspect of it could possibly have been part of Bach\u2019s understanding.\n\nLutherans like Bach certainly would have condemned as a grievous sin of idolatry any notion that the essence of a piece of music is, or turns into, the essence of God. And Bach\u2019s somewhat cryptic note is not even about the less heretical notion of God\u2019s possibly just \u201cdwelling\u201d within music, either. Its language plainly echoes more particularized orthodox Lutheran observations about God and music that were laid out in Johann Gerhard\u2019s \u201cSchool of Piety\u201d (1623), one of many books of practical theology listed in Bach\u2019s estate inventory.\n\nThus the impetus behind Bach\u2019s remark was not progressivist but doctrinal. The Old Testament text Bach commented on presents the \u201cshadow\u201d: At the sound of the priestly music, the \u201cGlory of the Lord\u201d inhabited the Jerusalem Temple. Bach\u2019s marginal note points to the orthodox Lutheran understanding of the \u201csubstance\u201d: At a rendering of devout music, the \u201cGrace-Presence\u201d of God will always inhabit the hearts of Christian believers, whose bodies, according to the New Testament, are \u201ca temple of the Holy Spirit.\u201d Bach had worked with these very tenets earlier in his career, when he composed glorious musical settings of them in his Cantata No. 172, \u201cRing Out, Ye Songs.\u201d\n\nBeside another significant passage in Calov, Bach wrote, \u201cA splendid demonstration [\u2018Beweis\u2019] that music has been mandated by God\u2019s spirit.\u201d Christoph Wolff\u2019s magisterial biography, \u201cJohann Sebastian Bach: The Learned Musician\u201d (2000), identifies Bach\u2019s use of \u201cBeweis\u201d here as an approving nod toward the term\u2019s centrality in the progressive methodology of scientific empiricism, a methodology that was held already during Bach\u2019s lifetime to be applicable also to theological principles.\n\nBut the noun \u201cBeweis\u201d was also used frequently, from the 16th through 18th centuries, in the same conservative way it\u2019s used in Bach\u2019s note: for the \u201cdemonstration\u201d of theological principles through study of biblical revelation alone. Bach\u2019s music likewise employs the word \u201cBeweis\u201d in its conventional pre\u2011Enlightenment, nonscientific sense. A recitative in his \u201cChristmas Oratorio\u201d proclaims that a believer\u2019s heart should safeguard the biblical account of the miracle of Christ\u2019s birth \u201cas a sure demonstration [\u2018Beweis\u2019]\u201d of salvation.\n\nBach was contractually answerable for choosing the liturgical poetry he set to music, and modern-day critics, in a bit of wishful thinking, often proclaim that his theologically conservative choices were designed simply to please his employers. But on this biographical question, the Calov volumes turn out to be acutely instructive. The sentiments expressed in Bach\u2019s vocal music are continually paralleled in his Calov notations. Most of his vocal music was composed from the 1710s to 1730s, whereas his Calov notations were entered in the 1730s and 1740s. In view of the fact that almost all the private notations come well after the public compositions, Bach obviously subscribed to the sentiments expressed in his vocal music.\n\nBoth Bach\u2019s music and his Calov notations put powerful stress upon: (1) contempt for human reason, along with the exalting of biblical revelation as the proper arbiter of truth; (2) disparagement of notions of human autonomy and achievement, along with the exalting of dependence on God, including for one\u2019s position in the social hierarchy; (3) contempt \u2014 explicit or implicit \u2014 for Judaism, Catholicism and Islam, along with the exalting of orthodox Lutheranism; (4) disdain for foreigners, along with the exalting of German faithfulness and goodness; and (5) the emphatic exalting of monarchical power, as authorized not by the people but by God. Nowhere in Bach\u2019s music or Calov notations are these sentiments contradicted.\n\nIn short, Bach, in his unswerving religious conservatism, was living and working very much at odds with the progressivist currents of his day, and ours. While we\u2019re arguably free to make use of him and his music in whatever new ways we find fitting, we ought also to be on the ethical alert for casting Bach in our own image.", "title": "Bach Was Far More Religious Than You Might Think", "authors": ["Michael Marissen"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "I yelled, \u201cAre you O.K.?\u201d but you didn\u2019t glance backward. You just kept running.\n\nI read it as a testament to the fear of social embarrassment over concern for your own welfare. That I can understand. But are you O.K.?\n\nI think that because it was a temporary wooden wall, it would have yielded a little. It could have been a lot worse. You got lucky.\n\nI was on my way to a talk by Rutger Bregman, an author who was visiting the university and who offers an optimistic view of the future. I had hoped maybe you were on your way there, too, but you weren\u2019t.\n\nThe audience was mostly baby boomers.\n\nI would guess you are student in your 20s and have little interest in such talks, which is ironic as the future he talks of belongs more to you than them. I think you would have appreciated it, though.\n\nOne of the points he made is that most people are actually pretty nice. People care about strangers and want to help when they can. So if you run into a wall, most people\u2019s immediate reaction will not be, \u201cOh, that was funny,\u201d but \u201cAre you O.K.?\u201d", "title": "Back in My Day ...", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "SATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 If we were in a David Attenborough special right now he would be whispering excitedly to us about the rare, wily Saturday-themed crossword, something many have heard about but never seen in its natural environment. Hopefully, the next scene is not of us being dragged up a path to this puzzle\u2019s well-hidden lair.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nWe\u2019re getting this grid today because it was too hard for a Thursday, I imagine. This is one of the few puzzles I\u2019ve done where the notion that someone could sit down and fill out the grid out cleanly is pretty amazing \u2014 I guess if you were so big-picture perspicacious that you established the trick that affects half the answers you might have been able to do it, but most of us toss an answer or two onto a grid when getting started. But, first things first.\n\nThere are technically two Manhattan-centric theme entries \u2014 19A and 52A.\n\nIf you aren\u2019t familiar with our fair isle, 19A refers to the interesting fact that about nine out of 10 cross streets \u2014 those streets running east to west, and west to east \u2014 are ONE WAY STREETS. Most of the time they alternate as they stack up the height of the borough, forming a zigzag, the widest possible slalom course from top to bottom (or bottom to top). Just like everything else in Manhattan there are plenty of complications, including streets that split in two, end unexpectedly or funnel you and your car into irreversible, borough-exiting bridge and tunnel maneuvers. But the idea of running back and forth is key to solving this puzzle.\n\nWhat about avenues, the roads that run up and down the borough, from Battery Park to Inwood? Well, these tend to be wider and mainly commercial strips; but a fair number of these are also one-way. When you really look at our traffic setup it\u2019s sort of amazing people get anywhere in a vehicle, above ground, any faster than walking.", "title": "Back on the Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWill I be the oldest person here?\u201d I asked the chairman of the nonfiction writing program at Columbia University, shortly after I was accepted. He laughed and said no. There were two or three older, but not by much.\n\n\u201cIt takes a lifetime to make a writer,\u201d he continued.\n\nAnd I\u2019ve had the lifetime.\n\nI was 64 when I entered graduate school. I had just left the work force \u2014 not retired, just tired. Tired of hitting the glass ceiling and of policies that failed to protect employees from abuse. As disenchantment with my job grew, writing became a healthy distraction.\n\nI applied to Columbia with no expectation of acceptance and no idea how to pay for it. My husband and I had just finished paying for our kids\u2019 education and we didn\u2019t have enough for retirement. But then one snowy February evening, the head of the writing program called as I stirred a pot of soup, and said, \u201cYou\u2019re in, and there will be a scholarship.\u201d I dropped my wooden spoon.\n\nSure, I\u2019d written copy at ad agencies for 20 years, started a memoir and taken some online classes. But did that make me a writer? And the Ivy League part scared me. I imagined I wasn\u2019t smart enough. But I also realized I had some things to say.", "title": "Opinion | Back to School, at 64", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "This drives premiums up, making insurance still less attractive to the healthiest people. That, in turn, causes many to drop out, producing the fabled \u201cdeath spiral\u201d in which only the least healthy people remain insured. But at that point, private health insurance may no longer be viable, because annual treatment costs for serious illnesses often exceed several hundred thousand dollars.\n\nMost nations have solved this problem by adopting universal coverage financed by taxes. The United States probably would have followed this approach except for a historical anomaly during World War II. Fearing runaway inflation in tight labor markets, the American government imposed a cap on wages.\n\nBut the cap didn\u2019t apply to fringe benefits, which employers quickly exploited as a recruiting tool. Employer health plans proved particularly attractive, since their cost was a deductible expense and they were not taxed. Before the war started, only 9 percent of workers had employer-provided insurance, but 63 percent had it by 1953.\n\nTo be eligible for favorable tax treatment, companies were required to make their plans available to all employees, which mitigated the adverse-selection problem. People would lose insurance if they lost their jobs, which inhibited labor mobility, but since employment relationships were relatively durable in the postwar years, this arrangement worked well enough.\n\nBut after peaking at almost 70 percent in the 1990s, employer coverage began declining in the face of stagnating wages and rising insurance costs. By 2010, only 56 percent of the nonelderly American population still had workplace health plans.\n\nEven so, because more than 100 million Americans still had such plans and were reasonably satisfied with them, the Obama administration opted to build health reform atop the existing system. In addition to allowing people to keep their existing employer coverage, Obamacare expanded eligibility for Medicaid and established exchanges in which people without employer plans could buy insurance.\n\nAt the outset, Obamacare had three central features:\n\n\u2022 Insurers could not charge higher prices to people with pre-existing conditions.\n\n\u2022 Those without coverage had to pay a penalty to the government (the \u201cmandate\u201d).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Low-income people would be eligible for subsidies.\n\nThe first two provisions were necessary to prevent the death spiral, and government couldn\u2019t mandate insurance purchases without adding subsidies for the poor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDespite a bumpy rollout and some frustrations over shrinking choices and rising prices at health care exchanges, Obamacare was working remarkably well by most important metrics. Program costs were much lower than expected, and the uninsured rate among nonelderly Americans fell sharply \u2014 from 18.2 percent in 2010 to only 10.3 percent in 2018.\n\nThis progress is now imperiled.\n\nThe mandate \u2014 by far the program\u2019s least popular provision \u2014 was repealed as part of tax legislation passed in December 2017. And because economists predict that its absence will slowly rekindle the insurance death spiral, we\u2019re forced back to the policy drawing board.\n\nThe most common response has been to call for a variant of the single-payer systems employed by most other countries, which promise dramatic reductions in health costs.\n\nThe United States spends far more on health care than any other nation, yet gets worse outcomes on most measures. In part this is because administrative and marketing expenses are much lower under single-payer plans. But by far the most important source of savings is that governments are able to negotiate much more favorable terms with service providers. Virtually every procedure, test, and drug costs substantially more here than elsewhere.\n\nAn American hospital stay, for example, costs more than twelve times as much as one in the Netherlands. The single-payer approach also sidesteps the thorny mandate objection by covering everyone out of tax revenue.\n\nA June 2017 poll showed that 60 percent of Americans said the government should provide universal coverage, and support for single-payer insurance rose more than one-third since 2014.\n\nYet a move to a single-payer system faces the same hurdle that shaped Obamacare: Millions of Americans would resist any attempt to take their employer-provided plans away. And although single-payer health care would be far less costly overall, it would be paid for by taxes \u2014 the most visible form of sacrifice \u2014 rather than by the implicit levies that underwrite employer coverage.\n\nFrom a purely economic standpoint, the increased tax burden is irrelevant. It\u2019s a truism that making the economic pie larger necessarily makes it possible for everyone to get a larger slice than before. And because the gains from single-payer insurance would be so large, there must be ways to make everyone come out ahead, even in the short run.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Yale political scientist Jacob Hacker, for example, has proposed the introduction of Medicare Part E (Medicare for Everyone), which would allow anyone to buy into Medicare, regardless of age. The program\u2019s budget would be supported in part by levies on employers that don\u2019t offer insurance.\n\nThe cost savings inherent in this form of single-payer coverage would lead more and more firms to abandon their current plans voluntarily. Gradually, the age for standard Medicare eligibility also would fall until the entire population was covered by it. The Center for American Progress has now introduced a similar proposal.\n\nIt\u2019s critical to realize that there are attractive paths forward. In no other wealthy country do we see people organize bake sales to help pay for a neighbor\u2019s cancer care. We can avoid this national embarrassment without requiring painful sacrifices from anyone.", "title": "Back to the Health Policy Drawing Board", "authors": ["Robert H. Frank", "Economic View"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJAKARTA, Indonesia \u2014 When the head of a prominent Islamic university in Indonesia banned the face-concealing niqab headdress on campus this month, calling it out of step with the country\u2019s true culture, it seemed a significant pushback against the conservative drift of Islam.\n\nPerhaps more significant is that the ban lasted just a week.\n\nA string of protests broke out, including by former members of an Islamic group banned by the Indonesian government last year for spreading a Saudi-influenced brand of extremism. And at the start of last week, the rector\u2019s office at the university, the Sunan Kalijaga State Islamic University in the Central Java city of Yogyakarta, confirmed that the niqab ban had been rescinded. No reason was given.\n\nThe issue has again pitted conservative Islamic groups here, which insist it is a woman\u2019s right to publicly wear the niqab \u2014 a full head covering with only eye slits, usually accompanied by a shoulder-to-toe gown \u2014 against advocates who are concerned that more extreme strains of Islam have become ascendant.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s good that there\u2019s a debate on the niqab,\u201d said Julia Suryakusuma, a prominent Indonesian author and social commentator. \u201cBut it\u2019s scary that the debate is happening at all, because usually the more progressive view buckles under to the conservatives.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndonesia is the world\u2019s most populous Muslim-majority country. But it is not an Islamic state, and it has influential Christian, Hindu and Buddhist minorities. While many Muslim women among the country\u2019s 260 million people wear hijabs \u2014 the traditional Islamic head scarf that hides the hair and neck \u2014 many others do not.", "title": "Ban on Face Veils at Indonesian University Lasted Just a Week", "authors": ["Joe Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter a brief foray into Brooklyn, the annual Bang on a Can Marathon is moving back to downtown Manhattan, where it has resided for much of its 30-year run.\n\nThe free concert will take place at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center on Washington Square Park on May 13 from noon to 10 p.m. The Bang on a Can founders, Michael Gordon, David Lang, and Julia Wolfe, will present their own compositions and serve as M.C.\u2019s; other performers include Terry Riley and Stephin Merritt of the Magnetic Fields.\n\nThe event took place at the Brooklyn Museum last year after losing its longtime home at Brookfield Place in Lower Manhattan. Now it will move to just a few blocks north of where the first marathon took place in 1987, at the now-defunct gallery Exit Art.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re excited to come back to the roots,\u201d Ms. Wolfe said in a phone interview.\n\nIn their new venue, the organizers will aim to strike a balance between encouraging audience mobility while keeping the focus on the music. The large, open space at the Brooklyn Museum encouraged more audience movement and socialization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe space was beautiful, but it was tough to program really delicate pieces,\u201d Ms. Wolfe said. \u201cThe invitation to go back into a place where we can really have that sound separation \u2014 it seemed like a natural fit.\u201d\n\nThe Bang on a Can All-Stars and Mr. Riley will perform his \u201cAutodreamographical Tales,\u201d inspired by a dream diary Mr. Riley kept in 1987; the piece flows in and out of Indian raga, New Age music and bluesy asides. The All-Stars will also perform Frederic Rzewski\u2019s \u201cComing Together,\u201d about the Attica prison riots.", "title": "Bang on a Can Marathon Returns to Downtown Manhattan", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "In Sri Lanka, the time to act was months, if not years, earlier, engaging with all types of media. Facebook and internet penetration in the country is still around 30 percent. It\u2019s just as likely that this violence was organized not only through Facebook and WhatsApp but also through phone calls and words exchanged across a neighbor\u2019s fence. Facebook and WhatsApp are growing fast in Sri Lanka, but they are only a small part of an extremely polarized media world dominated by television and radio. Anti-minority hate speech, particularly against the Tamil minority, has been part of the Sri Lankan political landscape for decades. Now, it\u2019s Muslims, not just Tamils, who have become the target.\n\nWe have been conducting surveys and qualitative research on how people use mobile phones and the internet around the region for more than a decade. We recently focused on Myanmar to understand better how hate speech spreads. Social media use has grown at a stunning rate in Myanmar since 2014, at the same time that anti-Muslim violence linked to Buddhist chauvinist groups has escalated.\n\nWe noticed that people usually first encountered false stories in \u201caffinity circles\u201d \u2014 messages sent through Facebook or WhatsApp groups. Within those circles, the messages appear as a communication from a trusted friend or relative. Because many people belong to multiple affinity circles, the hate-speech messages would jump from one circle to another, in each case appearing as from a trusted person.\n\nIn other words, the human factor, not the platform alone, is important. This pattern is consistent with recent research about how falsehoods spread. A study by Sinan Aral at MIT analyzing about 126,000 Twitter \u201ccascades\u201d showed that false stories spread faster and further than true ones, perhaps because of their novelty, and that human beings \u2014 people passing along messages to their friends \u2014 were more important than bots.\n\nWhen mob-related violence does occur, the government relies on tactics developed during the colonial era: preventing the formation of mobs, usually through curfews, which stop people from gathering in public spaces. The same principle gives Sri Lanka\u2019s telecommunications minister the power to prohibit the transmission or reception of entire categories of messages in emergencies or \u201cin the interest of public safety and tranquillity.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Banning Social Media Won\u2019t Stop Hate Speech", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Similarly bizarre false claims are made by non-American far-right politicians, who also regularly engage in anti-Semitic innuendo. There is a natural next step to using innuendo and the manufacturing of reasons to justify racism and xenophobia \u2014 namely to drop the facade altogether. Bannon is urging the adoption of an irrational bias against racial minorities, immigrants and foreigners, one that does not require reasons, even bad ones, to support it. And he recommends presenting such irrationality as virtuous.\n\nAccepting Bannon\u2019s advice requires rejecting empathy for already embattled groups. Some might view that as acceptable, preferring to weigh only statistical arguments in deciding what to do about, for example, immigration policy. But taking Bannon\u2019s advice also requires rejecting any recognizable practice of giving plausible reasons for holding a view or position. To proudly identify as a xenophobe is to identify as someone who is not interested in argument. It is to be irrationally fearful of foreigners, and proudly so. It means not masking one\u2019s irrationality even from oneself.\n\nBannon\u2019s rhetorical move of transforming vices based on irrational prejudice into virtues is not without historical precedent. Hitler devotes the second chapter of \u201cMein Kampf\u201d to explaining how his time in Vienna as a young man transformed him into a \u201cfanatical anti-Semite.\u201d To be fanatical is, by definition, to be irrational. To be an anti-Semite is to have irrational prejudice against Jews. Hitler presents his transformation into a fanatical anti-Semite positively. It is, in Hitler\u2019s rhetoric, not only a good thing to harbor irrational hatred of Jewish people. One should do so fanatically. Such fanatical irrationality is, in Hitler\u2019s rhetoric, virtuous.\n\nOf course, comparing rhetoric and policies are two different things. No recent far-right movement in Europe or the United States has enacted the sort of genocidal policies that the Nazis did, and no such comparison is intended. But history has shown that the sort of subversion of language that Bannon has engaged in is often deeply intertwined with what a government will do, and what its people will allow. Bannon\u2019s own cheer to the National Front members \u2014 \u201cThe tide of history is with us and it will compel us to victory after victory after victory\u201d \u2014 shows clearly enough that he does not mean his efforts to end in mere speech.\n\nIn the 20th-century scholar Victor Klemperer\u2019s \u201cLanguage of the Third Reich\u201d there is a chapter titled \u201cFanatical.\u201d In it, Klemperer reports that the Nazis regularly inverted the meanings of ordinary words, in just the way that Bannon recommends: by turning vices or negative ideals into virtues. (This point is well-known enough to have been the basis of a famous comedy sketch, \u201cAre we the baddies?\u201d) To be sure, it was not only the Nazis who chose to invert the valence of words that were negative because of their connection with unthinking irrationality; some American slavery abolitionists called their own beliefs in the moral wrongness of slavery fanatical. But it was the Nazis who most thoroughly and efficiently turned the ungrounded hatred and fear of minority groups into an explicit virtue.", "title": "Opinion | Bannon\u2019s Deviant \u2018Badge of Honor\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe latest is Malibu, Calif. Before that came Seattle; Davis and San Luis Obispo, Calif.; and Miami Beach and Fort Myers, Fla.\n\nThey\u2019re all cities that have banned or limited the use of plastic straws in restaurants. Straws, routinely placed in glasses of water or soda, represent a small percentage of the plastic that\u2019s produced and consumed but often end up on beaches and in oceans.\n\nAdvocates said laws aimed at cutting back on the use of plastic straws can help spur more significant behavioral changes.\n\n\u201cI think a lot of people feel overwhelmed by the magnitude of the plastic problem,\u201d said Diana Lofflin, the founder of StrawFree.org, an activist organization based in San Diego. \u201cGiving up plastic straws is a small step, and an easy thing for people to get started on. From there, we can move on to larger projects.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe City Council in Malibu voted on Monday to bar restaurants from giving out plastic straws, utensils and stirrers. Similar measures are being considered in other coastal cities, including Berkeley, Calif. A bevy of restaurants across the country have also voluntarily stopped providing straws.", "title": "Bans on Plastic Straws in Restaurants Expand to More Cities", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNow, it\u2019s as though we\u2019re perceived, and perceive ourselves, as only a subset of U.S. fiction, lost in its margins and eventually, this dilution of the community of writers plays out in the writing,\u201d she added.\n\nFears of American hegemony have surrounded the award since the decision was made. They grew as American authors began to dominate the shortlists and longlists, and as two consecutive prizes were awarded to Americans \u2014 Paul Beatty in 2016 for \u201cThe Sellout\u201d and George Saunders in 2017 for \u201cLincoln in the Bardo.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Saunders won the prize in October, Lola Young, the chair of judges, dismissed the notion that Americans had colonized Britain\u2019s award, saying: \u201cWe don\u2019t look at the nationality of the writer. We\u2019re solely concerned with the book, with what that book is telling us.\u201d\n\nNeither Mr. Beatty nor Mr. Saunders wished to weigh in on the debate, and the academy did not release the names of the members who voted on the matter. A spokeswoman for Ms. Atwood said by email that the author had not been aware of the academy\u2019s campaign.\n\nBut some American publishers have said that changing the prize\u2019s criteria had taken away an opportunity to learn about new books that they would not have normally come across. Thirty of Britain\u2019s leading publishers signed a letter that was meant to privately urge the Man Booker organizers to reverse the change or risk a \u201chomogenized literary future.\u201d\n\nThe signatories highlighted the fact that last year\u2019s Man Booker shortlist consisted of three Americans, two Britons and one Anglo-Pakistani writer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe shortlist in 2013, the last year before Americans became eligible, included authors from Britain, Canada, India, Ireland, New Zealand and Zimbabwe.\n\nThe Booker Foundation responded to the publishers\u2019 letter by saying that expanded eligibility rules were intended to allow writers of any nationality, regardless of geography, and not specifically to include Americans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe trustees believe that this mission cannot be constrained or compromised by national boundaries,\u201d the Booker Foundation said in a statement.\n\nBut with the 2018 Man Booker award approaching (the longlist will be announced in July, and the prize awarded in October), the Rathbones Folio Academy took up the battle, canvassing its 300 members this month. Ninety-nine percent of the members who have responded to the question said that the Booker prize should change its rules again, restoring the former eligibility criteria.\n\nOther writers argued that the prize should not be opened to American writers until American awards, such as the Pulitzer and National Book Awards, were opened to British writers.\n\nThe Folio group oversees its own literary prize, a rival to the Man Booker, established after the 2011 Man Booker chairwoman of judges, Stella Rimington, stressed \u201creadability\u201d and books that \u201czip along,\u201d according to The Guardian. The Folio group notably awarded its prize to Mr. Saunders before he won the Man Booker.\n\nNot all British writers and critics oppose the Booker\u2019s expanded criteria, however.\n\n\u201cIt seems to be that the Commonwealth isn\u2019t a particularly sensible remit for a book prize that is purporting to be for the English language novel,\u201d said Sam Leith, a Rathbone Folio Academy member who judged the Man Booker Prize in 2015. \u201cThe English language itself is a much more obvious constituency for it.\u201d\n\nMr. Leith said by telephone that he understood why some authors were upset about the decision, but added that it was a form of \u201ccultural cringe\u201d to say that British writers can\u2019t compete with American authors.\n\n\u201cAny judging panel is vulnerable to the \u2018names\u2019 of authors \u2014 the Booker isn\u2019t judged blind,\u201d Mr. Leith added. \u201cBut most of the panels that they select are relatively serious critics who will be able to look at a novel on its merits rather than on the merits of its author.\u201d\n\nAs for Mr. Saunders, reached by email, he wrote, \u201cIt would be better sportsmanship to stay on the sidelines about this.\u201d", "title": "Bar Americans From Man Booker Prize, Fed-Up British Authors Urge", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Barbara Alston, a founding member of the 1960s girl group the Crystals, who sang lead on the band\u2019s first two hits, \u201cThere\u2019s No Other Like My Baby\u201d and \u201cUptown,\u201d died on Feb. 16 in Charlotte, N.C. She was 74.\n\nThe cause was complications of the flu, her daughter Donielle Prophete said.\n\nMs. Alston was a choir-trained teenager in Brooklyn when she formed the Crystals with her high school friends Mary Thomas, Dolores Kenniebrew (who is known as Dee Dee), Myrna Giraud and Patsy Wright. Their harmonious songs, often about young romance, were like those of many other popular all-female R&B vocal groups in the early 1960s, like the Shirelles and the Ronettes.\n\nThe producer Phil Spector signed the Crystals in 1961, and they became an early example of his dense, layered \u201cwall of sound\u201d production style. Ms. Alston\u2019s clear, bright voice made her a natural lead for the wistful \u201cThere\u2019s No Other Like My Baby,\u201d written by Mr. Spector and Leroy Bates. It reached No. 20 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1961.", "title": "Barbara Alston, Who Sang With the Crystals, Dies at 74", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Barbara Lekberg, a sculptor who infused her welded-metal works with motion and grace in a career that spanned more than 60 years, died on Feb. 14 at a nursing home in the Bronx. She was 92.\n\nHer friend Toni Danilevsky confirmed the death. She said Ms. Lekberg had Alzheimer\u2019s disease.\n\nWhere some artists work with paint brush and palette, Ms. Lekberg often wielded a blowtorch, welding steel, bronze and other materials into works featuring dancers, trees, contemplative figures and more. Moving to New York from the Midwest in the late 1940s, she began studying and working at the Clay Club, soon to become the Sculpture Center, making a strong impression in shows there and elsewhere.\n\n\u201cBarbara Lekberg is an out-and-out romantic whose welded figures are made from thin, flowing sheets of steel, here and there adorned with color in vitreous enamel,\u201d Stuart Preston wrote in The New York Times in 1955, reviewing a Sculpture Center exhibition.\n\n\u201cShe creates figures,\u201d he went on, \u201cwhose high emotional temperature might have been thought inexpressible in solid sculpture but which find an entirely suitable vehicle in this flexible medium.\u201d", "title": "Barbara Lekberg, Artist With a Blowtorch, Dies at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Barbara Lewalski, a renowned Renaissance scholar and expert on the poet John Milton who became the first woman to be granted tenured and endowed professorships in the English departments of Brown and Harvard Universities, died on March 2 in Providence, R.I. She was 87.\n\nHer son, David Lewalski, her only immediate survivor, said she had a heart attack at her home in Providence and died in a hospital. She had recently learned that she had congestive heart failure, he said.\n\nProfessor Lewalski was an accomplished author, teacher, mentor to doctoral students and an enterprising researcher who was named an honored scholar by the Milton Society of America when she was 46. In 2016 she received a lifetime achievement award from the Renaissance Society of America.\n\n\u201cProfessor Lewalski was without a doubt the foremost scholar of English Renaissance Studies in America and England, setting the standard for several generations of scholars,\u201d Diana Trevino Benet, a past president of both the John Milton Society of American and the John Donne Society of America, wrote in an email.", "title": "Barbara Lewalski, 87, Milton Scholar and Barrier Breaker, Is Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "To Tuchman, folly begins with the most fundamental of things: an outsize and self-destructive will to power. Both the governors and the governed can overreach, convinced of their own rectitude and righteousness. \u201cChief among the forces affecting political folly is lust for power, named by Tacitus as \u2018the most flagrant of all the passions,\u2019\u201d Tuchman wrote. \u201cBecause it can only be satisfied by power over others, government is its favorite field of exercise,\u201d or what she calls the \u201cparamount area of folly because it is there that men seek power over others \u2014 only to lose it over themselves.\u201d In this light, President Trump and his alt-right coterie are not something new under the sun but another chapter in the oldest of human dramas: the tension between appetite and the common good, between ambition and common sense.\n\nThere is a lesson here not only for the president but for the people \u2014 particularly the people who chose to support him in 2016 and who stand with him now, apparently come what may. \u201cPersistence in error is the problem,\u201d Tuchman wrote. One of the more troubling features of popular political life is blind tribal loyalty \u2014 the refusal to acknowledge that your chief or your kind could be wrong. A perennial issue, this reflexive defensiveness is especially pronounced at the moment. But the historically literate voter, like a historically literate decision maker, need not be captive to previously held opinions at all times and at any cost. \u201cThere is,\u201d Tuchman wrote, \u201calways freedom of choice to change or desist from a counterproductive course if the policy-maker\u201d \u2014 or, in my view, the voter \u2014 \u201chas the moral courage to exercise it. He is not a fated creature blown by the whims of Homeric gods. Yet to recognize error, to cut losses, to alter course, is the most repugnant option in government.\u201d And in the mind and heart of a fervent voter who was determined to send a message to Washington that business as usual was not working. The question now, more than a year into business as unusual, is whether those who supported the populist insurgency of 2016 will honestly assess its effectiveness in 2018 and in 2020. \u201cWooden-headedness\u201d in the Oval Office, alas, begins in the voting booth.\n\nHow do we stop marches of folly? Tuchman was thoughtful on the question, realizing that history was not a panacea. \u201cWhole philosophies have evolved over the question whether the human species is predominately good or evil,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI only know that it is mixed, that you cannot separate good from bad, that wisdom, courage and benevolence exist alongside knavery, greed and stupidity; heroism and fortitude alongside vainglory, cruelty and corruption.\u201d\n\nThat observation appeared in a 1981 collection of her essays titled \u201cPracticing History.\u201d Perhaps her least known work, it is engaging and wise, and in it she took a proportionate view of the human condition. \u201cAmid a mass of worldwide troubles and a poor record for the 20th century,\u201d Tuchman wrote, \u201cwe see our species \u2014 with cause \u2014 as functioning very badly, as blunderers when not knaves, as violent, ignoble, corrupt, inept, incapable of mastering the forces that threaten us, weakly subject to our worst instincts; in short, decadent.\u201d\n\nIt was, she argued, an easy, if unhappy, case to make at the time. (As it is now.) \u201cA century that took shape in the disillusion which followed the enormous effort and hopes of World War I,\u201d Tuchman wrote, \u201cthat saw revolution in Russia congeal into the same tyranny it overthrew, saw a supposedly civilized nation revert under the Nazis into organized and unparalleled savagery, saw the craven appeasement by the democracies, is understandably marked by suspicion of human nature.\u201d", "title": "Barbara W. Tuchman, Folly and the Stream of History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "She was also a teacher and mentor to writers, contributed to magazines and journals, and was a frequent reviewer of children\u2019s literature for The New York Times Book Review. In addition, she founded a small press.\n\nMs. Wersba has written that she was the last surviving member of her family. Her partner of many years, Zue Sharkey, died in 1994.\n\nBarbara Wersba was born on Aug. 19, 1932, in Chicago to Robert Wersba and the former Lucy Jo Quarles. The family moved to California when Barbara was small.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Wersba once wrote that although she remembered \u201cjoining the Girl Scouts, selling war bonds (for this was World War II), and spending every Saturday afternoon at the movies,\u201d she grew up in what she felt was \u201calmost total solitude.\u201d She dreamed of acting as an escape, and had her first role at a community theater where she had volunteered to take on tasks.\n\nHer parents\u2019 troubled marriage broke apart when she was 11, and she and her mother moved to New York City, where they lived in the theater district. Ms. Wersba, at 12, headed straight for the box office and bought a ticket for \u201cThe Glass Menagerie\u201d with Laurette Taylor, a performance that cemented her love for the theater.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a teenager, she studied acting at the Neighborhood Playhouse and took dance classes with Martha Graham.\n\nAfter graduating from Bard College in 1954, where she immersed herself in dramatic arts, she returned to the city, living in an East Village tenement with other performers, studying at the Paul Mann Actors Workshop and getting parts where she could.\n\nHer acting career ended and her writing career began when she contracted hepatitis in her 20s and was faced with a long convalescence. Her first few books, including \u201cThe Boy Who Loved the Sea\u201d (1961) and \u201cDo Tigers Ever Bite Kings?\u201d (1966), were for younger children.\n\nTo a question about why she wrote for children, she responded, \u201cIt is all the same life, it is all one, and the best children\u2019s writers know that they are writing for the child in the adult, and the adult in the child.\u201d\n\nHer breakthrough came in 1968 with \u201cThe Dream Watcher,\u201d about a dejected young nonconformist whose friendship with a quirky if less than truthful aged actress nurtures his sense of individualism.\n\n\u201cThis theme of older person helping younger person had been the underlying theme of my own life,\u201d Ms. Wersba wrote in an autobiographical entry in a Gale reference series on writers. \u201cUnable to relate to my parents, I had sought parent substitutes everywhere.\u201d\n\nOne older person she grew close to was the author Carson McCullers, the author of the novels \u201cThe Heart Is a Lonely Hunter\u201d and \u201cReflections in a Golden Eye,\u201d among other works. They met in 1966 when a friend asked if Ms. Wersba might be willing to read to an invalid.\n\n\u201cFor the next two years,\u201d she said, \u201cI visited Carson McCullers every day \u2014 read aloud to her, went shopping for her, ate meals with her, and loved her deeply. She was not easy to love, but before me always, in my mind, were her books. Her great books. Unable now to write physically, she dictated stories to me, phoned in the middle of the night with ideas.\u201d", "title": "Barbara Wersba, 85, Dies; Wrote Candid Books for Young Adults", "authors": ["Helen T. Verongos"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "She\u2019s a straight-haired Coton de Tulear, like most people want. My Sammie was curly haired and that\u2019s why my husband initially picked her out for me as an anniversary present \u2014 she was the odd one, different, just like I felt as a little girl. One of the reasons I chose cloning was because I couldn\u2019t find another curly-haired Coton.\n\nAnd then I got a call from the lab. Not only did the cloning process take, but it produced four puppies! Unfortunately the runt of the litter died before the puppies were old enough to be delivered to me.\n\nBut still, five dogs were too much for me to handle, as a person who was used to taking my dog everywhere with me, and who never had more than one dog at a time living in my house.\n\nMy manager\u2019s assistant really wanted Sadie, and I knew she would give her a good home. And then the 13-year-old daughter of my A&R man bonded with one of the clones, so I gave them that puppy. It was hard to part with both dogs, but since they were going to close friends I knew I could keep each dog in the family, so to speak, and I can still watch over them as they grow.\n\nSo now I have three puppies at home, Miss Fanny, Miss Violet and Miss Scarlett, and it\u2019s a bit overwhelming. But we love them so much. Each puppy is unique and has her own personality.", "title": "Barbra Streisand Explains: Why I Cloned My Dog", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Crimmins went from comic to activist in May 1992, when, during a performance at Stitches in Boston (another club Mr. Crimmins booked), he revealed that he had been raped as a child by a man who knew his babysitter. The Boston Globe called the admission \u201cperhaps the most highly charged and soul-baring monologue ever staged in one of the city\u2019s comedy clubs.\u201d\n\nHe later wrote about the subject for The Boston Phoenix.\n\nMr. Crimmins became alarmed when he went to research sexual abuse on the just-evolving internet and found that child pornographers were trading images and observations in the newly created chat rooms of AOL.\n\nBy 1995 he was expert enough in the subject that he testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee, calling AOL \u201cthe key link in a network of child-pornography traffickers\u201d that was growing rapidly. At the time, many of the senators had only a vague knowledge of the internet and its dangers.\n\n\u201cThe proliferation of child-pornography trafficking has created an anonymous pedophile superstore,\u201d he told them.\n\nInvestigators and AOL began cracking down on the abuses. Mr. Crimmins recently expressed some satisfaction with the role he had played in bringing the problem to light.", "title": "Barry Crimmins, Comic and Warrior Against Sex Abuse, Dies at 64", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "That is why Zlotnick has been unable to get the Yankees to reimburse him for his out-of-pocket medical expenses arising from the surgery to repair his injuries. Or, since an initial conversation with team president Randy Levine back in 2011, even to get them to return his phone calls.\n\nIt is why the family of the 2-year-old girl who suffered a broken nose, an orbital fracture and bleeding on the brain on Sept. 20 will face an uphill battle if they ever decide to sue the Yankees.\n\nAnd it is why, of all the thousands of spectators who suffer serious injuries from flying objects \u2014 a 2014 statistical analysis by Bloomberg News determined that approximately 1,750 fans per year are injured at major league games \u2014 only a handful have successfully sued a baseball team.\n\nIn 2010, the Georgia Court of Appeals allowed a man whose 6-year-old daughter\u2019s skull was fractured by a foul ball at Turner Field to sue the Atlanta Braves. The suit was settled in April.\n\nIn 2014, the Supreme Court of Missouri overturned the dismissal of a lawsuit against the Kansas City Royals by a spectator who was hit in the eye by a hot dog tossed into the stands by the team mascot. Such injury, the court ruled, \u201cis not one of the risks inherent in watching the Royals\u201d at Kauffman Stadium.\n\nThat same year, the Indiana Supreme Court refused to enforce the baseball rule in a woman\u2019s case against the South Shore RailCats, a minor-league team in Gary, Ind., saying it was \u201cnot convinced that any sport, even our national pastime, merits its own rule of liability.\u201d But the court dismissed her suit on the grounds that the club had satisfied its obligation to provide protective screening. (The Idaho Supreme Court also declined to use the baseball rule in a similar case in 2013.)\n\nIt is unclear whether those rulings are an indication of shifting legal attitudes toward the authority of the baseball rule.", "title": "Baseball Improved Fan Safety, but in Court, It\u2019s Teams That Are Protected", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine teleporting into a baseball video game. That, John Mozeliak said, is how he felt watching college hitters on a recent visit to a Division I program. All the data that might appear on the screen of a virtual game was available, in real time, during batting practice.\n\n\u201cThese kids are getting instant feedback,\u201d said Mozeliak, the St. Louis Cardinals\u2019 president for baseball operations. \u201cThey know how hard they\u2019re hitting it and they know what angle they\u2019re hitting it at. They know right away what happens if they make subtle changes. So, mentally, it\u2019s easier for these kids to just make the change, because they\u2019re used to that type of instant feedback.\u201d\n\nGive elite athletes an incentive to play a certain way \u2014 and the tools to show them how \u2014 and this is what you get: a convergence of talent and technology that has rapidly turned baseball into a test of power at the plate and on the mound. Hitters seek home runs and pitchers hunt strikeouts, and both statistics reached unprecedented levels last season: 6,105 homers and 40,104 strikeouts.\n\nBut as a new season dawns, many baseball people wonder where the game evolves from here. It is not a question of if things will change, they say, only when and how.", "title": "Baseball Loves the Long Ball. But for How Long?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Baseball\u2019s great power partnerships range from the foundational (Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig) to the quintessential (Willie Mays and Willie McCovey) to the clutch (Manny Ramirez and David Ortiz) and the chemically enhanced (Alex Rodriguez and Rafael Palmeiro).\n\nNow comes the supercharged slugging duo of Aaron Judge and Giancarlo Stanton of the Yankees. The union of the reigning National and American League home run leaders in one batting order has sent fans leafing back through record books for comparable tandems.\n\nYet one deserving pair often remains overlooked in these discussions. In the 1930s and \u201940s, catcher Josh Gibson and first baseman Buck Leonard anchored one of the most potent lineups in baseball history, but they did so for the Homestead Grays of the Negro leagues.\n\nThe disgrace of the time, that qualified stars were barred from the Major League Baseball because of their race, echoes now as a statistical frustration. While their white contemporaries enjoyed M.L.B.\u2019s tidy schedules and scrupulous statistics-keeping, the black players of the early 20th century made do with a mixture of official and unofficial contests across borders of league and nation. The numbers that resulted are slapdash and incomplete; in the case of Gibson and Leonard, the statistics obscure the truth as much as tell it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom 1937 to 1946, with an interruption at the start of the 1940s during Gibson\u2019s sojourn in the Mexican League, Gibson and Leonard batted third and fourth for the Grays, who played in Pittsburgh and Washington. To see them play was, by all accounts, to see the ideal heart of a batting order.", "title": "Baseball\u2019s Unappreciated Power Duo", "authors": ["Robert O Connell"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cJohn Bolton Is Right About the U.N.,\u201d by Bret Stephens (column, March 24):\n\nYes, the United Nations does have flaws. Nobody will dispute that. But there is another side to the story.\n\nThe United Nations, through the years, has helped bring peace to states like Mozambique, Guatemala, Angola, El Salvador, Serbia, Kosovo, Kuwait, South Africa, Colombia, Liberia, Cyprus, Cambodia, Bosnia, Macedonia, Croatia, Sierra Leone, Ivory Coast, Tajikistan, East Timor, Burundi, Haiti, Mali and Lebanon.\n\nThese are hardly negligible accomplishments.\n\nSTEPHEN SCHLESINGER, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is the author of \u201cAct of Creation,\u201d about the United Nations\u2019 founding in 1945.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nBret Stephens begins and ends his assault on the United Nations by referring to its failure to acknowledge its responsibility for bringing cholera to Haiti and its failure to compensate the more than 10,000 victims who died.", "title": "Opinion | Bash the U.N.? There\u2019s Another Side to the Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "It helps that Mr. Twist\u2019s idea of puppetry is expansive; it includes anything that can be manipulated. The puppets don\u2019t have to look like an animal or a person or anything else. \u201cPuppetry is an abstraction of the spark of life,\u201d he said. In this case, \u201cIt\u2019s just a piece of fabric, and because it\u2019s in the water and because someone with skill is giving little impulses to it and we\u2019re all looking at it, it looks like it\u2019s alive.\u201d\n\nOver lunch, Mr. Twist recounted how he came up with the inspiration for \u201cSymphonie Fantastique\u201d some 20 years ago. One day, he found a small cracked aquarium lying on the sidewalk in the West Village, discarded by its owner, and dragged it home. After patching it up, he filled it with water and started experimenting: \u201cI would take a hanger and attach a piece of fabric to it, and I could just watch it forever. It was hypnotizing.\u201d He did this with feathers, and shapes he cut out of plastic, and fringe and anything else that came to hand. Then he experimented with light.\n\nTo this aquatic ballet, he added Berlioz\u2019s \u201cSymphonie Fantastique,\u201d which he remembered from his parents\u2019 record collection. The 50-minute piece was a respectable length, and intensely theatrical. Berlioz conceived it in 1830, after falling almost dementedly in love \u2014 from afar \u2014 with an Irish actress he saw in a performance of \u201cHamlet\u201d at the Od\u00e9on theater in Paris. He poured his unrequited passion into the music, for which he wrote a loopy program note explaining its content.", "title": "Basil Twist\u2019s Fantastic Feathered World (With Tinsel and Berlioz)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The closed-door administrative hearings took place on Thursday. Chief Paul noted that while Officer Lake answered all of the questions put to him at his hearing, Officer Salamoni, on the advice of his lawyer, chose not to answer questions.\n\nThe chief\u2019s announcement was expected to bring a modicum of relief to activists and Mr. Sterling\u2019s family members, who have grown increasingly frustrated after the state and federal decisions.\n\nThe decision also came amid tension and protests over another police shooting in Sacramento. Stephon Clark, a 22-year-old unarmed black man, was shot at more than 20 times by the police in his grandmother\u2019s backyard on March 18. A private autopsy commissioned by Mr. Clark\u2019s family and released Friday found that eight bullets had struck him and that his death took three to 10 minutes, raising questions about why he did not receive medical care more quickly.\n\nPart of Mr. Sterling\u2019s fatal encounter with the Baton Rouge officers was captured in a widely seen cellphone video, in which the officers can be seen holding down Mr. Sterling. At one point, someone can be heard saying, \u201cHe\u2019s got a gun! Gun!\u201d\n\nThe two officers were responding to a call that a man who fit Mr. Sterling\u2019s description had been brandishing a gun.\n\nOne newly released video from the vantage of the convenience store shows Mr. Sterling standing by a folding table, where he appears to be doing business with two customers. Officer Lake approaches, and takes Mr. Sterling by the arm.\n\nFootage from Mr. Salamoni\u2019s video camera shows him approaching moments later.\n\nThe three men tussle as the officers try to bend Mr. Sterling over the hood of a car and as Officer Salamoni, using expletives, repeatedly threatens to shoot Mr. Sterling in the head.
