Officer Lake fires his Taser at Mr. Sterling, twice, and Officer Salamoni tackles him to the ground.\n\nGunshots ring out. As Mr. Sterling lies motionless on the parking lot, Officer Salamoni swears at him and searches his pockets, apparently for a firearm.", "title": "Baton Rouge Officer Is Fired in Alton Sterling Case as Police Release New Videos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "A pair of white police officers in Baton Rouge, La., will not be prosecuted by the state authorities in a fatal shooting of a black man there almost two years ago, the latest example of how rarely law enforcement officers are prosecuted for violence against suspects.\n\nThe Louisiana attorney general, Jeff Landry, announced the decision at a news conference on Tuesday, almost 11 months after the Justice Department declined to bring charges in the death of the man, Alton B. Sterling. Mr. Landry\u2019s decision was widely expected, in part because officers in numerous other cases across the country have been cleared of criminal liability for using deadly force against civilians in recent years.\n\nThe Baton Rouge officers were called to the Triple S Food Mart on July 5, 2016, to respond to a report that a black man had brandished a gun and threatened someone. The officers and the man, Mr. Sterling, 37, ended up in a confrontation that left Mr. Sterling dead, prompted large protests in Baton Rouge, the Louisiana capital, and broadened the national debate about law enforcement tactics and the influence of race on American policing. It also set off a retaliatory incident in which a man shot and killed two Baton Rouge police officers and a deputy sheriff.\n\nThe officers at the scene, Blane Salamoni and Howie Lake II, face administrative punishment, including dismissal, as well as a lawsuit from the man\u2019s family. On Tuesday, John S. McLindon, a lawyer for Mr. Salamoni, said he all but expected his client to be fired, and said he would likely appeal the decision. Mr. McLindon noted that the shooting had been determined to be justified by independent use of force experts, including two cited in the state and federal investigations.", "title": "Baton Rouge Officers Will Not Be Charged in Alton Sterling\u2019s Killing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was 7:30 in the morning. As usual, I was taking the train to Manhattan. It was a beautiful morning. The sun was shining, and the birds were singing. It was like a scene from a movie.\n\nAs always, my phone was in my hands, ready to be used. Not this time. I put it back in my purse and looked around: beautiful humans, so different and similar at the same time.\n\nFor the first time, I felt connected to the people on the train. I did not know their names, where they came from, what they did in their lives. They were just humans with souls.\n\nThe train stopped. I got off, and the beautiful souls moved away.", "title": "Beautiful Souls", "authors": ["Iryna Vasko", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "To experience Lola Flash\u2019s portraits is to come face to face, eye to eye, with a subject who will not stay on the margins or in the shadows. From classic portraits of accomplished older women and rich-hued photos of cultural trendsetters to portraits of people who question gradations of skin color or gender roles, her images are hardly mute. They are strong, dignified, happy and proud.\n\nIt helps that for almost all of these images she uses a 4x5 view camera with transparency film, which makes her not only take her time, but also telegraphs to her subject that this sitting is serious business.\n\n\u201cEspecially now with selfies everywhere and all these people taking pictures of themselves, the camera says to them, \u2018Lola Flash is here and she wants someone who looks dignified,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s about beauty, pride and power. They\u2019re going to sit up straight and strike a pose. For all of my different series, gone are the days of Massa with people slumped over and not being able to look anybody in the face. Now, we stand up straight.\u201d", "title": "Beauty, Pride and Power in Photos by Lola Flash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "To get a sense of what $300,000 could buy, Ms. McQueen encouraged Ms. Burns to visit open houses in areas south of Prospect Park where co-ops are available for about $400,000 or less. Ms. Burns stuck to places within her price range. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to tempt myself,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWithin weeks, Ms. Burns saw the first place she liked, an alcove studio in a 1939 building on a pretty block in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. It was asking $349,000, with monthly maintenance of $400. At the open house, she talked to some neighbors, who were \u201call superfriendly and engaging,\u201d she said.\n\nThe studio, which was in great shape, had a sunken living area, a separate kitchen and a built-in bookshelf sectioning off the sleeping alcove.\n\nIt had been on the market for a month, and the price had fallen, so \u201cI felt confident I could put in a slightly lower offer and they would bite,\u201d Ms. Burns said. She bid $330,000. But someone else had the winning bid at $340,000.\n\nShe found another promising alcove studio on Ocean Parkway in Kensington. The location, on a thoroughfare, was less appealing, but the 1965 building, called Caton Towers, had a similar close-knit feel, with children running a bake sale in the lobby.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis apartment was listed at $279,000, with maintenance of $600 a month. Ms. Burns offered $308,000. She was at a work conference, and stayed in touch with Ms. McQueen throughout the day as the seller negotiated, but it went to someone else for $315,000.\n\nShe was more disheartened after losing out on this second co-op. She checked listings multiple times a day, but rarely saw anything new. \u201cI felt I had memorized every listing,\u201d she said, and many of them seemed to be in terrible condition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut then, another studio in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens appeared, in a 1927 building, for just $199,000, with monthly maintenance in the mid-$500s and a monthly assessment of around $150. Ms. Burns immediately had Ms. McQueen contact the listing agent, who already had an offer in hand. \u201cThat was crazy,\u201d Ms. Burns said. \u201cIt was listed mere hours before.\u201d\n\nShe left work to see it, and loved what she found: a sunny, boxy sponsor unit, just renovated, with plenty of closet space. She immediately offered $250,000.\n\nHaving been outbid twice, she said, \u201cI knew it was a good find. I would rather go in aggressive up front.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe offer was accepted. Relieved, she arrived in the fall, having measured everything \u2014 including distances between electrical outlets \u2014 so she could plan the space. Her parents, who had done plenty of work on their own Arts and Crafts house in Worcester, Mass., helped her install curtains and some light fixtures.\n\nHer mother, a ceramic artist, also made a planter to hang in the bathroom. But it soon fell into and damaged the bathtub. \u201cI think we didn\u2019t install it correctly,\u201d Ms. Burns said. To repair the tub, she used the contractor who did the renovation for the sponsor.\n\nUsing her own sense of d\u00e9cor, she added a room divider with plantation shutters and is now collaborating with her mother to design wallpaper for the kitchen. She also built a coffee table from a slab of wood and four hairpin legs.\n\n\u201cI love living by myself and being able to decorate and style the place exactly as I want to,\u201d Ms. Burns said. \u201cOwning is what I needed in order to tackle my biggest design project yet.\u201d", "title": "Becoming a First-Time Buyer in Brooklyn", "authors": ["Joyce Cohen", "The Hunt"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Although the ritual itself has an incalculably long history, the term \u201csexual harassment\u201d has only been around since the mid-1970s, when activists at Cornell University coined it during a consciousness-raising session. It was MacKinnon\u2019s book, though dense and academic, that brought the idea broader attention, charting a course for the legal system to more effectively handle instances of harassment as cases of sex discrimination, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. As far back as the 19th century, women were occasionally able to reap monetary damages through the courts if men touched them inappropriately in public, but tort law was an inadequate means of addressing harassment claims, MacKinnon believed, because it personalized injuries that were inflicted socially and ecumenically.\n\nLawyers who had tried to apply the civil rights statute to these claims had largely failed, in part because courts struggled to process what was essentially discriminatory about a practice that could theoretically victimize anyone: How could you ever know that a woman was subject to harassment because she was a woman, rather than, say, an individual who happened to be female? MacKinnon\u2019s approach was rooted in the theory that sexual harassment realized and reiterated women\u2019s inequality, that it locked women into a kind of dependence and failure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was not until seven years after the arrival of MacKinnon\u2019s book, though, that the Supreme Court recognized sexual harassment as a Title VII violation. The case was Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson and it had little nuance. In it a bank teller had charged that a company vice president had coerced her into having sex with him repeatedly, that he had touched her in public and raped her. Here the court ruled unanimously that harassment resulting in a hostile work environment was discriminatory and unlawful.\n\nIn a recent essay in The New York Times, MacKinnon celebrated the #MeToo movement, acknowledging that it was able to achieve what sexual harassment law, despite its sporadic victories, could not: a unified movement against an intractable brand of predation. Accusers were suddenly believed. Why the revolution finally got the reception it deserved has still not entirely been sorted out, but it seems clear that a war waged from the vantage point of legal theory was bound to have a harder time than a war waged from the modern media.\n\nThe 1970s and \u201980s witnessed various efforts to expose and address the dark and dangerous habits of American intimacy. Movements against domestic violence and child abuse, for example, had meaningful allies in popular culture. In 1984, \u201cThe Burning Bed,\u201d a television movie based on the true story of a Michigan housewife, Francine Hughes Wilson, who lit her husband on fire while he was sleeping, in retaliation for years of brutality, was viewed by 75 million people. The movie was crucial in transforming public understanding of spousal abuse: Shelters for battered women began opening around the country; the police began to take the issue more seriously; women who killed battering partners, and children who killed battering parents, were understood to be victims of a destructive syndrome that often gave them judicial reprieve.\n\nBest-selling thrillers like \u201cFlowers in the Attic\u201d and \u201cWhen the Bough Breaks\u201d took on child abuse and molestation, and by the 1990s we began to see the spread of community notification laws that required convicted sex offenders to register. The law followed in a sense what narrative awakened first.\n\nThe movement against sexual harassment had something else, however: a mass-market antagonist in the empire of Helen Gurley Brown and Cosmopolitan magazine, which preached a feminism of patriarchal compliance. Brown encouraged young women to work hard, build careers and run companies, but to accomplish it all by coddling the men they worked with and finding sexual freedom along the way. In \u201cSex and the Office,\u201d Brown\u2019s sequel to her loopy best-selling instructional \u201cSex and the Single Girl,\u201d she delivered a playbook for the way young women should understand male bosses that included lessons in making them feel godlike. Colleagues were potential sexual partners and the cubicle was Tinder: \u201cThough it may seem to the untrained eye that you are selflessly working on office projects together, what you are really doing is sinking into them like a cobalt treatment so that you may make off with them after work.\u201d\n\nThe book appeared in 1968 and in 2004 was reissued with an enthusiastic blurb from Donald Trump. In the 1990s, Brown\u2019s brand of feminism, dependent on the idea that women needed to work within the structures available to them, gained a new currency and held on for a long time. MacKinnon, of course, believed that the structure itself was the problem, a notion that for more than three decades has largely been received as benighted and fusty. At long last, we\u2019re coming around.", "title": "Before #MeToo, There Was Catharine A. MacKinnon and Her Book \u2018Sexual Harassment of Working Women\u2019", "authors": ["Ginia Bellafante"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBols, a centuries-old Dutch spirits company, has been reviving genever, the ancestor of gin, for several years. It has had two versions on the market and now is introducing what it says is one of the oldest recipes, dating from 1664. Within an old-fashioned clay bottle, the spirit, distilled entirely from malted grain, is clear, with complex, fruity and herbal notes and the all-important piney note of juniper. It\u2019s best enjoyed on the rocks, or perhaps straight out of the freezer with some matjes herring: Bols Genever 100 percent malt spirit, $69.99 for 750 milliliters, warehousewinesandspirits.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Before There Was Gin, There Was Genever", "authors": ["Rosie Schaap"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Trade rules limit how much technology the Chinese partner can get from a joint venture. But some American businesses and the Trump administration say Chinese officials often demand technology under the table.\n\nThe joint venture requirements have spread to other fields. China is pressuring foreign companies to share knowledge with local partners if they want to make electric cars in China \u2014 an industry in which China has plans to become a major player. Companies like Qualcomm, Hewlett Packard Enterprise and Microsoft have also struck up Chinese partnerships in recent years to avoid political pressure or regulatory tangles.\n\nHaving a foreign partner is no sure indicator that a Chinese company is ready to take on the world. While Chinese factories have churned out higher-quality cars, including some destined to be exported to the United States, no Chinese automaker has developed a homegrown brand appealing enough to sell overseas in major numbers.\n\nPhoto\n\nLicense to Share\n\nThe Trump administration also said Thursday that Chinese officials used bureaucratic licensing and approvals to gain control over sensitive data.\n\nTake cloud computing. New Chinese rules require companies running cloud-computing operations to be locally controlled. To comply, Apple and Amazon have handed stewardship of their Chinese data to local companies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCompanies like Apple and Amazon have set up ventures with local partners to handle data in China \u2014 a requirement that Chinese officials say is driven by security and privacy concerns. Chinese officials have also pressured foreign companies to give them access to sensitive technology as part of a review process to make sure those products are safe for Chinese consumers.\n\nThe foreign companies involved, like Apple, argue that the sensitive data remains safeguarded. Technology companies say the reviews they submit to are not thorough enough to expose their deepest secrets. Chinese officials say many foreign companies voluntarily hand over technology.\n\nShopping Spree\n\nIf the technology won\u2019t come to China, China will go out and buy it.\n\nThursday\u2019s report accuses the Chinese government of directing private Chinese companies to buy American know-how through corporate deals. Those purchases include some cutting-edge areas, like semiconductors, aviation, robotics and self-driving cars. A Department of Defense report last year also argued that Chinese investors were financially backing innovative start-ups.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trump administration isn\u2019t the first to worry. After Chinese buyers snapped up some American semiconductor companies three years ago, the Obama administration began rejecting other deals on national security grounds.\n\nIn many cases, the Chinese buyers have argued that they have no ties to the government and invest in technology for the same reasons that everybody else does. One start-up executive told The New York Times last year that his company took Chinese financial backing simply because American officials and companies didn\u2019t.\n\nFive-Finger Discount\n\nSome American companies say their Chinese rivals get secrets the old-fashioned way.\n\nAmerican companies and their Washington backers contend that Chinese companies have stolen secrets to help build up businesses in areas like wind turbines, often through hacking. The complaint is a longstanding one. Under the Obama administration, the government indicted in absentia five Chinese military officers for engaging in commercial espionage.\n\nThe Chinese government angrily denied the accusations. In recent years, some experts say, Chinese hacking has ebbed.", "title": "Beg, Borrow or Steal: How Trump Says China Takes Technology", "authors": ["Carlos Tejada"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In one recent video shown on state television, he was depicted as the \u201carms, legs and heart\u201d of the entire nation. The script evoked the \u201cfamily-state\u201d ideal at the center of Confucianism, showing a cutout of Mr. Xi guiding a bicycle with a young girl behind him. In the report from Sichuan, part of a 23-minute feature that appeared on state television two days later, two villagers uttered the same refrain on the theme.\n\n\u201cHe is like our parents,\u201d each said.\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s deliberations and decisions unfold in utmost secrecy. Leaks have all but ended in the Xi era, a reflection of fear as much as loyalty. Even a move that could profoundly reshape China\u2019s destiny was opaque to all but the few who work closely under him in Zhongnanhai, the government compound beside the Forbidden City that is, for ordinary Chinese, an informational black hole.\n\n\u201cWe know nothing about how this decision came about,\u201d said Kerry Brown, a professor at King\u2019s College London and author of a 2016 biography, \u201cC.E.O., China: The Rise of Xi Jinping.\u201d\n\nHe and other experts described the extreme secrecy around China\u2019s leader \u2014 even where Mr. Xi lives is not broadly known \u2014 as symptomatic of an affliction that can often hobble autocratic leaders: living inside a closed bubble of self-affirmation, echoed by yes-men (all men, in his case).\n\nStrongman on the Rise\n\n\u201cThe reason it is hard to see inside,\u201d Mr. Brown said of Zhongnanhai, \u201cis in part because it is hard to see out.\u201d\n\nThe secrecy certainly contributes to the mystique of power in China, as elsewhere, but the closed and by all accounts small circle where decisions are made could also lay the foundation for challenges to his rule, especially if China faces unforeseen crises in the years ahead, experts say.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat could explain why the government seemed not to anticipate the opposition to removing the term limits, which sent the censors into overdrive, blocking mentions of words like \u201cmy emperor.\u201d The state news media has since played down the issue as if it were a small, routine matter.\n\n\u201cChinese politicians value term limits and retirement rules as protection for their security against a leader who otherwise could ruin their careers at any time,\u201d Susan L. Shirk, a professor at the University of California, San Diego, wrote in an essay titled \u201cThe Return to Personalistic Rule,\u201d which appears in the April issue of \u201cJournal of Democracy.\u201d\n\n\u201cAlthough the odds of success for an elite rebellion may be low,\u201d she went on, \u201cthe more autocratically a leader behaves the more likely are other politicians to try to bring him down.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s dominance of politics was on display on Monday when the National People\u2019s Congress opened in Beijing. A sampling of the nearly 3,000 delegates found no one who would express even the slightest reservation about the constitutional change. One delegate, Tang Chunya, who runs a traditional medicine business in Hunan Province, said the removal of term limits was \u201can improvement of the political environment.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am definitely supporting Chairman Xi because he leads the country and he builds it into a strong one,\u201d Ms. Tang said. \u201cUnder his leadership, people are happy.\u201d\n\nIt is difficult to measure popular opinion in China, but there seems to be little doubt that the country\u2019s economic and political stability in recent years \u2014 bolstered by hagiographic coverage \u2014 has bolstered Mr. Xi\u2019s efforts to consolidate political power.\n\nSo has his campaign against corruption, which, according to Ms. Shirk\u2019s count, punished 20 members of the Central Committee or the Politburo and more than 100 generals or admirals. The campaign has had the dual benefits of eliminating potential rivals while delivering a populist message to ordinary Chinese sickened by the flaunting of wealth among the politically connected.\n\n\u201cThe conventional theory is that the party hates him but the people love him,\u201d said Richard McGregor, the author of \u201cThe Party: The Secret World of China\u2019s Communist Rulers.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn his book, Mr. Brown writes that Mr. Xi, unlike his predecessors, used his personal narrative to give himself \u201cpolitical validation\u201d that proved useful as he rose through the ranks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis father, Xi Zhongxun, was a commander in the war against Japan and then in the civil war that brought the Communists to power. He then became a senior government minister, working in the Propaganda Ministry when the younger Xi, the third of four children, was born in 1953.\n\nMr. Xi grew up as a princeling of the new ruling elite, but in the fractious era that followed, his father fell out of favor, targeted for humiliation in the Cultural Revolution and imprisoned. Mr. Xi was also harassed \u2014 paraded by Mao\u2019s Red Guards, with his mother forced to join in one public denunciation \u2014 before he was, at 16, \u201csent down\u201d to toil in the countryside in the name of the revolution.\n\nHe spent seven years in Shaanxi Province, but instead of recollecting the experience as a punishment, he has done as Mao evidently intended, describing it as a lesson that made him more confident and enlightened. He often describes himself as having been a farmer for those years.\n\n\u201cI am from the grass roots, too,\u201d he told a group of farmers during a 2013 visit to Costa Rica in remarks shown in a documentary on his diplomatic travels that was broadcast in January. \u201cI have a natural bond with the common people.\u201d\n\nIn the same way, he uses his brief service in uniform \u2014 he worked on the general staff of the State Council and the Central Military Commission from 1979 to 1982 \u2014 to claim a military pedigree as well, though he was more of a staff officer than a foot soldier.\n\nAs commander in chief, he often appears in fatigues when overseeing military parades, which have become more prominent as he has pressed ahead with a modernization program for the People\u2019s Liberation Army. Mr. McGregor said that Mr. Xi\u2019s predecessors were far less personable and charismatic, especially Jiang Zemin and Hu Jintao.\n\n\u201cHe presents much better in public,\u201d he said. \u201cHu Jintao was, by comparison, an automaton.\u201d", "title": "Behind Public Persona, the Real Xi Jinping Is a Guarded Secret", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cThere was no question in our minds that we would use a portrait of Aleksander Doba, the 71-year-old Polish man who has kayaked across the Atlantic Ocean three times, for the cover of this Voyages issue. I mean, look at him! He already seems to be plotting his next journey.\u201d\n\nRead the cover story, \u201cWhy Would Anyone Kayak Across an Ocean \u2014 at 70?\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: The Voyages Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Gail Bichler, design director: \u201cIn the middle of Hagar Vardimon\u2019s colorful collage of Hawaiian plants and flowers, there is an absence. The cutout bird in the center symbolizes the question explored by this week\u2019s cover story: As more and more species are kept alive only by extreme measures, should some be allowed to die out?\u201d\n\nRead the cover story, \u201cShould Some Species Be Allowed to Die Out?\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: Should Some Species Be Allowed to Die Out?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cThis week\u2019s cover story presented an unusual visual challenge: Because Leopoldo L\u00f3pez has been imprisoned or under house arrest for four years and prohibited from speaking to the press, we were unable to send a photographer to take his picture. Luckily, we were able to reach Diana L\u00f3pez, his sister, who photographed her brother for us during a recent visit. She is not a professional photographer, but this portrait she took has an intimacy and frankness that felt very powerful to us, especially considering the great risks he has taken by speaking for this article.\u201d\n\nRead the cover story, \u201cCan Venezuela Be Saved?\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: 3.4.18", "authors": ["The New York Times Magazine"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Behind the Cover Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cDefense Secretary Jim Mattis declined to sit for a formal portrait, so Mark Peterson followed him around and tried to get a cover-worthy shot during public appearances. We thought this one admirably captured some of the militaristic themes of Robert F. Worth\u2019s story, as well as the sense of foreboding.\u201d\n\nRead the cover story \u201cCan Jim Mattis Hold the Line in Trump\u2019s \u2018War Cabinet\u2019?\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: Last Man Standing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The activities of Wang Wei have been central to HNA\u2019s transformation from a small regional airline to a vast global conglomerate, one with nearly $100 billion in revenue and stakes in Deutsche Bank, Hilton Hotels and Swissport.\n\nFor nearly 25 years, Mr. Wang has been a little-known force at HNA, working behind the scenes to orchestrate investments, build supply chains and transfer assets, according to a review of annual reports, court filings and corporate documents by The New York Times. In one of the most pivotal moves, Mr. Wang helped set the stage for a takeover of HNA by company insiders and their families \u2014 a change that transferred control of a state-backed company into private hands.\n\nIn recent years, HNA emerged seemingly out of nowhere to become one of the most prolific dealmakers in the world, spending billions of dollars on acquisitions in real estate, finance and logistics. Investors and regulators in the United States, in Europe and elsewhere have been trying to understand the ambitions, operations and finances of the global behemoth \u2014 and the players who have helped shape the company, including Wang Wei.\n\nThose questions have taken on more urgency as Chinese authorities press the country\u2019s most aggressive acquisitors to pare back their debt. In a dramatic move, the Chinese government last month seized control of the Anbang Insurance Group, which owns the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in New York City and other multibillion-dollar properties around the world.\n\nIn the current climate, HNA, which has amassed about $90 billion in debt, is reversing course and selling off assets. Other pending deals by the company remain in limbo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnderstanding HNA is difficult. The conglomerate controls a vast network of public and private companies, subsidiaries and affiliates spread across the world. Scores of them have business ties to the friends and family members of the company\u2019s senior executives.\n\nA review by The Times found that few, if any, of those personal ties were disclosed to stock and bonds investors of the company\u2019s affiliates. Typically, investors want to understand such dealings, which could create conflicts of interest.\n\nWhether Wang Wei was ever formally employed by HNA or its predecessor, Hainan Airlines, is unclear. A review of hundreds of company filings going back to the mid-1990s turned up only a handful of mentions of him by name, and none indicate that he is the younger brother of a top HNA executive. In some cases \u2014 like the early negotiations for the Oki Golf deal \u2014 the private investment firms of Wang Wei, or those of other relatives, operated behind the scenes.\n\n\u201cThese transactions are carefully reviewed to ensure that they were in all respects beneficial to HNA,\u201d Thomas A. Clare, a lawyer for HNA, said in an email. \u201cWorking with a business partner who is known to the company and its leadership allowed the parties to work collaboratively from a position of trust and cooperation and, in so doing, achieved even greater results.\u201d\n\nCalls to Mr. Wang\u2019s homes and offices were not returned.\n\nFor years, Mr. Wang was largely unknown as a businessman in China. He granted few media interviews and rarely posed for photographs. Even on Hainan Island, where he worked for more than a decade, he was mainly known for running a company that was trying to produce Cuban-style cigars.\n\nThen roughly a decade ago, Mr. Wang appeared as a major investor in one of China\u2019s biggest property companies, Dalian Wanda. Records show that in July 2007, he bought a sizable stake in the family holding company of Wanda\u2019s chairman on the same day that a company controlled by the son of a member of the Communist Party\u2019s ruling Politburo took a stake in one of its subsidiaries. Another one of Wang Wei\u2019s investment firms bought a big stake in the Three Gorges Bank, in the city of Chongqing, in about 2008.\n\nThe roots of his wealth, though, are tied to HNA and Hainan Airlines.\n\nAfter his brother Wang Jian helped found the state-backed Hainan Airlines in the early 1990s, the younger Mr. Wang became one of the company\u2019s frequent business partners. He set up joint ventures and other businesses to provide services to the airline, including advertising and leasing. He also helped the carrier move into golf, resorts and property development.\n\nBetween 1994 and 2010, Mr. Wang set up more than 30 companies that did business with HNA and its affiliates, according to corporate filings. One company, a software services firm called eKing, was acquired by HNA, which later sold a piece to private investors for $500 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn some deals, Mr. Wang started out managing a project on behalf of HNA before quietly taking ownership through another entity.\n\nIt happened with West Coast Golf.\n\nIn October 1996, Hainan Airlines invited some of the world\u2019s leading golf course designers, including a team working for the golf legend Jack Nicklaus, to help build an 18-hole golf course on a 350-acre plot of oceanfront property in Haikou, the capital of Hainan. When construction began, the winning design team was introduced to Wang Wei.\n\n\u201cHe would attend all the meetings,\u201d said O\u2019Brien McGarey, the president of the Dye Designs Group of Denver, which won the design competition. \u201cI never really understood what his role was, but I knew he was Wang Jian\u2019s younger brother. And it was Hainan Airlines that paid me.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLater, records show, investment companies affiliated with Mr. Wang acquired majority ownership of West Coast Golf, which grew from a single golf course into a large property development with luxury villas.\n\nIt played out similarly when HNA wanted to build a more upscale development, a five-star hotel and resort surrounded by villas, on Hainan Island.\n\nThe architectural design team was hired by Hainan Airlines. But Wang Wei was involved in the planning. Mr. Wang eventually gained control of the development through one of his businesses, the Sunny Bay Development Company, according to corporate filings.\n\nToday, the development site is home to one of the island\u2019s most expensive tourist destinations \u2014 the Park Hyatt Sanya Sunny Bay Resort and a collection of luxury villas that each sell for more than $7 million. Caleb Wang, chief executive of the HTW Tourism Group, said that in 2005 his company bought a majority stake in the development site from Wang Wei.\n\n\u201cHe is still a small shareholder,\u201d said the chief executive of HTW, who is not related to Mr. Wang. \u201cI\u2019ve only met him once. He was here for the opening of the Park Hyatt.\u201d\n\nWang Wei also has ties to one of HNA\u2019s biggest shareholders.\n\nBeginning around 2000, a company managed by Mr. Wang built a stake in one of the airline\u2019s largest investors, a company called Hainan Qixing, with other HNA insiders that included his brother. The participation of HNA insiders does not appear to have been disclosed in public filings. Regulators in China and elsewhere often require disclosure of so-called related party deals involving senior executives or members of their families.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThrough Qixing, Mr. Wang and company insiders restructured the state-backed airline into a privately held parent company called the HNA Group. A large portion of HNA\u2019s shares were then shifted offshore, to Pan American Aviation, a company registered in the Cayman Islands, according to a review of corporate filings in China and Hong Kong.\n\nIn recent months, United States regulators conducting a review of HNA acquisition have pressed the conglomerate to explain its corporate ownership structure, according to court papers filed in an American lawsuit.\n\nAs HNA grew into a global powerhouse, Wang Wei went global, too.\n\nWhen Hainan Airlines was expanding, it needed to procure goods like jet fuel, aircrafts and spare parts from foreign companies, including Boeing, General Electric and Mitsubishi of Japan. Hainan Airlines formed a series of companies inside and outside China to help source these goods and ship them into the country, for a fee.\n\nOne of the companies set up to work with the airline was the Hainan HNA Import & Export Company, a firm partly controlled by Wang Wei, his brother Wang Jian and a group of their longtime business associates, according to corporate records. The import company, in other words, gave the Wang brothers an interest in the company\u2019s purchase of overseas goods, giving them a stake in a business that apparently was not disclosed to investors in Hainan Airlines, a listed company.\n\nMr. Wang\u2019s ties to HNA and its top executives run deep. In 2007, he bought what is now a $5 million residence near Seattle from a company controlled by HNA\u2019s co-chairman, Chen Feng. Then, Mr. Wang\u2019s daughter registered two limited liability companies in the city.\n\nOne of those companies helped West Coast Golf initiate talks to acquire the Oki Golf properties.\n\nIn the summer of 2014, one of Mr. Wang\u2019s associates asked for help locating golf facilities in the United States, according to Mr. McGarey, the Denver-based golf course designer who had begun working with Wang Wei in the mid-1990s.\n\nMr. McGarey said that he had negotiated an agreement, which included a \u201csuccess fee,\u201d and then signed a contract with Mr. Wang\u2019s West Coast Golf. The document, he said, was reviewed by HNA lawyers on behalf of West Coast Golf. Soon after, he was put in touch with Mr. Wang\u2019s son-in-law in Seattle, Mike Ji. They began scouting golf courses in Washington State.\n\nWhen they settled on Oki Golf as a prospect, Mr. McGarey brought in two advisers to help with the assessment of Oki\u2019s courses: Dan Conway and Don Lewison.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTogether, they approached Scott Oki, the former Microsoft executive who owned Oki Golf.\n\n\u201cI got a hold of Scott Oki. He lives across the street from me,\u201d Mr. Lewison, a Seattle real estate broker, recalled. \u201cWe met in my house, over coffee and doughnuts. I told him we had a friend who had Chinese clients, and he told me he might want to sell to them.\u201d\n\nNegotiations got underway quickly \u2014 but by the end of 2015, the American advisers said the talks appeared to have gone nowhere.\n\nThen in October 2016, Oki Golf announced that it had agreed to sell a collection of courses to the HNA Group for $137 million in cash. Mr. Oki and HNA declined to comment on the deal.\n\nMr. McGarey said he and the two advisers were cut out of the deal \u2014 and the fees promised in the contract with West Coast Golf.\n\n\u201cHis son-in-law Mike Ji called me after the deal was announced, and said, \u2018HNA was the buyer, and it had nothing to do with Wang Wei.\u2019\u201d Mr. McGarey recalled. \u201cI was furious. This deal definitely goes back to Wang Wei.\u201d", "title": "Behind the Rise of China\u2019s HNA: The Chairman\u2019s Brother", "authors": ["David Barboza", "Michael Forsythe"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "What do you see when you look in the mirror?\n\nMy grandmother loved to ask me that question. She was, by any measure, an entertaining woman; one of her standard party tricks was asking me, at the height of an evening\u2019s hilarity, if she had \u201cever told the story of the night your father was conceived.\u201d\n\nWhich, of course, she had. I would recount the details for you now, in fact, except that even in the age of Trump, there are some stories that cannot be told in print.\n\nBut she had a serious side as well. I remember her standing me on top of a stool before the bathroom mirror when I was 10 or so, and asking me, \u201cWhat do you see?\u201d And before I could even reply with the obvious, \u201cMyself,\u201d she\u2019d cut me off with a firm declaration \u2014 \u201cThat\u2019s not you!\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not?\u201d I asked, and she pointed to herself. \u201cAnd that\u2019s not me!\u201d\n\nThen she pointed to her heart. \u201cThe real you is in here!\u201d she said. And then, as if I had somehow missed her meaning, she said, \u201cIn your bosom!\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Behind the Selfie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Far from abating, Syria\u2019s civil war is raging \u2014 slowly but surely becoming more lethal to Russia\u2019s forces, more damaging to its reputation, and more of a drain on its resources. Moscow is fully complicit in Mr. Assad\u2019s murderous campaign against the primarily Sunni opposition, which has now reached new levels of depravity with the indiscriminate bombing of civilians in Ghouta, a suburban area outside Damascus. Moscow\u2019s alliance with Mr. Assad and Iran in slaughtering Sunnis risks alienating Saudi Arabia, the Gulf States and Turkey. It also will inflame Russia\u2019s own Sunni Muslim population and their brethren in Central Asia and the Caucasus, lighting the fuse for more terrorism directed at Moscow.\n\nMr. Putin insists that any Russians now fighting on the ground in Syria are guns for hire. But American intelligence believes that the man who controls them is Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, a prominent oligarch close to Mr. Putin who takes his orders from the Kremlin and is one of the 13 oligarchs recently indicted in the United States\u2019 special prosecutor\u2019s investigation of Russian meddling the 2016 election. Irregular or not, the Russian fighters in Syria increasingly find themselves in crossfires of their own making, including an ill-advised attack on American-backed anti-Islamic State forces in eastern Syria. When American air power came to their defense, as many as 200 Russians may have been killed. Mr. Putin swept the debacle under the rug to avoid acknowledging the deaths at home \u2014 having repeatedly declared mission accomplished \u2014 or risking direct conflict with the United States.\n\nSyria may not be Russia\u2019s new Afghan quagmire yet, but its quicksand is sucking Russia in deeper and deeper.\n\nMeanwhile, whatever national pride Mr. Putin piqued in seizing Crimea is getting old, and the region\u2019s needs make a consistent claim on Russia\u2019s treasury. Worse, his intervention in Eastern Ukraine has precipitated many of the very developments Mr. Putin sought to prevent.\n\nNATO is more energized than it has been in years \u2014 not because of President Trump\u2019s browbeating, but in response to Mr. Putin\u2019s aggression. The alliance now has forces on regular rotational air, land and sea deployments along Russia\u2019s border, and its budget is increasing, in part with a sustained infusion of funds from the United States. The European Union has revived the idea of strengthening its own defense capacity, spurred on by Mr. Putin\u2019s threats and Mr. Trump\u2019s rhetorical retreat from America\u2019s commitment to Europe\u2019s defense. Europeans are getting more serious about energy security. They are multiplying new routes, connections and sources for fuel and renewable power. That\u2019s making it harder for Mr. Putin to use oil and gas as strategic levers. American-led sanctions, despite Mr. Trump\u2019s reluctance to impose them, have done real, sustained damage to Russia\u2019s economy.", "title": "Opinion | Behold Vladimir V. Potemkin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump\u2019s decision to impose broad tariffs in the coming days on imports of steel and aluminum from around the world has drawn condemnation from the European Union, Canada and Brazil. But the intended target of Mr. Trump\u2019s action, China, has been fairly cautious.\n\nChina\u2019s commerce and foreign ministries have publicly criticized the decision, and the Commerce Ministry raised the possibility on Friday that China might retaliate. But the threat was carefully calibrated to say that any retaliation would be based on the direct effects of the United States\u2019 actions on China\u2019s own interests.\n\nThose direct effects could be limited. China represents only a little more than 2 percent of American steel imports, and just 0.1 percent of China\u2019s overall steel production. China also exports only a very small share of its raw aluminum production to the United States.\n\nChina uses most of its aluminum to manufacture everything from auto parts to solar panel frames, although many of these are then exported all over the world. Cautious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "His wife, who now lives in Italy, did not respond to repeated attempts to reach her.\n\n\u201cI cut off ties with everyone, as I didn\u2019t want them tracking me down,\u201d he said about family and friends in Romania. \u201cI knew it was hard for my daughter, but I felt it would be better for her.\u201d\n\nAfter a 7.6-magnitude earthquake struck Turkey in August 1999, resulting in an estimated 17,000 deaths, those in Romania who knew Mr. Constantin wondered if he had been among the dead.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t until 2013, after not hearing from her husband for 14 years, that Mr. Constantin\u2019s wife asked a court to declare him dead. With family and friends testifying that they had not heard from him since 1999, and the Turkish Interior Ministry saying they had no record of him for that period, the Romanian court concluded that he was most likely dead.\n\nHis death certificate was issued in May 2016, with the year of death listed as 2003, the same year his passport expired.\n\nMr. Constantin, who was living in Istanbul at the time, was oblivious to all of this. When the authorities detained him, he was told that his case was classified and that he would never be allowed to return to Turkey. It was only upon landing in the Romanian capital after 26 days in Turkish detention that he was told he was legally dead.\n\n\u201cAt the airport in Bucharest, I was surrounded by customs officials. They said, \u2018You\u2019re dead,\u2019\u201d he recalled with disbelief. \u201cI thought they were joking. I was the only one who didn\u2019t know. The people who escorted me off the plane knew, everyone knew except me.\u201d\n\nFor the next six hours, he was questioned about his hometown \u2014 where the schools and factories were, details about his family, including dates of birth. Finally, he was released.", "title": "Being Dead, He Learned, Is Hard to Overcome", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Over a melting ice cream sundae on our first date away from our new son, my partner and I talked about what we\u2019d be doing if we were still drinking. A cozy-looking bar across the street might have suited our purposes. Yet years of partying had shown us that abstinence was necessary for him and best for me. So, ice cream it was.\n\nPopular parenting culture doesn\u2019t have much room for sober sorts like us. Jokey messages on coffee mugs and T-shirts reinforce the notion that the best cure for the demands of our children is a generous glass of chardonnay. Parents who don\u2019t drink are not offered such a simple solution to stress.\n\nDr. Leena Mittal, a perinatal psychiatrist and addiction specialist at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital in Boston, said there is a long history of chemical management of women\u2019s distress. Tranquilizers widely prescribed to mothers in the 1950s and \u201960s were known as Mother\u2019s Little Helper. \u201cThis sends women the message that their emotions need to be squelched and not addressed,\u201d she said.\n\nAs the opioid crisis draws attention to the impact of addiction on families, there may be a new openness to sober parenting. More children are entering the foster care system because of the opioid epidemic. The National Survey on Drug Use and Health found that between 2009-14, approximately 10 percent of American children lived in homes where at least one parent had an alcohol use disorder. Dr. Mittal said women with the disorder often do not get treatment for their addiction because they fear losing custody of their children. Policy changes can encourage more women to seek help. The Family First Prevention Services Act, signed into law on February 8, 2018, provides substance abuse prevention and treatment services to parents whose children are at risk for being removed from their homes. Though data shows parents tend to drink less than nonparents, social context affects how much they consume.", "title": "Being a Sober Parent in a Wine Mom Culture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "No doubt, Mayor Bill de Blasio convinced himself that he was raising consciousness. But mostly he raised eyebrows, sky high, with a lament that his wife, Chirlane McCray, isn\u2019t allowed to collect a paycheck on the taxpayer\u2019s dime.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t understand it,\u201d he said the other day, \u201cbecause if someone is working full time and is a professional with a whole lot of background and applying themselves, I don\u2019t understand why they can\u2019t get paid.\u201d\n\nLet\u2019s explain it to him. It\u2019s called nepotism, and it\u2019s clearly outlawed under the City Charter, New York\u2019s equivalent of a constitution. Right there in Chapter 68 it forbids public servants to use their position \u201cto obtain any financial gain, contract, license, privilege or other private or personal advantage, direct or indirect, for the public servant or any person or firm associated with the public servant.\u201d Ms. McCray, married to Mr. de Blasio since 1994, surely qualifies as a person associated with a public servant.\n\nNot that the mayor has to be told this. He did not appear in court, and he can appeal the conviction, but failure to pay the fine could land him in prison, officials said.\n\n\u201cShut your mouth, I don\u2019t talk to women, being a police officer is not a job for women,\u201d the man told the female police officer during the arrest, according to Gilles Blondeau, a spokesman for the public prosecutor\u2019s office. The sexism law was passed in 2014 as an amendment to an earlier law condemning discrimination in general.", "title": "Belgian Man Convicted of \u2018Sexism in the Public Space,\u2019 a First", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Belgium\u2019s national soccer association ended a collaboration with the rapper Damso on Friday after protests from women\u2019s groups, politicians and corporate sponsors that his lyrics were sexist. Damso was to create the country\u2019s official song for the World Cup, which begins in June in Russia.\n\nNational soccer teams often commission musicians to create songs for big tournaments as a way of building morale and reflecting national identity. But the choice of Damso, whose songs feature threats of violence against women and crude references to the female anatomy, has instead inflamed tensions between fighting sexism and freedom of expression.\n\nThe Royal Belgian Football Association said on Tuesday that it would not be \u201ctaken hostage\u201d by the controversy. But in the early hours of Friday, it announced that it had ended the collaboration with Damso \u201cby mutual agreement,\u201d according to a statement. The association went on to say, \u201cWe especially wish to apologize to all those who felt offended, discriminated against or diminished by the choice of the artist in question.\u201d\n\nGendered insults and sexist intimidation were outlawed in Belgium in 2014, partly in response to a 2012 video taken with a hidden camera by Sofie Peeters, a film student, that showed her being showered with harassment and insults as she walked through Brussels. We would sit around for hours, riffing on all the punny ways to talk about foot fungus powder, until it was 5 o\u2019clock and time to go to happy hour. There isn\u2019t a lot that I miss about the 1980s, but those were good times.\n\nToday, Mr. Koetters continues that tradition with punny slogans for capital cities, should you want to visit them. For example, at 50A, the testimonial \u201c\u2018I was afraid to ski, but in New Hampshire I ___!\u2019\u201d is answered by CONCORD MY FEARS, as a sound-alike for \u201cconquered my fears\u201d and CONCORD being the capital of New Hampshire.\n\nThat\u2019s very clever. Now you go visit the other three cities.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n11A: Were you suspicious of this clue? \u201cFixer at a horse race?\u201d sounds like someone who fixes the races themselves, but the person who \u201cfixes\u201d the horses is the VET.", "title": "Belted One Out of This World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Ben Carson, the secretary of housing and urban development, told a House committee on Tuesday that he had \u201cdismissed\u201d himself from the decision to buy a $31,000 dining room set for his office last year, leaving the details to his wife and staff.\n\nMr. Carson offered a rambling, at times contradictory, explanation of the purchase of the table, chairs and hutch, a transaction that turned into a public relations disaster that led President Trump to consider replacing him, according to White House aides.\n\nThe hearing, before the House Appropriations subcommittee that determines the Department of Housing and Urban Development\u2019s budget, was supposed to center on the administration\u2019s proposed budget cuts to the agency. Instead it was dominated by questions about Mr. Carson\u2019s judgment, the conduct of his wife, Candy Carson, and son Ben Carson Jr., and Mr. Carson\u2019s initial denial that he was aware of the expenditure, a position he has modified.\n\n\u201cI was not big into redecorating. If it were up to me, my office would look like a hospital waiting room,\u201d said Mr. Carson, who repeatedly told committee members that he had no knowledge of the $5,000 limit imposed on cabinet secretaries for redecorating their offices \u2014 despite the release of emails between top aides discussing how to justify getting around the cap.", "title": "Ben Carson Defends Buying $31,000 Dining Set to Congress: \u2018I Left It to My Wife\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Carson modified that account in a Facebook post on Monday, acknowledging that he had provided some comment about the set, and that his wife had expressed a preference for the color of the cushions.\n\n\u201cI briefly looked at catalogs for dining furniture and was shocked by the cost of the furniture,\u201d he wrote. \u201cMy wife asked if used furniture was an option. Our acquisition process did not allow for that.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe were told there was a $25,000 budget that had to be used by a certain time or it would be lost. I indicated that they needed to take care of the needs of the deputy secretary out of that money too,\u201d he continued. \u201cMy wife also looked at the catalogs and wanted to be sure that the color of the chair fabric of any set that was chosen matched the rest of the decour.\u201d\n\nLast week, Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina and the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, requested a wide range of documents and emails relating to the redecorating and Mrs. Foster\u2019s complaint.\n\nIn his letter, Mr. Smallwood also claimed that most of his department had been singled out for \u201cretribution\u201d because they refused to cooperate with requests from Mr. Carson\u2019s staff.\n\n\u201cHelen Foster is not the only person at HUD that has been persecuted in this witch hunt under your watch. The rest of us have operated in fear,\u201d he wrote, adding that about 30 employees in his division had been denied access to their annual agency performance plans, leaving them adrift and ineligible for performance-based bonuses.\n\n\u201cI made a decision to speak out even though I know I might be fired,\u201d said Mr. Smallwood, who serves at the discretion of Mr. Carson. \u201cBut somebody had to speak out.\u201d", "title": "Ben Carson Is Asked to Acknowledge Wife\u2019s Role in HUD Office Renovation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Ben Carson, the secretary of housing and urban development, is attempting to cancel a $31,000 order for a customized hardwood dining room table, chairs, sideboard and hutch the day after the chairman of the House Oversight Committee announced an investigation into the refurbishment of his HUD office.\n\n\u201cAt the request of the secretary, the agency is working to rescind the order for the dining room set,\u201d Armstrong Williams, Mr. Carson\u2019s business manager and an informal adviser, said on Thursday.\n\nHe added, however, that \u201cit might not be possible.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, Raffi Williams, a department spokesman said Mr. Carson had no problem with the order and no intention of returning the table. But early Thursday, Mr. Williams said the secretary, who was sharply criticized for the purchase at a time when his agency is facing $6.8 billion in budget cuts requested by the White House, seemed to change his mind.\n\n\u201cNobody was more surprised than me,\u201d about the order, Mr. Carson said in a statement.\n\nBut several department officials, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation, said it would have been highly unusual for Mr. Carson not to have been told that a significant section of his office suite was about to be upgraded.", "title": "Ben Carson Tries to Cancel $31,000 Dining Furniture Purchase for HUD Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere are more complexities here than in brain surgery,\u201d Mr. Carson said in an interview last week. \u201cDoing this job is going to be a very intricate process.\u201d\n\nMr. Carson\u2019s efforts to steer the agency toward programs that foster self-sufficiency, one of his stated goals, have been undermined by staffing mistakes, his indecisiveness and a president indifferent, at best, to the department\u2019s mission of helping the poor, according to two dozen current and former HUD and administration officials.\n\nAll of this has been exacerbated by Mr. Carson\u2019s tin ear for politics \u2014 such as the damaging disclosure that he had looked the other way when subordinates spent, at a time of savage budget cuts, $31,000 to buy him a new mahogany dining room suite for his office that included a pair of $1,000 side chairs.\n\n\u201cI think you have to come to the job with a sense of what the duties and responsibilities are,\u201d said Representative Al Green, a Texas Democrat and frequent Carson critic. \u201cIf you don\u2019t come with that sense, and the doctor didn\u2019t, it doesn\u2019t matter what your intentions are, you aren\u2019t going to succeed. We are seeing that now.\u201d\n\n\u201cSecretary Carson has to step up,\u201d said Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, who voted against his confirmation a year ago.\n\n[READ MORE: Don\u2019t Make Housing for the Poor Too Cozy, Carson Warns]\n\nHUD, created in 1965 as a Great Society response to a growing urban crisis, is a lot less powerful than its vast portfolio suggests. It is mostly a conduit for congressional appropriations and a caretaker for a patch quilt of existing anti-poverty programs.\n\nMr. Carson accepted the job after an intense multiple-call-a-day barrage from Mr. Trump, who saw a chance to infuse HUD with the self-help philosophy that was the theme of Mr. Carson\u2019s presidential campaign. His model is his own mother, a domestic worker who rescued her two sons from poverty, roach-infested apartments and the low expectations of their teachers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he has not yet been able to get serious buy-in from Mr. Trump or secure commitments from his staff on the programs he favors, especially his plan to create thousands of community centers geared toward fostering self-sufficiency. In part, this is because the president views him as a secondary player, a nice guy unlikely to make waves.\n\nWhile Mr. Trump treats him with respect, he views him as a beta \u201cwinner,\u201d not as a \u201ckiller,\u201d the alpha in his organizational taxonomy, according to several White House officials.\n\nThat lack of influence was painfully apparent during the internal debate before the release of Mr. Trump\u2019s budget, which would help pay for increases in military and Homeland Security spending with steep cuts to HUD\u2019s Community Development Block Grant and core housing programs.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Carson, people close to him say, hates asking anybody for money \u2014 and has told advisers that he feels acutely uncomfortable asking the president for anything that could be construed as a favor.\n\nWhen the White House budget director, Mick Mulvaney, proposed an 18 percent cut to HUD late last year, Mr. Carson reluctantly reached out to the president. Mr. Trump expressed sympathy. Then he told him to \u201ctalk to Mick\u201d about the details.\n\nMr. Carson denies that he has been marginalized and says he backs Mr. Trump\u2019s guns-before-butter budget approach. \u201cI believe in what the president believes,\u201d Mr. Carson said. \u201cWe are in a very precarious situation with North Korea, with radical terrorists who want to destroy us, with the Soviet Union, who has ambitions.\u201d An aide later said he was referring to Russia.\n\nIn private, however, Mr. Carson has been profoundly frustrated, telling friends he would find it difficult to stay if deep cuts to two housing programs, focused on helping the elderly and the disabled, were enacted.\n\n\u201cHe was ready to walk \u2014 he would have walked,\u201d said Mr. Carson\u2019s longtime business manager and political adviser, Armstrong Williams.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEventually, Mr. Carson persuaded the White House chief of staff, John F. Kelly, and the president to restore about $2 billion for HUD\u2019s budget. That dropped the total percentage cut to 14 percent. It was bad but better.\n\nRaising his voice in defense of HUD doesn\u2019t come naturally to the defiantly low-key Mr. Carson. That sotto voce serenity prompted Mr. Trump as a candidate to mock a favorite Carson anecdote about his troubled youth \u2014 the one in which a teenage \u201cBennie\u201d Carson tried to stab a buddy, only to be stopped by a providentially thick belt buckle.\n\n\u201cHow stupid are the people of the country to believe this crap?\u201d Mr. Trump asked at a November 2015 rally.\n\nMr. Trump later apologized for his remarks, Mr. Carson has told associates, confessing to being \u201ca little bit panicked\u201d by the doctor\u2019s early popularity.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Carson has, at times, and in a measured way, criticized Mr. Trump, mildly taking him to task for his profane description of Haiti and African countries in January. But he said he did not \u201cspend a lot of time thinking about race, quite frankly,\u201d when asked if he felt responsibility as the most prominent African-American in an overwhelmingly white administration.\n\nStill, Mr. Carson said that he was trying to soften Mr. Trump\u2019s tone. \u201cI have moderated my own speech because I recognized that when I say things in an inflammatory manner, that\u2019s not particularly helpful,\u201d he said. \u201cI have made it known to everyone in the administration, including the president.\u201d\n\nThe power dynamic in the relationship, however, is clearly tilted. Mr. Trump shot down Mr. Carson\u2019s choice for deputy secretary, Rick A. Lazio, a former Long Island congressman who savaged the president during the campaign.\n\nAt around the same time, the White House press office also rejected the secretary\u2019s request to appear on CNN and then told him to clear all media appearances, much to Mr. Carson\u2019s annoyance, aides said.\n\nHe often simply seems out of the loop \u2014 telling senior staff members at a gathering last spring that the president had given him assurances that HUD\u2019s budget would not be cut at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCongressional Democrats have also proved to be a problem. Until she relented in late 2017, Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, blocked the confirmation of the eventual nominee for deputy secretary, and Ms. Warren continues to delay the confirmation of two other top housing officials.\n\n[READ MORE: Carson Tries to Cancel $31k Dining Furniture Purchase for HUD Office]\n\nPeople close to Mr. Carson have been prodding him to show more fight with the White House and Congress. \u201cI like the aggressiveness! That\u2019s a new secretary I haven\u2019t seen!\u201d Mr. Williams said after the secretary raised his voice during a televised town-hall-style meeting recently.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut that forcefulness has often been absent in his dealing with staff members. His first six months in office were marked by damaging infighting and the departure of dozens of experienced people.\n\nMr. Carson\u2019s first chief of staff, Sheila Greenwood, a HUD veteran, clashed with Lynne Patton, a former officer with a charitable foundation run by Mr. Trump\u2019s son Eric, who was given a top department job without any consultation with the secretary.\n\nTheir conflict came to a head when Ms. Greenwood rejected Ms. Patton\u2019s request for an Amtrak ticket from Washington to New York, ordering her to take a shuttle flight at a cheaper contracted rate. Ms. Patton told associates she was offended, then paid for the train ticket out of pocket. To alleviate the tension, Mr. Carson arranged for Ms. Patton to be transferred to HUD\u2019s New York City regional office, according to people with knowledge of the situation.\n\nMr. Carson complained about her behavior \u2014 and requested her apology this year when she called a White House reporter \u201cMiss Piggy\u201d on Twitter \u2014 but he has not taken more serious disciplinary action, and Ms. Patton still enjoys the protection of her friends in the White House.\n\nTo the consternation of some staff members, Mr. Carson has leaned heavily on his family, especially his wife, Candy \u2014 who occupied a space in Mr. Carson\u2019s office suite for much of his first year in office, said a Carson confidant.\n\nA former chief administrative officer in the department, Helen Goff Foster, has filed a complaint with the federal whistle-blower agency, the Office of Special Counsel, alleging that she was demoted and transferred after she refused Mrs. Carson\u2019s request to circumvent a rule capping redecorating expenses for Mr. Carson\u2019s office to $5,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Carsons, through a HUD spokesman, denied her claim. But shortly after, someone in Mr. Carson\u2019s office decided to pay a small Baltimore company $31,561 to replace his dining room table, chairs and hutch. The secretary did not know about the purchase, according to his spokesman, Raffi Williams. After the spokesman said last week that Mr. Carson had no plans to reverse the decision, Armstrong Williams said two days later that the secretary was trying to cancel the order.\n\nIssues involving Ben Carson Jr., the secretary\u2019s son and a Maryland-based businessman, have proven equally troublesome. Mr. Carson invited him to a Baltimore listening tour last summer, despite a warning from department lawyers, during one of his daily briefings, about a potential ethics problem.\n\nIn response to the lawyers, Mr. Carson summoned his son and his wife, a government contractor, to ask if they were doing anything wrong \u2014 then left the decision of whether they planned to attend up to them, according to two people with knowledge of the conversation. They did.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have any problem with ethics,\u201d Mr. Carson said. \u201cHere is a rather unique situation, Ben is somebody who is integrally important to me, and wants to help. I\u2019m not going to just say no because it looks this way or that way.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe are ethically pure.\u201d\n\nSuch questions, Mr. Carson believes, are a distraction from his grand vision of HUD as a ladder out of dependency for the working poor. Increasingly, he is staking that legacy on a single program, the so-called EnVision Centers project.\n\nOver the next three to five years, Mr. Carson hopes to establish more than 3,000 of the centers to provide low-income families, especially young people, with one-stop access to educational, job training, mentorship and health care services. But Ms. Greenwood argued that Mr. Carson\u2019s team was not experienced enough to make it work, and it soon became apparent that there was little appetite in the White House for more than a pittance in funding \u2014 $2 million over the next year.\n\nIn response, Mr. Carson has turned to charitable foundations for funding. But he has not proved to be the best pitchman, according to a dozen attendees at a January meeting with potential donors at HUD headquarters. He began with a libertarian lecture, extolling the genius of the 19th-century robber barons who created the country\u2019s philanthropic charities. They had spared the country from \u201cEuropean socialism,\u201d he said.\n\nOne skeptical foundation officer countered by asking the secretary where \u201cthe public\u201d part of the public-private partnership was coming from. Another asked, \u201cWhat does this have to do with public housing?\u201d\n\nBut his audience, mainly composed of community development specialists who believe that the government has an enduring moral responsibility to help the poor, was most put off by Mr. Carson\u2019s assertion that the goal of EnVision was to put HUD out of business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere is nothing wrong with encouraging safe, inviting places for youth to grow,\u201d said Adrianne Todman, chief executive of the Washington-based National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials. \u201cBut it is time for us to focus on the \u2018H\u2019 in HUD \u2014 \u2018housing.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Ben Carson of HUD on His Vexing Reign: Brain Surgery Was Easier Than This", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRight now Benedict Cumberbatch\u2019s most precious commodity just might be time.\n\nThat would explain the clashing of pans and plates in the background of a phone interview. It was 8 p.m. in London, the actor was at home in the Hampstead neighborhood, and, he admitted, \u201cI\u2019m eating my supper that I just cooked.\u201d\n\nBut it didn\u2019t stop the BBC \u201cSherlock\u201d star from explaining how time and ways to measure it have featured prominently in his life recently.\n\nA broken watch, inscribed \u201cTime will tell how much I love you,\u201d had a key role in Mr. Cumberbatch\u2019s 2016 Marvel film \u201cDoctor Strange.\u201d The title character was \u201ca massive collector, trapped in a gilded cage, alone in all the materialism,\u201d the actor, 41, said. \u201cBut he keeps the watch, even though it\u2019s broken, because of what it said.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe watch was a Jaeger-LeCoultre Master Ultra Thin Perpetual, which led Mr. Cumberbatch to becoming an ambassador for the brand and turning up at the Salon de la Haute Horlogerie in Geneva in January. But what impressed him most from the trip was a visit to the Jaeger-LeCoultre atelier in the Swiss mountain village of Le Sentier.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI saw up close and personal how enameling is done, how a tourbillon is created, how a watch is assembled,\u201d he said. \u201cThe real beauty lies in the human touch. The watches are built by hand; that\u2019s what made me fall in love.\u201d", "title": "Benedict Cumberbatch on the \u2018Human Touch\u2019 of Watchmaking", "authors": ["Kathleen Beckett"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Inside the Balfour Street residence, Mr. Netanyahu was questioned for hours under caution as a possible suspect, according to the police. His wife, Sara, was questioned simultaneously as a suspect in the same case at the fraud investigation unit\u2019s headquarters in Lod, central Israel.\n\nThe latest twist in a spiraling corruption scandal comes on the eve of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s departure for Washington, where he is scheduled to meet President Trump and address the American Israel Public Affairs Committee\u2019s annual policy conference.\n\nMr. Netanyahu has made a point of maintaining a high-profile presence on the world stage, traveling in recent weeks to India, where he was treated like royalty; to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland; and to an international security conference in Munich.\n\nDenying all wrongdoing, Mr. Netanyahu has been trying to project a business-as-usual approach despite his mounting legal troubles, aiming to burnish his credentials both at home and abroad as an international player.\n\nIn a short video posted on Facebook after he was questioned, Mr. Netanyahu said he was about to embark on \u201ca very important visit\u201d to the United States and added, in reference to the police investigations, \u201cI feel confident that nothing will come of it.\u201d\n\nThe questioning of the prime minister, who also served as communications minister from 2014 to 2017, in this latest case was expected.\n\nSeveral members of his close circle have been arrested in the case, including Nir Hefetz, a former media adviser to the Netanyahus, and Shlomo Filber, a political operative for Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s conservative Likud Party and Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s pick as director general of the Communications Ministry. Mr. Filber, a long-serving Netanyahu aide, has turned state witness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe case involves a dicey mix of political power, big business and personal relationships. Mr. Netanyahu is a friend of Mr. Elovitch, who owns the Eurocom Group holding company, which owns Bezeq, the Israeli telecommunications giant that has long had a near-monopoly on land lines in the country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sara Netanyahu, a friend of Mr. Elovitch\u2019s wife, Iris, is reported to have sent messages to her with demands to tilt the coverage in her husband\u2019s favor. Mrs. Elovitch has already been arrested in the affair and spent several days in detention.\n\nMrs. Netanyahu is facing possible fraud charges in a separate case in which she is accused of misusing about $100,000 in public funds in her management of the prime minister\u2019s official residence.\n\nAmong other things, the Communications Ministry is said to have pushed regulators to allow the merger of a money-losing satellite network, Yes, also owned by Mr. Elovitch, with Bezeq, a deal that would have reaped huge tax savings for Mr. Elovitch.\n\nAt a hearing for two of the suspects in the case in a Tel Aviv court this week, Yehudit Tirosh, a prosecution lawyer, pointed a finger at Mr. Netanyahu in his role as communications minister.\n\n\u201cThis is a grave case of giving and receiving bribes,\u201d Ms. Tirosh was quoted as saying by the Israeli news media. \u201cThe term \u2018positive coverage\u2019 is misleading. This is harnessing a leading website in return for regulatory favors by the minister of communications and the director general of the Ministry of Communications.\u201d The value of the regulatory benefits was about $500 million, she said.\n\nMr. Netanyahu responded in another Facebook post this week, saying, \u201cAll actions were carried out in a professional manner based on the recommendations of the professional echelon, professional committees and legal counsel.\u2019\u2019\n\nJack Chen, a lawyer representing Mr. Elovitch, said in an interview on Friday that the allegations were \u201cbaseless,\u201d and that his client categorically denied that there was ever any such deal.\n\nMr. Netanyahu, who has been accused of accepting nearly $300,000 in gifts over 10 years, has found himself and his close associates accused on a variety of fronts:\n\n\u2022 Case 1000, the gifts-for-favors affair in which the police last month recommended that Mr. Netanyahu be charged with bribery, fraud and breach of trust.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Case 2000, in which Mr. Netanyahu is suspected of back-room dealings with Arnon Mozes, publisher of the popular newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth, to ensure more favorable coverage. The police have also recommended charges in that case.\n\n\u2022 Case 3000, which involves suspicions of corruption surrounding a multibillion-dollar purchase of submarines and other naval vessels from a German shipyard. Mr. Netanyahu is not a suspect in that case, though some of his closest confidants are.\n\n\u2022 Case 4000, which was the subject of the police questioning on Friday.\n\nThe Walla news site has changed its tune in recent months, offering some considerably less fawning coverage of the Netanyahus.\n\nIn January, it published an earsplitting recorded telephone conversation from 2009 in which Mrs. Netanyahu could be heard berating a publicist over a short gossip column item about her participation in a school fund-raising event that did not cite her educational and professional credentials to her satisfaction.", "title": "Benjamin Netanyahu Is Questioned in 3rd Corruption Case in Israel", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Benjamin Toff and Andrew Tangel were married March 17 at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum in Tucson.
