The team\u2019s third-base coach, Glenn Sherlock, who handles the catching instruction, said the catchers\u2019 past preparation was good but in need of taking the next step. By talking more about the art of pitching, the goal is to help the catchers develop the confidence of the pitching staff.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just about getting through the game and not discussing it,\u201d Sherlock said. \u201cThere\u2019s going to be a lot of discussion about effectiveness and pitch selection this season.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBy studying the information and presenting it, d\u2019Arnaud said he would have faster recall and better memorization.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019ll help us learn the information better,\u201d d\u2019Arnaud said. \u201cNot only do we hear it, but we\u2019ll have to say it. It\u2019s two ways of remembering it.\u201d\n\nIn spring training games, d\u2019Arnaud and Plawecki have been testing play-calling wristbands, similar to those worn by quarterbacks in football. A flap hides the team\u2019s secrets from the prying eyes of batters and cameras.\n\nBut in this data-driven era of baseball, there is so much information to remember that the wristbands can also serve as an in-game reference. And with new Major League Baseball rules limiting the number of mound visits to six per team per game, the wristbands can be a guide when hand signals between the pitcher and catcher need to be changed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a bit of trial and error right now to see what\u2019s comfortable and see what\u2019s working,\u201d Sherlock said.\n\n\n\nAlthough pitch calling is a joint effort between the catcher and pitcher, Eiland said the final decision on what to throw will continue to fall on the man on the mound. Eiland said he would serve as a guide from the dugout only if the battery was in trouble and asked for his help.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nD\u2019Arnaud said he appreciated the new responsibilities; in the past, he said, he has made mistakes he regrets by putting a scouting report ahead of his instincts.\n\nEiland said the catchers also needed \u201cto know that pitcher\u2019s personality, know which buttons to push and what catchphrases are going to work.\u201d\n\nD\u2019Arnaud, 29, and Plawecki, 27, have been around most of these pitchers for years. But d\u2019Arnaud, once the centerpiece of the 2012 R. A. Dickey trade, has been injured and much maligned, and Plawecki, a compensatory first-round pick in 2012, has developed slowly.\n\nPhoto\n\nStatistically, both are average major league catchers, a hard truth about their grueling position. Last season, the league average catcher posted a .720 on-base-plus-slugging percentage, the lowest of all the nonpitching positions, according to FanGraphs.com. Including strong finishes to the 2017 season by both, d\u2019Arnaud posted a .735 O.P.S. over 112 games, and Plawecki notched a .764 in a third as many appearances.\n\nDefensively, though, d\u2019Arnaud is considered a better pitch framer and receiver than the analytics give him credit for. But he and Plawecki have room for improvement, especially in preventing stolen bases, another Mets weakness.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m expecting more out of them, especially a team like this and Mickey\u2019s philosophy on pitching,\u201d said the Hall of Fame catcher Mike Piazza, who spent a few days late last month in his annual role as a Mets spring training instructor. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing wrong with challenging yourself to take the next step.\u201d\n\nDuring their roster overhaul in the off-season, the Mets did not upgrade at catcher, preferring the potential of their in-house options to the cost of adding a new player.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe final month and a half of a disappointing 2017 season offered the Mets some hope that a combination of d\u2019Arnaud and Plawecki might just work. After the team let the veteran backup Rene Rivera go as part of its late-season sell-off, d\u2019Arnaud and Plawecki platooned and flourished.\n\nPerhaps it was the competition or the regular rest, but d\u2019Arnaud hit .297 with six home runs and 20 runs batted from Aug. 19 on. Plawecki hit .303 with three home runs and 12 walks in the same period.\n\nThe Mets plan to play either catcher based on the matchups this season, and neither player said that would be an issue.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a competition, but a friendly competition, where we can turn it into a positive and benefit from it,\u201d Plawecki said. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to sit there and wish bad things on each other. We\u2019re ultimately rooting for each other and want to win.\u201d\n\nEach also knows that the most important work will still be done at the other end of the battery. Callaway, a former pitcher and pitching coach, said that he wanted his catchers to rely on the pitchers\u2019 best two pitches, instead of getting beat on their third or fourth option.\n\n\u201cWe really have to hone our pitch selection,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cWe\u2019re really going to be looking to those two guys to take ownership of that and start getting guys to use their pitches the right way.\u201d", "title": "Better Pitching? Mets Think It\u2019s in the Wrist, and the Preparation", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Bowser graduated from Granby High School in Norfolk in 1962 and enrolled at Ohio Wesleyan University, where she joined the student newspaper and quickly displayed a trait that would mark her whole career: versatility.\n\n\u201cBetty Ann started off at the weekly Ohio Wesleyan Transcript as a cub reporter, covering general university news that ranged from the serious to campus hi-jinx,\u201d recalled Larry Heinzerling, who was her editor there and went on to a distinguished career with The Associated Press. \u201cIn the first category was coverage of faculty efforts, eventually successful, to have Ohio Wesleyan end racial discrimination at its fraternities and sororities. The latter included a story in May 1965 on \u2018spring fever.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThat spring fever article reported on an epic campus water fight.\n\n\u201cA parking ticket for the Dean of Women, four flat tires for the campus policeman and free 1:30s for coeds\u201d \u2014 the privilege of staying out until 1:30 a.m. \u2014 \u201cwere some of the side effects of the season\u2019s first all-campus water battle last Thursday night,\u201d Ms. Bowser wrote in her opening sentence.\n\nPhoto\n\nPursuing a double major in English and journalism, Ms. Bowser graduated in 1966 and took a job at WAVY, a Norfolk-area TV station, and later moved to WTAR, a station in the same market, where she was a co-anchor of the news report. She joined CBS in 1974.\n\nThe PBS article said she would sometimes tell the story of scoring a brief interview with Richard M. Nixon, shortly after he resigned the presidency in 1974, by dropping in at a golf course near his California home on a whim. The modest scoop impressed Walter Cronkite, the CBS anchor, enough that he made a congratulatory phone call to the recently hired Ms. Bowser, who credited the incident with elevating her profile at the network.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe ranged far and wide as a CBS correspondent, covering national stories as well as international ones like the persistent famine in parts of Africa. In 1980 she became a host of \u201c30 Minutes,\u201d a newsmagazine program aimed at teenagers. The program won some Daytime Emmys but was canceled in 1982 because of low ratings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bowser left CBS in the mid-1980s, amid cutbacks at the network. She almost left journalism as well. She intended to go into the real estate business, and did briefly. But then her husband, Chris Kelley, a former Pentagon correspondent at CBS, got a job in Texas, and the housing market went dormant.\n\n\u201cI was in Texas, I was unemployed and we needed money,\u201d she told The Virginian-Pilot in 1997, \u201cso I went to the local PBS station looking for some freelance work for \u2018NewsHour.\u2019 \u201d\n\nIt was a step she took reluctantly, she said. She had become disillusioned with television news and concerned about whether women in the TV news business would be allowed to \u201cage gracefully\u201d in their jobs.\n\n\u201cI went back kicking and screaming,\u201d she said. But \u201cNewsHour\u201d proved a good match; she became a general assignment correspondent, covering stories that included the terrorist bombing in Oklahoma City in 1995.\n\nIn the PBS tribute, colleagues recalled her ability to connect and sympathize with ordinary people, as was evident in her work on the Oklahoma City attack, which killed 168 people. She spent weeks reporting on the friends and family members of victims, and returned several times later.\n\n\u201cI followed people\u2019s lives,\u201d she told The Virginian-Pilot. \u201cThere are incredible stories about what people have done, all these individuals who\u2019ve risen to the occasion and done amazing things with their lives.\u201d\n\nMs. Bowser became the \u201cNewsHour\u201d health correspondent in 2006, reporting on issues like the shortage of dental care and primary physicians in parts of the United States. In 2013 she returned to Oklahoma to report on a growing problem that has since garnered much more attention: deaths from the misuse of prescription opioids.\n\n\u201cThe people dying from painkiller abuse don\u2019t fit the profile of illegal drug users,\u201d she said in the segment, which focused on a football player at the University of Oklahoma who died at 22.\n\nMs. Bowser retired in 2013. Her marriage to Mr. Kelley ended in divorce in 1996. In addition to her son Patrick, she is survived by another son, Matthew.\n\nIn the PBS tribute, Brian Gill, a cameraman, recalled working with Ms. Bowser covering Hurricane Katrina in 2005.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeople we talked to would open up to her,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause they knew that she cared about them and their situation.\u201d", "title": "Betty Ann Bowser, Versatile TV Newswoman, Is Dead at 73", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "As the industry increasingly integrates artificial intelligence into digital advertising, however, disinformation operations and legitimate political communications will gradually become concerted, automatic and seamless. The real innovation in digital marketing \u2014 and the type of thing that the United States Congress and American voters should be particularly concerned about \u2014 is the execution of disinformation that operates at real scale. Where there were once a couple dozen human operators stitching together a few divisive messages during working hours in Moscow to pick at the digital halls of our democracy, there will soon be countless A.I. systems testing and probing a plethora of content on a vast field of social media user audiences that are highly segmented by race, ethnicity, gender, location, socioeconomic class and political leaning. We can expect advisory firms like Cambridge Analytica, the Russians and other participants \u2014 not to mention our own political parties themselves \u2014 to pounce on this new vector for political messaging and take direct aim at our open political discourse.\n\nDespite these myriad risks, industry professionals seem to have turned a blind eye to the oncoming specter of A.I., likely because they are optimistic about its commercial potential. The leading internet firms are offering free A.I. courses for their brightest engineers; are developing plans to integrate A.I. across their leading brands and products; and are staffing up with brilliant philosophers, ethicists and technocrats to deflect nosy regulators and win over the merchants of information. In his interview with The New York Times last week, Mark Zuckerberg even went so far as to describe A.I. as the antidote that will cure the internet of such negative externalities as hate speech and election interference. What internet firms are not transparent about, though, is the degree to which they plan to integrate A.I. into their principal profit-generating engine: digital advertising.\n\nConsider the scale and complexity of the advertising ecosystem. Global internet firms like Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and Google collectively enjoy billions of active users who on average spend more than two hours on these platforms every day. Each user might be shown hundreds or thousands of digital display ads \u2014 or \u201csponsored\u201d content \u2014 within that time. People in the industry leverage an intricate web of ad agencies, exchanges, networks, demand-side platforms and supply-side platforms to manage the delivery of those ads around the clock.\n\nBut if you could remove those people from the equation, you could quietly turn a $100 billion digital ad industry into a $1 trillion persuasion machine.\n\nTo be clear, algorithms have long been part and parcel of the industry. Organizations like the Russian government and Cambridge Analytica were taking advantage of them simply by virtue of using social media for political communications. But the sharp uptick in industry research and development in A.I. over the past year strongly suggests that this new technology will soon be brought to bear in digital advertising. This will increase the speed of ad mediation, inundating users with content finely tuned to their personal desires. It will abet the seamless and accurate development of \u201clook alike\u201d audiences, enabling advertisers to upload their customer lists and automatically send ads to like-minded people that they do not already know. And it will enable automated contingency-based marketing, allowing clients to programmatically trigger certain kinds of content to be shared in the moments after real world events transpire.", "title": "Opinion | Beware of A.I. in Social Media Advertising", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Now, with their forthcoming report, the Republicans on the committee have turned their focus to attacking the substance of the Mueller investigation.\n\nThe special counsel is examining three core issues: Did Russia attack the 2016 elections to aid Mr. Trump; did Mr. Trump or members of his campaign collude with the Russians to do so; and did Mr. Trump or others obstruct the investigation of these matters? The committee majority report, which has yet to be released but which members of the majority have begun to tease out in recent days, is an attempt to defang the first question, finding against all evidence that the Russian attack was not intended to help Mr. Trump (though a few members of the majority, including Representative Trey Gowdy, have been more equivocal). And the majority report endeavors to gut the second question, declaring the absence of collusion altogether.\n\nIt would be a grave error to think the committee will stop here, especially its chairman. There is nothing in Mr. Nunes\u2019s record to suggest that he will let up in the face of opposition, whether from the stray dissenters within his own (still largely compliant) ranks who have emerged, or from the outside. The so-called \u201cNunes memo,\u201d although widely considered a flop, was just the first in a series that he has said he plans to issue.\n\nHaving assailed the first two prongs of the Mueller investigation, we can now expect Mr. Nunes and his colleagues to turn to the third, and the one perhaps most perilous to the president: obstruction of justice. The president and his supporters have argued that his constitutional power to direct the Justice Department and the F.B.I. and to fire their personnel means he cannot as a matter of law be held accountable for obstructing an investigation. That is wrong; the Supreme Court has held that those presidential powers may be curtailed, and American law is replete with examples of obstruction prosecutions of officials for abusing their undoubted official powers.\n\nMr. Nunes and his committee majority have demonstrated little regard for such niceties, and we fully expect them to weigh in on the side of the president, and against accountability. Should Mr. Mueller move to compel the president to testify by obtaining a grand jury subpoena, for example, look for them to back arguments circulated by Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers that the special counsel has not met the threshold for such a step. The fact that Mr. Mueller has accumulated compelling evidence of obstruction is unlikely to give the committee majority pause.", "title": "Opinion | Beware of Devin Nunes\u2019s Next Move", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe had been aware of the Walker exhibit but hadn\u2019t quite known how to connect,\u201d said Steve Weaver, executive director of the Chicago Public Art Group. On April 7 it is hosting a Terra-supported tour of neighborhood murals by Mr. Walker, as well as by artists including Mitchell Caton, Calvin Jones and Justine DeVan, with a stop at the Hyde Park exhibition. The umbrella of Art Design Chicago helps \u201cadvertise the tour to a citywide audience, even outside Chicago,\u201d Mr. Weaver said.\n\nBarbara Jones-Hogu, a contributor to the Wall of Respect who died in November, has her first ever solo museum exhibition at the DePaul Art Museum through March 25. There\u2019s always got to be the memory of how he had failed to step up when Anita Hill was telling her harassment story, making him both the man who helped give us 25 years of Clarence Thomas on the Supreme Court, and a Judiciary Committee chairman who failed to chide fellow senators for suggesting that having to listen to your boss talk about breasts is no big deal.\n\nSo he threw himself into the subject and told the students how he\u2019d like to be back in high school so he could beat up the \u201cguy who ended up becoming our national leader\u201d for saying he could \u201cgrab a woman anywhere and she likes it.\u201d\n\nIt is not actually a good idea under any circumstances to advocate an assault on the president of the United States, even if you don\u2019t refer to him by name and restrict your threats to stuff that might have happened back in junior year.\n\nAnd Biden couldn\u2019t let it go at that. \u201cI\u2019ve been in a lot of locker rooms my whole life,\u201d he said. A floater in the lane from Rodney Bullock of Providence tied the score, 64-64. A capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden roared. A \u201cLet\u2019s go, Friars\u201d chant resounded.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI love it!\u201d Ed Cooley, the Providence coach, cried, clapping his hands. \u201cI love it.\u201d\n\nThe game went to overtime before the Friars sprinted off the court having handed Xavier only its sixth loss of the season.\n\n\u201cWhat a game, what an atmosphere, what a league,\u201d Cooley said afterward.\n\nThe championship matchup on Saturday between the fifth-seeded Friars and second-seeded Villanova, in front of a capacity crowd for the tournament\u2019s third night in a row, also harkened back to the halcyon years. It got so intense down the stretch that Cooley apparently ripped his trousers. He paced the sideline in the final minutes with a towel draped around his waist.\n\nHe needed several more towels to dab the sweat from his brow. Providence, led by the sophomore Alpha Diallo (22 points) and the senior Kyron Cartwright (19 points), again fought back from a double-digit deficit in the second half to send the game into overtime, the fourth time that has happened in a Big East title game.\n\nBut two 3-pointers by Mikal Bridges (25 points; named tournament\u2019s most outstanding player) in the extra period revived the Wildcats, who held on for a 76-66 victory \u2014 their second consecutive Big East tournament title and third in four years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was easy to forget that the Big Ten Conference had just commandeered the Garden for its conference tournament a week earlier. We\u2019re in good shape. Then again, the three newcomers, Xavier, Butler and Creighton, have been consistent winners.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Ackerman\u2019s mind, so has the league\u2019s partnership with Fox Sports 1, which puts its games on national television, and with Madison Square Garden, a deal that runs through 2026.\n\nAnd for a fledgling league, even a small, somewhat semantical triumph such as being able to maintain the old Big East record books is not insignificant.\n\n\u201cIt seems to be making a difference in terms of the selling of the conference,\u201d she said.\n\nAckerman said the league was content with 10 teams, although Gonzaga, of the West Coast Conference, has been consistently rumored as a candidate to extend the conference\u2019s reach to the opposite coast.\n\n\u201cI think the low number together with the common nature of our schools has been a contributing factor\u201d to the league\u2019s success, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think I could\u2019ve ever envisioned it was this big,\u201d Villanova Coach Jay Wright said.\n\nWright, the most devoted and vocal pitchman for the conference, in either iteration, said what was exciting about the old league were the frequent intraconference matchups between highly ranked opponents. Many thought those days were gone.\n\n\u201cWell,\u201d Wright said, \u201cwe\u2019re doing the same thing now.\u201d\n\nHow to explain it?\n\n\u201cWe were doing O.K.,\u201d Ackerman said. \u201cWe had four teams in the first year,\u201d referring to the N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\n\u201cBut the year that Villanova won, that was the holy grail,\u201d she continued. \u201cThat\u2019s what you dream about. But while engagement is good, there is real opportunity to do much more.\n\nBlackRock could make a reasonable argument that, between customer blowback and the potential for regulatory pressure, it is in the financial interests of everyone in the gun manufacturing and retail chain to reform themselves voluntarily. And if companies don\u2019t take such steps, BlackRock \u2014 and everyone else who owns shares in these companies \u2014 could vote to oust their boards of directors.\n\nBlackRock has enormous influence over both gun makers and retailers. It could pressure them to raise the minimum age for buying AR-15-style rifles to 25 years old, and impose strict screening and background checks that go far beyond what is required by law. BlackRock could even push gun makers to stop producing such weapons altogether.\n\nIt could also recommend that gun manufacturers and retailers make and sell \u201csmart guns\u201d employing technology that allows only the registered owner to use it; that could prevent children from using guns and reduce deaths and injuries related to stolen firearms. (No retailer has ever sold a \u201csmart gun\u201d in the country, in part because of pressure from the gun industry and lobby. Where are you Dick\u2019s and Walmart?)\n\nAt the moment, BlackRock seems to be doing a lighter-touch version of what I described. In its statement on Friday it made a veiled threat: \u201cBased on our engagement conversations and our long-term view of the company, we may vote against specific directors or we may vote against management on shareholder proposals.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBlackRock is a fiduciary so it must make a financial case for such changes \u2014 showing that taking those steps would turn out to be more profitable in the end. It can\u2019t simply press for such action on moral grounds.\n\nBut the evidence is already clear: Remington, America\u2019s oldest gun company, which since the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in 2012 has struggled to access the capital markets or find any buyer, filed for bankruptcy protection just two days before the shooting in Parkland. And retailers are already forcing the issue: Companies like Dick\u2019s, Walmart and Kroger have raised the age for gun purchases on their own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot to mention that consumer boycotts could hurt the bottom line of both gunmakers and retailers that don\u2019t take action on their own.\n\nGunmakers may want to focus more on what\u2019s playing out with REI. The outdoor retailer doesn\u2019t sell guns, but it said it would stop selling Camelbak water pouches and Giro helmets because they are made by Vista Outdoor, which does sell guns.\n\nREI was direct in stating that it was holding Vista accountable for its approach. \u201cThis morning we learned that Vista does not plan to make a public statement that outlines a clear plan of action,\u2019\u2019 it said in a statement last week. \u201cAs a result, we have decided to place a hold on future orders of products that Vista sells through REI while we assess how Vista proceeds.\u201d\n\nIt is not just BlackRock that has an opportunity to use its ownership clout.\n\nGoldman Sachs, for example, took a stake in Cabela\u2019s, the outdoor and firearms retailer \u2014 which sells AR-15\u2019s \u2014 as part of a private equity deal it financed last year when Bass Pro Shops acquired Cabela\u2019s. Why Goldman Sachs, which has had its own share of bad publicity over the years and always talks about being in the business of making sound judgments, would actively participate in a deal for a major gun retailer is baffling. (Several Goldman employees told me there has been a lot of conversations about how embarrassing it is that the firm was involved in the transaction.)\n\nBut now that Goldman is involved, it has a chance to use whatever influence it can muster to bring about reforms. The bank says it has been in touch with Cabela\u2019s management so we\u2019ll have to see what happens next.\n\nOthers are also surveying the landscape.\n\n\u201cWe will be engaging with weapons manufacturers and distributors to seek greater transparency from them on the ways that they will support the safe and responsible use of their products,\u201d State Street, the financial services firm, said in a statement. Vanguard is talking to manufacturers, but it has not taken a public stance.\n\nFor gun-control advocates, any business that invests in gun makers or retailers may seem an anathema. But given the pressure already coming from the outside, the best chance for real change may end up coming from those very same investors.", "title": "Big Investors Have Clout. They Can Use It With Gun Makers.", "authors": ["Andrew Ross Sorkin"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "CHICAGO \u2014 Three years ago, Bruce Rauner, a multimillionaire private equity executive, charged into the governor\u2019s office vowing to use \u201can agenda and a steel backbone\u201d to transform this debt-laden state, where no Republican had been elected to the job in more than a decade.\n\nBut the bold declarations of Mr. Rauner, who arrived pledging to \u201cshake things up,\u201d have wilted some. As he runs for a second term, Mr. Rauner is one of the most vulnerable incumbent governors in the nation, having spent much of his brief political career clashing with Democrats who control the State Legislature over labor unions, taxes, the state\u2019s budget and schools.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not in charge,\u201d the governor said after leaving an Illinois Farm Bureau conference not long ago. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get to be in charge.\u201d\n\nMr. Rauner, 61, who sold himself as an outsider who would bring a businessman\u2019s sensibility to the task of untangling Illinois\u2019s political and fiscal morass, now finds himself fighting for re-election on two dizzying fronts. On the right, Jeanne Ives, a Republican legislator and Army veteran known for her hard-right stances on taxes, immigration and abortion, has forced him into a contested primary on Tuesday. And on the left, a who\u2019s who of Democratic circles wants to take on Mr. Rauner this fall, including J.B. Pritzker, a billionaire heir and entrepreneur; Chris Kennedy, a businessman and son of Robert F. Kennedy; and Daniel Biss, a suburban state senator.", "title": "Big Names and Big Money in Illinois as Governor Faces Challenges on All Sides", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Your rules should revolve around added sweeteners, rather than the natural ones in fruits, vegetables and dairy. It\u2019s not that the added ones are so much worse (despite what you may have heard about high-fructose corn syrup). Many researchers believe that sugar is sugar. But people don\u2019t generally overeat natural sugars. Have you ever inhaled five apples in one sitting?\n\nThe online guide has many more details, but here are a few rules to consider:\n\nFix your breakfast. It\u2019s the most sugar-packed meal, and it doesn\u2019t need to be. Eggs, fruit, nuts, plain yogurt, plain oatmeal and traditional pita bread are delicious \u2014 and free of added sugars. If you\u2019re pressed for time, boil a dozen eggs, refrigerate them and grab one or two in the morning. A sign of a good breakfast plate: It has an array of natural colors.\n\nRedo your pantry. Steer clear of staples \u2014 like sauces, crackers and breads \u2014 with unnecessary sugars. There are plenty of unsweetened alternatives, like Victoria\u2019s pasta sauces, French\u2019s Yellow Mustard, Maille Dijon mustard, Saltines, Triscuits and some Trader Joe\u2019s tortillas. Once you spend a little time reading ingredient lists, the unsweetened staples can become your defaults. Trader Joe\u2019s is an especially good place to shop, but supermarkets work, too.\n\nEliminate soda. Just get rid of it. Soda and sports drinks are essentially liquid sugar, and are the largest source of added sweeteners in the American diet. Switch to flavored seltzer or, if you must, diet soda. The health effects of diet soda still are not clear, but it seems considerably less bad.\n\nWhip portion inflation. Restaurant desserts are often family-size servings marketed as individual portions. The marble-loaf cake at Starbucks, for example, has more sugar than most adults should eat in an entire day. Your grandparents didn\u2019t eat desserts like this. When you eat out, think of every dessert as a serving for two. It\u2019s better to put some in the garbage than on your waistline.\n\nThe best news about sugar is that Americans are finally catching on. Sales of regular soda are plunging. Some food brands are starting to brag about not adding sweeteners. For a long time, we didn\u2019t even realize what Big Sugar was trying to do us. Now we do \u2014 and we can fight back.", "title": "Opinion | Big Sugar Versus Your Body", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Now, less than four years later, the big banks are buoyed by a White House and Congress that sees deregulation as an overarching goal.\n\nThat has helped fuel efforts to relax some post-crisis rules that toughened oversight on all banks, regardless of their size and the risk their stumbles could pose to the financial system. The current push involves one such rule, which requires banks to hold a certain level of capital on their balance sheets based on their total asset size, regardless of how risky those assets are. For instance, cash or customer deposits held at the Federal Reserve are treated the same as riskier assets like subprime mortgages or junk bonds. The rule, known as the supplementary leverage ratio, is aimed at keeping banks from being able to take big risks without properly preparing for a disaster.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Senate bill, sponsored by Mike Crapo, an Idaho Republican, would create a small exemption. As it is currently worded, it would most likely apply to just three banks, all of which take deposits primarily from large asset managers and other banks, rather than Main Street customers, and are known as custody banks.\n\nThe three custody banks \u2014 Bank of New York Mellon, State Street and Northern Trust \u2014 would, when calculating how much capital to hold on their balance sheets, be able to set aside deposits they received from other banks and immediately gave to the Federal Reserve or another central bank for safekeeping.\n\nJennifer Hendricks Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Bank of New York Mellon, said in an email that the exemption was structured in a way that \u201crecognizes the unique business model of the custody banks.\u201d\n\nCitigroup and JPMorgan argue that the exemption is not fair. They say that since they, too, take deposits from other banks and stash them at the Fed, they should get the same relief \u2014 even though that is not the primary focus of their business. Lobbyists for the two banks are hoping to persuade lawmakers to change the bill to allow all banks that accept custodial deposits to take advantage of the exemption, according to people familiar with the banks\u2019 efforts who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss those efforts.\n\n\u201cAs Congress has sought to make a common sense change to the way capital rules treat custody assets, we have asked that they apply that change to all custody banks to maintain a level playing field in this important business,\u201d a Citigroup spokesman said in an email on Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpokesmen from JPMorgan and State Street declined to comment.\n\nWhether the language is broadened or not, the presence of a carve-out has made supporters of the law\u2019s original capital requirement nervous. They say its purpose is to keep banks from convincing regulators that certain products aren\u2019t dangerous when they may ultimately pose a risk.\n\n\u201cThis is not a tweak,\u201d said Sheila C. Bair, former chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. \u201cThis could be a very significant weakening of bank capital rules.\u201d\n\nMs. Bair and others who support keeping capital requirements unchanged for big banks point to lessons from the 2008 crisis that demonstrated how financial panics can change the risk profile of certain kinds of assets. For instance, before the crisis, many banks held securities that appeared safe and backed by highly rated mortgages, but they were actually backed by loans whose borrowers were at risk of default. Synthetic bonds and other similar products that received Triple-A ratings before 2008 became nearly worthless when the panic hit, bringing the country\u2019s financial system to the brink of collapse. The role of the leverage ratio enshrined in Dodd-Frank is to ensure that, next time, such miscalculations are impossible.\n\nPhoto\n\nAaron Klein, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who helped write Dodd-Frank as chief economist for the Senate Banking Committee, said changes to the leverage ratio could create a \u201cslippery slope\u201d in which banks start arguing for more exemptions, effectively blunting the rule\u2019s power. Banks could start arguing that other kinds of assets, like cash and United States Treasury securities, should not count.\n\n\u201cOnce you start picking one thing or another to remove, where does it end?\u201d Mr. Klein said.\n\nThe prospect of a lobbying fight is spooking smaller banks, which have been waiting years for a legislative vehicle that would relax restrictions on them, including requirements that they undergo regular stress tests. The bill\u2019s success hinges on the support of Democrats who may balk at voting for legislation that is seen as helping the industry\u2019s biggest players.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s everyone\u2019s right to lobby for whatever they want to lobby for, but this is a very careful, delicately balanced bill with very solid bipartisan support,\u201d said Paul Merski, the top lobbyist for the Independent Community Bankers of America, a trade association that has pushed hard for the changes central to Mr. Crapo\u2019s bill.\n\n\u201cIf this should fail, then I don\u2019t think the financial sector will have an opportunity to get much relief brought up again in a long time,\u201d he said.\n\nEven if the bill fails, the Fed could ease the burden on banks. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chairman, said in congressional testimony last Tuesday that he favored changing the way the entire leverage ratio is calculated, which would naturally benefit the three custody banks, without making any special exceptions for them.\n\nAn aide to a Democratic senator who supports the legislation insisted that no changes would be made to benefit big banks like Citigroup. But members of the progressive wing of the Democratic Party have already been mounting their resistance to the entire bill.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Warren took to Twitter on Friday and warned that the bill, which she called the \u201cbank lobbyist act,\u201d benefits only big banks and said she was planning a series of public events to decry the legislation.\n\nAnd Senator Sherrod Brown, the Ohio Democrat who sits on the Senate Banking Committee, said in an interview that lawmakers who support the bill were suffering from \u201ccollective amnesia\u201d about the financial crisis.\n\n\u201cDozens of my colleagues think it\u2019s important for banks to make more money,\u201d Mr. Brown said. \u201cThe public is not calling for us to deregulate Wall Street.\u201d", "title": "Big Wall Street Banks See Chance to Weaken Post-Crisis Rule", "authors": ["Emily Flitter", "Kenneth P. Vogel", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 I have spent my entire life pushing for new protected areas in the world\u2019s oceans. But a disturbing trend has convinced me that we\u2019re protecting very little of real importance with our current approach.\n\nFrom Hawaii to Brazil to Britain, the establishment of large marine protected areas, thousands of square miles in size, is on the rise. These areas are set aside by governments to protect fisheries and ecosystems; human activities within them generally are managed or restricted. While these vast expanses of open ocean are important, their protection should not come before coastal waters are secured. But in some cases, that\u2019s what is happening.\n\nNear-shore waters have a greater diversity of species and face more immediate threats from energy extraction, tourism, development, habitat degradation and overfishing. If we leave these places at risk, we\u2019re not really accomplishing the goal of protecting the seas.\n\nAs the United States undertakes an alarming rollback in environmental protections, other countries are making news by safeguarding remote expanses in efforts to meet or even surpass commitments to the United Nations to protect 10 percent of marine areas by 2020. We should not continue applauding countries that are simply drawing a line around relatively empty waters where protections are neither essential nor most effective to meet a target. Instead we need to do the harder work of safeguarding the most threatened regions of the ocean \u2014 the coastlines \u2014 even if they\u2019re smaller.", "title": "Opinion | Bigger Is Not Better for Ocean Conservation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "That may be overly optimistic. Sixteen American states and Puerto Rico have pledged to stick to the commitment that the United States made in the Paris agreement to reduce emissions by at least 26 percent by 2025. Those states are on track to keep their promise.\n\nBut they represent less than a half of the country\u2019s population, and the United States as a country will most likely fall short of its Paris pledge as Mr. Trump dismantles environmental regulations, according to a 2017 study by the Rhodium Group, a private economic research company. And a group led by Michael R. Bloomberg, the United Nations special envoy on climate change, and Gov. Jerry Brown of California, came to the same conclusion in a report that relied on the same data.\n\nThe Paris accord is written in such a way that the United States, in fact, remains in the pact even though it announced its intent to pull out. The actual withdrawal does not happen until 2020.\n\nMr. Guterres is planning a summit meeting next year to goad world leaders to raise their emissions reductions targets. But few countries are even close to meeting the targets they set under the Paris agreement, which was drafted in November and December in 2015, according to independent analyses.\n\nHis warnings came a week after the World Meteorological Organization, a United Nations agency, reported that a barrage of extreme weather events had made 2017 the costliest year on record for such disasters, with an estimated $320 billion in losses.", "title": "Biggest Threat to Humanity? Climate Change, U.N. Chief Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Legal experts said that the standard for removing a judge for a potential conflict of interest was very high, and that judges are normally allowed to decide for themselves whether they can be impartial in a case.\n\n\u201cPennsylvania has long been very clear that a judge decides the recusal issue himself or herself, and that those decisions are not overturned absent a clear abuse of discretion,\u201d said Dennis C. McAndrews, a lawyer in Berwyn, Pa., just outside Montgomery County.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe irony to me is that Judge O\u2019Neill has a reputation as being a total straight shooter,\u201d Mr. McAndrews added. \u201cHe\u2019s done both prosecution and defense work. He\u2019s very experienced.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis is not the first time a defendant has tried to get a judge replaced because of the political activities of his or her spouse. In 2010 and 2011 \u2014 when the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit was hearing a challenge to Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in California \u2014 supporters of Proposition 8 called on Judge Stephen Reinhardt to recuse himself because his wife was the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, which opposed the proposition.\n\nJudge Reinhardt refused to step aside and wrote in a 15-page explanation: \u201cMy wife\u2019s views, public or private, as to any issues that may come before this court, constitutional or otherwise, are of no consequence. She is a strong, independent woman who has long fought for the principle, among others, that women should be evaluated on their own merits and not judged in any way by the deeds or position in life of their husbands (and vice versa).\u201d\n\nStephen Gillers, a professor at New York University School of Law and an expert on legal ethics, said that standard prevailed in the judicial system. It has been applied even at the United States Supreme Court, where Justice Clarence Thomas has sometimes been urged to \u2014 and declined to \u2014 recuse himself from cases that involve issues on which his wife is politically active.\n\n\u201cWe do not attribute the ideological views of a spouse to a judge,\u201d Mr. Gillers said. \u201cWe trust judges to make decisions based on the law, and not because their husbands or wives would like to see a particular result. We trust judges to be independent of the influence of good friends, of parents, of spouses, and decide on the law.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are certain situations in which recusal is warranted, Mr. Gillers said: if the judge\u2019s spouse is a lawyer in the case, for example, or a member of a law firm that would benefit from a particular decision. But \u201cif it\u2019s pure ideology, if it\u2019s pure public policy, positions on a controversial issue, that is insufficient to warrant recusal,\u201d he said.\n\nJudge O\u2019Neill has served on the bench in Montgomery County since 2002, when he was appointed by Gov. Mark S. Schweiker, a Republican.\n\nHe presided over Mr. Cosby\u2019s original trial, which ended with a hung jury in June. Since then, the landscape of sexual assault cases has changed profoundly with the advent of the #MeToo movement in October \u2014 a shift that could have implications for Mr. Cosby.\n\nIn the past week, Judge O\u2019Neill has made two major decisions in the case that complicated matters for Mr. Cosby\u2019s defense team. Last week, he ruled that five accusers could testify in addition to Ms. Constand. And on Monday, he denied Mr. Cosby\u2019s request to delay the retrial, scheduled to begin in early April, for 90 days. Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers had argued that they needed more time to prepare for the additional witnesses.", "title": "Bill Cosby Wants to Replace Judge in His New Assault Trial", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers said they are going to argue the encounter happened before the end of December 2003. O\u2019Neill of the Montgomery County Court of Common Pleas ultimately rejected the motion to dismiss and said the issue should be addressed at trial.\n\n\u201cThis is a matter that will be determined by the jury ultimately,\u201d said the judge, who also presided last year when Mr. Cosby\u2019s first trial ended with a hung jury.\n\nThe ruling came on the first of two days of pretrial hearings in the case in which Ms. Constand \u2014 who worked for the women\u2019s basketball program at Temple University, Mr. Cosby\u2019s alma mater \u2014 has accused Mr. Cosby of assaulting her at his suburban home near here.\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers also asked the judge to dismiss the case because, they said, prosecutors had failed to properly investigate claims made by another potential witness, Marguerite Jackson, a student adviser at Temple.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Jackson said that years ago Ms. Constand had told her that she had been drugged and assaulted by a famous person, then later said it had not happened, but that making the allegation could result in a valuable lawsuit settlement.\n\nMs. Constand testified last year at trial that she did not know Ms. Jackson, and Judge O\u2019Neill then blocked Ms. Jackson from testifying, asserting her evidence was hearsay.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers suggested Monday that they had evidence the two women did know each other and argued that investigators should have delved more deeply into their relationship.\n\n\u201cThey would have seen that this woman has obvious credibility,\u201d Kathleen Bliss, one of Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers, said of Ms. Jackson.\n\nThe Montgomery County district attorney, Kevin R. Prosecutors say the additional women helped to bolster Ms. Constand\u2019s credibility and establish that Mr. Cosby was a predator with a signature method of assaulting women.\n\n\u201cIt is needed to counter the defense\u2019s inevitable attacks on Ms. Constand\u2019s credibility,\u201d said Adrienne Jappe, an assistant district attorney.\n\n\u201cIt happens 19 times before Ms Constand, it\u2019s not an accident.\u201d\n\nProsecutors had tried to admit 13 other women to the case last year, but Judge O\u2019Neil admitted only one. He never disclosed his reasoning.", "title": "Bill Cosby\u2019s Retrial Proceeds as Judge Rejects Motions to Dismiss", "authors": ["Graham Bowley"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The title is a reference to his early years ascending a fashion ladder invisible and disreputable to his stern Catholic family. On one page of the manuscript, he drew a little doodle of a young Bill ascending a ladder, and added a line attributed in the book to his mother: \u201cWhat will the neighbors say?\u201d\n\nThe book chronicles his dress-mad childhood, service in the Korean War (during which he decorated his helmet with flowers), a move to New York, success as the ladies milliner \u201cWilliam J.\u201d and his beginnings as a journalist. It is also the poignant portrait of a boy growing up in a \u201clace-curtain Irish suburb of Boston\u201d whose passions do not necessarily align with the expectations for him.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a crime families don\u2019t understand how their children are oriented, and point them along their natural way,\u201d Mr. Cunningham wrote in an early chapter. \u201cMy poor family was probably scared to death by all these crazy ideas I had, and so they fought my direction every inch of the way.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout this familial disapproval Mr. Cunningham is blunt but not rancorous.\n\n\u201cThere I was, 4 years old, decked out in my sister\u2019s prettiest dress,\u201d reads the memoir\u2019s second sentence. \u201cWomen\u2019s clothes were always much more stimulating to my imagination. That summer day, in 1933, as my back was pinned to the dining room wall, my eyes spattering tears all over the pink organdy full-skirted dress, my mother beat the hell out of me, and threatened every bone in my uninhibited body if I wore girls\u2019 clothes again.\u201d\n\nThough Mr. Cunningham lived to see greater acceptance, he became modest and effacing in his self-presentation, usually wearing a French sanitation worker\u2019s blue jacket and khakis to capture the more flamboyant citizens of New York. He submitted reluctantly to a 2010 documentary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt feels like he had internalized that reaction,\u201d Mr. Richards said of the disapprovals of his childhood. \u201cIt\u2019s speculation to think of why he decided not to publish this in his lifetime, but my assumption, having spent a lot of time with the text, is because though he really wanted to tell the story of this special period in his life, his education in creativity and style, at the same time he was worried how people were going to respond.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut aside from some scenes of family discord, Mr. Cunningham\u2019s memoir is a rosy account of an irrepressible dreamer who tripped his way from the stockroom of Boston\u2019s newly opened Bonwit Teller to hat shops of his own in New York. He arrives in the city in November 1948 on opening night of the opera \u2014 then a tent pole of the New York social calendar \u2014 and stays long after the Social Register stopped being anyone\u2019s bible.\n\nMuch of the material is new, even to his relatives. \u201cBill kept his family life in Boston and his work life in New York very separate,\u201d wrote his niece Trish Simonson, in an email. \u201cHe told us stories over the years, but nothing that painted a full picture of what he did and how he came to do it. The drafts of the memoir we found, titled and edited and written in his own unmistakable voice, filled in a lot of blanks of how he made it from here to there, and what he thought along the way.\u201d\n\nThere is some gossip, mostly decades old (the columnist Eugenia Sheppard does not come off very well), but little about Mr. Cunningham\u2019s personal life, other than sly asides.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a preface commissioned by Mr. Richards, Hilton Als, a writer for The New Yorker, remarks on the \u201cBreakfast at Tiffany\u2019s\u201d flavor of Mr. Cunningham\u2019s reminiscences. The photographer tells of subsisting in lean years on jars of Ovaltine, three spoonfuls a day, feasting on the sight of Madison Avenue shop windows instead.\n\nIn an industry where the right invitation is all, Mr. Cunningham didn\u2019t wait for one, pedaling from street corner to show to benefit on the bicycle he had occasionally had to pawn when low on hatmaking supplies. \u201cGate-crashing was part of my self-education in fashion,\u201d he wrote. When he boldly asks to rent a space for his first shop above Hattie Carnegie\u2019s store, a saleswoman sends him to go see the proprietress \u2014 and gives him the address of the Bellevue mental hospital.\n\n\u201cBill was a true original,\u201d Mr. Richards said. \u201cFor me, this book is really for those of us who came to New York with a dream and saw New York City as a real oasis of creativity and freedom, a place to be who we want to be. It\u2019s a really beautiful story about a young, artistic man finding his way in the city, in a particular kind of bohemian world that doesn\u2019t quite exist anymore.\u201d\n\nPublication is planned for September \u2014 just in time for New York Fashion Week.", "title": "Bill Cunningham Left Behind a Secret Memoir", "authors": ["Matthew Schneier"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA lot of people have been like, \u2018So, yeah, this show is really dark,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Hader said in a recent phone interview. \u201cThey\u2019re like, \u2018Huh. What happened to you, man?\u2019 Oh come on, it\u2019s not that dark. Other than people getting killed, come on.\u201d\n\nMr. Hader spoke about the therapeutic value of acting class and how he reconciled his distaste for guns and violence with the subject of the show. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nHow did you, Bill Hader, end up playing a professional assassin?\n\nI have this development deal with HBO. I had to turn a script in, and I had no ideas. Alec Berg and I have the same agents, so they said, you should meet up with Alec. We chatted about one idea for about a month and a half. And then one day, we both realized that the idea sucked. [laughs]\n\nWhat was that idea?\n\nIt was me, basically, playing a guy I went to high school with. A very weird portrait of a very specific Oklahoma dude. The stakes in the show were like, oh, no, the neighbor has the same coffee table as my character \u2014 what\u2019s he going to do? The shows I like are ones that have a real propulsive narrative. I was like, \u201cThe stakes should be death.\u201d Alec was like, well, that\u2019s funny. I said, \u201cSo what if I played a hit man? It\u2019s him as a hit man.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow was that suggestion received?\n\nAlec said, \u201cUgh, I hate the word hit man \u2014 the whole cool guy with two .45\u2019s in his hand, shooting in slow motion.\u201d I was like, no, it\u2019ll be more like a Travis Bickle character. The lonely guy who moonlights as a hit man, even though he knows it\u2019s wrong. Him taking an acting class \u2014 I don\u2019t know where that came from. Just from Alec going, \u201cHim taking an acting class is funny.\u201d And I was like, \u201cO.K.\u201d\n\nActors have huge aspirations, and over-dramatize minor setbacks. Does that make them funny?\n\nIn my life, I\u2019m probably that person. Acting classes are like group therapy. Actors are over-sharers. They will immediately tell a stranger the worst thing that ever happened to them. And if Barry did that, he would implicate himself, and they\u2019d all have to be killed. It was this darkly funny conundrum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDid you have to learn how to handle firearms for this role?\n\nI didn\u2019t enjoy any of that. It\u2019s funny because I grew up in Tulsa, where it\u2019s like the minute you\u2019re born, they plop a gun in your lap, before they even cut the umbilical cord. We were very conscious that we didn\u2019t want the violence to be funny or cool. It should be shown for what it is, which is really ugly, so you would understand why he wouldn\u2019t want to be in that world anymore. What complicates it is that he\u2019s really good at it. So I had to learn how to quickly load machine guns and stuff. You can see, in the behind-the-scenes videos, I couldn\u2019t do it. What you see in the show are like the two times I did it right.\n\nAmong the cast, Henry Winkler stands out as the self-infatuated coach of Barry\u2019s acting troupe. What inspired you to cast him?\n\nIn the pilot, he really has to yell at Sarah Goldberg. He did it a couple of times, and I said, \u201cHenry, don\u2019t worry about the words \u2014 just go at her.\u201d And he pulled me aside and said, \u201cOh, I\u2019m playing an [expletive]. Aha. O.K.\u201d Henry\u2019s the nicest person in the world. He studied at Yale and with Stella Adler, and he gave us a lot of insight into the hubris of those acting teachers. He knows, in this theater, you\u2019re a god, but the minute you step out, you\u2019re just an out-of-work actor.\n\nYou\u2019re slated to host \u201cS.N.L.\u201d on March 17. What\u2019s it like when you come back?\n\nThe best part of it is seeing everybody. But the down side of it is, as a cast member, you know how much of the show is on the host\u2019s shoulders. You\u2019re in a meeting, like, \u201cI don\u2019t think you should do this with me.\u201d When I was there, guys like Tom Hanks would come in and be like, \u201cWhere do you want me?\u201d That\u2019s a good lesson. Preplanning too much stuff never works. What\u2019s exciting \u2014 and terrifying \u2014 is no matter what you do, it\u2019s going to be what it\u2019s going to be.", "title": "Bill Hader Kills With More Than Just Kindness on His New HBO Show", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff", "A Word With"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Bill Simmons Media Group and its president, Eric Weinberger, \u201cmutually agreed\u201d to part ways two weeks ago, according to a statement released Tuesday by a company spokesman.\n\nThe announcement comes three months after Weinberger was suspended and placed on indefinite leave following the filing of a lawsuit by a former NFL Network wardrobe stylist that claimed Weinberger had groped her and sent her lewd text messages, including nude pictures of himself.\n\nWeinberger, a former NFL Network executive, left the league-owned media company in 2015 to become president of the Bill Simmons Media Group. He has yet to respond publicly to the allegations set forth in the lawsuit. He did not respond to messages seeking comment on Tuesday.\n\nWhen announcing Weinberger\u2019s suspension in December, a Bill Simmons Media Group spokesman said the company was conducting an \u201cinternal investigation\u201d of his behavior. The spokesman declined to comment Tuesday on whether the investigation had been completed, or what it found.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Bill Simmons Media Group, founded by Bill Simmons after ESPN announced in 2015 that it had decided not to extend his contract, in 2015, publishes The Ringer, a sports and culture website, and produces podcasts and documentaries.\n\nThe wardrobe stylist, Jami Cantor, sued the NFL Network in December.
