Ms. Piper says it \u201cis enough to send anyone mad. The biological clock is a thing! To say that there aren\u2019t periods in my life where I\u2019m governed by my hormones would be a lie and if that makes me \u2018antifeminist\u2019 then I guess I am. Because that\u2019s my experience of my body.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Piper, the play also resonates because it isn\u2019t just about the particular hell of in vitro fertilization. \u201cIt\u2019s also about a relationship burning out, the pressure of the modern world on a relationship,\u201d she said. Currently, Ms. Piper is seeing Johnny Lloyd, the former frontman of Tribes. But when the show opened in 2016, she had just gotten divorced from the actor Laurence Fox, the father of her sons, Winston, 9, and Eugene, 5. Was that something she was drawing on?\n\n\u201cThere will be things that happen in your life that inform the decisions you make as an actor,\u201d she said. \u201cSomething will connect. But once you put an audience in front of it, you hand it over.\u201d\n\nIn Britain, however, Ms. Piper\u2019s private life has often been the story. She grew up in Swindon, in the south of England, and moved to London when she was only 12, to go to stage school. By 15, she was a pop star, and in 1998 became the youngest artist ever to debut at No. 1 on the British charts, with the bratty single \u201cBecause We Want To.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not a real musician,\u201d she now concludes, frankly. \u201cIt\u2019s a hard industry, and in the \u201990s, you worked inappropriate hours. I was so young, I just burnt out really quickly.\u201d\n\nUnsurprisingly, perhaps, the #MeToo campaign has rung bells. \u201cThere were definitely areas I found challenging \u2014 nothing criminal, just an overall energy. We were winning awards for being sexy teenagers. I became quite cynical about it quite quickly.\u201d\n\nHer first marriage, at 18, to the radio D.J. Chris Evans, also made headlines, thanks to a 16-year age gap. But around the time of their separation in 2004, Ms. Piper\u2019s career regenerated: She was cast as the companion Rose in the BBC\u2019s rebooted \u201cDoctor Who.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt came out of the blue, that opportunity, and it was an amazing one,\u201d Ms. Piper said. It\u2019s a role she\u2019ll never quite shake. Today, she meets teenagers named after Rose, though unthinkingly adding a rose emoji to an Instagram post recently sent the internet into a tizzy, with fans predicting a \u201cDoctor Who\u201d comeback \u2014 a rumor she\u2019s quick to scotch.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore recently, Ms. Piper has made a reputation for herself as one of Britain\u2019s finest stage actors, in Lucy Prebble\u2019s \u201cThe Effect,\u201d and Richard Bean\u2019s phone hacking scandal satire \u201cGreat Britain.\u201d\n\n\u201cPeople look at someone who\u2019s willing to be naked in their soul,\u201d Mr. Stone said of watching her perform. \u201cYerma\u201d is set in a glass box, which helps. \u201cBut I use glass walls a lot, and I\u2019ve never had an actor that was so willing to go so warts and all \u2014 that\u2019s her great beauty.\u201d\n\nMs. Piper is also in David Hare\u2019s crime thriller \u201cCollateral,\u201d now on Netflix. \u201cThat was a great female part, because she\u2019s wild,\u201d Ms. Piper said of her role as a spiky young mother with a drug habit. But she points out that, too often, film and TV roles for women are just boring.\n\nThis frustration led to Ms. Piper\u2019s latest reinvention: as a writer. She\u2019s written her own film, due to shoot this year, as well as having a TV series in the pipeline. Both are dark comedies, both about women in their 30s; both will star Ms. Piper.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe movie, \u201cRare Beasts,\u201d is about \u201cwhat it really feels like to be a modern woman moving through female emancipation, and how that affects our relationships with men,\u201d she said. \u201cWhat happens if this movement divides men and women?\u201d\n\nThe TV series will center on a woman who\u2019s been hacked and has her private life exposed, but it also looks more broadly at the pressures of being a woman her age. Ms. Piper had noticed friends questioning their lives, asking \u201cwhat have I not achieved and where\u2019s my family and will I ever own a home and what\u2019s my mental health like?\u201d\n\nIt is written with Ms. Prebble, who became a close friend after they met working on the TV series \u201cSecret Diary of a Call Girl\u201d in 2007. \u201cWe\u2019re like sisters,\u201d Ms. Piper said, cracking her wide, irresistible smile.\n\nMs. Prebble was equally effusive. \u201cI love her,\u201d she said emphatically. \u201cWhen my life fell apart a couple of years ago she took me into her home. In your 30s as a woman it feels like everything has to break or survive. And the people who are there, the people who show up, are the women.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTheir shared creative preoccupations \u2014 the fragility of relationships, the gap between men and women, the failure of life\u2019s promises as we age \u2014 all chime with those Mr. Stone found within \u201cYerma.\u201d And that may be another reason Ms. Piper is so keen to return to this exceptional role, readily admitting, \u201cI\u2019m still not over it.\u201d", "title": "Billie Piper Hasn\u2019t Looked Back Since She Left the Tardis", "authors": ["Holly Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Some signs are subtle, like the \u201cWhole Foods + Amazon\u201d one near the bananas. Others are more obvious, like the kiosk with Amazon devices for sale.\n\nIt has been six months since Amazon took over Whole Foods, a $13.4 billion deal that made the internet retailer a major player in the world of brick-and-mortar retailing. For the most part, the 470 stores are still the same upscale, expensive healthy food emporiums that they have always been.\n\nAmazon has grander ambitions as well. The company\u2019s executives are busy devising ways to connect its Prime membership program, which offers benefits like fast and free shipping and video streaming, with the stores.", "title": "Bit by Bit, Whole Foods Gets an Amazon Touch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Somehow a few days before the arrival of one set of bureaucrats, the smoke from the Georgia-Pacific facility decreases and the air smells better. After the meeting, the noxious plumes reappear.\n\nGovernment spokespeople, the Koch brothers and the supervisors of Georgia-Pacific dispute the directors\u2019 argument and evidence. Yet \u201cCompany Town\u201d mounts a passionate protest on behalf of overlooked victims of corporate negligence and greed.\n\nBy putting into play the words \u201crace\u201d and \u201ccancer,\u201d the film motivated me to ponder the impact of race on cancer outcomes nationally \u2014 and therefore disentangled from local ecological factors. The big picture is grim.\n\nA 2016 report of the American Cancer Society states that the \u201cfive-year relative survival is lower for blacks than whites for most cancers at each stage of diagnosis.\u201d African-American men, for example, are twice as likely to die from prostate cancer. Experts continue to debate why, even as many ascribe this scandalous phenomenon to inequalities in access to screening and treatment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn women\u2019s cancer, the mortality gap has widened. According to the 2016-18 report on Cancer Facts and Figures for African-Americans, \u201cdespite lower incidence rates for breast and uterine cancers, black women have death rates for these cancers that are 42 percent and 92 percent higher, respectively, than white women.\u201d Investigators connect the ghastly numbers to the usual socioeconomic discrepancies but also to biological differences in the malignancies of black women.\n\nWith regard to breast cancer, is the mortality gap related to a greater percentage of black women than white women contending with an aggressive form of the disease that lacks estrogen receptors?\n\nDr. Otis Webb Brawley, the chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society, rejects an explanation based on \u201cbiological difference,\u201d pointing instead to dietary disparities.\n\nDisadvantaged Americans consume more calories and carbohydrates, \u201cthe sort of food that is available in poor areas of inner cities,\u201d Dr. Brawley writes in his book \u201cHow We Do Harm.\u201d Greater body weight means African-American girls menstruate earlier and the number of uninterrupted menstrual cycles increases the risk of breast cancer: \u201cThe black-white gap in the onset of menstruation and body weight has dramatically widened, which means that the disease disparities will widen also.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Brawley quotes an all-white study in Scotland that \u201cfound evidence pointing to a correlation between social deprivation and incidence of breast cancer that lacks estrogen receptors.\u201d In addition, he cites the insight of his friend Dr. Samuel Broder, a former director of the National Cancer Institute: \u201cPoverty is a carcinogen.\u201d\n\nGiven the mortality discrepancies, it is disturbing that African-Americans are underrepresented as subjects in cancer research, as are other minorities. According to research by Dr. Narjust Duma of the Mayo Clinic, only 6 percent of participants in clinical trials are black, although African-Americans make up approximately 12 percent of the population; Hispanics amount to 3 percent of participants, although they make up about 15 percent of the population.\n\n\u201cIf our government doesn\u2019t fix this,\u201d one protester in \u201cCompany Town\u201d says, \u201cthen I don\u2019t know what kind of government they are.\u201d If we don\u2019t fix this, I chime in, what sort of people are we?", "title": "Black Cancer Matters", "authors": ["Susan Gubar", "Living With Cancer"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, stories about the everyday beauty of being a little human being of color are scarce. Regardless of what the publishing industry seems to think, our babies don\u2019t spend their days thinking about Harriet Tubman, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and black bodies swinging; they\u2019re excited about what the tooth fairy will leave under their pillows, contemplating their first ride on the school bus, looking for dragons in their closets.\n\nThey want to read books that engage with their everyday experiences, featuring characters who look like them. Just like any other child. White children, too, deserve \u2014 and need \u2014 to see black characters that revel in the same human experiences that they do.\n\nReal diversity would celebrate the mundane \u2014 like a little kid going out after a snowstorm \u2014 rather than the exceptional.\n\nOne of my first books, \u201cEarly Sunday Morning,\u201d about a little girl overcoming her jitters as she prepares to sing her first choir solo, was roundly rejected by editors when I pitched it back in 2003. They just couldn\u2019t connect with the black-family-getting-ready-for-church ritual that starts on Saturday. They didn\u2019t get how black Baptist church communities devote themselves to nurturing children in ways beyond the Bible.\n\nAnd I have to presume that they couldn\u2019t see past skin color to embrace the story\u2019s lesson: Pushing past fear is hard, but, with the help of family, you can learn to be courageous. It\u2019s a universal lesson for all little humans, no matter their race.\n\nAll this led me to create my own children\u2019s book imprint. We published \u201cEarly Sunday Morning\u201d last year, and many of the black parents and children who are buying it now have told me they are grateful for the story.\n\nI\u2019ve been grateful for a number of recent books, including Vanessa Brantley-Newton\u2019s \u201cGrandma\u2019s Purse,\u201d and Bunmi Laditan\u2019s \u201cThe Big Bed.\u201d Everyone can relate to the subjects here \u2014 the magical bond between children and grandparents, and a pushy kid\u2019s takeover of the parental bed. Color is of no consequence to the stories, but it still matters to black children looking for themselves in the pages.\n\nThe success of these books proves that parents, teachers, librarians and children are craving stories that celebrate the humanity and everyday experiences of black children and families. There is a demand \u2014 just look at the excitement around the new movies \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d both starring black characters \u2014 even if some in the industry have struggled to recognize it.", "title": "Opinion | Black Kids Don\u2019t Want to Read About Harriet Tubman All the Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Last summer, Shawnna Graham fired up Netflix in her Williamsburg, Va., home and looked for her grandfather\u2019s name in the closing credits of \u201cMarvel\u2019s Luke Cage.\u201d It was nowhere to be found.\n\n\n\nIt was a surprise. After all, the Harlem-based comic book artist Billy Graham had worked on the first 17 issues of \u201cLuke Cage, Hero for Hire,\u201d and even had a hand in writing a few of them. He\u2019d been the only African-American person working on what was the first African-American superhero comic book series.\n\nIn fact, he was the only African-American person working for Marvel, period.\n\n\u201cI thought, maybe this was missed only because he had passed, and no one was thinking of his contribution,\u201d Ms. Graham said. When she began seeing ads for the film adaptation of Black Panther, the character her grandfather drew after finishing work on Luke Cage, she prevailed upon her father, Mardine, to pull out what they called \u201cthe Treasure Chest.\u201d It consisted of a steamer trunk, a portfolio, a briefcase and boxes of artwork that they had retrieved from her grandfather\u2019s 143rd Street apartment after he died in 1997. She started taking pictures, and opening social media accounts \u201cto bring Billy\u2019s name and legacy from the shadows.\u201d", "title": "Black Panther, Luke Cage and the First Black Artist to Draw Both", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Meredith, playing the role of understanding gal pal, installs Grindr and Tinder on Niru\u2019s cellphone. Of course the boy loses the phone, and the secret comes out. The ensuing confrontation with his father is violent and heartbreaking: \u201cAre you really telling me the truth, that you are going out and gallivanting with the gays, the homosexuals? Where did you learn this kind of behavior? Is it in school? Is this what they are teaching you?\u201d\n\nNot long ago, in his column for New York magazine, Andrew Sullivan wrote that \u201cthe radicalization of the movement\u2019s ideology and rhetoric\u201d is to blame for \u201ca retrenchment in comfort with gay equality.\u201d Iweala gives the lie to this claim elegantly; some people just hate homosexuality, no matter how much they love their children.\n\nNiru\u2019s mother is a cosmopolitan daughter of privilege, now a physician; his father is a \u201ctrue village boy\u201d who climbed his way to corporate success and American comfort. Upon discovering their son\u2019s secret, they turn to faith. \u201cIt sometimes seems that every African living in the D.C. area goes to this church, Nigerians, Ghanaians, Cameroonians, Congolese. Some work for embassies. Some are taxi drivers. Some are illegal, but they are all truly welcome.\u201d Well, not quite all. Niru\u2019s father takes him to his boyhood home in Nigeria, where they visit still another church.\n\nThis intercession, existing in the realm of the spiritual, seems less pernicious than it actually is; it\u2019s not religion but psychological torture, and it occasions a kind of break in the narrator\u2019s psyche. His parents replace his smartphone with Bible verses. \u201cI take the cards \u2014 Genesis 4:7, Luke 5:32, First Corinthians 6:18 \u2014 and put them in my pocket without looking at them. I have a stack on a shelf in my closet. They remind me of all the things I should do.\u201d It\u2019s not Niru who is closeted any longer; it\u2019s his parents\u2019 God.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNiru\u2019s homosexuality is very much the book\u2019s subject, and the text is interested in dualities \u2014 Americans and Africans, white and black, gay and straight, devout and skeptic, the black immigrant and the black American (a role filled by Damien, a college student with whom our hero has a sweet, chaste fling) \u2014 while always returning to the question of what his gayness says about who Niru is.\n\nIweala writes with such ease about adolescents and adolescence that \u201cSpeak No Evil\u201d could well be a young adult novel. At the same time he toys with other well-defined forms: the immigrant novel, the gay coming-of-age novel, the novel of being black in America. The resulting book is a hybrid of all these.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf he\u2019s something of a remix artist, Iweala remains faithful to the conventions of these forms, a writer so adept that the book\u2019s climax feels both surprising and wholly inevitable. Its concluding third is narrated by Meredith, not Niru, a strategy that should feel clunky but doesn\u2019t. As with \u201cBeasts of No Nation,\u201d Iweala resists offering the reader much in the way of closure or even insight, as though to suggest that\u2019s the reader\u2019s job, not his.\n\nA writer cannot be judged for his project, only its execution. Uzodinma Iweala is a fine and confident novelist. Genre is a useful thing when organizing texts in a bookshop, but immaterial to the particular exchange between writer and reader.\n\nForm ossifies into genre through repetition. Eventually readers \u2014 and writers are of course readers themselves \u2014 understand that stories about immigrants function in a certain way, that stories about gayness require a moral reckoning, that stories about blackness require the sacrifice of the black body. For all the interest among readers in creating a literature that reflects its readership, so-called \u201cdiverse books,\u201d there are times that \u201cdiverse book\u201d seems itself a genre, bound by convention and largely a matter of the identity of a writer who is different from the thousand or so writers we believe to be the canon.\n\nIn his smart exploration of generational conflict, of what it is to be a gay man, of the crisis of existence as a black man, Iweala is very much a realist. Perhaps the trouble is my own wish that reality itself were different.", "title": "Black, Gay and Losing Faith", "authors": ["Rumaan Alam", "Uzodinma Iweala"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "In 2007, several large bombs were planted along the route Mr. Abbas was about to use to attend a meeting with a Hamas leader in Gaza. The bombs were discovered, Mr. Abbas aborted the meeting, and he has not returned to Gaza since, Mr. Rumley said.\n\nThe relatively limited damage caused by the bomb on Tuesday gave rise to considerable speculation among analysts and officials in Gaza and beyond about who, beside Hamas, might have had reason to set off the device \u2014 either as an authentic assassination attempt or, perhaps, to send a message.\n\nIn Gaza\u2019s complex political and factional thicket there was no shortage of other potential suspects: Salafi jihadists, who of late have attacked Hamas about as much as they have attacked Israel; allies of Muhammad Dahlan, the exiled Fatah leader who is reviled by Mr. Abbas but widely seen as a potential successor to him; and the Palestinian Authority itself \u2014 an embarrassing security lapse could bolster its case that Hamas ought to turn over security control in Gaza to the authority.\n\nIndeed, within hours of the attack and Mr. Hamdallah\u2019s return to the West Bank, Palestinian Authority officials were making precisely that argument in local media coverage.\n\nLater, in Washington, Jason Greenblatt, the president\u2019s Middle East envoy, drew a similar conclusion in opening remarks at the White House meeting. \u201cThis attack, once again, demonstrates that Hamas is profoundly unfit to govern Gaza,\u201d Mr. Greenblatt said.\n\nAt the blast site in Beit Hanoun, a few hundred yards from the Erez crossing from Israel, windows were shattered in nearby buildings and witnesses reported that a security officer in Mr. Hamdallah\u2019s motorcade had been lightly wounded in the face. Investigators at the scene said that the explosive device was planted next to a streetlight and that a second bomb, powered by 9-volt batteries, was found nearby, less than a foot underground.\n\nThe police said that security personnel escorting Mr. Hamdallah had shot at four men on two motorcycles who were seen in the area before the blast, and then arrested them as suspects.", "title": "Blast Hits Palestinian Prime Minister\u2019s Convoy in Gaza", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "It was only when they got out that they noticed Firefighter Davidson was not with them. Other firefighters went looking for him in desperation.\n\nHe was found above the cellar, on the same level as the jazz club where the film shoot had taken place, the city official said. He had apparently run out of air \u2014 when he was found, his mask was off. The official said he may have removed it instinctively when his air supply ran out. Firefighter Davidson also had burns on his legs.\n\nHe was taken to Harlem Hospital, where he died of his injuries.\n\nFirefighter Davidson, 37, left behind a wife and four young children. He was a 15-year veteran of the department and he came from a family of firefighters. His father was one, as was a brother and at least one cousin.\n\nTwo other firefighters were injured as well; one remained hospitalized on Friday afternoon.\n\nTwo separate inquiries are underway. One, which might take a year, will examine procedures and decision-making, and will provide a step-by-step account of the fatal fire. The second will focus on the cause and origin of the fire. As of Thursday night, there were several feet of water in the cellar that promised to slow down the second inquiry. But there was no immediate indication, a city official said, that any of the electronics associated with the movie shoot had played a role in the ignition.\n\nThe filming of \u201cMotherless Brooklyn\u201d had, until Thursday night, been a source of amusement, curiosity, and minor frustration for the neighborhood.", "title": "Blaze Erupts Beneath a Movie Set in Harlem, and a Firefighter Dies Rushing In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "TORONTO \u2014 A day into the season it became clear that one of the hardest jobs in Major League Baseball this year will be divided among whatever pitchers are facing the Yankees\u2019 lineup.\n\nOn Thursday the duty fell to J.A. Happ and a host of relievers for the Toronto Blue Jays. The group expended 172 pitches and untold quantities of mental energy navigating through one of the most feared lineups in recent years.\n\nWith much of the American League looking on from afar to gauge the extent of the damage the Yankee lineup is capable of, the Blue Jays were unable to ease any of their concern. Giancarlo Stanton delivered the most damage, hitting two home runs and added a run-scoring double in his remarkable Yankee debut.\n\nGary Sanchez added a run-scoring double and Aaron Judge singled, doubled and scored a run. Even the leadoff batter, Brett Gardner, joined in with a home run as the Yankees rapped out 11 hits to beat the Blue Jays, 6-1, on opening day.", "title": "Blue Jays Pitchers Run Into a Pinstriped Buzz Saw", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "In 2016, Mr. Trump tapped into similar suspicions, particularly among white men who were crushed by the financial crisis and are clinging to jobs that are being transformed by technology and global competition. He narrowly won Montgomery County, in greater Dayton, the first Republican to do so since 1988.\n\nAnd Republicans will need those voters to return in the fall if they are to maintain control of Congress.\n\nThe increase in take-home pay for Mr. Kazee was near the top among those for the more than two dozen workers interviewed \u2014 at the tavern, the lumberyard, a machine shop, a restaurant and a municipal building \u2014 about how the tax cut has affected them. Mr. Trump often spoke of how the average worker would receive $2,000 or more, but most workers said they did not expect anything close to that.\n\n\u201cIn the blue-collar world, it is about looking to get a little bit more at the end of the week,\u201d said Shandy Cossell, who was seated near Mr. Kazee at Slyder\u2019s, where every stool at the bar was filled, mostly with men who work with their hands. The dark wood and neon signs suggested another era in a place where blue-collar workers have been coming since Harry Truman was president.\n\nSeveral said they were most concerned about the rising cost of health care, and others questioned whether getting more money now would mean paying more later.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe economy in the Dayton area, where the median household income is about $46,000, was crushed by the financial crisis, and manufacturing was hit particularly hard. In January 2010, the unemployment rate was 13.2 percent. It has dropped steadily since and is about 4.6 percent today.\n\nBut the improved numbers do not tell the whole story. A major General Motors plant in Moraine closed in 2008, eliminating about 2,000 jobs. A Chinese-owned auto glass company has replaced it, with roughly the same number of jobs, but at half the pay.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat kind of downward mobility affected smaller machine shops and general manufacturing, depressing wages and fueling the sense of grievance and resentment that led to Mr. Trump\u2019s rise. \u201cI think there needs to be a little more shame in the world,\u201d Mr. Cossell said.\n\nRob Wright, a strong supporter of Mr. Trump who works in a machine shop, said that the 30 additional dollars he is seeing in his paycheck is \u201c30 a week that the government isn\u2019t seeing.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a little extra money I can count on,\u201d he shrugged. \u201cIt\u2019s not going to change my life.\u201d\n\nFor others at his machine shop, he said, \u201cIt\u2019s a couple gallons of milk and loaves of bread to feed their kids.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt Requarth Lumber, on the edge of downtown, Matt Higgins paused after moving a load of wood onto a forklift. He said he backed Mr. Trump \u201conly because I don\u2019t trust Hillary.\u201d The change in his paycheck is modest and difficult to calculate because his hours fluctuate, he said, but he knows one thing: \u201cIt\u2019s definitely not going to change my life.\u201d\n\nOne of his younger co-workers, Mr. Barkalow, was more skeptical than thankful. He said he was concerned that he would end up owing more taxes next year. He noticed a small increase in his check. \u201cIt\u2019s about gas money, but that\u2019s about it,\u201d said Mr. Barkalow, who did not vote for Mr. Trump.\n\nAt Insignia, the sign company where Mr. Cossell works, Brandon Eifert helped him apply a banner to a Warped Wing Brewing Company truck. Mr. Eifert said he was anxious that a tax cut now might mean that he would not get a refund next year. \u201cIs the tax break just giving you the money now instead of later?\u201d he asked.\n\n\u201cI used my taxes as a forced savings,\u201d he said. When he received a refund, he would use the money to \u201cgo on a trip or buy something.\u201d He estimated that the additional cash might be gas for a week, but it was not enough to take his girlfriend to a nice dinner.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen asked which candidate he supported in 2016, Mr. Eifert said, \u201cRegretfully now, I voted for Trump.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said the president\u2019s manner, more than his policies, put him off and he would not vote for him again. \u201cIt\u2019s somewhat embarrassing to hear how he talks, tacky and uneducated.\u201d\n\nHis colleague April Sakach said she was thrilled with the extra $30 to $40 in her paycheck. \u201cFor me, every little penny counts,\u201d she said.\n\nBut it will not change her opposition to the president. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make me like him any more,\u201d she said. \u201cHe just needs to do more to get me on his side. And I don\u2019t know that he has it in him to do it.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cI get speaking your mind, but you are the face of America, and you can\u2019t do the things that he\u2019s doing. It makes us look like a joke.\u201d\n\nA few miles to the south, at Paradigm Industrial, a small-job machining and welding shop, the effect on personal finances appeared to be similar. Dan Neff said his wife paid the bills in the family, and she noticed an increase \u201cright off.\u201d\n\nIt amounted to about $6 a week.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s lunch money,\u201d he said. \u201cStill, it is moving in the right direction.\u201d\n\nHe voted for the president and said he supported Mr. Trump \u201cto the greatest degree.\u201d\n\nHis co-worker, Dan Marker, was not so sure.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s always nice to get a few more dollars in the pocket,\u201d Mr. Marker said. But, he added, \u201cprobably my bigger concern here is that if Washington cuts taxes, fine, what services are they going to do without?\u201d\n\nBack at Slyder\u2019s, Al Yarcho, 63, who has been retired for five years, is not a beneficiary of the tax cut, but he expressed worry about its consequences for the nation\u2019s finances and entitlement programs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI just know this,\u201d Mr. Yarcho said. \u201cWhen you cut revenue, you either have to find new revenue streams or you have to cut expenses. They\u2019ve covered all the cuts. How are you going to pay for it?\u201d", "title": "Blue-Collar Trump Voters Are Shrugging at Their Tax Cuts", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The Huggins oeuvre is the essence of the man himself: brief, to the point, technical, adaptable, unfussy and, beneath it all, quite generous.\n\nWhile serving as an undergraduate manager for Fordham\u2019s basketball team, Zak Boisvert discovered Huggins\u2019s literary output. He immediately ordered a four-pack.\n\n\u201cWhen I was first getting into coaching, they were absolute gold,\u201d said Boisvert, who is now an assistant coach at Army.\n\nOne book explained to Boisvert a crucial defensive principle: that if a defense forced the ballhandler to one side of the floor and then rotated to deny passes back to the top of halfcourt, the court essentially shrank, giving the defenders a huge advantage, since they had less open space to cover.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe standard coach\u2019s book is co-written or ghostwritten and covers an abstract and more broadly applicable concept such as leadership. There are Tony Dungy\u2019s \u201cPrinciples, Practices and Priorities of a Winning Life\u201d and Urban Meyer\u2019s \u201cLessons in Leadership and Life From a Championship Program,\u201d for instance.\n\nHuggins has produced his obligatory coaching memoir (1995\u2019s \u201cPressed for Success\u201d), but his other books have titles like \u201cSet Plays to Score,\u201d \u201cPress Breakers\u201d and \u201cMotion Offense: The Principles of the Five-Man Open Post.\u201d\n\nIf other coaches\u2019 books are the equivalent of slick pinstripe suits, Huggins\u2019s are like those plain pullovers he famously wears to games. \u201cAs far as I\u2019m aware, there aren\u2019t any coaches who have produced the same amount of books,\u201d Trevor McLean, a former youth coach in Australia who now runs the Basketball for Coaches website, said in an email.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHuggins wrote the books himself, often while flying Comair, a now-defunct Midwest regional airline, to and from games and recruiting visits while at Cincinnati. His style is spare and technical. There are diagrams and occasional flourishes of whimsy that reveal Huggins\u2019s roots in the Ohio River Valley and his identity as a true basketball nerd.\n\nFrom \u201cFast Break\u201d:\n\nEd McClusky (who I feel may be the greatest coach of all time) told me many years ago that every time the ball was passed he was looking for a mismatch or an advantage for the offense.\n\nFrom \u201cCoaching the Matchup Press\u201d:\n\nIf our opponent has a distinct size advantage, we may adjust our press so that once the ball is entering the offensive half-court area of the floor, it is necessary for them to flash their big people up to the top of the circle or high on the wings to relieve the pressure we are applying to the guards. Again, this strategy will make them play to their weakness and away from their strength.\n\nFrom \u201cSpecial Situations\u201d:\n\nIn the last five years at the University of Cincinnati, we have played 88 games decided by 10 points or less. We have averaged six games a year that have come down to a single possession of the basketball! How many of your games next year will be decided by a few possessions? Will you have prepared your team to play with relaxed confidence when those opportunities arise?\n\nTheir overarching philosophy, which can be seen in West Virginia\u2019s aggressive full-court defenses (which have earned the program the nickname Press Virginia) as well as their acuity at offensive rebounding, is deceptively simple: Give your team as many chances to score as possible, and your opponent as few.\n\nHuggins traces most of his basketball philosophy to his father, Charlie, a longtime Ohio high school basketball coach, and his father\u2019s mentor, the aforementioned western Pennsylvania high school coach named Ed McClusky.\n\nHuggins\u2019s father and McClusky both ran what was then a rare form of the motion offense \u2014 in basketball terms a 1-1-3. \u201cI\u2019m not saying they invented it, but they were one of the few doing it,\u201d Huggins said.\n\nAt first, Huggins self-published the books, but soon he connected with Coaches Choice, a house in Monterey, Calif., that specializes in such books. It is run by Jim Peterson, who helped write the former San Francisco 49ers coach Bill Walsh\u2019s celebrated book, \u201cFinding the Winning Edge,\u201d a favorite of football coaching geeks.\n\nTechnical football books are more popular than technical basketball ones, Peterson said. \u201cBasketball coaches, they want you to write a book on how to recruit another seven-footer,\u201d he said. Coaches Choice sells a few hundred copies of Huggins\u2019s books every year, primarily through Amazon.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe gets $250, $300 every six months from us, and has for 20 years,\u201d Peterson said. (Huggins\u2019s base salary is $3.75 million, per USA Today\u2019s database.)\n\n\u201cThey sold better at Cincinnati,\u201d Peterson added, \u201cbecause he actually tried to sell them.\u201d\n\nJerry Krause, Gonzaga\u2019s director of men\u2019s basketball operations (and a fellow Coaches Choice author), praised the Huggins collection for its emphasis on motivation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cEverybody that writes has some tactics and strategy,\u201d Krause said. \u201cI don\u2019t think his are better than any other coach\u2019s. But the thing that he is the best at is getting players to play hard and getting them to play hard on defense, and second, getting them to play unselfishly together. It\u2019s laced through his books that if you can get kids to play hard and play together, the X\u2019s and O\u2019s will take care of themselves.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimilarly, Army\u2019s Boisvert said that for all the technical acumen Huggins delivers, the larger theme is adaptability.\n\n\u201cHe has one about the press he ran at Cincinnati,\u201d Boisvert said. \u201cBut the one he does at West Virginia is so different. And that speaks to: The great ones, they change.\u201d\n\nThere is an obvious risk to Huggins\u2019s writing down all his basketball thoughts: giving the opposition your game plan. There is a famous scene in one of Huggins\u2019s favorite movies, \u201cPatton,\u201d in which Gen. George S. Patton Jr. sniffs out his foe Erwin Rommel\u2019s battle plan by poring over one of his books. \u201cRommel, you magnificent bastard, I read your book!\u201d Patton declaims as his tanks decimate the German army. Huggins said he rewatches \u201cPatton\u201d about once every three months.\n\nHuggins\u2019s father used to fear demonstrating his plays in front of coaches whom he would later play, Huggins said.\n\n\u201cThat was a different era,\u201d Huggins said. \u201cIn my era, we were on television more than Homer Simpson. People saw it. It wasn\u2019t some secret.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cPatton\u201d scene that sticks with him, he added, is when Patton, who believed people came back to life in new bodies, visits the site of an ancient battle and tells an aide that he was there.\n\n\u201cI like when he talks about reincarnation,\u201d Huggins said. \u201cHow he\u2019s seen the battle before.\u201d", "title": "Bob Huggins Is March\u2019s Author-in-Residence", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think they are much cooler, much more simple and caring about things that matter, meaning family, work,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cI think it\u2019s not about the big giant handbag, not about the designer. It\u2019s not about a cream that promises you endless possibilities. Honestly, I think that the young girls are more simple and they just want the truth. They don\u2019t want, like, marketing-speak. They don\u2019t want gobbledygook.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cSatisfaction\u201d riff sounded; Ms. Brown let the call go to voice mail. She recalled early in her career, doing a shoot with the photographer Annie Leibovitz. She shut the dressing room door. Then a stylist reopened it. \u201cAs I\u2019m cleaning up, I look in the mirror and I\u2019m with the Rolling Stones in their underwear,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cAll of them!\u201d\n\nYears later she became friends with a girlfriend of Mr. Jagger, the fashion designer L\u2019Wren Scott who had asked her and the hairdresser Sam McKnight to work on one of her last fashion shows in London. (Ms. Scott committed suicide in 2014.) \u201cShe was so kind to me,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cOnce she invited me to this amazing dinner with Mick and Ron Wood and Daphne Guinness. One by one all these people would show up. Bryan Ferry.\u201d\n\nThe next season, she and Mr. Plofker were invited to a dinner party at Mr. Jagger\u2019s house. \u201cI\u2019ll never forget, we were wondering what are we going to bring them for a gift \u2014 what do you give Mick Jagger?\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cSo Steven bought him a bottle of wine and a Coravin. They said to come at 7 so we came at 7, rang the doorbell. It was only Mick, home alone. L\u2019Wren had to run out for something, and they showed us up to the study \u2014 \u2018Oh, Bobbi, Steven! How are you?\u2019 And I\u2019ll never forget, he\u2019s like, \u2018Oh my God! I can\u2019t believe you bought me a bottle, it\u2019s amazing!\u2019 He loved the Coravin and we sat there like a half-hour, talking with Mick. So there have been so many of those kind of cool situations in my life because of makeup.\u201d\n\nAnother happened when the musician Patti Scialfa hired Ms. Brown to do her makeup for the 12/12 concert to raise money for Hurricane Sandy. Nicely.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nShortly after I moved to Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn, before I\u2019d had a chance to go to a supermarket, I stopped by my local bodega to pick up breakfast.\n\nIt was a flawless Sunday in the middle of October. The air was crisp and the sun was strong. My hunger nearly matched my appreciation for the day, for the city, for finally being out of my parents\u2019 home.\n\nThere was a woman ahead of me at the deli counter. She ordered French toast.\n\n\u201cWhat kind of cheese would you like on that?\u201d the man behind the counter asked. He looked a little like a young John Turturro, gangly, with dark, frizzy hair\n\n\u201cCheese?\u201d the woman said. \u201cThere\u2019s no cheese on French toast.\u201d\n\n\u201cO.K.,\u201d he said. \u201cNo cheese.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe turned to get to work, and I exchanged a skeptical glance with the woman.\n\n\u201cAre you sure you know what you\u2019re doing?\u201d she asked.\n\n\u201cYeah, yeah,\u201d the counterman said.\n\nShe was unconvinced. The memo called for \u201cAll hands on deck.\u201d\n\nWannaCry is a particularly vicious form of what is known as ransomware \u2014 malware that locks up victims\u2019 computers and data with encryption, until attackers\u2019 extortion demands are met, often in the form of the virtual currency Bitcoin. Even for victims who agree to pay, decryption is not always guaranteed. The City of Atlanta was hit with a different form of ransomware last week and was still reeling from the fallout on Wednesday.", "title": "Boeing Possibly Hit by \u2018WannaCry\u2019 Malware Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "ABUJA, Nigeria \u2014 Boko Haram militants have killed at least 11 people, including three aid workers, in an attack on a military base near a camp for displaced people in the northeastern state of Borno in Nigeria, according to the United Nations migration agency.\n\nThe raid Thursday night in the town of Rann, near the border with Cameroon, was the latest high-profile attack by militants in Nigeria\u2019s northeast, and it comes less than two weeks after the abduction of 110 girls from a school in the town of Dapchi in neighboring Yobe State.\n\nThe United Nations agency, the International Organization for Migration, said the attack had been carried out by militants using automatic weapons, rocket-propelled grenades and gun trucks. The three aid workers who were killed were all Nigerian, the agency said.\n\nFour soldiers and four police officers were also killed in the attack, the agency said, with three other humanitarian workers wounded.", "title": "Boko Haram Militants Kill Aid Workers at Military Base in Nigeria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "DAKAR, Senegal \u2014 Dozens of schoolgirls from the northern Nigerian community of Dapchi were returned early Wednesday morning, dropped off by the same group of Boko Haram militants who kidnapped them more than a month ago as they offered a stern warning to never go back to school again.\n\nThe surprising turn of events was greeted with joy from parents whose daughters were safely returned, but the relief was tempered by suspicions that several girls had died while in the hands of the militants. At least one is apparently still being held.\n\nJauro Usman, a resident of Dapchi who is close to many of the parents of the kidnapped girls, said those who had been reunited were \u201cvery, very happy.\u201d\n\n\u201cBoko Haram came themselves and dropped our daughters,\u201d he said.\n\nThe return of the girls might wind up as a major propaganda coup for Boko Haram as villagers had been outraged at the way Nigerian officials had handled the girls\u2019 capture, and some questioned why the military did not launch a rescue operation.", "title": "Boko Haram Returns Dozens of Schoolgirls Kidnapped in Nigeria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Fatima Bukar, 14, was in her dorm near to the school fence when she heard gunshots. \u201cWe weren\u2019t sure where it was coming from,\u201d she said. \u201cWe were confused.\u201d\n\nOne girl ran toward Fatima and her friends, telling them to flee for their lives because Boko Haram had arrived. Fatima said she saw girls being led outside the school gate and into militants\u2019 trucks; she recognized many friends among them.\n\n\u201cThey were saying if you run we will shoot you,\u201d she said. \u201cThey were shooting into the air.\u201d\n\nFatima bolted over the fence and ran through the bush, thinking that because the area had no road, the militants would be less likely to chase her. She fled with about 30 girls and a teacher who led them to a farm, where the group spent the night, too terrified to fall asleep.\n\nAt his home not far from the school, Fatima\u2019s father, Auwal Bukar, was panicking. He had crouched in his house when he heard gunshots. He peeked outside later and saw trucks packed with girls. It was dark, but their sobs were unmistakable.\n\n\u201cWe could hear them crying very clearly,\u201d he said.\n\nAs the trucks headed outside town, witnesses said, some of the girls appeared to be tied up with their own clothing. They heard the screams as the vehicles sped away.\n\nAfterward, an eerie silence fell over the area. Not long after, many of the girls who had been hiding in the bush started to trickle back to the school. But tallying the missing was complicated. Some girls, like Fatima, spent the entire night in the countryside, too terrified to return. Some fled straight to their family farms, far from the reach of cellular networks. Hours after the kidnapping, school officials found girls still hiding in toilets, classrooms and other buildings on the campus.", "title": "Boko Haram\u2019s Seizure of 110 Girls Taunts Nigeria, and Its Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The world\u2019s largest known listeria outbreak has spread throughout South Africa for 15 months, killing 189 people. Health officials believe they have identified the source: bologna.\n\nSince January last year, 982 confirmed cases of listeriosis had been recorded, the National Institute for Communicable Diseases in South Africa reported on Thursday. The infection, caused by food that has been contaminated with the bacterium Listeria monocytogenes, is often lethal.\n\nA cluster of gastroenteritis cases among toddlers in a Johannesburg hospital this January led authorities to the sandwich meat in a day care center\u2019s refrigerator \u2014 and in turn, to a meat production facility in the northern city of Polokwane. There, officials said they detected traces of LST6, the listeria strain identified in 91 percent of the outbreak\u2019s cases.\n\nThe South African meat processor, Enterprise Foods, issued a recall of some of its processed products in early March. Food safety experts at the World Health Organization plan to review the company\u2019s exports to 15 countries across Africa, many of which lack reliable disease surveillance systems and diagnostic tools. Namibia recently reported one listeriosis case; its link to South Africa\u2019s outbreak is uncertain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTiger Brands, the parent company of Enterprise Foods, did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nThe highly processed meat, locally called \u201cpolony,\u201d is known for its fluorescent artificial color. It is often consumed in low-income communities and sold by street vendors, making distribution difficult to track.", "title": "Bologna Blamed in Worst Listeria Outbreak in History", "authors": ["Emily Baumgaertner", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "His mistreatment of underlings was so legendary \u2014 one claimed that he had thrown objects \u2014 that I once dubbed him the Naomi Campbell of the Bush administration.\n\nBy far the best thing about the Trump campaign was watching many of those culpable for the Iraq war go ballistic trying to stop the neophyte, who kept pointing out that Americans had been deceived into the historic debacle with Iraq. He even went where no one else had dared to go and correctly pointed out that W. and his administration had dropped the ball before 9/11.\n\nBill Kristol, Eliot Cohen, Robert Kagan and Max Boot, all of whom pushed to \u201cliberate\u201d Iraq, denounced Trump, saying he would be a foreign policy disaster. Kagan and Boot said they would vote for Hillary Clinton.\n\nAfter lukewarm support for the invasion, Trump often criticized W. on Iraq. \u201cNo matter how long we stay in Iraq, no matter how many soldiers we send, the day we leave, the meanest, most vicious, most brilliant man in the country, a man who makes Saddam Hussein look like a baby, will take over and spit on the American flag,\u201d he told me in 2006. \u201cBush will go down as the worst and by far the dumbest president in history.\u201d\n\nTrump was a Hillary supporter in those days and said that although her vote to authorize the Iraq war was \u201chorrendous,\u201d she should be forgiven because \u201cthat decision was based on lies given to her.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s very smart and has a major chance to be our next president,\u201d he told me.\n\nIn 2013, Trump tweeted: \u201cAll former Bush administration officials should have zero standing on Syria. Iraq was a waste of blood & treasure.\u201d\n\nWhen he ran for president against Jeb Bush, he continued attacking W. and presenting himself as a noninterventionist, focus-on-America candidate.", "title": "Opinion | Bolt the Oval Against Bolton", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe data and modeling Bolton\u2019s PAC received was derived from the Facebook data,\u201d said Christopher Wylie, a data expert who was part of the team that founded Cambridge Analytica. \u201cWe definitely told them about how we were doing it. We talked about it in conference calls, in meetings.\u201d\n\nCambridge Analytica, which rose to prominence through its work with Mr. Trump\u2019s 2016 election campaign, has found itself confronting a deepening crisis since reports this past weekend in The New York Times and The Observer of London that the firm had harvested the data from more than 50 million Facebook profiles in its bid to develop techniques for predicting the behavior of individual American voters.\n\nCambridge\u2019s so-called psychographic modeling techniques, which were built in part with the data harvested from Facebook, underpinned its work for Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign in 2016, setting off a furious \u2014 and still unsettled \u2014 debate about whether the firm\u2019s technology worked. The same techniques were also the focus of its work for Mr. Bolton\u2019s super PAC.\n\n\u201cThe Bolton PAC was obsessed with how America was becoming limp wristed and spineless and it wanted research and messaging for national security issues,\u201d Mr. Wylie said.\n\n\u201cThat really meant making people more militaristic in their worldview,\u201d he added. \u201cThat\u2019s what they said they wanted, anyway.\u201d\n\nUsing the psychographic models, Cambridge helped design concepts for advertisements for candidates supported by Mr. Bolton\u2019s PAC, including the 2014 campaign of Thom Tillis, the Republican senator from North Carolina, according to Mr. Wylie and another former employee, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid being dragged into the investigations that now appear to be engulfing Cambridge.\n\nOne advertisement, a video that was posted on YouTube, was aimed at people who scored high for conscientiousness, and were thought to respect hard work and experience. It emphasized Mr. Bolton\u2019s time working for Ronald Reagan and how Mr. Tillis embodied the spirit and political ethos of the late president.\n\nBeyond their conservative politics, Mr. Trump, Mr. Bolton and Cambridge Analytica all share a patron \u2014 the Mercer family of Long Island, whose patriarch, Robert L. Mercer, made a fortune at the helm of a top-yielding hedge fund.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCambridge Analytica, which grew out of the London-based SCL Group, was founded in 2014 with a $15 million investment from Mr. Mercer, whose daughter Rebekah sits on the firm\u2019s board of directors. Stephen K. Bannon was also a co-founder.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Mercer was financially supporting Mr. Bolton\u2019s PAC, donating $5 million between April 2014 and September 2016, according to Federal Election Commission filings. The Mercers also backed Mr. Trump in the presidential election.\n\nThe Mercer family has not publicly commented since the reports about the misuse of Facebook data by Cambridge first surfaced in The Times and The Observer.\n\nThe reports have prompted calls from lawmakers in Britain and the United States for renewed scrutiny of Facebook, and at least two American state prosecutors have said they are looking into the misuse of data by Cambridge Analytica.\n\nThe company also suspended its chief executive, Alexander Nix, after a television broadcast this week in which he was recorded suggesting that the company had used seduction and bribery to entrap politicians and influence foreign elections.\n\nBut it is the harvesting of Facebook data that has cast the harshest spotlight on Cambridge, and Mr. Bolton\u2019s experience with the company appears to have provided a model for how it sold itself to future political campaigns, including Mr. Trump\u2019s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe firm took the psychographic profiles it was building off the Facebook data at the time and combined them with voter databases and other sets of data. Staff from SCL\u2019s elections division, which through a convoluted corporate structure was interchangeable with Cambridge, discussed what they were doing at a meeting in July 2014 with another contractor for the Bolton PAC, according to an agenda of the meeting obtained by The Times.\n\nThe profiles would be used to \u201cidentify the personality traits of individuals\u201d in states to be targeted by the Bolton PAC, said the agenda, which was prepared for SCL and Cambridge staff. \u201cIndividuals can be targeted with the right message,\u201d it said.\n\nThe agenda also included a line, in boldfaced text, that said SCL wanted to use voter contact lists available to Bolton\u2019s campaign to direct people \u201ctoward the FB app.\u201d Cambridge, working through an outside researcher, used a Facebook app to harvest data from the social network\u2019s profiles. The app claimed to be collecting data for academic research, and users were not aware of its true purpose.\n\nMonths later, the relationship between Cambridge and the Bolton PAC had grown so close that the firm was writing up talking points for Mr. Bolton. In an email dated Oct. 1, 2014, Cambridge staff outlined a few sentences that Mr. Bolton could use to describe the work the new firm was doing for his super PAC.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just about how much you spend. It\u2019s also about how smart you spend,\u201d the email advised Mr. Bolton to say.\n\n\u201cOne way we\u2019re doing that is by enlisting an outside firm\u201d \u2014 Cambridge Analytica \u2014 \u201cto provide deepdive research into who makes up our audience of target voters,\u201d it continued. \u201cWe are producing ads specifically designed for voters of a certain personality and demographic profile. So if you\u2019re a young woman in New Hampshire with a specific kind of personality and a particular set of issues that you care about, our research allows us to connect with that voter in a way that truly resonates with her.\u201d\n\nThe subject line of the email: \u201cDid Bannon come back to you on this?\u201d", "title": "Bolton Was Early Beneficiary of Cambridge Analytica\u2019s Facebook Data", "authors": ["Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Chooses Hawk for 3rd Security Adviser as Shake-Up Continues\u201d (front page, March 23):\n\nThe Trump administration has transitioned from the merely inept to the patently terrifying. The appointment of John Bolton as national security adviser places him next to the hand that has access to the nuclear button.\n\nMr. Bolton is the hawk extraordinaire, with a total disdain for accomplishing anything through negotiation. He was an important cog of the George W. Bush team that prosecuted the Iraq war in 2003 and remains adamant that it was the right policy long after even its most ardent proponents distanced themselves from that misadventure.\n\nHe has advocated military pressure against both Iran and North Korea. His attitudes kept him from the position of secretary of state under Mr. Bush when it was made clear to the president that he could not be confirmed.\n\nNow, in his emeritus years, Mr. Bolton has been given one last chance to pursue his extreme ideology, but this time with proximity to the one person who could make it reality. At best, this could mean additional ill-advised deployments of ever greater numbers of American troops. At worst \u2026 well, who wants to consider that?", "title": "Opinion | Bolton the Hawk Gets His Chance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "On the volatile Billboard album chart these days, one week you can be No. 1, and the next you drop to No. 169.\n\nCase in point: Bon Jovi\u2019s \u201cThis House Is Not for Sale.\u201d The album, which came out almost a year and a half ago, returned from oblivion last week to reach No. 1, thanks to a deal that bundled the CD with the cost of concert tickets for Bon Jovi\u2019s latest tour.\n\nSuch deals have become the music industry\u2019s favorite new sales gimmick, used by everyone from Metallica and Arcade Fire to Pink. And since chart positions are now computed by looking at both sales and streams \u2014 with sales of full albums given the most weight by far \u2014 a well-timed ticket bundle can be a quick path to No. 1. This practice has raised concerns, but Nielsen denies any chart manipulation.\n\nBon Jovi\u2019s 168-spot plunge, however, is the biggest drop for a No. 1 album in the six-decade history of the chart, according to Billboard. (The previous record-holder was the emo band Brand New, whose album \u201cScience Fiction\u201d fell 96 spots last September.)", "title": "Bon Jovi Falls a Record 168 Spots as \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Is No. 1 Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 U2\u2019s frontman, Bono, said this weekend he was \u201cfurious\u201d after a charity he co-founded was rocked by newly revived accusations that it had fostered an atmosphere of bullying, abuse and, in one case, attempted sexual coercion in its Johannesburg operation.\n\nBono apologized to the former employees of the charity, ONE, who have detailed on social media and in a British newspaper what they said was demoralizing treatment by managers at their office in the South African city from late 2011 to 2015.\n\nHe said the charity, which aims to \u201cend extreme poverty and preventable disease, particularly in Africa,\u201d had failed to protect the workers.\n\n\u201cI need to take some responsibility for that,\u201d Bono said in a statement issued on Saturday and published by The Mail on Sunday. \u201cWe are all deeply sorry. Gandhi, among others.\n\nPublished by the Pegasus imprint of B. Jain Publishing Group of India, the book came under fire this month after the Simon Wiesenthal Center, a global human rights organization researching the Holocaust and hate in historical and contemporary contexts, called the decision to include Hitler an \u201cabomination.\u201d\n\nIn a statement released this week, Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate director of the center, hailed the removal of the 48-page book from the publisher\u2019s online store, where it was sold for about $1.70.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe children of this great nation should be reading \u2018The Diary of Anne Frank,\u2019 \u201d he said, \u201cnot a picture book that lists Hitler as a \u2018great\u2019 leader alongside Gandhi, Mandela, Modi, Churchill and Obama.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnnshu Juneja, the publishing manager for Pegasus, did not respond to a question by email about why the book had been taken off the website. College.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nHow did we baby boomers mess up? Let me count the ways.", "title": "Opinion | Boomers, Millennials and Generation Z", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Asked why Moscow would feel it could carry out such an attack, Mr. Johnson said: \u201cIt was a sign that President Putin, or the Russian state, wanted to give to potential defectors in their own agencies that this is what happens to you if you decide that you support a country with a different set of values such as our own: You can expect to be assassinated.\n\n\u201cI think the reason that they picked the United Kingdom is very simple: It\u2019s because this is a country that does have that particular set of values, it does believe in freedom and in democracy and in the rule of law, and has time and again called out Russia over its abuses of those values.\u201d\n\nMr. Johnson\u2019s remarks drew anger in Moscow, where Maria Zakharova, the Foreign Ministry\u2019s spokeswoman, said in a statement: \u201cThere isn\u2019t the slightest doubt now that all of London\u2019s actions in terms of Russia are aimed at creating an image of an enemy. Even the most absurd tools are used to do that.\n\nShe added: \u201cIf there is no clarity with the poisoning of the Skripals, it is clear what happened with Boris Johnson: he was poisoned by the hatred and anger, unprofessionalism and, therefore, rudeness.\u201d\n\nEarlier on Wednesday, the ministry took the extraordinary step of summoning representatives from every foreign diplomatic mission in Moscow to hear a long, public diatribe \u2014 the latest attempt to rebut British accusations that Russia used a weapons-grade nerve agent in the poisoning in Salisbury, England.\n\nSpeaking in a stiff, scolding tone, Vladimir Yermakov, the head of the ministry\u2019s department of arms control and nonproliferation, called the attack on the Skripals a terrorist act that could have been staged by the British government to discredit Russia.\n\n\u201cEither the British authorities are unable to protect against a terrorist attack on their territory or staged the attack against the Russian citizen themselves, directly or otherwise,\u201d Mr. Yermakov told dozens of foreign envoys during the two-hour meeting, which was broadcast live on Russian state television. \u201cAll facts are being intentionally hidden, and the real evidence may have already disappeared.\u201d", "title": "Boris Johnson, Top U.K. Diplomat, Likens Russia World Cup to \u201936 Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The first step was making sake at home, said Mr. Polen, and \u201cit was better than we expected it to be,\u201d especially the sakes made by Mr. Doughan. He had both a rigorous science background and 20 years of home-brewing experience, including experimentation with soy sauce, which is also made with a type of koji.\n\nMr. Doughan moved to Brooklyn in 2016, and last September they started outfitting their soaring space in the Industry City warehouse complex in Sunset Park. (Kura refers to a warehouse where products like sake are traditionally made.) Their fellow tenants now share the roasted-chestnut-and-mushroom perfume of Aspergillus oryzae, or koji, growing on steamed, polished rice.\n\nThough it has the alcohol content of wine, sake is brewed more like a beer: Rice implanted with koji mold is slowly mixed with yeast, water and more steamed rice, then fermented for several weeks. It\u2019s usually pressed to remove most but not all of the solids, after which it can be aged or filtered further.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe heart of the monthlong process is culturing the koji, Mr. Doughan said. It\u2019s a multiday, labor-intensive undertaking that begins when he shakes flakes of mold over mini-mountains of washed and steamed rice grown specifically for sake-making.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Doughan and Mr. Polen plan to start with more traditional sake styles \u2014 still new to most Americans \u2014 using their taproom to highlight how they\u2019re made. There, they serve shiboritate, or freshly pressed sake, and orizake, a pre-pressed sake still cloudy and creamy with microscopic particles of rice. They even let customers buy a clay mug of moromi, a thick, tart drink with still-discernible grains straight from the fermenting tank. (Mr. Doughan eventually plans to also make more experimental styles, he said, citing the dry-hopped sake made by Setting Sun Sake Brewing Co. in San Diego.)\n\nJohn Gauntner, the Tokyo sake educator who is considered one of the foremost English-language experts on the drink, appreciates their initial focus on the basics. Brooklyn Kura\u2019s sake was \u201cvery, very good,\u201d he wrote in an email, but he was \u201cmost impressed that the brewer there wants to get his process down first, reproducibility, and then work on tweaking it to make it better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThough Mr. Polen attended Mr. Gauntner\u2019s sommelier seminars, Mr. Doughan is mainly self-taught, with previously unavailable help from YouTube videos and WhatsApp discussions with Japanese brewers. He also served a weeklong internship at a traditional brewery in Japan, and a short stint at the 21-year-old SakeOne brewery in Oregon.\n\nOther brewers around the country have been following their own paths, and Brooklyn Kura likely won\u2019t be the sole sake maker here for long. A company called SakeBrooklyn is working to find a space by the beginning of next year, and the Japanese producer Asahi Shuzo will soon break ground on a large-scale brewery in Hyde Park, N.Y. near the Culinary Institute of America, which will work with them to develop a sake education program.\n\nIt\u2019s all evidence of the drink\u2019s growing presence in the United States, said Timothy Sullivan, a sake educator and a founder of the new American Sake Association. The group will officially incorporate later this year with the aim of linking brewers, buyers, sommeliers and others in the industry.\n\nStronger connections are good news for Mr. Doughan. \u201cThe first thing I learned about sake brewing,\u201d he said, \u201cis I\u2019ll be learning about it for the rest of my life.\u201d\n\nBrooklyn Kura, 68 34th Street (Third Avenue), Sunset Park, Brooklyn; 347-766-1601; brooklynkura.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Born in Japan, and Now Made in Brooklyn: Sake", "authors": ["Rachel Wharton"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "During the administration of President Barack Obama, attorneys general from Republican states developed a powerful tool: They teamed up dozens of times to sue the federal government to block environmental initiatives.\n\nNow, Democrats are using the same playbook to fight the Trump administration.\n\nBlue-state attorneys general have filed more than two dozen environmental lawsuits against the Trump administration since January 2017, and the victories are piling up. This month, a court said the Environmental Protection Agency had broken the law by delaying smog protections. In February, states forced the Department of Energy to enact efficiency standards for household appliances. And in two different decisions in the past year, courts thwarted the administration\u2019s attempts to delay regulations on emissions by the oil and gas industry.\n\nThe rise of state attorneys general as partisan warriors against presidential administrations is a relatively new phenomenon, according to some who served in more amicable days. \u201cUp until 1999, the attorneys general were very nonpartisan,\u201d said Grant Woods, a former Arizona attorney general and a Republican. For instance, Republicans and Democrats in the 1990s teamed up to sue the tobacco industry over the health effects of its products and the burdens cigarette smoking placed on state Medicaid budgets.\n\nMr. Woods recalled that, when pursuing such cases with fellow state attorneys general, he was not even sure of some colleagues\u2019 party affiliations. \u201cToday everyone has it branded on their forehead, like a scarlet letter,\u201d he said.", "title": "Borrowing G.O.P. Playbook, Democratic States Sue the Government and Rack Up Wins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Boston Symphony announced Friday that four women who worked for the orchestra in the 1980s and 1990s had given its investigators credible accounts of sexual misconduct at the hands of Charles Dutoit, a frequent guest conductor.\n\nThe orchestra severed its ties with Mr. Dutoit in December, after The Associated Press reported accusations that he had sexually assaulted several women elsewhere. Boston opened an independent investigation into Mr. Dutoit after Fiona Allan, a prominent figure in British theater, accused him of having sexually assaulted her in 1997 when she was as an intern at Tanglewood, the orchestra\u2019s summer home in the Berkshires.\n\nThe orchestra said in a statement that its investigator had determined that Ms. Allan\u2019s accusations were credible. It said that the investigator had also spoken with three other women who \u201ccredibly described incidents in the 1980s and 1990s in which they, too, were victims of sexual misconduct by Mr. Dutoit.\u201d It did not provide any details about the other women.\n\nMr. Dutoit, 81, denied wrongdoing in December, issuing a statement in which he said that \u201cwhilst informal physical contact is commonplace in the arts world as a mutual gesture of friendship, the serious accusations made involving coercion and forced physical contact have absolutely no basis in truth.\u201d But major orchestras around the world cut ties with him, and in January he stepped down as principal conductor of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London nearly two years early.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Boston Symphony said that none of the women had complained to the orchestra\u2019s management, and that there were no indications that the orchestra\u2019s management had been aware of Mr. Dutoit\u2019s behavior until it was reported late last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
