View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe orchestra revoked an honorary title it had given him in 2016 at Tanglewood and said that it was enhancing its employee training, reviewing its policies and working to clarify its expectations of guest artists. \u201cLet me be clear that we want to send a strong message that any form of sexual harassment or assault goes completely against our values and will not be tolerated,\u201d the orchestra\u2019s managing director, Mark Volpe, said in a statement.", "title": "Boston Symphony Finds Accusations Against Charles Dutoit \u2018Credible\u2019", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAt the top of my list of satisfying meals that nurture body and soul is a big, steaming bowl of noodles in broth.\n\nMy introduction to the Japanese version came on my first trip to Japan, 30 years ago, to visit American friends living in the town of Matsuyama in Ehime Prefecture on the island of Shikoku. Matsuyama (which means Pine Mountain) is known for its historic traditional bathhouse, Dogo Onsen. On a cold, drizzly day, I gladly bathed in its steaming hot waters.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfterward, we lunched at an ancient noodle house, with great blackened ceiling beams, heavy wooden tables and impressive pottery. All the noodles were served in beautiful large, heavy handmade bowls, which to my untrained eye seemed like priceless museum pieces. The whole place (and its menu) appeared unchanged for centuries, despite the fact that the hip young waiters used what was then a high-tech electric notebook to take our order.\n\nThere were over two dozen choices of noodle soup, some with slender buckwheat soba noodles, others with fat white chewy udon noodles. I hadn\u2019t encountered udon before, so I ordered a bowl of them with shiitake mushrooms. The broth was sensational. The noodles were delightfully chewy. My one mistake as a novice eater of Japanese noodles was continuously sprinkling my bowl with shichimi togarashi, a red chile spice mixture that was new to me. By the time I reached the bottom, the last few spoonfuls of broth were incendiary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe mushroom soup was fitting, since we had just visited a mushroom farm and observed shiitakes growing. Rather than cultivate them in a cave, the locals drill holes in logs and inoculate them with spores. Then the logs are placed in the woods so the mushrooms grow in a natural setting.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast week, to satisfy my sudden craving for a bowl of udon, I set to the task of making broth. Cooking from memory, with no ingredients on hand to make a proper Japanese dashi broth from kombu (dried kelp) and shaved bonito tuna, I improvised a vegetarian version using dried shiitakes and miso. I did have dried seaweed and udon noodles in the cupboard, bought at my favorite Japanese grocery. I started off with a not-very-Japanese saut\u00e9 of leeks in butter, a favorite base for vegetarian soups. Fresh shiitake mushrooms, greens and tofu filled out the dish.", "title": "Bouncy Noodles, Bright Greens, Quick Broth: A Perfect Bowl", "authors": ["David Tanis", "City Kitchen"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Their raw, minimalist mixes became popular with the club kids in New York and soon spread to other cities.\n\n\u201cHe came up with his own style of bass lines, and he parlayed the bass lines into a lot of different music, and it opened the gateway to what they now call house music,\u201d Mr. Regisford said in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Jarvis\u2019s bass lines \u201creally penetrated the dance floor; it was deeper than any bass that you could ever hear,\u201d Mr. Regisford continued. \u201cThat\u2019s what signified his sound.\u201d\n\nThe two released \u201cThe Music Got Me,\u201d a dance song with a sinuous bass line, in 1983.\n\n\u201cWe had a vibe, and a ragtag, rough edge to what we did,\u201d Mr. Jarvis said in an interview with Red Bull Music Academy in 2016. \u201cOur stuff wasn\u2019t orthodox at all. We were just kids, with toys that we were playing with, and the record became big.\u201d\n\nThey went on to produce records, sometimes in collaboration with artists and under different names, and remixed songs by Madonna, Sade and Chaka Khan, among others.\n\nMr. Jarvis also worked as an uncredited session musician, playing for artists like Herbie Hancock, Stevie Wonder, Mariah Carey and Patti LaBelle, Mr. Regisford said.\n\nBoyd Henry Jarvis was born in Brooklyn on Oct. 26, 1958. He moved to Boston to live with his father, Henry Jarvis, a freelance photographer, after his mother, Joan Smith, died in 1968 from injuries sustained in a car crash.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter Mr. Jarvis returned to Brooklyn in his late teens, he became quickly immersed in the club scene and taught himself to play the synthesizer.\n\nIn the early 1990s, he sued the producers Robert Clivill\u00e9s and David Cole \u2014 known for their hip-hop-inflected dance records \u2014 for sampling \u201cThe Music Got Me\u201d on a song titled \u201cGet Dumb! (Free Your Body).\u201d The case was settled for a little under $100,000, his family said.\n\nYvette Jarvis said her brother had been making and recording music until his death. In addition to her, he is survived by another sister, Lorraine Jarvis; his partner, Beverly Jackson; two daughters, Monique and Genesys Jarvis; two sons, Azande and Zion; and many grandchildren.", "title": "Boyd Jarvis, Whose Synthesizer Fueled Dance Music, Dies at 59", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCALL ME ZEBRA\n\nBy Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi\n\n292 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $24.\n\nThere\u2019s a first-person poem by Baudelaire, not particularly well known, though it\u2019s one of his \u201cFlowers of Evil,\u201d called \u201cL\u2019H\u00e9autontimourom\u00e9nos\u201d (\u201cThe Self-Tormenter\u201d) in which he describes the all-consuming masochistic act of writing. Ink, he declares, fills the writer\u2019s veins: \u201cIt\u2019s all my blood, this black poison! / I am the sinister mirror / Where the Fury sees herself.\u201d\n\nThis could also be an ode to the furiously introspective, fiercely literary young narrator of Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi\u2019s second novel, \u201cCall Me Zebra.\u201d That narrator, Bibi Abbas Abbas Hosseini, was born in the library of her family\u2019s home, between the Caspian Sea and Iran\u2019s Alborz Mountains, early in that country\u2019s war against Iraq. An only child, she is the last in a long line of self-taught sages whose creed is \u201cLove nothing except literature.\u201d Barely out of toddlerhood, the girl absorbs her father\u2019s lessons on \u201cGreat Writers of the Past,\u201d reciting passages by Goethe, Dante, Stendhal, Borges, Cervantes and the Persian poet Hafez because \u201cmemorization is our only recourse against loss.\u201d (Later she records more quotations in a notebook that \u201cwill smell like ink, like the blood of literature, the blood that runs through all Hosseini veins.\u201d) At the age of 5, as the war worsens, Bibi flees with her parents toward the Turkish border, but her mother dies when a building collapses on her as she forages for food. Bibi and her father must continue on alone, making their way through Kurdistan, Turkey and Spain. Eventually, years later, they come to a halt in New York.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s here, when Bibi is in her early 20s, that her father dies, leaving her \u201camong the loneliest of this pitiful world.\u201d As she watches the light fall in stripes on her father\u2019s coffin, she decides that she will take on a new identity: She will now be known as Zebra, a name that \u201crepresents ink on paper,\u201d making her \u201ca martyr of thought.\u201d Thus armed, she will embark on yet another journey, returning to the places she once visited as a refugee \u2014 inspired not by a need for self-discovery but by a thirst for vengeance. Outraged when confronted with the misfortunes of exiles and the complacency of nonexiles, she believes she has a duty to \u201cmirror back to this miserly universe its own terrible distortions.\u201d This is Zebra\u2019s quest: \u201cI, a modern literary inventor, was going to walk the void of my multiple exiles causing trouble, discombobulating the world.\u201d Her map will be literature, \u201cthe only true form of cartography in the world,\u201d and she will begin her mission in Catalonia.\n\nIn this ferociously intelligent novel, Van der Vliet Oloomi \u2014 who came to the United States from Iran with her family when she was a child \u2014 gradually brings her orphaned heroine to the realization that literature (Zebra calls it the \u201ccorpse of my past\u201d) may not be enough to sustain her. So when a \u201csurprisingly good-looking\u201d Italian philologist named Ludovico Bembo (Ludo, for short) meets her at the Barcelona airport, he shoulders her suitcase full of books and shakes her determination to exist via thought and abstraction, to paraphrase (as Zebra does) the French philosopher and literary theorist Maurice Blanchot. Sex with Ludo she welcomes without hesitation, seeing it as a way to \u201cannihilate each other through hot passion,\u201d but she recoils from any emotional connection. She\u2019s \u201cantilove,\u201d she tells him, and if pushed will \u201cretreat into the Matrix of Literature.\u201d Yet as she stubbornly pursues her literary \u201cGrand Tour of Exile,\u201d she finds it increasingly difficult to conduct her expedition solo.\n\nWith intricacy and humor, Van der Vliet Oloomi relays Zebra\u2019s brainy, benighted struggles as a tragicomic picaresque whose fervid logic and cerebral whimsy recall the work of Bola\u00f1o and Borges. In her first novel, \u201cFra Keeler,\u201d a psychological thriller about a man who buys a house and is obsessed with the circumstances of the previous owner\u2019s death, she showed similar acuity and dark wit; here, however, she immeasurably expands her terrain. Literature, as Zebra\u2019s father has observed, is \u201ca nation without boundaries\u201d and for this high-minded heroine, \u201clandscape and literature are entwined like the helix of DNA.\u201d But the pilgrimage she undertakes in \u201cCall Me Zebra\u201d teaches her to raise her eyes and register the reality of the people who exist in her present, not just those who survive in the pages of her past.", "title": "Brainy and Benighted, Lost in the Books of Bola\u00f1o and Borges", "authors": ["Liesl Schillinger", "Azareen Van Der Vliet Oloomi"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "While other young brands may draw their inspiration from city streets or club scenes, Ernest W. Baker, a new men\u2019s wear label, takes its name \u2014 and some aesthetic guidance \u2014 from an unlikely place: the designer Reid Baker\u2019s 91-year-old grandfather. A former Detroit ad man, Ernest W. Baker is the brand\u2019s muse \u2014 and Reid and his co-designer, Ines Amorim, create clever riffs on the kind of classic American suiting found in his wardrobe. Recently, they even studied his journals from the \u201970s and \u201980s, for inspiration.\n\nFounded in 2016, the brand is an amalgamation of western American influences and Old-World European style, drawn from the founders\u2019 heritage: Baker grew up in Utah and Amorim in a small town outside of Porto, Portugal. The result is off-kilter tailoring that feels simultaneously nostalgic and contemporary. The designers reinterpret traditional men\u2019s wear fabrics \u2014 tweed, velvet and cotton shirting \u2014 with surprising, often cropped, silhouettes.\n\nThe designers begin each collection with a cast of characters inspired by their cinematic interests. These are especially visible in the brand\u2019s fall/winter 2018 offering, which recently won the brand a place on the shortlist for the LVMH Prize. The pieces include a sharply cut brown leather trench coat, chunky mustard-yellow knitwear and a purple velvet suit with kick-flare pants. \u201cThe overall design is simple,\u201d says Amorim, \u201cbut we want the looks to be memorable. We think of small details from the \u201870s and \u201880s and put them into the pieces, to give them an old feel.\u201d\n\nImage Ines Amorim and Reid Baker. Credit Courtesy of Ernest W. Baker\n\n\u201cWe kind of let our inspirations come naturally,\u201d adds Baker. This most recent collection, for example, started with the designers\u2019 immersion in the world of David Lynch. \u201cWe watched \u2018Blue Velvet\u2019 and then the whole \u2018Twin Peaks\u2019 series, which brought in that Western element.\u201d", "title": "Brand to Know: A Men\u2019s Wear Line With a Nostalgic Bent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The rising men\u2019s wear line Namacheko, designed by the siblings Dilan and Lezan Lurr, makes deceptively simple clothes that are, in fact, loaded with personal meaning. For example: A moss-green mohair peacoat, from the fall/winter 2018 collection, looks classic apart from its sculptural toggles. The biomorphic shape of the fastenings was inspired by the English sculptor Barbara Hepworth \u2014 a tribute to the designers\u2019 mother, who is, as Hepworth\u2019s was, a math teacher.\n\nThe brand also showed a navy blue sleeveless jacket made from fireproof fabric. The Lurrs, who founded the label in 2017, are inspired by their dual Swedish-Kurdish nationality, and the flame-retardant garment was a statement about the indestructibility of identity. \u201cAs a teenager growing up in Sweden, you just want to be like your friends \u2014 but you never lose being a Kurd,\u201d says Dilan, \u201cIt\u2019s a funny thing. You are what you are. I want to translate that into the garments.\u201d\n\nDilan is on a short visit to Belgium, where Namacheko is manufactured \u2014 in part by Gysemans Clothing Group, a production and distribution company that has also worked with Raf Simons since his early years. But both Dilan, 29, and Lezan, 24, spend most of the year in Sweden, where they moved from Iraq with their family in 1997.", "title": "Brand to Know: Men\u2019s Wear Inspired by a Swedish-Kurdish Upbringing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 Exxon Mobil and other oil companies opened their wallets at an offshore oil auction in Brazil on Thursday in a sign that the industry was stepping back into the deepwater drilling business.\n\nIt was the third encouraging Brazilian offshore auction since September, and a vote of confidence for the country\u2019s energy reform program at a time when oil companies have been reluctant to make ambitious offshore investments.\n\nAs oil prices plunged in recent years, global investment in offshore oil and gas operations collapsed to roughly $160 billion in 2017, from a high of $335 billion in 2014. Rystad Energy, a Norwegian energy consulting firm, projects that offshore investments will level off at $155 billion this year, and gradually pick up over the next five years.\n\nBut BP, Royal Dutch Shell and Germany\u2019s Wintershall defied the global trend and were among the big winners at the Brazilian auction on Thursday. Chevron had kept a low profile in Brazil since an oil spill in 2011 off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, but it successfully bid for four exploration units.", "title": "Brazilian Auction Draws Oil Companies Back to Offshore Drilling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe fact that the mechanism has no ideology is fundamental,\u201d Mr. Padilha said. \u201cMy thesis is that the mechanism operates in all elections at all levels of government in Brazil, everywhere. Companies that are big clients of the government, usually construction companies but also big commercial banks, finance them all, either legally or through secret slush funds.\u201d\n\nIn return, whoever is in power \u201chires those companies to perform services, and the companies inflate the contracts heavily, with kickbacks either to individual politicians or their parties.\u201d\n\nVirtually all of the 20-odd parties with seats in the Brazilian Congress have been stained by the scandal, soon to begin its fifth year. One president has been impeached; her predecessor has been convicted of corruption and money laundering; and her successor is being investigated by the real-life equivalents of the prosecutors and police officers that Mr. Padilha portrays.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBrazil is very interesting as a case study, in the sense that the corruption is not in the politics,\u201d he said. \u201cThe corruption is the politics.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe creators and cast of \u201cThe Mechanism\u201d went into the series knowing that they were taking on a weighty and controversial topic. Supporters of the nominally left-wing Workers Party, which was in power from 2003 to 2016 and was the main focus of early phases of the investigations, vociferously maintain that their leader, former president Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva (and the one convicted of corruption and money laundering), is the object of a witch hunt. Some even allege that the judge overseeing the Car Wash investigations is a C.I.A. plant.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m from the generation born during the dictatorship, when all of civil society was united in opposition to the military, so I\u2019ve never experienced anything like this,\u201d said Elena Soarez, who wrote the script of \u201cThe Mechanism\u201d with Mr. Padilha. \u201cThe country has been riven, with families divided and lifelong friends quarreling, and that makes this a special challenge to write.\u201d\n\nRather than focus on politicians and business magnates, the series revolves around three fictionalized characters: a well-connected and morally warped money launderer and two tenacious police investigators, an older man and a younger woman. Though the intricacies of the Brazilian legal and political system may not be familiar to foreign viewers, the series\u2019 political thriller format \u2014 cast and creators referenced works like \u201cAll the President\u2019s Men,\u201d \u201cScandal\u201d and \u201cThree Days of the Condor\u201d \u2014 certainly will be, as will be the idiosyncrasies of the main characters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always enjoyed watching noir detectives, and now I finally get to play one, a guy who is fighting against his external and internal demons,\u201d said Selton Mello, cast as the investigator Marco Ruffo. \u201cRuffo is an obsessive in a search for justice, an almost solitary figure amid the machinery of corruption, a kind of Quixote with a lot of personal dramas.\u201d\n\nThroughout his international career, which began in 2002 with \u201cBus 174,\u201d a documentary which used a bus hijacking to examine how Brazil\u2019s criminal justice system treats the poor, Mr. Padilha has focused on the related issues of crime, justice and violence. scrutinizing both those who mete it out and those who are on the receiving end. Regardless of where, what language or in what medium he has worked, whether in a pair of \u201cElite Squad\u201d movies about SWAT-like teams in Rio, his 2014 remake of \u201cRoboCop,\u201d or in \u201cNarcos,\u201d the police have always been central to the stories he tells.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor the state to sustain itself, there must be some repressive force that it manages and controls,\u201d he explained. \u201cSo the police are not a detail, they are an essential feature of any complex society. They offer a glimpse into all kinds of social systems, because they are very, very much on the edge, the fringe of society, where institutions meet.\u201d\n\nIn \u201c7 Days in Entebbe,\u201d a new feature film that opened March 16, Mr. Padilha offers a variation on some themes he first raised in \u201cBus 174,\u201d this time with a hijacked airplane instead of a bus. In the new film he shows not only the workings of the Israeli army and political establishment, but also the motivations of the terrorists who in 1976 seized an Air France flight from Tel Aviv to Paris with 248 passengers aboard, nearly half of them Israelis or Jews of other nationalities, and had it flown to Idi Amin\u2019s Uganda.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Entebbe crisis ended violently, with soldiers of the Israel Defense Force storming an airport terminal and rescuing more than 100 of the hostages: All of the German and Palestinian terrorists were killed, as well as the leader of the Israeli commandos (the older brother of Israel\u2019s current prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu), four of the hostages and 45 Ugandan soldiers. Though the Entebbe raid is often described as one of the most spectacular military missions of modern times, Mr. Padilha sees it as an ultimately Pyrrhic victory.\n\n\u201cAs soon as the operation succeeded,\u201d he said, \u201cit played into the hands of people who thought that everything can be solved by violence,\u201d which in turn contributed to the persistence of conflict in the Middle East.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe Mechanism\u201d tells a much less familiar story, but Mr. Padilha and his collaborators are convinced that the series, which contains an optional voice-over in English and minimal violence, will travel well. As if to prove his point, during an interview in the lounge of a New York hotel last month, an American guest who had been eavesdropping and was fascinated by what she was hearing interrupted the conversation to ask Mr. Padilha the name of his series and when she would be able to watch it. \u201cI can\u2019t wait to see it,\u201d she told him.\n\n\u201cCorruption is a universal theme, and that is going to generate empathy everywhere,\u201d said Caroline Abras, who plays the police investigator Verena Cardoni. \u201cPeople the world over, in all of the countries this is going to be seen, will understand what is going on.\u201d\n\nOf course, since Mr. Padilha wrapped the first eight episodes of \u201cThe Mechanism,\u201d the Car Wash scandal has taken even more unexpected turns, which he recognizes would be ideal fodder for future seasons. The generalized disgust with the political class, for instance, already seems to be having an effect on a presidential election scheduled for October. Possible candidates include a former army parachutist famous for his stridently alt-right views and the host of a weekend TV variety show who has never held public office but has 13 million Twitter followers.\n\n\u201cNobody knows how this is going to turn out,\u201d Mr. Padilha said. \u201cBrazil is at a crossroads, and everything is up for grabs. It\u2019s a crazy situation, but it\u2019s my role as a political filmmaker to tackle these issues.\u201d", "title": "Brazil\u2019s Jaw-Dropping Corruption Scandal Comes to Netflix", "authors": ["Larry Rohter"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. The news from the beach is the snowy owl is still hanging in the dunes at Breezy Point at the western end of Queens, still knocking down rats and rabbits for dinner, still letting us know that winter\u2019s afoot, that even if spring arrives tomorrow, it\u2019s not quite time to head north to the Arctic tundra, the back of beyond. And I\u2019m glad the owl is down there, visiting big, old New York, eating up a storm. It\u2019s a sign, one of many, that we\u2019re really all part of something much bigger than our gigantic city or mid-sized hamlet, our jobs, our struggle, our narrow interests, our particular beliefs, ourselves. Things move around. Food\u2019s a big part of that.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t make Mondays any easier, of course. I didn\u2019t quite get around to cooking that big vat of Caribbean stew (above) that I\u2019d intended to make yesterday, so the family could eat big tonight. There are no ravioli verdi in the freezer to make dinner a breeze. I don\u2019t have a roast chicken to shred into enchiladas. And I don\u2019t have time for risotto. Not tonight.\n\nEnter Alison Roman, under a spotlight, with a bag of chips, a carton of eggs and a smart new recipe for a kind of fake-o cheater\u2019s chilaquiles. It makes for the best kind of breakfast-for-dinner: fast and super-flavorful. Watch the video a couple of times and then make the dish your own.\n\nOther new recipes to try out this week or very soon include David Tanis\u2019s vision of udon noodles with oodles of mushrooms and Melissa Clark\u2019s bold foray into chocolate oatmeal: soft, custardy and profoundly bittersweet. Both are appropriate to midweek consumption.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Cooking Newsletter Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Behind all of this is the Second Amendment.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s only 27 words long,\u201d said Adam Liptak, who covers the Supreme Court for The New York Times. \u201cBut it is probably the most cryptic part of the United States Constitution.\u201d\n\nThis video explainer breaks down those 27 words, teases out the two clauses that judges and scholars examine and looks at how the amendment is interpreted today.\n\nIn this video:\n\n\u2022 Mr. Liptak has covered the Supreme Court for 10 years. Before that, he was a national legal correspondent, covering the law more generally. He joined The Times after practicing law for 14 years.", "title": "Breaking Down the 27 Words of the Second Amendment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The city can also designate \u201cSpecial Purpose Districts,\u201d which have restrictions and incentives customized to the specific nature of the area. One aim of the Special City Island District, for example, is to protect the nautical character of that Bronx neighborhood.\n\nNow let\u2019s look at how zoning designations affect new construction.\n\nMost development in the city is done \u201cas of right,\u201d meaning the proposed use matches the site\u2019s zoning regulations.\n\nLet\u2019s say you want to build a warehouse on land zoned M2-1, a manufacturing district that allows certain industrial uses. As long as that warehouse complies with the M2-1 zoning regulations, in most cases you can start building once you have the proper permits.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut what if you want to build a 14-story residential tower on that plot? You\u2019d need to get the zoning designation changed.\n\nNew York adopted the nation\u2019s first citywide zoning laws in 1916. In 1975, voters approved a new City Charter that gave neighborhoods a stronger voice in determining land use. It was a rebuke to the actions of the urban planning czar Robert Moses, whose aggressive (and largely unchecked) decades-long building spree destroyed the character of dozens of neighborhoods \u2014 if not the neighborhoods themselves.\n\nThese new provisions stipulated that any change in zoning would require public hearings and several levels of nonbinding review. This procedure is called the uniform land use review process, or Ulurp (pronounced \u201cYOU-lurp\u201d).\n\nA typical Ulurp review takes six to eight months. First, the local community board, the borough president and the city planning commission weigh in on the proposal.\n\nAll of these entities\u2019 recommendations, however, are advisory. It is the City Council that holds the power to approve or reject the Ulurp request. What\u2019s more, council members tend to defer to their colleague who represents the area affected.\n\nBecause zoning changes are often contentious, officials now usually work with the community and interested parties to agree on a deal before Ulurp begins. In November, the City Council approved a sweeping rezoning to East Harlem, nearly two years after community discussions began; and the process is playing out right now near the Gowanus Canal for the second time in 10 years.", "title": "Breaking Down the City\u2019s Rezoning Process", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Breitbart News is taking a step into the live events business.\n\nFollowing the lead of other media companies seeking fresh sources of revenue, the right-wing news and opinion site is set to host its first-ever town hall in suburban New Orleans next month, a panel on privacy and technology with the commentator Ann Coulter and Peter Schweizer, the author of \u201cClinton Cash.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s an experiment for a site that has lately been confronting declining web traffic and turbulence in its top ranks. Stephen K. Bannon, the site\u2019s longtime executive chairman, was forced out in January. Its page views last month were down by nearly half from a year earlier, according to the data-tracking firm comScore, though Breitbart disputes the figure.\n\nThe Louisiana event is \u201cthe latest evolution in how to consume Breitbart content,\u201d said Alexander Marlow, the site\u2019s editor in chief.\n\nBy branching into public forums, the site is taking a cue from one of its perennial foes: the mainstream media. For $50,000, you too can clone yours.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIt has been called \u201cthe toughest job you\u2019ll ever love.\u201d\n\nThe Peace Corps got its start on this day in 1961, established under an executive order by President John F. Kennedy.\n\nThe idea to send American volunteers around the world to assist with development projects and to promote the image of the United States existed in various forms after the end of World War II.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut it was during a campaign stop at the University of Michigan a few weeks before he was elected president that Kennedy asked a crowd of students, \u201cHow many of you who are going to be doctors are willing to spend your days in Ghana?\u201d\n\nKennedy would repeat that call to service a few months later during his inaugural address, when he urged Americans to \u201cAsk not what your country can do for you \u2014 ask what you can do for your country.\u201d\n\nThe Peace Corps has not been without criticism: Richard Nixon said it was a haven for draft dodgers, and, more recently, the organization has faced questions about the health and safety of its volunteers, particularly women.\n\nBut after initially operating in only a handful of countries, the Peace Corps has sent more than 230,000 volunteers to 141 nations.\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Brexit, Hope Hicks, Neymar: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s the right time for the artists that have been using this technology,\u201d said Nicholas Meehan, the founding chairman and artistic director of the Institute for Sound and Music in Berlin, which is building a six-screen, surround-sound projection structure called the ISM Hexadome.\n\nOn March 29, Mr. Eno will unveil a different immersive work in the ISM Hexadome, to be presented for the first time in the atrium of the Martin Gropius-Bau museum in Berlin, where he\u2019ll be joined by other artists including Mr. Yorke and Mr. Barri; the composer and producer Ben Frost, collaborating with the visual artist MFO; and the sound artists Holly Herndon and Peter van Hoesen.\n\nAfter the Berlin show, the mobile structure will tour Europe and America through 2019. Nine works created in Berlin will form the basis of the tour, with newly commissioned ones added at subsequent stops, until the presentation includes more than 20. It will return to Berlin in September 2019.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing the beginning of the wave, not even the crest yet, of what\u2019s coming,\u201d Mr. Meehan said in a telephone interview. In addition to virtual reality and augmented reality, what is now emerging is \u201cspatial technology where everyone is experiencing something together,\u201d he said.\n\nIn an interview in Amsterdam, Mr. Eno said that he saw \u201cBloom: Open Space,\u201d which had a limited five-day run here last month, as \u201cthe beginning of an experiment\u201d with these new technologies. It is based on \u201cBloom,\u201d a 2008 smartphone app Mr. Eno created with Mr. Chilvers, which also generates bubbles and tones when the phone\u2019s screen is pressed. Its immersive evolution was \u201ca kind of demo to see how far we could take it with the technology as it stands at the moment,\u201d Mr. Eno said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Eno wasn\u2019t entirely enthusiastic about the prospects. \u201cI think there\u2019s something there,\u201d he said, ambiguously. \u201cI\u2019m very aware of the limitations, but I\u2019m also alert to the possibilities.\u201d But he\u2019s attracted to the potential. \u201cI want to be able to be inside the music, to walk around and examine it from different places,\u201d he added. \u201cI don\u2019t feel this is a replacement for other musical experiences. I feel it\u2019s an easy thing to add.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Barri, who has made videos for Radiohead and toured with the Chilean-American electronic musician Nicolas Jaar, creates live video effects during his concerts. In the past decade, he\u2019s been developing his own software, Versum, which creates what he calls a \u201c3D real-time virtual world\u201d that is responsive to his input.\n\nDuring a live performance, Mr. Barri sits at the center of the Hexadome and guides the audience through a musical composition inside his virtual world, using a joystick. \u201cWe, the listeners, the viewers, will start at some point in space, and then where we will move will determine what we see or what we hear,\u201d he explains. \u201cIt really depends on how I move what music will be heard.\u201d\n\nMr. Barri doesn\u2019t employ virtual reality goggles because he thinks having \u201csomething stuck to your face\u201d is awkward and restrictive. He said much of the technology being developed doesn\u2019t have musicians in mind, so the only way for him to create the work he wants is to \u201creally intensively dive into the programming.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Eno, an early member of the band Roxy Music, has had a long career of bending technologies to his alternative sound purposes, like using multiple cassette tapes in the 1980s to create overlapping, unsynchronized sounds, or using 12 high-powered computer-controlled projectors to beam visuals for his musical piece \u201c77 Million Paintings\u201d across the sails of the Sydney Opera House in 2009.\n\nThis month, Mr. Eno announced that he would release a CD box set, \u201cMusic for Installations,\u201d in May featuring works he has composed since 1986 for mixed-media installations in galleries, airports, hospitals and other public spaces. One piece, \u201cKazakhstan,\u201d for example, was written to accompany the artist Asif Khan\u2019s 360-degree movie, \u201cWe Are Energy,\u201d in the British Pavilion at the World Expo in Kazakhstan.\n\nLike Mr. Barri, Mr. Eno says he feels that musicians are only beginning to explore the potential of immersive tools.\n\n\u201cPhilosophically, in terms of our understanding of what it is, we\u2019re right at the beginning,\u201d he said. \u201cBut also technically, it is difficult. There\u2019s a slightly awkward imbalance between the complexity of the system and the simplicity of the results.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat will change, of course,\u201d he added. \u201cThe technology will become more and more transparent, and using it will become less difficult. Right now, it\u2019s quite a struggle remembering that you\u2019re not only trying to get it working, but also trying to do something worthwhile with it.\u201d", "title": "Brian Eno Wants to Take You \u2018Inside the Music\u2019", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are the pride and joy of the Cuban community,\u201d said Modesto A. Maidique, a former university president.\n\nBut the student body has also diversified, and enrollment has grown to more than 50,000 from 15,000 three decades ago. Despite opposition from competing schools, the university used its tight relationships with politicians to elevate its athletic program to Division 1, add doctoral programs and open schools of architecture, law, medicine and engineering.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe as an institution see ourselves as an anchor in the community,\u201d Dr. Rosenberg said, with a responsibility to address major issues, including sea level rise, disparity in health outcomes, hurricanes, AIDS prevention and transportation. \u201cWe are leaning in. As an institution, we\u2019re not in a fetal position waiting for the sky to fall.\u201d\n\nAs the university grew, traffic on Southwest Eighth Street, along the northern edge of campus, became one of its problems. About 4,000 students lived in neighboring Sweetwater, across the busy eight-lane street. University students also work with the local elementary school in Sweetwater, which in turn sends children to the art museum on campus.\n\nA pedestrian bridge became necessary for safety.\n\n\u201cThis was a good project,\u201d Dr. Rosenberg said Friday. \u201cThis was a project that spoke to our desire to build bridges. When the board hired me, I told them, \u2018If you give me a pile of rocks, I\u2019m going to build a bridge, not a wall.\u2019 This was about neighborliness and collaboration.\u201d\n\nExperts in accelerated bridge construction, in which bridges are prefabricated and quickly moved into place, said it was particularly unfortunate that the collapse occurred at F.I.U. The university is known for its expertise in the field and has attracted top international scholars as Ph.D. students.\n\nThe Accelerated Bridge Construction University Transportation Center at F.I.U., a federally financed research center that received a round of $10 million in government funding in 2016, gathers, organizes and distributes information about the timesaving method.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn addition to sponsoring industry conferences in Miami every two years, the center also hosts monthly online seminars that are viewed regularly by about 4,000 people, according to Michael P. Culmo, an expert in accelerated bridge construction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey do play a key role in the field,\u201d said Mr. Culmo, the chief technical officer for CME Associates, an engineering firm based in Mansfield, Conn.\n\nThe professor who leads the center, Atorod Azizinamini, a bridge engineer, has become something of an evangelist for accelerated bridge construction.\n\nPhoto\n\nA 2016 news release from F.I.U. said that Dr. Azizinamini, who declined to comment for this article, had presented the method to the federal Transportation Department as a way to replace deficient or obsolete bridges with minimal disruptions to traffic flow.\n\nBut F.I.U. needed a bridge of its own.\n\nIn September 2015, Munilla Construction Management, a business led by a Cuban-American family, submitted its proposal to build the pedestrian bridge that collapsed on Thursday. The project was officially known as the University City Prosperity Project.\n\nThe company\u2019s proposal described the bridge as an innovative design that would \u201cserve as an icon, a destination in its own right.\u201d At the core of this proposal was accelerated bridge construction, which the company said would \u201cshowcase F.I.U.\u2019s prominence in the international A.B.C. marketplace.\u201d\n\nThe proposal emphasized the bridge\u2019s dramatic features \u2014 a tapering pylon, glass-enclosed elevator and programmable lighting \u2014 as well as the Munilla firm\u2019s connections. Forty percent of the firm\u2019s team members were F.I.U. graduates, \u201cwhich enhances our passion for success,\u201d the proposal said.\n\nIt was signed by Jorge Munilla, Munilla Construction Management\u2019s president. \u201cThey\u2019re significant players in the Cuban community,\u201d said Dr. Maidique, who is also Cuban-American. Mr. Munilla\u2019s company won the project, beating out several other firms.\n\nOn campus, where students were on spring break, the reactions of those who remained were shock, sadness and anger.\n\nDr. Rosenberg said the institution was planning an independent investigation of the collapse of the pedestrian bridge, which was intended to be a showcase of engineering and collaboration with the community.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe will try to understand if there are areas where we could have done better,\u201d he said.", "title": "Bridge Collapse Saps Spirits and Research Efforts at Florida International University", "authors": ["Patricia Mazzei", "Stephanie Saul"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Holder, who was born in Trinidad and died at 84 in 2014, was a force in the form of a dancer, choreographer, actor, composer, designer and painter. (You might also remember him from the Uncola 7-Up commercials of the 1970s and \u201980s.) He met Ms. de Lavallade when they were cast in Harold Arlen\u2019s \u201cHouse of Flowers,\u201d a Broadway musical that featured a wealth of important figures in the dance world, including Alvin Ailey, Louis Johnson and Arthur Mitchell, who was a founder of Dance Theater in 1969. \u201cDougla\u201d hasn\u2019t been performed by the professional company since 2004, the year that the company went on hiatus because of financial difficulties.\n\nReviving \u201cDougla\u201d for Dance Theater\u2019s season at New York City Center, beginning April 4, has been a group effort, masterminded by Ms. de Lavallade and her son, Leo Holder, 61, who is supervising the production. Former Dance Theater members have helped: Along with Kellye Saunders and Keith Saunders \u2014 ballet masters with the company \u2014 Donald Williams and Charmaine Hunter have worked with the cast.\n\nPhoto\n\nTania Le\u00f3n\u2019s shimmering, percussive score, created with Holder, will be performed live, and Dance Theater will be joined by guests from Collage Dance Collective. There are soloist roles \u2014 namely the bride and the groom \u2014 but the ballet, featuring 25 dancers, achieves its power through unison scenes in which the classical body must become more grounded by using fluid hips and an open chest to dig inside the music\u2019s driving pulse.\n\nIn \u201cDougla,\u201d a grand and earthy mainstay of Dance Theater\u2019s repertory for years, repetition is used in abundance as dancers \u2014 and their costumes \u2014 spin in sync. There are details from Indian dance that crop up, in facial expressions and in vibrating fingers, and the dancers possess a sense of majesty. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing like a big group that is just absolutely together,\u201d Ms. de Lavallade said. \u201cYou cannot be yourself. You have to be like one person.\u201d\n\nMs. de Lavallade wasn\u2019t involved in the creation of the ballet, but she said: \u201cI remember him working on this and running out and getting the materials. Just like when he worked on \u2018Timbuktu.\u2019 There wasn\u2019t a piece of lam\u00e9 left in New York City.\u201d\n\nHolder directed, choreographed and designed the costumes for \u201cTimbuktu,\u201d a 1978 musical. (He also directed and designed the costumes for \u201cThe Wiz,\u201d which won him Tonys in both categories in 1975.) In the case of \u201cDougla,\u201d Ms. de Lavallade said: \u201cThere were different versions. It kept changing. Things do that. We\u2019re putting back certain things from the first and rearranging. Not that much \u2014 just little bits and pieces. It\u2019s like a hunt to put it back together.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite those nips and tucks, Leo Holder said the revival is completely derived from his father\u2019s ballet. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing there that isn\u2019t of him,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Holder, who designs graphics and scenery for movies and television, has been consumed with organizing his parents\u2019 archives in recent months. \u201cI\u2019m basically here to provide context and to make sure that the choreographer is still in the house,\u201d he said with a laugh.\n\nHe didn\u2019t want \u201cDougla\u201d to be seen as a museum piece. In order for it to live for a new generation of dancers, Mr. Holder brought a hefty object for each of them to hold: a silver-and-turquoise ring that belonged to his father.\n\n\u201cI wanted them to understand what kind of force created this particular piece,\u201d said Mr. Holder, whose father was a towering 6-foot-6 with a melodious, booming voice. \u201cThe person who wore that ring was not 5-foot-2 and sitting in a corner. When those lights go up, they have to be that grand.\u201d", "title": "Bringing Back \u2018Dougla\u2019 Is a Family Affair", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBefore there was Euro Disney the theme park, there was Euro Disney the comic books. Now, after more than six decades, the European adventures of Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Uncle Scrooge will be released in the United States.\n\nThe Disney comics written by European cartoonists, including Romano Scarpa, Luciano Bottaro and Daan Jippes, have been translated into English as part of a new series introducing American readers to some of Disney\u2019s international artists.\n\nFantagraphics, a graphic novel imprint, is publishing the collection as part of its \u201cDisney Masters\u201d series. Starting in May, the series will feature full-color hardback volumes of the comics, many of which are in English for the first time. \u201cIt\u2019s an international look at Disney comic creation,\u201d Michael Catron, the series editor, said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s taking a look at the very large history of Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck from around the world,\u201d he continued, \u201c bringing it back and putting it in a \u2018best of\u2019 package for North America.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first volume is by Mr. Scarpa, a prestigious Italian cartoonist who started working for Disney in 1953.
