But the Gorki has defined itself along political lines even more strongly under Ms. Langhoff.\n\nThe novelist Olga Grjasnowa \u2014 whose \u201cDer Russe ist einer, der Birken liebt\u201d (, (\u201cAll Russians Love Birch Trees\u201d) about a soul-searching Russian-Jewish \u00e9migr\u00e9, was adapted for stage by the theater in 2013 and remains in repertoire \u2014 said that the house has had an effect on cultural politics by sheer force of its diverse ensemble and topics. \u201cAt the beginning, it was as if the future belonged to us,\u201d she said.\n\nComparing German public theater to a \u201cfeudal system,\u201d Ms. Grjasnowa called the ability \u201cto introduce a new structure and fight one\u2019s way to the top\u201d a \u201chuge achievement,\u201d but also expressed hopes that artistic planning \u201cwon\u2019t stagnate.\u201d\n\nMs. Langhoff emigrated to Germany as a child and made her start in the film industry, working as an assistant to the now international director Fatih Akin.\n\nShe considers herself indebted to a postwar German school of thought that arose in the aftermath of the Holocaust, pointing to a tradition of \u201cfemale Jewish author theater\u201d that the Gorki has cultivated through the work of Ms. Grjasnowa, Ms. Ronen and Sasha Marianna Salzmann, artistic director of the side stage \u201cStudio R.\u201d Ms. Langhoff was also shaped, however, by the political activism and stories \u201cabout loss and injustice\u201d to which she was exposed in Turkey and in circles of immigrants in Germany.\n\nMs. Langhoff \u2014 who bears the surname of a German theater dynasty through her ex-husband, the director Lukas Langhoff \u2014 called the situation for women in German theaters \u201ccatastrophic\u201d given that only 22 percent of artistic directors are female. \u201cIt is mostly men who sit on the councils that make decisions about who will be hired for a position,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is time that we address such structural issues.\u201d", "title": "Bringing Her Turkish Background to German Theater", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSherry Blockinger, who had a pastry shop and cafe in Chappaqua, N.Y., for six years, is bringing her treats to Manhattan. Among her specialties are ice cream sandwiches made-to-order with cookies, and premade ice cream sandwiches layered with thick slices of cake. New for spring are carrot cake, tart lemon and coconut in individual servings or, with 72 hours\u2019 notice, a larger size. The carrot cake with cream-cheese ice cream would make a nice finale for Easter dinner. Cookies, scones and filled brownies are the other specialties sold in the bright shop with deep mauve banquettes and white tables. She is adding a number of savory items, including cheeses that can be served on a \u201cboard\u201d made of a giant edible cracker: Sherry b dessert studio, 643 Hudson Street (Gansevoort Street), 646-850-0170, sherryb.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Bringing Pastries and Ice Cream Together", "authors": ["Samantha Seneviratne"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "One of Italy\u2019s most respected cultural critics, Tomaso Montanari, described the over-the-top effects as \u201cvisual Viagra,\u201d wondering outright whether they were \u201cmore of a mirror of the present than a means to better understand the past.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like all the buzz over virtual sex \u2014 but what\u2019s wrong with the real thing?\u201d said Mr. Montanari, who teaches art history at the University of Naples. \u201cIt\u2019s based on the notion that Michelangelo no longer speaks to modern sensibilities.\u201d\n\nThe Vatican followed the process step by step. While it did not interfere with the creative aspects of the production, Vatican officials kept tabs to make sure that the show\u2019s content and references were historically accurate and did not stray too far from the righteous path.\n\n\u201cWe have been very, very, very obedient and careful and precise because that was our insurance policy. To have them on board was to be sure that everything will be exact and appropriate,\u201d Mr. Balich said of the Vatican\u2019s support during a break in the rehearsal. \u201cObviously this comes with a price,\u201d he said conceding that if he\u2019d had his way, he would have \u201cprobably added more special effects.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe musical merger between the Vatican Museums, the keepers of one of the greatest artistic troves of humanity, and Mr. Balich, best known as the designer of over-the-top spectacles \u2014 among them the closing ceremony of the Sochi Olympics in 2014, both ceremonies for the Turin Games in 2006 and the 550th anniversary celebration of Kazakhstan \u2014 wasn\u2019t an obvious match.\n\nPhoto\n\nPope Francis is known for his casual, avuncular style, but the Vatican is not accustomed to sharing top billing with Sting, who wrote the main theme of the show, as they do on the playbill.\n\nBut Mr. Balich believes that his past experience with the Olympics played in his favor. \u201cThe Vatican understood that our work is always celebrating values,\u201d he said. \u201cIn the Olympics, you don\u2019t go in with a cynical approach.\u201d\n\nMr. Balich said he wanted \u201cto put the grammar of the big Olympics at the service of the Sistine Chapel, which is one of the milestones of humanity.\u201d The Vatican, he added, understood \u201cthat we were well intentioned.\u201d\n\nIt took some time. Mr. Balich first began discussing his idea with the Vatican in 2015. He laughed when it was pointed out that it took Michelangelo four years to paint the Sistine Chapel\u2019s ceiling, between 1508 and 1512, about the same time as it took to complete the project.\n\nThe Roman Catholic Church has a long history of embracing technological advancements, however. The Vatican was at the forefront of astronomical research for centuries. Pope Pius XI championed Guglielmo Marconi to establish Vatican Radio in 1931. Several popes were intrigued by photography in its nascent years, and Leo XIII was the first pope to be filmed giving a blessing in 1896.", "title": "Bringing the Sistine Chapel to Life, With the Vatican\u2019s Blessing", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "It was his longstanding friendship with Ms. Forbes that softened his stance and led him to award her the stage rights. They met in 1994, when Ms. Forbes was a freshman at Howard University and Mr. Coates was a sophomore; they helped organize a hip-hop and poetry cypher on campus that year and remained close ever since. \u201cKnowing Kam, there\u2019s nobody else I would have trusted to do it,\u201d Mr. Coates said.\n\nBut rather than providing input, Mr. Coates decided to remove himself from the process entirely and give Ms. Forbes full artistic control. When Ms. Forbes tried showing Mr. Coates some of the more aggressive edits, he declined to look at all. \u201cKam has the freedom to pursue her truth. She don\u2019t need me breathing down her neck,\u201d he said, adding jokingly: \u201cI\u2019ll give you my review next week. We\u2019ll see if this friendship is still a thing.\u201d\n\nAt a rehearsal at the Apollo on Friday, Mr. Moran sat at a grand piano on a platform far above the stage, attacking taut arpeggio patterns with the bassist Mimi Jones and the drummer Nate Smith. Mr. Moran, a MacArthur fellow and composer behind the score for the 2014 film \u201cSelma,\u201d nonetheless approached the project with trepidation. \u201cI usually think that nothing needs music because I love silence so much,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnstage, his anxious chords matched the book\u2019s seething tone and simmering tension. \u201cWhat I like about the book is that there\u2019s no soft edge on it,\u201d Mr. Moran said. \u201cI\u2019m trying to make sure I don\u2019t soften anything up.\u201d Behind and below him, the projections, by the artist Tal Yarden, flashed across multiple screens, showing the smiling face of Prince Jones, or two black hands outstretched in surrender or protest.\n\nTo adapt the book, Ms. Forbes enlisted two dramaturges, Lauren A. Whitehead and Talvin Wilks, who faced the challenge of paring down a text that, under 200 pages, was already concise. They decided to use the poetry technique of erasure, which consists of blacking out portions of a larger text, to expose terse emotional outbursts and visually arresting moments.\n\nIn his book, for example, Mr. Coates wrote about Jones\u2019s murder: \u201cThis entire episode took me from fear to a rage that burned in me then, animates me now, and will likely leave me on fire for the rest of my days.\u201d\n\nIn the production, the sentence became: \u201cThis entire episode took me from fear to / rage / Fire for the rest of my days.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe process stripped away Mr. Coates\u2019s sober tone, Ms. Whitehead said, revealing that \u201cthere was actually a voice of rage.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Forbes and the two dramaturges started to develop the work at an intensive two-week residency at Sundance in December along with four actors, including the Tony-nominated actress Michelle Wilson (\u201cSweat\u201d), who will perform in Monday\u2019s show. The reading sessions were filled with discussions, arguments and crying.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe first day was so emotionally and spiritually exhausting,\u201d Ms. Wilson said.\n\nEventually, the team whittled down the book into a 90-minute presentation consisting of 21 excerpts from the book. The cast, which will be different for each performance and includes Susan Kelechi Watson, Joe Morton and Pauletta Washington, will not memorize lines but rather will rely on scripts onstage to channel the effect of reading something powerful for the first time.\n\nSome excerpts will be read verbatim, while other poetic passages will be less recognizable, with dialogue being passed back and forth among actors. One of those moments, which captures Mr. Coates\u2019 whirlwind education at Howard, \u201crelies on overlap and speed,\u201d Ms. Whitehead said. \u201cYou have this feeling of vertigo, which is what he was experiencing when he was learning all these other black narratives he had never heard before.\u201d\n\nIn Harlem, the production will be seen by thousands, including the one person the book was meant for originally. Mr. Coates said that his son, Samori, whom \u201cBetween the World and Me\u201d is addressed to, will be in the audience. He will watch as an intensely personal letter will be transformed into a communal performance.\n\nThough there are no concrete plans for further shows, Ms. Forbes said she will observe how the text from three years ago plays to an already drastically changed world and think about how the project could continue and evolve.\n\n\u201cIf there isn\u2019t an immediate resonant response, for at least the work we\u2019ve set out to do, we\u2019ve got to change it,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s not just a reflection: I see this work as a call to action.\u201d", "title": "Bringing the World of Ta-Nehisi Coates, Briefly, to Stage", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Britain\u2019s prime minister said on Monday that it was \u201chighly likely\u201d that Moscow was to blame for the poisoning of a former Russian spy attacked with a nerve agent near his home in southern England, and she warned of possible reprisals.\n\nThe remarks by Prime Minister Theresa May, delivered in an address to Parliament, were an unusually direct condemnation of a country that Britain has, in the past, been loath to blame for attacks on its soil. Critics say the British authorities took only modest countermeasures after Russian agents poisoned a former MI6 informant in 2006 with the rare isotope polonium 210.\n\nThe prime minister, who as home secretary resisted an open inquiry into Russia\u2019s role in that case, is under pressure to show more resolve this time. The March 4 nerve agent attack on Sergei V. Skripal, once an informant for Britain\u2019s foreign intelligence service, and his daughter, Yulia, exposed untold numbers of bystanders to risk around public spaces in the city of Salisbury. Traces of the poison have been found at a pub and a pizza parlor visited by the Skripals.\n\n\u201cIt is now clear that Mr. Skripal and his daughter were poisoned with a military-grade nerve agent of a type developed by Russia,\u201d Mrs. May said in the House of Commons. \u201cThe government has concluded that it is highly likely that Russia was responsible for the act against Sergei and Yulia Skripal.\u201d", "title": "Britain Blames Moscow for Poisoning of Former Russian Spy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Sixty percent of penny and 2 pence coins are used only once, and in 8 percent of cases, pennies are simply thrown away. In addition, more than 500 million penny and 2 pence coins have been produced every year to make up for the shortfall of pennies taken out of circulation when they are, for example, lost to piggy banks or down the backs of couches.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, the \u00a350 note is rarely used for routine purchases. While there is significant overseas demand for the notes, the perception in Britain is that the \u00a350 is used mostly for money laundering, tax evasion and in illicit transactions. Some shops, fearing a costly mistake with a counterfeit, refuse to accept them.\n\nThe contretemps occurred as Britain is increasingly moving away from cash and becoming reliant on credit and debit cards and digital payments. Card transactions accounted for more than half of retail purchases for the first time in 2016, according to the British Retail Consortium, and the Treasury predicted cash would be used for only 21 percent of payments by 2026.\n\nAdvocates for keeping the \u00a350 were few and far between, but champions of the copper-colored coins were fiercely vocal as soon as the idea of abandoning them was announced. Charities raised concerns about losing pennies, which are almost exactly the size of the American cent, because they rely on them for donations, often collected at shops or on the street.\n\n\u201cCertainly cash is still a very significant form of fund-raising for charities. It is still where we receive the majority of our donations,\u201d said Andrew O\u2019Brien, director of policy and engagement at the Charity Finance Group.", "title": "Britain Drops Plan to Scrap the Penny, for Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The prime minister also said that the government had agreed on new powers to crack down on the activities of foreign intelligence agents in Britain, that there was no place for \u201cserious criminals and corrupt elites\u201d in the country, and that an invitation for Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia to visit had been withdrawn.\n\nShe added that no British ministers or royals would attend the World Cup in Russia this summer, that Britain would \u201cincrease checks on private flights, customs and freight,\u201d and that it would \u201cfreeze Russian state assets wherever we have the evidence that they may be used to threaten the life or property of U.K. nationals or residents.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey have treated the use of a military-grade nerve agent in Europe with sarcasm, contempt and defiance,\u201d Mrs. May said of Russia. \u201cTheir response has demonstrated complete disdain for the gravity of these events. They have provided no credible explanation.\u201d\n\nExperts have described a number of tougher measures Britain could also take, like seizing any assets of questionable provenance belonging to Russians who have invested and settled in the country, changing laws that made it possible to hide the true ownership of assets, and calling on the international community to tighten economic restrictions on Russia. Britain\u2019s broadcast regulator has also hinted that it could revoke the license of RT, the Kremlin-controlled English-language news channel.\n\nSince Monday, when Mrs. May said that \u201cit is highly likely that Russia was responsible\u201d for the nerve-agent attack on Mr. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, in Salisbury, England, this month, President Vladimir V. Putin\u2019s government has made a series of statements denying any involvement and threatening dire consequences for Britain if it acts against Russia.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Wednesday, the Russian embassy in London said the British \u201chostile action\u201d was \u201ctotally unacceptable, unjustified and shortsighted.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEarlier, Mr. Lavrov had said Britain was \u201cacting out political drama\u201d rather than investigating the matter seriously.\n\n\u201cRussia could not have had any motives\u201d for the attack, he said, \u201cbut those who would like to continue a Russophobic campaign in absolutely all areas of human activities\u201d could have had such motives.\n\nMoscow has demanded that it be part of a joint investigation into the attack on the Skripals, along with the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, and that Britain turn over a sample of the nerve agent. Mrs. May identified the chemical as a Novichok, a class of extremely deadly nerve agents developed by the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 1980s. Britain was sending samples of the toxin to the chemical weapons organization for verification, the British prime minister said on Wednesday.\n\nThe country has tried to marshal support from international organizations, an effort potentially complicated by Britain\u2019s impending exit from the European Union, disputes within NATO, and the reluctance of President Trump to denounce Mr. Putin. Despite those tensions, several of Britain\u2019s European allies have been quick to express solidarity over the attack on the Skripals, who remain hospitalized in critical condition.\n\nDonald Tusk, president of the European Council, wrote on Twitter on Wednesday that he stood with Mrs. May on what he called a \u201cbrutal attack inspired, most likely, by Moscow,\u201d and said he was prepared to put the matter on the agenda for the council\u2019s meeting next week.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso on Wednesday, Britain called for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the attack, and delivered a statement to the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, decrying Russian aggression in Ukraine and Georgia, the country\u2019s involvement in the Syrian civil war, and civil rights abuses within Russia, as well as the nerve agent attack.\n\nMr. Skripal, a former Russian military intelligence officer, was imprisoned in 2006 for selling secrets to the British. In 2010, he was sent to Britain as part of a spy swap. He and his daughter were found unresponsive on a park bench in the cathedral city of Salisbury on March 4.\n\nThe use of an exotic poison in an attempt on his life has echoes of the assassination in 2006 of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian agent and vocal critic of Mr. Putin, who was poisoned in London with a radioactive isotope. A British investigation concluded that the killing was not only carried out by Russian agents, but was probably approved by Mr. Putin.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe attack on the Skripals has prompted the British government to say that it will re-examine other suspicious deaths of Putin foes in Britain, which critics say the government has not pursued seriously enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMrs. May\u2019s remarks came as the investigation into the attack in Salisbury continued to widen, with the police cordoning off more sites that might have been contaminated, and anxiety in that city remained high. Hundreds of people who might have been exposed have been told to thoroughly wash their clothes, phones, glasses and anything else that might be carrying minute traces of the chemical.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to carry on as normal, but it\u2019s hard when the police keep tarping up new parts of the city,\u201d said Adrian Mendes, an employee of a local fish-and-chip shop. \u201cIt makes you think, what else could be contaminated? It makes you want to stay away.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTuesday was a market day in the city\u2019s picturesque central square, but even with the sun shining, stalls that would usually be bustling stood empty.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never seen it this quiet,\u201d said Fiona Dawson, who works at a jewelry stall. \u201cAll you hear now is the military helicopters hovering above.\u201d\n\nSeveral residents claimed that swans and ducks that passed police cordons on the Avon River had been put down to prevent the spread of contamination. The police did not immediately respond to a request for confirmation.\n\nLocal merchants were visibly worried about the long-term impact on business after Neil Basu, chief of the counterterrorism police, announced on Tuesday that the investigation could take many weeks.\n\nSome shops put up signs trying to reassure people. \u201cBusiness is open,\u201d read one. \u201cNerve-agent-free products,\u201d read another, on an open vegetable stand, which was later taken down after other stall owners complained that it was putting customers off.\n\nOn Tuesday, the police said that counterterrorism investigators were looking into the unexplained death of Nikolai Glushkov, a Russian exile found dead at his home in London, who was close to Boris Berezovsky, once a leading Putin opponent. Mr. Berezovsky\u2019s death in England in 2013, an apparent suicide by hanging, is one of those that critics have insisted should be investigated further.\n\nThe police said that they had no reason to believe the death of Mr. Glushkov was suspicious, but that they were being especially cautious in light of recent events.", "title": "Britain Expels 23 Russian Diplomats Over Ex-Spy\u2019s Poisoning", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you start to take away Astons and Bentleys and huge apartments in Kensington, freezing those assets, people will care a lot more,\u201d said Cliff Kupchan, chairman of Eurasia Group, a consulting firm, adding that the pressure would be conveyed to Mr. Putin.\n\n\u201cThese people are loyal,\u201d Mr. Kupchan said. \u201cCan they get him to do a 360? No. But is there some dual directionality, going up and going down, the elite to the president? Yes.\u201d\n\nWealthy Russians began shifting their money into Britain in the mid-1990s, snapping up properties through anonymous companies registered in overseas territories like the British Virgin Islands. A 2015 study by Deutsche Bank, based on figures from the Russian Central Bank and the Bank of England, suggested that since 2006, around $129 billion had flowed into Britain through secret offshore transactions, much of it from Russia.\n\nAs capital migrated, the subculture known as Londongrad grew in size and influence. In 2003, Mr. Abramovich bought the iconic Chelsea Football Club. In 2009, Alexander Lebedev, a former K.G.B. officer, and his son, Evgeny, bought a controlling share in The Evening Standard, one of London\u2019s oldest daily newspapers. In recent years, Russian expatriates have begun to build networks in British politics, making large donations to the Conservative Party.\n\nThough Mr. Putin has condemned capital flight as unpatriotic, he tolerates it in his inner circle, Mr. Kupchan said.\n\n\u201cPutin wants repatriation, but the social contract is that if you show loyalty, you can live the way you want,\u201d he said.\n\nFor Russians, part of Britain\u2019s draw was its offer of legal shelter; it refuses extradition requests from Russia. British institutions, meanwhile, have been lenient with wealthy foreign buyers, skimming through due diligence procedures intended to determine the source of a buyer\u2019s funds, said Ian Bond, director of foreign policy at the Center for European Reform.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis has been a very weak part of our money-laundering system,\u201d Mr. Bond said. \u201cNot enough questions are being asked about overseas shell properties. Estate agents are not asking the right questions \u2014 or any questions \u2014 about the beneficial owners.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe government has promised this will change.\n\nOn Wednesday, under pressure to display a tough response to the poisoning of the former spy, Sergei V. Skripal, Mrs. May promised to \u201cfreeze Russian state assets wherever we have the evidence that they may be used to threaten the life or property of U.K. nationals or residents.\u201d She went on to say that investigators will crack down on \u201cserious criminals and corrupt elites.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere is no place for these people \u2014 or their money \u2014 in our country,\u201d she said.\n\nMrs. May has several tools available to challenge the legitimacy of Russian holdings. Just six weeks ago, Britain rolled out a new campaign to stem the flow of dirty money into its real estate sector, presenting an unnamed political figure, reportedly from Central Asia, with the first-ever \u201cunexplained wealth order.\u201d The order requires the target to present a court with evidence that the property was purchased with legal funds. If that fails, the state can seize the asset.\n\nUnexplained wealth orders could most easily be used against government officials, whose incomes are clearly insufficient for them to purchase billion-pound London properties, said Ben Cowdock, a researcher at Transparency International. The orders would be difficult to use against wealthy businessmen with multiple income streams, he said.\n\nMrs. May also promised on Wednesday to introduce legislation similar to the Magnitsky Act in the United States. That act allows American officials to deny visas to Russians implicated in human rights violations and freeze their assets. In 2012, when Congress passed its legislation, the British government chose not to follow suit, arguing that it had sufficient sanction powers.\n\nMrs. May said she was also ready to freeze Russian state-owned property that had been used in attacks on British soil, a category potentially broad enough to include Aeroflot planes that carried assailants to Britain, Mr. Bond said.\n\n\u201cIt is intended to say, \u2018We will go after anything that isn\u2019t nailed down,\u2019\u201d he said.\n\nOne concern for Britain is whether the measures would jeopardize British business interests in Russia \u2014 in particular, its flagship oil producer, BP, which owns a 20 percent stake in Rosneft, the Russian oil and gas giant.\n\nAnti-Putin activists and investigative journalists here have long urged a crackdown on oligarchs\u2019 lavish holdings, whose ownership is often concealed by layers of offshore transactions. Mark Hollingsworth, co-author of \u201cLondongrad: From Russia With Cash,\u201d has spent years compiling a database of thousands of properties by cross-referencing public records and prowling neighborhoods popular with wealthy Russians.\n\n\u201cThey love the area near Harrods, they love Eaton Square, Belgrave Square,\u201d he said. \u201cOf course, they don\u2019t live there. It\u2019s all about parking their money, and acceptance and reputation. Being accepted by the British establishment.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hollingsworth said an aggressive campaign of asset seizures could serve as \u201ca warning shot against Russian billionaires who have made their money in dubious circumstances,\u201d stripping them of their sense of security.\n\n\u201cIf they target the right ones and shut them down, they\u2019ll lose a fair amount of money,\u201d he said. \u201cIf that happens, Londongrad probably no longer exists.\u201d\n\nBut Roman Borisovich, an anti-Putin campaigner who organizes a \u201cklepto-tour\u201d of mansions and penthouses owned by people close to the Kremlin, said Mrs. May\u2019s speech on Wednesday suggested she was not ready to press forward with asset seizures.\n\n\u201cNow all the arsenal of weaponry is available to the government,\u201d he said. \u201cThe prime minister can use any tools, but she didn\u2019t use them.\u201d", "title": "Britain Hints at Tougher Blow Against Russia: Stripping Tycoons\u2019 Assets", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump recently issued an executive order to keep the Guant\u00e1namo prison open, although his administration so far has taken no new detainees there. Senator Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican who is a proponent of using wartime detention for terrorism cases, has been pushing the administration to take Mr. Kotey and Mr. Elsheikh to Guant\u00e1namo.\n\nBut Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, whom Mr. Trump has tasked with leading a policy review about what to do with newly captured terrorism suspects, does not want the military to take on the headache of holding the men in long-term detention and prosecuting them in the troubled military commissions system, the officials said.\n\nMr. Mattis\u2019s reluctance, coupled with the British demands, means bringing Mr. Kotey and Mr. Elsheikh to American soil for civilian court prosecution is seen as far more likely. The Justice Department is now trying to decide whether the Southern District of New York or the Eastern District of Virginia would handle the prosecution, the officials said.\n\nSome prosecutors and F.B.I. agents in New York have argued that they should get the case because their area of operations includes Western Europe, and the suspects are Londoners. But their counterparts in Virginia and the F.B.I.\u2019s Washington Field Office have already been handling most of the casework related to the killings of American hostages in Syria, according to an official familiar with the deliberations.\n\nIn February 2016, for example, federal prosecutors in Virginia charged the wife of an Islamic State leader in the death of Kayla Mueller, an American, although the United States military transferred her to the Iraqi justice system.\n\nMs. Mueller was kidnapped in August 2013 and is believed to have been sexually abused by a leader of the Islamic State, which later said she died in an airstrike in early 2015. The British-accented captors tortured prisoners under their control, according to former hostages; Mr. Kotey is suspected of being a particularly brutal one whom the prisoners called George.\n\nThe parents of four Americans who were kidnapped by the Islamic State and abused in various ways before their killing \u2014 Ms. Mueller and three men who were beheaded, James Foley, Steven Sotloff and Peter Kassig \u2014 recently wrote an Op-Ed in The New York Times calling on the United States government to prosecute the suspects in civilian court and not to seek the death penalty.", "title": "Britain Presses U.S. to Avoid Death Penalty for ISIS Suspects", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "The identification of Novichok as the weapon has become the linchpin of the British case for Russia\u2019s culpability in the poisoning. Though one of the scientists who developed the nerve agent, Vil Mirzayanov, published its chemical structure and now lives in the United States, it is extremely dangerous to manufacture. He said in an interview that the only laboratories known to have fine-tuned the process were in Russia and parts of the former Soviet Union.\n\nRussian officials have strenuously argued against this point in recent days, suggesting at different times that the Skripals had not been attacked and that Britain was behind the attack.\n\nIn Moscow on Sunday, in his first extensive remarks about the poisoning, President Vladimir V. Putin called it \u201ctotal rubbish, drivel and nonsense\u201d to think that someone in Russia would carry out such \u201cantics\u201d so close to Russia\u2019s presidential election, which was Sunday, and the World Cup soccer tournament, which begins in June in Russia.\n\nMr. Putin said he first learned about the poisoning, which he called a \u201ctragedy,\u201d from the news.\n\nHis initial reaction, he said, was that people would have died on the spot if it had really been a military-grade poison. He also denied that Russia had any such substance.\n\n\u201cWe destroyed all of our chemical weapons under the control of international observers,\u201d Mr. Putin said, speaking at a late-night news conference to celebrate his election victory. \u201cMoreover, we were the first to do this, unlike some of our partners who promised to do this but have yet, unfortunately, to keep their pledge.\u201d", "title": "Britain Says It Has Proof Russia Stockpiled Lethal Nerve Agent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 For years, anticorruption campaigners have railed against Britain\u2019s openness to ill-gotten riches from overseas and the foreigners who invest them. After a nerve agent attack on British soil, and the resulting diplomatic showdown between Russia and the West, that may be starting to change.\n\nThe British government said this week that it would review the cases of 700 Russians who were granted visas to live in Britain largely because they could invest millions of dollars in the country. And it signaled an openness to cutting off access to British financial markets for President Vladimir V. Putin\u2019s government in Russia.\n\nThe government\u2019s expressed determination to crack down on dirty money came on a day of rare good news in the poisoning attack. Yulia S. But a deal reached in December for BAE to produce 24 Typhoons for Qatar was valued at almost $7 billion.\n\nSaudi Arabia already has 72 Typhoon jets.\n\nThe civil war in Yemen, which has been called the world\u2019s worst humanitarian crisis, has killed thousands of people and displaced more than 3 million in three years of fighting. It pits Saudi Arabia\u2019s Sunni Muslim monarchy against Yemen\u2019s Houthi rebel movement, which is backed by Shiite Muslim power Iran. Other Arab nations contribute to the Saudi-led coalition and the United States provides it with logistical support.\n\nThe Houthis, along with elements of the Yemeni military, seized the capital, Sana, and overthrew President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi in 2015. Saudi Arabia ostensibly supports Mr. Hadi, who is Sunni. But the Saudi-led coalition has shown signs of fragmenting.\n\nHuman rights groups have accused both sides of abuses. The State Department said the American was an \u201caccredited diplomat\u201d who had been assaulted as part of systematic harassment of American Embassy staff members by the Russian authorities.\n\n2013: From Russia With Wigs\n\nIn May 2013, the Russian government ordered an American Embassy official, identified as Ryan C. Fogle, to leave the country. His expulsion followed an almost comical arrest in which he was caught carrying two wigs \u2014 one blond and one brown \u2014 a Moscow street atlas, $130,000 in cash and a letter offering \u201cup to $1 million a year for long-term cooperation.\u201d\n\n2010: A Sleeper Cell\n\nIn 2010, 10 Russians accused of membership in a sleeper cell were deported after pleading guilty to conspiracy in a federal court in Manhattan. As part of a deal, the spies were swapped for four Russian prisoners, three serving sentences on treason convictions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe case, often compared to the plot of a spy novel, included evidence of letters written in invisible ink, buried cash and a red-haired woman whose romantic exploits and risqu\u00e9 photographs made for tabloid fodder.\n\n2001: An F.B.I. Turncoat\n\nIn March 2001, the United States expelled 50 Russian diplomats in the wake of the arrest of Robert P. Hanssen, who was a counterintelligence expert at the F.B.I. and had spied for Moscow for more than 15 years.\n\nAmerican officials said Mr. Hanssen had been paid hundreds of thousands of dollars after he volunteered to turn over United States secrets to Russia, and they blamed the Kremlin for not turning him down or turning him in. In response, Russian officials expelled several American diplomats.\n\n1994: A Mild Blowback\n\nShortly after the arrest of Aldrich H. Ames, a career C.I.A. officer who turned out to be a double agent, United States officials expelled a senior Russian diplomat, Aleksandr Lyskenko, whom they called a top officer of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service. According to the State Department, Mr. Lyskenko was \u201cin a position to be responsible\u201d for Mr. Ames\u2019s activities as a very productive mole.\n\nAlthough Mr. Ames\u2019s treachery was almost certainly the most damaging breach of American intelligence since World War II \u2014 Moscow executed several operatives whom he had betrayed \u2014 Washington\u2019s response was considerably less severe than it would have been in Soviet times. In the years after the fall of the Soviet Union, the Clinton administration, eager to encourage friendly relations and reform, supported the new government of President Boris N. Yeltsin. Before Mr. Lyskenko was told to leave the country, in February 1994, the Americans even gave the Russians the option of voluntarily sending him back home.\n\n1986: A Mass Expulsion\n\nFifty-five Soviet diplomats were expelled by President Ronald Reagan in November 1986 in an effort to curb espionage activities. Similarly, the authorities in Moscow ordered 260 Soviet employees of the United States Embassy in Moscow to stop working.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was the largest number of diplomatic officials to be expelled by the United States at once. The conflict arose after a Soviet employee of the United Nations, Gennadi F. Zakharov, was arrested on espionage charges. The Russians responded by arresting Nicholas S. Daniloff, the Moscow correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, and accusing him of spying. That\u2019s the Easy Part\u201d (front page, March 15):\n\nThe rapid endorsement by its European and North American allies of Britain\u2019s assessment and retaliatory actions in relation to the Salisbury nerve agent attack is to be welcomed. Skripal, and his daughter visited the graves of Mr. Skripal\u2019s wife and son in the cathedral town of Salisbury, England, on Friday.\n\nDressed in large hazardous-material suits, the investigators began collecting evidence at Mr. Skripal\u2019s house in the town and erected a blue forensic tent around the grave of the son. The police said that they had requested military assistance to \u201cremove a number of vehicles and objects from the scene.\u201d\n\nMr. Skripal\u2019s wife, Lyudmila, 59, died in 2012 of uterine cancer, according to records from the National Health Service. He also blamed Western governments for failing to negotiate, noting that some hostages were released for ransoms.\n\nMr. Elsheikh said the killings were a \u201cmistake\u201d and might not have been justified. But, he said, they were in retaliation for the killings of civilians by the United States-led coalition fighting ISIS.\n\nThe beheadings, often videotaped, horrified the world soon after ISIS took over much of Iraq and Syria in 2014. The group also committed wide-scale atrocities, massacring thousands of Iraqi troops and civilians and taking sex slaves.\n\n\n\nMr. Foley\u2019s killing was followed by those of two other Americans, Steven Sotloff and Peter Kassig; the British aid workers David Cawthorne Haines and Alan Henning; and the Japanese journalists Haruna Yukawa and Kenji Goto.\n\nMr. Foley\u2019s mother, Diane Foley, called on the international community and United States government \u201cto have the courage to hold these men accountable in an open trial where we can face them and they can hear all the pain and suffering they\u2019ve inflicted on the world.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe said she opposed the death penalty for the detainees since it would feed jihadi \u201cdesire for martyrdom and heroic afterlife.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two suspects\u2019 detention has set off a debate in the United States and Europe about how to prosecute Westerners who joined the militants \u2014 as the Kurds pressure the West to take them back to relieve prison crowding.\n\nMr. Elsheikh, whose family went to Britain from Sudan when he was a child, was a mechanic from White City in West London. He traveled to Syria in 2012, initially joining a branch of Al Qaeda before moving on to ISIS, according to the State Department. It said he had \u201cearned a reputation for waterboarding, mock executions and crucifixions\u201d while serving as an ISIS jailer.\n\nMr. Kotey, who is of Ghanaian and Greek-Cypriot descent and converted to Islam in his 20s, is from the Paddington district of London.\n\nThe leader of the cell, Mohammed Emwazi, was called \u201cJihadi John\u201d after he appeared, masked in the videos, sometimes performing the butchery. He was killed in an American-led coalition drone strike in 2015 in the Syrian city of Raqqa. Another member, Aine Davis, was arrested in Turkey, convicted there in 2017 and sentenced to seven years in prison.\n\nThe two detainees in Syria denounced as \u201cillegal\u201d the British government\u2019s reported decision in February to strip them of citizenship. The revocation exposes them to \u201crendition and torture,\u201d Mr. Elsheikh said.\n\n\u201cI was born in the U.K.,\u201d he said. \u201cMy mother was born in the U.K. I have a daughter there in the U.K.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kotey said the fairest venue for a trial might be the International Criminal Court in The Hague. The citizenship decision was widely reported in the news media, though British officials have not confirmed or denied it, citing privacy rules.\n\nBoth men seemed dismissive of the idea that they were part of the ISIS cell, depicting the allegations as created by media and foreign intelligence \u201cso the world can say this is the bad guy and kill the bad guy,\u201d Mr. Elsheikh said.\n\nHe added: \u201cNo fair trial when I am \u2018the Beatle\u2019 in the media. No fair trial.\u201d\n\nBethany Haines, whose father, David Haines, was held hostage and died in Syria, told the BBC: \u201cIt shocks me that two individuals who have committed such heinous crimes have been treated like guests with access to the media and are allowed access to smartphones. As for them saying that their actions in Syria are regrettable is an understatement.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe men said they had been questioned repeatedly by American military officials and the F.B.I. The United States has been pressing for the home countries of foreign jihadis in Iraq and Syria to take their nationals for trial. Though Britain\u2019s defense secretary has said they should not be allowed back into the country, officials had asked the United States for reassurance that the men would not face the death penalty.\n\nAt the Kurdish security building, the men appeared to speak openly. Mr. Elsheikh was strait-laced and reserved, referring more often to Islamic texts. But Mr. Kotey often cracked jokes \u2014 when asked whether ISIS\u2019 leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, was alive, he joked that some people thought that Elvis never died and that Tupac Shakur is still alive.\n\nThey were unrepentant, however, about belonging to the group \u2014 though they said they did not agree with everything it did. Mr. Kotey said he did not think suicide bombings were permissible in Islam. Mr. Elsheikh said ISIS\u2019 killing of a captured Jordanian pilot by burning him alive in a cage was \u201catrocious.\u201d", "title": "Britons Accused of Being Islamic State \u2018Beatles\u2019 Call Beheadings \u2018Regrettable\u2019", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "One main reason for the pessimistic outlook is that the Senate, for various political and logistical reasons, has essentially given up on the time-honored method of considering individual spending bills on the floor after they have been hashed out in committee.\n\nThe threat of a slew of politically charged amendments, the need for 60 votes to move any spending legislation and the reluctance of the leadership to devote the necessary floor time to debate the bills have effectively ended public review of the 12 annual spending bills by the full Senate.\n\nWhat that means is that most senators have no real opportunity to try to influence the individual spending measures and are instead presented with the take-it-or-leave-it choice they faced last week when they could either vote for a 2,232-page, $1.3 trillion spending measure with many provisions they supported \u2014 notably a big increase in Pentagon spending \u2014 or balk and be responsible for shutting down the government. Those options left many lawmakers dissatisfied, including some of those most closely involved in writing the legislation.\n\n\u201cI would rather we brought these bills to the floor one at a time,\u201d said Senator Roy Blunt, Republican of Missouri and a member of the spending panel, who lamented the packaging of the bills. \u201cIt didn\u2019t used to be that way. It has been that way for about 10 years now. It needs to stop. Every member needs to have a right to be able to amend these bills, to bring them to the floor one or two at a time, have a real debate.\u201d\n\nCongressional leaders say they don\u2019t like jamming the spending bills through en bloc, but there are real incentives for them to continue to do so because it concentrates considerable power in their hands.", "title": "Broad Spending Bills Here to Stay as Long as Congressional Dysfunction Reigns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Broadcom officially withdrew a $117 billion takeover bid for its rival chip maker Qualcomm on Wednesday, two days after President Trump issued an extraordinary order to block the acquisition effort on national security grounds.\n\nIn a statement, Broadcom said that it would comply with Mr. Trump\u2019s order, formally abandoning what would have been the biggest takeover in the history of the technology industry. Broadcom has nevertheless said it will continue with plans to move its legal headquarters from Singapore to the United States.\n\n\u201cBroadcom\u2019s board of directors and management team sincerely appreciate the significant support we received from the Qualcomm and Broadcom stockholders throughout this process,\u201d Broadcom said.\n\nMr. Trump issued his order after a government panel tasked with reviewing the national security implications for business deals disclosed serious concerns about the bid. The panel\u2019s finding was in keeping with the misgivings within the White House about China\u2019s gaining access to important technologies like the nascent wireless standard known as 5G.", "title": "Broadcom Drops Bid for Qualcomm After Trump\u2019s Intervention", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The giant chip maker Broadcom pledged on Wednesday to keep the United States at the forefront of emerging mobile technology if it were to acquire Qualcomm, its latest effort to allay the Trump administration\u2019s national security concerns about its hostile $117 billion takeover bid.\n\nIn a statement, Broadcom said that, were it to complete what would be the largest technology deal in history, it would not only maintain Qualcomm\u2019s current spending on research and development but it would increase that amount. It added that it would create a $1.5 billion investment fund to train American engineers.\n\n\u201cThis will ensure America\u2019s lead in future wireless technology,\u201d Broadcom said.\n\nThe response came after the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, the government panel that reviews transactions\u2019 national security implications, ordered a delay of Qualcomm\u2019s shareholder meeting as Broadcom sought to win a majority of the company\u2019s board seats.\n\nThat proactive move, all but unprecedented in the history of the panel, highlighted both how much the White House values the wireless technology known as 5G as a matter of national security and its fears of falling behind China in the race to develop the standard. The decision put a spotlight on efforts to expand the reach of the panel, known as Cfius, as a way to bolster the White House\u2019s nationalist economic agenda.", "title": "Broadcom Pledges 5G Investment to Win Approval of Qualcomm Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "A government panel reviewing Broadcom\u2019s $117 billion bid for Qualcomm has warned that it may refer the potential deal to President Trump for rejection, further dimming the prospects for what would be the biggest technology takeover in history.\n\nIn a letter to the two companies on Sunday, the panel, the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, said that it believed the offer by Broadcom posed national security concerns. Broadcom is currently headquartered in Singapore, but is in the process of relocating its legal base to the United States to allay those issues.\n\nThe threat by the panel, known as Cfius, could stop in its tracks Broadcom\u2019s monthslong quest to buy its fellow chip maker. Cfius already ordered a one-month delay of Qualcomm\u2019s annual shareholders\u2019 meeting, where Broadcom had been expected to win at least some seats on Qualcomm\u2019s board, if not a majority.\n\nUnder Mr. Trump, several deals involving foreign buyers have been squelched after a Cfius review, including Moneygram\u2019s sale to an affiliate of the Alibaba Group and Lattice Semiconductor\u2019s sale to an investment firm with reported ties to the Chinese government.", "title": "Broadcom\u2019s Bid for Qualcomm May Be Headed for Rejection, U.S. Panel Warns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Such accusations help explain why the Federal Trade Commission started an investigation of Broadcom\u2019s business practices, which was disclosed in January. They add to the reasons that Mr. Tan\u2019s hostile bid for Qualcomm \u2014 which would be the costliest technology acquisition ever \u2014 has consumed Silicon Valley and companies on three continents.\n\nBroadcom declined to discuss the document, and a Western Digital spokesman declined to comment. A Federal Trade Commission spokeswoman also declined to comment.\n\nThe fate of Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm was expected to be settled Tuesday in San Diego. There, shareholders at Qualcomm\u2019s annual meeting were scheduled to choose between the company\u2019s incumbent directors and six Broadcom nominees expected to back the deal.\n\nBut the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States on Sunday ordered Qualcomm to delay the meeting by 30 days so it could investigate the transaction. On Monday, Cfius sent a letter to Qualcomm and Broadcom stating it would investigate the deal for national security reasons. Broadcom is based in Singapore, though it has announced plans to move its headquarters to the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Wednesday, Broadcom pledged that it would keep the United States at the forefront of emerging mobile technology if it were to acquire Qualcomm, saying it would increase Qualcomm\u2019s research and development spending and create a $1.5 billion fund to train American engineers.\n\nBefore the committee\u2019s unusual move, antitrust authorities were the ones who paid the closest attention to the chip makers \u2014 mainly Qualcomm.\n\nQualcomm is the biggest supplier of chips for smartphones but gets much of its profit from patent royalties. Its business practices have prompted antitrust probes in the United States, Europe and Asia and a lawsuit by Apple, a longtime customer, challenging the royalty payments. Qualcomm denies wrongdoing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBroadcom has built its market muscle by acquiring several dominant lines of chips, a mainstay of smartphones, data storage gear, set-top boxes and networking hardware. Customers include Apple, Samsung Electronics, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Dell, AT&T and Cisco.\n\nBuying Qualcomm would sharply expand Broadcom\u2019s position in smartphones, adding technology that manages cellular communications and runs apps. For that and other reasons, Qualcomm has predicted long and risky antitrust reviews of the deal in several countries, though Broadcom has said it could navigate the process swiftly.\n\nAny Broadcom tactics that the Federal Trade Commission is studying now are not likely to affect merger reviews unless some link can be found to Qualcomm\u2019s business, said James Rill, a lawyer at Baker Botts who once headed the Justice Department\u2019s antitrust division.\n\nBroadcom said in January, \u201cThis F.T.C. review is immaterial to our business, does not relate to wireless and has no impact on our proposal to acquire Qualcomm.\u201d\n\nBut it has been difficult to handicap such oversight, particularly in China. The authorities there forced Qualcomm to lower patent royalty rates in 2015, and some big smartphone makers have expressed fears that Broadcom would raise chip prices if it bought Qualcomm.\n\nAt a minimum, the Federal Trade Commission\u2019s review adds another facet to the aggressive image of Mr. Tan, a Malaysian-born executive who has pleased Wall Street but alarmed tech workers by cutting jobs and long-term research after acquisitions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s as tough as nails,\u201d said Raymond Bingham, a Silicon Valley veteran who helped found the China-backed private equity fund Canyon Bridge Capital Partners.\n\nA CNBC article last week said Broadcom had used price increases and other threats to press for exclusive sales deals from customers such as Amazon, which was also hit by a Broadcom patent suit that was later settled. An Amazon spokeswoman declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome competitors and former customers echo such stories, insisting on anonymity because the negotiations are confidential. Western Digital\u2019s document, titled \u201cBroadcom Matters,\u201d provides a new level of detail.\n\nAt issue were chips known as preamps, used in sending signals to and from disks that store data in drives. The document said Western Digital had no problems in acquiring them until its supplier, LSI, was acquired by Avago in 2014. Avago was renamed Broadcom after buying that company in 2016.\n\nBroadcom executives demanded that Western Digital commit to buying 100 percent of its preamps from their company, a gambit to block new rivals, the document said. Western Digital, which had been testing other chips for potential use, wrote that \u201ca new entrant was compared to a \u2018suicide bomber\u2019 that would put downward pressure on prices.\u201d\n\nWestern Digital refused to comply with Broadcom\u2019s demands. Broadcom then stopped preamp shipments in February 2017, Western Digital wrote, though the cutoff was temporary. Broadcom \u201cattempted to backtrack,\u201d citing \u201cvarious excuses\u201d for the cutoff and ultimately \u201cadmitted that it should not have withheld shipments,\u201d the document said.\n\nToshiba filed the document in response to a SanDisk lawsuit that unsuccessfully sought to block a sale of operations involved in their memory chip venture, which became part of a sale led by Bain Capital. The suit was settled last year.\n\nOther Broadcom customers said the chip maker had been fair. \u201cBroadcom is a pretty good partner for us,\u201d said Bruce McClelland, chief executive of Arris International, which makes set-top boxes using Broadcom chips.\n\nIn an interview in December, Mr. Tan scoffed at the notion of raising prices or otherwise exploiting customer reliance on key Broadcom chips.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s not sustainable,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you do that, customers never come back to you.\u201d", "title": "Broadcom\u2019s Other Regulatory Hurdle: How It Treats Customers", "authors": ["Don Clark"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The bodies that run the game of golf announced a plan Monday to simplify and modernize the rules beginning in 2019. For example, penalty drops can be taken from a lower height, and caddies will no longer be able to line up their players when putting.\n\nBut simplification and modernization don\u2019t automatically go hand in hand. Want more straightforward rules? Go in the other direction, back in time, to 1744, the year of the first known written rules of golf, drawn up by golfers in Edinburgh who played on the Leith Links.\n\nThe 13 rules, rendered here mostly in their original form, are mostly simple, though sometimes a bit weird. They also reveal that golf was a lot harder back then.\n\n1. You must tee your ball within a club\u2019s length of the hole.\n\nNo, it wasn\u2019t miniature golf. By \u201chole,\u201d the rules mean the previous hole. In the absence of tee boxes, golfers just set up near the last hole and fired away.", "title": "Broken Balls and \u2018Wattery Filth\u2019: Golf\u2019s Original Rules Show a Rougher Game", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Henry Bello, who had resigned from the hospital in 2015 amid a sexual harassment charge and blamed doctors there for destroying his career, legally bought the gun about a week before his rampage. He killed himself in the aftermath of the June 30 attack.\n\nAt a news conference on Tuesday, Dr. Timperio recounted how he was shot through the liver while filing medical notes on the hospital\u2019s 16th floor. He and a female resident, who had been shot in the neck, narrowly escaped past Dr. Bello as he was setting the nearby nursing station on fire.\n\n\n\nDr. Bello had turned to them, a wall of flames towering behind him. \u201cHe was shouting after us, come back here, cursing at us,\u201d Dr. Timperio said. \u201cI was certain I was going to die.\u201d\n\nBy the time Dr. Timperio and his colleague made it to the 11th floor, where security guards helped them, Dr. Bello had fatally shot himself on the 16th floor.\n\nNew York State has an assault-weapon ban that prevents unmodified versions of the AR-15 from being sold. But gun dealers and manufacturers can modify the weapon to get around the ban. Upstate Guns and Ammo had legally sold the modified weapon to Dr. Bello, a spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said last July.\n\nNew York City\u2019s assault-rifle ban is stricter than elsewhere in the state. As a result, Dr. Timperio\u2019s lawsuit charges that the gun dealer should have called the New York Police Department to check whether Dr. Bello, as a New York City resident, held a special permit that would be required of owners of rifles in the city.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere does not appear to be a specific legal statute requiring such a call be placed. However, Arnold Kriss, Dr. Timperio\u2019s lawyer, said he believes the gun store had an obligation to do so under general gun laws that require weapons be sold safely, according to local ordinances.\n\nMr. Kriss said that to his knowledge this issue has not been litigated, and he is hoping to set precedent with the case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt will be up to a judge and hopefully, a jury, to make the final determination about whether the firearms dealer had a duty to make that phone call,\u201d he said.\n\nMichael Murphy, a lawyer in Albany representing Upstate Guns and Ammo, said he had no comment.\n\nThe lawsuit also questions whether the appropriate background check was done before hiring Dr. Bello, and it alleges the hospital was negligent in permitting Dr. Bello to retain his hospital badge after he resigned in 2015, despite concerns about his aggressive behavior with the staff.\n\nOn the day of the shooting, Dr. Bello was wearing his badge prominently on his white lab coat, Dr. Timperio recalled. Dr. Bello entered the hospital at around 2:45 p.m., wearing a hooded sweatshirt under his lab coat despite the summer heat. He was carrying a box large enough to hide a rifle in, as well as a juice container filled with gasoline, the police said.\n\nA spokesman for Bronx-Lebanon Hospital declined to comment, citing the litigation.\n\nAfter being shot, Dr. Timperio spent 10 days intubated and in a coma. Bullets shot from an AR-15 can result in particularly brutal injuries, and in his case, after the bullet passed through his liver, it ricocheted through his stomach and intestines before exiting through his right thigh.\n\nDr. Timperio, a Canadian citizen who will return to a medical residency later this year, said he still has general nerve pain, as well as pain near the scars left by five surgeries. He said he doesn\u2019t know if his condition will worsen to where he will not be able to work; it is for that reason he said he is suing for cash damages.\n\nHe also is hoping to use the lawsuit to push hospitals to improve security. But he hesitated before saying he was angry at Bronx-Lebanon, calling that a strong word.\n\n\u201dI wish that people that go to a hospital for medical care don\u2019t get shot, and that doctors don\u2019t get shot,\u201d he said. \u201cWhether you want to call that anger or hope is up to you.\u201d", "title": "Bronx Hospital Shooting Victim Calls for Limiting Sales of AR-15s", "authors": ["Sharon Otterman"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The latest dispute began this fall when the clothing company H&M was looking for a place to hold a fashion shoot and found what seemed like a perfectly gritty \u2014 but not actually dangerous \u2014 location: a graffitied handball court in the William Sheridan Playground in the heart of one of Brooklyn\u2019s hipster meccas.\n\nOn Halloween, a production firm that H&M had hired wrote a letter to the city\u2019s parks department asking if it needed to pay royalties to use the graffiti in an advertising video. That same day, a department official wrote back, saying that the city had not sanctioned the mural (\u201cThis graffiti should NOT have been on the handball wall\u201d) and admitting she had no idea who painted it.\n\nTaking this as tacit permission, H&M shot footage of a model in its new line of apparel using the graffiti as a backdrop. And this being the internet age, the artist, Jason Williams, saw it within months.\n\nIn early January, Mr. Williams, who lives in California and uses the tagging name Revok, had his lawyer, Jeff Gluck, send H&M a cease-and-desist letter. The letter claimed that the company had availed itself of Mr. Williams\u2019s work without approval and threatened legal action in the absence of \u201can amicable settlement.\u201d\n\nThere was no settlement \u2014 amicable or otherwise \u2014 and on Jan. 26, H&M\u2019s lawyers wrote to Mr. Gluck explaining they had done due diligence and now felt that the mural was not only \u201cunauthorized,\u201d but also \u201cconstituted vandalism.\u201d H&M, the lawyers said, no longer needed Mr. Williams\u2019s permission, seeing, as they put it, that \u201chis graffiti was created through criminal conduct.\u201d Last Friday, the company filed suit asking a judge to declare that Mr. Williams had no claims on his own piece of art and to let it use the mural free of charge.", "title": "Brooklyn Lawsuit Asks if Illegal Graffiti Is Protected by Copyright Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The bombing was part of a broader attempt by Mr. Kingsley to retaliate against officers from the 67th Precinct who arrested him in January 2014 for carrying a stun gun, the police said. After the brother became mayor in 2010, Mr. Ford successfully campaigned to take his former seat on the Toronto City Council.\n\nBut the two men diverged in many other ways. Frustrated by political life, Mr. Ford left his only elected post after one four-year term and an unsuccessful bid to succeed the brother as mayor. Mr. Ford mostly ran the label business that had been founded by their father, also named Doug, who was a Progressive Conservative member of Ontario\u2019s legislature.\n\nThere have never been any suggestions of drug or excessive alcohol use by Mr. Ford. The Globe and Mail, a Toronto newspaper, has reported that he sold hashish for several years during the 1980s, but Mr. Ford has denied that report.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough Mr. Ford can be as vocal as his brother was, he does not appear to be as comfortable with public life. (Those are prices paid to the box office \u2014 some people spend more buying from resellers.)\n\nEven critics liked it. \u201cAs portraits of artists go,\u201d Jesse Green wrote in The New York Times, \u201cthere may never have been anything as real \u2014 and beautiful \u2014 on Broadway.\u201d", "title": "Bruce Springsteen Signs Up for More Time on Broadway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Almost every day, Ms. Micu weighed her choices. Some days, she was sure she would stay. The house was in a safe neighborhood, roomy with a swing set in the backyard. Before the storm, she was even planning an addition. Other days, she knew moving was her only choice. Both options were expensive. Selling meant taking a big hit: She paid $183,000 for the house six years ago and figured it was not worth much more than half of that now. But for as long as they lived in their temporary apartment, she was paying rent and a mortgage. FEMA gave her about $16,000, but the renovation bids were all around $70,000.\n\nBy the time the four-bedroom house passed a mold test in February, Ms. Micu was thinking that she might split the difference. Move her family elsewhere, but keep the house as a rental. \u201cWith my son\u2019s immune system, I can\u2019t have a situation where the mold is a trigger,\u201d said Ms. Micu, a Houston native whose parents are Filipino immigrants. \u201cI can\u2019t take the chance.\u201d\n\nSomething else was nagging Ms. Micu. She wondered how the subdivisions could have been built in a reservoir. And if they had to be sacrificed, shouldn\u2019t the homeowners be compensated?\n\n\u201cThis pushed our lives in another path,\u201d she said. \u201cHow could we have known that we would return from Dallas and practically have to start over?\u201d\n\nThe questions are what pushed her to look for a law firm. In September, she became one of the lead plaintiffs in a federal class-action suit against the Army Corps of Engineers.\n\n\u201cHarvey took away my photo album with pictures from every year of my life. It took so many things. It took the purse that my husband bought me as a gift. He spent three months looking for it,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cHarvey took away my sense of security, but so did the Army Corps of Engineers. What happened to us was wrong.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStarting Over\n\nWhen Paulette Delynn Archer, 70, greets a visitor in the doorway of her one-story brick house, she is framed by large picture windows that reveal the emptiness inside, where flooding and renovation have left little more than wood studs between the front door and the back patio.\n\n\u201cCome in, let me show you the house,\u201d Ms. Archer offered in a cheery voice that soon gave way to silence. \u201cWell, this used to be my house. Now it\u2019s just a shell.\u201d\n\nMs. Archer had once delighted in having guests over to see her four-bedroom home, where everything was the color of soft gold or pumpkin. This is where she had raised her only son, where her husband and mother spent their final days, where she had planned to spend her remaining days. But the four feet of mud and water that gushed through the house had demanded something radically different.\n\nTwo decades ago, Ms. Archer and her husband had paid roughly $200,000 for the house and watched it appreciate to more than $300,000. She said it would cost well over $100,000 to renovate the house and her FEMA grant would only cover a small fraction.\n\nVideo\n\nIn the mornings, while staying at a La Quinta Inn, Ms. Archer would make lists in a blue three-ring binder of items lost, mostly items that came to her in her dreams. \u201cI finally stopped trying to sum up my entire life. It was just too stressful. But that list told me that as much as I loved my house, there was no way out of this but to sell,\u201d said Ms. Archer, who spent the first part of her career as a flight attendant then became a police officer for the Port of Houston Authority. \u201cI couldn\u2019t get a loan at my age and with no job. How would I pay it back?\u201d\n\nShe had lost everything once before, as a teenager in a house fire. The crushing loss felt the same; the inability to recover felt far different.\n\nLike other homeowners, Ms. Archer said she had no idea the house was built in a reservoir. She was told over and over that she did not need flood insurance, she said. Two or three times she purchased it anyway and then let the policy expire.\n\nThree years earlier, she had taken out a reverse mortgage, which allows homeowners over 62 years old to convert equity into cash. After the flood, her house was worth less than the loan balance. It left her in a terrible bind. \u201cI am sitting here thinking that I am not going to be able to get out of this situation,\u201d she said.\n\nShe eventually negotiated with the lender to offer the house as a short sale for $125,000. Earlier this month, Ms. Archer closed on the sale and walked away for good. Now fearful of floods and the sound of hard rain, she plans to move near a nephew in Dallas, where she will re-enter the job market 10 years after her retirement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere is no way I could have imagined I would be starting over at this point in my life,\u201d she said, then sighed deeply. \u201cI know everything will be O.K. Eventually.\u201d\n\nStaying Home\n\nOn a fall afternoon, as they were in the garage sorting the few salvageable pieces \u2014 the roar of trucks carting debris in the distance \u2014 Mr. Swanson turned to Ms. Swanson, his wife of 24 years.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to leave. Do you?\u201d he blurted out. Ms. Swanson shook her head. Neither did she.\n\nFor the Swansons, rebuilding was the only choice. They knew it would be hard, but this was home.\n\nInstead of returning to work, Mr. Swanson pitched in on the repairs. \u201cFor now,\u201d Ms. Swanson said, \u201cit make more sense for Jeff to be home helping with the house rather than to be on a job making $12 an hour.\u201d The couple also bought flood insurance.", "title": "Brutal Choice in Houston: Sell Home at a Loss or Face New Floods", "authors": ["Audra D. S. Burch"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But he never trailed in the 28 holes he played Sunday and was never seriously threatened.\n\nThe tougher match was against Thomas, the P.G.A. champion, who needed only to reach the championship match to replace Dustin Johnson at No. 1. Watson went out to a 3-up lead on the front nine, and when Thomas closed to 1 down at the turn with his first birdie putt, Watson won two of the next three holes and regained control. Thomas did not make another birdie until the par-5 16th, and by then it was too late. Watson made his birdie from 3 feet for a 3-and-2 victory.\n\nThomas said he had been too consumed with what was at stake in the semifinals.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t had such a hard time not thinking about something so much,\u201d Thomas said.\n\nNoren beat Thomas in the consolation match, 5 and 3.\n\nOne year after Watson disappeared from among the elite in golf, he has won twice in his last four starts. He was No. 117 in the world when he arrived at Riviera, where he won for the third time in his career.
