Mitchell followed a third-round 75 with a 67.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKelly Kraft was third at 13 under after a 67, and Denny McCarthy (70) was 12 under. Harris English (70) and K. J. Choi (66) topped the group at 11 under.\n\nThe former Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo dropped out on Friday, finishing last in the 132-man field in his PGA Tour debut. He shot 77 and 82 playing as an amateur on a sponsor exemption.\n\nPGA TOUR CHAMPIONS Steve Stricker pulled away on the back nine at Fallen Oak in Biloxi, Miss., and won the Rapiscan Systems Classic, his second straight PGA Tour Champions victory.\n\nStricker, 51, closed with a four-under 68, birdieing all four par-5 holes on the Tom Fazio-designed layout with big and fast greens. He finished at 11-under 205 for a three-stroke victory over Billy Andrade.", "title": "Bubba Watson Cruises to Match Play Title in Texas", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "This is the essence of p\u00e9tillant naturel, though it is now done with intention, often with the help of modern refrigeration equipment, and without shattered glass.\n\nUp until about 15 years ago, this sort of sparkling wine was pretty rare, the method having largely given way to two more modern techniques. One, the method used for Champagne and many other top sparkling wines, requires a finished still wine to be bottled with a little yeast and sweetness. Within the sealed container, a second fermentation begins, which creates the sparkle. This method can yield wines of gorgeous complexity, refinement and finesse.\n\nThe second, the Charmat method, is a technique for making inexpensive sparklers in quantity by doing a second fermentation in pressurized tanks. Of course, the cheapest way to make sparkling wine is to simply pump still wine full of carbon dioxide as you would Coca-Cola. These are more carbonated alcohol delivery beverages than they are wine.\n\nThe modern renaissance of p\u00e9tillant naturel traces back to the early days of natural wines, a genre of minimalist grape-growing and winemaking that over the last 15 years has grown from a small, scattered collection of producers to a niche that has become increasingly popular and influential, though endlessly contentious.\n\nThe Loire Valley, a center for natural wine, was also home to many early p\u00e9tillant naturel revivalists. It was hardly intended to be a movement. Rather, it was a delicious beverage for enjoyment with friends.\n\nBut what is delicious has a way of catching on. This informal, unpretentious sparkling wine, which can be made from an untold number of grapes in styles ranging from hazy, unfiltered and full of sediment to clean-as-a-whistle, has caught on all over the winemaking world.\n\nYet it\u2019s not quite \u201cthe new ros\u00e9.\u201d It\u2019s not being made in industrial quantities, nor has it achieved brand-name status in supermarket aisles. It has ridden the wave of interest in natural wines, which will never be a mass-market phenomenon, no matter how important they are to discerning consumers nor how influential they have been to the wine industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNoting the widening availability of p\u00e9tillant naturel, the wine panel recently tasted through 20 bottles from seven countries, just a cross-section of what is available in retail markets. For the tasting, Florence Fabricant and I were joined by Kimberly Prokoshyn, the head sommelier at Scampi, a new restaurant near Union Square, and Caleb Ganzer, managing partner and wine director at Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels in Lower Manhattan.\n\nWhat was most obvious in our tasting was the high level of quality. This was surprising, not because I associate natural wines with inconsistency but because every type of wine has its share of lemons.\n\nThe flaws in some natural wines glare more because they are not typical in the modern age, when technology and artifice can eliminate issues like excessive volatile acidity or barnyard aromas that come from unwanted yeast strains. But to me, the tedious insipidity of many processed wines is just as much a flaw.\n\nYet these p\u00e9tillants, an almost completely random category where anything goes, showed very few flaws. They were not only easy, approachable and refreshing, the best had resonance, depth and length. And they were diverse.\n\nSome were simply straightforward easy drinking, but others were nuanced and complex, a description rarely associated with p\u00e9tillant naturel. Some seemed raw, as if the producer had captured in the bottle the transformation of juice into wine. Others had a yeasty, bready weight that is seen more often in Champagne.\n\n\u201cThey are not just a gimmick,\u201d Florence said. Kimberly said she was struck by the texture, rawness and pleasing eccentricity of the wines.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t realize I had such a preconceived notion of p\u00e9tillant naturel as an easy sparkling wine,\u201d she said. \u201cThere was great diversity.\u201d\n\nCaleb called them \u201csessionable,\u201d a beer-culture term connoting beverages low enough in alcohol and intensity to permit them to be consumed in quantity while maintaining coherence. Indeed, as near as we could tell after the tasting, only one of the 20 bottles touched 13 percent alcohol \u2014 moderate in today\u2019s world \u2014 and many were under 12 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur favorite was from California, the 2016 Cobolorum from J. Brix, made entirely from riesling grown in Santa Barbara County. It was full of flavor and absolutely delicious.\n\nLike some of the more hands-off p\u00e9t-nats, this was cloudy, almost hazy. As with any p\u00e9tillant naturel, or Champagne-style sparkler, after the yeasts are finished with their fermenting duties, they die, leaving sediment in the bottle.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Champagne, and in some p\u00e9t-nats, the sediment is disgorged, a process of maneuvering the sediment to the neck of the bottle and then ejecting it. But some of the more natural p\u00e9t-nats avoid this step, which can leave a hazy appearance. There is no harm in this; the dead yeast, or lees, can improve the flavor and texture and also can act as an antioxidant. But you might want to keep the bottle standing up so the sediment settles.\n\nOur No. 2 bottle, the lively, deep and resonant 2015 Rurale from Melsheimer in the Mosel region of Germany, was also largely riesling, 80 percent, with the remainder johanniter, a grape I had not knowingly encountered before. No. 3 was the savory, refreshing and bone dry 2014 from Laurent Barth in Alsace, made of a combination of auxerrois and pinot noir.\n\nP\u00e9tillant naturel can sometimes be a bit sweet if the fermentation ends before all the sugar in the wine is consumed. Almost all the wines in our tasting were dry, but our No. 4 bottle, the 2016 Pi\u00e8ge \u00e0 Filles ros\u00e9 from Les Capriades in the Touraine region of the Loire Valley, was not. This wine, made mostly of gamay, was sweet yet juicy and refreshing because it was so well balanced.\n\nThe range and textures of these wines were fascinating. The 2016 Pet Sounds from Jess Miller in the Eola-Amity Hills of the Willamette Valley, made entirely of pinot noir, was creamy and rich, much weightier than some of the others, yet spicy and savory. The 2016 Phaunus Vinho Verde from Aphros in Portugal, made entirely of the loureiro grape, seemed to have the weight and depth of Champagne.\n\nYet the 2016 \u00c9xil\u00e9 ros\u00e9 from Lise et Bertrand Jousset in the Loire Valley, made mostly of gamay, was yeasty let light and lithe, while the 2016 Indigeno from Ancarani in Emilia-Romagna, made of trebbiano, was taut and earthy.\n\nApart from our top 10, we found many other p\u00e9t-nats that we liked, including bottles from Broc Cellars, Franz Strohmeier and Christoph Hoch.\n\nAs different as these wines were, they shared a sort of joyousness and lack of pretension. They are intended to be enjoyed with relish rather than sipped with contemplation, though they will not disappoint if you feel compelled to take notes. They are moderately priced as well, costing largely $20 to $30. So feel free to experiment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTasting P\u00e9tillant Naturel\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605\u00bd J. BRIX COBOLORUM RIESLING P\u00c9TILLANT NATUREL SANTA BARBARA COUNTY KICK ON RANCH 2016 $24\n\nCloudy and textured with tangy, complex aromas and flavors of flowers, dried fruits, citrus and spices.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605\u00bd MELSHEIMER RURALE P\u00c9TILLANT NATUREL MOSEL 2015 $21\n\nIntensely floral aromas; pure, deep, resonant and alive. Made of 80 percent riesling and 20 percent johanniter.(M.S. Walker, Boston)\n\nBEST VALUE: \u2605\u2605\u2605 LAURENT BARTH ALSACE P\u00c9TILLANT NATUREL EXTRA BRUT 2014 $20\n\nYeasty, earthy, rich, savory and refreshing. Mostly auxerrois with some pinot noir. (Louis/Dressner Selections, New York)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 LES CAPRIADES VIN DE FRANCE PI\u00c8GE \u00c0 FILLES P\u00c9TILLANT NATUREL ROS\u00c9 2016 $26\n\nSweet yet juicy and refreshing with bright flavors of tart, spicy cherries; 90 percent gamay. (Selection Massale, Oakland, Calif.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 JESS MILLER PET SOUNDS P\u00c9TILLANT NATUREL EOLA-AMITY HILLS PINOT NOIR 2016 $22\n\nCreamy, rich and fuller bodied than most with spicy, savory flavors.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd LISE ET BERTRAND JOUSSET \u00c9XIL\u00c9 ROS\u00c9 P\u00c9TILLANT VIN DE FRANCE 2016 $23\n\nYeasty and creamy with flavors of tart, spicy cherries, made of gamay. (T. Edward Wines, New York)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd APHROS PHAUNUS VINHO VERDE P\u00c9T NAT BRUT 2016$24\n\nRich and deep with aromas of flowers and savory, saline flavors. (Skurnik Wines, New York)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd JULIEN BRAUD LA BULLE DE L\u2019OUEST MELON DE BOURGOGNE NV $30\n\nRich, raw, dry and earthy with floral aromas and fresh fruit flavors. (Verity Wine Partners, New York)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd ANCARANI RAVENNA I.G.T. INDIGENO TREBBIANO SUR LIE 2016 $22\n\nTaut and savory with lingering peppery, earthy flavors. (Jan D\u2019Amore Wines, Brooklyn, N.Y.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd MATTHIAS HAGER KAMPTAL GR\u00dcNER VELTLINER P\u00c9T-NAT 2017 $24\n\nSimple but lip-smacking with floral aromas and tangy flavors of fresh fruits. (SoilAir Selection, New York)\n\nRecipe: Roquefort, Leek and Walnut Tart\n\nAs demanding and diverse as p\u00e9tillant naturel wines can be, those we sampled were, like Champagne and other sparklers, quite food-friendly. Many were clearly aperitif wines, though a few could accompany a meal. I felt that a dish featuring cheese would suit either option. And because a scintilla of sweetness lingered on the palate with some of them, I selected Roquefort for top billing. The pungent, salty cheese is often served with sweet wines. I tamed it with some cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche and spread it on pastry in a riff on the Alsatian tarte flamb\u00e9e. I included bacon but swapped in leeks for onions and added walnuts, often a partner for Roquefort. Though tarte flamb\u00e9e is frequently made with pizza dough, I used a quick pie pastry instead. FLORENCE FABRICANT\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Bubbles, With Joy: P\u00e9tillant Naturel\u2019s Triumphant Return", "authors": ["Eric Asimov", "Wines Of The Times", "Florence Fabricant"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The low-income housing tax credit was created in 1986 as part of Congress\u2019s last sweeping tax overhaul and has grown into a $9 billion-a-year program. It funds virtually all of the nation\u2019s subsidized rental housing and created a sprawling industry of affordable-housing developers that now makes up a vital piece of the safety net \u2014 especially in high-cost cities like New York, San Francisco and Seattle.\n\nThe program has been increasingly important in the aftermath of the Great Recession. As home building declined sharply and millennials entered the work force, the number of renters surged by about one million a year \u2014 the largest increase since the baby-boom generation came of age in the 1970s, according to the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University.\n\nRents have risen steadily since 2010, pushing the housing cost burden to punishing levels. In 2017, about half of renters paid more than 30 percent of their income on housing, and a quarter paid more than half.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe program works like this: The federal government allocates tax credits that are eventually awarded to affordable-housing developers. The credits are then transferred to corporations \u2014 usually banks \u2014 in exchange for investments in rental buildings for tenants who do not make more than 60 percent of the area\u2019s median income. The corporations then use the credits as a coupon against future taxes.\n\nThe tax bill that was passed last year amounted to a big cut in the program, because with corporations now paying lower tax rates, the credits aren\u2019t as valuable as they once were. Even though the law has been in place only for a few months, it has already forced developers and municipal affordable-housing agencies to scramble to make up millions in funding shortfalls that emerged as the value of the credits fell.\n\nAccording to an analysis by Novogradac & Company, a national accounting firm based in San Francisco, the tax law will reduce the growth of subsidized affordable housing by 235,000 units over the next decade, compounding an existing shortage.\n\nMs. Cantwell\u2019s provision would increase the number of tax credits available, but only for four years. It would also change the income cutoff for affordable projects, making it easier for developers to secure financing.\n\nStill, even if the increase in tax credits was made permanent, only about 30 percent of the decline in affordable housing due to last year\u2019s tax cuts would be restored, according to Novogradac\u2019s analysis.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to help us reclaim some of the units lost by tax reform,\u201d said Michael Novogradac, the firm\u2019s managing partner. \u201cHowever, there\u2019s still a large shortage of units that aren\u2019t going to get produced or preserved, so additional action is going to be needed to get back to the production levels before tax reform.\u201d", "title": "Budget Deal in Congress Includes Help for Affordable Housing", "authors": ["Conor Dougherty"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Neidlinger saw early on that a career in jazz could spell hardship. \u201cBeing out of town all the time and living in cheap hotels, starving to death,\u201d he told All About Jazz. \u201cAnd so I was determined to learn to do every style I could, and it\u2019s put me in good stead.\u201d\n\nImage Mr. Neidlinger teamed with the jazz musician Anthony Braxton, left, for one of his albums for his label, K2B2.\n\nHe complemented his jazz gigs with studio work in the early 1960s, recording on a number of pop singles, including Tony Bennett\u2019s \u201cI Left My Heart in San Francisco.\u201d\n\nBut after being caught with heroin in his possession, Mr. Neidlinger lost his cabaret card \u2014 the New York City-issued license required of musicians playing in nightclubs \u2014 and moved to Providence, R.I. He kicked his drug habit while immersing himself again in classical music.\n\nLater he became a member of the Houston Symphony and received a series of performance grants. He played on the debuts of new works by Cage, Stravinsky and other prominent composers and eventually landed a spot in the prestigious Boston Symphony Orchestra.\n\nIn 1971, he moved to California, lured by the thriving studio work there. He was hired by the California Institute of the Arts and became the principal bassist for the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra. He spent almost 30 years as the principal bassist in the Warner Bros. Studio Orchestra, and recorded with pop stars like Barbra Streisand, Dolly Parton and the Eagles.\n\nAs with so many virtuoso musicians a level below stardom, much of his work was unattributed. Mr. Neidlinger liked to tell the story about the night when he was awakened after midnight by an assistant to Ms. Streisand. He went to the studio, he said, and helped her finish writing the song \u201cEvergreen,\u201d which became the theme song of her 1976 movie \u201cA Star Is Born\u201d and a hit as a commercial release.\n\n\u201cShe never gave me any publishing on it,\u201d he said, referring to a credit that would allow him to collect royalties. \u201cIf she had, I\u2019d be living in Monaco or something.\u201d\n\nBut to some degree Mr. Neidlinger took business into his own hands; in 1979 he started a small record label, K2B2, with the saxophonist Marty Krystall. In 1980 the label released \u201cReady for the 90\u2019s\u201d as Krystall Klear and the Buells, Mr. Neidlinger\u2019s first album as a leader since \u201cNew York City R&B.\u201d", "title": "Buell Neidlinger, Acclaimed Genre-Crossing Bassist, Dies at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "At their core, programs like these are meant to connect employees at different levels and help them get to know people in other departments. They are meant to alleviate the barriers that rise between people in different roles and also at different pay levels. They are meant to build workplace trust in the hope that it will extend to the work the company does.\n\nPhoto\n\nNathalie Perez, Silvercrest\u2019s receptionist, said she initially felt unsure about how the CPR course would help her understand the company any better. Assistants, portfolio managers, members of the executive committee all together on the floor trying to resuscitate a mannequin was not an everyday sight at a firm that projects a genteel, tidewater Virginia air in its marketing materials.\n\nBut since that first course Ms. Perez has taken 11 more courses. \u201cBefore, I wouldn\u2019t just call up the director of operations and ask her a question that seems silly, but I need help with,\u201d Ms. Perez said. \u201cNow I have the confidence to call her and ask her directly and I know I\u2019ll get a helpful response.\u201d\n\nFor a company\u2019s clients, classes like these can help build trusted working relationships that a company hopes will translate into more seamless service.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf we find something in common, we\u2019re more likely to connect and bond, no matter what it is we\u2019re doing,\u201d said Sue Langley, chief executive of the Langley Group, which works with companies and nonprofits globally to improve workplaces.\n\nShe said those connections could ultimately lead to greater bonds of trust and comfort within a company, which is also good for customers.\n\n\u201cIf I see your name on the phone, I\u2019m going to pick up in a welcoming manner,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s how can I help versus what do they want?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDean Dewey, a vice president at Silvercrest, was one of the people charged with creating Silvercrest Academy in the summer of 2016. Mr. Dewey said Mr. Hough met with a group of seven people being groomed for leadership positions in the firm to brainstorm the idea.\n\n\u201cHe said he wanted to plant the seed and walk away and let us run it,\u201d Mr. Dewey said. \u201cHe wanted a curriculum that would educate the firm but also bring the firm together.\u201d\n\nThe team came up with a program divided into corporate, personal and professional development. In addition to first aid and CPR, there have been courses on the firm\u2019s trading systems, the process of asset allocation, the role that marketing plays, how to set goals and manage your time and even an introduction to backgammon.\n\nLast year, Silvercrest Academy ran 27 classes, with between 10 and 35 people in each one. The group planning the courses decided to eliminate one thing that can induce people to attend an internal meeting: the food bribe.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not the right motivation, even though it works,\u201d Mr. Dewey said. \u201cWe\u2019ve avoided it because we want people to learn and take the course with some sort of seriousness.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe idea of using workplace courses to advance productivity and trust is rooted in the disruptive culture of Silicon Valley. Google and Amazon have long had speakers series meant to bring their employees together to learn something new and challenge their thinking.\n\nMs. Langley said increasingly her clients included more established, old-line companies that had realized a breakdown in trust and communication between their workers was hurting company productivity and ultimately what they did for clients.\n\nShe said that one client, who was in charge of safety at a large manufacturing company, had learned to start meetings with a list of the things his team had done well and saved the near-misses or accidents where someone was hurt until later. That is a reversal of what he used to do and has boosted the morale of his team, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt has created a more trusting environment where employees are working to improve processes, not worrying that they are going to make a mistake.\n\nTaking down that divide between employees was what Mr. Hough set out to do with Silvercrest Academy. He wanted a more integrated workplace but he also wanted his effort to help the bottom line.\n\n\u201cThe business has to have segregated functions to be effective,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the flip side is you have people in different jobs not understanding what people are doing and their value to the business. You want to break those barriers down so people can cooperate.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe added, \u201cIn our business, and Wall Street in general, what is valued is often confused with money.\u201d\n\nRobert Savino, a retired Wall Street trader and Silvercrest client, said he felt the courses might benefit him as a client. He said he applied something similar but more ad hoc with the people supporting his trading desk.\n\n\u201cI knew what the importance was of having a good relationship between me and the people doing the back-office work,\u201d Mr. Savino said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of difference between us. What you have to maintain is a mutual respect. When people respect you they\u2019ll help you solve the problem. Things run smoothly when they\u2019re together.\u201d", "title": "Building Trust at Financial Firms With CPR and First Aid", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "For those who think that Bulgari is synonymous with the \u203250s and \u203260s La Dolce Vita years, a new book delves into other stylish eras that have shaped the famed Italian house \u2014 all told through the rich lives of its clients.\n\n\u201cBulgari: Treasures of Rome,\u201d published in February to coincide with the opening of the jewelry house\u2019s New Curiosity Shop there, was a four-year labor of love for its author, Vincent Meylan.\n\nFor him, Bulgari\u2019s heyday began early. \u201cEven if it wasn\u2019t called La Dolce Vita, it started in Rome in the \u203220s, with people like Dorothy di Frasso, Mary Pickford, Gary Cooper, Marlene Dietrich and the prince and princesses of the old Roman families,\u201d said Mr. Meylan, who also has written jewelry-themed books on the houses of Van Cleef & Arpels and Boucheron. \u201cThat was the original idea of the book: to write about what started not after World War II, but after World War I.\u201d\n\n[MORE: Bulgari\u2019s New Curiosity Shop]\n\nThe 300-page volume opens with a chapter on Ms. di Frasso, a famed hostess married to an Italian count, who, Mr. Meylan said, was his favorite person in the book because she has been \u201ccompletely forgotten.\u201d Through letters, articles and speaking to people, including members of the Bulgari family, who knew the American socialite, Mr. Meylan came to understand Ms. di Frasso\u2019s importance to Bulgari.", "title": "Bulgari\u2019s Clients Prove to Be the \u2018Treasures of Rome\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "It decided the answer lay in the Old Curiosity Shop. Back in fin-de-si\u00e8cle Rome, Mr. Bulgari had picked the name of Charles Dickens\u2019s novel in hopes of attracting well-heeled British and American tourists in the Eternal City. \u201cSotirio Bulgari didn\u2019t want to only attract Italians,\u201d Ms. Schwarzer said. \u201cHe already knew then that he wanted Bulgari to be international.\u201d\n\nBut rather than a Victorian cabinet of curiosities, his was a paean to objects collected on his travels: jewelry, of course, but also silver buttons, glass perfume bottles and objects etched with the Islamic and Byzantine motifs that then were all the rage. The Old Curiosity Shop was a temple for the inquisitive, imaginative and well-traveled \u2014 and a profile that, more than a century later and some 300 boutiques on, was not far from the Bulgari customer of today.\n\nSo the New Curiosity Shop was born, playing on Mr. Bulgari\u2019s founding ideas of discovery and inspiration, most notably by changing the shop\u2019s theme, d\u00e9cor and products every six months. \u201cBulgari has over 130 years of history, and with each change, we can reveal a piece of this history in a younger, modern way,\u201d Ms. Schwarzer said. \u201cIt\u2019s about curiosity \u2014 and curiosity is never static.\u201d\n\nVisitors to the shop first encounter a stylish mirrored gold bar, its surface doubling as a touch-screen interface to information about the Bulgari brand. During a visit in February, customers were seated around it, casually trying on jewelry, watches and handbags they had taken from the displays and glass drawers. (There are shop assistants but they don\u2019t seem to spend a lot of time guarding product-filled vitrines, like the salespeople of yesterday.)\n\nPhoto\n\nIn one drawer was an archive picture of Mr. Bulgari; in another, a piece from Bulgari\u2019s heritage collection: a round gold cigarette lighter from the \u203280s.\n\nHanging above was an impressive, custom-made chandelier by the Murano glassmakers Venini \u2014 which took eight people to install \u2014 and hip dance music played.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBehind the bar was a room Ms. Schwarzer called \u201cItalian hospitality,\u201d where \u203240s-era Guglielmo Ulrich tables and chairs, upholstered in funky contemporary fabrics, offered a place to have a drink while browsing Bulgari books, or signature collections like B.zero1 rings or ceramic Serpenti watches.\n\nThe third, and final, room was dedicated to personalization \u2014 that millennial power word \u2014 where visitors can order customized Bulgari handbags. The choice of leathers, clasps and straps are stored in a wall of brass-fronted cabinets that, again, are open to all.\n\nIt was exciting to think that in six months, the entire shop will look entirely different.\n\nThe debut theme was Mirabilia, Latin for marvels, interpreted by Bulgari in futuristic, outer-space decorations. Nestled among the products were handmade paper artworks of planets and astronauts, which Bulgari commissioned from the young Italian artist Mauro Seresini. And there was an installation of furniture and the whimsical black-and-white portrait plates by Maison Fornasetti.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo increase the sense of exclusivity, Bulgari also will be creating one-off collections for each theme.\n\nMirabilia\u2019s selection included a necklace and ring set of diamonds, blue topaz and tanzanite in its Divas\u2019 Dream style, which was displayed alongside the handwritten label: \u201cOnly in R*me Exclusivity.\u201d\n\nAlso sold only in the shop: a special Condotti10 jewelry line featuring a pink-gold bracelet and matching ring with interior design elements from both the flagship and New Curiosity Shop: graphic circles, stars and squares set in diamond pav\u00e9, malachite and mother-of-pearl. Prices are on request.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere also is a limited-edition watch, a Serpenti Twist Your Time design featuring interchangeable pink and blue metallic wraparound leather straps. The company, which is based in Austin, Tex., and also operates a networking service for professionals and a friend-matching function, is donating $100,000 toward a nationwide protest against gun violence planned for later this month.\n\n\u201cCompared to what\u2019s going on with Facebook and Twitter, we take a very proactive approach,\u201d she said. \u201cIf I could police every other social platform in the world, I would.\u201d\n\nBumble\u2019s policy is likely to meet with \u201csignificant backlash\u201d from certain users and could even spawn niche dating apps for firearms aficionados, said Sarah Roberts, an assistant professor of information studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. (Some matchmaking services for gun advocates already exist.)\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an interesting demonstration of the ways in which apps and social media platforms both reflect and are sensitive to cultural change and serve as a cultural barometer but can also codify what is acceptable behavior,\u201d she said. \u201cThey have immense power to make changes like that, seemingly overnight, typically behind closed doors.\u201d\n\nMs. Herd plans to eventually filter out mentions of guns in written content as well.\n\n\u201cThis is not a politically driven decision, nor a decision driven by hatred of people\u2019s personal beliefs or choices,\u201d she said. \u201cNot everyone\u2019s going to love us for it, but it\u2019s the right thing to do.\u201d", "title": "Bumble Dating App Bans Gun Images After Mass Shootings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTrade wars are good, and easy to win.\u201d So declared Donald Trump a few weeks ago, after announcing tariffs on steel and aluminum. Actually, trade wars are rarely good, and not at all easy to win \u2014 especially if you have no idea what you\u2019re doing. And boy, do these people not know what they\u2019re doing.\n\nIt\u2019s odd, in a way. After all, trade is clearly an issue about which Trump is truly passionate. He tried to kill Obamacare, but to all appearances his main concern was tarnishing his predecessor\u2019s legacy. He wanted a tax cut, but more to score a \u201cwin\u201d than because he cared about what was in it. But reducing the trade deficit has been a long-term Trump obsession, so you might expect him to learn something about how world trade works, or at least surround himself with people who do understand the subject.\n\nBut he hasn\u2019t. And what he doesn\u2019t know can and will hurt you.\n\nIn the case of steel, here\u2019s what happened: First came the splashy announcement of big tariffs, ostensibly in the name of national security \u2014 infuriating U.S. allies, which are the main source of our steel imports. Then came what looks like a climb-down: The administration has exempted Canada, Mexico, the European Union and others from those tariffs.\n\nWas this climb-down a reaction to threats of retaliation, or did the administration not at first realize that the tariffs would mainly hit our allies? Either way, Trump may have gotten the worst of both worlds: angering countries that should be our friends and establishing a reputation as an untrustworthy ally and trading partner, without even doing much for the industry he was supposedly trying to help.", "title": "Opinion | Bumbling Into a Trade War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "On a tour of her Upper East Side home, Bunny Williams, the interior designer and high society tastemaker, gestured to a dog bed in the living room.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s Regency style,\u201d she said of the handsome wooden frame. I wish I had that extra funding, but I don\u2019t, so I just try to find another way to take care of that.\u201d\n\nHis teammate Steve Emt, who served in the Army, teaches seventh-grade math in Connecticut, where, to his eternal gratitude, the school board grants him time off to compete. Emt, a former walk-on basketball player at the University of Connecticut who became a paraplegic from a car accident in 1995, recruits veterans to curling.\n\n\u201cI was told that I could be a Paralympian,\u201d Emt said. \u201cBeing a young sport, it\u2019s a big selling point. The chances of vets making the basketball team are slim. So, come curl. If we can tell them, \u2018Hey, we\u2019ve got a trip to the U.S. Open in New York that could be fully funded for you because you\u2019re a veteran, come on up and play and learn the sport,\u2019 they\u2019ll be hooked.\u201d\n\nRick Adams, the United States Olympic Committee\u2019s chief of Paralympics, agreed that infrastructure and support for veterans across the nascent stages of an athlete\u2019s development were beneficial, but he hesitated to say that could be parlayed into an increased presence on the American team.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a possibility, but most of the time what you find is that they may not have been in a sport for a long time,\u201d Adams said. \u201cI think there\u2019s a balance between someone who\u2019s been participating for a long period of time and someone who\u2019s been in the military for a long time and then they\u2019re in a situation where they\u2019re Paralympic-eligible and take up a sport. I don\u2019t know I would extrapolate out to say that they\u2019re at an advantage.\u201d\n\nThe U.S.O.C. bases how much money to award sports in the Olympics and Paralympics on many factors, but above all success. It is unlikely that the wheelchair curlers, who have yet to medal since the sport was added in 2006 and finished in last place here out of 12 nations, will receive more money than in the past. And so Schieber, to improve the team\u2019s fortunes in the future, might be more likely to recruit as many military veterans as possible: He knows that they\u2019d be more likely to afford the expenses to compete.\n\n\u201cIf I\u2019m looking at two athletes that are absolutely equal, does it fall into my mind that the veteran may have the better opportunity for funding and may be long-term a better athlete down the road?\u201d Schieber said. \u201cYou hate to say it. Following Mr. Bailey\u2019s decision last fall to step down, after years of flatlining sales and a failed experiment that saw him take on a dual role as both chief creative and chief executive, the brand unveiled a turnaround strategy at the end of last year.\n\nMr. Gobbetti intends to take the brand more upmarket to the realm of rivals like Gucci or Dior, with higher prices and profit margins to match. But sales thus far have continued to miss analyst forecasts, and the industry had been waiting to see who would be appointed to lead the creative aspects of Burberry into the next era.\n\nNow, with most editors and buyers in Paris for fashion week, they have their answer.\n\nAnd most seemed impressed \u2014 if somewhat surprised \u2014 by the decision.\n\n\u201cI love the idea. If these people see the administration as unequipped to handle an emergency, they owe the country a firsthand account of our vulnerability. But there is, at least, a certain logic to the argument made in their defense. That logic, however, only holds for those who remain on decent terms with Trump. Which means that if there\u2019s one person who has no excuse for not speaking out, it\u2019s Tillerson, once one of the most powerful private citizens in America, now humbled and defiled by his time in Trump\u2019s orbit.\n\nThere\u2019s little doubt that Tillerson holds Trump in contempt and disagrees with large parts of his agenda. After Charlottesville, Tillerson refused to say that the president\u2019s words represented American values. (\u201cThe president speaks for himself,\u201d he told Fox News.) In office, he struggled to save the Iran nuclear deal and opposed Trump\u2019s \u2014 and Jared Kushner\u2019s \u2014 support for a blockade of Qatar by other Arab states. After his ignominious firing, he gave a live address in which he didn\u2019t even mention the president\u2019s name.\n\n\u201cRex is never going to be back in a position where he can have any degree of influence or respect from this president,\u201d my Republican source said. Because of that, the source continued, \u201cRex is under a moral mandate to do his best to burn it down.\u201d That would mean telling the truth \u201cabout how concerned he is about the leadership in the Oval Office, and what underpins those concerns and what he\u2019s seen.\u201d\n\nIn this case, patriotism and self-interest point in the same direction. Before entering this administration, Tillerson was a vastly more respected businessman than Trump; as chief executive of Exxon Mobil, he presided over what The Times described as a \u201cstate within a state.\u201d Now the first line of his obituary will be about a year of abject failure as the country\u2019s lead diplomat, culminating in a humiliation fit for reality TV.\n\nThe only way he will ever change that is by joining those who would bring this despicable presidency down. If Tillerson came out and said that the president is unfit, and perhaps even that venal concerns for private gain have influenced his foreign policy, impeachment wouldn\u2019t begin tomorrow, but Trump\u2019s already narrow public support would shrink further. Republican members of Congress like Bob Corker, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, might be induced to rediscover their spines and perform proper oversight.\n\nLast year, Axios\u2019s Allen and Jim VandeHei half-jokingly called the insiders trying to circumscribe Trump the \u201cCommittee to Save America.\u201d Now the committee, having failed, is disbanding. Many of them have been prosecuted on charges of violating antiterrorism laws introduced in 2015 by the conservative government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy.\n\nThe protest case, however, dates from 2007, when Catalan secessionism was still a fringe political movement. It was very different than anything I\u2019d done. There weren\u2019t any cars or things jumping other cars or girls and stuff. It was a fun picture, and he was a nice man.\u201d\n\nVisiting New York from Valhalla, his estate in Jupiter, Fla., Mr. Reynolds, 82, arrived at The New York Times with an entourage before heading to a career retrospective at the Metrograph in downtown Manhattan. His body ravaged from stunt work, he made his way with help from a fancy cane. But he fired off a barrage of jokes, and that storied charisma was still there. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nHow much did Adam Rifkin get right about you in his script?\n\nWell, I don\u2019t know. I mean, I\u2019ve been acting for 60 years now. I don\u2019t know who the hell I am. But I think he did a real good job. We wanted the guy to be an Everyman who thinks he\u2019s a movie star, but it\u2019s over. There are these ups and downs where he realizes he\u2019s not a movie star anymore. So he just sort of wanders into the ghettos and streets and makes friends with a lot of down-and-outers, which is what he is. He\u2019s a real sweet man, when you get to know him, I hope.\n\nSweet but something of a rascal.\n\nI think you have to be a little bit of a rascal, because people would be disappointed if I didn\u2019t do that. [Chuckles] We\u2019re only here for a little while, and you\u2019ve got to have some fun, right? I don\u2019t take myself seriously, and I think the ones that do, there\u2019s some sickness with people like that. That\u2019s why I live in Florida.\n\nVic butts heads with Ariel Winter\u2019s Lil. What was she like to work with?\n\nShe started out trying to be tough. Her language was atrocious. I didn\u2019t like it. So I took her around behind the wagon and said: \u201cAriel, I don\u2019t know if you heard Anne Bancroft talk like that or who, but I can tell you Sally [Field] doesn\u2019t. And you don\u2019t have to. It doesn\u2019t mean anything. But not only that, it throws me. I think I\u2019m doing a scene with this girl, and you say the F-word and we don\u2019t need it. But He Regrets Nothing.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Andy Byford, the president of New York City Transit, has met with the Police Department to encourage the agency to increase its vigilance. Blocking the bus lane, \u201cis selfish, and it\u2019s unacceptable,\u201d Mr. Byford said in a recent interview aboard a bus that was forced to swerve in and out of a designated bus lane to avoid parked vans and idling taxis.\n\n\u201cI get that people have to deliver things, but the bus lane should be for the buses, period,\u201d Mr. Byford said, adding that the transit agency is developing a plan to improve bus service that may include adding front-facing cameras mounted on buses, a measure that other cities have taken to strengthen enforcement of bus-only lanes.\n\nIncreasing the number of bus and bike lanes, but under-enforcing the rules to keep them unimpeded, \u201cis one of these programs that ratchets up New Yorker sincere cynicism about government doing the right thing,\u201d Mr. White said.\n\nTo gather actual data on how often blockages occur, Mr. Bell downloaded 10 days of publicly available video from a Department of Transportation camera mounted on a traffic light at the corner of 145th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Then he fed over 2,000 images of different types of vehicles, like trucks, buses and cars into his computer, training it to identify what exactly was blocking the way. In the case of bus stops, for example, Mr. Bell adjusted the computer program so that it was able to differentiate between buses that are supposed to be there from vehicles that were sitting there illegally.\n\nHis work took about three weeks. After the programming was complete, it took the computer about a day to crunch though the 10 days of footage. Mr. Bell\u2019s program only measured the percentage of time the lanes on his test block were obstructed, but from that he said he was able to extrapolate actual numbers and calculated about 850 vehicles blocking the bike lane and over 1,000 in the bus lane. He has made the source code he developed to monitor the lanes free and publicly available online in the hope that it will be picked up and used to amplify the extent of the issue.\n\n\u201cI want to raise up New York City,\u201d said Mr. Bell, who grew up on the Upper West Side, and attended Horace Mann School and Columbia University. \u201cI never want to live anywhere else, but we have big problems. We have big problems especially when it comes to transportation. (LivingSocial was eventually sold to its competitor Groupon in 2016.) The relationships started largely in secret, or at the very least went unmentioned in public.\n\nWorking long hours together fostered strong friendships among the group.\n\n\u201cThe culture was such that we were constantly working events, constantly working as a team,\u201d Ms. Becker said.\n\nThe group became so close that they spent much of their free time together on the weekends. Ms. Becker and Mr. Hirschhorn were hatching one of those group weekend plans when Mr. Hirschhorn had a different idea.\n\n\u201cJeremy and I decided to go bike riding from the East Village to Coney Island,\u201d Ms. Becker recalled. \u201cWe were G-Chatting at work, and I asked him if we should invite the others, and he said no. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The survey, which took nearly a year to complete, comes as the conditions at CUNY\u2019s cafeterias have increasingly alarmed students, faculty and the others. The main cafeteria at Kingsborough Community College was forced to close for a period in December after the city\u2019s Department of Health in December found mice and flies. John Jay College announced in January that it would search for a new food service vendor after its Dining Commons received a C inspection rating.\n\nAbout two dozen workers, meanwhile, testified at a CUNY public hearing in November, charging health violations and making allegations of harassment, wage theft and discrimination. In response, William C. Thompson Jr., CUNY\u2019s chairman, said at a board meeting this month that \u201coutraged\u201d board members were \u201ccommitted to ensuring that food service workers enjoy dignity in their workplaces on our campus.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is something that we are not going to let slide,\u201d he said.\n\nAccording to the survey, 19 percent of the workers reported being injured on the job \u2014 with most suffering falls, cuts and burns. Nearly half reported an annual household income of under $30,000, and one-fifth said that they had more than one job. But only seven workers said that they had health insurance through their job, while about four-fifths said that they received Medicaid.\n\n\u201cWhen we learned about the working conditions and health and safety issues at campus food vendors and cafeterias, we were shocked,\u201d said Stuart Appelbaum, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. As a result, he said, his union has launched a campaign to \u201censure that their workers are treated with dignity and respect and that students and faculty get the services they deserve at CUNY.\u201d\n\nTightening control over all CUNY-related foundations has been a goal of Mr. Thompson, a former city comptroller who was appointed in 2016 by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, since the New York State inspector general criticized the university\u2019s financial practices as \u201cripe for abuse.\u201d To that end, Mr. Thompson said at the board meeting that CUNY would seek to centralize the awarding of future food service contracts, in hopes of identifying two or three vendors who could effectively serve all campuses.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe report recommends that these contracts \u2014 including scorecards related to contract compliance \u2014 be more easily accessible. It also recommends that CUNY consolidate its contracting process to ensure more accountability.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTwo vendors which have been criticized frequently are Metropolitan Food Service and MBJ Food Services, which operate on nine campuses. Chen"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The White House has created a working group to prepare for the landmark meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea. But Mr. Trump\u2019s sudden ousting on Tuesday of Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson could delay critical elements of the planning until the Senate confirms his successor, Mike Pompeo.\n\nFew officials expect Mr. Pompeo\u2019s arrival at the State Department to derail the meeting itself, as long as the president and Mr. Kim remain committed to it. But Mr. Tillerson\u2019s departure deprives the White House of the person most experienced in efforts to reach out to North Korea. As the C.I.A. director, Mr. Pompeo has focused more on the threats posed by Pyongyang.\n\nMr. Pompeo will not be able to establish contact with the South Korean foreign minister, let alone his North Korean counterpart, until the Senate approves his nomination \u2014 a process that officials on Capitol Hill said could take several weeks. The White House has not yet even completed the paperwork to begin that process, the officials said.\n\nAdding to the confusion is the lack of official confirmation of a meeting from North Korea. Mr. Kim\u2019s offer was relayed to Mr. Trump by two envoys from South Korea who had recently visited him in Pyongyang. The Rev. John Job, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.\n\nMrs. Burns, 31, is an associate in the wealth management group of Allen & Company, an investment advisory firm in New York. She graduated from Boston College and received a law degree from the University of Virginia.\n\nShe is a daughter of Catherine P. O\u2019Hern and James K. O\u2019Hern of Morristown, N.J. The bride\u2019s father is the executive director of member engagement at the Conference Board, a nonprofit business membership and research group in New York. Her mother is a lawyer at the New York law firm Clausen Miller.\n\nMr. Burns, also 31, works in East Rutherford, N.J., as the chief executive of Epta America, the exclusive representative of the 7Days food brand and distributor of its products in the United States; his father, Mr. Burns III, is the chairman of the company. The groom graduated from Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., and received an M.B.A. from Cornell.\n\nHe is also a son of Ligerie P. Burns; his parents live in Saddle River, N.J. The groom\u2019s father is also a partner of Great Falls Consulting, a consultancy for product development of snack foods, in East Rutherford. The groom\u2019s mother, a former lawyer in Morristown, is retired as the owner of an exercise studio that was in Ridgewood, N.J.\n\nThe couple met in April 2017 on the dating app Bumble.", "title": "Caitlin O\u2019Hern, James Burns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nResponding to public outcry over a police shooting in which an unarmed black man was killed in his own backyard in Sacramento, Attorney General Xavier Becerra of California said Tuesday his office would step in to oversee the investigation.\n\nThe shooting of Stephon Clark, 22, widely viewed in publicly released police videos, has triggered demonstrations and community anguish, the latest example of an African-American man killed by the police under ambiguous circumstances.\n\nMr. Becerra, speaking with city officials, including the mayor and police chief, announced that the California Department of Justice would also review the Sacramento police\u2019s training and policies regarding the use of force.\n\nChief Daniel Hahn of the Sacramento Police Department said he welcomed the state\u2019s involvement in the wake of \u201cextremely high emotions, anger and hurt in our city.\u201d He said his department would grant full access to state investigators.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Clark was killed March 18 by officers responding to a report of a suspect breaking the windows of vehicles. Officers confronted Mr. Clark in the backyard of his grandmother\u2019s home, where he lived, at which point he advanced toward the officers while extending an object, according to an initial police statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVideo from body cameras and a police helicopter overhead showed that officers shouted that Mr. Clark had a gun, and then fired 20 shots, continuing to shoot after he dropped to his hands and knees.", "title": "California Attorney General to Investigate Stephon Clark\u2019s Killing", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Taylor Made Farm, a leading thoroughbred operation in Kentucky, had bought into the champion and spent the summer of 2015 determining what to do.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCalifornia Chrome was a Kentucky Derby winner, and he came close to winning the Triple Crown, but it was a year later and he was off form,\u201d said Duncan Taylor, the president and chief executive of Taylor Made. \u201cIf we had retired him then, he would have stood for $15,000, and if he had 100 live foals, we would have made $1.5 million. If you go to Dubai and win the Dubai World Cup, you make $6 million less the fees, so it ends up about $4.8 million.\n\n\u201cYou are weighing these things, and we knew we had a horse who had already shown he was a world-class athlete. Everything was basically right with him, he just needed some time off.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBalancing business with horsemanship, it was determined California Chrome, who had some bone bruising, would go to Taylor Made to rest and ideally race as a 5-year-old. It proved to be the smart, and sporting, decision.\n\n[READ MORE: The Dubai World Cup, a Story of Horses and Money]\n\nCalifornia Chrome romped to an almost four-length victory in Dubai the following March, and his win was ultimately named the Moment of the Year by the National Thoroughbred Racing Association.\n\nHis triumph, which included drama as his saddle slipped, was part of another championship season that culminated in him once again being named Horse of the Year.\n\nComing back as an older horse proved California Chrome\u2019s 2014 Triple Crown run was not a fluke, which made him more commercial as a stallion, and it meant his popularity with the general public continued to grow.\n\nRetired and standing for $40,000, California Chrome \u2014 whose name is a result of the fact he was born in California and has significant white, or chrome, markings \u2014 was bred to 145 mares in the Northern Hemisphere last year. A mare\u2019s gestation period is about 11 months, and the first foals sired by California Chrome are being born this spring.\n\n\u201cWith California Chrome, there is a real pedigree pattern that is very similar to what Triple Crown winner Seattle Slew had,\u201d Taylor said. \u201cTo have that kind of breeding further back in his pedigree, that\u2019s how you get a great horse like that. Seattle Slew had the same kind of breeding, and he ended up becoming a good stallion.\u201d\n\nWhile Taylor Made is all in on promoting its star, whether California Chrome succeeds as a stallion will be determined in the years to come, as his first runners will not hit the track until 2020. A stallion\u2019s fee is initially determined by his own accomplishments and pedigree, then later by how his foals sell, and ultimately, by how his progeny run.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe first two stages are largely speculative, and while the last one is not, it takes years to determine. For example, the most expensive stallion in North America is Tapit, who has wildly outperformed expectations. He first stood for $15,000 before dropping to $12,500 because his popularity waned. When his runners hit the track though, he became the leading sire in the country and now he commands $300,000. Tapit is also an exception to the rule.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe number of stallions that actually make it are probably 1 out of 15, and there might be 3 out of 15 that look like they are going to make it,\u201d Taylor said. \u201cThis is a very emotional business. It changes easily, and it is all about having the momentum at the right time.\u201d\n\nTaylor Made is aware that California Chrome\u2019s fans are still invested in his story, and it is part of an initiative called Horse Country, a nonprofit started in Kentucky by farms, equine medical clinics, and other equine attractions looking to offer experiences to the public.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHorse Country serves as the central booking outlet and first began arranging tours of farms and industry businesses at the end of 2015. Today, visits with California Chrome and American Pharoah, who is at Ashford Stud, are two of the most common requests.\n\nAccording to Horse Country officials, more than 8,600 fans have come to Taylor Made, and most are there to see California Chrome. This led to the creation of another tour called The California Chrome Experience, which guarantees meeting both the horse and some of his first foals. It is almost sold out.\n\n\u201cI think people were so compelled by California Chrome because of his underdog story and his longevity,\u201d said Anne Hardy, the executive director of Horse Country. \u201cHe was on the track longer than we typically see champions racing now. People love a special way to connect authentically, and that the Taylors would be so open to welcoming guests in so close is exceptional.\u201d\n\nThe Taylors want to help the sport grow, and California Chrome\u2019s popularity is a way to get people to the farm to see behind the scenes. With that in mind, they also partnered with adventure magazine True.Ink to offer fans a chance to vote on a broodmare to be covered by California Chrome with an opportunity to buy into the resulting foal.\n\nAccording to True.Ink, more than 600 people joined the project, which is called The People\u2019s Horse, in an effort to breed the world\u2019s first crowdfunded racehorse. The chosen mare, Colerful Bride, will deliver in April.\n\n\u201cHorse racing for the most part in America is boiled down to brief moments,\u201d said True.Ink\u2019s founder Geoffrey Gray. \u201cThere is the Kentucky Derby and mint juleps and celebrities, and then the year turns. But there is so much more to a horse\u2019s life, and there is more to the experience.\n\n\u201cNot only is this project a way to get people involved in horse racing, but it is another way to be part of California Chrome\u2019s legacy. It is a way to be part of the California Chrome family, only in this version, the family is going to be a lot larger than normal.\u201d", "title": "California Chrome Was a Winner, but What About His Kids?", "authors": ["Amanda Duckworth"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "As a result, the Reno housing market has gone from moribund to scorching. As of February, the median home price in the metropolitan area was about $340,000, more than double its recessionary trough of about $150,000, according to Zillow. The inventory of homes for sale was down 22 percent from a year earlier, according to Redfin, and sales were happening at a much faster clip. The typical home for sale was under contract in 55 days, 24 days faster than a year earlier.\n\nIn Reno and elsewhere, one distinguishing feature of the recent migration is that it is not limited to retirees who sold their home with plans to funnel the profits toward a cheaper and lower-tax retirement. There is also an influx of young professionals like Brian Quon, a automation engineer at Tesla.\n\nMr. Quon, 37, moved to Reno last year, mostly for professional reasons. He bought a house for $400,000, about a third of what his home in San Jose, Calif., was worth, and he said Reno was friendlier and had a slower pace. He said he was not really aware of the debate about growing pains, because he was extremely busy at work and almost no one he worked with was from Nevada.\n\n\u201cAs the kids grow up and go to school, I\u2019m sure we\u2019ll be more involved in the community,\u201d said Mr. Quon, who is married and has two children under 3.", "title": "California Housing Problems Are Spilling Across Its Borders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Doesn\u2019t that mean, in effect, that today\u2019s teachers are being paid less?\n\nThe reality is that pension funds are not busting most budgets and employees are going to the bargaining table to help employers ensure pensions are funded and stable and there for them when they retire. And if that means negotiating their salaries down, that\u2019s a choice employees make. I don\u2019t see these employees getting any credit for going to the table and eating those costs.\n\nDo you think cities and states will eventually need to raise taxes to cover rising retirement costs?\n\nNo.\n\nSome cities, such as Palo Alto, have talked about opening up their labor negotiations so citizens have a better idea of what kinds of services they are paying for and how the costs break down. Thoughts?\n\nI\u2019m generally for transparency, but you have to be very careful because at some point if you bring the public in it changes the dynamic. And why just collective bargaining? In Orange County when they proposed this the union said, \u201cO.K. if you want to make it public, let\u2019s pass a law that says let\u2019s make everything (including negotiations with city contractors) public.\u201d And then all of a sudden the management said, \u201cWe no longer want it anymore.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). [The Los Angeles Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Westside Pavilion along Pico Boulevard in west Los Angeles was once a model mecca of retail. The mall made an appearance in \u201cClueless,\u201d the 1995 film that chronicled the escapades of a group of wealthy high school students.\n\nBut the place has steadily lost its sheen over the years, eclipsed by pristine outdoor malls and online shopping. Last year, Nordstrom shut its doors and Macy\u2019s will close by the end of the month.\n\nRoughly 80 percent of the retail space will be converted into offices by 2021, developers announced this month. The remade building will include about 500,000 square feet for offices and 100,000 for retail.\n\nWhile the news has inspired much teenage-years nostalgia online, it appears few will miss actually shopping there: Several Instagram photos posted in recent weeks show a nearly empty space. \u201cDeath of the American mall,\u201d one user wrote. \u201cWeird time to be alive.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. The law allows state law enforcement to communicate with federal immigration authorities in the case of serious crimes. You think the list of crimes isn\u2019t broad enough?\n\nA. That\u2019s correct. For example, repeat drunk driving \u2014 you get someone who is arrested two or three times; domestic battery, assault on a peace officer; animal cruelty or abuse; serial theft \u2014 someone who has been arrested multiple times for shoplifting.\n\nQ. You are also concerned about gang members.\n\nA. If someone is in custody \u2014 and it could be for a minor offense \u2014 and if that person is a known member of a gang that is a criminal enterprise, like MS-13 for example, we see no reason why that person should be released back into the community. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: An Oscars Roundup You Can Read in 3 Minutes", "authors": ["Matt Stevens", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nDelaine Eastin, a former Democratic member of the State Assembly and onetime superintendent of public education, is one of nearly 30 candidates running to succeed Gov. Jerry Brown. California Today is planning occasional Q. and A. sessions with candidates for office, and we\u2019re starting with Ms. Eastin. The interview has been edited and condensed.\n\nQ. How much do you see yourself continuing with \u2014 or not \u2014 programs and policies put in place under Governor Brown?\n\nA. Jerry Brown has very high marks when it comes to financial responsibility and he\u2019s a strong environmental governor. Always has been. I don\u2019t give him as high marks in education. I give his father the high marks in education. His father was amazing. Having said that, Jerry Brown has a lot to be proud of, and there\u2019s a lot we should continue and I will.\n\nQ. How big a problem is poverty and homelessness in California?\n\nA. It\u2019s enormous. In your life have you ever seen as many homeless children? Twenty-five percent of the homeless in America are in California. We need to urgently get these children off the street \u2014 and their mothers as well.", "title": "California Today: Bullet Train Is Not Top Priority, a Candidate for Governor Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nCalifornians like to think of themselves as green. But are they green enough to give up their cars (or at least drive less)?\n\nThat difficult question sits at the center of a recent article about an audacious new bill that would essentially force California cities to allow eight-story buildings around transit stops. The goal is to make it possible for more people to commute to work by increasing height limits within a half-mile of rail stations.\n\nGiven that California is falling behind its climate goals and suffering from a dire housing shortage that has given the state the distinction of having the nation\u2019s highest poverty rate, it seems clear that some inevitably controversial plan will have to be adopted if the state is going to become greener and more economically equal. It seems equally clear that the state won\u2019t get there without some big changes to existing neighborhoods \u2014 which won\u2019t be easy.\n\nTo gauge the impact of the bill, Urban Footprint, a software platform that allows people to map neighborhoods and analyze planning policies, recently ran the numbers for three consecutive East Bay BART stations: the higher-density MacArthur station in Oakland, the slightly lower-density Rockridge station (also in Oakland), and the very low-density station in the next door suburb of Orinda.", "title": "California Today: Can Californians Drive Less?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe governor doesn\u2019t restate every single priority of the administration or issue facing California in his State of the State speech \u2014 and it would be a mistake to conflate commitment with a speech\u2019s word count,\u201d Mr. Westrup said in an email. \u201cThe word \u2018homelessness\u2019 wasn\u2019t in last year\u2019s remarks either, yet California took unprecedented action to increase the state\u2019s housing supply and affordability (the mayor should certainly remember, he was in San Francisco for the bill signing).\u201d\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump stunned Republicans by embracing gun control and urging lawmakers to resurrect gun safety legislation. [The New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nThe rain storms hitting California this week have been called many things, but two related terms keep popping up to describe this weather system: \u201catmospheric river\u201d and \u201cPineapple Express.\u201d\n\nSo which one is it?\n\n\u201cPineapple Express was a term for many years used to identify storms that came from Hawaii and hit the West Coast,\u201d said Marty Ralph, a research meteorologist affiliated with U.C. San Diego\u2019s Scripps Institution of Oceanography. \u201cAbout 15 years ago we recognized that there\u2019s a broader definition called an atmospheric river, and those happen all over the planet.\u201d\n\nFor non-scientists, atmospheric rivers can be conceptualized visually.\n\n\u201cIf you look from space from a satellite, it does look like a sinuous river,\u201d said Daniel Swain, a climate scientist at U.C.L.A. \u201cIt\u2019s a colorful term, and it\u2019s actually the official meteorological term to describe this process.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut while all Pineapple Express storms are atmospheric rivers, not all atmospheric rivers are classified as Pineapple Express storms.\n\nThe source for the particular atmospheric river hitting California this week is near the Hawaiian Islands, hence the playful \u201cPineapple Express.\u201d Not everyone agrees, though, that this storm falls under that category.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t call this one a Pineapple Express. The storm is coming from the West, but the tail of this atmospheric river didn\u2019t come from Hawaii, it came from east of Hawaii,\u201d Mr. Ralph said. \u201cBut I\u2019m not sure about arguing the jargon too much on this. The modern term is atmospheric river.\u201d\n\nNomenclature aside, Mr. Swain urged residents in burn areas not to ignore the orders because of storm fatigue. Though the storm may not hit Los Angeles too hard, it could wallop those in Santa Barbara County. The forecast is severe, and if water falls too quickly it could lead to substantial flooding and mudslides.\n\n\u201cThe forecast is for a really, really big rain,\u201d he said. \u201cMaybe half a foot or more of water is going to fall in a lot of places that have had intense fire activity. Whether all those inches of rain fall over three days or in a six hours is hard to predict.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [Twitter] Her appointment was announced here.\n\nAnd Finally \u2026\n\nPhoto\n\nOn baseball\u2019s opening day Thursday the Giants beat the Dodgers 1-0. But it was just the start of a season for California teams with some high-profile additions to show off.\n\nAs everyone remembers, the last baseball season ended at Dodger Stadium, where the Houston Astros squeezed the life from the home team in Game 7 of the World Series. The Dodgers cut ties with the goat of that series \u2014 the twice-thrashed starter Yu Darvish, who signed with the Chicago Cubs \u2014 but retain a strong roster in pursuit of their first championship in 30 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThree of their California neighbors made some of the splashiest additions of the off-season. The San Francisco Giants traded for the cornerstones of two faraway teams, acquiring third baseman Evan Longoria from the Tampa Bay Rays and outfielder Andrew McCutchen from the Pittsburgh Pirates.\n\nThe San Diego Padres \u2014 rarely big spenders \u2014 gave out the richest contract on the free agent market, lavishing $144 million on an eight-year deal for first baseman Eric Hosmer, who won a World Series title and four Gold Gloves for the Kansas City Royals.\n\nIn Anaheim, the Los Angeles Angels scored a coup when Shohei Ohtani, a pitching and hitting sensation from Japan, chose them over the field. Ohtani had a rocky spring training, but he started at designated hitter in Oakland on opening day Thursday and is scheduled to make his pitching debut against the A\u2019s on Sunday. The Angels have still not won a playoff game with the sublime Mike Trout on their roster, but they\u2019ll try to change that with help from Ohtani and new infielders Ian Kinsler and Zack Cozart.\n\nThe A\u2019s have finished in the American League West cellar in each of the last three seasons, and two of their most promising young pitchers \u2014 Jharel Cotton and A.J. Puk \u2014 learned in spring training that they needed Tommy John surgery. Even so, the A\u2019s made a few additions, including catcher Jonathan Lucroy and right fielder Stephen Piscotty, who could help them move up a spot or two.\n\nAs for the Dodgers, they will most likely face tougher competition in the National League West than the Padres and the Giants \u2014 especially after the Giants lost their ace, Madison Bumgarner, to a broken finger on his pitching hand last week. The Arizona Diamondbacks and the Colorado Rockies both won wild cards last season, and could challenge the Dodgers\u2019 attempt to win their sixth division title in a row.\n\nOf course, for the Dodgers, winning the division is not the goal. The best pitcher on the planet, Clayton Kershaw, can opt out of his contract after the season. For all his individual success, Kershaw is missing the one thing Johnny Podres, Sandy Koufax, Don Drysdale, Fernando Valenzuela and Orel Hershiser all captured in Dodger blue: a championship ring.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays.
