Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: In Oakland, a Clash of Artists vs. Big Cannabis", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller", "Tyler Kepner", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nDavid Crane, a lecturer at Stanford and a former adviser to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is the bringer of bad news. For more than a decade, Mr. Crane, a San Francisco Democrat and former investment banker, has been forecasting a disaster in California\u2019s pension system. He was removed from the board of directors that oversees benefits paid to California\u2019s teachers after repeatedly warning that the fund\u2019s investment assumptions were too rosy, and since then has continued to scream about a coming financial reckoning.\n\nToday, in addition to teaching at Stanford, Mr. Crane is the president of Govern for California, a network of political donors whose members include the former mayor of Los Angeles, Richard Riordan, and the Oakland A\u2019s owner John Fisher, and supports candidates from both parties \u2013 so long as they are willing to tackle important but politically unpopular issues like pension and education reform.\n\nBelow is a condensed interview with Mr. Crane:\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWho/what is Govern for California?\n\nIt\u2019s a network of about 300 donors and growing, and they are Democrats, Republicans and Independents. The legislature is a coequal branch of government and governors can\u2019t do anything without them. Generally speaking, the only people who know the names of California state legislators are people who feed at the trough or benefit from new legislation. The people who get screwed are everyone else in California.\n\nThe headlines make it seem as if the pension problem is always coming and never here. You say it\u2019s already here. Explain.\n\nState revenues have gone up about 30 percent over the last decade, but state spending on virtually everything other than retirement costs and medical spending \u2013 like universities, courts, parks and welfare \u2013 is flat to down. That kind of stuff happens because the money is going out the door to something else, and you ain\u2019t seen nothing yet. The way the math works, the problem doubles every seven years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOakland schools recently cut their budget $15 million in the ninth year of a bull market and after a 30 percent state tax increase. People are teaching kids but can\u2019t afford to live in their city. That to me is a crisis. School systems can\u2019t afford to hire specialists. That to me is a crisis.", "title": "California Today: Is the Long-Looming Pension Crisis Already Here?", "authors": ["Conor Dougherty", "Jose A. Del Real", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nThe proposal was a 49-unit homeless housing complex on a vacant corner in the Boyle Heights section of Los Angeles. But it ran into a wall of neighborhood opposition \u2014 and was blocked by Jose Huizar, the city councilman who represents the area.\n\nFor over a year, the Boyle Heights project loomed as a dispiriting reminder of the challenges of building housing for the homeless \u2014 no matter that California is in the midst of a housing crisis and Los Angeles voters last year agreed to spend $1.2 billion on homeless housing construction.\n\nBut this week, Mr. Huizar dropped his opposition. For anyone concerned with the crisis, this seems a moment worth examining.\n\nMr. Huizar said he changed his mind after the nonprofit agency building the project agreed to include a child-care center, increase security and conduct an environmental impact study, since the land has a dormant oil well on it. Mr. Huizar said his initial mistrust of the agency, A Community of Friends, was resolved after the two sides met and the agency agreed to those alterations.", "title": "California Today: L.A. Homeless Complex Moves Forward", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nFor more than a decade, Christopher Hawthorne has had his dream job: architecture critic at The Los Angeles Times. From his perch, he has explored the region\u2019s history and pondered the future of the urban landscape.\n\nMr. Hawthorne broke some surprising news to readers on Monday: He is leaving the newspaper to become the chief design officer for Mayor Eric Garcetti. The role grew in part out of Mr. Hawthorne\u2019s conversations with the mayor during \u201cThird L.A.,\u201d a public lecture series Mr. Hawthorne led at Occidental College. During one event, he and the mayor spoke about the idea of a design czar, a position other cities have recently created. Soon after, Mr. Garcetti offered him the job.\n\nWe spoke to Mr. Hawthorne about his decision, his vision of the new role and what the next decade holds for Los Angeles. Here\u2019s some of our conversation, which has been edited and condensed:\n\nWorking inside City Hall is a big change. What made you decide to do so?\n\nI\u2019ve always been interested in the intersection of politics and architecture. A lot is up for grabs, in terms of the civic identity of L.A. For me, it really is about the timing. The mayor has a five-and-half-year term, and on top of that there is the arrival of the Olympics in 2028. It\u2019s rare that a city has that kind of civic deadline. It\u2019s really an ideal time frame. It\u2019s long enough to take on some ambitious projects, but not so distant that it feels too abstract and too far-off. We have housing and transit funding in hand that was approved by voters, so bringing that all together and leveraging it is key.\n\nWhat\u2019s the biggest challenge for L.A. right now?\n\nHousing and homelessness are No. 1, there\u2019s no question about that. We have an affordability crisis and a homelessness crisis on our hands. I think the mayor is really committed to building as much housing as possible. We also have a re-embrace of the public realm. We have an underappreciated history of a rich tradition of transit and public space, but it\u2019s also fair to say that the city really lost that thread.", "title": "California Today: Meet L.A.\u2019s New Design Czar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nDon\u2019t write an obituary for the Orange Curtain just yet. For years, it seemed that the demographic change in Orange County might push the suburban enclave to shed its image as a conservative island. And in 2016, voters chose a Democrat candidate for president for the first time since the Great Depression.\n\nBut now, political leaders there seem poised to reclaim their role as a counterpoint to much of the rest of California. On Tuesday, the county Board of Supervisors took two significant votes: One scrapped a previously approved plan to open temporary shelters for the homeless in the wealthy towns of Huntington Beach, Irvine and Laguna Niguel. In the other, the board voted to join a lawsuit from the Trump administration against California\u2019s so-called sanctuary state law. Both votes from the all-Republican board were unanimous, though one member was not present.\n\nThousands of people had shown up to voice their views on the divisive policies. The vote to join the federal government\u2019s lawsuit against the state came just days after the Los Alamitos City Council adopted a measure to exempt itself from the new state law that strictly limits communication between local law enforcement and federal immigration officers.\n\n\u201cWe cannot let the state begin cherry-picking which federal laws it decides to follow,\u201d Supervisor Michelle Steel said in a statement after the meeting. Immigrant rights advocates called the vote \u201cshameful\u201d and said they were \u201cscapegoating our own communities.\u201d Other opponents reminded the jurors that Orange County was a leader in backing Proposition 187, an anti-illegal immigrant measure that was later struck down by the courts.", "title": "California Today: Orange County Backs Trump on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nSilicon Valley is over.\n\nMany people have come to that conclusion over the years \u2014 some hopefully, some sadly \u2014 and they have always been wrong. San Francisco and the peninsula to the south are still the global hub of tech finance and innovation.\n\nPeter Thiel, one of the most successful tech entrepreneurs and investors, is the latest to proclaim the end of the valley. He is giving up his San Francisco rental and moving to a house in Hollywood he bought some time ago. His personal investment firm will be making the journey as well.\n\nIn 2005, Mr. Thiel explained, he was on a panel at Stanford. The question up for discussion was: Where will we find the next Google? \u201cIt was a search problem you couldn\u2019t solve by typing into the Google search engine,\u201d he says. \u201cThe answer I gave was there was 50 percent chance you would find it within a five-mile radius of the room we were in.\u201d\n\nIt turned out the next Google \u2014 at least in terms of the wealth it generated \u2014 was Facebook, in which Mr. Thiel was an investor. It was less than two miles away.", "title": "California Today: Peter Thiel Is Leaving Silicon Valley. [The Los Angeles Times]\n\n\u2022 A former employee has filed a lawsuit alleging that YouTube stopped hiring white and Asian men for technical positions last year because doing so would not have improved diversity. [The Wall Street Journal]\n\n\u2022 Facebook said it would end an experiment in six countries that separated posts from news sites and publishers from other material. News organizations in the countries complained that it had led to a rise in misinformation. Taylor, a professor emeritus at Stanford University who shared the 1990 Nobel Prize for the discovery of quarks, has died. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nEighty-five years ago this week, officials were preparing to celebrate the start of work on the Golden Gate Bridge \u2014 a $35 million feat of engineering that was touted at the time as the longest clear-span bridge in the world.\n\nAnd, my, what a celebration it would be.\n\nIn a 1933 story previewing the Feb. 26 groundbreaking ceremonies, The New York Times noted that all the elaborate planning for the festivities was actually overshadowing the bridge itself.\n\nIt seemed that just about anyone considered important \u2014 including politicians from across the country \u2014 planned to participate in what The Times called \u201cone of the most pretentious celebrations of its kind ever held west of the Rockies.\u201d\n\nBut the article noted that in calmer moments, Californians were proud to boast about their bridge. It would dwarf other bridges in size, and importantly, the story said, it would \u201cafford to sightseers a glimpse of that magnificent vista of hills and water that hitherto has been possible only from the decks of ships.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. The park is adorned by colorful murals honoring Mexican-American and Native American history \u2013 a lineage linked by oppression and revolt. Or, as Mr. Salazar, put it, \u201can unbroken chain of collective consciousness.\u201d\n\nHowever, not everyone at the Trump rally was waving a Trump sign.\n\nTwo Mexican-Americans were holding signs for Point Loma Electric (\u201chundreds of five star reviews\u201d). An early version of yesterday\u2019s newsletter had it wrong.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter correcting our mistake, we took a spin through a new walking tour phone app that celebrates the history of a place that became a counterculture hub in the 1960s and \u201970s, helping to form Berkeley\u2019s identity.\n\nThe tour has 11 stops with titles like \u201cthe Free Speech Movement\u201d and \u201cSatanic Verses and Cody\u2019s Books,\u201d and it is narrated by people who participated in the avenue\u2019s history. Among them is Osha Neumann, a lawyer and painter of the People\u2019s Mural, which depicts social movements of the 1960s. This includes Bloody Thursday, a 1969 clash between students and police officers over the park that led to the death of a man named James Rector.\n\n\u201cI painted this mural originally because I thought history was important to be remembered, and I still do that,\u201d Mr. Neumann says. \u201cAnd that\u2019s what this mural is about, trying to keep that monument to that spirit as everything around us tries to erase it.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [East Bay Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nThe police in Mendocino County are trying to unravel the mystery of a family from Washington State found dead at the bottom of a cliff off a remote stretch of Highway 1. The bodies of the parents, Jennifer and Sarah Hart, were found on Monday inside the family\u2019s vehicle, which was upside down on the rocky shore, according to a summary of the case by the Mendocino County Sheriff\u2019s office. The bodies of three of their adopted children were found nearby but another three children were still missing late Wednesday.\n\n\u201cAn entire family vanished,\u201d Tom Allman, the Mendocino County Sheriff, told reporters in a briefing on Wednesday.\n\n[Our article on the car crash can be found here.]\n\nOne of the missing children, Devonte Hart, was the subject of a viral photograph in 2014 that captured him hugging a Portland, Ore., police officer during the nationwide protests over the killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.\n\nThe sheriff said there were no skid marks or indications that the car had tried to stop before falling 100 feet to the edge of the ocean. But he also said the police had found no evidence that it was an \u201cintentional act.\u201d\n\nThe Santa Rosa Press Democrat reported Wednesday that the Washington State Department of Social Services had opened an investigation into the family last Friday based on reports of potential abuse or neglect.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [The New York Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nThe Times reporter David Streitfeld had an article Wednesday on Facebook\u2019s plans to build a community with housing and retail in its hometown, Menlo Park in Silicon Valley. But if reader comments are any indication, the project faces an uphill battle to acceptance.\n\nMany commenters referenced the escalating crisis over Cambridge Analytica and the company\u2019s lax approach to privacy as reason enough to stay away. Facebook might have two billion users, but many are wary of living in Facebookland:\n\n\u2022 \u201cThat sounds great: a whole city full of \u2018Ready Player One\u2019 arrogant nerds closing ranks against reality. We can measure their success by the zeroed-out birthrate and the truckloads of Amazon boxes full of inflatable companionship.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 \u201cMuch like smart speakers, this new model community is a Faustian bargain, where you sacrifice your personal privacy and private data rights in exchange for high-end centrally located conveniences all too willingly provided by a company whose sole intent is to monetize the details of your daily life by auctioning off your information to the highest bidder.\u201d\n\nBut a few readers celebrated the efficiency of Big Tech:\n\n\u2022 \u201cI\u2019ve been much more pleased with my dealings with Facebook \u2014 and Google, and Apple, and Amazon \u2014 than any city, county, or state government. I\u2019ve gotten extreme value from tech, while I\u2019ve mostly got waste, incompetence and corruption from government.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Kennedy.\n\n\u201cChicano history was not separate from American history, it was a part of American history,\u201d Mr. Verdugo said.\n\nOne of the sparks for the protests here in 1968 was a high dropout rate among Latino students. And Mr. Verdugo, who was failing in school, left for good after the protests. But later that year he was admitted to U.C.L.A. under an affirmative action program.\n\n\u201cI walked out in March, dropped out in May, and in October I walked on to the campus of U.C.L.A.,\u201d he said.\n\nHe never graduated, but years later earned a degree from another university and went on to a long career in social work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 What is Cfius? [Tribune News Service]\n\nComing Up This Week\n\nL.A. Cycle Tours is organizing a nine-mile taco tour around downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday.\n\nThe San Francisco Art Institute will hold its public opening for its new Philippe Rahm exhibition on Thursday.\n\nA live tribute concert on Friday at LIT Nightclub in Los Angeles will commemorate the Mexican-American singer Selena Quintanilla P\u00e9rez for the anniversary of her death.\n\nBeyond Baroque in Los Angeles is hosting its second annual L.A. Punk Film Festival on Friday.\n\nThe third annual San Diego Wine Festival, \u201cUncorked,\u201d is Saturday at Embarcadero Marina Park North.\n\nAnd Finally \u2026\n\nAngelenos gathered Sunday evening at Stories Bookstore and Cafe in Echo Park for the fourth anniversary installation of the \u201cBUSted\u201d story series. The tales centered on a common theme: getting around in Los Angeles without a car. The stories all took place on buses, trains, bicycles and sidewalks around the city.\n\nThe stories ranged from mundane to outrageous to poignant. One man, who has a slight visual impairment, described \u201cseeing the light go out in a woman\u2019s eyes\u201d when he explained he didn\u2019t have a car. (\u201cIt\u2019s O.K., I live a full life.\u201d) Another talked about meeting people of all walks of life through a running club, including homeless people, former gang members and public defenders. In between folk songs, a singer recalled his experience getting a D.U.I.\n\nThe faces in the audience \u2014 huddled in the bookstore\u2019s patio, beneath Edison bulbs and a canopy \u2014 were young and old, bushy and clean-shaven, of all shades. The show started just a little late. \u201cI\u2019m going to give the performers an opportunity to get here before we get started,\u201d the organizer told the audience. \u201cThey\u2019re all on the bus, so sometimes it takes a little bit longer than your typical guest.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCalifornia Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: They Marched for Gun Control. Will Anything Change?", "authors": ["Jose A. Del Real", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "He added that it was difficult to know what next year might bring in terms of rain and snowpack, and pointed out that many towns and areas that aren\u2019t connected to the state water system are subject to limited water availability.\n\n\u201cI think that gets to the heart of the issue,\u201d Mr. Swain said. \u201cHow do we define \u2018drought?\u2019 There are different definitions formally, but I think in a practical sense it can mean a lot of things depending on your perspective.\u201d\n\nMr. Rizzardo urged Californians to remain mindful of how much water they are using.\n\n\u201cWater conservation is a way of life in Southern California. They were there to offer their support after the couple had spent five days behind bars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast week, the parents, Daniel Panico and Mona Kirk, were arrested after police officers discovered their children living in a makeshift desert shelter made of plywood and thin sheeting. Garbage and human waste surrounded the area. Their three children were taken into protective custody.\n\nBut since their arrest, another view has emerged. Friends and supporters have vocally questioned whether their living situation itself constitutes abuse. The couple\u2019s supporters have accused the police of punishing the family for being poor, reflected on the signs:\n\n\u201cGuilty of Being Poor\u201d\n\n\u201cBeing Homeless is not a crime.\u201d\n\n\u201cPoverty is not a choice.\u201d\n\nMr. Panico and Ms. Kirk pleaded not guilty to the charges and were released, though they still do not have access to their children.\n\n\u201cWe are just minding our own business, trying to raise our three kids on little money,\u201d Mr. Panico told The Los Angeles Times in the courtroom on Tuesday.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [Pacific Standard Magazine]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nComing up this week\n\nThe annual PaleyFest festival starts Friday in Hollywood. The casts of \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d \u201cWill & Grace,\u201d and \u201cSilicon Valley\u201d are all scheduled to host panels this weekend.\n\nThe Los Angeles Marathon is on Sunday. The race begins at Dodger Stadium, moves downtown and continues west along Sunset and Hollywood Boulevards then southwest toward Santa Monica.\n\nA festival for foodies, the \u201cBrunch Bash,\u201d is coming to San Diego on Sunday. The event is hosted by San Diego Magazine.\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nHundreds of Angelenos gathered at Plaza de la Raza Saturday, in L.A.\u2019s Lincoln Heights neighborhood, to celebrated International Women\u2019s Day. Defying the rain that poured over Southern California, attendees mingled throughout the stuccoed outdoor community center, danced to live music and perused artwork being showcased.\n\nLucia Torres, 38, who helped plan \u201cViva La Muxer,\u201d said the event sought to bring together the community to celebrate the voices of women, especially women of color. The musicians, the food vendors and the art on display were all women-centered endeavors.\n\nProceeds from the event, now in its fourth year, help a local photography and arts organization called Las Fotos Project, a mentorship program for young women that teaches them photography.\n\n\u201cWe really want people to feel they\u2019re a part of something,\u201d Ms. Torres said. \u201cLas Fotos Project is not just young women learning about photography and taking photos. They\u2019re telling the stories of their communities, about gentrification, about what it means to be at home and to have an identity.\u201d\n\nPlaza de la Raza is a central pillar in the Lincoln Heights community, which is heavily Latino. It is often used as a performance and events space, and to host after-school activities for children. Las Fotos Project also works with women in South Central Los Angeles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Saturday, the smell of sopes and elote-on-a-stick wafted through La Plaza. Toward the back, young men and women snapped pictures with a mural of the acclaimed Mexican-American singer Selena Quintanilla-Perez.\n\n\u201cSpaces like this are really important to community, especially right now in Los Angeles when things are being gobbled up by development,\u201d Ms. Torres said. \u201cYou really have to have a space that holds the heart of the community. Plaza de la Raza is one of those places.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: \u2018We Are Focusing on Bridges, Not Walls,\u2019 Brown Says to Trump", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney", "Jose A. Del Real", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mass protests and another burning took place this weekend in Sydney, where the Cambodian leader was attending the first formal gathering of Southeast Asian leaders in Australia.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe thinks he can do anything he wants in Cambodia, and so he thinks he can come to Australia and do the same thing,\u201d Mr. Lim said.\n\nHosting this weekend\u2019s summit meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations is an effort by the government of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to position Australia as a regional leader and to counter the influence of China.\n\nBut rights supporters have raised concerns about the propriety of feting the leaders, many of whom have presided over serious abuses or rollbacks of democratic freedoms in recent years. Human Rights Watch has described the meeting as a \u201cdance with dictators.\u201d\n\nAttendees include Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, the leader of the Thai junta, who seized power in a coup in 2014 and has postponed elections indefinitely; and Myanmar\u2019s de facto leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been criticized for inaction in the face of a brutal military campaign against the Rohingya Muslim minority.\n\nParticular outrage has coalesced around the presence of Mr. Hun Sen, who has spent the past six months methodically jailing or exiling his political opponents and critics, in advance of elections scheduled for July.\n\nElaine Pearson, Australia director for Human Rights Watch, said that Australia should be doing more to oppose abuses in the region but that the country appeared to be holding back in an effort to jostle for position with China. Australia has also been constrained by a widely criticized deal it made in 2014 to send refugees trying to reach its shores to live in Cambodia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt seems like there\u2019s almost a race to the bottom with China in terms of human rights, and that\u2019s exactly the wrong approach,\u201d Ms. Pearson said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe summit meeting also comes as a small but impassioned proxy battle for political supremacy in Cambodia has been playing out in Australia.\n\nAfter nearly being voted out in 2013 by a new opposition party that counted many overseas Cambodians among its supporters and funders, the Cambodian People\u2019s Party of Mr. Hun Sen, which has held power in some form since 1979, began to aggressively target the diaspora.\n\nIn 2015, the prime minister\u2019s eldest son, Hun Manet, a senior figure in Cambodia\u2019s military, was placed in charge of a new effort to drum up support in countries including Australia. Since then, he has made multiple visits to Melbourne and Sydney.\n\nSpeech by Cambodians abroad has also come under increased scrutiny at home. In September, the country\u2019s opposition leader, Kem Sokha, was jailed on charges of treason, and his party was later dissolved by court order. The primary evidence in both cases was a speech to supporters in Melbourne in 2013.\n\nMr. Lim, a dual citizen, was barred from Cambodia two years ago for calling its government \u201cbeastly,\u201d and he has been threatened with arrest if he returns.\n\nJulie Heckscher, an official at the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, said at a Senate hearing on March 1 that the government had informed Cambodian officials that threats of violence toward protesters on Australian soil were \u201cnot acceptable.\u201d\n\nMr. Lim, who peppers his Cambodian-accented speech with distinctly Australian words like \u201ccrikey,\u201d clearly relishes his new role as an international mischief maker. But beneath the showmanship, he appears genuinely concerned at what he says is a concerted effort by Mr. Hun Sen\u2019s party to co-opt and threaten Cambodians abroad.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Cambodian People\u2019s Party has opened an Australian branch of its uniformed youth corps, and has ordered Cambodia\u2019s ambassador in Canberra to double as a political organizer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor his part, Mr. Lim recently helped arrange political asylum in Australia for Bou Rachana, the widow of a government critic who was assassinated in the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, in 2016. Since she arrived in late February, Mr. Lim said they had both received a crudely worded death threat in Khmer, the language of Cambodia, which they reported to the Australian police.\n\nMr. Lim was studying in Australia on a scholarship when Phnom Penh fell to the Khmer Rouge in 1975. Diplomatic relations between the countries were cut off, and he took a job drilling metal in a boat factory to make ends meet. Back home, his parents died of starvation under the brutal Communist regime.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStarting in 1979, the fall of the Khmer Rouge and ensuing civil war sent a wave of refugees to Australia, and Mr. Lim became a community leader. In 1996, he became the first Australian of Asian descent elected to a state Parliament\u2019s lower house.\n\nFor years, he refrained from overtly supporting any side in Cambodian politics, and he even welcomed Mr. Hun Sen during a visit to Australia in the early 1990s. But he said that recent political developments had forced his hand.\n\n\u201cThe Labor left just loved him, and when he visited, many of them turned up for him in one of the local restaurants, and people just mobbed him like a movie star,\u201d he recalled.\n\n\u201cHe was such an orator, and now look at him \u2014 he has become such a monster. We used to love and respect him and now we fear and loathe him.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Hun Sen, a former guerrilla fighter who seems particularly sensitive about his image, threatened to withdraw his participation in the summit meeting or veto any joint communiqu\u00e9s if he was \u201cpressured\u201d by protesters.\n\nIn a speech this month, he compared Mr. Lim to an \u201cendlessly barking\u201d dog and expressed sympathy with the Australian government for having to deal with him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt a Friday evening protest at Hyde Park in Sydney, Sawathey Ek, 48, a Cambodian-born lawyer, arrived with his two sons and a homemade poster featuring a patchwork of unflattering photographs of Mr. Hun Sen.\n\nPolice officers had asked protesters not to set fires in the city center, so attendees stomped on the photographs instead, or poked them with umbrellas. Mr. Ek said Mr. Hun Sen\u2019s threats had galvanized the community.\n\n\u201cHe wanted to impose his tentacles of violence on all of us, and we feel it is completely unacceptable,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Ek said he wanted to teach his children that they had the right to speak freely, and even to deface the image of the Cambodian prime minister if they wished.\n\nFor Ms. Bou, the widow, the stakes felt higher. Although she and her five sons are still settling into their new life in Melbourne, she said she had been determined to attend the protest, where she addressed the crowd with a bullhorn.\n\n\u201cI had never gotten a chance to do this, to express my personal feelings,\u201d she said.", "title": "Cambodia\u2019s Ruler Dared Australians to Burn His Effigy, So They Did", "authors": ["Julia Wallace"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kenyatta won re-election last October after two presidential votes. The first, in August, was nullified by the Supreme Court, which cited widespread irregularities and ordered a second election. Mr. Odinga pulled out of the second vote, which was held in October, saying the process was unfair.\n\nThe acrimonious political season included divisive speech by both parties, observers said, and continued well past Mr. Kenyatta\u2019s inauguration. The two archrivals shook hands and reconciled this month.\n\nMoses Karanja, a researcher on a project at Strathmore Law School in Nairobi about social media and misinformation during the presidential election, said the recent reports about Cambridge Analytica\u2019s role in Kenya, and its abuse of Facebook data globally, reinforced concerns raised in his own work about how Kenyans\u2019 personal data was accessed by political parties and even by government institutions, like the elections commission.\n\nHe said targeted text messages that he and others received during the campaign season suggested that individuals\u2019 voter registration information, social media data and telephone numbers were being independently linked \u2014 although it\u2019s still unclear how.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know how they accessed this data, or how it all ended up being linked to phone numbers and such,\u201d Mr. Karanja said. \u201cFor me that\u2019s scary. Those are questions those platforms should answer.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGacheke Gachihi, who leads the Mathare Social Justice Center in Nairobi, said Cambridge Analytica\u2019s branding for Mr. Kenyatta was \u201cdivisive propaganda,\u201d raising ethnic enmity.\n\n\u201cThe way you paint your opponent, you paint also his supporters,\u201d he said, \u201cand you and your ethnic base will feel like, \u2018This man is a devil.\u2019 That undermines the work we are trying to do for social justice.\u201d\n\nLocal news media had reported last spring that Mr. Kenyatta\u2019s party had retained Cambridge Analytica for his re-election campaign. And David Murathe, the vice chairman of the Jubilee Party, told Reuters on Tuesday that SCL helped the campaign with branding last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Odinga\u2019s party also enlisted a data-driven political consulting firm, but its on-the-ground team was deported from Kenya just a week before the election, according to The Los Angeles Times.\n\nOn its website, Cambridge Analytica names Kenya as one of its political case studies, describing a 47,000-person survey it conducted in 2013 to identify Kenyan voters \u201creal needs (jobs)\u201d and \u201cfears (tribal violence),\u201d as well as their \u201cpreferred information channels.\u201d\n\nThe company also said it targeted youth voters with a social media campaign.\n\nCambridge Analytica\u2019s parent group, SCL, described similar activities on an archived page of its website, and said it also advised on communications, branding and strategy during the electoral period.\n\nCambridge said its survey was \u201cthe largest political research project ever conducted in East Africa.\u201d Mr. Turnbull told Channel 4\u2019s undercover reporter that it repeated the survey in 2017.\n\nThose survey results, Mr. Karanja said, could reverberate beyond social media campaigns and \u201cbe translated into non-Internet platforms like radio, television advertisements and billboards.\u201d\n\nHe said his research team documented several examples of misinformation spreading on WhatsApp and other social media and filtering down to local talk radio shows or newspaper articles.", "title": "Cambridge Analytica Had a Role in Kenya Election, Too", "authors": ["Jina Moore"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The reports quickly put Mr. Nix in the cross hairs of a parliamentary committee investigating fake news and Russian interference in Britain\u2019s referendum to exit the European Union. Earlier this month, he told the committee that Cambridge Analytica had never obtained or used Facebook data \u2014 a statement that the firm itself has contradicted in recent days.\n\nBut it was Monday\u2019s broadcast by Channel 4 News in Britain that appeared to push the board of Cambridge Analytica to move against Mr. Nix. Channel 4 spent months investigating the company, and sent a reporter to pose as a prospective client from Sri Lanka, secretly filming the encounters with Mr. Nix.\n\nThe most damning footage was captured in January when Mr. Nix, sitting in a hotel bar in London, suggested the firm could send an attractive woman to seduce a rival candidate and secretly videotape the encounter, or send someone posing as a wealthy land developer to pass a bribe.\n\n\u201cWe have a long history of working behind the scenes,\u201d Mr. Nix said.\n\nInside Cambridge Analytica, Mr. Nix, the scion of a wealthy family who attended Eton College, the exclusive secondary school, had a reputation for lashing out at staff members, and for aggressively pursuing deals.\n\nChristopher Wylie, a data expert who worked at the firm in 2013 and 2014 and helped develop its voter-profiling technology, said in a recent interview that he kept memberships at a number of exclusive strip clubs near Pall Mall in London at the insistence of Mr. Nix, who often entertained clients from African and Caribbean countries there.\n\n\u201cWhy would I have these memberships?\u201d said Mr. Wylie, who is gay. \u201cI didn\u2019t want them.\u201d\n\nChannel 4 followed up Tuesday with a second part of its investigation that focused mainly on Mr. Nix\u2019s claims that Cambridge Analytica played a pivotal role in the election of Mr. Trump \u2014 a claim that many inside the Trump campaign have disputed.\n\nThe Channel 4 report also included allegations first reported by The Times this past weekend that Cambridge Analytica\u2019s use of foreigners to work on election campaigns in the United States could have violated American election laws. (The Times did not work with Channel 4.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnnouncing its chief executive\u2019s suspension, Cambridge Analytica said in a statement that \u201cin the view of the board, Mr. Nix\u2019s recent comments secretly recorded by Channel 4 and other allegations do not represent the values or operations of the firm and his suspension reflects the seriousness with which we view this violation.\u201d\n\nThe company said it had asked Alexander Tayler, its chief data officer, to serve as its acting chief executive. Mr. Tayler trained as a chemical engineer and joined Cambridge Analytica in 2014 as its lead data scientist, according to his LinkedIn profile.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the same time, the company said it was initiating an \u201cindependent investigation\u201d of Mr. Nix\u2019s comments and the allegations facing the firm.\n\nThe company said it had hired a lawyer, Julian Malins, \u201cto lead this investigation, the findings of which the board will share publicly in due course.\u201d\n\nIt added: \u201cThe board will be monitoring the situation closely, working closely with Dr. Tayler, to ensure that Cambridge Analytica, in all of its operations, represents the firm\u2019s values and delivers the highest-quality service to its clients.\u201d\n\nIt was not immediately clear what impact Mr. Nix\u2019s resignation would have on the SCL Group, the parent company of Cambridge Analytica. The companies were set up with a convoluted corporate structure, and their operations are deeply intertwined.\n\nMr. Nix, for instance, holds dual appointments at the two companies. Cambridge Analytica is registered in Delaware and almost wholly owned by the Mercer family, but it is effectively a shell \u2014 it holds intellectual property rights to its psychographic modeling tools, yet its clients are served by the staff at London-based SCL and overseen by Mr. Nix, who is a British citizen.\n\nNeither the Mercer family nor Mr. Bannon has publicly commented since the reports in the Times and The Observer.\n\nFacebook, too, has sought to avoid the spotlight but also found itself under a similarly unwelcome glare. In the United States, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday that it had opened an investigation into whether Facebook violated an agreement with the agency on data privacy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition, Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, said the state was joining Massachusetts in an investigation into whether the company failed to protect the privacy of users in those states. Their attorneys general have demanded that Facebook hand over information about its interactions with Cambridge Analytica.\n\n\u201cConsumers have a right to know how their information is used \u2014 and companies like Facebook have a fundamental responsibility to protect their users\u2019 personal information,\u201d Mr. Schneiderman said.\n\nIn Britain, Damian Collins, the chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee of the House of Commons, which is running the inquiry into fake news, called on Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, to give evidence to Parliament.\n\nIn a letter, Mr. Collins said that previous answers from Facebook officials about the misuse of data had been \u201cmisleading.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is now time to hear from a senior Facebook executive with the sufficient authority to give an accurate account of this catastrophic failure of process,\u201d the letter said, adding, \u201cI hope that this representative will be you.\u201d", "title": "Cambridge Analytica Suspends C.E.O. Amid Facebook Data Scandal", "authors": ["Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Cambridge Analytica released a statement describing Mr. Wylie as \u201ca part-time contractor who left in July 2014 and has no direct knowledge of our work or practices since then.\u201d It said Cambridge Analytica, a subsidiary of the SCL political consultancy, did not use its cache of data in Donald J. Trump\u2019s 2016 campaign, and had no involvement in the European Union referendum that ended with a victory for those who support withdrawal, or Brexit, from the bloc.\n\nMr. Wylie\u2019s testimony bluntly contradicted that of his former boss, Alexander Nix, who has recently appeared before the same committee twice. Mr. Wylie said a cluster of pro-Brexit organizations employed a Canadian subsidiary company, Aggregate IQ, which provided them with SCL\u2019s store of data.\n\n\u201cI think it is completely reasonable to say that there could have been a different outcome of the referendum had there not been, in my view, cheating,\u201d he said.\n\nHe also suggested that Russian intelligence agencies could have easily scooped up the company\u2019s vast library of data on American voters in advance of the 2016 elections in the United States, because Aleksandr Kogan, the scientist who collected it, made regular return trips to Russia.\n\n\u201cPut a key logger in Kogan\u2019s computer in Russia and you\u2019ve got everything,\u201d Mr. Wylie said. He added: \u201cIt would make it incredibly easy for them to get access to this data. For me, that\u2019s concerning and I think it should be looked into.\u201d\n\nMr. Wylie\u2019s appearance has coincided with a surge of collective dismay over data-mining, and many found themselves riveted by his testimony on Tuesday. Georgia Rakusen, 33, a user researcher at a technology firm in London, urged her Twitter followers to tune into the hearing, which she called \u201cabsolutely gripping stuff.\u201d\n\nHis testimony, she said, \u201cwas something that, as a lay person, you could watch and start to grasp the enormity of how your data is used.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think maybe people are just beginning to open up, to realize that maybe it\u2019s not just about ads, maybe it\u2019s not just what bands I like,\u201d she said. Ms. Rakusen, who described her own work as \u201ca space where we are supposed to make people click more,\u201d said she hoped that employees of large technology companies would come forward more, looking at whistle-blowers like Mr. Wylie and Edward J. Snowden.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t watch the whole three and a half hours,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I basically didn\u2019t get any other work done during that time.\u201d\n\nMr. Wylie, who has described himself a \u201cgay Canadian vegan,\u201d dropped out of high school but discovered a genius for coding and, still in his teens, began working for political campaigns. He came close to losing his composure at only one moment on Tuesday, when he was asked what prompted him to turn against the technology he had helped create. He said his views had changed when Mr. Trump was elected.\n\n\u201cIt was no longer this niche, shady firm,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was a firm that was making a massive impact on the world. It\u2019s a process of coming to terms with what you have created, and the impact that has had.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am incredibly remorseful for my role in setting it up,\u201d he added, his voice wavering. \u201cI\u2019m the first person to say that I should have known better. But what\u2019s done is done.\u201d\n\nHe was caustic on the subject of his former boss, Mr. Nix, who he said enjoyed the colonial challenge of manipulating the affairs of less developed countries. He recalled that once, they were late to a meeting because Mr. Nix had to collect a chandelier he had bought for $283,000.\n\n\u201cYou have to remember that a lot of these people are very wealthy already,\u201d he said. \u201cThe thing that I learned is for certain wealthy people, they need something to keep them occupied. They need projects. And for certain wealthy people, going into the developing world and running a country is something that appeals to them.\u201d\n\nAt times, he seemed slightly pitying of British officials who are investigating data-mining, saying they did not have enough resources and lacked a \u201crobust technical background.\u201d\n\n\u201cI have had to explain and re-explain and re-explain and re-explain, you know, how relational databases work, what is an eigenvector, what is dimensionality reduction,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThey have been working really, really hard. But as a point of observation, one of the weak points that I\u2019ve seen \u2014 again, this is an empathetic criticism \u2014 is the lack of technical people,\u201d he said, apparently searching for a polite way to say it. \u201cThey have had to ask me a lot of questions that a database engineer would not ask.\u201d", "title": "Cambridge Analytica Whistle-Blower Contends Data-Mining Swung Brexit Vote", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "There were rumors that the president would fire other members of his cabinet, but they didn\u2019t materialize. President Trump boasted that he insisted to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, above, that the U.S. runs a trade deficit with his country \u2014 without knowing whether that was true.\n\nOur White House correspondent says the episode goes to the heart of a fundamental debate about Mr. Trump: When does he know the things he says are false and when is he simply misinformed?\n\nAnd Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers filed court papers claiming that Stephanie Clifford, the pornographic film actress who alleges she had an affair with him, could be liable for $20 million in damages for violating a nondisclosure pact.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. It had not yet opened to the public.\n\nWe talked to people who saw the bridge come down and looked at how it was built, using a method called accelerated construction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. A $100 million federal study is now underway that could provide medical evidence needed to recommend a daily alcoholic drink as part of a healthy lifestyle. (Above, a happy drinker in Philadelphia in 1907.)\n\nAnd alcohol companies are paying for most of it, through donations to a private foundation that raises money for the National Institutes of Health.\n\nUsing a Freedom of Information Act request, we obtained documents showing that the institute waged a vigorous campaign to court the alcohol industry. It even paid for scientists to travel to meetings with executives, where they gave talks strongly suggesting that the study\u2019s results would endorse moderate drinking as healthy.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. The nene, however, is special. Not only is it Hawaii\u2019s state bird, the nene, above, is the world\u2019s rarest goose.\n\nIts webbed feet have adapted to living on hardened lava, but it is a weak flier. Nenes were once hunted nearly to extinction, but conservation efforts have bolstered their population.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother reason to know your nenes is that, although they may be rare in the wild, they come up quite a bit in crossword puzzles. Nene has been an entry in The Times\u2019s crossword 295 times since 1944.\n\nIt appeared in the puzzle on March 12, with the clue \u201cHawaiian goose.\u201d The word might also appear in the easier puzzles at the beginning of the week, with the clue \u201cHawaiian state bird\u201d or \u201cHawaiian honker.\u201d\n\nLater in the week, as the crosswords become more difficult, it might be referred to as \u201cAloha State bird,\u201d \u201cEndangered state bird,\u201d \u201cLava geese,\u201d \u201cBird so-called from its call\u201d or \u201cGray-brown goose.\u201d\n\nYou can find out about the nene and other birds that appear regularly in our Crossword Aviary.\n\nDeb Amlen contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region.
