He also reserved a spot for State Department officials at all his meetings with foreign defense ministers \u2014 at a time when those same officials were struggling to get into similar meetings with Tillerson. No other secretary of defense in recent memory has so insistently catered to his diplomatic counterparts, the former official said. Mattis gave a concise summary of his views on diplomacy in 2013, when he told a congressional hearing, \u201cIf you don\u2019t fund the State Department fully, then I need to buy more ammunition ultimately.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithin a few weeks of Trump\u2019s inauguration, the worsening chaos in the West Wing made the traditional channels of decision-making almost meaningless. Typically, the National Security Council convenes meetings across the bureaucracy in an effort to channel expertise and reach consensus; this process generates recommendations that are sent to the national security adviser and onward, as needed, to the president. But in Trump\u2019s early days, veteran staff members watched in amazement as documents they had contributed to were ignored or overridden by Trump family members and loyalists like Stephen K. Bannon and Sebastian Gorka. \u201cThere were very few opportunities to get information to Trump,\u201d I was told by one former staff member who worked at both the National Security Council and the State Department before leaving late last year. \u201cHe\u2019s not reading five-to-10 page memos on national security. That magnifies the ability of some people to walk into his office and tell him what they think.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJared Kushner embodied the strangeness of this new power structure. He had developed relationships with leading figures in Mexico, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and other countries, and he seemed to be shaping foreign policy via his son-in-law status with Trump. Yet he had no relevant expertise and no formal position; his security clearance remained on hold. Not since Clark Clifford, the Washington lawyer who advised a string of Democratic presidents in the 1940s, \u201960s and \u201970s, has anyone held such influence when he didn\u2019t hold a cabinet position. But Clifford had vast experience and held positions of real authority before acquiring his clout. Kushner had only his father\u2019s real estate empire, and it was becoming clear that his inexperience made him ripe for manipulation by people at the receiving end of United States foreign policy.\n\nThis breakdown burst into view with the Qatar crisis. On June 5, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates announced an economic embargo and blockade of Qatar, their tiny neighbor. The pretext was that Qatar was funding and hosting terrorists, but the feud was much wider and went back decades. For the Pentagon, this was a rude shock \u2014 and not just because the whole premise of Mattis\u2019s effort to push back against Iran presumed unity among America\u2019s Persian Gulf allies. Qatar is host to al-Udeid Air Base, the United States military\u2019s largest command center in the Middle East and the launch point for the ongoing war against ISIS and other extremist groups in the region. The blockade threatened to complicate those operations. In the early days of the blockade, diplomats sent back reports that the Saudis and Emiratis might even be planning a military takeover of Qatar, a far more destabilizing possibility. (Emirati government officials have denied that there was ever such a plan.)\n\nIn the first week of the crisis, Mattis spoke by phone with the United States ambassador in Qatar, Dana Shell Smith, multiple times, she told me. She did not receive any calls from Tillerson. Mattis soon discovered his efforts to tamp down the crisis were facing opposition from within the White House. At an interagency meeting, a C.I.A. official opened with an assessment that made clear the Saudi-Emirati accusations against the Qataris were exaggerated. Sebastian Gorka, the controversial Trump adviser, responded angrily, I was told by another participant in the meeting. \u201cWhat you need to understand is that the Qataris are evil,\u201d Gorka said. \u201cI just can\u2019t believe this, you are totally wrong.\u201d On June 9, Tillerson issued an appeal for the conflict to be resolved, but barely an hour later Trump publicly called Qatar \u201ca funder of terrorism at a very high level.\u201d\n\nTrump\u2019s ardent sympathy for the Saudi perspective seemed to have been greatly enhanced by his fawning reception in Riyadh two weeks earlier, where his hosts thrilled him with sword dances, cannon salutes and a huge image of him beamed onto the side of his hotel at night. A photo-op with Trump clutching a weird glowing orb alongside the leaders of Saudi Arabia and Egypt inspired endless internet memes. The gulf leaders used the visit to whisper to Trump about Qatar\u2019s supposed terrorist sympathies, and after they began the embargo, he seemed to take credit for it in one of his tweets.\n\nBut Trump wasn\u2019t the only object of this charm offensive. For months, the leaders of Saudi Arabia and the Emirates had been befriending and cajoling Kushner, who had no background in the Arab world, through several meetings and frequent WhatsApp conversations. Kushner was soon bragging about his closeness to Arab leaders to other foreign dignitaries in Washington. He happily adopted the Saudi-Emirati perspective on the Qatar crisis, apparently believing that they would be supportive of his future efforts to broker a peace deal in Israel. \u201cIt\u2019s clear that they were able to get their hooks into him,\u201d I was told by the official who worked in the National Security Council and State Department until recently. \u201cThey were able to shape his views.\u201d By midsummer, Tillerson was complaining bitterly to aides that Kushner had undermined his efforts to resolve the Qatar embargo. Around the same time, Kushner\u2019s blend of arrogance and ignorance about the Middle East was exposed in a leaked video of his comments to a group of congressional interns. \u201cWe don\u2019t want a history lesson,\u201d Kushner told the interns. \u201cWe\u2019ve read enough books.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn July, Mattis and Tillerson invited Trump and his top staff members for a meeting where they would guide him through the essentials of America\u2019s global power, with an emphasis on the importance of allies, treaties and international order. It would take place in the Tank, the historic Pentagon boardroom where the Joint Chiefs of Staff meet, a hallowed inner sanctum that was bound to appeal to Trump\u2019s taste for hidebound power rituals.\n\nAbout 20 people attended the meeting on July 20, including five cabinet secretaries, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and other top advisers, including Kushner, I was told by one person who attended. Mattis was clearly in charge, and as the meeting began, he stood in front of two huge screens that showed color representations of NATO, capital markets and various trade deals to which the United States is a signatory. \u201cThe greatest gift the greatest generation left us was the rules-based postwar international order,\u201d Mattis said. He went on to outline the military side of our alliance structures and was followed by Tillerson; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; and Gary Cohn, Trump\u2019s chief economic adviser. Trump listened in silence for a whole hour. When he finally spoke up, the attendee told me, his first words were, \u201cThis is exactly what I don\u2019t want.\u201d He went on to repeat many of the complaints that had become familiar during his campaign: the Europeans are deadbeats, our allies are taking advantage of us, we\u2019re paying for everyone else. A heated discussion broke out, with Bannon facing off against Tillerson and Mnuchin over the nuclear deal with Iran.\n\nThe meeting lasted almost three hours, and by the end, Mattis and Tillerson knew they were facing an uphill battle. There were more meetings over the course of the next month as the internal review of Afghanistan policy heated up. At least one of them turned into a nasty sparring match between Bannon and the generals. Bannon was even more determined than Trump to force an American pullout, and he pelted McMaster with derisive taunts about the futility of throwing more money into Afghanistan\u2019s corrupt army. At one point, McMaster got so angry that Mattis patted his knee as he counseled him to keep his cool, I was told by one of the attendees. At another meeting, Tillerson grew so frustrated with Trump\u2019s complaints about the Iran deal that he seemed unable to look at the president and stared at the wall, his face flushed with emotion, as he repeated the words \u201cit\u2019s your deal,\u201d according to one participant. It was after this meeting broke up that Tillerson described Trump as a \u201cmoron.\u201d He made the comment to Mattis, who was sitting directly across from him. (Tillerson has neither confirmed nor denied his use of the word.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy September, Bannon\u2019s exit from the White House had brought a welcome respite for Mattis and Tillerson and especially for McMaster, who clashed repeatedly with him. The populist-nationalist wing of the administration, with its apocalyptic take on international affairs, appeared to be in retreat. Trump had relinquished his campaign vow to abandon Afghanistan, and signed onto a Pentagon-driven plan to bolster the American presence there. But the progress came at a cost. Tillerson\u2019s battles with the White House had damaged his stature, and the following weeks made that painfully clear.\n\nIn mid-September Tillerson and Mattis briefly thought they had won a breakthrough on the continuing Qatar-Gulf crisis when Trump said he would be willing to host a meeting with the leaders of all the countries involved. Tillerson called the Saudi foreign minister, Adel al-Jubeir, to issue the invitation. What happened next was a grim landmark in the State Department\u2019s eroding stature. Thirty years ago, a direct call from the United States secretary of state, offering an invitation to meet the president, would have been treated with the utmost deference. Jubeir did not respond that way. According to an Arab diplomat I spoke with, Jubeir replied, \u201cPlease don\u2019t do this because we won\u2019t show up.\u201d Tillerson, shocked and angry, said, \u201cYou would refuse to show up for a meeting with the president of the United States?\u201d and warned of \u201cconsequences.\u201d Jubeir backpedaled a bit, but held firm. Tillerson then called the Emirati foreign minister and got a similar response, the diplomat told me. Apparently, the Saudis and Emiratis felt they had a hold on Trump \u2014 and his son-in-law \u2014 and could safely treat the secretary of state as irrelevant.\n\nIn the hand-held video, Mattis strolls out into the bright sunshine, dressed in a black suit, looking pleased but surprised to be addressing a group of young American recruits on a base in Jordan. He thanks them and then says something more unusual: \u201cYou\u2019re a great example for our country right now, it\u2019s got some problems. You know it and I know it. It\u2019s got problems that we don\u2019t have in the military. You just hold the line, my fine young soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines. Just hold the line until our country gets back to understanding and respecting each other and showing it.\u201d\n\nAfter the video emerged online, in late August, some liberal columnists were quick to argue that Mattis\u2019s unscripted monologue amounted to a stinging rebuke of Trump\u2019s handling of the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., which had descended into riots and death just days earlier. Mattis pushed back emphatically at a news conference, saying that his words were not a critique and that he\u2019d been echoing the president\u2019s own call for unity. But this explanation didn\u2019t quite parse. Mattis\u2019s comments on the Jordan video were not just a bland call for unity. He was clearly suggesting that America had lost its historic \u201cpower of inspiration\u201d as a model of democracy and social tolerance, and the context \u2014 with the country\u2019s four military-service chiefs having just issued unequivocal condemnations of racial bigotry \u2014 gave his words added meaning.\n\nThe Jordan video also yielded a telling phrase \u2014 \u201chold the line\u201d \u2014 that seemed to capture Mattis\u2019s own efforts to balance the chaos of the Trump administration. As always, Mattis preferred to keep his differences with the president private. He had been maintaining a low profile for months, granting no press interviews, where any stray comment could have been used to create a wedge between him and Trump. (Mattis\u2019s spokesperson declined to comment on any conversations between Mattis and the president because of their privileged and confidential nature; a White House spokesperson did not respond to a detailed request for comment.) In early October, as a crucial deadline for the Iran deal approached, members of a Senate committee pressed Mattis on whether he believed the Iran deal was in the country\u2019s national security interest. Mattis paused before delivering his verdict. \u201cYes, Senator, I do,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe struggle over the nuclear deal in September and October exposed one of the recurring curiosities of this administration: For all the president\u2019s love of bullying, he seems unable to turn menace into strategic advantage. Trump\u2019s repeated threats to cancel the nuclear deal scared the European leaders who negotiated it with the Obama administration, and some of them expressed a willingness to approve a side agreement addressing Trump\u2019s concerns. \u201cEveryone was looking to placate Trump,\u201d said Ilan Goldenberg, a former Pentagon official now at the Center for a New American Security. \u201cThere was a dialogue that could have been constructive.\u201d In other words, Trump bought himself some useful leverage. But no one in the administration made use of it. No side deal emerged; the deadline came and went. The same pattern has been repeated several times over the course of the past year. Last April, after the administration launched missile strikes on Syrian regime targets in retaliation for the poison-gas attack in Khan Sheikhoun, there was a welcome opportunity to pressure the Syrians and their Russian backers. This was precisely what John Kerry dreamed of during Obama\u2019s final years: a decisive show of force that would create leverage on the diplomatic front. Now Trump had achieved it. A European diplomat told me he spoke to McMaster just after the Syria strike and asked him: \u201cNow you have leverage: What will you do?\u201d McMaster stared back at him blankly, he told me. \u201cFor them, it was not leverage,\u201d the diplomat said. \u201cIt was just a strike.\u201d\n\nThe root of the problem is not a lack of sophistication or experience in Trump\u2019s national security team. It is more basic than that: No one, from Mattis on down, could say what terms the United States would accept in any of these negotiations. And that is because not a single person in the government can confidently say what Trump will say or do tomorrow. This unpredictability came up again and again in my conversations with foreign diplomats. Several of them said it has profoundly rattled governments that have long looked to the United States \u2014 whatever their differences with it \u2014 to abide by its commitments and thereby undergird a wider sense of global order.\n\nUltimately, the Iranian nuclear-deal crisis was averted when Trump reluctantly decided not to void the agreement. He said he would focus (for the moment) on other ways to push back against Iran\u2019s aggressive role in the Middle East, exactly as Mattis, Tillerson and McMaster had been suggesting. But pushing back on Iran is easier said than done, especially when half the government is consumed with reacting to the president\u2019s Twitter feed. The Iranians, meanwhile, had their own plans to extend their control over Iraq. In mid-October, Iranian-backed militia forces helped the Iraqi government recapture the oil-rich city of Kirkuk, driving out America\u2019s most loyal ally in the region, the Iraqi Kurds. The whole thing was stage-managed by Qassim Suleimani, the shadowy commander who runs external operations for Iran\u2019s Revolutionary Guards. The result was a significant coup for Iran, which once again made Iraq\u2019s government look like puppets. The United States, with its foreign service in disarray, was caught off guard. When McMaster heard about the episode, he was so angry that he asked why the United States bothered putting anyone in Iraq at all, a former State Department official told me.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn March 13, hours after learning via Twitter that he\u2019d been fired, Tillerson gave an emotional farewell speech at the State Department. His voice trembling at times, Tillerson spoke of the close working relationship he\u2019d had with Mattis and their shared belief in the importance of diplomacy. \u201cNothing is possible without allies and partners,\u201d he said, with what sounded like a hint of self-vindication and perhaps a warning about the future.\n\nTillerson\u2019s departure will leave Mattis far more isolated, with an incoming secretary of state and a national security adviser who are said to share Trump\u2019s \u201cAmerica First\u201d instincts. The change comes at a time when several global threats are coming to a head. Russia is already attempting to interfere in the midterm elections, according to United States intelligence chiefs, and behaving more aggressively on other fronts as well. Trump has been conspicuously silent on this issue, but Mattis quietly laid out the dangers in his introduction to a new nuclear strategy, leaked in draft form in January and aimed in part at countering Russia. Putin, Mattis wrote, is adopting \u201cmilitary strategies and capabilities that rely on nuclear escalation for their success. These developments, coupled with Russia\u2019s invasion of Crimea and nuclear threats against our allies, mark Moscow\u2019s unabashed return to Great Power competition.\u201d\n\nA more immediate danger is North Korea. In early August, after Trump and Kim Jong-un began exchanging warlike noises, Mattis and Tillerson responded by writing a joint op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, emphasizing that \u201cdiplomatic and economic pressure\u201d were the administration\u2019s chief tools, not the \u201cfire and fury\u201d Trump had promised. It sounded reassuring. But inside the government, there was widespread alarm. A Senate staff member on the Armed Services Committee told me she called the Pentagon to ask if it was safe for her boss to travel to Seoul. A high-ranking officer told her that \u201cour posture is the same,\u201d she told me. But even Mattis sounded rattled when he gave a news conference on Aug. 14: \u201cWe will defend the country \u2014 hear me now \u2014 we will defend the country from any attack ... at any time, from any quarter. ... But it is not declaring war. It\u2019s not that I\u2019m over here, you know, Dr. Strangelove, you know, doing things like that, O.K.?\u201d\n\nNow Trump is preparing for what promises to be a surreal one-on-one encounter with North Korea\u2019s dictator. He agreed to the meeting \u2014 proposed by a South Korean envoy in the Oval Office \u2014 despite a warning from Mattis and McMaster about the risks. There are many. Kim is unlikely to agree to the kind of \u201cdenuclearization\u201d Trump has in mind without some parallel American concessions. Merely holding the talks is a victory for North Korea, and Trump could come out of them looking like a dupe. Timing is another problem. The next deadline for waiving sanctions against Iran as part of the nuclear deal is also in May, and Mike Pompeo has made clear many times that he sees the deal as a \u201cdisastrous\u201d mistake that should be torn up. If that happens, Iranian officials have said they could start producing enriched uranium within days. The risk of a war between Israel, Hezbollah and Iran, which is already high, might escalate. And the repercussions in Pyongyang would be immediate. \u201cIf you\u2019re trying to get a deal with North Korea, good luck getting it if they see you walking away from a deal you made previously with Iran,\u201d I was told by Andrew Exum, a former Army officer who served in the Pentagon during the Obama administration.\n\nPerhaps the greatest risk of all lies in Trump\u2019s insistence on making everything personal. If he feels slighted by Kim, or senses that his outreach has gone unanswered, anything could happen. Most people, faced with real catastrophe, recoil from the brink. But at least one group of observers is not so sanguine about our prospects. In late January, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved their Doomsday Clock 30 seconds closer to midnight. The scientists believe the planet is closer to nuclear annihilation than at any time since 1953, just after the United States decided to develop the hydrogen bomb.\n\nHow Mattis would reckon with a real impending catastrophe is hard to predict. Over a long career, he has made countless tough decisions but always within a military culture where hierarchy is a given, where obedience is a paramount value. In 2014, Mattis was asked whether there was any order that should cause a four-star general to resign in protest. \u201cHad I ever been asked to do something unethical, immoral,\u201d he said, \u201cof course you would owe it to yourself, you would owe it to your troops. But I think, too, you have to be very careful about doing that. ... Loyalty really counts when there\u2019s a hundred reasons not to be loyal.\u201d The limits of Jim Mattis\u2019s loyalty have yet to be truly tested.", "title": "Can Jim Mattis Hold the Line in Trump\u2019s \u2018War Cabinet\u2019?", "authors": ["Robert F. Worth"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The symbolism of the visit is striking, given that the South Korean military uses K-pop for psychological warfare, blasting it from loudspeakers in the Demilitarized Zone that divides the two countries. Defectors from the North have been known to cite K-pop as one of their inspirations for escaping to the South.\n\nIt seems odd that the autocratic North Korean regime, which has sought to cut off its citizens from what it calls \u201cdecadent capitalism,\u201d is now rolling out the red carpet for these performers.\n\nRed Velvet\u2019s concert in Tokyo, attended mostly by teenage girls, was a nonstop cavalcade of overtly consumerist imagery. The singers enacted a pajama party where they tossed popcorn around a bedroom and sucked on pinwheel lollipops. In another scene, they wore candy-colored satin dressing gowns, twirling in chairs designed to look as if they were seated in a nail salon. Twice during the show, the women boarded carts built to look like circus animal cages and rode through the audience.\n\nPyongyang\u2019s apparent openness to the South Korean performers \u201cis part of this charm offensive to make them seem like a really normal country,\u201d said Jieun Baek, a doctoral candidate in public policy at the University of Oxford and the author of \u201cNorth Korea\u2019s Hidden Revolution.\u201d\n\nWhen K-pop performers went to Pyongyang on several occasions in the early 2000s, the North Korean audiences \u201cpulled faces or were expressionless because they were probably told to react negatively,\u201d said Kang Dong-wan, a professor of North Korean culture and politics at Dong-A University in Busan, South Korea.\n\nBut now that the North has made dramatic advances in its nuclear program, it may even promote the visit as an achievement.\n\n\u201cThe propaganda will say, \u2018The South Korean artists came because we developed our nuclear weapons, and they are here to celebrate our nuclear development,\u2019\u201d said Shim Jin-sup, a retired psychological warfare officer in the South Korean military.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cSouth Korea is probably being played by Kim Jong-un, but still, there is nothing to lose,\u201d Mr. Shim added. \u201cSuch cultural exchanges never hurt South Korea in the past.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnalysts say the artists will probably give carefully vetted versions of their usual acts.\n\n\u201cEverything from their costumes to the choreography will be part of the performance negotiations,\u201d said Darcie Draudt, a nonresident Korean studies fellow at the Honolulu-based Pacific Forum at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.\n\nIn an interview on Friday in Seoul at the offices of Mystic Entertainment, a talent agency, Choi Jung-in, 37, an R&B vocalist who is joining the Pyongyang tour, said her agents told her South Korean officials had asked her to sing \u201cUphill Road,\u201d a hit from five years ago, because it \u201cbrought solace to people and touched their hearts.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Choi said she wasn\u2019t thinking much about how the North Korean audience would respond. \u201cThere is no difference between music for propaganda and music for music to enjoy, is there?\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince K-pop performers last went to Pyongyang, North Korean artists themselves have started to emulate their Southern counterparts. North Korea\u2019s Moranbong Band, often said to be Mr. Kim\u2019s favorite girl group, has been known to dance in short skirts and high heels.\n\nStill, some South Korean performers were evidently deemed too risqu\u00e9. Although the South Korean government had hoped to send the global star Psy, the singer of \u201cGangnam Style,\u201d as part of the traveling troupe, the plan did not materialize. A Seoul television channel, MBC, reported that North Korean officials had rejected Psy from the concert lineup.\n\nThe concerts are partly a reciprocal gesture from the South after the North sent cheerleaders and a performance troupe to Pyeongchang, South Korea, for the Winter Olympics in February.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSuch cultural exchanges \u201ccan build trust between the two Koreas that are part of the same race and share the same language,\u201d said Yang Moo-jin, a professor of North Korean studies at Kyungnam University in Seoul and an adviser to the presidential Blue House on the coming summit meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon.\n\nThere is no question that a fair bit of propaganda will be involved. According to the South Korean news media, several of the stars going on the trip this week, including some in their 60s, will perform North Korean ballads and other songs invoking peace and reunification.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe audiences for the concerts will consist mostly of elite, loyal cadres unlikely to undergo a sudden ideological conversion under the influence of a few K-pop stars. The South Koreans will perform on Sunday in a theater that holds about 1,500 people, and artists from North and South will perform together in a 10,000-capacity stadium on Tuesday.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe North Korean authorities probably won\u2019t broadcast the South Korean performances in North Korea,\u201d said Mr. Shim, \u201ceither intentionally or due to lack of electricity.\u201d\n\nOn social media in South Korea, fans generally expressed support for the artists\u2019 trip. \u201cIf Red Velvet goes to North Korea to perform at a concert, half of its people would cheer and would want to be reunified,\u201d wrote one Twitter user.\n\nIn Japan, some fans expressed fears for the performers. \u201cIs it a safe country?\u201d a Twitter user wrote. \u201cIn North Korea there is only one TV channel and people who listen to K-pop songs are executed, right?\u201d\n\nAt the concert in Tokyo on Thursday, Rio Kikuchi, 20, a factory inspector from Iwate, said she was a little worried about Red Velvet\u2019s going to North Korea. But Ms. Kikuchi, who feels a vague dread of North Korean missiles aimed toward Japan, said that \u201cif anyone can help achieve peace, they can.\u201d\n\nIn a brief appearance backstage by the members of Red Velvet, their minders deflected questions.\n\nBut when a reporter asked if they were looking forward to going to Pyongyang, Kim Yerim, who is known as Yeri, grinned and nodded. \u201cYes, yes, Pyongyang,\u201d she said, and gave a thumbs-up.", "title": "Can North Korea Handle a K-Pop Invasion?", "authors": ["Motoko Rich", "Su-Hyun Lee"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "On most issues Donald Trump is inconstant, persuadable, bored and eager to move on. But on a few questions there is real consistency across his years as a public eminence. One is his belief, which may give us new steel tariffs, that America is a big loser from the international trade system. Another, which may give us a Trumpian t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate with Kim Jong-un, is his belief that he alone can solve the problem of nuclear proliferation.\n\nIn 1984, near the peak of Reagan-era nuclear fears, he told The Washington Post that he should lead nuclear deal-making with the Soviets. Six years later, he warned Playboy that \u201cthe greatest of all stupidities is people\u2019s believing [nuclear war] will never happen.\u201d In 1999, flirting with a presidential bid, he promised to \u201cnegotiate like crazy\u201d to prevent North Korea from going nuclear.\n\nNow he gets the chance to actually follow through on these boasts (though the chances of a Kim-Trump summit actually coming off are perhaps still somewhat modest). And as with many problems to which Trump is getting the chance to turn his hand, one can doubt his competence and judgment while also doubting the perfect wisdom of the approaches that preceded him.\n\nThe dilemma facing American policymakers since the Cold War is that you can have a denuclearizing world or you can have a world where liberal values are always on the march \u2014 but you can\u2019t necessarily have both. We have failed to strike a lasting deal with the North Koreans because they are duplicitous and wicked, certainly. But we also have no clear example to offer Pyongyang of a denuclearization that worked out for the authoritarian regime that accepted it.", "title": "Opinion | Can North Korea Trust Us?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "More recently, former President Alejandro Toledo has been a fugitive from justice fighting extradition from the United States. Another former president, Ollanta Humala, is behind bars pending charges of corruption. And Mr. Fujimori\u2019s daughter, Keiko, whose party, Popular Force, holds the majority in Congress and has been instrumental in driving Mr. Kuczynski from office, is under investigation for corruption and money laundering. She also wants to be president and was only narrowly defeated by Mr. Kuczynski in 2016.\n\nShould we despair? I don\u2019t think so, because in the past 25 years the country has actually made great progress. It ended an internal war against the terrorist group Shining Path, settled conflicts with its neighbors, overcame hyperinflation, became a relatively stable democracy and, despite its current predicament, achieved economic growth and reduced poverty.\n\nSo why has eradicating corruption proved so difficult? The recipes for good governance and anticorruption strategies have long been known, but enforcement has dismally failed.\n\nA crucial issue is that the lack of control of illegal and foreign financing of presidential elections combined with extremely weak party structures have turned campaigns into an easy way for adventurous newcomers to become millionaires even before reaching power. Presidential candidates in Peru have been financed by Venezuela and Brazil, and the funding from the latter came linked to allocating huge public infrastructure contracts to previously handpicked Brazilian construction firms. With such a system in place, little wonder Peruvians continue to elect thieves as presidents.\n\nAnd we\u2019ve been here before. Venality was widespread in the 1990s under Mr. Fujimori, when his top adviser, the infamous head of the secret services Vladimiro Montesinos, corrupted the whole spectrum of Peruvian society, bribing politicians, bankers, entrepreneurs, judges, military officers and journalists, videotaping them in the act, building grotesque pyramids of cash as he carried out extortions. When the tapes were shown on prime-time TV, a governmental commission with respected figures was created to design a thorough and vigorous strategy to fight corruption.\n\nIronically, it was Mr. Toledo, a candidate running on a banner of eradicating corruption, who even before becoming president stole campaign money given to him by George Soros. He then asked Odebrecht\u2019s chief executive in Peru for a $35 million bribe \u2014 he got only $20 million \u2014 and set up fresh machinery for graft.\n\nAs finance minister and prime minister a decade ago in Mr. Toledo\u2019s government, Mr. Kuczynski was in charge of overseeing a system that resulted in overpriced public projects. Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s firm had contracts with Odebrecht while he was a public servant.\n\nWhat next? It is not clear whether Mr. Kuczynski will face charges. But he is under investigation and a judge has ordered that he not be allowed to leave Peru and granted a search warrant for his three houses in Lima. His successor, Mr. Vizcarra, who has an untarnished public record, will face public pressure to put an effective anticorruption strategy into effect.", "title": "Opinion | Can Peru\u2019s Democracy Survive Corruption?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "I don\u2019t need to tell you that something is wrong with social media.\n\nYou\u2019ve probably experienced it yourself. Maybe it\u2019s the way you feel while scrolling through your Twitter feed \u2014 anxious, twitchy, a little world weary \u2014 or your unease when you see a child watching YouTube videos, knowing she\u2019s just a few algorithmic nudges away from a rabbit hole filled with lunatic conspiracies and gore. Or maybe it was this month\u2019s Facebook privacy scandal, which reminded you that you\u2019ve entrusted the most intimate parts of your digital life to a profit-maximizing surveillance machine.\n\nOur growing discomfort with our largest social platforms is reflected in polls. One recently conducted by Axios and SurveyMonkey found that all three of the major social media companies \u2014 Facebook, Twitter and Google, which shares a parent company with YouTube \u2014 are significantly less popular with Americans than they were five months ago. (And Americans might be the lucky ones. Outside the United States, social media is fueling real-world violence and empowering autocrats, often with much less oversight.)\n\nBut it would be a mistake to throw up our hands and assume that it has to be this way. The original dream of social media \u2014 producing healthy discussions, unlocking new forms of creativity, connecting people to others with similar interests \u2014 shouldn\u2019t be discarded because of the failures of the current market leaders. And lots of important things still happen on even the most flawed networks. The West Virginia teachers\u2019 strike and last weekend\u2019s March for Our Lives, for example, were largely organized on Facebook and Twitter.\n\nThe primary problem with today\u2019s social networks is that they\u2019re already too big, and are trapped inside a market-based system that forces them to keep growing. Facebook can\u2019t stop monetizing our personal data for the same reason that Starbucks can\u2019t stop selling coffee \u2014 it\u2019s the heart of the enterprise.\n\nMany of the fixes being proposed involve regulation. The Honest Ads Act, a bill in the Senate, would require greater transparency for online political ads. The European Union\u2019s General Data Protection Regulation, which goes into effect in May, aims to give users greater control of their digital information trails.", "title": "Can Social Media Be Saved?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "I envisioned plaster falling from the walls with a low rumble and a boulder rolling toward me, \u201cRaiders of the Lost Ark\u201d-style.\n\nInstead, Mr. Spielberg answered in a gentle, undefensive tone. \u201cI\u2019m really too busy, both in my private life and in my professional life, to have a lot of time to dwell on success or failure,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m always moving really fast, and I don\u2019t look back a lot. That\u2019s why I don\u2019t sit down and look at my movies on a movie screen after I\u2019ve made them. Sometimes it\u2019s years before I will even dare look at a movie again, and sometimes I\u2019ll shut it off after five minutes.\u201d He looked out the window.\n\n\u201cI have this scary image, which haunts me, of Gloria Swanson sitting in her living room watching her glory days,\u201d he continued, referencing \u201cSunset Boulevard.\u201d \u201cAnd I\u2019ve always said to myself, \u2018I\u2019ll never catch myself reminiscing nostalgically.\u2019\u201d\n\nUnless he is making a movie that reminisces nostalgically.\n\n\u201cReady Player One\u201d is an adaptation of the 2011 Ernest Cline novel, which overflows with references to pop culture of the 1980s \u2014 a movie era dominated by Mr. Spielberg, both as a director and as a producer (\u201cBack to the Future,\u201d \u201cThe Goonies,\u201d \u201cPoltergeist\u201d). The title \u201cReady Player One\u201d comes from the words that flashed on Atari arcade games after the drop of a quarter. The screenplay, written by Zak Penn and Mr. Cline, nods to John Hughes movies and incorporates Michael Jackson\u2019s red \u201cThriller\u201d outfit, Mechagodzilla and Chucky. Tunes by Twisted Sister, Van Halen and Joan Jett populate the tongue-in-cheek soundtrack.\n\nIn the film, which Warner Bros. will release March 29, the teenage Wade Watts (Tye Sheridan, best known for the indie film \u201cMud\u201d) lives in a filthy, severely overcrowded trailer park in Columbus, Ohio. The year is 2045, and most Americans have given up. (Upward mobility? No such thing.) People now spend all their time wearing virtual reality goggles and haptic gear, which allows them to explore a pretend 3-D world called the Oasis as if they were really there. The Oasis, created by an eccentric billionaire, is a wondrous place where you can be anything \u2014 another gender, another species \u2014 and the 1980s-loving Wade and his crush, Samantha Cook (played by Olivia Cooke, from \u201cMe and Earl and the Dying Girl\u201d), race to solve a three-part treasure hunt before an evil corporation, in both worlds, gets there first.", "title": "Can Steven Spielberg Remember How to Have Fun?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "For much of the first century of American politics, young people operated as unpaid foot soldiers of partisan political armies. In a popular, loud, dirty system there was plenty of unglamorous work to be done. For every enormous rally or rowdy election, there were people still too young to vote working behind the scenes, handing out ballots and emptying spittoons, toasting allies\u2019 speeches and cracking rivals\u2019 skulls.\n\nThe one thing young people were not supposed to do, for much of the 1800s, was to champion themselves. They were referred to as \u201cgenerous and unsophisticated\u201d \u2014 worker bees to be directed by the older and wiser. As one 16-year-old antislavery activist in Maine complained, when he tried to talk politics with voters many laughed at his \u201cchildish enthusiasm and coolly reminded me that I was a boy.\u201d\n\nEven among youthful activists, many felt conflicted about whether they should \u201coriginate opinions\u201d or merely carry them out. Young men and women were raised to revere their democracy, did they really have a right to guide it yet? During an 1831 rally against what they called the \u201cslimy mark\u201d President Andrew Jackson was leaving on the country, young men in Baltimore nonetheless worried that they were \u201coverstepping the modesty which befits our age.\u201d\n\nWhen young men and women did play a role in their nation\u2019s politics, it was often over the resistance of older Americans. When young African-Americans in Philadelphia in 1838 fought to keep black Pennsylvanians\u2019 right to vote, they had to justify themselves even to their own community. Dismissed as \u201cinexperienced, hasty, immature\u201d by their elders, young black Philadelphians published newspaper statements directed at the city\u2019s black elite, announcing \u201cwe will not be put down.\u201d\n\nThis was an age that could not afford to \u201cput down\u201d the young. Over the second half of the 1800s, American politics darkened. The succession of Civil War, Reconstruction and the Gilded Age was marked by bitter partisanship, endemic corruption, appalling violence and a general sense that democracy was failing. Adults seemed to be stuck, recycling the same partisan issues over and over.", "title": "Opinion | Can Teenagers Save America? They\u2019ve Done It Before", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "When viewers have access to context, they can see us discussing our boundaries, talking about getting screened for sexually transmittable infections and chatting about how we choose partners. Occasionally, they can even see us laying bare how we navigate the murky intersection of capitalism, publicity and sexuality.\n\nBut this context is usually stripped out when a work is pirated and uploaded to one of the many \u201cfree tube\u201d sites that offer material without charge. These sites are where the bulk of pornography is being viewed online, and by definition don\u2019t require a credit card \u2014 making it easier for minors to see porn. And so the problems that come with porn are inseparable from the way it\u2019s distributed.\n\nHow it\u2019s distributed also shapes the type of porn that is most readily available to teenagers. I frequently hear pornography maligned as catering only to men. That\u2019s not quite fair: Most heterosexual pornography caters to one type of man, yes, but to ignore the rest does a disservice the pornographers who have been creating work with a female gaze, or for the female gaze, for decades.\n\nCandida Royalle founded Femme Productions in 1984 and Femme Distribution in 1986. Ovidie and Erika Lust have been making pornography aimed at women for over 10 years. Of course, their work also isn\u2019t the sort of content that\u2019s easy to find on free sites. But plenty of men enjoy this sort of work, too \u2014 just as some women like seeing bleach blondes on their knees.\n\nSex and sexual fantasies are complicated. So much of emotionally safer sex is dependent on knowing and paying attention to your partner. We in the industry can add context to our work, but I don\u2019t know that it\u2019s possible, at the end of the day, for what is meant to be an entertainment medium to regularly demonstrate concepts as intangible as these. We cannot rely on pornography to teach empathy, the ability to read body language, or how to discuss sexual boundaries \u2014 especially when we\u2019re talking about young people who have never had sex. Porn will never be a replacement for sex education.\n\nBut porn is also not going anywhere. That means that we have a choice to make. We can hide our heads in the sand, or we can \u2014 in addition to pushing for real lessons on sex for young people again \u2014 tackle the job of understanding the range of what porn is, evaluating what\u2019s working and what we can qualitatively judge as good, and try to build a better industry and cultural understanding of sex. I choose to try.", "title": "Opinion | Can There Be Good Porn?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Rather than just one kind of industry defendant, this litigation has several, each playing a different role \u2014 not only drug makers but also distributors and retailers. That makes the apportionment of liability even more contentious, with defendants blaming one another.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll the defendants say the drugs were approved by the Food and Drug Administration and prescribed by doctors.\n\nPlaintiffs claim that manufacturers, like Purdue Pharma and Johnson & Johnson, aggressively marketed the pills for years, despite knowing about addictive properties; that distributors, like McKesson and Cardinal Health, shipped alarming quantities without reporting to the authorities; that pharmacy chains, like Walgreens and CVS Health, looked away while selling flag-raising amounts to individuals.\n\nAdding weight to the plaintiffs\u2019 case, the Justice Department filed a so-called statement of interest in the litigation last week, to emphasize the government\u2019s \u201csubstantial costs and significant interest in addressing the opioid epidemic.\u201d\n\nThe theories under which parties are suing make for a legal cacophony: public nuisance laws; fraud, racketeering and corruption; violations of federal and state laws on controlled substances. With the judge pushing for settlement, legal experts worry that these arguments may not get full consideration.\n\n\u201cCourts are hard-wired for litigation,\u201d through which facts can come to light, said Elizabeth C. Burch, a law professor at the University of Georgia who writes about multidistrict litigation. \u201cHere, there\u2019s a short-circuiting of that process. So how do you know if it\u2019s the right settlement if you don\u2019t have all the information in front of you?\u201d\n\nJudge Polster has reminded both sides that if they resist settling swiftly in favor of litigation, they could be setting themselves on a path toward unpredictable jury trials.\n\nThe night before the conference, many lawyers, expert witnesses and clients stayed in the same hotel. They gathered in rooms and the restaurant lounge, strategizing, trying to second-guess the judge. On occasion, their voices could be overheard, rising in exasperation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEarlier that day, Judge Polster, 66, ate a hasty lunch of a hard-boiled egg and tangerine unpacked from sandwich baggies, having just returned to his chambers from tutoring reading to a third-grader at a school near the courthouse. He glanced at his wristwatch, its fraying band wrapped in duct tape.\n\nBefore his day was over, the judge, shadowed by a reporter, would oversee a half-dozen legal matters, help teach a class on mediation at Cleveland-Marshall College of Law, dine with the opioid litigation\u2019s special masters \u2014 court-appointed intermediaries who expedite negotiations \u2014 and then lug home a nearly foot-thick binder of materials to study.\n\nJudge Polster, who is married to an arbitration lawyer, grew up in a middle-class Cleveland neighborhood that his parents fought to integrate. Their activism taught him \u201cordinary people can do extraordinary things if they don\u2019t take a pass.\u201d His Jewish faith has also shaped his outlook on justice and compassion, he said; he teaches a confirmation class about ethical decision-making.\n\nAfter graduating from Harvard Law School, he began a lifelong career in public service, working for the Justice Department\u2019s Antitrust Division in Cleveland and then the United States attorney\u2019s office there, prosecuting economic crimes. In 1998, President Bill Clinton appointed him to the federal bench.", "title": "Can This Judge Solve the Opioid Crisis?", "authors": ["Jan Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The situation in Venezuela demands sophisticated diplomacy and Latin American leadership, and if Mr. Trump wants to make progress toward new punitive sanctions against Nicol\u00e1s Maduro\u2019s petro-dystopian dictatorship, he will be better off if he publicly lets other countries in the region drive the debate and follows their lead.\n\nThose other countries are deeply troubled by recent events, and they want to act. But they are worried about perceived association with the United States. The worst thing Mr. Trump could do would be to undercut American allies by making it appear they are simply doing his bidding.\n\nMr. Trump would do well to remember his dinner meeting with a group of friendly Latin American presidents last September, in which he returned to his repeated suggestion of United States military intervention, according to sources at the meeting. \u201cRex tells me you don\u2019t want me to use the military option in Venezuela,\u201d he reportedly said, referring to Rex Tillerson, who was then secretary of state. \u201cIs that right? Are you sure?\u201d The Latin American presidents were understandably rattled. When it comes to Venezuela, Mr. Trump is better off consulting with other governments first to test ideas, rather than insisting on them.\n\nThe surest path to success would be if Mr. Trump were to engage directly with the summit meeting\u2019s core theme, Democratic Governance Against Corruption.\n\nYes, Mr. Trump has conflict-of-interest problems of his own, but the United States still has an enormous role to play in the international fight against impunity. Information sharing, which was critical in the sprawling multinational investigation into bribery by Brazil\u2019s Odebrecht construction conglomerate; best practices and technical assistance; and financial support for law enforcement, judicial reform and anticorruption prosecutors, the best known example of which is the United States-supported International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala, or Cicig \u2014 none of these are possible without the backing of the American government and the ability to track illicit financial flows through Wall Street.\n\nThere is always more that the United States can do to support Latin America\u2019s continuing fight against corruption. The Trump administration should develop a list of new commitments to bring to the table on Day 1. That, more than anything, would go a long way toward improving United States-Latin American relations.\n\nIn short, to make his first Latin America trip worthwhile, the president just needs to follow three simple guidelines:\n\nListen first. Talk softly. And do your homework.", "title": "Opinion | Can Trump Succeed at the Summit of the Americas?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "In 2012, still barred from running for office, L\u00f3pez threw his support behind an opposition candidate in the presidential election. Ch\u00e1vez beat that candidate by a 10-point margin but died soon after, opening the door for a repeat campaign against Maduro. When the electoral board announced that Maduro had won by a single percentage point, L\u00f3pez suspected fraud. He pushed for the opposition movement to stage a public demonstration. Most of the other opposition leaders dismissed the idea, but in January 2014, L\u00f3pez called for his supporters to take the streets.\n\nBy February, protests were springing up in every province. On Feb. 12, L\u00f3pez rallied thousands of students at the edge of a park in Caracas. After his speech, they marched to the office of the attorney general a mile away. Some of the protesters began throwing rocks at the building. Security officers emerged, and two protesters were shot. Though L\u00f3pez was gone before the violence began, officials accused him of being the \u201cintellectual author\u201d of the skirmish, and the attorney general issued a warrant for his arrest.\n\nL\u00f3pez and Tintori took refuge that night in a friend\u2019s apartment. They recorded a video message for the public. \u201cI want to say to all Venezuelans that I do not repent,\u201d L\u00f3pez said. He spent a few days in hiding, then recorded another video asking his supporters to gather at a downtown plaza on Feb. 18, dressed in white as a sign of peace, to bear witness as he turned himself in.\n\nThat morning, he climbed on a motorcycle and rode into the city. A large crowd was gathering, and the police had set up checkpoints to intercept him. L\u00f3pez tried to find a way around the checkpoints but couldn\u2019t. He finally rode up to a cluster of police officers from the Chacao district and removed his helmet. The officers recognized him, saluted and waved him through. L\u00f3pez saw the crowd extending in every direction. Thousands upon thousands of people had come dressed in white. He waded through them to a statue of the Cuban independence hero Jos\u00e9 Mart\u00ed and climbed the pedestal to look over the sea of faces. Someone handed him a megaphone, and he raised it. \u201cIf my imprisonment helps to awaken a people,\u201d he called out, \u201cthen it will be worth the infamous imprisonment imposed on me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a short speech, he climbed down from the pedestal, where soldiers were waiting to arrest him. They pulled him inside an armored vehicle, but the crowd pressed in, rocking it. Minutes passed, then half an hour. The truck was trapped by the crowd. Someone gave L\u00f3pez a handset connected to the vehicle\u2019s outside speakers. He called to the crowd that he was safe and that they should clear a way for the truck to get through. Slowly, almost grudgingly, they parted the path for L\u00f3pez to prison.\n\nPhoto\n\nOfficials placed L\u00f3pez in a concrete tower on a military base outside the city, charging him with terrorism, arson and homicide. Amnesty International condemned his prosecution as \u201can affront to justice\u201d and \u201ca politically motivated attempt to silence dissent.\u201d For his initial arraignment, he was taken from his cell in the middle of the night and marched outside to face a judge on a bus. The rest of the proceedings took place at the Palace of Justice in Caracas, a five-story edifice that sprawls across 1.5 million square feet downtown. Over the next 19 months, he traveled there nearly 100 times, in a motorcade of armored S.U.V.s, wearing a bulletproof vest, with his hands shackled together, wedged between two guards armed with machine guns and two more behind him. Each time L\u00f3pez appeared in court, the Palace of Justice shut down.\n\nThe trial hinged on speech. No one accused L\u00f3pez of being violent himself. Prosecutors scaled back the charges, arguing that he inspired violence in others. They brought in a linguistic expert to examine transcripts of his speeches and claimed that his message of peaceful protest disguised a \u201csubliminal\u201d call to violence. They introduced more than 100 witnesses, some of whom testified that they had received the subliminal messages. L\u00f3pez tried to introduce his own witnesses, but the judge wouldn\u2019t allow it.\n\nA few words about the judge who signed his arrest warrant and a lead prosecutor and attorney general: They all repent. The judge who signed the warrant later admitted that she had been forced to do so. The lead prosecutor, after fleeing the country, denounced the case against L\u00f3pez as \u201ca farce,\u201d saying \u201c100 percent of the investigation was invented.\u201d The attorney general, Luisa Ortega, escaped to Colombia last summer and says that the vice president of Maduro\u2019s party instructed her to pursue L\u00f3pez. I tracked Ortega down a few weeks ago, and we met for coffee in Bogot\u00e1. When I asked her about the criminal charges against L\u00f3pez, she shook her head in dismay. \u201cWithout a doubt,\u201d she said, \u201cLeopoldo L\u00f3pez is a political prisoner.\u201d\n\nOrtega told me it had been illegal to hold a civilian like L\u00f3pez in a military prison. Over the course of three years, his conditions grew progressively worse. In the early stage, he was allowed to read and write, and a local university devised a program of study. He read Venezuelan poets, Ralph Waldo Emerson, the diary of Ho Chi Minh and a biography of Nguyen Van Thuan. He was consuming several volumes a week, until officials began to restrict what he could read. Eventually, they prohibited everything except the Bible. He read it from Genesis to Revelation. Then they took the Bible, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was moved to a new cell, then another. He spent months in solitary confinement in a room that was six feet by 10 feet. He would sit in silence trying to pray or meditate and summon any possible reason for gratitude: that he could feel himself breathing; that his wife and children were safe; that through the window he could hear the commotion of the outside world \u2014 a passing truck, a twisting wind, some emphatic bird.\n\nWithout his books, he reflected on those he had read. He remembered biographies of nonviolent leaders and the Birmingham letter from King, and he began to wonder if what they had in common wasn\u2019t just a commitment to resistance but some deeper observation about the character of history. This came through most clearly in King. His goal was never just to provoke or confront. It was to locate the elusive fulcrum between conflict and mediation \u2014 to produce an onslaught of pressure that forced officials to react while preserving an almost irrational faith in their capacity for good will.\n\n\u201cI had an illumination moment,\u201d L\u00f3pez recalled. \u201cOne night, I couldn\u2019t sleep, and I was tossing from one side of the bed to the other, thinking about the son-of-a-bitch director of the prison. I was very, very angry, and I woke up the next morning, and I said: \u2018What am I doing? This guy is taking away my tranquillity, my sleep.\u2019 \u201d He realized that the buildup of anger threatened to distort his thinking. He began trying to separate his outrage from his fury. He continued to defy the arbitrary rules of prison \u2014 composing and smuggling a stream of subversive messages to the outside \u2014 but when the guards would charge into his cell to look for contraband, shouting and tearing through his things, he searched for calm. He would stand back, lifting his hands in a posture of self-defense and say in the most measured tone he could muster that he would protect himself if necessary. In the hours between, the interminable stretches of solitude, he tried to be honest with himself about what anger had cost him. It wasn\u2019t just a threat to his state of mind but to his politics, his movement and the way he conceived the future.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the past, I was in confrontation with different views,\u201d he told me. \u201cNow I understand that everybody is needed in order to reach a way out of this disaster.\u201d He thought of books he had read on postwar Europe and the South African emergence from apartheid, and he realized that Venezuela would never find stability if it were cleaved into disparate sectors. It would be necessary to forge, like Mandela with F.W. de Klerk or King with Lyndon Johnson, some tentative confianza between the opposition and supporters of chavismo. \u201cA lot of people in the opposition have resentment, and I understand that,\u201d he told me. \u201cBut I think our responsibility is to move beyond the personal resentment. Four years in prison have given me the possibility of seeing things a different way, of putting rage in its perspective.\u201d\n\nA few nights ago, I was speaking with L\u00f3pez a little before midnight. His family was asleep, and in the quiet hours he was bracing for the possibility that appearing in these pages could trigger his return to prison. This was something we had talked about many times. His eldest daughter was a toddler when he first went to prison and is now a little girl. His son had been less than a year old and was just now getting to know his father. At the end of January, L\u00f3pez and Tintori had a second daughter, and it troubled him to think that years could pass before he saw any of his children again.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not easy,\u201d he said quietly. \u201cIt\u2019s not easy, but I have the responsibility to speak my mind. I\u2019ve been in prison four years now because of speaking my mind, and if I self-censor, I\u2019m beaten by the dictatorship.\u201d L\u00f3pez said he still believed that with the right leadership, Venezuela could rebound. He thought of postwar Japan and South Korea and Europe. He knew that stabilizing the bol\u00edvar could be accomplished by attaching its value to a foreign currency, and that under a new government, the private sector would return. He believed the country\u2019s oil production would recover under good management, and he had been working for nearly a decade on a plan to convert the national oil company into a kind of Social Security trust, with investment shares assigned to the public for retirement, education and emergencies.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe challenge was to reach a point where any of that work could begin. As the crisis in Venezuela deepened, the path to a transition seemed more obscure than ever. Politicians, historians, think-tank pontificators \u2014 everyone had some sort of proposal, but the problem, if you studied each of them, was that none had very much chance of happening, or of working.\n\nStart with the Trump administration, which has lately suggested a military coup. Speaking in February, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson mused that in a situation like Venezuela\u2019s, \u201cit\u2019s the military that handles that,\u201d to which Senator Marco Rubio later added on Twitter that the Venezuelan military should \u201crestore democracy by removing a dictator.\u201d Apart from the obvious fact that removing a dictator is no guarantee of democracy, there aren\u2019t many people in Venezuela who consider a coup likely. A few weeks ago, I met up with the leader installed by the last military coup, Pedro Carmona, who told me the military has been purged of dissent, with senior officers monitored for ideological purity by the Cuban intelligence service. \u201cThe G2 has a facility in Caracas, spying on the Venezuelan military,\u201d he said. \u201cSo on the military side, the best I could hope would be for them not to repress the people.\u201d\n\nPressure from outside Venezuela has also been slow to coalesce. Critics accuse the members of the Organization of American States of failing to constrain the Maduro government, which showers oil bounty on several member nations. A smaller coalition of Latin American countries has joined with Canada to create the Lima Group, whose vociferous condemnation of the political repression has not converted to much concrete action. American sanctions have been steadily tightening in recent years. After a protracted debate between the National Security Council and the State Department, the Obama administration imposed limited sanctions in 2015, primarily targeting the financial assets of individual Venezuelan leaders. Mark Feierstein, who assumed responsibility for N.S.C. policy in the Western Hemisphere later that year, told me the administration had missed a critical opportunity to influence a 2016 negotiation between the Maduro government and the opposition. \u201cThe N.S.C., or at least I, was inclined to move more quickly,\u201d he said, \u201cand I think the negotiations largely failed because pressure was taken off.\u201d The Trump administration has expanded the sanctions program, but how far to deepen sanctions, or expand them, or restrict the import of Venezuelan oil, is a brutal calculation about how much of the burden would be carried by the Venezuelan people, and whether adding to their misery is more likely to inspire an uprising or simply worsen the humanitarian disaster.\n\nIn recent months, there has also been rumbling about war. Trump has made oblique suggestions of a \u201cmilitary option\u201d in Caracas, and even relatively moderate voices have begun to fantasize about cavalry. In January, the Harvard scholar Ricardo Hausmann, who served as Venezuela\u2019s minister of planning from 1992 to 1993, published a proposal suggesting that the Legislature invite a multilateral invasion force to help support a new government, making a comparison to the liberation of Europe. I spoke with several opposition leaders who welcome this idea, but this might say more about the country\u2019s desperation than the wisdom of the proposal. It\u2019s difficult to imagine Russia and China, after years of propping up the Venezuelan economy in exchange for oil, allowing a foreign invasion to threaten their investment. An even greater concern is internal: Maduro is polling at about 30 percent approval in a devastated economy, but nothing would rally former chavistas to his side like an occupying army. Venezuela is a heavily armed society and increasingly violent. To invite a military intervention is to welcome civil war.\n\nA few months ago, it was possible to imagine an electoral path to change, but today nearly all the opposition parties have been disqualified from running. On the evening of Feb. 15, Maduro took this a step further, interrupting television and radio broadcasts to announce that the party L\u00f3pez founded in 2009 is not a political organization but a \u201cviolent fascist group\u201d operating \u201coutside the law.\u201d When I spoke with L\u00f3pez the next morning, he said that 87 party leaders were already in prison. Those who remained were preparing to convert the party into a \u201cclandestine organization.\u201d Soon, he said, they could be reduced to secret meetings and tossing pamphlets on street corners from unmarked vans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut even as conditions spiraled down, I watched L\u00f3pez try to incorporate what he learned in prison to daily life. Unable to speak publicly, he developed a network of private channels \u2014 reconnecting with leaders of the political parties from which he\u2019d split, making inroads with members of the Maduro government and with foreign ministers and heads of state. During the recent negotiation between opposition leaders and the government, L\u00f3pez was in contact with all sides; even after his party withdrew from the dialogue, he continued to consult with leaders who remained at the table. When disputes spilled over among them, he provided a back channel, an invisible hub to which it seemed as if all spokes connected.\n\nL\u00f3pez was also flexible in his thinking about transition. Through most of our conversations, he strongly opposed the idea of military action, but when we spoke late the other night, he said he was beginning to think differently. An unwelcome mechanism can bring welcome change.\n\n\u201cIn 1958, there was a military coup that began the transition to democracy,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd in other Latin American countries, there have been coups that called elections. So I don\u2019t want to rule anything out, because the electoral window has been closed. We need to go forward on many different levels. One is street demonstrations; a second is coordination with the international community. But this is how I\u2019m thinking now: We need to increase all forms of pressure. Anything, anything that needs to happen to produce a free and fair election.\u201d\n\nIf it was jarring to hear this from L\u00f3pez, it was matched by another development. For several months, the secret police had been coming to his front door about four times a day to photograph him with a copy of the day\u2019s newspaper. Lately, L\u00f3pez had begun to invite the agents in. He had recently spoken with one for more than two hours, offering him a slice of cake from his daughter\u2019s birthday and talking about the inflation crisis and the recent massacre of a small rebel group. \u201cWe\u2019ve developed \u2014 I wouldn\u2019t say a good relationship, but a relationship,\u201d he said.\n\nThinking about these developments together, it seemed to me that L\u00f3pez was trying to strike an increasingly difficult balance. He was willing to entertain proposals that he found abhorrent six months ago, but he was also making a greater effort to open the door for dialogue. The struggle he faced was a heightened version of the tension in all history. It was to locate the elusive fulcrum between his rage and faith.", "title": "Can Venezuela Be Saved?", "authors": ["Wil S. Hylton"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Can I get two colds at once?\n\nA. Yes, you can. The phenomenon is known medically as coinfection and occurs when two germs, in this case viruses, cause infections at the same time.\n\nMore than 100 viruses can cause the common cold, so it\u2019s not unusual to be exposed to two at once. And, since one virus doesn\u2019t typically confer immunity against the other, it\u2019s not unusual to be infected by two viruses at once.\n\nThe best data about coinfection come from studies of more serious viruses, such as H.I.V. and hepatitis. These studies show that coinfection can worsen, ameliorate or have no impact on the course of an illness. The outcome depends on the viruses involved.\n\nWith H.I.V., coinfection with the two main types, H.I.V.-1 and H.I.V.-2, is actually beneficial. It slows the progression of the disease. Coinfection with H.I.V. and hepatitis C virus, on the other hand, worsens the outcome.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith influenza viruses, which cause respiratory infections similar to that of the common cold, coinfection is uncommon. Coinfection with influenza A and B, two major types of flu virus, occurs in fewer than 2 percent of cases but doesn\u2019t seem to affect the overall outcome.", "title": "Can You Get Two Colds at Once?", "authors": ["Richard Klasco", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Q: I live in a large Upper West Side co-op with a BuildingLink online message board. Management approves all posts, without providing guidelines on what might be approved or rejected. This is a private bulletin board, and I don\u2019t expect complete freedom of speech. Still, it feels like anything more than an innocuous \u201cfor sale\u201d announcement gets blocked. The moderators have rejected posts about an Upper West Side school rezoning debate; a post questioning what materials would be used for building improvements; and a post from a shareholder asking about a Paris apartment exchange. Should we have a stated policy? Is management being too controlling or is this normal oversight? Can shareholders request that questions not be subject to management approval?\n\nA: Of the roughly 4,300 residential buildings that use BuildingLink message boards, about 85 percent moderate the posts that residents make, with 90 percent of those posts getting approved by management, according to data provided by BuildingLink.\n\nYour board sounds more conservative than many others, however the problem may be about the content that shareholders try to post. People generally seem to use these message boards for pretty innocuous stuff. According to BuildingLink, half of all the posts that appeared on message boards were advertising items for sale. Other popular topics included requests for babysitters and housekeeping. The issues you mentioned are thornier, potentially making management nervous.\n\nMark A. Hakim, the director of the co-op and condo department at the Manhattan law firm Chaves and Perlowitz, advises boards to restrict the use of online message boards to business uses, like posting the names of candidates for board elections, disseminating building notices, and letting residents make service requests. Turn the message board into an online water cooler and the board could open itself up to a possible defamation suit should conversations take a heated turn.\n\nYour building should circulate a written policy explaining the permitted uses of the message board so residents understand the rules. Residents could also request a more open forum. However, the board would not be obligated to change its policy. To do that, you\u2019d need to elect board members sympathetic to your cause.\n\nConsider a different forum for more impassioned debates. Set up a private Facebook, Yahoo or Google group for shareholders, moderated by residents. With such a group, the residents, not the management, would decide how to restrict the content and conversations. But brace yourself: Moderating social media groups can be a headache.", "title": "Can a Building Message Board Be an Open Forum?", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "When Jerome Powell presided over his first policy move as chairman of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, it was against a backdrop of very good economic news: Unemployment is low and falling; inflation is low and stable; financial markets remain buoyant.\n\nThat is also the bad news.\n\nThat\u2019s because there are a lot more ways for the economy to get worse than to get better. Mr. Powell faces the tricky task of trying to keep growth going, and his success as the nation\u2019s most powerful economic policymaker will depend on his ability to judge the various risks to the current expansion.\n\nWithin the announcement that the Fed will raise its interest rate target a quarter of a percentage point to a range of between 1.5 percent and 1.75 percent, there are signs that Mr. Powell and his colleagues think they can lead the nation to even greater prosperity while keeping the inevitable risks created by that growth \u2014 inflation and financial bubbles \u2014 under control.\n\nIf all goes according to plan, this would imply that the United States economy in 2019 and 2020 will be the healthiest it has been in half a century. Fed officials project the lowest unemployment rate since 1969, paired with more modest inflation than was experienced that year.", "title": "Can the Fed Engineer the Best Economy Since the 1960s?
