In one case, 45 live on one snow-swept street in the city\u2019s southwest quadrant. The workers put on Yazidi-only English classes for the refugees\u2019 comfort.\n\nStill, none of this was enough. So, in August a mental health therapist began a \u201cwellness\u201d program, tailor-made for the Yazidis. The women are taught basic coping strategies, like smelling essential oils and cross-body exercises, said to connect the two sides of the brain.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn November, the organization hired a third crisis counselor to offer one-on-one therapy. Few, however, have taken her up on it \u2014 not even Jihan.\n\n\u201cWe all have mental issues,\u201d said Jihan, over dinner with five Yazidi neighbors. The names of seven loved ones \u2014 all taken by ISIS \u2014 are crudely tattooed across her chest, arms and hands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor her, the tattooing was an act of resistance, which she did while imprisoned in Raqqa, using a sewing needle, ash and another inmate\u2019s breast milk. \u201cWe all think a lot about what happened to us,\u201d she said.\n\nJihan was diagnosed with conversion disorder, a catchall description for neurological symptoms not explained by medical causes.\n\nSince she arrived in Canada last June, and began taking anxiety medication, her seizure-like attacks have been greatly reduced \u2014 from four a day that each might last hours, to one every couple months. She doesn\u2019t want therapy.\n\nA lack of interpreters who speak Kurmanji \u2014 the Yazidi dialect of Kurdish \u2014 has proved a hindrance too. A year ago, before the arrival of the Islamic State victims, there were only 1,000 to 1,500 Yazidis in Canada, according to government estimates. Sixteen Kurmanji-speaking interpreters have been hired, but that\u2019s not enough.\n\nMany Yazidis refuse to speak Arabic or use translation services offered by Muslim Kurds who speak Badini, a similar dialect of Kurdish.\n\n\u201cMy heart won\u2019t let me tell a Muslim person what happened to me,\u201d said Kamo, another Yazidi refugee, who survived more than slavery.\n\nHer husband and four of her seven children were pried from her and she doesn\u2019t know their fate. The memory of the last time she saw her eldest daughter, Suzan, brings her to tears. The 14-year-old girl was screaming as ISIS soldiers surrounded her and stripped off her clothing, she said.\n\n\u201cI escaped from these people two years ago, but I still feel captured,\u201d said Kamo, 38. \u201cMy heart is not with me. It is with my kids.\u201d", "title": "Canada Struggles as It Opens Its Arms to Victims of ISIS", "authors": ["Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The National Hockey League expressed concern about the warming trend as part of its first sustainability report, issued in 2014. The league commissioner, Gary Bettman , wrote that \u201cOur sport can trace its roots to frozen freshwater ponds, to cold climates.\u201d\n\nMany immigrants to Canada and their families, Mr. McLeman said, find hockey as \u201can entry point to access mainstream Canadian culture.\u201d He pointed to the N.H.L. defenseman P.K. Subban, whose parents came to Toronto from Jamaica and Montserrat. \u201cIt\u2019s our version of the melting pot,\u201d he said. \u201cAnybody who shows up with skates and a stick can join in.\u201d\n\nRink Watch has helped Canadians understand the real-life consequences of climate change, Mr. Robertson said: \u201cThe fact that this could be taken away and is tied to climate has been a real eye-opener.\u201d\n\nMr. McLeman added: \u201cYour average Canadian will never see a polar bear in the wild, will never see a glacier, will never go to the South Pacific. There\u2019s no personal connection. But say your kids or grandkids might not be able to skate on the backyard rink, and they say, \u2018Oh, I see the connection!\u2019\u201d\n\nCanadian officials are coming to grips with the implications of climate change for their open-air town rinks. Brantford, a city of 100,000 people, maintains as many as 25 outdoor rinks each winter through the work of volunteers. The large number of rinks for such a small city means that most young people can skate within walking distance of home.\n\nBut Lori-Dawn Cavin, the manager of community recreation development for Brantford, said she was uncertain how long that could last. Despite many days of bitter cold this winter, she said, \u201cTwo days of Mother Nature not cooperating, and all their work basically drains away.\u201d\n\nWhile nothing has been formally decided, city officials are talking about concentrating Brantford\u2019s efforts on a smaller number of artificially refrigerated rinks that will stand up to moderate thaws. So far, they have not acted on the idea because the volunteers are determined to keep the old-fashioned rinks open, and the city is committed to the volunteers.", "title": "Canada\u2019s Outdoor Rinks Are Melting. So Is a Way of Life.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Among the hundreds of suggestions so far, there were appeals to visit historic convents near Quebec City, to go on a sugaring off expedition and to visit the Royal Montreal Curling Club in Montreal, which was founded in 1807 and is the oldest curling club in North America. I am hoping to add all of that to my itinerary.\n\nThe office of the premier of Quebec, Philippe Couillard, also reached out to me, and we are exploring whether a meeting in Quebec City is possible to discuss, among other things, what it means to be Quebecois.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral readers asked me to consider why so-called trash radio is so popular in Quebec. With that in mind, I plan to meet Jeff Fillion, among the most polarizing radio talk show hosts in the province, and to see for myself why he both attracts and repels so many people.\n\nSeveral readers also suggested I meet more leading women of the province. As part of my trip, I now plan to meet in Montreal with Phyllis Lambert, who at 91 is still one of the city\u2019s most important civic leaders, an architect and philanthropist. Her father, Samuel Bronfman, built Seagram into the world\u2019s biggest distiller.\n\nMs. Lambert, who is known as Montreal\u2019s \u201cJoan of Architecture,\u201d founded the pioneering Canadian Center for Architecture and played a leading role in commissioning Ludwig Mies van der Rohe to build the towering Seagram headquarters in New York in the 1950s. The building became a memorable emblem of modernism. She also has shaped the architecture of contemporary Montreal like few others.\n\nI also hope to have a laughter-fueled drink with Mariana Mazza, a 27-year-old whose boisterous energy and blunt humor has made her one-woman show, \u201cFemme Ta Guele,\u201d a hit at comedy festivals and beyond. Her subjects include her embrace of celibacy and her relationship to masturbation. Born in Quebec to a Lebanese mother and a Uruguayan father, Ms. Mazza\u2019s multicultural background in many ways embodies contemporary Quebec.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany readers suggested that any road trip through Quebec would be incomplete without examining the state of the contemporary Catholic church. During the so-called Quiet Revolution of the 1960s, Quebecers revolted against the domination of the church, and this secular streak has formed an important part of Quebec identity. With that in mind, I plan to visit a slew of cathedrals across the province, including a church in Montreal that has been converted into a sports club (I work out there!).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlso high on peoples\u2019 lists was a request for me to go to a sugar shack and sample some maple syrup. It doesn\u2019t get more Quebecois than that. With that in mind, I am planning to make a pilgrimage to Martin Picard\u2019s Cabane A Sucre Au Pied De Cochon, in Mirabel, outside Montreal, where this enfant terrible of Quebecois cuisine conjures artery-hardening dishes inspired by maple syrup \u2014 all washed down, of course, with a good Burgundy wine. Dinners have been known to start with foie gras cake.\n\nA big merci for your suggestions for my road trip playlist. They have been wonderfully diverse, from the plaintive love ballads of Richard Desjardins to the hip-hop tunes of Quebecois band Dead Obies, who rap in Franglais, a mix of English and French that is oh so Quebecois. Other names that came up repeatedly were Coeur de Pirate, Arcade Fire and, of course, Leonard Cohen, whose cultural sway in Montreal I recently explored in a story. I am still making my way through the suggestions and will come up with the finalists.\n\nI will also keep you posted as things take shape. I finish packing this weekend and kick off the road trip on Monday. It\u2019s time to start this adventure!\n\nFollow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, as well as on The Times\u2019s Reader Center, where I will be posting dispatches of my journey. And don\u2019t forget to sign up for the Canada newsletter.", "title": "Canadians Share Quebec Tips, Infused With a Love of La Belle Province", "authors": ["Dan Bilefsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Some publishing houses have reacted swiftly to sexual misconduct charges. In October, Penguin Press quickly scrapped a forthcoming book on the 2016 election by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, co-authors of the best-selling political tell-alls \u201cGame Change\u201d and \u201cDouble Down,\u201d after it emerged that Mr. Halperin had sexually harassed multiple women at ABC News, where he oversaw political coverage years ago. (Mr. Heilemann has said in a radio interview that he hopes to revive the project on his own.)\n\nOther publishers have issued bland statements \u2014 or taken no action at all. Henry Holt & Company has continued to publish Bill O\u2019Reilly following a New York Times report that Mr. O\u2019Reilly settled claims by multiple women who accused him of sexual harassment and verbal abuse. Mr. O\u2019Reilly was fired by Fox News, and last fall, his literary agent, William Morris Endeavor, said it would \u201cno longer represent Bill O\u2019Reilly for future deals.\u201d But Holt has so far remained steadfast in its support of Mr. O\u2019Reilly, whose best-selling \u201cKilling\u201d series has more than 17 million copies in circulation. Its fall 2018 catalog lists an untitled book by Mr. O\u2019Reilly. \u201cThe corporate stance is that it\u2019s not our job to judge our authors,\u201d Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Holt, told The Times in a recent interview.\n\nThe disparate responses underscore the commercial and ethical challenges publishing houses face. Some, including Hachette Book Group, are expanding the use of morals clauses and \u201cauthor conduct\u201d clauses in book contracts, which allow publishers to cancel book deals if the author is credibly accused of unethical behavior. But some editors and publishers say privately that it\u2019s difficult to impose a code of conduct on writers, who are not their employees.\n\nIn an industry that is overwhelmingly female \u2014 women account for around 80 percent of people who work in publishing \u2014 publishers may also face pressure from within their own ranks to take a firm stance against sexual harassment.\n\nLast month, when the novelist Anne Ursu published an article on Medium about sexual harassment in the children\u2019s book world, it set off a cascade of online accusations against prominent authors, many made anonymously. Ms. Ursu said she has been in touch around 100 women in the industry who have experienced some form of harassment.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI was very saddened to see how many women had left the industry or quit writing or quit illustrating because of something that had happened,\u201d she said. \u201cWe are losing talent because of this, and we need to find a way to privilege the women who have been hurt over the men who make publishing houses a lot of money.\u201d\n\nAfter Ms. Ursu\u2019s article sparked an outpouring of allegations, the fallout was swift for several best-selling authors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBallantine, a Random House imprint, canceled a contract for an adult novel by James Dashner, after multiple women accused Mr. Dashner of harassment. Mr. Dashner is one of the industry\u2019s most successful young adult novelists: His dystopian series \u201cThe Maze Runner\u201d has sold more than 14 million copies across all formats. Mr. Dashner, who apologized for his behavior, was also dropped by his agent.\n\nAnother blockbuster author, Jay Asher, whose young adult novel \u201cThirteen Reasons Why\u201d has more than four million copies in print, was let go by his agent following a chorus of online accusations that he had harassed women and behaved in a predatory manner at an annual industry conference. (Mr. Asher has disputed the women\u2019s claims.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe novelist Sherman Alexie asked his publisher to delay the publication of a forthcoming paperback edition of his memoir, \u201cYou Don\u2019t Have to Say You Love Me,\u201d following a recent NPR report in which three women accused him of sexual misconduct ranging from inappropriate comments to unwanted advances. The American Indian Library Association withdrew an award that it gave to Mr. Alexie in 2008 for his young adult novel \u201cThe Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian.\u201d Mr. Alexie also declined to accept the 2018 Andrew Carnegie Medal for nonfiction for his memoir, which was given to him last month by the American Library Association.\n\nOn his website, Mr. Alexie expressed regret for his actions but also sounded defiant, writing that he rejects \u201cthe accusations, insinuations and outright falsehoods\u201d made by a woman he said he had a consensual affair with and who accused him online of being a serial predator.\n\nGrove Atlantic and Hachette Book Group, which both publish Mr. Alexie\u2019s books, issued statements saying that they were surprised and troubled by the accusations, but that they will continue to publish his earlier books.\n\nPublishers face complex calculations as they weigh whether or not to cut ties with an author. Canceling a book can lead to lost profits, but publishing and promoting a book by an author accused of misconduct can have other negative ramifications.\n\nAfter the recent rash of allegations against prominent authors, Jamie Thomas, a manager and children\u2019s book buyer at the bookstore Women & Children First in Chicago, removed books by Mr. Asher, Mr. Dashner and Mr. Alexie from the store\u2019s shelves. \u201cI don\u2019t want to have our customers having to come in here and ask why we\u2019re supporting someone accused of sexual misconduct,\u201d she said.\n\nDanielle Foster, the co-owner of Bookworks in Albuquerque, said that she will not reorder books by Mr. Alexie and will instead be featuring works by up-and-coming Native American authors. Still, she is wary of limiting customers\u2019 access to books by popular writers and said the store still has \u201cmany books on our shelves by accused authors.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese discussions need to happen among booksellers and publishers, and at the same time, do you censor the art?\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re taking the stance that we don\u2019t want to censor or ban anything.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut at a moment of heightened scrutiny, some publishers are willing to sacrifice worthwhile books \u2014 and lose money \u2014 to signal their support for the #MeToo movement.\n\n\u201cApparently no industry is exempt from the pervasiveness of sexual harassment and misogyny,\u201d said Yolanda Scott, the associate publisher and editorial director of Charlesbridge, which destroyed finished copies of the picture book \u201cMario and the Hole in the Sky\u201d after harassment allegations against its illustrator surfaced. \u201cWe want the children\u2019s publishing world to be a safe and equitable space.\u201d\n\nThough finished copies had already gone out to book critics and pulling it at such a late stage was costly, Charlesbridge decided publishing the book with Mr. Diaz\u2019s name and illustrations might dampen enthusiasm for the title from readers, reviewers, librarians and booksellers. The company, now searching for a new illustrator, has pushed the publication to 2019.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Diaz acknowledged that he made flirtatious comments and advances at a conference hosted by the Society of Children\u2019s Book Writers and Illustrators and that he had gone through harassment training after the society\u2019s board received a complaint about his behavior in 2012. He also went through a probation period where his conduct was regularly reviewed. When a separate allegation arose in the fall of 2017 about a sexual comment that Mr. Diaz made to a woman at a conference five years earlier, before his harassment training, Mr. Diaz voluntarily resigned from the board and apologized to the woman who made the complaint.\n\n\u201cIt stings a little bit, knowing the work that I\u2019ve done, but I support their choice,\u201d Mr. Diaz said about Charlesbridge\u2019s decision to withdraw the book with his illustrations. \u201cIf I were the author, I would want my book to have every chance at success, without anything attached to it that might hinder it.\u201d", "title": "Canceled Deals and Pulped Books, as the Publishing Industry Confronts Sexual Harassment", "authors": ["Alexandra Alter"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Clenbuterol, often used by asthmatics, has fat burning properties and athletes have been known to use it to help them drop body fat and weight quickly. She had been there for three months in 1973 with an anthropologist, following families as they battled alcoholism and poverty. She had dreamed of becoming a documentary photographer like Dorothea Lange, but her time in Canada left her questioning her privileged status as a photographer.\n\n\u201cHere I was photographing these impoverished people and they didn\u2019t have any sense of where I was coming from and what I might do with those photographs, how it might affect them,\u201d she said. \u201cI started thinking about how much documentary photography is from a position of looking down on somebody who has less power.\u201d\n\nSo what would happen if she flipped the narrative and photographed scenes apropos of her own upper-middle-class background?", "title": "Capturing Photos of Corporate Office Life in 1970s America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "During that time, accusations of abuse by priests swirled through the area, but Cardinal Pell later said that he had no memory of hearing about specific substantiated cases of sexual abuse.\n\nHis rise through the church was swift. He became bishop of Melbourne in 1996. Less than a year later, he formed the \u201cMelbourne Response,\u201d a process to investigate local accusations of sexual abuse against Catholic clergymen.\n\nMore than a dozen priests accused of abuse stepped down during Cardinal Pell\u2019s time in Melbourne, but he also protected the church\u2019s finances. The Melbourne Response capped payouts to victims at 50,000 Australian dollars ($38,000), far below what victims in other countries would later receive.\n\nIn 2007, he was appointed to a council of cardinals assigned to improve the Vatican\u2019s finances. In 2014, Pope Francis named him prefect of the Secretariat for the Economy, effectively making him the Vatican\u2019s treasurer and its third most senior figure.\n\nLast June, his legal team received the charges against him in the state of Victoria. Pope Francis gave him a leave of absence to return to Australia to mount his defense.\n\nCardinal Pell appeared in court on Monday wearing a black suit and clerical collar and did not speak during the initial session.\n\nPhoto\n\nRead: How Cardinal Pell Rose to Power, Trailed by a Cloud of Scandal\n\nRead: George Pell, Aide to Pope, Is Put on Defensive in Abuse Inquiry\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat has he been accused of?\n\nCardinal Pell has been charged with \u201chistorical sexual offenses.\u201d No further details of those charges have been publicly released by the courts.\n\nCardinal Pell previously denied knowing about abuse in the 1970s and \u201980s, but the description of the crimes that have been made available to the public would suggest that he is now being accused of having been personally engaged in sexual offenses. However, nothing has been made public about the details \u2014 not the number of accusers, not the time frame of the accusations, nor the severity of the acts at the center of the case.\n\nWhat\u2019s known is that Cardinal Pell is the highest-ranking Vatican cleric to face charges of sexual crimes, and that he has aggressively denied the charges.\n\n\u201cThe whole idea of sexual abuse is abhorrent to me,\u201d he said at a news conference in Rome last June.\n\nDuring Monday\u2019s hearing, the prosecution requested amendments to certain charges and requested that emotional support dogs be available to witnesses who testified via video link.\n\nRead: Australian Cardinal and Aide to Pope Is Charged With Sexual Assault\n\nRead: Vatican Sex Abuse Scandal Reveals Blind Spot for Francis\n\nWhat happens next?\n\nExpected to run for four weeks, the cardinal\u2019s committal hearing will decide whether there is sufficient evidence to take the case to trial.\n\nAll relevant evidence will be presented to the magistrate by the prosecution, including witness testimony.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLocal news outlets have reported that up to 50 witnesses could be called during the hearing process. The court heard last year that some of the witnesses were choir boys at the time of the alleged incidents.\n\nAll witnesses can be subject to cross-examination by the defense \u2014 a noteworthy detail because Robert Richter, the cardinal\u2019s lawyer, has a reputation for a withering and aggressive approach.\n\n\u201cWe want to demonstrate that what was alleged was impossible,\u201d Mr. Richter told the court last October.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven if the magistrate decides that there is not sufficient evidence to proceed, Victoria\u2019s director of public prosecutions can still decide to try Cardinal Pell.\n\nThe hearing\u2019s proceedings are largely conducted outside of public view. Reporters are being granted access for the first day of the hearing but will not be allowed to return to cover actual testimony.\n\nRead: Cardinal George Pell Returns to Australia, Charged With Sexual Offenses\n\nWhy can\u2019t the public know more about criminal cases?\n\nAustralian law tends to be more favorable to defendants, and proceedings more secretive, than in the United States.\n\nThe country\u2019s contempt standards prohibit reporting \u2014 after charges have been filed and before a verdict has been reached \u2014 that might be seen as prejudicial against or for a defendant.\n\nDepending on the type of offense, journalists cannot publish information on a wide range of topics including: specific accusations against an individual, prior convictions and affiliations with convicted criminals, and material that might be deemed unreasonably favorable to a defendant\u2019s case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll news media organizations in Australia are subject to this restriction, which has the potential to create vast differences in articles about the case published from inside or outside Australia.\n\nSuppression orders are also used in many cases to further restrict what journalists can report in Australia, placing details that appear in court records off limits.\n\nIn rare cases, even the existence of a suppression order can be banned from publication, meaning that journalists cannot report precisely why certain details are missing from their coverage. These are sometimes referred to as superinjunctions.\n\n\u201cQuite often, orders will be made to protect the fairness of the defendant\u2019s trial,\u201d said Jason Bosland, a law professor at the University of Melbourne, whose research has focused on court proceedings. \u201cThat\u2019s the main purpose of an order.\u201d\n\nBut, he added, such orders are often approved without rigorous scrutiny about whether they are in fact necessary.\n\nIn a report published before Cardinal Pell\u2019s case began, Mr. Bosland wrote: \u201cOpen justice is increasingly being undermined in Victoria due to the inappropriate use of suppression orders by the courts.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, he added: \u201cThe problem in Australia is that the courts tend to make orders that don\u2019t comply with the strict requirements of the law.\u201d\n\nRead: Suppression Orders Vs. Open Justice", "title": "Cardinal George Pell Appears in Court Over \u2018Historical\u2019 Sexual Abuse", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi", "Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s decision to step aside \u2014 announced \u201cwith the greatest sadness\u201d in a video posted on YouTube \u2014 ended one monthslong standoff, but heralded the start of another.\n\nHe called on lawmakers instead to appoint Jordi Sanchez, another legislator from his pro-independence party, who is in prison in Madrid pending his own trial on charges of sedition.\n\nThe Spanish government did not react immediately to Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s decision. But the announcement was expected, and Mr. Rajoy has already warned that Catalonia should not be led by any politician \u201ctied up in legal issues.\u201d\n\nIn public, Mr. Puigdemont maintained that he had the right to be president despite not being in the country, since the Catalan public had given the independence movement a democratic mandate in the December elections.\n\nBut in private, Mr. Puigdemont had for some time admitted that his position was untenable. In late January, a Spanish broadcaster surreptitiously captured text messages that he had sent to a colleague admitting that \u201cthis is over.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, he finally reconciled his private position with his public one.\n\nYet his decision does not take Catalonia significantly closer to getting a new regional leader. The judge presiding over a case against several separatist leaders has already indicated that Mr. Sanchez and other jailed Catalan lawmakers would not be allowed prison leave in order to be sworn into office.\n\nMr. Puigdemont, however, insisted on Thursday that selecting Mr. Sanchez was \u201cthe only way to agree on a new government in the current conditions.\u201d He described his own decision to step aside as \u201ctemporary\u201d and said that he would take his fight with the Spanish state before the United Nations, on grounds of human rights violations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe announcement created the latest in a series of seemingly irreconcilable differences between the region and the Rajoy government, one in which each has briefly outwitted the other, without either scoring a lasting victory.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter the Spanish courts refused to allow Catalans to vote in an independence referendum, Mr. Puigdemont went ahead with it anyway last October. Amid confrontations between voters and Spanish police, only 43 percent of Catalans participated \u2014 but of those, more than 90 percent voted to secede from Spain.\n\nSeveral days later, Mr. Puigdemont then declared independence \u2014 before suspending his declaration moments later, hoping to draw the Rajoy government into negotiations.\n\nBut when Mr. Rajoy refused to budge and instead called on Mr. Puigdemont to recognize the illegality of the referendum, Mr. Puigdemont and other separatist lawmakers declared Catalonia independent after all. Fearing arrest, Mr. Puigdemont soon left for Belgium.\n\nFrom his perch in exile, Mr. Puigdemont has tried to drum up support for the Catalan cause across Europe, but has ultimately found few willing to listen. No European Union official would meet with him publicly, and the handful of European politicians who spoke in his favor tended to be from separatist movements themselves.\n\nIn Belgium, Mr. Puigdemont became a chimera of Catalonia\u2019s expectations, an elusive Where\u2019s Waldo-like figure whose appearances were breathlessly tracked by journalists. He was seen hiking in a forest near Brussels, and then spotted at a market in Ghent. He was photographed at the opera, and then dining at a restaurant close to the border with Holland.\n\nIn a last-ditch attempt to foster alliances farther afield, he emerged one day in January in Denmark, where he met with a separatist politician from the Faroe Islands. But even that trip ended in frustration, after he was publicly criticized by a Danish professor, Marlene Wind, during a debate about Catalan independence.\n\n\u201cHe had this expectation that he would be welcomed as a hero,\u201d Ms. Wind said in an interview afterward. \u201cHe simply got it wrong \u2014 and it could be because of the bubble he\u2019s been living in.\u201d\n\nIn Belgium, a Spanish broadcaster caught him texting a fellow separatist lawmaker about the hopelessness of his position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat was after the president of the Catalan Parliament heeded warnings from Spain\u2019s judiciary and postponed a session in which Mr. Puigdemont had hoped to be elected.\n\nAt the time, Mr. Puigdemont portrayed the revelation as a rare moment of self-doubt, and claimed that his position had not changed.\n\nNow, Mr. Puigdemont appears to have finally admitted that he has run out of road.", "title": "Carles Puigdemont Abandons Bid for Catalonia Presidency", "authors": ["Patrick Kingsley", "Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But in a column on Sunday in the German newspaper S\u00fcddeutsche Zeitung, Thomas Urban said Mr. Puigdemont had managed to \u201cinternationalize\u201d the Catalan conflict, and that this \u201ccannot be in the interest of Madrid.\u201d He argued that Madrid\u2019s hard line risked reuniting the pro-independence movement, only days after the bickering separatists could not agree on a new leader.\n\nOn Saturday, Finland\u2019s National Bureau of Investigation said it had received the warrant for Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s detention issued by Spain, but the police said they had no knowledge of his whereabouts. According to Spanish media reports, Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s car was trailed by the Spanish secret service as it left Finland, who alerted their German counterparts about his arrival.\n\nWith Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s arrest in Germany, the spotlight now turns to judges in European countries who will review Spanish arrest warrants, including in Belgium, Scotland and Switzerland. The countries the separatists chose for refuge is important, because European nations have different criminal codes. Some may not recognize the charges brought by Spanish state prosecutors against the Catalan politicians, particularly rebellion.\n\nThe arrest in Germany could pose a challenge for Angela Merkel, who started her fourth term as chancellor this month at the helm of a coalition government after months of tense negotiations.\n\n\u201cLegally, the arrest of Mr. Puigdemont is not objectionable, but politically it creates great problems,\u201d a member of Parliament from the Free Democrats, Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, told The Augsburger Allgemeinen Zeitung, a regional paper, on Sunday.\n\nIn Scotland, the police said that the lawyer for one fugitive there, the former Catalan education minister, Clara Ponsati, had been in touch with them, and that they were preparing for her to turn herself in.\n\nIn December, Pablo Llarena, the Spanish Supreme Court judge who is leading the case against the Catalan separatist leadership, withdrew his initial European arrest warrant against Mr. Puigdemont and others who fled to Belgium, amid concerns that the Belgian judiciary might seek to limit the crimes for which the separatists could be charged if they were returned to Spain.", "title": "Carles Puigdemont Is Arrested in Germany, Drawing E.U. Giant Into Catalan Fight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The benchmark created by the sale of the Panthers, a team that plays in a midsize market with strong growth potential, could come into play in the near future when other N.F.L. teams go up for sale. Sports bankers said the Denver Broncos, New Orleans Saints and Tennessee Titans could change hands in the next few years.\n\nWhile bidders have emerged for the Panthers, several of them appear unwilling to pay far more than what they believe to be the fair price \u2014 around $2.3 billion, according to people with knowledge of the process.\n\nSo far, there are six bidders, according to a person with knowledge of the process, though only four are publicly known. David Tepper, the founder of the hedge fund Appaloosa Management and a minority owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers; Michael Rubin, the chairman of Fanatics, the sports merchandise company; and Ben Navarro, who owns Sherman Financial Group, an investment firm, have each made bids to buy the team. The three offers were between $2 billion and $2.2 billion, according to several people with knowledge of the bids who could not publicly discuss the auction.\n\nAlan Kestenbaum, the chief executive of Bedrock Industries, which owns and operates metal and mining companies, has also bid, though it\u2019s unclear at what price.\n\nThe sale of the team has been a point of focus at the N.F.L. owners meeting here. Representatives from the 32 teams were briefed on the auction on Monday. They were told that a winning bid could be selected by the end of April. Assuming the prospective owner survives due diligence, the owners could vote on that bid at their next meeting in Atlanta in late May. At least 24 owners have to approve a buyer before the transaction can be completed.\n\nRichardson, who has taken a less active role in league proceedings in recent years, has not attended the meetings here. Credit One has been sued for using aggressive collection techniques.\n\nAmong other things, Sherman Financial also buys and manages consumer debt. Sherman Financial also paid a $175,000 penalty to settle a case brought by New York attorney general Eric Scheiderman for unlawful debt collection.\n\nAdditionally, Sherman Financial also owns about half of a joint venture with the Chedraui family in Mexico that provides similar lending services. The company, Consupago, offers loans that are among the most expensive in Mexico to a captive market of government employees.\n\nOn Sunday, Bob McNair, the owner of the Houston Texans, voiced support for Navarro. He scored a best-seller in 2009 with \u201cNudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth and Happiness,\u201d written with Richard H. Thaler, which has been consulted by policymakers around the world. In \u201cImpeachment: A Citizen\u2019s Guide,\u201d released in October, Mr. Sunstein examined the history and legal issues surrounding what he calls \u201cthe ultimate civic authority.\u201d\n\nAs for intergalactic concerns, he covered that topic in \u201cThe World According to Star Wars\u201d (2016), which used the film franchise as a lens onto questions of religion, politics, family, morality and more (while also, some critics complained, making a foolish effort to rank the various installments).\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Sunstein summed up his work as addressing \u201chow to promote enduring constitutional ideals \u2014 freedom, dignity, equality, self-government, the rule of law \u2014 under contemporary circumstances, which include large bureaucracies that sometimes promote, and sometimes threaten, those ideals.\u201d\n\nPast winners of the Holberg Prize include the British philosopher Onora O\u2019Neill, the American literary scholar Stephen Greenblatt and the French sociologist Bruno Latour.", "title": "Cass Sunstein Wins Holberg Prize", "authors": ["Jennifer Schuessler"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Cassidy Chea Luitjen and Eric Yablong Minoff were married March 24 at Club Giraud in San Antonio. She is the vice chairwoman of the Kentucky Democratic Party.\n\nShe is the daughter of Wilma C. Chambers and Dr. Orlando D. Chambers of Berea, Ky. The bride\u2019s father is the director of the University of Kentucky's Tobacco Research and Development Center in Lexington. Her mother, who is retired, was the director of the Berea College Child Development Laboratory in Berea.\n\nMr. Armstrong, 38, is a lawyer in private practice in Louisville. He graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and received a law degree from the University of Louisville.\n\nHe is a son of Karen S. Armstrong of Louisville and the late Dr. Lyman G. Armstrong. The groom\u2019s mother is a kindergarten teacher at the Holy Spirit School in Louisville. Characters", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCatalonia\u2019s pro-independence coalition splintered on Saturday over a proposal by Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of the restive Spanish region, to select his replacement from his own party while he remained in Belgium to avoid prosecution in Spain.\n\nThe political committee of the Popular Unity Candidacy \u2014 a far-left party known by its Catalan acronym, CUP \u2014 announced that its lawmakers would abstain from voting if two larger separatist parties presented Jordi Sanchez as candidate to lead Catalonia \u2014 as Mr. Puigdemont had proposed on Thursday, when he agreed to give up his campaign to be reappointed.\n\nCUP has only four lawmakers among the 135 in the Catalan Parliament, but its backing is essential for the separatist coalition to keep the thin majority of 72 seats that it won in December, after Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain called a snap election in the region.\n\nOne of the CUP lawmakers, Vidal Aragon\u00e9s, on Saturday portrayed his party\u2019s decision not as an attack on Mr. Sanchez himself, but as a way of criticizing other separatist parties for focusing on who should lead the pro-independence movement instead of agreeing on policies and a plan \u201cto materialize the republic\u201d of Catalonia, independent from Spain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite its small size, CUP has long played a pivotal role in driving Catalonia toward independence. In January 2016, it forced a leadership change by blocking the re-election of Artur Mas, instead backing Mr. Puigdemont, then a city mayor and a relative unknown.\n\nEven before the CUP announcement, Mr. Sanchez faced significant hurdles. He is in jail in Madrid pending his sedition trial and has repeatedly been denied bail by the judge leading the investigation into how separatist leaders held a referendum and declared unilateral independence in October, in violation of Spain\u2019s Constitution.", "title": "Catalonia Coalition Splinters After Puigdemont Picks a Successor", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI have Kabbalistic rabbis in the family,\u201d she said and shrugged.\n\nMs. Gleyzer led me to the Cadillac, a large table-shaped piece of equipment found in most Pilates studios, and she asked me to bring my knees to my chest to check my pelvic floor alignment. My right knee was stiff and higher than the left \u2014 a sign, she said, that my foot had never healed properly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. She spent 10 minutes doing bodywork on my ankle, kneading at the tendons, then spent another 10 minutes on my calf muscle. The 60-minute session was like that, with a few basic moves on my part and a lot of diagnosis and hands-on work on hers. I didn\u2019t break a sweat, but I felt so much more flexible and at ease as I left her studio. My only wish was that she would consider a New York residency.\n\nI took an Uber to Culver City to the newish WMN Space, a chic, hushed very white studio where one can go to a Moon Circle or see a doula or have the brow guru Jimena Garcia sculpt one\u2019s eyebrows with a side of something called \u201cenergy resurfacing.\u201d I was there to see Alexandra Roxo, a healer (and occasional actress \u2014 she was on \u201cThe Knick\u201d) who was recommended by a friend of a friend of a friend for her work around love and sex. If I was going to go full-on Los Angeles-style woo-woo, it might as well be about reclaiming my feminine power.\n\nWe started by talking about how much I live in my head and how difficult it is for me to be tender and vulnerable and simply exist in my body. Ms. Roxo has curly red hair and the vibe of someone who has seen and heard enough that opening up to her was easy.\n\nThen I lay down on a massage table and we went to work, with me murmuring and growling. Sage was burned, reiki was administrated, and after about an hour I felt as if I had had a cathartic emotional experience not by talking but by following Ms. Roxo\u2019s coaching to tune into my own energy and desire. My homework was to tune into my chthonic goddess energy daily, which I often do on the subway. I wonder if anyone can tell?\n\nThe next morning, my last in California, was more familiar ground: a morning class at Love Yoga in Venice. I had met Kyle Miller, who owns the studio with Sian Gordon and Jeff Schwartz, last summer when she taught at a yoga retreat and had loved her classes, which usually incorporated breath work, holding poses for a long time and a lot of Drake as soundtrack. It was Saturday and the class was at capacity as we made our way through a sweaty but not especially fast-paced vinyasa and Katonah-based class.\n\nLater that day I picked up my dog and met Ms. Miller and her dog, Smokey, for a walk to the beach. We stood on the beach, sharing a pack of M&Ms and watching our dogs play in the sand.\n\n\u201cThis, for me, is all I want,\u201d she said. I think she was referring to the picture-perfect moment with the sun setting over the Pacific, and also the pace of West Coast living.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI get it,\u201d I said. \u201cI don\u2019t really want to leave.\u201d In the moment I meant it. But at least you can get a good chia bowl in New York these days.", "title": "Catching Up With California-Style Woo-Woo", "authors": ["Marisa Meltzer", "Me Time"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m probably at 70 percent of where my savings were in 2008,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I still plan to work two days a week as long as I can. I enjoy it.\u201d\n\nNed and Barbara Petrucci, 70 and 67\n\nPlanned to retire: 2012\n\nActual retirement date: 2013\n\nWhen the Petruccis were interviewed for a 2009 Times article about older workers\u2019 being unable to retire, Mr. Petrucci, a sales representative for several printing companies, and his wife, Barbara, were feeling the recession\u2019s impact.\n\n\u201cA lot of competition from overseas cutting into the market,\u201d had damaged his job prospects, he said.\n\n\u201cThen we took a nice, big hit to our 401(k). We had downsized our home before that. Then the economy took the icing off our retirement cake.\n\n\u201cWe were about to start doing whatever we wanted to do. But, you know, you have to roll with this stuff,\u201d he said.\n\nThe couple moved in 2013 to Colorado, where Mrs. Petrucci worked as a part-time dialysis nurse before returning to Atlanta. The couple have been replenishing their savings, and Social Security\u2019s full benefits kicked in last October when Mr. Petrucci turned 70.\n\n\u201cI can see continuing to work part time,\u201d Mrs. Petrucci said, \u201cand be involved in a charitable organization. But, as you get older, it gets harder to find a part-time situation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFred Sanford, 65\n\nPlanned to retire: Undecided\n\nActual retirement date: 2018 (with an interim 2012 retirement)\n\nIn 2004, Mr. Sanford moved to Orlando, Fla., to become a financial adviser at Merrill Lynch. \u201cBut 2008 upset the whole applecart,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was a slow drip, drip, drip of clients withdrawing, but in August 2010 I lost a large client, and that tipped everything.\u201d\n\nHis wife took a job helping special-needs children, the couple rented out a room in their house and adopted \u201ca very frugal\u201d lifestyle, he said. And he decided to pursue a different line of work, but something he knew he could do: singing.\n\nStarting in college, he had been a member of a Chicago-area band, the Onstage Majority, whose four members played a number of instruments and had a wide repertoire.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI decided to sing, in supper clubs, restaurants and other places, as a solo act singing what I called boomer tunes,\u201d he said.\n\nHe sang a couple of nights a week and put the money toward the mortgage. But \u201cthere was a lot of competition so it wasn\u2019t always easy.\u201d\n\nThen he had a hip replacement, which made work more difficult. But in July, he will turn 66 and qualify for Social Security.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going for full retirement then,\u201d he said.\n\nKitty Ruderman, 71\n\nPlanned to retire: 2009\n\nActual retirement date: 2009 (partial)\n\nAfter decades as a legal secretary, Ms. Ruderman took a job in 1989 as secretary to John C. Whitehead, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs who later became chairman of AEA Investors, and led the effort to rebuild downtown Manhattan after the 2001 terrorist attacks. She retired from that position after two decades because, she said, \u201cI just wanted a life for myself.\u201d\n\n\u201cI thought I had factored everything in between my pension, medical benefits and Social Security, but the rent on my apartment keeps going up,\u201d she said. Her daughter and grandson live nearby, she said, \u201cso I don\u2019t see myself moving out of New York, and I love the neighborhood around me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, ReServe Inc., which helps place workers 55 and older in jobs, helped her find a data entry position two days a week for the New York Department of Corrections in an office near La Guardia Airport.\n\nThe job pays minimum wage, Ms. Ruderman said, but the commute from her home in Queens is fairly easy and she can still spend time with her grandson and volunteer for AARP.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have to dip into savings,\u201d she said, \u201cand I plan on working as long as my health is fine.\u201d\n\nPatricia Cotton, 77\n\nPlanned to retire: 2003\n\nActual retirement date: 2015\n\nMs. Cotton, an immigrant from Trinidad, was working 60 hours a week as a home care aide in 2012 when she was interviewed for a Times article about people working past age 65. During the 2008 economic meltdown, Ms. Cotton\u2019s $150,000 retirement savings lost half its value.\n\nHer retirement funds took another blow when she incurred tax and penalties for withdrawing her remaining individual retirement account money. That left her short of the extra funds she had been counting on to supplement her monthly Social Security check.\n\nTo put more money away, she said, \u201cI stopped buying clothes, I cut back on everything. I just bought the food I needed.\u201d\n\nShe continued to work as a home care aide in Hyattsville, Md., and saved every penny, but it was tough, she said. \u201cYou do what you\u2019ve got to do,\u201d she added, echoing many who have had setbacks on the road to retirement.", "title": "Catching Up With Retirement After a Recession", "authors": ["Elizabeth Olson"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s a new kind of bucket list item known informally as \u201clast chance travel.\u201d\n\nCuban street life fits into the category. So do African black rhinos and glaciers around the world. As local cultures and natural habitats are transformed by globalization, technology and climate change, a growing number of travelers want to experience them before they are irrevocably altered or vanish.\n\nAmit Sankhala, the owner of Encounters Asia in New Delhi, has been guiding travelers, mostly from America, for the last 14 years. Now, he said, more of his clients are expressing the desire to see a place or a certain animal species before it\u2019s too late. They\u2019re \u201cmore and more conscious that things are disappearing.\u201d\n\nDan Austin, owner of the travel company Austin Adventures, said he fielded questions almost daily on the current state of glaciers in Alaska, the Canadian Rockies or Glacier National Park. The number of glaciers at Glacier National Park is down to 26, from about 150 in 1910, when the park was created.\n\nThat\u2019s the kind of statistic that keeps Ken Lyons of Ridgewood, N.J., traveling to ecosystems on three continents. At Exit Glacier in Kenai Fjords National Park in Alaska, physical markers show the glacier\u2019s retreat each year, and \u201cas you walk up the trail the signs just get farther apart because a larger amount is melting each year,\u201d Mr. Lyons said.", "title": "Catering to \u2018Last Chance\u2019 Travelers Who Seek Disappearing Marvels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Last month, she met Gretchen Carlson, the former Fox News anchor who, more recently, became a public face of sexual harassment. In July 2016, Ms. Carlson sued Roger Ailes, then chairman and chief executive of Fox News, claiming sexual harassment. After dozens of women came forward with their own accounts of harassment by Mr. Ailes, he was forced to resign.\n\nTwo months later, 21st Century Fox, the parent company of Fox News, settled Ms. Carlson\u2019s harassment claim for $20 million and issued a rare public apology for her mistreatment. (Mr. Ailes died in May.)\n\nMs. Carlson, 51, is the author of the best-selling book \u201cBe Fierce: Stop Harassment and Take Your Power Back.\u201d A former Miss America, she was named chairwoman of the Miss America board of directors in January. The previous chairman and other leaders of the organization resigned in December, after emails surfaced that showed leaders of the organization making derogatory remarks about the physical appearance, intelligence and sex lives of past pageant winners. The day before we met, Ms. Carlson joined Norman Lear and others as an executive producer of \u201cAmerica Divided\u201d on Epix, for which she will produce and appear in a program about sexual harassment.\n\nOver afternoon coffees and a shared fruit plate at the Bryant Park Grill in Manhattan, the pair \u2014 both Minnesotans \u2014 discussed the waves of women who have come forward with their own stories in the past year (and why it took so long for them to do so), whether the workplace has been altered in meaningful and sustained ways, and whether Miss America can be relevant in the #MeToo era.\n\nPhilip Galanes Kitty, you were a law student, just a kid in your 20s, when you developed the claim for sexual harassment. Was there a flash of inspiration?\n\nPhoto\n\nCatharine MacKinnon Sexual harassment was \u201cjust life,\u201d as Gloria Steinem put it. For a couple thousand years, women put up with sexual pressure they were not in a position to refuse. In the mid-\u201970s, I was a graduate student at Yale, and among the things I did to make money was play music with a friend. We went around to schools, and we gave a concert at the Cornell Women\u2019s Center. I signed up for their newsletter, and I received one that told the story of a woman named Carmita Wood. Carmita had been working at Cornell for a man who continually pressured her in a sexual way. He was ogling her; he was looking up her skirt at the file cabinet; he was bumping into her in the elevator and pushing her in sexual ways. And the stress produced physical illness. She had to be hospitalized. But when she went to the unemployment board for compensation, they said she couldn\u2019t because she left her job for \u201cpersonal reasons.\u201d When I read that, it exploded in my brain! I remember it to this day: \u201cNow this is what sexual discrimination is about.\u201d\n\n\u2018I Blamed Myself. I Felt Guilty.\u2019\n\nPG Gretchen, flash forward 15 years, when you enter the work force. Was sexual inequality a concern of yours?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGretchen Carlson I was brought up in a strong family in Minnesota. My parents told me every day that with hard work, I could do anything I wanted. I was a gifted violinist and a good student, and I worked incredibly hard. So, when I graduated from Stanford, the idea that women were not equal to men was a new concept to me.\n\nPG First job?\n\nGC At an ABC-TV affiliate in Richmond, Va. And one of my first stories was covering Anita Hill [who accused Clarence Thomas, then a Supreme Court nominee, of sexual harassment].\n\nCM I did commentary with Tom Brokaw from beginning to end on that. We were out there in parallel on that one.\n\nGC I believed her, and I was blown away that other people didn\u2019t, primarily the members of Congress, all men, who were interrogating her. Then I went out on another story, a month later, with a cameraman from my station. We got into the car in a rural part of the state \u2014 this was before cellphones \u2014 and he started asking me if I\u2019d loved it when he touched my breasts when he put the microphones on me. It went downhill from there. I kept pressing myself against the passenger door, and I actually wondered how much it would hurt if I opened the door and rolled out, like they do in the movies.\n\nPG How did you handle it?\n\nGC I did what many women do: I blamed myself. I felt guilty.\n\nPG Kitty, explain this to me. Women make up half the world. How do we make them feel ashamed of the lousy things men do?\n\nCM It doesn\u2019t have to be this way. No, I would just say it is socially the case in societies of male dominance.\n\nGC And that wasn\u2019t an isolated incident. I had two sexual assault experiences when I was Miss America, by two top television executives who attacked me in cars.\n\nPG Because they thought Miss America would be a bimbo?\n\nGC I don\u2019t think it had anything to do with Miss America. They assaulted me because I was a woman.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCM You were there; they could.\n\nGC The first man helped me all day, making calls to help me break into the television business. I was so proud of myself for cold-calling him and asking for help. Then we were riding in the back of his car, and he was all over me \u2014 his tongue down my throat. I didn\u2019t realize that getting into TV meant him getting into my pants. In the second incident, the perpetrator took my neck in his hand and shoved my face into his crotch so hard I couldn\u2019t breathe.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut you know what\u2019s amazing? I never called them \u201cassaults\u201d until after my experience at Fox News. I was interviewing women for my book, and one of them said: \u201cYou realize that\u2019s assault, right?\u201d I was like: No! This is what women have been socialized to do: think we can overcome it by working just a little harder.\n\nCM And part of it is: Don\u2019t let this get in your way. Push it aside. Get past it.\n\n\u2018It Did Not Kill Me. I\u2019m Right Here.\u2019\n\nPG I watched clips of you on \u201cFox and Friends,\u201d Gretchen. I also read your book and heard your TED Talk. That second woman is much smarter than the one I watched on Fox News. Was that part of your job, in bare legs and high heels: to check your I.Q. at the door? To make the guys on the couch with you feel more comfortable?\n\nGC No, my thought process was that I was the only journalist on that couch. I was doing the best job I could every day, and doing the best interviews amid tremendous chaos.\n\nPG Kitty, when you were at Yale, you were unquestionably the most popular professor with students. You invented the legal claim for sexual harassment; your work was hugely influential. And yet you wandered in the desert as a visiting professor for 15 years before you were offered a tenured position. Did that kill you?\n\nCM [Laughing.] It did not kill me. I am right here. I just kept doing what I did. But let\u2019s get realistic: What people do is trim their sails in terms of content. They don\u2019t tell the truth about what\u2019s really happening to women, for example, so they get the job. It never occurred to me to do that. And even though I didn\u2019t get the jobs, there continued to be major fights about appointing me for two decades. The big exception was Michigan, a great school, which offered me a position with tenure. Wandering in the desert, as you put it, was my tenure process. And it turns out, in many of those years, I was the most frequently cited scholar writing in English on law. But nobody knew that because the studies hadn\u2019t been done yet.\n\nPG Let\u2019s turn to #MeToo. Kitty\u2019s been pushing for 40 years. Gretchen topples Roger Ailes in 2016. Why does sexual harassment only go viral with Harvey Weinstein last year?\n\nGC Since I lived it, I\u2019d say it\u2019s because people saw consequences in my story. I didn\u2019t jump off the cliff and disappear. People saw that the perpetrator was brought down in short order. And when I started hearing from other women, thousands of them, they said two things: First, thank you for being a voice for the voiceless. Because the women who had come forward, their lives were in tatters. They were all fired, and never worked in their chosen profession again. That\u2019s outrageous! And second, they felt a sense of victory through me \u2014 even though they personally may not have won. That encouraged other women to say: \u201cWow! They believed her. I\u2019m going to come forward, too.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPG Did you feel it coming?\n\nCM Let me put it this way: I actually thought that Donald Trump was going to win \u2014 in part, because of the racism and misogyny he was running on. A lot of people woke up to the reality of sex inequality because of that election. They also saw someone who admitted being something of a perpetrator get elected to the presidency, as if it didn\u2019t matter at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGC The number-one question I get is: How can the president of the United States have these accusations against him and still be in power?\n\nCM And there be no consequences.\n\nPG Other than possibly fanning #MeToo?\n\nGC I do think it played into women deciding they were going to have a voice on this issue and others.\n\nCM Women have talked to each other about this issue forever. But the media\u2019s reporting it, and staying on it, is an amazing credit to journalists. They discovered that this is a story with legs. It matters, and it\u2019s everywhere. It\u2019s not just for the latest iteration of the women\u2019s page. It\u2019s in sports, politics, business, tech. Now that they\u2019ve discovered the abuse is everywhere, they can cover it everywhere. It also means that men in power \u2014 generally white men, wealthy men \u2014 can\u2019t afford to ignore it, which they\u2019d always been able to do before. Now it\u2019s going to cost them \u2014 their customers, their advertisers \u2014 in a way that\u2019s going to bring them down. Before, it was easy to get rid of the women. Now, they have to get rid of the men, or they\u2019re going to go down themselves.", "title": "Catharine MacKinnon and Gretchen Carlson Have a Few Things to Say", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Table For Three"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "ATLANTA \u2014 Friday\u2019s acquittal of Noor Salman, the widow of the gunman who killed 49 people at an Orlando, Fla., nightclub in 2016, on charges that she helped carry out and cover up the attack, likely means that no one will ever be convicted in connection with the siege.\n\nBut the scrutiny of Ms. Salman by law enforcement was not unusual.\n\n(Read about Noor Salman\u2019s acquittal.)\n\nIn major cases, even when the suspects are killed and never brought to trial, law enforcement officials carry out exhaustive inquiries that can lead to charges against family members and acquaintances. The charges are often, but not always, connected to the crimes that provoked the primary investigation.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s easy to identify people you can charge,\u201d said William N. Nettles, who was the United States attorney in South Carolina when nine people were killed at a church in Charleston. \u201cThe hard part is exercising the discretion and charging the right people.\u201d", "title": "Caught Up in a Killing Spree, and Facing Charges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith just 13 games to go in the regular season, Coach Tyronn Lue announced Monday that he was taking an indefinite leave of absence from the Cleveland Cavaliers to try to address health issues that he has battled for months.\n\nLarry Drew, who has previously served as a head coach in Atlanta and Milwaukee, will be Cleveland\u2019s interim coach while Lue, who turns 41 in May, recuperates.\n\n\u201cI have had chest pains and other troubling symptoms, compounded by a loss of sleep, throughout the year,\u201d Lue said in a statement. \u201cDespite a battery of tests, there have been no conclusions as to what the exact issue is.\u201d\n\nLue has missed part or all of three games this season because of his health, including the second half of Saturday\u2019s victory at Chicago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe team has yet to announce a specific return timetable, but Lue told ESPN after the statement was issued that he hopes to miss only a week. He has been urged to step away in this manner by team officials at various points this season as his symptoms persisted, but Lue resisted until now, fearful that even a temporary departure would cause further upheaval in a Cavaliers season filled with chaos.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhile I have tried to work through it, the last thing I want is for it to affect the team,\u201d Lue said. \u201cI am going to use this time to focus on a prescribed routine and medication, which has previously been difficult to start in the midst of a season. My goal is to come out of it a stronger and healthier version of myself so I can continue to lead this team to the championship we are all working towards.\u201d", "title": "Cavaliers Coach Tyronn Lue Cites Health Issues as He Steps Away From Team", "authors": ["Marc Stein"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "If a phone buzzes on the moon and no one\u2019s there to answer it, does it make a sound? What does it matter, it\u2019s bound to make news.\n\nOn Tuesday, the phone companies Vodafone and Nokia said that they planned to build a cellular network in space to support what would be the first privately funded moon landing, planned for next year. The announcement earned headlines around the world, but much more would have to be done to make the plan a reality.\n\nThe companies vowed to produce what would be groundbreaking technology, weighing in at less than a kilogram, to provide a fourth-generation, or 4G, cellular network, which a pair of lunar vehicles would use to communicate with a base station. The station would then transmit data and high-definition video back to Earth via different medium.\n\nThe rovers and the network technology would be transported aboard a rocket owned by SpaceX, the company founded and run by the billionaire Elon Musk, as part of the \u201cMission to the Moon,\u201d an ambitious plan by PTScientists, a Berlin-based company. Once on the moon, the rovers will carefully approach NASA\u2019s Apollo 17 rover, which was delivered there in 1972, without damaging the overall site.", "title": "Cellphones on the Moon? Not So Fast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "In its statement, the scientific advisory panel said Mr. Ross\u2019s analysis was based on \u201cdata collected in a different data collection context, in a different political climate, before anti-immigrant attitudes were as salient and consequential\u201d as they are today. The members also challenged his decision to forgo testing the question\u2019s wording, saying it reflected different motivations and uses in the American Community Survey \u2014 including a reference to United States territories that would appear \u201cpuzzling\u201d on the 2020 census.\n\nThe last-minute decision to include the citizenship question prevented the bureau from putting it on its only full trial run of the head count, which began this month in Providence County, R.I. The panel urged the bureau to immediately begin testing the language of the query, saying that in the current charged atmosphere surrounding foreign-born residents, the question could lead respondents to misstate or avoid answering other questions about race and ethnicity.\n\nThe committee worried as well that whatever citizenship data the bureau collected might inadvertently compromise the confidentiality of those who provided it. Federal law bars the bureau from releasing any information that specifically identifies respondents, and the bureau\u2019s record of keeping data private is spotless. But the only citizenship data that is currently collected, from the American Community Survey, is aggregated into large parcels called census block groups.\n\nIn contrast, citizenship data collected in 2020 will be reported down to the bureau\u2019s smallest geographic unit, called census blocks, which can be as small as an apartment building. So while individuals\u2019 responses to the question would remain nominally private, block data could allow others to target small areas where noncitizens are reported to live.\n\nSenior census bureau officials at the committee\u2019s meetings carefully avoided criticizing the decision to add the citizenship question, but at the same time admitted that they did not know how much \u2014 or even how \u2014 it would affect the head count. The bureau is polling 50,000 households and conducting 42 focus groups with minorities and other slices of the population to learn their attitudes toward the census. But \u201cthere\u2019s a lot of uncertainty,\u201d Mr. Jarmin said. \u201cThere\u2019s no way of really testing what it\u2019s going to look like.\u201d\n\nWhile community organizations and minority groups have made their fears about the question clear, said Timothy Olson, the bureau\u2019s associate director for field operations, some census offices have also seen shows of support, including an \u201cunheard-of\u201d 400 job applications received in one day.\n\n\u201cRegardless of how you feel about it, it has elevated the awareness of 2020 to the population,\u201d Mr. Olson said, \u201chigher than I can recall in four decennials.\u201d", "title": "Census Bureau\u2019s Own Expert Panel Rebukes Decision to Add Citizenship Question", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "A day after two people were shot and killed in a dorm room at Central Michigan University on Friday, the police charged the victims\u2019 son, a sophomore at the school, with murder.\n\nThe son, James E. Davis Jr., 19, had been acting strangely the day before the shooting, Chief Bill Yeagley of the Central Michigan University Police Department said at a news conference on Saturday.\n\nHe said the gun recovered at the scene was registered to Mr. Davis\u2019s slain father, James E. Davis Sr., a police officer.\n\nOn Saturday afternoon, the university police said in a statement that Mr. Davis was in police custody at a hospital. He was charged with two counts of murder and one count of possession of a weapon to commit murder.", "title": "Central Michigan University Gunman Was Acting Oddly Before Shooting, Police Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The committee\u2019s findings, which are not publicly announced, are sent to the president, who may suspend or prohibit the deal.\n\nBut cases do not often get that far: The rejection of a deal by the committee is usually enough to kill it.\n\nCfius \u201cis the No. 1 weapon in the Trump administration\u2019s protectionist arsenal, the ultimate regulatory bazooka,\u201d said Hernan Cristerna, co-head of global mergers and acquisitions at JPMorgan Chase.\n\nIt grew out of fears of Japanese investment\n\nPresident Gerald R. Ford signed an executive order creating Cfius in 1975, mainly as a vehicle to study foreign investment. But its responsibilities expanded after a crisis in the 1980s involving \u2014 like Qualcomm \u2014 an American chip maker: Fairchild Semiconductor, one of the pioneers of Silicon Valley, wanted to sell itself to Fujitsu, a Japanese company.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJapanese companies were at the forefront of the electronics industry then, and Reagan administration officials mustered intense pressure to force Fairchild to cancel the deal (it later struck a deal with National Semiconductor). But the threat of more Japanese investment led Congress to pass the Exon-Florio Amendment in 1988, granting the president the ability to stop a foreign acquisition if there is \u201ccredible evidence\u201d that a \u201cforeign interest exercising control might take action that threatens to impair the national security.\u201d\n\nCfius was empowered with reviewing mergers for potential threats.\n\nChina is a frequent element in the deals Cfius reviews\n\nCfius reviews deals across a variety of industries and companies from dozens of different countries. It has often set its sites on deals involving Chinese companies, as the country\u2019s economic might has grown in recent years. From 2013 to 2015, the latest years for which the committee has made data public, about 20 percent of the deals that Cfius reviewed involved investors from China.\n\nAmong the notable recent reviews were:\n\nMONEYGRAM \u2014 ANT FINANCIAL Ant Financial, a Chinese electronic payments company, wanted to purchase MoneyGram, a money transfer company based in Dallas, for $1.2 billion. But the deal collapsed in January after both sides said Cfius refused to approve it. The collapse came despite a charm offensive by Jack Ma, the Chinese tycoon who controls Ant Financial, who had visited President-elect Donald Trump at Trump Tower and pledged to create one million American jobs. But he could not overcome the Trump administration\u2019s concerns about Chinese acquisition of American know-how. CANYON BRIDGE CAPITAL \u2014 LATTICE Canyon Bridge Capital, a private equity firm, wanted to acquire Lattice, a chip maker based in Portland, Ore. Canyon Bridge received investment from a group that included China Venture Capital Fund Corporation, which is owned by Chinese government-backed organizations. Lattice said Cfius objected to the deal, and the company tried to appeal to the president, offering to resolve national security concerns. But Mr. Trump formally blocked the deal in September 2017, prompting China\u2019s commerce ministry to issue a statement saying countries should not push protectionism through security reviews. GO SCALE \u2014 PHILIPS In 2015, the Dutch electronics giant Philips had an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED business for as much as $2.9 billion to GO Scale, an investment fund sponsored by GSR Ventures of China and Oak Investment Partners. Philips canceled the deal after it could not resolve Cfius\u2019s concerns, and in December 2016 announced it would sell the unit to Apollo Global Management for $1.5 billion, almost half the amount of the earlier deal.\n\nThe Broadcom-Qualcomm deal does not involve China-based companies. But there has been concern that the acquisition could undermine the ability of the United States to compete with China in the race for telecommunications supremacy. Members of Cfius pointed to Broadcom\u2019s statements that it would take a \u201c\u2018private equity\u2019-style\u201d approach if it acquired Qualcomm, suggesting to the committee that Broadcom could reduce long-term investment on research and development in favor of focusing on short-term profits.\n\nWhile the United States has remained a standard-bearer in mobile technology, the committee noted, \u201cChina would likely compete robustly to fill any void left by Qualcomm as a result of this hostile takeover.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawmakers want to expand Cfius\u2019s jurisdiction\n\nA bipartisan group in Congress has proposed legislation that would greatly expand the number of deals reviewed by Cfius. In November, Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, introduced a bill that could add thousands of companies with foreign ties to the list of those reviewed each year by Cfius and provide more funding to deal with that increase. A similar House bill was also introduced by Representative Robert Pittenger, Republican of North Carolina. The measure would expand Cfius\u2019s jurisdiction to include joint ventures, sales of minority stakes and real estate deals for property near military bases and other sensitive facilities.\n\n\u201cBy exploiting gaps in the existing Cfius review process,\u201d said Mr. Cornyn, \u201cpotential adversaries, such as China, have been effectively degrading our country\u2019s military technological edge by acquiring, and otherwise investing in U.S. companies.\u201d\n\nThe proposal has drawn objections from some businesses. IBM said the changes would limit \u201cthe ability of American firms to do business abroad while empowering foreign competitors to capture global markets.\u201d", "title": "Cfius, Powerful and Unseen, Is a Gatekeeper on Major Deals", "authors": ["Kevin Granville"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "It takes 10 minutes to drive from the military checkpoint, where anyone who has a pass to the city must stop, to an ice-filled stadium called Trud (Work).\n\nSince the days of the Soviet Union, there have been several dozen closed cities like Lesnoy, a community of 50,000 where access is tightly controlled and state secrets are protected. For decades, those not in on the secrets did not know about these cities at all.\n\nInside, however, citizens were hard at work: developing weapons of mass destruction, processing radioactive materials \u2014 and training for the Olympics.\n\nAccording to local officials, the number of Olympians per resident here is a record for the country. Lesnoy has given rise to 46 champions of the U.S.S.R., Russia and Europe, and has produced 11 athletes who competed at the Olympic Games and went home with medals.", "title": "Champions Behind the Wire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Sevilla last reached the round of 8 of the competition in 1958, when it was called the European Cup.
