The district is facing a $115 million budget shortfall, continued fallout from Hurricane Harvey and a potential state takeover of the district board because of its failure to turn around persistently low-performing schools. Houston has not announced an interim superintendent.\n\nIn New York, Mr. Carranza will inherit a system that is generally moving in a positive direction. Graduation rates and test scores have improved under Mayor Bill de Blasio, as they did under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But achievement gaps persist and the city\u2019s schools remain deeply segregated.\n\nMr. Carranza, the grandson of Mexican immigrants, grew up in Tucson, the son of a sheet metal worker and a hairdresser. It is a background that Mr. de Blasio has said will help him relate to New York City school children and their families, most of whom are poor people of color. Mr. Carranza has described his educational philosophy as very closely aligned with Mr. de Blasio\u2019s. \u201cThere is no daylight between Mayor de Blasio and myself,\u201d he said at a news conference on Monday announcing his selection.\n\nHe was Mr. de Blasio\u2019s second choice to lead the schools, after Alberto M. Carvalho, the superintendent of the Miami-Dade schools, turned down the job on live television.\n\nMr. Carranza\u2019s first week of work should be relatively quiet \u2014 the schools are on break that week, with students not returning to class until the following Monday.", "title": "Chancellor\u2019s First Day in Office Is Set", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe wanted a skeleton movement with a solid mass floating in the center to preserve the purity of the watch\u2019s lines,\u201d Mr. Beau said. \u201cThat is why the wheels are full rather than openwork. It is something you don\u2019t see often in watchmaking because it is difficult to achieve perfect flatness with full wheels and because they add to the overall weight.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo add a feminine touch to a sober construct, the case and bezel were made of what Chanel calls \u201cbeige gold,\u201d a rosy gold alloy exclusive to the house, which softens the look of the deep black galvanic treatment of the bridges and plates. The same beige gold alloy contours the edges of the more visible black components, a touch that Mr. Beau said was meant to evoke the light metal chain sewn on the inside hem of Chanel\u2019s jackets.\n\n\u201cAt Chanel, our primary concern is the beauty of the d\u00e9cor,\u201d Mr. Beau said. \u201cWe first come up with the design and then ask our watchmakers to create a movement that reflects the style of Chanel.\u201d\n\nThough it has been 31 years since Chanel first added watches to its repertoire, it is only in the last three years that the brand has produced its own in-house movements. That development was made possible by bringing outside expertise into its fold, similar to the m\u00e9tiers d\u2019art group in its fashion division, with the acquisition of French heritage houses like the plumassier Lemari\u00e9 or the embroidery specialist Lesage.\n\nIn 2011, Chanel took a minority interest in Romain Gauthier, an independent Swiss watchmaker from the Vall\u00e9e de Joux that supplies it with top-quality components.\n\nThat same year, it created a team dedicated to producing movements within the Manufacture G&F Ch\u00e2telain in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland, a specialist in the machining, assembly and finishing of high-end timepieces that Chanel acquired in 1993.\n\nEarlier, Chanel primarily had collaborated with Renaud & Papi, the master watchmakers at Audemars Piguet, to produce such models as the 2012 Premi\u00e8re Cam\u00e9lia Flying Tourbillon and its skeletonized version.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe were happy to work with Renaud & Papi so long as we produced the design,\u201d Mr. Beau said. \u201cBut about 10 years ago, we decided to make our own movements so we could be masters of our own destiny.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMaking movements is the most complex part of watchmaking, so acquiring the expertise to make its own, he added, \u201cwas the final brick in the construction of our watchmaking maison.\u201d\n\nLike the Parisian workshops that Chanel owns, both Ch\u00e2telain and Mr. Gauthier are free to supply other watch brands, including Chanel\u2019s competitors. \u201cChanel has a \u2018friendly\u2019 participation in our business,\u201d Mr. Gauthier said in an interview in Geneva. \u201cWe furnish them with high-precision components according to their specifications, but we do so with other brands as well. We have complete freedom when it comes to our business.\u201d\n\n\u201cChanel likes creative talents in different domains,\u201d Mr. Gauthier said. \u201cThey respect our work and do not question our expertise.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 2016, the alliances produced the Calibre 1, encased in Chanel\u2019s first men\u2019s watch, the Monsieur de Chanel, and the next year, the Calibre 2, used in the Premi\u00e8re Cam\u00e9lia Skeleton, a women\u2019s model. It went on to win the top prize in the women\u2019s watches category at the Grand Prix d\u2019Horlogerie de Gen\u00e8ve in November. (Ms. Lankarani was a judge at the event.)\n\n\u201cWe work with the best, and we don\u2019t hide the fact that we use outside talent,\u201d Mr. Beau said. \u201cWhen we do, we have no problem saying it.\u201d\n\nThe Calibre 3 is being presented at Baselworld in two versions, a plain beige gold and a diamond-studded version. They will be marketed to a primarily female audience, although that could include men willing to broaden their horizons.\n\n\u201cSome men may find it difficult to wear a watch made by Chanel,\u201d Mr. Beau said. \u201cIt takes a super-chic man who doesn\u2019t care what anyone thinks of him.\u201d", "title": "Chanel\u2019s New Watch? It Blends Right In", "authors": ["Nazanin Lankarani"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTillerson Ousted as Trump Silences Dissent in Cabinet\u201d (front page, March 14): It has been nearly a year and a half since Donald Trump became president, and only now is he assembling a cabinet he wants? That shows once again his abysmal and unprecedented unpreparedness for the office.\n\nAfter Stephen Bannon was fired, and then seemingly apolitical John Kelly made chief of staff, it appeared that Mr. Trump wanted to govern more from the center. But now, with the apparent declining influence of Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, the departures of Rex Tillerson and Gary Cohn, and the nomination of Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state, it seems that while Mr. Bannon left in disgrace, his ideology has taken hold in Mr. Trump\u2019s mind and government.\n\nJAMES ADLER, CAMBRIDGE, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a former superintendent of schools and executive director of a professional association, I know how difficult it is to fire someone face to face. So I understand why President Trump decided to fire Secretary of State Rex Tillerson via Twitter instead of meeting with him.\n\nUnderstanding, however, does not equate to justification. Nobody deserves to find out via a tweet that he has lost his job just because his boss does not have the courage to deliver the news in person.", "title": "Opinion | Changes in the Cabinet and the C.I.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s move down to 30A: \u201cCommit a peccadillo?\u201d This is Sunday, remember; peccadillo is usually clued as a \u201cslip\u201d or \u201csmall sin\u201d so we\u2019re looking for some sort of minor misdeed here, and it solves to SIN SOME SMALL WAY. \u201cIn some small way,\u201d + the letter S, and \u201cIn\u201d has now become \u201cSin.\u201d\n\nIf you picked up on this faster than I did, then the initial word of each phrase begins to be helpful and tip you off to the big trick of this puzzle. Let\u2019s look at one more, 47A: \u201cPerform the hit \u2018Things I Should Have Said\u2019?\u201d If I knew that the word \u201cSin,\u201d plus a letter inserted or added, began the entry, then \u201cSin of omission\u201d would pop into my head; knowing the rule of addition, the answer would be apparent: SING OF OMISSION.\n\nI won\u2019t finish them off here but if you\u2019re with me so far, and you take a look at Mr. Walden\u2019s notes, I think you\u2019ll successfully go with the flow. Each of the root phrases is common enough, and the new expressions created are clever to boot.\n\nI\u2019d be curious to see who grokked this without looking here, though! If this puzzle were an actual edifice, I\u2019d love to live in it, because I\u2019d be finding little doors to undiscovered rooms in it for years. Does anyone else have that dream?\n\nTricky Clues\n\n20A: I was completely misdirected by \u201cPauses for service\u201d and waited, in vain, for a verb to present itself. The answer, TEATIMES, was one of the last entries I filled in.\n\n29A: Does everyone remember Bill FRIST? He was the Senate majority leader for two Congresses, four years \u2014 as long as Mitch McConnell, thus far. I find this comforting because I wouldn\u2019t recognize Bill Frist if he fell down my chimney, and there are some politicians out there at the moment that I don\u2019t easily imagine forgetting. I look forward to the memory wipe.\n\n81A: There are at least 160 forms of martial arts (with lots of unique spellings; this would be a terrific theme for a puzzle, if it hasn\u2019t been already). Some are hands only, others have pretty fearsome weapons; KENDO is practiced using these long bamboo poles. I watched a short demonstration and was inspired to look up kendo\u2019s connection to Star Wars light sabers, and guess what, all you little boys who used to whack me with anything resembling a light saber in our youth, you know a little kendo. Use your power wisely, friends.\n\n101A: I doubt many of us think much about the impossibility of our lives without the microbial world. The nitrogen cycle relies on AEROBE and anaerobe organisms to turn a ubiquitous but unavailable gas into a vital component to plant growth, and where would we be without plants? AEROBE is also a really good crossword filler word, between the vowels and the placement of the B.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n3D: I was so surprised to learn that HAT TIP is a debut in the Times puzzle! It refers to a gesture that seems so charming and old-fashioned. When could one last expect a hat tip on the street, from anyone other than a swing dancer or Pharrell? Since I was stuck on TEATIMES (and reluctant to enter SEP at 33A, as I thought it one letter too short to abbreviate September), it took a while for this entry to make itself apparent. Every so often I think about getting a real hat, as opposed to some shapeless woolly number, but I don\u2019t like to stand out. Once upon a time it\u2019d have been the other way around.\n\n5D: The \u201cperformance for which one might grab a chair\u201d is a circus, and whomever is doing the LION TAMING isn\u2019t exactly sitting down; big cat trainers famously wave a chair about when they\u2019re tempting fate. At first I thought that this answer, another puzzle debut, was a bit anachronistic, or soon to be. The old-fashioned circus is going the way of sideshows, right? Little did I know the history of Clyde Beatty, lion tamer, whose introduction of the use of a chair as a distraction device has inspired 21st-century motivators who hope to improve our focus. Apparently, when a lion sees the four legs of a chair, he (or she, although the boys are usually the ones in these shows, I think) sees four separate pieces of prey, one for each leg, and pauses in a befuddled state. Don\u2019t be a lion! Break it down; savage one leg at a time.\n\nI don\u2019t have any \u201clittle lions\u201d of my own, because I must share my home with someone who has \u201cterrible allergies,\u201d but I attempted a similar technique using a kitchen whisk on a friend\u2019s kitten and she immediately rolled over in submissive confusion. When I dropped the whisk and went in for the cuddle my hands were badly mauled. Next time, the chair!\n\n16D: There were mirrored long down entries in this grid that threw a wrench in the works for me. Neither was so tricky, but I hadn\u2019t sufficiently narrowed down the theme to eliminate them from inclusion so I looked for some sort of shenanigans both here and at 38D. As far as I can tell they\u2019re straightforward. In this case, \u201cParts of math textbooks\u201d is PROBLEM SECTIONS; the other is the protagonist of \u201cA Christmas Carol,\u201d if you\u2019re stuck on that one.\n\n58D: Honestly, I knew Bears EARS was a monument in Utah only because it\u2019s been in the news recently.\n\n80D: I never remember my dynasties, and we didn\u2019t learn much about China before Mao in school, at least not during those few years when I was paying attention. I had \u201cMing\u201d for a while, which killed my chances at solving one of the theme answers at 77A; the QING dynasty came after Ming, held up for over a century, and really fell apart because of international pressures from Britain more than the United States.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nHAT TIP to the puzzle magazines of my long-gone youth. One of them (Dell?) had a little word puzzle where you had to go from STARTLING to I deleting one letter at a time, always forming a new word without anagramming. (BTW, there are two solutions.) One of my bugaboos is plural names, which I really try to avoid. This one has two! The second one came when I just had to get IN MEM out of the grid and upgraded it with TV MOM. I tried to do something about ALIS. I could replace the corner, but because of the interlock, it would require redoing the whole of the Eastern Seaboard, and I just couldn\u2019t pull it off. Because of a tough crossing, ALIS needed the easiest clue possible, but I like to tell myself the real clue is the first word of Oregon\u2019s state motto. I\u2019m pretty happy how the rest turned out. Hope you all enjoy it!\n\nThe Sunday Sherpa\n\nIf you would like to see the completed puzzle click here. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Character Building", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "In the throes of the campaign in September 2016, Mike Pence told a crowd at the Living Word Bible Church in Mesa, Ariz.:\n\n\u201cI\u2019m old enough to remember back in the last Clinton administration where America really had a debate over whether character mattered to the presidency. We don\u2019t need to have that debate again. We don\u2019t need to have that debate again. Character matters to the presidency and Donald Trump will bring the highest level of integrity to the highest office in the land. You can count on it.\u201d\n\nHa.\n\nThis after a lifetime of Trump boasting about his sexual conquests, after years of him going on the Howard Stern show and saying the most debauched things, and just two weeks before the release of the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape on which Trump boasted about kissing and groping women without their permission \u2014 in other words, sexual assault.\n\nPence\u2019s proclamation was a lie when he said it, and is even more of a lie now. Trump is involved in litigation over sexual encounters on three fronts, including with the porn star Stephanie Clifford, known as Stormy Daniels.\n\nBut the Daniels scandal is hardly making a dent.\n\nAs Politico reported Wednesday, \u201cThe data suggest Trump\u2019s past behavior with women is already known among voters \u2014 and many are willing to overlook it.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Character Should Still Matter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "In a \u201cMeet the Press\u201d interview on Sunday, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin shrugged off questions about President Trump\u2019s incendiary tweets, personal insults and vulgar language. Mr. Mnuchin suggested that he was above riffraff talk. \u201cI think you should be focused on what the policies are,\u201d he told the show\u2019s host, Chuck Todd.\n\nHis words sounded high-minded, but they rang hollow. Mr. Mnuchin, who has milked taxpayers so that he and his wife can travel in style, might benefit from a refresher course in the axiom that character is destiny. It\u2019s an idea that has been around for a couple of thousand years, and for good reason: It\u2019s inherently true.\n\nThis brings us to Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, who also once seemed to give that concept short shrift. \u201cI do not believe that politics in the long run is about individuals,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is about ideas, the public good and doing what is best for the state of New York.\u201d That was on March 10, 2008, a few days before Mr. Spitzer was forced to resign as governor amid revelations that he\u2019d been a frequent patron of a prostitution ring. His hypocrisy was manifest, given how he had proclaimed himself an implacable foe of the sex trade because it exploited women. Character, meet your destiny.\n\nThis week, the 10th anniversary of his resignation, news organizations have resurrected the scandal, exploring how it rapidly unfolded and offering where-are-they-now profiles of key figures. Mr. Spitzer, now 58, has taken control of his family\u2019s real-estate business. After an unsuccessful run for city comptroller five years ago, he\u2019s not through with politics so much as politics is through with him.", "title": "Opinion | Character Was Destiny for Spitzer; Will It Be for Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Shortly after the publication of the Times article, the United States attorney\u2019s office in Brooklyn opened an investigation into Nxivm. New York state officials are also investigating the group.\n\nIn an affidavit filed as part of the complaint, an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Michael Lever, stated that his inquiry had determined that Mr. Raniere maintained a \u201crotating group of fifteen to twenty women\u201d with whom he maintained sexual relations. Those women were allowed to have sex only with him, the agent stated in the filing.\n\nWomen who joined the secret sorority were unaware that Mr. Raniere was its supreme master, Mr. Lever said. And some slaves were required by their masters, who included high-ranking women within Nxivm, \u201cto have sex with Raniere, which they then did,\u201d the filing said.\n\nMr. Lever said that two women who cooperated with the federal investigation said they believed they had to \u201ccomplete the assignment or risk release of their collateral.\u201d\n\nWhen one of the women started having sex with Mr. Raniere, he began giving her money and provided a job, but when she defected he demanded the money back, according to the filing.\n\nBoth Nxivm and Mr. Raniere have long attracted controversy. Former members have depicted him as a man who manipulated his adherents, had sex with them and urged women to follow near-starvation diets to achieve the type of physique he found appealing.\n\nOver the years, much of Nxivm\u2019s funding has come from Clare and Sara Bronfman, sisters who are members of the group and the youngest daughters of Edgar Bronfman, the chairman of the Seagram Company who died in 2013.", "title": "Charges Filed Against Leader of Secretive Group Where Women Were Branded", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI would say the political fundamentals which he learned on the streets of Boston, he was still applying in the streets of Michigan for Hillary Clinton in 2016,\u201d said Senator Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, a close friend who was advised by Mr. Campion. \u201cChuck\u2019s philosophy was that the message should be direct, simple and to the heart of the issue.\u201d\n\nMr. Campion came up in Massachusetts politics as a member of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis\u2019s administration from 1975 to 1978. He went on to work for President Jimmy Carter on advance planning.\n\nIt was in Washington that he got to know Mr. Mondale, the vice president under Mr. Carter. Mr. Mondale\u2019s presidential campaign in 1984 would be Mr. Campion\u2019s first.\n\n\u201cPolitics is a fickle game,\u201d he said in an interview with The New York Times in 1983 as he was building a campaign operation for Mr. Mondale in New Hampshire in advance of the state\u2019s primary. No matter how bright a candidate\u2019s prospects seem, he said, \u201cyou\u2019re always worried about winning.\u201d\n\nNew Hampshire was a case in point. Though Mr. Mondale led in the polls, he lost the primary in a stunning upset by Gary Hart, then a little-known senator from Colorado. (Mr. Mondale nevertheless went on to win the Democratic nomination before losing to President Ronald Reagan in a landslide.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Campion came to know more losses working for other presidential campaigns, including those of Mr. Dukakis in 1988 (Mr. Campion was its political director), Vice President Al Gore in 2000 and Senator Kerry in 2004.\n\nThe Dewey Square Group said that in 2008, as an adviser to Mrs. Clinton\u2019s first presidential run, it was Mr. Campion who arranged coffee events with voters ahead of the New Hampshire primary, including one at a coffee shop where she cried in conversation with a voter, generating wide publicity.\n\n\u201cHe was a magician in understanding a community he hadn\u2019t been into,\u201d Mr. Kerry said. \u201cHe ran Michigan for me, and we won Michigan.\u201d\n\nMr. Campion\u2019s friends and family said he had been undeterred by the losses. \u201cHe never got discouraged, he never quit,\u201d Ms. Campion said. \u201cYou have your values, you just keep going.\u201d\n\nAs a founder of the Dewey Square Group, in 1993, and its chairman, Mr. Campion was familiar to Boston\u2019s political scene. Sometimes he wrote jokes for the annual St. Patrick\u2019s Day breakfast, an all-but-mandatory event for the local political class. He wrote one in 2003 for Mr. Kerry, who had recently discovered that he had Jewish ancestors.\n\n\u201cSo who said I don\u2019t have the matzo balls to be here today?\u201d Mr. Kerry said, to laughter.\n\nMr. Campion was born in Boston on Aug. 20, 1955, the middle child and only son in a family of five children. A product of Brookline High School, he was a political science major at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, graduating in 1977. He met his wife, the former Heather Pars, while he was working in the Carter administration. She was a speechwriter for the president.\n\nIn addition to his wife, with whom he lived in Brookline, Mass., Mr. Campion is survived by their son, Maxwell; their daughter, Courtney Campion; his sisters, Rosella, Suzanne, Tracy and Leigh, all with the surname Campion; a half brother, Christian Richard; and his mother, Mary Donlan Richard.\n\nMr. Campion\u2019s family said he did not slow down in his later years, even as he endured the three kidney transplants. In one instance, five years ago, his wife said, 37 people stepped forward to be tested as possible donors.\n\n\u201cHe had more best friends that anyone I know,\u201d she said.", "title": "Charles Campion, Campaign Adviser to Democrats, Dies at 62", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJason L. Freeman, a purported grandson of Charles Manson, claimed in court papers that he was the notorious killer\u2019s true heir.\n\nHe wanted to give him a proper burial, Mr. Freeman said in a recent interview, noting that he would invite a small \u201cinner circle\u201d of his grandfather\u2019s friends to a private funeral service and then spread his ashes over water.\n\nNow, it appears, Mr. Freeman will get that chance.\n\nIn a messy legal battle over Mr. Manson\u2019s remains and belongings, a judge in Kern County, Calif., ruled on Monday that Mr. Freeman, a Florida man who had claimed that his father was Mr. Manson\u2019s son, was the \u201csurviving competent adult next of kin.\u201d Three other men who had also staked claims \u2014 a purported friend who said he filed Mr. Manson\u2019s will in court; and two people, including a purported son, who filed a joint petition \u2014 could not refute Mr. Freeman\u2019s assertion, the judge said.\n\nMr. Freeman, who could not be reached for comment on Monday evening, said in an interview in January : \u201cI\u2019d like to grab ahold of my grandfather\u2019s name and have a little more control over it. Everybody\u2019s had a free-for-all for the past 50 years.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ruling on Monday capped the first part of what has become a complicated tug-of-war over what Mr. Manson left behind, which some have speculated would probably not be much beyond his body. The order, which was issued by Judge Alisa R. Knight of the Bakersfield Division of the Superior Court of California, addressed only who could take Mr. Manson\u2019s body, which has been held in a storage facility in Kern County since his death at 83 on Nov. 19 while serving a sentence of life in prison.", "title": "Charles Manson\u2019s Remains Will Go to Purported Grandson, Judge Rules", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "An aggressive entrepreneur, Mr. Lazarus steered his company through decades of growth and several years of financial turmoil, including a previous bankruptcy. The company\u2019s ultimate success came down to Mr. Lazarus\u2019s ability to master a basic question: What do children want to play with?\n\n\u201cWhen you look at what the creativity of the toy market is, you have to have imagination, you have to think like a child,\u201d he told a documentary filmmaker in a 2016 interview.\n\nMr. Lazarus opened his first store, Children\u2019s Bargain Town, which sold furniture, in 1948, seeking to cash in on the post-World War II baby boom. Within a few years, he began selling toys along with cribs and strollers.\n\nIn toys, Mr. Lazarus discovered a more lucrative business: Because toys and stuffed animals quickly fell out of favor with children, parents had to make frequent trips to the store to keep up with the latest fads.\n\nHe opened his first store dedicated exclusively to toys in 1957 and called it Toys \u201cR\u201d Us (though he turned the \u201cR\u201d around to face the other way to make it look as if a child had written it).\n\nThe company went on to open up cavernous big-box stores across the American suburbs, dominating toys sales with deep discounts and a huge selection, and squeezing out smaller toy shops.\n\nAlong the way Mr. Lazarus\u2019s company endeared itself to generations of children, with a lovable mascot in Geoffrey the Giraffe and a hummable jingle \u2014 \u201cI don\u2019t want to grow up, I\u2019m a Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us kid.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us became a retailing powerhouse internationally with stores in Spain, Canada and Singapore. President George H. W. Bush joined Mr. Lazarus for the opening of the company\u2019s first store in Japan in 1992.\n\n\u201cHe was a pioneer in the big box movement,\u201d said Gerald Storch, who was chief executive of Toys \u201cR\u201d Us from 2006 to 2013. \u201cHis business concept was as innovative as eCommerce is today.\u201d\n\nMr. Storch said he regularly reminded his staff of the founder\u2019s key business principles: \u201cHaving more toys than anyone else, having great prices and being in stock when no one else is in stock.\u201d\n\nBorn on Oct. 4, 1923, in Washington and raised there, Charles Philip Lazarus was inspired to open his own retail business after helping his parents, Frank and Phoebe, run a bicycle shop. He decided to go into baby furniture after watching servicemen return from World War II, marry and start having children.\n\nToys, he learned, can be a more fickle business. \u201cIf you come to us to buy a toy, nobody makes you buy a toy,\u2019\u2019 he told the documentary filmmaker. \u201cAlthough over the years, I have taught children to say \u2018I need, rather than I want it.\u2019 \u201d\n\nHis understanding of a child\u2019s mind-set helped him amass a considerable fortune; he owned a Fifth Avenue duplex in Manhattan, which was sold for $21 million in 2013.\n\nMr. Lazarus stepped down as chief executive and chairman in March 1994. But he remained involved in the company as chairman emeritus, making a visit to the Toys \u201cR\u201d Us headquarters in Wayne, N.J., as recently as last year.\n\nHe is survived by his wife, Joan Lazarus, and two daughters, Diane and Ruth.\n\nMichael Goldstein, a former chief executive at Toys \u201cR\u201d Us who worked with Mr. Lazarus for many years and had become a close friend, said he did not mention the liquidation to Mr. Lazarus when he saw him on Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe beauty of Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us was that we were the toy store for children across the world,\u201d Mr. Goldstein said.\n\nBy the early 2000s, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us\u2019s business model was under pressure, and the company was purchased by a group of private equity investors in a leveraged buyout in 2005. The new owners loaded the company with $5 billion in debt, a burden it was never able to overcome.\n\n\u201cThere have been many sad moments for Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us in recent weeks, and none more heartbreaking than today\u2019s news about the passing of our beloved founder, Charles Lazarus,\u201d Toys \u201cR\u201d Us said in its statement on Thursday afternoon. \u201cWe will forever be grateful for his positive energy, passion for the customer and love for children everywhere.\u201d", "title": "Charles P. Lazarus, Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us Founder, Dies at 94", "authors": ["Michael Corkery"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Wilson sometimes worked in three operating rooms simultaneously: Residents would surgically open and prepare patients for his arrival, and he would then enter to seal an aneurysm or remove a tumor before moving on to the next case.\n\n\u201cHe never spent much more than 30 or 60 minutes on each case, and we were left to close the case and make sure everything was O.K.,\u201d Dr. Mitchel Berger, a former resident who is chairman of U.C.S.F.\u2019s neurosurgical department, said in an interview. \u201cIt was unorthodox, but it worked. He demanded excellence and we gave him excellence.\u201d\n\nThey also gave him silence. He allowed no music, no ringing phones and no idle chatter. Scrub nurses were expected to anticipate his requests.\n\n\u201cHe would manage any break of silence with a stern look,\u201d said Dr. Brian Andrews, a neurosurgeon who was one of Dr. Wilson\u2019s residents and also his biographer, with the book \u201cCherokee Surgeon\u201d (2011). (Dr. Wilson was one-eighth Cherokee.)\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Wilson became world renowned for excising pituitary tumors through the sinus in a surgery called transsphenoidal resection. He had embraced the procedure, which had been done for decades, after being displeased with results that U.C.S.F. surgeons had achieved using another technique.\n\nHis zeal to understand the operation had led him one day to call the chairman of neurosurgery at the University of Florida, in Gainesville, with an unexpected request: Could the chairman acquire 100 cadaver heads, regardless of the cost, and bring them to the university\u2019s laboratory so that Dr. Wilson might then fly there to study the anatomy he would encounter in the surgery?\n\n\u201cSometime later, when the laboratory was fully stocked, Charles traveled on a Friday to Gainesville and, over a weekend, practiced his technique on each and every one of the cadavers,\u201d Dr. Andrews wrote in the biography.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe writer Malcolm Gladwell, in a profile of Dr. Wilson in The New Yorker in 1999, described one of those pituitary cancer surgeries. Looking at a tumor through a surgical microscope, Dr. Wilson used an instrument called a ring curette to peel the tumor from the gland.\n\n\u201cIt was, he would say later, like running a squeegee across a windshield,\u201d Mr. Gladwell wrote, \u201cexcept that in this case, the windshield was a surgical field one centimeter in diameter, flanked on either side by the carotid arteries, the principal sources of blood to the brain.\u201d\n\nA wrong move could nick an artery or damage a nerve, endangering the patient\u2019s vision or his life.\n\nWhen Dr. Wilson saw bleeding from one side of the gland, he realized that he had not gotten all of the tumor. He found it and removed it. The surgery took only 25 minutes.\n\nDr. Wilson performed the surgery more than 3,300 times.\n\nHe told Mr. Gladwell that he had a special feel for surgery that he could not entirely explain.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s sort of an invisible hand,\u201d he said. \u201cIt begins almost to seem mystical. Sometimes a resident asks, \u2018Why did you do that?\u2019 \u201d His response, he told Mr. Gladwell, was to shrug and say, \u201cWell, it just seemed like the right thing.\u201d\n\nCharles Byron Wilson was born on Aug. 31, 1929, in Neosho, Mo., a farming community in the Ozark Mountains with a population of 5,000. His father, Byron, was a pharmacist who owned a local drugstore; his mother, the former Margaret Polson, also worked there.\n\nCharles, though slightly built, was a three-sport athlete in high school and received academic and football scholarships to Tulane University, where he played running back as a freshman. But he went no further in football because of an ankle injury. He eventually turned to running marathons.\n\nPhoto\n\nA skilled pianist, he also played Dixieland jazz at a French Quarter nightclub during his college years in New Orleans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Wilson graduated from the Tulane School of Medicine and spent a year as a pathology resident at Charity Hospital, also in New Orleans, where he gained expertise in removing brains as well as hearts, lungs and abdominal organs. He considered becoming a pathologist, but he also wanted to help living people.\n\n\u201cI was deeply interested in neuropathology, the art of diagnosis, and the precision of surgery,\u201d he said in \u201cCherokee Surgeon.\u201d \u201cNeurosurgery brought all of my interests together, and it just felt right.\u201d\n\nAfter a residency in neurosurgery that had been jointly offered by Tulane and the Ochsner Clinic (now part of the Ochsner Health System), Dr. Wilson became a neurosurgery resident at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in New Orleans. He later returned to Charity as chief resident, taught neurosurgery at Louisiana State University and, in 1963, joined the University of Kentucky, where he started its division of neurosurgery.\n\nHe joined U.C.S.F. in 1968 as chairman of its neurosurgery division and soon expanded the brain tumor research he had begun in Kentucky.\n\n\u201cHe was a visionary in how he built a multidisciplinary approach to studying brain cancer, linking basic science and clinical research together,\u201d Dr. Susan Chang, director of the division of neuro-oncology at U.C.S.F., said in an interview. \u201cHe was able to set up an infrastructure to test new therapies on tumors and spare patients the side effects of treatments.\u201d\n\nDr. Wilson continued to operate into his early 70s, retiring in 2002 after performing one last pituitary tumor surgery.\n\nHe had already planned for his retirement. He had co-founded the Global AIDS Interfaith Alliance, which develops health care programs in African countries greatly affected by AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. And he helped raise money and set policy for Clinic by the Bay, which provides free medical services to uninsured working people in the Bay Area.\n\nIn addition to his wife, Dr. Wilson is survived by his daughter, Rebecca Cohn; his son, Byron; a stepdaughter, Kathryn Petrocelli; and six grandchildren. Another son, Craig, died in 1983. Dr. Wilson\u2019s three previous marriages ended in divorce.\n\nIn 1994, in a speech to a medical conference, he offered his thoughts on how patients can better cope with a brain tumor. They cannot control the diagnosis, he said, and suggested that they face their mortality.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLife can be beautiful,\u201d he said, as he approached his 65th birthday, \u201cbut it is certainly not forever. A part of the end of life is dying, and it\u2019s O.K. to think about it; it\u2019s O.K. to wonder about it, but it\u2019s not O.K. not to think about it.\u201d", "title": "Charles Wilson, Top Brain Surgeon and Researcher, Dies at 88", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Right here. The spot used to be Gadsden\u2019s Wharf. Historians estimate nearly half of all African slaves brought to America arrived in Charleston, most of them at Gadsden\u2019s Wharf. At 840-feet-long, it was, two centuries ago, the largest wharf in America. Thousands of Africans waited in the wharf\u2019s warehouses to be auctioned off.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn what has become a parking lot, just inland, 700 of them froze to death.\n\nFor millions of African-Americans today, the site is \u201cground zero,\u201d as the Harvard scholar Henry Louis Gates, Jr., has put it, for \u201cblackness, black culture, the African experience, the African-American experience, slavery \u2014 however you want to slice it.\u201d\n\nEvery era erects, removes, amends \u2014 or ignores \u2014 monuments. Monuments and historical museums are always mirrors, advertisements, time bombs. Hardly a street or building in Germany today lacks some sign or plaque, redressing the past. It was the proposed removal of a Jim Crow-era statue of Robert E. Lee that became the excuse for the neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Va., last year, where a white nationalist is to go on trial late this year in the murder of a protester at the event.\n\nUnlike Virginia, South Carolina hasn\u2019t taken down Confederate monuments. Much has changed here but much has not. The state\u2019s most recent proposal for social studies standards in public schools doesn\u2019t mention the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., or Rosa Parks.\n\nThe Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston where a young white man massacred nine black congregants in 2015 is virtually in the shadow of what\u2019s still the city\u2019s tallest monument (another Jim Crow relic) of the antebellum vice president and proud white supremacist John C. Calhoun.\n\nIt has been nearly two decades since Joseph P. Riley Jr., Charleston\u2019s mayor at the time, floated the idea of a museum of African-American culture and history, on a different site, nearby. A dozen years passed, then more.\n\nMr. Riley retired in 2016, after 40 years in office, having been elected during the 1970s as a racial bridge builder. White racists called him \u201cL\u2019il Black Joe\u201d when he appointed a black police chief in 1975. Charleston prospered over the intervening decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut gentrification had its effects. Two-thirds black in the early 1980s, the population has become 70 percent white. I suggested to Mr. Riley the other day that Charleston can come across to a visitor as Disneyland for the Confederacy, still enthralled by its era of slavery, with a monument on seemingly every downtown corner commemorating some Confederate soldier, plantation aristocrat or antebellum judge who opposed Lincoln.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a process,\u201d he replied. \u201cWe worked hard while I was mayor to avoid alienation, to make this a city where everyone feels welcome. When I was in school, they didn\u2019t teach us about slavery. I really only learned the truth about how slaves were treated when I had already been in office for many years. That\u2019s when I began to think seriously about the museum.\u201d\n\nBut without enough money or much public enthusiasm, the plan sputtered. Then excavations turned up traces of Gadsden\u2019s Wharf in the muck beneath the grassy lot. Through the exhibition designer Ralph Appelbaum, Mr. Riley reached out to Mr. Cobb.\n\nPretty much the architect\u2019s first question: Why not build on the location of the wharf?\n\nBy that point, the city had sold the property to a local restaurateur, unaware of its history. Mr. Riley spent a tidy sum buying the land back.\n\n\u201cSometimes you quick-cook something, it\u2019s a mistake,\u201d rationalized the former mayor, who has taken to calling the museum his \u201cmost important work,\u201d especially after the church murders. \u201cIt turned out to be good that we had a lengthy germination period.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow 91, the soft-spoken Mr. Cobb is known for designing the John Hancock Tower in Boston, 7 Bryant Park in New York, and a variety of big, sleek buildings in between, the best of which are geometrically eloquent and deceptively simple. Working here with the structural engineer Guy Nordenson, he describes this project as an \u201cunrhetorical work of architecture.\u201d\n\nBut that\u2019s not quite true. On the edge of the cobblestoned tourist area, with its ornate Gothic Revival-style churches and Queen Anne houses, the museum\u2019s plain-spoken modernism comes across as almost whisperingly defiant, a turning of the page, promising a deliverance from history, modernism\u2019s originating goal.\n\nPhoto\n\nMoody Nolan are the architects of record. Slender brick cladding underscores the pavilion\u2019s long horizontal spans and extended cantilevers on either end. Pointed columns are meant to make the structure\u2019s mass appear to float. Perching the museum on piers will take account of rising waters. But it\u2019s also hard not to see an allusion to a wharf.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInside, galleries will document the many diverse cultures Africans brought to America, and a family center will let visitors trace their roots to Gadsden\u2019s Wharf.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Hood has reimagined a constrained and narrow property, about a football-field long. The late, great Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer was an inspiration. Mr. Hood creates a shaded public plaza, in the breezy space underneath the raised structure, where people may congregate around the building\u2019s double-sided staircase, so the museum can become a gathering spot, not just a pilgrimage site.\n\nThe memorial garden and tidal pool, at the same time, insure that it\u2019s recognized as hallowed ground, a place for contemplation.\n\nThe budget for building the museum is $75 million. The goal is for bulldozers to start digging later this year and for construction to finish in 2020. But there\u2019s a hitch. No shovel will be lifted until all the money is raised. Charleston has committed its $25 million share, along with the land, and private donations are approaching the $25 million goal.\n\nBut the South Carolina legislature, after an understanding that it would contribute $25 million over five years, allocated $14 million, and now won\u2019t promise the remaining $11 million. The clock is ticking. The current legislature remains in session only until the end of May.\n\nState Representative Brian White, a Republican who heads South Carolina\u2019s House Ways and Means Committee, is one of those holding the money back. The museum \u201cis not a state project and we have a lot of state needs right now that far outweigh a municipality\u2019s request,\u201d he recently told the Greenville News, citing competing priorities like education.\n\nBobby Hitt, South Carolina\u2019s commerce secretary, by contrast, has pointed out that the museum will help attract businesses to the state. It adds a work of architectural dignity. And as for educational value, plainly it fills a gap.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis ain\u2019t a black project,\u201d as Bakari Sellers, a former Democrat in the state legislature, put it to the Greenville News. \u201cThis ain\u2019t a Charleston project. This is an American project.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr as James Baldwin said, \u201cIf you know whence you came, there are absolutely no limitations to where you can go.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne recent morning I toured the site with Mr. Hood and Michael Boulware Moore, the museum\u2019s president, then we looked out over the harbor. Mr. Moore said his ancestors were among the slaves who arrived in shackles at Gadsden\u2019s Wharf.\n\nHis great-great grandfather was Robert Smalls, who commandeered a Confederate ship, turning it over to Union forces and winning freedom for himself, his family and his crew. Smalls became a crusading state legislator and United States congressman during Reconstruction. He brought free public education to South Carolina.\n\nA plaque honoring Smalls was installed on a squat little pillar downtown not long ago. Mr. Moore showed me a picture of it.\n\nPhoto\n\nThink, the Stonehenge set from \u201cSpinal Tap.\u201d The memorial looks tiny, and is periodically obscured by bushes.\n\nNot far away, a big statue on a huge round pedestal, at the tip of the battery facing Fort Sumter, honors the Confederate Defenders of Charleston.\n\nSymbols matter. The past is present. The museum would clearly be good for more than just business.", "title": "Charleston Needs That African American Museum. And Now.", "authors": ["Michael Kimmelman"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTwo months after the start of a sexual misconduct investigation into the high-ranking music executive Charlie Walk, the president of the Republic Group, the label and Mr. Walk \u201chave mutually agreed to part ways,\u201d the company said Wednesday night in a brief statement.\n\nUniversal Music Group, which oversees the label, declined to comment further on the outcome of the review, which was conducted by an outside law firm. Mr. Walk, who worked with artists including Lorde, the Weeknd and Ariana Grande, and who also appeared as a judge on Fox\u2019s singing competition show \u201cThe Four,\u201d did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nAccused in January of persistent harassment and inappropriate touching by at least six women who had worked with him, Mr. Walk denied the charges at the time. \u201cI did not do these things and this is not who I am,\u201d he told Rolling Stone last month. \u201cI support the national discussion taking place right now because I believe fully in the importance in treating everyone with respect and dignity at all times.\u201d He retained the lawyer Patricia Glaser, who is also representing Harvey Weinstein, to address the claims.\n\nMr. Walk had been known as one of music\u2019s most effective promotion executives. He represents perhaps the highest-profile employee in the industry to lose his job amid the #MeToo movement, which has been met by large swaths of silence on the part of both artists and music\u2019s rank-and-file.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe accusations against Mr. Walk first surfaced on a women\u2019s wellness blog in the form of an open letter. Tristan Coopersmith, who worked under Mr. Walk at Columbia Records, a division of Sony, around 2004, wrote that Mr. Walk had frequently made inappropriate remarks to her and attempted to initiate sexual contact, including pushing her onto a bed in his home.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFor a year I shuddered at the idea of being called into your office, where you would stealthily close the door and make lewd comments about my body and share your fantasies of having sex with me,\u201d Ms. Coopersmith wrote. She said she had been paid a settlement and left the entertainment industry.", "title": "Charlie Walk, Record Executive Accused of Harassment, Is Out at Republic", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "His first charm bracelet collection \u2014 created with Leandra Medine, the fashion blogger and founder of Man Repeller \u2014 was introduced in July. It continued his hallmark style of setting diamonds into stones collected on beaches from Greece to Argentina but added coral, pink sapphires and more.\n\n\u201cI could do a lot more diamonds and precious stones on the charms than there are on our regular stones as the gemstones are smaller,\u201d he said, \u201cand I liked the idea of finding a stone that would work on both sides, so not only the side you are wearing it but the other side, too.\u201d\n\nHe also added clips to his charms, so they can be easily removed and added to other jewelry or chains.\n\nCarolina Bucci, the Italian-born and London-based designer, has a similar approach. \u201cCharms always push me to have fun with fine jewelry so I have to keep coming up with new offers for new charms,\u201d she said, like creating bracelets of colorful beads like bamboo coral or white jade interspersed with charms. Or contrasting spiky star charms with round freshwater pearls: \u201cPutting two things that almost don\u2019t go together, together,\u201d she said.\n\nImage From Carolina Bucci, the Lucky Bracelet with a 10th anniversary charm. The piece is an 18-karat gold chain, hand braided with white silk and finished with the gray- and white-diamond pav\u00e9 charm.\n\nShe also has done a take on the cotton friendship bracelets of her childhood, recreating them in an 18-karat gold diamond-cut chain braided with colored silks, which the wearer then ties in a double knot to secure. The bracelets are finished with charms like balloons, palm trees and an evil eye amulet.\n\nWhen it comes to trends, charm bracelets even stand up to the gender-fluid style of recent fashion.\n\n\u201cEven men wear a lot of these bracelets around the wrist, whether in silver or black and gold with dead heads or bones,\u201d said Caroline Scheufele, Chopard\u2019s artistic director and co-president.", "title": "Charmed, We\u2019re Sure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "When the Liberty Media Corporation took over Formula One in January 2017, the most immediate impact was the ousting of Bernie Ecclestone, who had run the sport for decades.\n\nChase Carey, an American whose r\u00e9sum\u00e9 includes long stints with the News Corporation and DirecTV, was named chief executive of the Formula One Group. A regular presence in the sport\u2019s paddock, Carey\u2019s style of leadership has been to act first and talk later. It has made for a striking change for a sport that had long conducted negotiations via public salvos.\n\n\u201cIf I go back, I feel pretty good about what we\u2019ve achieved and where we\u2019ve gotten to in 12 months,\u201d Carey said in an interview. \u201cBecause we don\u2019t go out and talk about where we are in various discussions doesn\u2019t mean there isn\u2019t a lot of stuff going on, but it has complexities to it that we\u2019re wrestling to the ground.\u201d\n\nThe coming year will be important because the Ecclestone-era commercial agreements binding teams, determining the system of governance and the distribution of the prize fund will expire in 2020. The deals have historically taken several years of negotiating, and discussions on the shape of Formula One are underway.", "title": "Chase Carey Is Making Some Big Plans for Formula One", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Can I have a conversation with Google Assistant, or will there be an update in the future that will let me have one?\n\nA. Google Assistant, the company\u2019s voice-based helper software that is similar to Amazon\u2019s Alexa, Apple\u2019s Siri and Microsoft\u2019s Cortana software, can already hold basic two-way conversations based on spoken or typed questions and commands. However, more intricate interaction with all these virtual assistant apps is coming as companies expand their research into the scientific areas of artificial intelligence, machine learning and natural language processing. (For those with privacy concerns, keep in mind that most virtual assistant software is designed to collect personal data.)\n\nThe Google Assistant software is available as an app for Android and iOS devices, built into Google Home and other speakers, Android-based wearables, cars, televisions, smart-home appliances and other gear. If you are not sure how to talk to the program, the Google Assistant site has a lengthy list of the questions, commands and topics that you can use with the software, complete with suggestions on how to phrase your requests.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYou can, for example, tell Google Assistant to remember where you parked your car and then ask the software to remind you of the location later. For those with Google Home speakers, the company recently released a series of Routines, which run through a set of regular daily tasks like adjusting the thermostat and lights before reporting the traffic and weather as you wake up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen you ask, Google Assistant will start a conversation with third-party chatbot personalities like the Hogwarts Sorting Hat or Bobo the Panda. The Cyber Argument bot on the site can even pit a Google Home speaker against a nearby Amazon Alexa-powered device; for the curious, video clips of chatbots arguing are available, as is an online publication called Chatbots Magazine.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut beyond novelty applications, Google (and the other companies) are pushing to develop conversational user interfaces for their products to make them more useful and able to handle complex sets of tasks. An online guide for Google Assistant developers can give you an idea of how apps are designed to work with the software, and you will most likely see software updates to Google Assistant as the software becomes more advanced.\n\nAmazon, Apple and Microsoft have similar developer programs for their own virtual assistants. To help inspire its developers even more, Amazon last year created the Alexa Prize, a contest to advance conversational artificial intelligence with a financial reward to the research team that creates the best \u201csocialbot\u201d that can \u201ccan converse coherently and engagingly with humans on a range of current events and popular topics such as entertainment, sports, politics, technology and fashion.\u201d", "title": "Chatting Up the Google Assistant", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re familiar with the predicament: You\u2019ve got a few hours before you can check into your vacation rental, or before you leave for your flight, and you want to do some sightseeing \u2014 but that means slogging along crowded sidewalks with your (undoubtedly overstuffed) luggage in tow.\n\nOr does it?\n\nIncreasingly, you may not only store your bags for a couple of hours at the usual places (airports, train stations, luggage storage companies), but also with a surprising variety of businesses \u2014 delis, dry cleaners, clothing boutiques, wine shops, eyebrow-shaping salons \u2014 for less than the cost of a couple of Starbucks lattes.\n\nIn New York City, for example, you can stash your bags for $2 an hour per bag at Chelsea Bicycles, the Puerh Brooklyn teashop, or an Al Horno Lean Mexican Kitchen (which is convenient if you\u2019re also in the mood for a burrito), among hundreds of other untraditional storage locations.\n\nWebsites and apps that help travelers find these short-term spots have likened themselves to Airbnb for luggage: Travelers go online and book a date (it can be the same day) and location (maps show you your options), then drop off their bags. Afterward, some sites allow users to rate the storage location to help fellow travelers pick and choose. (While many places require advance booking, you can usually cancel free of charge.) Each storage network has its own rules, but they all typically provide luggage security seals as well as some version of insurance against damage, theft and loss.", "title": "Check-in Time Hours Away? How to Ditch Those Annoying Bags", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "MANCHESTER, England \u2014 On the sideline, in the pouring rain, Antonio Conte did not look much like a manager who supposedly no longer cares, who has apparently long since accepted that his time at Chelsea is nearly over. He shouted and he bawled, at his players and at the officials, at the situation and at the gods. If it is an act, it is a good one.\n\nOn the field, meanwhile, Chelsea\u2019s players did not look as if they were harboring dark thoughts of rebellion. They might have struggled to lay a glove on Manchester City; they might have slipped, without much of a whimper, to a dour 1-0 defeat, but they made for strange revolutionaries.\n\nThey doggedly remained in shape. They determinedly tracked their runners. They did all they could not to be mesmerized, as so many have been this season, by the swirling patterns City can paint; they closed the space and they gritted their teeth. They stuck to the tasks Conte had given them. Prospective mutineers tend not to follow orders so well.\n\nWhenever Chelsea finds itself stuck in a rut, whenever an occasional defeat becomes a run of them, it is easy to assume that the problem, and the solution, are the same as always, that history is about to repeat itself.", "title": "Chelsea Spins Its Wheels in a Cycle of Its Own Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cWhat Poisons Are in Your Body?\u201d (column, Feb. 25), Nicholas Kristof painted a number of chemicals with a broad brush and left readers to believe that the mere presence of these chemicals in the body posed an imminent threat to human health.\n\nBut this ignores information from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reported:\n\n\u201cThe measurement of an environmental chemical in a person\u2019s blood or urine is an indication of exposure; it does not by itself mean that the chemical causes disease. \u2026 Research studies, separate from these data, are required to determine which blood or urine levels are safe and which are associated with disease.\u201d\n\nMr. Kristof\u2019s concerns come at a time when chemical oversight is stronger than it has ever been thanks to a law enacted in 2016, which significantly strengthened the regulation of chemicals in commerce.\n\nThis means that consumers can benefit from various lifesaving and life-enhancing chemicals, knowing that chemicals are subject to rigorous federal review.", "title": "Opinion | Chemicals and Consumers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "All the things I love about the pancakes at Chez Ma Tante, near the Greenpoint waterfront in Brooklyn, are things that normal chefs would try to fix. They are a little too tall and too big around. The outside is nearly black in parts, and crunchy, which American pancakes almost never are.\n\nWhat they most closely resemble are the pancakes I\u2019ve made on camping trips, from a mix, with about a quarter-stick of melted butter in a smoking-hot pan over a fire. Each one is the size of Frisbee because too many people are waiting for breakfast for any space in the pan to be wasted.\n\nAssuming my campfire pancakes were to catch a chef\u2019s eye, the standard way of turning them into a brunch dish would be to refine them. The heat would come down so they\u2019d cook to an even golden-brown. My quantity of butter would seem insane in a professional kitchen, so it would be cut. The batter would probably be thinned to make the pancakes shorter and more elegantly rounded.\n\nRounding out the rough edges is, in a broad sense, one of the main things chefs do. They may not always do it consciously, any more than a copy editor consciously corrects typos. It\u2019s supposed to become a reflex, which is the point of the sign on the kitchen wall at Eleven Madison Park: MAKE IT NICE.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis is just what the chef Aidan O\u2019Neal at Chez Ma Tante does not do to the pancakes. Rising up from a small flood of maple syrup, they look and taste as if they\u2019d been made in the woods. I will gladly admit they\u2019re better than mine. At weekend brunch, they are on virtually every table.", "title": "Chez Ma Tante, Where Falafel and Kedgeree Live in Harmony", "authors": ["Pete Wells", "Restaurant Review"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The little guys always have their day in Martha Grimes\u2019s witty mysteries featuring Detective Superintendent Richard Jury. In THE KNOWLEDGE (Atlantic Monthly, $26), honors go to the London cabbies who have an encyclopedic grasp of the city\u2019s highways and byways, called (of course) \u201cthe knowledge.\u201d They also have exclusive use of a pub with the same name (\u201cunlocatable: untraceable, unfindable, unmappable\u201d). Robbie Parsons is one of the \u201cknowledge boys,\u201d but he might not live to make the best use of his skills. When we first meet him, his latest fare has just shot two people to death at the door of an exclusive gambling club, then jumped into Robbie\u2019s cab and demanded to be taken to Waterloo Station.\n\nWhatever Robbie was expecting at the end of this tense trip, it wasn\u2019t a big tip and a compliment on his driving. But that\u2019s the way it is with Grimes: Great characters who say and do the most unexpected things are her stock in trade. The charmer here is 10-year-old Patty Haigh (\u201clooks like a little girl, but acts like MI6\u201d), one of a group of loosely parented children who hang around the stations at Waterloo and Heathrow, practicing the skills needed to be cops. Patty even talks her way into a first-class seat on a plane to Nairobi by attaching herself to the murderer she\u2019s pursuing. \u201cFor someone who shoots people,\u201d she acknowledges, \u201che was pretty nice.\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, Grimes\u2019s irresistibly attractive Scotland Yard man is busy solving the murder of his newly acquired friends David Moffit, an American astronomer, and his wife, Rebecca. With enthusiastic assistance from his wealthy friend Melrose Plant and Plant\u2019s fellow drinkers at the Jack and Hammer pub, Jury manages to have multiple sets of eyes on his suspect. But our eyes are glued to Patty, off in Africa and having the time of her life.\n\n\u2666\n\nWhat\u2019s that smell? The acrid odor of fire is always cause for alarm in the mysteries C. J. Box sets in heavily forested Wyoming. But there\u2019s something strange about the odor that\u2019s coming from the burner at a lumber mill in THE DISAPPEARED (Putnam, $27), \u201csomething that smelled a little like roast chicken.\u201d Wylie Frye, the night manager, recognizes the peculiar stench, but for $2,500 he can take shallow breaths and ignore it.", "title": "Child Sleuths and Child Victims", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Those reports, from the early 2000s, indicate that a man named Oscar Munoz discovered the six-inch-long mummy next to an abandoned church in a ghost town called La Noria. The body was remarkable not just for its size, but also for its abnormalities, including an elongated skull that ended in a point, giant eye sockets and bones that were as mature as those of a 6-year-old.\n\nRumors spread that Mr. Munoz had found an alien. It gained the nickname \u201cAta,\u201d for the Atacama Desert in Chile where the remains supposedly came from.\n\nEventually Ata ended up in the private collection in Barcelona of Ramon Navia-Osorio, who did not immediately respond to an email query about whether he had legally obtained Ata\u2019s remains.\n\nIn 2012, the producers of a documentary claiming to have evidence of UFOs got access to Ata\u2019s skeleton.\n\nWhen Dr. Nolan learned of their efforts, he offered to examine samples sent to him for DNA.\n\nWorking with a team of researchers from both Stanford and the University of California, San Francisco, Dr. Nolan reconstructed Ata\u2019s entire genome. Far from being an alien, they concluded, Ata was a Chilean girl who was probably stillborn and suffered from previously unknown bone disorders.\n\nPublication of the study in the journal Genome Research enraged some researchers in Chile, where the looting and sale of artifacts and even mummies have long been a concern.\n\nLike many other countries, Chile now has laws that make such exhumations and smuggling illegal, punishable by fines and prison sentences. But it can be hard to stop treasure hunters from plundering remote sites.\n\nMore Reporting on Archaeology\n\nOn Sunday, Cristina Dorador, a biologist at the University of Antofagasta, called the study an \u201coutrage\u201d in a commentary on Etilmercurio, an online science publication in Chile. \u201cIf samples are obtained unethically, any resulting science is not ethical,\u201d she wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChilean scientific societies officially condemned the study as well. \u201cCould you imagine the same study carried out using the corpse of someone\u2019s miscarried baby in Europe or America?\u201d the Chilean Society of Biological Anthropology asked in a statement released on Wednesday.\n\nThe society also co-signed a letter, along with a number of Chilean researchers, that was sent on Wednesday to Genome Research, the journal where the Ata study was published.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe scientific community in Chile is deeply upset and concerned about this situation,\u201d they wrote.\n\nGabriel Le\u00f3n, a geneticist at the University of Andr\u00e9s Bello and a co-signer, said that he hoped the journal would retract the paper. \u201cIt would be a strong signal about this sort of research on human samples stolen from the country,\u201d Dr. Le\u00f3n said.\n\nHilary Sussman, the editor of Genome Research, said that the journal lacked a set of instructions for researchers to discuss ethical issues they had considered, citing a \u201ctechnical error\u201d that had been corrected. She added that the journal \u201cis paying close attention\u201d to the issue of studying DNA from ancient human remains, and \u201cwill return to it in future issues of the journal.\u201d\n\nDr. Nolan, of Stanford, said that the researchers did not ask their universities for permission to examine the sample, because they suspected that it was possible the remains belonged to a nonhuman primate. In addition, the researchers said that the DNA and X-rays of the skeleton did not provide \u201cidentifiable information about a living individual, as defined by federal regulations, and does not qualify as human subjects research, per the Federal Office of Human Research Protections.\u201d\n\nDr. Butte pointed out how the research had helped put an end to the outlandish stories about Ata. \u201cThe study has provided a definitive scientific basis to put a stop to unscientific accounts of the skeleton\u2019s true human nature and accord it the respect it deserves,\u201d he said.\n\nChip Colwell, the curator of anthropology at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science, said that the dispute over Ata is part of a long series of conflicts. \u201cIt\u2019s hardly unique in the bigger story about human remains,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 19th century, scientists themselves routinely plundered burial grounds, with no thought about getting consent from families or communities for their work.\n\nIn recent years, the ethical controversies have shifted to the museums and private collections where many remains are now kept. Geneticists can use new technologies to retrieve DNA from those remains, often needing only a small amount of bone to get it.\n\nDr. Santana-Sagredo and other Chilean scientists said that research on DNA from ancient human remains in their country could yield important insights.\n\nBut the value of those findings should not override the ethical treatment of human remains, they said. Dr. Santana-Sagredo worried that the study on Ata might encourage more plundering. \u201cPeople might follow their example,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cWe have these powerful new tools in DNA research, but if it ends up destroying relationships between local communities and scientists, then are we losing more than we might gain?\u201d Dr. Colwell asked.", "title": "Chile and Its Scientists Protest Research on Tiny Mummy", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTonight, Chilean film reached the stars,\u201d Mr. Pi\u00f1era wrote. \u201cGo Chile and a big hug, with pride and emotion, to the whole team behind #UnaMujerFantastica,\u201d he added using the film\u2019s title in Spanish as a hashtag.\n\nMr. Pi\u00f1era came under attack during a presidential campaign debate in December for suggesting that a child\u2019s gender identity \u201cmight be corrected over time.\u201d He said that his government would not discriminate against anyone, but argued that \u201cwe need to handle these cases in a responsible manner, in a serious way, not treating gender identity as something that is practically like a shirt that you can change every day.\u201d\n\nGay and transgender rights advocates in Chile said they hoped the movie\u2019s recognition would galvanize bills and initiatives to expand rights and fight discrimination, even as Ms. Bachelet\u2019s socialist government is replaced by a conservative one.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Senate approved the gender identity bill in January 2014. The lower House in January passed a version of the bill but lawmakers remain at odds over whether the legislation should cover children and teenagers.\n\n\u201cPoliticians can\u2019t just celebrate the artistic aspect and refuse to take ownership of the reality that transgender people in our country face,\u201d Juan Enrique Pi, the president of Iguales Foundation, a gay and transgender rights advocacy group, said. \u201cThe outgoing and incoming governments must assume their responsibility to defend the human rights of transgender people.\u201d\n\nSenator Juan Pablo Letelier, one of the original proponents of the bill, said it was drafted with narrow aims. \u201cThanks to this Oscar perhaps it will be understood that this law is not about an issue of values, but rather the basic human right to an identity,\u201d Mr. Letelier said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
