In his speech, Mr. Yi said that China would act resolutely against anyone who engaged in illegal financial activities without a license \u2014 a reference to a continuing campaign against so-called shadow banking.\n\nChina said last November that it would open its financial sector to greater international competition, in an unsuccessful move to tamp down President Trump\u2019s demands for a narrowing of the United States trade deficit with China. Mr. Yi, explaining himself clearly in terms that frequently hinted at his background as an economics professor, said that the opening would continue.\n\n\u201cThe more a sector opens, the more competitive it will become,\u201d he said.\n\nAfter a quarter-century of rapid growth, the Chinese economy stalled momentarily at the start of 2009 during the global financial crisis. China\u2019s leaders responded by flooding the economy with credit, in a massive monetary stimulus program that exceeded those of the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank in terms of the increase in broadly measured money supply.\n\nThat stimulus program allowed the Chinese economy to resume rapid growth almost immediately. But China has been adding debt ever since, building a national grid of high-speed train lines and forests of city skyscrapers as leaders have been reluctant to let growth slow.\n\nTwo credit rating agencies, Standard & Poor\u2019s and Moody\u2019s, downgraded China\u2019s sovereign debt last year on concerns about the buildup of domestic debt. Chinese officials have publicly acknowledged that they need to address rising leverage but contend that the country\u2019s minimal foreign debt, strong economic growth and increasingly stringent financial regulation mean that they have ample time to defuse the problem without a sharp slowdown in economic growth.\n\nMr. Guo has previously served as the chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission and as the governor of Shandong Province \u2014 two posts that gave him considerable clout and status in the Communist Party, which oversees all agencies of the government.\n\nBy contrast, Mr. Yi is a former economics professor in Indiana who then taught in Beijing and spent the past two decades working his way up the ranks of the civil service at the central bank.", "title": "China Splits Top Jobs at Central Bank, Adding Another Reformer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 Days after China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, consolidated his position as national leader, he moved to extend his control on Tuesday by unveiling new superagencies to tackle three major potential threats to popular support for Communist Party rule: financial recklessness, environmental pollution and official corruption.\n\nThe plan for reorganizing the government, released to the national legislature in Beijing, would shake up some of China\u2019s most powerful bureaucracies by gathering powers that had been scattered across multiple regulatory agencies into a few new, stronger entities.\n\nIt would create two enlarged ministries for protecting the environment and managing natural resources, as well as a new financial regulator spanning banking and insurance. A separate draft law would create a new anticorruption agency with greater reach than the current one, which is run by the Communist Party.\n\nWith the announcements, Mr. Xi is moving to strengthen his authoritarian leadership over the entrenched cadres and vested interests that his allies have blamed for frustrating reforms he promised in 2013, a year after taking power. Mr. Xi has pushed for firmer action to control rising corporate and state debt, and to cut the smog and water pollution that have caused widespread fear and anger about public health.", "title": "China Unveils Superagencies to Fight Pollution and Other Threats to Party Rule", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China pledged Thursday to hit back at the United States if it sets off a trade war, issuing its strongest threat yet as President Trump prepares to impose more tariffs against China.\n\nThe White House is hours away from putting into effect sweeping steel and aluminum tariffs on its trading partners that have caused an international outcry. But more worrying to China are separate trade sanctions that Mr. Trump could impose under an investigation into China\u2019s intellectual property practices. Hundreds of Chinese companies could be singled out in that process, known as a Section 301 investigation.\n\nSpeaking on the sidelines of the annual meeting of China\u2019s legislature, Foreign Minister Wang Yi said, \u201cHistory has shown that fighting a trade war has never been a correct way to solve a problem.\u201d\n\n\u201cEspecially given today\u2019s globalization, choosing a trade war is a mistaken prescription,\u201d Mr. Wang said. \u201cThe outcome will only be harmful. China would have to make a justified and necessary response.\u201d", "title": "China Vows Retaliation if Trump Engages in Trade War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "The post is not new, but the man who has held the job for the past five years, Ma Kai, is a longtime central planner who appeared to spend most of his time on issues involving state-owned enterprises.\n\nIn financial policy, \u201cone thing that is very clear is that Liu He will play a more important role than Ma Kai\u201d did, said Jianguang Shen, an economist in the Hong Kong office of Mizuho Securities, a Japanese investment bank.\n\nThe rest of the world will be watching what happens. China\u2019s continued use of economic planning and ongoing support for state-owned companies has prompted pushback by global leaders. President Trump\u2019s new tariffs on steel and aluminum are aimed, in part, at China\u2019s own protectionist policies.\n\nDavid Malpass, the Treasury Department\u2019s under secretary for international affairs, said before the Group of 20 finance ministers gathering in Argentina on Sunday that China had reversed its path toward more open markets, in favor of greater subsidies of its industries and more shoring-up of state-owned enterprises.\n\n\u201cChina\u2019s gone in a different direction, really, from the rest of the world,\u201d Mr. Malpass said.\n\nHe also noted it was \u201cworrisome\u201d that President Xi had done away with term limits, leaving him free to rule indefinitely, and that the United States\u2019 longstanding economic discussions with China had stalled.\n\nAs Mr. Xi has sought to extend it leadership, he has brought more centralized control to the country\u2019s main policy levers.\n\nThe government has just approved a plan to combine China\u2019s banking and insurance regulators, as a way to bolster oversight. The agencies will relinquish some policymaking responsibilities to China\u2019s central bank.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast summer, Mr. Xi created a Financial Stability and Development Committee to coordinate all financial regulation, and Mr. Liu is widely expected to lead it. The new committee, while small, has the power to resolve differences among the People\u2019s Bank of China and the agencies that oversee the regulation of the banking, insurance and securities industries.\n\nIn 2013, the president also made Mr. Liu the director of the Communist Party\u2019s powerful Leading Group on Financial and Economic Affairs. A few months later, Mr. Liu named Mr. Yi as one of his deputies at the group, the state-run news media reported at the time.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe rapid rise of both men once again show the president\u2019s willingness to dispense with the conventions of China\u2019s bureaucracy when he wants to promote someone he may perceive as especially competent, especially loyal or both. Mr. Liu was promoted several rungs overnight to the Politburo last October despite having been only the deputy director of a ministry, the National Development and Reform Commission.\n\nSimilarly, Mr. Yi has not followed the traditional path to a top financial position, like a stint running a big state-owned bank or overseeing one of the lesser regulators. (Mr. Zhou did both before running the central bank.)\n\nMr. Yi worked his way up the ladder at the People\u2019s Bank of China, where he has been since 1997. The current central bank chief, who is retiring, has lately given considerable visibility to Mr. Yi by sending him to international meetings and encouraging him to answer questions at important news conferences.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Yi is also among the rare officials to reach the top ranks after spending considerable time overseas. He earned a doctorate in economics at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and then taught economics at Indiana University in Indianapolis for eight years. Mr. Liu studied at Seton Hall University and Harvard.\n\nThe job of running the People\u2019s Bank of China has become much more technical in the past several years as it has shifted away from simply mandating the interest rates that banks can charge for loans and pay for deposits. Instead, the central bank increasingly relies on open-market trading in bonds and other securities to influence interest rates, much as the Federal Reserve does in the United States.\n\nMr. Yi has an extensive academic background in monetary policy and has overseen much of the trading in recent years. But he will face a big challenge in managing the central bank, including shifting political priorities.\n\nThrough the central bank and other institutions, China tightly controls how its currency, the renminbi, is used and valued. That means limiting the amount of money that Chinese citizens and companies, both foreign and domestic, can send across its border.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChina has also long used its banking system as an economic throttle, unleashing waves of loans when the government wants growth and ratcheting back when debt looks out of control. The system has kept China stable in times of global economic distress. But as China\u2019s economy has matured, cracks have begun to show.\n\nPrevious efforts to juice the economy led to a startling rise in corporate debt. The system has long supported bloated, inefficient state-owned industries that many economists say are slowing down China\u2019s development.\n\nMr. Zhou, an urbane English speaker who frequently hobnobs with world leaders in places like the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, has worked to gradually change China\u2019s dependence on debt and its control of its currency. Under his administration, the central bank somewhat loosened China\u2019s grip on the value of its currency. And he has championed programs that allow money to cross borders more easily.\n\nHe has also been a vocal, if diplomatic, critic of some Chinese economic policies \u2014 a rarity in a country that values consensus. \u201cIn recent years, nonperforming loans have risen, eroding bank capital and risk resilience,\u201d he said in a statement posted on the central bank\u2019s website on Nov. 4.\n\nBut the direction of China\u2019s economic policy ultimately comes from the top, so Mr. Liu and Mr. Yi will take their cues from the president. It\u2019s an agenda that emphasizes stability and growth, meaning they will most likely focus more on China\u2019s priorities than those of the global markets.\n\nAfter an exodus of capital, China tightened its limits on money flows outside the country over the past two years to bolster the value of its currency. It undermined Mr. Zhou\u2019s efforts to loosen the reins.\n\nNow debt is a paramount focus. The central bank will need to provide just enough credit to keep the economy running but not so much that debt keeps rising and inflation eventually becomes a problem.\n\nMr. Yi\u2019s earliest well-known article for an economics journal, published in 1990 in the China Economic Review while he was still an assistant professor at Indiana University, had a turgid title that might prove especially useful: \u201cInflation and Price Instability: An Empirical Study of the People\u2019s Republic of China.\u201d", "title": "China to Name New Central Bank Chief as It Seeks Continuity Amid Change", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Confident, reasonable \u2014 willing to bargain.\n\nThat\u2019s how North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, came across in his debut as a global statesman \u2014 and he did so with a dash of mystery. Here\u2019s how the Chinese and North Korean news media portrayed the meeting with President Xi Jinping.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s two-day visit \u2014 his first trip abroad since taking power \u2014 was a reminder of how much he has set the agenda in the North Korean nuclear crisis and, our correspondent writes, what a strong hand he has going into negotiations.\n\nPresident Trump was quick to chime in. He posted on Twitter that Mr. Xi told him that the meeting went \u201cvery well\u201d and that Mr. Kim \u201clooks forward to his meeting with me.\u201d", "title": "China, Kim Jong-un, Easter: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 After a morning of tension and chaos at the White House, President Trump announced stiff tariffs on steel and aluminum. The Dow dropped hundreds of points.\n\nThe measures would impose tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum. Mr. Trump said he would formally sign the measures next week.\n\nThe announcement came on the same day that senior officials are to meet with China\u2019s top economic adviser, Liu He, who has been tasked with trying to pre-empt a trade war.", "title": "China, Nuclear Weapons, Spotify: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "To cope, HNA is trying to reverse what had been one of the world\u2019s biggest and most aggressive deal machines by unloading billions of dollars\u2019 worth of properties. It also has pledged some of the assets it bought over the past two years to lenders as collateral to raise cash. HNA has even announced plans to sell some of the assets it acquired when it bought a 25 percent stake in Hilton Worldwide Hotels, according to a regulatory filing.\n\nThe Chinese government has tightened its grip on the economy as the country\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, consolidates his power and paves the way toward running China longer than any ruler since Mao Zedong. That tightened grip includes increasing pressure on major Chinese companies that piled on heavy debt to make audacious deals abroad.\n\nThat pressure has intensified in recent weeks amid indications that China is trying to tackle its debt and financial problems. Just two weeks ago, the Chinese authorities seized Anbang Insurance Group, a once-quiet insurer that turned to sales of opaque investment products to fuel a global buying binge that included the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York. Other companies, like Dalian Wanda Group, have already sold off billions of dollars\u2019 worth of properties at home and abroad as the authorities worried about growing debt and risk.\n\nAs official attitudes turn against flashy but potentially frivolous foreign spending, the pressure is catching up to HNA.\n\nAbout $1.8 billion of its pending deals still await regulatory approval. Among those is a $775 million deal to acquire a majority stake in the storage and logistics business owned by Glencore International with operations around the world. They also include the purchase of a company from Anthony Scaramucci, a former Trump administration aide.\n\nPhoto\n\nHNA\u2019s problems could hit investors both at home and abroad.\n\nHNA has suspended trading in shares of seven of its listed units in China and Hong Kong pending what it says could be a major restructuring announcement. Owners of those stocks could face big losses when they begin trading again.\n\nLenders could be on the hook, too. HNA is using much of the shares it owns in those businesses as collateral for loans. The company has also used the offshore bond market to raise billions of dollars from investors in Hong Kong, Singapore, Ireland and elsewhere to help finance its global deal-making, according to its regulatory filings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA lawyer for HNA, Thomas A. Clare, said that debt periodically coming due was business as usual and that the company had always met its obligations.\n\nIts sales, he said, stemmed from routine business decisions, as well as changing Chinese government views on property. \u201cWe announced publicly several months ago that real estate investments are now discouraged by Chinese regulators,\u201d he said, \u201cand consequently HNA would consider opportunistically exiting from properties that have gained in value.\u201d\n\nHNA could weather the turbulence. It is moving quickly to sell assets, saying this week that it would sell a stake in a trust that owns Hilton hotel properties worth $1.4 billion. China also has a history of bailing out troubled firms to avoid big financial disruptions or job losses. Last month, one of China\u2019s biggest state-controlled banks, Citic, pledged $3.2 billion in credit. Mr. Chen, the company\u2019s 64-year-old co-chairman, has said the company is hopeful it can move past its problems.\n\nStill, HNA\u2019s bond prices have plummeted, and the cost of raising new capital has skyrocketed over concerns that the company could default on its debts.\n\nSales by HNA this year could total $16 billion, by some estimates \u2014 more than the nearly $14 billion in deals it struck last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe think the only way the firm can procure enough cash to stave off this liquidity crunch is through asset divestments, which have already begun,\u201d said Chung Yuh Ang, a senior fixed-income analyst at iFast Corporation.\n\nMr. Chen has acknowledged that the company struck a lot of deals at a difficult time. But HNA has also blamed outside factors \u2014 including, one executive has said, an anti-China conspiracy in other countries.\n\nIn a speech on Feb. 3, the company\u2019s co-chairman, Wang Jian, cited attacks on the company from \u201creactionary forces from both China and overseas countering China\u2019s rise,\u201d adding that these forces were \u201ca major conspiracy against the Communist Party Central Committee with Xi Jinping at its core,\u201d according to a transcript of the speech sent to employees and seen by The New York Times. Mr. Clare said Mr. Wang was not referring to HNA\u2019s financial situation.\n\nMany corporate management experts are not surprised by HNA\u2019s difficulties. HNA has made 123 acquisitions since 2015, becoming a sprawling enterprise comprising planes, hotels, property developments, computer equipment and even shipping lines. It now has 400,000 employees, roughly five times the number it had in 2015, according to regulatory filings.\n\nHNA Group\u2019s Run of Deals Deal Value ($m) Number of Deals 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 YTD $436 $1,142 $2,843 $3,182 $2,206 $4,022 $1,391 $12,256 $31,476 $13,722 n/a 22 11 33 29 24 29 21 31 47 43 2\n\nEven among China\u2019s big spenders, HNA stood out. Over the last six years, HNA has paid more in fees to banks for deal advice than Dalian Wanda, Anbang and Fosun combined, according to Dealogic data. HNA in particular has struck ties over the years with pillars of the global financial system, including big banks in China, on Wall Street and in Europe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThose ties have paid off handsomely for Wall Street. HNA paid $140 million in fees over that six-year period to big banks to advise on deals, according to Dealogic. Those banks could score big fees for helping HNA sell what it bought.\n\n\u201cBanks were clearly keen on doing business with these companies when they were on acquisition sprees,\u201d Paul Gillis, who teaches at the Guanghua School of Management at Peking University, in Beijing, said of HNA and other Chinese companies that bought globally. \u201cThere were lots of fees to be earned backing these transactions.\u201d\n\nHNA\u2019s fate could affect businesses \u2014 and tens of thousands of workers \u2014 around the world thanks to its spending spree. HNA owns Ingram Micro, an American distributor of technology products that it bought two years ago for $6 billion; Swissport, a baggage handler, and Gategroup, an airline caterer, both of Switzerland; and hotels and other properties in the United States and elsewhere.\n\nSome of those properties are now on the block. The company hired JPMorgan Chase in January to help find a buyer for its stake in NH Hotels, a Spanish chain. One week after Mr. Chen, HNA\u2019s founder, received an award at the New York gala from Mr. Schwarzman, it sold a Sydney office building for $160 million to Blackstone, Mr. Schwarzman\u2019s firm.\n\nHNA is also a significant minority shareholder in a number of international companies. It owns 26 percent of Hilton Hotels, the American hospitality chain; a 19.8 percent stake in Virgin Australia, the airline; and a 20.9 percent stake in Dufry, the Swiss airport retailer. It also owns shares representing 3.5 percent voting rights in Deutsche Bank, the German lender.\n\nHNA recently began selling Deutsche Bank shares and had pledged many of them for loans. It has also pledged some of its shares in Dufry and Hilton in exchange for loans. In response to questions, Deutsche Bank cited a statement from HNA that the Chinese company would not sell more of its stake of the bank and declined to comment further. Dufry, Hilton and Virgin Australia declined to comment.\n\nSome of HNA\u2019s selling is coming amid rising skepticism about the company from foreign governments over questions about its ownership. The company\u2019s ownership structure has raised the eyebrows of regulators in New Zealand \u2014 where a $460 million deal was recently rejected \u2014 Switzerland, Germany and the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSearching for a cheaper source of funds, company executives have talked about listing shares of Swissport and Gategroup on the public market.\n\nNo matter what solutions HNA might find for its debt problems, its executives face a difficult challenge in making such a big, sprawling company work well, say experts.\n\n\u201cWhen companies go on acquisition sprees like this, they can suffer from what some call indigestion,\u201d said Robert Salomon, an associate professor at the Stern School of Business at New York University.\n\n\u201cDeals are incredibly complex,\u201d he added. \u201cThe real work is what happens after you buy something.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Biggest Deal Maker Spent Billions. Now the Bill Comes Due.", "authors": ["David Barboza", "Alexandra Stevenson"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Anxious to suppress criticism, and maintain an appearance of mass support, the Communist Party\u2019s censors have scoured the internet and social media for content deemed subversive. The sanitizing has included many images of Winnie the Pooh \u2014 Mr. Xi is sometimes likened to the cartoon bear \u2014 and search terms like \u201cmy emperor,\u201d \u201clifelong\u201d and \u201cshameless.\u201d\n\nFor a short time, even the English letter \u201cN\u201d was censored, according to Victor Mair, a University of Pennsylvania professor, apparently to pre-empt social scientists from expressing dissent mathematically: N > 2, with \u201cN\u201d being the number of Mr. Xi\u2019s terms in office.\n\nStrongman on the Rise\n\nIn their coverage, China\u2019s state-run news outlets have played down the move, as if in hopes that most Chinese simply will not notice, or care. When reports mention the change, they argue that term limits should be eliminated to ensure leadership continuity at a time when China has ambitions to challenge American dominance and reclaim its rightful place on the global stage. \u201cChina cannot stop and take a break,\u201d the nationalistic Global Times warned. \u201cThe country must seize the day, seize the hour.\u201d\n\nDespite the blanket of censorship, and the fear that many expressed in stating their actual opinions in public, some cracks have appeared in the facade of public unity behind China\u2019s strongman.\n\nRetirees who endured the trauma of Mao\u2019s Cultural Revolution are warning of a return to dictatorship. University students are posting quotes from George Washington\u2019s farewell address online. Business executives, concerned about the Communist Party\u2019s growing grip on private enterprises, are hastening plans to relocate overseas.\n\nLi Datong, a former journalist and critic of the government, has circulated an open letter calling on the Communist Party to block Mr. Xi\u2019s plan or risk \u201conce again planting seeds of chaos in China and causing untold damage.\u201d He said that Mr. Xi\u2019s power grab would overturn the very stable and predictable system for peaceful transitions of power set up decades ago after the chaos of Mao and succession struggles under Deng Xiaoping.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to break the chains placed on the system,\u201d Mr. Li said in an interview. \u201cIt\u2019s going to be very dangerous.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile some have likened Mr. Xi to Mao, others reached further into Chinese history, comparing Mr. Xi to Yuan Shikai, an early 20th-century warlord who briefly restored China\u2019s monarchy with himself as emperor.\n\nFor all the discontent, analysts said it was unlikely anything would block Mr. Xi\u2019s attempts to extend his rule.\n\nFor one, much of the frustration over the term-limits plan is limited to the urban elite. Mr. Xi remains immensely popular among farmers and blue-collar workers, as well as a new generation of young nationalists, who admire what they view as his steely drive and see him as the architect of China\u2019s ascent in the 21st century.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a bad thing to remove term limits, so long as the leader has strong abilities,\u201d said one such supporter, Mou Yuxiu, 19, a college freshman in the southwestern province of Sichuan. \u201cPresident Xi is such a person.\u201d\n\nFor another, Mr. Xi already has an iron grip on Chinese society. A sweeping anticorruption campaign has ensnared tens of thousands of officials and imposed discipline on the Communist Party and other powerful institutions like the People\u2019s Liberation Army, China\u2019s military. There have also been conspicuously public arrests of lawyers and dissidents, including Gui Minhai, a Hong Kong-based publisher who has been in custody for more than two years, apparently for publishing books critical of Mr. Xi and China.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile the plan to abolish term limits may be one of the most important political decisions in decades, many citizens are simply unaware of it. The decision has been buried inside newspapers and mentioned only in passing on television news shows.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t pay much attention to the change,\u201d said Peng Man, a worker from the countryside now living in Beijing. \u201cIt\u2019s a good thing if they are good officials. It\u2019s bad thing, if they are not good officials.\u201d\n\nBut for others, Mr. Xi\u2019s maneuvering has rekindled memories of the Cultural Revolution, the decade-long upheaval instigated by Mao that fractured Chinese society and left more than one million dead.\n\nMany see echoes of Mao\u2019s obsession with power in Mr. Xi, who has placed the ideal of absolute loyalty to the party at the center of everyday life. Like Mao, Mr. Xi has also filled China\u2019s society with political slogans and used propaganda to present himself as the leader needed to guide China to its destiny.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics argue that by putting such a personal stamp on power and eliminating the previous collective leadership model, Mr. Xi is setting the stage for a return to the excesses of personal loyalty and fanaticism that nearly tore China apart during Mao\u2019s time.\n\n\u201cMany people inside and outside the system went through the Mao era and their anxiety is intensified,\u201d said Zhang Lifan, a historian in Beijing, whose father, a government official, was persecuted during the Cultural Revolution.\n\nOthers harbor nostalgia for the politics of the Cultural Revolution, which they see as a time of decisiveness and ideological purity. They dismiss criticism of Mr. Xi\u2019s strongman tendencies, saying centralized power is a sign of prosperity and stability.\n\n\u201cXi Jinping can explore a new mass democracy in his own way, without the chaos, disorder and blood, and without the darkness and negatives,\u201d said Zhang Hongliang, a Maoist commentator. \u201cCentralized power is just a tool. What matters is who holds it.\u201d\n\nMr. Xi has presented himself as a singular figure who has what it takes to eliminate corruption, reduce income inequality and extend China\u2019s influence in the world.\n\nWhile gauging public opinion in an authoritarian country is difficult, surveys suggest Mr. Xi has an approval rating of more than 80 percent. In interviews, many praise him for maintaining robust economic growth at a time when more advanced nations have faltered and for challenging America\u2019s dominance in areas like the South China Sea.\n\nBut even many of Mr. Xi\u2019s admirers have been taken aback by his bid for indefinite rule. Some worry that he might upset the peaceful transitions of power that have brought stability.\n\n\u201cMore mistakes can be made if the term is longer,\u201d said Shi Jin, 45, a stay-at-home mother in Beijing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOthers are now looking to leave China, and immigration agencies are seizing the moment to advertise their services.\n\nWu Dan, a graphic designer, said she had received four calls from immigration agents this week. She said she had decided against it, even though she disagreed with the plan to abolish term limits.\n\n\u201cAs a patriotic young person, I hope our country can have fewer people who are starving, our government can think for the people and our media can speak for the people,\u201d Ms. Wu said. \u201cI still hope our government will make the right decision by reflecting on history.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Censors Ban Winnie the Pooh and the Letter \u2018N\u2019 After Xi\u2019s Power Grab", "authors": ["Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The securities regulator oversees the country\u2019s stock markets and competes for jurisdiction with the other banking and insurance agencies for oversight of a large gray area of investments that combine aspects of debt and equity. The central bank seeks to maintain the overall stability of the financial system.\n\nThe intellectual justification for the merger of just the banking and insurance regulators, Chinese experts said in interviews over the last two weeks, is to create a single regulator for financial institutions that accept money from the public and invest it with guaranteed rates of return. But the China Securities Regulatory Commission needed to stay separate from the new banking and insurance agency, they suggested, because its role involves overseeing markets, in which customers know that they are taking a risk that they may not recover their investments.\n\nBut some Western experts have tended to recommend a broader combination of regulatory agencies. They have warned that Chinese financial institutions like Anbang Insurance Group, recently taken over by the central government after it embarked on a program of feverish overseas investment, have tended to exploit gaps in regulatory responsibility between the agencies.\n\nMr. Xi did create a lightly staffed financial supervisory commission last summer, which Mr. Liu is expected to take charge of in the coming days, that oversees all the regulatory agencies. Alicia Garcia-Herrero, an economist in the Hong Kong office of Natixis, a French financial institution, said that the limited financial regulatory consolidation set forth on Tuesday would leave that commission with a lot of power.\n\n\u201cThe beauty of this more fragmented model for Xi is that he is still the final overseer through the oversight commission he created,\u201d she said.\n\nThe restructuring will also create a new, separate National Market Regulation and Administration Bureau to take over responsibility for registering and supervising companies, food and drug inspection, and price supervision. The new bureau will also grab control over antimonopoly actions from the Ministry of Commerce and another, smaller government agency.\n\nChina\u2019s industrial takeoff and feverish urban growth have created dangerous levels of air, water and soil pollution, and placed deepening strains on land and water resources. The reforms proposed creating two superministries to take on those problems: a Ministry of Natural Resources and a Ministry of Ecology and Environment.", "title": "China\u2019s Communist Party Centralizes Power Over Finance and Pollution Control", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China\u2019s newly appointed economic czar told Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Saturday that Beijing was ready to defend its interests after President Trump announced plans to slap tariffs on billions of dollars worth of Chinese imports.\n\nVice Premier Liu He told Mr. Mnuchin in a phone call that the order Mr. Trump signed on Thursday violated international trade rules, China\u2019s official Xinhua News Agency reported.\n\nThe White House says the planned tariffs are intended to punish Beijing for what it depicts as the theft of American technology.\n\nXinhua quoted Mr. Liu as saying that China was \u201cready and capable of defending its national interest and hopes both sides will remain rational.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Economic Czar Warns U.S. Treasury Secretary on Tariffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Eventually, China\u2019s economy will have to become more balanced, as the government well knows. But the Chinese Communist Party\u2019s plan for that is to have the state play the \u201cleading\u201d role in the economy while the market plays the \u201cdecisive\u201d role in allocating resources. Squaring that circle can be tricky.\n\nHow will China\u2019s leaders reform state-owned enterprises, whose profitability keeps declining (especially relative to that of private firms), when they still see those companies as national champions?\n\nMass urbanization is expected to continue, still not out of people\u2019s personal preferences but at the state\u2019s behest, by way of residency restrictions, evictions and forced relocations. Yet China\u2019s planners now seem intent on redirecting migrants from megacities to smaller cities, and this could curb economic growth: As the World Bank points out, labor productivity is much higher in larger cities than in smaller ones.\n\nThen, there is the corruption issue, which will require another delicate balancing act. Corruption has benefited the Chinese economy by, in effect, allowing the transfer of state assets to more efficient private actors. But over time such gains are being outweighed by the social costs of bribes, wasteful expenditures and growing inequities. Allowing corruption to run rampant could undermine the legitimacy of the Chinese Communist Party. Yet combating it with draconian measures could hurt growth by discouraging both officials and entrepreneurs from taking economic risks.\n\nHence the importance, and sensitivity, of Mr. Xi\u2019s signature anticorruption campaign. It has been cast as an effort to discipline errant officials, but some see it as a means for Mr. Xi to purge political opponents or exert more control over society. It seems to have been popular so far: The general public perceives local officials as taking advantage of the system, and here is the central government appearing to rectify the situation. But some warn that the National Supervision Commission, a new agency designed to institutionalize anti-graft efforts, could signal overreach.\n\nTo discourage corruption effectively, the Chinese government will eventually have to leaven the rule of the party with more rule of law. In the meantime, some practical reforms would help, including creating a civil code to define acceptable commercial practices, basic property rights and the status of private companies. More sweeping \u2014 and more politically sensitive \u2014 reforms will also be needed to ensure that private actors have more access to major resources, like land and financing, without having to rely on personal connections to local officials.\n\nThe Chinese economy\u2019s glory days may be over, but even a 6 percent growth rate over the next decade would be remarkable. At that pace, the economy would double by 2030 and likely become the world\u2019s largest in nominal dollar terms. (It already is the world\u2019s largest economy in terms of purchasing power parity.)\n\nChina\u2019s remarkable success to date can be credited in part to its leaders\u2019 willingness to set aside communism for pragmatism. Some observers worry that Mr. Xi is now reinjecting ideology into major policies, Mao-style. But he also is concentrating power and promoting action-oriented reformers like Mr. Wang and Mr. Liu \u2014 signaling his intention to address China\u2019s social and economic needs even as he gathers the means to do so. China may not become a normal country for some time yet.", "title": "Opinion | China\u2019s Economy Is Not Normal. It Doesn\u2019t Have to Be.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "As a result, he wrote, Chinese companies such as Huawei could get the technological edge.\n\n\u201cA shift to Chinese dominance in 5G would have substantial negative national security consequences for the United States,\u201d Mr. Mir wrote. Broadcom sought to assuage the concerns on Wednesday by pledging to increase research spending.\n\nWith the first phase of 5G standards due to be completed this year, the outcome of the Broadcom deal may not affect the complicated protocols themselves much. One major set of standards was already delivered in December.\n\nIt is clear, though, that Huawei, which is not state-run, wants to drive the global charge toward 5G \u2014 and that Washington would rather it didn\u2019t.\n\nPhoto\n\nHuawei has evolved, over the last three decades, from a seller of cheap telephone switches to a powerhouse partner to cell networks around the world. Yet until recently, it had lagged behind Western companies like Qualcomm, Intel, Nokia and Ericsson in taking part in wireless standard-setting, and in owning crucial technology.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s part of China\u2019s technological coming-of-age,\u201d said Chris Lane, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein in Hong Kong. \u201cThey\u2019re saying: \u2018We\u2019re a technological powerhouse. We should be sitting at the table with the Germans, the British, the Americans, the Japanese and the Koreans and doing our part.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe United States government has pushed back before. In 2011, Washington blocked Huawei from buying a California tech start-up, 3Leaf Systems. Huawei is also under investigation by the Treasury and Commerce Departments over whether it broke American trade sanctions in countries including Iran and North Korea.\n\nOfficials in Washington have also watched with trepidation as Huawei has become a major international smartphone brand. In January, after lawmakers wrote to the Federal Communications Commission to reiterate the security worries, AT&T ended a deal to sell Huawei\u2019s new flagship phones in the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Huawei spokesman on Wednesday called the company \u201can early driver and leader in 5G research and development,\u201d as well as \u201ca key architect and contributor\u201d to 5G standards. The company has previously said it complies with the law wherever it operates. It has denied that its products carry security risks.\n\nFor China, taking a top role in 5G is no mere matter of national pride. The new technology will not only permit ultrafast video streaming and communication between, say, a self-driving car and a traffic control system. It is also meant to accommodate simultaneous connections with large numbers of devices \u2014 everything from consumer wearables to industrial sensors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat dovetails with China\u2019s aim, outlined in its most recent five-year plan, to transform its cities and upgrade its manufacturing capabilities using the so-called internet of things.\n\nChinese companies\u2019 efforts in earlier generations of wireless technology mostly flopped. Despite government-inspired efforts by state-run China Mobile \u2014 the world\u2019s largest cellular provider \u2014 during the development of 4G, few carriers in other countries chose to rely on China Mobile\u2019s preferred standard.\n\nWith 5G, Chinese companies started developing know-how early. Huawei has invested $600 million in 5G research since 2009, according to a company spokesman, and has committed an additional $800 million for this year. The company is testing 5G equipment with European telecom operators including BT, Deutsche Telekom and Vodafone.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs of early 2017, 10 percent of the 1,450 patents essential for 5G networks were in Chinese hands, according to analysts with Jefferies, who wrote that they expected the figure to rise. That number includes intellectual property rights held by Huawei; another Chinese equipment maker, ZTE; and others. Qualcomm alone owned 15 percent of 5G patents, Nokia 11 percent and Ericsson 8 percent.\n\nAs of 2011, Huawei and ZTE owned a combined 7 percent of 4G patents, according to Jefferies\u2019s estimates. Qualcomm, at the time, owned 21 percent.\n\nChinese companies have also been increasing their influence at 3GPP, or the Third-Generation Partnership Project, the international body that decides wireless standards and includes representatives from telecom operators, equipment makers and more. The work of deciding technical matters at 3GPP is divided among different groups and subgroups, and Chinese organizations have expanded their presence in the top ranks.\n\nThe number of Chinese representatives serving as chair or vice chair of a group or subgroup was 10 last year, up from eight in 2013, according to Jefferies. There are almost 60 leadership positions in total. Huawei holds five top spots among the different groups; China Mobile has three. The chair and vice chair are elected by each group\u2019s members.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of Huawei\u2019s representatives were hired from other global telecom players, such as Nokia and Nortel, according to their LinkedIn profiles. Other companies well represented atop the standards groups are Ericsson (six representatives), Samsung (five) and Qualcomm (four).\n\nIn 2015, Georg Mayer, a Huawei executive born in Germany, was elected chairman of the group responsible for core network equipment and network terminals, a position he still holds. In an important subgroup that sets specifications related to radio transmission, however, Qualcomm\u2019s representative beat out Huawei\u2019s last year for the chairmanship.\n\nOnce 5G networks begin to be built and deployed, the technical protocols will help determine which companies win lucrative equipment contracts.\n\n\u201cIf you own a significant portion of the patents in the underlying technology, then you should be able to very cost-effectively bid for network projects,\u201d said Mark Natkin, managing director of Marbridge Consulting in Beijing.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a commercial advantage which parlays itself into a security advantage,\u201d he added. \u201cWhoever controls the technology knows, intimately, how it was built and where all the doors and buttons are.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Huawei Is at Center of Fight Over 5G\u2019s Future", "authors": ["Raymond Zhong"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China faced \u201ccritical battles\u201d in defusing economic risks and reining in pollution, the country\u2019s premier, Li Keqiang, said on Monday in an annual state-of-the-nation report to lawmakers that has been overshadowed by a plan for President Xi Jinping to abandon term limits on his power.\n\nMr. Xi was among the Communist Party leaders who listened on the podium as Mr. Li laid out the government\u2019s goals for 2018 in his report to the legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress. Almost 3,000 handpicked delegates attending the congress in the Great Hall of the People also received an explanation of proposed constitutional amendments that included ending a limit of two five-year terms on the presidency.\n\nHere are highlights from the opening day of the congress\u2019s annual meeting, which this year will last for more than two weeks.\n\nJustifying Xi Jinping\u2019s power push\n\nJust a week ago, the Chinese Communist Party abruptly revealed a proposed constitutional change that would lift the term limit on the presidency. That change would clear the way for Mr. Xi to stay in power as president and Communist Party leader well into the next decade, perhaps even longer. There is no term limit for party leaders.", "title": "China\u2019s Leaders Meet, and See \u2018Critical Battles\u2019 on Economy and Pollution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "This was not the direction that many imagined Mr. Xi would take when he stood at the congress in 2013 to accept his first term as president, soon after he became Communist Party general secretary.\n\nIn his first months as leader, Mr. Xi vowed fidelity to China\u2019s 1982 Constitution, which brought in the two-term limit on the president, and paid homage to Deng, the patriarch who had vowed to end lifelong rule so an autocrat like Mao could not re-emerge. Such gestures led some to think that Mr. Xi be would be a relatively mild leader.\n\nInstead, Mr. Xi has proved to be a strongman who now appears intent on at least partially undoing Deng\u2019s political legacy.\n\n\u201cTerm limits, avoidance of a cult of personality, and the end of routine political purges \u2014 all of these were part of China\u2019s reform-era leaders\u2019 efforts to steer the nation out of the chaos and instability of the Maoist era,\u201d said Carl Minzner, a professor of law at Fordham University in New York and author of a new book on Mr. Xi\u2019s authoritarianism. \u201cAs these start to fall like dominoes, the operative question is: What could go next?\u201d\n\nRemoving the term limit follows a series of political victories for Mr. Xi, including being crowned \u201ccore leader\u201d of the party in 2016. But none of these steps ignited as much astonishment, and disquiet, as Mr. Xi\u2019s decision to end term limits on the presidency. Even most experts who thought Mr. Xi might take that step assumed he would build up to it over several more years.\n\nFor now, opposition in China to the constitutional changes has mostly been smothered. Censorship erases much online discussion, and critics have been detained. Many liberal intellectuals and former officials are privately alarmed, but most also seem pessimistic about the potential to rein in Mr. Xi unless a crisis breaks his authority.\n\nSunday\u2019s vote showed Mr. Xi\u2019s control of the National People\u2019s Congress, which in theory is separate from the Communist Party. The handful of dissenting votes this time was lower than the 45 votes of no and abstentions lodged against less important constitutional amendments in 1999, and the 27 no votes and abstentions in 2004.", "title": "China\u2019s Legislature Blesses Xi\u2019s Indefinite Rule. It Was 2,958 to 2.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "The People\u2019s Bank of China sets short-term interest rates (like the Fed) and tries to control bank lending to support growth while keeping inflation low. It also determines how freely the Chinese currency\u2019s exchange rate can move and manages restrictions on the flow of money in and out of China. Last week, the government increased the central bank\u2019s oversight responsibilities, putting it in charge of drafting key banking regulations.\n\nWhat Mr. Yi will do with all this power matters for the whole world.\n\nChina\u2019s mostly state-owned banking system is burdened with bad loans to state-owned enterprises, many of which are unprofitable, and the pet projects of powerful provincial leaders. Mr. Yi must push these banks to clean up their books. Otherwise, depositors might eventually lose confidence and pull out their savings. China\u2019s banks manage investments and make loans in many other countries, so turbulence in those banks could infect financial markets worldwide.\n\nAnd if China\u2019s banks falter, that could set off a sharp drop in growth because China would no longer be able to rely on debt-fueled spending to keep its economy growing. If China\u2019s growth slows, Chinese consumers and companies would import less, and the government would then try to increase exports to resuscitate growth \u2014 exactly the opposite of what the United States and most other countries want. That could set back economic recovery for the rest of the world, depress international prices of commodities and other goods, and escalate trade tensions.\n\nMr. Yi must come up with a policy that changes the incentives for banks. As long as loans to state-owned enterprises are guaranteed by the government, banks will keep making them. Mr. Yi can\u2019t end that policy on his own, but he can tell bankers that they can recognize bad loans on their books without worrying so much about keeping their unprofitable state-sponsored clients afloat. And he can encourage them to focus instead on lending to private firms at the higher interest rates that they are now allowed to charge.\n\nOtherwise, China\u2019s government will not be able to shift its growth model from one driven by (often wasteful) investment in unproductive factories and ghost cities to one driven by consumer spending. This, too, matters to the world as much as to China. If China allows its banks to keep financing industries such as steel, aluminum and cement that produce more than the domestic market needs, it will have no alternative but to export its excess supply to the rest of the world.", "title": "Opinion | China\u2019s New Central Banker Is Just as Important as the Fed\u2019s", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMiracles are constantly emerging across this great land of China,\u201d Mr. Xi told nearly 3,000 lawmakers in the Great Hall of the People.\n\nThe annual meeting of the Communist Party-run legislature, held every March, has usually been a stolid ritual giving leaders a chance to show collective unity, lay out goals for the year and hear mildly worded suggestions from the lawmakers, who are picked for their loyalty.\n\nNot this time. Mr. Xi transformed this year\u2019s extended meeting into an adulatory celebration of him and his policies to permanently install the Communist Party at the heart of China\u2019s resurgence. Just over a week before the meeting, the party made a bombshell announcement about ending a constitutional term limit on the presidency, clearing an obstacle to Mr. Xi\u2019s long-term hold on power. Some lawmakers shed tears of joy as they unanimously re-elected Mr. Xi.\n\nHe is now officially China\u2019s \u201cnational helmsman,\u201d an accolade echoing one of the honorifics used for Mao, the \u201cgreat helmsman.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like the word Maoist, but Xi really is bringing back the party in charge, but also bringing back a personified power in charge,\u201d Ryan Manuel, an expert on the Chinese Communist Party at the University of Hong Kong, said by telephone.\n\n\u201cBut personifying power has risks,\u201d he said. \u201cXi has, better than anyone since Mao, gone around the checks and balances that were placed on him.\u201d\n\nAfter the lawmakers assembled on March 5, they swept away the constitutional term limit on Mr. Xi\u2019s presidency, with only two no votes out of 2,960 submitted. They approved a new investigation agency to extend his anticorruption drive. They inserted \u201cXi Jinping Thought\u201d into the Constitution, putting Mr. Xi in China\u2019s ideological honor roll even before he formally started his second term as president. And they elected him for that second term without a single dissenting vote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese are really long-term risks that he\u2019s leading to with these choices,\u201d Mr. Manuel said. \u201cIt\u2019s not going to happen in the next two years. But if in 10 years\u2019 time, Xi Jinping is still in power, he may have had 10 years of no one telling him the truth.\u201d\n\nChinese media coverage of the congress was saturated by Mr. Xi\u2019s images and words, drowning out other members of the leadership, including the premier, Li Keqiang. On Sunday, the day after Mr. Xi was reappointed president, the front page of the People\u2019s Daily, the party\u2019s main newspaper, and other papers were dominated by large pictures of Mr. Xi, underscoring his unrivaled status.\n\n\u201cXi and his supporters within the Chinese Communist Party have broken the post-Mao-era taboo of promoting one individual leader above the whole party,\u201d said Anne-Marie Brady, a professor of political science at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand who studies Chinese propaganda. \u201cI haven\u2019t seen a People\u2019s Daily cover like that \u2014 big red headlines and only one leader\u2019s face featured in the photos \u2014 since circa 1966-1976.\u201d\n\nMr. Li\u2019s annual news conference on Tuesday, usually a highlight of the final day of the congress, now seemed an afterthought. Reporters\u2019 questions are usually vetted beforehand, and Mr. Li took none that asked about the removal of Mr. Xi\u2019s term limit.\n\nAfter Mr. Xi gave his speech in the morning, the newly appointed chairman of the congress, Li Zhanshu, paid extravagant tribute.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cSupported by the whole party, loved and esteemed by the people, Comrade Xi Jinping is full deserving to be the core of the party, commander of the military and leader of the people,\u201d Mr. Li said. \u201cHe is the national helmsman for a new era of socialism with Chinese characteristics and the guide of the people.\u201d\n\nThe term \u201chelmsman of the nation\u201d has been promoted by the People\u2019s Daily and other party-run media in recent days. It has clear parallels with the \u201cgreat helmsman,\u201d a phrase used in the Cultural Revolution of the 1960s to venerate Mao Zedong, China\u2019s founding revolutionary leader. The Chinese word used for Mao the \u201chelmsman\u201d (duoshou) was slightly different from the one used for Mr. Xi (zhangduozhe).\n\nBut still, for many Chinese, the term inevitably evoked Mao and the Cultural Revolution, said Zhang Lifan, a historian and former businessman in Beijing. \u201cThe helmsman is the one who steers the direction of the craft,\u201d he said. \u201cThere was also a song about how a ship at sea depends on its helmsman.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Xi does not approach Mao in raw, untethered power, the glorification of Mr. Xi has approached levels not seen in Chinese politics since that time. During the congress, some delegates swooned and wept about Mr. Xi.\n\nParty media outlets have suggested that Mr. Xi will not remain leader for life, despite facing no term limits. But some lawmakers would hear none of that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI felt this wave of heat from people around me,\u201d one delegate, Du Meishuang from Hunan Province in southern China, told reporters after Mr. Xi won his second term as president on Saturday. \u201cIt should be lifelong, a whole life. That\u2019s what the hearts of the ordinary people are saying, really.\u201d\n\nSuch fervor in the Great Hall of the People was unthinkable under Mr. Xi\u2019s predecessor, Hu Jintao, a poker-faced functionary. Even Deng Xiaoping, for all his personal power, discouraged personal adulation as a dangerous remnant of Mao\u2019s time.\n\nMore measured advocates of Mr. Xi have said his power must be extended and consolidated so that China can push through hard economic changes essential to ensuring the country\u2019s continued prosperity. They also point to the rot of corruption that set in during the collective leadership of Mr. Xi\u2019s predecessors.\n\n\u201cTo achieve the things that need to be done \u2014 and the big three right now are controlling financial risk, eliminating extreme poverty and pollution \u2014 he is now more able to affect more changes than ever before,\u201d said Robert Lawrence Kuhn, a biographer of Chinese leaders who appears on China\u2019s main state television network. \u201cBecause any resistance will realize that it\u2019s futile and they can\u2019t wait him out.\u201d\n\nBut the acclaim for Mr. Xi has unnerved Chinese people and foreign observers who fear hubris by a leader unrestrained by checks and balances. In private chats over recent weeks, retired officials and academics in Beijing have also said Mr. Xi\u2019s inflated power may encourage him to press harder for the return of Taiwan, the democratically governed island that Beijing views as a breakaway province. Mr. Xi\u2019s latest comments appeared likely to encourage that view.\n\n\u201cNow you have almost all the power in your hands, and you have all the trusted people on your team, you need to deliver miracles,\u201d Ding Xueliang, a professor at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology who studies Chinese politics, said before Mr. Xi\u2019s speech. \u201cXi Jinping needs to deliver something big, and Taiwan is something very, very big.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s New \u2018Helmsman\u2019 Offers a Strident Nationalist Message", "authors": ["Chris Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 In a country where the Communist Party makes all the big decisions, Chinese lawmakers hold very little political power. But they have plenty of money \u2014 $650 billion of it \u2014 and that\u2019s growing.\n\nAccording to the Hurun Report, a research organization in Shanghai that tracks the wealthy in China, the net worth of the 153 members of China\u2019s Parliament and its advisory body that it deems \u201csuper rich\u201d amounts to $650 billion, up by nearly a third from a year ago. That is just a touch below Switzerland\u2019s annual economic output.\n\nWhile President Xi Jinping has pledged to close the income gap and alleviate poverty, the wealth of the nation\u2019s lawmakers has kept soaring. In 2017, it topped $500 billion, more than doubling from the year before. The surge in wealth reflects the strength of the Chinese economy, which grew 6.9 percent in 2017, and stock markets all over the world.\n\nDelegates to Parliament, or the National People\u2019s Congress, rubber-stamp most of the policies set out by the party\u2019s leadership and are expected to approve Mr. Xi\u2019s plan to scrap term limits and allow him to rule indefinitely when they meet in Beijing next week. But the gathering provides businesspeople with an opportunity to hobnob with one another. The title of delegate also gives them extra cachet in making business deals.", "title": "China\u2019s Parliament Is a Growing Billionaires\u2019 Club", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe sky is falling. Again.\n\nChina\u2019s first space station, Tiangong-1, abandoned and out of control, is expected to drop out of orbit around this weekend, with pieces of it likely to survive the fiery re-entry and crash somewhere on Earth.\n\nDon\u2019t worry.\n\nAccording to space debris experts, the chances that you personally will be hit by of a chunk of space metal are essentially zero \u2014 less than one in a trillion.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really very, very, very tiny odds,\u201d said Andrew Abraham, an analyst leading efforts to track and predict the demise of the space station at the Aerospace Corporation, a nonprofit that performs research and analysis for the United States Air Force. \u201cI certainly would worry about things like crossing the street far more than debris from Tiangong.\u201d\n\nTim Flohrer, a space debris analyst at the European Space Agency, said the risk is \u201csignificantly smaller than being hit by lightning.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor people north of 42.7 degrees north latitude \u2014 that includes the residents of Seattle, Britain and almost all of Russia \u2014 the odds are even better: exactly zero. That\u2019s because the orbit of Tiangong-1 never passes that far north.", "title": "China\u2019s Space Station May Crash to Earth on April Fools\u2019 Day", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Room is hard to find. So when the Guangzhou government began reserving cars for female passengers worried about being groped and harassed, they filled up \u2014 but not with the intended passengers.\n\n\u201cMen are totally clueless,\u201d said Lu Lili, a 28-year-old bank employee, who was waiting for a train on Guangzhou\u2019s Line 1 to appear. \u201cIt\u2019s basically all the men trying to squeeze in.\u201d\n\nShe gestured at the passengers like her, waiting for a women-only car. Many were men.\n\n\u201cIn the past, there would be workers trying to tell them and remind them repeatedly: \u2018This is a women-only car,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cBut all these men still want to rush over. They really are uncivilized.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Women-Only Subway Cars, Where Men Rush In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAs we live and grow, I feel like, my goodness, I am actually capable; I could do this,\u201d she said in the interview, citing possible offices for a future run. \u201cIt could be something in Albany, it could be Brooklyn, local, citywide. I don\u2019t know,\u201d she said.\n\nTellingly, Mr. de Blasio began his week out of town, the tail end of a long weekend of appearances in Maryland, Texas and Washington and the latest in his ongoing \u2014 and as yet futile \u2014 attempt to establish himself as a player on the national stage.\n\nWith the trip to Puerto Rico this week, Ms. McCray has taken four out-of-state jaunts on city business this year, the same number she took in the first two years after her husband took office. The pace of her travel, much of it paid for by city taxpayers, quietly accelerated in the final two years of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s first term, when she logged at least 18 out-of-state trips.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe trips, she said, are chances to teach and to learn from others, yet always with a broader political goal shaped by national politics: to \u201cpush the national agenda so that we cannot lose ground, which I feel like we\u2019re doing every day.\u201d\n\nMs. McCray wears many hats, but she has only one formal city job: chairwoman of the Mayor\u2019s Fund to Advance New York City, a government-controlled nonprofit that raises money to support city programs. Her other jobs, described by City Hall as informal or advisory, include leading the ThriveNYC effort, acting as a chairwoman of both the Commission on Gender Equity and the NYC Domestic Violence Task Force, heading up the Gracie Mansion Conservancy and acting as a member of the NYC Children\u2019s Cabinet.\n\nMs. McCray resisted the characterization of her multiple roles as informal, although she is not paid for any of them. \u201cI\u2019m highly scheduled,\u201d she said. \u201cI work hard.\u201d\n\nThat is also a notion that her husband has pressed recently, insisting that Ms. McCray should be paid for her work, and bristling at the anti-nepotism laws and rules that prevent her from drawing a salary or holding an official position with the city.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAsk the people who wrote the laws; I don\u2019t understand it,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said. \u201cShe works full time. It makes no sense to me. But that\u2019s the reality.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAsked about the statement, Ms. McCray laughed and said: \u201cI love my husband.\u201d But she added, \u201cI should not be paid.\u201d\n\nStill, she said that it was an idea that should be studied, for the benefit of future mayoral spouses. \u201cI do think that the appropriate body should look at the role of spouse or partner and make some kind of recommendations or guidelines,\u201d she said. The charter review commission, which her husband has promised to create, might present an opportunity to take on such a task, she said.\n\nIn the last two weeks alone, Ms. McCray has appeared with the mayor at a town-hall meeting for high school students to discuss gun violence and safety; accompanied him to a makeshift memorial placed where two children were killed by a driver in Brooklyn; and visited Washington on her own to discuss mental health with congressional lawmakers.\n\nHer increased role has not escaped attention.\n\n\u201cPay My Wife,\u201d The New York Post shouted in a headline about the mayor\u2019s perspective. And Errol Louis, who interviews Mr. de Blasio every Monday on NY1, recently questioned the mayor about Ms. McCray\u2019s influence over government decisions.\n\n\u201cWhat is her role and, when people say, \u2018Look, we didn\u2019t elect her, we elected you\u2019 \u2026\u201d Mr. Louis said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the most idiotic thing I\u2019ve heard in my life, and it smacks of sexism,\u201d the mayor interjected.\n\nChristina M. Greer, a political-science professor who is a McSilver Institute Fellow at New York University, said that concerns over nepotism may be particularly strong at the moment given the way President Trump has included his daughter and son-in-law in his inner circle.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Professor Greer also saw the Clinton parallel in the working relationship between Mr. de Blasio and Ms. McCray.\n\n\u201cThat reminds me of the Clintons from the \u201990s, when they said you can get two for the price of one,\u201d Professor Greer said. \u201cBut many voters say, \u2018I didn\u2019t ask for two for the price of one. I asked for one. I voted for one person on the ballot.\u2019 \u201d\n\nCity Hall refused to provide details about the cost of Ms. McCray\u2019s travel. Last year, she spent 19 days away on nine out-of-state work trips, and she brings a security detail and frequently travels with staff members.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. David Goodman", "William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI was deep into a new book, \u201cThe Monk of Mokha\u201d by Dave Eggers, about a young Yemeni-American named Mokhtar Alkhanshali, who has been reviving the coffee trade in Yemen, its country of origin. Even if you do not read the book, you can appreciate the confection because the box includes a brief explanation of Mr. Alkhanshali\u2019s story: Mokha Mocha Beans, $28 for six ounces, Dandelion Chocolate, dandelionchocolate.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. This week Chopard, however, has a different kind of grand reveal: announcing that it plans by July to become the first luxury watch and jewelry house to use only responsibly sourced gold.\n\n\u201cIt is a bold commitment but one that we must pursue if we are to make a difference to the lives of people who make our business possible,\u201d Karl-Friedrich Scheufele, co-president of Chopard, said.\n\nAt the announcement March 22, he was to be joined by Livia Firth, founder of the sustainability consultancy Eco Age, and the actress Julianne Moore, both of whom have continuing relationships with the brand. New high-jewelry pieces also were to be displayed, part of Chopard\u2019s collaboration with Eco Age\u2019s Green Carpet Collection initiative.\n\nImage Chopard will use gold from two sources: small mines verified by the Swiss Better Gold Association or refineries certified as meeting the Responsible Jewellery Council\u2019s Chain of Custody Standard.\n\nTo ensure its raw materials are responsibly sourced, Mr. Scheufele said, the brand would use gold from two sources: small mines verified by the Swiss Better Gold Association or refineries certified as meeting the Responsible Jewellery Council\u2019s Chain of Custody Standard, which has strict environmental and social guidelines.", "title": "Chopard Pledges Responsible Gold Advance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Though \u201cLobby Hero\u201d is his Broadway debut, Mr. Evans is not a total stranger to the theater. He grew up in Sudbury, Mass., outside of Boston, in a family of performers: His mother was a dancer who later ran a children\u2019s theater, his elder sister Carly studied drama at New York University and his younger brother Scott is a television actor who recently appeared on the Netflix comedy \u201cGrace and Frankie.\u201d\n\nIn high school, Mr. Evans balanced wrestling and lacrosse practice with Shakespeare, and was voted \u201cmost theatrical\u201d after appearing in \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream\u201d and \u201cThe Winter\u2019s Tale.\u201d The summer before his senior year, he moved to New York to intern for a casting company and went back to Sudbury with his first agent. By graduation, he\u2019d landed a role on television, as one of three boys in a former all-girls\u2019 school on the short-lived Fox drama \u201cOpposite Sex.\u201d\n\nHe spent the next several years playing a series of clean-cut hunks with an ambivalent relationship to their shirts: There was the shirtless jock in \u201cNot Another Teen Movie,\u201d the shirtless musician in \u201cWhat\u2019s Your Number?\u201d and the shirtless flame-throwing superhero in two \u201cFantastic Four\u201d movies, which put him in Marvel\u2019s orbit.\n\nIn conversation, Mr. Evans is more thoughtful and grounded than his filmography might suggest. He is animated by the challenge of playing against type, but has no regrets over his previous roles and surprisingly little anxiety about future prospects.\n\n\u201cI used to have thoughts of wanting to climb to the top of something, or wanting to be somebody,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when you get the thing that you think you want and then you wake up and realize that you still have pockets of sadness, and that your struggle will reinvent itself, you stop chasing after those things and it\u2019s liberating, because you realize that right here, right now, is exactly all I need.\u201d\n\nMr. Evans was wearing the urban camouflage of a black NASA baseball cap with a cuffed brim pulled low. At around 6 feet tall, he is much less physically imposing in person than he appears onscreen, with the unassuming athleticism of the friend you forget does CrossFit until beach season comes around.", "title": "Chris Evans, a.k.a. Captain America, Comes Back Down to Earth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s no surprise that Mr. Trump\u2019s critics pounced. Where was this concern for due process, they asked, when the president and his supporters chanted \u201cLock her up\u201d about Hillary Clinton, who hadn\u2019t even been formally accused of a crime? Where was his devotion to due process when he called for the Central Park Five to be executed, and then, after their exoneration, still maintained that they were guilty?\n\nAs tempting as it is to hammer Mr. Trump for his epic hypocrisy, it is a mistake. The president\u2019s boundless benefit of the doubt for the Rob Porters and Roy Moores of the world, combined with off-with-their-heads capriciousness for immigrants accused of even minor crimes, is not a contradiction. It is the expression of a consistent worldview that he campaigned on and has pursued in office.\n\nIn this view, crime is not defined by a specific offense. Crime is defined by who commits it. If a young black man grabs a white woman by the crotch, he\u2019s a thug and deserves to be roughed up by police officers. But if Donald Trump grabs a white woman by the crotch in a nightclub (as he\u2019s accused of doing, and denies), it\u2019s locker-room high jinks.\n\nThis view is also expressed by many of the president\u2019s staff members, supporters and prominent allies. During the same week that the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, repeatedly vouched for Rob Porter\u2019s integrity, Mr. Kelly also mused that hundreds of thousands of unauthorized immigrants who did not fill out the paperwork for DACA protections had refused to \u201cget off their asses.\u201d\n\nA political movement that rails against \u201cimmigrant crime\u201d while defending alleged abusers and child molesters is one that has stopped pretending to have any universalist aspirations. The president\u2019s moral framework springs from an American tradition of cultivating fear and contempt among its white citizens against immigrants, indigenous people and people of color, who are placed on the other side of \u201cthe law.\u201d It\u2019s a practice that has taken on new strength at a time when many white people fear they may be outnumbered, outvoted and out of time.", "title": "Opinion | Chris Hayes: What \u2018Law and Order\u2019 Means to Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Last Sunday, Boston signed Gionta\u2019s Olympic teammate Ryan Donato, its second-round draft pick in 2014, after he completed his third season at Harvard. He had two goals and four assists in his first 12 games.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was a little bit of a whirlwind at first, obviously,\u201d Gionta said. \u201cComing back from South Korea and heading off to Boston right away. It\u2019s something that I knew was a possibility. So I was somewhat prepared for it. I\u2019ve enjoyed it. It\u2019s been a perfect fit. I love the city. I love the team. The guys have been great. They\u2019ve really made things pretty easy.\u201d\n\nGionta and Kelly\u2019s N.H.L. contracts were the exception.
