Playoff Hunt", "authors": ["Tal Pinchevsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Sitting in his office in the St. John\u2019s practice facility, Mullin said he was not big on \u201cfancy slogans\u201d to contrive a program identity. He does not promote himself on social media. To the players he recruits, he is selling what he never regretted buying into \u2014 a New York experience, the Garden atmosphere on the night of a big game in Midtown Manhattan.\n\n\u201cI do tell my personal experience, how I came to that decision, but what happened for me is going to vary,\u201d Mullin said. \u201cYou can dress that up, but it\u2019s not for everyone. Some kids need to leave, but for the ones that it\u2019s the right fit, there\u2019s nothing like it.\u201d\n\nLosing makes for a harder sell. Mullin made his St. John\u2019s coaching debut with a 90-58 exhibition defeat against St. Thomas Aquinas, a Division II school. His first-season record was 8-24, and then came modest improvement to 14-19, followed by this regular season\u2019s 15-16 heading into the Big East tournament \u2014 where St. John\u2019s will meet Georgetown on Wednesday.\n\nBecause most of the 14 losses in the conference were not decisive, the 2017-18 what-ifs begin with a knee injury to the point guard Marcus LoVett, who with Shamorie Ponds formed one of the more intriguing backcourts in the country. LoVett played in seven games as the Red Storm began the nonconference schedule by winning 10 of 12, but then he got hurt and subsequently left school, reportedly to turn pro.\n\nA 2016 recruiting coup went bad when Zach Brown, a 7-foot center from Florida, was arrested on a robbery charge, then dropped. In August, Sidney Wilson, an incoming freshman from the Bronx, abruptly transferred to Connecticut. More recently, Mullin\u2019s top-rated 2018 recruit, J\u2019Raan Brooks, rescinded his commitment.\n\nIt\u2019s not too difficult to imagine what Mullin finds distasteful about a career fate hanging on the whims of teenagers and those \u2014 parents, friends, the shoe-company crowd \u2014 whispering in their ears.\n\nWhat\u2019s to love? The game, he said. Always the game, and the gym.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t really differentiate from big-time college basketball to any other kind of basketball,\u201d Mullin said. \u201cIt\u2019s basketball. It\u2019s fundamentals and defense and shooting \u2014 they\u2019re all the same. There are some new innovations, of course. But on the court, the things that win games are the same, and the things that lose games are the same. It looks a little different \u2014 the 3-point line \u2014 but we were averaging 120 points with the Warriors in 1990.\u201d", "title": "Chris Mullin Preaches the Power of One Day at a Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Liddell, a New Zealander by birth, became Microsoft\u2019s chief financial officer in 2005, leading the company through the economic downturn. After joining General Motors in 2010, he helped guide the automaker\u2019s recovery from bankruptcy and execute the company\u2019s return to the public market. He also served as the chief financial officer of International Paper, and more recently, took on that role at the Hollywood talent agency William Morris Endeavor.\n\nMr. Liddell would also bring extensive management experience from his time in politics.\n\nIn 2012, he served as the executive director of Mitt Romney\u2019s presidential transition team, where his job centered on process, not policy. During that time, Mr. Liddell revealed few policy preferences with his colleagues, though he was viewed as an effective supervisor.\n\nAlthough Mr. Romney lost the presidential election, Mr. Liddell helped write a book on the team\u2019s planning process, \u201cRomney Readiness Project.\u201d The book chafed some on the transition team, who had viewed Mr. Liddell as highly ambitious in the job, and saw the book as trying to claim more credit for the transition than he deserved.\n\nMr. Liddell\u2019s background and public comments suggest that he could mimic Mr. Cohn\u2019s role in the administration as an ambassador to the business community.\n\n\u201cWe will deal with any businesses that are knowledgeable and can contribute in a way that we think is constructive on the agenda that we have,\u201d Mr. Liddell told a conference of chief executives that The Wall Street Journal held in November. \u201cThe message I would give to people is, we\u2019re not there to necessarily deal with every individual company\u2019s every individual issue. That\u2019s not us. We have multiple stakeholders that we need to address.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut businesses know that this is an administration that is receptive to feedback from business,\u201d he added. \u201cThis is an administration that will listen to businesses of all natures, large and small, of any industry in thinking about policy frameworks.\u201d\n\nIn a break from Mr. Cohn and business leaders, however, Mr. Liddell appears more sympathetic to Mr. Trump\u2019s populist trade agenda. After Mr. Trump\u2019s election in 2016, Mr. Liddell told a New Zealand journalist that \u201cI think the days of unbridled free trade and unbridled free markets are over.\u201d\n\n\u201cI worked in the private sector all my life, so I\u2019m a believer in free markets, but not unbridled free markets,\u201d Mr. Liddell said. \u201cAnd we\u2019ve had 30 years since the mid-\u201980s, both in New Zealand and here in the U.S. and globally, of basically free markets being driving the whole thinking, the whole rhetoric around governing. I think those days are over, personally. I think we\u2019re going to go through a circular trend of a much more restrained free market.\u201d", "title": "Christopher Liddell Is Front-Runner to Become Trump\u2019s Top Economic Adviser", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Christopher Scoates will join the Museum of Arts and Design as its new director on July 1. The museum, at Columbus Circle, champions contemporary craftsmanship and innovation in the field.\n\nMr. Scoates will succeed Jorge Daniel Veneciano, who resigned his post Jan. 31, 2017, a mere five months into the job. Before him, Glenn Adamson served as the museum\u2019s director, from 2013 to 2016.\n\n\u201cChris distinguished himself throughout the interview process with his deep knowledge, passion, and clear vision for taking MAD into the future,\u201d Michael Dweck, the treasurer of the museum\u2019s board and chairman of the director search committee, said in a statement.\n\nMr. Scoates is currently the director at the Cranbrook Academy of Art and Art Museum in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., from which he received his M.F.A. in photography in the 1980s. Before joining Cranbook, he was the director of the University Art Museum at California State University, Long Beach.", "title": "Christopher Scoates Is New Director for Museum of Arts and Design", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is the future of the stand-alone\u201d pharmacy benefit manager, said Tim Wentworth, the chief executive of Express Scripts, who would serve as president of the Express Scripts business under the deal. The two companies said that they would continue to offer pharmacy services to other insurers and to employers that do not use Cigna.\n\nThe deal would ensure that all of the major pharmacy benefit managers would have ties to big insurers. CVS Health, which also owns pharmacies, recently announced a merger agreement with the health insurer Aetna. OptumRx is owned by the insurance giant UnitedHealth Group. Anthem, which operates for-profit Blue Cross plans in several states, said it had plans to create its own pharmacy business.\n\nWith no other large independent pharmacy managers left for smaller insurers, federal and state officials could be reluctant to approve the Cigna-Express Scripts deal, said David A. Balto, an antitrust lawyer who worked at the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department who is a fierce critic of mergers of insurers and pharmacy managers. The CVS-Aetna deal could face the same problem, he said.\n\n\u201cHistory has shown where there are multiple mergers going on in a single industry, the Justice Department goes on high alert,\u201d Mr. Balto said.\n\nOther antitrust experts said it was unclear how the combination of Cigna and Express Scripts would reshape the market. \u201cIt\u2019s not nearly as obvious an antitrust risk as other deals,\u201d said Leemore S. Dafny, a business professor at Harvard. The deal could make the insurance industry more competitive by giving Cigna, which is not a major player in some markets, a way to challenge the dominant companies, she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nHealth insurers, thwarted by federal regulators in their attempts to combine with one another, have been hunting for possible acquisitions. Thursday\u2019s deal came little over a year after a judge blocked a proposed $48 billion merger of Cigna and Anthem. A judge also blocked a $37 billion deal between Aetna and another health insurer, Humana, last year.\n\nThe insurance companies now say they need to integrate the delivery of care and pharmacy benefits into their own operations in order to tackle high medical costs. UnitedHealth, for example, has been acquiring doctors\u2019 practices and surgery centers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing a lot of vertical integration,\u201d said Brian Marcotte, chief executive of the National Business Group on Health, which represents large employers. With insurers looking to operate their own pharmacy managers, \u201cit seemed like this was the next logical shoe to drop.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrustration over the rising costs of health care is mounting among employers \u2014 who insure most working Americans \u2014 and consumers, who are being asked to pay more out of pocket.\n\nIn January, Amazon, JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway announced plans to team up to address spiraling health care costs. Berkshire\u2019s founder, the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, described those costs as a \u201cgrowing tapeworm on the American economy.\u201d\n\nAdam J. Fein, chief executive of the Drug Channels Institute, which studies the drug industry, said the recent mergers may lead to better coordination because the companies will be looking at health care from multiple angles.\n\n\u201cWhen you have a hammer, everything looks like a nail,\u201d he said. \u201cIf everything you are thinking about is pharmacy costs, everything looks like a drug pricing problem.\u201d\n\nSome experts, though, see the combinations as potentially harmful. George Slover, senior policy counsel for Consumers Union, which also raised concerns about the Aetna-CVS merger, said in a statement that these deals \u201ccould result in restricted choices throughout the marketplace, ultimately leading to higher costs and potentially poorer coverage and care for consumers.\u201d\n\nCraig Garthwaite, a health economist with Northwestern University\u2019s Kellogg School of Management, said that whether consumers ultimately benefit \u201cwill hinge entirely on the amount of competition in the health insurance market.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, the model of a pharmacy benefit manager has also come under scrutiny. The pharmaceutical industry, among others, argues that benefit managers are profiting from higher drug prices by keeping a percentage for themselves. The Trump administration made a similar argument in February, noting that the top three benefits managers controlled 85 percent of the market.\n\nOn Wednesday, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Scott Gottlieb, said in a speech that the situation had created \u201cmisaligned incentives,\u201d as the discounts that manufacturers negotiate \u201cmay not always be passed along to employers or consumers.\u201d\n\nMr. Wentworth, the Express Scripts executive, said the company was \u201cfully transparent about how the money flows and the contracts we do.\u201d", "title": "Cigna to Buy Express Scripts in $52 Billion Health Care Deal", "authors": ["Katie Thomas", "Reed Abelson", "Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen I think about who we are as an institution and what happened last night, it represents what we tell our students: If you work hard, there can be these special moments where you\u2019re moving toward greatness,\u201d said the university\u2019s president, Freeman A. Hrabowski III.\n\n\u201cThe symbolism of last night is that my young men went out there to be the best that they can be, and believed in themselves, against all odds,\u201d he added from his hotel room in Charlotte, N.C. \u201cThere\u2019s such symbolism in that, for our families, for people from the working and middle class, for America.\u201d\n\nIn athletics or in academics, it\u2019s not often that Dr. Hrabowski, a mathematician and professed \u201cmega-nerd,\u201d thinks something is impossible.\n\nDr. Hrabowski, who has led the institution for 26 years, was born in Birmingham, Ala., at the start of the civil rights movement, and grew up in the same segregated neighborhood as former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. He spent five days in jail at age 12 for participating in a civil rights protest. He obtained his undergraduate degree, from Hampton University, at 19, and his doctorate, from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, at 24.\n\nHis efforts have helped drive U.M.B.C.\u2019s acclaimed Meyerhoff Scholars Program to the forefront of the push to increase diversity in science, technology, engineering and related fields, and the program has been replicated across the country. Dr. Hrabowski said he was most proud that it had been able to flourish over the years at a predominantly white institution.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe reason we do well with minorities is because we do so well with everybody else,\u201d he said.\n\nDr. Hrabowski has helped build the university, which was founded on farmland and initially educated 750 students, to include three huge research centers funded by NASA, a $170 million humanities building and a $140 million interdisciplinary building that is under construction.\n\nHe calls it \u201ca middle-class campus,\u201d but one that looks like the \u201cplaza of nations at the U.N.,\u201d representing the school\u2019s motto of \u201cinclusive excellence.\u201d More than the win last night, Dr. Hrabowski said he was proud of what else was on display: a diverse group in the stands, in the band, on the dance team.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou saw in the U.M.B.C. community what America wants to be,\u201d he said.\n\nU.M.B.C. sends 40 percent of its students to graduate programs, including Harvard and Stanford. Its graduates include high-profile researchers at Johns Hopkins and college presidents. It is a leading feeder to the National Security Agency and Northrop Grumman.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a campus where you come because you want to be a serious student, no matter your background, across disciplines,\u201d he said. (Two of the school\u2019s basketball players have 4.0 G.P.A.s.)\n\nThe school\u2019s balance of athletics and academics is perhaps its most valuable asset, said Kafui Dzirasa, who obtained a degree in chemical engineering from U.M.B.C. in 2001 and is now a physician scientist running a brain science research lab at Duke University.\n\nDr. Dzirasa was a conference champion in the long jump, but was also an academic All-American. \u201cIt was always this idea that you could do two things at once, and you could do two things with excellence,\u201d said Dr. Dzirasa, who obtained his graduate degrees from Duke. \u201cI\u2019ve always taken pride in the university doing well in everything it touches.\u201d\n\nDr. Hrabowski said that Friday night\u2019s victory sent a message to higher education institutions across the country.\n\nIt was not lost on him that Virginia is one of the oldest public universities in the country; has a legacy that stretches back to one of the nation\u2019s founders; and has $9 billion more in endowment money than U.M.B.C., which is trying to raise its first $100 million.\n\n\u201cPublic universities can be strong academically, even if they don\u2019t have hundreds of years and a major budget,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to help the public understand that institutions of all types have to have quality.\u201d\n\nAfter spending five years on U.S. News and World Report\u2019s \u201cup and coming\u201d list, a category that has been discontinued, U.M.B.C. has a running joke about when it will be able to say it has arrived. Dr. Hrabowski wonders if the basketball team\u2019s newfound fame will be it.\n\n\u201cI guess we don\u2019t ever want to arrive,\u201d Dr. Hrabowski said. \u201cBecause once you think you\u2019ve really arrived, you start going the opposite way.\u201d", "title": "Cinderella Story? It\u2019s True for U.M.B.C. in Academics, Too", "authors": ["Erica L. Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "In the weeks since the Parkland shootings, I\u2019ve had conversations with dozens of chief executives and other leaders from a variety of industries, many reaching out directly about the internal debates they have had. Virtually all the major banks, JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America among them, have created formal or informal working groups to consider the issue, as have the big credit card companies, including Visa, Mastercard and American Express.\n\n(Perhaps the bank that\u2019s least receptive to addressing the issue of guns is Wells Fargo, which has said it should be approached through the \u201cpolitical and legislative process.\u201d Wells Fargo is the largest financier in the nation of the gun industry and is the main bank for the National Rifle Association, according to Bloomberg.)\n\nWith the exception of Citi, most financial institutions are still grappling with how to properly carry out a plan that is both enforceable and does not encroach on the rights of its customers.\n\nWhile Citi\u2019s decision is significant, Mr. Corbat acknowledged that it was intended to be balanced \u2014 and he purposely didn\u2019t want it to be too broad. \u201cThis isn\u2019t an easy thing to simply take a stance on,\u201d he said, because of various privacy laws and rights.\n\n\u201cThere is an important nuance here,\u201d he said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t tell our hundred and sixty million card holders in the world how they can use their cards. It\u2019s their money. But what we did say \u2014 in terms of the people that Citi is going to do business with, the ones that we\u2019re going to finance and that we\u2019re going to, in essence, put our brands together on \u2014 that there needs to be something that makes sense for us and for both sides.\u201d\n\nHe said the bank had purposely left some of its policy ambiguous so it could accommodate potential exceptions \u2014 for example, to the 21-year-old age limit.\n\n\u201cMy inbox lit up with people saying: \u2018Dear Sir, I\u2019ve served in the military. Our country gave me a firearm when I was 18, and it was fine for me to go use that in the defense of our country,\u2019\u201d Mr. Corbat said.", "title": "Citigroup Acted. Now, Two New Ideas on How Banks Can Limit Gun Sales.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The bank said it has few gun manufacturing companies as clients, but those it does work with will be asked to provide details about their product and distribution networks.\n\nIf business customers decline Citigroup\u2019s restrictions, the bank said it would work with them to \u201ctransition their business away.\u201d The company declined to name clients or describe the extent of affected partnerships but said that \u201creal revenue is at risk\u201d if relationships fall through and customers protest. Some of Citigroup\u2019s clients, like Walmart, already adhere to the new policies.\n\nCitigroup said it did not have the technology nor the legal ability to monitor gun purchases at the payment-processing level, but said that the industry was discussing the possibility.\n\nEdward Skyler, an executive vice president at Citigroup who helped craft the policy, wrote in a blog post that the company\u2019s announcement \u201cwill invite passion on both sides.\u201d But he stressed that the policies were \u201cnot centered on an ideological mission to rid the world of firearms.\u201d\n\nFollowing various mass shootings, \u201cwe have waited for our grief to turn into action and see our nation adopt common-sense measures that would help prevent firearms from getting into the wrong hands,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThat action has sadly never come and as the weeks pass from the most recent mass shooting, it appears we remain in the same cycle of tragedy and inaction.\u201d\n\nThe company said it would not enforce a specific deadline and instead hoped to have all of its clients on board with the gun restrictions within a few months. Members of its corporate citizenship group, which also monitors whether clients engaged in coal mining and oil drilling are adhering to Citigroup\u2019s environmental standards, will check in regularly on partners\u2019 gun-selling procedures, the company said.\n\nThe Citigroup board was supportive of the decision. That injunction echoed a similar one issued in January by Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court in San Francisco, who is hearing a separate but related suit.\n\nThe ruling on Thursday took the legal process in New York one step further, strongly hinting at what Judge Garaufis thought about the suit\u2019s central claims. It did not offer a conclusive win for the plaintiffs, only allowing the case to move forward toward a summary judgment decision or a trial. But it was notable for its strong language suggesting that there may have been an improper racial motivation for rescinding the DACA program.\n\nOf the nearly 800,000 immigrants who are protected by DACA, referred to as Dreamers, more than 90 percent hail from Latin America, and almost 80 percent are originally from Mexico. In his order, Judge Garaufis specifically mentioned Mr. Trump\u2019s statements about Mexico sending \u201ccriminals\u201d and \u201crapists\u201d to the United States and his verbal attacks on an American-born jurist of Mexican descent, Judge Gonzalo P. Curiel of Federal District Court in San Diego. Judge Garaufis also cited Mr. Trump\u2019s assertions \u2014 both before and after his inauguration \u2014 that Latino immigrants were \u201canimals\u201d and \u201cbad hombres.\u201d\n\nWhile the judge noted that looking for racial bias, especially in \u201ccampaign-trail statements,\u201d was a potentially fraught process that could result in an \u201cevidentiary snark hunt,\u201d he concluded that his court could not \u201cbury its head in the sand when faced with overt expressions of prejudice.\u201d", "title": "Citing Trump\u2019s \u2018Racial Slurs,\u2019 Judge Says Suit to Preserve DACA Can Continue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "William D. He calls the amendment \u201ca relic,\u201d and says it needs to go.\n\nAnd after Citigroup limited firearm sales by its retail clients, our business columnist suggested two more steps that banks could take to influence the gun control debate.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Thank Nafta for avocados.\n\nIn 1994, Americans consumed a little more than one pound of the fruit per person per year \u2014 almost all from California growers, whose harvest comes only in the summer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToday, that figure is up to seven pounds per person year-round \u2014 and rising. An estimated 135 million pounds of avocados were consumed in the weeks leading up to this year\u2019s Super Bowl.\n\nOur magazine writer says that the drug war hasn\u2019t stopped the trade, and new tariffs might not either. But if Nafta is dissolved, avocado growers might set their sights on an even more important market: China.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. \u201cNow the fish looks better and its owner will love it even more.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s Eugene Ng, a cosmetic surgeon in Singapore who operates on Asian arowana fish, also known as dragon fish.\n\nThey\u2019re a prized status symbol across Asia, with price tags that can reach tens of thousands of dollars. Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Citizenship, Louisiana, North Korea: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Karen Zraick", "David Scull"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPARIS \u2014 The works of Fran\u00e7ois Victor Bazin, a World War I aviator turned artist, are familiar to automobile fans and collectors.\n\nSigned examples of the French sculptor\u2019s radiator ornaments \u2014 such as his first, \u201cLa Cigogne,\u201d a stork in flight designed in 1920 for Hispano Suiza, or the head of the African woman Nobosudru, created in 1925 for Citro\u00ebn\u2019s Croisi\u00e8re Noire \u2014 can sell for well into the four figures at auction.\n\nNow, a granddaughter that Mr. Bazin never knew is reviving some of his works for a wider \u2014 and distinctly more feminine \u2014 audience, both as decorative objects and in a collection of sterling silver jewelry.\n\n\u201cI grew up surrounded by his sculptures, bookends and car mascots \u2014 I always wanted to do something more,\u201d Julie Gardel Bazin said. \u201cThey may be iconic to classic car fans, but as sublime examples of Art Deco I felt they, and my grandfather, merited a broader reach.\u201d\n\nLast year, Ms. Bazin, a longtime project director for the Paris luxury packaging company Aesthete and a former artistic director at Asprey in London, introduced F. Bazin Paris with bronze statues. The elephant head, a centaur, the stork and the Nobosudru head were presented: numbered editions of eight in large formats and 100 in smaller sizes.\n\nThe pieces were cast by the art foundry Fusions, a heritage business recognized by the French state, based in the Auvergne region. Prices begin at 950 euros ($1,170) for a small centaur; large sizes are available by order.\n\nThis spring, that lineup has expanded into jewelry, beginning with the Croisi\u00e8re Noire collection: four variations of Nobosudru, said to have been the favorite of a Mangbetu chief in the Belgian Congo (now, the Democratic Republic of Congo). The most striking is a 3-D statement piece that reprises her elongated profile on a ring. The Favorite earrings sway with chain fringe; the Mangbetu bracelet portrays her in full-face relief. Coiffe, the most discreet and gender-neutral theme, reinterprets the concentric circles of her headdress on pendant and bracelet discs.\n\nPhoto\n\nPrices for jewelry range from \u20ac150 for a silver and leather bracelet to \u20ac460 for the fringed earrings. Like the sculptures, the pieces are made using the lost wax technique and finished by hand. Ms. Bazin said she deliberately chose to work in silver without rhodium plating so that, with wear, the jewelry would take on the same kind of patina as a sculpture.\n\nMs. Bazin said that, of the 70 or more possible ornaments to choose among, she decided to start with Croisi\u00e8re Noire for its femininity: \u201cWith jewelry, you can talk about the woman, the sculpture, adventure and an extraordinary era all at once.\u201d", "title": "Citro\u00ebn\u2019s Croisi\u00e8re Noire Sculpture Becomes Jewelry", "authors": ["Tina Isaac-Goiz\u00e9"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The new spending, which raises the Council\u2019s budget to $81 million, mostly goes toward the salaries for up to 125 new staff members, an increase of more than a third in the head count of the Council\u2019s work force. The new hires were slated to work for the various committees that have already been a priority for Mr. Johnson, including 20 for a newly constituted investigations division, 20 to work on recommendations for changes to the City Charter \u2014 a rival effort to one proposed by the mayor \u2014 and a large increase in the size of the Council\u2019s finance division, to 66 from 38. (Individual Council members\u2019 staff are not counted in the total.)\n\nThe increases come after several years under the former speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, in which spending on Council staff rose steadily, but more slowly. When Ms. Mark-Viverito took over the Council in 2014, she increased spending by about 10 percent to $57 million, then to $64 million by the time she left last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. de Blasio, for his part, has highlighted the reserves his budget has amassed and the spending reductions at city agencies he has requested \u2014 even as his administration grew the budget substantially to $87 billion over his first term.\n\n\u201cIt makes sense to beef up the Council\u2019s analytic capacity, but 130 new people is quite an increase,\u201d said Carol Kellermann, president of the nonprofit Citizens Budget Commission, a city budget watchdog, adding that the Council should have to show the necessity of that steep an increase in staffing. \u201cIf a city agency came in and asked for a 27 percent increase, the Council would rightfully be quite skeptical.\u201d\n\nMr. Johnson said there was \u201cnothing in this budget that I\u2019m uncomfortable with,\u201d and added that some of the money was aimed at seeking better pay for Council staffers whose salaries are often far lower than those across City Hall in the mayor\u2019s office and at city agencies.\n\n\u201cOne of the issues we have here at the Council is that we lose staff,\u201d he said.", "title": "City Council\u2019s Latest Power Play: Giving Itself More Money", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The number of riders between 5 a.m. and 7 a.m. increased by 14 percent from 2010 to 2016, but the number of trains running during those hours fell by 3 percent. Between 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. during those years, ridership increased by 13 percent, while the number of trains running increased only 3 percent. On an average weekday, 577 trains are in service at 8 a.m., while less than half that number are in service at 5 a.m.\n\nMany more riders are using the subway early and late as new types of jobs have emerged and grown. Nearly 60 percent of job growth in the city over the past decade has come in sectors where commutes are outside the usual 9-to-5 time frame, such as hospitality, retail, health care, food service and entertainment, according to data from the New York State Department of Labor. Today those industries make up about 40 percent of employment in the city\u2019s private sector.\n\n\u201cWhat does rush hour even mean in our new economy?\u201d Mr. Stringer said. He urged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the subways, to use money meant for repairs after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared a state of emergency on the subway to identify ways to improve service at odd hours.\n\n\u201cIf we take advantage of the crisis by rethinking how we run our subways and buses to become part of the 21st century economy, then we can move the ball forward,\u201d Mr. Stringer said.\n\nAndy Byford, president of New York City Transit, acknowledged that the subway has failed to keep pace with how people move. \u201cWe should be ahead of the curve in terms of providing public transit,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cYou shouldn\u2019t be playing catch-up.\u201d", "title": "City Never Sleeps, Yet Number of Trains at Off-Peak Hours Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Claire Elizabeth Carlin and Brendan Ross Parets were married March 24 at the Sagamore Pendry in Baltimore. The chain, which also owns the Icing brand, a jewelry chain targeting older shoppers, projected that its total store count in North America would slide to 1,400 locations in 2022 from 1,570 at the end of last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nClaire\u2019s said it secured $135 million in debtor-in-possession financing and support for its debt-slashing plan from top-priority debt holders like the Elliott Management and Monarch Alternative Capital hedge funds.\n\nApollo owns 97.7 percent of Claire\u2019s, which had $2.1 billion in long-term debt at the end of 2017.\n\nClaire\u2019s said it was up-to-date with its vendor payments and had \u201cample liquidity.\u201d It plans to emerge from bankruptcy in September, ahead of the crucial holiday season.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Women\u2019s Hockey Title in Five Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Now it is the men\u2019s turn. The Golden Knights (23-10-6), seeded third in the East Region, face No. 2 seed Providence (23-11-4) on Friday in Bridgeport, Conn., with the winner advancing to play Notre Dame or Michigan Tech for a berth in the Frozen Four in St. Paul.\n\nClarkson has had a men\u2019s hockey program since 1921, but the men are making their first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance in 10 years. The women\u2019s hockey program started in 2003 and made its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance in 2010, winning a national championship four years later.\n\n\u201cAcademics come first here, but hockey is the one time where we can play the Notre Dames and Minnesotas of the world,\u201d said Steve Yianoukos, the director of athletics and recreation at Clarkson. \u201cBut when we popped out in women\u2019s hockey, they didn\u2019t have a clue who we were.\u201d\n\nNow they do. Hockey is the only sport in which Clarkson competes at the Division I level; its other programs are Division III. The school, which sits only 30 miles from the Canadian border, is a true hockey hotbed.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one of our selling points \u2014 we\u2019re a great hockey school,\u201d said Matt Desrosiers, who finished his 10th season as the women\u2019s coach.\n\nWhen asked if the women might have inspired the men with their recent success, Savannah Harmon, who was a captain and played defense for the women\u2019s team, laughed. \u201cI don\u2019t know that I\u2019d go that far with it,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the hockey atmosphere is contagious, she said, and the teams tend to feed off each other\u2019s successes without being competitive about it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe all get along really well,\u201d she said. \u201cI know that me and my friends from the men\u2019s teams will all sit together in class, and we\u2019ll all talk about our games. The coaches\u2019 rooms are on each side of a hall, so we see each other all the time.\u201d\n\nThey share notes. Before Clarkson played in the Women\u2019s Frozen Four in Minneapolis last week, Desrosiers said, he asked a men\u2019s assistant, Josh Hauge, to study some video of opponents to help him with a tactic.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. It\u2019s a real dog-eat-dog world in this sport, but I think we\u2019re a viewed as a program as where we need to be.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cI actually think we\u2019re both successful because of the impact the university has had on the program.\u201d\n\nIt is spring break on the Clarkson campus, and some of the players on the women\u2019s team have scattered. Titles", "authors": ["Dave Caldwell"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Some puzzles just make you say \u201cwow.\u201d That was my response today as I solved Timothy Polin\u2019s crossword.\n\nThis is a delicious combination of a Schr\u00f6dinger puzzle and a rebus and I actually was able to solve it, despite my rebus blindness. A Schr\u00f6dinger puzzle has a theme in which more than one word or letter may be correct inside a single square (The most famous Schr\u00f6dinger puzzle was the 1996 BOB DOLE/CLINTON puzzle that ran the day of the United States presidential election. You can solve it yourself here.)\n\nIf you are not sure how to enter more than one letter in a square, take a gander at these instructions.\n\nStill puzzled? Let\u2019s take a closer look at Mr. Polin\u2019s theme.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nIt was the dog that saved me. I had most of 18A\u2019s FIGHTING __S, and had a hunch that 12D was going to be PAWS for the clue \u201cThings at the ends of dogs\u2019 legs.\u201d But there was clearly more to it, because FIGHTING WS made no sense.", "title": "Classic Letter Puzzle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "My life changed \u2014 and I do not say that with even a touch of hyperbole \u2014 when I got the Dyson DC44 Animal. I love this vacuum. In fact, I love this vacuum so much that I would marry it, in the event that any grammar school-aged children are reading this and are considering an attempt at nailing me with that old chestnut of a comeback. Amazon tells me that I purchased my Animal on Nov. 11, 2013 and, while I don\u2019t use Smalls (that\u2019s his name) every day, every day that do I use him, I feel happy. He makes my life better by being a part of it, truly.\n\nWhen Smalls first came into my life, I had dark, Rapunzel-length hair that wanted nothing more than to free itself from my scalp and transmogrify into tumbleweed-like clumps that drifted all around my home. Post-Smalls, that hair no longer has the option of assembling militia-style, because I run my little vacuum as soon as I see a strand beginning its forward march.\n\nAnd here\u2019s where the beauty of this thing comes in: I can vacuum as much as I want, because Smalls makes it so easy for me to do so. He resides in a wall-mounted holster, which means I don\u2019t have to dig him out of a closet. He\u2019s cordless, which means I don\u2019t have to fool with plugging him in. He\u2019s super lightweight, so I can grab him, zip around my apartment picking up hair or stray Golden Grahams (late night cereal habits are no joke) and hang him back up without exerting any effort at all. I have gone Full Oprah \u2014 arms outstretched as I bellow to anyone who will listen, \u201cI loooooove thiiiiiiis vacuuuuuuuuum!!!\u201d \u2014 when talking about this machine, that is how strongly I feel about it.\n\nCleana Gershon the Mopping Robot", "title": "Cleaning Tools for a Tiny Apartment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere are a lot of little worlds, religiously, ethnically and locational-ly, that thrive in Clifton, yet they\u2019re all happy to be part of the total picture,\u201d said Ernest J. Scheidemann, a local real estate and insurance agent and lifelong resident. The spirit of acceptance was famously demonstrated three years ago when the Clifton High School senior class selected a Muslim student who wore a hijab as its best-dressed female student.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor residents, the ethnic diversity is a selling point, even if some were initially unaware of it. Jason Chuon, who bought a $380,000 expanded Cape Cod after being uprooted from Staten Island by Hurricane Sandy, said he was worried that his Asian-American family might stand out. That was not the case in a town with vibrant Hispanic, Middle Eastern, Asian and Eastern European communities.\n\n\u201cWe have friends here who are Muslim, Hispanic, you name it,\u201d said Mr. Chuon, a 38-year-old online marketer. \u201cThere\u2019s a Colombian guy on one side of me, a Polish lady on the other. Everyone\u2019s trying to just make a living and better themselves. I tell my friends and family in New York, \u2018You\u2019ve got to check out this place.\u2019\u201d\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nWrapping like a horseshoe around Passaic, Clifton is adjacent to 10 other municipalities, including struggling Paterson, in Passaic County, and Montclair, Bloomfield and Nutley in Essex County. The city, which takes up five ZIP codes, is defined by its distinct neighborhoods, most with their own commercial districts, public elementary schools and parks. (Old-timers tend to say they\u2019re from Athenia or Allwood or Botany Village rather than Clifton.)\n\nWhat is called downtown Clifton is Main Avenue. Along this low-rise thoroughfare stretching between the Paterson and Passaic borders are Peruvian restaurants, hookah stores, Turkish markets \u2014 even a pierogi maker.\n\nAmong the neighborhoods, Allwood is known for its district of Tudor-style homes; Albion, in the shadow of the Garret Mountain Reservation, has street after street of tidy Cape Cods; Clifton Center, which includes Main Avenue, abounds with older, multifamily colonials on narrow lots. The most expensive properties are in Montclair Heights and Rosemawr.\n\nCondominiums and rentals are in ample supply. Cambridge Crossings, a 15-year-old gated townhouse community on a former industrial tract, has several hundred homes, some for ages 55 and older. Country Club Towers, next to the Upper Montclair Country Club, has 476 rental apartments in a pair of 1960s-era high-rises.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClifton\u2019s largest development project in years is in the early stages. A medical school affiliated with Seton Hall University and Hackensack Meridian Health is expected to begin operating later this year at the former headquarters of pharmaceutical giant Roche, once Clifton\u2019s largest taxpayer. The 116-acre site on Route 3, partly in Nutley, is being reimagined as a life sciences campus consisting of the medical school and ancillary businesses, including a hotel. New construction is planned for the Clifton portion. \u201cFive years from now, we hope to be talking about hundreds of new jobs,\u201d Mayor James Anzaldi said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\n\u201cAt the low-end, you can pick up a small one-family house in the $250,000 to $300,000 range in areas bordering Paterson and Passaic, and at the high end, you might find a million-dollar home in Montclair Heights,\u201d said Nicholas Tselepis, broker-owner of the Nicholas Real Estate Agency in Clifton. Mr. Tselepis noted that Clifton\u2019s accessibility and relative affordability appeal to buyers from New York City.\n\nOn Mar. 8, the New Jersey Multiple Listing Service website showed 137 properties for sale, the majority of them single-family houses, with about 60 in the $300,000 to $400,000 range. A dozen listings were for $599,000 and up, with the most expensive a $1.19 million custom-built Cape with four bedrooms and four and a half baths, in Rosemawr.\n\nFrom May 1, 2017, to Feb. 28, 2018, the median sale price for a single-family house was $336,000; for a condo or townhouse, $285,000; and for a two- to four-family house, $384,250, versus $308,000, $318,000 and $322,500 in the same period a year earlier, according to the Multiple Listing Service.\n\nAfter the new federal tax law capped the property tax deduction at $10,000, a survey by the city found that about three-quarters of homeowners were already at or under the $10,000 threshold, Mr. Anzaldi said.\n\nThe Vibe\n\nResidents of this suburban melting pot rally around their lone high school and its high-stepping Mustang Marching Band. Traditions like the Fourth of July picnic and fireworks show and the raising of a sea of American flags on patriotic holidays on the municipal complex grounds also bring people together.\n\nThen there are the hot dogs. Aficionados debate the merits of a pair of Clifton institutions that have been around a combined 147 years. Rutt\u2019s Hut is known for its \u201crippers,\u201d deep-fried dogs slathered with the roadside joint\u2019s sweet mustard relish. At the Hot Grill, chili sauce-topped Texas weiners are the specialty.\n\nAnother gastronomic landmark is the Tick Tock Diner, open 24 hours and beckoning Route 3 passers-by to \u201ceat heavy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Commute\n\nBuses provide Clifton transit commuters the most direct way to Manhattan: From Route 3, it is a straight shot to the Lincoln Tunnel. From the Allwood Park & Ride, New Jersey Transit\u2019s No. 192 bus gets to the Port Authority terminal in 35 minutes and costs $6 one way, or $167 monthly. Additionally, the private DeCamp Bus Lines serves Montclair Heights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe city\u2019s two rail stations are on New Jersey Transit\u2019s Main Line. From the Clifton station in Athenia, the trip to Penn Station in Manhattan requires changing trains at Secaucus Junction and takes 45 minutes; the cost is $7.25 one way or $210 monthly. From the Delawanna station, it is five minutes shorter and costs $5.50 one way, or $170 monthly.\n\nThe Schools\n\nThe Clifton district has 14 numbered grade schools, most enrolling 200 to 500 students. Christopher Columbus and Woodrow Wilson middle schools, each enrolling about 1,200, serve grades 6 to 8.\n\nClifton High School, on Colfax Avenue, is one of New Jersey\u2019s largest public high schools, with 2,924 students. Mean SAT schools for 2016-17 were 516 in reading and writing and 519 in math, versus 551 and 552 statewide. Sixty-one percent of the class of 2017 went on to college, versus 71 percent statewide.\n\nThe History\n\nVoters of Acquackanonk township greenlighted incorporation as a city in 1917 and ditched the tongue-twisting Lenni Lenape name in favor of Clifton, a reference to a prominent local cliff.\n\nThough a ways from Yankee Stadium, Clifton has Bronx Bomber connections. On April 29, 1923, Babe Ruth homered during an exhibition game against the semipro Doherty Silk Sox and had to be rescued from fans mobbing the field to congratulate him.\n\n\u201cThe ball traveled so high that it almost became lost in the thick haze that hovered over the desert wastes of Clifton,\u201d The Passaic Daily News rhapsodized. Decades later, the Yankee greats Phil Rizzuto and Yogi Berra would make their mark in Clifton \u2014 as owners of a bowling alley.", "title": "Clifton, N.J.: Where a Lot of Little Worlds Commingle", "authors": ["Jay Levin", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "There are six types of concussions: vestibular, ocular, fatigue, anxiety/mood, migraine headaches and cervical. Each of those concussions\u2019 symptoms has different triggers. For example, symptoms of an ocular concussion, which affects visual tasks and the ability to track moving objects, can be prompted by being in the bright light of a cellphone or being in a long passageway, Collins said. The Yankees, citing privacy laws, have not said what type of concussion Frazier has.\n\nEach type of concussion has distinctive therapies.\n\n\u201cIf you can have 30 different types of knee injuries, why do we think there\u2019s one type of concussion?\u201d said Collins, who added that each type of concussion has about 20 subsets. \u201cThere\u2019s different treatment to those different problems. Science is progressing rapidly now that we know it\u2019s not a homogeneous thing.\u201d\n\nAs diverse as the treatments might be for a concussion, they are almost all active, involving some sort of exercise or exposure to conditions that might exacerbate symptoms, Collins said. What is important is not pushing too far or easing off too much.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a brain injury; it takes awhile to recover,\u201d Collins said. \u201cBut it\u2019s a treatable problem. The best way to prevent concussions is to manage it effectively when you have one.\u201d\n\nThough concussions are typically associated with high-impact sports like football or hockey, or in a sport that requires heading a ball, like soccer, they do occur with some frequency in baseball. The Yankees, for example, have had a player get a concussion in six of the last seven seasons.\n\nAn ocular concussion can be significant for a baseball player, given how it impacts vision. \u201cTry to hit a 95-mile-per-hour fastball with really good eyes,\u201d said Collins, who treated the former Yankees infielder Stephen Drew when his 2015 season ended with a concussion he received after being hit in the face with a ground ball.\n\nResearch is indicating that even when players return from a concussion, their performance lags in the weeks upon their return. Erin Wasserman led a study of the performance of players who spent time on the disabled list with a concussion between 2007 and 2013, and used as a control group players who went on paternity or bereavement leave.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWasserman found that batting average dropped 31 points, slugging percentage declined 62 points and on-base-plus-slugging percentage fell by 99 points in the first two weeks upon players\u2019 returns from concussions. Performance was still lower four to six weeks after returning, but not significantly so, Wasserman said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe symptoms and neurocognitive computerized testing is all we have to measure whether an athlete is recovered, but the neurocognitive areas that are required for hitting may not be fully recovered,\u201d said Wasserman, a sports injury epidemiologist at the Datalys Center for sports injury research in Indianapolis. \u201cWe didn\u2019t find any evidence that it was dangerous for these players to return, but there may still be some sort of deficit.\u201d\n\nThat may help explain why Yankees center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury, who missed a month with a concussion last season, experienced a sharp decline in his performance when he returned, leading to his eventual benching.\n\nEllsbury was having a solid season, batting .281 with a .771 O.P.S., when he crashed into the center-field wall at Yankee Stadium making a catch. In a little over three weeks between his return and his benching, Ellsbury batted .177 with a .497 O.P.S.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEllsbury declined to be interviewed for this article, but General Manager Brian Cashman said that Ellsbury\u2019s decline after the concussion was not a surprise and that it was explained by a neurologist last season.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost like a period of time they\u2019ve got to work through on their own, regardless,\u201d Cashman said. \u201cYou have to grind it out and be patient.\u201d\n\nEventually, Ellsbury found his peak form, hitting .337 with a .912 O.P.S. in September.\n\nA tipping point in how baseball began to view concussions came 10 years ago with Ryan Church, a Mets outfielder whose career was derailed after he was allowed to continue to play for about a week despite experiencing symptoms from his second concussion in a two-month period. After a steep decline in performance, Church retired after the 2010 season at age 31.\n\nHis case spurred Major League Baseball to develop a concussion protocol, which was updated in the most recent collective bargaining agreement in 2016. It requires baseline testing of players when they enter professional baseball and dictates what tests must be administered before a player can return. It also allows for a seven-day concussion disabled list, removing an incentive for teams to keep players off what was then a 15-day disabled list. (It has since been shortened to 10 days.)\n\nIt also calls for a game to be stopped and a player to be evaluated on the field by a trainer if there is an incident that carries a high risk of concussion. If the trainer detects signs of a concussion, the player must be removed and examined further. But because a concussion\u2019s cause can be so nebulous, it is hard to know just what constitutes a high-risk collision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor example, Ellsbury was allowed to remain in a game last May after running into the wall at Yankee Stadium to make a catch. But when he was re-examined at the end of the inning, he was removed from the game. He missed a little more than a month.\n\nIt is not clear how Frazier became injured. He fell backward making a catch on Feb. 24 in Bradenton, Fla., and his head hit the wall. A trainer did not examine him until he came off the field at the end of the inning. Later in the game, Frazier caught a ball on the warning track and his shoulder hit the wall, jarring him. He did not begin experiencing symptoms \u2014 a headache and nausea \u2014 until after the team returned from Bradenton.\n\nFrazier has undergone a CT scan and an M.R.I. and has visited regularly with a league neurologist, as well as one in the Tampa area.\n\nAfter Frazier spoke with reporters last Saturday, expressing his frustration that the symptoms had improved but had not cleared up, he was barred by Cashman from speaking to the news media.\n\nCashman pointed to the N.F.L. and the N.B.A., which make their players off limits to the news media while they are recovering from concussions.\n\nAsked when Frazier, who had come to spring training motivated to make the opening day roster, might get back on the field, Cashman shrugged.\n\n\u201cNo one can predict that,\u201d he said.", "title": "Clint Frazier Is Part of Baseball\u2019s Evolution on Concussions", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "As recently as the summer, Mr. Flood, who currently works at the law firm Williams & Connolly, turned down an opportunity to represent Mr. Trump. It is not clear what has changed since then.\n\nPeople close to Mr. Trump have long praised Mr. Cobb as having a deft touch with an often mercurial president. Throughout last year, Mr. Cobb kept Mr. Trump from publicly airing grievances against Mr. Mueller in part by telling him that the investigation would be wrapped up by December, or soon after \u2014 an assessment that proved too optimistic.\n\nBut there have been signs in recent months that Mr. Trump may be looking to shake up his legal team and change his approach to Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation. The president has polled his advisers and friends, asking them what they think of Mr. Cobb, who persuaded Mr. Trump to take a cooperative approach to the inquiry.\n\nIn private conversations, Mr. Trump has seesawed between expressing confidence in Mr. Cobb\u2019s claim that the inquiry will wrap up in relatively short order and that he will be exonerated, and sounding frustrated with his team\u2019s legal strategy.\n\nMr. Cobb has clashed with the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, who believed that Mr. Cobb was too willing to hand over documents to Mr. Mueller when the White House could have shielded them by citing executive or attorney-client privilege. Officials familiar with the discussions with Mr. Flood said they were unrelated to tensions between Mr. McGahn and Mr. Cobb.\n\nIt is not clear what a shake-up would mean for John Dowd and Jay Sekulow, the two lawyers outside the White House who have also represented Mr. Trump since the summer. Ms. Pirro, a personal friend of Mr. Trump\u2019s and a former Westchester County district attorney, told Mr. Trump in an Oval Office visit months ago that Mr. Cobb and Mr. Dowd were leading him down a path toward his demise.", "title": "Clinton Impeachment Lawyer May Aid Trump in Mueller Response", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "PRISTINA, Kosovo \u2014 Physicists tell us that time expands and contracts because of relativity. Poets and philosophers tell us that time alters with love and age. And, across Europe, microwave ovens tell us that time changes with tussles between Balkan nations.\n\nA dispute between Serbia and Kosovo has disrupted the electric power grid for most of the Continent, making certain kinds of clocks \u2014 many of those on ovens, in heating systems and on radios \u2014 run up to six minutes slow.\n\nIt is one of the stranger examples of technology binding together far-flung parts of the world, and one quirky effect of more than two decades of conflict in the former Yugoslavia.\n\nThe slowdown began in mid-January, and since then clocks in 25 countries, from Poland to Portugal and Denmark to Turkey, have lost time. The fluctuation in the power supply is infinitesimally small \u2014 not nearly enough to make a meaningful difference for most powered devices \u2014 and if it were a brief disturbance, the effect on clocks might be too little to worry about.", "title": "Clocks Slow in Europe? Blame Kosovo-Serbia Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Now that I\u2019ve figured out how to turn on closed captions, how can I make the text for them bigger?\n\nA. Many of the same programs and devices that offer closed captions for videos have settings to change the type size, color and other aspects of the text on the screen. However, if you are using closed captions with your television provider\u2019s set-top box, check with its customer-service department to see if modifying the text size is possible \u2014 and, if so, how to find the settings on your specific equipment. (Some systems may not allow modification, but Comcast Xfinity, the Dish Network, Verizon FiOS and Frontier FiOS are among those providers with instructions on their sites. TiVo has them, too.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn video-streaming boxes like the Apple TV or one of Roku\u2019s many models, use the remote to navigate your way to the home screen\u2019s Settings area and look for Accessibility. Select Captions and then look for a Style menu where you can adjust text size, color, background and more; the Apple TV also lets you create your own new caption style.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Apple\u2019s iOS devices, you can adjust the look of the closed captions by opening the Settings icon, going to General and then Accessibility to Subtitles & Caption, and tapping Style. On a Mac, open the System Preferences icon from the desktop dock, click Accessibility and then select Captions on the left side of the box to see the style options.\n\nTo increase the type size and make other changes to closed-captioned video on a Windows 10 computer, go to the Start menu and Settings, open Ease of Access and then select Closed Captions on the left side of the box. Android users should open Settings and then Accessibility and Captions to see similar options.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany online video apps have caption-style settings of their own, including DirecTV Now and Netflix. YouTube, which has automatically added captions to more than one billion videos since 2009, recently announced that it was putting automatic captions on live-streamed clips. Mason attracted the investors to the league as minority shareholders, but they failed to meet their financial obligations. Chu-hi drinks are available across the country. Some are concocted on the spot in restaurants, but most are sold in cans at supermarkets, convenience stores and liquor shops or in vending machines.\n\nThe beverages are typically more affordable than other alcoholic drinks because their alcohol content, which is usually from 2 to 9 percent, means that they are taxed less than stronger drinks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy introducing a chu-hi drink, Coca-Cola is stepping into a crowded category. Companies like Asahi Beer and Takara Shuzo already make their own versions, as do Kirin (the Hyoketsu brand) and Suntory (the Horoyoi label).\n\nHoward Telford, who leads soft drink research at the market research firm Euromonitor International, said in email that Coca-Cola and its competitors would continue to test new variations as long as traditional beverage categories blurred.\n\n\u201cThis is a departure for Coca-Cola, but I think this reflects the way that changing consumer tastes are pushing the company into less familiar areas like premium dairy, coffee, tea and now low-alcohol flavored drinks,\u201d Mr. Telford wrote.\n\n\u201cThis also reflects a culture change at the company in terms of product development: Company leadership have spoken recently about being less afraid to experiment in terms of innovation,\u201d he added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Japan, Coca-Cola has introduced a soft drink with added fiber to appeal to the country\u2019s aging population and a product that mixes coffee with its namesake soda. It also plans to start selling an intensely carbonated beverage, called \u201cThe Tansan.\u201d\n\nCoca-Cola, which is based in Atlanta, flirted briefly with wine decades ago, creating a unit known as the Wine Spectrum in 1977. The subsidiary produced and bottled midprice wines on the West Coast and also offered chablis and burgundy in 6.3-ounce aluminum cans on some United Airlines flights.\n\nAfter testing what it called \u201clight\u201d wines and \u201cbag-in-box\u201d wines, Coca-Cola sold the unit to Seagram & Sons for $200 million in 1983.", "title": "Coca-Cola\u2019s Move to Juice Up Sales in Japan: Add a Splash of Booze", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu", "Hisako Ueno"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "He did not say how long he had been using cocaine, or whether he reported the extortion plot to law enforcement. In December, at the time of his resignation, Mr. Skipper said he was entering rehabilitation. The police departments in Bristol, Conn., and Wilton, Conn., the Connecticut State Police and the New York City Police Department all said then that there were no records of any incidents involving Mr. Skipper.\n\nMr. Skipper\u2019s resignation, which came on Dec. 18, a Monday, took everybody, even high-level ESPN employees, by surprise. The previous Wednesday, he had presided over a mandatory all-hands meeting on ESPN\u2019s Bristol, Conn., campus. Facing an audience nervous after layoffs, management changes and a very public battle with President Trump, Mr. Skipper projected an aura of calm and stability. He expressed optimism about the company\u2019s future, according to attendees.\n\nTwo days later, according to the account he gave The Hollywood Reporter, he met with Mr. Iger and the two mutually decided he should resign. \u201cI have struggled for many years with a substance addiction,\u201d Mr. Skipper said when announcing his resignation. \u201cI have decided that the most important thing I can do right now is to take care of my problem.\u201d\n\nIt was a problem almost nobody, including those who have spent extensive time with Mr. Skipper, knew he had.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. According to some, the news was a relief. It explained why they had seen no evidence of a problem, as well as why he had to resign.\n\nStill, plenty of questions remain. Did Mr. Skipper, Mr. Iger or ESPN report the extortion attempt to law enforcement? He says his cocaine problem didn\u2019t affect his professional work, but if he hadn\u2019t been using would he have handled the company\u2019s numerous challenges over his six-year tenure any differently? Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cCoffee is much more than acrylamide \u2014 it literally contains hundreds of substances, and is one of the most heavily studied foods of all time,\u201d he said.\n\nPutting warning labels on coffee would be \u201csimply confusing and misleading,\u201d he said, citing statements from the World Health Organization that the drink does not cause cancer and studies showing that coffee offers health benefits like longevity.\n\n\u201cCoffee has been shown, over and over again, to be a healthy beverage,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nStarbucks and other defendants can file objections to the proposed decision within the next two weeks. \u201cYou should expect that this matter will not be definitely settled in the courts for months to come,\u201d Mr. Murray wrote.\n\nBusinesses that violate Proposition 65 could face penalties of up to $2,500 per day for each violation, according to the California attorney general\u2019s office. Some companies have already settled.\n\nIn a court document filed in December, 7-Eleven agreed to post signs in its company and franchise stores and to pay $900,000 to cover civil penalties and the plaintiff\u2019s legal costs.\n\nThe National Cancer Institute notes that, among foods, coffee is a major source of acrylamide, along with potato chips, bread, breakfast cereals and canned black olives. The two men worked closely together to shepherd the tax bill and Mr. Mnuchin often tries to be a moderating force, attempting to calm markets and smooth Mr. Trump\u2019s provocative policy instincts.\n\nBut unlike Mr. Cohn, Mr. Mnuchin has not shown a willingness to publicly break with Mr. Trump and instead defends him. That tendency was on display this week when Mr. Mnuchin testified before Congress and insisted that he did not want to see a trade war. But when pressed about Mr. Trump\u2019s controversial tariffs on steel and aluminum, Mr. Mnuchin said he was fully behind them. In an interview with Fox Business on Wednesday morning, he said he was confident the tariffs would not hurt economic growth, as many economists have warned.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re comfortable that we\u2019re going to manage through this so that it is not detrimental to our growth projections,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said.\n\nMr. Cohn\u2019s departure comes amid the ascendence of advisers who have urged the president to take tougher action on trade. Peter Navarro, a trade skeptic who had been sidelined by Mr. Cohn, has been promised a promotion and made the rounds on Sunday talk shows to promote Mr. Trump\u2019s trade policy. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who oversaw an investigation that led to the tariffs, succeeded in moving up the announcement even as Mr. Cohn sought to delay it. Robert Lighthizer, the United States trade representative, has become a trusted adviser to the president.\n\nThose advisers have a much more binary view of trade, seeing it as a zero-sum game in which the United States is losing. They have pushed the president to withdraw from deals like Nafta unless trading partners agree to sharp concessions and to implement the type of stiff tariffs that he seems prepared to impose on steel and aluminum imports. Mr. Cohn has argued against some of the tougher positions that economists and businesses say could disrupt global supply chains, drive up costs for American businesses and hurt consumers.\n\nThe rise of the populist faction is already fanning fears on Wall Street and among foreign officials that Mr. Trump could start and escalate a global trade war or take a more combative stance toward trading partners and international groups like the World Trade Organization.
