Fate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nAs a manager raised in the 1970s, I am sensitive to differences between myself and my younger staff members, most of whom were raised in the 1990s. That said, I was surprised to stumble upon an apparent point of differentiation during the course of a conversation about childhood. I mentioned drinking out of a garden hose as a child, and younger staffers reacted with disgust and revulsion: \u201cYou drank all of those germs? Ugh!\u201d I thought of this recently after I was out sick for two days with a cold. Fully recovered, I returned to work \u2014 and one member of my staff, who was a good five yards away, backed into a wall. This usually warm employee muttered, \u201cI don\u2019t want to get sick,\u201d and darted into her office. Another staff member, in my office for a meeting, wouldn\u2019t touch anything, and closed the door with his elbow, presumably avoiding contagion. Throughout the day, he and his colleagues followed me silently with wet wipes, erasing my path of \u201cgerms.\u201d I\u2019m not an untidy or unclean person. In fact, I am rather fastidious. And I was perfectly healthy during this episode. I find this behavior rude and unprofessional, and can\u2019t imagine the reaction if they had treated a visitor to our office in the same way. How do I discuss this issue with workers who \u2014 given these dubious \u201cprevention\u201d tactics \u2014 evidently believe their own health comes before social propriety and respect to others? C.P., NEW YORK\n\nAnecdotal evidence aside, I think the generational angle is probably a distraction. A survey last year conducted on behalf of CityMD, a chain of urgent-care clinics, found that people ages 18 to 35 who had experienced \u201cflulike symptoms\u201d were much more likely than those above that age to venture into the world despite feeling sick.\n\nBefore we go any further, let\u2019s acknowledge that people who are sick and potentially contagious should not go to the office. And yet anyone who has ever worked in an office has experienced the sniffling, sneezing, hacking co-worker who insists on coming in. People do this for all sorts of reasons \u2014 from economic necessity to the misguided sense that the enterprise can\u2019t get by without them. The possibly contagious colleague is among the most familiar villains of office life.\n\nWe\u2019ve all encountered this menace, and especially during a rough flu season, it is understandable that your co-workers are worried. Address the situation directly, but keep it light: Treat the whole episode as a simple (and, like your note, amusing) misunderstanding, rather than a generational showdown. Assure your colleagues that you are well, and no threat to their health. Then pivot into your management role and make precisely the points you are making here. Affirm that you value your colleagues too much to put their health at risk \u2014 and that they need to show you the same respect.", "title": "Colleagues Think You\u2019re Contagious. You\u2019re Sure You\u2019re Not.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "I WROTE THIS BOOK BECAUSE I LOVE YOU\n\nEssays\n\nBy Tim Kreider\n\n206 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.\n\nImage\n\nKreider, a political cartoonist and essayist, has indeed written this book because he loves you. Or rather, because he has loved some women and one cat, and learned a few things along the way. In a style reminiscent of Orwell, E. B. White and David Sedaris, an affable hero gamely bumbles through adventures rich with moments of fleeting profundity and moral reckoning. He follows a manic circus tutor on a train to Mexico, falls for a fellow cartoonist amid the early aughts\u2019 war on terror and trysts with a politically enlightened prostitute. These stories entertain, though I prefer him being wittily deprecated by his female companions to his drawing binaries between \u201c\u2018Type A\u2019: smart, pretty, sane, moral girls with glasses who tended to work for nonprofits or write\u201d and \u201cbawdy dominatrices\u201d (to be fair, this reviewer is a Type A, former bawdy dominatrix who writes). But his depictions of the arc from ignorance to wisdom are reliably deft. With every blunder he gleans insights like \u201cHowever salacious it may seem to civilians, that\u2019s what prostitution is: another goddamn job.\u201d\n\nKreider is a curious and compassionate observer and a fantastic wit \u2014 I laughed to tears more than once. Though he excels at romantic comedy, the essays that stray from that convention resound longer, like \u201cThe Strange Situation,\u201d which ambitiously explores his relationship patterns vis-\u00e0-vis his childhood participation in the psychologist Mary Ainsworth\u2019s famous study on attachment theory.\n\nThese are pleasurable, well-wrought essays, though they sometimes feel like a throwback to a time when we were more easily charmed by the affable straight white man. In an essay about teaching at a former women\u2019s college, he is thrilled by not wanting to sleep with his students. His self-examination manages to be both endearing and irksomely self-congratulatory. That is, the character of Kreider is a good guy \u2014 self-aware, if not always scrutinizing. But how does the joke go? Why did the male feminist walk into the bar? Because it was set so low.\n\nTHIS WILL BE MY UNDOING\n\nLiving at the Intersection of Black, Female, and Feminist in (White) America\n\nBy Morgan Jerkins\n\n258 pp. Harper Perennial. Paper, $15.99\n\nImage\n\nJerkins cannily opens her book with a familiar scene: cheerleader tryouts. But the tale that begins \u201cWhen I was 10, I realized that I was black\u201d is not the cozy cultural appropriation fable of \u201cBring It On.\u201d Not because of its unhappy ending, but because it centers the black female experience. Much of the book\u2019s language is this deceptively simple: \u201cI couldn\u2019t make the team because I was not human.\u201d Without turning linguistic or lyrical cartwheels, Jerkins lucidly articulates social dynamics that have dictated the realities of American black women for centuries, like how white feminism erases black women. \u201cThis book is not about all women,\u201d Jerkins explains at the end of the opening essay, \u201cbut it is meant for all women, and men, and those who do not adhere to the gender binary. It is for you.\u201d Indeed, it is a book I wish everyone in this country would read.", "title": "Collections of Essays by Writers Old and Young", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMy thing is, if you yell at the refs, you should get a technical,\u201d he said.\n\nBut he defended his intention \u2014 leading his team to victory \u2014 and actions \u2014 shouting, pacing, pushing the limits of the coach\u2019s box.\n\n\u201cIf we\u2019re coaching our guys,\u201d he said, \u201cthat\u2019s what we\u2019re paid to do.\u201d\n\nThe N.C.A.A. doesn\u2019t necessarily disagree. This is the first season of an expanded coach\u2019s box, which is the area the head coach may patrol during play. Vigorous sideline generals received an extra 10 feet this season; they may now roam from the baseline all the way to a mark 38 feet away. That\u2019s a midrange jump shot from midcourt, which is 47 feet from the baseline.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI have had officials tell me that it was expanded for me,\u201d Weber said.\n\nCollege basketball coaches are easy subjects for ridicule. N.B.A. fans scoff at their hyperactivity and point to professional coaches\u2019 comparatively calm mien, even though N.B.A. coaches may stray as much as 43 feet from the baseline. Casual observers wonder why these blustering, nattily dressed bombasts can\u2019t stay cool.\n\nThe college coaches say they deserve sympathy. Their charges are younger than most players in the N.B.A. Their teams can feel especially far away while on defense, seeking crucial late-game stops out of vocal range for even the loudest coach. Most coaches are former players with decades of experience who now watch mostly helplessly as post-adolescents try to implement months of training in a few essential seconds. Their antics also make for great TV.\n\nYet they have to stay inside an invisible box during games or risk a penalty that could tangibly hurt their team. The correct call for a coach\u2019s box violation after a warning is a Class B technical foul, giving the other team one free throw and the ball, inbounded where it was when the foul was called.\n\n\u201cI have a young team, and sometimes they don\u2019t talk,\u201d Alabama Coach Avery Johnson said last week between first- and second-round games. \u201cYou can hear it in my voice. I\u2019ve got to talk for them. I got warned yesterday, and, probably, going to get warned tomorrow.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite plenty of yelling and straying, Johnson and Alabama lost to Duke on Sunday night.\n\nIn a world where referees \u201cT-up\u201d coaches for far more subjectively determined violations, there is an argument that the coach\u2019s box is extraneous, even condescending. Anecdotally, there appear to be few T\u2019s actually called (the N.C.A.A. said it did not keep the statistic). Kansas Coach Bill Self complained that he had been whistled once this year \u201cfor sticking my toe two inches outside the box.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe represent universities,\u201d South Carolina Coach Frank Martin said in a phone interview. \u201cWe\u2019re grown men. We\u2019re employed. We get treated like we\u2019re immature. We\u2019ve got to be in this small little confined area. We\u2019re not going to go to the other bench and instigate something.\u201d\n\nThis understanding was partly why the box was expanded, according to Art Hyland, secretary-rules editor of the N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball rules committee. It is also why referees are instructed to first give the bench a warning.\n\n\u201cPeople felt empathy that the coaches really needed a little more room in order to do their job correctly,\u201d Hyland said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAn extra 10 feet turns out to be a lot, Self said Thursday in Omaha before the Jayhawks\u2019 round of 16 game. He thought it was a \u201cpretty insignificant change\u201d when it was announced last June, but now that it has been in place for a season, he said, \u201cIt\u2019s been a great rule.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou feel like you can actually have a little bit more communication on the other end of the floor,\u201d he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, before Thursday night\u2019s violation, Calipari blamed the tight strictures of the old box for one of the most infamous coach\u2019s box technical fouls in the college game.\n\nIn 1992, Calipari\u2019s Massachusetts team was playing Kentucky in the round of 16 at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. The Minutemen had made up most of a double-digit deficit late in the second half when a referee called a technical foul on Calipari for a coach\u2019s box violation. The referee \u201cwas 50 feet away from the UMass bench when he called it,\u201d The Baltimore Sun reported. The call swung the momentum back the Wildcats\u2019 way, and they won. (They lost the next game to Duke on Christian Laettner\u2019s famous buzzer-beater.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAt the Spectrum where they had all those lines,\u201d Calipari said. \u201cI\u2019m standing there and the guy calls a T from 90 feet away. \u2018You\u2019re out of the box.\u2019 And I really wasn\u2019t out of the box, but it looked like it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCalipari had no such defense or excuse Thursday night.\n\nIn practice, there is frequently a live-and-let-live dynamic between referees and hyperactive coaches. Warnings are issued; actual fouls, less so.\n\nEd Hightower, a retired referee, said officials often find that assistant coaches are better interlocutors for conveying the warnings. Speraw, Weber\u2019s assistant, said that the referees had spoken to the staff at halftime of the U.M.B.C. game.\n\nWhen warning coaches that they were in danger of violating this rule, Hightower said he would often say, \u201cYou don\u2019t want to make me do something I don\u2019t want to do.\u201d\n\n\u201cNinety percent of the time, I would say, the coaches are just so caught up in the moment, coaching their kids,\u201d Hightower said. \u201cIt\u2019s an emotional sport.\u201d", "title": "College Coaches Cannot Be Contained", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Under the plan the students are proposing, an initial tax of $40 per ton of carbon would be levied at the point where fossil fuels enter the economy, for instance a mine or port. The tax would increase over time. That money would then be returned to taxpayers in a per-person monthly payment, with half-payments going to children under the age of 18 and a limit of two children per family. The Climate Leadership Council created by Mr. Baker and Mr. Shultz estimates a dividend would amount to about $2,000 a year for a family of four.\n\nAs part of the deal, there would also be limitations on regulatory actions like the Clean Power Plan, which former President Barack Obama impose d to reduce carbon emissions from coal-fired power plants. Members of the coalition said they considered a promise to scale back future regulation key to encouraging Republican support.\n\nAlexander Posner, 22, a Yale University senior who founded the group, said he has been interested in climate change and energy for years. When he read about the climate council Mr. Baker and Mr. Shultz began last year, he signed up for an internship . Soon after, he started contacting his peers at Republican clubs across the country to sound them out on creating a coalition of their own.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had a lot of conversations, and literally not once has the validity of climate science come up,\u201d Mr. Posner said. \u201cI think students really want to have a solutions-based discussion.\u201d\n\nThe coalition of 23 Republican student groups, five college Democratic clubs and three university environmental clubs comes at a unique moment of youth political activism. Students nationwide are mobilizing for gun control, inspired by the survivors of the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., and Mr. Posner said that, despite the profound differences in the two movements, young Republicans working on issues like climate change were watching the gun protests with interest.\n\n\u201cI think the common theme here is if representatives are not responding to the desires of their constituents, in particular young people,\u201d he said, \u201cthen young people are going to step forward. This coalition on the climate front is sort of a reflecting of the inaction of adults.\u201d\n\nLast week the nonprofit Alliance for Market Solutions issued a survey on millennial attitudes toward climate change showing that nearly 60 percent of young Republicans acknowledge that human-induced climate change is real, and 88 percent of young Democrats . A majority of young people of both parties said they believed steps should be taken to slow or stop climate change.", "title": "College Republicans Propose an Unusual Idea From the Right: A Carbon Tax", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The campaigning did not go well. Mr. Londo\u00f1o was attacked by protesters who pelted his motorcade with rocks, on one occasion doing severe damage to his vehicle. A prominent Senate candidate, Luciano Mar\u00edn, known by his nom de guerre, Iv\u00e1n M\u00e1rquez, was forced to cancel campaign events after they were mobbed.\n\nThe tensions forced FARC to suspend its campaigning last month, declaring it unsafe. The former rebels blamed right-wing parties, while others in Colombia argued that the group was simply confronting an angry electorate victimized for years by FARC\u2019s kidnappings and deadly attacks. Just a tiny percentage of Colombians say they would consider voting for them.\n\nOn Thursday, F\u00e9lix Antonio Mu\u00f1oz, a former FARC commander who is running for the Senate, said the atmosphere remained unsafe for the group. \u201cWe need to generate new conditions that guarantee that political participation is inclusive,\u201d he told reporters gathered in the city of Armenia on Thursday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile the group has a diminished profile on the campaign trail, it will still have a presence in the Colombian legislature no matter how the election goes. Under the peace deal, the former guerrillas were guaranteed five seats in the Senate and five in the House of Representatives.\n\nBut the attacks on the campaign trail and the departure of their presidential candidate still left many commentators concerned.\n\n\u201cNothing has gone well for the party,\u201d said Le\u00f3n Valencia, a Colombian political analyst and former rebel who in the 1990s left the National Liberation Army, another guerrilla group. \u201cThe implementation of the peace accords going ahead will depend on their presence and political influence in the country and this is in question.\u201d\n\nMr. Londo\u00f1o\u2019s campaign, while always a long shot, had gotten off a positive start. In January, he began his bid in a downtrodden Bogot\u00e1 neighborhood, where a large crowd greeted him waving flags bearing the group\u2019s new logo, a red rose. He pledged to work on behalf of Colombia\u2019s poor and fight corruption in government.\n\n\u201cMay the voice of those below, those millions and millions of poor who never were counted, may they be listened to,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the health of Mr. Londo\u00f1o, who is 59 and spent years in the jungle as a rebel commander and long suffered from heart problems, was in decline. Last week he was hospitalized after chest pains that began while he was exercising, the group said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Wednesday night, Mr. Londo\u00f1o underwent heart surgery and was also being treated for lung problems and an obstructed cerebral artery. The hospital which treated him, the Shaio Clinic in Bogot\u00e1, said he had left the surgery as doctors expected and cited no complications.", "title": "Colombia Rebel Ends Presidential Campaign, in Blow to Peace Process", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Voters also offered a drubbing to a newly created party of the former rebels. The Common Alternative Revolutionary Force, which kept its wartime acronym FARC, got just a fraction of a percentage of votes. That would not have won it any legislative seats at all had it not been for a deal with the government that guaranteed the group five in each chamber.\n\nWith Congress elected, attention now turns to the presidential race, whose first round of balloting will be in May. The match appears set to be dominated by the right-wing candidate Iv\u00e1n Duque and Gustavo Petro, a leftist former mayor of Bogot\u00e1, the capital, each of whom won primaries on Sunday for their respective coalitions.\n\nAlso prominent in polls is Sergio Fajardo, another former mayor campaigning on a centrist platform who is known for fighting poverty and significantly improving infrastructure in his city, Medell\u00edn.\n\nThe election has been dominated by issues including street crime and corruption scandals involving public funds. A main punching bag has also been the peace deal with the FARC, which was narrowly voted down in a referendum in 2016, but forced through Congress by Mr. Santos after minor changes to the text.\n\nWhile it is unlikely that major changes to the deal would be easily achieved under the new government, its divisions could mean that parts of the accord, like grants to former coca farmers who switch crops, could find themselves in the cross hairs as the next government puts them into effect.", "title": "Colombian Election Brings Divided Congress to Power", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "The museum\u2019s location in Medell\u00edn also makes it an extraordinary landmark: in the 1980s and 1990s, the city was one of the most violent in the world. It was from here that Pablo Escobar ruled his cocaine empire and where he was killed by Colombian police in 1993. According to Human Rights Watch, more than seven million Colombians were displaced, disappeared or murdered during the 52 years of fighting. The Museum of Modern Art was founded by artists in 1978 and opened its doors to the public in 1980.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople didn\u2019t go out then,\u201d said the museum\u2019s director Mar\u00eda Mercedes Gonz\u00e1lez. \u201cLife took place indoors. But the artists, this museum, as well as many other social and cultural institutions persisted. There was a very powerful social will, a barrier of resistance, and, despite war and economic crisis, this city was resilient.\u201d\n\nEncouraged by growing popularity \u2014 it hosted the First Latin American Colloquium of Non-Object and Urban Art in 1981 \u2014 the museum by the 2000s was actually expanding. In 2006, city leaders approved the museum\u2019s relocation to the Talleres Robledo building, in the Ciudad del Rio area. In 2010, the museum called for architectural proposals to increase its exhibition space. Five years later, it opened new galleries, a theater, book and gift stores and a cafe.\n\nPhoto\n\nToday, the museum is a cavernous and commanding urban nucleus that, according to Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez, aims to draw as many local visitors as it does tourists from abroad. The museum\u2019s steps descend onto a plaza facing high-rise apartment complexes inching up Medell\u00edn\u2019s eastern hills and serves as a popular meeting venue for nearby residents.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJust a few years ago, this kind of gathering would have been unthinkable,\u201d said the museum\u2019s photographer, Juan Felipe Barreiro.\n\nPhoto\n\nExhibits avoid any thematic constant, such as the war years. One recent show, \u201cDesire: An Exhibition about Sex, Love, and Lust,\u201d included several striking Arango depictions of sensual yet pensive women adjacent to the English artist Celia Hempton\u2019s interpretations of anonymous sexual pleasure in the digital age.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to do something playful, something celebratory,\u201d said the chief curator Emiliano Vald\u00e9s. He added that inspiration for the show grew partly out of protest against socially conservative Colombian lawmakers, as well as a reflection on the global transgender rights movement.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother temporary exhibit, the short film \u201cBlack Box\u201d by Elkin Calder\u00f3n Guevara and Diego Pi\u00f1eros Garc\u00eda features the antiquated DC-3 airliner that continues to operate in Colombia\u2019s remote Orinoco and Amazon regions. Except for the plaintive engine hum as the plane glides over uninterrupted jungle, a ghostly silence pervades the presentation. An explanatory pamphlet notes that the planes were once in Colombia\u2019s military service \u201cand were even used for illicit transport. They are machines that tell the unspeakable, that moment between life and death when time is infinite and everything is silent.\u201d\n\nIn 2017, the museum\u2019s visitors numbered 110,000, a growth of six percent from the previous year. On March 21, it will inaugurate the exhibition \u201cArt in Antioquia and the Seventies,\u201d which reflects on the museum\u2019s first exhibition in 1978.\n\n\u201cOne of the museum\u2019s objectives,\u201d said Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez, is \u201cto present a temporary exhibitions program dedicated to contemporary art and its intersection with modern movements, and to take on issues that are culturally, socially, politically and aesthetically relevant to the local context,\u201d Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez said.\n\n\u201cThis all goes beyond an investment in physical space,\u201d she continued, with reference to the museum\u2019s gradual expansion. \u201cIt\u2019s mainly a commitment to the arts, artists, audiences so that they can enjoy exhibitions and fresh work, as well as better access to the permanent collection.\u201d", "title": "Colombia\u2019s Museum of Modern Art Celebrates Its 40th Year", "authors": ["Elizabeth Zach"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Columbia University on Wednesday removed a top neuroscientist from his posts and announced plans to dissolve his lab after an internal investigation uncovered violations of \u201cuniversity policies and values.\u201d\n\nThe scientist, Thomas Jessell, a professor of biochemistry, biophysics and neuroscience, is one of the world\u2019s foremost researchers into the basic biology of brain cells. His work at Columbia focused on how sensory and motor neurons coordinate movements.\n\nDr. Jessell, 66, was a winner of the prestigious Kavli Prize for Neuroscience in 2008 and has been a fellow of the Royal Society of London since 1996. He was a director of the Kavli Institute for Brain Science and a director of the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Initiative, both at Columbia.\n\nIn a statement, Columbia said that it \u201chas ended the administrative positions of Dr. Thomas Jessell and will be winding down the Jessell lab.\u201d", "title": "Columbia Removes Thomas Jessell, Renowned Neuroscientist, From His Posts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The three bottles I recommended were: Ch\u00e2teau Aney Haut-M\u00e9doc 2013, Ch\u00e2teau Moulin de Tricot Haut-M\u00e9doc 2013 and Ch\u00e2teau le Puy Emilien Francs C\u00f4te de Bordeaux 2013.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe two Haut-M\u00e9docs are from the so-called Left Bank, the region to the west of the Garonne River encompassing the M\u00e9doc north of the city of Bordeaux and Graves to the south. The Emilien is from Francs C\u00f4te de Bordeaux on the Right Bank, the area north and east of the Dordogne River.\n\nThe Aney and Moulin de Tricot are both dominated by cabernet sauvignon, grown on gravel soils, supplemented by merlot. The le Puy, by contrast, is mostly merlot grown on clay and limestone, with some cabernet franc and cabernet sauvignon.\n\nOne reader, NK of Washington, D.C., was perplexed by the choices.\n\n\u201cWhy did you pick two Left Banks and one Right Bank?\u201d he asked. \u201cSeems like we would be comparing apples to oranges.\u201d\n\nWell, sort of. Except in this case we were talking about the larger entity of Bordeaux rather than the specific terroir of one appellation within that region. In addition, I\u2019m thrilled that so many readers take the challenge of buying three bottles and comparing them. That adds another dimension to Wine School. But I don\u2019t expect all readers to do that, and it is not necessary. All you need is one of the bottles to participate.\n\nNow, many readers drank wines from other vintages, and found enjoyable wines, bearing out the original intent of the selections. But even those who drank the 2013s found some pleasure in the wines.\n\nFor me, the 2013s recalled Bordeaux I drank in the 1980s, resolutely dry, with flavors more herbal than fruity. Consumer tastes have evolved over the last 30 years, and many people would describe these wines as lean and weedy. Napa Valley, known for the opulent fruitiness of its wines, would fall to its knees and beg forgiveness if it produced bottles like these. But honestly, these wines are a lot easier to drink with food today than many highly praised Napa bottles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe key element here is \u201cwith food.\u201d I believe that wine is at its best as part of the synergy of food, wine and conversation, even if the conversation is simply an internal dialogue. And that, to me, is how these 2013s need to be enjoyed.\n\nWithout food, they were tart and somewhat cedary. More modern styles of Bordeaux, which you would see in vintages like 2012 or 2015, are rounder, fruitier and easier-going. You can enjoy a glass on its own, even though it would still improve with food. For me, the 2013s came alive with braised pork shoulder, fulfilling the bottom-line requirement of a wine, as is generally the case with classic Bordeaux, of simply being a good, fresh drink.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Moulin de Tricot was herbal, straightforward and refreshing. The Aney seemed a bit riper and smoother, though also compact and refreshing. The le Puy had almost a menthol edge to its aroma. It seemed a trifle richer than the Haut-M\u00e9docs, and a little more tannic. It was pure and also refreshing.\n\nreader perspectives Eric Asimov, The New York Times\n\nwine critic, is talking about\n\nvalue Bordeaux.\n\nIf you would like to join the conversation,\n\ntry one of the bottles listed here and as you try them, ask yourself these questions. Eric Asimov, The New York Timeswine critic, is talking aboutvalue Bordeaux.If you would like to join the conversation,try one of the bottles listed here and as you try them, ask yourself these questions. Freshness Are the wines alive and vibrant? Drinkability Do they refresh? Food Taste them before you eat. Are they different with food? respond\n\nNone of these bottles really have the potential to age. They lack structure, and the tart flavors will not evolve in particularly attractive ways. Yet these wines have their uses. They are ready to drink now, and if they are on a restaurant wine list, a 2013 might be preferable to a wine from a better vintage that is not yet ready to drink. But I would not want to pay a lot of money for them.\n\nRegardless of the particulars of these \u201913s, the question comes up: What priority should consumers place on vintages?\n\nFor many simple wines, like the vins de soifs we drank last summer, vintage will not be particularly important. But for wines that will evolve and develop nuance and complexity over time, vintage can be crucial to their personality \u2014 though not as important as the skill, intent and conscientiousness of the producer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn my experience, when thinking about vintages, too much emphasis is placed on those years that critics have deemed great. These years often require many years of aging before they can be pleasurable.\n\nMeanwhile, years that may not conform to certain definitions of great may still offer great pleasures, while being cheaper and ready to drink far sooner.\n\nI have seen this in Burgundy, where people flocked to the \u201999, \u201902, \u201905 and \u201909 vintages. Many of these wines are still developing, while the \u201900 and \u201907 vintages, far less esteemed, have given plenty of pleasure in the interim. Even the 2004s, which have been roundly assailed as peculiarly green, can offer pleasure. I recently drank a gorgeous \u201904 Chambolle-Musigny from Jacques-Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Mugnier.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe same phenomenon occurs in Bordeaux. With all the millennial hype paid to the 2000 vintage, 2001, a very good year, was largely ignored. The 2011 vintage was completely overshadowed by the critically acclaimed 2009s and \u201910s. And in Napa Valley, you can find some awfully good 2011s, a vintage that was essentially dismissed as an ugly duckling.\n\nI could go on and on with that sort of thing. But that does not mean the critics were wrong about the 2013 Bordeaux. Those wines are certainly drinkable, but if you have an opportunity, compare them with the 2014s, which, to my mind, is an absolutely delicious vintage. The \u201914s will offer far more pleasure, more nuance and complexity, and will evolve beautifully. Nonetheless, the critics prefer the 2015s, which are richer and rounder.\n\nSome readers agreed with me that these wines required food. Dan Barron of New York described the \u201913 Moulin de Tricot as a \u201creserved, elegant wallflower.\u201d\n\n\u201cBefore food, it was no one\u2019s favorite,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIt only shone \u2014 or let\u2019s say \u2018glowed\u2019 \u2014 with the lamb, where its weight lent balance and dignity.\u201d\n\nAnd Joseph of Ile de France found a lot to like in the le Puy. With c\u00f4te de boeuf and potatoes, he wrote, it showed \u201cvibrancy and depth.\u201d\n\nNaturally, not everybody saw it as I did. Without food, George Erdle of Charlotte, N.C., found the Aney to be \u201ca harmonious, light, friendly wine that showed a lot of vibrancy.\u201d With beef tacos, he said, it was overwhelmed.\n\nNot everybody will agree with my assessments of vintages, either. Compared with the \u201913s, Tom Lipton of Munich said, \u201cThe \u201912s were far better, and the \u201914s appear to be very tight, ungenerous.\u201d Personally, I far prefer 2014s to 2012s.\n\nSuch differences of opinion are exactly why educated wine consumers need to go beyond critics to drink for themselves. Only by calibrating a sense of their own tastes can people develop a sense of whom to pay attention to and whom to ignore. The voice in your own head knows best.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Come for the Values, Stay (or Leave) for the Vintage", "authors": ["Eric Asimov", "Wine School"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "No moment is too sacred to puncture: Scovell was invited to meet with Joss Whedon, the creator of \u201cBuffy the Vampire Slayer\u201d \u2014 then her favorite show on TV \u2014 about a staff position. She was 38 weeks pregnant at the interview. \u201cBoy, are you fat,\u201d Whedon said. (His producer followed up with, \u201cShould I put down a tarp?\u201d) She didn\u2019t get the job.\n\nIf the sprinkling of sociological terms like \u201cstereotype threat\u201d sounds familiar, it\u2019s because Scovell collaborated with Sheryl Sandberg on her study-laden blockbuster, \u201cLean In.\u201d Sandberg, the Facebook executive, provides the TED Talk-ready foreword to \u201cJust the Funny Parts,\u201d writing that \u201cwhoever said feminists weren\u2019t funny never met Nell.\u201d (At her own mother\u2019s funeral, Scovell, one of five siblings, held up an envelope and announced that it contained \u201cthe name of mom\u2019s favorite child.\u201d) A career in the entertainment industry \u2014 scaled like a jungle gym, not a ladder \u2014 meant Scovell lived \u201cLean In\u201d long before she wrote it, Sandberg says. \u201cJust the Funny Parts\u201d is a record of her scramble, retrofitted with post-\u201cLean In\u201d indignation. (She took Shandling\u2019s words as a compliment at first.)\n\nThe bar for contemporary women-in-comedy books was set in 2011 with Tina Fey\u2019s \u201cBossypants,\u201d which managed advice that was both hilarious and accurate \u2014 no pigtails or tube tops at the office, no diet foods in meetings and cry at work if you must because \u201cit terrifies everyone.\u201d Scovell\u2019s lessons are less jokey and more emotionally bare; she even confesses a few things that our feminist foremothers have taught us to keep buttoned up \u2014 like the lines that she crossed, too \u2014 which feels freeing. Over all, though, \u201cJust the Funny Parts\u201d functions best not when Scovell is recounting some backstage encounter on \u201cThe Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour\u201d or \u201cNewhart\u201d but when she\u2019s rankled. My first laugh came on Page 58, when Scovell, her contributions on a show once again ignored, asks a female co-worker: \u201cAm I corporeal? You can see and hear me, right?\u201d\n\nGender aside, her comedy bona fides are solid: Scovell is from a large, neurotic, bookish, mercilessly honest \u2014 though loving \u2014 Jewish family in Massachusetts. She went to Harvard and wrote for Spy magazine. With a few biographical tweaks, she could be Conan O\u2019Brien. (The two intersected as writers on a short-lived \u201980s talk show.) In typical overachiever fashion, even her failures \u2014 Scovell writes that she was too full of self-doubt to apply for The Harvard Lampoon \u2014 led her somewhere: She became a sportswriter for The Boston Globe, then moved to New York and got a staff job at Vanity Fair. But Scovell soon realized that her high-concept style was better suited for TV. \u201cWriting for TV made way more sense than writing for magazines,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd by sense, I mean money.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nFor aspiring writers, the book has just enough practical advice on story pitches and script editing to qualify as a how-to. \u201cWhen I write, I feel like an optometrist, constantly flipping between lenses and asking: \u2018Is this better? Is this?\u2019 Slowly, the work comes into focus,\u201d she explains. An appendix lists all of her jobs, from Lifetime movies to \u201cNCIS,\u201d and, more bracingly for those starting out, the dozens of scripts unproduced over her 30-year career. Along the way, she married an architect and had two sons, and she is brisk about the fact that her husband\u2019s staying at home with the boys \u2014 carting them around to sets as she wrote, produced and directed \u2014 is what made her employable.", "title": "Come-Ons, Takedowns and Insults: What It\u2019s Like to Write Comedy as a Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe had been struggling against voices. For at least a week she was fighting against them,\u201d Dr. Rosenbaum said. \u201cThey were screaming at her.\u201d\n\nThe day of the killings, the last thing Ms. Ortega claimed to remember was taking Lucia home to use the bathroom, Dr. Rosenbaum said. The psychiatrist said at that moment, the \u201cauditory hallucinations won over her and she went into an altered state of consciousness.\u201d\n\nDr. Rosenbaum said psychosis was the only logical explanation for the murders, as Ms. Ortega had told her relatives she cared deeply for the children. \u201cShe loved the children,\u201d she testified. \u201cThere is no reason she would want to hurt anybody other than the psychotic delusion she was experiencing.\u201d\n\nOn cross-examination, the lead prosecutor, Stuart Silberg, forced Dr. Rosenbaum to acknowledge Ms. Ortega had never mentioned to anyone, even her closest relatives, that the Devil or other voices had told her to kill the children.\n\nIn the months leading up to the crime, Ms. Ortega had talked about feeling depressed, about hearing voices and about being followed by shadows and a \u201cblack man,\u201d according to trial testimony. Yet it was not until months after the murders, when Dr. Rosenbaum interviewed her in a hospital, that Ms. Ortega said Satan had ordered her to kill the children.\n\n\u201cAfter the crime is when she starts telling you and other psychiatrists about how the Devil had been telling her to kill herself and the kids, correct?\u201d Mr. Silberg asked. \u201cYes,\u201d Dr. Rosenbaum replied.\n\nMr. Silberg also suggested that the number of wounds on the children told of a woman intent on killing, just as her two self-inflicted neck wounds proved she tried hard to end her own life. He said the evidence suggested \u201can intentional, thoughtful act.\u201d", "title": "Command From the Devil Drove Nanny to Kill, Psychiatrist Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Today, more than 99 percent of all new chips use the RISC architecture, according to the association.\n\n\u201cThis is the one fundamental idea that has been sustained over the last several decades of chip design,\u201d said Dave Ditzel, a chip industry veteran who studied with Mr. Patterson at Berkeley. Mr. Ditzel helped popularize many of the same ideas and is now building a new RISC chip at a start-up called Esperanto.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Patterson and Mr. Hennessy were interested in simpler chips because they ran faster, consumed less power, made life easier for chip designers and allowed machines to evolve at a faster rate. In the mid-1980s, new RISC chips emerged from two Silicon Valley start-ups, Sun Microsystems and MIPS Technologies, becoming the standard for the computer workstations and servers that underpinned big corporate operations.\n\nThose processors were eventually eclipsed by chips from Intel, which put its considerable muscle behind a competing design. But as computing expanded into smartphones, tablets, and other small devices \u2014 where power and space are at a premium \u2014 more and more chips used designs from a British company called ARM, short for Advanced RISC Machine.\n\nAs a book written by the two researchers in 1989, Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach, became the standard text for chip design, even Intel took a partial step toward the RISC idea. Its chips continued to use their own complex way of talking to a computer\u2019s software, but started to use some aspects of RISC.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIntel chips still drive the data centers that power the internet. But as these chips approach their physical limits, internet giants like Google, Facebook, and Amazon are pushing tasks onto a wide range of simpler processors that consume much less power, sparking a renaissance in chip design.\n\n\u201cComplexity is even more of an enemy than it was before,\u201d Mr. Ditzel said. \u201cWe have to design differently.\u201d\n\nMr. Patterson and Mr. Hennessy are at the heart of this change. Their book is now in its sixth edition. Mr. Hennessy is on the board of directors of Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet, after serving as the president of Stanford for 16 years. And Mr. Patterson works in the Google research lab that is designing low-powered chips specifically for artificial intelligence.\n\nAs time goes on, the world could move even more toward the RISC way of doing things, thanks to an organization called the RISC-V Foundation, which has published a chip architecture that anyone can use for free, said industry veteran Dennis Allison. The organization was founded by Dave Patterson and others from Berkeley.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI expect this to play a vital role in the future,\u201d Mr. Patterson said. \u201cAnd the architecture is not that different from what John and I described back in 1980.\u201d", "title": "Computer Chip Visionaries Win Turing Award", "authors": ["Cade Metz"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Feinstein, who has long pushed for a ban on assault weapons, had looked giddy at the president\u2019s meeting with lawmakers when Mr. Trump seemed open to new legislation to restrict the sale of the weapons. On Monday, she accused the president of having \u201ccompletely caved to the gun lobby.\u201d\n\nThe idea of arming teachers is vigorously opposed by many members of both parties, law enforcement officials and groups representing the nation\u2019s teachers. But it has been pushed for years by the N.R.A., which argues that arming school officials is the best way to protect students and teachers against a well-armed attacker. \u201cThe only way to stop a bad guy with a gun is with a good guy with a gun,\u201d the N.R.A. mantra has gone.\n\nOn Capitol Hill, several Republican senators sounded cool to the idea of federal involvement in arming teachers, saying it should be left to the states. \u201cThere would have to be tremendous training, tremendous effort to make that work,\u201d said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.\n\nThe White House on Sunday proposed creating the Federal Commission on School Safety, which would study the question of raising the minimum age for purchasing rifles. That proposal came just a day after Mr. Trump himself mocked the idea of federal commissions as ineffective.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t just keep setting up blue-ribbon committees,\u201d Mr. Trump said during a political rally on Saturday. The president said that members of such commissions do little more than \u201ctalk, talk, talk\u201d and then, \u201ctwo hours later, then they write a report.\u201d\n\nOn Capitol Hill, the energy has largely dissipated for the kind of expansive gun control legislation that Mr. Trump appeared to support earlier this month. But Mr. Steinberg, who was brought in by the building\u2019s developer, Taconic Investment Partners, to market the holdout, is aware of the abundance of luxury condos on the market in TriBeCa. So he has decided to throw in the parking space as an added enticement, on the theory that buyers with the wherewithal to purchase the apartment might also own a vehicle.\n\n\u201cYou can take the elevator down to your car,\u201d said Mr. Steinberg, estimating that the parking spot is worth about $1 million, based on the sale price for a similar perk in a nearby building. Stuff comes up in my head and it\u2019s a little bit enslaving.\n\nYou love watching reality TV with your husband.\n\nYes, sometimes, yes. Like \u201cAlaskan Bush People\u201d is an example. We used to watch \u201cMan v. Food\u201d in Ireland.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou once thought a devil lived in your linen closet.\n\nYes. And in the basement.\n\nYour husband\u2019s favorite movie is \u201cStep Brothers.\u201d", "title": "Confirm or Deny: Rebecca Miller", "authors": ["Maureen Dowd"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAt last year\u2019s Academy Awards, \u201cArrival\u201d won the Oscar for best sound editing. This was not to be confused with the award for best sound mixing, which went to \u201cHacksaw Ridge.\u201d\n\nThis year, the same movies \u2014 \u201cBaby Driver,\u201d \u201cBlade Runner 2049,\u201d \u201cDunkirk,\u201d \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d and \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi\u201d \u2014 are up for both awards.\n\nSo what\u2019s the difference? Isn\u2019t mixing levels a core part of sound editing? Not quite. In layman\u2019s terms, sound editing is about collecting the sounds needed for a film. Sound mixing refers to what is done after they are collected.\n\nThe sound editing category used to be known as sound effect editing, which is actually the more apt name. When scenes are shot, typically the focus is almost entirely on getting the dialogue and staging down pat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is left to the sound editors to put in other noise to complement the spoken words. This could be ambient sound, like an air-conditioner or the approach of a distant train. In the case of \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi,\u201d this would mean the sound of Luke\u2019s lightsaber in conjunction with the rustle of trees on Ahch-To, among many other sounds.", "title": "Confused by Sound Mixing vs. Sound Editing? We\u2019ve Got You.", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cShould New York Look Abroad to Get Out of Its Traffic Jam?\u201d (news article, Feb. 27):\n\nPioneered by the Nobel economics laureate William Vickrey at Columbia University in the 1950s, congestion pricing is the most local of solutions to Manhattan\u2019s traffic woes.\n\nThe fact that considering it amounts to looking abroad for \u201ca foreign fix,\u201d as your front-page photo caption puts it, is testament to decades of American political paralysis, particularly with regard to the deference with which we treat cars and their drivers.\n\nJONATHAN LEVINE\n\nANN ARBOR, MICH.\n\nThe writer is a professor of urban and regional planning at the University of Michigan.", "title": "Opinion | Congestion Pricing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "From the start, there was resistance from drivers, their advocates, commercial truckers and some elected officials \u2014 including state legislators \u2014 who saw congestion pricing as mainly benefiting Manhattan residents, at the expense of those from outside the borough who have to drive for work, school, medical appointments or other obligations because they do not have easy access to public transit or cannot use it.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t won the war yet on congestion pricing, but I did win this battle \u2014 it\u2019s not getting in the budget,\u201d said Assemblyman David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat who helped lead the opposition.\n\nStill, Mr. Cuomo and some congestion pricing advocates have sought to cast the new surcharge on for-hire vehicles as a first step toward congestion pricing, which would reduce car congestion and establish a long-term revenue source for public transportation. The task force had also recommended a per-ride surcharge of $2 to $5 on for-hire vehicles in a phased-in approach to congestion pricing.\n\nPeter Ajemian, a spokesman for the governor, said the new surcharge fees would \u201cprovide hundreds of millions of dollars in additional revenue to the M.T.A. every year,\u201d and called the budget \u201ca huge win for the millions of people who rely on mass transit every day.\u201d Fix NYC Transit, another coalition, said, \u201cthe governor and legislative leaders deserve credit for enabling New York to begin tackling our traffic and transit woes.\u201d\n\nThe budget agreement also expands an existing traffic camera program that targets drivers who block bus lanes, and provides funding for half of an $836 million emergency subway repair program, but would force the city to pay the remainder.\n\nSupporters of congestion pricing said they would continue to fight for a congestion zone and other measures.\n\n\u201cWe are disappointed that traffic challenges, aside from more bus enforcement cameras, are not addressed,\u201d said Kathryn Wylde, a member of the task force and president and chief executive of the Partnership for New York City, a group of the city\u2019s top business leaders. \u201cThe legislature is in session until the end of June, and congestion pricing can be taken up outside the budget, so we will continue to urge moving forward.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile congestion pricing has been shown to work in London, Stockholm and Singapore, it has stalled in New York since at least the 1970s. The last major effort in 2008 by then-Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to charge drivers $8 to enter a similar congestion zone in Manhattan, but died in Albany after legislative leaders refused to bring it to a vote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany had expected it to be different this time after Mr. Cuomo almost single-handedly revived congestion pricing last summer and assembled the task force, Fix NYC, to come up with a plan. Supporters saw the city\u2019s subway meltdown and daily traffic problems as giving new urgency and momentum to the issue.\n\nBut despite the backing of dozens of influential business, labor, transportation and community groups, congestion pricing\u2019s prospects again waned in Albany. In a sign of things to come, the congestion zone was not in budget amendments submitted by the governor, or in budget proposals by the Republican-led Senate and the Democrat-dominated Assembly.\n\nMr. Cuomo, a Democrat who faces re-election in November, came under increasing criticism from advocates who said he did not do enough to move congestion pricing forward. They pointed out that he did not aggressively line up legislative support as he had with other divisive issues such as same-sex marriage and the minimum wage \u2014 a suggestion the governor\u2019s aides rejected.\n\nIn recent weeks, the governor and his aides had sought to work around legislative opposition to the congestion zone by negotiating for authorization of about $200 million for infrastructure and technology investments for a congestion zone. The more controversial details of how it would actually work \u2014 the boundaries, prices, hours and any exemptions \u2014 would be shelved until next year or later.\n\nBut in the end, what they got was the surcharge on for-hire vehicles, whose skyrocketing numbers have added to congestion woes. It was Assembly leaders who initially proposed the $2.75 per-ride surcharge for Uber, Lyft and the other ride-hailing apps, though they have said the surcharge was not about congestion pricing but about raising money for the M.T.A.\n\nOther cities and states \u2014 including Chicago, Philadelphia and Portland, Ore. \u2014 have increasingly imposed fees or taxes on ride-hailing services to raise money. Last year, New York State also approved a 4 percent assessment on trips by the ride-hailing services that begin outside New York City (rides in the city are already subject to state and local taxes), which is expected to raise $24 million a year for the state\u2019s general fund.\n\nToday, more than 103,000 for-hire vehicles operate in New York City, or more than double the roughly 47,000 in 2013, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission. In contrast, yellow taxis are capped by city law at 13,587.\n\nAlix Anfang, a spokeswoman for Uber, which backed the Fix NYC plan, said that the company supported the new surcharge because it was limited to Manhattan, where there is more congestion and also more transportation options than in the other boroughs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe will continue to advocate for the adoption of a comprehensive congestion pricing plan that is applied to all vehicles because it is the best way to fully fund mass transit and reduce traffic in the central business district,\u201d she said.\n\nWhile the surcharge on taxis is lower, it is still a blow to an industry that has been decimated by the advent of ride-hailing apps.\n\nTaxi owners and drivers have argued that they should be exempt from any new fees because it is their rapidly expanding rivals who are creating much of the congestion, and because they pay far more for medallions that should already give them access to Manhattan streets.\n\n\u201cIt is deeply concerning and disappointing that the state is piling on costs on the yellow taxi industry when it is well known that the yellow taxi industry and its mainly immigrant medallion owners and drivers are struggling,\u201d said Ron Sherman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents medallion owners.", "title": "Congestion Pricing Falters in New York, Again", "authors": ["Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "At the White House, Mr. Trump\u2019s top advisers worked to put the best face on a package they conceded fell short of fully funding his priorities and contained many items he would rather not have accepted.\n\n\u201cIn order to get the defense spending, primarily, but all the rest of our priorities funded, we had to give away a lot of stuff that we didn\u2019t want to give away\u201d to Democrats, Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director, told reporters during a briefing where he also highlighted funding in important areas like the military, school safety, border security and combating the opioid crisis.\n\n\u201cMy job is to get the president\u2019s priorities funded, which this does,\u201d added Mr. Mulvaney, a onetime budget hawk in Congress who routinely voted against large spending packages and sidestepped a question on whether he would have done so for this week\u2019s measure. \u201cThe president wants it to pass and wants it to be signed.\u201d\n\nBut the bill landed with a thud among conservatives who are still on Capitol Hill. The House Freedom Caucus, whose founding members included Mr. Mulvaney, formally opposed it and sent a letter to Mr. Trump urging him to reject it.\n\nAnother founding member of the Freedom Caucus, Representative Jim Jordan, Republican of Ohio, said the spending bill was \u201cmaybe the worst bill I\u2019ve ever seen\u201d and recalled the 2016 election that put Republicans in full control of Washington.\n\n\u201cNov. 8, 2016, I doubt that the voters were saying, \u2018Put Republicans in power so that they can pass a bill that continues to fund sanctuary cities, continues to fund Planned Parenthood,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cReally? Really? That\u2019s what the election was about?\u201d\n\nAmong other things, the bill includes $1.6 billion for more than 90 miles of physical barriers along the border with Mexico, as well as related technology. But that sum is far short of what Mr. Trump would need to construct the expansive border wall that he promised in his campaign for president.", "title": "Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill, Averting a Shutdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The payday lending industry is pressing its friends in Congress to repeal rules that shield borrowers from short-term loans that trap them in debt at interest rates of 400 percent or more. The rules were issued last year by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in a last gasp of consumer financial protection before President Trump appointed Mick Mulvaney as its new chief.\n\nThe new administration is openly hostile to the rules \u2014 which become effective in August 2019 \u2014 and is clearly looking for ways to undermine them. Meanwhile, bills introduced in both the House and the Senate would repeal the rules outright, opening the door for the return of lending practices that make working-class families poorer.\n\nThe payday industry advertises itself as a source of \u201ceasy\u201d credit for workers who run short of money before their next paycheck and take out loans that are typically supposed to be repaid within two weeks. But there is nothing \u201ceasy\u201d about this arrangement, as the consumer protection bureau showed in a study of more than 12 million loans. Among other things, the research revealed that the industry relies on people who can almost never repay on time, which usually means they borrow over and over again.\n\nAmong the study\u2019s findings: Eighty percent of payday loans were rolled over or renewed within two weeks; three out of five loans were made to borrowers who paid more in fees than they borrowed; four out of five borrowers either defaulted or renewed a loan over the course of a year; and one in five payday borrowers \u2014 including elderly people on fixed income payments \u2014 remained mired in debt for the entire year.", "title": "Opinion | Congress Considers Going Easy on Predatory Lenders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "To this day, gun rights advocates dispute the study\u2019s findings. The N.R.A. pushed Congress in 1995 to stop the C.D.C. from spending taxpayer money on research that advocated gun control. Congress then passed the Dickey Amendment in 1996, and cut funding that effectively ended the C.D.C.\u2019s study of gun violence as a public health issue.\n\nThe result is that 22 years and more than 600,000 gunshot victims later, much of the federal government has largely abandoned efforts to learn why people shoot one another, or themselves, and what can be done to prevent gun violence.\n\nAfter the Parkland school massacre in Florida last month, lawmakers and gun control experts have demanded that the agency take up the issue of studying gun violence again, arguing that the federal law doesn\u2019t ban such research altogether but prohibits advocacy of gun control.\n\nAlex M. Azar II, the secretary for health and human services, said at a congressional hearing that he believed the C.D.C. should resume the work. \u201cWe\u2019re in the science business and the evidence-generating business,\u201d Mr. Azar said, \u201dand so I will have our agency certainly working in this field, as they do across the broad spectrum of disease control and prevention.\u2019\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nAt a meeting with reporters last week, Mr. Azar said that other priorities, like fighting the flu and Ebola, also competed for funds. He did not specify which subjects would be a priority, how much money he might ask Congress to allocate to gun violence research, or whether he will transfer money from other health agency programs.\n\nThere is no shortage of ideas \u2014 or criticism of the time lost in studying gun violence.\n\n\u201cWe have repeatedly and consciously turned our back on the problem,\u201d said Garen Wintemute, a professor of emergency medicine who in July started the Firearm Violence Research Center at the University of California, Davis, with funding from the state. \u201cHow many thousands of people are dead today who might have been alive if that research effort had been put in place and we had answered critical questions and set prevention measures in motion?\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a question that haunts researchers. In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook school shooting in 2012, President Obama directed the C.D.C. to reconsider gun violence research. The agency commissioned a report from the Institute of Medicine outlining priorities, but never followed up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe most pressing questions cited by the institute, now known as the National Academy of Medicine, still have no answers. Who is most likely to use a gun in a crime, and where does the gun come from? How often are guns used in domestic violence cases? How often are the people who are arrested for gun crimes the same individuals who actually bought the weapons?\n\nThen there is a separate set of questions about what kind of policy changes or prevention efforts actually reduce gun-related deaths and injuries.\n\nAndrew R. Morral, a senior behavioral scientist at the RAND Corporation, directed a recent study that found moderate evidence that background checks do reduce both firearm suicides and homicides. The report also said there is moderate evidence that stand-your-ground laws, which allow people to use guns to defend themselves without first trying to retreat, may increase the murder rate.\n\n\u201cIn many cases, we\u2019ve been having arguments about factual matters for decades,\u201d Mr. Morral said. As an example, he cited laws that seek to prevent children from killing themselves or others with guns.\n\n\u201cThe N.R.A. has argued that such laws make it tough for people to defend themselves in a crisis,\u201d Mr. Morral said. \u201cBut there\u2019s no research on that. We\u2019ve argued and argued and argued, and we have not invested in the research needed to answer the question: What is the trade-off between childhood deaths and self-defense?\u2019\u2019\n\nThe new set of proposals by President Trump calls for a commission to examine whether to raise the age to 21 from 18 for young people to buy certain firearms. Just after the Parkland killings, Mr. Trump repeatedly supported raising the age, but the latest proposals do not include such a measure \u2014 one that the N.R.A. opposes.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Thomas R. Frieden, who was director of the C.D.C. from 2009 to 2017, said in an email that he believed the study of firearms-related violence was important even though little was conducted during his tenure.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why year after year I asked Congress to fund C.D.C. to do research in this area,\u201d Dr. Frieden said. \u201dWe need to know which interventions are most effective and how they can best be implemented to save the most lives.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Congress refused to include funding for those proposals, he said. The National Institutes of Health has continued to fund some gun violence research, including violent crimes related to drug and alcohol consumption, and parental roles in preventing injury from firearms.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nN.I.H. is also assessing ways to reduce suicides and accidental deaths among children and adolescents and war veterans. More than 60 percent of all gun deaths in the United States are suicides.\n\nThe Justice Department also studies gun violence, but the budget for that research is a small fraction of what the federal government spends on looking at other high-mortality hazards, like car accidents or smoking \u2014 money that has led to actions that greatly reduced deaths in both categories.\n\nPrivate foundations have stepped up to fill the gap. But there is another congressional roadblock that private money cannot circumvent \u2014 the Tiahrt Amendments, which prevent the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives from sharing its firearms-tracking database with anyone outside of law enforcement.\n\nThose records, Mr. Morral and other experts say, are crucial to analyze the flow of guns used in crimes over state borders, from places where guns are easy to buy to places where it is tougher.\n\nThe Dickey Amendment technically did not ban gun research, only advocacy. Its real goal \u2014 one it easily achieved, according to public health officials in place at the time \u2014 was to scare federal agencies into thinking twice about even collecting data that might reflect badly on gun ownership.\n\nSince the Parkland murders, there have been signs of change. Several Republican lawmakers said they would support the C.D.C. taking on the issue.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a tremendous misunderstanding here and maybe an overabundance of caution on the part of C.D.C. and N.I.H.,\u201d said Representative Tom Cole, of Oklahoma, chairman of a House appropriations subcommittee that oversees funding for the health and human services department.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Cole also said he expected there would be money available for such work at both N.I.H. and C.D.C., but not until next year\u2019s appropriations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome Democrats are pressing to take advantage of the new mood on Capitol Hill. Senator Patty Murray, of Washington, the ranking Democrat on the health committee, and Senator Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, have both pressed Mr. Azar for details, but as of Friday neither had received a response.\n\n\u201cFrom fighting cancer to decreasing road traffic fatalities, public health research has played a critical role in saving lives,\u201d Ms. Murray wrote to Mr. Azar. \u2018\u2018It is immoral and unacceptable to treat gun violence any differently.\u201d\n\nIn the House of Representatives, Democratic members of the Committee on Energy and Commerce have called for a hearing on the adequacy of federal research into gun violence.\n\nJennifer Baker, a spokeswoman for the N.R.A., said the group continues to support the Dickey Amendment. \u201cWe oppose taxpayer dollars being spent to advocate for gun control,\u201d Ms. Baker said.\n\nAsked if there is any type of research the group would support, she said the N.R.A. would like to see a study of how often firearms are used in self-defense.\n\nThe Institute of Medicine report, published with the National Research Council, is still considered a road map by the C.D.C. The report proposed research on issues like motivations for gun ownership and use; the relationship between poverty and gun use; risk factors that lead youths to carry guns; and dozens of other questions.\n\nThe C.D.C. did ask for and receive money to expand its National Violent Death Reporting System, which tracks homicides and suicides in 40 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The project aims to help state health departments develop strategies to reduce violent deaths, but some critics say the database lacks sufficient detail to be very useful.\n\nResearch proponents want to make sure that new studies don\u2019t serve as an excuse for a lack of action on gun control.\n\n\u201cAlthough more gun research is needed,\u201d Dr. Frieden said, \u201cthere are proven means to reduce gun violence, including better background checks, getting guns away from domestic abusers and people convicted of violent crimes, and safe storage. More research can help. But this is no excuse for inaction.\u201d", "title": "Congress Quashed Research Into Gun Violence. Since Then, 600,000 People Have Been Shot.", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "In this time of political division, the broad story line of the omnibus spending bill approved late last week is largely a heartening one. With the Democratic leadership in full resistance mode and the Republicans facing a treacherous political climate in the fall elections, Congress repudiated President Trump\u2019s extreme budget cuts in rare bipartisan fashion. In doing so, it protected a range of domestic programs the president had targeted for huge reductions, if not outright elimination, and sent an infuriated Mr. Trump scuttling off to Mar-a-Lago with yet another problem to worry about: a mediocre Congress making a lazy president look even worse by actually accomplishing something.\n\nA cynic observing this unusual Capitol Hill lovefest could plausibly argue that it\u2019s easy enough for Republicans and Democrats to link arms when there\u2019s serious money to be spent. And it is: There is plenty of old-fashioned pork in this bill. Even so, it is hard to argue with an outcome that preserved and in some cases increased funding for vital health, education, foreign aid, infrastructure and environmental programs while providing a fraction of what Mr. Trump wanted for his border wall \u2014 the presumed reason for his choleric withdrawal to his Florida fortress.\n\nThere is another story line within the broader one, and it too is heartening: the willingness of the Democratic leadership to stand up to mischief-makers in Congress itself. A bill of this magnitude \u2014$1.3 trillion altogether, including hundreds of billions for the military \u2014 is fertile ground for legislators who wish to sneak in provisions that are unlikely to survive on their own and thus need the protective cover of a big must-pass bill. As a rule, these so-called riders have nothing to do with spending and are aimed primarily at changing policy or undermining basic laws.\n\nMost of the most damaging riders in the bill were devised by Republicans and involved environmental policy. Among other things, they would have delayed enforcement of clean-air regulations, killed two Obama-era rules aimed at reducing greenhouse gases from oil and gas wells, weakened protections for endangered species and insulated the Trump administration from legal challenges to its efforts to repeal clean-water rules.", "title": "Opinion | Congress Resists the President, for a Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Another sticking point in recent days was funding for a series of rail infrastructure projects in the New York City area known as the Gateway program, including a new tunnel under the Hudson River. Despite his New York roots, Mr. Trump zeroed in on Gateway and urged Republican leaders not to provide federal funds for it \u2014 an apparent rebuke to Mr. Schumer, whose caucus the president has repeatedly accused of obstructionism.\n\nThe spending bill does not include $900 million in funding for Gateway that had been included last year in House legislation. But according to a senior Senate Democratic aide, it includes hundreds of millions of dollars that could go toward the Gateway program, including funds that do not require the approval of Mr. Trump\u2019s Transportation Department.\n\nAs November\u2019s midterm elections loom, the legislation also includes $380 million for grants to states to improve their election infrastructure and bolster election security.\n\nAnd although Congress has shown little appetite for passing significant gun control legislation in response to the mass shooting last month in Parkland, Fla., the spending bill includes a modest measure to improve reporting to the national background check system for gun purchases. It also includes a measure to provide grants to improve school safety.\n\nCongress approved a broad two-year budget deal last month that paved the way for this week\u2019s legislation. That deal set overall spending levels, raising strict limits on military and domestic spending by a total of about $140 billion this year. The spending bill this week allocates the allowed spending among a vast array of federal programs.\n\nThe bill is long overdue, coming almost halfway through the 2018 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. Since then, Congress has needed five stopgap spending measures to keep the government open. By snapping that streak of short-term patches, lawmakers would provide a dose of stability to federal agencies that have been left in limbo as Congress lurched from one stopgap measure to the next.\n\nEven with the spending bill unveiled, there is still some risk of a brief shutdown this weekend, as any one senator can stop the Senate from speeding up consideration of the bill to meet Friday\u2019s deadline. Last month, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, did just that, causing an hourslong shutdown as he bemoaned the government\u2019s mounting debt.", "title": "Congressional Leaders Agree on $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill as Deadline Looms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Andrew J. McDonald, the nominee to be chief justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, was rejected on Tuesday by the State Senate, ending an unusually acrimonious process that has been rocked by claims of judicial activism, homophobia and close ties to the governor who appointed him.\n\nHis confirmation failed, 19 to 16, with one Democrat joining with Republicans and another abstaining from voting.\n\n\u201cThe enormous honor of leading the Connecticut judiciary as an independent and coequal branch of government will now fall to another,\u201d Justice McDonald said in a statement after the vote. \u201cIn this turbulent personal moment, I don\u2019t know what the future holds for me. I do know, however, that I will face it secure in the love and affection of my husband, Charles, and an amazing group of friends and family.\u2019\u2019\n\nJustice McDonald, who had been easily confirmed when he was nominated as an associate justice in 2013, faced robust opposition mounted by Republicans angered over his role in a Supreme Court decision on the repeal of the death penalty and his relationship with the governor, Dannel P.
