Is it possible to use external devices with an iPad Pro, particularly for file storage?\n\nA. The iPad Pro has a Lightning port for connecting a charger, syncing data over a USB cable or attaching peripherals. Any external devices (aside from headphones) must be compatible with that jack or wirelessly pair up with the iPad by Bluetooth.\n\nSeveral companies make Lightning-tipped USB flash drives that also have a standard USB connector on the other end that plugs into a computer to transfer files. Leef, Omars, Picture Keeper and SanDisk are among the companies that make these types of drives, and prices generally start around $45.\n\n(The iPad Pro can also store and download photos, videos, documents and other files on a cloud server or drive over a wireless-network connection. Apple\u2019s own iCloud Drive is one example, but as with other services, you have to pay for more server space if your files exceed your free storage limit.)", "title": "Connecting Hardware to an iPad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen your message is simply I am for new leadership and cleaning up Washington, and you look like you just walked out of an Orvis catalog, you are going to connect with voters on both sides of the aisle,\u201d wrote Salena Zito in The Washington Examiner late last week.\n\n\u201cLamb never slams Trump,\u201d she observed. \u201cHe is not part of the resistance.\u201d He further blunted Republicans\u2019 favorite weapon against Democratic candidates for the House \u2014 they\u2019re just would-be pawns of the dreaded Nancy Pelosi! \u2014 by running an ad that made clear that he would not support her as his party\u2019s leader in that chamber.\n\nThe point that Zito was correctly making was that many of the Democrats who will vie to unseat Republican incumbents in House races in November won\u2019t be able to follow Lamb\u2019s playbook. To get through their party\u2019s primaries, they\u2019ll have to stake out more progressive ground than he did, and adopt a more combative, fiery tone. That could undercut their chances of replicating his success.\n\nIndeed, Democrats\u2019 euphoria over how he fared on Tuesday will give way to sharp internal tensions and sustained quarreling over which sorts of candidates \u2014 soft-spoken or bold, centrist or liberal, eclectic or pure \u2014 the party would be wisest, from a pragmatic standpoint, to promote. Many Democratic voters want someone less mild and muddled than Lamb.\n\nBut if the Pennsylvania results put Democrats in an awkward position, they leave Republicans in an even worse place. What exactly is their best strategy for the midterms?\n\nNot all of their candidates will be leagues better than Saccone, who is no Roy Moore and is himself a military veteran. Sending President Trump into districts that supposedly smile on him isn\u2019t looking like such a hot proposition. The mantra of \u201ctax cuts, tax cuts, tax cuts\u201d is obviously no panacea.\n\nAnd with each passing week \u2014 each passing day \u2014 the Trump administration\u2019s turbulence intensifies and the scandals and scandal-ettes pile up. Yes, it\u2019s a long way from now until November, and much about the national mood and the playing field can change. But in that yawning stretch of time, Trump can also render himself and his enablers even less attractive. I have faith.", "title": "Opinion | Conor Lamb Roared. Republicans Should Quake.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Conor Lamb, a Democrat and former Marine, scored a razor-thin but extraordinary upset in a special House election in southwestern Pennsylvania after a few thousand absentee ballots cemented a Democratic victory in the heart of President Trump\u2019s Rust Belt base.\n\nThe Republican candidate, Rick Saccone, may still contest the outcome. But Mr. Lamb\u2019s 627-vote lead Wednesday afternoon appeared insurmountable, given that the four counties in Pennsylvania\u2019s 18th district have about 500 provisional, military and other absentee ballots left to count, election officials said.\n\nThat slim margin \u2014 out of almost 230,000 ballots cast in a district that Mr. Trump carried by nearly 20 percentage points in 2016 \u2014 nonetheless upended the political landscape ahead of November\u2019s midterm elections. It also emboldened Democrats to run maverick campaigns even in deep-red areas where Republicans remain bedeviled by Mr. Trump\u2019s unpopularity.\n\nRepublican officials in Washington said they were likely to demand a recount through litigation, and the National Republican Congressional Committee put out a call for voters to report any irregularities in the balloting. Matt Gorman, a spokesman for the committee, said the party was \u201cnot conceding anything.\u201d", "title": "Conor Lamb Wins Pennsylvania House Seat, Giving Democrats a Map for Trump Country", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nI\u2019m intrigued by one of the ways that Conor Lamb appealed to cultural conservatives in his Pennsylvania congressional campaign. He said that, as a Catholic, he is personally opposed to abortion but that he does not favor new anti-abortion laws.\n\nThis position still makes him pro-choice, of course, even if he rejects the label. It won\u2019t win over committed abortion opponents (like National Review\u2019s Alexandra DeSanctis, who criticized Lamb as a hypocrite).\n\nYet I still find Lamb\u2019s framing to be important. Personal opposition to abortion isn\u2019t just a catchphrase. It has real implications. People who are opposed to abortion \u2014 as well as those who have deep qualms about it \u2014 are unlikely to have fetuses tested for conditions like Down syndrome, to take one example. They\u2019re more likely to believe that babies with the syndrome have as much right to life as those without it.", "title": "Opinion | Conor Lamb and Abortion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Regardless of who wins the special House election in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, the Democratic candidate, Conor Lamb, has already accomplished something impressive by showing that his party ought to contest every election \u2014 no matter how daunting the odds.\n\n\u201cYou miss 100 percent of the shots you don\u2019t take,\u201d goes the line often attributed to the hockey great Wayne Gretzky and quoted in school gymnasiums ever since. It\u2019s a lesson that bears repeating to Democratic Party leaders, who in recent years effectively surrendered many seats to Republicans under the mistaken belief that Democrats had no chance. For example, the party did not bother fielding candidates during the 2016 and 2014 elections for Pennsylvania\u2019s 18th Congressional District seat, which recent polls show Mr. Lamb could narrowly win on Tuesday. While Donald Trump won the district by 20 percentage points, it has a large population of union members and more registered Democrats than Republicans.\n\nMr. Lamb, a former Marine and prosecutor, has campaigned energetically and made striking gains without much help from his party. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has put up a small fraction of the money that Republican groups are spending. Even if Mr. Lamb loses on Tuesday, analysts say he could easily win in November, when Pennsylvanians will vote under a new congressional map ordered by the State Supreme Court in an important gerrymandering lawsuit.\n\nThere is no doubt that Mr. Lamb has benefited from running against a lackluster opponent, Rick Saccone, who even many Republicans have privately grumbled is a \u201cweak\u201d candidate. But Mr. Saccone\u2019s weakness, which now seems obvious, would not have been much of a factor in the race had Mr. Lamb not decided to run in the first place. Without a serious Democratic challenger, Mr. Saccone might have coasted to victory like the last person to hold the seat, Tim Murphy, a Republican who resigned after it was revealed that he had encouraged a woman he was having an affair with to have an abortion even though he publicly opposed the procedure. The same argument applies in the case of the special Senate election in Alabama last year, in which the Democrat Doug Jones triumphed against Roy Moore, a Republican who several women said harassed and abused them when they were teenagers and he was in his 30s.", "title": "Opinion | Conor Lamb\u2019s Lesson for Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA profile update is an event we store on the blockchain and will subsequently update the live contract,\u201d Rick Schmitz, a co-creator of LegalFling, recently said. The transaction is encrypted, timestamped and stored. (A blockchain is a collection of digital transactions that are registered in a sequence of \u201cblocks\u201d of data.)\n\nWill these apps revolutionize sex? Not likely. As complex human beings with ever-changing desires, we may not fit so neatly into click-and-consent existence portrayed in that \u201cBlack Mirror\u201d episode, or envisioned by the app developers. But they are making steps toward addressing a problem that needs solving.\n\nWhen yes becomes no.\n\nDr. Michelle Drouin, a leading expert on technology and relationships, said the apps are good at documenting consent, but don\u2019t account much for fluctuating human emotions. They don\u2019t necessarily allow for any immediacy of one\u2019s feelings, she said.\n\nUse of the app \u201chas to be planned,\u201d she said, \u201cand it\u2019s really difficult for us to even know how we feel in the present moment, much less trying to anticipate how we might feel an hour from now.\u201d\n\nMr. Schmitz said that a LegalFling agreement does not override someone changing his or her mind in the moment or being too intoxicated, for example, to consent. The company suggests you withdraw consent via the app at that moment, but, of course, that\u2019s not always possible.\n\nIf encounters leave users feeling violated, Mr. Schmitz said, they should notify the aggressor afterward in a message, and it will be added to the record.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlso possible with a tap: triggering cease-and-desist letters, according to the website.\n\nThe creators of LegalFling, part of the blockchain company LegalThings, which digitized regulation for the Dutch government, said they decided to apply their technology to sexual consent when, in December, Sweden proposed a law that would require people to get explicit verbal consent before sexual contact.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Dr. Drouin is not sold on apps as a solution to a very human problem. The requirement to interact with an app during a sexual encounter is \u201ccompletely unrealistic,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cIt would be very awkward within the context of an intimate encounter to be like, \u2018Wait a second, I\u2019m changing my mind on the app and also with you,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nMore important, she said, the app could persuade someone to fulfill acts simply because they agreed to them in advance, or to overcommit in an effort to appear more sexually adventurous.\n\nLegitimate, but there are caveats.\n\nThese digital agreements could certainly be used as evidence of, at the time the button was pushed, what an individual\u2019s intent or desires were, according to Mr. Cherkasky. \u201cWe already see it all the time in social media or text messages,\u201d he said, adding that they would most likely be legally viable in cases globally, as well.\n\nBut these agreements do have the potential to be used as a means of protection to an aggressor, he said, especially by a violent and premeditating criminal. It\u2019s very common in domestic violence cases for an attacker to have a \u201cgreat deal of power over the person and force them to do a number of things,\u201d he said.\n\nEven implying that someone doesn\u2019t have the right to change their mind is a real risk, he said. Though the risk also exists for an accused person, who may have fully gotten consent in the moment even if \u201cthe box wasn\u2019t checked.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt turns consent into a joke, a technicality that people think is black and white or can be recorded in a moment of time,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut technology is reflecting a cultural shift in respecting and understanding the idea of consent, he said.\n\nDr. Drouin agreed: People are now communicating about these incidents in ways that are recordable and admissible in court, she said. \u201cIt\u2019s no longer \u2018he said, she said.\u2019\u201d\n\nAn app with a different lens.\n\nWhile LegalFling is the newest app hoping to address the rising tide of consent awareness, it\u2019s not the first. We-Consent, introduced in 2015 by the nonprofit Institute for the Study of Coherence and Emergence, was created for students on college campuses to help them adhere to the implementation of affirmative consent rules.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2014, California became the first state to require colleges to use affirmative consent as the standard in disciplinary decisions, which inspired the creation of We-Consent, said Michael Lissack, director of the institute.\n\nWe-Consent records a short video of two people stating their affirmative consent, according to the company, and uses facial recognition technology. That recording is encrypted and inaccessible without a legal petition.\n\nThere are over 100,000 encrypted files, Mr. Lissack said, but the institute has had only two requests ever to retrieve the videos. In both instances \u2014 before We-Consent turned in the videos \u2014 the fact that they were available spurred the cases to settle, Mr. Lissack said.\n\n\u201cFrom Day 1, the purpose of the app was to get people who are about do something to discuss what they\u2019re going to do with one another,\u201d he said.\n\nConsent can happen only from discussion, he said, \u201cnot from sending emoji back and forth, nodding your head or signing some weird legal agreement.\u201d", "title": "Consent in the Digital Age: Can Apps Solve a Very Human Problem?", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Given the partisan tumult of 2017, many Americans probably feel like they could use a cold shower or a hot bath. In stressful times like these, it can help to find a relaxation regimen, which might explain the popularity of Eastern traditions like tai chi, qigong and yoga.\n\nThe photographer Andy Richter, a Minnesota native and former ski patrolman, has been devoted to his yoga practice since 2004. In 2012, he set out on a mission to deeply explore yoga, including visiting with many masters.\n\n\u201cThe times we\u2019re living in, there\u2019s a lot of pressure on us that is really nonstop,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need tools and ways to be able to control our inner state. I\u2019m not just there trying to illustrate a posture or pose. I\u2019m trying to tune into what\u2019s going on before me, and really transmit this inner experience that the yogi in front of me is having.\u201d", "title": "Contemplating Yoga Around the World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "at 2 minutes 14 seconds\n\nSheer Imagination\n\nThe pianist Stephen Hough\u2019s perceptive essay on Debussy, which appeared recently in The New York Times, got me thinking about different approaches to this seminal composer, who died 100 years ago this month. Painterly colors and milky textures are requisite, of course. But details matter in Debussy, and I have problems with pianists who, in the name of \u201cimpressionism,\u201d are too slack with rhythm. So I was surprised by how much I loved this video of the extraordinary (and reclusive) Italian pianist Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli playing both books of \u201cImages\u201d in the 1960s. From the opening of the first piece, \u201cReflections on the Water,\u201d Michelangeli is liberal in his use of rubato. But he makes it work. And the colors and shadings, the cool beauty, the sheer imagination of his playing are remarkable. Listen to the way, a couple minutes in, he draws out the demonic from below the watery surfaces of the music. ANTHONY TOMMASINI\n\nRead Mr. Hough\u2019s essay on Debussy\u2019s piano music.", "title": "Controlled Madness: The Week\u2019s Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCall it the Art Boomerang.\n\nOn the eve of the opening last October of its major fall exhibition, \u201cArt and China After 1989: Theater of the World,\u201d the Guggenheim Museum pulled three works after an outpouring of protest from animal-rights activists. Now, one of those works, Xu Bing\u2019s \u201cA Case Study of Transference,\u201d is coming back to the museum, this time as a valued part of its permanent collection, purchased with funds provided by an anonymous donor. The website ARTnews first reported the gift.\n\nThe controversial work is a video documentation of a 1994 performance in which two pigs, one imprinted with nonsensical English words and one stamped with fanciful Chinese characters, copulate before a live audience. It is a satirical take on the collision of East and West.\n\nInstead of showing the video, the museum displayed a blank monitor with a wall label explaining, \u201cFor Xu, who, like many intellectuals of his generation, had spent time on a farm during the Cultural Revolution and was familiar with animal husbandry, the performance was a literal and visceral critique of Chinese artists\u2019 desire for enlightenment through Western cultural \u2018transference.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cXu Bing\u2019s \u2018A Case Study of Transference\u2019 is recognized as an iconic work of conceptual and performance art from China during this period and is now part of the exhibition history,\u201d said Sarah Eaton, a spokeswoman for the Guggenheim, who told The New York Times that the museum might show the work there in the future.\n\nIt could also be shown elsewhere sometime soon. \u201cArt and China After 1989\u201d will travel to the Guggenheim Bilbao from May 11 to Sept. 23, 2018, and to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art from Nov. 10, 2018, to Feb. 24, 2019, although neither institution has finalized its checklist yet.\n\nThe Guggenheim Abu Dhabi already owns another work that was altered for the exhibition, Huang Yong Ping\u2019s \u201cTheater of the World\u201d (1993), an empty cage that was intended to be filled with live insects, lizards and snakes that would ostensibly feed off each other during the course of the three-month show. In response to the museum\u2019s intervention, the artist scribbled a note of protest in Chinese on an airsickness bag on his flight to New York from Paris where he lives. This work, titled \u201cVomit Bag\u201d (2017), was displayed in a vitrine at the show and is also under consideration for entering the Guggenheim\u2019s permanent collection.", "title": "Controversial Xu Bing Work Enters the Guggenheim Museum\u2019s Collection", "authors": ["Barbara Pollack"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are plenty of big, overloaded, chunky cookies out there, but Bang Cookies, in Jersey City, takes the genre a step further. The company\u2019s new line of big, overloaded, chunky cookies has fillings. And they are delicious. The chocolate cookie-covered strawberry jam one, oozing preserves, was the winner. There\u2019s another cookie filled with peanut butter and jelly, and a caramel sea salt chocolate flavor with a gooey center: Stuffed cookies, $5.50 each, regular cookies in nine flavors, $4.50 to $5, bangcookies.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Cookies That Deliver a Bang With Flavorful Fillings", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "After adopting a bitterly contested plan a few years ago to charge students tuition for the first time in a century, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art announced Thursday that it hoped to make the college tuition-free again for all undergraduates in 10 years.\n\nUnder a plan approved by the board of trustees late Wednesday, Cooper Union would begin increasing tuition scholarships in two years, and aim to provide full tuition in 10. The additional outlay would be offset by unspecified cuts in expenses, more fund-raising and \u201cother revenue increases necessary,\u201d the college said in a statement.\n\n\u201cIf we exceed the financial targets in any given year, we may be able to accelerate the plan; if we don\u2019t meet the targets for any number of reasons, such as an economic downturn, we have built-in guardrails that allow us to slow the plan if necessary,\u201d said Laura Sparks, Cooper Union\u2019s president, who took office in January 2017.\n\nThe decision comes at a time when affordability has become an increasingly urgent issue in higher education, for both private and public institutions. The Excelsior Scholarship, rolled out by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo last year, offers free tuition to middle-class students at the State University of New York and the City University of New York.", "title": "Cooper Union Announces Plan to Reinstate Free Tuition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I thought you were supposed to be able to cut and paste content between Macs and iPhones, but I can\u2019t make it work.\n\nA. The Universal Clipboard tool allows people to copy text, images and videos on one Apple device and then paste the content into an app on another Apple device. The feature arrived in 2016 with iOS 10 and macOS Sierra, but you need to meet a few other conditions to use it. (Some apps, like Notes, can sync content between iOS and macOS automatically with iCloud.)\n\nYou need to be logged into the same iCloud account with the same Apple ID on all of the hardware in the mix. You can check the accounts in the iCloud system preference on the Mac and in the iOS settings on the iPhone; if you have multiple Apple IDs \u2014 like an old one used for iTunes Store purchases and another you created to set up a new iPad \u2014 you may be logged in under two different accounts.\n\nUniversal Clipboard is part of Apple\u2019s Continuity technology, and it generally requires at least iOS 10 on an iPhone 5, and macOS Sierra on Mac computers released in 2012 or later. Both the iOS gadgets and the Mac must have Wi-Fi and Bluetooth enabled, as well as the Handoff feature that allows one Apple device to pick up, using certain apps, where another let off.", "title": "Copy Here, Paste There", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCorinne Elizabeth Hagans and Derrick Arthur Morrison were married March 24 at the Yards Brewery in Philadelphia. Nathan Frew, an Assemblies of God pastor and a friend of the couple, officiated.\n\nMrs. Morrison, 29, work at BounceU, a children\u2019s amusement center. She is general manager of two locations, one in Elmsford, N.Y., the other in Nanuet, N.Y. She received an associate degree from Johnson & Wales University in Denver. She is a daughter of Ernest T. Hagans of Cherry Hill, N.J., and the late Pamela R. Hagans.\n\nMr. Morrison, also 29, is a New York-based actor, known as Derrick Arthur. His movie and television credits include \u201cDelivery Man,\u201d \u201cPeople Places Things,\u201d and \u201cThe Humbling.\u201d He graduated with a degree in acting from the New York Conservatory for Dramatic Arts. He is the son of Deanna Morrison and Arthur Morrison of Grand Island, Neb.", "title": "Corinne Hagans, Derrick Morrison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "FRONT PAGE\n\nAn article on Wednesday about a political standoff between the National Rifle Association and Delta Air Lines, using information provided by a consulting firm working for Delta, misstated the airline\u2019s estimate of its economic impact on Georgia. It is $8.65, not $2.90.\n\nNATIONAL\n\nAn article on Tuesday about complaints filed against White House officials for apparent violations of the Hatch Act described incorrectly the process by which such violations are punished. The decision to punish White House officials for violating the Hatch Act is made by the president or the Office of Special Counsel, which can request that the Merit Systems Protection Board take disciplinary action. It is not the case that cabinet secretaries play a role in deciding how and whether to discipline violators of the law.\n\nBUSINESS DAY\n\nAn article on Tuesday about self-piloted electric planes being tested in New Zealand misstated the wingspan of the Cora aircraft. It is 36 feet, not 12 feet.\n\nSPORTS\n\nAn article on Tuesday about teams capable of causing upsets in the N.C.A.A. tournament misstated the surname of a Loyola player. While Ms. Haspel oversaw the site during the torture of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri at the site, she did not supervise the interrogation and waterboarding of the suspected Qaeda operative Abu Zubaydah. Following Ms. Haspel\u2019s nomination this week to head the C.I.A., The Times published a profile of Ms. Haspel, detailing how her career was shaped by her time running the prison and her willingness to take part in the agency\u2019s rendition, detention and interrogation program. During that reporting, a former senior C.I.A. official confirmed that Ms. Haspel arrived at the Thai detention site after Mr. Zubaydah\u2019s interrogation had concluded.\n\nCORRECTIONS\n\nNATIONAL\n\nAn article on Thursday about a second round of tax cuts alluded to by the president, relying on a Fox Business Network transcript, misquoted Representative Kevin Brady, Republican of Texas. It was 2015, not 2014.\n\n\u2022\n\nA news analysis last week about populists\u2019 admiration of Vladimir Putin misidentified a political office once held by Silvio Berlusconi. At the last trial, prosecutors relied on an exception that permits such evidence when it shows conduct so similar it can be argued that it demonstrates a common scheme or plan, a kind of unique signature of the defendant.\n\nFor the retrial, prosecutors are also relying on a new argument, the \u201cdoctrine of chances,\u201d which essentially argues that the more times an event takes place, the less plausible it becomes that it happened by mistake.\n\nProsecutors and Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers tussled over what parts of a civil case that Ms. Constand brought against him in 2005 could be referred to at trial. That suit ended with a financial settlement and a confidentiality agreement, and the lawyers bickered over what details from those matters and the accompanying negotiations should be admitted.\n\nAnd the two sides argued over whether Mr. Cosby\u2019s team would be able to call as a witness Marguerite Jackson, a student adviser at Temple University, where Ms. Constand was employed when the episode with Mr. Cosby occurred. Ms. Jackson has said that years ago Ms. Constand told her that she had been drugged and assaulted by a famous person, then later said it had not happened, but that making such a complaint could result in a valuable lawsuit settlement.\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers said they intended to include Ms. Jackson in their opening statement at trial. Prosecutors have objected to her testimony on several grounds, including the contention that it constitutes hearsay. Judge O\u2019Neill did not allow her to testify at the first trial.\n\nThe judge said he might wait until the trial, on April 2, to decide both issues. He said no one could really say whether the #MeToo movement had already influenced the potential jury pool. But he said that a wide sampling of potential jurors had been sent some 3,500 notices and questionnaires as part of the effort to to begin the jury selection process.", "title": "Cosby Lawyers: #MeToo Moment Makes a Fair Trial Difficult", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Kathleen Bliss, a lawyer for Mr. Cosby, argued that the defense had received new information about Ms. O\u2019Neill\u2019s activities since the issue surfaced more than a year ago. The defense had argued that Ms. O\u2019Neill had donated \u201cmarital assets\u201d to V-Day UPenn, a campus group that gave money to another organization that plans to demonstrate outside the courthouse when the retrial begins.\n\n\u201cWe did not know and we could not have known that this group planned a protest,\u201d Ms. Bliss said, referring to the planned demonstration outside the courthouse. \u201cWe have a different set of circumstances here.\u201d\n\nBut the judge dismissed that defense claim, saying that he had a University of Pennsylvania document that showed the school, not his wife, had made the donation.\n\nAmong the additional accusers who will be allowed to testify in the coming trial will be Janice Dickinson, a former supermodel who says Mr. Cosby drugged and raped her in a Nevada hotel room in 1982, according to The Associated Press.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJudge O\u2019Neill ruled several weeks ago to allow testimony from five additional women who the prosecution says will show that Mr. Cosby was engaged in a distinct pattern of sexual assault that involved providing the women with drugs or alcohol before assaulting them. That situation is similar to that described by Andrea Constand, the former Temple University employee whom Mr. Cosby is accused of molesting in 2004.\n\nMr. Cosby is charged only in connection with his encounter with Ms. Constand, which occurred at his home outside Philadelphia. He says it was consensual, and he has denied all other accounts of sexual abuse.\n\nJurors will be selected starting Monday for the new trial, which will start April 9. The jury in the first trial last summer failed to reach a verdict.\n\nJudge O\u2019Neill said jurors would be sequestered starting the night before opening arguments, as they were in last year\u2019s trial because of the intense publicity the case has attracted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJurors will be selected for the retrial from Montgomery County. That is in contrast to the panel for Mr. Cosby\u2019s trial last year, when jurors were chosen from Allegheny County in western Pennsylvania because of concerns that it would hard to find an impartial jury near Mr. Cosby\u2019s hometown, Philadelphia.\n\nJudge O\u2019Neill said the jury would be chosen from an initial pool of 170 people, and they will be questioned on their knowledge of the case and their ability to deliver an impartial verdict. He signaled lingering concerns that the high-profile case might still make it hard to find jurors who will give Mr. Cosby a fair trial on three charges of aggravated indecent assault.\n\n\u201cIf we find that a Montgomery County panel is unable to be fair and impartial, then we\u2019ve got a problem,\u201d he said.", "title": "Cosby Trial Judge Defends Wife and His Independence", "authors": ["Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "SINGAPORE \u2014 Eugene Ng jabbed a pudgy finger against the side of the glass tank, like a predator singling out his unlucky target.\n\n\u201cThat fish\u2019s eye is looking a little droopy,\u201d said Mr. Ng, pointing to a fish with large metallic gold scales swimming happily among its companions.\n\nMinutes later, the fish was knocked out and getting an eyelift, a procedure that has become standard practice in Mr. Ng\u2019s job as one of the premier cosmetic surgeons for Asian arowana fish here in Singapore. Using a pair of forceps, Mr. Ng \u2014 known to his clients as Dr. Ark, after the pet fish store that he also runs \u2014 worked quickly, loosening the tissue behind the fish\u2019s eye and pushing the eyeball up into the socket.\n\n\u201cI know some people think it\u2019s cruel to the fish,\u201d said Mr. Ng, lifting his sedated patient with one hand to show off its newly straightened eye. \u201cBut really I\u2019m doing it a favor. Because now the fish looks better and its owner will love it even more.\u201d", "title": "Cosmetic Surgery for a Pet Fish? In Asia, This One Is King of the Tank", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cThe Price They Pay\u201d (Science Times, March 6) puts a face on \u201cWhy Your Pharmacist Can\u2019t Tell You That $20 Prescription Could Cost Only $8\u201d (news article, Feb. 25).\n\nAnyone watching the effort by CVS to buy Aetna should be alarmed by the prospect of a future filled with medication denials and cost shifts to the sickest in our midst.\n\nImagine the power and conflict in having Aetna determine the tier of a drug and letting CVS bill at least a third of the list price to the patient to save Aetna money.\n\nWorse, a person examined by a nurse in a CVS walk-in clinic may be prescribed a drug that might have a cheaper alternative. Unbeknown to the patient, the pharmacist is prohibited from revealing that.", "title": "Opinion | Cost-Shifting on Drugs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Tygart said American athletes have been demanding that the antidoping agency find ways to better protect clean athletes in the future so the Russian doping debacle is never repeated.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee punished Russia, sort of, for its widespread doping. It barred the Russian Olympic Committee, the Russian flag and the Russian national anthem from last month\u2019s Pyeongchang Games, while letting some Russian athletes compete under a neutral flag. It also barred for life one top Russian official: Vitaly Mutko. (He was implicated in the doping program as the Russian sports minister. After the scheme was exposed, he was promoted to deputy prime minister.)\n\nThree days after the Pyeongchang Games ended, the I.O.C. reinstated Russia\u2019s Olympic committee \u2014 even though two Russian athletes had failed drug tests during the competition.\n\nSo the United States antidoping group is looking for additional ways to punish the Russians. The Global Magnitsky Act is in its infancy and the sports angle might be a long-shot, but why not try?\n\nBesides, the United States government often has to do the dirty work for sports leagues and federations that refuse to police themselves.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo take down the principles and athletes involved in the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroids scandal that ensnared athletes like Barry Bonds and Marion Jones, law enforcement made arrests and prosecutors took it from there. To address the widespread doping problem in Major League Baseball, Congress had to drag players and management in to testify.\n\nTo uncover corruption in FIFA, United States prosecutors took the lead and indicted more than two dozen officials and businessmen from all over the world \u2014 much to the dismay of soccer\u2019s global establishment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd now it could be the Global Magnitsky Act that delivers a staggering blow to the Russians for corrupting the results of major global sports competitions \u2014 including, but certainly not limited to, the Olympics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong the people who could be targeted for sanctions are Mutko; Yuri D. Nagornykh, the former deputy sports minister; Irina Rodionova, the former deputy director of the Center for Sports Preparation; and others mentioned in an affidavit by Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, Russia\u2019s former longtime antidoping laboratory chief who blew the whistle on the whole operation.\n\nDoes such sports corruption rise to the level covered by the law? William F. Browder thinks so. He\u2019s a prominent investor who worked with Congress on the original Magnitsky Act, which was passed in 2012 in response to the death of Browder\u2019s Russian lawyer, Sergei L. Magnitsky. The lawyer had uncovered a $230 million tax-theft scheme before he was arrested and died in prison.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s one important issue and that\u2019s the doping scandal at the Sochi Games led to what I believe were murders,\u201d Browder said, referring to two officials from Russia\u2019s antidoping agency who died within two weeks of each other in 2016. \u201cThere were a number of people involved who died very suspiciously who were most likely liquidated to cover up a crime.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThere were people who effectively ruined institution of sport and have committed crimes to do so. That would reach the standard of Global Magnitsky, in my opinion. These people involved in sports doping, they\u2019re shameless. So there needs to be really hard consequences. They need to pay a very dear price.\u201d\n\nThat price would be losing access to their money and the freedom to move about the world. And they would be on a list with some of the world\u2019s worst criminals.\n\n\u201cIf the Olympic Games are unquestionably tainted, that has huge economic ramifications for not just U.S. athletes, but for U.S. industry, and the U.S. government has an interest in making sure that doesn\u2019t happen,\u201d said Robert G. Berschinski, senior vice president for policy at Human Rights First and a former deputy assistant secretary of state.\n\nI asked him if he thought the individuals involved in the Russian doping case could be sanctioned under the law. \u201cWithout getting into specifics,\u201d he said, \u201cit seems that you can make a case.\u201d\n\nTygart thinks so, too. He left the workshop on Tuesday thinking that sanctions were a last resort but \u201ca viable option.\u201d\n\nIs it truly a viable option, and will the antidoping agency act on it?\n\nA certain group of Russians might not be eager to learn the answers.", "title": "Could U.S. Law Help Punish Russians for Doping Scheme?", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Lobbyists, those with business before the city and others who regularly engage with both sides of city government, have taken notice of the rapid change in the relationship from the relatively placid days under Mr. Johnson\u2019s predecessor, Melissa Mark-Viverito, an early supporter of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s who gained her position in part because of a push from the newly elected mayor.\n\nMr. Johnson, by contrast, rose to the position of speaker with the support of county Democratic leaders, and he rode a wave of simmering resentment among Council members at their treatment by the de Blasio administration. Those sentiments boiled over after comments by Deputy Mayor Alicia Glen, during a deposition in a lawsuit over housing segregation, in which she referred to Council members as \u201cnot that smart.\u201d Council members were not amused.\n\nSeveral lobbyists and political observers note the benefits of greater Council independence: another set of ears to listen to concerns; a new way to exert pressure on City Hall.\n\n\u201cThe Council is supposed to be a counterbalance to the mayor, and we haven\u2019t had that in a long time,\u201d said Suri Kasirer, a city lobbyist. \u201cI think it\u2019s good government.\u201d\n\nEric F. Phillips, a spokesman for the mayor, pointed to areas of agreement with Mr. Johnson, including a decision to site a jail in the Bronx, part of the plan to close Rikers Island. \u201cTheir partnership on a frequently shared agenda is not only strong but already producing results for New Yorkers,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Johnson\u2019s more assertive posture is reflective of an attitude shared by many Council members, including those who ran against Mr. Johnson for speaker and others who did not support his bid.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCouncilman Benjamin Kallos of Manhattan welcomed a new era of debate. \u201cI think conflict is good for resolving problems,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThe notion that the mayor is the sole branch of New York City government is an anachronism,\u201d said Ritchie Torres, a councilman who represents the Bronx. \u201cIt has no place in the age of Corey Johnson.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Torres stood with Mr. Cuomo on Monday as the governor condemned the conditions in Nycha buildings. The next day, the governor welcomed a Council delegation into his Albany office. Several members called the sit-down remarkable because it gave the impression that Mr. Johnson was negotiating on behalf of the city \u2014 effectively working around the mayor.\n\nThe governor furthered that impression by releasing a letter, through a state lawyer, listing areas of agreement with the Council, including providing $400 million in new city subway funding, creating construction rules for public housing and accelerating the timeline for closing Rikers Island. Mr. de Blasio has proposed a 10-year closure plan. \u201cPlease notify us when you have a resolution with the mayor\u2019s office,\u201d the lawyer, Alphonso David, wrote to Mr. Johnson.\n\n\u201cI will discuss with members to decide best path forward,\u201d Mr. Johnson replied on Twitter hours later. \u201cNo final decisions were made.\u201d (He said much the same in a letter to the governor the next day.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Council\u2019s eagerness to be a counterweight to the mayor gave the governor leverage against Mr. de Blasio in their ongoing feud. Two members said they were worried that they had been na\u00efve in their handling of the meeting, which the governor led; others who attended the meeting said they feared they might appear to be \u201cundercutting\u201d Mr. de Blasio.\n\nMicah Lasher, who served as the chief Albany lobbyist for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said the episode makes it look as if the City Council \u201cnegotiated around the mayor.\u201d The mayor was not happy, according to two people familiar with his response.\n\n\u201cI cannot think of an instance in recent political history when the City Council negotiated with Albany on behalf of the city,\u201d Mr. Lasher said. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to see how a divided city government would result in better outcomes for the city.\u201d\n\nEven Mr. Bloomberg, a political moderate who ran as a Republican for mayor, managed to work closely with Christine C. Quinn, a Democrat who was Council speaker at the time, though there was periodic tension that led Mr. Bloomberg to veto bills. Mr. de Blasio, in his first term, did not issue a single veto.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany political observers expect that streak to end under Mr. Johnson.\n\n\u201cIt shouldn\u2019t be lost on anyone that we are both left-of-center Democrats who, ideologically, are pretty much in line with each other. But, there is still going to be disagreement,\u201d Mr. Johnson said.\n\nThe day after Mr. Johnson and his Council contingent met with the governor, he had his weekly sit-down with Mr. de Blasio.\n\n\u201cWe talk through it, have an open line of communication and try to not surprise each other,\u201d Mr. Johnson said.", "title": "Council Adopts a Gloves-Off Stance With Mayor de Blasio", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays", "J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The bill calls for the Council and the mayor to each appoint four members of the commission, with one additional member each being appointed by the borough presidents, the public advocate and the comptroller. In contrast, the mayor has said that he alone will appoint the commission that he plans to create.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t personal against the mayor,\u201d said Mr. Johnson, who was elected speaker in January, after vowing to chart a path for the Council more independent of the mayor. \u201cWe would love to do it together with him.\u201d\n\nMr. de Blasio\u2019s chief spokesman, Eric F. Phillips, said that the mayor\u2019s commission would be named soon.\n\nThe Council expects to hold a committee hearing about the bill next week.\n\nThe mayor has said that his commission will propose charter changes that can go before voters in November. The Council-created commission would aim to have its proposed changes on the ballot the following year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJerry Goldfeder, an election lawyer who has studied the charter review process, said it could be beneficial having two panels focusing on different issues.\n\n\u201cThey could be complementary rather than dueling,\u201d he said. \u201cIf we have two groups looking at the charter in ways that could improve the ways we govern ourselves, all the better.\u201d\n\nThe Council bill was originally sponsored last year by the public advocate, Letitia James, and the Manhattan borough president, Gale A. Brewer, with the goal of initiating a charter revision some 30 years after a landmark series of charter changes that were passed by voters in 1989.\n\nThe issues that could be addressed include questions of the balance of power between the mayor and the City Council \u2014 such as whether commissioners or board members appointed by the mayor should be approved by the Council.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCouncil members and others have also pushed for more transparency in budgeting, including rules that would require mayoral agencies to provide more information about how they plan to spend money during the budget approval process.\n\nOther proposed changes could alter the city\u2019s land use approval process and address the way facilities like homeless shelters are placed around the city, so that they would not be overly concentrated in certain neighborhoods, an issue known as Fair Share.\n\nMr. Johnson said the review he envisions would be wide open.\n\n\u201cThe mayor\u2019s talked about what he wants his commission to look at before it\u2019s been constituted, and we want a commission to go in with an open mind and look at the broad structure of city government,\u201d Mr. Johnson said.", "title": "Council May Defy Mayor With an Alternate Review of the City Charter", "authors": ["William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "In her 48-page opinion, Judge Caproni also waved aside Exxon\u2019s references to Republican attorneys general and members of Congress who attacked the Schneiderman and Healey investigations. If such statements could be considered as evidence worthy of being weighed, she wrote, \u201claw enforcement at the state level will be drawn to a screeching halt by what amounts to a heckler\u2019s veto.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for Exxon, Scott J. Silvestri, said the company officials \u201care reviewing the judge\u2019s decision and are evaluating our next steps.\u201d He went on to note, \u201cWe believe the risk of climate change is real and we want to be part of the solution.\u201d\n\nFor many years, however, Exxon attempted to cast doubt on climate science, funding organizations that argued that the science was far less certain than it actually was, even as the company had amassed its own research that pointed to the severity of the problem.\n\nMr. Schneiderman has said that while his office has examined the past actions, his investigation has focused on more recent statements by Exxon about climate change and what it means for the company\u2019s future.\n\nAs for Exxon\u2019s argument that investigators were seeking to violate the company\u2019s rights to freedom of speech, Mr. Schneiderman has repeatedly stated, \u201cThe First Amendment doesn\u2019t protect you for fraud.\u201d\n\nMr. Schneiderman said he was pleased by the judge\u2019s decision to dismiss what he called \u201cExxon\u2019s frivolous, nonsensical lawsuit.\u201d He pledged that his investigation would continue.\n\nMs. Healey said the decision was \u201ca turning point in our investigation and a victory for the people.\u201d Calling Exxon\u2019s case \u201ca scorched-earth campaign to avoid answering our basic questions about the company\u2019s awareness of climate change,\u201d she said, \u201cExxon\u2019s customers and investors deserve answers from the company about what it has known about the impact of burning fossil fuels, and whether it hid this information from the public.\u201d\n\nAs for the activists drawn into the case, Lee Wasserman, director of the Rockefeller Family Fund, said: \u201cThe judge\u2019s decision underscores that officials working to hold companies accountable for deceiving the public, and citizens working to address the catastrophic climate change Exxon helped cause, is not a conspiracy. It\u2019s an activity as American as baseball, motherhood and apple pie.\u201d", "title": "Court Dismisses Exxon\u2019s Effort to Block Climate Investigation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "As a next step, the Labor Department may request that all of the judges in the appeals court hear the case, rather than the three-judge panel, lawyers said. Because there was at least one decision in another circuit court that conflicts with the most recent case, it is also possible the Supreme Court could eventually weigh in.\n\n\u201cThe outcome could continue to be uncertain for quite a while,\u201d said Fred Reish, a lawyer who represents clients in fiduciary issues.\n\nThe Obama-era fiduciary regulation, drafted over roughly six years, had thus far survived intense criticism and resistance from the industry, which argued that the rule would make it too costly to work with smaller investors. The rule, which took partial effect in June 2017, requires financial advisers to act as fiduciaries when providing advice related to a client\u2019s retirement accounts, including individual retirement accounts and 401(k)\u2019s.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe future of the rule was already murky. The Trump administration\u2019s Labor Department, which oversees retirement accounts, said last year that it was reviewing the regulation and pushed back its full implementation by 18 months, to July 2019.\n\nConsumer advocates and others who are in favor of a strong fiduciary rule called the decision a blow to retirement savers.\n\n\u201cThis case was wrongly decided,\u201d said Micah Hauptman, financial services counsel to the Consumer Federation of America. \u201cThe industry opponents went forum shopping and finally found a court that was willing to buy in to their bogus arguments. This is a sad day for retirement savers.\u201d\n\nSeveral of the plaintiffs \u2014 including the U. S. Chamber of Commerce, Financial Services Institute, Financial Services Roundtable, Insured Retirement Institute, and Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association \u2014 said the court\u2019s decision would preserve access to affordable financial advice.\n\n\u201cOur organizations have long supported the development of a best interest standard of care,\u201d they said in a statement, \u201cand the Securities and Exchange Commission should now take the lead on a clear, consistent, and workable standard that does not limit choice for investors.\u201d\n\nThe S.E.C. is reportedly working on its own rule. But consumer advocates have long said that the financial services industry would prefer that the S.E.C. write a rule, which they believe would not be as strong as the Labor Department\u2019s rule.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Department of Labor could not be immediately reached for comment on Thursday night.", "title": "Court Overturns Obama-Era Rule on Retirement Planners", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The New York Police Department has a reputation for secrecy, often declining to promptly release the kind of documents \u2014 complaint reports, use-of-force investigations, officer narratives of arrests \u2014 that many other departments disseminate to the news media. In 2016, the New York Police Department stopped releasing basic information about officer discipline, though it recently indicated it would resume releasing some information, though without officers\u2019 names.\n\nThe case before the court involved public-record requests filed in 2012 by two men to get records relating to any surveillance of them by the police. The men, who are both Muslim, filed the requests after a series of articles by The Associated Press described a secretive Police Department counterterrorism program that conducted extensive surveillance of Muslim organizations and mosques. One of the men, Talib Abdur-Rashid, is the imam of a Harlem mosque. The other man, Samir Hashmi, was a student at Rutgers University and active in its Muslim Student Association. After the Police Department refused to confirm or deny the existence of the records they were requesting, the men sued.\n\nThe police maintained that even disclosing the existence or nonexistence of any such records \u2014 let alone publicly releasing any that existed \u2014 would provide too much information. \u201cThe knowledge that a person or group is the subject of a N.Y.P.D. counterterrorism investigation would allow that person or group to alter their behavior so as to avoid detection,\u201d the department\u2019s intelligence chief, Thomas Galati, wrote in an affidavit. \u201cConversely, the knowledge that a person or group is not a subject of investigation would allow such persons to more freely engage in illegal activity.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the court\u2019s majority opinion, Chief Judge Janet DiFiore, accepted that the police needed room to give a non-answer. \u201cThe need for government confidentiality may be at its zenith when a law enforcement agency is undertaking a covert investigation of individuals or organizations, where the lives of the public, cooperators and undercover officers may hang precariously in the balance and the reputation, livelihood or liberty of the subject may be at stake,\u201d she wrote.\n\nA partially concurring decision by one judge, Rowan Wilson, and a separate dissenting opinion, by Leslie Stein, expressed concern that the majority decision seems to make little distinction between long-ago surveillance related to past investigations and surveillance related to ongoing investigations.\n\nOmar T. Mohammedi, a lawyer for the two men, criticized the decision, saying that the court had been swayed by the \u201cfear-mongering\u201d of the New York Police Department. \u201cOur clients are good, law-abiding citizens,\u201d Mr. Mohammedi said. The case did not have to do with counterterrorism investigations \u2014 as the police claimed, he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not \u2014 this case is about abusing Muslims by surveilling them without having any leads on terrorism.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, the Police Department said it has \u201crarely\u201d responded to public record requests with a \u201cneither confirm nor deny\u201d answer. \u201cThe department will continue to do so only on a very limited basis and where appropriate,\u201d the statement said.\n\nBut Mr. Dunn, the civil liberties lawyer, expressed concern that the Police Department would keep to that.\n\n\u201cThe big question is how far they are going to push this,\u201d he said, noting that the Police Department recently issued a \u201cneither confirm nor deny\u201d answer to a public records request the New York Civil Liberties Union had filed that sought information regarding a 2014 Black Lives Matter protest. In that case, the civil liberties union wanted to know if the police had listened to \u2014 or jammed \u2014 phone calls among demonstrators.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve already used it in a protester case,\u201d Mr. Dunn said.", "title": "Court Permits New York Police to Use \u2018Neither Confirm nor Deny\u2019 Tactic", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "I carry two phones (in case one falls in the mud), a power strip that allows me to charge my computer from the car, and a Canon 5D camera that I bought off a White House photographer years ago. I use my iPhone\u2019s recording app, or a downloadable app called TapeACall, and I will occasionally pay for a transcription service for lengthy interviews. I\u2019ve used both Trint.com and Rev.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen I\u2019m working on breaking news stories, Twitter is crucial. Law enforcement agencies send out updates through social media, and the first thing I do when I head into a big story is make sure that I'm receiving their new tweets as immediate text messages. Then I use social media to report the texture of the story as it unfolds.\n\nBeyond breaking news, I\u2019ve found Twitter to be a great tool for conveying a sense of place. Sometimes a single picture or video can really cut to the heart of a story.\n\nLastly, roving reporters have to take care of themselves. I travel with an extra thin yoga mat from Manduka that packs down to the size of a book.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat could be better?\n\nWe need longer-lasting batteries. Battery life is a constant source of stress for reporters in the field.\n\nYou\u2019ve reported extensively on the Parkland, Fla., school shooting and many other such shootings. After Parkland, the survivors used Twitter and other outlets to speak out about gun control. Do you foresee this use of social media having any effect on gun control regulations?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe\u2019re already seeing that happen. Several of the Parkland students now have tens of thousands of followers on Twitter, and they have been using that tool to speak directly to people in power. And when Gov. Rick Scott of Florida passed a major gun bill recently, he credited the students for making it possible.\n\nPhoto\n\nI\u2019m curious to see what\u2019s next. Will social media messaging continue to be as powerful as the weeks go on? And how will students deal with their new roles as survivors, advocates and public figures?\n\nHas tech affected how you research and investigate the people you write about?\n\nSocial media has expanded the reporter-subject relationship, making it more personal, and allowing for interaction beyond the life of a particular story.\n\nThis means that I sometimes contact people on Facebook to ask for an interview, and stay connected to them for weeks or months. As a reporter covering a vast region \u2014 and as someone who focuses on capturing national narratives and sentiments \u2014 I find social media to be a helpful way to avoid a news bubble. It keeps me connected to Montana and Utah and Wyoming even when I can\u2019t be there.\n\nBeyond your job, what tech product are you currently obsessed with using in your daily life?\n\nAudible audiobooks and Spotify playlists have gotten me through many a road trip.\n\nBut my current obsession is taking time off from technology. As someone who spends a lot of time linked to the internet, I try to spend off-days away from devices. I buy books. I keep a physical calendar, not a digital one. I get two papers on Sundays and have several magazine subscriptions.\n\nAnd I try to spend as much non-travel time in face-to-face conversations with friends and family.", "title": "Covering Disasters With 2 Phones, in Case One Falls in the Mud", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhile Reyna is a professional engineer, he does not have control over the project and relies on the expertise of the licensed engineer of record,\u201d Mr. Kane said.\n\nAt no point during their communications, the department said, \u201cdid Figg or any member of the F.I.U. design-build team ever communicate a life-safety issue.\u201d\n\nWhether the cracking contributed to the collapse, which killed six people, remains a key question in the investigation.\n\nConstruction crews were working on a diagonal beam at the north end of the structure at or about the time of the collapse, according to information the National Transportation Safety Board provided to local members of Congress. Workers were tightening cables that ran inside the beam.\n\nSuch adjustments, which engineers call \u201cpost-tensioning,\u201d are common in concrete designs to fine-tune the structure once it is in place. In this case, however, it was not clear whether the cable-tightening was routine or an urgent undertaking in response to the discovery of the crack in the bridge.\n\nAround the same time the meeting was starting, about 9 a.m., Jorge Mesa, a 31-year-old university employee, said he was in his car near the bridge when he heard \u201ca cracking-whip kind of sound.\u201d He looked to his right and saw one of the construction workers on the street.\n\nThe worker\u2019s face, Mr. Mesa said, seemed to say, \u201cUm, that\u2019s not normal.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen he gave me that face, I got the chills all the way down my body,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bridge came down that afternoon.\n\nWitnesses said the collapse appeared to start near the north end. But no one, including the N.T.S.B., has so far placed any blame for the collapse on the cables or cable-tightening work.\n\nBy late Saturday evening, recovery crews had extracted four crushed vehicles from under the rubble. Workers covered the vehicles in black sheeting and towed them to the medical examiner to identify the remains of any victims inside.\n\nAt a news conference around 10 p.m., Juan J. Perez, the director of the Miami-Dade Police Department, said five people had been found under the 950 tons of rubble. A sixth person, Navarro Brown, was part of the crew working on the bridge and died at a hospital.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re pretty confident that no one\u2019s left,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Police Department identified one victim in one of the first vehicles as Roland Fraga Hernandez, and two people in the second vehicle, Oswald Gonzalez, 57, and Alberto Arias, 53.\n\nThe police said the first vehicle was a Jeep Cherokee. It was nearly flattened but still distinguishable by its front grille, according to videos by The Miami Herald and local television news outlets.\n\nThe second vehicle, crumpled almost beyond recognition, was a Chevrolet pickup truck. Cranes lifted the vehicles onto flatbed trucks, which were escorted to the medical examiner by a police motorcade.\n\nMr. Perez said the authorities had \u201ca pretty good idea\u201d who was in all of the vehicles, but he did not release additional names on Saturday night.\n\nSenator Marco Rubio of Florida, who also spoke at Saturday night\u2019s news conference, said someone he knew had a relative who was among those killed by the bridge collapse.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpeaking about the National Transportation Safety Board, he said, \u201cLet there be no doubt, they will know why this failed, and they will make sure that that is out there so it never happens again.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter the first two extractions Saturday morning, Joseph Smitha was walking around in a daze on the Florida International University campus. His niece, Alexa Duran, remained under the debris of the bridge a block away.\n\nMr. Smitha, a 55-year-old auto parts manager, had spent the night in his truck after making the four-hour drive from Palm Harbor, Fla., fitfully mourning Ms. Duran, a freshman at the university.\n\n\u201cHer mom is a wreck,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ll never hear her say, \u2018Hi, Uncle Joe,\u2019 again. I know it\u2019s not going to bring my niece back, but how did this happen?\u201d\n\nMr. Smitha and members of other victims\u2019 families are being given temporary quarters in a university building equipped with cots and snacks, awaiting news that none of them want to hear.\n\n\u201cI still think the kid is going to surface,\u201d he said, referring to his niece. \u201cMaybe she\u2019s at some friend\u2019s house. \u2018Hey, you had us scared,\u2019 I\u2019ll say to her. I\u2019d give everything I have to bring her back. It just kills me that this is something that could have been prevented.\u201d\n\nAt about 5:30 p.m., the gray Toyota 4Runner that Ms. Duran had been driving was pulled slowly from the rubble. A dark blue tarp covered its flattened shape. Her father, Orlando Duran, had arrived from London only minutes earlier.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s upset about how long it\u2019s taken for them to get his daughter out,\u201d Mr. Smitha, his brother-in-law, said.\n\nMs. Duran and a friend, the F.I.U. student Richard Humble, had been waiting at a red light when the bridge came crashing down on the Toyota and other vehicles.\n\n\u201cHer passenger walked away, God bless him,\u201d Mr. Smitha said. \u201cBut he\u2019s going to have to live with that for the rest of his life.\u201d", "title": "Crack on Florida Bridge Was Discussed in Meeting Hours Before Collapse", "authors": ["Nick Madigan", "Patricia Mazzei", "Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMore Cities Crack Down on Drinking Straws in Campaign Against Plastic Waste\u201d (news article, March 4):\n\nYour article on the international movement to ban straws and other single-use plastic food service items reflects what our eyes and the science tell us: Ocean plastic pollution is everywhere, it threatens the health of wildlife and it is finding its way onto our dinner plates.\n\nNearly 700 species have been affected by marine trash, most of which is plastic, including every species of sea turtle, and more than half of all whales, dolphins, porpoises and seabirds. By 2050, over 90 percent of Earth\u2019s seabirds will have ingested plastic. Ocean plastic pollution also concentrates toxins in the water, which find their way into marine food webs. With more than one billion people depending on protein from the ocean, what are the human health implications?\n\nTwenty-two public aquariums across the United States have eliminated straws and shopping bags, and will tackle plastic beverage bottles by 2020. We are driving market demand for innovative alternatives to single-use plastic. At the Monterey Bay Aquarium, our food service operations are nearly 100 percent free of single-use plastic.\n\nIt\u2019s clear: The solution to plastic pollution is in our hands.\n\nJULIE PACKARD, MONTEREY, CALIF.\n\nThe writer is executive director and co-founder of the Monterey Bay Aquarium.", "title": "Opinion | Cracking Down on Plastics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Craig Mack, the rapper whose \u201cFlava in Ya Ear,\u201d one of the most important rap songs of the 1990s, helped build the foundation for Bad Boy Records, one of hip-hop\u2019s most influential labels, died on Monday at his home in Walterboro, S.C. He was 47.\n\nRichard Harvey, the Colleton County coroner, said the death was \u201cnatural\u201d and did not otherwise give the cause.\n\nMr. Mack, who rapped under his given name, was born in the Bronx on May 10, 1970, and raised on Long Island. He began rapping as a teenager under the name MC EZ and released one single in 1988, \u201cJust Rhymin\u2019 \u201d backed with \u201cGet Retarded,\u201d as part of MC EZ & Troup.\n\nAt the time, Long Island was a burgeoning hip-hop talent center, home to Rakim, De La Soul and the duo EPMD. Mr. Mack was friends with EPMD and eventually went on tour with them, doing odd jobs. He helped their D.J., DJ Scratch, assemble and disassemble his turntables at shows.", "title": "Craig Mack, \u2018Flava in Ya Ear\u2019 Rapper, Is Dead at 47", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.\n\nRecently, the people of the The New York Times Book Review, who consider thousands of books each year, wanted to highlight the wave of women writers taking literature in new and interesting directions.\n\nThe critics distilled what they were seeing into \u201cThe New Vanguard,\u201d a list of 15 books included in a broader women-themed edition of the Sunday Book Review. The issue includes an interview with Tracy K. Smith, the poet laureate; a review from the entrepreneur Audrey Gelman about a new book on friendship; and an essay from the Times columnist Ginia Bellafante revisiting the work of feminist legal scholar Catherine MacKinnon. One goal of the section was to introduce readers to a range of ideas and writing from women. \u201cThe first idea we had was the word \u2018Vanguard,\u2019 because there was this sense that in lots of different ways there were things being done that were pioneering,\u201d John Williams, a daily books editor for The Times, said.\n\nBut the critics Parul Sehgal, Jennifer Szalai and Dwight Garner wanted to create neither an exhaustive inventory nor a definitive one, which would suggest hard lines between ideas. Instead, they aimed to present notable titles that each exemplify a broader theme, and to encourage readers to consider them together \u2014 in the manner of a syllabus for a cutting-edge university course \u2014 in the hopes of conveying a sense of literary moment.", "title": "Creating a Reading List for a New Literary Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 Disgraced in a blatant ball-scuffing scandal that has transfixed the cricket world, one of its most exalted players flew home to Australia from South Africa on Thursday and broke down in tears, apologizing on live national television for sullying his country and its national pastime.\n\n\u201cI know I\u2019ll regret this for the rest of my life,\u201d said the athlete, Steve Smith, who until a few days ago had been the Australia team\u2019s heroic captain. \u201cI\u2019m absolutely gutted.\u201d\n\n\u201cI hope in time I can earn back respect and forgiveness,\u201d Mr. Smith told a news conference at the Sydney airport as he struggled to keep his composure, his father standing behind him. \u201cCricket is the greatest game in the world. It\u2019s been my life, and I hope it will be again.\u201d\n\nMr. Smith returned to Australia five days after admitting to having concocted a plot with teammates to doctor the cricket ball by scuffing it with sandpaper during a match with South Africa last weekend. Scuffing can make the ball act unpredictably, making it more difficult for batsmen to hit. The cheating was caught on video.", "title": "Cricket Hero Breaks Down in Tears on TV Over Cheating", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFacebook Role in Data Misuse Sets Off Storm\u201d (front page, March 19):\n\nAlthough I do not use Facebook, it strikes me that if a large number of people closed their Facebook accounts until it demonstrates more careful use of their personal information, Facebook might make some important changes.\n\nBARBARA OSTBY, PALO ALTO, CALIF.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI\u2019m shocked! Millions of Facebook users have had their privacy compromised, just as with Equifax. Ten years ago, it was no secret that there was such a thing as hacking, and it was common knowledge that companies were buying and selling people\u2019s personal data.\n\nHardly anyone signed up for freezes with the Big 3 credit bureaus. Instead, they willingly input their information to social media and clicked on a button marked \u201cprivate.\u201d\n\nYeah, I guess it\u2019s all Equifax and Facebook\u2019s fault.\n\nALAN FIERSTEIN, individuals from serving in the military amounts to what legal experts said is essentially a reprise of an all-too-familiar directive at the Pentagon: the 1994 \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u201d policy.\n\nA slew of medical and legal professionals have already lined up against the newest White House order, issued late Friday night, which experts said may survive only if it is backed by the Supreme Court.\n\nThat order is based on recommendations outlined by Defense Secretary Jim Mattis in a Feb. 22 memo on the circumstances under which transgender people would be allowed to join or remain in the military.\n\nThe memo by Mr. Mattis disqualified all people \u201cwho require or have undergone gender transition.\u201d\n\nBut he also recommended that, going forward, Andrew M. Assembly leaders have even offered their own version of a surcharge, saying that it is not a congestion-pricing measure but a way to fund the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the city\u2019s subway and bus system.\n\nIt was Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat facing re-election in November, who almost single-handedly revived congestion pricing last summer after decades of failed efforts. But he has come under increasing criticism from some advocates who say that he has not aggressively lined up legislative support for it the way he did with other divisive issues such as same-sex marriage and the minimum wage \u2014 a comparison that the governor\u2019s aides reject.\n\nLast week, more than 100 transit riders and advocates rallied outside the governor\u2019s office in Midtown Manhattan during the evening commute to press for action on congestion pricing. \u201cWhere it really matters, he\u2019s not in the game,\u201d said Paul Steely White, the executive director of Transportation Alternatives, an advocacy group. \u201cWe\u2019re feeling abandoned, and that feeling is spreading quickly to everyone who relies on the transit system.\u201d\n\nJohn Raskin, the executive director of the Riders Alliance, another advocacy group, said that strong leadership from the governor was crucial because he dominates the budget and legislative process in Albany and controls the M.T.A. \u201cThe subways are a mess, Gotham is in trouble, and we\u2019ve been flashing the bat signal,\u201d he said. \u201cIt just seems like the governor hasn\u2019t decided yet whether he\u2019s going to rescue us.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo has repeatedly said that congestion pricing is one of his priorities. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn a recent conference call with a congestion-pricing supporters, Mr. Cuomo reassured them that he was not backing down and would push for a plan that included a congestion zone, according to people familiar with the discussion who did not want to be identified discussing a private conversation. Under this approach, authorization for around $200 million could be included in this year\u2019s budget for the infrastructure to create a congestion zone. The actual details of how it would operate \u2014 such as boundaries, fee amounts and hours and any exemptions \u2014 would not be hammered out until next year, or later.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Fix NYC panel of experts recommended a phased approach to congestion pricing, and the governor has been strongly pushing that strategy in budget negotiations, which continue as we speak,\u201d said Peter Ajemian, a spokesman for the governor.\n\nKathryn Wylde, a member of the task force who is president and chief executive officer of the Partnership for New York City, a group of the city\u2019s top business leaders, concurred that \u201cthe governor has been actively pushing negotiations to move forward the Fix NYC recommendations.\u201d\n\nScott Rechler, another member of the task force, urged Assembly leaders in particular to join the governor in backing congestion pricing since many of the members, including the speaker, Carl E. Heastie, represent city residents who would directly benefit. \u201cWith the state of our transit crisis and the congestion on our streets, it\u2019s time for the Assembly and Senate to recognize the severity of the problem and step up and be part of a comprehensive solution,\u201d he said.\n\nSenate leaders have repeatedly expressed concerns about imposing any additional financial burdens on New Yorkers. That is more than double the 21 percent who said in February 2011, his second month in office, that he was a liberal.\n\nBut among Democratic voters, a majority, 52 percent, still viewed Mr. Cuomo as a moderate, compared with only 34 percent of Democrats who labeled him a liberal.\n\nMs. Nixon is expected to challenge Mr. Cuomo from the political left.
