Two of the lawyers Mr. Weinstein retained after being brought in for questioning about his encounters with Ms. Battilana had personal and financial ties to Mr. Vance: Elkan Abramowitz was a former law partner of Mr. Vance and a donor to his campaign, and Daniel S. Connolly was a former prosecutor turned white-collar defense lawyer.\n\nMr. Weinstein\u2019s lawyers also brought on Linda Fairstein, a former Manhattan sex crimes prosecutor and close friend of the head of the district attorney\u2019s sex crimes bureau, as a consultant; she facilitated an introduction between Mr. Abramowitz and the bureau head, Martha Bashford.\n\nAnd David Boies, a lawyer for Mr. Weinstein who hired a private investigative firm to dig up information in an attempt to stop The New York Times\u2019s expose on his client, has given $55,000 to Mr. Vance over the years. Mr. Boies has said he never spoke to Mr. Vance about any criminal investigation of Mr. Weinstein.\n\nIn Ms. Battilana\u2019s case, Ms. Bashford determined after two weeks of investigation that she could not prove the crime of forcible touching or third-degree sexual abuse had been committed, even though she had the audio tape, Mr. Vance has said. Prosecutors judged it would be hard to prove Mr. Weinstein touched Ms. Battilana for sexual reasons because the advance came as the two were talking about Ms. Battilana becoming a lingerie model and whether her bosom had been surgically enhanced.\n\nProsecutors have wide discretion in deciding whether to pursue charges, and it is not uncommon for assistant district attorneys not to see eye-to-eye with detectives on the strength of a case. But the tensions over Mr. Vance\u2019s decision in the case have exploded in recent months into an open feud between some detectives in the Police Department\u2019s special victims unit and the district attorney.\n\nFor detectives, assembling enough evidence to establish that it is probable someone committed a crime \u2014 known in law as \u201cprobable cause\u201d \u2014 is enough to make an arrest. Prosecutors, however, must take things further and prove every element of the crime in court, and that can often be a much higher bar.\n\n\u201cThe police have a job to do, and we have a job to do, and they are very different jobs,\u201d Mr. Vance said in an interview Monday night. \u201cOur job is to ensure that any case that we bring has proof beyond a reasonable doubt, the standard we have to meet in court. Any other course of action only serves to hurt the victims of sex crimes. Andrew M. His family name, including a smattering of mentions of his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, appear almost 500 times. The report found that Ms. Olatoye knew of the falsifications, a disclosure that prompted calls for her to resign and that intensified tenant criticism of her agency. But Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, has defended her.\n\nMr. Cuomo blamed Nycha\u2019s delayed repairs of its aging buildings on years of mismanagement and a \u201cmaze of bureaucracy,\u201d which he said could be circumvented with the appointment of an independent entity through an emergency declaration.\n\nAn emergency declaration can be far-ranging and empowers the state to take actions not otherwise permitted.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a letter sent on Monday to the city, Alphonso David, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s counsel, said the declaration \u201ccould include a replacement of existing management, the appointment of an independent monitor, the identification and selection of contractors to be responsible for repairs, and/or the appointment of a public health monitor to focus on lead testing.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo said he would meet with City Council members in Albany on Tuesday and called on the mayor to offer input on a potential emergency declaration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI want the decision in two weeks. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith Mr. de Blasio in Washington, two of his top aides met with reporters at City Hall to counter some of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s assertions and to argue that an emergency declaration was unwarranted.\n\nThe emergency declaration is not a \u201cmagic cure-all,\u201d said Alicia Glen, the deputy mayor for housing and economic development, who faulted Mr. Cuomo for not releasing state funds that had already been appropriated to the housing authority.\n\nFederal subsidies to Nycha have dwindled since the 2000s, leaving the authority, which is administered locally, with billions of dollars in unfunded capital needs and a grim financial reality. The state is not obligated to fund Nycha, but the authority plays a vital role in providing housing for the city\u2019s poor, and since taking office, Mr. Cuomo has pledged more than $300 million.\n\nBut the city had not received $200 million of that money, Ms. Glen said.\n\nMr. Cuomo suggested on Monday that the money would be released if an independent monitor were appointed at Nycha.\n\n\u201cOnce an independent mechanism is chosen and we know the money will be spent in a timely way \u2014 not three to four years \u2014 the state will make $200 million available immediately,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said.\n\nSeemingly, the only agreement on Monday was support for a bill that would expedite the procurement process for public projects in New York City and reduce the cost of repairs at Nycha facilities. Deliver the key investments and reforms NYCHA tenants are waiting for.\u201d", "title": "Cuomo Weighs State of Emergency for New York City Public Housing", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWithin the context of all the corruption trials, which show the way in which money yields power in Albany, expanding the number of people who can contribute to the governor\u2019s campaign funds is not the reform that\u2019s needed,\u201d said Susan Lerner, the executive director of Common Cause New York, an advocacy group. \u201cIt\u2019s going in the wrong direction.\u201d\n\nThe new disclaimer language leaves out appointees to public authorities, which represent some of the most influential bodies in state government, including the New York Thruway Authority, the New York Power Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the subway, bus and commuter rail system in and around New York City.\n\nThe old disclaimer read: \u201cNo State agency officer or employee who serves at the pleasure of the governor or their appointing authority or members of state public authority or other boards appointed by the governor may contribute to and/or fund-raise for Andrew Cuomo 2018.\u201d\n\nThe new disclaimer is far more specific: \u201cUnder Executive Order 7, (1) New York State at-will employees, and (2) board or commission members appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the governor on a policymaking board or commission (i.e. members must file financial disclosure statements), may not contribute to and/or fund-raise for Andrew Cuomo 2018.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo far, the Cuomo administration has identified only three relatively minor boards that meet that criteria: the Albany Convention Center Authority; the Capital Program Review Board at the M.T.A.; and the Occupational Safety and Health Hazard Abatement Board.\n\nThe new interpretation of the executive order by Mr. Cuomo is at odds with the ethics handbooks of some state boards, which prohibit appointed board members from donating.\n\n\u201cNo board member, pursuant to executive order, may make or offer to make any monetary contribution to the campaign of the governor,\u201d according to the ethics code for M.T.A. board members, for instance.\n\nThe executive order was first signed by Gov. Eliot L. Spitzer and then rewritten slightly by Gov. David A. Paterson when he took office. Mr. Cuomo renewed Mr. Paterson\u2019s version of the order.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Cuomo administration has complained that the order is \u201cextremely vague,\u201d but the governor has the power to update it with a stroke of his pen. He has chosen not to, instead only updating the disclaimer on his website.\n\nThe governor\u2019s office declined to comment, and referred all questions about the changed wording to the Cuomo campaign.\n\nMr. Cuomo, a Democrat, is facing a primary challenge from the actress Cynthia Nixon, who has criticized the governor\u2019s fund-raising practices.\n\nSince the initial story in The Times, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign has kept almost all the roughly $890,000 it raised from appointees. It returned a $2,500 donation from one appointee, which it said violated its revised interpretation of the fund-raising ban.", "title": "Cuomo, in Writing, Reinterprets Fund-Raising Ban on Appointees", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher", "Brian M. Rosenthal"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "But in theater, it is not enough to just include dirty words to get a response from the audience. Obscenities must serve a purpose.\n\nMr. Guirgis, whose \u201cThe ___________ With the Hat\u201d ran on Broadway in 2011, said he uses curse words to depict reality. \u201cThe language is really just mostly a reflection of the characters I tend to create,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Guirgis works hard, he said, to make sure his characters\u2019 cursing doesn\u2019t overshadow the rest of the play. \u201cI pare it down so that the meat doesn\u2019t get obscured by the gravy. The meat and veg and gravy have to fit together. Often expletives or cursing is a part of that. It\u2019s a seasoning. I just try to get it so it\u2019s right.\u201d\n\nThere are places, however, that playwrights feel they can\u2019t go. Mr. Guirgis is reluctant to use racial epithets in his work, so he sometimes opts for an interchangeable profanity instead.\n\nThough profanity does sometimes help create a sense of verisimilitude, it can also be employed to punch up everyday speech. A sentence or phrase that might otherwise be flat can become, as if by magic, hilarious, heartbreaking or even beautiful when a curse word is inserted into it.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou get to a place where what things mean literally doesn\u2019t serve your expressive purpose,\u201d said Michael Adams, the author of \u201cIn Praise of Profanity\u201d and a professor of English at Indiana University, Bloomington. \u201cMetaphors aren\u2019t even helping you anymore. You just have to reach beyond that to something that is ultimately expressive non-literally, and for us that is often profanity.\u201d\n\nIn Mr. Presson\u2019s \u201c____ Marry Kill,\u201d expletives serve to both capture the way real teenagers speak and also to turn a story of adolescent depravity into a \u201cJacobean Revenge Comedy\u201d (the play\u2019s subtitle).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Presson\u2019s characters may use the same swear words that many American teenagers do, but the way they use them is entirely different.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always really trying to get to the musicality of the language and the rhythms \u2014 to in some ways invoke the verse of Elizabethan and post-Elizabethan texts,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re referencing the way speech is used in that era, where you have puns and double meaning and repeated things.\u201d\n\nThe musicality of bad language is taken to another level in \u201cJerry Springer \u2014 The Opera\u201d at the Pershing Square Signature Center. The profanities may be familiar, but they\u2019re rarely sung by trained opera singers.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got two languages happening at the same time \u2014 the language of words and the language of music \u2014 and it\u2019s the contrast that really makes it work,\u201d said Richard Thomas, the main creator of the show\u2019s music and lyrics. \u201cFor a thing that puerile to be afforded such grandiosity makes it land, makes it delicious.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile he delights in the disjunction between the beauty of his show\u2019s music and the often obscene content of its lyrics, Mr. Thomas encourages performers to ignore it. \u201cI tell the actors to forget the profanity,\u2019\u2019 he said. \u201cI tell them to focus on the transcendent nature of what you\u2019re singing. That\u2019s more important than the scatological or profane text you\u2019re articulating.\u201d\n\nKevin McCollum, the producer who controls the transfer rights to \u201cJerry Springer \u2014 The Opera,\u201d said he does not think the show\u2019s profanity negatively affects its commercial viability.\n\n\u201cWhat gets a show to Broadway is that people are talking about it,\u201d he said. \u201cAll good theater and all popular theater must reflect the time in which it is not only created, but also performed.\u201d\n\nStrong language can backfire, however, with critics and audiences sometimes reacting differently than the playwright intended.\n\nDavid Bar Katz said he felt that some audience members weren\u2019t able to recover from the obscenities used in the opening scene of his 2011 Labyrinth Theater Company production, \u201cThe Atmosphere of Memory.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA lot of the audience never came back from that scene,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was supposed to be comedic but it\u2019s incredibly profane. They don\u2019t know what to do with it.\u201d Mr. Katz said he learned something from the experience: \u201cIf you\u2019re trying to elicit a certain reaction and if profanity is not serving you, then you, as a disciplined artist, have to find another way.\u201d\n\nSome playwrights contend that they\u2019re particularly vulnerable to criticism for their use of profanity. Ms. Feiffer, who has had several prominent Off Broadway productions, said that she thinks female playwrights are more likely to be taken to task for the practice than their male counterparts are.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI feel pretty strongly that female playwrights are basically lauded when we write plays that fall into the category of \u2018feminine\u2019: plays that are more flowery in their language or use pretty metaphors or kooky imagery,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen we write more in the muscular, high-octane and, yes, profane vein of playwrights who are considered \u2018masculine\u2019 \u2014 Mamet, McDonagh, Stephen Adly Guirgis \u2014 we\u2019re sort of slapped on the wrist.\u201d (Both Mr. Mamet and Mr. McDonagh declined to be interviewed for this article.)\n\nDialogue is one thing, but as Mr. Guirgis\u2019s Broadway show demonstrated, unprintable titles bring their own extra challenge, as publications (like this one) have standards that don\u2019t allow for their use.\n\nWith a curse word in the title, getting the word out about the play itself can be difficult. That may be the situation for Tori Sampson, who is getting a prime Off Broadway slot in the Playwrights Horizons season in 2019.\n\nMs. Sampson said she had been warned by her mentor, the playwright Sarah Ruhl, that the title could cause problems, but she was still somewhat taken aback when several publications omitted all or some of it. She experienced the omission, she said, as a form of censorship, which she felt especially strongly as a female playwright and a person of color.\n\n\u201cThe theater is a place where people can fully express themselves,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s really no limit to what you can do, so it shocked me that there are gatekeepers to language in theater.\u201d\n\nHer new play \u2014 \u201cIf Pretty Hurts Ugly Must Be a _______\u201d \u2014 opens in February 2019.", "title": "Curses! And Why They Work So Well Onstage (Sometimes)", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Russian cyberattacks surged last year, starting three months after Mr. Trump took office.\n\nAmerican officials and private cybersecurity experts uncovered a series of Russian attacks aimed at the energy, water and aviation sectors and critical manufacturing, including nuclear plants, in the United States and Europe. In its urgent report in June, the Department of Homeland Security and the F.B.I. notified operators about the attacks but stopped short of identifying Russia as the culprit.\n\nBy then, Russian spies had compromised the business networks of several American energy, water and nuclear plants, mapping out their corporate structures and computer networks.\n\nThey included that of the Wolf Creek Nuclear Operating Corporation, which runs a nuclear plant near Burlington, Kan. But in that case, and those of other nuclear operators, Russian hackers had not leapt from the company\u2019s business networks into the nuclear plant controls.\n\nForensic analysis suggested that Russian spies were looking for inroads \u2014 although it was not clear whether the goal was to conduct espionage or sabotage, or to trigger an explosion of some kind.\n\nIn a report made public in October, Symantec noted that a Russian hacking unit \u201cappears to be interested in both learning how energy facilities operate and also gaining access to operational systems themselves, to the extent that the group now potentially has the ability to sabotage or gain control of these systems should it decide to do so.\u201d\n\nThe United States sometimes does the same thing. It bored deeply into Iran\u2019s infrastructure before the 2015 nuclear accord, placing digital \u201cimplants\u201d in systems that would enable it to bring down power grids, command-and-control systems and other infrastructure in case a conflict broke out. The operation was code-named \u201cNitro Zeus,\u201d and its revelation made clear that getting into the critical infrastructure of adversaries is now a standard element of preparing for possible conflict.\n\nThe Russians have gone farther.\n\nIn an updated warning to utility companies on Thursday, Homeland Security officials included a screenshot taken by Russian operatives that proved they could now gain access to their victims\u2019 critical controls.\n\nAmerican officials and security firms, including Symantec and CrowdStrike, believe that Russian attacks on the Ukrainian power grid in 2015 and 2016 that left more than 200,000 citizens there in the dark are an ominous sign of what the Russian cyberstrikes may portend in the United States and Europe in the event of escalating hostilities.", "title": "Cyberattacks Put Russian Fingers on the Switch at Power Plants, U.S. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Appropriating an attack line from her friend Mayor Bill de Blasio and the former presidential candidate Senator Bernie Sanders, Ms. Nixon cast New York as divided between the haves and have-nots.\n\n\u201cNew York State itself is the single most unequal state in the country,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThis is not something that just happens by mistake. It comes from a choice. It comes from a choice to slash taxes for corporations and the super rich and slash services on everybody else,\u201d she said from a podium. \u201cAnd it\u2019s a choice we\u2019re used to being made by Republicans like Donald Trump. But for the past eight years, it is a choice that\u2019s been made by our governor, Andrew Cuomo.\u201d\n\nOnly 4 in 10 voters know anything about Ms. Nixon, according to a Siena College poll released this week. That same survey showed Mr. Cuomo leading her among registered Democrats by nearly 40 percentage points, including among every subgroup including women, liberals and minorities.\n\nMr. Cuomo has cast Ms. Nixon, best known for her role on \u201cSex and the City,\u201d as a B-list celebrity \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m hoping that Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie and Billy Joel don\u2019t get into the race,\u201d he said dismissively earlier this month \u2014 but he and his allies have reacted swiftly to her entry.\n\nOn Tuesday, Christine Quinn, the former New York City Council speaker who has been discussed as a possible running mate for Mr. Cuomo, called Ms. Nixon an \u201cunqualified lesbian.\u201d Ms. Nixon backed Mr. de Blasio over Ms. Quinn in the 2013 mayor\u2019s race.\n\n\u201cCynthia Nixon was opposed to having a qualified lesbian become mayor of New York City,\u201d Ms. Quinn told The New York Post, referring to her own candidacy. \u201cNow she wants to be an unqualified lesbian to be the governor of New York. You have to be qualified and have experience.\u201d\n\nMs. Quinn later apologized in an interview. \u201cI was clearly trying to make, perhaps, a tongue-in-cheek comparison that was ill-advised and poorly delivered, and I should never have tried to make,\u201d she said, though she stood by her comments that Ms. Nixon was unqualified.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cuomo was silent on Tuesday, in Albany with no public schedule ahead of the April 1 state budget deadline.\n\nBut late on Monday, hours after Ms. Nixon jumped into the race, Mr. Cuomo did make a splash of his own: directing the state attorney general to review the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s handling of a 2015 sexual assault allegation into Harvey Weinstein.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCelebrities, including the actress and producer Reese Witherspoon, had called on him to do so hours earlier.\n\nMs. Nixon\u2019s candidacy also got a boost from celebrities; a \u201cSex and the City\u201d co-star, Kristin Davis, and Rosie O\u2019Donnell quickly endorsed her for governor. But in a sign of Ms. Nixon\u2019s political climb ahead, no prominent elected official attended her event on Tuesday; hours afterward, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York formally endorsed Mr. Cuomo.\n\nOn her first full day as a candidate, however, Ms. Nixon seemed more than happy to put the focus on Mr. Cuomo.\n\nShe mocked him for his handling of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the subways. Ms. Nixon barely made her own launch in time because of train delays.\n\n\u201cCuomo\u2019s M.T.A.,\u201d she said to laughs. \u201cThree trains pulled out of service. We had to get off three trains.\u201d\n\nShe was just getting warmed up.\n\nShe hammered Mr. Cuomo for raising only 0.1 percent of his campaign funds from small donors. \u201cIf you are a regular person in New York, the chance that Andrew Cuomo is going to care about your concerns is exactly that: 0.1 percent,\u201d she said.\n\nShe linked him to the Koch brothers, two conservative billionaires who have become liberal boogeymen in recent years. \u201cThe Koch brothers donated $87,000 to Andrew Cuomo when he first ran in 2010 because they knew a good investment when they see one,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd she sought to link him to the recent corruption conviction of a former top aide, Joseph Percoco. \u201cThere is a reason that people close to Andrew Cuomo keep winding up under indictment for corruption,\u201d she said. (Mr. Cuomo was not accused of any wrongdoing in the Percoco trial and has called his former aide\u2019s behavior a \u201ctotal aberration.\u201d)\n\nRepresentative Sean Patrick Maloney, a New York Democrat who has endorsed Mr. Cuomo, called Ms. Nixon\u2019s challenge \u201ca wasteful, negative, time-consuming exercise when we should be linking arms and trying to win back the Congress.\u201d\n\n\u201dI can tell you from my perspective down here in Washington, I don\u2019t even know what this fight is about,\u201d he said. \u201cIt just seems like a petty squabble when we\u2019ve got a real fight on our hands.\u201d\n\nIn her speech, Ms. Nixon touched only briefly on her own biography \u2014 born in New York City, attended public schools, the mother of public school attendees \u2014 as her wife, Christine Marinoni, looked on from the side of the room.\n\nShe answered a couple of questions from reporters after her speech, including about her qualifications, as her aides tried to drag her from the scrum of cameras and recorders.\n\n\u201cI think it is time, not just in New York State but all over this country, to hear from the voices of real people who understand that our government in New York, and in many places across this country, including federally, is in the clutches of millionaires, billionaires and corporations,\u201d she said.", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Asks if Cuomo Is a \u2018Real Democrat\u2019 at Campaign Debut", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "The actress Cynthia Nixon officially jumped into the race for governor of New York on Monday, setting off what promises to be a tumultuous six months as she challenges Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in this year\u2019s Democratic primary.\n\nMs. Nixon, 51, has never before run for elected office and has chosen a huge undertaking for her first bid: seeking to unseat a two-term incumbent (and son of a three-term governor) who is sitting atop more than $30 million in campaign cash.\n\nThe contest will likely become one of the marquee Democratic primaries in the nation, as Ms. Nixon is widely expected to challenge Mr. Cuomo from the political left. Her campaign immediately cast Mr. Cuomo as a \u201ccentrist and Albany insider,\u201d and some of her initial rhetoric on inequality echoed Senator Bernie Sanders.\n\n\u201cWe are now the most unequal state in the entire country, with both incredible wealth and extreme poverty,\u201d she said in a video posted on Twitter announcing her candidacy.", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Enters Race for New York Governor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "If a race between Ms. Nixon and Mr. Cuomo does materialize, it would instantly become one of the most intriguing Democratic primaries in the country, pitting a celebrity first-time candidate with an ability to command national media attention versus a two-term incumbent sitting atop $30 million and known for his aggressive political tactics.\n\nMs. Nixon, best known for her role in the \u201cSex and the City\u201d franchise, would also be New York\u2019s first female and openly gay governor, if elected.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Nixon\u2019s Instagram feed has showed her making visits in 2018 across New York, including in Montauk, Skaneateles and Binghamton. (In Binghamton, she posted a photo of a Muhammad Ali mural with the words, \u201cFloat like a butterfly, sting like a bee.\u201d)\n\nMr. Cuomo brushed off Ms. Nixon\u2019s possible challenge, and the involvement of former de Blasio operatives, in an unrelated conference call with reporters on Tuesday. \u201cIn this business,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said with a laugh, \u201cyou can\u2019t let these things bother you. Otherwise you won\u2019t last long.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo was first elected governor in 2010 and is running for a third term.\n\nPolls show he remains popular among the broader Democratic electorate in New York but he is deeply disliked by an impassioned cohort of liberal activists. Four years ago, Zephyr Teachout, a virtually unknown challenger when she launched her long-shot bid against him, secured 34 percent of the primary vote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Nixon\u2019s celebrity would represent a unique challenge for Mr. Cuomo because of her ability to garner media interest. After her name was first floated as a possible candidate in August, she talked about the race on NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d show.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of people who would like me to run for a variety of reasons,\u201d she said then.\n\nA few months earlier, she appeared on ABC\u2019s \u201cThe View,\u201d where she took Mr. Cuomo to task for \u201cshortchanging the children of New York.\u201d\n\nMs. Nixon, a spokeswoman for the union-backed Alliance for Quality Education for years, joined Twitter in December and has quickly amassed 25,000 followers while sending only 41 tweets, most of them about politics. She has another 300,000 followers on Instagram.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn January, she headlined an event for millennial women, where she told reporters she was \u201cmaybe\u201d running for governor. And in remarks after a recent Broadway show, Ms. Nixon again said she was considering a bid.\n\nA Nixon candidacy would inevitably also be seen as another chapter in the long-running feud between Mr. de Blasio and Mr. Cuomo. Ms. Nixon was a regular presence on the campaign trail for Mr. de Blasio in 2013, and Ms. Nixon\u2019s wife, Christine Marinoni, works in the de Blasio administration.\n\nMs. Nixon was on the stage in January as Mr. de Blasio was sworn in for a second term. Mr. Cuomo attended a different swearing-in.", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Explores Possible Run Against Andrew Cuomo", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Nixon\u2019s allies see something else. \u201cHe\u2019s almost been having an emotional meltdown in the last week and a half,\u201d said Billy Easton, who serves as executive director of the Alliance for Quality Education, an advocacy group where Ms. Nixon has previously served as a spokeswoman.\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s team said that most of his recent activity, such as the Gore event and the endorsements, were already in the works before Ms. Nixon\u2019s ambition became part of the conversation.\n\n\u201cSaying the governor\u2019s schedule \u2014 which is planned weeks in advance \u2014 has anything to do with potential political challengers is like saying the fact that it snowed yesterday is because of potential political challengers,\u201d said Richard Azzopardi, a spokesman for the governor.\n\nYet people close to Mr. Cuomo said his response to Ms. Nixon\u2019s possible candidacy is born from an abundance of caution rather than fear. One adviser to the governor described Mr. Cuomo\u2019s political reaction as akin to a person who aggressively treats the early symptoms of a cold \u2014 from taking Theraflu to increasing fluids \u2014 in order to avoid the nuisance of actually getting sick.\n\n\u201cPolitical opponents send each other messages that you\u2019re not going to beat me and Governor Cuomo would be foolish to not make it clear to this opponent that he\u2019s going to win,\u201d said Christine C. Quinn, the former speaker of the New York City Council, a Cuomo ally whom he helped install as vice chairwoman of the state party. \u201cIf he didn\u2019t, people would be rightly saying he\u2019s weak and asleep at the wheel.\u201d\n\nOthers close to the governor have told Mr. Cuomo and his team that the totality of his response has been out of proportion to the actual threat posed by a celebrity who has not yet even declared her candidacy, and that he should be more measured going forward.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not nervous about whoever runs,\u201d Mr. Cuomo told reporters on Wednesday. \u201cThere\u2019ll be people who run. That\u2019s called elections, and that\u2019s fine.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Nixon\u2019s potential candidacy has resuscitated the persistent chatter, including among Mr. Cuomo\u2019s associates, that he might reconsider swapping his running mate, Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul, who has traveled the state relentlessly on Mr. Cuomo\u2019s behalf. As a former congresswoman representing Buffalo, Ms. Hochul was seen as a moderate Democrat with an A rating from the National Rifle Association. She now faces a primary challenge from Jumaane D. Williams, an African-American councilman from Brooklyn.\n\nAmong the names bandied about to replace Ms. Hochul has been Ms. Quinn, who, like Ms. Nixon, is openly gay. (Ms. Nixon aggressively backed Mr. de Blasio in the 2013 mayor\u2019s race over Ms. Quinn.)\n\nMs. Quinn demurred when asked about the lieutenant governorship. \u201cMy focus is on serving homeless women and children,\u201d she said of her role as chief executive of the homeless group Women in Need.\n\nMr. Cuomo has already said publicly that Ms. Hochul will be his running mate and his office reiterated that stance this week.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere are increasing signals that Ms. Nixon, best known for playing the lawyer Miranda Hobbes in \u201cSex and the City,\u201d plans to run, including her being spotted last week on the streets of New York City with what appeared to be a campaign camera crew, and her wife stepping down from a job in city government this week.\n\nTwo former top advisers to Mr. de Blasio, Bill Hyers and Rebecca Katz, have been in talks with Ms. Nixon, and both are known for running campaigns that mobilize the Democratic left, the portion of the party that has been most vocal in its criticism of Mr. Cuomo.\n\n\u201cIn 2018, we don\u2019t just need to elect more Democrats,\u201d Ms. Nixon pointedly said in a speech last month. \u201cWe also need better Democrats.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Cuomo, whose former top aide, Joseph Percoco, was convicted Tuesday of federal corruption charges, remains a heavy front-runner. A Quinnipiac University poll last month showed that 75 percent of Democrats in the state said they were inclined to re-elect him, and he has more than $30 million in campaign money. Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign asked donors to bolster that war chest last week, inviting them to a half-dozen events in the coming months with price tags as high as $50,000.\n\nIn recent days, Mr. Cuomo has burnished his progressive credentials.\n\nOn Sunday, he headlined a rally for a Democrat in a competitive special election in Westchester. On Monday, he appeared at a public housing site in the Bronx and decried the conditions as \u201cdisgusting.\u201d On Tuesday, he delivered a firebrand speech to Planned Parenthood in Albany where he said Democrats were fighting a \u201cbiased, bigoted, misogynistic backward mentality.\u201d On Wednesday, he joined a student walkout protesting gun violence, including the \u201cdie-in\u201d in Manhattan\u2019s Zuccotti Park, the original home of the Occupy Wall Street movement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPointedly, Mr. Cuomo lay on the ground alongside Ms. Weingarten, the head of the American Federation of Teachers, and rallied with Michael Mulgrew, president of the United Federation of Teachers. Four years ago, New York\u2019s biggest teachers union did not endorse Mr. Cuomo.\n\nThree days earlier, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s budget director, Robert Mujica, issued an 1,100-word statement about \u201cfair and equitable\u201d school funding \u2014 an issue Ms. Nixon has advocated around for more than a decade.\n\n\u201cWhat they\u2019re trying to do is reposition him publicly to make it look like he is suddenly championing education equity,\u201d said Mr. Easton, the schools advocate who has been critical of Mr. Cuomo.\n\nOn Thursday, the New York arm of the National Organization for Women \u2014 which under different leadership backed Mr. Cuomo\u2019s challenger four years ago in the primary \u2014 announced its early endorsement of the governor and Ms. Hochul.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s as good a time as any,\u201d said Sonia Ossorio, the group\u2019s president. \u201cPeople felt confident enough, even if others jumped in, we were making the right decision.\u201d\n\nIn the last 10 days, Mr. Cuomo has also engaged in fresh public battles with Mr. de Blasio, his longtime Democratic rival, calling elements of his record \u201crepugnant,\u201d threatening to declare a state of emergency in the city\u2019s public housing and working closely with the City Council to secure money for the subways that the mayor has resisted spending.\n\nBradley Tusk, a political strategist who served as campaign manager for the previous mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, said Mr. Cuomo \u201cis giving Nixon a taste of what she might be in for\u201d \u2014 with her ally, Mr. de Blasio, acting as a proxy.\n\n\u201cHe has a tremendous amount of resources, both in terms of money and levers he can pull, and he\u2019s very good at using them,\u201d Mr. Tusk said of Mr. Cuomo. \u201cNo one would question that for a second.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe state party, for instance, began spending $100,000 on a television ad this week praising Mr. Cuomo for \u201cpassing the strongest gun law in the nation,\u201d with a separate, smaller digital campaign this week focused on congressional Republicans, noting that six of them were given an A rating from the National Rifle Association.\n\nIn a letter to the party\u2019s executive director, a dozen party committee members objected to the spending on what \u201cappears to be a re-election ad,\u201d calling it \u201cpatently inappropriate\u201d because the party has not yet technically endorsed Mr. Cuomo. The executive director responded that Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign had \u201ccovered every dollar spent\u201d on the gun ads.\n\nMr. Tusk said the balancing act for how to react to a potential challenger is difficult for any politician.\n\n\u201cOn one hand, you don\u2019t want to look like you\u2019re too worried about it,\u201d Mr. Tusk said. \u201cOn the other hand, you don\u2019t want to inadvertently goad them into running. You play so many mind games with yourself to figure it out.\u201d", "title": "Cynthia Nixon Hints at a Run, and Cuomo Flexes His Muscle", "authors": ["Shane Goldmacher"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Much of what\u2019s going on also reflects cynicism about the status quo. \u201cIt is appalling that we are a country that has descended into a complete disregard for expertise,\u201d said Michael Specter, the author of \u201cDenialism: How Irrational Thinking Hinders Scientific Progress, Harms the Planet and Threatens Our Lives.\u201d \u201cBut is this a rejection of reality or a rejection of politics? To argue that actual politicians are useless, so let\u2019s try something else, is not completely insane.\u201d\n\nIndeed it\u2019s not. On top of which, many experiences other than lower-level government work can be useful, as Michael Bloomberg\u2019s New York mayoralty and Ronald Reagan\u2019s California governorship show. I\u2019d argue that Winfrey now has a sturdier claim on office than Reagan did when he ran for governor. But she would be aiming straight for the presidency. That\u2019s a bit much, as Trump has amply demonstrated.\n\nPlenty of Democrats accused Nixon of similar overreach. Christine Quinn, the former speaker of the New York City Council, was among them. In a bizarrely worded comment to The New York Post, she called Nixon an \u201cunqualified lesbian\u201d who had failed to support her, a \u201cqualified lesbian,\u201d when she ran for mayor in 2013. Quinn later apologized for bringing sexual orientation into the discussion, but she isn\u2019t backing down from her assessment that Nixon\u2019s accomplishments as an actress and dedication as an activist aren\u2019t adequate credentials. Nor should she.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s as if I decided I wanted to be an actor,\u201d Quinn told me. \u201cI speak in public. I get my picture taken. I need to lose a little weight, but aside from that, why can\u2019t I do this? Because I can\u2019t. The years I might have spent developing skills in that area, I spent developing other skills.\u201d\n\nNichols, a professor of national security affairs at the Naval War College in Rhode Island, said that the downgrading of experience and devaluing of expertise can be explained partly by the internet, which allows people to assemble their own preferred information and affords them the delusion of omniscience.\n\nThe narcissism of our era also comes into play, he said. Feelings have been accorded as much currency as facts. No one can claim more or better feelings than anybody else. And so Nixon\u2019s empathy as a mother and frustration as a subway rider, to name two themes in her video, carry as much weight as a political veteran\u2019s legislative wrangling and budget balancing.\n\n\u201cAmericans have a tendency to look around and think, \u2018We are all peers now,\u2019\u201d Nichols told me. \u201cIt sounds lovely. Except that when you\u2019re up to your hips in water in the basement and you\u2019ve got a plumber standing there, you hand the wrench to him and say, \u2018O.K., maybe we\u2019re not peers.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe mess of the Trump administration suggests where an insufficient respect for germane experience can lead. The president put Carson in charge of federal housing, Rex Tillerson in charge of diplomacy and Jared Kushner in charge of civilization itself. None of this panned out, but all of it was true to how Trump campaigned.", "title": "Opinion | Cynthia Nixon and the Age of Inexperience", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cCynthia Nixon and the Age of Inexperience\u201d (column, March 25):\n\nFrank Bruni\u2019s argument that our current \u201cromance\u201d with inexperienced political candidates degrades the importance of experience more generally reflects an erroneous view of politics in the United States.\n\nHis essay is a response to Cynthia Nixon\u2019s decision to run in the Democratic primary against Andrew Cuomo for governor of New York, but his point reflects a division between those who believe that political experience is required to govern well and those who do not.\n\nThere is a long tradition in the United States of governance by people with nonpolitical experience. The reason is simple: In a representative democracy we, in some sense, govern ourselves. Politics is not a technical discipline for which esoteric knowledge is indispensable.\n\nMy problem with Donald Trump, for example, has nothing to do with his political inexperience and everything to do with his moral and intellectual incompetence. Governing requires wisdom, not technical expertise. It truly is not brain science.", "title": "Opinion | Cynthia Nixon\u2019s Campaign: No Experience Required?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "The world is a difficult place right now. And tough times call for serious self-care. Some people need 10 minutes with a kind-of-creepy-but-ultimately-relaxing sheet mask on their face to feel calm \u2014 and for dewy skin. Some people need pints of cookie dough ice cream and to hide their phones in the freezer.\n\nAnd some people need the perfect inspirational quotation to float across their social media feed and put things in perspective. The right message can be an ideal remedy for a lost sense of self \u2014 or a lost cabinet position.", "title": "Opinion | Daily Affirmations From the White House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "With his oeuvre ranging from pointillism to cadavers as sculpture \u2014 the infamous shark in formaldehyde, shocking in 1992, was inspired by the film \u201cJaws,\u201d he said \u2014 much of it was made by an army of helpers. Was that the impetus for this different show?\n\nMr. Hirst says no. Help is common, he points out, from Michelangelo to the modern day. \u201cWhether you use lots of assistants or do it on your own,\u201d he said, \u201cas long as the result is what you want, it doesn\u2019t matter to me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt might to collectors. This year\u2019s personal touch could bump a value thinned after years of flooding. Representatives from Gagosian Gallery say the entire series has sold.\n\n\u201cIf they\u2019re all sold, it\u2019s a testament to the fan base of Damien,\u201d said Adam Lindemann, a New York collector who owns a handful of the artist\u2019s work and said he doesn\u2019t intend to sell. \u201cPeople believe in him and follow him, those collectors aren\u2019t just market conscious. They\u2019re not buying as speculation.\u201d\n\nAsked about the Venice show when it debuted last year, Eli Broad, the philanthropist and museum founder, remarked that it was \u201ckind of hokey.\u201d Recently he called Mr. Hirst \u201can innovative artist who always moves in new directions.\u201d The Broad would not comment on whether it had purchased any of the new work to add to its collection.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe public, however, still responds. At last week\u2019s opening, A-listers from film and the arts stood in a line stretching around the block to get in.\n\nMr. Gagosian, who has represented Mr. Hirst for three decades (Mr. Hirst left him in 2012 but returned in 2016), said the series sold so quickly, he may have underpriced the paintings. \u201cHe\u2019s never shown work like this, so we agreed on pricing that we thought was correct. They went from half a million for the smallest, $1.7 million for the larger ones.\u201d\n\nThis isn\u2019t quite a new style. Mr. Hirst did similar paintings in the early 1990s, but color was frowned upon back then, the artist recalled, and he \u201cdidn\u2019t have the courage at the time\u201d to embark on such a large scale so early on. These paintings he pumped out of his London studio over 12-hour work days while his team of carpenters, architects and electricians ensured that Venice remained on schedule. This is the anti-Venice, Mr. Hirst said, adding, \u201cI won\u2019t be rushing to do something like that again.\u201d\n\n\u201cI just had a gap,\u201d he continued. \u201cMy work for Venice stopped about a year before it opened. In a way that was a stroll compared to this.\u201d\n\nAnother series of paintings, this one from 2016 and created by his team, will be shown later this month at Houghton Hall in England. They are an extension of his famous Spot Paintings.", "title": "Damien Hirst\u2019s Post-Venice, Post-Truth World", "authors": ["Adam Popescu"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe University of Connecticut has hired Dan Hurley as its next men\u2019s basketball coach, hoping to turn the page on the coaching tenure of Kevin Ollie, which began with a national championship but ended with an N.C.A.A. investigation, the team\u2019s first losing seasons in 30 years and potential litigation.\n\nHurley spent the previous six seasons as Rhode Island\u2019s head coach, and the two before that as the head coach at Wagner, on Staten Island. He took Rhode Island to the last two N.C.A.A. tournaments. Last week, the seventh-seeded Rams beat Oklahoma before falling to second-seeded Duke.\n\nHurley is the son of Bob Hurley, formerly the longtime coach at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, and the younger brother of Bobby Hurley, a college star at Duke who is now the head coach at Arizona State.\n\n\u201cThis program, which is part of one of the top public universities in the country, has a championship history and wonderful support from a passionate fan base,\u201d Dan Hurley said Thursday in a school statement. \u201cI look forward to continuing this proud tradition.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe UConn men\u2019s program was largely overlooked and unaccomplished until Jim Calhoun took over in the mid-1980s. The instrumental quintet Starebaby began performing \u201cThe Memory of My Memory\u201d in ballad mode, easing into a swaying, dreamlike melody. But before long, the tempo started to stutter and swim, and the drummer and bandleader Dan Weiss nudged the group toward a harsh and forbiddingly loud climax.\n\nThe transition reflected the band\u2019s unusually broad skill set, documented on Mr. Weiss\u2019s new album, also called \u201cStarebaby.\u201d (The project takes its name from a remark that a friend\u2019s 8-year-old son made about Mr. Weiss\u2019s infant daughter.) The record\u2019s eight pieces, all by Mr. Weiss, touch on thorny prog, gritty noise, hushed melody and a kind of sci-fi minimalism powered by Matt Mitchell and Craig Taborn\u2019s twin Prophet-6 analog synthesizers.\n\nAt home in Brooklyn, a few days after the group\u2019s two-night New School stand, Mr. Weiss showed off a battle scar: a patch of raw, red skin between his left thumb and forefinger, the result of thwacking his snare with peak force while using a jazz drummer\u2019s traditional stick grip. \u201cI\u2019ve never had that before,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Weiss, 41, is now best known as a virtuosic, in-demand jazz drummer \u2014 he\u2019s also a seasoned tabla player \u2014 and an ambitious, imaginative bandleader. But from mid-2005 through early 2007, he could be found performing shirtless and hooded as a member of the New York doom-metal band Bloody Panda. \u201cI had a lot of fun playing those live shows,\u201d he said. But they took a physical toll. \u201cI remember fainting after one of them, and I was like, \u2018Yeah, I\u2019m not doing this.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe left the group but continued to follow metal closely, as he had since Metallica\u2019s 1988 LP \u201c \u2026 And Justice for All\u201d blew his young mind. He obsessed over bizarre, challenging bands, and his 2006 album, \u201cNow Yes When,\u201d included a piano-trio composition called \u201cOde to Meshuggah,\u201d which hints at that Swedish group\u2019s mind-bending rhythmic cycles.\n\nHe had already begun bonding with fellow jazz progressives like Mr. Taborn and Ben Monder over their mutual interest in heavy music. Mr. Monder, Starebaby\u2019s guitarist, recalled being on tour with Mr. Weiss soon after the release of Meshuggah\u2019s \u201cI,\u201d a dauntingly intense 2004 EP. \u201cI remember him coming into my hotel room and just slapping the headphones on my head, like, \u2018You\u2019ve got to check this out,\u2019\u201d he said in an interview at his Brooklyn apartment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Which of the following makes sense?\n\na) Three pirate ships on a river in a landlocked country in the Balkans;\n\nb) A 47-foot-high bronze statue of an ancient warrior that is Alexander the Great and is also not Alexander the Great; or\n\nc) A house dedicated to Mother Teresa, a saint known for her modesty, done up in an opulent style that can best be described as Miami meets the Flintstones.\n\nAnswer: None, unless you are in Skopje, Macedonia. They all have a home there as part of a long-running face-lift for the city, which has turned it into what could be one of the kitschiest capitals on the planet.\n\nSerbia 50 miles Kosovo Bulgaria Skopje Macedonia Ohrid Albania Greece\n\nAbout a decade ago, the then-governing party of Macedonia came up with an idea for a citywide building and renovation project as a way to claim ownership of its history and draw in tourists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHundreds of new sculptures were put up across the city, and many new buildings erected in the center of town. Weather officials say 10 inches of snow \u2014 or perhaps more \u2014 could blanket parts of New York; some areas of New England could get three to four inches of rain; and some coastal towns are expected to be hit with winds of 50 miles per hour or more.\n\nAlerts have been issued up and down the coast, but Kim Buttrick, a meteorologist at the Weather Service\u2019s office in Taunton, Mass., said the state\u2019s east coast \u2014 from Cape Ann south to Cape Cod and Nantucket \u2014 was expected to experience some of the most severe flooding.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Weather Service said roads, basements and other structures in those areas could become inundated by three feet of water or more, adding that the most severe coastal flooding was likely to occur during the high tides Friday night and Saturday afternoon.", "title": "Dangerous Nor\u2019easter Wallops East Coast With Wind, Snow and Rain", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Vo, 42, has expanded the definition of art by minimizing the role of the artist as a maker of original objects. He is equally a curator, collector, exhibition designer, photographer, historian, archivist and scourer of auctions and antique emporia.\n\nAt the same time, with maximum faith in the ability of modest objects to carry meaning, he extends the tradition that began with Duchamp\u2019s deadpan ready-mades. Some of Mr. Vo\u2019s works are unaltered ready-mades. Others are transformed by being taken apart or joined with foreign objects to form startling hybrids. The sculptures Mr. Vo began making in 2015, for example, combine fragments of Roman marble statuary with slices of Medieval figures, especially wood images of the Madonna and Child eroded nearly beyond illegibility. With these jarring clashes of civilizations and faiths, Mr. Vo returns the favor of the cultural vandalism that is a colonialist privilege.\n\nThe best examples of found objects broken down \u2014 and full of righteous anger \u2014 are the nine sculptures each titled \u201cLot 20. Two Kennedy Administration Cabinet Chairs.\u201d They resulted from dismembering two sturdy arm chairs that Mr. Vo bought at an auction of the personal memorabilia of Robert S. McNamara, the defense secretary under John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson who led the U.S. into what was sometimes called \u201cMcNamara\u2019s War\u201d in Vietnam.", "title": "Danh Vo: An Artist at the Crossroads of History and Diary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMy dad is the most hard-working person I know and both of my parents, nothing was ever handed to them,\u201d she said. \u201cTheir opportunity growing up was different from my opportunity, and I\u2019m grateful that they did everything they could for me.\u201d\n\nCollins\u2019 father liked to play tennis, but he was by no means a professional coach. Her parents had little background in the costly, high-pressured world of tennis development, let alone access to the elite academies and junior circuits that funnel so many top players into the highest professional ranks.\n\nBut after seeing the Williams sisters, Collins knew she, too, could make it from public courts to the pros. As a child, she was a fixture at the local courts in St. Petersburg, whacking balls off the backboard and hanging around looking for a game. Eventually some \u201cold people,\u201d as she described them, asked her to join their league and they taught her how to play doubles.\n\nBetween ages 8 and 12, she designed her own high-performance development program \u2014 she would approach grown-ups, middle-aged men and women, at the courts and ask them to hit with her, and they usually did, she said. By the time she was 12, she could beat even the best of them.\n\n\u201cIt taught me to be really savvy and resourceful,\u201d she said, \u201cto be like a little adult.\u201d\n\nHer parents took her to a few camps, and some coaches helped out. Eventually Collins attracted the attention of major universities. She chose Virginia, for a combination of the athletics and academics.\n\nCollins won the N.C.A.A. singles championship in 2014 but turned down the opportunity to turn professional because her greatest victory, she felt, would be to graduate. She did, in 2016 with a degree in media studies, and she also won her second N.C.A.A. singles title that year.\n\nAs much as she learned on the court in college, Collins believes that it was her hard work in the classroom, and the degree in her back pocket, that gives her an edge in matches today. Owning a degree from a top university, she said, provides her with a sense of calm in critical moments of big matches, melting away some of the pressure that her opponent may feel more.\n\n\u201cIt gives you peace of mind knowing this isn\u2019t do or die,\u201d she said. \u201cIf tennis doesn\u2019t work out, if I get injured, I\u2019m going to be O.K. I\u2019m going to be able to get a job, and I\u2019m going to be able to get a good job. I went to a good university and I worked hard. I can go out on the court with a much different perspective maybe than people who didn\u2019t go to college, and I really try to utilize that to the fullest.\u201d", "title": "Danielle Collins Faces Venus Williams, Who Inspired Her Rise From Public Courts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The trial is expected to take place over 12 days during the next two months, with a verdict expected in late April. On Thursday, Mr. Madsen pleaded not guilty to murder.\n\nThe trial prosecutor, Jakob Buch-Jepsen, spent the morning summarizing the case, the charges and the main evidence that will be presented. He said 37 witnesses would be called, a handful by the defense.\n\nHe also warned the court that graphic and disturbing photographs would be presented and said that, according to a psychiatric evaluation, Mr. Madsen was \u201cseverely aberrant,\u201d but not insane. He added that Mr. Madsen was manipulative and lacked empathy and feelings of guilt.\n\nOn March 24, 2017, Ms. Wall contacted Mr. Madsen, requesting an interview. They then met on Aug. 10, the day they departed on the submarine. The prosecutor showed pictures of Mr. Madsen and Ms. Wall sailing off into the Oresund Strait around 7 p.m. At 8:16 p.m., she sent the last text messages to her boyfriend. An image of the chat was shared with the courtroom on a screen.\n\n\u201cim still alive btw\u201d\n\n\u201cbut going down now!\u201d\n\n\u201ci love you!!!!!\u201d\n\n\u201che brought coffee and cookies tho\u201d\n\nAfter that, she went silent.\n\nForensic experts later found her blood on Mr. Madsen\u2019s face. Her underpants and nylon stockings, with cut marks, were found in the submarine. The courtroom was shown a video tour of the vessel, and the prosecutor showed footage of divers\u2019 efforts to recover Ms. Wall\u2019s body parts from the bottom of the ocean. There were shots of plastic bags, containing clothing and limbs, weighed down by metal pipes.\n\nMr. Madsen sat calmly, resting his chin on his fists at times, as he followed the proceedings intently. After a lunch break, he took the stand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt times cheeky, at times condescending, he had an answer for everything. He stuck to his most recent account that the death was a terrible accident caused by a malfunction that made the engines stop, the pressure to drop, the hatch to lock shut and gases to poison the air in the submarine, resulting in Ms. Wall\u2019s death. He said he survived because he was on top of the submarine at the time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe said a vent suddenly opened, allowing the hatch to open and fresh air to gush in. He said he tried to hide the death out of consideration for Ms. Wall\u2019s family. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to share with the rest of the world the horrible manner in which she died,\u201d he said.\n\nHe said he tried for two hours to get her body overboard, but gave up.\n\n\u201cAt that point, Peter Madsen can\u2019t do anything else,\u201d he said, speaking of himself in the third person. He said he drove around, rested, then decided the only thing left to do was to cut her up.\n\nWhen it was suggested that violent online videos inspired the mutilation, he disagreed, saying that he watched them to access feelings of empathy. \u201cI have a tendency to always root for the underdog and the weaker party,\u201d he said.\n\nThe prosecution asked: \u201cHow could you even have the idea of dismembering her? Are you inspired by such films?\u201d\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he answered. \u201cBut I worry about you for asking.\u201d\n\nMr. Madsen\u2019s testimony is at odds with the record. In the indictment, prosecutors said he had taken a \u201csaw, sharpened screwdrivers, straps, strips and pipes\u201d into the submarine before the trip. The straps and pipes, they say, were tied to Ms. Wall\u2019s torso and limbs to weight them down after he threw them overboard.\n\nWhile an exact cause of death has not been established because the body parts were in the water for so long, investigators say that she was either strangled, or her throat cut.\n\nMs. Wall had apparently intended to write about Mr. Madsen as part of an article about a Danish amateur space race. Though she had been in touch with him months earlier, it was not until the afternoon of her disappearance that he extended an impromptu invitation to interview him that evening on his submarine, the UC3 Nautilus.\n\nMs. Wall and her boyfriend, Ole Stobbe, had been scheduled to move to Beijing less than a week after she went missing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProsecutors have asked for a life sentence or, failing that, a sentence of \u201csafe custody,\u201d a special psychiatric measure for those considered particularly dangerous.\n\nWhile both sentences can be indefinite, Mr. Madsen could apply for parole after 12 years if given a life sentence. A sentence of \u201csafe custody\u201d in a secure medical institution is reviewed on a regular basis by the courts. The Danish Medico-Legal Council, an independent medical body that advises the courts, has recommended that Mr. Madsen be placed in safe custody.\n\nIn Denmark, serious crimes that carry more than a four-year prison sentence are normally tried before three judges and a six-member jury. But the accused has the right to a smaller panel, which is what Mr. Madsen has chosen. His trial is being conducted before Judge Anette Burko and two lay jurors. The opinions of the judge and each of the jurors carry equal weight.\n\nIn memory of Ms. Wall, her family and friends have set up a fund to support young female journalists. The first recipient will receive a grant of $5,000 on March 23, Ms. Wall\u2019s birthday.", "title": "Danish Inventor Accused of Submarine Murder Takes the Stand", "authors": ["Christina Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSYDNEY, Australia \u2014 Though a beloved member of an Australian swimming club, Daphne has a less-than-athletic figure and usually prefers bobbing gently in the water from the sidelines.\n\nBut this month at her club\u2019s annual ocean swimming competition, Daphne, a huge inflatable duck, was blown out to sea by a strong gust of wind, and despite a rescue attempt, was quickly dragged out into the vast Indian Ocean.\n\nHer disappearance left the nation asking, Where is Daphne?\n\n\u201cAfter 50 meters she was just gone, baby, gone,\u201d Peter Marr, the club\u2019s president, told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of his effort to swim after Daphne, who was supposed to be the event\u2019s star attraction. \u201cI couldn\u2019t keep up.\u201d\n\nThe club appealed for help on Facebook in its search to find Daphne. Anyone who had seen the giant rubber duckie mascot, and could help with her safe return, would be offered a small reward, the Cockburn Masters Swimming Club wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut on Monday, Mr. Marr confirmed that Daphne was no longer missing and had been rescued out at sea. She also beat Halep, now the world No. 1, in Wuhan, China, last fall.\n\n\u201cIn the beginning it was really tough because I was really nervous going on the big stages, on the big courts against the big players,\u201d Kasatkina said. \u201cBut now with experience, with the time, I\u2019m getting into it.\u201d\n\nNext week, Kasatkina is set to become the highest-ranked Russian for the first time, at around No. 15. She is currently ranked 19th, one spot behind Svetlana Kuznetsova, and could break into the top 10 if she defeats Angelique Kerber, another former No. 1, in the quarterfinals Thursday and goes on to win the title here.\n\nInsiders already know Kasatkina is a big-time talent, but outsiders will soon figure out that she is an entertainer as well.\n\n\u201cI think when people will see her regularly in the Grand Slams, they are really going to gravitate to her because her game is really atypical,\u201d Dehaes said. \u201cShe likes the show. She likes the jump backhands, the drop shots. She plays this way naturally, but it\u2019s festive tennis. I insist on leaving her a lot of freedom when she plays, but she has to create, has to make things happen, really like an artist. I compared it to an empty canvas a few days ago, and I said she can make whatever art on that canvas that she wants as long as it\u2019s beautiful.\u201d\n\nIf you have access to all the colors, it seems a pity not to make use of as many of them as you can.\n\n\u201cExactly,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s exactly the image.\u201d\n\nDehaes, a Belgian, became Kasatkina\u2019s full-time coach late last year after she split with Vladimir Platenik, a Slovakian who coached her for three seasons.", "title": "Daria Kasatkina Is Building Up to a Tennis Masterpiece", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Williams, who has yet to reach the final here, was often aggressive and effective on Friday. She was just two points from victory when she went up, 5-4 and 0-30, on Kasatkina\u2019s serve in the third set. But she missed a big-swinging forehand return on the next point off Kasatkina\u2019s second serve and never found her range consistently again.\n\nShe faded as the young Russian gathered strength to close out her latest high-profile opponent.\n\n\u201cThe crowd was unbelievable,\u201d said Kasatkina, the No. 20 seed. \u201cTo play Venus Williams on center court in the United States in the semifinals, one of the biggest tournaments, you just put your heart there, and that\u2019s it.\u201d\n\nAfter the first set, her coach, Philippe Dehaes, came on court to remind her that she is 20 and Williams is 37, implying that she could have superior staying power in a third set.\n\nBut though Williams\u2019s coach, David Witt, believed she became weary by the end, Dehaes said he didn\u2019t think \u201cage played much of a role after all.\u201d\n\n\u201cVenus was incredible, running everywhere,\u201d he said.\n\nSince September, Kasatkina has beaten a series of leading players, including Halep and all four reigning Grand Slam singles champions: Jelena Ostapenko, Garbi\u00f1e Muguruza, Sloane Stephens and Caroline Wozniacki (twice).\n\nAt Indian Wells, where the relatively slow court and high-bouncing conditions suit her varied game, Kasatkina has now defeated four former major champions in a row: Stephens, Wozniacki, Angelique Kerber and Williams.\n\n\u201cI think something has clicked in the last few weeks,\u201d Dehaes said. \u201cAnd today was real confirmation. I can\u2019t say yet that a champion is born. She has to win the title here, and she\u2019s not there yet, but in terms of what she\u2019s shown mentally, the others can start getting worried.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat seems clear, and both she and Osaka, whose talent is absolutely no secret in tennis circles, represent a new wave.\n\nBefore Osaka finished off Halep, Kasatkina was asked what it would mean to have two 20-year-olds facing off in their first final in one of the tour\u2019s top-tier events.\n\n\u201cThat we are coming,\u201d she answered. \u201cVery soon.\u201d\n\nRanked 19th, Kasatkina will break into the top 10 for the first time if she wins on Sunday. Osaka, who is 40th, will rise to No. 22 if she wins.\n\nBoth are thriving with new coaches \u2014 Dehaes for Kasatkina and Sascha Bajin for Osaka \u2014 who were hired late last year.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think this final is very refreshing; even their personalities are refreshing,\u201d Bajin said. \u201cThey are both fun to watch, exciting players in different ways. Daria has her beautiful touch, always some crazy points. Naomi has raw power and pure talent, so it\u2019s going to be exciting.\u201d\n\nIt will be another stylistic contrast, one in which Kasatkina \u2014 with her heavy topspin forehand, kick serve and crisply sliced one-handed backhand \u2014 will try to use all the tools in her well-stocked kit to keep the ball out of Osaka\u2019s strike zone and deprive her of the leverage with which she is perfectly capable of ripping winner after winner from the backcourt.\n\n\u201cDaria will have to do the Kasatkina,\u201d Dehaes said with a grin. \u201cIt needs to become a copyrighted brand: change of rhythm, change of speed, change of trajectory. She also will have to come up a bit more to the net than she did today against Venus, where we could see that she is still a bit afraid of that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen Kasatkina did make it to the net, she often produced drop volley winners, just as her deft touch and chutzpah allowed her to hit a critical backhand drop-shot winner from the baseline, with Venus serving at 5-5, 15-0, in the third set.\n\nIt would have been a low-percentage shot for most players.\n\n\u201cYou just feel it, and you do it,\u201d Kasatkina said. \u201cIt was by instinct, for sure.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWilliams went on to lose the next three points and her serve with a backhand error and back-to-back double faults before Kasatkina served out the victory, dropping her racket to the court and putting her hands over her face before trotting forward to the net.\n\nIt was her second victory in three meetings over Williams, who was particularly closelipped after this match.\n\n\u201cAnyone who gets used to losses should give up on life,\u201d Williams said.\n\nHalep seemed more resigned than disgruntled, citing the unexpectedly late hour of her match, the cool conditions and Osaka\u2019s superior form and focus as reasons for her collapse.\n\nIn an interview, Chris Evert, the ESPN analyst and former No. 1, called Halep\u2019s lackluster performance \u201cunprofessional.\u201d\n\nOsaka, the daughter of a Japanese mother and Haitian father who is based in Boca Raton, Fla., has struggled with on-court negativity of her own. But staying upbeat and in the moment has been a focus with Bajin, who was Serena Williams\u2019s longtime hitting partner before working with Victoria Azarenka, Stephens and, most recently, Wozniacki.\n\nWozniacki won the WTA Finals in October with Bajin in her camp before splitting with him in November. In early December, after receiving an invitation from Osaka\u2019s camp, he drove to Boca Raton from his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., for a tryout training session and sprained his right ankle badly after about five minutes.\n\n\u201cOne of those freak accidents,\u201d he said. \u201cI tried to keep going, of course, because I really wanted to work with her, so I bit down on my lip. It wasn\u2019t the smartest thing to do because my ankle is still swollen now, but I think she liked the vibe and the communication was good and we decided to give it a try.\u201d\n\nOsaka and Kasatkina have practiced together on tour and in Boca Raton. But despite being the same age, they have never played an official match as juniors or on tour.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t see her in juniors,\u201d Kasatkina said. \u201cBut she\u2019s playing really well. She\u2019s hitting hard. She has a good serve. She\u2019s improving so much.\u201d\n\nHer tweener still needs improving, however. She has yet to master the between-the-legs and back-to-the-net shot that Kasatkina and many other leading pros find handy (and flashy) when they are chasing down lobs.\n\nKastatkina, at the WTA\u2019s invitation, did her best to help Osaka last week.\n\n\u201cTechnically, it was so-so, but the ball was going in at least,\u201d Kasatkina said.\n\nSo will Osaka try one on Sunday?\n\n\u201cYeah, right,\u201d she said.", "title": "Daria Kasatkina and Naomi Osaka Represent a New Wave", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Lukoil was interested in how data was used to target American voters, according to two former company insiders who said there were at least three meetings with Lukoil executives in London and Turkey. SCL and Lukoil denied that the talks were political in nature, and SCL also said there were no meetings in London.\n\nThe contacts took place as Cambridge Analytica was building a roster of Republican clients in the United States \u2014 and harvesting the Facebook profiles of over 50 million users to develop tools to analyze voters\u2019 behavior.\n\nCambridge Analytica also included extensive questions about Russia\u2019s president, Vladimir V. Putin, in surveys it was carrying out in American focus groups in 2014. It is not clear what \u2014 or which client \u2014 prompted the line of questioning, which asked for views on topics ranging from Mr. Putin\u2019s popularity to Russian expansionism.\n\nOn two promotional documents obtained by The New York Times, SCL said it did business in Russia. In both documents, the country is highlighted on world maps that specify the location of SCL clients, with one of the maps noting that the clients were for the firm\u2019s elections division. In a statement, SCL said an employee had done \u201ccommercial work\u201d about 25 years ago \u201cfor a private company in Russia.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCambridge Analytica has been a political flash point since its role in the Trump campaign attracted scrutiny after the election. While Mr. Nix\u2019s firm turned over some records to the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence during its investigation of Russian interference, Democrats on the committee want a fuller review. \u201cIt is imperative to interview a broader range of individuals employed by or linked to Cambridge Analytica,\u201d they said in a report this month.\n\nAsked about the Russian oil company, a spokesman for SCL said that in 2014 the firm\u2019s commercial division \u201cdiscussed helping Lukoil Turkey better engage with its loyalty-card customers at gas stations.\u201d The spokesman said SCL was not ultimately hired.\n\nArash Repac, chief executive of Lukoil Eurasia Petrol, offered a different explanation for the talks.
