Reuters reported last year that Lukoil and other companies received instructions from the state energy ministry on providing news stories favorable to Russian leadership.", "title": "Data Firm Tied to Trump Campaign Talked Business With Russians", "authors": ["Danny Hakim", "Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Fresh off his collaboration with the MSNBC commentator Rachel Maddow, the constructor Joe DiPietro returns to remind us to beware solving crossword puzzles in mid-month.\n\nWait, that can\u2019t be right. He must mean something else.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nWhat he\u2019s really trying to say is that today\u2019s date, March 15, was known to ancient Romans as \u201cTHE IDES of March,\u201d which meant the middle of the month to them.\n\nIt comes up when people talk about the emperor Julius Caesar, whose head became so swollen from political power that he began to think of himself as \u201cemperor for life\u201d and was pondering declaring himself king, if you are a fan of William Shakespeare\u2019s take on his life. In fact, Shakespeare\u2019s historical play would have you believe that the Roman senators who murdered Caesar did so because they felt it would save the republic:\n\n\u201cIf then that friend demand\n\nwhy Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:\n\n\u2014 Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved\n\nRome more.\u201d \u2014 Brutus, Julius Caesar, Act III, Scene 2\n\nAnd yet there are historians who now believe that it\u2019s all in how you look at things and that the senators felt that Caesar was a major fun-suck who was getting in the way of some righteous plundering of lands.\n\nAnyway, the puzzle. Mr. DiPietro uses THE IDES revealer at 38A to give us a hint to his theme set in the Down entries, all beginning with the homophonic contraction I\u2019D. For example, at 20D, we have the clue \u201c\u2018Yes, how nice of you to offer\u2019\u201d and the answer is I\u2019D BE HONORED. Collectively, the four theme entries make up THE IDES.", "title": "Date That Provides a Hint", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nM\u00e1 P\u00eache, David Chang\u2019s quirky, underground restaurant in the Chambers Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, will end its eight-year run on June 13.\n\nUntil then, the menu will feature dishes from over the years. The company decided to terminate its lease early to allow it to move employees over to the new Momofuku Noodle Bar in the Time Warner Center, opening around that time. Fuku+, the Momofuku chicken sandwich spot on the ground floor of the hotel, will also close, but Milk Bar, for baked goods, will remain open.\n\nPhoto\n\nM\u00e1 P\u00eache was Mr. Chang\u2019s breakaway restaurant, his first outside the East Village, where he made his name with various Momofuku iterations. (Sam Sifton, reviewing the restaurant for The New York Times in 2010, gave it two stars.) Now, he has major projects not only uptown at Columbus Circle, but also in Hudson Yards and the South Street Seaport area. He has opened a restaurant, Majordomo, in Los Angeles. At the same time, efforts at food delivery he has been involved in, Maple and Ando, have both closed.\n\nAnd, at the end of the year, Danny Meyer will close North End Grill, a pioneer for fine dining in Battery Park City when it opened in 2012. Pete Wells reviewed it twice for The Times, in 2012 and 2015, awarding it two stars each time. It is the third time Mr. Meyer\u2019s Union Square Hospitality Group has closed a restaurant, not counting Union Square Cafe, which lost its lease and has reopened in a new location. The first was Tabla, near Madison Square Park, and the second was GreenRiver in Chicago.\n\nUntil late last year, the North End Grill kitchen was under the direction of the chef Eric Korsh, who left amid allegations of misconduct with staff members. (Mr. Korsh, who has denied the accusations, has just left his post as executive chef at Racines NY in TriBeCa.) Until North End Grill closes, the executive chef will be Emily Brekke.", "title": "David Chang\u2019s M\u00e1 P\u00eache and Danny Meyer\u2019s North End Grill Announce Closings", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "It seems that these successes within the department have intensified the ambitions of people who want to put V.A. health care in the hands of the private sector. I believe differences in philosophy deserve robust debate, and solutions should be determined based on the merits of the arguments. The advocates within the administration for privatizing V.A. health services, however, reject this approach. They saw me as an obstacle to privatization who had to be removed. That is because I am convinced that privatization is a political issue aimed at rewarding select people and companies with profits, even if it undermines care for veterans.\n\nUntil the past few months, veteran issues were dealt with in a largely bipartisan way. (My 100-0 Senate confirmation was perhaps the best evidence that the V.A. has been the exception to Washington\u2019s political polarization.) Unfortunately, the department has become entangled in a brutal power struggle, with some political appointees choosing to promote their agendas instead of what\u2019s best for veterans. These individuals, who seek to privatize veteran health care as an alternative to government-run V.A. care, unfortunately fail to engage in realistic plans regarding who will care for the more than 9 million veterans who rely on the department for life-sustaining care.\n\nThe private sector, already struggling to provide adequate access to care in many communities, is ill-prepared to handle the number and complexity of patients that would come from closing or downsizing V.A. hospitals and clinics, particularly when it involves the mental health needs of people scarred by the horrors of war. Working with community providers to adequately ensure that veterans\u2019 needs are met is a good practice. But privatization leading to the dismantling of the department\u2019s extensive health care system is a terrible idea. The department\u2019s understanding of service-related health problems, its groundbreaking research and its special ability to work with military veterans cannot be easily replicated in the private sector.\n\nI have fought to stand up for this great department and all that it embodies. In recent months, though, the environment in Washington has turned so toxic, chaotic, disrespectful and subversive that it became impossible for me to accomplish the important work that our veterans need and deserve. I can assure you that I will continue to speak out against those who seek to harm the V.A. by putting their personal agendas in front of the well-being of our veterans.\n\nAs many of you know, I am a physician, not a politician. I came to government with an understanding that Washington can be ugly, but I assumed that I could avoid all of the ugliness by staying true to my values. I have been falsely accused of things by people who wanted me out of the way. But despite these politically based attacks on me and my family\u2019s character, I am proud of my record and know that I acted with the utmost integrity. Unfortunately, none of that mattered.\n\nAs I prepare to leave government, I am struck by a recurring thought: It should not be this hard to serve your country.", "title": "Opinion | David J. Shulkin: Privatizing the V.A. Will Hurt Veterans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement after his death, Loretta Swit, who played Maj. Margaret (Hot Lips) Houlihan on \u201cM*A*S*H,\u201d called Mr. Stiers \u201cmy sweet, dear shy friend,\u201d adding, \u201cWorking with him was an adventure.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDavid Allen Ogden Stiers was born on Oct. 31, 1942, in Peoria, Ill., the son of Kenneth Stiers and the former Margaret Elizabeth Ogden. The family later moved to Eugene, Ore., where David graduated from high school.\n\nAfter briefly attending the University of Oregon, he headed to California to pursue an acting career and worked with the Santa Clara Shakespeare Festival in California for seven years. In the late 1960s, he moved to New York to study drama at Juilliard.\n\nThere he became a member of John Houseman\u2019s City Center Acting Company, making his Broadway debut with the company in 1973. He appeared in \u201cThe Three Sisters,\u201d \u201cThe Beggar\u2019s Opera\u201d and three other plays, which ran in repertory.\n\nHe continued to appear on the New York stage in the 1970s and returned to Broadway later in his career, playing a beloved wartime general in the 2009-10 holiday run of \u201cIrving Berlin\u2019s White Christmas.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Stiers had made his film debut with a small role in Jack Nicholson\u2019s counterculture classic \u201cDrive, He Said\u201d (1971). That year, his voice was heard as the announcer in George Lucas\u2019s debut feature film, the dystopian sci-fi drama \u201cTHX 1138.\u201d\n\nVoice roles went on to become an important part of Mr. Stiers\u2019s career. He was in the cast of about two dozen Disney animated films, including \u201cLilo & Stitch\u201d (2002), as the villain Jumba Jookiba, and \u201cBeauty and the Beast\u201d (1991), in which he was the voice of Cogsworth, a strong-willed pendulum clock. That character, often described as \u201ctightly wound\u201d and \u201cticked off,\u201d suggests to the Beast at one point that he woo his love with \u201cflowers, chocolates, promises you don\u2019t intend to keep.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther movie work included roles in \u201cOh, God!\u201d (1977), \u201cThe Man With One Red Shoe\u201d (1985), \u201cThe Accidental Tourist\u201d (1988) and four Woody Allen films. (He was a peculiar hypnotist in Mr. Allen\u2019s \u201cThe Curse of the Jade Scorpion.\u201d) His last screen appearance was in \u201cThe Joneses Unplugged,\u201d a 2017 television movie about technology overload.\n\nLike his \u201cM*A*S*H\u201d character, Mr. Stiers was a devoted fan of classical music. He conducted frequently and was the resident conductor of the Newport Symphony Orchestra (formerly the Yaquina Chamber Orchestra) in Oregon.\n\nHe never married. Some reports have suggested that he is survived by a son from an early relationship.\n\nIn early 2009, at 66, Mr. Stiers announced that he was gay and \u201cvery proud to be so\u201d in a blog interview that was reported by ABC News. His secrecy, he said, had been strictly about the fear that openness about his sexuality might affect his livelihood. Now he regretted that.\n\n\u201cI wish to spend my life\u2019s twilight being just who I am,\u201d he said.", "title": "David Ogden Stiers, Major Winchester on \u2018M*A*S*H,\u2019 Dies at 75", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "This theory helped account for the kinds of languages spoken in the Pacific, the agriculture, and styles of pottery, as well as the mix of East Asian and New Guinea DNA found in the islanders.\n\nDr. Spriggs and other archaeologists provided Dr. Reich with bones from Vanuatu and Tonga, and his team succeeded in recovering DNA where others had failed. And what did it say about the prevailing theory?\n\n\u201cWe found genetically that wasn\u2019t right at all,\u201d Dr. Reich said. He and his colleagues published their results last month in the journal Current Biology.\n\nInstead, the people who first arrived on Vanuatu and other Pacific islands came directly from Asia \u2014 perhaps Taiwan or the Philippines \u2014 without ever stopping in New Guinea. Only later did a wave of Papuans arrive.\n\n\u201cWe know now when that wave hits \u2014 it hits before 2,400 years ago,\u201d said Dr. Reich. \u201cAnd it\u2019s a total replacement.\u201d\n\nAnd that second wave actually was made up of at least two migrations. The Papuans who came to what is now Vanuatu probably sailed from the Bismarck Islands. But the Papuans who arrived further east, in Polynesia, came from other islands, possibly New Britain.", "title": "David Reich Unearths Human History Etched in Bone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The book became a best seller. It also riled some of Dr. Wyman\u2019s fellow historians. Especially contentious was its unflattering portrait of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who Dr. Wyman concluded did nothing for 14 months after learning in 1942 of the mass exterminations of Jews in Nazi Germany \u2014 and, when he finally did act, did so only out of political calculus.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf you look in a larger context,\u201d the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. complained in 1994, reacting to an episode of PBS\u2019s documentary series \u201cAmerican Experience\u201d based largely on Dr. Wyman\u2019s book, \u201cno one did more to save the Jews in Europe than Franklin Delano Roosevelt, by his opposition to Hitler, by changing the United States from an isolationist nation to a nation prepared to go to war.\u201d\n\nDr. Wyman remained unapologetic.\n\n\u201cIf it had gone into depth on Roosevelt and the Holocaust,\u201d he said of the PBS program, \u201cit would have been worse. There would have been a couple of more positive things to say, and eight or 10 worse things.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDavid Sword Wyman was born on March 6, 1929, in Weymouth, Mass. His father, Hollis, was a mechanical engineer, and his mother, the former Ruth Sword, was a teacher and librarian.\n\nHis family attended the Centenary Methodist Church in Auburndale, Mass., where young David was involved with the youth group. He was a grandson of two Protestant ministers, and his later research took on a personal dimension when he documented the failure of American Christians to speak or act on behalf of European Jews during the war.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t cry easily, but all my life I had been taught to believe in the good Samaritan, yet here were Christians killing Jews in Europe,\u201d he told The New York Times in 1984, describing an emotional reaction to his own research. \u201cAnd here was The Christian Century, a religious magazine that had always been at the cutting edge of care and concern, failing to raise its voice against the Holocaust.\u201d\n\nHe graduated from Boston University in 1951 with a degree in history. He received a master\u2019s degree in education at Plymouth State College in New Hampshire in 1961 and a doctorate in history at Harvard in 1966, taking a job that same year teaching history at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. He retired there in 1991.\n\nDr. Wyman first began to examine the response to Naziism in \u201cPaper Walls: America and the Refugee Crisis 1938-1941,\u201d published in 1968. \u201cThe Abandonment of the Jews\u201d was not the first book to suggest a systemic failure to act on the part of the United States and England, but it was perhaps the most thoroughly researched. Dr. Wyman put 15 years into the project, scouring numerous archives. His book was 444 pages long and included 71 pages of footnotes.\n\nIn his research he found not only a president and Christian leaders who seemed uninterested in the problem, but also a federal bureaucracy that could be openly hostile to helping Jews, a news media that underplayed the shocking revelations about the exterminations, and a Congress and country where anti-Semitism and anti-immigration sentiment encouraged inaction. Gas chambers and the rail lines leading to them could easily have been bombed, he found, and rescue efforts could have saved at least some of the millions who died.\n\nDespite the complaints by some historians, John Gross, reviewing the book in The New York Times, found Dr. Wyman\u2019s conclusions well grounded.\n\n\u201cWhere there are allowances to be made, he makes them,\u201d he wrote; \u201cwhere there are honorable exceptions, he honors them; but in the end he is compelled to hand down a damning indictment.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2003 scholars and others inspired by Dr. Wyman\u2019s book founded the Wyman Institute to promote education and research on the response to the Holocaust. Dr. Medoff said Dr. Wyman had been reluctant to see his name on the letterhead.\n\n\u201cHe was an extremely humble person and never would have created an institute named after himself,\u201d Dr. Medoff said by email, adding, \u201cIt took considerable effort to persuade him to let us put his name on it.\u201d Dr. Wyman did, however, become chairman of the organization.\n\nDr. Medoff said that Dr. Wyman\u2019s book about the failure to rescue European Jews during World War II played a role in rescuing about 800 Ethiopian Jews four decades later. They had been stranded in Sudan when an effort to airlift them to Israel to escape famine and discrimination was halted. A copy of Dr. Wyman\u2019s book, then on the best-seller lists, was given to George H. W. Bush, who was then the vice president, and he and his aides were urged by Representative John Miller, Republican of Washington, to read it and take action.\n\n\u201cI told them that this was a chance to write a very different history than the history of America\u2019s response to the Holocaust,\u201d Mr. Miller was quoted as saying in a 2008 article that Dr. Medoff wrote about the moment.\n\nIn March 1985, American planes took the rest of the refugees to Israel. Dr. Wyman later met some of them on a visit to that country.\n\nDr. Wyman\u2019s wife, the former Mildred Louise Smith, whom he married in 1950, died in 2003. He is survived by a son, James; a daughter, Teresa; a sister, Nancy Bissell Spraragen; two grandchildren; and a great-grandson.\n\nIn his landmark book, Dr. Wyman posed questions that seem ever relevant.\n\n\u201cWould the reaction be different today?\u201d he asked. \u201cWould Americans be more sensitive, less self-centered, more willing to make sacrifices, less afraid of differences now than they were then?\u201d", "title": "David Wyman, Scholar of America\u2019s Holocaust Response, Dies at 89", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Davide Astori, who played 14 times for Italy\u2019s national soccer team, was found dead on Sunday in his hotel room in Udine, Italy. He was 31.\n\nAstori, a defender and captain of the Fiorentina team, was discovered by team staff members when he failed to show up for breakfast. The team was scheduled to play in Udine, in northeast Italy, later in the day.\n\n\u201cThe belief is that the player died of a cardiac arrest by natural causes,\u201d the Udine prosecutor, Antonio De Nicolo, said. \u201cIt is strange that such a thing should happen to a professional who is so closely monitored without there being any warning signs.\u201d", "title": "Davide Astori, Italian Soccer Star, Dies at 31", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "But does daylight time still save energy? Not really, according to most research on the subject. Lighting has become a smaller part of overall energy consumption, and extending the use of daylight hours encourages people to use more air conditioning and heating.\n\nA 2017 analysis of 44 different papers on the subject found that, on average, the policy helped save 0.34 percent of electricity use. Places farther from the Equator (with mild summers and lower cooling demands) might save energy, but places closer to the Equator used more energy during daylight time, the researchers found.\n\n\u201cThe policy makes some sense in Scandinavia, but not in Spain,\u201d Tomas Havranek, an associate professor in energy economics at Charles University in Prague who led the study, wrote in an email. Even in Scandinavia, Dr. Havranek noted, the savings would be moderate.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, when daylight time begins in spring, people are often waking up during \u201cthe coldest, darkest part of the day,\u201d and turning up heat to stay warm, said Matthew Kotchen, a professor of economics at Yale who led a 2008 study on the effectiveness of the policy in Indiana. During long evening hours in the summer, Dr. Kotchen added, people tended to \u201ccrank up the A.C.,\u201d leading to overall higher energy use.\n\nHe and his colleagues found that turning clocks forward increased residential electricity demand, costing households in Indiana an extra $9 million a year and increasing emissions. \u201cThe way people use energy now is different from when daylight saving came about,\u201d he said.", "title": "Daylight Saving Time Isn\u2019t Saving Much Energy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "When her neighborhood in Stafford, Va., went dark on Friday, Trisha Christian made the most of it. She and her boyfriend cooked some of their frozen and refrigerated food \u2014 spinach, beef, risotto and shrimp \u2014 before it could spoil.\n\n\u201cIt was a nice evening. You light the fire, every single candle that you own,\u201d Ms. Christian, 53, said in a phone interview on Sunday. \u201cDefinitely put the layers on.\u201d\n\nThings got trickier on Saturday when they began rationing \u2014 and then boiling \u2014 water for the shower. Ms. Christian said she thought power might be restored on Monday, but was unsure because she could not access internet data on her phone \u2014 that service was down, too.\n\nPower restoration schedules varied by utility company and the extent of damage. Some areas were expected to be restored by Monday, while others may have to wait until as late as Saturday.\n\nRichard Rodriguez, 53, of Stillwater, N.J., lost electricity on Friday.\n\n\u201cYou go outside and you hear this symphony of generators,\u201d he said in a phone interview on Sunday. Mr. Rodriguez has one, too, but the line to buy gas was long. He, his wife and his children were doing their best to conserve energy: no microwave, no dishwasher and no washing machine.\n\nWhile Mr. Rodriguez had seen a lot of anger toward the local utility companies, he said he understood that these things can take time. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to be thankful for the people going out there to fix this,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019re going to be working around the clock and risking their lives and safety.\u201d", "title": "Days After Powerful Storm, Hundreds of Thousands Remain Without Power", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Three days later, on Oct. 25, she was found in the bathroom of the Upper West Side apartment where she worked as a nanny for Marina and Kevin Krim. Two of the Krims\u2019 children \u2014 Lucia, 6, and Leo, 2 \u2014 lay stabbed to death in a bathtub. Ms. Ortega had plunged a knife into her own neck in a suicide attempt.\n\nCharged with two counts of first-degree murder, Ms. Ortega, 55, has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. Her trial will turn largely on her mental-health history and her state of mind on the day of the slayings.\n\nProsecutors maintain Ms. Ortega killed the children because she resented the Krims\u2019 affluence and was angry over her own financial straits.\n\nBut her defense team claims Ms. Ortega had suffered from chronic bouts with psychosis since she was a teenager, even though they went untreated until her arrest.\n\nThe lead prosecutor, Stuart Silberg, sought to use Mr. Caffrey\u2019s testimony to undermine Ms. Ortega\u2019s claim that she was too separated from reality at the time of the murders to be held legally responsible.\n\nOn cross-examination Ms. Ortega\u2019s lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, tried to highlight holes in Mr. Caffrey\u2019s evaluation, noting he failed to ask questions about her medical history to verify his diagnosis. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t that kind of evaluation,\u201d Mr. Caffrey said. \u201cIt was the beginning of a therapy deal.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo prevail in an insanity defense in New York, the defense must prove Ms. Ortega was so impaired by a mental disease that she could not understand the consequences of her acts or did not understand what she did was wrong.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is a high bar, defense lawyers have said.\n\nEven defendants with long, documented histories of mental illness have been found guilty because it was proved they understood they had killed someone and that it was wrong.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPsychiatrists who have examined Ms. Ortega in jail for the defense have said she has told them about hearing disembodied voices telling her to hurt people and about other hallucinations, among them seeing giants fighting and feeling Satan touch her skin.\n\nBut Mr. Caffrey is the only psychologist known to have evaluated Ms. Ortega before the murders, even if briefly. He said she called him on the morning of Oct. 22 and pleaded urgently for an appointment, offering to wait outside his office until he had a cancellation.\n\nShe arrived at about 12:30 p.m. with another woman, who did not come in, Mr. Caffrey said. Once seated in his office, Ms. Ortega said she was upset over the money she had spent to bring her teenage son to the United States and enroll him in a private school in the Bronx.\n\nThe boy\u2019s father had abandoned them when he was 4, she told Mr. Caffrey, and she had taken him to the Dominican Republic, leaving him in her sister\u2019s care and returning to New York to find work.\n\nShe told Mr. Caffrey that she had been \u201cfeeling racing-heart anxiety as a result of the moves and her son\u2019s being here.\u201d She said she felt she had \u201cnot done well by\u201d her son and spoke of having argued bitterly with her sister over the cost of the move, Mr. Caffrey said.\n\nThe psychologist said he interpreted the heart palpitations as a symptom of panic attacks. He also said Ms. Ortega also showed signs of melancholy. \u201cShe did not seem to see a bright future, proximately or remotely, for herself,\u201d he said.\n\nOn cross-examination, Mr. Caffrey acknowledged he had not asked Ms. Ortega about hallucinations or hearing voices. Nor had he asked other questions aimed at ruling out psychosis in reaching his diagnosis that she had a depressive disorder.\n\nHe said he would have done so as part of a full psychological evaluation, but this was a consultation for someone seeking therapy. \u201cThis was a first session,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Caffrey relied heavily on his notes, and said he had no independent recollection of what Ms. Ortega had said beyond his typewritten summary. For instance, he said he could not remember if he had asked Ms. Ortega about her work as a nanny.\n\nBut he said he was sure Ms. Ortega never made a threat to murder anyone or to commit suicide, and he would have called the authorities if she had. Asked if he was obligated to report such threats, he said: \u201cI feel I am, and I have in the past, but I put myself in some peril because I am breaching confidentiality.\u201d\n\nIn response to a question from Mr. Silberg about anything he would have done differently during his first and final therapy session with Ms. Ortega, Mr. Caffrey said: \u201cIn retrospect, there\u2019s lots of things I should have asked.\u201d", "title": "Days Before Slaying, Nanny Was \u2018Worried, Anxious, Frightened\u2019", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Under Mayor Bill de Blasio, New York City is financing affordable housing at a breakneck pace, creating or preserving over 24,500 units last year \u2014 more than any year on record. To do so, the administration spent $1.1 billion, the most ever by the city in a single year, according to City Hall officials.\n\nPart of the reason for the increased spending is simple mathematics: A plan that seeks to preserve the affordability of 180,000 units of existing apartments and build 120,000 new ones is going to cost more.\n\nBut there is another factor: The administration is trying to expand affordable housing at a time when the market has been increasingly unfavorable, following changes to the tax code under the Trump administration.\n\nMarc Jahr, who ran the city\u2019s Housing Development Corporation under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said that changes in the tax code had hurt the expansion of affordable housing, not just in New York City but across the nation. \u201cIt\u2019s reduced the price of credit and increased the amount of subsidy the city has to put in deals,\u201d he said.", "title": "De Blasio Bolsters Affordable Housing, but at What Price?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "On Thursday, not for the first time, defense lawyers at the Long Island trial raised the possibility that they might call the mayor as their own witness, and have him repeat to a jury the attacks on Mr. Singh\u2019s credibility that he has made in other public places.\n\nWhile the defense has not yet subpoenaed Mr. de Blasio, such a move could result in the unprecedented spectacle of a sitting New York mayor being hauled into court to describe as dishonest a man who has described him as corrupt.\n\nThe actual defendants at the trial, in Federal District Court in Central Islip, are Edward Mangano, the onetime Nassau County executive, and John Venditto, the former town supervisor of Oyster Bay, N.Y., both of whom Mr. Singh has already pleaded guilty to bribing.\n\nFor much of the week, Mr. Singh has been testifying about the men\u2019s alleged misdeeds \u2014 among them accusations of accepting thousands of dollars in furniture, plane tickets, discounted limousine rides and other gifts from Mr. Singh, in return for helping him get bank loans and county contracts between 2010 and 2014.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs part of his testimony, Mr. Singh said on Thursday that he had also improperly raised money for Mr. de Blasio in order to win better terms for a lease on the Water\u2019s Edge, his restaurant on city-owned property in Queens. Earlier this year, Mr. de Blasio said that he \u201cwas thoroughly looked at\u201d by investigators, and that there \u201cwere no charges brought because there was nothing there.\u201d On Friday, both the city\u2019s Law Department and Mr. de Blasio\u2019s personal lawyer declined to comment on the prospect of him being called as a witness.\n\nIf, however, Mr. de Blasio does get a subpoena, he would not be the first big-city mayor to be asked to testify at a federal court proceeding. In 2016, two Chicago police officers sought to compel testimony from Mayor Rahm Emanuel after Mr. Emanuel spoke about his Police Department\u2019s so-called code of silence in a speech to the Chicago City Council.\n\nLawyers for the city tried to block the court appearance, arguing that Mr. Emanuel was busy at City Hall and had no \u201cactual and unique knowledge\u201d of the case. They contended that it was \u201cabsurd to suggest that the mayor of the third largest city in the United States should be required to testify in a case of which he has no personal knowledge.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, a federal judge ruled against them and ordered Mr. Emanuel to testify. It never happened, though, because the case was settled before it went to trial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a similar situation, a group of black firefighters who were suing New York City for racial discrimination asked a federal judge in 2009 for permission to depose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in their case. The judge, Nicholas G. Garaufis, sided with the firefighters and allowed the deposition, ruling that Mr. Bloomberg had direct personal knowledge of the matter and that his testimony would not \u201csignificantly interfere\u201d with his management of city business.\n\nBut mayors \u2014 in New York City and elsewhere \u2014 have only rarely appeared as witnesses at criminal proceedings. In 1988, Mayor Edward I. Koch took the stand as a prosecution witness at the federal bribery trial of Bess Myerson, his onetime cultural affairs commissioner. Ms. Myerson stood accused of trying to influence a judge in the divorce case of her married boyfriend, Carl A. Capasso, a millionaire sewer contractor. Fidgeting and sighing, Mr. Koch showed up in court and told the jury he had \u201cno recollection\u201d of the matter. Ms. Myerson was eventually acquitted.\n\nLast year, lawyers for the Lake Boyz, a group of gang members in Fort Myers, Fla., issued a subpoena to the city\u2019s mayor, Randy Henderson, trying to force him to testify about policing practices at their trial. But the subpoena was quashed by the city\u2019s chief lawyer, Grant Alley, who successfully argued to a judge that the city\u2019s manager, not its mayor, was in charge of the police.\n\nMr. Alley, however, noted that things might turn out differently for Mr. de Blasio.\n\n\u201cIn a criminal case, you have to err on the side of the rights of the criminal defendant,\u201d he said. \u201cIf a mayor has relevant information related to a theory of defense, it will be difficult to shield that mayor from a protective order.\"", "title": "De Blasio Could End Up a Witness in Case He Sought to Avoid", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was thoroughly looked at, and there\u2019s a reason there were no charges brought, because there was nothing there,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said in January.\n\nOn Thursday, a mayoral spokesman reiterated Mr. de Blasio\u2019s stance, saying, \u201cThis administration acted appropriately at all times, as we\u2019ve said several thousand times.\u201d\n\nBut the testimony on Thursday raised new questions.\n\nMr. Singh testified that he met Mr. de Blasio when he was the city\u2019s public advocate. At the time, Mr. Singh said, he was having issues with his Water\u2019s Edge restaurant, which was on city property in Long Island City, Queens.\n\nThe restaurateur was behind on the rent, and a dispute had arisen over who was responsible for the replacement of a nearby pier. Mr. Singh\u2019s restaurant would benefit from the work, but he did not want to pay for it.\n\nHe also wanted to ensure that the lease would be renewed.\n\nMr. Singh said he called Thomas J. Garry, a lawyer and Democratic Party official, who knew Mr. de Blasio. The three met for lunch at Water\u2019s Edge in the summer of 2011 or 2012, the restaurateur said.\n\nThe lunch started what would eventually become \u201ca very close relationship,\u201d according to Mr. Singh.\n\nAs Mr. de Blasio and his staff arranged for meetings with officials, the restaurateur said he started fund-raising at Mr. Garry\u2019s request. Two events while Mr. de Blasio was public advocate each brought in $10,000, Mr. Singh said, and four more during the mayoral campaign added between $30,000 and $60,000, he said.\n\nThen there were the personal campaign contributions. Records show that Mr. Singh, his family and other associates collectively contributed tens of thousands of dollars. Garry, a campaign donor and former Democratic Party official \u2014 also connected Mr. Singh to Mr. de Blasio.\n\n\u201cOne thing that\u2019s going to come out in this case is that Singh has pleaded guilty to bribing Mayor Bill de Blasio,\u201d Mr. Agnifilo said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the same firm\u201d that he used to connect with the mayor, he explained to reporters later.\n\nMr. Singh\u2019s relationship with Mr. de Blasio was a focus of 18 months of investigations by the F.B.I. and the United States attorney\u2019s office for the Southern District of New York. Although prosecutors ultimately did not charge the mayor, they harshly criticized him and his fund-raising practices.\n\nThat investigation and the case that opened Wednesday are part of a string of corruption cases that federal prosecutors in New York have brought in recent years.\n\nIn the latest trial, a former Cuomo aide, Joseph Percoco, was convicted on Tuesday of soliciting and accepting more than $300,000 in bribes from executives for two companies with state business. Her leadership of a campaign against the construction of the dam, on the Gualcarque River, which is sacred to her Lenca people, garnered a prestigious international award and international attention, and her murder by gunmen two years ago generated intense pressure to find her killers.\n\nNow the Honduran police have arrested the man who at the time was chief executive of the company building the dam, Roberto David Castillo Mej\u00eda. He is at least the ninth person arrested in the killing, but, more important, he was identified as an \u201cintellectual author\u201d of the crime, or a mastermind behind the company employees, hired assassins and members of the army already under arrest for the murder.\n\nThe arrest offers a glimpse into the links between government, military and business elite in a culture of corruption. Honduras is the deadliest country in the world for environmental activists. Ms. C\u00e1ceres and two other members of her organization were among 14 killed in 2016.\n\nAfter her death, a team of international lawyers found that the killing had been months in the planning. Some of them had only recently regained power after losing it in Friday\u2019s storm.\n\nThe last two snowstorms have fallen particularly hard on the suburbs north and northeast of the city, where overhead power lines are vulnerable to high winds, heavy, wet snow and toppled trees.\n\nAfter suspending all service on Wednesday night, Metro-North sent 146 workers out across its network to remove 69 fallen trees, using chain saws and muscle, said Aaron Donovan, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. More than 31 of those trees were among the reasons that the Danbury and New Canaan branches of the railroad in Connecticut were shut down on Thursday, Mr. Donovan said.\n\nAlong Metro-North\u2019s Harlem Line, 13 power poles were damaged on Wednesday between Brewster and Goldens Bridge. The poles held up the cables that carried electricity to the trains and the track-side signals.\n\nIn contrast, the Long Island Rail Road, also operated by the transportation authority, never shut down and was running a nearly normal schedule on Thursday, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. In their wake, regulators demanded that the companies improve their storm preparedness, including the pruning of trees near power lines to reduce the risk of failures.\n\n\u201cVegetation management is always a problem,\u201d said Joseph L. The Weinstein Company\u2019s board said at the time that promised interim funding from the group had not materialized, leaving bankruptcy as the only option.\n\nBut on Thursday, Mr. Schneiderman got the sale back on track by holding a meeting in his offices with Mr. Burkle and Ms. Contreras-Sweet and members of the Weinstein Company\u2019s board, including Bob Weinstein and Lance Maerov, an executive at the advertising giant WPP Group. Mr. Burkle, who has a long history with the Weinstein Company, stepping in to help Harvey Weinstein finance films like \u201cOur Idiot Brother\u201d in 2011, asked for the meeting.\n\nMr. Schneiderman sued the company and the Weinstein brothers on Feb. 11, alleging that they violated state and city laws barring gender discrimination, sexual harassment and coercion. A deal for the company had been expected to be formalized on Feb. 12, but the lawsuit brought sale talks to a halt.\n\nAmy Spitalnick, the press secretary for Mr. Schneiderman, said on Feb. 11 that his office had recently reached out to representatives of Ms. Contreras-Sweet to emphasize the importance of adequately compensating victims, protecting employees and not rewarding those who enabled or perpetuated Mr. Weinstein\u2019s misconduct.\n\n\u201cWe were surprised to learn they were not serious about discussing any of those issues or even sharing the most basic information about how they planned to address them,\u201d Ms. Spitalnick said. Mr. Schneiderman said again in a Feb. 12 news conference \u201cthere was no victim compensation fund.\u201d\n\nMs. Contreras-Sweet was stunned by Mr. Schneiderman\u2019s public remarks, according to one person briefed on the matter, believing that he was overlooking money for victims that had been built into her proposal.", "title": "Deal for Weinstein Co., Seemingly Dead, Is Reached", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nMy friends around the country and I have started a video-chat book club. We have pretty eclectic tastes, and there are a few members of our club who have read practically everything, so finding new books is a challenge. So far we have read \u201cOut,\u201d by Natsuo Kirino, translated by Stephen Snyder (which we are happy to have read, though it was not a favorite); \u201cHer Body and Other Parties,\u201d by Carmen Maria Machado (most of us liked it); \u201cIza\u2019s Ballad,\u201d by Magda Szabo, translated by George Szirtes (we all liked it); and \u201cThe Arab of the Future,\u201d by Riad Sattouf, translated by Sam Taylor (our reviews were mixed). We\u2019d like to steer clear of white male authors, if possible. Do you have any somewhat recent, off-the-beaten-path recommendations?\n\nMARK THOMSON\n\nMINNEAPOLIS\n\nDear Mark,\n\nYou\u2019ve hit on the question that makes all book fiends beam. The next time you visit your local bookstore, try asking a few booksellers for their neglected favorites, and then watch them nearly levitate with previously pent-up joy. The injustice of under-read authors prompts passionate readers to evangelize about obscure loves.\n\nSmall Worlds\n\nThe stories of Nam Le\u2019s debut collection, \u201cThe Boat,\u201d will engage all the members of your book group, not least because their multiplicity offers something for everyone. In the opening story, a student at the Iowa Writers\u2019 Workshop navigates his filial relationship with his Vietnamese father who has come for a visit. In a more cinematic tale, Juan Pablo Merendez, a 14-year-old assassin in Colombia, has his considerable skills and nerve tested when his boss orders an intimate hit. A very different coming-of-age story, \u201cHalflead Bay,\u201d follows the romantic, social and family pressures facing Jamie, a high school athlete in a bleak seaside Australian town.\n\nTake Flight\n\nTwo novels about refugees in Europe would make a smart discussion pair for your group. In Mahi Binebine\u2019s dramatic and lyrical novel \u201cWelcome to Paradise,\u201d translated by Lulu Norman, a trafficker ferries a boatful of desperate migrants across the Strait of Gibraltar from Morocco toward Europe. In Jenny Erpenbeck\u2019s piercing novel \u201cGo, Went, Gone,\u201d translated by Susan Bernofsky, the searing personal stories of a group of African refugees in Berlin change the life course and emotional landscape of a recently retired classics professor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYouth and Consequences\n\nTwo moving books about teenage sexuality \u2014 both of which deserve a larger audience \u2014 evoke the raw feelings of youthful love affairs. The relationship between Aviva and Seung in \u201cThe Virgins,\u201d by Pamela Erens, makes them \u201cthe sexual and romantic templates\u201d for all the other students at their New England boarding school. But their story, diabolically \u201camplified and embroidered\u201d by the classmate who narrates it, twists to end in tragedy. The mood of \u201cSkim,\u201d a graphic novel written by Mariko Tamaki and illustrated by Jillian Tamaki, also has its share of heartbreak. But the narrator, Kim \u2014 a morose romantic who has a rocky home life, practices Wicca, avoids gym class and falls in love with her English teacher, Ms. Archer \u2014 keeps the tone winningly adolescent.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
