Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAltered States\n\nThe day after Helen Moran, the prickly narrator of Patty Yumi Cottrell\u2019s debut, \u201cSorry to Disrupt the Peace,\u201d learns about her adopted brother\u2019s suicide, she writes an email to her supervisor at the New York City center for troubled young people where she works, whose \u201csubject line was A DEATH IN THE FAMILY (NOT THE BOOK).\u201d Throughout the tale of sorrowful suspense, Helen seeks clarity and finds darkly skewed humor in the murkiest, bleakest setup: Teetering on the edge of sanity, she travels back to her childhood home in Milwaukee to look for answers surrounding her brother\u2019s sudden death.\n\nSince most of your group enjoyed \u201cHer Body and Other Parties,\u201d you should try \u201cMrs. Caliban,\u201d Rachel Ingalls\u2019s efficient, aberrant love story from 1982 (reissued last year). When Dorothy, the grieving mother and (mostly) estranged wife at the heart of this speculative, feminist gem, begins hearing odd, occasionally personalized messages issuing from her old-fashioned radio, her rationalization that \u201csound waves were getting mixed up\u201d can\u2019t stretch to cover what comes next. A new broadcast, slightly different in tone from the others, announces the violent escape from a research center of \u201cAquarius the Monsterman.\u201d The \u201c6-foot-7-inch froglike creature\u201d with \u201ca bit of a foreign accent\u201d soon shows up in Dorothy\u2019s kitchen. She feeds him spaghetti. He introduces himself as Larry. Interspecies romance ensues.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Hidden Gems", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nI am an avid reader of detective stories, and I am particularly interested in those with a strong sense of place. In my youth I loved reading about Dashiell Hammett\u2019s San Francisco, Raymond Chandler\u2019s Los Angeles and Ross Macdonald\u2019s Santa Barbara. More recently I have read the wonderful noir-themed anthologies published by Akashic Books, collecting stories set in regions from Moscow to Boston to Barcelona. I especially like to read books with international locations. Lawrence Osborne\u2019s \u201cThe Forgiven\u201d and \u201cHunters in the Dark\u201d are two of my most recent favorites. Can you help me find mysteries that unfold all over the globe?\n\nLILLIE CHALMERS\n\nREDLANDS, CALIF.\n\nDear Lillie,\n\nThe growing stacks of suspenseful books from around the world that are available to American readers provide a boon to both armchair detectives and armchair travelers \u2014 and to readers who identify as both. Fans of international thrillers no longer need to rely strictly on the observations of gumshoes who are just passing through. The more books are translated into English, the more opportunities readers have to experience the atmospheric thrills that come from native authors writing close to home.\n\nA Night to Remember\n\n\u201cIt is early evening in early December. Glasgow is wet and dark but still warm, the bitterness of winter has yet to bite.\u201d Denise Mina\u2019s moody, mesmerizing book from last year, \u201cThe Long Drop,\u201d opens in mild weather, but the historical novel, based on a real-life set of murders in 1950s Scotland, soon shows its teeth. Suspected of killing his wife, daughter and sister-in-law, William Watt seeks to clear his name and pinpoint the real perpetrator with the help of Peter Manuel, a career criminal with \u201can eye for a weakness or a half-opened window or a chance.\u201d In clipped prose, Mina reimagines the events surrounding the crimes, including the (weirdly true) story of the night the two men spent drinking together prior to Manuel\u2019s dramatic trial for the homicide.\n\nImperfect Unions\n\nThere\u2019s no hard-boiled detective brooding in Seicho Matsumoto\u2019s tightly controlled thriller \u201cA Quiet Place,\u201d translated by Louise Heal Kawai. Instead it is a middle-aged Japanese government bureaucrat, Tsuneo Asai, who investigates the sudden death of his much younger haiku enthusiast wife, Eiko. As the details behind Eiko\u2019s suspicious death surface, the story darkens and a devastating portrait of Japanese customs and manners emerges.\n\nAnother marriage marked by secrets cracks open early in \u201cCrimes of Winter,\u201d the third book in Philippe Georget\u2019s series about Inspector Gilles Sebag, translated by Steven Rendall. A more typical noir antihero, the whiskey-gulping, chain-smoking lieutenant is gifted with uncommon insight and empathy that enable him to first suspect and then confirm his wife\u2019s affair by the end of the first chapter. The trouble extends out of the inspector\u2019s front door into the streets of Perpignan, a Catalonian city in Southern France where a string of violent crimes \u2014 beginning with a murder in a seedy hotel \u2014 underscore the book\u2019s theme of betrayal and test the heartsick cop\u2019s investigative skills.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGiuseppe Lojacono, the hero of Maurizio de Giovanni\u2019s bleak crime story \u201cThe Crocodile,\u201d translated by Antony Shugaar, is another down-on-his-luck European detective with sharp instincts. Falsely accused by an informant of tipping off the Mafia, Lojacono begins the book exiled from Sicily to desk duty in Naples. But when a serial killer strikes, the detective makes an early break in the case by spotting a key piece of evidence at a crime scene. His quick work lands him a spot on the investigative team and the chance to stop the killer before he strikes again.\n\nYoung Blood\n\nThe teenage murder victims in Kwei Quartey\u2019s socially conscious crime novel \u201cChildren of the Street,\u201d the second Inspector Darko Dawson mystery, live on the bustling streets of Accra, Ghana. And it\u2019s up to Darko, the tenderhearted pot-smoking detective, to pursue leads in the cases of these gruesome slayings throughout the shadiest corners of the capital before the killer claims his next victim.\n\nThe Making of a Criminal\n\n\u201cA man by himself isn\u2019t honest for long,\u201d thinks the wily, impulsive, unemployed narrator in Patr\u00edcia Melo\u2019s grimly amusing thriller \u201cThe Body Snatcher,\u201d translated by Clifford E. Landers. After he witnesses a plane crash while river fishing in the lowlands of Brazil near the Bolivian border, the unnamed protagonist steals the dead pilot\u2019s watch and kilo of cocaine. Visions of cash propel him down an increasingly twisty path of crime, which gives the novel its exquisite tension as well as its ever-deepening sense of dread.\n\nYours truly,\n\nMatch Book\n\nDo you need book recommendations? Write to matchbook@nytimes.com.\n\nCheck out Match Book\u2019s earlier recommendations here.", "title": "Dear Match Book: International Books of Mystery", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Drawing Fire\n\nEven the most contemplative graphic novels offer a kinetic sense of play guaranteed to hook your colleagues\u2019 interest. Why not launch your feminist exploration with an illustrated book set in a place that may be unfamiliar to all of you? Marguerite Abouet\u2019s six-volume \u201cAya\u201d comics series, set in Ivory Coast in the 1970s (illustrated by Abouet\u2019s husband, Cl\u00e9ment Oubrerie, and translated by Helge Dascher), follows the lives of its ambitious but dutiful namesake protagonist and her more freewheeling friends, Bintou and Adjoua. In \u201cAya: Love in Yop City\u201d \u2014 which encompasses the last three chapters in the series \u2014 Aya, now a medical student, is sexually assaulted by her biology professor. The shame she feels in the wake of her attack shifts over the course of the book as she plans a fiery revenge.\n\nIn her illustrated story collection \u201cBoundless,\u201d Jillian Tamaki flips the script: To read the first and last of her kooky and elegant tales, you often must rotate the book 90 degrees. The stories\u2019 subjects \u2014 an eerie \u201cmirror Facebook\u201d; a promotional pitch for a skin care product \u2014 unfold with a deliciously wry feminist slant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStranger Things\n\nA pair of mesmerizing and eccentric story collections would make excellent additions to your reading list. Carmen Maria Machado\u2019s inventive, sexually exuberant debut, \u201cHer Body and Other Parties\u201d \u2014 which includes a novella-length section outlining 272 speculative, alternative views of \u201cLaw & Order: SVU\u201d episodes \u2014 reveals characters with crystalline consciousnesses clouded by their fabulist circumstances. In K\u014dno Taeko\u2019s \u201cToddler-Hunting and Other Stories\u201d (published in Japan throughout the 1960s and translated by Lucy North and Lucy Lower), it is the women themselves \u2014 alienated, but composed \u2014 who push past boundaries to enact lucid waking nightmares.\n\nThe Marriage Trap\n\nThe domestic bonds that doom the female characters in the classics of the Western feminist canon \u2014 from \u201cThe Yellow Wallpaper,\u201d by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, to \u201cWide Sargasso Sea,\u201d by Jean Rhys \u2014 find echoes in two arresting novels by Asian writers. \u201cThe Waiting Years,\u201d Fumiko Enchi\u2019s psychologically astute 1957 novel of stifled emotions, traces the protracted humiliation of Tomo, a 19th-century Japanese wife obliged to procure a series of mistresses for her husband over the course of their marriage.\n\nIn Han Kang\u2019s propulsive, lacerating novel \u201cThe Vegetarian,\u201d translated from the Korean by Deborah Smith, the bloodless union between Yeong-hye, a hushed bookworm, and her largely indifferent husband ruptures when she ceases to be a carnivore. \u201cStop eating meat, and the world will devour you whole,\u201d Yeong-hye\u2019s mother chides. And she\u2019s right: When Yeong-hye asserts her dietary will, characters around her react with violent rage.\n\nIsland Women\n\nFor a change of pace, introduce your book club to Jessica Hagedorn\u2019s raucous, warmly florid novel \u201cDogeaters,\u201d set in the Philippines in the 1950s. The book is crowded with politics and crime, movie stars and soapy family stories. The extended cast features women caught in a culture that fetishizes glamour, including an unlikely beauty queen who denounces her crown and the central narrator, a girl named Rio Gonzaga who is 10 when the book begins and already in possession of discerning tastes and an enviable wisdom about the world.\n\nYours truly,\n\nMatch Book\n\nDo you need book recommendations? Write to matchbook@nytimes.com.\n\nCheck out Match Book\u2019s earlier recommendations here.", "title": "Dear Match Book: I\u2019m Starting an International Feminist Book Club", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nI am the head librarian at an independent school for children from preschool through 12th grade. I am in the happy position of having many middle-school-age pupils who read significantly above their grade level, but I struggle to find books for them \u2014 especially realistic fiction \u2014 that are sophisticated but do not overwhelm the students with complex themes. In the years leading up to high school, readers walk a tightrope: They are ready to begin exploring more mature ideas and writing structures, but they aren\u2019t always ready for full-on realistic drama. What titles can you recommend for these avid readers?\n\nJENNIFER FALVEY\n\nCOLUMBIA, S.C.\n\nDear Jennifer,\n\nAt school my older children learned the five-finger rule for finding a \u201cjust-right book\u201d: If it has more than five unfamiliar words on one page, the book is deemed too challenging for a student to read. I sympathize with the practicality of the guideline, and understand that it is aimed mostly at developing readers, but in practice I find the rubric a little deflating for young bookworms. Part of the joy of unbridled childhood reading lies in the haze of misunderstanding; the mystifying behavior of adult characters and even scads of obscure vocabulary can spur curiosity and spark richly imaginative embellishments to fill in the gaps. Your more expansive approach \u2014 to look for books that will challenge your students \u2014 allows for who they are and who they will become.\n\nOld Standbys\n\nYour library is probably stocked with classics that your tightrope-walking middle schoolers will enjoy. Fluent, attentive readers of that age will fall for the warm, slyly playful first-person narration and meaty characters in Charles Dickens\u2019s \u201cGreat Expectations.\u201d And they might relate to the story of childhood friendship in Willa Cather\u2019s more leisurely paced prairie novel \u201cMy \u00c1ntonia.\u201d\n\nEverything Old Is New Again\n\nI\u2019m sure your shelves also hold some of my recent favorites: \u201cThe Thing About Jellyfish,\u201d by Ali Benjamin (for more science-minded kids); \u201cWhen You Reach Me,\u201d by Rebecca Stead (a great companion to \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d by Madeleine L\u2019Engle); and \u201cBrown Girl Dreaming,\u201d by Jacqueline Woodson (a memoir in verse for your budding poets). But I also want to make a pitch for some mid-to-late-20th-century (mostly) realistic books for younger readers that may have fallen off your radar. Robert Cormier\u2019s deeply unsettling, desperately suspenseful and structurally complicated novel from 1977, \u201cI Am the Cheese,\u201d tracks the thoughts of Adam Farmer, a troubled boy on a bicycle who is caught up in sinister events beyond his understanding.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Reading for Precocious Preteens", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "We will flex our muscles at the ballot box, too. Many high school seniors will cast their first ballots this November, and in 2020, a majority of today\u2019s high school students will most likely be able to vote in their first presidential election. And we will not forget the elected officials who turned their backs on their duty to protect children.\n\nLet us remind politicians like Donald Trump, Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell who accept donations from the National Rifle Association and oppose efforts to restrict gun purchases that we are the future leaders and voters of this country. Let us remind corporations like FedEx that provide discounts to N.R.A. members that we are their future customers.\n\nThe Stoneman Douglas students who began speaking out after the killings last month have better articulated the need for common-sense gun control laws and school safety than our elders ever have. But those students cannot do it alone. We as a generation must band together behind them, just as Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, Thomas Jefferson and others stood behind George Washington and fought to create this great country.\n\nWe applaud many of the elected officials who have said they will work to reduce gun violence in their states. We hope Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey, our home state, will work with us and other advocates to do the same. We also support companies like Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods, Avis Budget Group, Hertz, Delta, United and Walmart, which have stood behind the principles of the March for Our Lives movement and either cut ties with the N.R.A. or changed their policies on firearms sales.\n\nOn March 24, hundreds of thousands of children and teenagers nationwide will participate in March for Our Lives. We are among the 19 students helping organize New Jersey\u2019s march, which will take place in Newark, a city with far too much gun violence. We implore students, their parents, teachers, school administrators, religious leaders, corporate executives and elected officials across the country to join any march, no matter where they are, and fight to make our schools safe.\n\nMarch for Our Lives is not just one day. It represents the official start of when we all must stand with the Stoneman Douglas students and say, \u201cNever again.\u201d This isn\u2019t about being aligned with one political party or another. This is about protecting this nation\u2019s children, whether they are related to you by blood, or whether they are children you have taught or nurtured.", "title": "Opinion | Dear National Rifle Association: We Won\u2019t Let You Win. From, Teenagers.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIsrael\u2019s Self-Inflicted Wounds\u201d (Op-Ed, March 19):\n\nRonald S. Lauder expressed a sentiment felt by the more than 280 members of Commanders for Israel\u2019s Security, a network comprising the majority of retired Israeli generals.\n\nWe share Mr. Lauder\u2019s belief that \u201cthe only path forward is the two-state solution,\u201d and are united in the conviction that Israel\u2019s long-term security and Jewish and democratic character can be assured only by separating from the Palestinians in a two-state agreement.\n\nWe also agree with Mr. Lauder that West Bank annexation schemes are \u201cdestructive\u201d and must be stopped.\n\nWith more than three decades of security service each, we know that the Israel Defense Forces can handle any challenge, providing our leaders with the space needed for a bold initiative on the Palestinian front.", "title": "Opinion | Debating a Two-State Solution for the Middle East", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Deborah Carrington, who broke into Hollywood by answering an ad for dwarf actors, and later performed stunt work and costume-specific roles in Hollywood blockbusters and campy horror movies, died on March 23 at her parents\u2019 home in Pleasanton, Calif. She was 58.\n\nHer sister, Kathy Ellis, said that the cause had not been determined but that Ms. Carrington had dealt with health problems over the past year.\n\nAudiences might best remember Ms. Carrington, whose stage name was Debbie Lee Carrington, for her violent performance as Thumbelina, the 3-foot, 10-inch pink-clad prostitute in the 1990 sci-fi action film \u201cTotal Recall.\u201d The movie told the story of a construction worker in the future who visits a colonized Mars.\n\nDuring a mob scene, Thumbelina stabs one of the movie\u2019s villains with a bowie knife before jumping on a table and mowing down the police with a machine gun.", "title": "Deborah Carrington, 58, Dies; Actress and Stuntwoman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Without fresh oxygen coming in, the population dynamics of our internal bacterial communities change and our resident decomposers increase, and without a live immune system at work, they spread throughout the body. They consume the proteins in our cells and produce byproducts like methane and hydrogen sulfide gas that bloat and rupture the body. The nasty smells of the dead attract insects that disassemble the bulk of the body mass, and the altered acidity of our remains attracts fungal decomposers. If there are any pathogens on the corpse, microbes in the soil kill them, or they die of exposure or lack of food, which is why graveyards aren\u2019t hotbeds of disease.\n\nAll this can take months. And it\u2019s not just happening from the inside out. Top predators are broken down by top detritivores. In a Tibetan sky burial, a naked human corpse is transported to the top of a mountain on the back of a relative\u2019s moped, the flesh flayed and left exposed to be eaten by large carrion birds. The remaining bits are consumed by smaller detritivores like rats and beetles. Fungi and bacteria break down the molecular leftovers into life\u2019s raw ingredients, and still other types of bacteria help recycle the building blocks of life back into the pool of opportunity. Sad as death is, it\u2019s also about opportunity.\n\nSo it takes a village of detritivores and decomposers to recycle a corpse. That\u2019s why the designer Jae Rhim Lee\u2019s Infinity Burial Suit \u2014 basically pajamas threaded with fungal spores bred to decompose bodies \u2014 can\u2019t really fulfill its promise to ensure you a speedier decomposition. The suit costs $1,500, as does the Infinity Burial Shroud (there\u2019s an \u201cadd to cart\u201d button on Ms. Lee\u2019s website, which I think is a much more sensitive choice than \u201ccheck out\u201d). But fungi are actually pretty bad at decomposing corpses on their own. We bury our dead deep, and fungi are aerobic. They need air. The truth is, not much will happen quickly to a corpse or anything organic if it\u2019s buried six feet under the soil\u2019s surface, because the diversity of decomposers drops off the deeper you go.\n\nIf it\u2019s efficient land-based breakdown you are after, it\u2019s probably best to be buried under a pile of wood chips, which have lots of little air pockets to keep aerobic decomposers alive.\n\nThere is life after death, and it is mainly microbial. Microbes like bacteria bridge the living and nonliving spheres of the Earth. Life starts with microbes that use energy and secure food from inorganic sources like atmospheric gases and minerals (this includes plants: The parts of the plant that do the work of photosynthesis, chloroplasts, evolved from ancient bacteria). Once those nutrients are in the bacterium, they become terrestrialized, and available to other earthbound critters, all the way up the food chain to us. And then, when we die, there are bacteria waiting to release those elements back into the nonliving sphere.", "title": "Opinion | Decomposition: An Easter Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The British poet Alexander Pope once wrote that \u201cto err is human; to forgive, divine.\u201d Federal judges deciding the sentences of two white-collar defendants this month had to weigh whether requests for forgiveness and professions of remorse were enough to reduce the punishment.\n\nMartin Shkreli, nickname the Pharma Bro for raising the price of a decades-old drug more than 50-fold, was convicted on three counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. At his sentencing, a tearful Mr. Shkreli told the court that he was there \u201cbecause of my gross, stupid and negligent mistakes.\u201d Judge Kiyo A. Matsumoto of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn was sympathetic, but she rejected Mr. Shkreli\u2019s request for a sentence of 12 to 18 months. Instead, Judge Matsumoto imposed a seven-year prison term, finding that Mr. Shkreli had engaged in an \u201cegregious multitude of lies.\u201d\n\nJeffrey A. Wertkin, a former Justice Department lawyer, pleaded guilty in November to trying to sell secret complaints that he stole before leaving the government to companies named as defendants under a whistle-blower statute. His attorney asserted in a court filing that there was \u201clittle doubt that it was nonetheless an aberrant detour \u2014 one that he will never repeat.\u201d Rather than the proposed sentence of a year and a day, however, Judge Maxine M. Chesney of Federal District Court in San Francisco gave him a 30-month prison term.\n\nA long-held criticism of the sentences of white-collar defendants was that they got off easy compared with other criminals because the violations did not appear to be as threatening. That has changed. Claims that a monthslong pattern of misconduct was merely aberrational or that the defendants recognize the error of their ways now often fall on deaf ears.", "title": "Defendants Like Shkreli Find Saying Sorry Is No Longer Enough", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Alongside aides including Hope Hicks, who said last week that she would depart her role as White House communications director, Ms. Conway ran the campaign through its stormy final days, and then followed her candidate to the White House. In those early months, in an act born of savvy or necessity, Ms. Conway stepped back from the media glare to focus on demonstrating to her colleagues and her critics that she was as capable on policy as she was sparring with talking heads on TV.\n\nHer choice seems to have paid off.\n\n\u201cShe has this unique position that she\u2019s earned,\u201d said former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who worked closely on the opioid crisis with Ms. Conway and credited her with urging the president to personalize the issue through his brother\u2019s experience with addiction. \u201cShe\u2019s gotten a bad rap at times, but I think that\u2019s because of some of the really awful people inside the White House who have been trying to hurt her, as opposed to anything the press came up with on its own.\u201d\n\nIn recent months, Ms. Conway has watched, somewhat from the sidelines, as John F. Kelly, the president\u2019s current chief of staff, came in and pledged to bring order to the West Wing, dispatching a number of aides who had once envied the access Ms. Conway cultivated with the president.\n\n\u201cHe came around and wanted to know what everyone had been working on for the first six months,\u201d Ms. Conway said, \u201cand some of us were just better equipped to handle that question than others.\u201d\n\nFor the president, Ms. Conway, an outspoken opponent of abortion, is one of his most prominent ties to the conservative movement.\n\nRepresentative Mark Meadows, the chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, said Ms. Conway had been wise to engage in public appearances only \u201cat times when the president has asked her to engage.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not about Kellyanne,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s about the president of the United States and this country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Meadows added: \u201cThe limelight is not the primary concern for getting her agenda done, and I think that has served her well.\u201d\n\nShe has told allies in and outside the West Wing that her respect is not just for the president, but the presidency as an institution. Still, one of her biggest strengths, those who know her say, is that she has always understood whom she works for. Loyalty to her clients always came easily, but this time, her client just happens to be in the Oval Office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think that she is the president\u2019s political adviser and she is someone who is very skilled on television,\u201d Mr. Christie said. \u201cShe\u2019s unique in the White House in someone who can give him both political and policy advice.\u201d\n\nMr. Christie said that, early on, this prompted other aides to target her. A friend of Ms. Conway\u2019s, who didn\u2019t want to be identified because of the social opprobrium she would face as a Democrat, said Ms. Conway had particularly struggled with Reince Priebus, the president\u2019s former chief of staff, during the first chaotic months of the administration. She also survived efforts to curtail her influence by Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, who for months privately bristled over Ms. Conway\u2019s getting credit for the campaign victory.\n\nBut, that friend said, she learned that if her colleagues did not take her seriously, she could use it to her advantage. She kept her head down while other aides burned out, and kept her access to the president.\n\nIn fact, her portfolio has grown, with the addition of the opioid crisis and coordination with cabinet secretaries, which originally fell under Mr. Kushner\u2019s purview. On Thursday, she put together an opioid summit meeting with cabinet members at the White House, which the president briefly joined.\n\nOther Republicans say her loyalty to Mr. Trump \u2014 and thus her ability to survive in his chaotic White House \u2014 is no virtue.\n\n\u201cShe has no shame,\u201d Tim Miller, a former spokesman for Jeb Bush\u2019s presidential campaign, said in a text message, \u201cand that is a quality the president values.\u201d\n\nMs. Conway, of course, would see it differently. She refers to those who have lasted from the campaign until now as \u201cunbroken threads.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe was not originally part of the campaign, but her friends say she has known the president for more than a decade, and has come to understand him and how to speak with him in ways few aides do outside of Ms. Hicks and Keith Schiller, Mr. Trump\u2019s longtime bodyguard, who left the White House last year. For a president hit by crosscurrents on policy, Ms. Conway has frequently been a voice reminding him of his campaign promises.\n\nShe has called supporters from the final days of the Trump campaign members of the \u201cOctober 8th coalition,\u201d for defending Mr. Trump after audio of him bragging about sexual assault had leaked.\n\nA mother of four who moved her family to Washington last year, Ms. Conway has faced near-constant attack for defending Mr. Trump\u2019s track record with women. But she has also willingly stepped into battle, including when she criticized women for joining the Women\u2019s March the day after Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration last year.\n\n\u201cI frankly didn\u2019t see the point,\u201d Ms. Conway said at the time.\n\nBut she and her allies say the attacks against her often have a sexist undertone. And she has bristled at a line of thought in liberal spheres and on social media that she and other women have advanced in the White House by keeping their heads down in a misogynistic workplace.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump is more kind, open, gracious and respectful to the women in the White House than the so-called pro-women movement that criticizes everything from what we wear to what we say to what we believe,\u201d Ms. Conway said. \u201cI wouldn\u2019t work there if he weren\u2019t open to my opinion. It would literally make zero sense for me to be there.\u201d", "title": "Defying the Odds, Kellyanne Conway Steps Back and Hangs On", "authors": ["Katie Rogers", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Two sequels followed \u2014 \u201cThe Trial of Billy Jack\u201d (1974) and \u201cBilly Jack Goes to Washington\u201d (1977) \u2014 but a third, \u201cThe Return of Billy Jack,\u201d was never completed because of an injury to Mr. Laughlin. He died at 82 in 2013.\n\nMs. Taylor reprised her role in the two sequels, collaborated with Mr. Laughlin on the screenplays and was the executive producer.\n\nGrowing up in Winner, S.D., near the Rosebud Indian Reservation, Ms. Taylor recalled discrimination against the Sioux, like their being barred from her public school when she was in the third grade.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI decided, \u2018O.K., if they\u2019re not going to let them come in, I\u2019m not going to come in, too,\u2019 \u201d she said in an interview for a family video.\n\nHer father spoke to the school and it relented, she said. She then helped the frightened children acclimate to their new surroundings. But for her efforts, she believed, the school\u2019s principal forced her to repeat the third grade.\n\nAs a young adult, she said, she saw white men cut open bags of flour given by the state to needy Sioux, pour it on them and declare, \u201cNow you\u2019re white.\u201d\n\nWhen she began dating Mr. Laughlin, he was shocked to see some residents of the reservation living in rusted cars in winter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey both had a heightened sense of justice,\u201d Ms. Laughlin said in a telephone interview. \u201cAnything they saw profoundly affected them.\u201d\n\nFor their scripts, she said, Mr. Laughlin wrote extensively in longhand on yellow legal pads, and \u201ctogether they formulated something cohesive.\u201d\n\nDelores Judith Taylor was born in Winner on Sept. 27, 1932. Her father, Harry, was the local postmaster general; her mother, the former Ann Nelson, was a homemaker. A natural soprano, Delores won local contests for her singing and graduated from the University of South Dakota, Vermillion, where she met Mr. Laughlin.\n\nShe planned on a career in graphic arts while Mr. Laughlin acted on television and in films during the 1950s and \u201960s. When he started directing, Ms. Taylor helped pack lunches and find locations, she said in an interview with The Associated Press in 1971.\n\n\u201cI became a kind of super-gofer,\u201d she said. But as \u201cTom\u2019s pictures became bigger,\u201d she added, \u201cI started doing more things. It\u2019s a job, and I like it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe had a small role in \u201cThe Born Losers\u201d (1967), in which the Billy Jack character first appeared. She was the film\u2019s executive producer.\n\n\u201cThey became a really symbiotic match,\u201d Ms. Laughlin said. \u201cThey were opposites in so many ways. My mother was this calm, ethereal force who glided through and never went off one end or the other. My father was volatile and explosive, in good and bad ways, with all this full-on passion all the time. She was his ballast \u2014 incredibly spiritual \u2014 and a tempering force on him.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cHad \u2018Billy Jack\u2019 not been a coalescence of both their forces, it would have been far less interesting.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Taylor was nominated for a Golden Globe for most promising female newcomer in 1972 but rejected offers to work for filmmakers other than her husband. \u201cAs much as she loved acting,\u201d Ms. Laughlin said, \u201cshe did it only because my father needed her.\u201d\n\nTheir collaboration extended to education: Unhappy with traditional educational methods, they opened a Montessori school in Santa Monica, Calif., in 1959 or 1960, their daughter said, before selling it after several years.\n\nThe family liked to recall that Marlon Brando, whose son Christian had gone to the school, attended a screening of \u201cBilly Jack\u201d and praised Ms. Taylor for her performance in a scene after her character is raped, declaring it a yardstick to measure other actors by.\n\nIn addition to her daughter, Ms. Taylor is survived by a second daughter, Christina Harrington; a son, Frank; five grandchildren; and her sisters, Joan Wishart and Darlene Taylor\n\nMr. Laughlin, who had a passion for politics, was remembered for quixotically seeking the presidential nomination in several state primary races in 1992, 2004 and 2008.\n\n\u201cI never saw her object,\u201d Ms. Laughlin said. \u201cShe was amazing. She was forceful with her opinions privately, but once they decided to do something, she was all in. If that\u2019s what he wanted to do, she would be there for him.\u201d", "title": "Delores Taylor, 85, Dies; Writer and Star in \u2018Billy Jack\u2019 Films", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cDelta Took a Stand on the N.R.A.; Georgia Lawmakers Want to Make It Pay\u201d (news article, March 2): Wouldn\u2019t it be inspirational if Delta Air Lines offered airfare discounts to high school students planning to travel to Washington to attend the student convocation later this month to press our elected representatives to pass sensible gun legislation? It would give a needed lift to these brave young people, who are doing what adults have lacked the fortitude to do.\n\nIt would also be good for business, promoting sales for hundreds of thousands of young people to \u201cfly Delta,\u201d as opposed to the handful of gun advocates who took advantage of the discount to attend the National Rifle Association convention.\n\nThe idea could catch on, with other airlines, bus companies and hotel chains offering similar discounts for fares to other cities where students are planning demonstrations on that day.\n\nALLEN H. FISHER, MELVILLE, N.Y.", "title": "Opinion | Delta and the Gun Control Rally", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The big winner, with about 32 percent of the vote, was the Five Star Movement, a grass-roots m\u00e9lange of libertarians, progressives, Euroskeptics and other disenchanted voters formed less than a decade ago by a comedian, and now led by a 31-year-old college dropout, Luigi Di Maio.\n\nNext was the far-right League (formerly Northern League) led by Matteo Salvini, 44. An enthusiastic fan of Marine Le Pen\u2019s National Front and Donald Trump, Mr. Salvini fanned sadly familiar flames of nationalism, ethnocentrism and xenophobia, promising, among other things, \u201ccleansing\u201d Italy of immigrants, threatening force.\n\nThe League ran with Silvio Berlusconi\u2019s Forza Italia party. If there was a sliver of good news it was that the party of Mr. Berlusconi, forerunner of today\u2019s populists who was forced out as prime minister in 2011 in a swirl of sex scandals and legal troubles, took only 14 percent of the vote.\n\nThe biggest blow was to the governing Democratic Party, led by Matteo Renzi until his resignation on Monday. It sagged to a mere 19 percent of the vote. The party, which has led Italy in a technocratic direction for the past five years, pulled Italy out of recession and had been trying to modernize its economy. But the nation\u2019s problems proved too great for it to resist the rise of extremism and demagogy.\n\nWhatever government emerges will have a tough time satisfying voters\u2019 expectations while coping with Italy\u2019s real economic problems, including the largest public debt in the European Union and high youth unemployment. As Greece learned earlier, it\u2019s one thing to rage against European rules; it\u2019s a far different thing to try to buck them.\n\nItaly now poses a major challenge to the European project, already badly battered by the Brexit vote in Britain and the illiberal drift of Poland, Hungary and other East and Central European countries. That promise of instability and uncertainty is no doubt being celebrated in the Kremlin. (Both the Five Star Movement and the League have argued against union sanctions on Russia.) Italy is not likely to quit the union or drop the euro, but a government hostile to both is a headache to Brussels and the deeper integration championed by President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany. They will now need to decide whether to press ahead or hold off a while.", "title": "Opinion | Demagogues Win as Europe\u2019s Populist Tide Sweeps Italy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The federal investigation and threats followed recent news that the data collection firm Cambridge Analytica, which worked on the 2016 Trump presidential campaign, gained access to the personal data of more than 50 million Facebook users.\n\nThe F.T.C. said it planned to determine whether the social media giant had violated a consent decree it signed in 2011 to protect users\u2019 privacy.\n\nThe decree required Facebook to notify and receive explicit permission from users before sharing their personal information beyond the limits dictated by their privacy settings. Each violation of the agreement, which the agency reached with Facebook as part of a settlement over third-party apps, carries a penalty of up to $40,000 a day.\n\nThe agency\u2019s acknowledgment of its investigation helped push Facebook\u2019s stock down as much as 6.5 percent on Monday morning before it recovered. Facebook said last week that it was anticipating an inquiry by the agency.\n\nThe F.T.C. said in a statement on Monday that it \u201ctakes very seriously recent press reports raising substantial concerns about the privacy practices of Facebook.\u201d\n\nLawmakers have repeatedly called for Mr. Zuckerberg to appear in hearings on Capitol Hill. Last week, the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House and Senate commerce committees formally invited him to testify.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure this is much bigger than Cambridge Analytica, and I\u2019m sure there are other Cambridge Analyticas out there,\u201d Senator John Kennedy, Republican from Louisiana, said in an interview. \u201cFacebook isn\u2019t just a company. It is so powerful it is like a country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome lawmakers, such as Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat from Connecticut, asked the F.T.C. to look into whether Facebook should pay damages to users.\n\n\u201cThe sphere of scrutiny must be broader than just the consent decree,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cThere is no excuse for delay.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCambridge Analytica is facing intense criticism, too. On Monday, Common Cause, a government watchdog group in Washington, filed complaints seeking federal investigations into allegations that the company violated federal election law.\n\nIn an article that detailed how Cambridge Analytica obtained information about millions of Facebook users, The New York Times reported this month that employees of the data research firm with European or Canadian citizenship had worked extensively for its American clients during the 2014 and 2016 elections, despite a warning from its own election lawyer.\n\nThe employees worked on polling, message development, and the designing of target audiences for digital ads and fund-raising appeals.\n\nThe company said the work was permissible because none of the foreign employees had \u201cstrategic\u201d or \u201coperational\u201d roles. But former employees contradicted that account, suggesting that the work violated laws in the United States that strictly limit what non-Americans can do for American political campaigns.\n\nCommon Cause filed one complaint with the Justice Department, which has authority to investigate \u201cknowing and willful\u201d violations of campaign law. The group also filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission, which has day-to-day jurisdiction over enforcing election rules.\n\n\u201cIt defies belief that even after their own attorney warned them that they would be violating the prohibition on performing certain election-related activities in U.S. elections that they did so anyway,\u201d said Paul S. Ryan, Common Cause\u2019s vice president for policy and litigation.\n\nIn the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco, lawyers appealed two lawsuits that challenged the social media company\u2019s privacy and user data policies. One lawsuit claims that Facebook violates the Electronic Communications Privacy Act (Wiretap Act) and state law equivalents because of the way it monitors its users on and off the platform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe second suit claims that Facebook has been capturing and selling the details of users\u2019 browsing of third-party health sites. Any site with a Facebook \u201clike\u201d button, including those of medical institutions such as the American Cancer Society and the American Society of Clinical Oncology, could be used to track users as they browsed outside Facebook, according to the lawsuit.\n\nFacebook also has been targeted by several shareholder lawsuits since the reports detailing Cambridge Analytica\u2019s use of Facebook user information.\n\nVideo\n\nMany users have threatened to deactivate or delete their accounts to protest Facebook\u2019s stewardship of their personal data. The #deletefacebook campaign, as it has been called, has even received support from a creator of WhatsApp, one of Facebook\u2019s most popular services, who sold his company to the social media giant for $19 billion in 2014. Elon Musk, the chief executive of SpaceX and Tesla, removed the Facebook pages of both companies on Friday.\n\nWhile the Cambridge Analytica revelations have renewed regulatory interest in Facebook in the United States, pressure on the company in other countries has been building for years.\n\nThe company has been the subject of several privacy investigations and charges by European regulators. And Europe has approved a new privacy law, which takes effect in May, that will give users of Facebook, Google and other internet services more control over how their data is collected and what Silicon Valley companies know about them.", "title": "Demands Grow for Facebook to Explain Its Privacy Policies", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu", "Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "She\u2019s in and out for 20-minute sessions, Monday through Friday for six weeks. What we dreaded seems doable now. The nurses are so kind; they care for Mom gently and graciously, without a touch of impatience. She\u2019s doing well, says the radiologist. Better than expected, says the oncologist. Apparently squamous cell carcinoma is the best kind of cancer to get if you have to get anal cancer. It hasn\u2019t spread and has a high cure rate and might just be a bump in the road, although the road we\u2019re on is headed toward the desert of late-stage dementia.\n\nAt first I was shocked and furious about my mother\u2019s diagnosis, believing that Alzheimer\u2019s gave a person a free pass on other diseases. But aging is a high risk factor for cancer and Mom is nearly 71; if you do the math, it\u2019s not uncommon to have dementia along with other illnesses that prevail among the elderly.\n\nOne of my brothers called her cancer \u201ccruel and unusual punishment,\u201d and we all braced for the suffering she\u2019d endure. But anguish hasn\u2019t come yet and maybe it never will; maybe the mercy of dementia is that it places Mom purely in the present moment, immune to fear and dread, to the psychological distress that often accompanies cancer treatment.\n\nDon\u2019t get me wrong, I\u2019m not finding a silver lining. I never would have asked for this, would take it back if I could. My optimist father used to say that the Chinese character for \u201ccrisis\u201d contained the word \u201copportunity,\u201d but I\u2019ve since learned that he was wrong. His entrepreneur\u2019s mantra was a misinterpretation of language, a false New Age twist on Far Eastern wisdom, although it did offer me solace in times of despair.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd I can\u2019t deny that something has changed for me, some guard let down, a window opened that allows me to love my mother like a cloudless sky.\n\nDriving home, I play oldies radio and we sing along to \u201cHere Comes the Sun.\u201d Mom knows all the lyrics, belts them out in her sweet alto because Alzheimer\u2019s doesn\u2019t affect music memory, at least at this stage. Little darling, it\u2019s been a long cold lonely winter. I wonder if it\u2019s John or Paul on lead vocals. Later I look it up and learn it\u2019s actually George who wrote and recorded the song, a fact Mom once would have known without Google, but all she knows now is music and spring wind and her oldest child in the driver\u2019s seat singing it\u2019s all right. Crooning the chorus, she is free of self-consciousness. She has cancer but she\u2019s in a good mood.\n\nMy siblings and I had agonized about how to treat her carcinoma when she couldn\u2019t understand what was happening to her own body. She\u2019d been diagnosed with Alzheimer\u2019s at age 68 and could no longer make a cup of tea, let alone any medical decisions. I\u2019d consulted with her neurologist, fearing the aggressive chemo-radiotherapy might speed her cognitive decline (it probably wouldn\u2019t, he told me). Because of the high cure rate and the excruciating consequences of letting her tumor grow, we went ahead with the recommended treatment. My brother was her health care proxy and made the decision we all believed she would have made for herself.\n\nBefore I leave, I embrace Mom in the kitchen. Every chance I get I hold her hand. I remember how I used to half-hug her with one arm, keeping my body stiff and apart, just the way my preteen daughter now deigns to hug me. I was protecting myself from the pressure of her love, a force that seemed to obliterate my selfhood. Now I can\u2019t get enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy baby!\u201d she says, pulling me closer.\n\n\u201cYour big baby,\u201d I laugh. \u201cEven my own babies are big now.\u201d\n\n\u201cWell, that\u2019s O.K.,\u201d she answers. Sometimes she forgets I have children and what their names are, but she knows me, she\u2019s happy to see me. Who else in my life has ever been so happy to see me walk through the door?\n\nLast year the memory specialist tried to comfort us when we told him the Alzheimer\u2019s was progressing rapidly. \u201cWhen cognition falls away,\u201d he said, \u201cwhat remains is the ability to love and be loved.\u201d", "title": "Dementia\u2019s Gift: Facing Cancer Without the Fear", "authors": ["Diana Whitney"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "WHAT ARE WE DOING HERE?\n\nEssays\n\nBy Marilynne Robinson\n\n315 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.\n\nRecently, visiting family, I spent some time leafing through one of those ancestral histories that Americans in rootless moods feel compelled to write. The manuscript was typewritten, handbound, homespun. Its author, a late great-uncle of mine, had been a high school chemistry teacher. From him, I learned that some of my forebears came to the American Midwest in the 19th century not only for the reasons I\u2019d assumed \u2014 the arable soil offered to European immigrants by the Homestead Act, the freedoms of speech and religion. They also came for the schools, education having been in their corner of the Old Country a scarce resource, available to the few, withheld from the many.\n\nI don\u2019t know how much to trust my great-uncle\u2019s account. He may have been seeking in the past the seeds of his own biography, as authors of such volumes are prone to do \u2014 as all of us, I suspect, are prone to do. And yet it\u2019s true that the American Midwest, in the century after Jefferson purchased it from Napoleon, provided unusually fertile soil for schools as well as corn. Just how fertile, Americans seem to have forgotten of late, and in this, her fifth collection of essays, Marilynne Robinson is here to remind us \u2014 of the Midwest\u2019s intellectual and political heritage, of the public university\u2019s democratic and humanistic origins, and of much else.\n\nAs novelist and essayist both, Robinson has always been something of an underwater archaeologist, diving into the twilight zones of memory to drag lost histories into the light. \u201cI am especially fascinated by erasures and omissions, which seem to me to be strongly present in their apparent absence, like black holes, pulling the fabric of collective narrative out of shape,\u201d she writes here. It\u2019s worth pausing a moment over that metaphor to note how indebted it is to Melville and Dickinson and the other Transcendentalists, whose influence Robinson has long welcomed and acknowledged. Like them, she is an ardent armchair naturalist, not to mention an ardent armchair theologian, cosmologist, ethicist, historian. Like them, she sees, or creates through metaphor, correspondences across disparate fields, frames of reference, states of being \u2014 between cosmos and mind, or astronomy and history, black holes and the absences in stories. Her way with metaphor implies a metaphysics, in her case a metaphysics informed by her Calvinism: History is a fabric. So is the cosmos. So are the moments lived quietly beside a mountain lake in Idaho, or in a prairie town in Iowa. Or on a whaling ship. Or wherever you are now. \u201cWhat are all these fragments for,\u201d asks Ruth, the narrator of \u201cHousekeeping,\u201d Robinson\u2019s first novel, \u201cif not to be knit up, finally?\u201d\n\nIn her fiction Robinson knits narratively; in her essays rhetorically, inquisitively, at times polemically, but rarely autobiographically. Some writers moving between fiction and nonfiction are like musicians switching instruments. You can hear the difference when they put down one and pick up another, but the music, or the voice, is recognizably the same. Not so with Robinson. Readers who come to her essays having fallen under the spell of her fiction are likely to feel disoriented. There is a dreamlike intimacy to the voices that narrate her novels, as if we were not so much listening to a story being told as eavesdropping on a consciousness. In \u201cGilead,\u201d she gives us the diaristic letters of Reverend Ames, not his sermons. The voice of her essays, by contrast, seems to speak from a podium or pulpit. The difference between her fiction and nonfiction is akin to the one between practice and theory, or between a swim in a mountain lake and a lecture, delivered with unexpected brio and occasional thunder, on the properties of water.", "title": "Democracy\u2019s Fierce Defender", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "In Mr. Gerson\u2019s retelling of American religious history, liberal Christians \u201cfound better things to do with their Sundays than attend progressive services\u201d and abandoned key Christian tenets: \u201cMany combined their faith with the Social Gospel \u2014 a postmillennialism drained of the miraculous, with social reform taking the place of the Second Coming.\u201d\n\nThese critiques have grown more frequent over the past few years as the religious left became savvier and figures like the Rev. William Barber attracted national attention for his Moral Mondays campaign in North Carolina (a weekly social justice protest at the state capitol in Raleigh).\n\nGenerations of white evangelicals have been conditioned to see evangelicalism as so synonymous with Republican politics that the idea of a non-Republican political option for religious voters simply does not exist. Rather than contemplate this possibility and grapple with it, Mr. Erickson, Mr. Gerson and others simply disparage and deny it \u2014 while also condemning political tribalism.\n\nMany conservative evangelicals would say the problem with progressives isn\u2019t just a matter of doubting their religiosity \u2014 it\u2019s that Democrats are wrong on policy, and those progressives who claim to be religious are blinkered if they support Democrats. Mr. Falwell, a stalwart Trump supporter, took to Twitter last fall to counter the idea that Christians should factor concern for the poor into their political decisions.\n\n\u201cIt never ceases to amaze me how leftist Christians twist the words of Jesus,\u201d Mr. Falwell wrote. Jesus never told \u201cCaesar how to run Rome and never said to care for the least of these by voting to tax your neighbor to help the poor.\u201d\n\nEven widely respected evangelical leaders have spent the past few decades insisting that a correct reading of the Bible requires Christians to reject homosexuality, and especially gay marriage. In August 2017, a group of 150 prominent evangelicals released the \u201cNashville Statement,\u201d a document that condemned (among other things) Christians who support L.B.G.T.Q. issues. \u201cSuch approval,\u201d they asserted, \u201cconstitutes an essential departure from Christian faithfulness and witness.\u201d Their calculation is very simple: If you support gay rights and affirm the idea of gay Christians, then you aren\u2019t really Christian.\n\nThe biggest stumbling block for conservative evangelicals is the scarlet abortion \u201cA\u201d that Democrats wear for their support of abortion rights. Conservative evangelical preachers inveigh against \u201cpro-abortion\u201d forces throughout the country, and the columns of Mr. Gerson and his conservative peers are littered with the rhetorical labeling of Democrats and progressives as \u201cpro-abortion.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Democrats Are Christians, Too", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Throughout the 2016 election cycle and ever since, I\u2019ve been hearing that the Democratic Party has no bench. This is 100 percent true. When it comes to credible presidential prospects, the Democratic Party has several rows of benches. The Democratic Party has bleachers.\n\nDozens of prominent Democrats are at least flirting with running in 2020, and while it\u2019s easy to look at them and play Goldilocks \u2014 too cold, too hot, too bald, too blond, too Wall Street, too wordy \u2014 it\u2019s just as easy to believe. The perfect person? The party certainly lacks that. But potentially effective candidates? It\u2019s lousy with them, though we chromosomally dyspeptic pundits prefer to shake our heads and sigh.\n\nRepublicans crowed about their supposed bounty in 2016 even as Donald Trump laid waste to it. Democrats bemoan their slim pickings in 2020 even though the field is positively obese. There are elders in their 70s and whippersnappers below 50; governors who can present themselves as Washington outsiders and senators who can tout their inside game; show horses and workhorses; progressives who didn\u2019t just conveniently rechristen themselves that way and moderates who\u2019d probably be potent in the general election if they could just survive the primaries. There are Westerners and Easterners and, in happy contrast to cycles past, more than a few women and people of color.\n\nTo worry that there\u2019s no obvious winner is to ignore history. Presidents aren\u2019t obvious until they\u2019re sitting at the Resolute Desk (and sometimes not even then). Consider the last three.", "title": "Opinion | Democrats Are Primed for 2018 and Looking Pretty in 2020", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The geopolitical implications of Mr. Trump\u2019s trade decisions should also alarm Democrats. His decision to withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (which President Barack Obama negotiated) weakened America\u2019s economic standing in the world and was a gift to China. If the United States is not involved in setting the rules for international trade, China and Russia will now drive these decisions. Our strong allies will be pushed into trade deals dictated by China. The alternative to TPP\u2019s negotiated labor and environmental standards will be China\u2019s lack of standards on labor and the environment. The same applies to technology, where either the United States will set rules with a focus on innovation or China will set rules with a focus on government control of information.\n\nWhen Democrats focus on building a modern economy that competes globally, as we did particularly in 1992 and 2012, we appeal to the majority of voters who believe that trade benefits America. When we do not lean in on a positive case for competitive jobs of the future or are perceived as indecisive on America\u2019s role in the global economy, as we were in 2004 and 2016, it can come across as hypocritical to the recent history of our party and limits our ability to win over swing voters.\n\nElectorally, Democrats can win over small-business owners and moderate Republicans with a platform of investing in education and research to build an American economy that competes with the rest of the world. We proved this in Virginia, where the state has gone from being solidly Republican just 10 years ago to having a Democratic winning streak in statewide contests. That shift occurred both because Republicans focused on an extreme anti-woman, anti-gay, anti-immigrant agenda and because Democrats made the case directly to moderate Republicans and business owners that we were the only party focused on building a modern, vibrant Virginia economy.\n\nIn my 2013 campaign for governor, I won endorsements from many moderate Republicans because I campaigned on a welcoming Virginia economy, while my opponent was known for crusading on social issues that scared global companies away from Virginia.\n\nAs governor, I worked across party lines to help build a new Virginia economy that traded with the world. That work included 35 trade missions to five continents, which brought substantial foreign investment to Virginia and helped create over 200,000 jobs. The state\u2019s economy was driven in part by exports, and agriculture and forestry increased 31 percent, to $91 billion. That growth in trade meant more jobs, with Virginia\u2019s unemployment rate falling to 3.7 percent from 5.4 percent during my term.", "title": "Opinion | Democrats Should Embrace an Open Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Though the plan lays out a long-term vision, through 2022, some of its contents were displayed in a 14-page presentation to employees in February. And last week, the department announced it would reassign its budget director, the first move toward restructuring the budget office to reassign staff members elsewhere in the department. The decision, which officials said was meant to help spread expertise across the department, was made over the opposition of the White House\u2019s Office of Management and Budget, according to Politico. Several other staff changes were announced for 2019.\n\nRepresentative Rosa DeLauro, a Connecticut Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, told Ms. DeVos on Tuesday that she was disheartened to hear the plans for the budget office, which she said was central to managing the department\u2019s programs and resources.\n\nMs. DeLauro also said the shuffle, along with limited communication from department staff members, \u201cdirectly impugns on the critical work of this committee, and it needs to stop.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Rodney Frelinghuysen, Republican of New Jersey and the chairman of the committee, said he was concerned about \u201ca disconnect\u201d between Ms. DeVos\u2019s administration and his office.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to believe that people who have been on the job for this long don\u2019t have staff that understand how the system works,\u201d Mr. Frelinghuysen said. \u201cIt is important to connect with the people who pay the bills.\u201d\n\nThe plan aligns with measures Ms. DeVos has taken to shrink her agency, which she has described as bloated. She has shed hundreds of regulations, and hundreds of staff members through attrition and voluntary buyouts.\n\nFor the most part, Ms. DeVos\u2019s restructuring plan involves consolidating offices, such as merging the office that oversees charter and private schools with the main office that oversees elementary and secondary education in public schools. The plan would eliminate the Office of the Under Secretary, a position that has helped shape higher education policy, and create an Office of Lifelong Learning. It would also reduce the number of political appointees. The proposal also seeks to acquire several programs run by the Labor Department, including ones that connect unemployed adults and former prisoners with educational services.", "title": "Democrats Tell DeVos Her \u2018Head Is in the Sand\u2019 on Racial Bias", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "O\u2019Malley Dillon: Also, the national party was relatively thoughtful in how they supported this race and ensured that the resources they were spending and the services they were providing were less important than what Lamb was leading with. They made sure, to the extent they could control it, that the race wasn\u2019t about them \u2014 wasn\u2019t national \u2014 and was driven by Lamb. Tactically, I think they need to continue to do that through November.\n\nBruni: One more question on this front for each of you. First you, Seth: If Democrats retake the House \u2014 and that\u2019s looking more and more likely \u2014 would you vote for Representative Joe Crowley of New York over Pelosi for House speaker? What about Adam Schiff of California? Both of their names are being floated.\n\nMoulton: I\u2019m 100 percent focused on winning the House. Then we\u2019ll see who runs, and I\u2019ll decide based on the candidates and their platforms. That\u2019s exactly what I did after my letter to Leader Pelosi helped push back the election to allow others to run: I didn\u2019t endorse Representative Tim Ryan over her until I heard him make his case. But one thing is clear: We need leaders who will build the bench, not clear it.\n\nBruni: And Jen, there are those who find the Republican attacks on Pelosi \u2014 and the focus on her as a factor in all this \u2014 sexist. What\u2019s your feeling?\n\nO\u2019Malley Dillon: There is no doubt in my mind that the attacks on Leader Pelosi are driven in large part by her gender, and I think that is also why it often resonates more with certain segments of the population. Of course, there are other elements at play here, but anyone that suggests that gender isn\u2019t part of this isn\u2019t paying attention.\n\nBruni: As hugely encouraging as Lamb\u2019s performance was, I have to wonder: Would he even have been the Democratic candidate in that district if he\u2019d had to go through the kind of primary that other Democratic aspirants around the country will go through? It\u2019s interesting to note that both he and Doug Jones, victorious in Alabama, had no primary challenge to navigate. Most other House candidates do. How does the party make sure that in swingable districts, it has the most strategically optimal general-election candidates and not the riskier ideologues that highly partisan primary voters sometimes reward?\n\nMoulton: In 2014, I challenged an 18-year incumbent in my own party who was a frontline candidate every cycle \u2014 meaning he was a top Republican target \u2014 even though he had never had a significant primary challenge. The last general election poll before the primary had the Republican candidate, a respected state senator, beating the Democratic incumbent by six points, and it had me beating the Republican by six points. Folks in Washington on both sides of the aisle have told me since that we probably would have lost the seat if I hadn\u2019t won my primary challenge. And having to go through a tough primary absolutely made me a far better candidate for the general election; I ended up beating the Republican by 13 points, not six.", "title": "Opinion | Democrats, Put District Over Party, Pelosi and Washington", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "SALT LAKE CITY \u2014 Dallas Johnson, 18, stood at the top of a hill here on Saturday, flanked by men with pistols and children gripping protest signs.\n\nHe held a pole, and a giant flag flapped above him, bearing a rifle and a message in black: \u201cCome and take it.\u201d\n\nHundreds of thousands of people marched in cities on Saturday calling on officials to enact stricter gun laws, but they were not the only ones to demonstrate.\n\nAcross the country, supporters of the Second Amendment gathered at state capitals and in city centers, hoping to counter the swell that has emerged in the wake of a February massacre that killed 17 people at a high school in Parkland, Fla. Their message in many cases was that the surviving Parkland students have it all wrong \u2014 more guns, not fewer, is what will end the violence that has ripped through so many American communities.", "title": "Demonstrators Who Brought Guns and an Opposing Message: \u2018Shoot Back\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Though Denmark prohibited trans-Atlantic slave trafficking in 1792, it did not rush to enforce the ban. The rule took effect 11 years later, and slavery continued until 1848.\n\n\u201cThey wanted to fill the stocks first\u201d and ensure enough slaves would remain to keep plantations running, said Niels Brimnes, an associate professor at Aarhus University and a leading expert on colonialism in Denmark.\n\nThree decades after slavery formally ended on what today are known as the United States Virgin Islands, conditions for the former slaves had not improved significantly.\n\nThat continued injustice fomented the uprising on St. Croix.\n\nMary Thomas was tried for her role in the rebellion and ferried across the Atlantic to a women\u2019s prison in Copenhagen. The statue created in tribute to her, called \u201cI Am Queen Mary,\u201d sits in front of what was once a warehouse for Caribbean sugar and rum, just more than a mile from where she was jailed.\n\nThe only other tribute to Denmark\u2019s colonies or those who were colonized is a statue of a generic figure from Greenland.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Danish artist Jeannette Ehlers, who teamed up with Ms. Belle to create the \u201cQueen Mary\u201d monument, said, \u201cNinety-eight percent of the statues in Denmark are representing white males.\u201d\n\nThe torch and the cane bill held in the statue\u2019s hands symbolize the resistance strategies by those who were colonized, the artists said in a statement. Her seated pose \u201crecalls the iconic 1967 photograph of Huey P. Newton, founder of the Black Panther Party.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd the plinth on which her chair rests incorporates \u201ccoral cut from the ocean by enslaved Africans gathered from ruins of the foundations of historic buildings on St. Croix.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHenrik Holm, senior research curator at Denmark\u2019s National Gallery of Art, said in a statement: \u201cIt takes a statue like this to make forgetting less easy. It takes a monument like this to fight against the silence, neglect, repression and hatred.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cNever before has a sculpture like this been erected on Danish soil. Now, Denmark is offered a sculpture that addresses the past. But it is also an artwork for the future.\u201d\n\nThe preferred self-image of this country of 5.5 million is that of a nation at the forefront of democratization and a savior of Jews during World War II.\n\nAnd even though the Vikings raped and pillaged their way around the shores of Britain and Ireland, the Viking Age is generally a source of national pride and amusement in Denmark.\n\nOver the centuries, Danes have not undergone a national reckoning about the thousands of Africans forced onto Danish ships to work the plantations in Danish colonies in the Caribbean, historians say.\n\n\u201cIt may have to do with the narrative of Denmark as a colonial power saying, \u2018We weren\u2019t as bad as others,\u2019\u201d Professor Brimnes said. \u201cBut we were just as bad as the others. I can\u2019t identify a particular, humane Danish colonialism.\u201d\n\nIn a speech last year, the Danish prime minister, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, expressed regret for his country\u2019s part in the slave trade \u2014 but he stopped short of an apology.\n\n\u201cMany of Copenhagen\u2019s beautiful old houses were erected with money made on the toil and exploitation on the other side of the planet,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a proud part of Denmark\u2019s history.
