Congressional Primary", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDeontay walked through the fire tonight,\u201d said Lou DiBella, Wilder\u2019s shaken promoter, who like his fighter stood to lose a windfall had the fight run to what appeared to be its inevitable conclusion.\n\nSomehow, the three judges had Wilder leading, 85-84, through nine rounds, but to the 14,065 fans in the arena, who had raucously cheered Wilder\u2019s entrance into the ring but been stunned into silence by the fury of Ortiz\u2019s seventh-round onslaught, it had to appear that a monumental upset was in the works.\n\n\u201cHe had me in a whirlwind,\u201d Wilder said. \u201cAnd I knew I had to get out of it.\u201d\n\nWilder, who had dropped Ortiz for a brief count in the fifth round, weathered the worst moments of his unblemished career over the final 40 seconds of Round 7, after Ortiz beat Wilder to the punch as both simultaneously threw right hands. Wilder\u2019s head snapped back and he stumbled into the ropes, where Ortiz relentlessly poured in a series of 1-2s that had Fields, the referee, looking closely at the champion, who appeared out on his feet.\n\nBut Wilder made it to the bell, and was afforded an extra 10 seconds or so of rest when the ringside physician summoned him to a neutral corner for an examination as the bell rang for Round 8. With Ortiz visibly tired, Wilder was able to make it through that round and the ninth without sustaining much more damage, although he appeared to lose both of them.\n\n\u201cWhen he made it through that seventh round, I had a feeling he was going to get this guy,\u201d DiBella said. \u201cHe overcame adversity, and that\u2019s the true sign of a champion.\u201d\n\nOne ringside observer, Evander Holyfield, one of the last men to hold an undisputed heavyweight title, agreed. \u201cHe got hit so many times I don\u2019t know how he stayed up,\u201d Holyfield said. \u201cIt takes a lot of confidence to come back from that, and in the eighth round he came back out like he never even got hit. That\u2019s what made him win the fight.\u201d", "title": "Deontay Wilder Escapes Luis Ortiz. Anthony Joshua Awaits, at Some Point", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Deontay Wilder survived a pummeling from Luis Ortiz, then knocked out the challenger in the 10th round Saturday night to retain his W.B.C. heavyweight title.\n\nIt was a wild affair for the final few rounds after a dull series of pawing and gesturing by Wilder gave Ortiz a solid lead. Even after Wilder knocked down Ortiz in the fifth round, the bout remained in Ortiz\u2019s favor.\n\nThen, in the seventh, Wilder appeared out on his feet, but he never hit the canvas. Wilder stumbled to his corner when that round was over, and the end seemed near for Wilder.\n\nInstead, he closed the ninth with two hard rights, and then a series of vicious combinations in the 10th started Ortiz\u2019s downfall.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fight was over with 55 seconds to go in the 10th, when Ortiz went down for the second time in the round from a right uppercut. The referee, David Fields, stopped the fight.", "title": "Deontay Wilder Knocks Out Luis Ortiz in the 10th", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Admiral Zukunft, who was appointed by President Barack Obama, will step down as the 25th Coast Guard commandant in June. The Trump administration has not yet named his replacement.\n\nAdmiral Zukunft\u2019s speech, at the National Press Club in Washington, was also meant to be a reminder of the service\u2019s accomplishments.\n\nIt plays a crucial role in homeland security, particularly protection of the Southwest border, even as the administration plans to spend $25 billion on a border wall to combat drug trafficking and illegal immigration. The Coast Guard falls under the jurisdiction of the Department of Homeland Security rather than the Defense Department.\n\nLast year, the Coast Guard seized a record 455,000 pounds of cocaine, some by patrolling waters off the coasts of Colombia and Peru, worth over $7.2 billion wholesale. It also arrested more than 600 drug traffickers and captured nearly 3,500 people trying to enter the country illegally.\n\nThe Coast Guard also rescued nearly 12,000 people after deadly hurricanes hit the East Coast, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cDay in and day out, our men and women employ our broad authorities to ensure the security and prosperity of our nation,\u201d Admiral Zukunft said. \u201cThey stand ready to respond to any disaster \u2014 natural or man-made.\u201d\n\nGil Kerlikowske, a former commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection, credits the Coast Guard with being on the front lines of the Department of Homeland Security\u2019s battle against drug trafficking and a key to protecting the Southern border.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAdmiral Zukunft brought a laserlike focus on drug interdiction,\u201d said Mr. Kerlikowske, who worked closely with him during the Obama administration.\n\nThe Coast Guard operates simultaneously as a military service, a law enforcement agency and a member of the American intelligence community. Known primarily for its role in search-and-rescue missions, the Coast Guard has in recent years taken on missions around the world that include guarding the president and even cybersecurity.\n\nBut for years, the Coast Guard has suffered even as its mission has expanded, in part because of its image as a service that towed ships or searched for people lost at sea. Another issue has been a lack of funding. The Coast Guard does not receive any additional money from Congress for its work in areas such as disaster relief.\n\nThe Trump administration, in addition to moving to increase the Coast Guard\u2019s budget, has lavished praise on the service.\n\nDuring a celebration of the Department of Homeland Security\u2019s 15th anniversary on Thursday, Vice President Mike Pence singled out the Coast Guard. \u201cThe men and women of the Coast Guard have inspired the nation,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the administration\u2019s relationship with the Coast Guard has also been frayed.\n\nThe initial Trump White House spending plan would have cut the Coast Guard\u2019s funding by 14 percent, or about $1.3 billion, to help pay for Mr. Trump\u2019s border wall. The other military services \u2014 the Army, the Air Force, the Navy and the Marine Corps \u2014 all saw funding increases.\n\nThe administration reversed itself and increased the Coast Guard\u2019s budget request to, among other things, build a new Arctic icebreaker for the first time in 40 years as the United States competes with Russia and China in the polar region.\n\nThe vessel will not be ready until 2023, however, and will be one of only two such ships that the United States is operating. By comparison, Russia has 40 icebreakers and 11 more in production.\n\n\u201cRussia has really been asserting itself in the Arctic, and we\u2019ve been asserting ourselves with paper, with reports,\u201d Admiral Zukunft said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAdmiral Zukunft has not been shy about challenging the administration: Last year, when Mr. Trump posted on Twitter his intent to ban transgender troops from serving in the military, Admiral Zukunft said in a speech that same day that he would continue to support transgender troops under his command.", "title": "Departing Commandant Lays Out Coast Guard\u2019s Successes and Challenges", "authors": ["Ron Nixon"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "PHNOM PENH, Cambodia \u2014 It was fish for breakfast and fish for lunch and fish for dinner.\n\n\u201cI hate fish,\u201d Khan Hin said.\n\nWhat Mr. Hin wanted was a burger. Maybe a bowl of Cap\u2019n Crunch. Or some Tater Tots. \u201cI\u2019m feisty,\u201d he said, \u201cfor my Flamin\u2019 Hot Cheetos.\u201d\n\nMr. Hin\u2019s palate is American. His vernacular, slang from the streets of Stockton, Calif., is American.\n\nAnd his family\u2019s experience is all too American. His older sister was at school in Stockton in 1989 when a man sprayed gunfire on the schoolyard. Five children ages 6 to 9, all of Cambodian or Vietnamese heritage, were killed. Nearly 30 others, including Mr. Hin\u2019s sister, were injured. The killer had repeatedly spewed hatred of Asian immigrants.", "title": "Deported, and Sticking Out: \u2018This Ain\u2019t Home. America\u2019s My Home.\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMarch: It\u2019s the official start of spring, of course, but let us not forget that the word is also a directive to move forward. March! For homeowners, this means putting plans for renovation, reorganization and other stalled projects into action. Here are six new books to inspire you.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s Beautiful Here,\u201d by Megan Morton, a stylist (Thames & Hudson, $45, 240 pp.), showcases 19 international homes that are united by daringly original design. In the Notting Hill, London, townhouse of Nikki Tibbles, a florist, petal-pink walls play off riotous botanical-themed curtains, pillows, couches and throws. Phil Van Huynh, another florist, sprinkles his Melbourne, Australia, house with curiosities like French milk bins from Marseille and dairy feed sacks repurposed as pillows. And Olivier Abry, a lighting designer in Lyon, France, enlivens vintage d\u00e9cor with his own spidery sconces and lamps.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor those itching to really switch things up, look no further than Jane Webster. The Melbourne entrepreneur and mother of four became the doyenne of a French chateau after buying and gutting the neglected 19th-century property on a whim. Ms. Webster\u2019s latest book, \u201cFrench House Chic\u201d (Thames & Hudson, $45, 256 pp.), illuminates the sometimes-elusive appeal of French interiors by breaking them down room by room (the entrance, the bedroom, the kitchen) \u2014 and then even further into the elements that define those rooms (paneling, toile, berg\u00e8re chairs).\n\nPhoto\n\nIf your aesthetic inclinations are still shaky, Donna Garlough\u2019s \u201cYour Home, Your Style: How to Find Your Look & Create Rooms You Love\u201d (Rizzoli, $45, 208 pp.) offers to help you discover your \u201cdesign disposition\u201d: Self-Expressionist, Pragmatist, Historian, Dream Weaver or Tinkerer. The book\u2019s second half suggests ways to transform your home accordingly. It\u2019s an easily digestible guide that may turn the pain points of renovation into creative epiphanies.\n\nPhoto\n\nOftentimes, better organization is all you really need to make your home more livable. Cue Joanna and Peter Ahlberg\u2019s \u201cDiary of Your Home: Ideas, Tips and Prompts for Recording and Organizing Everything\u201d (Rizzoli, $24.95, 255 pp.). Here you can catalog room dimensions, recipes, shopping lists, contacts, wall colors and the status of maintenance projects \u2014 all in a friendly format that encourages deep thoughtfulness. The book will help you make your home \u201cbetter functioning, better at meeting your essential needs, better at expressing and nurturing your own identity,\u201d Ms. Ahlberg writes.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnce you\u2019ve mastered the art of concealing clutter you\u2019re ready for the 37 renovation projects that Francesc Zamora Mola chronicles in \u201cOpen Concept Houses\u201d (Harper Design, $35, 480 pp.). Be it a skyline-facing San Francisco residence with an unfortunately isolated kitchen or a Victorian rowhouse in need of light, these spaces have been reinvigorated by more gracious, flexible floor plans. \u201cThe homeowners had a common request: open rooms to each other and to the outdoors,\u201d Mr. Zamora Mola says.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn \u201cHudson Modern: Residential Landscapes\u201d (The Monacelli Press, $60, 262 pp.) David Sokol highlights 18 homes in the Hudson River Valley of New York, revealing how the bucolic region that inspired landscape painters now supports forward-thinking design. For the LM Guest House in Dutchess County, for instance, Katherine Chia and Arjun Desai created a wood-paneled master bedroom that practically seems to levitate within the foliage, while Robert Siegel designed his House 432 in Katonah with a rooftop courtyard that resembles a living room with the ceiling sliced clean off \u2014 a novel way to watch the seasons change.", "title": "Design Books to Kick-Start Your Decorating Projects", "authors": ["Jeremy Allen"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Murray Moss\u2019s legendary SoHo shop and gallery, Moss, left an indelible mark on the design world. Filled with unexpected displays of seemingly incongruous items \u2014 colorful Hella Jongerius ceramics, Maarten Baas chairs, 18th-century ceramics \u2014 the store, which he ran with his partner, Franklin Getchell, between 1994 and 2012, was a unique, avant-garde treasure trove that set new precedents in retail. Moss and Getchell recently left New York and moved into a 1929 colonial revival house in a small Connecticut town. From there, they run a design and retail consulting firm, and on April 10 they will release a Rizzoli book reflecting on the impact of the Moss store. To mark the occasion, T sent Moss a Polaroid camera and asked him to photograph some of the many objects that decorate his home.\n\n\u201cThese photos were all taken on the morning of March 1,\u201d Moss explains of his images, below. Every morning he rises at around 4 a.m. and, after making tea, surveys and rearranges his objects \u2014 crystal glasses, a Nymphenburg porcelain bird. It\u2019s an activity born of both love and habit, he says. \u201cI always enjoyed doing this when we had the store and galleries \u2014 and I still do it, although it\u2019s now at home, and on a much smaller scale.\u201d", "title": "Design Legend Murray Moss Captures His Beloved Objects \u2014 in Polaroids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nUpdate: Several states said they would sue the Trump administration over its decision to include a citizenship question in the 2020 census, including New York and California. Read the latest, here.\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The 2020 census will ask respondents whether they are United States citizens, the Commerce Department announced Monday night, agreeing to a Trump administration request with highly charged political and social implications that many officials feared would result in a substantial undercount.\n\nIn a statement released Monday, the Commerce Department, which oversees the Census Bureau, said Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross had \u201cdetermined that reinstatement of a citizenship question on the 2020 decennial census questionnaire is necessary to provide complete and accurate census block level data,\u201d allowing the department to accurately measure the portion of the population eligible to vote.\n\nBut his decision immediately invited a legal challenge: Xavier Becerra, California\u2019s attorney general, plans to sue the Trump administration over the decision, a spokeswoman for Mr. Becerra said late Monday.\n\nPhoto\n\nCritics of the change and experts in the Census Bureau itself have said that, amid a fiery immigration debate, the inclusion of a citizenship question could prompt immigrants who are in the country illegally not to respond. That would result in a severe undercount of the population \u2014 and, in turn, faulty data for government agencies and outside groups that rely on the census. The effects would also bleed into the redistricting of the House and state legislatures in the next decade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Justice Department had requested the change in December, arguing that asking participants about their citizenship status in the decennial census would help enforce Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, which aims to prevent voting rights violations.", "title": "Despite Concerns, Census Will Ask Respondents if They Are U.S. Citizens", "authors": ["Emily Baumgaertner"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Even as the special counsel expands his inquiry and pursues criminal charges against at least four Trump associates, House Intelligence Committee Republicans said on Monday that their investigation had found no evidence of collusion between Donald J. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign and Russia to sway the 2016 election.\n\nRepresentative K. Michael Conaway, the Texas Republican who is leading the investigation, said committee Republicans agreed with the conclusions of American intelligence agencies that Russia had interfered with the election, but they broke with the agencies on one crucial point: that the Russians had favored Mr. Trump\u2019s candidacy.\n\n\u201cThe bottom line: The Russians did commit active measures against our election in \u201916, and we think they will do that in the future,\u201d Mr. Conaway said. But, he added, \u201cWe disagree with the narrative that they were trying to help Trump.\u201d\n\nThe announcement brought an abrupt end to one of two remaining investigations into the topic on Capitol Hill and quickly provoked sharp objections from committee Democrats, who have warned Republicans not to close the matter before the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is done with his work.", "title": "Despite Mueller\u2019s Push, House Republicans Declare No Evidence of Collusion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "In a briefing for reporters later in the day, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, reiterated what she said in a Twitter post on Thursday night \u2014 that reports of General McMaster\u2019s imminent firing were not true.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have any personnel changes at this time,\u201d Ms. Sanders said, calling General McMaster a \u201cdedicated public servant\u201d who has a \u201cgreat relationship\u201d with Mr. Trump. She said the president told her he has no intention of firing him.\n\nThe absence of any formal announcements \u2014 or firings by presidential tweet \u2014 suggested that the White House was seeking to tamp down the anxiety inside the West Wing and the impression that the Trump administration is gripped by dysfunction.\n\nMs. Sanders said that Mr. Kelly had reassured senior members of the White House staff on Friday morning that \u201cthere were no immediate personnel changes at this time,\u201d and had urged officials to come to work focused on the policy goals ahead.\n\nShe said senior staff members passed that message on to others working in the West Wing in an attempt to diminish concerns about the record level of churn in the White House.\n\n\u201cOur focus is not on a lot of the news stories that you guys would like us to be focused on,\u201d she said.\n\nBut the lack of any resolution to the reports of coming firings is leaving many of the president\u2019s top advisers in a kind of political limbo that threatens to undermine their effectiveness until their fates are revealed, one way or the other.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGeneral McMaster, whose job requires him to negotiate internal disputes among factions within the administration, as well as deal directly with foreign officials, is operating with the public expectation that every day may be his last.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions remains at odds with the president, who has repeatedly \u2014 and publicly \u2014 demeaned his tenure at the head of the Justice Department, leaving it an open question how much longer he will remain in charge.\n\nMr. Kelly, too, is trying to run a White House under the cloud of reports that the president is looking for a replacement. Chiefs of staff to previous presidents have said that uncertainty is likely to hobble Mr. Kelly\u2019s ability to operate effectively.\n\nAnd both Mr. Carson and Mr. Shulkin are presiding over complex departments, and those efforts are likely to be more difficult if career officials and outside interest groups believe they could soon be ousted.\n\nThe Veterans Affairs inspector general issued a scathing report this year describing \u201cserious derelictions\u201d related to a trip Mr. Shulkin took last year to Britain and Denmark that cost more than $122,000. The report prompted bitter infighting within the department among Mr. Shulkin and his top lieutenants, generating politically damaging headlines for the administration.\n\nMr. Carson, the highest-ranking African-American man in an overwhelmingly white administration, had been dogged by the continuing story of HUD\u2019s purchase of a $31,000 dining set for his office. Mr. Carson initially claimed that neither he nor his wife, Candy, were involved in the selection of the dining room table, chairs and hutch when he was confronted with reports that the purchase far exceeded the $5,000 federal limit on office renovations.\n\nBut this week, the department released emails showing that Mr. Carson and his wife were, in fact, involved, down to reviewing a dozen swatches of material used on the seats of the 10 chairs, each costing taxpayers $600 to $700.", "title": "Despite Speculation, Trump\u2019s Cabinet Remains Intact", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Arts organizations around the country can breathe a sigh of relief.\n\nOnce again, Congress has rebuffed President Trump\u2019s call to gut the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities. In the new $1.3 trillion spending bill passed by Congress and signed by President Trump on Friday, both endowments actually saw a slight increase of about $3 million in their funding levels, to about $153 million each.\n\nIn Mr. Trump\u2019s first federal budget last year, he caused alarm after he became the first president to call for ending the endowments since they were created in 1965 \u2014 even though the combined budgets of both make up a mere fraction of the federal budget. Arts groups around the country mobilized immediately to save the federal funding.", "title": "Despite Trump Threat, N.E.A and N.E.H Are Spared in Spending Bill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 A devastating weekend fire that continued to rage into Monday consumed at least 69 homes in southern New South Wales, the state\u2019s rural fire service said.\n\nThe blaze began midday Sunday in Tarraganda, southeast of Bega, and quickly crossed the Bega River before advancing toward the seaside town of Tathra. Hundreds of its 1,600 residents fled to safety in Bega after receiving emergency alerts.\n\nAs Monday morning dawned, aerial footage showed the still-smoking extent of the damage. No serious injuries or fatalities had been reported, but one woman was being treated for respiratory problems and burns, said Shane Fitzsimmons, the commissioner for the New South Wales Rural Fire Service.\n\nThe blaze covered more than 1,000 hectares of land, or almost four square miles. It caused outages and disrupted cellphone service because of downed power lines and damaged cellular towers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe blaze comes amid increasing concern about extreme bush fires in southern and eastern Australia, with climate change and a paucity of rainfall believed to be behind the lengthening of the fire season from October through March.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShane Fitzsimmons, the commissioner for the state\u2019s Rural Fire Service, said on 7 News Sydney that the fire was still not under control and called the situation \u201cdangerous and dynamic.\u201d", "title": "Devastating Australia Bush Fire Destroys Scores of Homes", "authors": ["Isabella Kwai"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Both parents were found dead inside the S.U.V.; three of their children were discovered dead outside it; and the three other children, including Devonte, were still missing on Wednesday evening and feared dead, law enforcement officials said.\n\n\u201cWe have every indication to believe that all six children were in there, however only three bodies have been recovered,\u201d said Sheriff Tom Allman of Mendocino County. \u201cWe have no evidence and no reason to believe this was an intentional act. Certainly people are wondering what caused this.\u201d\n\nStill, the authorities did not discount the possibility that some of the children may have been staying with friends.\n\nAt a news conference on Wednesday, Sheriff Allman conceded that many questions remain: When did the \u201caccident,\u201d as he called it, occur? Why did the S.U.V. drive across at least 75 feet of dirt before plummeting into the ocean? Why weren\u2019t there skid marks? Sheriff Allman said his office knew of no witnesses.\n\nIn the meantime, troubling reports about the family have emerged.\n\nWashington State Child Protective Services learned on Friday of allegations of abuse against the Harts and tried to make contact with them that day, but no one answered when its employees visited their home, Norah West, a spokeswoman for the state\u2019s Department of Social and Health Services, said on Wednesday.", "title": "Devonte Hart, Boy in Famous Photo, Feared Dead With Family in S.U.V. Plunge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The newly formed Holt-Smithson Foundation has made its first move to secure the legacy of the pioneering land artist Nancy Holt (1938-2014), better known for safeguarding the work of her husband, Robert Smithson, after he died in 1973 than for promoting her own.\n\nHolt\u2019s monumental \u201cSun Tunnels\u201d (1973-76), sited in the Great Basin Desert in Utah, has just been acquired by the Dia Art Foundation \u2014 its first such work by a woman. The combination gift and purchase from the Holt-Smithson Foundation also includes Holt\u2019s room-size installation \u201cHoles of Light\u201d (1973), to be exhibited in September at Dia:Chelsea.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hoping the urban exhibition will encourage people to think about going out to the Great Basin Desert,\u201d said Lisa Le Feuvre, executive director of the foundation responsible for the estates of Holt and Smithson.", "title": "Dia Acquires \u2018Sun Tunnels,\u2019 Its First Piece of Land Art by a Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "But these aren\u2019t grimy street cubicles or sterile, forbidding isolation chambers. \u201cEach room is named after our favorite fictional female characters \u2014 like Ramona Quimby, Lieutenant Uhura, and Lisa Simpson \u2014 and provides members with a quiet space for private conversation,\u201d Ms. Gelman said. Each tiny space is equipped with a power outlet, a shallow shelf, a stool and a quaint, nonfunctional \u2014 but highly Instagrammable \u2014 retro telephone. (A third location of The Wing, in Dumbo, which opened earlier this month, has four phone booths hidden behind bookshelves, Clue-style.)\n\nFive new, maple-sided, portable, modular Zenbooth phone booths were installed late last year at the 17th Street headquarters of Gizmodo Media Group, the home of several websites, including Deadspin, Lifehacker, Jezebel and Splinter (where this reporter was previously employed).\n\nBut because approximately 230 employees work out of the GMG headquarters, the booths are frequently occupied by writers and editors looking to make a private call. Thus, the company\u2019s facilities manager, Will Sansom, recently ordered four additional Zenbooths \u2014 including one two-seater that acts a small stand-alone meeting room \u2014 explaining that there has been \u201cpositively positive feedback across the board.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOther companies that have recently purchased Zenbooths include Volkswagen, Lyft, Meetup and Capital One. The Berkeley, Calif., company was launched in 2016, and its products range from $3,995 (for a standard one-person booth) to $15,995 (for a two-person \u201cexecutive\u201d booth). The one-person booth is a soundproof, eco-friendly, American-made box that\u2019s about 36 inches wide and 34 inches deep, with an insulated glass door, a ventilation fan, power outlets and a skylight \u2014 and it can be assembled in roughly an hour. (It does not, however, contain an actual phone.)\n\nSam Johnson, a co-founder of the company, said it produced \u201chundreds\u201d of Zenbooths a month in 2017. This year, it\u2019s on track to quadruple that production. But he doesn\u2019t call them phone booths. \u201cWe\u2019re manufacturing quiet spaces and privacy,\u201d he said.\n\nZenbooth is not the only free-standing office phone booth in the game. Companies like Cubicall, Nomad, and TalkBox, among others, are offering up solutions to the modern office\u2019s privacy problem.\n\nThe Cubicall, which starts at $6,495, allows businesses to customize the exterior wall with a design or logo; the Nomad, priced at $2995, is partially made from recycled plastic bottles, and TalkBox, which starts at $4,500, has whiteboard walls for writing notes and ideas on the spot and counts companies both large (Google) and small (Ipsy, the cosmetics subscription service) among its clients.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut doesn\u2019t installing a free-standing phone booth in your company\u2019s sleek office admit some kind of failure of planning?\n\nPhoto\n\nYes, says Nikil Saval, the co-editor of n+1 magazine and the author of \u201cCubed: A Secret History Of The Workplace.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere has rarely been a premium placed on privacy for American office workers,\u201d Mr. Saval said in a phone interview, noting that while cubicles cut down on visual distractions, \u201cyou still have to deal with noise, and noise travels pretty easily. It\u2019s an incredibly common problem in open office plans.\u201d\n\nAdded Mr. Saval: \u201cThe clearest instance of how much of a problem it is? People put on headphones all the time. Headphones have become the new walls. It\u2019s also a signal: Don\u2019t disturb me. Because you\u2019re constantly surrounded by other people, and you\u2019re cheek to jowl, just crammed in with other people.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Saval said surveys have shown that while workers overwhelmingly prefer private offices to open-plan arrangements or cubicles \u2014 where they are often forced to hear a co-worker make dinner reservations, check in on the babysitter or, most awkwardly, argue with a significant other \u2014 there are economic forces that take precedence. \u201cThere are no measurable benefits as far as human interaction, sociability, running into each other, serendipitous encounters,\u201d he said of the open floor plan. \u201cIt\u2019s just cheaper, and that\u2019s why it exists.\"\n\nThus, the return of the phone booth signals a gesture toward more civility. Talking on the phone for others to overhear, especially in a work environment, has become at best an etiquette issue, and at worst, what Mr. Saval calls a pollutant. However small the footprint, the option for privacy is welcome.\n\nAs Ms. Gelman put it, \u201cSometimes you just need a minute to yourself.\u201d", "title": "Dial P for Privacy: The Phone Booth Is Back", "authors": ["Dodai Stewart"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019re a murderous dictator, this is a joyous time to be alive.\n\nNo one will make much of a fuss if your opposition leader is jailed, if an annoying journalist goes missing or if, as happened in Congo, a judge who displeases the dictatorial president suffers a home invasion in which goons rape his wife and daughter.\n\nAs President Trump replaces Secretary of State Rex Tillerson with the more hawkish Mike Pompeo, let\u2019s note something that goes far beyond personnel to the heart of the American role in the world: The U.S. has abandoned a bipartisan consensus on human rights that goes back decades.\n\nI\u2019m back from Myanmar, where leaders are finding that this is also the optimal time to commit genocide. The army conducted a scorched-earth campaign against the Rohingya ethnic minority, with soldiers throwing babies onto bonfires as they raped the mothers.\n\nWhat has Trump said to condemn Myanmar for these atrocities?\n\nEssentially nothing.\n\nIn the past, human rights was at least one thread of our foreign policy. This was pursued inconsistently, grudgingly or hypocritically, and it jostled constantly with realpolitik considerations, but in the past it was one of the factors in play.", "title": "Opinion | Dictators Love Trump, and He Loves Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRecipients are supposed to be the best of the best,\u201d said Rita Sostrin, a Los Angeles-based lawyer who has written extensively about EB-1s, \u201cbut meeting the criteria is no guarantee. An adjudication officer makes a judgment call.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cextraordinary ability\u201d immigrant visa category is one of the few visas for which an applicant does not require an employer or family sponsor. Only 5,530 people received a green card through that program in the fiscal year that ended in September 2016, the latest for which data is available, out of some one million issued. In 2001, when Mrs. Trump got hers, even fewer were granted.\n\nMarshall Cohen, a lawyer in Atlanta who specializes in EB-1s for world-ranked track and field athletes, said that he would not have hesitated to represent Mrs. Trump.\n\n\u201cI am assuming she made a lot of money, got a lot of press and was on the cover of magazines,\u201d he said. \u201cShe was probably a pretty easy case.\u201d\n\nMrs. Trump, then Melania Knauss, appeared on the cover of British GQ in 2000, the year she petitioned for the EB-1, and was featured in Sports Illustrated and other magazines later that year.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDo we need more foreign fashion models? Some might say no,\u201d said Mr. Cohen, who led a panel titled \u201cProving Extraordinary Ability Is Extraordinarily Challenging\u201d at a recent immigration lawyers\u2019 conference. \u201cWe might need more chemical engineers. But if there is a fashion model at the top of her field, she could qualify.\u201d\n\nPetitioners for the EB-1, which was created as part of the Immigration Act of 1990, face a two-part test. The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services first must determine whether a candidate has presented evidence to satisfy three out of 10 criteria, such as publishing material in professional publications or other major media, appearing in artistic exhibitions or commanding a high salary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce those are met, the decision comes down to a vague and undefined \u201cfinal merits determination\u201d by the immigration agency.\n\n\u201cThat is the mystery; nobody knows what it is,\u201d said Ms. Sostrin, the lawyer in Los Angeles, who recently secured EB-1s for an award-winning stunt performer and a high-end events planner.\n\nWhat is clear is that extraordinary intelligence is not necessary \u2014 nor sufficient on its own \u2014 to get one. Indeed, even Albert Einstein might have not qualified for an EB-1 before winning the Nobel Prize.\n\nA few years ago, Ms. Sostrin distributed a r\u00e9sum\u00e9 to immigration lawyers at a conference without revealing that it was Einstein\u2019s, or at least one devised from his career accomplishments. Ms. Sostrin asked them to assess the likelihood that he would be approved for an extraordinary ability visa.\n\nThe consensus was that it would be very challenging: The r\u00e9sum\u00e9, for a tutor and patent examiner turned professor, listed only a handful of the most important scientific works Einstein had published by 1920, more than a decade into his academic career.\n\n\u201cThe notion that you somehow have to be a genius or Einstein is utter fiction,\u201d said Chris Wright, a lawyer based in Los Angeles. \u201cWe have succeeded with models no more accomplished than Melania Trump.\u201d\n\nWhile the majority of applicants and recipients have titles like \u201cspace scientist,\u201d \u201ccancer researcher\u201d and \u201csoftware engineer,\u201d many have less scholarly pursuits. In 2012, Mr. Wright represented Shera B\u00e9chard, a Canadian model and Playboy Playmate who successfully petitioned for an EB-1. In her petition, Mr. Wright included scantily clad photographs of Ms. B\u00e9chard.\n\n\u201cWhen it\u2019s a glamorous model and pictures show cleavage rather than research, people assume there is something underhanded going on,\u201d said Mr. Wright, who said that he had also obtained the visas for a racecar driver, a hair dresser and a tennis player.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor Glenn Boswell, a stunt performer and director used to jumping out of buildings and moving vehicles, getting the EB-1 was a relative cake walk.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis lawyer filed a 439-page petition in 2016 detailing Mr. Boswell\u2019s achievements, which include credits in \u201cUnbroken,\u201d \u201cThe Matrix\u201d and \u201cThe Hobbit,\u201d and he received approval within a week. \u201cI was really excited when it came,\u201d Mr. Boswell, 60, said in a phone interview from his native Australia. He had no idea he had joined an exclusive club.\n\nDaniel Riffner, 35, an acrobat for Cirque du Soleil in Las Vegas, compiled a dossier in 2009 about his 25-year career, packed with medals, pictures of his high-wire acts and recommendations from coaches. Kinan Azmeh, 41, a Syrian clarinetist in Brooklyn who is a member of Yo-Yo Ma\u2019s Silk Road Ensemble, applied in 2012. Both received green cards.\n\nMr. Trump has championed an immigration overhaul that would replace the current family-based system, which he derides as \u201cchain migration,\u201d with one based on merit, emphasizing skill and educational level. His proposal would have made it impossible for the first lady to sponsor her parents for a green card, which she did after obtaining permanent legal residency and becoming a citizen herself. Meanwhile, highly skilled people, whether scientists or entrepreneurs, often get turned down when they apply to work and live in the country.\n\nEspecially under the Trump administration, immigration lawyers said, U.S.C.I.S. has made a habit of making requests for further evidence before deciding the fate of an applicant. The lawyers also said that scholars and scientists have a tougher time winning approval than models, actors and athletes.\n\nElissa Taub, a lawyer in Memphis who secured the EB-1 for the German gymnast, said that some of her denials \u201cburn me to this day,\u201d like that of a nuclear astrophysicist who had produced groundbreaking work at a national lab. Immigration officials said his title on the job was not senior enough to merit the EB-1.\n\n\u201cWe lost a great scientific mind due to this crazy decision,\u201d she said of the scholar, who returned to India.\n\nIn another case, U.S.C.I.S. acknowledged that a Chinese researcher had fulfilled three criteria to qualify, but that \u201cscientists who have risen to the very top of the field have garnered citations numbered in the thousands,\u201d not in the hundreds, as he had shown. He was denied.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite ample documentation and detailed letters from world-renowned experts supporting the petition of a molecular oncologist who studies drug-resistant cancer, U.S.C.I.S. questioned whether her scholarship was significant. After her lawyer submitted further evidence, she was approved.\n\n\u201cThese are people we should be rolling out the red carpet for,\u201d said David Soloway, the lawyer who handled the case.\n\n\u201cMost people would readily say that it makes sense for someone who is extraordinarily skilled in the sciences to be admitted to this country,\u201d Mr. Soloway added. \u201cBut in modeling? Really?\u201d", "title": "Did Melania Trump Merit an \u2018Einstein Visa\u2019? Probably, Immigration Lawyers Say", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Our newest Canada correspondent, Dan Bilefsky, recently spent 10 days on the road rediscovering his native Quebec after nearly three decades living away. Crisscrossing the province, he visited cafes and restaurants, a microbrewery, an aluminum factory, a First Nations community radio station and a mosque marked by bullet holes.\n\nDid you follow Dan\u2019s dispatches on nytimes.com, on social media or in our Canada newsletter? We\u2019d love your feedback about how we brought you along on his trip and what you would like to see in the future.", "title": "Did You Follow Along With Our Correspondent in Quebec?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nSubtitled TV shows often struggle to reach a wide audience in the United States, but since landing on Netflix in January, the German-language series \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d has become a sleeper hit. Set in Berlin during the Weimar Republic, the series mixes the police procedural, the gangland noir, the spy caper and the political thriller with unusual dexterity. Add romance, outlandish visuals, intricate plotting and breakneck pacing, and it\u2019s little surprise the series broke through.\n\n\u2018Babylon Berlin\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe characters are just as rich as the production, including a morphine-addicted detective (played by Volker Bruch); a corrupt chief inspector (Peter Kurth); and an amateur sleuth, who\u2019s a police typist by day, hard-partying flapper by night (Liv Lisa Fries). Once you\u2019ve burned through the 16 episodes on Netflix, you may be craving similar fare. Few series possess the riches of \u201cBabylon,\u201d but here are seven shows that should hit some of the same pleasure points.\n\nIf You Want to See More of Berlin During Dramatic Times\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Same Sky.\u201d Beta Film\n\n\u2018The Same Sky\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cThe Same Sky\u201d jumps ahead a few decades in Berlin\u2019s tumultuous history to 1974, when the German metropolis was split in two by the Berlin Wall. A collaboration between the British writer Paula Milne and the German director Oliver Hirschbiegel, the show is a canny evocation of the Cold War tensions that led the citizens of East and West Berlin to constantly spy on one another. The harsh toll that the espionage takes on the spies themselves unspools amid picture-perfect art direction, while a story line about the human toll of an East German doping program targeting teenage athletes is more chilling still. If you like \u201cThe Americans\u201d or \u201cDeutschland 83,\u201d you\u2019ll want to savor these six hourlong episodes.\n\nIf You\u2019re Wondering What It All Added Up To\n\nA scene from \u201cA French Village.\u201d Etienne Chognard/CCSP\n\n\u2018A French Village\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRemember the generals who were working hard to weaponize Germany again in \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d? Well, \u201cA French Village\u201d is effectively about the results. Set in a hamlet during World War II, this French-language series doesn\u2019t have the production values of \u201cBabylon Berlin,\u201d but it is just as addictive. Each season takes place in a different year, and the show, which brilliantly mixes melodrama and realism, follows a set of locals as they try to survive the German occupation by choosing collaboration or resistance \u2014 or, among the canniest of them, by choosing one and then the other. \u201cA French Village\u201d excels at setting up the kind of moral quandaries that make you wonder what you would do in similar circumstances. The answer is not always as obvious as one might hope.\n\n0\n\nIf You Can\u2019t Get Enough of Volker Bruch\n\nVolker Bruch in \u201cGeneration War.\u201d Music Box Films\n\n\u2018Generation War\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe quietly charismatic Bruch here portrays Vilhelm, one of five twentysomething friends at the center of this 2013 German mini-series, which tracks the diverse experiences of these Berlin buddies from 1941 to the end of World War II. Vilhelm and his brother, Friedhelm (Tom Schilling), are both in the army and are sent to the Eastern Front. Charlotte (Miriam Stein) finds herself there as well, but serving as a nurse. Back at home, Greta (Katharina Sch\u00fcttler) sleeps with a Gestapo officer in hopes of saving her secret lover, Viktor (Ludwig Trepte), who is Jewish. The show packs a lot into three 90-minute episodes. Some viewers have objected to its portrayal of some of the average Germans as innocent victims, but the horrors of war and their psychological aftermath are rendered well and with complexity, and the overall message is clear: A fanatical, delusional Germany set the world on fire, then succumbed to the flames.\n\nIf You Want More Stylish International Double-Crossing\n\nFrom left, Elizabeth Debicki, Hugh Laurie, Tom Hiddleston and David Avery in \u201cThe Night Manager.\u201d Des Willie/The Ink Factory, via AMC\n\n\u2018The Night Manager\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAmong the many mysteries in \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d are what, exactly, is on that Soviet train and who is the cargo\u2019s intended recipient. Trafficking and double-crossing are reliably suspenseful plot devices, especially when a sultry blonde is involved, and you will find all of this in \u201cThe Night Manager.\u201d Based on the novel by John le Carr\u00e9, this elegantly cinematic British mini-series boasts superb turns by Tom Hiddleston in the title role; Hugh Laurie as a diabolical, supremely composed villain; and Elizabeth Debicki as the object of their desire. The story jumps around the sunny climes of the Mediterranean and the Middle East, but make no mistake: Its heart is as cold as ice.\n\nIf You\u2019re Looking for More Period Gangsters\n\nCillian Murphy in \u201cPeaky Blinders.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Peaky Blinders\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA fan favorite in \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d is the mysterious Armenian cabaret owner and underworld kingpin, Edgar. The equivalent in \u201cPeaky Blinders\u201d is Cillian Murphy\u2019s Tommy Shelby, a criminal mastermind and gang leader, and the center of this British series. Set in Birmingham between the two world wars, this flashy, violent British show follows the titular local gang (so named for the razor blades kept in their caps, which they traditionally used to blind their enemies), which spreads its tentacles well beyond its home base and ruthlessly wipes out those who stand in its way. Another similarity with \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d is its elaborate soundtrack \u2014 most of them in \u201cPeaky\u201d are modern rock songs (including many interesting covers of the theme song, which is by Nick Cave), which is jarring at first, then quickly feels integral.\n\nIf You Loved the Lavish Period Reconstruction\n\nA scene from \u201cRome.\u201d Franco Biciocchi/HBO\n\n\u2018Rome\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, HBO\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nTwo hallmarks of \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d are the awe-inspiring crowd scenes and the mammoth sets. Among the few series to match that cinematic grandeur is HBO\u2019s \u201cRome,\u201d which was created in part by John Milius, who directed and helped write \u201cConan the Barbarian.\u201d (The first season reportedly cost $100 million.) Despite being eclipsed in recent years by \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d this sprawling production set in ancient Rome is well worth revisiting \u2014 or discovering, if you missed its original airing, from 2005 to 2007. The main characters are two humble former soldiers, but \u201cRome,\u201d like \u201cBabylon Berlin,\u201d offers a vivid cross-section of an entire society, from its ruling elite to its poor laborers. Need more convincing? The Romans\u2019 sex life was likely just as thrilling as that of the Berliners centuries later.\n\nIf You Want More Women Solving Crimes\n\nEssie Davis in \u201cMiss Fisher\u2019s Murder Mysteries.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Miss Fisher\u2019s Murder Mysteries\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Acorn, Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the best subplots in \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d involves Charlotte\u2019s dream to become a police officer at a time when women were not allowed on the force. Another woman with a talent for ferreting out illegal activities is Phryne Fisher (played by the excellent Essie Davis) in the Australian series \u201cMiss Fisher\u2019s Murder Mysteries.\u201d Set in 1920s Melbourne, the show tracks the glamorous, wealthy Phryne as she gets embroiled in one caper after another. The tone is decidedly more lighthearted than that of \u201cBabylon Berlin\u201d \u2014 think \u201cThe Thin Man\u201d \u2014 but it is still rewarding to see a smart, resourceful heroine take criminal matters into her own hands.", "title": "Did You Love \u2018Babylon Berlin\u2019? Here\u2019s What to Watch Next", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHopefully, it\u2019s the last one,\u201d said Mark Mito, 29, a finance manager for an auto sales company in Brooklyn as he helped clear snow off the cars. \u201cI don\u2019t know what season it is right now. I\u2019m kind of confused.\u201d\n\nEven before the slow-moving storm blanketed the region Wednesday, police and emergency crews stepped up their efforts. As of Thursday morning, New Jersey State Police had responded to 516 accidents over two days.\n\nDiane Gutierrez-Scaccetti, acting commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Transportation, said 3,800 plows and trucks loaded with de-icing agents were deployed during the storm. \u201cYesterday was a very smooth day for us in terms of being able to plow,\u201d she said.\n\nSnowfall reached at least 10 inches in more than a dozen New Jersey counties, with a high of 15 inches in Lacey Township in Ocean County, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nMore than 86,000 New Jersey homes were without power early Thursday, of which more than half were in the Atlantic City area, according to the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities. By afternoon, 72,000 homes remained dark.\n\nStill, Gov. Philip D. Murphy said that the number of homes without power were less than a third of what they had been during the last storm. \u201cWe have to be committed like heck to make sure we get everybody back on,\u201d he said at a news conference in Woodbridge.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn New York City, the public school system reopened on time, and there were no residual storm-related problems reported for the subways and buses during the morning commute. The Long Island Rail Road was also largely back to normal.\n\nNatalie Grybauskas, a spokeswoman for Mayor Bill de Blasio, said that cleanup efforts were well underway. \u201cA snowstorm on the first day of spring is a good reminder that anything can happen, but we\u2019re always prepared,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re still doing some snow-clearing and spot-checking around the city, but thanks to a full-force, nonstop effort by city workers \u2014 and slightly warmer temperatures \u2014 the streets are looking good, and we expect to be fully back to normal soon.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOutside the city, many suburban communities were also recovering quickly, in part because the storm\u2019s slow approach had allowed for preparations. On Long Island, where the snow topped 20.1 inches in Patchogue, the heaviest snowfall came overnight. Road crews worked through the night to ensure the roads were clear for the morning commute.\n\n\u201cThis spring storm demonstrates the difficulty of predicting weather, and what we try to do is err on the side of caution and public safety,\u201d said Steven Bellone, the Suffolk County executive.\n\nNew York State transportation workers kept open miles of highway lanes in the Long Island region during the storm, according to Joseph Brown, a regional director for the transportation department. They used more than 300 plow trucks, some of which were sent from upstate.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t expect to have a very mild February or a very tough March,\u201d he said. \u201cYou never know what\u2019s going to hit you.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, Gov. Cuomo said that state\u2019s aggressive preparations had paid off, with a full force of emergency workers strategically deployed and utility companies required to have a storm-response plan in place. \u201cThis weather is clearly the new normal and New Yorkers should know that no matter what Mother Nature throws our way, we will always remain vigilant and do whatever is necessary to keep people safe,\u201d he said.\n\nSome New Yorkers reveled in the aftereffect of the nor\u2019easter.\n\nMads Jakob Poulsen, 35, a graphic designer, let his 4-year-old pit bull, Astro, sprint across the snow at Herbert Von King Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn \u2014 in clear violation of a \u201cNo Pets\u201d sign. \u201cIt\u2019s a little bit like alternate-side parking: When that\u2019s off, this is off, too,\u201d he said.\n\nBut for others, the brief snowy interlude was over.\n\nSanjay Gupta, 55, a Verizon field technician on Long Island, was on his way to make a repair early Thursday morning. \u201cI figure about 80 percent of the other field techs called in today for a personal day,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t.\u201d", "title": "Digging Out From a Snowy Spring Day", "authors": ["Winnie Hu", "Nate Schweber"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 The British designer Kim Jones was confirmed as the new artistic director of Dior Homme on Monday, two months after he stepped down as artistic director of men\u2019s wear at Louis Vuitton.
