Milliken unexpectedly announced that he would step down at the end of the academic year.\n\nA CUNY spokesman declined to comment, citing the litigation. The state Attorney General\u2019s office, which is defending the university, is scheduled to respond by Wednesday.\n\nNeither Dr. Dodd nor her lawyer, Anne L. Clark, with the employment law firm of Vladeck, Raskin & Clark, would comment.\n\nBut in an unusual display of support, 50 political scientists who focus on law and courts wrote to Dr. Boudreau and Mr. Milliken, praising Dr. Dodd\u2019s work and calling the tenure decision \u201ca manifest injustice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe reaction I got was \u2014 you\u2019ve got to be kidding,\u201d said Charles R. Epp, a University of Kansas professor who spoke at City College forum in 2012, and helped organize the letter-writing effort. \u201cShe writes as if she\u2019s a much more senior scholar, and her contribution is equal to that of many senior scholars.\u201d\n\nDr. Dodd, 49, has a Ph.D. in politics from Princeton, and a law degree from Yale. After serving as a law professor at American University, she came to City College in 2010 to bolster a new, high-profile program, the Skadden Arps Honors Program in Legal Studies, to help prepare more students from underrepresented backgrounds for legal careers.\n\nSkadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom contributed $9.6 million, and Dr. Dodd received a higher-than-usual salary as the Joseph H. Flom Professor of Legal Studies. But, in an unusual move for named professorships, the position was not automatically tenured.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA Skadden spokeswoman did not respond to requests for comment. But some former students hold her in high esteem.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe was regarded as a tough professor, but fair,\u201d said Joel Sati, 24, who is now pursuing a doctorate at the University of California at Berkeley and a law degree at Yale. \u201cYou know \u2018The Paper Chase\u2019? Kind of like Kingsfield, but a much lighter version.\u201d\n\nBut Dr. Dodd experienced numerous health setbacks after 2010, as her progressive \u201cM.S. symptoms worsened, including declining mobility, extreme fatigue, and a severe form of pain,\u201d her lawsuit claimed.\n\nYet \u201cher efforts to obtain a reasonable accommodation of additional time to complete her research were met with hostility and obstruction,\u201d the suit said.\n\nPart of the complaint involves Dr. Dodd\u2019s need to win reappointment annually to the Flom professorship. In at least two years, while senior college officials voiced concerns that she did not meet the \u201chigh standards\u201d for \u201cresearch production\u201d and was \u201ctaking forever\u201d to produce books and articles, she kept her position by appealing successfully to Dr. Coico, then the president, according to the complaint.\n\nBy early 2017, after Dr. Boudreau had become interim president, the complaint said, Dr. Dodd believed that she had met the criteria for tenure, two years earlier than scheduled, citing a book contract with Cambridge University Press and other works. But her political science department voted against her in October. Dr. Dodd then notified CUNY that she would sue.\n\nGiven the importance of the Skadden program, several people affiliated with City College, speaking on condition of anonymity because of the litigation, said that Dr. Dodd may not have lived up to expectations. Others suggested that the college had legitimate concerns, and cautioned that her case may be more complicated than the complaint suggests.\n\nRogers M. Smith, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania who is the president-elect of the American Political Science Association, said that he took seriously the issue of productivity. But Dr. Smith, who tried unsuccessfully to recruit Dr. Dodd to Yale for graduate school when he taught there in the 1990s, said that he didn\u2019t think there was an issue with her productivity, given her medical issues and the fact that she had taken parental leave. \u201cI think very highly of her as a scholar, and I would need to be persuaded that those concerns have legitimacy,\u201d he said.", "title": "Disability Led to Tenure Denial at City College, Lawsuit Claims", "authors": ["David W. Chen"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u2666\n\nNasty, vicious, ruthless. That\u2019s the way we like our legal mysteries, so THE PLEA (Flatiron, $26.99) fits the bill. Steve Cavanagh\u2019s hero, Eddie Flynn, has taken to the profession with the same relish he showed for his previous work as a con man. A New York defense attorney with the dregs of the earth as clients, Flynn is living out of his office when a C.I.A. operative arrives with an offer he can\u2019t refuse: Lean on a client to plead guilty and cut a deal, a move for which Flynn will collect a fee of $100,000. The problem is, Flynn doesn\u2019t believe his client, David Child, is guilty of murdering his girlfriend. Could someone be framing him in order to steal his design for a security system that can be misused for laundering dirty money? The impressive legal maneuvering pays off in a centerpiece courtroom drama that Flynn describes as \u201cVegas time.\u201d But a lot of his showmanship is pure flimflam, meant to dazzle his audience. After all, as Robert Frost once said, \u201cA jury consists of 12 persons chosen to decide who has the best lawyer.\u201d\n\n\u2666\n\nThe marshland setting of Christobel Kent\u2019s psychological thriller THE DAY SHE DISAPPEARED (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27) holds a \u201cparticular magic\u201d for an old man named Victor, who appreciates the desolate beauty of this bleak spot \u201cwhere the sea turned into a river.\u201d Victor\u2019s less enchanted neighbors are more likely to turn their backs on the view and crowd into a pub like the Bird in Hand, where the mood is cheery and the barmaids, Nat and Beth, are pretty and friendly. But when Beth fails to show up for work, Nat is the only one who cares enough to look for her.\n\nKent doesn\u2019t play games with the whodunit plotting, and the novel\u2019s water imagery is properly eerie. But her higher aim is to expose the blunt social prejudice against attractive young women like Nat and Beth. \u201cGood riddance, I say,\u201d one old biddy curses the missing barmaid. \u201cThey need to learn, women like that,\u201d she adds. With neighbors like this, who needs a serial killer?\n\n\u2666\n\nWhen people speak of Albany, they usually mention the daunting weather. And there\u2019s a lot of weather in Robin Oliveira\u2019s WINTER SISTERS (Viking, $27). This stunning mystery is set back in 1879, when New York\u2019s capital city is hit by a blizzard that buries the parents of 10-year-old Emma and 7-year-old Claire and hurls the girls into the streets. Dr. Mary Stipp, who ministers to prostitutes, makes it her mission to find the missing girls. But evil men get to them first, and it takes another violent act of nature \u2014 a raging flood \u2014 to flush them out of their basement prison. Rescuing Emma from rapists is even more of a challenge because the age of consent in this not-so-enlightened era is 10. Oliveira writes with feeling about social issues like abortion and prostitution, and her grasp of causes like women\u2019s suffrage is firm. Like many others, Dr. Stipp has found that the freedoms she enjoyed during the Civil War quickly vanished in its aftermath. \u201cTherein lay the advantage of wartime,\u201d she notes. \u201cMen were too busy killing one another to take heed of women\u2019s activities.\u201d", "title": "Disappearing Acts: A Shelf of Missing-Person Mysteries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "AMSTERDAM \u2014 If you look at a map of Europe and imagine the Netherlands as a man\u2019s smiling face gazing out toward the North Sea, the city of Maastricht would be, perhaps, a crumb stuck in the man\u2019s scraggly beard. Brush it off in a westerly direction, and it\u2019ll drop in Belgium. If the wind blows it to the east, it will likely arrive in Germany.\n\nThere are lots of regulars and exhibitors to the annual Tefaf art fair in Maastricht who visit this lovely little city built on Roman ruins and gripe about the local offerings \u2014 the hotels aren\u2019t terribly modern, it\u2019s too remote from top European cities, the airports aren\u2019t sufficiently near.\n\nBut if you think of Maastricht as the nub of what is known as the Meuse-Rhine Euregion \u2014 which includes parts of the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany; four official languages; five provinces; 10 cities; and 3.9 million inhabitants \u2014 you\u2019ll start off with a better mind-set about the place.", "title": "Discovering Art in and Around Maastricht", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "8. When Nadia and Saeed learn that the magical doors do exist, and can in fact take them away from the violence of their city, they are excited and immediately pursue an agent to help them leave. Saeed\u2019s father, on the other hand, only says of the doors: \u201cLet us see.\u201d Does this feel resonant to you of the experience of different generations of migrants?\n\nWeek Three\n\n9. Chapter Five ends with Nadia making Saeed\u2019s father a promise to take care of his son, and the line: \u201cThat is the way of things, for when we migrate, we murder from our lives those we leave behind.\u201d Is Hamid referring to Saeed\u2019s father and the people we leave behind, or something more?\n\n10. As migrants move through the magical doors to other places, trying to escape war and chaos, the passage they take is described as: \u201cboth like dying and like being born.\u201d Does this description feel representative of the experience of people who migrate today?\n\n11. We never hear, though, about what actually happens as people migrate through these doors. Why do you think the migration itself is absent from the narrative?\n\n12. As Nadia and Saeed escape through the doors, we learn that not just their city, but much of the wider world, is in turmoil. Refugees are on the move to Mykonos in Greece and Marin County, near San Francisco. Riots are starting over migrants in Vienna and in London. What do you think Hamid wants us to understand about this global instability?\n\n13. As these cities become more unstable, they also come under greater surveillance, at the hands of unseen authorities. These authorities also control the electricity network and internet connectivity. How do these changes impact the people in the book? How does it feel relevant to today\u2019s world?\n\nWeek Four\n\n14. In the cities to which migrants flee, Hamid writes that people began to reassemble with others of their own kind, \u201clike superficially with like.\u201d At one point, even Saeed wants him and Nadia to relocate to live with others like them, though Nadia resists. What do you think is behind this human impulse?", "title": "Discussion Questions for \u2018Exit West\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Disney also promoted Robert Chapek, who has been chairman of Disney\u2019s theme park division for the last three years. Mr. Chapek was named chairman of a new division called Parks, Experiences and Consumer Products, which adds merchandising, video games, book publishing and the Disney Store chain to his purview. Mr. Chapek was in charge of consumer products for Disney before he was promoted to theme park chairman in 2015.\n\nThe reorganization, which involves significant changes for every part of Disney except for the movie division, sets up a structure for Disney to absorb the Fox businesses. They include the Fox movie and television studio, a large portion of Hulu, 22 regional cable networks dedicated to sports, the FX and National Geographic channels, and stakes in two behemoth overseas TV service providers, Sky of Britain and Star of India.\n\nThe elevation of Mr. Mayer and Mr. Chapek was instantly read by some people in Hollywood as positioning either as a possible successor to Mr. Iger. Disney insiders cautioned against drawing that conclusion, however.\n\nTo complete the Fox integration, Mr. Iger, 67, agreed to renew his contract for a fourth time, delaying retirement from July 2019 to the end of 2021. Rupert Murdoch, who controls 21st Century Fox, asked Mr. Iger to stay as a condition of the deal, which was valued at $66.1 billion including debt.\n\nAs part of the restructuring, Andy Bird, the longtime chairman of Walt Disney International, is expected to leave the company. The management shuffling was announced a week after Disney named James Pitaro as president of ESPN. Mr. Pitaro previously oversaw consumer products.", "title": "Disney Reorganization Anticipates 21st Century Fox Assets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "HANGBERG, South Africa \u2014 One man vanished diving at midnight. Another was attacked by a great white shark in deep water. Two more drowned, one in borrowed scuba gear he wasn\u2019t qualified to use.\n\nAll four men, who died over the past few months, were casualties of an entrenched illicit trade: poaching abalone, a seafood delicacy that sells for enormous prices in Asia.\n\nThe shellfish, which once smothered reefs in South Africa, in some places packed as tightly as cobblestones, has become more difficult to find as a result of overfishing, luring untrained divers into deeper and more deadly waters.\n\n\u201cThe old reefs have been hit too hard and haven\u2019t had time to recover,\u201d said a diver from Hangberg, an impoverished fishing community in Cape Town, who insisted on anonymity because he did not want to alert the police to his poaching.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith stocks of the shellfish declining in South Africa, legal quotas on harvesting it are strictly enforced. But in Hangberg, hundreds of families have turned to the abalone black market for income, as factory closings and the demise of commercial fishing have contributed to a spike in unemployment in recent years.\n\nPhoto\n\nFueling the demand for exports of the mollusk is China\u2019s rising middle class, increasingly eager to consume high-status foods. For more than 2,000 years, abalone has been served to celebrate special occasions and honor guests, taking a pride of place alongside other luxury ingredients like shark fin and sea cucumber. It has a rich, buttery flavor, and, when prepared correctly, the flesh is tender, though it can be rubbery and tough.", "title": "Divers Risk Drowning and Sharks to Poach Abalone Worth $200 a Pound", "authors": ["Kimon De Greef"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cShe Wants More Than M.L.K. at Bedtime\u201d (Sunday Review, March 11): As a psychologist, I know that the books Denene Millner calls for \u2014 portraying black children in ordinary childhood situations instead of only as victims or heroes \u2014 are desperately needed for white children, too!\n\nChildren living in white neighborhoods need to learn early that children with different skin colors, just like those with different hair colors, are not essentially different.\n\nResearch shows that consistent early exposure helps children to experience minorities as us, not them. As a white grandmother, I have been searching for such books, and I have been saddened to see that there are far too few.\n\nMARGARET L. WHITE\n\nUPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J.", "title": "Opinion | Diversity in Children\u2019s Books", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "More people in the United States are on antidepressants, as a percentage of the population, than any other country in the world. And yet the drugs\u2019 efficacy has been hotly debated.\n\nSome believe that the short-term benefits are much more modest than widely thought, and that harms may outweigh benefits in the long run. Others believe that they work, and that they can be life-changing.\n\nSettling this debate has been much harder than you might think.\n\nIt\u2019s not that we lack research. Many, many studies of antidepressants can be found in the peer-reviewed literature. The problem is that this has been a prime example of publication bias: Positive studies are likely to be released, with negative ones more likely to be buried in a drawer.\n\nIn 2008, a group of researchers made this point by doing a meta-analysis of antidepressant trials that were registered with the Food and Drug Administration as evidence in support of approvals for marketing or changes in labeling. Companies had to submit the results of registered trials to the F.D.A. regardless of the result. These trials also tend to have less data massaging \u2014 such as the cherry-picking of outcomes \u2014 than might be possible in journals.", "title": "Do Antidepressants Work?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How effective are antimicrobial \u201ccourtesy masks\u201d at preventing the spread of contagious airborne illnesses?\n\nA. The best evidence suggests that, when sick, wearing a mask can help to protect others from getting sick. And when well, wearing a mask around those who are sick will probably decrease your own chances of becoming infected. But the masks are far from foolproof.\n\nCourtesy masks, or what we doctors refer to as surgical masks, were introduced into the operating room in the late 1800s. They quickly became popular among a public eager to protect itself against the influenza pandemic of 1918.\n\nA century later, the advent of modern molecular techniques confirmed that surgical masks can indeed provide good protection against flu. In a 2013 study, researchers counted the number of virus particles in the air around patients with flu. They found that surgical masks decreased the exhalation of large viral droplets 25-fold. The masks were, however, less effective against the fine viral droplets that can remain suspended in the air longer and are therefore more infectious, cutting them by 2.8 times.", "title": "Do Face Masks Really Keep You Healthy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "[READ MORE: To Find the Right Financial Adviser, \u2018Do a Beauty Contest\u2019]\n\nThe rule still has a chance to live on, legal experts say, but its fate depends on the Trump administration\u2019s next steps and what may unfold in the courts. The future of the rule was already called into question last year when the new leadership at the Labor Department said it would review the regulation and delayed its full implementation by 18 months to July 2019. After this month\u2019s court ruling, the agency said that pending further review, it would not enforce the rule.\n\nBut there is another complication. The Securities and Exchange Commission is reportedly working on its own proposal for financial professionals, which would likely apply to all investment accounts and not just tax-advantaged retirement money.\n\nIn October, Jay Clayton, the S.E.C. chairman, said that he was \u201cfocused on the standards of conduct that investment professionals must follow in providing advice to Main Street investors.\u201d Last June, he invited the public to submit comments on the issue. (The S.E.C. declined to comment on the details of any future proposal.)\n\nRegardless of whether any form of the fiduciary rule survives, however, consumers need to proceed with caution.\n\n\u201cGiven the uncertainty, there is more reason now than ever for an investor to simply ask a financial adviser whether he or she is acting as a fiduciary, at all times,\u201d said Arthur Laby, a professor at Rutgers Law School. Fiduciary is the legal term that means an adviser must put its customers\u2019 financial well-being before their own.\n\nOne ally for consumers in lieu of the federal government could be the states. Champions of the Labor Department\u2019s fiduciary rule, include William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of the commonwealth, who recently called on the federal government to appeal the court decision striking down the rule.\n\nIn the meantime, he said his office would continue to aggressively pursue investigations to ensure retirees were protected. Just last month, he brought charges against Scottrade, now part of TD Ameritrade. \u201cIf the Department of Labor will not enforce its own laws and rules, then the states must do what they can to protect retirees,\u201d he said at the time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn anticipation of the fiduciary rule, Scottrade banned a list of activities that could tempt its representatives to put their own financial interests ahead of customers, including sales quotas and contests, bonuses and special awards. But Scottrade held two sales contests anyway, according to the Massachusetts regulator\u2019s complaint.\n\nBoth contests \u201cperversely incentivized Scottrade agents to bring in new assets from customers, including through the rollover of retirement assets,\u201d the complaint said. It also noted that \u201cScottrade\u2019s own internal-use materials instructed agents to target a client\u2019s \u2018pain point\u2019 and emotional vulnerability.\u201d\n\nUltimately, Secretary Galvin\u2019s office charged the firm with engaging in unethical and dishonest conduct. TD Ameritrade declined to comment on the matter.\n\nAmeriprise Financial recently settled allegations that the firm\u2019s representatives recommended and sold higher-priced mutual fund shares to retirement account holders, which made the brokers more money, when cheaper shares were available. About 1,791 customers\u2019 accounts paid nearly $1.8 million in unnecessary upfront sales charges, as well as higher ongoing fees and expenses, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.\n\nAmeriprise did not admit or deny the findings, but as part of a settlement with regulators it paid back customers (with interest) as well as a $230,000 penalty.\n\nRegardless of how the fiduciary saga ends, there are several things consumers can do to minimize that they will be on the receiving end of any of these shenanigans.\n\n\u2022 Work with a fiduciary, or someone who pledges to put your financial interests ahead of their own \u2014 all of the time, with all of your money. Get them to pledge to their fiduciary duty in writing. Working with a fiduciary is not fail-safe, but it is a consumer\u2019s best defense. So-called investment advisers, who generally must register with the S.E.C. or a state securities regulator, must put their customers\u2019 interests first, regardless of what accounts they are working with.\n\n\u2022 Choose a financial planner with strong credentials. Anyone can call themselves a financial adviser, at least for now, so don\u2019t accept titles at face value. Certified financial planners hold a professional designation with rigorous curriculum and experience requirements. They can manage your entire financial life, but can also provide guidance locating reputable specialists, like an estate planner, or, say, a life insurer who will sell you only what you need.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Consider paying the adviser outright. No financial adviser is entirely free of conflicts. But it\u2019s often easier to eliminate those conflicts when they are paid for their time or advice and their paychecks are not dependent on selling you a financial product.\n\n\u2022 You can find a list of fee-only financial planners through the Garrett Planning Network, the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors and the XY Planning Network.\n\nApply the same sort of rigor in your search for a financial adviser as you would when seeking a doctor or a lawyer, advised Tamar Frankel, a fiduciary expert and professor at Boston University School of Law. \u201cThe rules do not do it now,\u201d she said. \u201cSo you have to do it now.\u201d", "title": "Do Financial Advisers Have to Act in Your Interest? Maybe", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "It is perhaps not a shock that in this age of cellphone zombies, traffic deaths in the United States have risen, after years of steady declines thanks to safer cars and improved road design. The 2016 toll was 37,461, or 14 percent higher than that in 2014. The final tally for 2017 is expected to be no more heartening.\n\nThe increase in pedestrian deaths, which account for 16 percent of all traffic fatalities, is even more discouraging. There were 5,987 of them in 2016, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Expectations are that 2017 will end up with a toll at least that high. That\u2019s a rise of 22 percent from the 4,910 registered in 2014.\n\nNo doubt, inattentive driving is to blame in large measure. But distracted walking is a likely factor, too. And maybe so is pot-smoking. Analyzing data for the first half of 2017, the Governors Highway Safety Association found a notable increase in pedestrian deaths in states that had legalized marijuana. Elsewhere, the death toll declined. It is too early for firm conclusions, but you can\u2019t rule out that judgments are flawed when drivers and pedestrians go around stoned.\n\nEnforcing an ordinance like Montclair\u2019s won\u2019t be easy. You can\u2019t put police on every corner. And as sure as a sunrise, some people will wail about personal freedoms being violated. But there\u2019s a social contract to be observed. When you venture forth in public, you assume certain responsibilities, be it preserving your own life or having regard for others. Even in nonlethal situations, who isn\u2019t driven crazy when blocked on the sidewalk by people ambling so s-l-o-w-l-y, with eyes glued to their screens?\n\nMr. Starr says that people in Montclair seem to get it, including youngsters who deem smartphones a birthright. \u201cStudents are actually pretty understanding, and even tell us this was really needed,\u201d he said of the new rules. That\u2019s because they know their lives matter.", "title": "Opinion | Do Not Read This Editorial While Walking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf you are in high school, are you often asked about your plans for life after graduation? How many A.P. courses is she taking? Does she excel in a sport? Is she a leader? A volunteer? The valedictorian?\u201d Depending upon my answers, the conversation splits, Choose Your Own Adventure-style, in one of two directions. If I demur, I land in the chapter about how sad it is that our kids are so overstressed. If I play along, we arrive at, \u201cHave you guys made your list yet?\u201d I hate this question. \u201cWe\u201d aren\u2019t going through the \u201ccollege process\u201d; my daughter is.\n\nStudents: Read the entire essay, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Does anything Ms. Egan say resonate with you? What, if anything, about this echoes what is going on in your life?\n\n\u2014 If you have graduated high school already, how did your family handle your time of transition? What advice do you have for parents and their children?", "title": "Do Other People Care Too Much About Your Post-High School Plans?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nImage Mark Conditt Credit Facebook, via Associated Press\n\nCoverage of the bombings in Austin, Tex., by The Times and other media outlets has incited a discussion among readers about racial and religious bias in the news. Our journalists are available to address your questions and concerns about how we cover attacks and the people who commit them.\n\nPlease submit your questions and comments for Marc Lacey, our National editor; Cynthia Collins, our Social and Community editor; Anne Barnard, our Beirut bureau chief; and Hanna Ingber, our Reader Center editorial director.\n\nWe will publish a selection of the questions and answers in a coming Reader Center post.", "title": "Do We Cover White Christian Attackers Differently? Discuss How We Reported on the Austin Bombings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Germs can cause disease and infections; they can make us sick and even kill us. Even so, do we worry too much about them in our everyday lives?\n\nWith our ubiquitous hand sanitizers and antibacterial soaps, have we become obsessive when it comes to microbes?\n\nIn \u201cYour Cute Rubber Duck May Be a Haven for Bacteria,\u201d Ceylan Yeginsu writes about possible bacterial dangers lurking in the bathtub:\n\nThere\u2019s an ugly truth about the rubber duck, the popular bathroom toy that children put in their mouths and use to squeeze bath water into their siblings\u2019 faces. Something yucky is likely to be inside, scientists say: \u201cpotentially pathogenic bacteria\u201d that can cause eye, ear and stomach infections. A study by American and Swiss researchers found that toy ducks appeared to be a breeding ground for microbes. The murky water released from four out of every five ducks tested included Legionella along with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria, often associated with infections acquired in hospitals, the authors of the study said. The study, conducted by the Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology, ETH Zurich and the University of Illinois, was published on Tuesday in the journal N.P.J. Biofilms and Microbiomes. The researchers tested a range of bath toys, 19 different ones, and found 75 million cells of bacteria per square centimeter in the ducks \u2014 a strikingly high level that scientists say was a result of their polymer material releasing carbon, which acts as a nutrient for bacteria. \u201cIn addition to the nutrient supply, dirty bath water also serves as a further source of microbial seeding for the bath toys,\u201d the researchers noted. They suggested that using a higher-quality polymer to make the rubber ducks might prevent bacterial and fungal growth. The study, which received funding from the Swiss government, is part of broader research into bacteria on household objects.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 How much do you worry about germs? Are you careful about what you touch or put in your mouth? Are you mindful of washing your hands frequently, especially before you eat? Do you use hand sanitizer regularly? Do you feel that these behaviors help to keep you healthy?\n\n\u2014 A 2012 study determined that the average cellphone carried 10 times more bacteria than most toilet seats. And a recent study reported that a dirty kitchen sponge has about 82 billion bacteria living in just a cubic inch of space. Do you think studies like these, or the one discussed above, help us make more informed decisions about how to stay healthy? Or do they just confuse the general public or sow unnecessary fear?", "title": "Do We Worry Too Much About Germs?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Did you take part in the national school walkouts to protest gun violence on March 14?\n\nIf so, why did you decide to join, and what was the experience like? If not, why did you decide to opt out?\n\nHave you ever taken part in any other kind of political activism? Do you think that in general it is good for teenagers to participate this way? Why or why not?\n\nIn \u201cNational School Walkout: Thousands Protest Against Gun Violence Across the U.S.,\u201d Alan Blinder and Julie Turkewitz write:\n\nThousands of students, emboldened by a growing protest movement over gun violence, stood up in their classrooms on Wednesday and walked out of their schools in a nationwide demonstration, one month after a gunman killed 17 people at a high school in Florida. The 17-minute protests unfolding at hundreds of schools are intended to pressure Congress to approve gun control legislation after the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., and come 10 days before major protests in Washington and elsewhere. \u2026 The demonstrations unfolded in different ways from city to city and school to school. In some places, demonstrators chanted and held signs. At other schools, students stood in silence. In Atlanta, some students took a knee. Thousands of students around New York, many backed by permission slips from their parents, walked out of their schools and converged on central locations \u2014 Columbus Circle, Battery Park, Brooklyn Borough Hall, Lincoln Center. \u2026 In Washington, thousands left their classrooms in the city and its suburbs and marched to the Capitol steps, their high-pitched voices battling against the stiff wind: \u201cHey-hey, ho-ho, the N.R.A. has got to go!\u201d One sign said: \u201cFix This, Before I Text My Mom from Under A Desk.\u201d\n\nAnother article published on the same day, this one from the Well section, explains \u201cWhy Demonstrating Is Good for Kids.\u201d In it, Lisa Damour writes:\n\nParticipating in political activism may be good for our teenagers, according to a new research report. The study, published in January in the journal Child Development, found that late adolescents and young adults who voted, volunteered or engaged in activism ultimately went further in school and had higher incomes than those who did not mobilize for political or social change. By tracking nearly 10,000 young people from a wide variety of ethnic, racial and economic backgrounds, researchers from Wake Forest School of Medicine, Fordham University and the University of Massachusetts measured the long-term implications of youth political and social engagement. Remarkably, they found that civic activity linked to better academic and financial outcomes regardless of early school performance and parental education levels, two factors that usually drive later success. Of course, correlation does not prove causation, but the study makes a case for the benefits of civic engagement. In light of the findings, Parissa Ballard, the study\u2019s lead author and an assistant professor in the department of family and community medicine at Wake Forest School of Medicine, said that \u201chaving meaningful opportunities to volunteer or be involved in activism may change how young people think about themselves or their possibilities for the future.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read both articles, then tell us \u2026\n\n\u2014 What is your reaction to the national school walkouts to protest gun violence? What comes to mind as you read about and see photos and videos from students protesting around the country?\n\n\u2014 What is your opinion of the message that students were trying to send with these walkouts? Do you think this protest will be effective in addressing the issue of gun violence in the United States?", "title": "Do You Think It Is Important for Teenagers to Participate in Political Activism?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn search of reasonable rent, the middle-class backbone of San Francisco \u2014 maitre d\u2019s, teachers, bookstore managers, lounge musicians, copywriters and merchandise planners \u2014 are engaging in an unusual experiment in communal living: They are moving into dorms,\u201d The New York Times reports.\n\nBefore you read the article, what is your initial reaction? Do you think you might like living this way when you\u2019re adult \u2014 whether to save money, to meet other people, or for any other reason?\n\nIn \u201cDorm Living for Professionals Comes to San Francisco,\u201d Nellie Bowles writes:\n\nImageStarcity is renovating two large buildings in San Francisco\u2019s Tenderloin neighborhood to turn into dorm rooms for the middle class. CreditJason Henry for The New York Times Shared bathrooms at the end of the hall and having no individual kitchen or living room is becoming less weird for some of the city\u2019s workers thanks to Starcity, a new development company that is expressly creating dorms for many of the non-tech population. Starcity has already opened three properties with 36 units. It has nine more in development and a wait list of 8,000 people. The company is buying a dozen more buildings (including one-star hotels, parking garages, office buildings and old retail stores), has raised $18.9 million in venture capital and hired a team of 26 people. Starcity said it was on track to have hundreds of units open around the San Francisco Bay Area this year, and thousands by 2019. These are not micro-units, nor are they like WeWork\u2019s WeLive housing developments, where residents have their own small kitchens, living rooms and bathrooms but share common event space and industrial appliances for parties. These are not single-family homes that are being used as group houses. Instead, Starcity residents get a bedroom of 130 square feet to 220 square feet. Many of the buildings will feature some units with a private bath for a higher rent. But Jon Dishotsky, Starcity\u2019s co-founder and chief executive, said a ratio of one bathroom for every two to three bedrooms makes the most sense for large-scale affordability. The average one-bedroom apartment in San Francisco rents for $3,300 a month, but Starcity rooms go for $1,400 to $2,400 a month fully furnished, with utilities and Wi-Fi included. \u201cIf you think about the most private things that you do, a lot of them are related to the bathroom,\u201d said Mr. Dishotsky, 34. \u201cSo that\u2019s probably the hardest part.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What do you think of the Starcity living arrangements, and why? Look carefully through the article\u2019s images, making sure to read each caption. Would you feel comfortable living in the spaces pictured? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 If you had the opportunity to live in communal housing, what aspects of the arrangement do you think would suit you best, and why? What might be a challenge or disagreeable to you, and why?", "title": "Do You Think You Might Like Communal Living When You\u2019re an Adult?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "But it was Monsignor Vigano, who as communications director was the keeper of the pope\u2019s image, who created the headache this time.\n\nIn an apparent effort to buttress Francis against criticism from conservatives for breaking with his predecessor\u2019s doctrinal orthodoxy, Monsignor Vigano held a news conference last week to publicize a new series of books about the pope\u2019s theology. At the news conference, Monsignor Vigano said he had asked Francis\u2019 predecessor, Benedict, to \u201cwrite a page or a page and a half of dense theology in his clear and punctual style\u201d and that the 90-year-old retired pope responded instead with a \u201cbeautiful, personal letter.\u201d\n\nIn the letter, Benedict condemned the \u201cfoolish prejudice\u201d of critics who depicted Francis as a pragmatic pastor without theology and Benedict as an academic with his head in the clouds. Benedict added that the books helped clarify \u201cthe interior continuity between the two pontificates, with all the differences in style and temperament.\u201d\n\nMonsignor Vigano and the Vatican disseminated a photo of the letter and spun it as Benedict\u2019s seal of good papal housekeeping for Francis. The suggestion was that Benedict had read and approved of the books. But there were some key omissions.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt turned out that the Vatican had purposely blurred the final two lines on the letter\u2019s first page in which Benedict acknowledged that he had not actually read the books and that he was physically unable and too busy to contribute his own theological assessment of Pope Francis. Distorted though it was, at least the first page saw the light of day. In the photo, the letter\u2019s second page sits buried under the books about Francis. Only Benedict\u2019s signature was visible.\n\nMonsignor Vigano, in a sort of Keystone Clergy moment, himself drew attention to the omissions in the photo when he read the missing text at Monday\u2019s news conference. Mr. Magister, who was at the news conference, transcribed and published the remarks.\n\nThe Associated Press first drew attention to what appeared to be blurred lines in the photo of the letter. Its discovery prompted an outcry, especially among Catholic conservatives who complained that their hero, Pope Benedict, was being exploited to paper over Francis\u2019 doctrinal deficiencies. The Twitter hashtag #releasetheletter went viral. The Catholic Herald, a Catholic publication, ran the headline \u201cBlurred Lines: Vatican Manipulation of Photo Becomes the Story.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnder pressure to address what it called \u201cpresumed manipulation,\u201d the Vatican on Saturday released Benedict\u2019s full letter, of which almost the entire second page consisted of Benedict expressing his \u201csurprise\u201d that the 11-volume \u201cTheology of Pope Francis\u201d included a German author who, Benedict said, had targeted his teachings with \u201cvirulent\u201d and \u201canti-papist\u201d attacks. He said he was too busy to read the books and offer his assessment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m certain you can understand why I\u2019m declining,\u201d Benedict signed off.\n\nThe Vatican claimed it originally released only the portion of the letter it considered \u201copportune and relevant.\u201d\n\nBut it did not look good. Especially because Pope Francis, who frequently laments journalists who fail to report the full story, released a major document in January condemning \u201cfake news.\u201d In the document, he said deception in the media went back to the snake in the Garden of Eden.\n\nThat was not a good ancestry for the Vatican\u2019s communications director.\n\n\u201cIn recent days many controversies have arisen regarding my work, which beyond my intentions, has destabilized the complex and great work of reform that you entrusted to me,\u201d Monsignor Vigano, 55, wrote in his resignation letter.\n\nPerhaps in an effort to compensate for the previous redaction, the Vatican on Wednesday released what appeared to be the full text of the letters between Monsignor Vigano and the pope, who had hired him as communications director in 2015.\n\nOn Wednesday, Francis wrote back to Monsignor Vigano and said, \u201cI respect your decision and I welcome, not without some struggle, your resignation.\u201d\n\nThe Vatican press office added that until Francis names a replacement, the communications office will be run by its second-in-command, Msgr. Lucio Ruiz. The pope asked Monsignor Vigano to stay on to advise the future director, it said.\n\nA scandal in a communications department that had been a source of the pope\u2019s strength, Mr. Magister said, was not a good sign for Francis\u2019 reform agenda. \u201cThis is only the umpteenth proof of the failure,\u201d he said.", "title": "Doctored Photo Prompts a Keeper of the Pope\u2019s Image to Step Down", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The radiant photograph shows Duke Ellington at the piano, his hands dancing across the keyboard. Behind him, a drummer lifts his arms joyously in the air. It is the type of club photo we have seen many times, often taken in famous venues like the Savoy Ballroom, Caf\u00e9 Society or the Cotton Club.\n\nExcept this one was taken in Seattle, a city known more for grunge than great jazz.\n\nThe image appears in \u201cSeattle on the Spot: The Photographs of Al Smith,\u201d an exhibition at the Museum of History and Industry in Seattle, a city that played only a modest role in American jazz history. Mr. Smith\u2019s photos tell a compelling story, not just about the city\u2019s jazz scene but also about the complexity of life in an African-American community cloistered within a largely white, and for many decades, de facto segregated city. Organized by Howard Giske, the museum\u2019s curator of photography and a friend of Mr. Smith\u2019s, the exhibition is accompanied by a catalog with essays by Mr. Giske and the historians Jacqueline E. A. Lawson and Quin\u2019Nita Cobbins; the jazz critic Paul de Barros; and the photographer\u2019s son, Al Smith Jr., known as Butch.", "title": "Documenting the Dynamic Black Community of 1940s Seattle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Back then, according to the Distilled Spirits Council, a trade group, blends accounted for 98 percent of the Scotch market in the United States, about 13.1 million cases against just 240,000 cases of single malts. By 2017, that proportion had dropped to 77 percent of the Scotch market, which had dwindled in total to about 9.3 million cases.\n\nDuring that time, sales of blends dropped to about 7.2 million cases in 2017 while sales of single malts rose to about 2.1 million, an increase of almost ninefold. Nonetheless, a lot of blended Scotch is sold in the United States, nearly twice as much as Irish whiskey, which over the last few years has been the fastest-growing spirit in the country.\n\nLargely out of curiosity, the spirits panel recently tasted through 20 bottles of blended Scotch in an effort to see what they offered. For the tasting, Florence Fabricant and I were joined by two drinks writers, David Wondrich and Robert Simonson.\n\nFirst, some definitions. All Scotch whisky must be made in Scotland. Single malts come from a single distillery and are distilled entirely from malted barley. Malting simply means soaking the barley until it germinates, which releases enzymes that convert starches to fermentable sugars. The germination is stopped by heating the barley, sometimes over peat fires, which impart a smoky aroma.\n\nBlended Scotch combines malt whisky, either a single malt or many, with grain whisky. The whiskies must be aged at least three years in oak barrels, and if a bottle carries an age statement, like \u201c8 Years Old,\u201d it means that the youngest whisky in the blend is that old.\n\nWhile the malt components are the crucial elements, the grain whisky is not just neutral spirit, like vodka. It, too, takes on character as it ages.\n\nOne other important Scotch category exists, blended malt whisky, a combination of two or more single malts. These whiskies, which used to be called vatted malts, can be wonderful and complex. But they differ from blended Scotch as they do not contain any grain whisky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s tempting to think of blended Scotch as diluted malt whisky. There may be some truth to that, but it\u2019s not the whole story. In his excellent guide, \u201cThe World Atlas of Whisky,\u201d Dave Broom asserts that in good blended Scotches, grain whisky coaxes out the complexities of a malt by emphasizing secondary characteristics that might otherwise be hidden.\n\n\u201cMalts are about intensity of character,\u201d he writes. \u201cSingle-malt bottlings are about maximizing this singularity. Blends are about creating a totality.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Broom\u2019s book devotes just three pages to blended Scotch and more than 150 to single malts. \u201cThey don\u2019t get a lot of celebration,\u201d Robert said.\n\nDavid noted that efforts are made periodically to talk up blended Scotch, but they never really take hold, particularly among younger consumers. \u201cBlended Scotch doesn\u2019t have the craft imprimatur,\u201d he said, \u201ceven though some are really good, like Pinch, if you can even find it.\u201d\n\nSadly, we did not have Pinch among our 20 bottles.\n\nWe all found a lot to like among these blended Scotches. I was drawn to their mildness and restraint. It was easy to see how they would satisfy people who prefer whisky that is not as aggressive as many single malts.\n\nNonetheless, we preferred the whiskies that had assertive malt characters, with creamy textures and lingering flavors.\n\nThe differences among many of them were small and incremental. David said he was expecting more variation among them, and recalled that years ago blended Scotches were maltier and peatier. Robert felt that, as producers are able to blend any whiskies they want, they might have missed an opportunity to stand out from the crowd.\n\n\u201cBut they are making these whiskies for an audience,\u201d he said, \u201cso they are obliged to satisfy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur No. 1 bottle was Buchanan\u2019s Master, which seemed to epitomize the category: smoky but not too smoky, rich and creamy but not too much so, more complete package than singular distinctiveness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNo. 2 was Teacher\u2019s Highland Cream, which had a pleasant smokiness and an attractive oily texture. At $24 for a liter, it was also our best value.\n\nTeacher\u2019s was on the cusp of what the trade refers to as value and premium brands, the lower end of the price spectrum and the categories of Scotch that are declining the fastest. Any growth in blended Scotch, the Distilled Spirits Council said, is coming among high-end premium and especially super premium, the most expensive categories. Super premium includes brands like Johnnie Walker Blue Label, which, at $150 or so a bottle, exceeded our $100 cap.\n\nThe ever-popular Johnnie Walker Black Label, however, a high-end premium brand at $55 a liter, was our No. 3 bottle. It was creamy, complex and among the smoothest of the whiskies, which may be because it was one of only three bottles in our tasting to carry an age statement, 12 years. The other 12-year-old in our top 10 was Chivas Regal at No. 6, rounded and mild with subtle aromas of malt and flowers.\n\nNo. 4 was the spicy, easygoing Compass Box Asyla, which had a natural sort of sweetness that differed markedly from the sweetness that comes from the legal use of caramel as a coloring agent. We found several bottles that tasted overly of caramel. They did not make the cut.\n\nOther notable bottles included the fresh, chewy Ballantine\u2019s Finest, the smooth and spicy White Horse, the creamy J & B Rare, the gently peaty Dewar\u2019s White Label and the concentrated John Begg Blue Cap.\n\nI\u2019m not sure any of us were convinced enough by the tasting to trade in distinctive single malts for mild blends. \u201cIt\u2019s not an exciting group,\u201d David said. \u201cThey\u2019re for drinkers who do not want to be challenged.\u201d\n\nYet they have a clear place as a component for mixed drinks, whether Scotch and sodas or the few classic Scotch cocktails like Rob Roys and Rusty Nails.\n\nAside from those, I\u2019ll always have my fragrant memories.\n\nTasting Blended Scotches\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605\u00bd Buchanan\u2019s Master Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $48, 750 milliliters\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSmoky, rich and creamy, with discernible malt flavors that linger. (Diageo, Norwalk, Conn.)\n\nBest Value: \u2605\u2605\u2605 Teacher\u2019s Highland Cream Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $24, 1 liter\n\nAssertive flavors of peat and malt, creamy, almost oily texture. (Teacher & Sons, Deerfield, Ill.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 Johnnie Walker Black Label Blended Scotch Whisky 12 Years Old 40 percent $55, 1 liter\n\nCreamy and smooth, with complex aromas and flavors of flowers, smoke and chocolate. (Diageo)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 Compass Box Asyla Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $52, 750 milliliters\n\nLight, pleasant and easy, with flavors of spice, grain and smoke and a natural sweetness. (Compass Box, Manhasset, N.Y.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd Ballantine\u2019s Finest Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $35, 1 liter\n\nLight, fresh and pleasing, with a chewy texture and fruity flavors. (Pernot Ricard, Purchase, N.Y.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd Chivas Regal Blended Scotch Whisky 12 Years Old 40 percent $42, 750 milliliters\n\nRounded, creamy and mild, with light malt and floral aromas. (Chivas Brothers Imports, Purchase, N.Y.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd White Horse Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $23, 750 milliliters\n\nRich and smooth, with lingering flavors of smoke and spice. (Diageo)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd J & B Rare Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $55, 1.75 liters\n\nCreamy and mild, with flavors of malt, honey and anise. (Diageo.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd Dewar\u2019s White Label Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $33, 750 milliliters.\n\nMild and pleasing, with aromas and flavors of peat, iodine and earth. (John Dewar & Sons, Coral Gables, Fla.)\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd John Begg Blue Cap Blended Scotch Whisky 40 percent $37, 1.75 liters\n\nFragrant and concentrated, with straightforward flavors of malt and grain that linger. (Diageo)\n\nRecipe: Scotch-Orange Bread Pudding\n\nWith Scotch on the rocks to sip, not to ponder, I\u2019d happily ravage a bowl of salted peanuts. The same goes for a Scotch-based cocktail like a Rob Roy, for which these whiskies are particularly suited. Actually almost any tidbit \u2014 notably pigs in blankets \u2014 that the bar sends my way will satisfy. But that bottle of workmanlike Scotch can also contribute its alcohol and flavor to the cooking process. I have soaked dried currants in whisky to add to a simple chocolate cake. Here, taking my cue from the Blood and Sand cocktail, made with orange juice and Scotch, I used the spirit to bolster a warm bread pudding laced with orange, both grated zest and candied peel, and finished with a marmalade and whiskey glaze. Supermarkets and fancy food shops, as well as online sources, sell candied orange peel. But absent that ingredient you can substitute slivered dried Turkish apricots. FLORENCE FABRICANT\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Does Blended Scotch Still Have a Place in the Modern Bar?", "authors": ["Eric Asimov"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "As an undergraduate at Duke University, I was something of a campus unicorn. I was anything but quiet about my sexuality and my gender identity. I\u2019d hold my head high sporting bright red lipstick and a full beard; dance on the bar, unshaven legs exposed by a miniskirt; strut unashamed across cobblestones in four-inch heels. I wasn\u2019t just gay \u2014 I was a total queen. And for half of the gay men on campus, I was something of a goddess, an inspiration, a friend.\n\nBut for the other half, I was embarrassing. I was that flamboyant gay kid who made everyone else look bad by association. Many gay men on campus were so unsettled by me, so vicariously ashamed of my gender expression, that they\u2019d avoid eye contact, wouldn\u2019t even talk to me. The irony is that these very gay men were allowed to be \u201cnormal\u201d because I was the campus freak. My unabashed femininity was what paved the way for gay men in, say, fraternities to come out without jeopardizing their masculinity. I was the shameful femme foil to their butch pride. At the same time as they disavowed me, they profited from my existence.\n\nI had flashbacks to my campus years this weekend when I went to see the movie \u201cLove, Simon.\u201d From what I\u2019d heard, it was a revelation: a film that effortlessly normalized the queer experience in a touching, quirky and beautiful way, a film so important that celebrities were buying out theaters in their hometowns so that gay teenagers could see it free.\n\nI walked out at the end in a shambles, a veritable genderqueer mess.\n\nFor over a decade, the unspoken rule of gay cinema and television has been that gay men can be sexy protagonists \u2014 as long as they are masculine gay men. Feminine or gender-nonconforming gay men, on the other hand, are desexualized comedic relief. Masculine gay men are central characters, understood as attractive, powerful, interesting and dynamic. Feminine gay men, gender-nonconforming folks and trans people are, at best, guest stars, denied real plots, romantic story lines or central positions in the story.", "title": "Opinion | Does Gay Hollywood Have Room for Queer Kids?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "THE ACT OF producing art can be anything but romantic. To escape the blank page, the only thing on earth as passive as yourself, you cast about for distractions, half-convinced that avoiding your project will shower some sort of mystical growth hormone on your ideas. Yet for some artists, such as William Carlos Williams, life and art were more than each other\u2019s palate cleansers. The poet doctor saw his dual vocations as mysteriously fused. \u201cThey are two parts of a whole,\u201d he contended in his 1967 autobiography. \u201cIt is not two jobs at all \u2026 one rests the man when the other fatigues him.\u201d As a physician, Williams developed an antenna for the \u201cinarticulate poems\u201d emanating from his patients, even as he resolved to \u201cuse the material I knew\u201d from practicing medicine in his writing.\n\nWhat, then, is the real relationship between art and trade? Agonistic? Complementary? The question, suggesting something like a creative sanctum shimmering a few meters above the room in which you punch a clock or schedule a meeting, supposes that aesthetic experience is categorically different from everyday experience, and that muse-fueled invention floats apart from earthier forms of productivity.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut those borders have a tricky way of dispersing. Frank O\u2019Hara\u2019s 1964 \u201cLunch Poems,\u201d a set of imagistic, peripatetic musings on a city in motion, are beloved in part because they manage to articulate the balance of work and life. Written on his breaks, their title an invitation to us to read them on ours, the seemingly dashed-off lines celebrate the pleasure a mind can take in wandering through its own busyness: Creative practice can be meditative flow, but it can also be worthy of a Ricky Gervais punch line. The author Sujatha Gidla, whose recent memoir, \u201cAnts Among Elephants,\u201d examined India\u2019s caste system, has been a conductor for the New York City subway since 2009. \u201cI\u2019m very disorganized,\u201d she told me immediately, before I could frame my first question. \u201cYou must factor that in to how difficult it is to manage work and writing.\u201d But for all the stress of brainstorming ideas during her commute and transcribing interviews in the M.T.A. break room, Gidla would never quit her day job. \u201cIt\u2019s masculine; I fancy it,\u201d she said. What\u2019s more, Gidla fervently believes that the individual \u201cshould be participating in social production, something useful for society.\u201d She has met people from all over the world (\u201ceven Liberia\u201d) at the M.T.A., drinking in their \u201ccosmopolitanism and openness.\u201d She enjoys their company. \u201cWriting is kind of lonely,\u201d she said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make me feel like, this is my environment. At work I have no choice but to talk to people.\u201d\n\nSome cultivate their art because it sustains their work, or because it fulfills a sense of civic responsibility. Writing children\u2019s literature \u201chas helped me grow in confidence as a person, which in turn has helped me develop \u2026 as an officer, too,\u201d said Gavin Puckett, a U.K.-based policeman (it remains his primary income source) and author of the prizewinning 2013 \u201cFables From the Stables\u201d series. Puckett, who joined the service in 1998, sketched the rhyming adventure \u201cMurray the Horse\u201d after passing a horse in a field while listening to a radio announcer report on \u201csports and activities you can only complete backwards\u201d \u2014 he imagined a story about a horse that runs in reverse. He admits that telling stories still makes him feel as though he\u2019s \u201cstepping out of character.\u201d \u201cMy role as a police officer came first,\u201d he told me.\n\nOthers are pulled, almost involuntarily, the other way. Edi Rama, the Prime Minister of Albania, sometimes feels his hand doodling as he contemplates a political decision. The art pours out to center and steady him. In 1998, Rama left a promising career as an artist in Paris to become Albania\u2019s minister of culture. Now the country\u2019s leader, he shows his loose, improvisatory drawings and sculptures in galleries around the world. \u201cI found myself drawing almost all my working time whilst interacting with people in my office or on the phone,\u201d he said in a 2016 interview. \u201cI began to understand that my subconscious was being helped \u2026 by my hand to stay calm while my conscious had to focus on demanding topics.\u201d\n\nArt, so often the wild or ephemeral factor in this equation, stabilizes the politician. Do politics abet the artist? Unlike Williams, Rama does not borrow directly from his waking life for subject matter; he aims to explore automated and preconscious processes. But perhaps the day\u2019s noise makes the quiet of drawing more numinous and clarifying. A year ago, Rama papered the walls of the Kryeministria, Albania\u2019s main government building, with his own compositions. He wanted to remind himself of spaces in which \u201cpolitics, with its characters and struggles, has evaporated\u201d \u2014 to appreciate a freedom he might otherwise forget he had.\n\nPhoto\n\nBACK TO THE artist in her turret. Though ethereal, she possesses monomaniacal focus. She can barely cook for herself, let alone pursue other hobbies. Her cultural ascent coincides with the waning of another figure: the renaissance person, who is allowed to excel at multiple things. At the risk of overliteralizing, one of the West\u2019s foundational creatives, Leonardo da Vinci, held down at least a dozen occupations, from cartographer to engineer to painter to architect. But today, we ridicule Tom Hanks for composing short stories, Steve Martin for trying his hand at a novella, James Franco for making a run at poetry. Why do we rain down suspicion on those who seem ruled by competing creative impulses? In this moment when our pieties about identity are unraveling to admit more nuance, what\u2019s wrong with letting people do two things at once?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome artists may try to simultaneously grow both of their undertakings \u2014 and yet the balance shifts from year to year. Tanwi Nandini Islam launched Hi Wildflower, a line of perfumes, candles and beauty products in 2014, 12 months before her debut novel, \u201cBright Lines,\u201d arrived in bookstores. She needed a space for her \u201colfactory experiments,\u201d she told me, referring to the fragrant projects she\u2019d started as a species of \u201cmethod writing\u201d while crafting a story about an apothecary. At first, Islam imagined the two endeavors \u2014 the company and the writing \u2014 as \u201csisters,\u201d more similar than different. She inscribed lines of poetry on the candles\u2019 packaging and enmeshed herself in every aspect of design and production. Hi Wildflower also became a form of introspection, \u201ca space to rethink my values,\u201d Islam said. The business was separate from the work of book-composing, but not conceptually distant from it: Islam envisioned her aromatherapy and skin-care artifacts moving through the public sphere in the same tender way her sentences did.\n\nYet as Hi Wildflower developed into the author\u2019s main source of income, morphing from an alternate expression of the energies that drove her fiction into \u201ca way of keeping afloat in a society that doesn\u2019t pay artists to do their work,\u201d its meaning mutated. The company now has three employees, 70 products and distribution ties to boutique retailers. Business is where Islam works; writing is where she dreams and roams. She no longer notates individual candle wrappers with poems, and she\u2019s delegated some of the more menial production tasks. When I spoke to her, Islam was at work on a collection of poems and a second novel. Meanwhile, Hi Wildflower, an erstwhile extension of her aesthetic self, has clumped off into its own entity, an enterprise that props her up materially and gives her space to write.\n\nFinancial security (for now, at least) is not the only thing the business has bequeathed Islam. \u201cWhen I create, I want this sense of quietness and wisdom to seep in,\u201d she told me, echoing Rama. \u201cBut leading a company has made me tough on myself as an artist. You experience so much discomfort [in writing]: pitching articles, revising, building your brand. Having a business primes you for that kind of grind, that hustle.\u201d\n\nIn \u201cA Room of One\u2019s Own\u201d (1929), her famous, passionate argument about the material conditions necessary for writing, Virginia Woolf compared fiction to a \u201cspider\u2019s web, attached ever so lightly perhaps, but still attached to life at all four corners.\u201d It is a lovely vision of art hanging from the beams of reality, only people are not spiders \u2014 they don\u2019t generate just one thing. The trope of the secluded creator has echoes of imprisonment and stasis. (After all, who wants to spend all their time in one room, even if it belongs to them?) Sometimes the artist needs to turn off, to get out in the fray, to stop worrying over when her imagination\u2019s pot will boil \u2014 because, of course, it won\u2019t if she\u2019s watching. And regardless of whether the reboot results in brilliance down the line, that lunchtime stroll isn\u2019t going to take itself, those stray thoughts won\u2019t think themselves, the characters on the corner certainly won\u2019t gawk at themselves. Artists: They\u2019re just like us, unless they can afford not to be, in which case they still are, but doing a better job of concealing it.", "title": "Does Having a Day Job Mean Making Better Art?", "authors": ["Katy Waldman", "The Artist S Life"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "But the infernal remarks, especially as the pope prepared for Easter Sunday celebrations, proved too tempting for international tabloids, conservative websites antagonistic to the pope and many others to let go.\n\n\u201cPope Declares No Hell,\u201d read a screaming headline across the Drudge Report website.\n\n\u201cDoes the Pope Believe in Hell?\u201d asked Patrick J. Buchanan in an online column.\n\n\u201cVatican literally falls apart after Pope Francis says \u2018Hell doesn\u2019t exist,\u2019\u201d read a headline in Metro UK, a British newspaper.\n\nThe pope, in fact, has often talked about hell as a very real final destination for the wicked, and the Vatican made clear that the \u201cliteral words pronounced by the pope are not quoted\u201d and that \u201cno quotation of the article should be considered as a faithful transcription of the words of the Holy Father.\u201d\n\nMr. Scalfari agreed.\n\n\u201cThey are perfectly right,\u201d said Mr. Scalfari in an interview on Friday night, as the pope prepared for a ceremonial leading of the stations of the cross on Good Friday. \u201cThese are not interviews, these are meetings, I don\u2019t take notes. It\u2019s a chat.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Scalfari said he remembered the pope saying hell did not exist, he allowed that \u201cI can also make mistakes.\u201d He said he had committed an error of omission by failing to fully explain the pope\u2019s answer on the need for a stronger Europe. \u201cAt my age,\u201d Mr. Scalfari said, he was more used to being interviewed than interviewing.\n\nThe editor of La Repubblica, Mario Calabresi, said the paper had not labeled Mr. Scalfari\u2019s piece as an interview. It was, Mr. Calabresi said, the fruit of a \u201ccultural exchange and dialogue out of the 19th century between a Jesuit believer and a man of the enlightenment fascinated by religion.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSophisticated readers of Italian journalism understand how to read Mr. Scalfari, which is to say, with a grain of salt when it comes to papal quotations.\n\nTo many here, Mr. Scalfari personifies an impressionistic style of Italian journalism, prevalent in its coverage of the Vatican, politics and much else, in which the gist is more important than the verbatim, and the spirit greater than the letter.\n\nAnd yet, despite the public relations headaches Mr. Scalfari has caused, Francis, 81, seems to like talking to him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe pope, Mr. Scalfari said, has a \u201cneed to talk with a nonbeliever who stimulates him.\u201d This month\u2019s meeting was their fifth.\n\nIn September 2013, Francis sent a letter to Mr. Scalfari, later published in La Repubblica, in which the pontiff wrote that atheists should \u201cabide by their own conscience\u201d and said that Christians should engage in \u201ca sincere and rigorous dialogue\u201d with nonbelievers.\n\nWeeks later, the pope had a long discussion with Mr. Scalfari, the reconstructed transcript of which the journalist published in La Repubblica.\n\n\u201cEach one has his idea of good and evil and must choose to follow the good and fight the evil as he understands them,\u201d the pope said, according to Mr. Scalfari. He added that efforts to convert people to Christianity amounted to \u201csolemn nonsense.\u201d\n\nAt first, the Vatican\u2019s spokesman at the time, the Rev. Federico Lombardi, confirmed the interview as \u201cfaithful to the thought.\u201d He subsequently published the article in its entirety on L\u2019Osservatore Romano, the Vatican\u2019s official outlet, and in a space on the website of the Holy See usually reserved for papal speeches.\n\nThen the Vatican, which recently digitally blurred out embarrassing lines of a letter sent by Pope Benedict XVI, removed the text from its website. \u201cThere were some misunderstandings and disagreements about its value,\u201d Father Lombardi said back then.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two men spoke again in July 2014, and Mr. Scalfari published an article in which he said the pope had estimated that 8,000 members of the clergy, including bishops and cardinals, were pedophiles and that perhaps priestly celibacy should be reconsidered.\n\nThe Vatican responded by asking whether a lack of quotation marks suggested \u201can attempt to manipulate some na\u00efve readers.\u201d\n\nIn 2015, Mr. Scalfari quoted Francis as having said that \u201call the divorced and remarried who ask will be admitted\u201d to Communion. Father Lombardi responded that observers \u201cknow the way Scalfari writes.\u201d\n\nBut throughout, the Vatican has seemed reluctant to bring down the hammer on an erudite man toward whom the pope apparently had grown affectionate.\n\nFrancis stayed in touch with Mr. Scalfari, calling him on the phone and inviting him in for another long chat in November 2016. Mr. Scalfari described their warm greetings and reported that the pope said, \u201cIt is the communists who think like Christians.\u201d\n\nThis week\u2019s controversy is not the first time Mr. Scalfari and the pope have visited the subject of hell. In October 2017, Mr. Scalfari wrote, \u201cPope Francis has abolished the places where souls were supposed to go after death: hell, purgatory, heaven.\u201d\n\nBut the pope, who is surrounded by a court full of politically attuned cardinals, yes men and conservatives trying to undercut his mission, keeps coming back to Mr. Scalfari.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve become friends,\u201d Mr. Scalfari said, recalling that the pope helped him into his car during the last visit, and that this time he walked him to the door. \u201cHe blessed me, but knowing that I\u2019m not faithful, he blew me a kiss. And I responded in the same mode.\u201d", "title": "Does Hell Exist? And Did the Pope Give an Answer?", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "But Pelosi\u2019s unpopularity also feels different. She has remained the Republicans\u2019 favorite bogeywoman \u2014 appearing in ad after ad \u2014 long after the Democrats were last in the majority and she was speaker. Harry Reid, the former Democratic Senate leader, never became the target that Pelosi did, nor has Chuck Schumer, Reid\u2019s successor.\n\nIn an Atlantic piece, Peter Beinart lays out some strong evidence that sexism is a major reason. Beinart walks through the data on Republican ads that feature Pelosi as well as the social-science research on the prejudices that voters hold against female politicians. \u201cFor women politicians to succeed, they must defeat and outmaneuver men,\u201d Beinart writes. \u201cYet the better at it they are, the more detested they become.\u201d\n\nWhatever the cause of her unpopularity, Democrats still have a dilemma: Is she the best House leader for the party?\n\nMy own view is that Pelosi should remain in her job at least through this year\u2019s campaign. She probably doesn\u2019t actually influence many voters, Jonathan Bernstein of Bloomberg points out. And her effectiveness in holding together her caucus should not be taken for granted, as Chait notes.\n\nIf the Democrats fail to win back the House this year, Pelosi will probably step aside, and she should. If they win, she\u2019ll deserve to be the speaker again. Pelosi will also turn 78 next week, and she would do her party a favor by starting to think about a succession plan. If she were to step aside by the end of 2020, she would have had an 18-year run as her party\u2019s House leader \u2014 one of the most successful tenures in modern politics.\n\nElsewhere, Elena Schneider and Heather Caygle of Politico explain why more Democratic candidates are disavowing Pelosi, and Bernstein, in that Bloomberg piece, argues Pelosi should stay but her 78-year-old deputy, Steny Hoyer, should go.\n\nProgramming note. I\u2019ll be away next week, but the newsletter will continue. My colleague Ian Prasad Philbrick will give you a couple of reading suggestions based on the day\u2019s news. I will also have an item in each day\u2019s newsletter, writing about a topic that I find important but haven\u2019t found room to mention in the newsletter so far, given the pace of news.", "title": "Opinion | Does Nancy Pelosi Deserve to Keep her Job?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "If I had to say where my drinking began \u2014 which first time began it \u2014 I might say it started with my first blackout, or maybe the first time I sought blackout: the first time I wanted nothing more than to be absent from my own life. Maybe it started the first time I threw up from drinking; the first time I dreamed about drinking; the first time I lied about drinking; the first time I dreamed about lying about drinking, when the craving had become so deep that there wasn\u2019t much of me that wasn\u2019t committed to either serving or fighting it.\n\nI started drinking every day when I was in graduate school in Iowa City, where getting drunk daily didn\u2019t seem dramatic and pronounced so much as encompassing and inevitable. There were so many ways and places to get drunk: the fiction-writers\u2019 bar in a smoky double-wide trailer, with a stuffed fox head and a bunch of broken clocks; the poets\u2019 bar down the street, with its anemic cheeseburgers and glowing Schlitz ad, a scrolling electric landscape with a gurgling stream and neon grassy banks, a flickering waterfall. I mashed the lime in my vodka tonic and glimpsed \u2014 in the sweet spot between two drinks and three, then three and four, then four and five \u2014 my life as something illuminated from the inside. There were parties at a place called the Farm House, out in the cornfields, where poets wrestled in a kiddie pool full of Jell-O, and everyone\u2019s profile looked beautiful in the crackling light of a mattress bonfire. Winter took us below zero. There were endless potlucks where older writers brought braised meats and younger writers brought plastic tubs of hummus, and everyone brought whiskey, and everyone brought wine. Winter kept going; we kept drinking. Then it was spring. We kept drinking then too.\n\nThe first time I told the story of my drinking, I sat among other drinkers who no longer drank. Ours was a familiar scene: circled folding chairs, foam cups of coffee gone lukewarm, phone numbers exchanged. Before the meeting, I imagined what might happen after it was done: People would compliment my story or the way I\u2019d told it, and I\u2019d demur, Well, I\u2019m a writer, shrugging, trying not to make too big a deal out of it. I practiced with notecards beforehand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was after I\u2019d gone through the part about my abortion, and how much I\u2019d been drinking pregnant; after the part about the night I don\u2019t call date rape, and the etiquette of reconstructing blackouts \u2014 it was somewhere in the muddled territory of sobriety, getting to the repetitions of apology or the physical mechanics of prayer, that an old man in a wheelchair, sitting in the front row, started shouting: \u201cThis is boring!\u201d\n\nWe all knew him, this old man. He was instrumental in setting up a gay recovery community in our town, back in the \u201970s, and now he was in the care of his much-younger, soft-spoken partner, who changed the man\u2019s diapers and wheeled him faithfully to meetings where he shouted obscenities. He was ill, losing the parts of his mind that filtered and restrained his speech; \u201cKiss me, wench!\u201d he once said, as he held my hand for our closing prayer. But he often sounded like our collective id, saying all the things that were never said aloud in meetings: I don\u2019t care. This is tedious. I\u2019ve heard this before. He was nasty and sour, and he had also saved a lot of people\u2019s lives. Now he was bored.\n\nOther people at the meeting shifted uncomfortably in their seats. The woman sitting beside me touched my arm, a way of saying, Don\u2019t stop. So I didn\u2019t.
