Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Dow and S.&P. 500 Have Their Best Day in Nearly Three Years: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 More than a hundred people left a rebel-held enclave in Syria on Tuesday after rebel forces reached a medical evacuation agreement with the Syrian government\u2019s ally, Russia. The deal, brokered by the United Nations, came weeks after government forces began a ferocious assault to retake the insurgent stronghold.\n\nOne hundred and seventy people \u2014 31 of them sick or wounded, along with their families \u2014 were evacuated from eastern Ghouta to Damascus, Syria\u2019s capital, through a checkpoint near Douma.\n\nThey were but a small fraction of the estimated 1,000 people in need of emergency medical treatment but unable to get it within the besieged enclave, according to the Syrian American Medical Society.\n\n\u201cWe honestly feel reborn now that we have left Ghouta safely,\u201d one resident told Syrian state television. which showed footage of the evacuation, facilitated by the Syrian Arab Red Crescent.", "title": "Dozens Leave Besieged Syrian Enclave Under Evacuation Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The images of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivering his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech before a spellbound crowd on the National Mall in August 1963 are etched into history \u2014 and the American consciousness \u2014 as the defining moment in the struggle for civil rights.\n\nBut that reading distorts the movement\u2019s complex history, reinforcing the perception of Dr. King as an almost divine leader who was solely responsible for healing the nation\u2019s troubled race relations. Historical images frame our understanding of history , and photographs defined Dr. King in the public imagination, for better or worse. His enemies manipulated photos or gave false captions to discredit him, from accusing him of communist ties to purporting that he encouraged violence during peaceful demonstrations.\n\nAfrican-American newspapers and magazines routinely reported on the details of his life and activism through pictures, years before mainstream publications. And those mass media outlets \u2014 though at first circumspect and, in Dr. King\u2019s final years, increasingly critical as he turned his attention to poverty, war and racism outside the South \u2014 nevertheless produced a visual narrative that helped transform a regional movement into a national one.", "title": "Dr. King\u2019s Complex Relationship With the Camera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cV.A. Chief Is Shown the Door, and In Comes Trump\u2019s Doctor\u201d (front page, March 29):\n\nAs a retired police officer and a Vietnam veteran, I have been fortunate not to have had to rely on the V.A. for medical issues because of the medical coverage I received from my job and now through Medicare.\n\nIt should be criminal how our veterans have been treated over the years, by both political parties. Thank you for your service, and don\u2019t let the door hit you on the way out.\n\nDr. David Shulkin, the outgoing V.A. chief, betrayed his position when he spent over $120,000 of taxpayer money on a trip to Europe with his wife. Hardly the actions of a dedicated public servant.\n\nUnfortunately, I think the choice to replace him, Dr. Ronny Jackson, is a poor one for many reasons, but at the top of the list is his lack of experience running, well, anything. That, and the glowing physical report he gave Donald Trump \u2014 a poster boy for hardening of the arteries \u2014 make him suspect in this veteran\u2019s eyes.", "title": "Opinion | Dr. Ronny Jackson: A Poor Choice for the V.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, America\u2019s most celebrated baby doctor since Benjamin Spock and the pediatrician who revolutionized our understanding of how children develop psychologically, died on Tuesday at his home in Barnstable, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 99.\n\nHis daughter Christina Brazelton confirmed the death.\n\nBefore Dr. Brazelton began practicing medicine in the early 1950s, the conventional wisdom about babies and child rearing was unsparingly authoritarian. It was believed that infants could not feel pain. Parents were instructed to set strict schedules, demand obedience and refrain from kissing or cuddling. Babies were to be fed every four hours, by the clock, preferably from a bottle. When children were hospitalized, parents were allowed few if any visiting hours.\n\nDr. Brazelton, echoing Dr. Spock, whose book \u201cThe Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care\u201d became a best seller in 1946, rejected such beliefs and practices as being senseless, if not barbaric.\n\n\u201cHe put the baby at the center of the universe,\u201d Dr. Barry Lester, a pediatrician and director of the Center for the Study of Children at Risk at Brown University, said in an interview for this obituary in 2009. \u201cWe take for granted all the changes he helped bring about. He more than anyone is responsible for the return to natural childbirth, breast feeding and the ability of parents to stay with a hospitalized child.\u201d", "title": "Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, Who Explored Babies\u2019 Mental Growth, Dies at 99", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Drake isn\u2019t content to just break music records anymore.\n\nTwo months after the rapper set new highs on streaming services for his No. 1 single \u201cGod\u2019s Plan,\u201d he upended the gaming community on Wednesday night by showing up on Twitch, the video game streaming platform, to play the survival game Fortnite. Signing on as TheBoyDuddus, Drake formed a team with the professional gamer Tyler Blevins, who goes by Ninja and has the largest audience on Twitch, with 3.4 million followers.\n\nThe stream was soon trending on Twitter, and it hit around 630,000 concurrent views, blowing away the previous record on a single-player stream of 388,000. The pair were also joined by the rapper Travis Scott and the Steelers wide receiver JuJu Smith-Schuster as players in the game, where teams battle to be the last one standing in an apocalyptic landscape.", "title": "Drake Conquers Another Streaming Service: Twitch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Many young people leading safe, comfortable lives in the West take up causes like the environment or gender equality. Fewer devote themselves to the plight of Kurds in Syria\u2019s brutal civil war. Fewer still travel there to join the fighting, and those who do are usually men.\n\nBut Anna Campbell, a young woman from southern England, did all of that. Last week, as the Turkish military and its Syrian rebel allies hammered their way into Afrin, in northwestern Syria, Ms. Campbell died for her commitment \u2014 the eighth Briton and the first British woman to be killed fighting alongside Kurdish forces.\n\nIn Britain, Ms. Campbell, 26, was active in causes like animal rights and environmental protection, but until recently, she had no personal connection to the Kurds. Yet she was deeply moved, family and friends said, by the fight to defend an autonomous, mostly Kurdish region in northern Syria, known as Rojava, whose leaders advocate a secular, democratic and egalitarian politics, with equal rights for women.\n\n\u201cShe was somebody who saw the injustices of the world and the plight of the weak and vulnerable and disempowered, and she also saw the idealism, the amazing utopian vision of Rojava, and she found those two elements irresistible,\u201d her father, Dirk Campbell, said in an interview. \u201cShe wanted to prevent that from being stamped out, which Turkey and Syria are trying to do.\u201d", "title": "Drawn to a Cause, British Woman Dies Fighting Alongside Kurds in Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Australia has reached its 27th consecutive year without a recession by supplying energy and raw materials like iron ore to the manufacturing economies of Asia, and particularly China. Opening the Bight to drilling would help Australia stay on track to eclipse Qatar as the world\u2019s largest exporter of natural gas by 2020.\n\nBut opposition to the drilling plan highlights the limitations of relying so heavily on the exploitation of natural resources and their export. The plan has met surprisingly strong resistance, despite the need for jobs in a region where manufacturing used to employ one in five workers. Six town councils have raised objections to the drilling.\n\nCommunities on Australia\u2019s southern coast are questioning whether the government can justify putting at risk a unique marine wilderness area that supports the country\u2019s most valuable fisheries and a tourism industry worth more than $1 billion.\n\nThe term \u201cbight\u201d is related to the words \u201cbend\u201d and \u201cbow,\u201d and it refers to the crescent shape of a bay, with a curve shallow enough that mariners in a square-rigged ship could sail out in a single tack, regardless of wind direction. Its shared pronunciation with \u201cbite\u201d is a coincidence, although from space, it does look as though a giant bit into the southern coast of Australia. The bay runs for more than 700 miles, lined by the longest stretch of sea cliffs in the world.\n\nCoral Sea NORTHERN TERRITORY QUEENSLAND AUSTRALIA SOUTH australia NEW SOUTH WALES Great Australian Bight Sydney Port Lincoln VICTORIA Tasman Sea 500 miles\n\nPort Lincoln, a small seaside town of around 16,000 where sealing and whaling reaches back to the 1820s, is the main jumping-off point for access to the Bight. Today, the enormous wealth that it continues to bring is evident in the mansions that dot its coast \u2014 homes of the tuna barons who have made millions from selling to Japan, where sushi chefs pay top dollar for Australian tuna.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s potential for an oil spill that would be catastrophic for the industry and other industries along the coast,\u201d said Robbie Staunton, marine operations manager at Stehr Group, one of Australia\u2019s leading seafood companies.\n\nComputer modeling by the British oil company BP, which withdrew in 2016 from its plan to drill in the Bight, projected that an accident similar to the Deepwater Horizon blowout in 2010 could cause environmental damage along a wide stretch of the southern Australian coastline. This raised local concerns, particularly because the Bight\u2019s waters are deeper, rougher and more remote than those of the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe projection also raised another problem: whether Australia was even equipped to deal with an accident at an offshore drilling platform. The equipment needed to contain a blowout by capping the flow of oil is thousands of miles away in Singapore, and would take up to 35 days to put in place.", "title": "Drilling the Great Australian Bight: Hoping for Jobs, but Fearing a Spill", "authors": ["Jacqueline Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWoman\u2019s Death in Arizona Casts a Pall on Driverless Car Testing\u201d (front page, March 20):\n\nDry weather. Wide roads. Little traffic. An emergency backup driver at the wheel. Even under these optimal conditions, an autonomous vehicle ran down and killed Elaine Herzberg as she walked with her bicycle on Sunday night in Tempe, Ariz.\n\nAutonomous vehicles may be alluring, but we\u2019re not ready for them, and clearly they\u2019re not ready for us. As pointed out in \u201cHow Driverless Vehicles See the World\u201d (news article, March 20), the dominant technology \u2014 lidar, or light-detection and ranging devices \u2014 \u201cworks pretty well\u201d at low speeds when the signals of multiple autonomous cars don\u2019t interfere with one another.\n\nBecause of lidar\u2019s limitations, other detection technologies \u2014 cameras, radar, GPS \u2014 are loaded onto driverless cars. Even then, tragedy strikes.\n\nWhile engineers work out the gaping holes in driverless technology, let\u2019s remind ourselves that ordinary humans are doing better than pretty well at navigating some 3.2 trillion miles of America\u2019s roads every year.", "title": "Opinion | Driverless Car Technology", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "And there\u2019s a lot of admirable fill in the grid. I liked CLAUDIUS (clue it as \u201cHamlet\u201d or \u201cI, Claudius,\u201d I don\u2019t care. I love both the Shakespearean play and the Robert Graves book), UP FOR DISCUSSION (which I was surprised was not a debut, but it has been used only once before, in 2005), IT\u2019S HOPELESS, TEN PENNY, AW RATS, DON\u2019T EVEN, SHONDA (also a \u201conce before\u201d), LET ME SEE and OH MY LORD.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nAdding to the fun of the theme and the fill was some very clever cluing.\n\n1A: Does anyone really put on makeup to go to the beach? This was a clever clue: \u201cBeach makeup\u201d might sound like it\u2019s referring to cosmetics, but it\u2019s actually hinting at the makeup of the beach, which is (mostly) SAND.\n\n8A: These aren\u2019t your average \u201cHeads of families.\u201d These are the heads of organized crime families, and they are called CAPOS, which means \u201cbosses\u201d in Italian.\n\n19A: You have to admit this one is cute. \u201cThat\u2019s amoray!\u201d is a take off on the song \u201cThat\u2019s Amore,\u201d but we\u2019re talking EELs here, not love.\n\n22A: This was a tough one for me, and I\u2019ve seen a lot of wordplay. At first I thought we were talking about the first letter of the word \u201cdates\u201d (the clue is \u201cD as in dates?\u201d), and then my mind drifted to letter grades. You definitely don\u2019t want to get a D in dating. But that made little sense, so I moved on to thinking about years in the calendar. The word DOMINI is the D in \u201canno Domini,\u201d or A.D.\n\n29A: I had most of this one filled in and guessed TEAROOMS, but it took me a moment to understand how they could be \u201cCozy places?\u201d, not that I\u2019m disparaging TEAROOMS in the least. I\u2019m sure they\u2019re very cozy. But today we are talking about tea cozies, those covers for teapots that help keep the tea warm.\n\n33-/40-/47A: Lots of nails in today\u2019s puzzle. And all this time I thought they were held together with glue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n50A: Did you have TRA LA LA before SHA LA LA? Me too.\n\n7D: A very common crossword trick, for those of you just branching out into midweek puzzles. \u201cStart of something?\u201d is a familiar phrase, but we\u2019re being misdirected. We\u2019re supposed to be thinking about the start of the word \u201csomething,\u201d which is the letter S, or, when written out, ESS.\n\n8D: O.K., now you\u2019re just torturing me. \u201cThe secant\u2019s reciprocal\u201d is COSINE.\n\n12D: \u201cSome heirs\u201d are indeed SONS. I appreciate the inclusive wording.\n\n58D: I tried INC as \u201cBusiness letters?\u201d before LLC. I saw my mistake when I realized that NET ME SEE was not a thing.\n\n59D: This one made me chuckle. \u201cHe\u2019s a doll\u201d refers to KEN, the mercilessly teased partner (or is it ex-partner now?) of Barbie.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nNatan Last: This puzzle was such a treat to make, even by the standards of the already lovely J.A.S.A. process. We\u2019re joined by new faces, like instructor Andy Kravis up at the lectern, who\u2019s so encyclopedic we barely need to research clues anymore, and new constructors, who are injecting even more humor and breadth into these collaborations. This was one of those puzzles where the students became the teachers \u2014 the J.A.S.A. class came up with the revealer, brainstormed the best theme pairs, drew up the skeleton of the grid, and even bailed us out of a bad fill moment: They dropped in OH MY LORD where we\u2019d had OH MY WORD and were coming up empty or trivial [in the surrounding fill]. We were also able to keep a wide open construction with some nice long entries. Hope you all like it! Andy Kravis: Natan summed up my thoughts pretty well! This was my first puzzle with the J.A.S.A. class, and I\u2019m looking forward to making many more with them.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Driving Test Challenge", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou are the sons of our country,\u201d he said in one video. \u201cWe will protect all the people of Ghouta.\u201d\n\nIn bypassing the news media, Mr. Assad delivered an alternative view of the war, one in which he is assured and in charge, casually cruising past bombed-out buildings, often driving with just two fingers, an elbow propped casually out the window. It is a world in which his opponents are all terrorists and his troops all heroes.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn these areas, every meter has a drop of blood from a Syrian fighter,\u201d he says in one video. \u201cA hero among heroes.\u201d\n\nWhile other Arab leaders have aggrandized themselves with great wealth or military parades, Mr. Assad has cultivated a man-of-the-people image, a Syrian Everyman who loves his country and its people. In his simple Honda sedan, he speaks to an unidentified videographer documenting him from the passenger seat, with no other aides or security measures visible to the camera.\n\nIn 2016, he paid a similar visit to another Damascus suburb, Daraya, after his forces had starved and bombed its rebellious population into submission. In that video, he drove a silver Hyundai.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis time, as he drives by a line of buildings destroyed in combat, he speaks of feeling a mix of pride in the advances of his forces and of sadness for what the war had done to civilians, especially children.\n\n\u201cThe thing that is painful is to see is people who were forced without a choice because of the war, because of the terrorists, to leave their homes and to live for days in open areas,\u201d he said.\n\nHe does not hint at his own role in the war, his forces\u2019 history of inflicting tremendous violence and the costs to civilians his painful sieges have exacted on rebel-held areas. In eastern Ghouta, about 1,500 civilians have been killed since the Syrian government began its campaign to take the area last month, and some 20,000 civilians have fled in recent days. Witnesses have described scenes of families bombarded by government warplanes and artillery as they tried to flee, leaving the wounded lying in the street.\n\nThere were no scenes like that in Mr. Assad\u2019s video. At one stop, he spoke to a crowd of soldiers, telling them that they were playing a crucial role in a global battle against terrorists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEach bullet that you fire, when you hit a terrorist, when you get rid of a terrorist, you are changing the world system,\u201d he said, as the booms of an ongoing battle punctuated his speech. Every tank driver who goes one meter forward, he is changing the map of world politics.\u201d", "title": "Driving With Assad: Syria\u2019s President Tours a Destroyed Suburb", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Every autumn, caribou gather along the shores of Victoria Island in the Canadian Arctic and wait.\n\nOnce the temperature drops and the ice gets thick enough, dozens of them cross together to mainland Canada. There, if they make it, they will spend the winter breeding before heading back to birth and raise their young on the island.\n\nThe Inuit, who share an intimate connection with these caribou, have always said that a few lead and the rest follow along this treacherous Arctic journey. Now, new technology is confirming this centuries-old indigenous wisdom.", "title": "Drones Spy Caribou on a Treacherous, Icy Crossing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 When Drew Houston played computer games like Starcraft in high school, he made some changes so the games ran more smoothly on his friends\u2019 computers.\n\n\u201cHe created this one little application, and it would basically display everybody\u2019s shared files, and then if you clicked on a file, it would go ahead and ask everyone else on the network if they wanted to download it as well,\u201d said Andrew Croswell, a friend of Mr. Houston\u2019s from Acton-Boxborough Regional High School in Acton, Mass.\n\nMr. Houston, now 35, has since taken a version of that same concept and turned it into Dropbox, an online file storage and collaboration company that has grown rapidly since its founding in 2007.\n\nLast month, Dropbox filed to go public, and when it does Mr. Houston will become the newest member of a small club of tech founders who steered a start-up all the way to Wall Street. (The company is expected to set a price range for its offering as soon as this coming week and trade on the stock market by the end of the month.)", "title": "Dropbox Chief to Join Elite Ranks of Idea-to-I.P.O. Founders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDropbox is the latest so-called unicorn to trot into the public markets.\n\nSome 36 million shares in the company, based in San Francisco, were sold Thursday for $21 apiece, higher than the range of $18 to $20 a share that the company\u2019s investment bankers had recently envisioned.\n\nFounded in 2007 by two Massachusetts Institute of Technology computer science students, Drew Houston and Arash Ferdowsi, Dropbox sells software subscriptions that let users collaborate and share files online. Until now, it was financed by private investors \u2014 including venture capital firms Sequoia Capital and Accel Partners \u2014 who valued the start-up at $9.4 billion, according to the research firm CB Insights. That large valuation earned Dropbox the coveted \u201cunicorn\u201d designation, which applies to start-ups valued at more than $1 billion.\n\nThe share sale on Thursday gave Dropbox a market value of about $9.2 billion. The shares are expected start trading Friday on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol DBX.\n\nThe debut comes during a period of market turmoil. On Thursday, stock market indexes plunged more than 2 percent as investors fretted about the prospect of a trade war between the United States and China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDropbox\u2019s initial public offering could pave the way for other unicorns to soon go public, letting their early investors and founders cash in on huge investment gains that currently only exist on paper.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDropbox has never turned an annual profit, but the company has achieved annual sales growth of more than 30 percent in recent years, with its revenue topping $1 billion annually. Its losses have narrowed to $112 million last year from $326 million in 2015, and the company says it is moving toward becoming profitable.\n\nThe demand for Dropbox\u2019s shares suggests investors overcame any concern about daunting competition from the likes of Microsoft, Google and Amazon, all of which provide cloud storage services.", "title": "Dropbox Priced at $21 a Share in I.P.O., Valuing Company at $9.2 Billion", "authors": ["Matt Phillips"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Dropbox, the file-sharing company and Silicon Valley darling, had a strong market debut Friday, a reassuring sign for the technology industry and for the investors who have billions locked up in other highly valued but privately held start-ups.\n\nShares of San Francisco-based Dropbox, which had sold 36 million shares at $21 each on Thursday night, rose 36 percent in the first day of trading. That pushed Dropbox\u2019s market value to $11.2 billion, above where it had been valued in the private markets.\n\nThe initial public offering arrived at a dicey time. Stock markets have been on a roller coaster, with investors anxious about the threat of inflation, possible trade wars and geopolitical risks. The technology industry in particular has been buffeted by the prospect of tougher government regulation.\n\nGiant tech companies helped drive another sharp sell-off Friday. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index tumbled 2 percent, with both Facebook and Amazon falling more than 3 percent. The S.&P. is down more than 3 percent this year.", "title": "Dropbox Shares Leap in I.P.O., and Silicon Valley Smiles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dropbox, the online file storage company, is poised to hold one of the year\u2019s most highly awaited stock market debuts. But whether investors think the technology darling is more valuable as a publicly traded company or as a privately held start-up is debatable.\n\nThe San Francisco company said Monday that it planned to raise as much as $648 million in its initial public offering, pricing its shares between $16 and $18 each. At the midpoint of that range, Dropbox would be valued at roughly $7.5 billion, including restricted stock units and options \u2014 well below the $10 billion it commanded during its last private fund-raising round.\n\nThe lower potential valuation suggests that public market investors don\u2019t share nearly the same enthusiasm for technology companies that venture capitalists once did, raising questions for a horde of other high-priced start-ups that are edging their way toward the public markets.\n\nDropbox attained its $10 billion valuation as a privately held company more than four years ago, in a different age for Silicon Valley, when many start-ups raced to collect as high a valuation as they could. Since then, companies have been more reserved. Many learned that stretching for every last dollar of valuation could make it more difficult to raise additional capital in the future, or to attract and keep employees with stock grants.", "title": "Dropbox, Valued Privately at $10 Billion, Could Droop by 25% in I.P.O.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "At $29, Dropbox is trading at 11.5 times last year\u2019s revenue of $1.1 billion. That is far higher than the 2.6 times sales for the companies in the Nasdaq index, according to Bloomberg data.\n\nOf course, Dropbox\u2019s shares have benefited from demand for initial public offerings by technology companies. The stock might give back the gains, just as Snap\u2019s did after its I.P.O. last year.\n\nStill, Dropbox\u2019s fans believe that the company has a strong financial future, despite competition from the likes of Google and Amazon. One of their main arguments is that the company can increase its revenue faster than its costs, a dynamic that should expand profit margins over time. Rishi N. Jaluria, an analyst at D.A. Davidson, zeros in on its free cash flows, the amount of cash generated by a business after subtracting spending on plants and certain lease payments, to show this.\n\nHis measure of free cash flows was equivalent to 16 percent of revenue last year, but, in his estimation, that margin could rise to 19 percent this year, then 22 percent in 2019.\n\nAfter Friday\u2019s huge pop, Dropbox\u2019s stock has arguably \u201cpriced in\u201d the impressive future cash flows that some analysts expect. Indeed, using Mr. Jaluria\u2019s forecasts, Dropbox\u2019s shares are already trading at a far higher cash flow valuation than that of Salesforce, a software and cloud computing company with a long track record.\n\nWhat is more, Dropbox has areas of concern that should, in theory, give investors pause. The number of paid users grew 25 percent last year, slower than the 35 percent rate in 2016. Its average revenue per paying user edged up just 1 percent last year. Facebook\u2019s shares trade at the same multiple to sales as Dropbox\u2019s. Yet its revenue per user surged 26 percent last year.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nDropbox closed up 36 percent in its market debut.\n\nDropbox finished at $28.48, up 36 percent from its initial public offering price.\n\nThe file-storage company on Thursday sold 36 million shares at $21 apiece. That was above its expected range of $18 to $20 a share and valued the company $9.2 billion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Friday\u2019s close, Dropbox is valued at $12.5 billion\n\nHere are some more numbers to put the I.P.O. market into perspective:\n\n\u2022 So far this year, 38 companies have listed shares on American exchanges, raising $12.8 billion. That\u2019s up 13 percent from a year ago and the most year to date since 2011, according to Thomson Reuters.\n\n\u2022 The shares of companies that have debuted on American exchanges this year are up, on average, 15%.\n\n\u2022 The average gain for tech I.P.O. this year is 43%;\n\n\u2022 Since the start of 2017, shares of tech companies that have gone public are up 72 percent.\n\nThe three best performing I.P.O.s in 2018\n\n\u2022 Armo Biosciences (+126 percent)\n\n\u2022 CueBiopharma (+120 percent)\n\n\u2022 Menlo Therapeutics (+102 percent)\n\nThe three worst performing I.P.O.s in 2018\n\n\u2022 ADT (-38 percent)\n\n\u2022 Corporacion America Airports (-39 percent)\n\n\u2022 Solid Biosciences LLC (-48 percent)\n\nMarkets don\u2019t like Trump\u2019s tariffs\n\nThe closer investors look at President Trump\u2019s tariffs against China, the less they seem to like them.\n\nThis can be seen in the way the stock market has responded to the trade restrictions, which were announced on Thursday but were flagged a few days earlier. The S.&P. 500 index was down 5.95 percent this week, falling every day but one. And the selling at the end of the week looked like like it was turning into a rout, with the S.&P. 500 skidding 2.52 percent on Thursday and 2.1 percent on Friday.\n\nWe know that Mr. Trump watches the stock market\u2019s response to his policies. He was reassured when the stock market rose after he announced tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. Will this week\u2019s nosedive unsettle him to the point he softens his stance on trade with China? Mr. Trump sounded unfazed on Friday. \u201cI think the stock market is going to be great,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump signs spending bill.\n\nThe president abruptly backed down from his threat to veto the $1.3 trillion spending bill and signed it into law on Friday, avoiding a government shutdown.\n\nEarly in the day, the president had tweeted his displeasure with the bill, citing Congress\u2019s failure to fund his long-promised border wall.\n\nFrom this morning:\n\nJulie Hirschfeld and Michael D. Shear of the NYT:\n\nBut the president was most angry about the lack of funding in the bill for a massive wall on the nation\u2019s southern border that he has billed as the centerpiece of his crackdown on illegal immigrants. The measure includes nearly $1.6 billion for border security \u2014 including new technology and repairs to existing barriers \u2014 but not Mr. Trump\u2019s wall, as he claimed on Twitter on Wednesday. It provides $641 million for about 33 miles of fencing, but prohibits building a concrete structure or other prototypes the president has considered, and allocates the rest of the funding for new aircraft, sensors and surveillance technology.\n\n(The backstory to the bill: Here\u2019s how Congressional leaders settled lawmakers\u2019 objections.)\n\nMark Zuckerberg and the congressional hearing ahead\n\nAs Facebook plunged into a crisis over how Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm that provided voter-targeting services to the Trump campaign, improperly obtained data on 50 million Facebook users, Mark Zuckerberg came under criticism for saying nothing. Finally, on Wednesday he released a statement and sat down for interviews. We asked Paul Pendergrass, a long time corporate communication professional and formerly DealBook\u2019s \u201cJack Flack\u201d columnist, to offer his insights into the situation:\n\nIn most of the interviews on Wednesday, Mark Zuckerberg was asked if he would be willing to testify before Congress, a task he has previously delegated to other senior Facebook executives.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d be happy to\u2026\u201d he told CNN\u2019s Laurie Segall, before immediately qualifying that answer with, \u201cif it\u2019s the right thing to do.\u201d\n\nHe then went on to offer Facebook\u2019s standard response to questions about why it has previously chosen other executives for Congressional hearings.\n\nThe goal there is to get Congress all the information that they need to do their extremely important job. And we just want to send the person whoever is best informed to do that.\n\nHe elaborated:\n\nThe question in Congressional testimony is, \u201cWhat is the goal?\u201d That\u2019s not a media opportunity. At least it\u2019s not supposed to be.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg was surely being coy. When Congress requests the presence of a C.E.O. embroiled in a high-profile controversy, they\u2019re usually not looking for information. They want a pelt to hang on the wall, and celebrity chief executives are particularly attractive.\n\nSo it\u2019s definitely a media opportunity\u2026 but for members of Congress, not the C.E.O.\n\nIf Mr. Zuckerberg wants proof of that, he can ask John Stumpf, the former C.E.O. of Wells Fargo, and the bank\u2019s current chief executive, Tim Sloan, how much information they were asked to provide. He could ask the same of the C.E.O. of United Airlines, Oscar Munoz, about his trip to Capitol Hill just after a passenger was dragged off one of his airplanes. For that matter, Mr. Zuckerberg could walk down the hallway and ask Facebook\u2019s general counsel, Colin Stretch. Just last fall Mr. Stretch endured a Senate lashing over the use of Facebook by Russian operatives.\n\nWhen Mr. Zuckerberg is brought in to testify, the committee\u2019s \u201cgoal\u201d will be to ensure the American public understands why social media platforms can\u2019t be trusted to regulate themselves. Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s goal will be to try to avoid acting in a way that would elevate his role as the designated villain in the story.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zuckerberg seems resigned to the fact that he will likely end up testifying. \u201cI would imagine at some time there will be a topic where I will be the sole authority on, and it will make sense for me to do it,\u201d he told Ms. Segall.\n\nAfter this past week, he will have little leeway to refuse. Having been roundly accused of hiding in the crucial early days of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, he won\u2019t want to provide further evidence that he is inaccessible when people need to see him most.\n\nPhoto\n\nElon Musk joins #DeleteFacebook.\n\nElon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg have clashed on artificial intelligence, space travel and the direction of technology.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Musk showed just how little love lost there was between the two tech titans.\n\nMr. Musk, the chief executive of SpaceX and Tesla, deleted the Facebook pages of both of his companies, the NYT\u2019s Nellie Bowles reports.\n\nMr. Musk growing chorus of tech leaders calling for people to abandon Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s social network after it allowed a political consulting firm, Cambridge Analytica, to obtain and misuse data on 50 million users.\n\nPhoto\n\nDid China intervene to support its stock market?\n\nChina\u2019s state-backed funds have a history of stepping in to smooth out swings in the country\u2019s stock market. And so on Friday as China stocks tumbled amid fears of a trade war with the United States, those funds began buying, Bloomberg reports, citing unnamed sources.\n\nThey purchased large-cap stocks, including Sinopec and China Life Insurance Co., Bloomberg reports.\n\nShares of both those companies erased losses late in the trading session, and the large-cap CSI 300 Index finished down 2.9 percent after falling as much as 4.6 percent.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nMaybe not so fast on a Target-Kroger deal?\n\nShares in both retailers are up in premarket trading this morning after Fast Company reported that the two sides are weighing a union. Shares in Kroger were up 4 percent, while those in Target were up over 2 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe purported rationale: the usual one. Retailers are under pressure from Amazon and need to get bigger both in brick-and-mortar stores and online.\n\nBut Fast Company cautioned, \u201cThe companies appear to be struggling to decide whether a merger is the best path forward.\u201d And Courtney Reagan of CNBC, citing an unnamed source, threw cold water on the idea:\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Steve Wynn has sold his entire stake in Wynn Resorts, worth $2.1 billion as of Wednesday. And Hong Kong\u2019s Galaxy Entertainment Group, which aims to reshape the Asian gambling market, bought in.\n\n\u2022 In its opening statement at the Time Warner deal trial, the Justice Department warned that AT&T would use its newly bought content as a \u201cweapon\u201d to raise prices. Tim Wu of Columbia Law School agrees. Naturally, AT&T does not.\n\n\u2022 The entertainment mogul Byron Allen bought The Weather Channel\u2019s broadcast assets for $300 million from Comcast and Blackstone. (Variety)\n\n\u2022 Blade, the helicopter taxi service, has raised $38 million from the likes of Airbus and Colony NorthStar. (Axios)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 The publisher of New York magazine bought Splitsider from The Awl Network. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Deutsche Bank priced the spinoff of its DWS asset-management unit at the low end of the expected range. (WSJ)\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nToo little, too late.\n\nBroadcom\u2019s shareholders approved the chip maker\u2019s decision to move its headquarters to the United States from Singapore. The move is expected to be completed after the market\u2019s close on April 4.\n\nThe vote comes nearly two weeks after President Trump blocked Broadcom\u2019s $117 billion bid for Qualcomm, citing national security concerns.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe decision was a blow to Broadcom and its chief executive, Hock Tan, who had gone to great lengths to deflect concerns by American regulators and the Trump administration. That included appearing in a televised speech at the White House with Mr. Trump last November, during which Mr. Tan promised to redomicile Broadcom in the United States.\n\nWill the U.S.-China trade fight be a flicker or an inferno?\n\nThey\u2019re here. President Trump imposed $60 billion worth of tariffs and penalties on Chinese goods. China is threatening tariffs on $3 billion worth of U.S. goods like nuts, wine and pork. Now S.&P. 500 futures and markets in Asia and Europe are down this morning, following yesterday\u2019s steep sell-off (which was driven in large part by Boeing).\n\nThe context: Mr. Trump has made subtext \u2014 China is the U.S.\u2019s main economic rival and must be treated as a strategic competitor \u2014 text. Few in the U.S. are happy with Beijing\u2019s trade and intellectual property policies. But the world is now watching to see whether the fight turns out to be a spat, or a prolonged and damaging conflict.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: A trade fight that eventually relaxes some of China\u2019s disadvantageous conditions could bolster the long-term prospects of U.S. firms. And if the U.S. is able to recruit other countries to its cause, China may relent. Still, much could go wrong.\n\nOn the other tariffs: The E.U. is still waiting for confirmation of exemptions from the imported metals tariffs. They may get quotas instead. Meet Century Aluminum, the tiny manufacturer that pressed for those penalties.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Stephen Gandel of Gadfly writes, \u201cTrump\u2019s tariffs and especially his protectionist rhetoric threaten to cut more and more of the world off.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Paul Krugman writes, \u201cAmerica has much less trade leverage over China than Trump imagines, and a trade war with \u2018China\u2019 will anger a wider group of countries, some of them close allies.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The WSJ editorial board writes, \u201cA rising and aggressive China poses considerable risks to world order, but persuading its leaders to conform to trading norms requires more than scattershot tariffs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Christopher Beddor of Breakingviews writes, \u201cThe sweeping duties and investment restrictions the U.S. president ordered on Thursday in response to intellectual-property theft may prove largely symbolic.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nExclusive: Bank of America to pay $42 million to N.Y. over trades\n\nThe state\u2019s attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, is expected to announce today that Bank of America Merrill Lynch is settling an investigation over its electronic trading practices.\n\nMr. Schneiderman is expected to announce that the bank routed some clients\u2019 trade orders to so-called electronic liquidity providers like Citadel Securities, then doctored trade confirmations and post-trade reports to say it had executed them in-house. The attorney general said the process was applied to some 16 million client orders between 2008 and 2013.\n\nMore from Mr. Schneiderman:\n\n\u201cAs Wall Street firms offer increasingly complex electronic trading services, they cannot use new technology to exploit their clients in service of their business relationships with large industry players.\u201d\n\nHe has previously gone after Barclays, Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank over their electronic trading practices.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 President Trump has replaced his perpetually on-the-bubble national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, with the hard-line John Bolton. And John Dowd quit the president\u2019s legal team for the special counsel inquiry.\n\n\u2022 A donor to N.Y.C. mayor Bill de Blasio testified that he steered tens of thousands of dollars to the mayor\u2019s campaigns in exchange for favorable treatment. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Saudi Arabia\u2019s Mohammed bin Salman reportedly boasted that he had Jared Kushner \u201cin his pocket.\u201d Separately, the State Department approved a $670 million sale of anti-tank missiles to the kingdom.\n\n\u2022 In a CNN interview, the former Playboy model Karen McDougal laid bare what she said had been a 10-month affair with Mr. Trump in 2006. (CNN)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The former Trump International Hotel in Panama City has some new cocktails: the Stormy Jack Daniels and Little Rocket Man. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Dropbox\u2019s First-Day Pop Should Give Investors Pause: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "OMAHA \u2014 About seven minutes into the N.C.A.A. tournament game between second-seeded Duke and 11th-seeded Syracuse on Friday, the Blue Devils\u2019 all-world freshman big man, Marvin Bagley III, got the ball inside. He was quickly swallowed by Syracuse\u2019s zone, but somehow managed to kick it out to Duke\u2019s lone senior, Grayson Allen. Allen nailed a 3-pointer and pointed at Bagley in acknowledgment.\n\nAside from brief moments like that one, Duke never really solved Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim\u2019s celebrated 2-3 zone. And maybe it should have, given that Duke now runs the same defense.\n\nStill, in a game that was sloppy and came down to the final seconds, Duke held on for a 69-65 win in the round of 16.\n\nEven though upsets have spiced up much of this year\u2019s bracket, the Midwest regional final on Sunday will feature Duke against the quadrant\u2019s top seed, Kansas, which outlasted Clemson, 80-76, on Friday night.", "title": "Duke Survives a Battle With the Syracuse Zone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Even Duke managers with no basketball aspirations see the program as a springboard, as opposed to most college basketball managers, for whom the job is a way to get the best ticket in the arena. \u201cWith Coach K, I felt like I had the opportunity to learn about excellence and how to build excellence from the ground up,\u201d Spiera said.\n\nAsk the managers about their jobs, and they will articulate the ideology of Duke exceptionalism.\n\n\u201cI think the culture we have is really special,\u201d Zach Marcus, another senior manager, said. \u201cIt\u2019s a testament to Coach K, the program he\u2019s established.\u201d\n\nEverything they do is deliberate, specific, thought through. They wear matching uniforms, typically polo shirts, slacks, belts and Nike sneakers. During the opening segment of practices, eight of them line the court \u2014 three to a side, one under each basket \u2014 with a ball under an arm. During one drill, rebounding is a three-manager job: one under the basket, another in the corner, a third at the top of the arc next to a coach. At halftime, they sprint to the locker rooms to get them ready before players and staff arrive. After games, their duties done, they meet and critique their performance.\n\n\u201cI used to come back in there, and I see it now,\u201d said Nolan Smith, a former Duke player who is now a special assistant on the staff. \u201cThey meet as a team and talk about areas of improvement.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn-game timeouts are their shining moment. These are like Nascar pit stops. During Thursday\u2019s 89-67 first-round win over Iona, Spiera raced from his seat at the far end of the bench to the first one, pulled it out \u2014 creating a passage between the bench\u2019s front and back sides \u2014 and placed it facing the bench, so Krzyzewski could sit and face the five players in the game. Then he assumed his clipboard position. It all took about five seconds. After timeouts, the managers rushed to towel off the coaches\u2019 seats, which had just been occupied by sweaty players.\n\nIf Duke is Rome and the players are the gladiators, or perhaps the generals, then the managers are the Praetorian Guard, the emperor\u2019s personal division. There is no need to clarify who the emperor is in this analogy.\n\nKevin Pauga, Michigan State\u2019s director of basketball operations, was a Spartans manager. He now administers a postseason basketball tournament for team managers. (Duke\u2019s managers did not play the five regular-season games requisite for qualifying, he said.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cEvery school handles their managers just a little bit differently,\u201d Pauga said. \u201cEveryone has their nuances, whether it\u2019s tied to a head coach or a specific program.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany of the Duke managers\u2019 tasks are typical: rebounding during practices; providing towels and Gatorade during games; cleaning up afterward. They will rebound for any player who wants it, at all hours. They text players to remind them about practices; they fetch them if they are in danger of being late.\n\nThen there are odder assignments. When the freshman Trevon Duval forgot his sneakers at a hotel before a road game, a manager was dispatched to fetch them. When the former center Marshall Plumlee\u2019s leg cramped up during a home game last season and a muscle roller stick was not to be found, Krzyzewski had Michael Karamardian, now a senior manager, massage Plumlee\u2019s upper leg with his own hands. Coincidentally or not, Karamardian hopes to attend medical school.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019d be easier to tell you what they don\u2019t do,\u201d the sophomore Marques Bolden said.\n\nManagers begin as freshmen by signing up at the annual activities fair on Duke\u2019s East Campus. There has not been a female manager for several years, and a few months ago, Duke\u2019s student newspaper reported that one applicant had complained, citing another female applicant\u2019s belief that women were held to a higher standard. David Bradley, Duke\u2019s director of basketball operations, disputed this, saying, \u201cWe\u2019d love to have anyone.\u201d\n\nApplications include r\u00e9sum\u00e9s and cover letters. The first interview requires semiformal attire. The second involves basketball shorts and physical activities: managers, after all, are frequently rebounding and throwing hard chest passes to some of the country\u2019s best players. Duke prefers applicants who were involved in basketball, as a player or a manager, in high school. The program brings on three or four managers per class.\n\nThey typically spend four years on the job. (There is little attrition.) They travel with the team beginning their junior year. The seniors are in charge, and they share one full scholarship after three years of working without pay (though they may get paid for working summer camps).\n\nThey know they are mocked on the internet: for making an impromptu privacy tent out of towels as Marvin Bagley III recovered from a poked eye earlier this season; for just constantly running (\u201cWere they slow on filling the Gatorade cooler?\u201d a Kentucky fan wondered).\n\nTheir response, in standard Duke fashion, is to point to the scoreboard.\n\n\u201cAt a certain point, you realize you get to be part of the best program, you go to a really good school, some people are going to try to attack you for those things,\u201d Karamardian said. \u201cIf you just understand they\u2019re only attacking you because you\u2019re really good at these things, then who really cares?\u201d", "title": "Duke\u2019s Basketball Managers Strive to Be (What Else?) Elite", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "As hundreds of millions of people prepare to celebrate Easter and Passover, here are three books that reckon with religion and spirituality.\n\nPhoto\n\nWHY I AM A CATHOLIC\n\nBy Garry Wills\n\n390 pp. Houghton Mifflin Company. (2002)\n\nHalf history of the papacy and half investigation of the writer\u2019s faith, Wills\u2019s book is a response to readers who, after he wrote \u201cPapal Sin: Structures of Deceit,\u201d a critique of the Catholic church and its hierarchy, asked why he remained a Catholic. Wills has \u201cnever even considered leaving the Church,\u201d he writes, yet he does not present himself as a Catholic missionary. What he delivers instead is a balanced critique and a defense of his view that one can be both devoted to and critical of one\u2019s faith. Our reviewer called this book \u201ccandid, richly informative and perfectly timed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMAN SEEKS GOD\n\nMy Flirtations With the Divine\n\nBy Eric Weiner\n\n349 pp. Twelve. (2011)\n\nWeiner, a former foreign correspondent for National Public Radio, is compelled to begin his religious exploration when, while he is enduring a medical scare, a nurse asks him: \u201cHave you found your God yet?\u201d Weiner grew up in a family of \u201cgastronomical Jews,\u201d for whom he writes, \u201c God resided not in Heaven or the Great Void but in the Frigidaire, somewhere between the cream cheese and the salad dressing.\u201d This sentence might give you some indication of the humor with which he narrates his trip, which takes him to places such as Turkey to explore Sufism and the South Bronx, where he spends time with Franciscan monks.\n\nPhoto\n\n\n\nTHE WISDOM OF SUNDAYS\n\nLife-Changing Insights from Super Soul Conversations\n\nBy Oprah Winfrey\n\n240 pp. Flatiron Books. (2017)\n\nEvery week, on her television show \u201cSuper Soul Sunday,\u201d Winfrey explores spirituality with a rotating selection of star guests; Arianna Huffington, Shonda Rhimes and Joe Biden have all been guests. Here, she brings together excerpts from those conversations, as well as personal photographs taken in her home in Santa Barbara \u201cwhere I feel the presence of God, and the connection to All that is greater than myself, most deeply,\u201d she writes in the book\u2019s introduction. She begins most of her \u201cSuper Soul Sunday\u201d conversations with the same question: \u201cWhat does spirituality mean to you?\u201d The replies have helped Winfrey along her spiritual path, and this book explores how this wisdom has stayed with her.", "title": "During Holy Week, Explorations of the Divine", "authors": ["Concepci\u00f3n De Le\u00f3n"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Roof was taken to the Alvin S. Glenn Detention Center in Columbia, and local media reported that her bond was set at $5,000. It was not immediately clear whether she had been released or if she had a lawyer. Ms. Roof\u2019s parents did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nThe arrest of Ms. Roof took place as thousands of students at schools across the country participated in a walkout to protest gun violence, in honor of the 17 students and staff members who were shot to death last month at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.\n\nWhile the Snapchat post was not cited as a reason for Ms. Roof\u2019s arrest, Susan Childs, the principal of A.C. Flora High School, said in a letter to parents on Wednesday that several events on campus had caused concern.\n\nShe said that the walkout at the school \u201cwent well with only a minor verbal disagreement,\u201d but that an unloaded weapon had been recovered and was being investigated by law enforcement. She also said that a report of another weapon had been found to be inaccurate, and that a student had used social media \u201cto post a hateful message.\u201d She did not mention Ms. Roof by name.\n\n\u201cThe posting was not a threat, but was extremely inappropriate,\u201d Ms. Childs wrote. \u201cThat student was dealt with in a swift and severe manner as the posting caused quite a disruption.\u201d", "title": "Dylann Roof\u2019s Sister Arrested After Bringing Weapons to School Walkout", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Draghi, in an obvious reference to President Trump\u2019s plans to impose tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, said during a news conference that it was \u201cdangerous\u201d for countries to change the terms of trade unilaterally, rather than through negotiations.\n\nThe protectionist measures were part of a general diplomatic deterioration, Mr. Draghi added, and could damage the confidence that businesses needed before they would invest in expansion and hiring.\n\n\u201cIf you put tariffs against your allies,\u201d Mr. Draghi said, \u201cone wonders who the enemies are.\u201d\n\nIt was the second news conference in a row in which Mr. Draghi had expressed exasperation with the Trump administration. In January, he accused Steven Mnuchin, the U.S. treasury secretary, of violating international agreements by making comments that caused the dollar to fall against the euro, giving American products a price advantage in foreign markets.\n\nStill, the European Central Bank\u2019s Governing Council was not alarmed enough by the potential trade war to interrupt its gradual exit from the emergency measures it has used to keep the eurozone from falling apart during a decade of financial and economic turmoil.\n\nWhile Thursday\u2019s communiqu\u00e9 merely omitted a single sentence, and Mr. Draghi sought to downplay the importance of the change, investors appeared to find it significant.\n\nMarkets reacted swiftly, with the euro jumping as much as 0.5 percent against the dollar, and the yield on the German 10-year bond, the benchmark for the region, rising five basis points.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a tacit acknowledgment that the economic outlook in Europe is rosier than it was,\u201d James Athey, a senior investment manager at Aberdeen Standard Investments, said in a statement. He added, \u201cThe reaction should not be overdone. This is an infinitesimal step forwards.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome analysts had predicted that the central bank would make no changes in the language it uses to communicate its intentions to financial markets, in light of a confused election result in Italy.\n\nOn Sunday about half of Italians voted for populist candidates on the left and right, and left no party with a clear mandate to form a government. There is now very little chance that the country will make the sweeping changes needed to break its economy out of prolonged stagnation.\n\nIts political deadlock and economic doldrums are a threat to the rest of the common currency area. Italy\u2019s government debt, measured as a percentage of economic output, is among the highest in the world and, in Europe, second only to Greece\u2019s.\n\nBut Italy also has the eurozone\u2019s third-largest economy, with output 10 times that of Greece, making it a far bigger danger to the region\u2019s financial stability if investors begin to doubt the government\u2019s solvency.\n\n\u201cWe have to bury the hope that Italy will catch up with Germany and France with reforms,\u201d Holger Schmieding, chief economist at Berenberg, a German bank, said over lunch with reporters in Frankfurt on Tuesday. \u201cItaly will more likely worsen its ability to carry its debt.\u201d\n\nThe European Central Bank was also unfazed by the ups and downs of global stock markets since the Governing Council last met on monetary policy. Mr. Draghi pointed out that the market turmoil was centered on the United States and \u201cit was pretty short.\u201d\n\nAs expected, the Governing Council opted on Thursday to leave monetary policy unchanged. Interest rates will remain at a record low level.\n\nThere is a faction on the Governing Council that is worried that inflation, now dormant, could get out of hand if the central bank waits too long to stop its purchases of government and corporate bonds, a form of money printing intended to stimulate the economy.\n\nThat faction has been in the minority, but appeared to win the upper hand on Thursday.", "title": "E.C.B. Shifts Guidance, as Europe Moves Toward Normalcy", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The rules, aimed at cutting tailpipe emissions of carbon dioxide, a major contributor to global warming, were one of the two pillars of Mr. Obama\u2019s climate change legacy. Put forth in 2012, they would have required automakers to nearly double the average fuel economy of new cars and trucks to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025.\n\nIf fully implemented, the rules would have cut oil consumption by about 12 billion barrels and reduced carbon dioxide pollution by about six billion tons over the lifetime of all the cars affected by the regulations, according to E.P.A. projections.\n\nThe rules also would have put the United States, historically a laggard in fuel economy regulations, at the forefront worldwide in the manufacture of electric and highly fuel efficient vehicles. The United States and Canada are the only major nations that have adopted mandatory emissions standards through 2025. The European Union has only recently proposed standards for 2025 and 2030, while China has only started to work on standards for those years.\n\nLess restrictive regulations in the United States could provide an opening for automakers to push for more lenient standards elsewhere as well, leading to the emission of more pollution by cars around the world. While sales of electric vehicles are starting to take off, they still represent barely 1 percent of global car sales. A shift among car buyers toward larger cars and trucks is already impeding progress in fuel economy.\n\n\u201cThe concern is that automakers will go around the world basically trying to lobby regulators, saying, look, because the United States has reduced the pace, everywhere else should too,\u201d said Anup Bandivadekar, a researcher at the International Council on Clean Transportation, a think tank that focuses on clean car technology and policy. Global carmakers \u201capply developments in one region to lobby for changes in other regions.\u201d\n\nAmerican automakers initially accepted the plan by Mr. Obama in 2009 to harmonize what was then a hodgepodge of pollution and efficiency standards set by the E.P.A., the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and California. And the automakers weren\u2019t in much of a position to resist; they had just taken an $80 billion bailout to survive a global economic crisis .", "title": "E.P.A. Prepares to Roll Back Rules Requiring Cars to Be Cleaner and More Efficient", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The statement followed long talks in which Mrs. May described the reasoning behind Britain\u2019s conclusions that the Kremlin was behind the attack in the quiet cathedral city of Salisbury, including its identification of the chemical used \u2014 a strain of the nerve agent Novichok \u2014 and its belief that Russia has produced this substance in the last decade.\n\nWelcoming the E.U. response, Mrs. May said it was right that European nations were \u201cstanding together\u201d because the hostile challenge Russia poses \u201crespects no borders, and it is a threat to our values.\u201d\n\nIn response, Dmitri S. Peskov, the spokesman for the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, said that he \u201cdid not know what the heads of the E.U. states agreed with\u201d when they offered their support to Britain, as Russia was not given any information.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t agree with this and repeat that Russia had absolutely nothing to do with the Skripal case,\u201d he said.\n\nSergei Zheleznyak, a lawmaker from the United Russia party, said that the European Union, under pressure from London and Washington, \u201cwas forced to concoct a statement that is vague in content and politicized in essence.\u201d\n\nThe declaration was a somewhat surprising success for Mrs. May, who has often found herself at odds with her European counterparts as she negotiates Britain\u2019s exit from the bloc, a process known as Brexit. The text was tougher than one agreed to earlier this week by European Union foreign ministers after talks attended by Britain\u2019s foreign secretary, Boris Johnson.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe issue of relations with Russia divides European Union nations sharply, and there has been pressure from some to lift economic sanctions against Moscow, so Britain has not pressed for additional steps of that kind. However the Irish Prime Minister, Leo Varadkar, said there was talk of the existing measures being renewed for a 12-month period; currently they have to be rolled over every six months. In any event, the Skripal case has reduced prospects of them being relaxed anytime soon.\n\nBefore the summit meeting, Mr. Putin spoke by phone with three European Union leaders, the Kremlin announced, a reminder that Moscow has allies within the bloc.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral countries, including Cyprus and Greece, have close ties to the Kremlin and have been reluctant to take a tougher line. But in traditional European Union style, they agreed to the latest text after extracting concessions on other issues \u2014 in this case, wording critical of Turkey\u2019s actions in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean, the site of tensions over drilling for gas.\n\nThough the European Union\u2019s show of support for Britain is so far largely symbolic, it suggests that even after Brexit, London could retain close ties to the bloc on foreign policy, security and defense. It also underscored the strength of Anglo-French cooperation on such issues, with France taking the lead in pushing for a tough, Europe-wide, response. Mr. Macron said that in the poisoning case the French had been asked for \u201ctechnical cooperation\u201d by the British, and had reached similar conclusions about Russian culpability.\n\nYet, this time Mrs. May was arguing as the leader of a big member nation from inside a European summit. After next March, Britain\u2019s prime minister will no longer attend such meetings, making the prospect of such a unified European response to a British concern less likely.\n\nOn the broader Brexit agenda, things will undoubtedly get difficult again soon. European Union leaders agreed on Friday to the terms of a 21-month transition deal to prevent a \u201ccliff edge\u201d change in trading rules when Britain officially leaves the bloc next March.\n\nThe leaders also paved the way for far-reaching talks on a future trade partnership, though there is still no agreement on how to avoid border checkpoints on the frontier between Northern Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom, and Ireland, which will remain in the European Union.\n\nOn trade discussions, Mr. Macron took an uncompromising stance over Britain\u2019s intention to quit the European Union\u2019s single market, which lays down common rules and standards for goods and many services.\n\n\u201cIf you are out of the single market you are totally out of it,\u201d he said, adding that, to preserve its integrity, \u201cEurope will stand united.\u201d", "title": "E.U. Joins U.K. in Denouncing Russia Over Poisoning of Spy", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Hans J\u00fcrgen Kerkhoff, president of the German Steel Federation, said on Friday:\n\n\u201cThese measures clearly violate the rules of the World Trade Organization. If the E.U. does not react, our steel industry will pay the bill for U.S. protectionism.\u201d\n\nHe called on the bloc to take action, through the W.T.O.\n\nSimon Clarke, a Conservative member of Britain\u2019s Parliament and vice chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Steel and Metal Related Industries, wrote on Twitter on Friday:\n\n\u201cTariffs are the worst possible option for the world economy and a major threat to U.K. steel in particular.\u201d\n\nRoy Rickhuss, general secretary of Community Union, a British labor union, also denounced the move on Twitter:\n\n\u201cDonald Trump is putting jobs at risk on both sides of the Atlantic. Thousands of steelworkers across the country voted for Brexit on the promise it would deliver a new era of international trade.\u201d\n\nHe called on Prime Minister Theresa May to ensure that steel products exported by Britain were exempt from the proposed tariffs.\n\nThe global reactions hinted at a looming trade war if Mr. Trump followed through on campaign promises of an \u201cAmerica First\u201d trade policy. On Friday, the president doubled down on his promise in a Twitter post:\n\n\u201cWhen a country (USA) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win.\u201d He added later, \u201cIf you don\u2019t have steel, you don\u2019t have a country!\u201d\n\nPressed for reaction to Mr. Trump\u2019s first tweet, which was sent in the course of a regular weekly government news conference, Mr. Seibert declined to comment, except to say, \u201cThe German government has not changed its position in the past 18 minutes.\u201d\n\nThe White House has said that the tariff details remain to be worked out, and Mr. Seibert said the German government was awaiting the exact details before assessing the scope of the impact.\n\nBut Germany made clear that Berlin viewed such measures as damaging to the country\u2019s steel industry. Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel said he viewed the proposal with \u201cgreat concern\u201d and defended his country\u2019s practices in the industry.\n\nThe United States is the most important export country for German rolled steel products and the second-most important destination for the European Union, after Turkey, according to official government statistics.\n\nMr. Gabriel said, \u201cSuch a sweeping blow from the U.S. would reverberate around the world, but our exports and jobs would be among the hardest in the world hit.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDieter Kempf, head of the Federation of German Industries, warned that Mr. Trump was risking a \u201cspiral of protectionism\u201d that in the end would cost American jobs, as well as those in Germany and the rest of Europe.\n\nBut Mr. Kempf urged everyone to \u201ckeep a cool head\u201d in an effort to avoid feeding the flames of a global trade war.\n\nMr. Juncker\u2019s proposal to hit back at the United States through some of the products for which it is best known in Europe was first floated last month in the German news media. The German daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung cited a plan to target the home states of influential members of the Republican Party, including Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin.\n\n\u201cWe are here and they will get to know us,\u201d Mr. Juncker said. Asked if he believed a trade war was brewing, he responded, \u201cI can\u2019t see how this isn\u2019t part of warlike behavior.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBruno Le Maire, the French economy minister, speaking to reporters in Paris, said the tariffs would have a \u201cmajor impact\u201d on the European economy and on a number of French companies.\n\nHe said that the steel and aluminum industries were in a \u201cparticularly fragile\u201d situation and that certain countries practiced \u201cdumping\u201d and \u201cmassive subsidies\u201d that distorted trade.\n\n\u201cAmerican authorities know this perfectly well,\u201d he said. \u201cThat is the topic that needs to be addressed, and not another.\u201d He added, \u201cA trade war between Europe and the United States will only result in losers.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
