Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOfficials around the world have been voicing varying degrees of dismay and anger since the proposal was unveiled on Thursday.\n\nCanada\u2019s foreign minister, Chrystia Freeland, said: \u201cCanada will take responsive measures to defend its trade interests and workers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States has much to lose in a metals trade war with Canada, a crucial strategic ally and major trading partner, Ms. Freeland said. She noted that the United States has a steel trade surplus with its northern neighbor, which is both the largest buyer of American steel and the largest seller of steel to the United States.\n\nOn Friday, the criticism continued, with Australia\u2019s trade minister, Steven Ciobo, saying that Mr. Trump\u2019s action would provoke retaliatory measures that would hurt everyone. \u201cThe imposition of a tariff like this will do nothing other than distort trade and, ultimately, we believe, will lead to a loss of jobs,\u201d he said.\n\nAt a daily briefing on Friday, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, said: \u201cChina urges the United States to exercise restraint in using trade protectionism tools.\u201d\n\nBut Li Xinchuang, vice chairman of the China Iron and Steel Association, was more blunt. In a phone interview on Friday, he said: \u201cI feel Trump\u2019s decision is stupid. It will only make the U.S. steel industry, which is already 10 years behind China, more left behind.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cTrump\u2019s decision does no good to everyone except a few American steel enterprises. Trump is a businessman, and he should understand win-win. But he took such extreme action.\u201d\n\nThe countries hit hardest by the proposed tariffs would be Canada, Mexico, Brazil and South Korea, which together account for almost half of United States steel imports. The United States is also a substantial market for Britain\u2019s steel industry.\n\nIn an emailed statement on Friday, UK Steel, an industry group, said that almost 15 percent of Britain\u2019s steel exports or 360 million pounds ($496 million) a year went to the United States. Richard Warren, the group\u2019s head of policy, said in an email of the proposed tariffs: \u201cThis would be a unilateral and extremely blunt approach to what is a complex global problem of overcapacity in the steel sector.\u201d\n\nArcelor Mittal, the world\u2019s biggest steel maker and the largest steel producer in Europe and the United States, said it was assessing the possible impact of Mr. Trump\u2019s proposal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in a sign of the potentially adverse effects that Mr. Trump\u2019s plan may have on the American economy, Electrolux, a global maker of household appliances, said on Friday that it would delay a planned $250 million investment to expand and modernize a factory in Tennessee.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re concerned about the impact that the tariffs could have on the competitiveness of our U.S. operations,\u201d the company said in a statement, adding it would seek more details of Mr. Trump\u2019s plan before deciding whether to move forward.\n\nIn what was considered a rare comment on a member\u2019s trade stance, Roberto Azev\u00eado, the World Trade Organization\u2019s director general, said in a statement: \u201cThe W.T.O. is clearly concerned at the announcement of U.S. plans for tariffs on steel and aluminum. The potential for escalation is real, as we have seen from the initial responses of others.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cA trade war is in no one\u2019s interests. The W.T.O. will be watching the situation very closely.\u201d", "title": "E.U. Leader Threatens to Retaliate With Tariffs on Bourbon and Bluejeans", "authors": ["Melissa Eddy", "Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "But it reflects concern in Europe over the possible impact of new American tariffs, notably on steel. The United States is the world\u2019s largest importer of steel, and while many of Mr. Trump\u2019s arguments have focused on cheap steel from countries like China, the European Union as a whole is the single biggest exporter of steel to the United States. At the same time, the region is concerned that cheap steel that had been destined for the United States could now flood the Continent, putting significant pressure on European producers.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s push for tariffs is driven by his fixation on trade deficits. But most economists do not worry about trade deficits, and disagree with the president\u2019s characterization of them. Read more here \u00bb\n\nWhile retaliation from Brussels appears limited for now, it could have an impact on American domestic politics. Bourbon, one of the products that European officials have targeted, is made in Kentucky, the home state of Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader. Other items that could face tariffs are motorcycles, and the corporate headquarters of Harley-Davidson are in Wisconsin, Mr. Ryan\u2019s state.\n\n\u201cThe Europeans have rights, too, to retaliate,\u201d said Peter Chase, a former American diplomat who is now a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund in Brussels focusing on trade. \u201cThe E.U. is concerned that behind it all, there are people in the U.S. administration that don\u2019t care that there might be damage to the international system of rule of law that we have created.\u201d\n\nThe list, which was leaked on Monday and has been referred to by the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, is subject to the agreement of the bloc\u2019s 28 member states.\n\nIt highlights how sharply the outlook on trade between the United States and Europe has shifted. Since 2013, Washington and Brussels have been negotiating a vast trade deal, known as the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership.\n\nBy late 2016, however, those talks appeared to have reached a stalemate, and Mr. Trump\u2019s withdrawal from a similar pact with Pacific Rim countries early in his presidency signaled the death of the European agreement, as well.\n\nThe steel and aluminum tariffs have triggered a strong reaction, with business executives and political leaders voicing opposition. Read more here \u00bb\n\nThe strong negative reaction to Mr. Trump\u2019s planned tariffs appears to have had little impact on the president, who insisted this week that he would not back down.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Trump singled out the European Union, which he said had \u201cnot treated us very well, and it\u2019s been a very, very unfair trade situation.\u201d The president warned that the United States would also consider raising its tariffs on cars made within the bloc if the European Union were to retaliate.\n\nWhile he left the door open for compromise with allies, tensions are rising in Europe.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve loaded the guns,\u201d said Charles de Lusignan, a spokesman for the European Steel Association, a lobbying group, \u201cand we\u2019re ready to use them in case the aggression comes.\u201d", "title": "E.U. Pledges to Fight Back on Trump Tariffs as Trade War Looms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Headliner\n\nEMP SUMMER HOUSE The popular summer outpost in East Hampton, N.Y., that Will Guidara and the chef Daniel Humm of Eleven Madison Park ran last year returns, starting May 25 and running Wednesdays to Sundays through mid-September. It will again feature casual indoor and outdoor dining on the lawn and covered patio, with a somewhat more formal menu in the dining room inside. Lobster tempura, tomato salad and rib-eye for two are likely to be served. Large-format dinners for groups of six to eight will again be available. Unlike last season\u2019s pop-up, which was a way to keep staff employed while Eleven Madison Park underwent renovations, this one will hire mainly from the community. The success of the experiment led Mr. Humm and Mr. Guidara\u2019s Make It Nice group to plan a similar winter branch, to open in December, in Aspen, Colo. Both will be run in partnership with American Express, the only credit card accepted at the pop-ups. Starting May 1, reservations for the indoor dining room can be made online through June 30; as of June 1, they can be made through July 31, and starting July 1, they will be taken through September: 341 Pantigo Road, East Hampton, N.Y., empsummerhouse.com.\n\nOpening\n\nSAM WON GARDEN This Koreatown restaurant in Manhattan is the introductory American branch of what is said to have been the first Korean tabletop barbecue restaurant, opened in Seoul in 1976. The New York version will be on three floors and seat 180 people, tiny when compared to the 1,200-seat original. Run by Simon Lee, the owner of the Franco-Korean bakeries Paris Baguette, it will feature beef from a ranch in Arizona that is dry-aged at the restaurant. Other dishes will include beef tartare bibimbap, spicy intestine casserole, bacon-mung bean pancakes, and, special to New York, kimchi poutine. The wine list concentrates on New World selections. (Monday): 37 West 32nd Street, 212-695-3131.\n\nPLANTMADE A new addition to the chef Matthew Kenney\u2019s global collection of vegan restaurants (they say plant-based) has opened in New York. It\u2019s the fourth in the city for him and his partners. The 50-seat all-day cafe serves potato ni\u00e7oise bagels with almond p\u00e2t\u00e9 and olives, truffled \u201ccheese\u201d panini and coconut cream pie, among other items. It pours Haitian Bleu coffee, an heirloom variety that appears in drinks like pine pollen cappuccino. Proceeds from coffee sales go toward restoring land in Haiti that was devastated by recent natural disasters: 152 Second Avenue (Ninth Street), matthewkenneycuisine.com/plantmade.\n\nCLAY POT A clay bowl of Cantonese food that includes rice, egg, spinach, corn and tofu with a choice of two toppings (shrimp, beef, chicken, eel, pork belly, sausage or vegetable) is what\u2019s on offer for $12 at this new vest-pocket spot in the East Village. And if you\u2019ve come to appreciate Spanish socarrat, the crispy rice that clings to the bottom of the paella pan, you\u2019ll want to know fan jiao, the equivalent to be scraped up from the pot: 58 St. Marks Place (Second Avenue), 646-434-6449, claypotnyc.com.", "title": "EMP Summer House Returns to the Hamptons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAs this island would only have been accessible by watercraft 13,000 years ago,\u201d Dr. McLaren said, \u201cit implies that the people who left the footprints were seafarers who used boats to get around, gather and hunt for food and live and explore the islands.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter Every week, we\u2019ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey found their first footprint in 2014. While digging about two feet beneath the surface in a 20-square-inch hole, they saw an impression of something foot-shaped in the light brown clay.\n\nIn 2015 and 2016, they returned and expanded the muddy pit. They discovered several more steps preserved in the sediment. The prints were of different sizes and pointed in different directions. Most were right feet. When the team was finished they had counted 29 in total, possibly belonging to two adults and a child. Each was barefoot.\n\nThe researchers think that after the people left their footprints on the clay, their impressions were filled in by sand, thick gravel and then another layer of clay, which may have preserved them.\n\nMore Reporting on Archaeology\n\nUsing radiocarbon dating on sediment from the base of some footprint impressions, as well as two pieces of preserved wood found in the first footprint, Dr. McLaren and his team found them to be 13,000 years old.\n\nThat would make them the oldest preserved human footprints in North America.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not only the footprints themselves that are spectacular and so rare in archaeological context, but also the age of the site,\u201d said Michael Petraglia, an archaeologist from the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History in Germany who edited the paper for PLOS One but was not involved in the work. \u201cIt suggests an early entrance into the Americas.\u201d\n\nDr. Petraglia said the footprints also provided strong evidence for the coastal movement hypothesis and he added that they may have traveled the so-called \u201cKelp Highway,\u201d a hypothesis that underwater kelp forests supported ecosystems down the North Pacific coast that helped ancient seafaring people hunt, develop and migrate.\n\n\u201cThe work is important because it shows the \u2018real\u2019 people, not just artifacts or skeletal remains,\u201d said Steve Webb, a biological archaeologist at Bond University in Australia. \u201cHowever, the footprints are limited in number and don\u2019t shed light on activities or movement that tell us very much.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added that future hunts for footprints should keep in mind that not everyone from this time period walked around barefoot. If anthropologists are too busy searching for soles, toes and arches, they might miss clues from those who wore animal skin shoes.", "title": "Earliest Known Human Footprints in North America Found on Canadian Island", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Battling currents of 5 miles per hour and a water temperature below 40 degrees, he said, the responders pulled the passengers out of the submerged helicopter and brought them ashore.\n\nDespite the rescue efforts, all five passengers were killed, James Long, a Fire Department spokesman, said early Monday morning. Two were declared dead at the scene and three died in local hospitals. Commissioner Nigro said the pilot was at a hospital and in \u201cO.K.\u201d condition.\n\n\u201cIt was a great tragedy that we had here,\u201d he said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear what caused the helicopter to crash. Witnesses said it caught their attention because it was traveling faster and at a lower altitude than the helicopters that normally fly along the East River between Manhattan and Queens. The National Transportation Safety Board said Monday that 14 of its employees were en route to investigate the crash.\n\nThe helicopter, a Eurocopter AS350 owned by Liberty Helicopters, was flying as a private charter to take photos, Police Commissioner James P. O\u2019Neill said at the news conference. A brochure for Liberty Helicopters, which is based in New Jersey, says it is the only company licensed to fly within 1,000 feet of the Statue of Liberty on all of its tours.\n\nIts pilots have been \u201cflying safely\u201d for 28 years, according to the brochure. The company could not be reached for comment on Sunday night.\n\nPeople who witnessed the crash said they saw emergency responders pull one person out of the water \u2014 a man who was wrapped in a white blanket \u2014 and place him in an ambulance at about 8 p.m. About an hour later, three people were taken out of the water and placed on stretchers. Emergency responders were seen performing CPR on them as they were placed into ambulances.\n\nPhoto\n\nKaderia Melchon was walking in Carl Schurz Park on the Upper East Side of Manhattan when she said she spotted the helicopter descend into the water. Because it was red, she said she first thought it was a Fire Department helicopter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter it crashed, it flipped over almost immediately, its landing skids pointing into the air, she said. A man emerged and shouted for help, she said.\n\nAnother witness, Xinran Jiang, who lives on Roosevelt Island with her husband, said that helicopters zoom over the East River all the time but that this one immediately caught their attention.\n\n\u201cIt almost looked like it was landing,\u201d Ms. Jiang, who watched the crash from her bedroom window, said. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t moving fast. We were curious where it was going to land. Then the next minute, it was diving into the river.\u201d\n\nBy 9:30 p.m., a tugboat had taken the helicopter to the East 34th Street Heliport.\n\nPhoto\n\nHelicopters are a common sight over New York City\u2019s waterways, ferrying tourists on sightseeing trips and carrying commuters. Crashes are rare but not unheard-of.\n\nIn 2011, three tourists died after a helicopter crashed into the East River; two other people survived.\n\nIn 2004, a WNBC helicopter crashed onto a roof in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn while covering a shooting, but all three people on board survived. There were also no casualties when, in 2005, two helicopters \u2014 one of them carrying executives from MBNA Corporation, a major credit card company \u2014 crashed into the East River within less than a week.\n\nIn 2009, when a helicopter carrying five Italian tourists was struck by a single-engine airplane over the Hudson River, everyone on both aircraft died.\n\nIn 1997, an executive at Colgate-Palmolive was killed when a helicopter crashed into the East River moments after takeoff. And from 1985 to 1990, three aircraft owned by the same company, Island Helicopter, went down in the East River.", "title": "East River Helicopter Crash Kills 5 in New York; Pilot Survives", "authors": ["Matthew Haag", "Al Baker"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "In some ways, there was nothing surprising about this breach. I love my parish, but I have always had a vexed relationship with the church. Long before 2016, the fault line was there, rumbling with every papal pronouncement affirming the male-only priesthood or claiming to speak with moral authority on issues of human sexuality. What kind of faith community denies a sacrament to parishioners who don\u2019t happen to have been born heterosexual?\n\nDuring college and graduate school, I tried to talk myself out of believing in God. The reasons not to believe were multifarious and convincing. The reasons to believe came down to only one: I couldn\u2019t not believe. I seem to have been born with a constant ache for the sacred, a deep-rooted need to offer thanks, to ask for help, to sing out in fathomless praise to something. In time I found my way back to God, the most familiar and fundamental something I knew, even if by then my conception of the divine had enlarged beyond any church\u2019s ability to define or contain it.\n\nA church isn\u2019t a necessary thing to a believer for whom the whole world is holy. But when our first baby was on the way, my husband and I signed on. We could have chosen another branch of Christianity, one whose secular framework more closely matched our own understanding of a church\u2019s role in the world. But to a soul imprinted from birth on Roman Catholicism\u2019s stained glass and incense and 2,000 years of art and music, all the other churches just seemed a little slight somehow. Not quite finished.\n\nAnd if all human institutions are by definition imperfect, why not throw in your lot with the one that made you, the one where everyone you love belongs? The worldly church is always a work in progress, and there is still hope for its redemption. \u201cAnyway,\u201d my husband said, \u201cif a priest doesn\u2019t baptize this baby, you know my mother will just take him into the bathroom and baptize him herself.\u201d\n\nIn the past year, while my husband and his father were at church on Sunday mornings, I was in the woods, where God has always seemed more palpably present to me anyway. (And not just to me: \u201cSome keep the Sabbath going to Church,\u201d Emily Dickinson wrote back in the 19th century. \u201cI keep it, staying at Home.\u201d) For me, a church can\u2019t summon half the awe and gratitude inspired by a full-throated forest in all its indifferent splendor.", "title": "Opinion | Easter Is Calling Me Back to the Church", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIT\u2019S EVEN WORSE THAN YOU THINK\n\nWhat the Trump Administration Is Doing to America\n\nBy David Cay Johnston\n\n306 pp. Simon & Schuster. $28.\n\nIt takes a brave writer, in 2018, to attempt a book about Donald Trump\u2019s presidency. During his one year in the White House, Trump has so thoroughly warped the space-time continuum of our news cycle that it seems preposterous that any words about his presidency, slapped between covers, won\u2019t have been overtaken by events by the time they appear in print.\n\nYet there are routes to staying power. One comes from Michael Wolff, whose jaw-dropping (and thinly sourced) tales of White House dysfunction in \u201cFire and Fury\u201d cost Steve Bannon, Trump\u2019s onetime Svengali, both his media platform and his billionaire patron. Another successful approach is provided by David Frum, whose elegantly written jeremiad \u201cTrumpocracy\u201d will give future historians ample evidence that not all Republicans fell in line behind their party\u2019s president.\n\nWith \u201cIt\u2019s Even Worse Than You Think,\u201d David Cay Johnston has chosen a third, more difficult path. A former New York Times reporter who in 2001 won a Pulitzer Prize for his expos\u00e9s on tax loopholes, Johnston practices a brand of journalism that\u2019s an amalgam of advocacy and forensic accounting. \u201cIt is not enough just to cover politics and controversies,\u201d he writes. \u201cOften the most important news goes unannounced, lying right out in the open in the government documents most journalists are loath to uncover and read.\u201d It\u2019s Johnston\u2019s contention that much of the media\u2019s coverage of Trump \u2014 fixated as it is on the president\u2019s tweets and feuds \u2014 misses the real damage he\u2019s doing to the country. \u201cThe Trump administration deposited political termites throughout the structure of our government,\u201d Johnston argues. \u201cThe endgame is not just a smaller government, which Republicans always say they want, but a weak government.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJohnston sets out to shine a bright light on these termites. He finds an obvious one in Scott Pruitt, Trump\u2019s man at the Environmental Protection Agency, whose \u201cone-sided approach to E.P.A.\u2019s mandate,\u201d Johnston writes, favors the concerns of the industries it regulates at the expense of the public\u2019s health. Of course, Pruitt has already received considerable media attention. But Johnston uncovers some less well-known termites as well.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis chapter on the goings-on at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is a textbook example of the sort of green-eyeshade reportage on which he built his formidable reputation. First, Johnston explains how Trump\u2019s decision to force out the chairman left the commission with only two members, short of the three required for a quorum, which meant it was unable to approve \u201c$50 billion worth of energy projects\u201d that would have benefited American workers and consumers. Next, Johnston reports that when Trump finally got around to filling out the agency, he didn\u2019t pick anyone with a consumer-protection background, like the chairman he\u2019d just sacked, instead nominating three new commissioners who all favored the utilities. \u201cCongress created FERC \u2026 to protect families, small-business owners and industry from monopolists and pricing schemes that jack up prices while at the same time ensuring an abundant supply of electricity,\u201d Johnston writes. Under Trump, that mission is being eaten away at.", "title": "Eating Away at Government From the Inside", "authors": ["Jason Zengerle", "David Cay Johnston"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Ecuador\u2019s government said Wednesday that it had suspended internet access for Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who since 2012 has lived in Ecuador\u2019s Embassy in London, out of concern that he was harming its relationships with Britain and other European nations.\n\nThe decision set off a furious reaction from some Assange supporters. One of them, Kim Dotcom, an online renegade who founded a file-sharing site, urged supporters to gather outside the embassy in protest. The filmmaker Oliver Stone wrote on Twitter: \u201cFree Julian Assange! Restore his internet connection!\u201d\n\nEcuador\u2019s government granted Mr. Assange citizenship in January, the latest step in a longstanding diplomatic standoff. But it said it had suspended Mr. Assange\u2019s online communications on Tuesday because he had imperiled \u201cthe good relations that the country maintains with the United Kingdom, with the rest of the states of the European Union, and other nations\u201d through his social-media messages.\n\nThe government did not provide specifics, but some speculated that the decision might have been related to the Western nations\u2019 coordinated actions against Russia after the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain. In a series of Twitter posts this week, Mr. Assange was critical of Western nations\u2019 expulsions of Russian diplomats.", "title": "Ecuador Cuts Off Julian Assange\u2019s Internet Access. Again.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Ed Charles, the heart and soul of the Miracle Mets of 1969, died on Thursday at his home in East Elmhurst, Queens. He was 84.\n\nHis daughter-in-law, Tomika Charles, confirmed the death, saying he had been ill for several years.\n\nCharles was a vital member of the Mets team that suddenly jelled during the 1969 season, winning the World Series in one of the most surprising surges in baseball history and endearing themselves forever to fans who had suffered through the team\u2019s wretched play since its beginning, just seven years earlier.\n\nThe Mets\u2019 players relied on the smile and the wisdom of Charles, who was then 36.\n\n\u201cEd Charles was this guy, you wanted to sit on his knee and hear how he made it,\u201d Ron Swoboda, the right fielder on the 1969 team, said in a telephone interview on Thursday. He added: \u201cHe had a physical and emotional grace that most of us didn\u2019t seem to feel. He would say, \u2018Don\u2019t wrestle with what looks like complexity.\u2019\u201d\n\nEdwin Douglas Charles was born in Daytona Beach, Fla., on April 29, 1933, a time of racial segregation in Florida. But he took heart as a teenager when he spotted Jackie Robinson in town as a Montreal Royal farmhand during spring training in 1946. Robinson was expected to become the 20th century\u2019s first black player in the major leagues.", "title": "Ed Charles, Infield Sage of the Miracle Mets, Is Dead at 84", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe mature and esteemed Edinburgh International Festival, which celebrated its 70th anniversary last summer, will boldly embrace youth during the opening of the 2018 festival, which will run Aug. 3-27.\n\n\u201cFive Telegrams,\u201d the festival\u2019s opening event, an outdoor presentation of digital art and music, is being created by the eclectic young composer Anna Meredith \u2014 a former composer-in-residence with the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra \u2014 and the design and technology company 59 Productions (\u201cWar Horse\u201d).\n\nFergus Linehan, the festival\u2019s director, said in a phone interview Wednesday that \u201cFive Telegrams,\u201d to be presented in Festival Square and including projections on Edinburgh Castle, will also feature a performance element involving 250 young people in the crowd.\n\nMr. Linehan officially announced the program in Edinburgh on Wednesday evening. In a festival as large and complex as his, with years of planning sometimes required for operas or certain performers (like the soprano Christine Goerke, who will sing Br\u00fcnnhilde in Wagner\u2019s \u201cSiegfried\u201d this summer), trying to affix a theme to the event \u201cmakes it a bit too brittle for my liking,\u201d Mr. Linehan said. Still, outside influences do make their way in.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis year, for example, is the centennial of the end of the Great War. \u201cThe end of the first World War is very present in a lot of work in the U.K. at the moment,\u201d Mr. Linehan said. \u201cIt was the beginning of universal suffrage and the end of the Empire.\u201d So some works in the festival, like \u201cXenos,\u201d a new solo piece by the choreographer Akram Khan about a shellshocked colonial soldier \u2014 an Indian man fighting on behalf of the British Empire \u2014 reflect on this. The anniversary is also represented in \u201cFive Telegrams,\u201d which is partly inspired by soldiers\u2019 telegrams from 1918.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lineup of youth orchestras from Canada, Scotland and the United States, and other parts of the music program, nod to Scotland\u2019s Year of Young People, an initiative of the Scottish government. \u201cLight on the Shore,\u201d a celebration of Scottish music that will run throughout most of the festival, will showcase more of Ms. Meredith\u2019s music along with electronica, hip-hop, folk and rock by Django Django, Mogwai, King Creosote and others.", "title": "Edinburgh International Festival Embraces Youth at 71", "authors": ["Steven Mcelroy"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Wednesday\u2019s session was the secretive committee\u2019s first public hearing designed to scrutinize findings from its year-old investigation into Russia\u2019s interference campaign. It followed the committee\u2019s release on Tuesday of a set of recommendations for state and federal officials to shore up the ballot box.\n\nThat effort appeared likely to get substantial resources on Wednesday, as congressional leaders completed a more than $1 trillion government funding bill that included hundreds of millions of dollars for election security. The bill, which is expected to pass later this week, includes $380 million for state grants to improve election infrastructure, as well as $307 million above what the Trump administration had requested for the F.B.I. that can be used to combat cyberattacks, election fraud and other crimes.\n\nTop federal officials have concluded that Russian hackers targeted election systems in 21 states and breached that of at least one, Illinois, during the last election cycle. No votes were changed, but the effort \u2014 alongside a concerted Russian disinformation and hacking campaign \u2014 exposed dangerous vulnerabilities in the voting systems and the government\u2019s ability to respond.\n\nAmerican intelligence officials have warned that Russia considered its campaign to sow social and political divisions in 2016 a success, and is already meddling in the midterm elections. A central tool of the campaign \u2014 fake social media accounts to spread propaganda and disinformation \u2014 continues to be used unabated, the officials said.\n\nMs. Nielsen echoed those concerns on Wednesday, making clear that with voting already underway in primary elections around the country, the threat was not over.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe think the threat remains high. We think vigilance remains important. And we think there is a lot we need to do at all levels of government before the midterms,\u201d Ms. Nielsen said. \u201cOnce these vulnerabilities have been made clear, it\u2019s not just Russia we have to worry about.\u201d\n\nThere are other challenges, Ms. Nielsen said. She noted that two states were not cooperating with the department to ensure that their systems were safe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Nielsen appeared alongside Jeh Johnson, who was President Barack Obama\u2019s homeland security secretary during the 2016 election. Mr. Johnson was asked several times why his department and other Obama administration officials had not done more to warn state election officials and the public about the threats in the run-up to the election.\n\nHe repeatedly defended his decision-making, saying that some states had rebuffed federal outreach and that the department had been able to directly assist more than 30 others. Mr. Johnson also lamented that greater heed was not taken of an October 2016 statement he signed with the director of national intelligence alerting the public to the Russian intrusion into election systems.\n\n\u201cFrankly, it did not get the attention that I thought it should have received,\u201d he said, noting that the statement was issued the same day that the infamous \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape surfaced.\n\nSome senators went further.\n\nSenator Angus King, a Maine independent who caucuses with the Democrats, warned bluntly that the threat was \u201cnot being treated with the urgency that it deserves\u201d and that a patchwork of defenses would mean little without a comprehensive cyberdeterrence strategy. Of the Russians\u2019 targeting of state systems in 2016, he said, \u201cWhat it looks like is a test.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis country has to wake up,\u201d he said, later telling Ms. Nielsen, \u201cI encourage you to go back with your hair on fire.\u201d\n\nThe recommendations released by the committee on Tuesday \u2014 the first such disclosure in its investigation \u2014 covered much of what experts and intelligence officials have been urging election authorities to do for months.\n\nThe panel also pressed the Trump administration to make it clear that any attack on an American election would be viewed as a hostile act.\n\nThose recommendations come from a fuller classified report on election security that the committee has prepared. The fuller document has to be submitted to the intelligence agencies for declassification before it can be released publicly, a process that could take weeks or months. The committee\u2019s chairman, Senator Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, said on Wednesday that it would release an overview of its findings in the interim.\n\nThe committee is expected to prepare similar reports in the coming months on other areas of investigation, including the Russians\u2019 use of social media and whether the Trump campaign aided the meddling campaign.", "title": "Efforts to Secure Elections Moving Too Slowly, Senators Tell Homeland Security Chief", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Egyptian government is so deep in its own lies and propaganda, they have lost track of their own lies,\u201d Mr. Jarrar said.\n\nThere was no immediate reaction from the Egyptian government to Amnesty\u2019s assertion, which was released early Thursday Egyptian time. Officials at the Defense Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment. A State Department official, responding on the condition of anonymity, did not address Amnesty\u2019s assertion about the Feb. 21 video. But the official said in an emailed statement that \u201cthe Department continues to emphasize to our Egyptian government interlocutors the importance of a comprehensive approach to counterterrorism that protects and minimizes damage to civilian populations.\u201d\n\nCluster munitions encompass an array of rockets, bombs, missiles and artillery projectiles that scatter smaller weapons, called submunitions, over a wide area. They can hit civilians far from intended targets. Roughly 20 percent fail to properly detonate upon impact, leaving unexploded bomblets that can kill civilians even years later.\n\nEgypt, like many other Middle East countries, has not signed the treaty banning cluster munitions. While the United States has not signed the treaty either, it pledged in 2008 to restrict their use.\n\nDepartment of Defense documentation obtained by Human Rights Watch and cited in their cluster munition survey shows that Egypt possessed 1,300 Rockeye cluster bombs, containing 321,000 Mk-118 submunitions, as of 2007.\n\nStephen Goose, director of Human Rights Watch\u2019s arms division, said he had not yet been able to discuss with Amnesty its assessment of the video. But he said that any use of cluster bombs \u201cby Egypt or any other fighting force is appalling\u201d and should be condemned.\n\n\u201cThat is why they have been banned internationally,\u201d he said. \u201cEgypt should cease any use of cluster bombs immediately.\u201d", "title": "Egypt Is Using Banned U.S.-Made Cluster Munitions in Sinai, Rights Group Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday, the election authority repeated a threat to impose a $28 fine on voters who failed to cast their ballot. Voting was extended by an hour on Wednesday after a sandstorm lashed Cairo, keeping some people from polls, officials said.\n\nPhoto\n\nCoverage of those tactics in the international news media drew harsh criticism from the government and its supporters, who accused reporters of presenting a distorted picture of the election.\n\n\u201cSo the foreign media chose darkness,\u201d wrote Hany Assal, a columnist with the state-run Ahram newspaper. \u201cIt reported and searched for the negative and worked hard to emphasize it.\u201d\n\nThe State Information Service warned foreign reporters of unspecified consequences for \u201cunprofessional\u201d coverage of the election.\n\nMr. Sisi\u2019s Western allies have been largely silent through the campaign, offering little or no criticism even as journalists were being arrested and the military jailed a former army chief who tried to run against Mr. Sisi.\n\nIn a message posted to the United States Embassy\u2019s Twitter feed on Monday, the first day of the vote, the United States charg\u00e9 d\u2019affaires in Cairo, Thomas H. Two others, Andy Braner and Sasha Toperich, wrote an online article before the vote that concluded \u201cWe should give el-Sisi a chance.\u201d\n\nMr. Sisi has jailed tens of thousands of opponents, mostly from the banned Muslim Brotherhood. But he needs a strong showing to anchor his legitimacy as he presses the fight against Islamic State militants in Sinai and presses tough economic changes that are badly squeezing poor Egyptians.\n\nUnder Egyptian law, Mr. Sisi can serve only one more term and must leave office in 2022. He has denied speculation that he will amend the Constitution to extend or abolish those term limits.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. They did not receive a reply.", "title": "Egypt\u2019s Early Vote Tally: Sisi, 92%, Token Opponent, 3%", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "CAIRO \u2014 Days before Egypt\u2019s presidential election, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi\u2019s beaming visage adorns billboards across Egypt. His rivals are in jail, the news media is in his pocket and his sole challenger \u2014 a politician so obscure many Egyptians would struggle to name him \u2014 hasn\u2019t bothered to campaign.\n\nWith the Irish bookmaker Paddy Power putting Mr. Sisi\u2019s odds of losing at 1 in 500, most Egypt watchers are already looking past the vote that starts Monday to his next challenge: whether he can change the Constitution to extend his rule beyond the current eight-year limit.\n\nThe mystery, then, is why Mr. Sisi is acting like a man with something to lose.\n\nAs the election loomed, the Egyptian leader sometimes acted in ways that looked oddly jittery. He fired his army chief in October and a powerful spy chief in January. In speeches, he struck a choleric, sometimes threatening tone, railing against unspecified enemies. In a fierce media crackdown in the final month of campaigning, the government expelled a British reporter without explanation and even imprisoned a pro-Sisi TV host deemed to have stepped out line.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very confusing,\u201d said Mohamed Anwar el-Sadat, a presidential contender who quit the race in January out of concern for the safety of his campaign workers. \u201cSisi has everything in hand. The fire chief there said the child was in bed when a tree limb struck his home, fatally injuring him.\n\nThe adults who died in the storm were also killed by falling trees. In Massachusetts, it took more than four hours to extricate a man who was killed when a large tree fell on his car on Friday during the height of the storm, Warren Borsari, the fire chief in Plympton, Mass., said in a phone interview.\n\nIn Upper Merion Township, Pa., a 40-foot portion of a tree fell, crushing a car and killing a man inside it, the police chief there said.\n\nThe storm\u2019s effects were felt as far south as Georgia and as far north as Maine. In Rhode Island, the winds were so severe that officials shut down the Newport Bridge. In New York City, most flights were grounded for a time on Friday afternoon. In the Washington suburbs, downed trees were strewn across the streets.\n\nWeather officials said more than three feet of snow blanketed some parts of New York State on Friday. Meteorologists confirmed Friday that the storm had become the second \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d in two months. (The name essentially derives from how quickly the barometric pressure falls.)", "title": "Eight Dead, Including Two Children, in Fierce Nor\u2019easter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The informal web of relations between Israel and Saudi Arabia is usually maintained well below the radar, and the flyover permit granted to Air India is being seen in Israel as an unusually visible sign of improved ties as the old foes\u2019 interests have converged over issues like curbing Iran\u2019s influence in the region.\n\n\u201cThe Israeli skies are connecting with the Saudi Arabian skies in one direct flight,\u201d Mr. Katz, the transportation minister, said in a statement after greeting the maiden Air India flight on the tarmac in Tel Aviv.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not publicly commented on the matter. Mr. Netanyahu has been similarly opaque, avoiding mentioning Saudi Arabia by name in his remarks at the start of the weekly cabinet meeting on Sunday.\n\n\u201cAir India flew directly to Israel, on a straight line from India to Tel Aviv,\u201d he said. \u201cThe significance is clear to all. This is significant economically, technologically, diplomatically and for tourism.\u201d\n\nEl Al contends that Air India now has an advantage that violates the principle of fair competition and policies meant to ensure equal opportunities between Israeli airlines and foreign carriers.\n\n\u201cThe permit that Saudi gave to Air India to fly over its territory to Israel is a global precedent,\u201d Eli Defes, the chairman of El Al\u2019s board, said in an interview last week at the airline\u2019s offices at Ben Gurion Airport. \u201cAccording to all the international organizations we checked with, there is no similar phenomenon anywhere in the world.\u201d\n\nTo illustrate the perceived injustice, he added, \u201cIt\u2019s as if British Airways were allowed to fly a short route between London and New York while United Airlines or Delta were obligated to fly to London via Africa.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor years, El Al has been the sole airline operating direct flights to India, flying four times a week between Tel Aviv and Mumbai. El Al planes have to take a circuitous route, flying low along the Red Sea and across the Arabian Sea, circumventing the entire Arabian Peninsula.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe additional flight time requires more fuel and a larger crew, driving up the ticket price, according to Mr. Defes.\n\nAir India halted its direct flights to Israel via the longer route years ago, but is now flying the New Delhi-Tel Aviv route three times a week, with a flight time of about 7.5 hours.\n\nBut Mr. Defes fears that the Air India deal will be the start of a trend and that other airlines will obtain permission to fly over Saudi Arabia en route to Israel. Along with its attractive introductory fare, Air India is offering cheap transfers from New Delhi to Thailand, another destination popular with Israelis.\n\nThere has been talk of government compensation for El Al, but Mr. Defes said it was impossible to assess the scope of the damage given the possibility that other airlines may get permission to fly over Saudi Arabia.\n\nEl Al has prepared color-coded maps showing the areas from which it is banned from flying over: The air space over much of North Africa, the Middle East, Pakistan and Indonesia are among the no-go zones, requiring significant detours.\n\nEl Al\u2019s lawyers say that the deal with Air India violates a binding commitment to ensure fair competition and equal opportunities it made with the Israeli government when it was privatized in 1994, as well as international aviation conventions. The airline is asking for an injunction prohibiting Air India flights to Israel over Saudi Arabia until it is afforded the same privilege.\n\nIsraeli officials have responded with vague prospects that Israeli carriers may soon be granted permission to fly over Saudi Arabia. Mr. Katz wrote on Twitter last week that he hoped this would happen \u201cin the not so distant future.\u201d\n\nIn response to the court petition on Wednesday, the Transportation Ministry said in a statement that the permission to fly over Saudi Arabia was \u201ca diplomatic achievement of the first order,\u201d but that it was up to the Israeli government to ensure that El Al was not harmed by the development.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Netanyahu said his goal was to introduce shorter, five-hour flights from Tel Aviv to Mumbai, but did not specify if he was referring to flights by El Al or Air India. His office would not elaborate.\n\nThe Israeli Tourism Ministry has provided Air India with a grant to market its new route, as part of a campaign to encourage Indian tourism in Israel.\n\nAbout 58,000 Indian tourists visited Israel in 2017, according to the Tourism Ministry, up from 34,600 in 2014. \u201cMore than 50 million Indians hold passports,\u201d the ministry said.\n\nEl Al flies about 60,000 Israelis to India per year, about 70 percent of them business travelers. India is also popular with younger Israelis, particularly those who have completed their compulsory army service, but many take cheaper flights via connections in third countries.", "title": "El Al Sues Israel After Air India Flies Through Saudi Airspace", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The man was living alone with his two dogs, in a remote area outside San Antonio, when someone called the Texas state hotline to report that a supposed friend was financially exploiting him. So the state adult protective services agency sent a caseworker to the man\u2019s home.\n\nShe found an 86-year-old Vietnam veteran in a dirty, cluttered house full of empty liquor bottles. His legs swollen by chronic cellulitis, he could barely walk, so he used a scooter.\n\nHe missed doctor\u2019s appointments. He had the medications he needed for cellulitis and diabetes, but didn\u2019t take them. Though he had a functioning toilet, he preferred to urinate into plastic gallon jugs. He didn\u2019t clean up after his dogs. He wasn\u2019t eating well.\n\nThis behavior pointed to an underrecognized problem called self-neglect. It accounts for more calls to adult protective services agencies nationwide than any other form of elder abuse.", "title": "Elder Abuse: Sometimes It\u2019s Self-Inflicted", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Eli Leon, a psychologist, writer and collector and self-taught scholar of African-American quilts, who helped bring attention to the field and especially the quilts of Rosie Lee Tompkins, died on March 6 in Emeryville, Calif. He was 82.\n\nThe cause was septic shock, said Jenny Hurth, a close friend and the executor of his estate. Mr. Leon, who died at a care facility, had learned he had primary progressive aphasia in 2012.\n\nMr. Leon was an obsessive collector \u2014 or, perhaps more accurately, a highly discriminating hoarder. Every wall and shelf of his small Craftsman bungalow on Dover Street in Oakland, Calif., where he had lived since 1962, was lined with carefully arranged small, everyday objects and idiosyncratic thrift-store finds, many of them green.", "title": "Eli Leon, 82, Dies; Champion of African-American Quilt Makers", "authors": []}
